pɹeɪz fəɹ ðə wil ə taɪm "ðə bæɾəl sinz əv ðə bɹɛθləs ɝdʒənsi ʌv fɝsthæn ɪkspɪɹiəns, ən ði . . . ivəl leɪst ɪndə ðə fɔɹsɪz ʌv ɡʊd, ðə deɪnʒɝz leɪɾənt ɪn ɛni pɹɑməst sælveɪʃən, ðə sɛns ə ði ʌnəvɔɪɾəbəl ɔnslɔɾ ʌv ʌnpɹɪdɪktəbəl ɪvɛns bɛɹ ðə mɑɹks ʌv əmɛɹəkən næʃənəl ɪkspɪɹiəns dʊɹɪŋ ðə læs θɹi dɛkeɪdz."

Praise for THE WHEEL OF TIME "The battle scenes have the breathless urgency of firsthand experience, and the . . . evil laced into the forces of good, the dangers latent in any promised salvation, the sense of the unavoidable onslaught of unpredictable events bear the marks of American national experience during the last three decades."

 - ðə nu jɔɹk taɪmz "hɪz ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɪz dɪstɪŋɡwɪʃt . . . baɪ ðə ɹɪtʃnəs ʌv ɪts fæbɹɪk, wɪð ɔl ðə tʃɑɹm ən nɑivəteɪ ʌv ðə bɹʌðɝz ɡɹɪm, ən ðə soʊʃəlslæʃmɔɹəl kɑməntɛɹi ʌv hʌksliz bɹeɪv nu wɝld. wɪð ɪz wɛl-flɛʃt-aʊt kæɹɪktɝz, dɑɹk ɪmədʒɹi, kɑmɪk ɹɪlif, vɪvəd lændskeɪps, ən ə fæsəneɪɾɪŋ sɛns ə taɪmləsnəs, dʒɔɹɾən əz kɹieɪɾəd ə kɑmplɛks lɪɾɝətʃɝ wɪð ə læŋɡwədʒ ən ɹiæləɾi ɔl ɪts oʊn."

 - The New York Times "His writing is distinguished . . . by the richness of its fabric, with all the charm and naivete of the Brothers Grimm, and the social/moral commentary of Huxley's Brave New World. With his well-fleshed-out characters, dark imagery, comic relief, vivid landscapes, and a fascinating sense of timelessness, Jordan has created a complex literature with a language and reality all its own."

 - bɹustɝ mɪltən ɹɑbɝtsən, bʊkpɪdʒ "θɹuaʊt dʒɔɹɾənz pɹiɛmənən haɪ-fæntəsi sɑɡə . . . ðə kæɹɪktɝz (maɪnɝ əz wɛl əz meɪdʒɝ), ðə wɝld, ən ðə sɔɹs ə paʊɝz əv ɹɪmeɪn ɹɪmɑɹkəbli ɹɪtʃ ən kənsɪstənt - noʊ min fit. . . . əmɪɾ ɔl ðə stɝm ən dʒɹæŋ, haʊɛvɝ, ɪz ə faɪnli tun kɑmɪk stʃɹeɪn ðət boʊθ lɛvənz ðə stɔɹi ən ædz tə ɪts dɪvɛləpmənt. ə meɪdʒɝ fæntəsi ɛpɪk."

 - Brewster Milton Robertson, BookPage "Throughout Jordan's preeminent high-fantasy saga . . . the characters (minor as well as major), the world, and the source of powers have remained remarkably rich and consistent - no mean feat. . . . Amid all the Sturm and Drang, however, is a finely tuned comic strain that both leavens the story and adds to its development. A major fantasy epic."

 - bʊklɪst "tʃɹuθ ɪz nɑɾ oʊnli stʃɹeɪnʒɝ, ɪts ɹɪtʃɝ ðən fɪkʃən, bʌt dʒɔɹɾənz fɪkʃənəl junəvɝs əpɹoʊtʃɪz ðə vɝaɪəɾi ən kəmplɛksəɾi ʌv ðə ɹil. . . . plɔtlaɪnz [ɑɹ] stʃɹʌmd wɪð ɹɛzəneɪɾɪŋ lɔŋ-weɪv ɹɪðəmz sʌmθɪŋ laɪk beɪɾoʊvənz ɝɔɪkə."

 - Chicago Sun-Times "In the decades since J. R. R. Tolkien's Lord of the Rings trilogy was published, many fantasy writers have tried to capture the spirit of that seminal work. kɑntɛns mæps pɹoʊlɑɡ: snoʊ wʌn livɪŋ ðə pɹɑfət tu teɪkən θɹi kʌstəmz fɔɹ ɔfɝz faɪv flæɡz sɪks ðə sɛn ə mædnəs sɛvən ðə stʃɹits ə keɪɛmlɪn eɪt si foʊk ən kɪn naɪn eɪ kʌp ə ti tɛn eɪ plæn səksidz ɪlɛvən aɪdiəz ʌv ɪmpɔɹɾəns twɛlv eɪ lɪli ɪn wɪntɝ θɝtin wʌndɝfəl nuz fɔɹtin wʌɾ ə veɪl haɪdz fɪftin ɪn niɾ ʌv ə bɛlfndɝ sɪkstin ən ʌnɪkspɛktɪɾ ɪnkaʊntɝ sɛvəntin pɪŋk ɹɪbənz eɪtin ən ɔfɝ naɪntin θɹi wɪmən twɛnti kwɛstʃənz ə tʃɹizən twɛntiwʌn eɪ mæɾɝ ə pɹɑpɝɾi twɛntiɾu aʊɾ ə θɪn ɛɹ twɛntiθɹi tə luz ðə sʌn twɛntifɔɹ əmʌŋ ðə kaʊnsəlz twɛntifaɪv bɑnz twɛntisɪks ɛkspɛkteɪʃən twɛntisɛvən tə sɝpɹaɪz kwinz ən kɪŋz twɛntieɪt nuz ɪn ə klɔθ sæk twɛntinaɪn ənʌðɝ plæn θɝɾi koʊld, fæt ɹeɪndʒɹɑps θɝɾiwʌn wʌt ði æɛlfɪn sɛd θɝɾitu eɪ pɔɹʃən ʌv wɪzdəm θɝɾiθɹi blu kɑɹp stʃɹit θɝɾifɔɹ ðə hʌmɪŋbɝdz sikɹət θɝɾifaɪv wɪð ðə tʃoʊɾən kæl ɡlɔsɝi ðə silz ðət hoʊl bæk naɪt ʃæl wikən, ən ɪn ðə hɑɹɾ ʌv wɪntɝ ʃæl wɪntɝz hɑɹt bi bɔɹn əmɪd ðə weɪlɪŋ ə ləmɛnteɪʃənz ən ðə næʃɪŋ ə tiθ, fəɹ wɪntɝz hɑɹt ʃæl ɹaɪɾ ə blæk hɔɹs, ən ðə neɪm ʌv ɪts dɛθ.

 - fɹəm ðə kæɹæəθən saɪkəl:

 - from The Karaethon Cycle:

ðə pɹɑfəsiz ə ðə dʒɹæɡən 
The Prophecies of the Dragon 
pɹoʊlɑɡ snoʊ



PROLOGUE Snow

θɹi læntɝnz kæst ə flɪkɝɪŋ laɪt, mɔɹ ðən ɪnʌf tə ɪlumɪnɪt ðə smɔl ɹum wɪð ɪts stɑɹk waɪt wɔlz ən silɪŋ, bʌt sin kɛpt əɹ aɪz fɪkst ɑn ðə hɛvi wʊɾən dɔɹ. ɪlɑdʒɪkəl, ʃi nu; fulɪʃ ɪn ə sɪɾɝ fəɹ ðə waɪt. ðə wiv ə seɪaɪdɑɹ ʃi hæd pʊʃt ɝaʊn ðə dʒæm bɹɔɾ əɹ əkeɪʒənəl wɪspɝz ə dɪstən fʊtstɛps ɪn ðə wɔɹən ə hɔlweɪz aʊtsaɪd, wɪspɝz ðət feɪɾəd əweɪ ɔlmoʊst əz sun əz hɝd. ə sɪmpəl θɪŋ lɝn fɹəm ə fɹɛn ɪn əɹ lɔŋ-əɡoʊ nɑvəs deɪz, bʌt ʃi wʊɾə wɔɹnɪŋ lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ ɛniwʌn keɪm nɪɹ. fju pipəl keɪm daʊn əz dip əz ðə sɛkən beɪsmənt, ɛniweɪ.

Three lanterns cast a flickering light, more than enough to illuminate the small room with its stark white walls and ceiling, but Seaine kept her eyes fixed on the heavy wooden door. Illogical, she knew; foolish in a Sitter for the White. The weave of saidar she had pushed around the jamb brought her occasional whispers of distant footsteps in the warren of hallways outside, whispers that faded away almost as soon as heard. A simple thing learned from a friend in her long-ago novice days, but she would have warning long before anyone came near. Few people came down as deep as the second basement, anyway.

hɝ wiv pɪkt ʌp ðə fɑɹ-ɔf tʃɪɾɝɪŋ ə ɹæts. laɪt! haʊ lɔŋ sɪns ðəɹ hæd bɪn ɹæts ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn, ɪn ðə taʊɝ ɪtsɛlf? wɝ ɛni ʌv əm spaɪz fəɹ ðə dɑɹk wʌn? ʃi wɛɾ əɹ lɪps ənizəli. lɑdʒɪk kaʊntəd fəɹ nʌθɪŋ ɪn ðɪs. tʃɹu. ɪf ɪlɑdʒɪkəl. ʃi wɑntəd tə læf. wɪð ən ɛfɝt ʃi kɹɛp bæk fɹəm ðə bɹɪŋk ə hɪstɛɹiə. θɪŋk ə sʌmθɪŋ bɪsaɪdz ɹæts. sʌmθɪŋ bɪsaɪdz . . . ə mʌfəl skwil ɹoʊz ɪn ðə ɹum bɪhaɪn hɝ, fɔltɝɾ ɪndə mjuɾɪd wɪmpɝɪŋ. ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə stɑp ʌp əɹ ɪɹz. kɑnsəntʃɹeɪt!

Her weave picked up the far-off chittering of rats. Light! How long since there had been rats in Tar Valon, in the Tower itself? Were any of them spies for the Dark One? She wet her lips uneasily. Logic counted for nothing in this. True. If illogical. She wanted to laugh. With an effort she crept back from the brink of hysteria. Think of something besides rats. Something besides . . . A muffled squeal rose in the room behind her, faltered into muted whimpering. She tried to stop up her ears. Concentrate!

ɪn ə weɪ, ʃi ən əɹ kəmpænjənz hæd bɪn lɛd tə ðɪs ɹum kəz ðə hɛdz ə ði ədʒəz sim tə bi miɾɪŋ ɪn sikɹət. ʃi hɝsɛlf hæd ɡlɪmps fɛɹən nhɝən wɪspɝɪŋ ɪn ə sɪkluɾɪd nʊk ə ðə laɪbɹɛɹi wɪð dʒɛsi biləl, hu stʊd vɛɹi haɪ əmʌŋ ðə bɹaʊnz ɪf nɑɾ ət ðə vɛɹi tɑp. ʃi θɔt ʃi wɑz ɑn fɝmɝ ɡɹaʊn kənsɝnɪŋ swænə dʒɹeɪɡənd, ʌv ðə jɛloʊz. ʃi θɔt soʊ. bʌt waɪ hæd fɛɹən ɡɔn wɔkɪŋ wɪð swænə ɪn ə sɪkluɾɪd pɑɹɾ ə ðə taʊɝ ɡɹaʊnz, boʊθ swɑðd ɪn pleɪn kloʊks? sɪɾɝz ə dɪfɹən ədʒəz stɪl tɔk tə wʌn ənʌðɝ oʊpənli, ɪf koʊldli. ði ʌðɝz hæd sin sɪməlɝ θɪŋz; ðeɪ wəd nɑt ɡɪv neɪmz fɹəm ðɛɹ oʊn ədʒəz, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌt tu hæd mɛnʃən fɛɹən. ə tʃɹʌbəlɪŋ pʌzəl. ðə taʊɝ wɑz ə siθɪŋ swɑmp ðiz deɪz, ɛvɹi ədʒɑ əɾ ɛvɹi ʌðɝ ədʒɑz θɹoʊt, jɛt ðə hɛdz mɛɾ ɪn kɔɹnɝz. noʊ wʌn aʊtsaɪɾ ən ədʒɑ nu fəɹ sɝɾən u wɪðɪn ɪt lɛd, bʌɾ əpɛɹənli ðə liɾɝz nu itʃ ʌðɝ. wʌt kəd ðeɪ bi ʌp tə? wʌt? ɪt wɑz ənfɔɹtʃənət ðət ʃi kəd nɑt sɪmpli æsk fɛɹən, bʌɾ ivən hæd fɛɹən bɪn tɑlɝən ʌv ɛniwʌnz kwɛstʃənz, ʃi dɪd nɑt dɛɹ. nɑt naʊ.

In a way, she and her companions had been led to this room because the heads of the Ajahs seemed to be meeting in secret. She herself had glimpsed Ferane Neheran whispering in a secluded nook of the library with Jesse Bilal, who stood very high among the Browns if not at the very top. She thought she was on firmer ground concerning Suana Dragand, of the Yellows. She thought so. But why had Ferane gone walking with Suana in a secluded part of the Tower grounds, both swathed in plain cloaks? Sitters of different Ajahs still talked to one another openly, if coldly. The others had seen similar things; they would not give names from their own Ajahs, of course, but two had mentioned Ferane. A troubling puzzle. The Tower was a seething swamp these days, every Ajah at every other Ajah's throat, yet the heads met in corners. No one outside an Ajah knew for certain who within it led, but apparently the leaders knew each other. What could they be up to? What? It was unfortunate that she could not simply ask Ferane, but even had Ferane been tolerant of anyone's questions, she did not dare. Not now.

kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾ əz ʃi wʊd, sin kəd nɑt kip əɹ maɪn ɑn ðə kwɛstʃən. ʃi nu ʃi wɑz stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə dɔɹ ən wɝiɪŋ ət pʌzəlz ʃi kəd nɑt sɑlv dʒʌs tə əvɔɪd lʊkɪŋ oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ. təwɔɹd ðə sɔɹs ə ðoʊz staɪfəld wɪmpɝz ən snʌfəlɪŋ ɡɹoʊnz.

Concentrate as she would, Seaine could not keep her mind on the question. She knew she was staring at the door and worrying at puzzles she could not solve just to avoid looking over her shoulder. Toward the source of those stifled whimpers and snuffling groans.

əz ɪf θɪŋkɪŋ ə ðə saʊnz kəmpɛl hɝ, ʃi lʊk bæk sloʊli tə hɝ kəmpænjənz, hɝ bɹɛθ ɡɹoʊɪŋ mɔɹ ənivən əz əɹ hɛd muv baɪ ɪntʃəz. snoʊ wɑz fɔlɪŋ hɛvəli ɑn tɑɹ vəlɑn, fɑɹ oʊvɝhɛd, bʌt ðə ɹum simd ʌnəkaʊntəbli hɑt. ʃi meɪd hɝsɛlf si!

As if thinking of the sounds compelled her, she looked back slowly to her companions, her breath growing more uneven as her head moved by inches. Snow was falling heavily on Tar Valon, far overhead, but the room seemed unaccountably hot. She made herself see!

bɹaʊn-fɹɪnd ʃɔl lupt ɑn əɹ ɛlboʊz, sɹɪn stʊd wɪð əɹ fit plæntəɾ əpɑɹt, fɪŋɡɝɪŋ ðə hɪlt ə ðə kɝvd ɔltɑɹən dæɡɝ θɹʌs bɪhaɪn əɹ bɛlt. koʊld æŋɡɝ dɑɹkən əɹ ɑləv kəmplɛkʃən ɪnʌf tə meɪk ðə skɑɹ əlɔŋ əɹ dʒɔ stæn aʊɾ ɪn ə peɪl laɪn. pɛvɑɹə əpɪɹd kɑmɝ, ət fɝst ɡlæns, jɛt wʌn hænd ɡɹɪpt əɹ ɹɛd-ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd skɝts taɪtli ən ði ʌðɝ hɛl ðə smuð waɪt sɪləndɝ ə ði oʊθ ɹɑd laɪk ə fʊt-lɔŋ klʌb ʃi wɑz ɹɛɾi tə juz. ʃi maɪt bi ɹɛɾi; pɛvɑɹə wɑz fɑɹ tʌfɝ ðən əɹ plʌmp ɪkstɪɹiɝ sədʒɛstəd, ən dɪtɝmən ɪnʌf tə meɪk sɹɪn sim ə ʃɝkɝ.

Brown-fringed shawl looped on her elbows, Saerin stood with her feet planted apart, fingering the hilt of the curved Altaran dagger thrust behind her belt. Cold anger darkened her olive complexion enough to make the scar along her jaw stand out in a pale line. Pevara appeared calmer, at first glance, yet one hand gripped her red-embroidered skirts tightly and the other held the smooth white cylinder of the Oath Rod like a foot-long club she was ready to use. She might be ready; Pevara was far tougher than her plump exterior suggested, and determined enough to make Saerin seem a shirker.

ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə tʃɛɹ ə ɹɪmɔɹs, taɪni jukɪɝi hæɾ əɹ ɑɹmz ɹæp taɪtli ɝaʊn hɝsɛlf; ðə lɔŋ sɪlvɝi-ɡɹeɪ fɹɪnʒ ɑn əɹ ʃɔl tʃɹɛmbəld wɪð əɹ ʃɪvɝz. lɪkɪŋ əɹ lɪps, jukɪɝi kæst ə wɝid ɡlæns ət ðə wʊmən stændɪŋ bɪsaɪd hɝ. dʌsin, lʊkɪŋ mɔɹ laɪk ə pɹɪɾi bɔɪ ðən ə jɛloʊ sɪstɝ ə kənsɪɾɝəbəl ɹipjut, dɪspleɪd noʊ ɹiækʃən tə wʌt ðeɪ wɝ duɪŋ. ʃi wɑz ðə wʌn æktʃəli  mənɪpjəleɪɾɪŋ ðə wivz ðət stʃɹɛtʃt ɪndə ðə tʃɛɹ, ən ʃi stɛɹɾ ət ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil, foʊkəsɪŋ soʊ hɑɹɾ ɑn əɹ wɝk ðət pɝspɝeɪʃən biɾɪd ɑn əɹ peɪl fɔɹhɛd. ðeɪ wɝ ɔl sɪɾɝz, ɪnkluɾɪŋ ðə tɔl wʊmən ɹaɪðɪŋ ɑn ðə tʃɛɹ.

On the other side of the Chair of Remorse, tiny Yukiri had her arms wrapped tightly around herself; the long silvery-gray fringe on her shawl trembled with her shivers. Licking her lips, Yukiri cast a worried glance at the woman standing beside her. Doesine, looking more like a pretty boy than a Yellow sister of considerable repute, displayed no reaction to what they were doing. She was the one actually manipulating the weaves that stretched into the Chair, and she stared at the ter'angreal, focusing so hard on her work that perspiration beaded on her pale forehead. They were all Sitters, including the tall woman writhing on the Chair.

swɛt dʒɹɛntʃt tælin, mæɾɪŋ əɹ ɡoʊldən hɛɹ, soʊkɪŋ əɹ lɪnən ʃɪf tɪl ɪt klʌŋ tə hɝ. ðə ɹɛst ə hɝ kloʊðz meɪɾ ə dʒʌmbəl paɪl ɪn ə kɔɹnɝ. hɝ kloʊzd aɪlɪdz flʌɾɝd, ən ʃi lɛɾ aʊɾ ə kɑnstən stʃɹim ə stʃɹæŋɡəl moʊnz ən mulɪŋ, hæf-ʌɾɝd pliz. sin fɛlt ɪl, bʌt kəd nɑt dʒɹæɡ hɝ aɪz əweɪ. tælin wɑz ə fɹɛnd. hæd bɪn ə fɹɛnd.

Sweat drenched Talene, matting her golden hair, soaking her linen shift till it clung to her. The rest of her clothes made a jumbled pile in a corner. Her closed eyelids fluttered, and she let out a constant stream of strangled moans and mewling, half-uttered pleas. Seaine felt ill, but could not drag her eyes away. Talene was a friend. Had been a friend.

dɪspaɪɾ ɪts neɪm, ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil lʊk nʌθɪŋ laɪk ə tʃɛɹ, dʒʌst ə lɑɹdʒ ɹɛktæŋɡjəlɝ blɑk ə mɑɹbəld ɡɹeɪ. noʊ wʌn nu wʌɾ ɪt wɑz meɪɾ ʌv, bʌt ðə mətɪɹiəl wɑz hɑɹɾ əz stil ɛvɹiwɛɹ ɪksɛp ðə slæntəd tɑp. ðə stætʃuɛsk ɡɹin sæŋk ə lɪɾəl ɪndə ðæt, ən sʌmhaʊ ɪt moʊldəɾ ɪtsɛlf tə hɝ noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ ʃi twɪstəd. dʌsinz wivɪŋz floʊɾ ɪndə ði oʊnli bɹeɪk ɛniwɛɹ ɑn ðə tʃɛɹ, ə pɑm-saɪzd ɹɛktæŋɡjəlɝ hoʊl ɪn wʌn saɪd wɪð taɪni nɑtʃəz speɪst ənivənli ɝaʊn ɪt. kɹɪmənəlz kɑɾ ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn wɝ bɹɔt daʊn hɪɹ tə ɪkspɪɹiəns ðə tʃɛɹ ə ɹɪmɔɹs, tə ɪkspɪɹiəns kɛɹfəli səlɛktəd kɑnsəkwɛnsəz ə ðɛɹ kɹaɪmz. ɑn ɹilis, ðeɪ ɪnvɛɹiəbli flɛd ði aɪlənd. ðəɹ wɑz vɛɹi lɪɾəl kɹaɪm ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn. kwizəli, sin wʌndɝd wɛðɝ ðɪs wɑz ɛniθɪŋ laɪk ðə jus ðə tʃɛɹ hæd bɪn pʊt tə ɪn ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz.

Despite its name, the ter'angreal looked nothing like a chair, just a large rectangular block of marbled gray. No one knew what it was made of, but the material was hard as steel everywhere except the slanted top. The statuesque Green sank a little into that, and somehow it molded itself to her no matter how she twisted. Doesine's weavings flowed into the only break anywhere on the Chair, a palm-sized rectangular hole in one side with tiny notches spaced unevenly around it. Criminals caught in Tar Valon were brought down here to experience the Chair of Remorse, to experience carefully selected consequences of their crimes. On release, they invariably fled the island. There was very little crime in Tar Valon. Queasily, Seaine wondered whether this was anything like the use the Chair had been put to in the Age of Legends.

"wʌɾ ɪz ʃi . . . siɪŋ?" hɝ kwɛstʃən keɪm aʊɾ ə wɪspɝ ɪn spaɪɾ ə hɝsɛlf. tælin wəd bi mɔɹ ðən siɪŋ; tə hɝ, ɪɾ ɔl wəd sim ɹil. θæŋk ðə laɪt ʃi hæd noʊ wɔɹɾɝ, ɔlmoʊst ənhɝɾ ə fəɹ ə ɡɹin. ʃi hæd kleɪmd ə sɪɾɝ hæd noʊ nid fəɹ wʌn. dɪfɹən ɹizənz keɪm tə maɪnd, naʊ.

"What is she . . . seeing?" Her question came out a whisper in spite of herself. Talene would be more than seeing; to her, it all would seem real. Thank the Light she had no Warder, almost unheard of for a Green. She had claimed a Sitter had no need for one. Different reasons came to mind, now.

"ʃi ɪz blʌɾi biɪŋ flɑɡd baɪ blʌɾi tʃɹɑləks," dʌsin sɛd hɔɹsli. tʌtʃəz ə hɝ neɪɾɪv kɛɹhin hæɾ əpɪɹɾ ɪn əɹ vɔɪs, sʌmθɪŋ ðət sɛldəm hæpən ɪksɛpt ʌndɝ stʃɹɛs. "wɛn ðeɪ ɑɹ dʌn. . . . ʃi kən si ðə tʃɹɑləks' kʊk kɛɾəl bɔɪlɪŋ oʊvɝ ə faɪɝ, ən ə mɹdʒɹɑl wɑtʃɪŋ hɝ. ʃi mʌs noʊ ɪɾəl bi wʌn əɹ ði ʌðɝ nɛkst. bɝn mi, ɪf ʃi dʌzn bɹeɪk ðɪs taɪm. . . ." dʌsin bɹʌʃt pɝspɝeɪʃən fɹəm əɹ fɔɹhɛɾ ɪɹɪɾəbli ən dʒɹu ə ɹæɡəd bɹɛθ. "stɑp dʒɑəlɪŋ maɪ ɛlboʊ. ɪts bɪn ə lɔŋ waɪl sɪns aɪ dɪd ðɪs."

"She is bloody being flogged by bloody Trollocs," Doesine said hoarsely. Touches of her native Cairhien had appeared in her voice, something that seldom happened except under stress. "When they are done. . . . She can see the Trollocs' cook kettle boiling over a fire, and a Myrddraal watching her. She must know it will be one or the other next. Burn me, if she doesn't break this time. . . ." Doesine brushed perspiration from her forehead irritably and drew a ragged breath. "Stop joggling my elbow. It has been a long while since I did this."

"θɹi taɪmz ʌndɝ," jukɪɝi mʌɾɝd. "ðə tʌfəst stʃɹɔŋɡɑɹm ɪz bɹoʊkən baɪ hɪz oʊn ɡɪlt, ɪf nʌθɪŋ ɛls, æftɝ tu! wʌɾ ɪf ʃiz ɪnəsənt? laɪt, ðɪs ɪz laɪk stilɪŋ ʃip wɪð ðə ʃɛpɝd wɑtʃɪŋ!" ivən ʃeɪkɪŋ, ʃi mænədʒ tə əpɪɹ ɹiɡəl, bʌt ʃi ɔlweɪz saʊndəd laɪk wʌt ʃi hæd bɪn, ə vɪlədʒ wʊmən. ʃi ɡlɛɹɾ ɝaʊn ət ðə ɹɛst ə ðɛm ɪn ə sɪkli fæʃən. "ðə lɔ fɝbɪdz juzɪŋ ðə tʃɛɹ ɑn ɪnɪʃiəts. wɪl ɔl bi əntʃɛɹd! ən ɪf biɪŋ θɹoʊn aʊɾ ə ðə hɔl ɪzən ɪnʌf, wɪl pɹɑbli bi ɛɡzaɪld. ən bɝtʃt bɪfɔɹ wi ɡoʊ, dʒʌs tə dʒɹɑp sɔlt ɪn əɹ ti! bɝn mi, ɪf wɝ ɹɔŋ, wi kəɾ ɔl bi stɪld!"

"Three times under," Yukiri muttered. "The toughest strongarm is broken by his own guilt, if nothing else, after two! What if she's innocent? Light, this is like stealing sheep with the shepherd watching!" Even shaking, she managed to appear regal, but she always sounded like what she had been, a village woman. She glared around at the rest of them in a sickly fashion. "The law forbids using the Chair on initiates. We'll all be unchaired! And if being thrown out of the Hall isn't enough, we'll probably be exiled. And birched before we go, just to drop salt in our tea! Burn me, if we're wrong, we could all be stilled!"

sin ʃʌɾɝəd. ðeɪ wəɾ ɪskeɪp ðət læst, ɪf ðɛɹ səspɪʃənz pɹuvd ɹaɪt. noʊ, nɑt səspɪʃənz; sɝɾəntiz. ðeɪ hæd tə bi ɹaɪt! bʌɾ ivən ɪf ðeɪ wɝ, jukɪɝi wɑz kɝɛkt əbaʊt ðə ɹɛst. taʊɝ lɔ sɛldəm əlaʊd fəɹ nəsɛsəɾi, əɹ ɛni səpoʊz haɪɝ ɡʊd. ɪf ðeɪ wɝ ɹaɪt, ðoʊ, ðə pɹaɪs wɑz wɝθ peɪɪŋ. pliz, ðə laɪt sɛn ðeɪ wɝ ɹaɪt!

Seaine shuddered. They would escape that last, if their suspicions proved right. No, not suspicions; certainties. They had to be right! But even if they were, Yukiri was correct about the rest. Tower law seldom allowed for necessity, or any supposed higher good. If they were right, though, the price was worth paying. Please, the Light send they were right!

"ɑɹ jə blaɪn ən dɛf?" pɛvɑɹə snæpt, ʃeɪkɪŋ ði oʊθ ɹɑɾ ət jukɪɝi. "ʃi ɹəfjuz tə ɹɛswɛɹ ði oʊθ əɡɛnst spikɪŋ ən əntʃɹu wɝd, ən ɪt hæd tə bi mɔɹ ðən stupəd ɡɹin ədʒɑ pɹaɪɾ æftɝ wiɾ ɔl dʌn əz mʌtʃ ɔlɹɛɾi. wən aɪ ʃildɪd hɝ, ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə stæb mi! dʌz ðət ʃaʊɾ ɪnəsəns? dʌz ɪt? fəɹ ɔl ʃi nu, wi dʒʌs mɛn tə tɔk əɾ əɹ əntɪl əɹ tʌŋz dʒɹaɪɾ ʌp! wʌt ɹizən wəd ʃi hæv tə ɪkspɛk mɔɹ?"

"Are you blind and deaf?" Pevara snapped, shaking the Oath Rod at Yukiri. "She refused to reswear the Oath against speaking an untrue word, and it had to be more than stupid Green Ajah pride after we'd all done as much already. When I shielded her, she tried to stab me! Does that shout innocence? Does it? For all she knew, we just meant to talk at her until our tongues dried up! What reason would she have to expect more?"

"θæŋk jə boʊθ," sɹɪn pʊɾ ɪn dʒɹaɪli, "fɔɹ steɪɾɪŋ ði ɑbviəs. ɪts tu leɪt tə ɡoʊ bæk, jukɪɝi, soʊ wi maɪɾ əz wɛl ɡoʊ fɔɹwɝd. ən ɪf aɪ wɝ ju, pɛvɑɹə, aɪ wʊdn bi ʃaʊɾɪŋ ət wʌn ə ðə fɔɹ wɪmən ɪn ðə hoʊl taʊɝ aɪ nu aɪ kəd tʃɹʌst."

"Thank you both," Saerin put in dryly, "for stating the obvious. It's too late to go back, Yukiri, so we might as well go forward. And if I were you, Pevara, I wouldn't be shouting at one of the four women in the whole Tower I knew I could trust."

jukɪɝi flʌʃt ən ʃɪftəɾ əɹ ʃɔl, ən pɛvɑɹə lʊkt ə tʃɹaɪfəl əbæʃt. ə tʃɹaɪfəl. ðeɪ maɪɾ ɔl bi sɪɾɝz, bʌt sɹɪn hæd moʊs dɛfənətli teɪkən tʃɑɹdʒ. sin wɑz ənʃʊɹ haʊ ʃi fɛlt əbaʊt ðæt. ə fju aʊɝz əɡoʊ, ʃi ən pɛvɑɹə hæd bɪn tu oʊl fɹɛnz əloʊn ɑn ə deɪnʒɝəs kwɛst, ikwəlz ɹitʃɪŋ dɪsɪʒənz təɡɛðɝ; naʊ ðeɪ hæɾ ælaɪz. ʃi ʃəd bi ɡɹeɪtfəl fəɹ mɔɹ kəmpænjənz. ðeɪ wɝ nɑɾ ɪn ðə hɔl, ðoʊ, ən ðeɪ kəd nɑt kleɪm sɪɾɝz' ɹaɪts ɑn ðɪs. taʊɝ haɪɹɑɹkiz hæd teɪkən oʊvɝ, ɔl ðə sʌɾəl ən nɑt-soʊ-sʌɾəl dɪstɪŋkʃənz əz tə hu stʊd wɛɹ wɪð ɹɪspɛk tə hum. ɪn tʃɹuθ, sɹɪn hæd bɪn boʊθ nɑvəs ən æksɛptɪd twaɪs əz lɔŋ əz moʊst ə ðɛm, bʌt fɔɹɾi jɪɹz əz ə sɪɾɝ, lɔŋɡɝ ðən ɛniwʌn ɛls ɪn ðə hɔl, kaʊntəd fəɹ ə ɡɹeɪt dil. sin wəd bi lʌki ɪf sɹɪn æskt əɹ əpɪnjən, mʌtʃ lɛs əɹ ædvaɪs, bɪfɔɹ dəsaɪɾɪŋ ɛniθɪŋ əɾ ɔl. fulɪʃ, jɛt ðə nɑlədʒ pɹɪk laɪk ə θɔɹn ɪn əɹ fʊt.

Yukiri flushed and shifted her shawl, and Pevara looked a trifle abashed. A trifle. They might all be Sitters, but Saerin had most definitely taken charge. Seaine was unsure how she felt about that. A few hours ago, she and Pevara had been two old friends alone on a dangerous quest, equals reaching decisions together; now they had allies. She should be grateful for more companions. They were not in the Hall, though, and they could not claim Sitters' rights on this. Tower hierarchies had taken over, all the subtle and not-so-subtle distinctions as to who stood where with respect to whom. In truth, Saerin had been both novice and Accepted twice as long as most of them, but forty years as a Sitter, longer than anyone else in the Hall, counted for a great deal. Seaine would be lucky if Saerin asked her opinion, much less her advice, before deciding anything at all. Foolish, yet the knowledge pricked like a thorn in her foot.

"ðə tʃɹɑləks ɑɹ dʒɹæɡɪŋ əɹ təwɔɹd ðə kɛɾəl," dʌsin sɛd sʌɾənli, hɝ vɔɪs ɡɹeɪɾɪŋ. ə θɪn kinɪŋ ɪskeɪp θɹu tælinz klɛntʃt tiθ; ʃi ʃʊk soʊ hɑɹd ʃi sim tə vaɪbɹeɪt. "aɪ - aɪ də nɑt noʊ ɪf aɪ kən . . . kən fleɪmɪŋ meɪk maɪsɛlf . . ."

"The Trollocs are dragging her toward the kettle," Doesine said suddenly, her voice grating. A thin keening escaped through Talene's clenched teeth; she shook so hard she seemed to vibrate. "I - I do not know if I can . . . can flaming make myself . . ."

"bɹɪŋ əɹ əweɪk," sɹɪn kəmændəd wɪθaʊt soʊ mʌtʃ əz ɡlænsɪŋ əɾ ɛniwʌn ɛls tə si wʌt ðeɪ θɔt. "stɑp sʌlkɪŋ, jukɪɝi, ən bi ɹɛɾi."

"Bring her awake," Saerin commanded without so much as glancing at anyone else to see what they thought. "Stop sulking, Yukiri, and be ready."

ðə ɡɹeɪ ɡeɪv əɹ ə pɹaʊd, fjʊɹiəs stɛɹ, bʌt wən dʌsin lɛɾ əɹ wivz feɪɾ ən tælinz blu aɪz flʌɾɝd oʊpən, ðə ɡloʊ ʌv seɪaɪdɑɹ sɝaʊndəd jukɪɝi ən ʃi ʃildɪd ðə wʊmən laɪɪŋ ɑn ðə tʃɛɹ wɪθaʊɾ ʌɾɝɪŋ ə wɝd. sɹɪn wɑz ɪn tʃɑɹdʒ, ən ɛvɹiwʌn nu ɪt, ən ðət wɑz ðæt. ə vɛɹi ʃɑɹp θɔɹn.

The Gray gave her a proud, furious stare, but when Doesine let her weaves fade and Talene's blue eyes fluttered open, the glow of saidar surrounded Yukiri and she shielded the woman lying on the Chair without uttering a word. Saerin was in charge, and everyone knew it, and that was that. A very sharp thorn.

ə ʃil hɑɹdli sim nɛsəsɛɹi. hɝ feɪs ə mæsk ə tɛɹɝ, tælin tʃɹɛmbəld ən pæntɪɾ əz ðoʊ ʃi hæd ɹʌn tɛn maɪlz ət tɑp spid. ʃi stɪl sæŋk ɪndə ðə sɑf sɝfəs, bʌt wɪθaʊt dʌsin tʃænəlɪŋ, ɪt noʊ lɔŋɡɝ fɔɹmd ɪtsɛlf tə hɝ. tælin stɛɹɾ ət ðə silɪŋ wɪð bʌlʒɪŋ aɪz, ðən skwizd əm ʃʌt, bʌt ðeɪ pɑpt ɹaɪɾ oʊpən əɡɛn. wʌtɛvɝ mɛmɹiz leɪ bɪhaɪn əɹ aɪlɪdz wɝ nʌθɪŋ ʃi wɑntəd tə feɪs.

A shield hardly seemed necessary. Her face a mask of terror, Talene trembled and panted as though she had run ten miles at top speed. She still sank into the soft surface, but without Doesine channeling, it no longer formed itself to her. Talene stared at the ceiling with bulging eyes, then squeezed them shut, but they popped right open again. Whatever memories lay behind her eyelids were nothing she wanted to face.

kʌvɝɪŋ ðə tu stʃɹaɪdz tə ðə tʃɛɹ, pɛvɑɹə θɹʌs ði oʊθ ɹɑɾ ət ðə dɪstʃɹɔt wʊmən. "fɔɹswɛɹ ɔl oʊðz ðət baɪn jə ən ɹiteɪk ðə θɹi oʊðz, tælin," ʃi sɛd hɑɹʃli. tælin ɹikɔɪl fɹəm ðə ɹɑɾ əz fɹəm ə pɔɪzənəs sɝpənt, ðən dʒɝk ði ʌðɝ weɪ əz sɹɪn bɛn oʊvɝ hɝ.

Covering the two strides to the Chair, Pevara thrust the Oath Rod at the distraught woman. "Forswear all oaths that bind you and retake the Three Oaths, Talene," she said harshly. Talene recoiled from the Rod as from a poisonous serpent, then jerked the other way as Saerin bent over her.

"nɛks taɪm, tælin, ɪts ðə kʊkpɑt fəɹ ju. əɹ ðə mɹdʒɹɑlz tɛndɝ ətɛnʃənz." sɹɪnz feɪs wɑz ɪmplækəbəl, bʌɾ əɹ toʊn meɪɾ ɪt sim sɑf baɪ kəmpɛɹəsən. "noʊ weɪkɪŋ ʌp bɪfɔɹ. ən ɪf ðət dʌzn du, ðɛɹəl bi ənʌðɝ taɪm, ən ənʌðɝ, əz mɛni əz ɪt teɪks ɪf wi mʌst steɪ daʊn hɪɹ əntɪl sʌmɝ." dʌsin oʊpən əɹ maʊθ ɪn pɹoʊɾɛst bɪfɔɹ ɡɪvɪŋ oʊvɝ wɪð ə ɡɹɪmɑs. oʊnli ʃi əmʌŋ əm nu haʊ tə ɑpɝeɪt ðə tʃɛɹ, bʌɾ ɪn ðɪs ɡɹup, ʃi stʊɾ əz loʊ əz sin.

"Next time, Talene, it's the cookpot for you. Or the Myrddraal's tender attentions." Saerin's face was implacable, but her tone made it seem soft by comparison. "No waking up before. And if that doesn't do, there'll be another time, and another, as many as it takes if we must stay down here until summer." Doesine opened her mouth in protest before giving over with a grimace. Only she among them knew how to operate the Chair, but in this group, she stood as low as Seaine.

tælin kəntɪnjud tə stɛɹ ʌp ət sɹɪn. tɪɹz fɪld əɹ bɪɡ aɪz, ən ʃi bɪɡæn tə wip, ɡɹeɪt ʃʌɾɝɪŋ, hoʊpləs sɑbz. blaɪnli, ʃi ɹitʃt aʊt, ɡɹoʊpɪŋ əntɪl pɛvɑɹə stʌk ði oʊθ ɹɑɾ ɪndə hɝ hænd. ɛmbɹeɪsɪŋ ðə sɔɹs, pɛvɑɹə tʃænəld ə θɹɛɾ ə spɪɹəɾ ɪndə ðə ɹɑd. tælin ɡɹɪp ðə ɹɪst-θɪk ɹɑd soʊ hɑɹd ðəɾ əɹ nʌkəlz tɝnd waɪt, jɛt ʃi dʒʌs leɪ ðəɹ sɑbɪŋ.

Talene continued to stare up at Saerin. Tears filled her big eyes, and she began to weep, great shuddering, hopeless sobs. Blindly, she reached out, groping until Pevara stuck the Oath Rod into her hand. Embracing the Source, Pevara channeled a thread of Spirit into the Rod. Talene gripped the wrist-thick rod so hard that her knuckles turned white, yet she just lay there sobbing.

sɹɪn stʃɹeɪɾənd. "aɪ fɪɹ ɪts taɪm tə pʊɾ əɹ bæk tə slip, dʌsin."

Saerin straightened. "I fear it's time to put her back to sleep, Doesine."

tælinz tɪɹz ɹidʌbəld, bʌt ʃi mʌmbəl θɹu ðɛm. "aɪ - fɔɹswɛɹ - ɔl oʊðz - ðət baɪn mi." wɪð ðə læst wɝd, ʃi bɪɡæn tə haʊl.

Talene's tears redoubled, but she mumbled through them. "I - forswear - all oaths - that bind me." With the last word, she began to howl.

sin dʒʌmpt, ðən swɑloʊd hɑɹd. ʃi pɝsənəli nu ðə peɪn ə ɹimuvɪŋ ə sɪŋɡəl oʊθ ən hæd spɛkjəleɪɾəd ɑn ði æɡəni ʌv ɹimuvɪŋ mɔɹ ðən wʌn ət wʌns, bʌt naʊ ðə ɹiæləɾi wɑz ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ. tælin skɹim tɪl ðəɹ wɑz noʊ bɹɛθ lɛft ɪn hɝ, ðən pʊld ɪn ɛɹ oʊnli tə skɹim əɡɛn, əntɪl sin hæf ɪkspɛktəd pipəl tə kʌm ɹʌnɪŋ daʊn fɹəm ðə taʊɝ ɪtsɛlf. ðə tɔl ɡɹin kənvʌlsd, flɪŋɪŋ əɹ ɑɹmz ən lɛɡz əbaʊt, ðən sʌɾənli ɑɹtʃt ʌp tɪl oʊnli hɝ hilz ən hɛd tʌtʃt ðə ɡɹeɪ sɝfəs, ɛvɹi mʌsəl klɛntʃt, hɝ hoʊl bɑɾi spæzəmɪŋ waɪldli.

Seaine jumped, then swallowed hard. She personally knew the pain of removing a single oath and had speculated on the agony of removing more than one at once, but now the reality was in front of her. Talene screamed till there was no breath left in her, then pulled in air only to scream again, until Seaine half expected people to come running down from the Tower itself. The tall Green convulsed, flinging her arms and legs about, then suddenly arched up till only her heels and head touched the gray surface, every muscle clenched, her whole body spasming wildly.

əz əbɹʌpli əz ðə siʒɝ hæd bɪɡʌn, tælin kəlæps boʊnləsli ən leɪ ðəɹ wipɪŋ laɪk ə lɔs tʃaɪld. ði oʊθ ɹɑd ɹoʊl fɹəm əɹ lɪmp hæn daʊn ðə sloʊpɪŋ ɡɹeɪ sɝfəs. jukɪɝi mɝmɝd sʌmθɪŋ wɪð ðə saʊn ʌv ə fɝvən pɹɛɹ. dʌsin kɛpt wɪspɝɪŋ, "laɪt!" oʊvɝ ən oʊvɝ ɪn ə ʃeɪkən vɔɪs. "laɪt! laɪt!"

As abruptly as the seizure had begun, Talene collapsed bonelessly and lay there weeping like a lost child. The Oath Rod rolled from her limp hand down the sloping gray surface. Yukiri murmured something with the sound of a fervent prayer. Doesine kept whispering, "Light!" over and over in a shaken voice. "Light! Light!"

pɛvɑɹə skupt ʌp ðə ɹɑɾ ən kloʊz tælinz fɪŋɡɝz ɝaʊn ɪɾ əɡɛn. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ mɝsi ɪn sinz fɹɛnd, nɑɾ ɪn ðɪs mæɾɝ. "naʊ swɛɹ ðə θɹi oʊðz," ʃi spæt.

Pevara scooped up the Rod and closed Talene's fingers around it again. There was no mercy in Seaine's friend, not in this matter. "Now swear the Three Oaths," she spat.

fəɹ ən ɪnstənt, ɪt sim tælin maɪt ɹəfjuz, bʌt sloʊli ʃi ɹɪpiɾɪd ði oʊðz ðət meɪɾ əm ɔl ɛɛs sədaɪ ən hɛld əm təɡɛðɝ. tə spik noʊ wɝd ðət wɑz nɑt tʃɹu. nɛvɝ tə meɪk ə wɛpən fəɹ wʌn mæn tə kɪl ənʌðɝ. nɛvɝ tə juz ðə wʌn paʊɝ əz ə wɛpən ɪksɛpt əɡɛns dɑɹkfɹɛnz əɹ ʃæɾoʊzpɔn, əɹ ɪn dɪfɛns ə hɝ laɪf, əɹ ðəɾ ə hɝ wɔɹɾɝ əɹ ʌv ənʌðɝ sɪstɝ. ət ði ɛnd, ʃi bɪɡæn wipɪŋ ɪn saɪləns, ʃeɪkɪŋ wɪθaʊɾ ə saʊnd. pɝhæps ɪt wɑz ði oʊðz taɪɾənɪŋ daʊn ɑn hɝ. ðeɪ wɝ ənkʌmftəɹbəl wən fɹɛʃ. pɝhæps.

For an instant, it seemed Talene might refuse, but slowly she repeated the oaths that made them all Aes Sedai and held them together. To speak no word that was not true. Never to make a weapon for one man to kill another. Never to use the One Power as a weapon except against Darkfriends or Shadowspawn, or in defense of her life, or that of her Warder or of another sister. At the end, she began weeping in silence, shaking without a sound. Perhaps it was the oaths tightening down on her. They were uncomfortable when fresh. Perhaps.

ðən pɛvɑɹə toʊl ði ʌðɝ oʊθ ðeɪ ɹikwaɪɝɾ ə hɝ. tælin flɪntʃt, bʌt mʌɾɝd ðə wɝdz ɪn toʊnz ə hoʊpləsnəs. "aɪ vaʊ tə oʊbeɪ ɔl faɪv ə jə æbsəlutli." ʌðɝwaɪz, ʃi oʊnli stɛɹd stʃɹeɪɾ əhɛd dʌli, tɪɹz tʃɹeɪlɪŋ daʊn əɹ tʃiks.

Then Pevara told the other oath they required of her. Talene flinched, but muttered the words in tones of hopelessness. "I vow to obey all five of you absolutely." Otherwise, she only stared straight ahead dully, tears trailing down her cheeks.

"ænsɝ mi tʃɹuθfəli," sɹɪn toʊl hɝ. "ɑɹ jə ʌv ðə blæk ədʒɑ?"

"Answer me truthfully," Saerin told her. "Are you of the Black Ajah?"

"aɪ æm." ðə wɝdz kɹikt, əz ɪf tælinz θɹoʊt wɝ ɹʌsti.

"I am." The words creaked, as if Talene's throat were rusty.

ðə sɪmpəl wɝdz fɹoʊz sin ɪn ə weɪ ʃi hæd nɛvɝ ɪkspɛktəd. ʃi hæd sɛɾ aʊt tə hʌn ðə blæk ədʒɑ, æftɝ ɔl, ən bɪlivd ɪn əɹ kwɔɹi əz mɛni sɪstɝz dɪd nɑt. ʃi hæd leɪd hænz ɑn ənʌðɝ sɪstɝ, ɑn ə sɪɾɝ, hæd hɛlp bʌndəl tælin əlɔŋ dɪzɝɾɪd beɪsmən hɔlweɪz ɹæpt ɪn floʊz ʌv ɛɹ, hæd bɹoʊkən ə dʌzən taʊɝ lɔz, kəmɪɾəd sɪɹiəs kɹaɪmz, ɔl tə hɪɹ ən ænsɝ ʃi hæd bɪn nɪɹli sɝɾən ə bɪfɔɹ ðə kwɛstʃən wɑz æskt. naʊ ʃi hæd hɝd. ðə blæk ədʒɑ ɹɪli dɪɾ ɪɡzɪst. ʃi wɑz stɛɹɪŋ əɾ ə blæk sɪstɝ, ə dɑɹkfɹɛn u wɔɹ ðə ʃɔl. ən bɪlivɪŋ tɝn aʊt tə bi ə peɪl ʃædoʊ ʌv kənfɹʌntɪŋ. oʊnli hɝ dʒɔ klɛntʃt nɪɹ tə kɹæmpɪŋ kɛpt əɹ tiθ fɹəm tʃæɾɝɪŋ. ʃi stʃɹʌɡəl tə kəmpoʊz hɝsɛlf, tə θɪŋk ɹæʃənəli. bʌt naɪtmɛɹz wɝ əweɪk ən wɔkɪŋ ðə taʊɝ.

The simple words froze Seaine in a way she had never expected. She had set out to hunt the Black Ajah, after all, and believed in her quarry as many sisters did not. She had laid hands on another sister, on a Sitter, had helped bundle Talene along deserted basement hallways wrapped in flows of Air, had broken a dozen Tower laws, committed serious crimes, all to hear an answer she had been nearly certain of before the question was asked. Now she had heard. The Black Ajah really did exist. She was staring at a Black sister, a Darkfriend who wore the shawl. And believing turned out to be a pale shadow of confronting. Only her jaw clenched near to cramping kept her teeth from chattering. She struggled to compose herself, to think rationally. But nightmares were awake and walking the Tower.

sʌmwʌn ɛksheɪl hɛvəli, ən sin ɹilaɪzd ʃi wɑz nɑt ði oʊnli wʌn u faʊn əɹ wɝl tɝn ʌpsaɪd daʊn. jukɪɝi ɡeɪv hɝsɛlf ə ʃeɪk, ðən fɪkst əɹ aɪz ɑn tælin əz ðoʊ dɪtɝmən tə hoʊl ðə ʃild ɑn əɹ baɪ wɪlpaʊɝ ɪf nid bi. dʌsin wɑz lɪkɪŋ əɹ lɪps, ən smuðɪŋ əɹ dɑɹk ɡoʊldən skɝts ənsɝteɪnli. oʊnli sɹɪn ən pɛvɑɹə əpɪɹɾ əɾ iz.

Someone exhaled heavily, and Seaine realized she was not the only one who found her world turned upside down. Yukiri gave herself a shake, then fixed her eyes on Talene as though determined to hold the shield on her by willpower if need be. Doesine was licking her lips, and smoothing her dark golden skirts uncertainly. Only Saerin and Pevara appeared at ease.

"soʊ," sɹɪn sɛd sɔfli. pɝhæps "feɪnli" wɑz ə bɛɾɝ wɝd. "soʊ. blæk ədʒɑ." ʃi dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ, ən əɹ toʊn bɪkeɪm bɹɪsk. "ðɛɹz noʊ mɔɹ nid fəɹ ðæt, jukɪɝi. tælin, jə woʊn tʃɹaɪ tə ɪskeɪp, əɹ ɹɪzɪst ɪn ɛni weɪ. jə woʊn soʊ mʌtʃ əz tʌtʃ ðə sɔɹs wɪθaʊt pɝmɪʃən fɹəm wʌn ʌv ʌs. ðoʊ aɪ səpoʊz sʌmwʌn ɛls wɪl teɪk ðɪs fɔɹwɝd wʌns wi hæn jə oʊvɝ. jukɪɝi?" ðə ʃild ɑn tælin dɪsəpeɪɾɪd, bʌt ðə ɡloʊ ɹɪmeɪn ɝaʊn jukɪɝi, əz ɪf ʃi dɪd nɑt tʃɹʌs ði ɪfɛkt ə ðə ɹɑɾ ɑn ə blæk sɪstɝ.

"So," Saerin said softly. Perhaps "faintly" was a better word. "So. Black Ajah." She drew a deep breath, and her tone became brisk. "There's no more need for that, Yukiri. Talene, you won't try to escape, or resist in any way. You won't so much as touch the Source without permission from one of us. Though I suppose someone else will take this forward once we hand you over. Yukiri?" The shield on Talene dissipated, but the glow remained around Yukiri, as if she did not trust the effect of the Rod on a Black sister.

pɛvɑɹə fɹaʊnd. "bɪfɔɹ wi ɡɪv əɹ tə ɪleɪɾə, sɹɪn, aɪ wɑnə dɪɡ aʊɾ əz mʌtʃ əz wi kæn. neɪmz, pleɪsəz, ɛniθɪŋ. ɛvɹiθɪŋ ʃi noʊz!" dɑɹkfɹɛnz hæd kɪl pɛvɑɹəz ɪntaɪɝ fæmli, ən sin wɑz ʃʊɹ ʃi wəd ɡoʊ ɪndə ɛɡzaɪl ɹɛɾi tə hʌn daʊn ɛvɹi læs blæk sɪstɝ pɝsənəli.

Pevara frowned. "Before we give her to Elaida, Saerin, I want to dig out as much as we can. Names, places, anything. Everything she knows!" Darkfriends had killed Pevara's entire family, and Seaine was sure she would go into exile ready to hunt down every last Black sister personally.

stɪl hʌɾəld ɑn ðə tʃɛɹ, tælin meɪɾ ə saʊn hæf bɪɾɝ læf, hæf wipɪŋ. "wɛn jə də ðæt, wəɹ ɔl dɛd. dɛd! ɪleɪɾə ɪz blæk ədʒɑ!"

Still huddled on the Chair, Talene made a sound half bitter laugh, half weeping. "When you do that, we are all dead. Dead! Elaida is Black Ajah!"

"ðæts ɪmpɑsəbəl!" sin bɝst aʊt. "ɪleɪɾə ɡeɪv mi ði ɔɹɾɝ hɝsɛlf."

"That's impossible!" Seaine burst out. "Elaida gave me the order herself."

"ʃi mʌs bi," dʌsin hæf wɪspɝd. "tælinz swɔɹn ði oʊðz əɡɛn; ʃi dʒʌs neɪm hɝ!" jukɪɝi nɑɾəd viəmənli.

"She must be," Doesine half whispered. "Talene's sworn the oaths again; she just named her!" Yukiri nodded vehemently.

"juz jəɹ hɛdz," pɛvɑɹə ɡɹaʊld, ʃeɪkɪŋ əɹ oʊn ɪn dɪsɡʌst. "ju noʊ əz wɛl əz aɪ də ɪf jə bɪliv ə laɪ, jə kən seɪ ɪt fəɹ tʃɹuθ."

"Use your heads," Pevara growled, shaking her own in disgust. "You know as well as I do if you believe a lie, you can say it for truth."

"æn ðəɾ ɪz tʃɹuθ," sɹɪn sɛd fɝmli. "wʌt pɹuf dʒju hæv, tælin? hæv jə sin ɪleɪɾə ət jəɹ . . . miɾɪŋz?" ʃi ɡɹɪpt əɹ naɪf hɪl soʊ hɑɹd ðəɾ əɹ nʌkəlz peɪld. sɹɪn hæd hæd tə faɪt hɑɹɾɝ ðən moʊs fəɹ ðə ʃɔl, fəɹ ðə ɹaɪt tə ɹɪmeɪn ɪn ðə taʊɝ əɾ ɔl. tə hɝ, ðə taʊɝ wɑz mɔɹ ðən hoʊm, mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt ðən əɹ oʊn laɪf. ɪf tælin ɡeɪv ðə ɹɔŋ ænsɝ, ɪleɪɾə maɪt nɑt lɪv tə feɪs tʃɹaɪəl.

"And that is truth," Saerin said firmly. "What proof do you have, Talene? Have you seen Elaida at your . . . meetings?" She gripped her knife hilt so hard that her knuckles paled. Saerin had had to fight harder than most for the shawl, for the right to remain in the Tower at all. To her, the Tower was more than home, more important than her own life. If Talene gave the wrong answer, Elaida might not live to face trial.

"ðeɪ doʊn əv miɾɪŋz," tælin mʌɾɝd sʌlənli. "ɪksɛp ðə səpɹim kaʊnsəl, aɪ səpoʊz. bʌt ʃi mʌs bi. ðeɪ noʊ ɛvɹi ɹipɔɹt ʃi ɹəsivz, ivən ðə sikɹət wʌnz, ɛvɹi wɝd spoʊkən tə hɝ. ðeɪ noʊ ɛvɹi dɪsɪʒən ʃi meɪks bɪfɔɹ ɪts ənaʊnst. deɪz bɪfɔɹ; səmtaɪmz wiks. haʊ ɛls, ənlɛs ʃi tɛlz ðɛm?" sɪɾɪŋ ʌp wɪð ən ɛfɝt, ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə fɪks əm itʃ ɪn tɝn wɪð ən ɪntɛn stɛɹ. ɪɾ oʊnli meɪɾ əɹ aɪz sim tə dɑɹɾ æŋkʃəsli. "wi hæv tə ɹʌn; wɪv tə faɪn ə pleɪs tə haɪd. əl hɛlp jə - tɛl jə ɛvɹiθɪŋ aɪ noʊ! - bʌt ðəl kɪl əs ənlɛs wi ɹʌn."

"They don't have meetings," Talene muttered sullenly. "Except the Supreme Council, I suppose. But she must be. They know every report she receives, even the secret ones, every word spoken to her. They know every decision she makes before it's announced. Days before; sometimes weeks. How else, unless she tells them?" Sitting up with an effort, she tried to fix them each in turn with an intent stare. It only made her eyes seem to dart anxiously. "We have to run; we have to find a place to hide. I'll help you - tell you everything I know! - but they'll kill us unless we run."

stʃɹeɪnʒ, sin θɔt, haʊ kwɪkli tælin hæd meɪɾ əɹ fɔɹmɝ kɹoʊniz "ðeɪ" ən tʃɹaɪd tə aɪdɛntəfaɪ hɝsɛlf wɪð ðə ɹɛst ə ðɛm. noʊ. ʃi wɑz əvɔɪɾɪŋ ðə ɹil pɹɑbləm, ən əvɔɪɾəns wɑz wɪtləs. hæɾ ɪleɪɾə ɹɪli sɛɾ əɹ tə dɪɡ aʊt ðə blæk ədʒɑ? ʃi hæd nɛvɝ wʌns æktʃəli  mɛnʃən ðə neɪm. kəd ʃi hæv mɛn sʌmθɪŋ ɛls? ɪleɪɾə hæɾ ɔlweɪz dʒʌmp daʊn ðə θɹoʊɾ ʌv ɛniwʌn u ivən mɛnʃən ðə blæk. nɪɹli ɛni sɪstɝ wəd də ðə seɪm, jɛt . . .

Strange, Seaine thought, how quickly Talene had made her former cronies "they" and tried to identify herself with the rest of them. No. She was avoiding the real problem, and avoidance was witless. Had Elaida really set her to dig out the Black Ajah? She had never once actually mentioned the name. Could she have meant something else? Elaida had always jumped down the throat of anyone who even mentioned the Black. Nearly any sister would do the same, yet . . .

"ɪleɪɾəz pɹuvən hɝsɛlf ə ful," sɹɪn sɛd, "æn mɔɹ ðən wʌns aɪv ɹɪɡɹɛɾɪd stændɪŋ fəɹ hɝ, bʌɾ əl nɑt bɪliv ʃiz blæk, nɑt wɪθaʊt mɔɹ ðən ðæt." taɪt-lɪpt, pɛvɑɹə dʒɝkt ən əɡɹiɪŋ nɑd. əz ə ɹɛd, ʃi wəd wɑn mʌtʃ mɔɹ.

"Elaida's proven herself a fool," Saerin said, "and more than once I've regretted standing for her, but I'll not believe she's Black, not without more than that." Tight-lipped, Pevara jerked an agreeing nod. As a Red, she would want much more.

"ðæts əz meɪ bi, sɹɪn," jukɪɝi sɛd, "bʌt wi kænɑt hoʊl tælin lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ ðə ɡɹinz stɑɹɾ æskɪŋ wɛɹ ʃi ɪz. nɑt tə mɛnʃən ðə . . . ðə blæk. wid bɛɾɝ dɪsaɪd wʌt tə də fæst, əɹ wɪl stɪl bi dɪɡɪŋ ət ðə bɑɾəm ə ðə wɛl wən ðə ɹeɪnz hɪt." tælin ɡeɪv sɹɪn ə fibəl smaɪl ðət wɑz pɹɑbli mɛn tə bi ɪnɡɹeɪʃieɪɾɪŋ. ɪt feɪɾəd ʌndɝ ðə bɹaʊn sɪɾɝz fɹaʊn.

"That's as may be, Saerin," Yukiri said, "but we cannot hold Talene long before the Greens start asking where she is. Not to mention the . . . the Black. We'd better decide what to do fast, or we'll still be digging at the bottom of the well when the rains hit." Talene gave Saerin a feeble smile that was probably meant to be ingratiating. It faded under the Brown Sitter's frown.

"wi doʊn dɛɹ tɛl ɪleɪɾə ɛniθɪŋ əntɪl wi kən kɹɪpəl ðə blæk ət wʌn bloʊ," sɹɪn sɛd faɪnəli. "doʊn ɑɹɡju, pɛvɑɹə; ɪts sɛns." pɛvɑɹə θɹu ʌp əɹ hænz ən pʊɾ ɑn ə stʌbɝn ɪkspɹɛʃən, bʌt ʃi kloʊzd əɹ maʊθ. "ɪf tælin ɪz ɹaɪt," sɹɪn wɛn ɑn, "ðə blæk noʊz əbaʊt sin əɹ sun wɪl, soʊ wi mʌst ɛnʃʊɹ əɹ seɪfti, əz mʌtʃ əz wi kæn. ðət woʊn bi izi, wɪð oʊnli ðə faɪv ʌv ʌs. wi kæn tʃɹʌst ɛniwʌn əntɪl wəɹ sɝɾən ə ðɛm! ət list wɪv tælin, ən u noʊz wʌt wɪl lɝn bɪfɔɹ ʃiz ɹʌŋ aʊt?" tælin ətɛmptəd tə lʊk wɪlɪŋ tə bi ɹʌŋ aʊt, bʌt noʊ wʌn wɑz peɪɪŋ əɹ ɛni maɪnd. sinz θɹoʊt hæd ɡɔn dʒɹaɪ.

"We don't dare tell Elaida anything until we can cripple the Black at one blow," Saerin said finally. "Don't argue, Pevara; it's sense." Pevara threw up her hands and put on a stubborn expression, but she closed her mouth. "If Talene is right," Saerin went on, "the Black knows about Seaine or soon will, so we must ensure her safety, as much as we can. That won't be easy, with only the five of us. We can't trust anyone until we are certain of them! At least we have Talene, and who knows what we'll learn before she's wrung out?" Talene attempted to look willing to be wrung out, but no one was paying her any mind. Seaine's throat had gone dry.

"wi maɪt nɑt bi ɪntaɪɝli əloʊn," pɛvɑɹə sɛd ɹɪlʌktənli. "sin, tɛl əm jəɹ lɪɾəl skim wɪð zɛɹə ən əɹ fɹɛnz."

"We might not be entirely alone," Pevara said reluctantly. "Seaine, tell them your little scheme with Zerah and her friends."

"skim?" sɹɪn sɛd. "huz zɛɹə? sin? sin!"

"Scheme?" Saerin said. "Who's Zerah? Seaine? Seaine!"

sin ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt. "wʌt? oʊ. pɛvɑɹə ən aɪ ənkʌvɝɾ ə smɔl nɛst ə ɹɛbəlz hɪɹ ɪn ðə taʊɝ," ʃi bɪɡæn bɹɛθəli. "tɛn sɪstɝz sɛn tə spɹɛd dɪsɛnt." sɹɪn wɑz gɑnə meɪk ʃʊɹ ʃi wɑz seɪf, wɑz ʃi? wɪθaʊt soʊ mʌtʃ əz æskɪŋ. ʃi wɑz ə sɪɾɝ hɝsɛlf; ʃi hæd bɪn ɛɛs sədaɪ fəɹ ɔlmoʊst ə hʌnʒɹəd ən fɪfti jɪɹz. wʌt ɹaɪt hæd sɹɪn əɹ ɛniwʌn tə . . . ? "pɛvɑɹə ən aɪ hæv bɪɡʌn pʊɾɪŋ ən ɛn tə ðæt. wiv ɔlɹɛɾi meɪd wʌn ə ðɛm, zɛɹə dɑkən, teɪk ðə seɪm ɛkstʃɹə oʊθ tælin dɪd, ən toʊld əɹ tə bɹɪŋ bɝneɪl ɡɛlbɑɹn tə maɪ ɹumz ðɪs æftɝnun wɪθaʊt ɹaʊzɪŋ əɹ səspɪʃənz." laɪt, ɛni sɪstɝ aʊtsaɪd ðɪs ɹum maɪt bi blæk. ɛni sɪstɝ. "ðɛn wɪl juz ðoʊz tu tə bɹɪŋ ənʌðɝ, əntɪl ðeɪv ɔl bɪn meɪd tə swɛɹ oʊbiɾiəns. ʌv kɔɹs, wɪl æsk ðə seɪm kwɛstʃən wi pʊt tə zɛɹə, ðə seɪm wi pʊt tə tælin." ðə blæk ədʒɑ maɪɾ ɔlɹɛɾi hæv əɹ neɪm, ɔlɹɛɾi noʊ ʃi hæd bɪn sɛt hʌntɪŋ ðɛm. haʊ kəd sɹɪn kip əɹ seɪf? "ðoʊz u ɡɪv ðə ɹɔŋ ænsɝ kən bi kwɛstʃənd, ən ðoʊz u ɡɪv ðə ɹaɪt kən ɹipeɪ fəɹ ə lɪɾəl ə ðɛɹ tʃɹɛtʃɝi baɪ hʌntɪŋ ðə blæk ʌndɝ əɹ dɝɛkʃən." laɪt, haʊ?

Seaine gave a start. "What? Oh. Pevara and I uncovered a small nest of rebels here in the Tower," she began breathily. "Ten sisters sent to spread dissent." Saerin was going to make sure she was safe, was she? Without so much as asking. She was a Sitter herself; she had been Aes Sedai for almost a hundred and fifty years. What right had Saerin or anyone to . . . ? "Pevara and I have begun putting an end to that. We've already made one of them, Zerah Dacan, take the same extra oath Talene did, and told her to bring Bernaile Gelbarn to my rooms this afternoon without rousing her suspicions." Light, any sister outside this room might be Black. Any sister. "Then we will use those two to bring another, until they have all been made to swear obedience. Of course, we'll ask the same question we put to Zerah, the same we put to Talene." The Black Ajah might already have her name, already know she had been set hunting them. How could Saerin keep her safe? "Those who give the wrong answer can be questioned, and those who give the right can repay for a little of their treachery by hunting the Black under our direction." Light, how?

wən ʃi wɑz dʌn, ði ʌðɝz dɪskʌs ðə mæɾɝ ət səm lɛŋθ, wɪtʃ kəɾ oʊnli min ðət sɹɪn wɑz ənʃʊɹ wʌt dɪsɪʒən ʃi wəd meɪk. jukɪɝi ɪnsɪstəɾ ɑn ɡɪvɪŋ zɛɹə ən əɹ kənfɛɾɝeɪts oʊvɝ tə ðə lɔ ɪmiɾiətli - ɪf ɪt kəd bi dʌn wɪθaʊɾ ɪkspoʊzɪŋ ðɛɹ oʊn sɪtʃueɪʃən wɪð tælin. pɛvɑɹə ɑɹɡjud fəɹ juzɪŋ ðə ɹɛbəlz, ðoʊ hæfhɑɹɾɪdli; ðə dɪsɛn ðeɪ hæd bɪn spɹɛɾɪŋ sɛntɝɾ ɝaʊn vaɪl teɪlz kənsɝnɪŋ ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ ən fɔls dʒɹæɡənz. dʌsin sim tə bi sədʒɛstɪŋ ðət ðeɪ kɪdnæp ɛvɹi sɪstɝ ɪn ðə taʊɝ ən fɔɹs əm ɔl tə teɪk ði æɾəd oʊθ, bʌt ði ʌðɝ θɹi peɪd lɪɾəl ətɛnʃən tə hɝ.

When she was done, the others discussed the matter at some length, which could only mean that Saerin was unsure what decision she would make. Yukiri insisted on giving Zerah and her confederates over to the law immediately - if it could be done without exposing their own situation with Talene. Pevara argued for using the rebels, though halfheartedly; the dissent they had been spreading centered around vile tales concerning the Red Ajah and false Dragons. Doesine seemed to be suggesting that they kidnap every sister in the Tower and force them all to take the added oath, but the other three paid little attention to her.

sin tʊk noʊ pɑɹɾ ɪn ðə dɪskʌʃən. hɝ ɹiækʃən tə ðɛɹ pɹɪdɪkəmənt wɑz ði oʊnli pɑsəbəl wʌn, ʃi θɔt. tɑɾɝɪŋ tə ðə nɪɹəs kɔɹnɝ, ʃi vɑməɾəd nɔɪzəli.

Seaine took no part in the discussion. Her reaction to their predicament was the only possible one, she thought. Tottering to the nearest corner, she vomited noisily.

ɪleɪn tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə ɡɹaɪn əɹ tiθ. aʊtsaɪd, ənʌðɝ blɪzɝd pɛltɪd keɪɛmlɪn, dɑɹkənɪŋ ðə mɪddeɪ skaɪ ɪnʌf ðət ðə læmps əlɔŋ ðə sɪɾɪŋ ɹumz pænəld wɔlz wɝ ɔl lɪt. fɪɹs ɡʌsts ɹæɾəld ðə keɪsməns sɛɾ ɪndə ðə tɔl ɑɹtʃt wɪndoʊz. flæʃɪz ə laɪtnɪŋ lɪt ðə klɪɹ ɡlæs peɪnz, ən θʌndɝ bum hɑloʊli oʊvɝhɛd. θʌndɝ snoʊ, ðə wɝs kaɪndə wɪntɝ stɔɹm, ðə moʊs vaɪələnt. ðə ɹum wɑz nɑt pɹɪsaɪsli koʊld, bʌt . . . spɹɛɾɪŋ əɹ fɪŋɡɝz ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə lɔɡz kɹæklɪŋ ɪn ðə bɹɔd mɑɹbəl faɪɝpleɪs, ʃi kəd stɪl fil ə tʃɪl ɹaɪzɪŋ θɹu ðə kɑɹpəts leɪɝɾ oʊvɝ ðə flɔɹ taɪlz, ən θɹu hɝ θɪkəs vɛlvət slɪpɝz, tu. ðə waɪd blæk fɑks kɑlɝ ən kʌfs ɑn əɹ ɹɛd-ænd-waɪt ɡaʊn wɝ pɹɪɾi, bʌt ʃi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ ðeɪ æɾəd ɛni mɔɹ tə ɪts wɔɹmθ ðən ðə pɝlz ɑn ðə slivz. ɹəfjuzɪŋ tə lɛt ðə koʊl tʌtʃ əɹ dɪd nɑt min ʃi wɑz ʌnəwɛɹ.

Elayne tried not to grind her teeth. Outside, another blizzard pelted Caemlyn, darkening the midday sky enough that the lamps along the sitting room's paneled walls were all lit. Fierce gusts rattled the casements set into the tall arched windows. Flashes of lightning lit the clear glass panes, and thunder boomed hollowly overhead. Thunder snow, the worst kind of winter storm, the most violent. The room was not precisely cold, but . . . Spreading her fingers in front of the logs crackling in the broad marble fireplace, she could still feel a chill rising through the carpets layered over the floor tiles, and through her thickest velvet slippers, too. The wide black fox collar and cuffs on her red-and-white gown were pretty, but she was not sure they added any more to its warmth than the pearls on the sleeves. Refusing to let the cold touch her did not mean she was unaware.

wɛɹ wɑz nɪneɪiv? ən vændin? hɝ θɔts snɑɹəld laɪk ðə wɛðɝ. ðeɪ ʃəd bi hɪɹ ɔlɹɛɾi! laɪt! aɪ wɪʃ aɪ kəd lɝn tə ɡoʊ wɪθaʊt slip, ən ðeɪ teɪk ðɛɹ swit taɪm! noʊ, ðət wɑz ənfɛɹ. hɝ fɔɹməl kleɪm fəɹ ðə laɪən θɹoʊn wɑz oʊnli ə fju deɪz oʊld, ən fəɹ hɝ, ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɛls hæd tə teɪk sɛkən pleɪs fəɹ ðə taɪm biɪŋ. nɪneɪiv ən vændin hæɾ ʌðɝ pɹaɪɔɹəɾiz; ʌðɝ ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾiz, əz ðeɪ sɔ ðɛm. nɪneɪiv wɑz ʌp tə hɝ nɛk plænɪŋ wɪð ɹin ən ðə ɹɛst ə ðə nɪɾɪŋ sɝkəl haʊ tə spɪɹət kɪnswɪmən aʊɾ ə sintʃæn-kəntʃɹoʊld lænz bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ wɝ dɪskʌvɝɾ ən kɑlɝd. ðə kɪn wɝ vɛɹi ɡʊɾ ət steɪɪŋ loʊ, bʌt ðə sintʃæn wəd nɑt dʒʌs pæs əm baɪ fəɹ waɪldɝz ðə weɪ ɛɛs sədaɪ ɔlweɪz hæd. səpoʊzədli, vændin wɑz stɪl ʃeɪkən baɪ hɝ sɪstɝz mɝɾɝ, bɛɹli iɾɪŋ ən hɑɹdli eɪbəl tə ɡɪv ædvaɪs ʌv ɛni sɔɹt. ðə bɛɹli iɾɪŋ pɑɹt wɑz tʃɹu, bʌt faɪndɪŋ ðə kɪlɝ kənsum hɝ. səpoʊzədli wɔkɪŋ ðə hɔlz ɪn ɡɹif əɾ ɑɾ aʊɝz, ʃi wɑz sikɹɪtli hʌntɪŋ ðə dɑɹkfɹɛn əmʌŋ ðɛm. θɹi deɪz ɝliɝ, dʒʌs ðə θɔɾ ə ðət kəd meɪk ɪleɪn ʃɪvɝ; naʊ, ɪt wɑz wʌn deɪnʒɝ əmʌŋ mɛni. mɔɹ ɪntəmət ðən moʊst, tʃɹu, bʌɾ oʊnli moʊst.

Where was Nynaeve? And Vandene? Her thoughts snarled like the weather. They should be here already! Light! I wish I could learn to go without sleep, and they take their sweet time! No, that was unfair. Her formal claim for the Lion Throne was only a few days old, and for her, everything else had to take second place for the time being. Nynaeve and Vandene had other priorities; other responsibilities, as they saw them. Nynaeve was up to her neck planning with Reanne and the rest of the Knitting Circle how to spirit Kinswomen out of Seanchan-controlled lands before they were discovered and collared. The Kin were very good at staying low, but the Seanchan would not just pass them by for wilders the way Aes Sedai always had. Supposedly, Vandene was still shaken by her sister's murder, barely eating and hardly able to give advice of any sort. The barely eating part was true, but finding the killer consumed her. Supposedly walking the halls in grief at odd hours, she was secretly hunting the Darkfriend among them. Three days earlier, just the thought of that could make Elayne shiver; now, it was one danger among many. More intimate than most, true, but only most.

ðeɪ wɝ duɪŋ ɪmpɔɹɾənt tæsks, əpɹuvd ən ɛnkɝɪdʒ baɪ ɛɡwin, bʌt ʃi stɪl wɪʃt ðeɪ wəd hɝi, sɛlfɪʃ ðoʊ ɪt maɪt bi. vændin hæɾ ə wɛlθ ʌv ɡʊɾ ædvaɪs, ði ædvæntɪdʒ ə lɔŋ ɪkspɪɹiəns ən stʌɾi, ən nɪneɪivz jɪɹz dilɪŋ wɪð ðə vɪlədʒ kaʊnsəl ən ðə wɪmənz sɝkəl bæk ɪn ɛmənz fild ɡeɪv əɹ ə kin aɪ fəɹ pɹæktəkəl pɑlətɪks, haʊɛvɝ mʌtʃ ʃi dɪnaɪɾ ɪt. bɝn mi, aɪ hæv ə hʌnʒɹəd pɹɑbləmz, səm ɹaɪt hɪɹ ɪn ðə pæləs, ən aɪ nid ðɛm! ɪf ʃi hæɾ əɹ weɪ, nɪneɪiv ɑlmɹə wɑz gɑnə bi ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ædvaɪzɝ tə ðə nɛks kwin ʌv ændɝ. ʃi niɾəd ɔl ðə hɛlp ʃi kəd faɪnd - hɛlp ʃi kəd tʃɹʌst.

They were doing important tasks, approved and encouraged by Egwene, but she still wished they would hurry, selfish though it might be. Vandene had a wealth of good advice, the advantage of long experience and study, and Nynaeve's years dealing with the Village Council and the Women's Circle back in Emond's Field gave her a keen eye for practical politics, however much she denied it. Burn me, I have a hundred problems, some right here in the Palace, and I need them! If she had her way, Nynaeve al'Meara was going to be the Aes Sedai advisor to the next Queen of Andor. She needed all the help she could find - help she could trust.

smuðɪŋ əɹ feɪs, ʃi tɝn əweɪ fɹəm ðə bleɪzɪŋ hɑɹθ. θɝtin tɔl ɑɹmtʃɛɹz, kɑɹv sɪmpli bʌt wɪð ə faɪn hænd, meɪɾ ə hɔɹsʃu ɑɹk ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə faɪɝpleɪs. pɛɹədɑksəkli, ðə pleɪs ʌv ɑnɝ, wɛɹ ðə kwin wəd sɪɾ ɪf ɹəsivɪŋ hɪɹ, stʊd fɑɹðəs fɹəm ðə faɪɝz hit. sətʃ əz ɪt wɑz. hɝ bæk bɪɡæn tə wɔɹm ɪmiɾiətli, ən əɹ fɹʌn tə kul. aʊtsaɪd, snoʊ fɛl, θʌndɝ kɹæʃt ən laɪtnɪŋ flɛɹd. ɪnsaɪɾ əɹ hɛd, tu. kɑm. ə ɹulɝ hæɾ əz mʌtʃ niɾ ə kɑm əz ɛni ɛɛs sədaɪ.

Smoothing her face, she turned away from the blazing hearth. Thirteen tall armchairs, carved simply but with a fine hand, made a horseshoe arc in front of the fireplace. Paradoxically, the place of honor, where the Queen would sit if receiving here, stood farthest from the fire's heat. Such as it was. Her back began to warm immediately, and her front to cool. Outside, snow fell, thunder crashed and lightning flared. Inside her head, too. Calm. A ruler had as much need of calm as any Aes Sedai.

"ɪt mʌs bi ðə mɝsənɛɹiz," ʃi sɛd, nɑt kwaɪt mænɪdʒɪŋ tə kip ɹəɡɹɛɾ aʊɾ ə hɝ vɔɪs. ɑɹmmɪn fɹəm əɹ ɪsteɪts ʃʊɹli wəd bɪɡɪn ɝaɪvɪŋ ɪnsaɪɾ ə mʌnθ - wʌns ðeɪ lɝnd ʃi wɑz əlaɪv - bʌɾ ɪt maɪt bi spɹɪŋ bɪfɔɹ ɛni səɡnɪfɪkənt nʌmbɝz keɪm, ən ðə mɛn bɝdʒɪt wɑz ɹəkɹuɾɪŋ wəd ɹikwaɪɝ hæf ə jɪɹ əɹ mɔɹ bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ wɝ fɪt tə ɹaɪɾ ən hændəl ə sɔɹɾ ət ðə seɪm taɪm. "æn hʌntɝz fəɹ ðə hɔɹn, ɪf ɛni wɪl saɪn ən swɛɹ." ðəɹ wɝ plɛnti ʌv boʊθ tʃɹæpt ɪn keɪɛmlɪn baɪ ðə wɛðɝ. tu mɛni ʌv boʊθ, moʊs pipəl sɛd, kəɹaʊzəŋ, bɹɔlɪŋ, tʃɹʌbəlɪŋ wɪmən u wɑntəd noʊ pɑɹɾ ə ðɛɹ ətɛnʃənz. ət list ʃi wəd bi pʊɾɪŋ əm tə ɡʊd jus, tə stɑp tʃɹʌbəl ɪnstɛɾ ə bɪɡɪnɪŋ ɪt. ʃi wɪʃt ʃi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ʃi wɑz stɪl tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kənvɪns hɝsɛlf ə ðæt. "ɪkspɛnsɪv, bʌt ðə kɑfɝz wɪl kʌvɝ ɪt." fəɹ ə lɪɾəl waɪl, ðeɪ wʊd. ʃi hæd bɛɾɝ stɑɹt ɹəsivɪŋ ɹɛvənuz fɹəm əɹ ɪsteɪts sun.

"It must be the mercenaries," she said, not quite managing to keep regret out of her voice. Armsmen from her estates surely would begin arriving inside a month - once they learned she was alive - but it might be spring before any significant numbers came, and the men Birgitte was recruiting would require half a year or more before they were fit to ride and handle a sword at the same time. "And Hunters for the Horn, if any will sign and swear." There were plenty of both trapped in Caemlyn by the weather. Too many of both, most people said, carousing, brawling, troubling women who wanted no part of their attentions. At least she would be putting them to good use, to stop trouble instead of beginning it. She wished she did not think she was still trying to convince herself of that. "Expensive, but the coffers will cover it." For a little while, they would. She had better start receiving revenues from her estates soon.

wʌndɝ ʌv wʌndɝz, ðə tu wɪmən stændɪŋ bɪfɔɹ əɹ ɹiæktəɾ ɪn mʌtʃ ðə seɪm fæʃən.

Wonder of wonders, the two women standing before her reacted in much the same fashion.

daɪɛlɪn ɡeɪv ən ɪɹəteɪɾəd ɡɹʌnt. ə lɑɹdʒ, ɹaʊn sɪlvɝ pɪn wɝkt wɪð tæɹɑvɪnz aʊl ən oʊk wɑz fæsən ət ðə haɪ nɛk ə hɝ dɑɹk ɡɹin dʒɹɛs, hɝ oʊnli dʒuəlɹi. ə ʃoʊ ʌv pɹaɪɾ ɪn əɹ haʊs, pɝhæps tu mʌtʃ pɹaɪd; ðə haɪ siɾ ə haʊs tæɹɑvɪn wɑz ə pɹaʊd wʊmən ɔltəɡɛðɝ. ɡɹeɪ stʃɹikt əɹ ɡoʊldən hɛɹ ən faɪn laɪnz wɛb ðə kɔɹnɝz ə hɝ aɪz, jɛɾ əɹ feɪs wɑz stʃɹɔŋ, hɝ ɡeɪz lɛvəl ən ʃɑɹp. hɝ maɪnd wɑz ə ɹeɪzɝ. əɹ meɪbi ə sɔɹd. ə pleɪnspoʊkən wʊmən, əɹ soʊ ɪt simd, hu dɪd nɑt haɪɾ əɹ əpɪnjənz.

Dyelin gave an irritated grunt. A large, round silver pin worked with Taravin's Owl and Oak was fastened at the high neck of her dark green dress, her only jewelry. A show of pride in her House, perhaps too much pride; the High Seat of House Taravin was a proud woman altogether. Gray streaked her golden hair and fine lines webbed the corners of her eyes, yet her face was strong, her gaze level and sharp. Her mind was a razor. Or maybe a sword. A plainspoken woman, or so it seemed, who did not hide her opinions.

"mɝsənɛɹiz noʊ ðə wɝk," ʃi sɛd dɪsmɪsɪvli, "bʌt ðeɪ ɑɹ hɑɹd tə kəntʃɹoʊl, ɪleɪn. wən jə niɾ ə fɛðɝ tʌtʃ, ðəɹ laɪəbəl tə bi ə hæmɝ, ən wən jə niɾ ə hæmɝ, ðəɹ laɪəbəl tə bi ɛlswɛɹ, ən stilɪŋ tə but. ðeɪ ɑɹ lɔɪəl tə ɡoʊld, ən oʊnli əz lɔŋ əz ðə ɡoʊld læsts. ɪf ðeɪ doʊn bɪtʃɹeɪ fəɹ mɔɹ ɡoʊl fɝst. aɪm ʃʊɹ ðɪs wʌns leɪɾi bɝdʒɪt wɪl əɡɹi wɪð mi."

"Mercenaries know the work," she said dismissively, "but they are hard to control, Elayne. When you need a feather touch, they're liable to be a hammer, and when you need a hammer, they're liable to be elsewhere, and stealing to boot. They are loyal to gold, and only as long as the gold lasts. If they don't betray for more gold first. I'm sure this once Lady Birgitte will agree with me."

ɑɹmz foʊldəd taɪtli bɪniθ əɹ bɹɛsts ən hil buts plæntəd waɪd, bɝdʒɪt ɡɹɪməst, əz ɔlweɪz wən ɛniwʌn juzd əɹ nu taɪɾəl. ɪleɪn hæd ɡɹæntəɾ əɹ ən ɪsteɪɾ əz sun əz ðeɪ ɹitʃt keɪɛmlɪn, wɛɹ ɪt kəd bi ɹɛdʒəstɝd. ɪn pɹaɪvət, bɝdʒɪt ɡɹʌmbəld ɪnsɛsənli oʊvɝ ðæt, ən ði ʌðɝ tʃeɪnʒ ɪn əɹ laɪf. hɝ skaɪ-blu tʃɹaʊzɝz wɝ kʌt ðə seɪm əz ðoʊz ʃi juʒəwəli wɔɹ, bɪloʊɪŋ ən ɡæðɝɾ ət ði æŋkəlz, bʌɾ əɹ ʃɔɹt ɹɛd koʊt hæɾ ə haɪ waɪt kɑlɝ, ən waɪd waɪt kʌfs bændɪd wɪð ɡoʊld. ʃi wɑz ðə leɪɾi bɝdʒɪt tʃɹɑilaɪən ən ðə kæptən-dʒɛnɝəl ə ðə kwinz ɡɑɹd, ən ʃi kəd mʌɾɝ ən waɪn ɔl ʃi wɑntəd, soʊ lɔŋ əz ʃi kɛpt ɪt pɹaɪvət.

Arms folded tightly beneath her breasts and heeled boots planted wide, Birgitte grimaced, as always when anyone used her new title. Elayne had granted her an estate as soon as they reached Caemlyn, where it could be registered. In private, Birgitte grumbled incessantly over that, and the other change in her life. Her sky-blue trousers were cut the same as those she usually wore, billowing and gathered at the ankles, but her short red coat had a high white collar, and wide white cuffs banded with gold. She was the Lady Birgitte Trahelion and the Captain-General of the Queen's Guard, and she could mutter and whine all she wanted, so long as she kept it private.

"aɪ du," ʃi ɡɹaʊld ənwɪlɪŋli, ən ɡeɪv daɪɛlɪn ə nɑt-kwaɪt-saɪɾɛlɔŋ ɡlɛɹ. ðə wɔɹɾɝ bɑn kæɹid wʌɾ ɪleɪn hæd bɪn sɛnsɪŋ ɔl mɔɹnɪŋ. fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən, ɪɹɪteɪʃən, dɪtɝməneɪʃən. səm ə ðət maɪɾ əv bɪn ə ɹəflɛkʃən ə hɝsɛlf, ðoʊ. ðeɪ mɪɹɝɾ itʃ ʌðɝ ɪn sɝpɹaɪzɪŋ weɪz sɪns ðə bɑndɪŋ, ɪmoʊʃnəli ən ʌðɝwaɪz. waɪ, hɝ kɔɹsəz hæd ʃɪftəd baɪ mɔɹ ðən ə wik tə mætʃ ði ʌðɝ wʊmənz!

"I do," she growled unwillingly, and gave Dyelin a not-quite-sidelong glare. The Warder bond carried what Elayne had been sensing all morning. Frustration, irritation, determination. Some of that might have been a reflection of herself, though. They mirrored each other in surprising ways since the bonding, emotionally and otherwise. Why, her courses had shifted by more than a week to match the other woman's!

bɝdʒɪts ɹɪlʌktəns tə teɪk ðə sɛkənd-bɛst ɑɹɡjəmənt wɑz klɪɹli ɔlmoʊst əz ɡɹeɪɾ əz əɹ ɹɪlʌktəns tə əɡɹi. "hʌntɝz ɑɹən mʌtʃ blʌɾi bɛɾɝ, ɪleɪn," ʃi mʌɾɝd. "ðeɪ tʊk ðə hʌntɝz oʊθ tə faɪn ædvɛntʃɝ, ən ə pleɪs ɪn ðə hɪstɝiz ɪf ðeɪ kæn. nɑt tə sɛɾəl daʊn kipɪŋ ðə lɔ. hæf ɑɹ supɝsɪliəs pɹɪɡz, lʊkɪŋ daʊn ðɛɹ fleɪmɪŋ noʊzɪz əɾ ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls; ðə ɹɛs doʊn dʒʌs teɪk nɛsəsɛɹi tʃænsəz, ðeɪ lʊk fəɹ tʃænsəz tə teɪk. ən wʌn wɪspɝ ʌv ə ɹumɝ ə ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ, ən jəl bi lʌki ɪf oʊnli tu ɪn θɹi vænɪʃ oʊvɝnaɪt."

Birgitte's reluctance to take the second-best argument was clearly almost as great as her reluctance to agree. "Hunters aren't much bloody better, Elayne," she muttered. "They took the Hunter's Oath to find adventure, and a place in the histories if they can. Not to settle down keeping the law. Half are supercilious prigs, looking down their flaming noses at everyone else; the rest don't just take necessary chances, they look for chances to take. And one whisper of a rumor of the Horn of Valere, and you'll be lucky if only two in three vanish overnight."

daɪɛlɪn smaɪld ə θɪn smaɪl, əz ðoʊ ʃi hæd wʌn ə pɔɪnt. ɔɪl ən wɔɾɝ wɝ nɑɾ ɪn ɪt kəmpɛɹd tə ðoʊz tu; itʃ mænədʒd wɛl ɪnʌf wɪð nɪɹli ɛniwʌn ɛls, bʌt fəɹ səm ɹizən ðeɪ kəɾ ɑɹɡju oʊvɝ ðə kʌlɝ ə tʃɑɹkoʊl. kəɾ ən wʊd. "bɪsaɪdz, hʌntɝz ən mɝsənɛɹiz əlaɪk, nɪɹli ɔl ɑɹ fɔɹənɝz. ðət wɪl sɪt pʊɹli wɪð haɪ ən loʊ əlaɪk. vɛɹi pʊɹli. ðə læs θɪŋ jə wɑn ɪz tə stɑɹɾ ə ɹɪbɛljən." laɪtnɪŋ flɛɹd, bɹifli laɪɾɪŋ ðə keɪsməns, ən ə pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli laʊd pil ə θʌndɝ pʌŋktʃueɪɾɪd əɹ wɝdz. ɪn ə θaʊzən jɪɹz, sɛvən kwinz ʌv ændɝ hæd bɪn tɑpəl baɪ oʊpən ɹɪbɛljən, ən ðə tu hu sɝvaɪv pɹɑbli wɪʃt ðeɪ hæd nɑt.

Dyelin smiled a thin smile, as though she had won a point. Oil and water were not in it compared to those two; each managed well enough with nearly anyone else, but for some reason they could argue over the color of charcoal. Could and would. "Besides, Hunters and mercenaries alike, nearly all are foreigners. That will sit poorly with high and low alike. Very poorly. The last thing you want is to start a rebellion." Lightning flared, briefly lighting the casements, and a particularly loud peal of thunder punctuated her words. In a thousand years, seven Queens of Andor had been toppled by open rebellion, and the two who survived probably wished they had not.

ɪleɪn staɪfəld ə saɪ. wʌn ə ðə smɔl ɪnleɪd teɪbəlz əlɔŋ ðə wɔlz hɛld ə hɛvi sɪlvɝ ɹoʊpwɝk tʃɹeɪ wɪð kʌps ən ə tɔl pɪtʃɝ ə hɑt spaɪst waɪn. lukwɔɹm spaɪst waɪn, naʊ. ʃi tʃænəl bɹifli, faɪɝ, ən ə θɪn wɪsp ə stim ɹoʊz fɹəm ðə pɪtʃɝ. ɹihiɾɪŋ ɡeɪv ðə spaɪsəz ə slaɪt bɪɾɝnəs, bʌt ðə wɔɹmθ ə ðə wɝkt-sɪlvɝ kʌp ɪn əɹ hænz wɑz wɝθ ɪt. wɪð ən ɛfɝt ʃi ɹɪzɪstɪd ðə dɪzaɪɝ tə hit ði ɛɹ ɪn ðə ɹum wɪð ðə paʊɝ ən ɹilis ðə sɔɹs; ðə wɔɹmθ wəd nɑɾ əv læstəɾ ənlɛs ʃi meɪnteɪn ðə wivz, ɛniweɪ. ʃi hæd kɑŋkɝɾ əɹ ənwɪlɪŋnɪs tə lɛt ɡoʊ ɛvɹi taɪm ʃi tʊk ɪn seɪaɪdɑɹ - wɛl, tə səm ɪkstɛnt - jɛɾ ə leɪt, ðə dɪzaɪɝ tə dʒɹɔ mɔɹ ɡɹu ɛvɹi taɪm. ɛvɹi sɪstɝ hæd tə feɪs ðət deɪnʒɝəs dɪzaɪɝ. ə dʒɛstʃɝ bɹɔt ði ʌðɝz tə pɔɹ ðɛɹ oʊn waɪn.

Elayne stifled a sigh. One of the small inlaid tables along the walls held a heavy silver ropework tray with cups and a tall pitcher of hot spiced wine. Lukewarm spiced wine, now. She channeled briefly, Fire, and a thin wisp of steam rose from the pitcher. Reheating gave the spices a slight bitterness, but the warmth of the worked-silver cup in her hands was worth it. With an effort she resisted the desire to heat the air in the room with the Power and released the Source; the warmth would not have lasted unless she maintained the weaves, anyway. She had conquered her unwillingness to let go every time she took in saidar - well, to some extent - yet of late, the desire to draw more grew every time. Every sister had to face that dangerous desire. A gesture brought the others to pour their own wine.

"ju noʊ ðə sɪtʃueɪʃən," ʃi toʊl ðɛm. "oʊnli ə ful kəd θɪŋk ɪɾ ɛniθɪŋ bʌt daɪɹ, ən jəɹ niðɝ ə jə fulz." ðə ɡɑɹdz wɝ ə ʃɛl, ə hændfʊl ʌv æksɛptəbəl mɛn ən ə dʌbəl hændfʊl ə stʃɹɔŋɡɑɝmz ən tʌfs bɛɾɝ suɾəd tə θɹoʊɪŋ dʒɹʌŋks aʊɾ ə tævɝnz, əɹ biɪŋ θɹoʊn aʊt ðɛmsɛlvz. ən wɪð ðə sɑldəiənz ɡɔn ən ði il livɪŋ, kɹaɪm wɑz blumɪŋ laɪk widz ɪn spɹɪŋ. ʃi wʊɾə θɔt ðə snoʊ wəd dæmp ɪt daʊn, bʌɾ ɛvɹi deɪ bɹɔt ɹɑbɝi, ɑɹsən ən wɝs. ɛvɹi deɪ, ðə sɪtʃueɪʃən ɡɹu wɝs. "æt ðɪs ɹeɪt, wɪl si ɹaɪəts ɪn ə fju wiks. meɪbi sunɝ. ɪf aɪ kæn kip ɔɹɾɝ ɪn keɪɛmlɪn ɪtsɛlf, ðə pipəl wɪl tɝn əɡɛns mi." ɪf ʃi kəd nɑt kip ɔɹɾɝ ɪn ðə kæpəɾəl, ʃi maɪɾ əz wɛl ənaʊns tə ðə wɝl ðət ʃi wɑz ənfɪt tə ɹul. "aɪ doʊn laɪk ɪt, bʌɾ ɪts tə bi dʌn, soʊ ɪɾəl bi." boʊθ oʊpən ðɛɹ maʊðz, ɹɛɾi tə ɑɹɡju fɝðɝ, bʌt ʃi ɡeɪv əm noʊ tʃæns. ʃi meɪɾ əɹ vɔɪs fɝm. "ɪt wɪl bi dʌn."

"You know the situation," she told them. "Only a fool could think it anything but dire, and you're neither of you fools." The Guards were a shell, a handful of acceptable men and a double handful of strongarms and toughs better suited to throwing drunks out of taverns, or being thrown out themselves. And with the Saldaeans gone and the Aiel leaving, crime was blooming like weeds in spring. She would have thought the snow would damp it down, but every day brought robbery, arson and worse. Every day, the situation grew worse. "At this rate, we'll see riots in a few weeks. Maybe sooner. If I can't keep order in Caemlyn itself, the people will turn against me." If she could not keep order in the capital, she might as well announce to the world that she was unfit to rule. "I don't like it, but it has to be done, so it will be." Both opened their mouths, ready to argue further, but she gave them no chance. She made her voice firm. "It will be done."

bɝdʒɪts weɪst-lɔŋ ɡoʊldən bɹeɪd swʌŋ əz ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd, jɛt ɡɹʌdʒɪŋ æksɛptəns fɪltɝd θɹu ðə bɑnd. ʃi tʊk ə dɪsaɪɾədli ɑd vju ʌv ðɛɹ ɹileɪʃənʃɪp əz ɛɛs sədaɪ ən wɔɹɾɝ, bʌt ʃi hæd lɝn tə ɹɛkəɡnaɪz wən ɪleɪn wəd nɑt bi pɹɛst. æftɝ ə fæʃən ʃi hæd lɝnd. ðəɹ wɑz ði ɪsteɪɾ ən taɪɾəl. ən kəmændɪŋ ðə ɡɑɹdz. ən ə fju ʌðɝ smɔl mæɾɝz.

Birgitte's waist-long golden braid swung as she shook her head, yet grudging acceptance filtered through the bond. She took a decidedly odd view of their relationship as Aes Sedai and Warder, but she had learned to recognize when Elayne would not be pressed. After a fashion she had learned. There was the estate and title. And commanding the Guards. And a few other small matters.

daɪɛlɪn bɛn əɹ nɛk ə fɹækʃən, ən pɝhæps əɹ niz; ɪt maɪɾ əv bɪn ə kɝtsi, jɛɾ əɹ feɪs wɑz stoʊn. ɪt wɑz wɛl tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðət mɛni hu dɪd nɑt wɑn ɪleɪn tʃɹəkən ɑn ðə laɪən θɹoʊn wɑntəd daɪɛlɪn tæɹɑvɪn ɪnstɛd. ðə wʊmən hæd bɪn nʌθɪŋ bʌt hɛlpfəl, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ɝli deɪz jɛt, ən səmtaɪmz ə nɪɡəlɪŋ vɔɪs wɪspɝɾ ɪn ðə bæk ʌv ɪleɪnz hɛd. wɑz daɪɛlɪn sɪmpli weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ əɹ tə bʌŋɡəl bædli bɪfɔɹ stɛpɪŋ ɪn tə "seɪv" ændɝ? sʌmwʌn səfɪʃənli pɹuɾənt, səfɪʃənli diviəs, maɪt tʃɹaɪ ðət ɹut, ən maɪɾ ivən səksid.

Dyelin bent her neck a fraction, and perhaps her knees; it might have been a curtsy, yet her face was stone. It was well to remember that many who did not want Elayne Trakand on the Lion Throne wanted Dyelin Taravin instead. The woman had been nothing but helpful, but it was early days yet, and sometimes a niggling voice whispered in the back of Elayne's head. Was Dyelin simply waiting for her to bungle badly before stepping in to "save" Andor? Someone sufficiently prudent, sufficiently devious, might try that route, and might even succeed.

ɪleɪn ɹeɪzd ə hæn tə ɹʌb əɹ tɛmpəl bʌt meɪɾ ɪɾ ɪndə ədʒʌstɪŋ əɹ hɛɹ. soʊ mʌtʃ səspɪʃən, soʊ lɪɾəl tʃɹʌst. ðə ɡeɪm ə haʊsəz hæɾ ɪnfɛktəɾ ændɝ sɪns ʃi lɛft fəɹ tɑɹ vəlɑn. ʃi wɑz ɡɹeɪtfəl fəɹ əɹ mʌnθs əmʌŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ fəɹ mɔɹ ðən lɝnɪŋ ðə paʊɝ. deɪz deɪmɑɹ wɑz bɹɛθ ən bɹɛd, tə moʊst sɪstɝz. ɡɹeɪtfəl fəɹ tɑmz titʃɪŋ, tu. wɪθaʊt boʊθ, ʃi maɪt nɑɾ əv sɝvaɪvd əɹ ɹɪtɝn əz lɔŋ əz ʃi hæd. ðə laɪt sɛn tɑm wɑz seɪf, ðəɾ i ən mæt ən ði ʌðɝz hæɾ ɪskeɪp ðə sintʃæn ən wɝ ɑn ðɛɹ weɪ tə keɪɛmlɪn. ɛvɹi deɪ sɪns livɪŋ ɛbu dɑɹ ʃi pɹeɪd fəɹ ðɛɹ seɪfti, bʌt ðət bɹif pɹɛɹ wɑz ɔl ʃi hæd taɪm fɔɹ, naʊ.

Elayne raised a hand to rub her temple but made it into adjusting her hair. So much suspicion, so little trust. The Game of Houses had infected Andor since she left for Tar Valon. She was grateful for her months among Aes Sedai for more than learning the Power. Daes Dae'mar was breath and bread, to most sisters. Grateful for Thom's teaching, too. Without both, she might not have survived her return as long as she had. The Light send Thom was safe, that he and Mat and the others had escaped the Seanchan and were on their way to Caemlyn. Every day since leaving Ebou Dar she prayed for their safety, but that brief prayer was all she had time for, now.

teɪkɪŋ ðə tʃɛɹ ət ðə sɛntɝ ə ði ɑɹk, ðə kwinz tʃɛɹ, ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə lʊk laɪk ə kwin, bæk stʃɹeɪt, hɝ fɹi hæn ɹɛstɪŋ laɪtli ɑn ðə kɑɹv tʃɛɹ ɑɹm. lʊkɪŋ ə kwin ɪz nɑɾ ɪnʌf, hɝ mʌðɝ hæd toʊld əɹ ɔfən, bʌɾ ə faɪn maɪnd, ə kin ɡɹæsp ʌv əfɛɹz, ən ə bɹeɪv hɑɹt wɪl ɡoʊ fəɹ nʌθɪŋ ɪf pipəl də nɑt si jə əz ə kwin. bɝdʒɪt wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ əɹ kloʊsli, ɔlmoʊst səspɪʃəsli. səmtaɪmz ðə bɑnd wɑz dɪsaɪɾədli ɪnkənvinjənt! daɪɛlɪn ɹeɪzd əɹ waɪnkʌp tə hɝ lɪps.

Taking the chair at the center of the arc, the Queen's chair, she tried to look like a queen, back straight, her free hand resting lightly on the carved chair arm. Looking a queen is not enough, her mother had told her often, but a fine mind, a keen grasp of affairs, and a brave heart will go for nothing if people do not see you as a queen. Birgitte was watching her closely, almost suspiciously. Sometimes the bond was decidedly inconvenient! Dyelin raised her winecup to her lips.

ɪleɪn tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ. ʃi hæd hɛɹid ðɪs kwɛstʃən fɹəm ɛvɹi dɝɛkʃən ʃi nu, ən ʃi kəd si noʊ ʌðɝ weɪ. "bɝdʒɪt, baɪ spɹɪŋ, aɪ wɑn ðə ɡɑɹdz tə bi ən ɑɹmi ikwəl tə ɛniθɪŋ tɛn haʊsəz kən pʊɾ ɪn ðə fild." ɪmpɑsəbəl tə ətʃiv, laɪkli, bʌt dʒʌs tʃɹaɪɪŋ mɛn kipɪŋ ðə mɝsənɛɹiz u saɪnd naʊ ən faɪndɪŋ mɔɹ, saɪnɪŋ ɛvɹi mæn u ʃoʊd ðə list ɪnkləneɪʃən. laɪt, wʌɾ ə faʊl tæŋɡəl!

Elayne took a deep breath. She had harried this question from every direction she knew, and she could see no other way. "Birgitte, by spring, I want the Guards to be an army equal to anything ten Houses can put in the field." Impossible to achieve, likely, but just trying meant keeping the mercenaries who signed now and finding more, signing every man who showed the least inclination. Light, what a foul tangle!

daɪɛlɪn tʃoʊkt, hɝ aɪz bʌlʒɪŋ; dɑɹk waɪn spɹeɪd fɹəm əɹ maʊθ. stɪl spləɾɝɪŋ, ʃi plʌkt ə leɪs-ɛdʒ hæŋkɝtʃɪf fɹəm əɹ sliv ən dæbd əɾ əɹ tʃɪn.

Dyelin choked, her eyes bulging; dark wine sprayed from her mouth. Still spluttering, she plucked a lace-edged handkerchief from her sleeve and dabbed at her chin.

ə weɪv ə pænɪk ʃɑt daʊn ðə bɑn fɹəm bɝdʒɪt. "oʊ, bɝn mi, ɪleɪn, jə kæn min . . . ! aɪm æm ɑɹtʃɝ, nɑɾ ə dʒɛnɝəl! ðæts ɔl aɪv ɛvɝ bɪn, doʊn jə ʌndɝstæn jɛt? aɪ dʒʌs dɪd wʌɾ aɪ hæd tə du, wʌt sɝkəmstænsəz fɔɹst ɑn mi! ɛniweɪ, aɪm nɑt hɝ, ɛnimɔɹ; aɪm dʒʌs mi, ən . . . !" ʃi tʃɹeɪld ɔf, ɹilaɪzɪŋ ʃi maɪɾ əv sɛd tu mʌtʃ. nɑt fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm. hɝ feɪs wɛn kɹɪmzən əz daɪɛlɪn aɪɾ əɹ kjʊɹiəsli.

A wave of panic shot down the bond from Birgitte. "Oh, burn me, Elayne, you can't mean . . . ! I'm am archer, not a general! That's all I've ever been, don't you understand yet? I just did what I had to do, what circumstances forced on me! Anyway, I'm not her, anymore; I'm just me, and . . . !" She trailed off, realizing she might have said too much. Not for the first time. Her face went crimson as Dyelin eyed her curiously.

ðeɪ hæd pʊɾ ɪɾ əbaʊt ðət bɝdʒɪt wɑz fɹəm kændɝ, wɛɹ kʌntʃɹi wɪmən wɔɹ sʌmθɪŋ laɪk əɹ kloʊðz, jɛt daɪɛlɪn klɪɹli səspɛktəd ðə laɪ. ən ɛvɹi taɪm bɝdʒɪt lɛɾ əɹ tʌŋ slɪp, ʃi keɪm kloʊsɝ tə lɛɾɪŋ əɹ sikɹət slɪp, tu. ɪleɪn ʃɑɾ əɹ ə lʊk ðət pɹɑməst ə tɔkɪŋ-tə, leɪɾɝ.

They had put it about that Birgitte was from Kandor, where country women wore something like her clothes, yet Dyelin clearly suspected the lie. And every time Birgitte let her tongue slip, she came closer to letting her secret slip, too. Elayne shot her a look that promised a talking-to, later.

ʃi wəd nɑɾ əv θɔt bɝdʒɪts tʃiks kəd ɡɛɾ ɛni ɹɛɾɝ. mɔɹɾəfəkeɪʃən dʒɹaʊn ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɛls ɪn ðə bɑnd, flʌɾɪŋ θɹu əntɪl ɪleɪn fɛlt əɹ oʊn feɪs kʌlɝɪŋ. kwɪkli ʃi pʊɾ ɑn ə stɝn ɪkspɹɛʃən, hoʊpɪŋ əɹ kɹɪmzən tʃiks wəd pæs fəɹ sʌmθɪŋ ʌðɝ ðən ən ɪntɛns dɪzaɪɝ tə skwɝm ɪn əɹ sit wɪð bɝdʒɪts hjumɪlieɪʃən. ðət mɪɹɝɪŋ ɪfɛkt kəd bi mɔɹ ðən mɪɹli ɪnkənvinjənt!

She would not have thought Birgitte's cheeks could get any redder. Mortification drowned everything else in the bond, flooding through until Elayne felt her own face coloring. Quickly she put on a stern expression, hoping her crimson cheeks would pass for something other than an intense desire to squirm in her seat with Birgitte's humiliation. That mirroring effect could be more than merely inconvenient!

daɪɛlɪn weɪstəɾ oʊnli ə moʊmən ɑn bɝdʒɪt. tʌkɪŋ əɹ hæŋkɝtʃɪf bæk ɪn ɪts pleɪs, ʃi kɛɹfəli sɛɾ əɹ kʌp bæk ɑn ðə tʃɹeɪ, ðən plæntəɾ əɹ hænz ɑn əɹ hɪps. hɝ feɪs wɑz ə θʌndɝhɛd, naʊ. "ðə ɡɑɹdz əv ɔlweɪz bɪn ðə kɔɹ ʌv ændɝz ɑɹmi, ɪleɪn, bʌt ðɪs. . . . laɪts mɝsi, ðɪs ɪz mædnəs! jə kəd tɝn ɛvɹi hæn əɡɛns jə fɹəm ðə ɹɪvɝ ɛɹɪnɪn tə ðə maʊntənz ə mɪst!"

Dyelin wasted only a moment on Birgitte. Tucking her handkerchief back in its place, she carefully set her cup back on the tray, then planted her hands on her hips. Her face was a thunderhead, now. "The Guards have always been the core of Andor's army, Elayne, but this. . . . Light's mercy, this is madness! You could turn every hand against you from the River Erinin to the Mountains of Mist!"

ɪleɪn foʊkəst ɑn kɑm. ɪf ʃi wɑz ɹɔŋ, ændɝ wəd bɪkʌm ənʌðɝ kɛɹhin, ənʌðɝ blʌd-soʊk læn fɪld wɪð keɪɑs. ən ʃi wəd daɪ, ʌv kɔɹs, ə pɹaɪs nɑt haɪ ɪnʌf tə mit ðə kɑst. nɑt tʃɹaɪɪŋ wɑz ənθɪŋkəbəl ən ɪn ɛni keɪs wəɾ əv ðə seɪm ɹɪzʌl fəɹ ændɝ əz feɪljɝ. kul, kəmpoʊzd, stili kɑm. ə kwin kəd nɑt ʃoʊ hɝsɛlf əfɹeɪd, ivən wən ʃi wɑz. ɪspɛʃli wən ʃi wɑz. hɝ mʌðɝ hæɾ ɔlweɪz sɛd tə ɪkspleɪn dɪsɪʒənz əz sɛldəm əz pɑsəbəl; ðə mɔɹ ɔfən jə ɪkspleɪnd, ðə mɔɹ ɛkspləneɪʃənz wɝ nɛsəsɛɹi, əntɪl ðeɪ wɝ ɔl jə hæd taɪm fɔɹ. ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn sɛd tə ɪkspleɪn ɪf jə kʊd; jəɹ pipəl dɪd bɛɾɝ ɪf ðeɪ nu ðə waɪ əz wɛl əz ðə wʌt. tədeɪ, ʃi wəd fɑloʊ ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn. ə ɡʊd mɛni vɪktɝiz hæd bɪn wʌn baɪ fɑloʊɪŋ hɪm.

Elayne focused on calm. If she was wrong, Andor would become another Cairhien, another blood-soaked land filled with chaos. And she would die, of course, a price not high enough to meet the cost. Not trying was unthinkable and in any case would have the same result for Andor as failure. Cool, composed, steely calm. A queen could not show herself afraid, even when she was. Especially when she was. Her mother had always said to explain decisions as seldom as possible; the more often you explained, the more explanations were necessary, until they were all you had time for. Gareth Bryne said to explain if you could; your people did better if they knew the why as well as the what. Today, she would follow Gareth Bryne. A good many victories had been won by following him.

"aɪ hæv θɹi dɪklɛɹd tʃælənʒɝz." ən meɪbi wʌn nɑt dɪklɛɹd. ʃi meɪd hɝsɛlf mit daɪɛlɪnz ɡeɪz. nɑɾ æŋɡɹəli; dʒʌst aɪz miɾɪŋ aɪz. əɹ meɪbi daɪɛlɪn dɪd teɪk ɪt fəɹ æŋɡɝ, wɪð əɹ dʒɔ taɪɾ ən əɹ feɪs flʌʃt. ɪf soʊ, soʊ bi ɪt. "baɪ hɝsɛlf, ɛɹəmɪlə ɪz nɛɡlədʒəbəl, bʌt næsən əz dʒɔɪn haʊs kɝən tə hɝ, ən wɛðɝ əɹ nɑt hiz seɪn, hɪz səpɔɹt minz ʃi mʌs bi kənsɪɾɝd. nɑiən ən ɛləniə ɑɹ ɪmpɹɪzənd; ðɛɹ ɑɹmmɪn ɑɹ nɑt. nɑiənz pipəl meɪ dɪðɝ ən ɑɹɡju əntɪl ðeɪ faɪn ə liɾɝ, bʌt dʒɑɝɪɾ ɪz haɪ siɾ ə sɑɝənd, ən hɪl teɪk tʃænsəz tə fiɾ ɪz waɪfs æmbɪʃən. haʊs bɛɹɪn ən haʊs ænʃɝ flɝt wɪð boʊθ; ðə bɛst aɪ kən hoʊp ɪz ðət wʌn ɡoʊz wɪð sɑɝən ən wʌn wɪð ɑɝɔn. naɪntin haʊsəz ɪn ændɝ ɑɹ stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf ðət smɔlɝ haʊsəz wɪl fɑloʊ wɛɹ ðeɪ lɛd. sɪks ɑɹ ɝeɪɾ əɡɛns mi, ən aɪ hæv tu." sɪks soʊ fɑɹ, ən ðə laɪt sɛnd ʃi hæd tu! ʃi wəd nɑt mɛnʃən ðə θɹi ɡɹeɪt haʊsəz ðət hæɾ ɔl bʌt dɪklɛɹd fəɹ daɪɛlɪn; ət list ɛɡwin hæɾ əm taɪd daʊn ɪn mʊɹændi fəɹ naʊ.

"I have three declared challengers." And maybe one not declared. She made herself meet Dyelin's gaze. Not angrily; just eyes meeting eyes. Or maybe Dyelin did take it for anger, with her jaw tight and her face flushed. If so, so be it. "By herself, Arymilla is negligible, but Nasin has joined House Caeren to her, and whether or not he's sane, his support means she must be considered. Naean and Elenia are imprisoned; their armsmen are not. Naean's people may dither and argue until they find a leader, but Jarid is High Seat of Sarand, and he will take chances to feed his wife's ambition. House Baryn and House Anshar flirt with both; the best I can hope is that one goes with Sarand and one with Arawn. Nineteen Houses in Andor are strong enough that smaller Houses will follow where they lead. Six are arrayed against me, and I have two." Six so far, and the Light send she had two! She would not mention the three great Houses that had all but declared for Dyelin; at least Egwene had them tied down in Murandy for now.

ʃi moʊʃən tə ə tʃɛɹ nɪɹ hɝ, ən daɪɛlɪn sæt, kɛɹfəli ɝeɪnʒɪŋ əɹ skɝts. ðə stɔɹm klaʊdz hæd lɛf ði oʊldɝ wʊmənz feɪs. ʃi stʌɾid ɪleɪn, ɡɪvɪŋ noʊ hɪn əz tə hɝ kwɛstʃənz əɹ kənkluʒənz. "aɪ noʊ ɔl ðəɾ əz wɛl əz ju, ɪleɪn, bʌt lwɑn ən ɛlɹin wɪl bɹɪŋ ðɛɹ haʊsəz tə ju, ən æbəl wɪl əz wɛl, aɪm ʃʊɹ." ə kɛɹfəl vɔɪs, tu, bʌɾ ɪt ɡæðɝd hiɾ əz ʃi wɛn ɑn. "ʌðɝ haʊsəz wɪl si ɹizən, ðɛn. əz lɔŋ əz jə doʊn fɹaɪɾən əm aʊɾ ə ɹizən. laɪt, ɪleɪn, ðɪs ɪz nɑɾ ə səksɛʃən. tʃɹəkən səksidz tʃɹəkənd, nɑɾ ənʌðɝ haʊs. ivən ə səksɛʃən əz sɛldəm kʌm tə oʊpən faɪɾɪŋ! meɪk ðə ɡɑɹdz ɪndə ən ɑɹmi, ən jə ɹɪsk ɛvɹiθɪŋ."

She motioned to a chair near her, and Dyelin sat, carefully arranging her skirts. The storm clouds had left the older woman's face. She studied Elayne, giving no hint as to her questions or conclusions. "I know all that as well as you, Elayne, but Luan and Ellorien will bring their Houses to you, and Abelle will as well, I'm sure." A careful voice, too, but it gathered heat as she went on. "Other Houses will see reason, then. As long as you don't frighten them out of reason. Light, Elayne, this is not a Succession. Trakand succeeds Trakand, not another House. Even a Succession has seldom come to open fighting! Make the Guards into an army, and you risk everything."

ɪleɪn θɹu hɝ hɛd bæk, bʌɾ əɹ læftɝ hɛl noʊ əmjuzmənt. ɪt fɪt ɹaɪɾ ɪn wɪð ðə pilz ə θʌndɝ. "aɪ ɹɪskt ɛvɹiθɪŋ ðə deɪ aɪ keɪm hoʊm, daɪɛlɪn. jə seɪ nɔɹwlɪn ən tʃɹæmən wɪl kʌm tə mi, ən pɛnʒɹ? faɪn; ðən aɪ hæv faɪv tə feɪs sɪks. aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ði ʌðɝ haʊsəz wɪl 'si ɹizən,' əz jə pʊɾ ɪt. ɪf ɛni ʌv əm muv bɪfɔɹ ɪts klɪɹ əz ɡʊd ɡlæs ðə ɹoʊz kɹaʊn ɪz maɪn, ɪɾəl bi əɡɛns mi, nɑt fɔɹ." wɪð lʌk, ðoʊz lɔɹdz ən leɪɾiz wəd ʃaɪ əweɪ fɹəm əsoʊsieɪɾɪŋ wɪð kɹoʊniz ʌv ɡeɪbɹəl, bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt laɪk dɪpɛndɪŋ ɑn lʌk. ʃi wɑz nɑt mæt kɔθən. laɪt, moʊs pipəl wɝ ʃʊɹ ɹænd hæd kɪld əɹ mʌðɝ, ən fju bɪliv ðət "lɔɹd ɡeɪbɹəl" hæd bɪn wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən. mɛndɪŋ ðə dæmədʒ ɹɑvɪn hæd dʌn ɪn ændɝ maɪt teɪk əɹ ɪntaɪɝ laɪftaɪm ivən ɪf ʃi mænədʒ tə lɪv əz lɔŋ əz ðə kɪnswɪmən! səm haʊsəz wəd stæn əsaɪd fɹəm səpɔɹɾɪŋ əɹ kəz ə ði aʊtʃɹeɪdʒɪz ɡeɪbɹəl hæd pɝpətʃɹeɪɾɪd ɪn mɔɹɡeɪsəz neɪm, ən ʌðɝz kəz ɹænd hæd sɛɾ i ɪntɛndəd tə "ɡɪv" hɝ ðə θɹoʊn. ʃi lʌv ðə mæn tə hɝ toʊz, bʌt bɝn ɪm fəɹ ɡɪvɪŋ vɔɪs tə ðæt! ivən ɪf ɪt wɑz wʌt ɹeɪn ɪn daɪɛlɪn. ðə minəs kɹɔftɝ ɪn ændɝ wəd ʃoʊldɝ ɪz saɪð tə pʊl ə pʌpət fɹəm ðə laɪən θɹoʊn!

Elayne threw her head back, but her laughter held no amusement. It fit right in with the peals of thunder. "I risked everything the day I came home, Dyelin. You say Norwelyn and Traemane will come to me, and Pendar? Fine; then I have five to face six. I don't think the other Houses will 'see reason,' as you put it. If any of them move before it's clear as good glass the Rose Crown is mine, it will be against me, not for." With luck, those lords and ladies would shy away from associating with cronies of Gaebril, but she did not like depending on luck. She was not Mat Cauthon. Light, most people were sure Rand had killed her mother, and few believed that "Lord Gaebril" had been one of the Forsaken. Mending the damage Rahvin had done in Andor might take her entire lifetime even if she managed to live as long as the Kinswomen! Some Houses would stand aside from supporting her because of the outrages Gaebril had perpetrated in Morgase's name, and others because Rand had said he intended to "give" her the throne. She loved the man to her toes, but burn him for giving voice to that! Even if it was what reined in Dyelin. The meanest crofter in Andor would shoulder his scythe to pull a puppet from the Lion Throne!

"aɪ wɑnə əvɔɪɾ ændɔɝən kɪlɪŋ ændɔɝən ɪf aɪ kæn, daɪɛlɪn, bʌt səksɛʃən əɹ noʊ səksɛʃən, dʒɑɝɪɾ ɪz ɹɛɾi tə faɪt, ivən wɪð ɛləniə lɑkt əweɪ. nɑiən ɪz ɹɛɾi tə faɪt." bɛs tə bɹɪŋ boʊθ wɪmən tə keɪɛmlɪn əz sun əz pɑsəbəl; tu mʌtʃ tʃæns ə ðɛm slɪpɪŋ mɛsədʒəz, ən ɔɹɾɝz, aʊɾ ʌv ɑɹɪŋɡəl. "ɛɹəmɪlə ɪz ɹɛɾi, wɪð næsənz mɛn bɪhaɪn hɝ. tə ðɛm, ðɪs ɪz ə səksɛʃən, ən ði oʊnli weɪ tə stɑp əm fɹəm faɪɾɪŋ ɪz tə bi soʊ stʃɹɔŋ ðeɪ doʊn dɛɹ. ɪf bɝdʒɪt kən bɪl ðə ɡɑɹdz ɪndə ən ɑɹmi baɪ spɹɪŋ, wɛl ən ɡʊd, kəz ɪf aɪ doʊn əv ən ɑɹmi bɪfɔɹ ðɛn, əl əv niɾ ʌv wʌn. ən ɪf ðəɾ ɪzən ɪnʌf, ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðə sintʃæn. ðeɪ woʊn bi sæɾəsfaɪd wɪð tæntʃəkoʊ ən ɛbu dɑɹ; ðeɪ wɑn ɛvɹiθɪŋ. aɪ woʊn lɛɾ əm əv ændɝ, daɪɛlɪn, ɛni mɔɹ ðən əl lɛɾ ɛɹəmɪlə." θʌndɝ ɹɔɹɾ oʊvɝhɛd.

"I want to avoid Andoran killing Andoran if I can, Dyelin, but Succession or no Succession, Jarid is ready to fight, even with Elenia locked away. Naean is ready to fight." Best to bring both women to Caemlyn as soon as possible; too much chance of them slipping messages, and orders, out of Aringill. "Arymilla is ready, with Nasin's men behind her. To them, this is a Succession, and the only way to stop them from fighting is to be so strong they don't dare. If Birgitte can build the Guards into an army by spring, well and good, because if I don't have an army before then, I will have need of one. And if that isn't enough, remember the Seanchan. They won't be satisfied with Tanchico and Ebou Dar; they want everything. I won't let them have Andor, Dyelin, any more than I'll let Arymilla." Thunder roared overhead.

twɪstɪŋ ə lɪɾəl tə lʊk bæk ət bɝdʒɪt, daɪɛlɪn mɔɪsən əɹ lɪps. hɝ fɪŋɡɝz plʌkt ʌnkɑnʃəsli əɾ əɹ skɝts. vɛɹi lɪɾəl fɹaɪɾənd hɝ, bʌt teɪlz ə ðə sintʃæn hæd. wʌt ʃi mɝmɝd, ðoʊ, əz ɪf tə hɝsɛlf, wɑz, "aɪ hæd hoʊp tə əvɔɪɾ aʊtʃɹaɪt sɪvəl wɔɹ." ən ðət maɪt min nʌθɪŋ, əɹ ə ɡɹeɪt dil! pɝhæps ə lɪɾəl pɹoʊbɪŋ maɪt ʃoʊ wɪtʃ.

Twisting a little to look back at Birgitte, Dyelin moistened her lips. Her fingers plucked unconsciously at her skirts. Very little frightened her, but tales of the Seanchan had. What she murmured, though, as if to herself, was, "I had hoped to avoid outright civil war." And that might mean nothing, or a great deal! Perhaps a little probing might show which.

"ɡɔɪn," bɝdʒɪt sɛd sʌɾənli. hɝ ɪkspɹɛʃən hæd laɪɾənd, ən soʊ hæd ði ɪmoʊʃənz floʊɪŋ ðoʊ ðə bɑnd. ɹɪlif stʊɾ aʊt stʃɹɔŋ. "wɛn i kʌmz, hɪl teɪk kəmænd. hɪl bi jəɹ fɝs pɹɪns ə ðə sɔɹd."

"Gawyn," Birgitte said suddenly. Her expression had lightened, and so had the emotions flowing though the bond. Relief stood out strong. "When he comes, he'll take command. He'll be your First Prince of the Sword."

"mʌðɝz mɪlk ɪn ə kʌp!" ɪleɪn snæpt, ən laɪtnɪŋ flɛɹɾ ɪn ðə wɪndoʊz fəɹ ɛmfəsəs. waɪ dɪd ðə wʊmən əv tə tʃeɪnʒ ðə sʌbʒɪkt naʊ? daɪɛlɪn ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt, ən hit flʌɾəd bæk ɪndə ɪleɪnz feɪs. baɪ ði oʊldɝ wʊmənz ɡeɪpɪŋ maʊθ, ʃi nu ɪɡzækli haʊ kɔɹs ðət kɝs wɑz. stʃɹeɪnʒli ɪmbɛɹəsɪŋ, ðæt; ɪt ʃəd nɑɾ əv kaʊntəd fəɹ ɛniθɪŋ ðət daɪɛlɪn hæd bɪn əɹ mʌðɝz fɹɛnd. ənθɪŋkɪŋ, ʃi tʊk ə dip swɑloʊ ʌv waɪn - ən nɪɹli ɡæɡd ət ðə bɪɾɝnəs. kwɪkli ʃi səpɹɛst ɪmədʒəz ə lini θɹɛɾənɪŋ tə wɑʃ aʊɾ əɹ maʊθ ən ɹimaɪndəd hɝsɛlf ðət ʃi wɑz ə ɡɹoʊn wʊmən wɪð ə θɹoʊn tə wɪn. ʃi daʊɾɪd əɹ mʌðɝ hæɾ ɛvɝ faʊn hɝsɛlf filɪŋ fulɪʃ soʊ ɔfən.

"Mother's milk in a cup!" Elayne snapped, and lightning flared in the windows for emphasis. Why did the woman have to change the subject now? Dyelin gave a start, and heat flooded back into Elayne's face. By the older woman's gaping mouth, she knew exactly how coarse that curse was. Strangely embarrassing, that; it should not have counted for anything that Dyelin had been her mother's friend. Unthinking, she took a deep swallow of wine - and nearly gagged at the bitterness. Quickly she suppressed images of Lini threatening to wash out her mouth and reminded herself that she was a grown woman with a throne to win. She doubted her mother had ever found herself feeling foolish so often.

"jɛs, hi wɪl, bɝdʒɪt," ʃi wɛn ɑn, mɔɹ kɑmli. "wɛn i kʌmz." θɹi kɝiɝz wɝ ɑn ðɛɹ weɪ tə tɑɹ vəlɑn. ivən ɪf nʌn mænədʒ tə ɡɛt pæst ɪleɪɾə, ɡɔɪn wəd lɝn ɪvɛntʃəwəli ðət ʃi hæd meɪɾ əɹ kleɪm, ən i wəd kʌm. ʃi niɾəd ɪm dɛspɝətli. ʃi hæd noʊ ɪluʒənz ə hɝsɛlf əz ə dʒɛnɝəl, ən bɝdʒɪt wɑz soʊ fɪɹfəl ʃi kəd nɑt lɪv ʌp tə ðə lɛdʒənz əbaʊɾ əɹ ðət səmtaɪmz ʃi simd əfɹeɪd tə tʃɹaɪ. feɪs ən ɑɹmi, jɛs; lɛɾ ən ɑɹmi, nɛvɝ ʌndɝ ðə sʌn!

"Yes, he will, Birgitte," she went on, more calmly. "When he comes." Three couriers were on their way to Tar Valon. Even if none managed to get past Elaida, Gawyn would learn eventually that she had made her claim, and he would come. She needed him desperately. She had no illusions of herself as a general, and Birgitte was so fearful she could not live up to the legends about her that sometimes she seemed afraid to try. Face an army, yes; lead an army, never under the sun!

bɝdʒɪt wɑz wɛl əwɛɹ ə ðə tæŋɡəl ɪn əɹ oʊn maɪnd. ɹaɪt ðət moʊmən əɹ feɪs wɑz fɹoʊzən, bʌɾ əɹ ɪmoʊʃənz wɝ fʊl ə sɛlf-æŋɡɝ ən ɪmbɛɹəsmənt, wɪð ðə fɝst ɡɹoʊɪŋ stʃɹɔŋɝ baɪ ðə moʊmənt. wɪð ə stæb ʌv ɪɹɪteɪʃən, ɪleɪn oʊpən əɹ maʊθ tə pɝsu daɪɛlɪnz mɛnʃən ə sɪvəl wɔɹ bɪfɔɹ ʃi bɪɡæn ɹəflɛktɪŋ bɝdʒɪts æŋɡɝ.

Birgitte was well aware of the tangle in her own mind. Right that moment her face was frozen, but her emotions were full of self-anger and embarrassment, with the first growing stronger by the moment. With a stab of irritation, Elayne opened her mouth to pursue Dyelin's mention of civil war before she began reflecting Birgitte's anger.

bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəɾ ʌɾɝ ə wɝd, ðoʊ, ðə tɔl ɹɛd dɔɹz oʊpənd. hɝ hoʊps fəɹ nɪneɪiv əɹ vændin wɝ dæʃt baɪ ði ɛntʃɹəns ə tu si foʊk wɪmən, bɛɹfʊt dɪspaɪt ðə wɛðɝ.

Before she could utter a word, though, the tall red doors opened. Her hopes for Nynaeve or Vandene were dashed by the entrance of two Sea Folk women, barefoot despite the weather.
