He could hear her muttering to herself as she rummaged through the shelves where they had been stored after Fel's death. With the bounty for books and manuscripts it did not yet possess, the Academy's library was fast outgrowing the rooms that could be spared in Lord Barthanes' former palace. Alanna sat in the back of his head, sulking it seemed; she would know he was in the City. This near, she would be able to walk straight to him, but he would know if she tried. Blessedly, Lews Therin was silent for the moment. Of late, the man seemed madder than ever.

hi ɹʌbd ə spɑt klɪɹ ɑn ə wɪndoʊpeɪn wɪð ɪz koʊtsliv. staʊt dɑɹk ɡɹeɪ wʊl, ɡʊɾ ɪnʌf fəɹ ə mæn wɪð ə lɪɾəl mʌni ən fju ɛɹz, ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ə ɡɑɹmən ɛniwʌn wəɾ ɪkspɛk tə si ɑn ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. ðə ɡoʊldən-meɪn dʒɹæɡənz hɛɾ ɑn ðə bæk ə hɪz hænd ɡlɪɾɝd mɛɾəlɪkli; ɪt pɹizɛntəd noʊ deɪnʒɝ hɪɹ. hɪz but tʌtʃt ðə lɛðɝ skɹɪp sɪɾɪŋ bɪloʊ ðə wɪndoʊ əz i lin fɔɹwɝd tə lʊk aʊt.

He rubbed a spot clear on a windowpane with his coatsleeve. Stout dark gray wool, good enough for a man with a little money and few airs, it was not a garment anyone would expect to see on the Dragon Reborn. The golden-maned Dragon's head on the back of his hand glittered metallically; it presented no danger here. His boot touched the leather scrip sitting below the window as he leaned forward to look out.

ɪn ðə steɪbliɑɹd, ðə peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz hæd bɪn swɛp klɪɹ ə snoʊ, ən ə lɑɹdʒ wæɡən stʊd sɝaʊndəd baɪ bʌkəts laɪk mʌʃɹumz ɪn ə klɪɹɪŋ. hæf ə dʌzən mɛn ɪn hɛvi koʊts ən skɑɹvz ən kæps sim tə bi wɝkɪŋ ɑn ðə wæɡənz ɑd kɑɹɡoʊ, məkænɪkəl dɪvaɪsəz kɹaʊɾəd ɝaʊn ə fæt mɛɾəl sɪləndɝ ðət tʊk ʌp mɔɹ ðən hæf ðə wæɡən bɛd. ivən stʃɹeɪnʒɝ, ðə wæɡən-ʃæfs wɝ mɪsɪŋ. wʌn ə ðə mɛn wɑz muvɪŋ splɪt faɪɝwʊd fɹəm ə lɑɹdʒ wilbɛɹoʊ ɪndə ðə saɪɾ ʌv ə mɛɾəl bɑks fæsən bɪloʊ wʌn ɛn ə ðə bɪɡ sɪləndɝ. ði oʊpən dɔɹ ɪn ðə bɑks ɡloʊd wɪð ðə ɹɛɾ ə faɪɝ ɪnsaɪd, ən smoʊk ɹoʊz fɹəm ə tɔl, nɛɹoʊ tʃɪmni. ənʌðɝ fɛloʊ dænst ɝaʊn ðə wæɡən, bɪɹɾəd, keɪpləs ən bɔld-hɛɾəd, dʒɛstʃɝɪŋ ən əpɛɹənli ʃaʊɾɪŋ ɔɹɾɝz ðət dɪd nɑt sim tə meɪk ði ʌðɝz muv ɛni fæstɝ. ðɛɹ bɹɛθ meɪd feɪnt waɪt plumz. ɪt wɑz ɔlmoʊst wɔɹm ɪnsaɪd; ði əkæɾəmi hæd lɑɹdʒ fɝnəsəz ɪn ðə sɛlɝz ən ən ɪkstɛnsɪv sɪstəm ə vɛns. ðə hæf-hild, nɛvɝ hilɪŋ wunz ɪn ɪz saɪd wɝ hɑt.

In the stableyard, the paving stones had been swept clear of snow, and a large wagon stood surrounded by buckets like mushrooms in a clearing. Half a dozen men in heavy coats and scarves and caps seemed to be working on the wagon's odd cargo, mechanical devices crowded around a fat metal cylinder that took up more than half the wagon bed. Even stranger, the wagon-shafts were missing. One of the men was moving split firewood from a large wheelbarrow into the side of a metal box fastened below one end of the big cylinder. The open door in the box glowed with the red of fire inside, and smoke rose from a tall, narrow chimney. Another fellow danced around the wagon, bearded, capless and bald-headed, gesturing and apparently shouting orders that did not seem to make the others move any faster. Their breath made faint white plumes. It was almost warm inside; the Academy had large furnaces in the cellars and an extensive system of vents. The half-healed, never healing wounds in his side were hot.

hi kəd nɑt meɪk aʊt mɪnz kɝsɪz - hi wɑz ʃʊɹ ðeɪ wɝ kɝsɪz - bʌɾ əɹ toʊn wɑz ɪnʌf tə seɪ ðeɪ wəd nɑt bi livɪŋ jɛɾ ənlɛs i dʒɹæɡd əɹ əweɪ. ðəɹ wɝ wʌn əɹ tu aɪɾəmz i maɪɾ æsk əbaʊt stɪl. "wʌɾ ɑɹ pipəl seɪɪŋ? əbaʊt ðə pæləs?"

He could not make out Min's curses - he was sure they were curses - but her tone was enough to say they would not be leaving yet unless he dragged her away. There were one or two items he might ask about still. "What are people saying? About the Palace?"

"wʌt jə maɪɾ ɪkspɛkt," lɔɹd dɑbɹeɪn ænsɝd bɪhaɪn ɪm wɪð lɛvəl peɪʃəns, əz i hæɾ ænsɝɾ ɔl ði ʌðɝ kwɛstʃənz. ivən wən i ədmɪɾəd ə læk ə nɑlədʒ, hɪz toʊn hæd nɑt tʃeɪnʒd. "sʌm seɪ ðə fɔɹseɪkən ətæk ju, əɹ ðəɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ dɪd. ðoʊz u θɪŋk jə swɔɹ fiəlti tə ði æmɪɝlɪn sit feɪvɝ ðə fɔɹseɪkən. iðɝ weɪ, ðəɹ ɪz kənsɪɾɝəbəl dəbeɪɾ ɑn wɛðɝ jə ɑɹ dɛɾ əɹ kɪdnæpt əɹ flɛd. moʊs bɪliv jə laɪv, wɛɹɛvɝ jə ɑɹ, əɹ seɪ ðeɪ du. sʌm, ə ɡʊd mɛni aɪ fɪɹ, θɪŋk . . ." hɪz vɔɪs feɪɾəd tə saɪləns.

"What you might expect," Lord Dobraine answered behind him with level patience, as he had answered all the other questions. Even when he admitted a lack of knowledge, his tone had not changed. "Some say the Forsaken attacked you, or that Aes Sedai did. Those who think you swore fealty to the Amyrlin Seat favor the Forsaken. Either way, there is considerable debate on whether you are dead or kidnapped or fled. Most believe you live, wherever you are, or say they do. Some, a good many I fear, think . . ." His voice faded to silence.

"ðæɾ aɪv ɡɔn mæd," ɹænd fɪnɪʃt fəɹ ɪm ɪn ðə seɪm lɛvəl toʊn. nɑɾ ə mæɾɝ fəɹ kənsɝn, əɹ æŋɡɝ. "ðæɾ aɪ dɪstʃɹɔɪd pɑɹɾ ə ðə pæləs maɪsɛlf?" hi wəd nɑt spik ə ðə dɛd. fjuɝ ðən ʌðɝ taɪmz, ʌðɝ pleɪsəz, bʌɾ ɪnʌf, ən səm ə ðɛɹ neɪmz əpɪɹd wɛnɛvɝ i kloʊzd ɪz aɪz. wʌn ə ðə mɛn bɪloʊ klaɪm daʊn fɹəm ðə wæɡən, bʌt ðə bɔl fɛloʊ kɑɾ ɪz ɑɹm ən dʒɹæɡd ɪm bæk ʌp, meɪkɪŋ ɪm ʃoʊ wʌɾ i hæd dʌn. ə mæn ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪd dʒʌmp tə ðə peɪvmən kɛɹləsli, skɪɾɪŋ, ən ðə keɪpləs mæn əbændən ðə fɝs tə tʃeɪs ɝaʊn ðə wæɡən ən meɪk ðət wʌn klaɪm bæk ʌp wɪð hɪm. wʌɾ ɪn ðə laɪt kəd ðeɪ bi duɪŋ? ɹænd ɡlænst oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. "ðeɪɹ nɑt fɑɹ ɹɔŋ."

"That I've gone mad," Rand finished for him in the same level tone. Not a matter for concern, or anger. "That I destroyed part of the Palace myself?" He would not speak of the dead. Fewer than other times, other places, but enough, and some of their names appeared whenever he closed his eyes. One of the men below climbed down from the wagon, but the bald fellow caught his arm and dragged him back up, making him show what he had done. A man on the other side jumped to the pavement carelessly, skidding, and the capless man abandoned the first to chase around the wagon and make that one climb back up with him. What in the Light could they be doing? Rand glanced over his shoulder. "They're not far wrong."

dɑbɹeɪn tæbɔɹwɪn, ə ʃɔɹt mæn wɪð ðə fɹʌn ə hɪz hɛd ʃeɪvd ən fɔɹməli paʊɾɝd ən ðə ɹɛst ə hɪz hɛɹ nɪɹli ɔl ɡɹeɪ, lʊk bæk wɪð dɑɹk ɪmpæsɪv aɪz. nɑɾ ə hænsəm mæn, bʌt stɛɾi. blu-ænd-waɪt stʃɹaɪps mɑɹtʃt daʊn ðə fɹʌn ə hɪz dɑɹk vɛlvət koʊt fɹəm ɪz nɛk ɔlmoʊs tə hɪz niz. hɪz sɪɡnɪt ɹɪŋ wɑz ə kɑɹvd ɹubi, ən i wɔɹ ənʌðɝ əɾ ɪz kɑlɝ, nɑt mʌtʃ lɑɹdʒɝ jɛt flæmbɔɪən fəɹ ə kɛɹhinɪn. hi wɑz haɪ siɾ ə hɪz haʊs, wɪð mɔɹ bæɾəlz bɪhaɪn ɪm ðən moʊst, ən nɑt mʌtʃ fɹaɪɾənd hɪm. hi hæd pɹuv ðəɾ ət dəməaɪz wɛlz.

Dobraine Taborwin, a short man with the front of his head shaved and formally powdered and the rest of his hair nearly all gray, looked back with dark impassive eyes. Not a handsome man, but steady. Blue-and-white stripes marched down the front of his dark velvet coat from his neck almost to his knees. His signet ring was a carved ruby, and he wore another at his collar, not much larger yet flamboyant for a Cairhienin. He was High Seat of his House, with more battles behind him than most, and not much frightened him. He had proved that at Dumai's Wells.

bʌt ðɛn, ðə stɑki, ɡɹeɪɪŋ wʊmən peɪʃənli weɪɾɪŋ əɹ tɝn əɾ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ əpɪɹd dʒʌst əz ʌnəfɹeɪd. ɪn ʃɑɹp kɑntʃɹæs tə dɑbɹeɪnz noʊbəl ɛləɡəns, ɪdʒɹin tɑɹsənz sɛnsəbəl bɹaʊn wʊlənz wɝ pleɪn ɪnʌf fəɹ ə ʃɑpkipɝ, jɛt ʃi hæɾ əɹ oʊn wɛl ʌv əθɔɹəɾi ən dɪɡnəɾi. ɪdʒɹin wɑz hɛdmɪstʃɹəs ə ði əkæɾəmi, ðə taɪɾəl ʃi hæd ɡɪvən hɝsɛlf sɪns moʊst ə ðə skɑlɝz ən məkænɪks kɔl ðɛmsɛlvz mæstɝ ə ðɪs əɹ mɪstʃɹəs ə ðæt. ʃi ɹæn ðə skul wɪð ə stʃɹɔŋ hæn ən bɪlivd ɪn pɹæktəkəl θɪŋz, nu mɛθədz ə sɝfəsɪŋ ɹoʊdz əɹ meɪkɪŋ daɪz, ɪmpɹuvməns tə faʊnʒɹiz ən mɪlz. ʃi ɔlsoʊ bɪlivd ɪn ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. wɛðɝ əɹ nɑt ðət wɑz pɹæktəkəl, ɪt wɑz pɹæɡmæɾɪk, ən i wəd sɛɾəl fəɹ ðæt.

But then, the stocky, graying woman patiently waiting her turn at his shoulder appeared just as unafraid. In sharp contrast to Dobraine's noble elegance, Idrien Tarsin's sensible brown woolens were plain enough for a shopkeeper, yet she had her own well of authority and dignity. Idrien was Headmistress of the Academy, the title she had given herself since most of the scholars and mechanics called themselves master of this or mistress of that. She ran the school with a strong hand and believed in practical things, new methods of surfacing roads or making dyes, improvements to foundries and mills. She also believed in the Dragon Reborn. Whether or not that was practical, it was pragmatic, and he would settle for that.

hi tɝn bæk tə ðə wɪndoʊ ən klɪɹɾ ɪz pætʃ ɑn ðə ɡlæs əɡɛn. meɪbi ɪt wɑz fəɹ hiɾɪŋ wɔɾɝ - səm ə ðoʊz bʌkəts sim tə hæv wɔɾɝ ɪn əm stɪl; ɪn ʃaɪnɝ, ðeɪ juz bɪɡ bɔɪlɝz tə hit wɔɾɝ fəɹ ðə bæθs - bʌt waɪ ɑn ə wæɡən? "hæz ɛniwʌn lɛf sʌɾənli sɪns aɪ wɛnt? əɹ kʌm ʌnɪkspɛktɪdli?"

He turned back to the window and cleared his patch on the glass again. Maybe it was for heating water - some of those buckets seemed to have water in them still; in Shienar, they used big boilers to heat water for the baths - but why on a wagon? "Has anyone left suddenly since I went? Or come unexpectedly?"

hi dɪd nɑɾ ɪkspɛk ðəɾ ɛniwʌn hæd, ɛniwʌn ʌv ɪmpɔɹɾəns tə hɪm. bɪtwin mɝtʃəns' pɪdʒənz ən waɪt taʊɝ aɪz-ænd-ɪɹz - ən mæzɹim teɪm; hi mʌs nɑt fɝɡɛt teɪm; luz θɝɪn snɑɹəld wɝdləsli ət ðə neɪm - wɪð ɔl ðoʊz pɪdʒənz ən spaɪz ən bæbəlɪŋ tʌŋz, ɪn ə fju mɔɹ deɪz ðə hoʊl wɝld wəd bi əwɛɹ ðəɾ i hæd vænɪʃt fɹəm kɛɹhin. ɔl ðə wɝl ðət mæɾɝd, hɪɹ ən naʊ. kɛɹhin wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ðə ɡɹaʊnd wɛɹ ðə bæɾəl wəd bi fɔt. dɑbɹeɪnz ænsɝ sɝpɹaɪz hɪm.

He did not expect that anyone had, anyone of importance to him. Between merchants' pigeons and White Tower eyes-and-ears - and Mazrim Taim; he must not forget Taim; Lews Therin snarled wordlessly at the name - with all those pigeons and spies and babbling tongues, in a few more days the whole world would be aware that he had vanished from Cairhien. All the world that mattered, here and now. Cairhien was no longer the ground where the battle would be fought. Dobraine's answer surprised him.

"noʊ wʌn, ɪksɛpt . . . eɪlɪl ɹieɪɾən ən səm haɪ si foʊk əfɪʃəl ɑɹ boʊθ mɪsɪŋ sɪns ði . . . ətæk." ə bɛɹ pɔz, bʌɾ ə pɔz. pɝhæps i wɑz nɑt soʊ ʃʊɹ wʌt hæd hæpənd, iðɝ. jɛɾ i wəd kip ɪz wɝd. hi hæd pɹuv ðəɾ ət dəməaɪz wɛlz, tu. "noʊ bɑɾiz wɝ faʊnd, bʌt ðeɪ meɪ hæv bɪn kɪld. ðə si foʊk weɪvməstʃɹəs ɹəfjuzəz tə kaʊntənəns ðə pɑsəbɪləɾi, ðoʊ. ʃiz ɹeɪzɪŋ ə stɔɹm wɪð dɪmænz ðəɾ əɹ wʊmən bi pɹədust. ɪn tʃɹuθ, eɪlɪl meɪ hæv flɛd tə ðə kʌntʃɹisaɪd. əɹ ɡɔn tə dʒɔɪn əɹ bɹʌðɝ, dɪspaɪɾ əɹ plɛdʒɪz tə ju. jəɹ θɹi æʃəmən ɑɹ stɪl ɪn ðə sʌn pæləs. flɪn, nɛɹɪʃmə ən hɑpwəl. ðeɪ meɪk pipəl nɝvəs. mɔɹ soʊ naʊ ðən bɪfɔɹ." ðə hɛdmɪstʃɹəs meɪɾ ə saʊn ɪn əɹ θɹoʊt, ən əɹ ʃuz ʃɪftəɾ ɑɾəbli ɑn ðə flɔɹbɔɹdz. ðeɪ sɝɾənli meɪɾ əɹ nɝvəs.

"No one, except . . . Ailil Riatin and some high Sea Folk official are both missing since the . . . attack." A bare pause, but a pause. Perhaps he was not so sure what had happened, either. Yet he would keep his word. He had proved that at Dumai's Wells, too. "No bodies were found, but they may have been killed. The Sea Folk Wavemistress refuses to countenance the possibility, though. She is raising a storm with demands that her woman be produced. In truth, Ailil may have fled to the countryside. Or gone to join her brother, despite her pledges to you. Your three Asha'man are still in the Sun Palace. Flinn, Narishma and Hopwil. They make people nervous. More so now than before." The Headmistress made a sound in her throat, and her shoes shifted audibly on the floorboards. They certainly made her nervous.

ɹænd dɪsmɪs ði æʃəmən. ənlɛs mʌtʃ kloʊsɝ ðən ðə pæləs, nʌn wɑz stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf tə hæv fɛlt ɪm oʊpən ə ɡeɪtweɪ hɪɹ. ðoʊz θɹi hæd nɑt bɪn pɑɹɾ ə ði ətæk ɑn hɪm, bʌɾ ə waɪz plænɝ maɪɾ əv kənsɪɾɝd ðə tʃæns ə feɪljɝ. plæn haʊ tə kip sʌmwʌn kloʊs tə hɪm ɪf i sɝvaɪvd. jə woʊn sɝvaɪv, luz θɝɪn wɪspɝd. nʌn ʌv əs wɪl sɝvaɪv.

Rand dismissed the Asha'man. Unless much closer than the Palace, none was strong enough to have felt him open a gateway here. Those three had not been part of the attack on him, but a wise planner might have considered the chance of failure. Planned how to keep someone close to him if he survived. You won't survive, Lews Therin whispered. None of us will survive.

ɡoʊ bæk tə slip, ɹænd θɔɾ ɪɹɪɾəbli. hi nu hi wɑz nɑt ɡoʊɪŋ tə sɝvaɪv. bʌɾ i wɑntəd tə. ə dɝɪsɪv læf ænsɝɾ ɪn ɪz hɛd, bʌt ðə saʊn θɪn ən wɑz ɡɔn. ðə bɔl mæn wɑz lɛɾɪŋ ði ʌðɝz klaɪm daʊn, naʊ, ən ɹʌbɪŋ ɪz hænz təɡɛðɝ ɪn ə pliz fæʃən. ʌv ɔl θɪŋz, ðə fɛloʊ sim tə bi ɡɪvɪŋ ə spitʃ!

Go back to sleep, Rand thought irritably. He knew he was not going to survive. But he wanted to. A derisive laugh answered in his head, but the sound thinned and was gone. The bald man was letting the others climb down, now, and rubbing his hands together in a pleased fashion. Of all things, the fellow seemed to be giving a speech!

"eɪlɪl ən ʃələn ɑɹ əlaɪv, ən ðeɪ dɪdn fli," ɹænd sɛɾ əlaʊd. hi hæd lɛft əm baʊn ən ɡæɡd, stʌft ʌndɝ ə bɛd, wɛɹ ðeɪ wʊɾə bɪn faʊn baɪ sɝvəns ɪn ə fju aʊɝz, ðoʊ ðə ʃild i hæd woʊvən ɑn ðə si foʊk wɪndfɪndɝ wʊɾə dɪsəpeɪɾɪd bɪfɔɹ ðæt. ðə tu wɪmən ʃʊɾə bɪn eɪbəl tə fɹi ðɛmsɛlvz ðɛn. "lʊk tə kædzueɪn. ʃɪl əv əm ɪn leɪɾi ɑɹɪlɪnz pæləs."

"Ailil and Shalon are alive, and they didn't flee," Rand said aloud. He had left them bound and gagged, stuffed under a bed, where they would have been found by servants in a few hours, though the shield he had woven on the Sea Folk Windfinder would have dissipated before that. The two women should have been able to free themselves then. "Look to Cadsuane. She'll have them in Lady Arilyn's palace."

"kædzueɪn sədaɪ ɪz ɪn ən aʊɾ ə ðə sʌn pæləs əz ɪf ɪt wɝ əɹ oʊn," dɑbɹeɪn sɛd dʒudɪʃɪsli, "bʌt haʊ kəd ʃi hæv teɪkən əm aʊɾ ənsin? ən waɪ? eɪlɪl ɪz tɔɹæmz sɪstɝ, jɛɾ ɪz kleɪm tə ðə sʌn θɹoʊn ɪz dʌs naʊ, ɪf ɪt wɑz ɛvɝ mɔɹ. ʃiz ənɪmpɔɹɾənt ivən əz ə kaʊntɝ, naʊ. əz fəɹ hoʊldɪŋ ən æθɑn maɪɹ ə haɪ ɹæŋk . . . tə wʌt pɝpəs?"

"Cadsuane Sedai is in and out of the Sun Palace as if it were her own," Dobraine said judiciously, "but how could she have taken them out unseen? And why? Ailil is Toram's sister, yet his claim to the Sun Throne is dust now, if it was ever more. She is unimportant even as a counter, now. As for holding an Atha'an Miere of high rank . . . To what purpose?"

ɹænd meɪɾ ɪz vɔɪs laɪt, ənkɛɹɪŋ. "waɪ ɪz ʃi kipɪŋ leɪɾi kæɹɑlin ən haɪ lɔɹd dɑɹlɪn əz 'ɡɛsts,' dɑbɹeɪn? waɪ də ɛɛs sədaɪ də ɛniθɪŋ? jəl faɪn əm wɛɹ aɪ sɛd. ɪf ʃi lɛts jə ɪn tə lʊk." waɪ wɑz nɑɾ ə fulɪʃ kwɛstʃən. hi dʒʌs dɪd nɑɾ əv ði ænsɝ. ʌv kɔɹs, kæɹɑlin dəmədʒɹɾ ən eɪlɪl ɹieɪɾən dɪd ɹɛpɹəzɛn ðə læs tu haʊsəz tə hoʊl ðə sʌn θɹoʊn. ən dɑɹlɪn sɪsnɛɹə lɛd ðə noʊbəlz ɪn tiɹ u wɑntəɾ ɪm θɹoʊn aʊɾ ə ðɛɹ pɹɛʃəs stoʊn, aʊɾ ə tiɹ.

Rand made his voice light, uncaring. "Why is she keeping Lady Caraline and High Lord Darlin as 'guests,' Dobraine? Why do Aes Sedai do anything? You'll find them where I said. If she lets you in to look." Why was not a foolish question. He just did not have the answer. Of course, Caraline Damodred and Ailil Riatin did represent the last two Houses to hold the Sun Throne. And Darlin Sisnera led the nobles in Tear who wanted him thrown out of their precious Stone, out of Tear.

ɹænd fɹaʊnd. hi hæd bɪn ʃʊɹ kædzueɪn wɑz foʊkəst ɑn ɪm dɪspaɪɾ əɹ pɹitɛns ʌðɝwaɪz, bʌt wʌɾ ɪf ɪt wɑz nɑt pɹitɛns? ə ɹɪlif, ɪf soʊ. ʌv kɔɹs ɪt wɑz. ðə læs θɪŋ i niɾəd wɑz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ hu θɔt ʃi kəd mɛɾəl ɪn ɪz əfɛɹz. ðə vɛɹi læst. pɝhæps kædzueɪn wɑz dɝɛktɪŋ əɹ mɛɾəlɪŋ ɛlswɛɹ. mɪn hæd sin sɪsnɛɹə wɛɹɪŋ ə stʃɹeɪnʒ kɹaʊn; ɹænd hæd θɔɾ ə ɡɹeɪt dil ɑn ðət vjuɪŋ ə hɝz. hi dɪd nɑt wɑnə θɪŋk ʌv ʌðɝ θɪŋz ʃi hæd sin, kənsɝnɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ən ðə ɡɹin sɪstɝ. kəɾ ɪt bi əz sɪmpəl əz kædzueɪn θɪŋkɪŋ ʃi kəd dɪsaɪɾ u wəd ɹul boʊθ tiɹ ən kɛɹhin?

Rand frowned. He had been sure Cadsuane was focused on him despite her pretense otherwise, but what if it was not pretense? A relief, if so. Of course it was. The last thing he needed was an Aes Sedai who thought she could meddle in his affairs. The very last. Perhaps Cadsuane was directing her meddling elsewhere. Min had seen Sisnera wearing a strange crown; Rand had thought a great deal on that viewing of hers. He did not want to think of other things she had seen, concerning himself and the Green sister. Could it be as simple as Cadsuane thinking she could decide who would rule both Tear and Cairhien?

sɪmpəl? hi ɔlmoʊs læft. bʌt ðət wɑz haʊ ɛɛs sədaɪ bɪheɪvd. ən ʃələn, ðə wɪndfɪndɝ? pəzɛsɪŋ əɹ maɪt ɡɪv kædzueɪn lɛvɝɪdʒ wɪð hɑɹɪn, ðə weɪvməstʃɹəs, bʌɾ i səspɛktəd ʃi hæd dʒʌs bɪn skupt ʌp wɪð eɪlɪl, tə tʃɹaɪ haɪɾɪŋ u tʊk ðə noʊbəlwʊmən. kædzueɪn wəɾ əv tə bi dɪsɑbjuzd. hu wəd ɹul ɪn tiɹ ən kɛɹhin hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi bɪn dɪsaɪɾɪd. hi wəd pɔɪn ðəɾ aʊt tə hɝ. leɪɾɝ. ɪt stʊd fɑɹ daʊn ɪz lɪst ə pɹaɪɔɹəɾiz.

Simple? He almost laughed. But that was how Aes Sedai behaved. And Shalon, the Windfinder? Possessing her might give Cadsuane leverage with Harine, the Wavemistress, but he suspected she had just been scooped up with Ailil, to try hiding who took the noblewoman. Cadsuane would have to be disabused. Who would rule in Tear and Cairhien had already been decided. He would point that out to her. Later. It stood far down his list of priorities.

"bɪfɔɹ aɪ ɡoʊ, dɑbɹeɪn, aɪ nid tə ɡɪv jə - " wɝdz fɹoʊz ɑn ɪz tʌŋ.

"Before I go, Dobraine, I need to give you - " Words froze on his tongue.

ɪn ðə steɪbliɑɹd, ðə keɪpləs mæn hæd pʊld ə lɛvəl ɑn ðə wæɡən, ən wʌn ɛn ʌv ə lɔŋ hɔɹəzɑntəl bim sʌɾənli ɹoʊz, ðən sæŋk, dʒɹaɪvɪŋ ə ʃɔɹɾɝ bim daʊn θɹu ə hoʊl kʌɾ ɪn ðə wæɡən bɛd. ænd, vaɪbɹeɪɾɪŋ tɪl ɪt simd ɹɛɾi tə ʃeɪk əpɑɹt, tʃɹeɪlɪŋ smoʊk fɹəm ðə tʃɪmni, ðə wæɡən lɝtʃt əhɛd, ðə bim ɹaɪzɪŋ ən fɔlɪŋ, sloʊli ət fɝst, ðən fæstɝ. ɪt muvd, wɪθaʊt hɔɹsəz!

In the stableyard, the capless man had pulled a level on the wagon, and one end of a long horizontal beam suddenly rose, then sank, driving a shorter beam down through a hole cut in the wagon bed. And, vibrating till it seemed ready to shake apart, trailing smoke from the chimney, the wagon lurched ahead, the beam rising and falling, slowly at first, then faster. It moved, without horses!

hi dɪd nɑt ɹilaɪz i hæd spoʊkən əlaʊɾ əntɪl ðə hɛdmɪstʃɹəs ænsɝd hɪm.

He did not realize he had spoken aloud until the Headmistress answered him.

"oʊ, ðæt! ðæts mɝvɪn poʊəlz stimwæɡən, əz i kɔlz ɪt, maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən." dɪsəpɹuvəl fɹeɪɾɪd əɹ haɪ, stɑɹtlɪŋli juθfəl vɔɪs. "kleɪmz i kən pʊl ə hʌnʒɹəd wæɡənz wɪð ðə kəntʃɹæpʃən. nɑɾ ənlɛs i kən meɪk ɪt ɡoʊ fɝðɝ ðən fɪfti peɪsɪz wɪθaʊt bɪts bɹeɪkɪŋ əɹ fɹizɪŋ ʌp. ɪts oʊnli dʌn ðət fɑɹ wʌns, ðəɾ aɪ noʊ."

"Oh, that! That's Mervin Poel's steamwagon, as he calls it, my Lord Dragon." Disapproval freighted her high, startlingly youthful voice. "Claims he can pull a hundred wagons with the contraption. Not unless he can make it go further than fifty paces without bits breaking or freezing up. It has only done that far once, that I know."

ɪndid, ðə - stimwæɡən? - ʃʌɾɝəd tə ə hɔl nɑt twɛnti peɪsɪz fɹəm wɛɹ ɪt fɝst stʊd. ʃʌɾɝəd ɪndid; ɪt sim tə bi ʃeɪkɪŋ hɑɹɾɝ baɪ ðə hɑɹtbit. moʊst ə ðə mɛn swɔɹmd oʊvɝ ɪɾ əɡɛn, wʌn ə ðɛm fɹæntəkəli twɪstɪŋ ət sʌmθɪŋ wɪð ə klɔθ ɹæpt ɝaʊn ɪz hænd. əbɹʌpli stim ʃɑɾ ɪndə ði ɛɹ fɹəm ə paɪp, ən ðə ʃʌɾɝɪŋ sloʊd, stɑpt.

Indeed, the - steamwagon? - shuddered to a halt not twenty paces from where it first stood. Shuddered indeed; it seemed to be shaking harder by the heartbeat. Most of the men swarmed over it again, one of them frantically twisting at something with a cloth wrapped around his hand. Abruptly steam shot into the air from a pipe, and the shuddering slowed, stopped.

ɹænd ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. hi ɹɪmɛmbɝd siɪŋ ðɪs fɛloʊ mɝvɪn, wɪð ə dɪvaɪs ðət kwɪvɝɾ ɑn ə teɪbəltɑp ən dɪd nʌθɪŋ. ən ðɪs mɑɹvəl hæd kʌm fɹəm ðæt? hi hæd θɔɾ ɪt wɑz mɛn tə meɪk mjuzɪk. ðət mʌs bi mɝvɪn lipɪŋ əbaʊɾ ən ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz fɪsts ət ði ʌðɝz. wʌɾ ʌðɝ ɑd θɪŋz, wʌt mɑɹvəlz, wɝ pipəl bɪldɪŋ hɪɹ ət ði əkæɾəmi?

Rand shook his head. He remembered seeing this fellow Mervin, with a device that quivered on a tabletop and did nothing. And this marvel had come from that? He had thought it was meant to make music. That must be Mervin leaping about and shaking his fists at the others. What other odd things, what marvels, were people building here at the Academy?

wən i æskt, stɪl wɑtʃɪŋ ðə mɛn ɪn ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹd wɝk ɑn ðə wæɡən, ɪdʒɹin snɪf laʊdli. ɹɪspɛk fəɹ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn hɛld oʊnli ə θɪn ɛdʒ ɪn əɹ vɔɪs əz ʃi bɪɡæn, ən kwɪkli lɔst ɡɹaʊn tə dɪsɡʌst. "bæɾ ɪnʌf aɪ mʌst ɡɪv speɪs tə fəlɑsəfɝz ən hɪstɔɹiənz ən æɹɪðmtɪsts ən ðə laɪk, bʌt jə sɛd teɪk ɪn ɛniwʌn u wɑntəd tə meɪk ɛniθɪŋ nu ən lɛɾ əm steɪ ɪf ðeɪ ʃoʊd pɹɑɡɹɛs. aɪ səpoʊz jə hoʊp fəɹ wɛpənz, bʌt naʊ aɪ hæv dʌzənz ə dʒɹimɝz ən weɪstʃɹəlz ɑn maɪ hænz, ɛvɹi wʌn wɪð ən oʊl bʊk əɹ mænjəskɹɪpt əɹ sɪks, ɔl ʌv wɪtʃ deɪt bæk tə ðə kɑmpækt ə ðə tɛn neɪʃənz, maɪnd, ɪf nɑt ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz ɪtsɛlf, əɹ soʊ ðeɪ seɪ, ən ðeɪ ɑɹ ɔl tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə meɪk sɛns ə dʒɹɔɪŋz ən skɛtʃəz ən dɪskɹɪpʃənz ə θɪŋz ðeɪv nɛvɝ sin ən meɪbi noʊbɑdi ɛvɝ dɪd si. aɪ hæv sin oʊl mænjəskɹɪps ðət tɔk əbaʊt pipəl wɪð ðɛɹ aɪz ɪn ðɛɹ bɛliz, ən ænəməlz tɛn fit tɔl wɪð tʌsks lɔŋɡɝ ðən ə mæn, ən sɪɾiz wɛɹ - "

When he asked, still watching the men in the courtyard work on the wagon, Idrien sniffed loudly. Respect for the Dragon Reborn held only a thin edge in her voice as she began, and quickly lost ground to disgust. "Bad enough I must give space to philosophers and historians and arithmetists and the like, but you said take in anyone who wanted to make anything new and let them stay if they showed progress. I suppose you hoped for weapons, but now I have dozens of dreamers and wastrels on my hands, every one with an old book or manuscript or six, all of which date back to the Compact of the Ten Nations, mind, if not the Age of Legends itself, or so they say, and they are all trying to make sense of drawings and sketches and descriptions of things they've never seen and maybe nobody ever did see. I have seen old manuscripts that talk about people with their eyes in their bellies, and animals ten feet tall with tusks longer than a man, and cities where - "

"bʌt wʌɾ ɑɹ ðeɪ meɪkɪŋ, hɛdmɪstʃɹəs tɑɹsən?" ɹænd dɪmændəd. ðə mɛn wɝkɪŋ ɑn ðə θɪŋ bɪloʊ muvd wɪð ən ɛɹ ə pɝpəs, nɑɾ əz ɪf ðeɪ sɔ feɪljɝ. ən ɪt hæd muvd.

"But what are they making, Headmistress Tarsin?" Rand demanded. The men working on the thing below moved with an air of purpose, not as if they saw failure. And it had moved.

ʃi snɪf laʊɾɝ ðɪs taɪm. "fulɪʃnəs, maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən, ðəɾ ɪz wʌt ðeɪ meɪk. kɪn tʌvɪɹ kənstʃɹʌktəɾ ɪz bɪɡ lʊkɪŋ ɡlæs. jə kən si ðə mun θɹu ɪt pleɪn əz jəɹ hænd, ən wʌɾ i kleɪmz ɑɹ ʌðɝ wɝlz, bʌt wʌɾ ɪz ðə ɡʊɾ ə ðæt? hi wɑns tə bɪld ə bɪɡɝ, naʊ. mæɹəl hɑɹk meɪks hjudʒ kaɪts ʃi kɔlz ɡlaɪɾɝz, ən kʌm spɹɪŋ, ʃɪl bi θɹoʊɪŋ hɝsɛlf ɔf hɪlz əɡɛn. pʊts jəɹ hɑɹɾ ɪn jəɹ maʊθ tə si hɝ seɪlɪŋ daʊnhɪl ɑn ðə θɪŋz; ʃɪl bɹeɪk mɔɹ ðən əɹ ɑɹm nɛks taɪm wʌn foʊlz ʌp ɑn hɝ, aɪ wɔɹənt. dʒændɝ pɛɹɛntɑkɪs bɪlivz i kən muv ɹɪvɝboʊts wɪð wɔtɝwilz ɔf ə mɪl, əɹ nɪɹ ɪnʌf, bʌt wən i pʊɾ ɪnʌf mɛn ɪndə ðə boʊt tə tɝn ðə kɹæŋks, ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɹum fəɹ kɑɹɡoʊ, ən ɛni kɹæft wɪð seɪlz kəɾ aʊtʃɹʌn ɪt. ɹɪn ænhɑɹə tʃɹæps laɪtnɪŋ ɪn bɪɡ dʒɑɹz - aɪ daʊɾ ivən i noʊz waɪ - ən nikoʊ təkɑmə ɪz dʒʌst əz sɪli wɪð əɹ - "

She sniffed louder this time. "Foolishness, my Lord Dragon, that is what they make. Kin Tovere constructed his big looking glass. You can see the moon through it plain as your hand, and what he claims are other worlds, but what is the good of that? He wants to build a bigger, now. Maryl Harke makes huge kites she calls gliders, and come spring, she will be throwing herself off hills again. Puts your heart in your mouth to see her sailing downhill on the things; she will break more than her arm next time one folds up on her, I warrant. Jander Parentakis believes he can move riverboats with waterwheels off a mill, or near enough, but when he put enough men into the boat to turn the cranks, there was no room for cargo, and any craft with sails could outrun it. Ryn Anhara traps lightning in big jars - I doubt even he knows why - and Niko Tokama is just as silly with her - "

ɹænd spʌn ɝaʊn soʊ fæs ðət ʃi stɛp bæk, ən ivən dɑbɹeɪn ʃɪftəɾ ɑn ɪz fit, ə sɔɝdzmənz muv. noʊ, ðeɪ wɝ nɑt ʃʊɹ ə hɪm əɾ ɔl. "hi tʃɹæps laɪtnɪŋ?" hi æskt kwaɪətli.

Rand spun around so fast that she stepped back, and even Dobraine shifted on his feet, a swordsman's move. No, they were not sure of him at all. "He traps lightning?" he asked quietly.

kɑmpɹihɛnʃən flʌɾəd əɹ blʌn feɪs, ən ʃi weɪvd əɹ hænz ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ. "noʊ, noʊ! nɑt laɪk . . . laɪk ðæt!" nɑt laɪk ju, ʃi hæɾ ɔlmoʊst sɛd. "ɪɾ ɪz ə θɪŋ ʌv waɪɝz ən wilz ən bɪɡ kleɪ dʒɑɹz ən ðə laɪt noʊz wʌt. hi kɔlz ɪt laɪtnɪŋ, ən aɪ sɔ ə ɹæt dʒʌmp daʊn ɑn wʌn ə ðə dʒɑɹz wʌns, ɑn ðə mɛɾəl ɹɑdz stɪkɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə tɑp. ɪt sɝɾənli lʊk stʃɹʌk baɪ laɪtnɪŋ." ə hoʊpfəl toʊn ɛntɝɾ əɹ vɔɪs. "aɪ kən meɪk ɪm stɑp, ɪf jə wɪʃ."

Comprehension flooded her blunt face, and she waved her hands in front of her. "No, no! Not like . . . like that!" Not like you, she had almost said. "It is a thing of wires and wheels and big clay jars and the Light knows what. He calls it lightning, and I saw a rat jump down on one of the jars once, on the metal rods sticking out of the top. It certainly looked struck by lightning." A hopeful tone entered her voice. "I can make him stop, if you wish."

hi tʃɹaɪd tə pɪktʃɝ sʌmwʌn ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɑn ə kaɪt, bʌt ði ɪmədʒ wɑz luɾəkɹəs. kætʃɪŋ laɪtnɪŋ ɪn dʒɑɹz wɑz bɪɑn ɪz əbɪləɾi tə ɪmædʒən. ən jɛt . . . "lɛɾ əm ɡoʊ ɑn əz bɪfɔɹ, hɛdmɪstʃɹəs. hu noʊz? meɪbi wʌn ə ðiz ɪnvɛnʃənz wɪl tɝn aʊt tə bi ɪmpɔɹɾənt. ɪf ɛni wɝk əz kleɪmd, ɡɪv ði ɪnvɛntɝ ə ɹɪwɔɹd."

He tried to picture someone riding on a kite, but the image was ludicrous. Catching lightning in jars was beyond his ability to imagine. And yet . . . "Let them go on as before, Headmistress. Who knows? Maybe one of these inventions will turn out to be important. If any work as claimed, give the inventor a reward."

dɑbɹeɪnz lɛðɝi, sʌn-dɑɹkən feɪs lʊk dubiəs, ðoʊ hi ɔlmoʊs mænədʒ tə kənsil ɪt. ɪdʒɹin baʊɾ əɹ hɛɾ ɪn sʌlən əsɛnt, ən ivən kɝtsid, bʌt pleɪnli ʃi θɔɾ i wɑz æskɪŋ tə lɛt pɪɡz flaɪ ɪf ðeɪ kʊd.

Dobraine's leathery, sun-darkened face looked dubious, though he almost managed to conceal it. Idrien bowed her head in sullen assent, and even curtsied, but plainly she thought he was asking to let pigs fly if they could.

ɹænd wɑz nɑt sɝɾən i dɪsəɡɹid. ðən əɡɛn, meɪbi wʌn ə ðə pɪɡz wəd ɡɹoʊ wɪŋz. ðə wæɡən hæd muvd. hi wɑntəd vɛɹi bædli tə liv sʌmθɪŋ bɪhaɪnd, sʌmθɪŋ tə hɛlp ðə wɝl sɝvaɪv ðə nu bɹeɪkɪŋ ðə pɹɑfəsiz sɛɾ i wəd bɹɪŋ. ðə tʃɹʌbəl wɑz, hi hæd noʊ aɪdiə wʌt ðət maɪt bi, seɪv fəɹ ðə skulz ðɛmsɛlvz. hu nu wʌɾ ə mɑɹvəl kəd du? laɪt, hi wɑntəd tə bɪl sʌmθɪŋ ðət kəd læst.

Rand was not certain he disagreed. Then again, maybe one of the pigs would grow wings. The wagon had moved. He wanted very badly to leave something behind, something to help the world survive the new Breaking the Prophecies said he would bring. The trouble was, he had no idea what that might be, save for the schools themselves. Who knew what a marvel could do? Light, he wanted to build something that could last.

aɪ θɔɾ aɪ kəd bɪld, luz θɝɪn mɝmɝɾ ɪn ɪz hɛd. aɪ wɑz ɹɔŋ. wəɹ nɑt bɪldɝz, nɑt ju, əɹ aɪ, əɹ ði ʌðɝ wʌn. wəɹ dɪstʃɹɔɪɝz. dɪstʃɹɔɪɝz.

I thought I could build, Lews Therin murmured in his head. I was wrong. We are not builders, not you, or I, or the other one. We are destroyers. Destroyers.

ɹænd ʃɪvɝd, ən skɹʌbd ɪz hænz θɹu hɪz hɛɹ. ði ʌðɝ wʌn? ət taɪmz, ðə vɔɪs saʊndəd seɪnəst wən ɪt wɑz ðə moʊs mæd. ðeɪ wɝ wɑtʃɪŋ hɪm, dɑbɹeɪn vɛɹi nɪɹli haɪɾɪŋ ənsɝɾənti, ɪdʒɹin meɪkɪŋ noʊ ɛfɝt tə. stʃɹeɪɾənɪŋ əz ɪf nʌθɪŋ wɑz ɹɔŋ, hi dʒɹu tu slɪm pækɪts fɹəm ɪnsaɪɾ ɪz koʊt. boʊθ kæɹid ðə dʒɹæɡən ɪn ə lɔŋ lʌmp ə ɹɛd wæks ɑn ði aʊtsaɪd. ðə bɛl bʌkəl i wɑz nɑt wɛɹɪŋ ət ðə moʊmən sɝv fəɹ ən ɪmpɹɛsɪv sɪɡnɪt.

Rand shivered, and scrubbed his hands through his hair. The other one? At times, the voice sounded sanest when it was the most mad. They were watching him, Dobraine very nearly hiding uncertainty, Idrien making no effort to. Straightening as if nothing was wrong, he drew two slim packets from inside his coat. Both carried the Dragon in a long lump of red wax on the outside. The belt buckle he was not wearing at the moment served for an impressive signet.

"ðə tɑp wʌn neɪmz jə maɪ stuɝɾ ɪn kɛɹhin," hi sɛd, hændɪŋ ðə pækɪts tə dɑbɹeɪn. ə θɝd stɪl nɛsəl nɛks tə hɪz tʃɛst, fəɹ ɡɹɛɡɹɪn dɛn lʌʃɪnoʊz, meɪkɪŋ ɪm stuɝɾ ɪn ɪljən. "soʊ ðɛɹəl bi noʊ tʃɹʌbəl wɪð ɛniwʌn kwɛstʃənɪŋ jəɹ əθɔɹəɾi waɪl aɪm ɡɔn." dɑbɹeɪn kəd hændəl ðət sɔɹɾ ə tʃɹʌbəl wɪð ɪz ɑɹmmɪn, bʌt bɛs tə meɪk ʃʊɹ noʊ wʌn kəd kleɪm ɪɡnɝəns əɹ daʊt. meɪbi ðəɹ wəd bi noʊ tʃɹʌbəl tə hændəl ɪf ɛvɹiwʌn bɪliv ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn wəd dɪsɛn ɑn tʃɹænzɡɹɛsɝz. "ðɛɹ ɑɹ ɔɹɾɝz əbaʊt θɪŋz aɪ wɑn dʌn, bʌɾ əsaɪd fɹəm ðoʊz, jus jəɹ oʊn dʒʌdʒmənt. wən ðə leɪɾi ɪleɪn leɪz kleɪm tə ðə sʌn θɹoʊn, θɹoʊ jəɹ fʊl səpɔɹt bɪhaɪn hɝ." ɪleɪn. oʊ, laɪt, ɪleɪn, ən eɪvinhə. ət lis ðeɪ wɝ seɪf. mɪnz vɔɪs saʊndəd hæpiɝ, naʊ; ʃi mʌst əv faʊn mæstɝ fɛlz bʊks. hi wɑz gɑnə lɛɾ əɹ fɑloʊ hɪm tə hɝ dɛθ kəz i wɑz nɑt stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf tə stɑp hɝ. aɪlaɪɛnə, luz θɝɪn moʊnd. fɝɡɪv mi, aɪlaɪɛnə! ɹændz vɔɪs keɪm aʊɾ əz koʊld əz wɪntɝz hɑɹt. "jul noʊ wən tə dɪlɪvɝ ði ʌðɝ. wɛðɝ tə dɪlɪvɝ ɪt. pɹaɪ hɪm aʊɾ ɪf nid bi, ən dɪsaɪd baɪ wʌɾ i sɛz. ɪf jə dɪsaɪd noʊ, əɹ i ɹəfjuzəz, əl pɪk sʌmwʌn ɛls. nɑt ju."

"The top one names you my steward in Cairhien," he said, handing the packets to Dobraine. A third still nestled next to his chest, for Gregorin den Lushenos, making him steward in Illian. "So there'll be no trouble with anyone questioning your authority while I'm gone." Dobraine could handle that sort of trouble with his armsmen, but best to make sure no one could claim ignorance or doubt. Maybe there would be no trouble to handle if everyone believed the Dragon Reborn would descend on transgressors. "There are orders about things I want done, but aside from those, use your own judgment. When the Lady Elayne lays claim to the Sun Throne, throw your full support behind her." Elayne. Oh, Light, Elayne, and Aviendha. At least they were safe. Min's voice sounded happier, now; she must have found Master Fel's books. He was going to let her follow him to her death because he was not strong enough to stop her. Ilyena, Lews Therin moaned. Forgive me, Ilyena! Rand's voice came out as cold as winter's heart. "You'll know when to deliver the other. Whether to deliver it. Pry him out if need be, and decide by what he says. If you decide no, or he refuses, I'll pick someone else. Not you."

pɝhæps ðət wɑz bɹʌsk, bʌt dɑbɹeɪnz ɪkspɹɛʃən hɑɹdli tʃeɪnʒd. hɪz aɪbɹaʊz ɹoʊz slaɪtli ət ðə neɪm ɹɪɾən ɑn ðə sɛkən pækət; ðət wɑz ɔl. hi meɪɾ ə smuð baʊ. kɛɹhinɪn juʒəwəli wɝ smuð. "ɪt ʃæl bi əz jə seɪ. fɝɡɪv mi, bʌt jə saʊn əz ðoʊ jə min tə bi ɡɔn ə lɔŋ waɪl."

Perhaps that was brusque, but Dobraine's expression hardly changed. His eyebrows rose slightly at the name written on the second packet; that was all. He made a smooth bow. Cairhienin usually were smooth. "It shall be as you say. Forgive me, but you sound as though you mean to be gone a long while."

ɹænd ʃɹʌɡd. hi tʃɹʌstɪd ðə haɪ lɔɹɾ əz fɑɹ əz i tʃɹʌstɪɾ ɛniwʌn. ɔlmoʊst əz fɑɹ. "hu kən seɪ? ðə taɪmz ɑɹ ənsɝɾən. meɪk ʃʊɹ hɛdmɪstʃɹəs tɑɹsən əz wʌtɛvɝ kɔɪn ʃi nidz, ən ðə mɛn stɑɹɾɪŋ ðə skul ɪn keɪɛmlɪn. ðə skul ɪn tiɹ, əz wɛl, əntɪl mæɾɝz tʃeɪnʒ ðɛɹ."

Rand shrugged. He trusted the High Lord as far as he trusted anyone. Almost as far. "Who can say? The times are uncertain. Make sure Headmistress Tarsin has whatever coin she needs, and the men starting the school in Caemlyn. The school in Tear, as well, until matters change there."

"æz jə seɪ," dɑbɹeɪn ɹɪpiɾɪd, tʌkɪŋ ðə pækɪts ɪndə hɪz koʊt. hɪz feɪs bɪtʃɹeɪd noʊ ɪmoʊʃən, naʊ. ən ɪkspɪɹiəns pleɪɝ ɪn ðə ɡeɪm ə haʊsəz, wɑz dɑbɹeɪn.

"As you say," Dobraine repeated, tucking the packets into his coat. His face betrayed no emotion, now. An experienced player in the Game of Houses, was Dobraine.

fəɹ əɹ pɑɹt, ðə hɛdmɪstʃɹəs mænədʒ tə lʊk plizd ən dɪsɡɹʌntəld ət ðə seɪm taɪm, ən bɪzid hɝsɛlf smuðɪŋ əɹ dʒɹɛs ənnɛsəsɛɹəli ðə weɪ wɪmən dɪd wən hɑɹd-pɹɛs nɑt tə spik ðɛɹ maɪnz. kəmpleɪn haʊ ʃi wəɾ əbaʊt dʒɹimɝz ən fəlɑsəfɝz, ʃi wɑz dʒɛləs ə ði əkæɾəmiz wɛl-biɪŋ. ʃi wəd ʃɛd noʊ tɪɹz ɪf ðoʊz ʌðɝ skulz vænɪʃt ən ðɛɹ skɑlɝz wɝ fɔɹs tə kʌm tə ði əkæɾəmi. ivən ðə fəlɑsəfɝz. wʌt wəd ʃi θɪŋk ʌv wʌn pɝtɪkjəlɝ ɔɹɾɝ ɪn dɑbɹeɪnz pækət?

For her part, the Headmistress managed to look pleased and disgruntled at the same time, and busied herself smoothing her dress unnecessarily the way women did when hard-pressed not to speak their minds. Complain how she would about dreamers and philosophers, she was jealous of the Academy's well-being. She would shed no tears if those other schools vanished and their scholars were forced to come to the Academy. Even the philosophers. What would she think of one particular order in Dobraine's packet?

"aɪv faʊn ɛvɹiθɪŋ aɪ nid," mɪn sɛd, kʌmɪŋ aʊt fɹəm ðə ʃɛlvz stæɡɝɪŋ slaɪtli ʌndɝ ðə weɪɾ ə ðə θɹi bʌlʒɪŋ klɔθ skɹəps ðət hʌŋ fɹəm hɝ. hɝ pleɪn bɹaʊn koʊɾ ən bɹitʃɪz wɝ vɛɹi laɪk wʌt ʃi hæd wɔɹn wən i fɝst sɔ hɝ ɪn bɛɹlən. fəɹ səm ɹizən, ʃi hæd ɡɹʌmbəld oʊvɝ əm əntɪl ɛniwʌn u nu hɝ wʊɾə θɔɾ i wɑz æskɪŋ əɹ tə pʊɾ ɑn ə dʒɹɛs. ʃi smaɪl naʊ, ðoʊ, wɪð dɪlaɪɾ ən ə hɪn ə mɪstʃəf. "aɪ hoʊp ðoʊz pækhɔɹsɪz ɑɹ wɛɹ wi lɛf ðɛm, əɹ maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən wɪl əv tə bi fɪɾəd fəɹ ə pæksæɾəl."

"I've found everything I need," Min said, coming out from the shelves staggering slightly under the weight of the three bulging cloth scrips that hung from her. Her plain brown coat and breeches were very like what she had worn when he first saw her in Baerlon. For some reason, she had grumbled over them until anyone who knew her would have thought he was asking her to put on a dress. She smiled now, though, with delight and a hint of mischief. "I hope those packhorses are where we left them, or my Lord Dragon will have to be fitted for a packsaddle."

ɪdʒɹin ɡæspt, skændəlaɪz tə hɪɹ ɪm ədʒɹɛst soʊ, bʌt dɑbɹeɪn mɪɹli smaɪld ə lɪɾəl. hi hæd sin mɪn ɝaʊn ɹænd bɪfɔɹ.

Idrien gasped, scandalized to hear him addressed so, but Dobraine merely smiled a little. He had seen Min around Rand before.

ɹænd ɡɑt ɹɪɾ ə ðɛm əz kwɪkli əz pɑsəbəl ðɛn, sɪns ðeɪ hæd hɝɾ ən sin əz mʌtʃ əz i wɑntəɾ əm tə - sɛn əm ɔf wɪð ə faɪnəl ædmənɪʃən ðəɾ i hæd nɛvɝ bɪn ðəɹ əɾ ɔl. dɑbɹeɪn nɑɾəd əz ɪf i hæɾ ɪkspɛktəd noʊ lɛs. ɪdʒɹin lʊk θɔtfəl əz ʃi lɛft. ɪf ʃi lɛɾ ɛniθɪŋ slɪp wɛɹ ə sɝvən kəd hɪɹ, əɹ ə skɑlɝ, ɪt wəd bi ɔl oʊvɝ ðə sɪɾi ɪn tu deɪz. ðəɹ wɑz nɑt mʌtʃ taɪm ɪn ɛni keɪs. pɝhæps noʊ wʌn u kəd tɛl hæd bɪn kloʊs ɪnʌf tə fil ɪm oʊpən ə ɡeɪtweɪ hɪɹ, bʌɾ ɛniwʌn lʊkɪŋ fəɹ ðə saɪnz wəd bi ʃʊɹ baɪ naʊ ðəɹ wɑz ə tɑvɝən ɪn ðə sɪɾi. ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ɪz plæn tə bi faʊn jɛt.

Rand got rid of them as quickly as possible then, since they had heard and seen as much as he wanted them to - sent them off with a final admonition that he had never been there at all. Dobraine nodded as if he had expected no less. Idrien looked thoughtful as she left. If she let anything slip where a servant could hear, or a scholar, it would be all over the City in two days. There was not much time in any case. Perhaps no one who could tell had been close enough to feel him open a gateway here, but anyone looking for the signs would be sure by now there was a ta'veren in the city. It was not his plan to be found yet.

wən ðə dɔɹ kloʊz bɪhaɪn ðɛm, hi stʌɾid mɪn fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ðən tʊk wʌn ə ðə skɹəps ən slʌŋ ɪt fɹəm ɪz ʃoʊldɝ.

When the door closed behind them, he studied Min for a moment, then took one of the scrips and slung it from his shoulder.

"oʊnli wʌn?" ʃi sɛd. sɛɾɪŋ ði ʌðɝz ɑn ðə flɔɹ, ʃi plæntəɾ əɹ fɪsts ɑn əɹ hɪps ən skaʊld. "səmtaɪmz jə ɹɪli ɑɹ ə ʃifɝɾɝ. ðiz bæɡz mʌs bi ə hʌnʒɹədweɪt itʃ." bʌt ʃi saʊndəd mɔɹ əmjuz ðən əpsɛt.

"Only one?" she said. Setting the others on the floor, she planted her fists on her hips and scowled. "Sometimes you really are a sheepherder. These bags must be a hundredweight each." But she sounded more amused than upset.

"ju ʃʊɾə pɪk smɔlɝ bʊks," hi toʊl hɝ, pʊlɪŋ ɑn ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɡlʌvz tə haɪd ðə dʒɹæɡənz. "ɔɹəɡən laɪɾɝ." hi tɝn təwɔɹd ðə wɪndoʊ, tə fɛtʃ ðə lɛðɝ skɹɪp, ən ə weɪv ə dɪzinəs hɪt hɪm. niz tɝnɪŋ tə wɔɾɝ, hi stʌmbəld. ə ʃɪmɝɪŋ feɪs i kəd nɑt meɪk aʊt flæʃt θɹu hɪz hɛd. wɪð ən ɛfɝt, hi kɑt hɪmsɛlf, fɔɹst ɪz lɛɡz stʃɹeɪt. ən ðə wɝlɪŋ sɛnseɪʃən vænɪʃt. luz θɝɪn pæntɪd hɔɹsli ɪn ðə ʃædoʊz. kəd ðə feɪs bi hɪz?

"You should have picked smaller books," he told her, pulling on riding gloves to hide the Dragons. "Or lighter." He turned toward the window, to fetch the leather scrip, and a wave of dizziness hit him. Knees turning to water, he stumbled. A shimmering face he could not make out flashed through his head. With an effort, he caught himself, forced his legs straight. And the whirling sensation vanished. Lews Therin panted hoarsely in the shadows. Could the face be his?

"ɪf jə θɪŋk jəl meɪk mi kæɹi ðɛm ɔl ðət weɪ, θɪŋk əɡɛn," mɪn ɡɹʌmbəld. "aɪv sin bɛɾɝ pɹitɛndɪŋ fɹəm steɪbəlɪhənz. jə kəd tʃɹaɪ fɔlɪŋ daʊn."

"If you think you'll make me carry them all that way, think again," Min grumbled. "I've seen better pretending from stablehands. You could try falling down."

"nɑt ðɪs taɪm." hi wɑz ɹɛɾi fəɹ wʌt hæpənd wən i tʃænəld; hi kəd kəntʃɹoʊl ɪt tə səm ɪkstɛnt. juʒəwəli. moʊst ə ðə taɪm. ðɪs dɪzinəs wɪθaʊt seɪɾɪn wɑz nu. meɪbi hi hæd dʒʌs tɝn tu fæst. ən meɪbi pɪɡz dɪd flaɪ. hi sɛɾəld ðə lɛðɝ skɹɪps stʃɹæp oʊvɝ ɪz fɹi ʃoʊldɝ. ðə mɛn ɪn ðə steɪbliɑɹd wɝ stɪl bɪzi. bɪldɪŋ. "mɪn - "

"Not this time." He was ready for what happened when he channeled; he could control it to some extent. Usually. Most of the time. This dizziness without saidin was new. Maybe he had just turned too fast. And maybe pigs did fly. He settled the leather scrip's strap over his free shoulder. The men in the stableyard were still busy. Building. "Min - "

hɝ bɹaʊz loʊɝɾ ɪmiɾiətli. ʃi pɔz fəɹ ən ɪnstən ɪn dʒɹɔɪŋ ɑn əɹ ɹɛd ɡlʌvz ən bɪɡæn tæpɪŋ əɹ fʊt. ə deɪnʒɝəs saɪn wɪð ɛni wʊmən, ɪspɛʃli wʌn u kæɹid naɪvz. "wi hæd ðɪs aʊt, ɹænd blʌɾi dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn ælθɹ! jə ɑɹ nɑt livɪŋ mi bɪhaɪnd!"

Her brows lowered immediately. She paused for an instant in drawing on her red gloves and began tapping her foot. A dangerous sign with any woman, especially one who carried knives. "We had this out, Rand bloody Dragon Reborn al'Thor! You are not leaving me behind!"

"ðə θɔt nɛvɝ kɹɔs maɪ maɪnd," hi laɪd. hi wɑz tu wik; hi kəd nɑt meɪk hɪmsɛlf seɪ ðə wɝdz, tə meɪk əɹ steɪ. tu wik, hi θɔt bɪɾɝli, ən ʃi maɪt wɛl daɪ fəɹ ɪt, ðə laɪt bɝn mi fɝɛvɝ!

"The thought never crossed my mind," he lied. He was too weak; he could not make himself say the words, to make her stay. Too weak, he thought bitterly, and she might well die for it, the Light burn me forever!

ɪt wɪl, luz θɝɪn pɹɑməst sɔfli.

It will, Lews Therin promised softly.

"aɪ dʒʌs θɔt jə ʃəd noʊ wʌt wiv bɪn duɪŋ, ən wʌt wəɹ ɡoʊɪŋ tə du," ɹænd wɛn ɑn. "aɪ hævən bɪn vɛɹi fɔɹθkʌmɪŋ, aɪ səpoʊz." ɡæðɝɪŋ hɪmsɛlf, hi siz seɪɾɪn. ðə ɹum sim tə wɝl, ən i ɹoʊd ði ævəlæntʃ ə faɪɝ ən aɪs ən fɪlθ wɪð nɔziə siθɪŋ ɪn ɪz bɛli. hi wɑz eɪbəl tə stæn ɪɹɛkt wɪθaʊt sweɪɪŋ, ðoʊ. bɛɹli. ən dʒʌst eɪbəl tə wiv ðə floʊz ʌv ə ɡeɪtweɪ ðəɾ oʊpən ɪndə ə snoʊi klɪɹɪŋ wɛɹ tu sæɾəld hɔɹsəz wɝ tɛðɝd tə ə loʊ bɹæntʃ ʌv ən oʊk.

"I just thought you should know what we've been doing, and what we are going to do," Rand went on. "I haven't been very forthcoming, I suppose." Gathering himself, he seized saidin. The room seemed to whirl, and he rode the avalanche of fire and ice and filth with nausea seething in his belly. He was able to stand erect without swaying, though. Barely. And just able to weave the flows of a gateway that opened into a snowy clearing where two saddled horses were tethered to a low branch of an oak.

hi wɑz ɡlæd tə si ði ænəməlz stɪl ðɛɹ. ðə klɪɹɪŋ wɑz wɛl əweɪ fɹəm ðə nɪɹəst ɹoʊd, bʌt ðəɹ wɝ stɪl wɑndɝɝz u hæd tɝn ðɛɹ bæks ɑn fæmliz ən fɑɹmz, tʃɹeɪdz ən kɹæfs, kəz ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn hæd bɹoʊkən ɔl bɑnz. ðə pɹɑfəsiz sɛd soʊ. ɑn ði ʌðɝ hænd, ə ɡʊd mɛni ʌv ðoʊz mɛn ən wɪmən, fʊtsɔɹ ən hæf-fɹoʊzən naʊ ɑn tɑp ʌv ɪt, wɝ taɪɝɾ ə sɝtʃɪŋ wɪθaʊɾ ɛni noʊʃən wʌt ðeɪ wɝ sɝtʃɪŋ fɔɹ. ivən ðiz nɑndɪskɹɪp maʊns ʃʊɹli wʊɾə vænɪʃt wɪð ðə fɝs mæn tə faɪn əm ənətɛndɪd. hi hæd ɡoʊld ɪnʌf tə baɪ ʌðɝz, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt θɪŋk mɪn wʊɾə ɛndʒɔɪd ði aʊɝz wɔk tə ðə vɪlədʒ wɛɹ ðeɪ hæd lɛf ðə pækhɔɹsɪz.

He was glad to see the animals still there. The clearing was well away from the nearest road, but there were still wanderers who had turned their backs on families and farms, trades and crafts, because the Dragon Reborn had broken all bonds. The Prophecies said so. On the other hand, a good many of those men and women, footsore and half-frozen now on top of it, were tired of searching without any notion what they were searching for. Even these nondescript mounts surely would have vanished with the first man to find them unattended. He had gold enough to buy others, but he did not think Min would have enjoyed the hour's walk to the village where they had left the packhorses.

hɝiɪŋ θɹu ɪndə ðə klɪɹɪŋ, pɹitɛndɪŋ ðə tʃeɪnʒ fɹəm flɔɹ tə ni-dip snoʊ kɑzd ɪz stʌmbəl, hi oʊnli weɪɾəd əntɪl ʃi hæd snætʃt ʌp əɹ bæɡz ə bʊks ən stæɡɝd θɹu æftɝ ɪm bɪfɔɹ ɹilisɪŋ ðə paʊɝ. ðeɪ wɝ faɪv hʌnʒɹəd maɪlz fɹəm kɛɹhin, ən nɪɹɝ tɑɹ vəlɑn ðən ɛniwɛɹ ɛls ə noʊt. ɑlɑnə hæd feɪɾəd ɪn ɪz hɛd wən ðə ɡeɪtweɪ kloʊzd.

Hurrying through into the clearing, pretending the change from floor to knee-deep snow caused his stumble, he only waited until she had snatched up her bags of books and staggered through after him before releasing the Power. They were five hundred miles from Cairhien, and nearer Tar Valon than anywhere else of note. Alanna had faded in his head when the gateway closed.

"fɔɹθkʌmɪŋ?" mɪn sɛd, saʊndɪŋ səspɪʃəs. ʌv ɪz moʊɾɪvz, hi hoʊpt, əɹ ɛniθɪŋ bʌt ðə tʃɹuθ. ðə dɪzinəs ən nɔziə feɪɾəd sloʊli. "ju hæv bɪn əz oʊpən əz ə mʌsəl, ɹænd, bʌɾ aɪm nɑt blaɪnd. fɝst wi tʃɹævəl tə ɹɪɾiən, wɛɹ jə æsk soʊ mɛni kwɛstʃənz əbaʊt ðɪs ʃɑɹə pleɪs ðəɾ ɛnibəɾi wəd θɪŋk jə mɛn tə ɡoʊ ðɛɹ." fɹaʊnɪŋ feɪnli, ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛɾ əz ʃi fæsənd wʌn ə hɝ bɝɾənz tə ðə sæɾəl ə hɝ bɹaʊn ɡɛldɪŋ. ʃi ɡɹʌntɪd wɪð ði ɛfɝt, bʌt ʃi wɑz nɑɾ əbaʊt tə sɛt ði ʌðɝ bæɡ ʌv bʊks daʊn ɪn ðə snoʊ. "aɪ nɛvɝ θɔt ði il weɪst wɑz laɪk ðæt. ðət sɪɾi ɪz bɪɡɝ ðən tɑɹ vəlɑn, ivən ɪf ɪts hæf ɹuənd. ən ɔl ðoʊz faʊntənz, ən ðə leɪk. aɪ kʊdn ivən si ðə fɑɹ saɪd. aɪ θɔt ðəɹ wɑzn ɛni wɔɾɝ ɪn ðə weɪst. ən ɪt wɑz əz koʊld əz hɪɹ; aɪ θɔt ðə weɪst wɑz hɑt!"

"Forthcoming?" Min said, sounding suspicious. Of his motives, he hoped, or anything but the truth. The dizziness and nausea faded slowly. "You have been as open as a mussel, Rand, but I am not blind. First we Traveled to Rhuidean, where you asked so many questions about this Shara place that anybody would think you meant to go there." Frowning faintly, she shook her head as she fastened one of her burdens to the saddle of her brown gelding. She grunted with the effort, but she was not about to set the other bag of books down in the snow. "I never thought the Aiel Waste was like that. That city is bigger than Tar Valon, even if it is half ruined. And all those fountains, and the lake. I couldn't even see the far side. I thought there wasn't any water in the Waste. And it was as cold as here; I thought the Waste was hot!"

"ɪn sʌmɝ, jə fɹaɪ dʊɹɪŋ ðə deɪ, bʌt jə stɪl fɹiz ət naɪt." hi fɛlt ɹəkʌvɝɾ ɪnʌf tə bɪɡɪn ʃɪftɪŋ ɪz oʊn bɝɾənz tə ðə ɡɹeɪz sæɾəl. ɔlmoʊst ɪnʌf. hi dɪɾ ɪɾ ɛniweɪ. "ɪf jə ɔlɹɛɾi noʊ ɛvɹiθɪŋ, wʌt wɑz aɪ duɪŋ bɪsaɪdz æskɪŋ kwɛstʃənz?"

"In summer, you fry during the day, but you still freeze at night." He felt recovered enough to begin shifting his own burdens to the gray's saddle. Almost enough. He did it anyway. "If you already know everything, what was I doing besides asking questions?"

"ðə seɪm əz ɪn tɛɹ læs naɪt. meɪkɪŋ ʃʊɹ ɛvɹi kæɾ ən blækbɝd nu jə wɝ ðɛɹ. ɪn tɛɹ, ɪt wɑz tʃeɪkɪn jə æskt əbaʊt. ɪts ɑbviəs. jə ɑɹ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kənfjuz ɛniwʌn u tʃɹaɪz tə faɪn aʊt wɛɹ jə ɑɹ ən wɛɹ jəɹ ɡoʊɪŋ nɛkst." ðə sɛkən bæɡ ʌv bʊks bælənsɪŋ ðə fɝs bɪhaɪn əɹ sæɾəl, ʃi əntaɪɾ əɹ ɹeɪnz ən klaɪmd ɪndə ðə sæɾəl. "soʊ, æm aɪ blaɪnd?"

"The same as in Tear last night. Making sure every cat and blackbird knew you were there. In Tear, it was Chachin you asked about. It's obvious. You are trying to confuse anyone who tries to find out where you are and where you're going next." The second bag of books balancing the first behind her saddle, she untied her reins and climbed into the saddle. "So, am I blind?"

"jɔɹ aɪz bɪlɔŋ ɑn ən iɡəl." hi hoʊpt ɪz pɝsuɝz sɔ əz klɪɹli. əɹ ðət huɛvɝ dɝɛktəɾ əm dɪd. ɪt wəd nɑt də tə hæv əm hɛɹɪŋ ɔf ðə laɪt nu wɛɹ. "aɪ nid tə leɪ səm mɔɹ fɔls tʃɹeɪlz, aɪ θɪŋk."

"Your eyes belong on an eagle." He hoped his pursuers saw as clearly. Or that whoever directed them did. It would not do to have them haring off the Light knew where. "I need to lay some more false trails, I think."

"waɪ teɪk ðə taɪm? aɪ noʊ juv ə plæn, aɪ noʊ ɪt kənsɝnz sʌmθɪŋ ɪn ðət lɛðɝ skɹɪp - ə sɑŋɡɹil? - ən aɪ noʊ ɪts ɪmpɔɹɾənt. doʊn lʊk soʊ sɝpɹaɪzd. jə bɛɹli lɛt ðət bæɡ aʊɾ ə jəɹ saɪt. waɪ nɑt ɡoʊ əhɛɾ ən də wʌtɛvɝ ɪts jə plæn, ðən leɪ jəɹ fɔls tʃɹeɪlz? ən ðə ɹil wʌn, ʌv kɔɹs. jəɹ gɑnə tɝn ɑn əm wən ðeɪ list ɪkspɛkt, jə sɛd. jə kən hɑɹdli də ðəɾ ənlɛs ðeɪ fɑloʊ wɛɹ jə wɑnt."

"Why take the time? I know you have a plan, I know it concerns something in that leather scrip - a sa'angreal? - and I know it's important. Don't look so surprised. You barely let that bag out of your sight. Why not go ahead and do whatever it is you plan, then lay your false trails? And the real one, of course. You're going to turn on them when they least expect, you said. You can hardly do that unless they follow where you want."

"aɪ wɪʃ jud nɛvɝ stɑɹɾəd ɹiɾɪŋ hɹɪd fɛlz bʊks," hi mʌɾɝd saʊɝli, pʊlɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ɪndə ðə ɡɹeɪz sæɾəl. hɪz hɛd spʌn oʊnli ə lɪɾəl. "ju pʌzəl aʊt tu mʌtʃ. kən aɪ kip ɛni sikɹəts əɾ ɔl fɹəm ju, naʊ?"

"I wish you'd never started reading Herid Fel's books," he muttered sourly, pulling himself into the gray's saddle. His head spun only a little. "You puzzle out too much. Can I keep any secrets at all from you, now?"

"ju nɛvɝ kʊd, wʊlhɛd," ʃi læft, ən ðɛn, kɑntʃɹədɪktɪŋ hɝsɛlf, "wʌɾ ɑɹ jə plænɪŋ? əsaɪd fɹəm kɪlɪŋ dæʃivə ən ðə ɹɛst, aɪ min. aɪ hæv ə ɹaɪt tə noʊ ɪf aɪm tʃɹævlɪŋ wɪð ju." əz ɪf ʃi hæd nɑɾ ɪnsɪstəɾ ɑn tʃɹævlɪŋ wɪð hɪm.

"You never could, woolhead," she laughed, and then, contradicting herself, "What are you planning? Aside from killing Dashiva and the rest, I mean. I have a right to know if I'm traveling with you." As if she had not insisted on traveling with him.

"aɪm gɑnə klɛnz ðə meɪl hæf ə ðə sɔɹs," hi sɛɾ ɪn ə flæt vɔɪs. ə moʊmɛntəs ənaʊnsmənt. ə ɡɹæn skim, mɔɹ ðən ɡɹænd. ɡɹændioʊs, moʊst wəd seɪ. hi maɪɾ əv sɛɾ i ɪntɛndəd tə teɪk ən æftɝnun stʃɹoʊl, fəɹ ɔl ə mɪnz ɹiækʃən. ʃi sɪmpli lʊkt ət hɪm, hænz foʊldəɾ ɑn ðə pɑməl ə hɝ sæɾəl, əntɪl i wɛn ɑn.

"I'm going to cleanse the male half of the Source," he said in a flat voice. A momentous announcement. A grand scheme, more than grand. Grandiose, most would say. He might have said he intended to take an afternoon stroll, for all of Min's reaction. She simply looked at him, hands folded on the pommel of her saddle, until he went on.

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ haʊ lɔŋ ɪɾəl teɪk, ən wʌns aɪ stɑɹt, aɪ θɪŋk ɛvɹiwʌn wɪðɪn ə θaʊzən maɪlz ə mi hu kən tʃænəl wɪl noʊ sʌmθɪŋ ɪz hæpənɪŋ. aɪ daʊɾ əl bi eɪbəl tə dʒʌst stɑp ɪf dæʃivə ən ðə ɹɛst, əɹ ðə fɔɹseɪkən, sʌɾənli əpɪɹ tə si wʌɾ ɪɾ ɪz. ðə fɔɹseɪkən, aɪ kæn də ɛniθɪŋ əbaʊt, bʌt wɪð lʌk, aɪ kən fɪnɪʃ ði ʌðɝz." meɪbi biɪŋ tɑvɝən wəd ɡɪv ɪm ði ɛdʒ i niɾəd soʊ dɛspɝətli.

"I don't know how long it will take, and once I start, I think everyone within a thousand miles of me who can channel will know something is happening. I doubt I'll be able to just stop if Dashiva and the rest, or the Forsaken, suddenly appear to see what it is. The Forsaken, I can't do anything about, but with luck, I can finish the others." Maybe being ta'veren would give him the edge he needed so desperately.

"dɪpɛn ɑn lʌk, ən kɔɹlən dæʃivə əɹ ðə fɔɹseɪkən, iðɝ wʌn, wɪl əv jə fəɹ bɹɛkfəst," ʃi sɛd, tɝnɪŋ əɹ hɔɹs aʊɾ ə ðə klɪɹɪŋ. "meɪbi aɪ kən θɪŋk ʌv ə bɛɾɝ weɪ. kʌm ɑn. ðɛɹz ə wɔɹm faɪɝ ət ðəɾ ɪn. aɪ hoʊp jəɹ gɑnə lɛɾ əs əv ə hɑt mil bɪfɔɹ wi liv."

"Depend on luck, and Corlan Dashiva or the Forsaken, either one, will have you for breakfast," she said, turning her horse out of the clearing. "Maybe I can think of a better way. Come on. There's a warm fire at that inn. I hope you're going to let us have a hot meal before we leave."

ɹænd stɛɹɾ æftɝ əɹ ɪnkɹɛdʒjələsli. jə wʊɾə θɔt faɪv ɹɛnəɡeɪɾ æʃəmən, nɑt tə mɛnʃən ðə fɔɹseɪkən, wɝ lɛs bɑðɝ ðən ə sɔɹ tuθ. buɾɪŋ ðə ɡɹeɪ əhɛɾ ɪn ə spɹeɪ ʌv snoʊ, hi kɑɾ ʌp tə hɝ ən ɹoʊɾ ɪn saɪləns. hi stɪl hæɾ ə fju sikɹəts fɹəm hɝ, ðɪs sɪknəs ðət hæd bɪɡʌn əfɛktɪŋ ɪm wən i tʃænəld, fəɹ wʌn. ðət wɑz ðə ɹil ɹizən i hæd tə dil wɪð dæʃivə ən ði ʌðɝz fɝst. ɪt ɡeɪv ɪm taɪm tə ɡɛɾ oʊvɝ ðə sɪknəs. ɪf ðət wɑz pɑsəbəl. ɪf nɑt, hi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ ðə tu tɛɹæŋɡɹil ɹaɪɾɪŋ bɪhaɪn ɪz sæɾəl wɝ gɑnə bi ɛni jus əɾ ɔl.

Rand stared after her incredulously. You would have thought five renegade Asha'man, not to mention the Forsaken, were less bother than a sore tooth. Booting the gray ahead in a spray of snow, he caught up to her and rode in silence. He still had a few secrets from her, this sickness that had begun affecting him when he channeled, for one. That was the real reason he had to deal with Dashiva and the others first. It gave him time to get over the sickness. If that was possible. If not, he was not sure the two ter'angreal riding behind his saddle were going to be any use at all.


tʃæptɝ wʌn


CHAPTER 1

livɪŋ ðə pɹɑfət


Leaving the Prophet

ðə wil ə taɪm tɝnz, ən eɪdʒəz kʌm ən pæs, livɪŋ mɛmɹiz ðət bɪkʌm lɛdʒənd. lɛdʒən feɪdz tə mɪθ, ən ivən mɪθ ɪz lɔŋ fɝɡɑɾən wən ði eɪdʒ ðət ɡeɪv ɪt bɝθ kʌmz əɡɛn. ɪn wʌn eɪdʒ, kɔl ðə θɝɾ eɪdʒ baɪ sʌm, ən eɪdʒ jɛt tə kʌm, ən eɪdʒ lɔŋ pæst, ə wɪn ɹoʊz əbʌv ði ɛɹɪθ oʊʃən. ðə wɪnd wɑz nɑt ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ. ðəɹ ɑɹ niðɝ bɪɡɪnɪŋz nɔɹ ɛndɪŋz tə ðə tɝnɪŋ ə ðə wil ə taɪm. bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ə bɪɡɪnɪŋ.

The Wheel of Time turns, and Ages come and pass, leaving memories that become legend. Legend fades to myth, and even myth is long forgotten when the Age that gave it birth comes again. In one Age, called the Third Age by some, an Age yet to come, an Age long past, a wind rose above the Aryth Ocean. The wind was not the beginning. There are neither beginnings nor endings to the turning of the Wheel of Time. But it was a beginning.

is ðə wɪn blu əbʌv ðə koʊld ɡɹeɪ-ɡɹin oʊʃən swɛlz, təwɔɹd tæɹɑbən, wɛɹ ʃɪps ɔlɹɛɾi ənloʊɾəd əɹ weɪɾɪŋ ðɛɹ tɝnz tə ɛntɝ ðə hɑɹbɝ ə tæntʃəkoʊ tɔst əɾ æŋkɝ fəɹ maɪlz əlɔŋ ðə loʊ koʊstlaɪn. mɔɹ ʃɪps, ɡɹeɪɾ ən smɔl, fɪl ðə hjudʒ hɑɹbɝ, ən bɑɹdʒəz fɛɹiɪŋ pipəl ən kɑɹɡoʊ əʃɔɹ, fəɹ ðəɹ wɑz noʊ mʊɹɪŋ ɛmpti əɾ ɛni ʌv ðə sɪɾiz dɑks. ði ɪnhæbəɾənts ə tæntʃəkoʊ hæd bɪn fɪɹfəl wən ðə sɪɾi fɛl tə ɪts nu mæstɝz, wɪð ðɛɹ pəkjuljɝ kʌstəmz ən stʃɹeɪnʒ kɹitʃɝz ən wɪmən hɛld ɑn liʃɪz u kəd tʃænəl, ən fɪɹfəl əɡɛn wən ðɪs fliɾ ɝaɪvd, maɪnd-nʌmɪŋ ɪn ɪts saɪz, ən bɪɡæn dɪsɡɔɹdʒɪŋ nɑɾ oʊnli soʊlʒɝz bʌt ʃɑɹp-aɪd mɝtʃəns, ən kɹæftsfoʊk wɪð ðə tulz ə ðɛɹ tʃɹeɪdz, ən ivən fæmliz wɪð wæɡənz fʊl ə fɑɹm ɪmpləməns ən ənnoʊn plæns. ðəɹ wɑz ə nu kɪŋ ən ə nu pɑnɑɹtʃ tə ɔɹɾɝ ðə lɔz, ðoʊ, ən ɪf kɪŋ ən pɑnɑɹtʃ oʊd fiəlti tə səm fɑɹ dɪstən ɛmpɹɛs, ɪf sintʃæn noʊbəlz ɑkjəpaɪd mɛni ʌv ðə pæləsəz ən dɪmændəd dipɝ oʊbaɪsəns ðən ɛni tæɹɑbənɝ lɔɹɾ əɹ leɪɾi, laɪf wɑz lɪɾəl tʃeɪnʒd fəɹ moʊs pipəl, ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə bɛɾɝ. ðə sintʃæn blʌd hæd smɔl kɑntækt wɪð ɔɹɾənɛɹi foʊk, ən ɑd kʌstəmz kəd bi lɪvd wɪð. ði ænɝki ðət hæd ɹɪp ðə kʌntʃɹi əpɑɹt wɑz dʒʌst ə mɛmɹi, naʊ, ən hʌŋɡɝ wɪð ɪt. ðə ɹɛbəlz ən bændəts ən dʒɹæɡənzɔɹn u hæd pleɪɡd ðə lænd wɝ dɛɾ əɹ kæptʃɝɾ əɹ dʒɹɪvən nɔɹθ ɑntu ɑlməθ pleɪn, ðoʊz u hæd nɑt jildəd, ən tʃɹeɪd muvd wʌns mɔɹ. ðə hɔɹdz ə stɑɹvɪŋ ɹɛfjudʒiz ðət hæd klɔɡd ðə sɪɾi stʃɹits wɝ bæk ɪn ðɛɹ vɪlədʒəz, bæk ɑn ðɛɹ fɑɹmz. ən noʊ mɔɹ ə ðə nuəst ɝaɪvəlz ɹɪmeɪn ɪn tæntʃəkoʊ ðən ðə sɪɾi kəd səpɔɹɾ izəli. dɪspaɪt ðə snoʊz, soʊlʒɝz ən mɝtʃəns, kɹæftsfoʊk ən fɑɹmɝz fæn aʊɾ ɪnlæn ɪn ðɛɹ θaʊzənz ən tɛnz ə θaʊzənz, bʌt ði aɪsi wɪn læʃt ə tæntʃəkoʊ ət pis ænd, æftɝ ɪts hɑɹʃ tʃɹʌbəlz, fəɹ ðə moʊs pɑɹt kɑntɛnt wɪð ɪts lɑt.

East the wind blew above the cold gray-green ocean swells, toward Tarabon, where ships already unloaded or waiting their turns to enter the harbor of Tanchico tossed at anchor for miles along the low coastline. More ships, great and small, filled the huge harbor, and barges ferrying people and cargo ashore, for there was no mooring empty at any of the city's docks. The inhabitants of Tanchico had been fearful when the city fell to its new masters, with their peculiar customs and strange creatures and women held on leashes who could channel, and fearful again when this fleet arrived, mind-numbing in its size, and began disgorging not only soldiers but sharp-eyed merchants, and craftsfolk with the tools of their trades, and even families with wagons full of farm implements and unknown plants. There was a new King and a new Panarch to order the laws, though, and if King and Panarch owed fealty to some far distant Empress, if Seanchan nobles occupied many of the palaces and demanded deeper obeisance than any Taraboner lord or lady, life was little changed for most people, except for the better. The Seanchan Blood had small contact with ordinary folk, and odd customs could be lived with. The anarchy that had ripped the country apart was just a memory, now, and hunger with it. The rebels and bandits and Dragonsworn who had plagued the land were dead or captured or driven north onto Almoth Plain, those who had not yielded, and trade moved once more. The hordes of starving refugees that had clogged the city streets were back in their villages, back on their farms. And no more of the newest arrivals remained in Tanchico than the city could support easily. Despite the snows, soldiers and merchants, craftsfolk and farmers fanned out inland in their thousands and tens of thousands, but the icy wind lashed a Tanchico at peace and, after its harsh troubles, for the most part content with its lot.

is ðə wɪn blu fəɹ liɡz, ɡʌstɪŋ ən feɪɾɪŋ, dɪvaɪɾɪŋ bʌt nɛvɝ daɪɪŋ, ist ən vɪɹɪŋ tə ðə saʊθ, əkɹɔs fɔɹəsts ən pleɪnz ɹæpt ɪn wɪntɝ, bɛɹ-bɹæntʃt ən bɹaʊn-ɡɹæst, ət læs kɹɔsɪŋ wʌt hæd wʌns bɪn ðə bɔɹɾɝ bɪtwin tæɹɑbən ən ɑmɑdɪʃiə. ə bɔɹɾɝ stɪl, bʌɾ oʊnli ɪn neɪm, ðə kʌstəmz poʊsts dɪsmæntəld, ðə ɡɑɹdz ɡɔn. ist ən saʊθ, ɝaʊn ðə sʌðɝn ɹitʃəz ə ðə maʊntənz ə mɪst, swɝlɪŋ əkɹɔs haɪ-wɔld æmədɔɹ. kɑŋkɝɾ æmədɔɹ. ðə bænɝ ətɑp ðə mæsɪv fɔɹtʃɹəs ə ðə laɪt snæpt ɪn ðə wɪnd, ðə ɡoʊldən hɔk ɪt bɔɹ tʃɹuli simɪŋ tə flaɪ wɪð laɪtnɪŋ boʊls klʌtʃt ɪn ɪts təlɑnz. fju neɪɾɪvz lɛf ðɛɹ hoʊmz ɪksɛpt ət nid, ən ðoʊz fju hɝiɾ əlɔŋ ðə fɹoʊzən stʃɹits, kloʊks klʌtʃt ɝaʊn əm ən aɪz daʊn. aɪz daʊn nɑt dʒʌs tə maɪn fʊɾɪŋ ɑn slɪk peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz bʌt tə əvɔɪd lʊkɪŋ ət ði əkeɪʒənəl sintʃæn ɹaɪɾɪŋ baɪ ɑn ə bis laɪk ə bɹɑnz-skeɪl kæt ðə saɪz ʌv ə hɔɹs, əɹ stil-veɪl tæɹɑbənɝz ɡɑɹɾɪŋ ɡɹups ʌv wʌntaɪm tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt, naʊ tʃeɪn ən leɪbɝɪŋ laɪk ænəməlz tə hɔl ɹɛfjus wæɡənz aʊɾ ə ðə sɪɾi. ə bɛɹ mʌnθ ən ə hæf ɪn ðə sintʃæn foʊld, ðə pipəl ʌv ɑmɑdɪʃiəz kæpəɾəl sɪɾi fɛl ðə bɪɾɝ wɪn laɪk ə skɝdʒ, ən ðoʊz u dɪd nɑt kɝs ðɛɹ feɪt mɛɾəteɪtɪd ɑn wʌt sɪnz hæd bɹɔɾ əm tə ðɪs.

East the wind blew for leagues, gusting and fading, dividing but never dying, east and veering to the south, across forests and plains wrapped in winter, bare-branched and brown-grassed, at last crossing what had once been the border between Tarabon and Amadicia. A border still, but only in name, the customs posts dismantled, the guards gone. East and south, around the southern reaches of the Mountains of Mist, swirling across high-walled Amador. Conquered Amador. The banner atop the massive Fortress of the Light snapped in the wind, the golden hawk it bore truly seeming to fly with lightning bolts clutched in its talons. Few natives left their homes except at need, and those few hurried along the frozen streets, cloaks clutched around them and eyes down. Eyes down not just to mind footing on slick paving stones but to avoid looking at the occasional Seanchan riding by on a beast like a bronze-scaled cat the size of a horse, or steel-veiled Taraboners guarding groups of onetime Children of the Light, now chained and laboring like animals to haul refuse wagons out of the city. A bare month and a half in the Seanchan fold, the people of Amadicia's capital city felt the bitter wind like a scourge, and those who did not curse their fate meditated on what sins had brought them to this.

is ðə wɪn haʊld oʊvɝ ə dɛsəleɪɾɪd lænd wɛɹ əz mɛni vɪlədʒəz leɪ bɝn ən fɑɹmz ɹuən əz hɛl pipəl. snoʊ blæŋkəɾɪd tʃɑɹd tɪmbɝz ən əbændən bɑɹnz əlaɪk, sɔfənɪŋ ðə vju ivən əz ɪɾ æɾəd fɹizɪŋ tə stɑɹveɪʃən əz ə weɪ ʌv daɪɪŋ. sɔɹɾ ən æks ən spɪɹ hæd bɪn ðəɹ ɔlɹɛɾi, ən ɹɪmeɪn tə kɪl əɡɛn. ist, əntɪl ðə wɪn moʊn ə dɝdʒ oʊvɝ ənwɔld ɑbilə. noʊ bænɝz flu əbʌv ðə taʊnz wɑtʃtaʊɝz, fəɹ ðə pɹɑfəɾ ə ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən wɑz ðɛɹ, ən ðə pɹɑfət niɾəd noʊ bænɝ seɪv ɪz neɪm. ɪn ɑbilə, pipəl ʃɪvɝd hɑɹɾɝ ət ðə neɪm ə ðə pɹɑfət ðən ðeɪ dɪd fəɹ ðə wɪnd. pipəl ɛlswɛɹ ʃɪvɝɾ ət ðət neɪm, tu.

East the wind howled over a desolated land where as many villages lay burned and farms ruined as held people. Snow blanketed charred timbers and abandoned barns alike, softening the view even as it added freezing to starvation as a way of dying. Sword and axe and spear had been there already, and remained to kill again. East, until the wind moaned a dirge over unwalled Abila. No banners flew above the town's watchtowers, for the Prophet of the Lord Dragon was there, and the Prophet needed no banner save his name. In Abila, people shivered harder at the name of the Prophet than they did for the wind. People elsewhere shivered at that name, too.

stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə tɔl mɝtʃəns haʊs wɛɹ mæsimə lɪvd, pɛɹɪn lɛt ðə wɪnd wɪp ɪz fɝ-laɪn kloʊk əz i pʊld ɑn ɪz ɡlʌvz. ðə mɪddeɪ sʌn ɡeɪv noʊ wɔɹmθ, ən ði ɛɹ bɪt dip. hi kɛpt ɪz feɪs smuð, bʌɾ i wɑz tu æŋɡɹi tə fil ðə koʊld. kipɪŋ ɪz hænz fɹəm ði æks əɾ ɪz bɛlt wɑz ən ɛfɝt. mæsimə - hi wəd nɑt kɔl ðə mæn pɹɑfət, nɑɾ ɪn ɪz oʊn hɛɾ i wəd nɑt! - mæsimə wɑz vɛɹi laɪkli ə ful, ən vɛɹi sɝɾənli ɪnseɪn. ə paʊɝfəl ful, mɔɹ paʊɝfəl ðən moʊs kɪŋz, ən mæd wɪð ɪt.

Striding out of the tall merchant's house where Masema lived, Perrin let the wind whip his fur-lined cloak as he pulled on his gloves. The midday sun gave no warmth, and the air bit deep. He kept his face smooth, but he was too angry to feel the cold. Keeping his hands from the axe at his belt was an effort. Masema - he would not call the man Prophet, not in his own head he would not! - Masema was very likely a fool, and very certainly insane. A powerful fool, more powerful than most kings, and mad with it.

mæsiməz ɡɑɹdz fɪl ðə stʃɹit fɹəm saɪd tə saɪɾ ən stʃɹɛtʃt ɝaʊn ðə kɔɹnɝz ə ðə nɛkst stʃɹits, boʊni fɛloʊz ɪn stoʊlən sɪlks, bɪɹdləs əpɹɛntəsɪz ɪn tɔɹn koʊts, wʌns-plʌmp mɝtʃəns ɪn ðə ɹɪmeɪnz ə faɪn wʊlənz. ðɛɹ bɹɛθ wɑz waɪt mɪst, ən səm ʃɪvɝd wɪθaʊɾ ə kloʊk, bʌɾ ɛvɹi mæn klʌtʃt ə spɪɹ, əɹ ə kɹɔsboʊ wɪð ðə boʊlt ɪn pleɪs. stɪl, nʌn lʊkt aʊtwɝdli hɑstəl. ðeɪ nu hi kleɪmd əkweɪntəns wɪð ðə pɹɑfət, ən ðeɪ ɡeɪpt əz ɪf ɪkspɛktɪŋ ɪm tə lip ɪndə ði ɛɹ ən flaɪ. əɹ ət lis tɝn sʌmɝsɔls. hi fɪltɝɾ aʊt ðə smɛl ʌv wʊdzmoʊk fɹəm ðə taʊnz tʃɪmniz. ðə lɑɾ ə ðɛm stæŋk ʌv oʊl swɛɾ ən ənwɑʃt bɑɾiz, ʌv iɡɝnəs ən fɪɹ. ən ʌv ə stʃɹeɪnʒ fivɝ i hæd nɑt ɹɛkəɡnaɪz bɪfɔɹ, ə ɹəflɛkʃən ə ðə mædnəs ɪn mæsimə. hɑstəl əɹ nɑt, ðeɪ wəd kɪl hɪm, əɹ ɛniwʌn, ət mæsiməz wɝd. ðeɪ wəd bʊtʃɝ neɪʃənz ət mæsiməz wɝd. smɛlɪŋ ðɛm, hi fɛlt ə koʊlnəs dipɝ ðən ɛni wɪntɝ wɪnd. hi wɑz ɡlæɾɝ ðən ɛvɝ ðəɾ i hæd ɹəfjuz tə lɛt feɪl kʌm wɪð hɪm.

Masema's guards filled the street from side to side and stretched around the corners of the next streets, bony fellows in stolen silks, beardless apprentices in torn coats, once-plump merchants in the remains of fine woolens. Their breath was white mist, and some shivered without a cloak, but every man clutched a spear, or a crossbow with the bolt in place. Still, none looked outwardly hostile. They knew he claimed acquaintance with the Prophet, and they gaped as if expecting him to leap into the air and fly. Or at least turn somersaults. He filtered out the smell of woodsmoke from the town's chimneys. The lot of them stank of old sweat and unwashed bodies, of eagerness and fear. And of a strange fever he had not recognized before, a reflection of the madness in Masema. Hostile or not, they would kill him, or anyone, at Masema's word. They would butcher nations at Masema's word. Smelling them, he felt a coldness deeper than any winter wind. He was gladder than ever that he had refused to let Faile come with him.

ðə mɛn i hæd lɛft wɪð ðə maʊns wɝ pleɪɪŋ ət daɪs əlɔŋsaɪd ði ænəməlz, əɹ ɡoʊɪŋ ðoʊ ðə moʊʃənz ʌv ɪt, ɑn ə speɪs ə peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz skɹeɪp moʊsli klɪɹ ə snoʊi slʌʃ. hi dɪd nɑt tʃɹʌs mæsimə əz fɑɹ əz i kəd θɹoʊ hɪz beɪ, ən nɔɹ dɪd ðeɪ. ðeɪ wɝ peɪɪŋ mɔɹ maɪn tə ðə haʊs, ən ðə ɡɑɹdz, ðən tə ðɛɹ ɡeɪm. ðə θɹi wɔɹɾɝz spɹæŋ tə ðɛɹ fiɾ əz sun əz i əpɪɹd, ðɛɹ aɪz ɡoʊɪŋ tə hɪz kəmpænjənz kʌmɪŋ aʊt bɪhaɪn hɪm. ðeɪ nu wʌt ðɛɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ hæd fɛlt ɪnsaɪd ðɛɹ. nild wɑz sloʊɝ, pɔzɪŋ tə skup ʌp ðə daɪs ən kɔɪnz. ði æʃəmən wɑz ə poʊpənʒ, ɔlweɪz stʃɹoʊkɪŋ ɪz kɝl mʌstæʃɪz, stʃɹʌɾɪŋ ən smɝkɪŋ ət wɪmən, bʌɾ i stʊɾ ɑn ðə bɔlz ə hɪz fit naʊ, wɛɹi əz ə kæt.

The men he had left with the mounts were playing at dice alongside the animals, or going though the motions of it, on a space of paving stones scraped mostly clear of snowy slush. He did not trust Masema as far as he could throw his bay, and nor did they. They were paying more mind to the house, and the guards, than to their game. The three Warders sprang to their feet as soon as he appeared, their eyes going to his companions coming out behind him. They knew what their Aes Sedai had felt inside there. Neald was slower, pausing to scoop up the dice and coins. The Asha'man was a popinjay, always stroking his curled mustaches, strutting and smirking at women, but he stood on the balls of his feet now, wary as a cat.

"aɪ θɔt wiɾ əv tə faɪɾ əɹ weɪ aʊɾ ə ðəɹ fəɹ ə taɪm," ɛlaɪəs mɝmɝɾ ət pɛɹɪnz ʃoʊldɝ. hɪz ɡoʊldən aɪz wɝ kɑm, ðoʊ. ə læŋki oʊl mæn ɪn ə bɹɔd-bɹɪm hæt, wɪð ɡɹeɪɪŋ hɛɹ ðət hʌŋ daʊn ɪz bæk tə hɪz weɪst ən ə lɔŋ bɪɹd fænɪŋ əkɹɔs ɪz tʃɛst. ə lɔŋ naɪf əɾ ɪz bɛlt, nɑɾ ə sɔɹd. bʌɾ i hæd bɪn ə wɔɹɾɝ. hi stɪl wɑz, ɪn ə weɪ.

"I thought we'd have to fight our way out of there for a time," Elyas murmured at Perrin's shoulder. His golden eyes were calm, though. A lanky old man in a broad-brimmed hat, with graying hair that hung down his back to his waist and a long beard fanning across his chest. A long knife at his belt, not a sword. But he had been a Warder. He still was, in a way.

"ðæts ði oʊnli θɪŋ ðət wɛn ɹaɪt," pɛɹɪn toʊl hɪm, teɪkɪŋ steɪɝz ɹeɪnz fɹəm nild. ði æʃəmən kwɝkt ən aɪbɹaʊ kwɛstʃənɪŋli, bʌt pɛɹɪn ʃʊk ɪz hɛd, nɑt kɛɹɪŋ wʌt ðə kwɛstʃən wɑz, ən nild, wɪð ə twɪs tə hɪz maʊθ, hændəɾ ɛlaɪəs ðə ɹeɪnz ə hɪz maʊs-kʌlɝd ɡɛldɪŋ bɪfɔɹ klaɪmɪŋ ɑntu hɪz oʊn dæpəl.

"That's the only thing that went right," Perrin told him, taking Stayer's reins from Neald. The Asha'man quirked an eyebrow questioningly, but Perrin shook his head, not caring what the question was, and Neald, with a twist to his mouth, handed Elyas the reins of his mouse-colored gelding before climbing onto his own dapple.

pɛɹɪn hæd noʊ taɪm fəɹ ðə mʊɹændiənz sʌlks. ɹænd hæd sɛn ɪm tə bɹɪŋ bæk mæsimə, ən mæsimə wɑz kʌmɪŋ. əz ɔlweɪz ə leɪt wən i θɔɾ ə ɹænd, kʌlɝz swɝld ɪn ɪz hɛd, ən əz ɔlweɪz, hi ɪɡnɔɹd ðɛm. mæsimə wɑz tu ɡɹeɪɾ ə pɹɑbləm fəɹ pɛɹɪn tə weɪs θɔt fɹɛɾɪŋ oʊvɝ kʌlɝz. ðə blʌɾi mæn θɔɾ ɪt blæsfəmi fəɹ ɛniwʌn bʌt ɹænd tə tʌtʃ ðə wʌn paʊɝ. ɹænd, ɪt simd, wɑz nɑt ɹɪli mɔɹɾəl; hi wɑz ðə laɪt meɪd flɛʃ! soʊ ðəɹ wəd bi noʊ tʃɹævlɪŋ, noʊ kwɪk lip tə kɛɹhin θɹu ə ɡeɪtweɪ meɪd baɪ wʌn ə ði æʃəmən, noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ pɛɹɪn hæd tʃɹaɪd tə bɹɪŋ mæsimə ɝaʊnd. ðeɪ wəɾ əv tə ɹaɪd ðə hoʊl fɔɹ hʌnʒɹəd liɡz əɹ mɔɹ, θɹu ðə laɪɾ əloʊn nu wʌt. ən kip ɪt sikɹəɾ u ðeɪ wɝ, ən mæsimə əz wɛl. ðoʊz hæd bɪn ɹændz ɔɹɾɝz.

Perrin had no time for the Murandian's sulks. Rand had sent him to bring back Masema, and Masema was coming. As always of late when he thought of Rand, colors swirled in his head, and as always, he ignored them. Masema was too great a problem for Perrin to waste thought fretting over colors. The bloody man thought it blasphemy for anyone but Rand to touch the One Power. Rand, it seemed, was not really mortal; he was the Light made flesh! So there would be no Traveling, no quick leap to Cairhien through a gateway made by one of the Asha'man, no matter how Perrin had tried to bring Masema around. They would have to ride the whole four hundred leagues or more, through the Light alone knew what. And keep it secret who they were, and Masema as well. Those had been Rand's orders.

"ðɛɹz oʊnli wʌn weɪ aɪ kən si tə də ɪt, bɔɪ," ɛlaɪəs sɛɾ əz ɪf i hæd spoʊkən əlaʊd. "ə slɪm tʃæns. wi maɪɾ əv hæd bɛɾɝ ɑdz nɑkɪŋ ðə fɛloʊ ɑn ðə hɛɾ ən faɪɾɪŋ klɪɹ ɛniweɪ."

"There's only one way I can see to do it, boy," Elyas said as if he had spoken aloud. "A slim chance. We might have had better odds knocking the fellow on the head and fighting clear anyway."

"aɪ noʊ," pɛɹɪn ɡɹaʊld. hi hæd θɔɾ ʌv ɪt mɔɹ ðən wʌns dʊɹɪŋ ði aʊɝz ʌv ɑɹɡjəmənt. wɪð æʃəmən ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ən waɪz wʌnz ɔl tʃænəlɪŋ, ɪt maɪɾ əv bɪn pɑsəbəl. bʌɾ i hæd sin ə bæɾəl fɔt wɪð ðə wʌn paʊɝ, mɛn ɹɪp tə blʌd-soʊkt ʃɹɛdz ɪn ðə blɪŋk ʌv ən aɪ, ði ɝθ ɪtsɛlf blumɪŋ ɪn faɪɝ. ɑbilə wʊɾə bɪn ə bʊtʃɝz jɑɹd bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ wɝ dʌn. hi wəd nɛvɝ lʊk ɑn ðə laɪk əɡɛn, ɪf i hæɾ ɪz weɪ.

"I know," Perrin growled. He had thought of it more than once during the hours of argument. With Asha'man and Aes Sedai and Wise Ones all channeling, it might have been possible. But he had seen a battle fought with the One Power, men ripped to blood-soaked shreds in the blink of an eye, the earth itself blooming in fire. Abila would have been a butcher's yard before they were done. He would never look on the like again, if he had his way.

"wʌt dʒju θɪŋk ðɪs pɹɑfət wɪl meɪk ʌv ɪt?" ɛlaɪəs æskt.

"What do you think this Prophet will make of it?" Elyas asked.

pɛɹɪn hæd tə klɪɹ ɪz maɪn ə dəməaɪz wɛlz, ən ɑbilə lʊkɪŋ laɪk ðə fild ət dəməaɪz wɛlz, bɪfɔɹ i kəd θɪŋk ʌv wʌɾ ɛlaɪəs wɑz tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt. oʊ. haʊ hi wɑz gɑnə də ði ɪmpɑsəbəl. "aɪ doʊn kɛɹ wʌɾ i meɪks ʌv ɪt." ðə mæn wəd meɪk tʃɹʌbəl, ðət wɑz fəɹ sɝɾən ʃʊɹ.

Perrin had to clear his mind of Dumai's Wells, and Abila looking like the field at Dumai's Wells, before he could think of what Elyas was talking about. Oh. How he was going to do the impossible. "I don't care what he makes of it." The man would make trouble, that was for certain sure.

ɪɹɪɾəbli, hi ɹʌbd əɾ ɪz bɪɹd. hi niɾəd tə tʃɹɪm ɪt. tə hæv ɪt tʃɹɪmd, ɹæðɝ. ɪf i pɪkt ʌp ðə sɪzɝz, feɪl wəd teɪk əm əweɪ ən ɡɪv əm tə læmɡwɪn. ɪt stɪl simd ɪmpɑsəbəl ðət ðət hʌlkɪŋ ʃoʊldɝθʌmpɝ wɪð ɪz skɑɹd feɪs ən sʌŋkən nʌkəlz ʃəd noʊ ðə skɪlz ʌv ə bɑdaɪsɝvənt. laɪt! ə bɑdaɪsɝvənt. hi wɑz faɪndɪŋ ɪz fʊɾɪŋ wɪð feɪl ən əɹ stʃɹeɪnʒ sɑldəiən weɪz, bʌt ðə bɛɾɝ ɪz fʊɾɪŋ, ðə mɔɹ ʃi mænədʒ tə ɹʌn θɪŋz tə sut hɝsɛlf. wɪmən ɔlweɪz dɪd ðəɾ ɛniweɪ, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌt səmtaɪmz i θɔɾ i hæɾ ɪkstʃeɪnʒd wʌn sɔɹɾ ʌv wɝlwɪn fəɹ ənʌðɝ. meɪbi hi kəd tʃɹaɪ səm ə ðɪs mæstɝfəl ʃaʊɾɪŋ ʃi sim tə laɪk soʊ mʌtʃ. ə mæn ɔt tə bi eɪbəl tə pʊt sɪzɝz tə hɪz oʊn bɪɹɾ ɪf i wɑntəd. hi daʊɾɪd i wʊd, ðoʊ. ʃaʊɾɪŋ əɾ əɹ wɑz hɑɹɾ ɪnʌf wən ʃi bɪɡæn ʃaʊɾɪŋ fɝst. ful θɪŋ tə bi θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt naʊ, ɛniweɪ.

Irritably, he rubbed at his beard. He needed to trim it. To have it trimmed, rather. If he picked up the scissors, Faile would take them away and give them to Lamgwin. It still seemed impossible that that hulking shoulderthumper with his scarred face and sunken knuckles should know the skills of a bodyservant. Light! A bodyservant. He was finding his footing with Faile and her strange Saldaean ways, but the better his footing, the more she managed to run things to suit herself. Women always did that anyway, of course, but sometimes he thought he had exchanged one sort of whirlwind for another. Maybe he could try some of this masterful shouting she seemed to like so much. A man ought to be able to put scissors to his own beard if he wanted. He doubted he would, though. Shouting at her was hard enough when she began shouting first. Fool thing to be thinking about now, anyway.

hi stʌɾid ði ʌðɝz meɪkɪŋ ðɛɹ weɪ tə ðə hɔɹsəz əz i wʊɾə stʌɾid tulz i niɾəd fəɹ ə hɑɹd dʒɑb ʌv wɝk. hi wɑz əfɹeɪd mæsimə wəd meɪk ðɪs dʒɝni əz bæɾ ə dʒɑb əz i hæɾ ɛvɝ teɪkən ɑn, ən ɪz tulz wɝ fʊl ə kɹæks.

He studied the others making their way to the horses as he would have studied tools he needed for a hard job of work. He was afraid Masema would make this journey as bad a job as he had ever taken on, and his tools were full of cracks.

siɑnɪɾ ən mɑsʊɝi pɔz bɪsaɪd hɪm, ðə hʊdz ə ðɛɹ kloʊks pʊld wɛl fɔɹwɝd, pʊɾɪŋ ðɛɹ feɪsəz ɪn ʃædoʊ. ə ɹeɪzɝ-ʃɑɹp kwɪvɝɪŋ leɪs ðə feɪn sɛn ə ðɛɹ pɝfjumz, fɪɹ ʌndɝ kəntʃɹoʊl. mæsimə wʊɾə kɪld əm ɑn ðə spɑɾ ɪf i hæd hæɾ ɪz weɪ. ðə ɡɑɹdz stɪl maɪt, ɪf ɛni ɹɛkəɡnaɪzd ən ɛɛs sədaɪ feɪs. əmʌŋ ðɪs mɛni, ðəɹ hæd tə bi səm u kʊd. mɑsʊɝi wɑz ðə tɔlɝ baɪ ɔlmoʊst ə hænd, bʌt pɛɹɪn stɪl lʊk daʊn ɑn ðə tɑps ə ðɛɹ hɛdz. ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ɛlaɪəs, ðə sɪstɝz ɪkstʃeɪnʒd ɡlænsɪz ʃɛltɝd wɪðɪn ðɛɹ kaʊlz; ðən siɑnɪd spoʊk kwaɪətli.

Seonid and Masuri paused beside him, the hoods of their cloaks pulled well forward, putting their faces in shadow. A razor-sharp quivering laced the faint scent of their perfumes, fear under control. Masema would have killed them on the spot if he had had his way. The guards still might, if any recognized an Aes Sedai face. Among this many, there had to be some who could. Masuri was the taller by almost a hand, but Perrin still looked down on the tops of their heads. Ignoring Elyas, the sisters exchanged glances sheltered within their cowls; then Seonid spoke quietly.

"du jə si naʊ waɪ hi mʌs bi kɪld? ðə mæn ɪz . . . ɹæbɪd." wɛl, ðə ɡɹin wɑz sɛldəm wʌn tə mɪns wɝdz. lʌkəli, nʌn ə ðə ɡɑɹdz wɑz kloʊs ɪnʌf tə oʊvɝhɪɹ.

"Do you see now why he must be killed? The man is . . . rabid." Well, the Green was seldom one to mince words. Luckily, none of the guards was close enough to overhear.

"ju kəd tʃuz ə bɛɾɝ pleɪs tə seɪ ðæt," hi sɛd. hi dɪd nɑt wɑnə hɪɹ ði ɑɹɡjəməns əɡɛn, naʊ əɹ leɪɾɝ, bʌɾ ɪspɛʃli nɑt naʊ. ən ɪt simd i dɪd nɑɾ əv tə.

"You could choose a better place to say that," he said. He did not want to hear the arguments again, now or later, but especially not now. And it seemed he did not have to.

ɛdʒɹə ən kɛɹɛl lum bɪhaɪn ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, dɑɹk ʃɔlz ɔlɹɛɾi ɹæpt ɝaʊn ðɛɹ hɛdz. ðə bɪts ðət hʌŋ daʊn əkɹɔs tʃɛst ən bæk hɑɹdli simd ɛni pɹətɛkʃən fɹəm ðə koʊld, bʌt ðɛn, snoʊ bɑðɝd ðə waɪz wʌnz mɔɹ, dʒʌs ði ɛɡzɪstəns ə sətʃ ə θɪŋ. ðɛɹ sʌn-dɑɹk feɪsəz maɪɾ əv bɪn kɑɹv fəɹ ɔl ðeɪ ɹɪvild, jɛt ðə sɛn ə ðɛm wɑz ə stil spaɪk, ɛdʒɹəz blu aɪz, juʒəwəli soʊ kəmpoʊz ðət ðeɪ simd ɑd sɛɾ ɪn əɹ juθfəl fitʃɝz, wɝ əz hɑɹɾ əz ðət spaɪk. ʌv kɔɹs, hɝ kəmpoʊʒɝ mæsk stil. ʃɑɹp stil.

Edarra and Carelle loomed behind the Aes Sedai, dark shawls already wrapped around their heads. The bits that hung down across chest and back hardly seemed any protection from the cold, but then, snow bothered the Wise Ones more, just the existence of such a thing. Their sun-dark faces might have been carved for all they revealed, yet the scent of them was a steel spike, Edarra's blue eyes, usually so composed that they seemed odd set in her youthful features, were as hard as that spike. Of course, her composure masked steel. Sharp steel.

"ðɪs ɪz noʊ pleɪs fəɹ tɔkɪŋ," kɛɹɛl toʊl ði ɛɛs sədaɪ maɪldli, tʌkɪŋ ə stʃɹæn ə faɪɝi ɹɛd hɛɹ bɪniθ əɹ ʃɔl. əz tɔl əz mɛni mɛn, ʃi wɑz ɔlweɪz maɪld. fəɹ ə waɪz wʌn. wɪtʃ oʊnli mɛnt ʃi dɪd nɑt baɪt jəɹ noʊz ɔf wɪθaʊt ɡɪvɪŋ wɔɹnɪŋ fɝst. "ɡɛt tə jəɹ hɔɹsəz."

"This is no place for talking," Carelle told the Aes Sedai mildly, tucking a strand of fiery red hair beneath her shawl. As tall as many men, she was always mild. For a Wise One. Which only meant she did not bite your nose off without giving warning first. "Get to your horses."

ən ðə ʃɔɹɾɝ wɪmən kɝtsid tə hɝ bɹifli ən hɝid tə ðɛɹ sæɾəlz əz ɪf ðeɪ wɝ nɑɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ əɾ ɔl. ðeɪ wɝ nɑt, tə ðə waɪz wʌnz. pɛɹɪn θɔɾ i wəd nɛvɝ ɡɹoʊ əkʌstəm tə ðæt. ivən ɪf mɑsʊɝi ən siɑnɪd sim tə hæv dʌn soʊ.

And the shorter women curtsied to her briefly and hurried to their saddles as if they were not Aes Sedai at all. They were not, to the Wise Ones. Perrin thought he would never grow accustomed to that. Even if Masuri and Seonid seemed to have done so.

wɪð ə saɪ, hi swʌŋ ʌp ɑntu steɪɝ əz ðə waɪz wʌnz fɑloʊd ðɛɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ əpɹɛntəsɪz. ðə stæljən fɹɪskt ə fju stɛps æftɝ ɪz ɹɛst, bʌt pɛɹɪn bɹɔɾ ɪm ʌndɝ kəntʃɹoʊl wɪð ðə pɹɛʃɝ ə hɪz niz ən stɛɾi hænz ɑn ðə ɹeɪnz. ði il wɪmən maʊntəɾ ɔkwɝdli ivən æftɝ ɔl ðə pɹæktəs ðeɪ hæd hæd ðiz pæst wiks, ðɛɹ hɛvi skɝts pʊʃt ʌp tə bɛɹ wʊl-stɑkɪnɡd lɛɡz əbʌv ðə ni. ðeɪ əɡɹid wɪð ðə tu sɪstɝz əbaʊt mæsimə, ən soʊ dɪd ði ʌðɝ waɪz wʌnz bæk əɾ ɪz kæmp. ə faɪn bɔɪlɪŋ stu fəɹ ɛniwʌn tə kæɹi tə kɛɹhin wɪθaʊt biɪŋ skɔldɪd.

With a sigh, he swung up onto Stayer as the Wise Ones followed their Aes Sedai apprentices. The stallion frisked a few steps after his rest, but Perrin brought him under control with the pressure of his knees and steady hands on the reins. The Aiel women mounted awkwardly even after all the practice they had had these past weeks, their heavy skirts pushed up to bare wool-stockinged legs above the knee. They agreed with the two sisters about Masema, and so did the other Wise Ones back at his camp. A fine boiling stew for anyone to carry to Cairhien without being scalded.

ɡɹeɪɾi ən ɛɹæm wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi maʊntəd, ən i kəd nɑt meɪk aʊt ðɛɹ sɛns əmʌŋ ɔl ði ʌðɝz. ðəɹ wɑz lɪɾəl nid. hi hæɾ ɔlweɪz θɔt ɡɹeɪɾi lʊkt ə fɑɹmɝ dɪspaɪɾ ɪz blæk koʊɾ ən ðə sɪlvɝ sɔɹɾ ɑn ɪz kɑlɝ, bʌt nɑt naʊ. stætʃu-stɪl ɪn ɪz sæɾəl, ðə stɑki æʃəmən sɝveɪd ðə ɡɑɹdz wɪð ðə ɡɹɪm aɪz ʌv ə mæn dəsaɪɾɪŋ wɛɹ tə meɪk ðə fɝs kʌt. ən ðə sɛkənd, ən θɝd, ən haʊɛvɝ mɛni wɝ niɾəd. ɛɹæm, bɪliəs ɡɹin tɪŋkɝz kloʊk fleɪlɪŋ ðə wɪn əz i hændəld ɪz ɹeɪnz, ðə hɪlt ə hɪz sɔɹd ɹaɪzɪŋ əbʌv ɪz ʃoʊldɝ - ɛɹæmz feɪs wɑz ə mæp ʌv ɪksaɪtmən ðət meɪd pɛɹɪnz hɑɹt sɪŋk. ɪn mæsimə, ɛɹæm hæd mɛɾ ə mæn u hæd ɡɪvən ɪz laɪf ən hɑɹɾ ən soʊl tə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. ɪn ɛɹæmz vju, ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn ɹæŋkt kloʊs bɪhaɪn pɛɹɪn ən feɪl.

Grady and Aram were already mounted, and he could not make out their scents among all the others. There was little need. He had always thought Grady looked a farmer despite his black coat and the silver sword on his collar, but not now. Statue-still in his saddle, the stocky Asha'man surveyed the guards with the grim eyes of a man deciding where to make the first cut. And the second, and third, and however many were needed. Aram, bilious green Tinker's cloak flailing the wind as he handled his reins, the hilt of his sword rising above his shoulder - Aram's face was a map of excitement that made Perrin's heart sink. In Masema, Aram had met a man who had given his life and heart and soul to the Dragon Reborn. In Aram's view, the Dragon Reborn ranked close behind Perrin and Faile.

jə dɪd ðə bɔɪ noʊ feɪvɝ, ɛlaɪəs hæd toʊl pɛɹɪn. jə hɛlpt ɪm lɛt ɡoʊ ʌv wʌɾ i bɪlivd, ən naʊ ɔl hiz tə bɪliv ɪn ɪz jə ən ðət sɔɹd. ɪts nɑɾ ɪnʌf, nɑt fəɹ ɛni mæn. ɛlaɪəs hæd noʊn ɛɹæm wən ɛɹæm wɑz stɪl ə tɪŋkɝ, bɪfɔɹ i pɪkt ʌp ðə sɔɹd.

You did the boy no favor, Elyas had told Perrin. You helped him let go of what he believed, and now all he has to believe in is you and that sword. It's not enough, not for any man. Elyas had known Aram when Aram was still a Tinker, before he picked up the sword.

ə stu ðət maɪɾ əv pɔɪzən ɪn ɪt, fəɹ sʌm.

A stew that might have poison in it, for some.

ðə ɡɑɹdz maɪt ɡeɪz ət pɛɹɪn ɪn wʌndɝ, bʌt ðeɪ dɪd nɑt muv tə klɪɹ ə pæsədʒ əntɪl sʌmwʌn ʃaʊɾəd fɹəm ə wɪndoʊ ʌv ðə haʊs. ðən ðeɪ ɛdʒd əsaɪɾ ɪnʌf fəɹ ðə ɹaɪɾɝz tə liv sɪŋɡəl faɪl. ɹitʃɪŋ ðə pɹɑfət wɑz nɑɾ izi, wɪθaʊɾ ɪz pɝmɪʃən. wɪθaʊɾ ɪz pɝmɪʃən, livɪŋ ɪm wɑz ɪmpɑsəbəl.

The guards might gaze at Perrin in wonder, but they did not move to clear a passage until someone shouted from a window of the house. Then they edged aside enough for the riders to leave single file. Reaching the Prophet was not easy, without his permission. Without his permission, leaving him was impossible.

wʌns əweɪ fɹəm mæsimə ən ɪz ɡɑɹdz, pɛɹɪn sɛɾ əz fɛɹ ə peɪs əz i kəd θɹu ðə kɹaʊɾəd stʃɹits. ɑbilə hæd bɪn ə lɑɹdʒ, pɹɑspɝəs taʊn nɑt soʊ lɔŋ əɡoʊ, wɪð ɪts stoʊn mɑɹkətpleɪsɪz, ən sleɪt-ɹuf bɪldɪŋz əz tɔl əz fɔɹ stɔɹiz. ɪt wɑz stɪl lɑɹdʒ, bʌt maʊnz ə ɹʌbəl mɑɹkt wɛɹ haʊsəz ən ɪnz hæd bɪn tɔɹn daʊn. nɑɾ ən ɪn ɹɪmeɪn stændɪŋ ɪn ɑbilə, əɹ ə haʊs wɛɹ sʌmwʌn hæd bɪn sloʊ tə pɹoʊkleɪm ðə ɡlɔɹi ʌv ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. mæsiməz dɪsəpɹuvəl wɑz nɛvɝ sʌɾəl.

Once away from Masema and his guards, Perrin set as fair a pace as he could through the crowded streets. Abila had been a large, prosperous town not so long ago, with its stone marketplaces, and slate-roofed buildings as tall as four stories. It was still large, but mounds of rubble marked where houses and inns had been torn down. Not an inn remained standing in Abila, or a house where someone had been slow to proclaim the glory of the Lord Dragon Reborn. Masema's disapproval was never subtle.

ðə θɹɔŋ hɛl fju hu lʊkt əz ɪf ðeɪ lɪvd ɪn ðə taʊn, dʒɹæb foʊk ɪn dʒɹæb kloʊðz fəɹ ðə moʊs pɑɹt skʌɾəlɪŋ fɪɹfəli əlɔŋ ðə saɪdz ə ðə stʃɹit, ən noʊ tʃɪlʒɹən. noʊ dɑɡz, iðɝ; hʌŋɡɝ wɑz ə laɪkli pɹɑbləm ɪn ðɪs pleɪs, naʊ. ɛvɹiwɛɹ ɡɹups ʌv ɑɹmd mɛn stʃɹæɡəl θɹu ði æŋkəl-dip mʌk ðət hæd bɪn snoʊ læs naɪt, twɛnti hɪɹ, fɪfti ðɛɹ, nɑkɪŋ daʊn pipəl tu sloʊ tə ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ə ðɛɹ pæθ, ivən meɪkɪŋ ði ɑks-kɑɹts wɛn ɝaʊn ðɛm. ðəɹ wɝ ɔlweɪz hʌnʒɹədz ɪn saɪt. ðəɹ hæd tə bi θaʊzənz ɪn ðə taʊn. mæsiməz ɑɹmi wɑz ə ɹæbəl, bʌt ðɛɹ nʌmbɝz hæd meɪɾ ʌp fəɹ ʌðɝ læks soʊ fɑɹ. θæŋk ðə laɪt ðə mæn hæɾ əɡɹid tə bɹɪŋ əlɔŋ oʊnli ə hʌnʒɹəd. ɪt hæd teɪkən ən aʊɝz ɑɹɡjəmənt, bʌɾ i hæɾ əɡɹid. ɪn ði ɛnd, mæsiməz dɪzaɪɝ tə ɹitʃ ɹænd kwɪkli, ivən ɪf i wəd nɑt tʃɹævəl, hæd wʌn ðə pɔɪnt. fju ʌv ɪz fɑloʊɝz hæd hɔɹsəz, ən ðə mɔɹ ðət keɪm əfʊt, ðə sloʊɝ ðeɪ wəd ɡoʊ. ət list i wəɾ ɝaɪv ət pɛɹɪnz kæmp baɪ naɪtfɔl.

The throng held few who looked as if they lived in the town, drab folk in drab clothes for the most part scuttling fearfully along the sides of the street, and no children. No dogs, either; hunger was a likely problem in this place, now. Everywhere groups of armed men straggled through the ankle-deep muck that had been snow last night, twenty here, fifty there, knocking down people too slow to get out of their path, even making the ox-carts wend around them. There were always hundreds in sight. There had to be thousands in the town. Masema's army was a rabble, but their numbers had made up for other lacks so far. Thank the Light the man had agreed to bring along only a hundred. It had taken an hour's argument, but he had agreed. In the end, Masema's desire to reach Rand quickly, even if he would not Travel, had won the point. Few of his followers had horses, and the more that came afoot, the slower they would go. At least he would arrive at Perrin's camp by nightfall.

pɛɹɪn sɔ noʊ wʌn maʊntəɾ ɪksɛpt ɪz oʊn pɑɹɾi, ən ðeɪ dʒɹu stɛɹz fɹəm ði ɑɹmd mɛn, stoʊni stɛɹz, fivɝd stɛɹz. faɪnli dʒɹɛs foʊk keɪm tə ðə pɹɑfəɾ ɔfən ɪnʌf, noʊbəlz ən mɝtʃəns hoʊpɪŋ ə səbmɪʃən ɪn pɝsən wəd ɡeɪn mɔɹ blɛsɪŋz ən fjuɝ pɛnəltiz, bʌt ðeɪ juʒəwəli dɪpɑɹɾəd əfʊt. ðɛɹ weɪ wɑz ʌnɪmpiɾɪd, haʊɛvɝ, əsaɪd fɹəm ðə nəsɛsəɾi ʌv ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɝaʊn ðə klʌmps ə mæsiməz fɑloʊɝz. ɪf ðeɪ lɛf maʊntəd, ɪt mʌs bi baɪ mæsiməz wɪl. ivən soʊ, pɛɹɪn hæd noʊ nid tə tɛl ɛniwʌn tə steɪ kloʊs. ðəɹ wɑz ə fil ʌv weɪɾɪŋ ɪn ɑbilə, ən noʊ wʌn wɪð hæf ə bɹeɪn wəd wɑnə bi nɪɹ wən ðə weɪɾɪŋ ɛndəd.

Perrin saw no one mounted except his own party, and they drew stares from the armed men, stony stares, fevered stares. Finely dressed folk came to the Prophet often enough, nobles and merchants hoping a submission in person would gain more blessings and fewer penalties, but they usually departed afoot. Their way was unimpeded, however, aside from the necessity of riding around the clumps of Masema's followers. If they left mounted, it must be by Masema's will.
