Even so, Perrin had no need to tell anyone to stay close. There was a feel of waiting in Abila, and no one with half a brain would want to be near when the waiting ended.

ɪt wɑz ə ɹɪlif wən beɪlwɝ niɾ ɪz hæmɝ-noʊzd ɡɛldɪŋ aʊɾ ʌv ə saɪd stʃɹit dʒʌst ʃɔɹɾ ə ðə loʊ wʊɾən bɹɪdʒ ðət lɛɾ aʊɾ ə taʊn, ɔlmoʊst əz ɡɹeɪɾ əz ðə ɹɪlif i fɛlt wən ðeɪ hæd kɹɔs ðə bɹɪdʒ ən pæs ðə læst ɡɑɹdz. ðə pɪntʃ-feɪs lɪɾəl mæn, ɔl nɑbi dʒɔɪns ən wɪð ɪz pleɪn bɹaʊn koʊt mɔɹ hæŋɪŋ ɑn ɪm ðən wɔɹn, kəd lʊk æftɝ hɪmsɛlf ɪn spaɪɾ ʌv əpɪɹənsəz, bʌt feɪl wɑz sɛɾɪŋ ʌp ə pɹɑpɝ haʊshoʊl fəɹ ə noʊbəlwʊmən, ən ʃi wəd bi mɔɹ ðən dɪsplizd ɪf pɛɹɪn lɛɾ ɛni hɑɹm kʌm tə hɝ sɛkɹətɛɹi. hɝz, ən pɛɹɪnz. pɛɹɪn wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ haʊ hi fɛlt əbaʊt hævɪŋ ə sɛkɹətɛɹi, jɛt ðə fɛloʊ pəzɛst skɪlz bɪɑn ɹaɪɾɪŋ ə faɪn hænd. wɪtʃ i dɛmənstʃɹeɪɾəd əz sun əz ðeɪ wɝ klɪɹ ə ðə taʊn, wɪð loʊ, fɔɹəstəd hɪlz ɔl ɝaʊnd. moʊst ə ðə bɹæntʃəz wɝ stɑɹk ən bɛɹ, ən ðoʊz ðət ɹɪteɪn lif əɹ niɾəl splæʃt ə vɪvəd ɡɹin əɡɛns ðə waɪt. ðeɪ hæd ðə ɹoʊd tə ðɛmsɛlvz, bʌt snoʊ fɹoʊzən ɪn ɹʌts kɛp ðɛɹ ɹaɪɾɪŋ sloʊ.

It was a relief when Balwer kneed his hammer-nosed gelding out of a side street just short of the low wooden bridge that led out of town, almost as great as the relief he felt when they had crossed the bridge and passed the last guards. The pinch-faced little man, all knobby joints and with his plain brown coat more hanging on him than worn, could look after himself in spite of appearances, but Faile was setting up a proper household for a noblewoman, and she would be more than displeased if Perrin let any harm come to her secretary. Hers, and Perrin's. Perrin was not sure how he felt about having a secretary, yet the fellow possessed skills beyond writing a fine hand. Which he demonstrated as soon as they were clear of the town, with low, forested hills all around. Most of the branches were stark and bare, and those that retained leaf or needle splashed a vivid green against the white. They had the road to themselves, but snow frozen in ruts kept their riding slow.

"fɝɡɪv mi, maɪ lɔɹd pɛɹɪn," beɪlwɝ mɝmɝd, linɪŋ ɪn ɪz sæɾəl tə pɪɹ pæst ɛlaɪəs, "bʌɾ aɪ hæpən tə oʊvɝhɪɹ sʌmθɪŋ bæk ðəɹ jə maɪt faɪn ʌv ɪntʃɹəst." hi kɔf dɪskɹitli ɪndə hɪz ɡlʌv, ðən hɝidli ɹikæptʃɝɾ ɪz kloʊk ən pʊld ɪt kloʊs.

"Forgive me, my Lord Perrin," Balwer murmured, leaning in his saddle to peer past Elyas, "but I happened to overhear something back there you might find of interest." He coughed discreetly into his glove, then hurriedly recaptured his cloak and pulled it close.

ɛlaɪəs ən ɛɹæm hɑɹdli niɾəd pɛɹɪnz dʒɛstʃɝ tə fɔl bæk wɪð ði ʌðɝz. ɛvɹiwʌn wɑz əkʌstəm tə ðə dʒɹaɪ lɪɾəl mænz dɪzaɪɝ fəɹ pɹaɪvəsi. waɪ hi wɑntəd tə pɹitɛn ðət noʊ wʌn ɛls nu hi fɛɹəɾəd aʊɾ ɪnfɝmeɪʃən əɾ ɛvɹi taʊn əɹ vɪlədʒ ðeɪ pæst, pɛɹɪn kəd nɑt bɪɡɪn tə ɡɛs. hi hæd tə noʊ ðət pɛɹɪn dɪskʌst wʌɾ i lɝnd wɪð feɪl, ən ɛlaɪəs. ɪn ɛni keɪs, hi wɑz vɛɹi ɡʊɾ ət fɛɹəɾɪŋ.

Elyas and Aram hardly needed Perrin's gesture to fall back with the others. Everyone was accustomed to the dry little man's desire for privacy. Why he wanted to pretend that no one else knew he ferreted out information at every town or village they passed, Perrin could not begin to guess. He had to know that Perrin discussed what he learned with Faile, and Elyas. In any case, he was very good at ferreting.

beɪlwɝ tɪltəɾ ɪz hɛd tə wʌn saɪd tə wɑtʃ pɛɹɪn əz ðeɪ ɹoʊd saɪd baɪ saɪd. "aɪ hæv tu pisəz ə nuz, maɪ lɔɹd, wʌn aɪ bɪliv ɪmpɔɹɾənt, ən wʌn ɝdʒənt." ɝdʒən əɹ nɑt, ivən ðə fɛloʊz vɔɪs saʊndəd dʒɹaɪ, laɪk dɛd livz ɹʌslɪŋ.

Balwer tilted his head to one side to watch Perrin as they rode side by side. "I have two pieces of news, my Lord, one I believe important, and one urgent." Urgent or not, even the fellow's voice sounded dry, like dead leaves rustling.

"haʊ ɝdʒənt?" pɛɹɪn meɪɾ ə weɪdʒɝ wɪð hɪmsɛlf oʊvɝ u ðə fɝs pis ə nuz wəd bi əbaʊt.

"How urgent?" Perrin made a wager with himself over who the first piece of news would be about.

"vɛɹi, pɝhæps, maɪ lɔɹd. kɪŋ eɪlɹən əz bɹɔt ðə sintʃæn tə bæɾəl nɪɹ ðə taʊn ə dʒɹəməl, əpɹɑksəmətli wʌn hʌnʒɹəd maɪlz wɛst ə hɪɹ. ðɪs wɑz əbaʊt tɛn deɪz əɡoʊ." beɪlwɝz maʊθ pɝs moʊməntɛɹəli ɪn ɪɹɪteɪʃən. hi dɪslaɪkt ɪmpɹsɪʒən; hi dɪslaɪk nɑt noʊɪŋ. "ɹɪlaɪəbəl ɪnfɝmeɪʃən ɪz skɛɹs, bʌt wɪθaʊt daʊt, ði ɑmɑdɪʃən ɑɹmi ɪz dɛd, kæptɪv əɹ skæɾɝd. aɪ wəd bi vɛɹi sɝpɹaɪzd ɪf mɔɹ ðən ə hʌnʒɹəd ɹɪmeɪn təɡɛðɝ ɛniwɛɹ, ən ðoʊz wɪl teɪk tə bændətʃɹi sun ɪnʌf. eɪlɹən hɪmsɛlf wɑz teɪkən, əlɔŋ wɪð ɪz ɪntaɪɝ kɔɹt. ɑmɑdɪʃiə noʊ lɔŋɡɝ əz ɛni noʊbɪləɾi, nɑt tə əmaʊn tə ɛniθɪŋ."

"Very, perhaps, my Lord. King Ailron has brought the Seanchan to battle near the town of Jeramel, approximately one hundred miles west of here. This was about ten days ago." Balwer's mouth pursed momentarily in irritation. He disliked imprecision; he disliked not knowing. "Reliable information is scarce, but without doubt, the Amadician army is dead, captive or scattered. I would be very surprised if more than a hundred remain together anywhere, and those will take to banditry soon enough. Ailron himself was taken, along with his entire court. Amadicia no longer has any nobility, not to amount to anything."

mɛntəli, pɛɹɪn mɑɹk ðə weɪdʒɝ lɔst. juʒəwəli, beɪlwɝ bɪɡæn wɪð nuz ə ðə waɪtkloʊks. "ə pɪɾi fəɹ ɑmɑdɪʃiə, aɪ səpoʊz. fəɹ ðə pipəl kæptʃɝd, ɛniweɪ." əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə beɪlwɝ, ðə sintʃæn hæɾ ə hɑɹʃ weɪ wɪð ðoʊz kæptʃɝɾ ʌndɝ ɑɹmz əpoʊzɪŋ ðɛm. soʊ ɑmɑdɪʃiə hæd noʊ ɑɹmi lɛft, ən noʊ noʊbəlz tə ɹeɪz əɹ lɛɾ ənʌðɝ. nʌθɪŋ tə stɑp ðə sintʃæn spɹɛɾɪŋ əz fæst əz ðeɪ wɪʃt, ðoʊ ðeɪ sim tə spɹɛd vɛɹi kwɪkli ivən wən ðəɹ wɑz ɑpəzɪʃən. bɛst ɪf i ɹoʊɾ ist əz sun əz mæsimə ɹitʃt ðə kæmp, ən ðən muvd əz fæst əz i kəd fəɹ əz lɔŋ əz ðə mɛn ən hɔɹsəz kəd səsteɪn ɪt.

Mentally, Perrin marked the wager lost. Usually, Balwer began with news of the Whitecloaks. "A pity for Amadicia, I suppose. For the people captured, anyway." According to Balwer, the Seanchan had a harsh way with those captured under arms opposing them. So Amadicia had no army left, and no nobles to raise or lead another. Nothing to stop the Seanchan spreading as fast as they wished, though they seemed to spread very quickly even when there was opposition. Best if he rode east as soon as Masema reached the camp, and then moved as fast as he could for as long as the men and horses could sustain it.

hi sɛɾ əz mʌtʃ, ən beɪlwɝ nɑɾəd, wɪð ə θɪn smaɪl ʌv əpɹuvəl. ðə mæn əpɹiʃieɪɾɪd ɪt wən pɛɹɪn sɔ ðə vælju ʌv wʌɾ i ɹipɔɹɾəd.

He said as much, and Balwer nodded, with a thin smile of approval. The man appreciated it when Perrin saw the value of what he reported.

"wʌn ʌðɝ pɔɪnt, maɪ lɔɹd," hi wɛn ɑn. "ðə waɪtkloʊks tʊk pɑɹɾ ɪn ðə bæɾəl, bʌɾ əpɛɹənli vɑldə mænədʒ tə ɡɛt moʊst ə ðɛm ɔf ðə fild ət ði ɛnd. hiz ðə dɑɹk wʌnz oʊn lʌk. noʊ wʌn simz tə noʊ wɛɹ ðeɪv ɡɔn. əɹ ɹæðɝ, ɛvɹi tʌŋ ɡɪvz ə dɪfɹən dɝɛkʃən. ɪf aɪ meɪ seɪ soʊ, aɪ feɪvɝ ist. əweɪ fɹəm ðə sintʃæn." ən təwɔɹɾ ɑbilə, ʌv kɔɹs.

"One other point, my Lord," he went on. "The Whitecloaks took part in the battle, but apparently Valda managed to get most of them off the field at the end. He has the Dark One's own luck. No one seems to know where they have gone. Or rather, every tongue gives a different direction. If I may say so, I favor east. Away from the Seanchan." And toward Abila, of course.

ðə weɪdʒɝ wɑz nɑɾ ə lɔs, ðɛn. ðoʊ ðə mæn hæd nɑt bɪɡʌn wɪð ɪt. ə dʒɹɔ, meɪbi. fɑɹ əhɛd, ə hɔk sɔɹd haɪ ɪn ðə klaʊdləs skaɪ, hɛɾɪŋ nɔɹθ. ɪt wəd ɹitʃ ðə kæmp lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ i wʊd. pɛɹɪn kəd ɹikɔl ə taɪm wən i hæd hæɾ əz fju kənsɝnz əz ðət hɔk. kəmpɛɹd tə naʊ, ət list. ɪt hæd bɪn ə vɛɹi lɔŋ taɪm əɡoʊ.

The wager was not a loss, then. Though the man had not begun with it. A draw, maybe. Far ahead, a hawk soared high in the cloudless sky, heading north. It would reach the camp long before he would. Perrin could recall a time when he had had as few concerns as that hawk. Compared to now, at least. It had been a very long time ago.

"aɪ səspɛk ðə waɪtkloʊks ɑɹ mɔɹ ɪntʃɹəstəɾ ɪn əvɔɪɾɪŋ ðə sintʃæn ðən ɪn bɑðɝɪŋ ʌs, beɪlwɝ. ɛniweɪ, aɪ kæn muv ɛni fæstɝ fəɹ əm ðən fəɹ ðə sintʃæn. wɝ ðeɪ ðə sɛkən pis ə nuz?"

"I suspect the Whitecloaks are more interested in avoiding the Seanchan than in bothering us, Balwer. Anyway, I can't move any faster for them than for the Seanchan. Were they the second piece of news?"

"noʊ, maɪ lɔɹd. sɪmpli ə pɔɪn ʌv ɪntʃɹəst." beɪlwɝ sim tə heɪt ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt, moʊst ɪspɛʃli vɑldə - ə mæɾɝ ə ɹʌf tʃɹitmən sʌmwɛɹ ɪn ɪz pæst, pɛɹɪn səspɛktəd - bʌt laɪk ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɛls əbaʊt ðə mæn, ɪt wɑz ə dʒɹaɪ, koʊl heɪt. pæʃənləs. "ðə sɛkənd nuz ɪz ðət ðə sintʃæn əv fɔɾ ənʌðɝ bæɾəl, ðɪs ɪn sʌðɝn ɔltɑɹə. əɡɛnst ɛɛs sədaɪ, pɑsəbli, ðoʊ səm mɛnʃən mɛn tʃænəlɪŋ." hæf tɝnɪŋ ɪn ɪz sæɾəl, beɪlwɝ lʊk bæk ət ɡɹeɪɾi ən nild ɪn ðɛɹ blæk koʊts. ɡɹeɪɾi wɑz ɪn kɑnvɝseɪʃən wɪð ɛlaɪəs, ən nild wɪð ɛɹæm, bʌt boʊθ æʃəmən əpɪɹd tə bi kipɪŋ əz kloʊz ən aɪ ɑn ðə fɔɹəsts əz dɪd ðə wɔɹɾɝz bɹɪŋɪŋ ʌp ðə ɹɪɹ. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ən ðə waɪz wʌnz wɝ tɔkɪŋ ɪn loʊ vɔɪsəz, tu. "huɛvɝ ðeɪ fɔt, maɪ lɔɹd, ɪts klɪɹ ðət ðə sintʃæn lɔst ən wɝ sɛn ɹilɪŋ bæk ɪndə ɛbu dɑɹ."

"No, my Lord. Simply a point of interest." Balwer seemed to hate the Children of the Light, most especially Valda - a matter of rough treatment somewhere in his past, Perrin suspected - but like everything else about the man, it was a dry, cold hate. Passionless. "The second news is that the Seanchan have fought another battle, this in southern Altara. Against Aes Sedai, possibly, though some mentioned men channeling." Half turning in his saddle, Balwer looked back at Grady and Neald in their black coats. Grady was in conversation with Elyas, and Neald with Aram, but both Asha'man appeared to be keeping as close an eye on the forests as did the Warders bringing up the rear. The Aes Sedai and the Wise Ones were talking in low voices, too. "Whoever they fought, my Lord, it is clear that the Seanchan lost and were sent reeling back into Ebou Dar."

"ɡʊd nuz," pɛɹɪn sɛd flætli. dəməaɪz wɛlz flæʃt ɪndə hɪz hɛɾ əɡɛn, stʃɹɔŋɝ ðən bɪfɔɹ. fəɹ ə moʊmənt, hi wɑz bæk-tə-bæk wɪð lɔɪəl əɡɛn, faɪɾɪŋ dɛspɝətli, ʃʊɹ ðəɾ ɛvɹi bɹɛθ wəd bi hɪz læst. fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm ðət deɪ, hi ʃɪvɝd. ət list ɹænd nu əbaʊt ðə sintʃæn. ət list i dɪd nɑɾ əv tə wɝi əbaʊt ðæt.

"Good news," Perrin said flatly. Dumai's Wells flashed into his head again, stronger than before. For a moment, he was back-to-back with Loial again, fighting desperately, sure that every breath would be his last. For the first time that day, he shivered. At least Rand knew about the Seanchan. At least he did not have to worry about that.

hi bɪkeɪm əwɛɹ ə beɪlwɝ aɪɪŋ hɪm. kənsɪɾɝɪŋ hɪm, laɪk ə bɝd kənsɪɾɝɪŋ ə stʃɹeɪnʒ ɪnsɛkt. hi hæd sin ɪm ʃɪvɝ. ðə lɪɾəl mæn laɪk tə noʊ ɛvɹiθɪŋ, bʌt ðəɹ wɝ səm sikɹəts noʊ wʌn wəɾ ɛvɝ noʊ.

He became aware of Balwer eyeing him. Considering him, like a bird considering a strange insect. He had seen him shiver. The little man liked to know everything, but there were some secrets no one would ever know.

pɛɹɪnz aɪz ɹɪtɝn tə ðə hɔk, bɛɹli vɪzəbəl naʊ ivən tə hɪm. ɪt meɪɾ ɪm θɪŋk ə feɪl, hɪz fɪɹs fælkən ʌv ə waɪf. hɪz bjuɾəfəl fælkən ʌv ə waɪf. hi pʊt sintʃæn ən waɪtkloʊks ən bæɾəl ən ivən mæsimə aʊɾ ə hɪz maɪnd. fəɹ ðə taɪm, ət list.

Perrin's eyes returned to the hawk, barely visible now even to him. It made him think of Faile, his fierce falcon of a wife. His beautiful falcon of a wife. He put Seanchan and Whitecloaks and battle and even Masema out of his mind. For the time, at least.

"lɛts pɪk ʌp ðə peɪs ə lɪɾəl," hi kɔl bæk tə ði ʌðɝz. ðə hɔk maɪt si feɪl bɪfɔɹ i dɪd, bʌɾ ənlaɪk ðə bɝd, hi wəd bi siɪŋ ðə lʌv ə hɪz hɑɹt. ən tədeɪ, hi wəd nɑt ʃaʊɾ əɾ əɹ noʊ mæɾɝ wʌt ʃi dɪd.

"Let's pick up the pace a little," he called back to the others. The hawk might see Faile before he did, but unlike the bird, he would be seeing the love of his heart. And today, he would not shout at her no matter what she did.


tʃæptɝ tu


CHAPTER 2

teɪkən


Taken

ðə hɔk sun pæst aʊɾ ə saɪt, ən ðə ɹoʊd ɹɪmeɪn ɛmpti ʌv ʌðɝ tʃɹævəlɝz, bʌt pɹɛs əz pɛɹɪn wʊd, fɹoʊzən ɹʌts ɹɛɾi tə bɹeɪk ə hɔɹsəz lɛɡ ən ə ɹaɪɾɝz nɛk əlaʊd noʊ ɡɹeɪt spid. ðə wɪn kæɹiɾ aɪs, ən ə pɹɑməs ə snoʊ əɡɛn təmɑɹoʊ. ɪt wɑz mɪdæftɝnun baɪ ðə taɪm i tɝn ɔf θɹu ðə tʃɹiz ɪndə waɪt dʒɹɪfs ðət wɝ ni-dip ɑn ðə hɔɹsəz ɪn pleɪsəz, ən kʌvɝd ðə læs maɪl tə ðə fɔɹəs kæmp wɛɹ i hæd lɛf ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn ən ði il, ðə minɝz ən ɡildænɪn. ən feɪl. nʌθɪŋ ðəɹ wɑz əz i ɪkspɛktəd.

The hawk soon passed out of sight, and the road remained empty of other travelers, but press as Perrin would, frozen ruts ready to break a horse's leg and a rider's neck allowed no great speed. The wind carried ice, and a promise of snow again tomorrow. It was midafternoon by the time he turned off through the trees into white drifts that were knee-deep on the horses in places, and covered the last mile to the forest camp where he had left the Two Rivers men and the Aiel, the Mayeners and Ghealdanin. And Faile. Nothing there was as he expected.

əz ɔlweɪz, ðəɹ wɝ fɔɹ kæmps speɪst aʊɾ əmʌŋ ðə tʃɹiz, ɪn tʃɹuθ, bʌt ðə wɪŋd ɡɑɹdz' smoʊkɪŋ kæmpfaɪɝz stʊɾ əbændən ɝaʊn bɹəleɪnz stʃɹaɪp tɛns, əmɪɾ oʊvɝtɝn kɛɾəlz ən bɪts ʌv ɡɪɹ dʒɹɑpt ɑn ðə snoʊ, ən ðə seɪm saɪnz ə heɪs dɑɾəd ðə tʃɹæmpəld ɡɹaʊnd wɛɹ æliændɝz soʊlʒɝz hæd bɪn sɛɾ ʌp wən i lɛf ðət mɔɹnɪŋ. ði oʊnli ɛvəɾəns ə laɪf ɪn iðɝ pleɪs wɑz ðə hɔɹs hænlɝz ən fɛɹiɝz ən kɑɹt dʒɹaɪvɝz, bʌndəld ɪn wʊlənz ən hʌɾəld ɪn klʌmps ɝaʊn ðə hɔɹslaɪnz ən haɪ-wil səplaɪ kɑɹts. ðeɪ wɝ ɔl stɛɹɪŋ təwɔɹd wʌt kɑɾ ɪz aɪ ən hɛld ɪt.

As always, there were four camps spaced out among the trees, in truth, but the Winged Guards' smoking campfires stood abandoned around Berelain's striped tents, amid overturned kettles and bits of gear dropped on the snow, and the same signs of haste dotted the trampled ground where Alliandre's soldiers had been set up when he left that morning. The only evidence of life in either place was the horse handlers and farriers and cart drivers, bundled in woolens and huddled in clumps around the horselines and high-wheeled supply carts. They were all staring toward what caught his eye and held it.

faɪv hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz fɹəm ðə ɹɑki, flæt-tɑp hɪl wɛɹ ðə waɪz wʌnz hæd pleɪs ðɛɹ loʊ tɛns, ðə ɡɹeɪ-koʊɾəd minɝz wɝ dʒɹɔn ʌp, ɔl naɪn hʌnʒɹəd əɹ soʊ ʌv ðɛm, hɔɹsəz stæmpɪŋ ɪmpeɪʃənli, ɹɛd kloʊks ən ðə lɔŋ ɹɛd stʃɹimɝz ɑn ðɛɹ lænsɪz ɹɪpəlɪŋ ɪn ðə koʊl bɹiz. nɪɹɝ ðə hɪl ən ɔf tə wʌn saɪd, dʒʌst ət ðə nɪɹ bæŋk ʌv ə fɹoʊzən stʃɹim, ðə ɡildænɪn meɪɾ ə blɑk ə lænsɪz dʒʌst əz lɑɹdʒ, ðiz wɪð ɡɹin stʃɹimɝz. ðə maʊntəd soʊlʒɝz' ɡɹin koʊts ən ɑɹmɝ əpɪɹd dʒɹæb kəmpɛɹd wɪð ðə minɝz' ɹɛd hɛlməts ən bɹɛstpleɪts, bʌt ðɛɹ ɔfəsɝz spɑɹkəld ɪn sɪlvɝɾ ɑɹmɝ ən skɑɹlət koʊts ən kloʊks, wɪð ɹeɪnz ən sæɾələkloʊθs fɹɪn ɪn kɹɪmzən. ə bɹeɪv ʃoʊ, fəɹ mɛn ɑn pɝeɪd, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ nɑt pɝeɪɾɪŋ. ðə wɪŋd ɡɑɹdz feɪs təwɔɹd ðə ɡildænɪn, ðə ɡildænɪn təwɔɹd ðə hɪl. ən ðə kɹɛst ə ðə hɪl wɑz ɹɪŋ baɪ tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn, lɔŋboʊz ɪn hænd. noʊ wʌn hæd dʒɹɔn, jɛt, bʌɾ ɛvɹi mæn hæɾ ə ʃæf nɑkt ən ɹɛɾi. ɪt wɑz mædnəs.

Five hundred paces from the rocky, flat-topped hill where the Wise Ones had placed their low tents, the gray-coated Mayeners were drawn up, all nine hundred or so of them, horses stamping impatiently, red cloaks and the long red streamers on their lances rippling in the cold breeze. Nearer the hill and off to one side, just at the near bank of a frozen stream, the Ghealdanin made a block of lances just as large, these with green streamers. The mounted soldiers' green coats and armor appeared drab compared with the Mayeners' red helmets and breastplates, but their officers sparkled in silvered armor and scarlet coats and cloaks, with reins and saddlecloths fringed in crimson. A brave show, for men on parade, but they were not parading. The Winged Guards faced toward the Ghealdanin, the Ghealdanin toward the hill. And the crest of the hill was ringed by Two Rivers men, longbows in hand. No one had drawn, yet, but every man had a shaft nocked and ready. It was madness.

buɾɪŋ steɪɝ tə əz nɪɹ ə ɡæləp əz ðə beɪ kəd mænədʒ, pɛɹɪn plaʊd θɹu ðə snoʊ, fɑloʊd baɪ ði ʌðɝz, əntɪl i ɹitʃt ðə hɛɾ ə ðə ɡildænɪn fɔɹmeɪʃən. bɹəleɪn wɑz ðɛɹ, ɪn ə fɝ-tʃɹɪmd ɹɛd kloʊk, ən ɡælɛn, ðə wʌn-aɪd kæptən ə hɝ wɪŋd ɡɑɹdz, ən ənʊɹə, hɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ ædvaɪzɝ, ɔl əpɛɹənli ɑɹɡjuɪŋ wɪð æliændɝz fɝs kæptən, ə ʃɔɹt, hɑɹd-bɪɾən fɛloʊ neɪm dʒɝɑɹɾ ɑɹɡændə, hu wɑz ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛd soʊ hɑɹd ðə fæt waɪt plumz kwɪvɝɾ ɑn ɪz ɡlimɪŋ hɛlmət. ðə fɝst ə min lʊkt ɹɛɾi tə baɪɾ aɪɝn, vɛkseɪʃən ʃoʊd θɹu ənʊɹəz ɛɛs sədaɪ kɑm, ən ɡælɛn wɑz fɪŋɡɝɪŋ ðə ɹɛd-plum hɛlmət hæŋɪŋ əɾ ɪz sæɾəl əz ðoʊ dəsaɪɾɪŋ wɛðɝ tə dɑn ɪt. ət ðə saɪɾ ə pɛɹɪn, ðeɪ bɹoʊk ɔf ən tɝn ðɛɹ maʊns təwɔɹd hɪm. bɹəleɪn sæɾ əɹ sæɾəl ɪɹɛkt, bʌɾ əɹ blæk hɛɹ wɑz wɪnbloʊn, ən əɹ faɪn-æŋkəld waɪt mɛɹ wɑz ʃɪvɝɪŋ, ðə læðɝ ʌv ə hɑɹd ɹʌn fɹizɪŋ ɑn əɹ flæŋks.

Booting Stayer to as near a gallop as the bay could manage, Perrin plowed through the snow, followed by the others, until he reached the head of the Ghealdanin formation. Berelain was there, in a fur-trimmed red cloak, and Gallenne, the one-eyed Captain of her Winged Guards, and Annoura, her Aes Sedai advisor, all apparently arguing with Alliandre's First Captain, a short, hard-bitten fellow named Gerard Arganda, who was shaking his head so hard the fat white plumes quivered on his gleaming helmet. The First of Mayene looked ready to bite iron, vexation showed through Annoura's Aes Sedai calm, and Gallenne was fingering the red-plumed helmet hanging at his saddle as though deciding whether to don it. At the sight of Perrin, they broke off and turned their mounts toward him. Berelain sat her saddle erect, but her black hair was windblown, and her fine-ankled white mare was shivering, the lather of a hard run freezing on her flanks.

wɪð soʊ mɛni pipəl əbaʊt, ɪt wɑz ɔl bʌɾ ɪmpɑsəbəl tə meɪk aʊɾ ɪndəvɪdʒəwəl sɛns, bʌt pɛɹɪn dɪd nɑt niɾ ɪz noʊz tə ɹɛkəɡnaɪz tʃɹʌbəl hæŋɪŋ baɪ ə hɛɹ. bɪfɔɹ i kəd dɪmæn tə noʊ wʌɾ ɪn ðə laɪt ðeɪ θɔt ðeɪ wɝ duɪŋ, bɹəleɪn spoʊk wɪð ə pɔɹsələn-feɪs fɔɹmæləɾi ðət meɪɾ ɪm blɪŋk ət fɝst.

With so many people about, it was all but impossible to make out individual scents, but Perrin did not need his nose to recognize trouble hanging by a hair. Before he could demand to know what in the Light they thought they were doing, Berelain spoke with a porcelain-faced formality that made him blink at first.

"lɔɹd pɛɹɪn, jəɹ leɪɾi waɪf ən aɪ wɝ hʌntɪŋ wɪð kwin æliændɝ wən wi wɝ ətæk baɪ il. aɪ mænədʒ tə ɪskeɪp. noʊ wʌn ɛls ɪn ðə pɑɹɾi hæz ɹɪtɝnd, jɛt, ðoʊ ɪt meɪ bi ði il tʊk pɹɪznɝz. aɪ hæv sɛn ə skwɑɾ ə lænsɝz tə skaʊt. wi wɝ əbaʊt tɛn maɪlz tə ðə saʊθist, soʊ ðeɪ ʃəd ɹɪtɝn wɪð nuz baɪ naɪtfɔl."

"Lord Perrin, your Lady wife and I were hunting with Queen Alliandre when we were attacked by Aiel. I managed to escape. No one else in the party has returned, yet, though it may be the Aiel took prisoners. I have sent a squad of lancers to scout. We were about ten miles to the southeast, so they should return with news by nightfall."

"feɪl wɑz kæptʃɝd?" pɛɹɪn sɛd θɪkli. ivən bɪfɔɹ kɹɔsɪŋ ɪndə ɑmɑdɪʃiə fɹəm ɡildən ðeɪ hæd hɝɾ ʌv il bɝnɪŋ ən luɾɪŋ, bʌɾ ɪt hæɾ ɔlweɪz bɪn sʌmwɛɹ ɛls, ðə nɛks vɪlədʒ oʊvɝ əɹ ðə wʌn bɪɑn ðæt, ɪf nɑt fɑɹðɝ. nɛvɝ kloʊs ɪnʌf tə wɝi əbaʊt, əɹ tə bi ʃʊɹ ðeɪ wɝ mɔɹ ðən ɹumɝ. nɑt wən i hæd ɹænd blʌɾi ælθɹz ɔɹɾɝz tə kæɹi aʊt! ən lʊk wʌɾ ɪt hæd kɑst.

"Faile was captured?" Perrin said thickly. Even before crossing into Amadicia from Ghealdan they had heard of Aiel burning and looting, but it had always been somewhere else, the next village over or the one beyond that, if not farther. Never close enough to worry about, or to be sure they were more than rumor. Not when he had Rand bloody al'Thor's orders to carry out! And look what it had cost.

"waɪ ɑɹ jə ɔl stɪl hɪɹ?" hi dɪmændəɾ əlaʊd. "waɪ ɑɹən jə ɔl sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ hɝ?" hi ɹilaɪzd i wɑz ʃaʊɾɪŋ. hi wɑntəd tə haʊl, tə sævədʒ ðɛm. "bɝn jə ɔl, wʌɾ ɑɹ jə weɪɾɪŋ fɔɹ?" ðə lɛvlnəs ə hɝ ɹɪplaɪ, əz ɪf ɹipɔɹɾɪŋ haʊ mʌtʃ fɑɾɝ wɑz lɛft fəɹ ðə hɔɹsəz, pʊʃt niɾəlz ə ɹeɪdʒ ɪndə hɪz hɛd. ðə mɔɹ soʊ kəz ʃi wɑz ɹaɪt.

"Why are you all still here?" he demanded aloud. "Why aren't you all searching for her?" He realized he was shouting. He wanted to howl, to savage them. "Burn you all, what are you waiting for?" The levelness of her reply, as if reporting how much fodder was left for the horses, pushed needles of rage into his head. The more so because she was right.

"wi wɝ æmbʊʃt baɪ tu əɹ θɹi hʌnʒɹəd, lɔɹd pɛɹɪn, bʌt jə noʊ əz wɛl əz aɪ, fɹəm wʌt wɪv hɝd ðəɹ izəli kəd bi ə dʌzən əɹ mɔɹ sətʃ bænz ɹoʊmɪŋ ðə kʌntʃɹisaɪd. ɪf wi pɝsu ɪn fɔɹs, wi meɪ faɪn ə bæɾəl ðət wɪl kɑst əs hɛvəli, əɡɛnst il, wɪθaʊɾ ivən noʊɪŋ wɛðɝ ðeɪ ɑɹ ðə wʌnz u hoʊl jəɹ leɪɾi waɪf. əɹ ivən ɪf ʃi stɪl laɪvz. wi mʌs noʊ ðət fɝst, lɔɹd pɛɹɪn, əɹ ðə ɹɛst ɪz wɝs ðən jusləs."

"We were ambushed by two or three hundred, Lord Perrin, but you know as well as I, from what we have heard there easily could be a dozen or more such bands roaming the countryside. If we pursue in force, we may find a battle that will cost us heavily, against Aiel, without even knowing whether they are the ones who hold your Lady wife. Or even if she still lives. We must know that first, Lord Perrin, or the rest is worse than useless."

ɪf ʃi stɪl lɪvd. hi ʃɪvɝd; ðə koʊld wɑz ɪnsaɪd hɪm, sʌɾənli. ɪn ɪz boʊnz. hɪz hɑɹt. ʃi hæd tə bi əlaɪv. ʃi hæd tə bi. oʊ, laɪt, hi ʃʊɾə lɛɾ əɹ kʌm tə ɑbilə wɪð hɪm. ənʊɹəz waɪd-maʊð feɪs wɑz ə mæsk ə sɪmpəθi fɹeɪm baɪ θɪn tæɹɑbənɝ bɹeɪdz. sʌɾənli hi bɪkeɪm əwɛɹ ə peɪn ɪn ɪz hænz, kɹæmpɪŋ ɑn ðə ɹeɪnz. hi fɔɹst əm tə lusən ðɛɹ ɡɹɪp, flɛkst ɪz fɪŋɡɝz ɪnsaɪɾ ɪz ɡɔnləts.

If she still lived. He shivered; the cold was inside him, suddenly. In his bones. His heart. She had to be alive. She had to be. Oh, Light, he should have let her come to Abila with him. Annoura's wide-mouthed face was a mask of sympathy framed by thin Taraboner braids. Suddenly he became aware of pain in his hands, cramping on the reins. He forced them to loosen their grip, flexed his fingers inside his gauntlets.

"ʃiz ɹaɪt," ɛlaɪəs sɛd kwaɪətli, muvɪŋ ɪz ɡɛldɪŋ kloʊsɝ. "hoʊld ɑn tə jɝsɛlf. blʌndɝ ɝaʊnd wɪð il, ən jəɹ æskɪŋ tə daɪ. meɪbi teɪk ə lɑɾ ə mɛn wɪð jə tə ə bæɾ ɛnd. daɪɪŋ dʌz noʊ ɡʊɾ ɪf ɪt livz jəɹ waɪf ə pɹɪznɝ." hi tʃɹaɪd tə meɪk ɪz vɔɪs laɪɾɝ, bʌt pɛɹɪn kəd smɛl ðə stʃɹeɪn. "ɛniweɪ, wɪl faɪn hɝ, bɔɪ. ʃi kəd wɛl əv ɪskeɪp ðɛm, ə wʊmən laɪk ðæt. bi tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə meɪk əɹ weɪ bæk hɪɹ əfʊt. teɪk taɪm, ðət wʊd, ɪn ə dʒɹɛs. ðə fɝsts skaʊts wɪl loʊkeɪt tʃɹeɪsəz." ɹeɪkɪŋ fɪŋɡɝz θɹu hɪz lɔŋ bɪɹd, ɛlaɪəs ɡeɪv ə sɛlf-dɛpɹəkeɪɾɪŋ tʃʌkəl. "ɪf aɪ kæn faɪn mɔɹ ðən ðə minɝz, əl it bɑɹk. wɪl ɡɛɾ əɹ bæk fəɹ ju."

"She's right," Elyas said quietly, moving his gelding closer. "Hold on to yourself. Blunder around with Aiel, and you're asking to die. Maybe take a lot of men with you to a bad end. Dying does no good if it leaves your wife a prisoner." He tried to make his voice lighter, but Perrin could smell the strain. "Anyway, we'll find her, boy. She could well have escaped them, a woman like that. Be trying to make her way back here afoot. Take time, that would, in a dress. The First's scouts will locate traces." Raking fingers through his long beard, Elyas gave a self-deprecating chuckle. "If I can't find more than the Mayeners, I'll eat bark. We'll get her back for you."

pɛɹɪn wɑz nɑt fuld. "jɛs," hi sɛd hɑɹʃli. noʊbɑdi kəɾ ɪskeɪp il əfʊt. "ɡoʊ naʊ. hɝi." nɑt fuld əɾ ɔl. ðə mæn ɪkspɛktəd tə faɪn feɪlz bɑɾi. ʃi hæd tə bi əlaɪv, ən ðət mɛn kæptɪv, bʌt bɛɾɝ ə pɹɪznɝ ðən . . .

Perrin was not fooled. "Yes," he said harshly. Nobody could escape Aiel afoot. "Go now. Hurry." Not fooled at all. The man expected to find Faile's body. She had to be alive, and that meant captive, but better a prisoner than . . .

ðeɪ kəd nɑt tɔk bɪtwin ðɛmsɛlvz əz ðeɪ dɪd wɪð wʊlvz, bʌɾ ɛlaɪəs hɛzɪteɪɾɪd əz ɪf i ʌndɝstʊd pɛɹɪnz θɔts. hi dɪd nɑt tʃɹaɪ tə dɪnaɪ ðɛm, ðoʊ. hɪz ɡɛldɪŋ sɛɾ ɔf saʊθist əɾ ə wɔk, əz kwɪk əz ðə snoʊ wəɾ əlaʊ, ən æftɝ ə kwɪk ɡlæns ət pɛɹɪn, ɛɹæm fɑloʊd, hɪz feɪs dɑɹk. ðə wʌn-taɪm tɪŋkɝ dɪd nɑt laɪk ɛlaɪəs, bʌɾ i nɪɹ ɪnʌf wɝʃəp feɪl, ɪf oʊnli kəz ʃi wɑz pɛɹɪnz waɪf.

They could not talk between themselves as they did with wolves, but Elyas hesitated as if he understood Perrin's thoughts. He did not try to deny them, though. His gelding set off southeast at a walk, as quick as the snow would allow, and after a quick glance at Perrin, Aram followed, his face dark. The one-time Tinker did not like Elyas, but he near enough worshipped Faile, if only because she was Perrin's wife.

ɪt wəd də noʊ ɡʊd tə faʊndɝ ði ænəməlz, pɛɹɪn toʊl hɪmsɛlf, fɹaʊnɪŋ ət ðɛɹ ɹitʃɹiɾɪŋ bæks. hi wɑntəɾ əm tə ɹʌn. hi wɑntəd tə ɹʌn wɪð ðɛm. faɪn kɹæks sim tə bi spaɪɾɝɪŋ θɹu hɪm. ɪf ðeɪ ɹɪtɝnd wɪð ðə ɹɔŋ nuz, hi wəd ʃæɾɝ. tə hɪz sɝpɹaɪz, ðə θɹi wɔɹɾɝz tʃɹɑɾəd ðɛɹ maʊns θɹu ðə tʃɹiz æftɝ ɛlaɪəs ən ɛɹæm ɪn splæʃəz ə snoʊ, pleɪn wʊlən kloʊks stʃɹimɪŋ bɪhaɪnd, ðən mætʃt spid wən ðeɪ kɑɾ ʌp.

It would do no good to founder the animals, Perrin told himself, frowning at their retreating backs. He wanted them to run. He wanted to run with them. Fine cracks seemed to be spidering through him. If they returned with the wrong news, he would shatter. To his surprise, the three Warders trotted their mounts through the trees after Elyas and Aram in splashes of snow, plain woolen cloaks streaming behind, then matched speed when they caught up.

hi mænədʒ tə ɡɪv mɑsʊɝi ən siɑnɪɾ ə ɡɹeɪtfəl nɑd, ən ɪnkluɾəd ɛdʒɹə ən kɛɹɛl. huɛvɝ hæd meɪd ðə sədʒɛstʃən, ðəɹ wɑz noʊ daʊɾ u hæd ɡɹæntəd pɝmɪʃən. ɪt wɑz ə mɛʒɝ ə ðə kəntʃɹoʊl ðə waɪz wʌnz hæɾ ɪstæblɪʃt ðət niðɝ sɪstɝ wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə teɪk tʃɑɹdʒ. ðeɪ vɛɹi laɪkli wɑntəd tə, bʌt ðɛɹ ɡlʌv hænz ɹɪmeɪn foʊldəɾ ɑn ðə pɑməlz ə ðɛɹ sæɾəlz, ən niðɝ bɪtʃɹeɪɾ ɪmpeɪʃəns baɪ soʊ mʌtʃ əz ðə flɪkɝ ʌv ən aɪləd.

He managed to give Masuri and Seonid a grateful nod, and included Edarra and Carelle. Whoever had made the suggestion, there was no doubt who had granted permission. It was a measure of the control the Wise Ones had established that neither sister was trying to take charge. They very likely wanted to, but their gloved hands remained folded on the pommels of their saddles, and neither betrayed impatience by so much as the flicker of an eyelid.

nɑɾ ɛvɹiwʌn wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ ðə dɪpɑɹɾɪŋ mɛn. ənʊɹə ɔltɝneɪɾəd bɪtwin bimɪŋ sɪmpəθi əɾ ɪm ən stʌɾiɪŋ ðə waɪz wʌnz aʊɾ ə ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɝ aɪ. ənlaɪk ði ʌðɝ tu sɪstɝz, ʃi hæd meɪd noʊ pɹɑməsəz, bʌt ʃi wɑz ɔlmoʊst əz sɝkəmspɛkt wɪð ði ilwɪmən əz ðeɪ. ɡælɛnz wʌn aɪ wɑz ɑn bɹəleɪn, əweɪɾɪŋ ə saɪn i ʃəd dʒɹɔ ðə sɔɹɾ i wɑz ɡɹɪpɪŋ, waɪl ʃi wɑz ɪntɛn ɑn pɛɹɪn, hɝ feɪs stɪl smuð ən ənɹiɾəbəl. ɡɹeɪɾi ən nil hæd ðɛɹ hɛdz təɡɛðɝ, kæstɪŋ kwɪk, ɡɹɪm ɡlænsɪz ɪn ɪz dɝɛkʃən. beɪlwɝ sæt vɛɹi stɪl, laɪk ə spɛɹoʊ pɝtʃt ɑn ðə sæɾəl, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə bi ɪnvɪzəbəl, lɪsnɪŋ ɪntɛnli.

Not everyone was watching the departing men. Annoura alternated between beaming sympathy at him and studying the Wise Ones out of the corner of her eye. Unlike the other two sisters, she had made no promises, but she was almost as circumspect with the Aielwomen as they. Gallenne's one eye was on Berelain, awaiting a sign he should draw the sword he was gripping, while she was intent on Perrin, her face still smooth and unreadable. Grady and Neald had their heads together, casting quick, grim glances in his direction. Balwer sat very still, like a sparrow perched on the saddle, trying to be invisible, listening intently.

ɑɹɡændə pʊʃt ɪz tɔl ɹoʊn ɡɛldɪŋ pæst ɡælɛnz hɛvi-tʃɛstəd blæk, ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ðə minɝz wʌn-aɪd ɡlɛɹ ʌv aʊtʃɹeɪdʒ. ðə fɝs kæptənz maʊθ wɝkt æŋɡɹəli bɪhaɪn ðə ʃaɪnɪŋ feɪs-bɑɹz ə hɪz hɛlmət, bʌt pɛɹɪn hɝd nʌθɪŋ. feɪl fɪld ɪz hɛd. oʊ, laɪt, feɪl! hɪz tʃɛs fɛl baʊnd wɪð aɪɝn stʃɹæps. hi wɑz nɪɹ tə pænɪk, hoʊldɪŋ tə ðə pɹɛsəpəs wɪð ɪz fɪŋɡɝneɪlz.

Arganda pushed his tall roan gelding past Gallenne's heavy-chested black, ignoring the Mayener's one-eyed glare of outrage. The First Captain's mouth worked angrily behind the shining face-bars of his helmet, but Perrin heard nothing. Faile filled his head. Oh, Light, Faile! His chest felt bound with iron straps. He was near to panic, holding to the precipice with his fingernails.

dɛspɝətli hi ɹitʃt aʊt wɪð ɪz maɪnd, fɹæntəkəli sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ wʊlvz. ɛlaɪəs mʌst əv tʃɹaɪd ðɪs ɔlɹɛɾi - ɛlaɪəs wəd nɑɾ əv ɡɪvən weɪ tə pænɪk ət ðə nuz - bʌɾ i hæd tə tʃɹaɪ hɪmsɛlf.

Desperately he reached out with his mind, frantically searching for wolves. Elyas must have tried this already - Elyas would not have given way to panic at the news - but he had to try himself.

sɝtʃɪŋ, hi faʊn ðɛm, θɹi toʊz' pæk ən koʊld wɔɾɝz, twaɪlaɪts ən spɹɪŋhɔɹnz ən ʌðɝz. peɪn floʊɾ aʊt wɪð ɪz pli fəɹ hɛlp, bʌt ɡɹu ɡɹeɪɾɝ ɪnsaɪɾ ɪm ɹæðɝ ðən lɛs. ðeɪ hæd hɝɾ ə jʌŋ bʊl, ən ðeɪ kəməzɝeɪɾɪd oʊvɝ ðə lɔs ə hɪz ʃi, bʌt ðeɪ kɛp klɪɹ ə ðə tu-lɛɡz, hu fɹaɪɾənd əweɪ ɔl ðə ɡeɪm ən wɝ dɛθ fəɹ ɛni wʊlf kɑɾ əloʊn. ðəɹ wɝ soʊ mɛni pæks ə tu-lɛɡz əbaʊt, əfʊɾ ən ɹaɪɾɪŋ ðə hɑɹd-fʊɾɪd fɔɹ-lɛɡz, ðət ðeɪ kəd nɑt seɪ wɛðɝ ɛni ðeɪ nu ʌv wɝ ðə wʌn i sɔt. tu-lɛɡz wɝ tu-lɛɡz, tə ðɛm, ɪndɪstɪŋɡwɪʃəbəl ɪksɛp fəɹ ðoʊz u kəd tʃænəl, ən ðə fju hu kəd spik wɪð ðɛm. mɔɹn, ðeɪ toʊl hɪm, ən muv ɑn, ən miɾ əɹ əɡɛn ɪn ðə wʊlf dʒɹim.

Searching, he found them, Three Toes' pack and Cold Water's, Twilight's and Springhorn's and others. Pain flowed out with his plea for help, but grew greater inside him rather than less. They had heard of Young Bull, and they commiserated over the loss of his she, but they kept clear of the two-legs, who frightened away all the game and were death for any wolf caught alone. There were so many packs of two-legs about, afoot and riding the hard-footed four-legs, that they could not say whether any they knew of were the one he sought. Two-legs were two-legs, to them, indistinguishable except for those who could channel, and the few who could speak with them. Mourn, they told him, and move on, and meet her again in the wolf dream.

wʌn baɪ wʌn, ði ɪmədʒəz ðəɾ ɪz maɪn tɝn tə wɝdz feɪɾəd əweɪ, əntɪl oʊnli wʌn lɪŋɡɝd. mɔɹn, ən miɾ əɹ əɡɛn ɪn ðə wʊlf dʒɹim. ðən ðəɾ ɔlsoʊ wɑz ɡɔn.

One by one, the images that his mind turned to words faded away, until only one lingered. Mourn, and meet her again in the wolf dream. Then that also was gone.

"ɑɹ jə lɪsnɪŋ?" ɑɹɡændə dɪmændəd ɹʌfli. hi wɑz nɑɾ ə smuð-feɪs noʊbəl, ən dɪspaɪɾ ɪz sɪlks ən ðə ɡoʊld-wɝk ətɑp ðə sɪlvɝ ə hɪz bɹɛstpleɪɾ i lʊk laɪk wʌɾ i wɑz, ə ɡɹeɪɪŋ soʊlʒɝ u hæd fɝs hɛftəɾ ə læns əz ə bɔɪ ən pɹɑbli kæɹid tu dʌzən skɑɹz. hɪz dɑɹk aɪz wɝ ɔlmoʊst əz fivɝɾ əz ðoʊz ə mæsiməz mɛn. hi smɛld ə ɹeɪdʒ, ən fɪɹ. "ðoʊz sævədʒəz tʊk kwin æliændɝ, əz wɛl!"

"Are you listening?" Arganda demanded roughly. He was not a smooth-faced noble, and despite his silks and the gold-work atop the silver of his breastplate he looked like what he was, a graying soldier who had first hefted a lance as a boy and probably carried two dozen scars. His dark eyes were almost as fevered as those of Masema's men. He smelled of rage, and fear. "Those savages took Queen Alliandre, as well!"

"wi wɪl faɪn jəɹ kwin wən wi faɪn maɪ waɪf," pɛɹɪn sɛd, hɪz vɔɪs əz koʊld ən hɑɹɾ əz ði ɛdʒ ə hɪz æks. ʃi hæd tə bi əlaɪv. "səpoʊz jə tɛl mi wʌɾ ɔl ðɪs ɪz əbaʊt, jə dʒɹɔn ʌp ɹɛɾi tə tʃɑɹdʒ, ɪt lʊks laɪk. ən feɪsɪŋ maɪ pipəl, ət ðæt." hi hæɾ ʌðɝ ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾiz, tu. æknɑlɪdʒɪŋ ðət wɑz bɪɾɝ əz ɡɔl. nʌθɪŋ ɛls kaʊntəɾ əlɔŋsaɪd feɪl. nʌθɪŋ! bʌt ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn wɝ ɪz pipəl.

"We will find your Queen when we find my wife," Perrin said, his voice as cold and hard as the edge of his axe. She had to be alive. "Suppose you tell me what all this is about, you drawn up ready to charge, it looks like. And facing my people, at that." He had other responsibilities, too. Acknowledging that was bitter as gall. Nothing else counted alongside Faile. Nothing! But the Two Rivers men were his people.

ɑɹɡændə dæʃt ɪz maʊn kloʊs ən siz pɛɹɪnz sliv ɪn ə ɡɔntələɾəd fɪst. "ju lɪsən tə mi! ðə fɝs leɪɾi bɹəleɪn sɛz ɪt wɑz il tʊk kwin æliændɝ, ən ðəɹ ɑɹ il ʃɛltɝɪŋ bɪhaɪn ðoʊz ɑɹtʃɝz ə jʊɹz. aɪ hæv mɛn u wɪl bi hæpi ɪnʌf tə pʊɾ əm tə ðə kwɛstʃən." hɪz hiɾəd ɡeɪz swʌŋ bæk tə ɛdʒɹə ən kɛɹɛl fəɹ ə moʊmənt. pɝhæps i wɑz θɪŋkɪŋ ðət ðeɪ wɝ il wɪð noʊ ɑɹtʃɝz bɑɹɪŋ ɪz pæθ.

Arganda dashed his mount close and seized Perrin's sleeve in a gauntleted fist. "You listen to me! The First Lady Berelain says it was Aiel took Queen Alliandre, and there are Aiel sheltering behind those archers of yours. I have men who will be happy enough to put them to the question." His heated gaze swung back to Edarra and Carelle for a moment. Perhaps he was thinking that they were Aiel with no archers barring his path.

"ðə fɝs kæptən ɪz . . . oʊvɝɹɔt," bɹəleɪn mɝmɝd, leɪɪŋ ə hæn ɑn pɛɹɪnz ʌðɝ ɑɹm. "aɪ hæv ɪkspleɪn tə hɪm ðət nʌn ə ði il hɪɹ wɝ ɪnvɑlvd. aɪm ʃʊɹ ðəɾ aɪ kən kənvɪns ɪm - "

"The First Captain is . . . overwrought," Berelain murmured, laying a hand on Perrin's other arm. "I have explained to him that none of the Aiel here were involved. I'm sure that I can convince him - "

hi ʃʊk əɹ ɔf, ɹɪpt ɪz ɑɹm əweɪ fɹəm ðə ɡildænɪn. "æliændɝ swɔɹ fiəlti tə mi, ɑɹɡændə. jə swɔɹ fiəlti tə hɝ, ən ðət meɪks mi jəɹ lɔɹd. aɪ sɛɾ əl faɪn æliændɝ wən aɪ faɪn feɪl." ði ɛdʒ ʌv ən æks. ʃi wɑz əlaɪv. "ju kwɛstʃən noʊ wʌn, tʌtʃ noʊ wʌn, ənlɛs aɪ seɪ. wʌt jəl də ɪz teɪk jəɹ mɛn bæk tə jəɹ kæmp, naʊ, ən bi ɹɛɾi tə ɹaɪd wən aɪ ɡɪv ði ɔɹɾɝ. ɪf jəɹ nɑt ɹɛɾi wən aɪ kɔl, jəl bi lɛf bɪhaɪnd."

He shook her off, ripped his arm away from the Ghealdanin. "Alliandre swore fealty to me, Arganda. You swore fealty to her, and that makes me your lord. I said I'll find Alliandre when I find Faile." The edge of an axe. She was alive. "You question no one, touch no one, unless I say. What you will do is take your men back to your camp, now, and be ready to ride when I give the order. If you're not ready when I call, you will be left behind."

ɑɹɡændə stɛɹɾ ət hɪm, bɹiðɪŋ hɑɹd. hɪz aɪz stʃɹeɪɾ əɡɛn, ðɪs taɪm təwɔɹd ɡɹeɪɾi ən nild, ðən dʒɝk bæk tə pɛɹɪnz feɪs. "æz jə kəmænd, maɪ lɔɹd," hi sɛd stɪfli. wilɪŋ ɪz ɹoʊn, hi ʃaʊɾəd ɔɹɾɝz tə hɪz ɔfəsɝz ən wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi ɡæləpɪŋ əweɪ bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ bɪɡæn ɪʃuɪŋ ðɛɹ oʊn. ðə ɡildænɪn bɪɡæn tə pil əweɪ baɪ kɑləmz, ɹaɪɾɪŋ æftɝ ðɛɹ fɝs kæptən. təwɔɹd ðɛɹ kæmp, ðoʊ wɛðɝ ɑɹɡændə ɪntɛndəd tə ɹɪmeɪn ðəɹ wɑz ɛniwʌnz ɡɛs. ən wɛðɝ ɪt maɪt nɑt bi fəɹ ðə wɝs ɪf i dɪd.

Arganda stared at him, breathing hard. His eyes strayed again, this time toward Grady and Neald, then jerked back to Perrin's face. "As you command, my Lord," he said stiffly. Wheeling his roan, he shouted orders to his officers and was already galloping away before they began issuing their own. The Ghealdanin began to peel away by columns, riding after their First Captain. Toward their camp, though whether Arganda intended to remain there was anyone's guess. And whether it might not be for the worse if he did.

"ju hændəl ðət vɛɹi wɛl, pɛɹɪn," bɹəleɪn sɛd. "ə dɪfəkəl sɪtʃueɪʃən, ən ə peɪnfəl taɪm fəɹ ju." nɑt fɔɹməl əɾ ɔl, naʊ. dʒʌst ə wʊmən fʊl ə pɪɾi, hɝ smaɪl kəmpæʃənət. oʊ, ʃi hæɾ ə θaʊzənd ɡaɪzəz, bɹəleɪn dɪd.

"You handled that very well, Perrin," Berelain said. "A difficult situation, and a painful time for you." Not formal at all, now. Just a woman full of pity, her smile compassionate. Oh, she had a thousand guises, Berelain did.

ʃi stʃɹɛtʃt aʊɾ ə ɹɛd-ɡlʌv hænd, ən i bæk steɪɝ əweɪ bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəd tʌtʃ hɪm. "ɡɪv ɪɾ oʊvɝ, bɝn ju!" hi snɑɹəld. "maɪ waɪf əz bɪn teɪkən! aɪv noʊ peɪʃəns fəɹ jəɹ tʃaɪldɪʃ ɡeɪmz!"

She stretched out a red-gloved hand, and he backed Stayer away before she could touch him. "Give it over, burn you!" he snarled. "My wife has been taken! I've no patience for your childish games!"

ʃi dʒɝkt əz ɪf i hæd stʃɹʌk hɝ. kʌlɝ blumd ɪn əɹ tʃiks, ən ʃi tʃeɪnʒd əɡɛn, bɪkʌmɪŋ sʌpəl ən wɪləwi ɪn əɹ sæɾəl. "nɑt tʃaɪldɪʃ, pɛɹɪn," ʃi mɝmɝd, hɝ vɔɪs ɹɪtʃ ən əmjuzd. "tu wɪmən kəntɛstɪŋ oʊvɝ ju, ən jə ðə pɹaɪz? aɪ wəd θɪŋk jud bi flæɾɝd. ətɛn mi, lɔɹd kæptən ɡælɛn. aɪ səpoʊz wi, tu, ʃəd bi ɹɛɾi tə ɹaɪɾ ət kəmænd."

She jerked as if he had struck her. Color bloomed in her cheeks, and she changed again, becoming supple and willowy in her saddle. "Not childish, Perrin," she murmured, her voice rich and amused. "Two women contesting over you, and you the prize? I would think you'd be flattered. Attend me, Lord Captain Gallenne. I suppose we, too, should be ready to ride at command."

ðə wʌn-aɪd mæn ɹoʊd bæk təwɔɹd ðə wɪŋd ɡɑɹdz əɾ əɹ saɪd, əz kloʊs tə ə kæntɝ əz ðə snoʊ meɪd pɑsəbəl. hi wɑz linɪŋ təwɔɹɾ əɹ əz ɪf hɪɹɪŋ ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz. ənʊɹə pɔzd wɛɹ ʃi wɑz, ɡæðɝɪŋ ðə ɹeɪnz ə hɝ bɹaʊn mɛɹ. hɝ maʊθ wɑz ə ɹeɪzɝd laɪn bɪniθ əɹ bik ʌv ə noʊz. "səmtaɪmz jə ɑɹ ə vɛɹi lɑɹdʒ ful, pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə. kwaɪɾ ɔfən, ɪn fækt."

The one-eyed man rode back toward the Winged Guards at her side, as close to a canter as the snow made possible. He was leaning toward her as if hearing instructions. Annoura paused where she was, gathering the reins of her brown mare. Her mouth was a razored line beneath her beak of a nose. "Sometimes you are a very large fool, Perrin Aybara. Quite often, in fact."

hi dɪd nɑt noʊ wʌt ʃi wɑz tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt, ən dɪd nɑt kɛɹ. ət taɪmz ʃi simd ɹɪzaɪn tə bɹəleɪn tʃeɪsɪŋ æftɝ ə mɛɹid mæn, ən ʌðɝ taɪmz əmjuz baɪ ɪt, ivən hɛlpɪŋ aʊt baɪ ɝeɪnʒɪŋ fəɹ bɹəleɪn tə bi əloʊn wɪð hɪm. ɹaɪt ðɛn, fɝst ən ɛɛs sədaɪ boʊθ dɪsɡʌstəd hɪm. hilɪŋ steɪɝ ɪn ðə flæŋks, hi tʃɹɑɾəd əweɪ fɹəm əɹ wɪθaʊɾ ə wɝd.

He did not know what she was talking about, and did not care. At times she seemed resigned to Berelain chasing after a married man, and other times amused by it, even helping out by arranging for Berelain to be alone with him. Right then, First and Aes Sedai both disgusted him. Heeling Stayer in the flanks, he trotted away from her without a word.

ðə mɛn ɑn ðə hɪltɑp oʊpən ɪnʌf tə lɛɾ ɪm θɹu, mʌɾɝɪŋ tə wʌn ənʌðɝ ən wɑtʃɪŋ ðə lænsɝz bɪloʊ ɹaɪd təwɔɹd ðɛɹ ɹɪspɛktɪv kæmps, pɑɹɾəd əɡɛn tə lɛt ðə waɪz wʌnz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ən æʃəmən pæs. ðeɪ dɪd nɑt bɹeɪk ʌp ən kɹaʊɾ ɝaʊn hɪm, əz i hæɾ ɪkspɛktəd, fəɹ wɪtʃ i wɑz ɡɹeɪtfəl. ðə hoʊl hɪltɑp smɛld ʌv wɛɹinɪs. moʊst ʌv ɪt dɪd.

The men on the hilltop opened enough to let him through, muttering to one another and watching the lancers below ride toward their respective camps, parted again to let the Wise Ones and Aes Sedai and Asha'man pass. They did not break up and crowd around him, as he had expected, for which he was grateful. The whole hilltop smelled of wariness. Most of it did.

ðə snoʊ ətɑp ðə hɪl hæd bɪn tʃɹæmpəld əntɪl səm pætʃəz wɝ klɪɹ ɪksɛp fəɹ fɹoʊzən klʌmps ən ʌðɝz wɝ ʃits ʌv aɪs. ðə fɔɹ waɪz wʌnz u hæd ɹɪmeɪn bɪhaɪnd wən i ɹoʊd tə ɑbilə wɝ stændɪŋ ɪn fɹʌn ʌv wʌn ə ðə loʊ il tɛns, tɔl ənɹʌfəld wɪmən wɪð dɑɹk wʊlən ʃɔlz ɝaʊn ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz, wɑtʃɪŋ ðə tu sɪstɝz dɪsmaʊnt wɪð kɛɹɛl ən ɛdʒɹə, ən simɪŋli peɪɪŋ noʊ maɪn tə wʌt wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn ɝaʊn ðɛm. ðə ɡeɪʃeɪn u sɝvd əm ɪn pleɪs ə sɝvəns wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ əbaʊt ðɛɹ nɔɹməl tæsks kwaɪətli, mikli, feɪsəz hɪɾən ɪn ðə dip kaʊlz ə ðɛɹ waɪt ɹoʊbz. wʌn fɛloʊ wɑz ivən biɾɪŋ ə kɑɹpət hʌŋ oʊvɝ ə ɹoʊp taɪd bɪtwin tu tʃɹiz! ði oʊnli saɪn əmʌŋ ði il ðət ðeɪ maɪɾ əv bɪn ɑn ðə bɹɪŋk ʌv ə faɪt wɑz ɡɔl ən ðə meɪɾənz. ðeɪ hæd bɪn skwɑɾɪŋ ɑn ðɛɹ hilz, ʃoʊufə ɝaʊn ðɛɹ hɛdz ən blæk veɪlz haɪɾɪŋ ɔl bʌt ðɛɹ aɪz, ʃɔɹt spɪɹz ən bʊl-haɪd bʌklɝz ɪn hænd. əz pɛɹɪn dʒʌmp daʊn fɹəm ɪz sæɾəl, ðeɪ ɹoʊz.

The snow atop the hill had been trampled until some patches were clear except for frozen clumps and others were sheets of ice. The four Wise Ones who had remained behind when he rode to Abila were standing in front of one of the low Aiel tents, tall unruffled women with dark woolen shawls around their shoulders, watching the two sisters dismount with Carelle and Edarra, and seemingly paying no mind to what was going on around them. The gai'shain who served them in place of servants were going about their normal tasks quietly, meekly, faces hidden in the deep cowls of their white robes. One fellow was even beating a carpet hung over a rope tied between two trees! The only sign among the Aiel that they might have been on the brink of a fight was Gaul and the Maidens. They had been squatting on their heels, shoufa around their heads and black veils hiding all but their eyes, short spears and bull-hide bucklers in hand. As Perrin jumped down from his saddle, they rose.

dænɪl luɪn tʃɹɑɾəd ʌp, tʃuɪŋ wɝidli ət ðə θɪk mʌstæʃ ðət meɪɾ ɪz noʊz lʊk ivən bɪɡɝ ðən ɪt wɑz. hi hæɾ ɪz baʊ ɪn wʌn hæn ən wɑz slaɪɾɪŋ ən æɹoʊ bæk ɪndə ðə kwɪvɝ əɾ ɪz bɛlt. "aɪ dɪdnt noʊ wʌɾ ɛls tə du, pɛɹɪn," hi sɛɾ ɪn ə dʒɝki vɔɪs. dænɪl hæd bɪn ət dəməaɪz wɛlz, ən feɪs tʃɹɑləks bæk hoʊm, bʌt ðɪs wɑz aʊtsaɪɾ ɪz vju ʌv ðə wɝld. "baɪ ðə taɪm wi faʊn aʊt wʌt hæpənd, ðoʊz ɡildænɪn fɛloʊz wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi stɑɹɾɪŋ ðɪs weɪ, soʊ aɪ sɛn ɔf dʒɑndɪn bæɹən ən ə kʌpəl ʌv ʌðɝz, hu mɑɹwɪn ən ɡɛɾ eɪliə, toʊl ðə kɛɹhinɪn ən jəɹ sɝvəns tə meɪk ə sɝkəl wɪð ðə kɑɹts ən steɪ ɪnsaɪɾ ɪt - hæd tə dʒʌst əbaʊt taɪ ʌp ðoʊz foʊks hɔɹ ɔlweɪz fɑloʊɪŋ ðə leɪɾi feɪl ɝaʊnd; ðeɪ wɑntəd tə ɡoʊ ɔf æftɝ hɝ, ən nɑɾ ə wʌn ə ðɛm noʊz ə fʊtpɹɪn fɹəm ən oʊk tʃɹi - ðən aɪ bɹɔɾ ɛvɹibɑɾi ɛls hɪɹ. aɪ θɔt ðoʊz ɡildænɪn maɪt tʃɑɹdʒ ʌs, əntɪl ðə fɝst ɡɑt ðəɹ wɪð əɹ mɛn. ðeɪ mʌs bi kɹeɪzi, θɪŋkɪŋ ɛni ʌv əɹ il wəd hɝt ðə leɪɾi feɪl." ivən wən ðeɪ pɝɹən hɪm, feɪl nɪɹli ɔlweɪz ɹəsiv ði ɑnɝɪfɪk fɹəm ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn.

Dannil Lewin trotted up, chewing worriedly at the thick mustache that made his nose look even bigger than it was. He had his bow in one hand and was sliding an arrow back into the quiver at his belt. "I didn't know what else to do, Perrin," he said in a jerky voice. Dannil had been at Dumai's Wells, and faced Trollocs back home, but this was outside his view of the world. "By the time we found out what happened, those Ghealdanin fellows were already starting this way, so I sent off Jondyn Barran and a couple of others, Hu Marwin and Get Ayliah, told the Cairhienin and your servants to make a circle with the carts and stay inside it - had to just about tie up those folks who're always following the Lady Faile around; they wanted to go off after her, and not a one of them knows a footprint from an oak tree - then I brought everybody else here. I thought those Ghealdanin might charge us, until the First got there with her men. They must be crazy, thinking any of our Aiel would hurt the Lady Faile." Even when they Perrined him, Faile nearly always received the honorific from the Two Rivers men.

"ju dɪd ɹaɪt, dænɪl," pɛɹɪn sɛd, tɔsɪŋ ɪm steɪɝz ɹeɪnz. hu ən ɡɛt wɝ ɡʊd wʊdzmɪn, ən dʒɑndɪn bæɹən kəd fɑloʊ jɛstɝdeɪz wɪnd. ɡɔl ən ðə meɪɾənz wɝ stɑɹɾɪŋ tə liv, ɪn sɪŋɡəl faɪl. ðeɪ wɝ stɪl veɪld. "tɛl ɔf wʌn mæn ɪn θɹi tə steɪ hɪɹ," pɛɹɪn toʊl dænɪl hɝidli; dʒʌs kəz i hæd feɪst ɑɹɡændə daʊn wɑz noʊ ɹizən tə bɪliv ðə mæn hæd tʃeɪnʒd ɪz maɪnd, "æn sɛn ðə ɹɛs bæk tə pæk ʌp. aɪ wɑnə ɹaɪɾ əz sun əz ðɛɹz wɝd."

"You did right, Dannil," Perrin said, tossing him Stayer's reins. Hu and Get were good woodsmen, and Jondyn Barran could follow yesterday's wind. Gaul and the Maidens were starting to leave, in single file. They were still veiled. "Tell off one man in three to stay here," Perrin told Dannil hurriedly; just because he had faced Arganda down was no reason to believe the man had changed his mind, "and send the rest back to pack up. I want to ride as soon as there's word."

wɪθaʊt weɪɾɪŋ ɑn ə ɹɪplaɪ, hi hɝid tə pʊt hɪmsɛlf ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ɡɔl ən stɑp ðə tɔlɝ mæn wɪð ə hæn tə hɪz tʃɛst. fəɹ səm ɹizən, ɡɔlz ɡɹin aɪz taɪɾənd əbʌv ɪz veɪl. səlɪn ən ðə ɹɛst ə ðə meɪɾənz stʃɹʌŋ aʊt bɪhaɪn ɪm wɛn ʌp ɑn ðə bɔlz ə ðɛɹ fit.

Without waiting on a reply, he hurried to put himself in front of Gaul and stopped the taller man with a hand to his chest. For some reason, Gaul's green eyes tightened above his veil. Sulin and the rest of the Maidens strung out behind him went up on the balls of their feet.

"faɪn əɹ fəɹ mi, ɡɔl," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "ɔl ə ju, pliz faɪn u tʊk hɝ. ɪf ɛniwʌn kən tʃɹæk il, ɪts ju."

"Find her for me, Gaul," Perrin said. "All of you, please find who took her. If anyone can track Aiel, it's you."

ðə taɪtnəs ɪn ɡɔlz aɪz vænɪʃt əz sʌɾənli əz ɪt hæd kʌm, ən ðə meɪɾənz ɹɪlækst, tu. əz mʌtʃ əz il ɛvɝ kəd bi sɛd tə ɹɪlæks. ɪt wɑz vɛɹi stʃɹeɪnʒ. ðeɪ kəd nɑt θɪŋk i bleɪmd əm ɪn ɛni weɪ.

The tightness in Gaul's eyes vanished as suddenly as it had come, and the Maidens relaxed, too. As much as Aiel ever could be said to relax. It was very strange. They could not think he blamed them in any way.

"wi ɔl weɪk fɹəm ðə dʒɹim wʌn deɪ," ɡɔl sɛd dʒɛnli, "bʌɾ ɪf ʃi stɪl dʒɹimz, wɪl faɪn hɝ. bʌɾ ɪf il tʊk hɝ, wi mʌst ɡoʊ. ðəl muv kwɪkli. ivən ɪn . . . ðɪs." hi pʊt kənsɪɾɝəbəl dɪsɡʌst ɪn ðə wɝd, kɪkɪŋ əɾ ə klɑɾ ə snoʊ.

"We all wake from the dream one day," Gaul said gently, "but if she still dreams, we will find her. But if Aiel took her, we must go. They will move quickly. Even in . . . this." He put considerable disgust in the word, kicking at a clod of snow.

pɛɹɪn nɑɾəd ən heɪstəli stɛpt əsaɪd, lɛɾɪŋ ði il sɛɾ aʊɾ əɾ ə tʃɹɑt. hi daʊɾɪd ðeɪ kəd meɪnteɪn ðət fəɹ vɛɹi lɔŋ, bʌɾ i wɑz ʃʊɹ ðeɪ wəd kip ðə peɪs lɔŋɡɝ ðən ɛniwʌn ɛls kəd hæv. əz ðə meɪɾənz pæs hɪm, itʃ kwɪkli pɹɛs fɪŋɡɝz tə ðə veɪl oʊvɝ əɹ lɪps, ðən tʌtʃt ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. səlɪn, ɹaɪt bɪhaɪnd ɡɔl, ɡeɪv ɪm ə nɑd, bʌt nʌn sɛɾ ə wɝd. feɪl wʊɾə noʊn wʌt ðeɪ mɛnt wɪð ðɛɹ fɪŋɡɝ kɪsɪŋ.

Perrin nodded and hastily stepped aside, letting the Aiel set out at a trot. He doubted they could maintain that for very long, but he was sure they would keep the pace longer than anyone else could have. As the Maidens passed him, each quickly pressed fingers to the veil over her lips, then touched his shoulder. Sulin, right behind Gaul, gave him a nod, but none said a word. Faile would have known what they meant with their finger kissing.

ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ɛls ɑɾ əbaʊt ðɛɹ dɪpɑɹtʃɝ, hi ɹilaɪzd əz ðə læs meɪɾən wɛn baɪ. ðeɪ wɝ lɛɾɪŋ ɡɔl lɛd. nɔɹməli, ɛni ʌv əm wʊɾə stʌk ə spɪɹ ɪn ɪm bɪfɔɹ əlaʊɪŋ ðæt. waɪ . . . ? meɪbi . . . kiæɾ ən beɪn wʊɾə bɪn wɪð feɪl. ɡɔl dɪd nɑt kɛɹ wʌn weɪ əɹ ði ʌðɝ əbaʊt beɪn, bʌt kiæd wɑz ə dɪfɹən mæɾɝ. ðə meɪɾənz sɝɾənli hæd nɑt bɪn ɛnkɝɪdʒɪŋ ɡɔlz hoʊp ðət kiæd wəd ɡɪv ʌp ðə spɪɹ tə mɛɹi hɪm - ɛniθɪŋ bʌt! - jɛt meɪbi ðət wɑz ɪt.

There was something else odd about their departure, he realized as the last Maiden went by. They were letting Gaul lead. Normally, any of them would have stuck a spear in him before allowing that. Why . . . ? Maybe . . . Chiad and Bain would have been with Faile. Gaul did not care one way or the other about Bain, but Chiad was a different matter. The Maidens certainly had not been encouraging Gaul's hope that Chiad would give up the spear to marry him - anything but! - yet maybe that was it.

pɛɹɪn ɡɹʌntɪɾ ɪn dɪsɡʌst ət hɪmsɛlf. kiæɾ ən beɪn, ən u ɛls? ivən blaɪnd wɪð fɪɹ fəɹ feɪl, hi ʃʊɾə æsk ðət mʌtʃ. ɪf i wɑz gɑnə ɡɛɾ əɹ bæk, hi niɾəd tə stʃɹæŋɡəl fɪɹ ən si. bʌɾ ɪt wɑz laɪk tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə stʃɹæŋɡəl ə tʃɹi.

Perrin grunted in disgust at himself. Chiad and Bain, and who else? Even blind with fear for Faile, he should have asked that much. If he was going to get her back, he needed to strangle fear and see. But it was like trying to strangle a tree.

ðə flæt hɪltɑp swɔɹm naʊ. sʌmwʌn hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi lɛd steɪɝ əweɪ, ən tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn wɝ livɪŋ ðə ɹɪŋ ɝaʊn ðə kɹɛst, hɝiɪŋ təwɔɹd ðɛɹ kæmp ɪn ə skæɾɝd stʃɹim, ʃaʊɾɪŋ tə wʌn ənʌðɝ əbaʊt wʌt ðeɪ wʊɾə dʌn hæd ðə lænsɝz tʃɑɹdʒd. əkeɪʒənəli ə mæn ɹeɪzd ɪz vɔɪs æskɪŋ əbaʊt feɪl, dɪɾ ɛniwʌn noʊ ɪf ðə leɪɾi wɑz seɪf, wɝ ðeɪ gɑnə lʊk fəɹ hɝ, bʌɾ ʌðɝz ɔlweɪz ʃʌʃt ɪm hɝidli wɪð wɝid ɡlænsɪz ət pɛɹɪn. ðə ɡeɪʃeɪn wɛn əbaʊt ðɛɹ tæsks plɑtʃədli ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ʌv ɔl ðə ɹʌʃ. ənlɛs kəmændəd tə stɑp, ðeɪ wʊɾə dʌn ðə seɪm ɪf ə bæɾəl hæd swɝld ɝaʊn ðɛm, nɑt ɹeɪzɪŋ ə hæn tə hɛlp əɹ hɪndɝ. ðə waɪz wʌnz hæɾ ɔl ɡɔn ɪndə wʌn ə ðə tɛns wɪð siɑnɪɾ ən mɑsʊɝi, ən ðə flæps wɝ nɑɾ oʊnli daʊn, bʌt taɪd. ðeɪ dɪd nɑt wɑnə bi dɪstɝbd. ðeɪ wəd bi dɪskʌsɪŋ mæsimə, noʊ daʊt. pɑsəbli dɪskʌsɪŋ haʊ tə kɪl ðə mæn wɪθaʊɾ ɪm əɹ ɹænd lɝnɪŋ ðeɪ hæd dʌn ɪt.

The flat hilltop swarmed now. Someone had already led Stayer away, and Two Rivers men were leaving the ring around the crest, hurrying toward their camp in a scattered stream, shouting to one another about what they would have done had the lancers charged. Occasionally a man raised his voice asking about Faile, did anyone know if the Lady was safe, were they going to look for her, but others always shushed him hurriedly with worried glances at Perrin. The gai'shain went about their tasks placidly in the middle of all the rush. Unless commanded to stop, they would have done the same if a battle had swirled around them, not raising a hand to help or hinder. The Wise Ones had all gone into one of the tents with Seonid and Masuri, and the flaps were not only down, but tied. They did not want to be disturbed. They would be discussing Masema, no doubt. Possibly discussing how to kill the man without him or Rand learning they had done it.

hi smækt ə fɪst ɪndə hɪz pɑm ɪn ɪɹɪteɪʃən. hi hæɾ æktʃəli  fɝɡɑɾən mæsimə əntɪl naʊ. ðə mæn wɑz səpoʊz tə bi fɑloʊɪŋ bɪfɔɹ naɪtfɔl, wɪð ðəɾ ɑnɝ ɡɑɹɾ ʌv ə hʌnʒɹəd mɛn. wɪð lʌk, ðə minɝ skaʊts wəd bi bæk baɪ ðɛn, ən ɛlaɪəs ən ði ʌðɝz sun æftɝ.

He smacked a fist into his palm in irritation. He had actually forgotten Masema until now. The man was supposed to be following before nightfall, with that honor guard of a hundred men. With luck, the Mayener scouts would be back by then, and Elyas and the others soon after.

"maɪ lɔɹd pɛɹɪn?" ɡɹeɪɾi sɛd bɪhaɪn hɪm, ən i tɝnd. ðə tu æʃəmən stʊɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz, fɪdlɪŋ ənsɝteɪnli wɪð ðɛɹ ɹeɪnz. ɡɹeɪɾi dʒɹu bɹɛθ ən wɛn ɑn wɪð nil nɑɾɪŋ əɡɹimənt. "ðə pɛɹ ʌv əs kəd kʌvɝ ə lɑɾ ʌv ɡɹaʊnd, tʃɹævlɪŋ. ən ɪf wi faɪn ðə lɑɾ u kɪdnæp hɝ, wɛl, aɪ daʊɾ ivən ə fju hʌnʒɹəd il kəd stɑp tu æʃəmən fɹəm teɪkɪŋ əɹ bæk."

"My Lord Perrin?" Grady said behind him, and he turned. The two Asha'man stood in front of their horses, fiddling uncertainly with their reins. Grady drew breath and went on with Neald nodding agreement. "The pair of us could cover a lot of ground, Traveling. And if we find the lot who kidnapped her, well, I doubt even a few hundred Aiel could stop two Asha'man from taking her back."

pɛɹɪn oʊpən ɪz maʊθ tə tɛl əm tə stɑɹɾ ɪmiɾiətli, ðən kloʊzd ɪɾ əɡɛn. ɡɹeɪɾi hæd bɪn ə fɑɹmɝ, tʃɹu, bʌt nɛvɝ ə hʌntɝ əɹ wʊdzmən. nil θɔɾ ɛni pleɪs wɪθaʊɾ ə stoʊn wɔl wɑz ə vɪlədʒ. ðeɪ maɪt noʊ ə fʊtpɹɪn fɹəm ən oʊk tʃɹi, jɛɾ ɪf ðeɪ dɪd faɪn tʃɹæks, vɛɹi laɪkli niðɝ wəd bi eɪbəl tə seɪ wɪtʃ dɝɛkʃən ðeɪ wɝ hɛɾəd. ʌv kɔɹs, hi kəd ɡoʊ wɪð ðɛm. hi wɑz nɑɾ əz ɡʊɾ əz dʒɑndɪn, bʌt . . . hi kəd ɡoʊ, ən liv dænɪl tə dil wɪð ɑɹɡændə. ən wɪð mæsimə. nɑt tə mɛnʃən ðə waɪz wʌnz' skimz.

Perrin opened his mouth to tell them to start immediately, then closed it again. Grady had been a farmer, true, but never a hunter or woodsman. Neald thought any place without a stone wall was a village. They might know a footprint from an oak tree, yet if they did find tracks, very likely neither would be able to say which direction they were headed. Of course, he could go with them. He was not as good as Jondyn, but . . . He could go, and leave Dannil to deal with Arganda. And with Masema. Not to mention the Wise Ones' schemes.

"ɡoʊ ɡɛt jʊɹsɛlvz pækt," hi sɛd kwaɪətli. wɛɹ wɑz beɪlwɝ? noʊwɛɹ ɪn saɪt. nɑt vɛɹi laɪkli ðəɾ i hæd ɡɔn hɛɹɪŋ ɔf tə faɪn feɪl. "ju meɪ bi niɾəd hɪɹ."

"Go get yourselves packed," he said quietly. Where was Balwer? Nowhere in sight. Not very likely that he had gone haring off to find Faile. "You may be needed here."

ɡɹeɪɾi blɪŋkt ɪn sɝpɹaɪz, ən nilz maʊθ dʒɹɑpt oʊpən.

Grady blinked in surprise, and Neald's mouth dropped open.

pɛɹɪn ɡeɪv əm noʊ tʃæns tə ɑɹɡju. hi stʃɹoʊɾ oʊvɝ tə ðə loʊ tɛnt wɪð ðə taɪd flæps. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ weɪ tə əndu ðə taɪz fɹəm ði aʊtsaɪd. wən waɪz wʌnz wɑntəd tə ɹɪmeɪn ʌndɪstɝbd, ðeɪ wɑntəd tə ɹɪmeɪn ʌndɪstɝbd, baɪ klæn tʃifs əɹ ɛniwʌn ɛls. ɪnkluɾɪŋ ə wɛtləndɝ lʌmbɝd wɪð ðə taɪɾəl ə lɔɹɾ ə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. hi dʒɹu hɪz bɛl naɪf, ən bɛn tə slaɪs ðə taɪz, bʌt bɪfɔɹ i kəd slaɪd ðə bleɪd θɹu ðə taɪt kɹæk bɪtwin ði ɛntʃɹi flæps, ðeɪ dʒɝkt əz ɪf sʌmwʌn wɑz ənfæsənɪŋ əm fɹəm ɪnsaɪd. hi stʃɹeɪɾənd ən weɪɾəd.

Perrin gave them no chance to argue. He strode over to the low tent with the tied flaps. There was no way to undo the ties from the outside. When Wise Ones wanted to remain undisturbed, they wanted to remain undisturbed, by clan chiefs or anyone else. Including a wetlander lumbered with the title of Lord of the Two Rivers. He drew his belt knife, and bent to slice the ties, but before he could slide the blade through the tight crack between the entry flaps, they jerked as if someone was unfastening them from inside. He straightened and waited.

ðə tɛntflæps oʊpənd, ən nəvɛɝɪn slɪpt aʊt. hɝ ʃɔl wɑz taɪɾ ɝaʊn əɹ weɪst, bʌɾ ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə mɪst ə hɝ bɹɛθ, ʃi ɡeɪv noʊ ɛvəɾəns ə ði aɪsi ɛɹ. hɝ ɡɹin aɪz tʊk ɪn ðə naɪf ɪn ɪz hænd, ən ʃi plæntəɾ əɹ fɪsts ɑn əɹ hɪps ɪn ə ɹæɾəl ə bɹeɪslɪts. ʃi wɑz nɪɹ ɪnʌf boʊn-θɪn, wɪð lɔŋ sændi jɛloʊ hɛɹ hɛl bæk baɪ ə dɑɹk foʊldəd kɝtʃəf, ən mɔɹ ðən ə hæn tɔlɝ ðən nɪneɪiv, bʌt ðət wɑz u ʃi ɔlweɪz meɪɾ ɪm θɪŋk ʌv. ʃi stʊd blɑkɪŋ ði ɛntʃɹəns tə ðə tɛnt.

The tentflaps opened, and Nevarin slipped out. Her shawl was tied around her waist, but except for the mist of her breath, she gave no evidence of the icy air. Her green eyes took in the knife in his hand, and she planted her fists on her hips in a rattle of bracelets. She was near enough bone-thin, with long sandy yellow hair held back by a dark folded kerchief, and more than a hand taller than Nynaeve, but that was who she always made him think of. She stood blocking the entrance to the tent.

"ju ɑɹ ɪmpɛtʃwəs, pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə." hɝ laɪt vɔɪs wɑz lɛvəl, bʌɾ i hæd ði ɪmpɹɛʃən ðət ʃi wɑz kənsɪɾɝɪŋ bɑksɪŋ ɪz ɪɹz. vɛɹi mʌtʃ laɪk nɪneɪiv. "ðoʊ ðət maɪt bi ʌndɝstændəbəl, ɪn ðə sɝkəmstænsəz. wʌt dʒju wɑnt?"

"You are impetuous, Perrin Aybara." Her light voice was level, but he had the impression that she was considering boxing his ears. Very much like Nynaeve. "Though that might be understandable, in the circumstances. What do you want?"

"haʊ . . . ?" hi hæd tə stɑp tə swɑloʊ. "haʊ wɪl ðeɪ tʃɹit hɝ?"

"How . . . ?" He had to stop to swallow. "How will they treat her?"

"aɪ kænɑt seɪ, pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə." ðəɹ wɑz noʊ sɪmpəθi ɑn əɹ feɪs, noʊ ɪkspɹɛʃən əɾ ɔl. il kəd ɡɪv ɛɛs sədaɪ lɛsənz ɪn ðæt. "teɪkɪŋ wɛtləndɝz kæptɪv ɪz əɡɛns kʌstəm, ɪksɛp fəɹ tʃɹikɪlɝz, ðoʊ ðəɾ əz tʃeɪnʒd. soʊ ɪz kɪlɪŋ wɪθaʊt nid. bʌt mɛni hæv ɹəfjuz tə æksɛp ðə tʃɹuθs ðə kɑɹəkɑɹn ɹɪvild. səm wɝ teɪkən baɪ ðə bliknəs ən θɹu daʊn ðɛɹ spɪɹz, jɛt ðeɪ meɪ hæv teɪkən əm ʌp əɡɛn. ʌðɝz sɪmpli lɛft, tə lɪv əz ðeɪ bɪliv wəɹ mɛn tə. aɪ kænɑt seɪ wʌt kʌstəmz maɪt bi kɛpt əɹ əbændən baɪ ðoʊz u hæv əbændən klæn ən sɛpt." ði oʊnli ɪmoʊʃən ʃi dɪspleɪd wɑz ə hɪn ə dɪsɡʌst ət ði ɛnd, fəɹ ðoʊz u əbændən klæn ən sɛpt.

"I cannot say, Perrin Aybara." There was no sympathy on her face, no expression at all. Aiel could give Aes Sedai lessons in that. "Taking wetlanders captive is against custom, except for Treekillers, though that has changed. So is killing without need. But many have refused to accept the truths the Car'a'carn revealed. Some were taken by the Bleakness and threw down their spears, yet they may have taken them up again. Others simply left, to live as they believe we are meant to. I cannot say what customs might be kept or abandoned by those who have abandoned clan and sept." The only emotion she displayed was a hint of disgust at the end, for those who abandoned clan and sept.

"laɪt, wʊmən, jə mʌst əv səm aɪdiə! ʃʊɹli jə kən meɪk ə ɡɛs - "

"Light, woman, you must have some idea! Surely you can make a guess - "

"du nɑt bɪkʌm ɪɹæʃənəl," ʃi bɹoʊk ɪn ʃɑɹpli. "mɛn ɔfən də ɪn sətʃ sɪtʃueɪʃənz, bʌt wɪv niɾ ə ju. aɪ θɪŋk ɪɾəl də jəɹ stændɪŋ wɪð ði ʌðɝ wɛtləndɝz noʊ ɡʊɾ ɪf wi mʌs baɪn jə əntɪl jə kɑm daʊn. ɡoʊ tə jəɹ tɛnt. ɪf jə kænɑt kəntʃɹoʊl jəɹ θɔts, dʒɹɪŋk əntɪl jə kænɑt θɪŋk. ən də nɑt bɑðɝ əs wən wəɹ ɪn kaʊnsəl." ʃi dʌk bæk ɪndə ðə tɛnt, ən ðə flæps dʒɝkt kloʊzd ən bɪɡæn tə twɪtʃ əz ðeɪ wɝ taɪɾ əɡɛn.

"Do not become irrational," she broke in sharply. "Men often do in such situations, but we have need of you. I think it will do your standing with the other wetlanders no good if we must bind you until you calm down. Go to your tent. If you cannot control your thoughts, drink until you cannot think. And do not bother us when we are in council." She ducked back into the tent, and the flaps jerked closed and began to twitch as they were tied again.

pɛɹɪn kənsɪɾɝd ðə kloʊz flæps, ɹʌnɪŋ ɪz θʌm oʊvɝ ðə bleɪɾ ə hɪz naɪf, ðən ʃʌvd ɪɾ ɪndə ðə ʃiθ. ðeɪ dʒʌs maɪt də əz nəvɛɝɪn hæd θɹɛɾənd ɪf i bɑɹdʒd ɪn. ən ðeɪ kəd nɑt tɛl ɪm ɛniθɪŋ i wɑntəd tə noʊ. hi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ʃi wəd kip sikɹəts əɾ ə taɪm laɪk ðɪs. nɑɾ əbaʊt feɪl, ɛniweɪ.

Perrin considered the closed flaps, running his thumb over the blade of his knife, then shoved it into the sheath. They just might do as Nevarin had threatened if he barged in. And they could not tell him anything he wanted to know. He did not think she would keep secrets at a time like this. Not about Faile, anyway.

ðə hɪltɑp hæd ɡɹoʊn kwaɪəɾɝ, wɪð moʊst ə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn ɡɔn. ðə ɹɪmeɪndɝ, stɪl wɑtʃfəl ə ðə ɡildænɪn kæmp bɪloʊ, stæmp ðɛɹ fiɾ əɡɛns ðə koʊld, bʌt noʊ wʌn tɔkt. ðə skɝiɪŋ ɡeɪʃeɪn hɑɹdli meɪɾ ə saʊnd. tʃɹiz əbskjʊɹd pɑɹts ə ðə ɡildænɪn ən minɝ kæmps, bʌt pɛɹɪn kəd si kɑɹts biɪŋ loʊɾəd ɪn boʊθ. hi dɪsaɪɾɪd tə liv mɛn ɑn ɡɑɹɾ ɛniweɪ. ɑɹɡændə kəd bi tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə lʌl hɪm. ə mæn u smɛld laɪk ðət kəd bi . . . ɪɹæʃənəl, hi fɪnɪʃt ðə θɔt dʒɹaɪli.

The hilltop had grown quieter, with most of the Two Rivers men gone. The remainder, still watchful of the Ghealdanin camp below, stamped their feet against the cold, but no one talked. The scurrying gai'shain hardly made a sound. Trees obscured parts of the Ghealdanin and Mayener camps, but Perrin could see carts being loaded in both. He decided to leave men on guard anyway. Arganda could be trying to lull him. A man who smelled like that could be . . . Irrational, he finished the thought dryly.

ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ lɛft fəɹ ɪm tə də ɑn ðə hɪl, soʊ hi sɛɾ aʊt tə wɔk ðə hæf maɪl tə hɪz tɛnt. ðə tɛn i ʃɛɹd wɪð feɪl. hi stʌmbəld əz mʌtʃ əz wɔkt, leɪbɝɪŋ wən ðə snoʊ ɹoʊz ɝaʊn ɪz lɛɡz. əz mʌtʃ tə stɑp ɪt snæpɪŋ ɪn ðə wɪn əz fəɹ wɔɹmθ, hi hɛld ɪz kloʊk taɪɾ ɝaʊn hɪm. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ wɔɹmθ.

There was nothing left for him to do on the hill, so he set out to walk the half mile to his tent. The tent he shared with Faile. He stumbled as much as walked, laboring when the snow rose around his legs. As much to stop it snapping in the wind as for warmth, he held his cloak tight around him. There was no warmth.

ðə tu ɹɪvɝz kæmp wɑz æzwɝm wɪð æktɪvəɾi wən i ɝaɪvd. ðə kɑɹts stɪl meɪɾ ə bɪɡ sɝkəl, wɪð mɛn ən wɪmən fɹəm dɑbɹeɪnz ɪsteɪts bæk ɪn kɛɹhin loʊɾɪŋ ðɛm, ən ʌðɝz ɹɛɾiɪŋ hɔɹsəz fəɹ sæɾəlɪŋ. ɪn ðɪs dɛpθ ə snoʊ, kɑɹtwilz maɪɾ əz wɛl əv tʃɹaɪd tə ɹoʊl θɹu mʌd, soʊ ðeɪ wɝ ɔl læʃt tə ðə saɪdz ə ðə kɑɹts, naʊ, ɹipleɪs baɪ pɛɹz ə bɹɔd wʊɾən slɛdz. bʌndəld əɡɛns ðə wɛðɝ tɪl moʊst sim twaɪs əz waɪɾ əz ðeɪ ɹɪli wɝ, ðə kɛɹhinɪn hɑɹdli pɔz tə ɡlæns ət hɪm, bʌɾ ɛvɹi tu ɹɪvɝz mæn u sɔ hɪm stɑp tə stɛɹ əntɪl sʌmwʌn ɛls pɹɑɾɪd ðə fɛloʊ tə ɡɛɾ ɑn wɪð wʌtɛvɝ i wɑz əbaʊt. pɛɹɪn wɑz ɡlæd nʌn ɡeɪv wɝdz tə ðə sɪmpəθi ɪn ðoʊz stɛɹz. hi θɔɾ i maɪt bɹeɪk daʊn ən kɹaɪ ɪf ɛniwʌn dɪd.

The Two Rivers camp was aswarm with activity when he arrived. The carts still made a big circle, with men and women from Dobraine's estates back in Cairhien loading them, and others readying horses for saddling. In this depth of snow, cartwheels might as well have tried to roll through mud, so they were all lashed to the sides of the carts, now, replaced by pairs of broad wooden sleds. Bundled against the weather till most seemed twice as wide as they really were, the Cairhienin hardly paused to glance at him, but every Two Rivers man who saw him stopped to stare until someone else prodded the fellow to get on with whatever he was about. Perrin was glad none gave words to the sympathy in those stares. He thought he might break down and cry if anyone did.

ðəɹ sim tə bi nʌθɪŋ fəɹ ɪm tə də hɪɹ, iðɝ. hɪz bɪɡ tɛnt - hɪz ən feɪlz - wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi daʊn ən ɑn ə kɑɹt, əlɔŋ wɪð ɪts kɑntɛns. bɑzəl ɡɪl wɑz wɔkɪŋ əlɔŋ ðə kɑɹts wɪð ə lɔŋ lɪst ɪn ɪz hænz. ðə staʊt mæn hæd teɪkən tə ðə dʒɑb ə ʃæmbaɪən, ɹʌnɪŋ feɪlz haʊshoʊld, pɛɹɪnz, laɪk ə skwɝəl tə ə kɔɹn kɹɪb. mɔɹ juz tə sɪɾiz ðən tʃɹævlɪŋ aʊtsaɪd ðɛɹ wɔlz, ðoʊ, hi sʌfɝd fɹəm ðə koʊld, ən wɔɹ nɑɾ oʊnli ə kloʊk bʌɾ ə θɪk skɑɹf ɝaʊn ɪz nɛk, ə flɑpi-bɹɪm fɛl hæɾ ən hɛvi wʊlən ɡlʌvz. fəɹ səm ɹizən, ɡɪl flɪntʃt ət ðə saɪɾ ə hɪm, ən mʌmbəl sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt siɪŋ tə ðə kɑɹts bɪfɔɹ hɝiɪŋ ɔf əz fæst əz i kʊd. ɑd.

There seemed to be nothing for him to do here, either. His big tent - his and Faile's - was already down and on a cart, along with its contents. Basel Gill was walking along the carts with a long list in his hands. The stout man had taken to the job of shambayan, running Faile's household, Perrin's, like a squirrel to a corn crib. More used to cities than traveling outside their walls, though, he suffered from the cold, and wore not only a cloak but a thick scarf around his neck, a floppy-brimmed felt hat and heavy woolen gloves. For some reason, Gill flinched at the sight of him, and mumbled something about seeing to the carts before hurrying off as fast as he could. Odd.

pɛɹɪn dɪd θɪŋk ʌv wʌn θɪŋ ðɛn, ən faɪndɪŋ dænɪl, hi ɡeɪv ɔɹɾɝz tə ɹɪliv ðə mɛn ɑn ðə hɪl ɛvɹi aʊɝ ən meɪk ʃʊɹ ɛvɹiwʌn hæɾ ə hɑt mil.

Perrin did think of one thing then, and finding Dannil, he gave orders to relieve the men on the hill every hour and make sure everyone had a hot meal.

"teɪk kɛɹ ə ðə mɛn ən hɔɹsəz fɝst," ə θɪn bʌt stʃɹɔŋ vɔɪs sɛd. "bʌt ðən jə mʌs teɪk kɛɹ ə jɝsɛlf. ðɛɹz hɑt sup ɪn ðə kɛɾəl, ən bɹɛɾ ʌv ə sɔɹt, ən aɪv pʊt baɪ səm smoʊk hæm. ə fʊl bɛli wɪl meɪk jə lʊk lɛs laɪk mɝɾɝ wɔkɪŋ."

"Take care of the men and horses first," a thin but strong voice said. "But then you must take care of yourself. There's hot soup in the kettle, and bread of a sort, and I've put by some smoked ham. A full belly will make you look less like murder walking."

"θæŋk ju, lini," hi sɛd. mɝɾɝ wɔkɪŋ? laɪt, hi fɛlt laɪk wʌn ə ðə dɛd, nɑɾ ə mɝɾɝɝ. "aɪl iɾ ɪn ə lɪɾəl waɪl."

"Thank you, Lini," he said. Murder walking? Light, he felt like one of the dead, not a murderer. "I'll eat in a little while."

feɪlz tʃif meɪd wɑz ə fɹeɪl-əpɪɹɪŋ wʊmən, wɪð skɪn laɪk pɑɹtʃmən ən waɪt hɛɹ ɪn ə bʌn ɑn tɑp ə hɝ hɛd, bʌɾ əɹ bæk wɑz stʃɹeɪɾ ən əɹ dɑɹk aɪz wɝ klɪɹ ən ʃɑɹp. wɝi kɹist əɹ fɔɹhɛd naʊ, ðoʊ, ən əɹ hænz ɡɹɪpt əɹ kloʊk tu taɪtli, stʃɹeɪnɪŋ. ʃi wəd bi wɝiɾ əbaʊt feɪl, sɝɾənli, bʌt . . .

Faile's chief maid was a frail-appearing woman, with skin like parchment and white hair in a bun on top of her head, but her back was straight and her dark eyes were clear and sharp. Worry creased her forehead now, though, and her hands gripped her cloak too tightly, straining. She would be worried about Faile, certainly, but . . .

"meɪaɪɡdɪn wɑz wɪð hɝ," hi sɛd, ən dɪd nɑt niɾ əɹ nɑd. meɪaɪɡdɪn wɑz ɔlweɪz wɪð feɪl, ɪt simd. ə tʃɹɛʒɝ, feɪl kɔl hɝ. ən lini sim tə kənsɪɾɝ ðə wʊmən əɹ dɔɾɝ, ðoʊ səmtaɪmz meɪaɪɡdɪn dɪd nɑɾ əpɪɹ tə ɛndʒɔɪ ðəɾ əz mʌtʃ əz lini dɪd. "aɪl ɡɛɾ əm bæk," hi pɹɑməst. "ɔl ə ðɛm." hɪz vɔɪs ɔlmoʊs bɹoʊk ɑn ðæt. "ɡɛɾ ɑn wɪð jəɹ wɝk," hi wɛn ɑn ɹʌfli, hɝidli. "aɪl iɾ ɪn ə bɪt. aɪ hæv tə si tə . . . tə . . ." hi stʃɹoʊɾ əweɪ wɪθaʊt fɪnɪʃɪŋ.

"Maighdin was with her," he said, and did not need her nod. Maighdin was always with Faile, it seemed. A treasure, Faile called her. And Lini seemed to consider the woman her daughter, though sometimes Maighdin did not appear to enjoy that as much as Lini did. "I'll get them back," he promised. "All of them." His voice almost broke on that. "Get on with your work," he went on roughly, hurriedly. "I'll eat in a bit. I have to see to . . . to . . ." He strode away without finishing.

ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ i hæd tə si tə. nʌθɪŋ i kəd θɪŋk ʌv, ɪksɛp feɪl. hi hɑɹdli nu wɛɹ i wɑz hɛɾɪŋ əntɪl ɪz stɛps tʊk ɪm aʊtsaɪd ðə sɝkəl ə kɑɹts.

There was nothing he had to see to. Nothing he could think of, except Faile. He hardly knew where he was heading until his steps took him outside the circle of carts.

ə hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz bɪɑn ðə hɔɹslaɪnz, ə loʊ, stoʊni ɹɪdʒ θɹʌst ə blæk pik θɹu ðə snoʊ. fɹəm ðɛɹ, hi wəd bi eɪbəl tə si ðə tʃɹæks lɛf baɪ ɛlaɪəs ən ði ʌðɝz. fɹəm ðɛɹ, hi wəd si ðɛm ɹɪtɝnɪŋ.

A hundred paces beyond the horselines, a low, stony ridge thrust a black peak through the snow. From there, he would be able to see the tracks left by Elyas and the others. From there, he would see them returning.

hɪz noʊz toʊld ɪm i wɑz nɑɾ əloʊn wɛl bɪfɔɹ i ɹitʃt ðə nɛɹoʊ kɹɛst ə ðə ɹɪdʒ, toʊld ɪm u wɑz ʌp ðɛɹ. ði ʌðɝ mæn wɑz nɑt lɪsnɪŋ, kəz pɛɹɪn kɹʌntʃt ɪz weɪ tə ðə tɑp bɪfɔɹ i spɹæŋ ʌp fɹəm wɛɹ i hæd bɪn kɹaʊtʃɪŋ ɑn ɪz hilz. tɑlænvɝz ɡɔntələɾəd hænz niɾɪd ɪz lɔŋ sɔɹd hɪlt, ən i pɪɹɾ ət pɛɹɪn ənsɝteɪnli. ə tɔl mæn u hæd teɪkən hɑɹd nɑks ɪn ɪz laɪf, hi juʒəwəli wɑz vɛɹi ʃʊɹ ə hɪmsɛlf. pɝhæps i ɪkspɛktəɾ ə taɪɹeɪd fəɹ nɑt hævɪŋ bɪn ðəɹ wən feɪl wɑz teɪkən, ðoʊ ʃi hæd ɹɪdʒɛktɪd ði ɑɹmsmən əz ə bɑɾiɡɑɹd, ɹɪdʒɛktɪɾ ɛni bɑɾiɡɑɹd. bɪɑn beɪn ən kiæd, ət list, hu əpɛɹənli dɪd nɑt kaʊnt. əɹ meɪbi hi dʒʌs θɔɾ i wəd bi sɛn əweɪ, bæk tə ðə kɑɹts, soʊ pɛɹɪn kəd bi əloʊn. pɛɹɪn tʃɹaɪd tə meɪk ɪz feɪs lʊk lɛs laɪk - wʌt hæd lini kɔld ɪt? - mɝɾɝ wɔkɪŋ? tɑlænvɝ wɑz ɪn lʌv wɪð meɪaɪɡdɪn, ən wəd bi wɛd tə hɝ sun ɪf feɪlz səspɪʃənz wɝ kɝɛkt. ðə mæn hæɾ ə ɹaɪt tə kip wɑtʃ.

His nose told him he was not alone well before he reached the narrow crest of the ridge, told him who was up there. The other man was not listening, because Perrin crunched his way to the top before he sprang up from where he had been crouching on his heels. Tallanvor's gauntleted hands kneaded his long sword hilt, and he peered at Perrin uncertainly. A tall man who had taken hard knocks in his life, he usually was very sure of himself. Perhaps he expected a tirade for not having been there when Faile was taken, though she had rejected the armsman as a bodyguard, rejected any bodyguard. Beyond Bain and Chiad, at least, who apparently did not count. Or maybe he just thought he would be sent away, back to the carts, so Perrin could be alone. Perrin tried to make his face look less like - what had Lini called it? - murder walking? Tallanvor was in love with Maighdin, and would be wed to her soon if Faile's suspicions were correct. The man had a right to keep watch.

ðeɪ stʊd ðəɹ ɑn ðə ɹɪdʒ waɪl twaɪlaɪt fɛl, ən nʌθɪŋ muvd ɪn ðə snoʊi fɔɹəs ðeɪ wɑtʃt. dɑɹknəs keɪm wɪθaʊt muvmənt, ən wɪθaʊt mæsimə, bʌt pɛɹɪn dɪd nɑɾ ivən θɪŋk ə mæsimə. ðə ɡɪbəs mun ʃoʊn waɪɾ ɑn ðə snoʊ, ɡɪvɪŋ nɪɹli əz mʌtʃ laɪɾ əz ə fʊl mun, ɪt simd. əntɪl skəɪŋ klaʊdz bɪɡæn tə haɪɾ ɪt, ən munʃæɾoʊz ɹeɪst əkɹɔs ðə snoʊ, θɪkɝ ən θɪkɝ. snoʊ bɪɡæn tə fɔl wɪð ə dʒɹaɪ ɹʌslɪŋ. snoʊ ðət wəd bɛɹi tʃɹeɪsəz ən tʃɹæks. saɪlən ɪn ðə koʊld, ðə tu mɛn stʊd ðɛɹ, wɑtʃɪŋ ɪndə ðə snoʊfɔl, weɪɾɪŋ, hoʊpɪŋ.

They stood there on the ridge while twilight fell, and nothing moved in the snowy forest they watched. Darkness came without movement, and without Masema, but Perrin did not even think of Masema. The gibbous moon shone white on the snow, giving nearly as much light as a full moon, it seemed. Until scudding clouds began to hide it, and moonshadows raced across the snow, thicker and thicker. Snow began to fall with a dry rustling. Snow that would bury traces and tracks. Silent in the cold, the two men stood there, watching into the snowfall, waiting, hoping.


tʃæptɝ θɹi


CHAPTER 3

kʌstəmz


Customs

fɹəm ðə fɝst aʊɝ æftɝ biɪŋ kæptʃɝd, leɪbɝɪŋ θɹu ðə snoʊi wʊdz, feɪl wɝiɾ əbaʊt fɹizɪŋ. bɹizɪz stɝɾ ən daɪd, stɝɾ ən daɪd. fju ʌv ðə skæɾɝd tʃɹiz stɪl kæɹid livz, ən moʊst ə ðoʊz hʌŋ dɛɾ ən bɹaʊn. ðə bɹizɪz swɝl θɹu ðə fɔɹəst ənhɪndɝd, ən smɔl əz ðə ɡʌsts wɝ, ðeɪ kæɹiɾ aɪs. pɛɹɪn hɑɹdli ɛntɝɾ əɹ θɔts, ɪksɛp fəɹ ə hoʊp ðəɾ i sʌmhaʊ lɝn ə mæsiməz sikɹət dilɪŋz. ən ə ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ, ʌv kɔɹs. ivən ɪf ðət tʃɹʌl bɹəleɪn wɑz ði oʊnli wʌn u kəd tɛl hɪm, naʊ. ʃi hoʊp bɹəleɪn hæɾ ɪskeɪp ði æmbʊʃ ən toʊl pɛɹɪn ɛvɹiθɪŋ. ən ðən fɔlən ɪndə ə hoʊl ən bɹoʊkən əɹ nɛk. bʌt ʃi hæd fɑɹ mɔɹ pɹɛsɪŋ kənsɝnz ðən əɹ hʌzbənd.

From the first hour after being captured, laboring through the snowy woods, Faile worried about freezing. Breezes stirred and died, stirred and died. Few of the scattered trees still carried leaves, and most of those hung dead and brown. The breezes swirled through the forest unhindered, and small as the gusts were, they carried ice. Perrin hardly entered her thoughts, except for a hope that he somehow learned of Masema's secret dealings. And of the Shaido, of course. Even if that trull Berelain was the only one who could tell him, now. She hoped Berelain had escaped the ambush and told Perrin everything. And then fallen into a hole and broken her neck. But she had far more pressing concerns than her husband.

ʃi hæd kɔl ðɪs wɛðɝ ɔtʌmnəl, jɛt pipəl fɹoʊz tə dɛθ ɪn ə sɑldəiən ɔɾəm, ən ə hɝ kloʊðz ʃi ɹɪteɪn oʊnli hɝ dɑɹk wʊlən stɑkɪŋz. wʌn læʃt əɹ ɛlboʊz taɪt bɪhaɪn əɹ bæk, waɪl ðə sɛkən hæd bɪn taɪɾ ɝaʊn əɹ nɛk fəɹ ə liʃ. bɹeɪv wɝdz meɪd skæn kʌvɝɪŋ fəɹ bɛɹ skɪn. ʃi wɑz tu koʊl fəɹ swɛt, jɛɾ əɹ lɛɡz sun ætʃt wɪð ðə stʃɹʌɡəl tə kip ʌp wɪð əɹ kæptɝz. ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ kɑləm, veɪl mɛn ən meɪɾənz, sloʊd wən ðə snoʊ ɹoʊz təwɔɹd ðɛɹ niz bʌɾ ɪmiɾiətli ɹɪzumd ə stɛɾi tʃɹɑt wən ɪt sæŋk təwɔɹd ðɛɹ æŋkəlz, ən ðeɪ dɪd nɑt sim tə taɪɝ. hɔɹsəz kəd nɑɾ əv muv fæstɝ oʊvɝ ðə dɪstəns. ʃɪvɝɪŋ, ʃi leɪbɝɾ ɑn ət ði ɛn ə hɝ liʃ, duɪŋ əɹ bɛs tə ɡʌlp ɛɹ θɹu tiθ ɡɹɪɾɪd tə stɑp ðɛɹ tʃæɾɝɪŋ.

She had called this weather autumnal, yet people froze to death in a Saldaean autumn, and of her clothes she retained only her dark woolen stockings. One lashed her elbows tight behind her back, while the second had been tied around her neck for a leash. Brave words made scant covering for bare skin. She was too cold for sweat, yet her legs soon ached with the struggle to keep up with her captors. The Shaido column, veiled men and Maidens, slowed when the snow rose toward their knees but immediately resumed a steady trot when it sank toward their ankles, and they did not seem to tire. Horses could not have moved faster over the distance. Shivering, she labored on at the end of her leash, doing her best to gulp air through teeth gritted to stop their chattering.

ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ wɝ fjuɝ ðən ʃi hæɾ ɛstəmeɪɾəd dʊɹɪŋ ði ətæk, noʊ mɔɹ ðən ə hʌnʒɹəd ən fɪfti ʃi θɔt, ən nɪɹli ɔl kæɹid spɪɹz əɹ baʊz ət ðə ɹɛɾi. smɔl tʃæns ɛniwʌn kəd sɝpɹaɪz ðɛm. ɔlweɪz əlɝt, ðeɪ ɡɑstɪɾ əlɔŋ ɪn saɪləns ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə feɪn kɹʌntʃ ə ðə snoʊ ʌndɝ ðɛɹ sɑft, ni-haɪ buts. ðə ɡɹinz ən ɡɹeɪz ən bɹaʊnz ə ðɛɹ kloʊðɪŋ stʊɾ aʊɾ əɡɛns ðə waɪt lændskeɪp, ðoʊ. ɡɹin hæd bɪn æɾəd tə ðə keɪɾɪnsɝ sɪns kɹɔsɪŋ ðə dʒɹæɡoʊnwɔl, soʊ beɪn ən kiæd hæd toʊl hɝ, tə eɪd kənsilmən ɪn ə ɡɹin lænd. waɪ hæd ðiz pipəl nɑɾ æɾəd waɪt, fəɹ ðə wɪntɝ? əz ɪt wɑz, ðeɪ kəd bi sin ət səm dɪstəns. ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə noʊɾəs ɛvɹiθɪŋ, ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɛniθɪŋ ðət maɪt pɹuv jusfəl leɪɾɝ, wən ɪt keɪm taɪm tə ɪskeɪp. ʃi hoʊpt əɹ fɛloʊ pɹɪznɝz wɝ duɪŋ əz mʌtʃ. pɛɹɪn wəd bi hʌntɪŋ fəɹ hɝ, sɝɾənli, bʌt ðə θɔɾ ə ɹɛskju nɛvɝ ɛntɝɾ əɹ kælkjəleɪʃənz. weɪt fəɹ ɹɛskju, ən jə maɪt weɪt fɝɛvɝ. bɪsaɪdz, ðeɪ niɾəd tə ɪskeɪp əz kwɪkli əz pɑsəbəl, bɪfɔɹ ðɛɹ kæptɝz dʒɔɪnd wɪð ðə ɹɛst ə ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ. ʃi kəd nɑt si haʊ, jɛt, bʌt ðəɹ mʌs bi ə weɪ. ðə wʌn bɪɾ ə lʌk wɑz ðət ðə meɪn bɑɾi ʌv ʃeɪɾoʊ mʌs bi deɪz dɪstənt. ðɪs pɑɹɾ ʌv ɑmɑdɪʃiə wɑz keɪɑs, bʌt θaʊzənz ə ʃeɪɾoʊ kəd nɑt bi tu nɪɹ wɪθaʊɾ əɹ hævɪŋ hɝɾ ə ðɛm.

The Shaido were fewer than she had estimated during the attack, no more than a hundred and fifty she thought, and nearly all carried spears or bows at the ready. Small chance anyone could surprise them. Always alert, they ghosted along in silence except for the faint crunch of the snow under their soft, knee-high boots. The greens and grays and browns of their clothing stood out against the white landscape, though. Green had been added to the cadin'sor since crossing the Dragonwall, so Bain and Chiad had told her, to aid concealment in a green land. Why had these people not added white, for the winter? As it was, they could be seen at some distance. She tried to notice everything, remember anything that might prove useful later, when it came time to escape. She hoped her fellow prisoners were doing as much. Perrin would be hunting for her, certainly, but the thought of rescue never entered her calculations. Wait for rescue, and you might wait forever. Besides, they needed to escape as quickly as possible, before their captors joined with the rest of the Shaido. She could not see how, yet, but there must be a way. The one bit of luck was that the main body of Shaido must be days distant. This part of Amadicia was chaos, but thousands of Shaido could not be too near without her having heard of them.

wʌns, ɝli ɑn, ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə lʊk bæk ət ðə wɪmən u hæd bɪn kæptʃɝd wɪð hɝ, bʌt ði oʊnli ɹɪzʌlt wɑz ə stʌmbəlɪŋ fɔl ɪndə ə snoʊbæŋk. hæf-bɛɹiɾ ɪn ðə waɪt paʊɾɝ, ʃi ɡæsp fɹəm ði aɪsi ʃɑk, ən ɡæspt əɡɛn wən ðə ɡɹeɪt hʌlkɪŋ ʃeɪɾoʊ hu hɛld əɹ liʃ sɛɾ əɹ bæk ɑn əɹ fit. əz waɪɾ əz pɛɹɪn ən ə fʊl hɛd tɔlɝ, ɹoʊlən sɪmpli hɔld əɹ əpɹaɪt baɪ ə fɪsfəl ə hɝ hɛɹ, sɛɾ əɹ muvɪŋ əɡɛn wɪð ə bɹɪsk slæp ɑn əɹ bɛɹ bɑɾəm, ən wʌns mɔɹ tʊk ʌp ðə lɔŋ stʃɹaɪdz ðət fɔɹst əɹ tə stɛp kwɪkli. ðə slæp maɪɾ əv bɪn ɡɪvən tə meɪk ə poʊni muv. dɪspaɪɾ əɹ neɪkədnəs, ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ ʌv ə mæn lʊkɪŋ əɾ ə wʊmən ɪn ɹoʊlənz blu aɪz. pɑɹɾ ə hɝ wɑz vɛɹi ɡɹeɪtfəl. pɑɹɾ əɹ wɑz veɪɡli . . . teɪkən əbæk. ʃi sɝɾənli dɪd nɑt wɑn ɪm ɡeɪzɪŋ əɾ əɹ wɪð lʌst əɹ ivən ɪntʃɹəst, bʌt ðoʊz blænd ɡlænsɪz wɝ ɔlmoʊst ɪnsʌltɪŋ! æftɝ ðət ʃi meɪd ʃʊɹ nɑt tə fɔl, ðoʊ əz ði aʊɝz pæst wɪθaʊɾ ə pɔz ɪn ðə mɑɹtʃ, sɪmpli steɪɪŋ əpɹaɪt bɪkeɪm mɔɹ ən mɔɹ ʌv ən ɛfɝt.

Once, early on, she tried to look back at the women who had been captured with her, but the only result was a stumbling fall into a snowbank. Half-buried in the white powder, she gasped from the icy shock, and gasped again when the great hulking Shaido who held her leash set her back on her feet. As wide as Perrin and a full head taller, Rolan simply hauled her upright by a fistful of her hair, set her moving again with a brisk slap on her bare bottom, and once more took up the long strides that forced her to step quickly. The slap might have been given to make a pony move. Despite her nakedness, there was nothing of a man looking at a woman in Rolan's blue eyes. Part of her was very grateful. Part her was vaguely . . . taken aback. She certainly did not want him gazing at her with lust or even interest, but those bland glances were almost insulting! After that she made sure not to fall, though as the hours passed without a pause in the march, simply staying upright became more and more of an effort.

ɪn ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ ʃi wɝiɾ oʊvɝ wɪtʃ bɪts ə hɝ wəd fɹiz fɝst, bʌt baɪ ðə taɪm mɔɹnɪŋ hæd ɹoʊld ɪndə æftɝnun wɪθaʊɾ ə pɔz ɪn ðə mɑɹtʃ, ʃi wɑz foʊkəst ɑn əɹ fit. ɹoʊlən ən ðoʊz əhɛɾ ə hɪm tʃɹæmpəld ə sɔɹɾ ə pæθ fəɹ hɝ, jɛɾ ɪnʌf snoʊkɹʌst ɹɪmeɪn fəɹ ʃɑɹp ɛdʒəz, ən ʃi bɪɡæn tə liv ɹɛd steɪnz fɹizɪŋ ɪn əɹ fʊtpɹɪns. wɝs wɑz ðə koʊld ɪtsɛlf. ʃi hæd sin fɹɔstbaɪt. haʊ lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ əɹ toʊz bɪɡæn tə tɝn blæk? stæɡɝɪŋ, ʃi flɛkst itʃ fʊɾ əz ʃi swʌŋ ɪt fɔɹwɝd, ən wɝkt əɹ hænz kɑnstənli. fɪŋɡɝz ən toʊz wɝ ɪn ðə wɝs deɪnʒɝ, bʌɾ ɛni ɪkspoʊz skɪn wɑz ət ɹɪsk. əbaʊɾ əɹ feɪs ən ðə ɹɛst ə hɝ ʃi kəɾ oʊnli hoʊp. ðə flɛksɪŋ hɝt, meɪkɪŋ ðə kʌts ɑn əɹ fit bɝn, bʌɾ ɛni filɪŋ wɑz bɛɾɝ ðən nʌn. wən sɛnseɪʃən wɛnt, ʃi wəɾ əv vɛɹi lɪɾəl taɪm lɛft. flɛks ən stʃɹaɪd, flɛks ən stʃɹaɪd. ðət fɪld əɹ θɔts. ʃi kɛp muvɪŋ ɑn kwɪvɝɪŋ lɛɡz, ən kɛpt əɹ hænz ən fit fɹəm fɹizɪŋ. ʃi kɛp muvɪŋ.

In the beginning she worried over which bits of her would freeze first, but by the time morning had rolled into afternoon without a pause in the march, she was focused on her feet. Rolan and those ahead of him trampled a sort of path for her, yet enough snowcrust remained for sharp edges, and she began to leave red stains freezing in her footprints. Worse was the cold itself. She had seen frostbite. How long before her toes began to turn black? Staggering, she flexed each foot as she swung it forward, and worked her hands constantly. Fingers and toes were in the worst danger, but any exposed skin was at risk. About her face and the rest of her she could only hope. The flexing hurt, making the cuts on her feet burn, but any feeling was better than none. When sensation went, she would have very little time left. Flex and stride, flex and stride. That filled her thoughts. She kept moving on quivering legs, and kept her hands and feet from freezing. She kept moving.

əbɹʌpli, ʃi stʌmbəld ɪndə ɹoʊlən ən ɹɪbaʊndɪd fɹəm ɪz waɪd tʃɛst, pæntɪŋ. hæf deɪzd, əɹ meɪbi mɔɹ ðən hæf, ʃi hæd nɑt ɹilaɪz ðəɾ i hæd stɑpt. soʊ hæd ði ʌðɝz əhɛd, ə fju lʊkɪŋ bæk, ðə ɹɛs feɪsɪŋ aʊtwɝɾ ən wɛɹəli ɑn ɡɑɹd, wɛpənz ʌp əz ðoʊ ɪkspɛktɪŋ ətæk. ðət wɑz ɔl ʃi hæd taɪm tə si bɪfɔɹ ɹoʊlən sizd ə hændfʊl ə hɝ hɛɹ əɡɛn ən bɛn tə lɪft wʌn ə hɝ fit. laɪt, ðə mæn ɹɪli wɑz tʃɹiɾɪŋ əɹ laɪk ə poʊni!

Abruptly, she stumbled into Rolan and rebounded from his wide chest, panting. Half dazed, or maybe more than half, she had not realized that he had stopped. So had the others ahead, a few looking back, the rest facing outward and warily on guard, weapons up as though expecting attack. That was all she had time to see before Rolan seized a handful of her hair again and bent to lift one of her feet. Light, the man really was treating her like a pony!

ɹilisɪŋ əɹ hɛɹ ən əɹ fʊt, hi sneɪkt ən ɑɹm ɝaʊn əɹ lɛɡz, ən ðə nɛks moʊmən əɹ vɪʒən wɝld əz ʃi wɑz hivd ʌp ɑntu hɪz ʃoʊldɝ, hɛd-daʊn bɪsaɪd ðə hɔɹn baʊ keɪst ɑn ɪz bæk. ɪndɪɡneɪʃən wɛld ʌp əz i kæʒəwəli ʃɪftəɾ əɹ əbaʊt tə faɪn ði iziəs pəzɪʃən fəɹ kæɹiɪŋ, bʌt ʃi tæmpt ɪt daʊn əz fæst əz ɪt ɹoʊz. ðɪs wɑz noʊ pleɪs əɹ taɪm. hɝ fit wɝ aʊɾ ə ðə snoʊ; ðət wɑz wʌt mæɾɝd. ən ʃi kəd kætʃ əɹ bɹɛθ, laɪk ðɪs. hi cʊɾə wɔɹn hɝ, ðoʊ.

Releasing her hair and her foot, he snaked an arm around her legs, and the next moment her vision whirled as she was heaved up onto his shoulder, head-down beside the horn bow cased on his back. Indignation welled up as he casually shifted her about to find the easiest position for carrying, but she tamped it down as fast as it rose. This was no place or time. Her feet were out of the snow; that was what mattered. And she could catch her breath, like this. He could have warned her, though.

wɪð ən ɛfɝt, ʃi ɑɹtʃt əɹ nɛk soʊ ʃi kəd si hɝ kəmpænjənz, ən fɛlt ɹɪlif tə faɪn əm ɔl stɪl ðɛɹ. neɪkəd pɹɪznɝz, tʃɹu, bʌt ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ oʊnli ə kɔɹps wʊɾə bɪn lɛf bɪhaɪnd. ði ʌðɝz u wɔkt wɝ liʃt wɪð stɑkɪŋz əɹ stʃɹɪps ə klɔθ kʌt fɹəm ðɛɹ lɔst ɡɑɹməns, ən moʊst ɔlsoʊ hæd ðɛɹ ɑɹmz taɪd bɪhaɪnd. æliændɝ wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə bɛn dʌbəl ɪn ən ətɛmp tə ʃil hɝsɛlf. ʌðɝ kənsɝnz hæd ɹipleɪs mɑɾəsti fəɹ ðə kwin ʌv ɡildən. pæntɪŋ ən tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ, ʃi maɪɾ əv fɔlən ɪf ðə skwɑt ʃeɪɾoʊ ɪɡzæmɪnɪŋ əɹ fit hæd nɑt səpɔɹɾəd əɹ baɪ hɝ baʊn ɛlboʊz. skwɑt fəɹ ən il mɛn i cʊɾə pæst ənɹɪmɑɹk moʊs pleɪsəz, ɪksɛp fəɹ ʃoʊldɝz nɪɹli əz waɪɾ əz ɹoʊlənz. ðə dɑɹk hɛɹ spɪlɪŋ daʊn æliændɝz bæk wɑz wɪnbloʊn, hɝ feɪs hæɡɝd. bɪhaɪn hɝ, meɪaɪɡdɪn əpɪɹɾ ɪn ɔlmoʊst əz bæɾ ə steɪt, ɡʌlpɪŋ ɛɹ, ɹɛd-ɡoʊl hɛɹ ɪn dɪsɝeɪ ən blu aɪz stɛɹɪŋ, jɛt ʃi mænədʒ tə steɪ ɪɹɛkt ɑn əɹ oʊn wɪð ə boʊn-lin meɪɾən lɪftɪŋ əɹ fʊt. sʌmhaʊ, feɪlz meɪd lʊk mɔɹ ə kwin ðən æliændɝ dɪd, ɪf ə vɛɹi dɪʃɛvəl kwin.

With an effort, she arched her neck so she could see her companions, and felt relief to find them all still there. Naked prisoners, true, but she was sure only a corpse would have been left behind. The others who walked were leashed with stockings or strips of cloth cut from their lost garments, and most also had their arms tied behind. Alliandre was no longer trying to bend double in an attempt to shield herself. Other concerns had replaced modesty for the Queen of Ghealdan. Panting and trembling, she might have fallen if the squat Shaido examining her feet had not supported her by her bound elbows. Squat for an Aiel meant he could have passed unremarked most places, except for shoulders nearly as wide as Rolan's. The dark hair spilling down Alliandre's back was windblown, her face haggard. Behind her, Maighdin appeared in almost as bad a state, gulping air, red-gold hair in disarray and blue eyes staring, yet she managed to stay erect on her own with a bone-lean Maiden lifting her foot. Somehow, Faile's maid looked more a queen than Alliandre did, if a very disheveled queen.
