ɪn kəmpɛɹəsən, beɪn ən kiæd simd ɪn noʊ wɝs steɪt ðən dɪd ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ, ðoʊ kiædz tʃik wɑz jɛloʊɪŋ ən swoʊlən fɹəm ə bloʊ wən ðeɪ wɝ fɝs teɪkən, ən ðə blæk blʌd mæɾɪŋ beɪnz ʃɔɹt faɪɝi hɛɹ ən spɹɛɾ əkɹɔs əɹ feɪs sim tə hæv fɹoʊzən. ðət wɑz bæd; ðət kəd skɑɹ. ðə tu meɪɾənz wɝ nɑt bɹiðɪŋ hɑɹd, ðoʊ, ən ivən ɹeɪz ðɛɹ oʊn fit fəɹ ɪɡzæməneɪʃən. əloʊn ə ðə pɹɪznɝz ðeɪ wɝ ənbaʊnd - ɪksɛp baɪ kʌstəm stʃɹɔŋɝ ðən tʃeɪnz. ðeɪ hæd kɑmli æksɛptɪd ðɛɹ feɪt, tə sɝv ə jɪɹ ən ə deɪ əz ɡeɪʃeɪn. beɪn ən kiæd maɪt bi ʌv səm hɛlp ɪn ɪskeɪpɪŋ - feɪl wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ haʊ fɑɹ kʌstəm kənstʃɹeɪn əm - bʌt ðeɪ ðɛmsɛlvz wəd nɑt tʃɹaɪ tə ɡɛɾ əweɪ.

In comparison, Bain and Chiad seemed in no worse state than did the Shaido, though Chiad's cheek was yellowing and swollen from a blow when they were first taken, and the black blood matting Bain's short fiery hair and spread across her face seemed to have frozen. That was bad; that could scar. The two Maidens were not breathing hard, though, and even raised their own feet for examination. Alone of the prisoners they were unbound - except by custom stronger than chains. They had calmly accepted their fate, to serve a year and a day as gai'shain. Bain and Chiad might be of some help in escaping - Faile was not sure how far custom constrained them - but they themselves would not try to get away.

ðə læs pɹɪznɝz, lətʃəl ən ɹɛlə, ətɛmptəd tə pæɾɝn ðɛmsɛlvz æftɝ ðə meɪɾənz, ʌv kɔɹs, wɪð ɪndɪfɹən səksɛs. ə tɔl ilmən hæd sɪmpli tʌk taɪni lətʃəl ʌndɝ ɪz ɑɹm tə lʊk əɾ əɹ fit, ən kɹɪmzən mɔɹɾəfəkeɪʃən steɪn əɹ peɪl tʃiks. ɹɛlə wɑz tɔl, bʌt ðə pɛɹ ə meɪɾənz u hæd tʃɑɹdʒ ə hɝ wɝ tɔlɝ ðən feɪl hɝsɛlf, ən ðeɪ hændəl ðə tɛɹən wʊmən wɪð ɪmpɝsənəl iz. ə skaʊl kəntɔɹɾəd əɹ dɑɹk feɪs ət ðɛɹ pɹɑɾɪŋ, ən meɪbi ət ðə ɹæpəd hæntɔk ðeɪ wɝ ɪkstʃeɪnʒɪŋ. feɪl hoʊpt ʃi wəd nɑt meɪk tʃɹʌbəl, nɑt naʊ. ɛvɹiwʌn ɪn tʃɑ feɪl tʃɹaɪd tə bi laɪk ði il, tə lɪv əz ðeɪ θɔt ði il dɪd, bʌt ɹɛlə wɑntəd tə bi ə meɪɾən, ən ʃi ɹizɛntəd ðə fæk ðət səlɪn ən ði ʌðɝz wəd nɑt titʃ əɹ hæntɔk. ʃi wʊɾə bɪn wɝs ɪf ʃi nu beɪn ən kiæd hæd tɔt feɪl ə lɪɾəl. nɑɾ ɪnʌf tə meɪk aʊt mɔɹ ðən ɛvɹi ʌðɝ wɝd ðə meɪɾənz wɝ seɪɪŋ naʊ, bʌt sʌm. əz wɛl ɹɛlə kəd nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd. ðeɪ θɔt ðə wɛtləndɝ hæd sɑft fit, ðət ʃi wɑz ɔltəɡɛðɝ tu pæmpɝɾ ən sɑft, ən ðət ʃʊɹli wʊɾə sɛt ðə wʊmən ɔf.

The last prisoners, Lacile and Arrela, attempted to pattern themselves after the Maidens, of course, with indifferent success. A tall Aielman had simply tucked tiny Lacile under his arm to look at her feet, and crimson mortification stained her pale cheeks. Arrela was tall, but the pair of Maidens who had charge of her were taller than Faile herself, and they handled the Tairen woman with impersonal ease. A scowl contorted her dark face at their prodding, and maybe at the rapid handtalk they were exchanging. Faile hoped she would not make trouble, not now. Everyone in Cha Faile tried to be like the Aiel, to live as they thought the Aiel did, but Arrela wanted to be a Maiden, and she resented the fact that Sulin and the others would not teach her handtalk. She would have been worse if she knew Bain and Chiad had taught Faile a little. Not enough to make out more than every other word the Maidens were saying now, but some. As well Arrela could not understand. They thought the wetlander had soft feet, that she was altogether too pampered and soft, and that surely would have set the woman off.

əz ɪt tɝn aʊt, feɪl nid nɑɾ əv wɝiɾ əbaʊt ɹɛlə. ðə tɛɹən stɪfənd wən wʌn ə ðə meɪɾənz hɛftəɾ əɹ ɑntu ə ʃoʊldɝ - pɹitɛndɪŋ tə stæɡɝ, ðə bɝɾənd wʊmən juzd əɹ fɹi hæn tə flɪkɝ ə mɛsədʒ ðət meɪd ði ʌðɝ meɪɾən bɑɹk ə læf bɪhaɪn əɹ veɪl - bʌɾ æftɝ ə ɡlæns ət beɪn ən kiæd, ɔlɹɛɾi mikli bɛli daʊn ɑn ilmɛnz ʃoʊldɝz, ɹɛlə sʌlənli lɛt hɝsɛlf hæŋ lɪmp. lətʃəl skwild wən ðə bɪɡ mæn hoʊldɪŋ əɹ əbɹʌpli spʌn əɹ əbaʊt tə læn ɪn ðə seɪm pəzɪʃən, bʌt ʃi kwaɪəɾəd æftɝ ðæt, ðoʊ hɝ feɪs wɑz stɪl bɹaɪt skɑɹlət. ðəɹ wɝ dɛfənəɾ ædvæntɪdʒɪz tə ðɛɹ ɛmjəleɪʃən ʌv il.

As it turned out, Faile need not have worried about Arrela. The Tairen stiffened when one of the Maidens hefted her onto a shoulder - pretending to stagger, the burdened woman used her free hand to flicker a message that made the other Maiden bark a laugh behind her veil - but after a glance at Bain and Chiad, already meekly belly down on Aielmen's shoulders, Arrela sullenly let herself hang limp. Lacile squealed when the big man holding her abruptly spun her about to land in the same position, but she quieted after that, though her face was still bright scarlet. There were definite advantages to their emulation of Aiel.

æliændɝ ən meɪaɪɡdɪn, haʊɛvɝ, ðə læst wɪmən feɪl wʊɾə ɪkspɛktəd tə kɑz pɹɑbləmz, wɝ ənʌðɝ mæɾɝ ɪntaɪɝli. wən ðeɪ ɹilaɪzd wʌt wɑz hæpənɪŋ, ðə pɛɹ ə ðɛm fɔt waɪldli. ɪt wɑz nɑt mʌtʃ ʌv ə faɪt, tu neɪkəɾ ən ɪɡzɔstəd wɪmən wɪð ðɛɹ ɛlboʊz baʊn taɪt bɪhaɪn ðɛɹ bæks, bʌt ðeɪ twɪstəɾ ən ʃaʊɾəd ən kɪkt əɾ ɛniwʌn u keɪm wɪðɪn ɹitʃ, ən meɪaɪɡdɪn ivən sæŋk əɹ tiθ ɪndə ðə hæn ʌv ə kɛɹləs ilmən, hæŋɪŋ ɑn laɪk ə bɔɹhaʊnd.

Alliandre and Maighdin, however, the last women Faile would have expected to cause problems, were another matter entirely. When they realized what was happening, the pair of them fought wildly. It was not much of a fight, two naked and exhausted women with their elbows bound tight behind their backs, but they twisted and shouted and kicked at anyone who came within reach, and Maighdin even sank her teeth into the hand of a careless Aielman, hanging on like a boarhound.

"stɑp ɪt, jə fulz!" feɪl kɔl tə ðɛm. "æliændɝ! meɪaɪɡdɪn! lɛɾ əm kæɹi ju! oʊbeɪ mi!" niðɝ əɹ meɪd nɔɹ əɹ væsəl peɪd ðə slaɪɾəst hid. meɪaɪɡdɪn ɡɹaʊld laɪk ə laɪən ɝaʊn əɹ maʊθfʊl ʌv il. æliændɝ wɑz ɹɛsəl daʊn, stɪl ʃaʊɾɪŋ ən fleɪlɪŋ wɪð əɹ fit. feɪl oʊpən əɹ maʊθ fəɹ ənʌðɝ kəmænd.

"Stop it, you fools!" Faile called to them. "Alliandre! Maighdin! Let them carry you! Obey me!" Neither her maid nor her vassal paid the slightest heed. Maighdin growled like a lion around her mouthful of Aiel. Alliandre was wrestled down, still shouting and flailing with her feet. Faile opened her mouth for another command.

"ðə ɡeɪʃeɪn wɪl bi kwaɪət," ɹoʊlən ɡɹʌntɪd, spæŋkɪŋ əɹ hɑɹd.

"The gai'shain will be quiet," Rolan grunted, spanking her hard.

ʃi ɡɹaʊn əɹ tiθ ən mʌɾɝd ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛθ. wɪtʃ ɝn ənʌðɝ slæp! ðə mæn hæɾ əɹ naɪvz tʌk bɪhaɪn ɪz bɛlt. ɪf ʃi kəd leɪ hænz ɑn dʒʌst wʌn . . . ! noʊ. wʌt mʌs bi ɛndʒjʊɹd, kəd bi ɛndʒjʊɹd. ʃi ɪntɛndəd tə ɪskeɪp, nɑt meɪk jusləs dʒɛstʃɝz.

She ground her teeth and muttered under her breath. Which earned another slap! The man had her knives tucked behind his belt. If she could lay hands on just one . . . ! No. What must be endured, could be endured. She intended to escape, not make useless gestures.

meɪaɪɡdɪnz faɪt læstəɾ ə lɪɾəl lɔŋɡɝ ðən æliændɝz, əntɪl ə pɛɹ ə bɝli mɛn kəd pɹaɪ hɝ dʒɔz fɹəm ðə ʃeɪɾoʊz hænd. ɪt ɹikwaɪɝɾ ə pɛɹ. tə feɪlz sɝpɹaɪz, ɪnstɛɾ ə kʌffɪŋ meɪaɪɡdɪn, ðə bɪɾən fɛloʊ ʃʊk blʌɾ ɔf ɪz hæn ən læft! ðət dɪd nɑt seɪv hɝ, ðoʊ. ɪn ə tʃɹaɪs, feɪlz meɪd wɑz feɪsdaʊn ɪn ðə snoʊ əlɔŋsaɪd ðə kwin. ðeɪ wɝ ɡɪvən oʊnli ə fju moʊməns tə ɡæsp ən ɹɪð ɪn ði æɾəd koʊld. tu ʃeɪɾoʊ, wʌn ə meɪɾən, əpɪɹɾ aʊɾ ə ðə sɝaʊndɪŋ tʃɹiz, ʃeɪvɪŋ ðə stʌbz fɹəm lɔŋ swɪtʃəz wɪð ðɛɹ hɛvi bɛl naɪvz. ə fʊt plæntəd bɪtwin itʃ wʊmənz ʃoʊldɝ bleɪdz, ə fɪst ɑn baʊn ɛlboʊz tə ɹeɪz flʌɾɝɪŋ hænz aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ, ən ɹɛd wɛls bɪɡæn tə blum ɑn waɪt hɪps.

Maighdin's fight lasted a little longer than Alliandre's, until a pair of burly men could pry her jaws from the Shaido's hand. It required a pair. To Faile's surprise, instead of cuffing Maighdin, the bitten fellow shook blood off his hand and laughed! That did not save her, though. In a trice, Faile's maid was facedown in the snow alongside the Queen. They were given only a few moments to gasp and writhe in the added cold. Two Shaido, one a Maiden, appeared out of the surrounding trees, shaving the stubs from long switches with their heavy belt knives. A foot planted between each woman's shoulder blades, a fist on bound elbows to raise fluttering hands out of the way, and red welts began to bloom on white hips.

ət fɝs boʊθ wɪmən kəntɪnjud tə faɪt, twɪstɪŋ əbaʊt dɪspaɪt ðə weɪ ðeɪ wɝ hɛld. ðɛɹ stʃɹʌɡəl wɑz ivən mɔɹ jusləs ðən wən ðeɪ wɝ əpɹaɪt. lɪɾəl muvd əbʌv ðɛɹ weɪsts bɪɑn tɔsɪŋ hɛdz ən waɪldli weɪvɪŋ hænz. æliændɝ kɛpt ʃɹɪlɪŋ ðət ðeɪ kəd nɑt də ðɪs tə hɝ, ʌndɝstændəbəl kʌmɪŋ fɹəm ə kwin, ɪf fulɪʃ ɪn ðə sɝkəmstænsəz. pleɪnli ðeɪ kʊd, ən ðeɪ wɝ. sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli, meɪaɪɡdɪn ɹeɪzd əɹ vɔɪs ɪn ðə seɪm pɪɹsɪŋ dɪnaɪəlz. ɛniwʌn wʊɾə θɔɾ əɹ ɹɔɪəlti ɪnstɛɾ ʌv ə leɪɾiz meɪd. feɪl nu fəɹ ə fæk ðət lini hæd teɪkən ə swɪtʃ tə meɪaɪɡdɪn wɪθaʊɾ ɔl ðiz hɪstʃɹiɑnɪks. ɪn ɛni keɪs, dɪnaɪəlz dɪd noʊ ɡʊd fəɹ iðɝ wʊmən. ðə məθɑɾəkəl θɹæʃɪŋz kəntɪnjuɾ əntɪl ðeɪ boʊθ wɝ kɪkɪŋ ən haʊlɪŋ wɝdləsli, ən ə lɪɾəl lɔŋɡɝ fəɹ ɡʊd mɛʒɝ. wən ðeɪ wɝ faɪnəli hɔɪstəd laɪk ði ʌðɝ pɹɪznɝz, ðeɪ hʌŋ wipɪŋ, ɔl faɪt ɡɔn aʊɾ ə ðɛm.

At first both women continued to fight, twisting about despite the way they were held. Their struggle was even more useless than when they were upright. Little moved above their waists beyond tossing heads and wildly waving hands. Alliandre kept shrilling that they could not do this to her, understandable coming from a queen, if foolish in the circumstances. Plainly they could, and they were. Surprisingly, Maighdin raised her voice in the same piercing denials. Anyone would have thought her royalty instead of a lady's maid. Faile knew for a fact that Lini had taken a switch to Maighdin without all these histrionics. In any case, denials did no good for either woman. The methodical thrashings continued until they both were kicking and howling wordlessly, and a little longer for good measure. When they were finally hoisted like the other prisoners, they hung weeping, all fight gone out of them.

feɪl fɛl noʊ sɪmpəθi. ðə fulz hæɾ ɝn ɛvɹi stʃɹaɪp, ɪn əɹ əpɪnjən. fɹɔstbaɪɾ ən kʌt fiɾ əsaɪd, ðə lɔŋɡɝ ðeɪ ɹɪmeɪn aʊtsaɪd wɪθaʊt kloʊðz, ðə mɔɹ tʃæns ðət səm ə ðɛm maɪt nɑt sɝvaɪv tə ɪskeɪp. ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ hæd tə bi teɪkɪŋ əm tə səm sɔɹɾ ə ʃɛltɝ, ən æliændɝ ən meɪaɪɡdɪn hæd dɪleɪd ɹitʃɪŋ ɪt. meɪbi ɪt wɑz lɪɾəl mɔɹ ðən ə kɔɹɾɝ aʊɝz dɪleɪ, bʌt mɪnəts kəd bi ðə dɪfɝəns bɪtwin ðə lɪvɪŋ ən ðə dɛd. ɑn tɑp ʌv wɪtʃ, ivən il wəd ʃʊɹli lɛt daʊn ðɛɹ ɡɑɹɾ ə lɪɾəl wʌns ðeɪ faʊnd ʃɛltɝ ən meɪd faɪɝz. ən ðeɪ kəd ɹɛst, biɪŋ kæɹid. ðeɪ kəd bi ɹɛɾi tə teɪk ðɛɹ tʃæns wən ɪt keɪm.

Faile felt no sympathy. The fools had earned every stripe, in her opinion. Frostbite and cut feet aside, the longer they remained outside without clothes, the more chance that some of them might not survive to escape. The Shaido had to be taking them to some sort of shelter, and Alliandre and Maighdin had delayed reaching it. Maybe it was little more than a quarter hour's delay, but minutes could be the difference between the living and the dead. On top of which, even Aiel would surely let down their guard a little once they found shelter and made fires. And they could rest, being carried. They could be ready to take their chance when it came.

kæɹiɪŋ ðɛɹ pɹɪznɝz, ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ sɛɾ aʊɾ əɡɛn ət ðət ɡɹaʊnd-kʌvɝɪŋ peɪs. ɪf ɛniθɪŋ, ðeɪ sim tə muv θɹu ðə fɔɹəs mɔɹ kwɪkli ðən bɪfɔɹ. ðə hɑɹd lɛðɝ baʊ keɪs bʌmp feɪlz saɪɾ əz ʃi sweɪd, ən ʃi bɪɡæn tə fil dɪzi. ɹoʊlənz ɛvɹi lɔŋ stʃɹaɪd sɛn ə dʒoʊl θɹu hɝ mɪɾəl. sɝəptɪʃəsli, ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə faɪn səm pəzɪʃən wɛɹ ʃi wəd nɑt bi poʊkt ən θʌddɪd kwaɪt soʊ vɪɡɝəsli.

Carrying their prisoners, the Shaido set out again at that ground-covering pace. If anything, they seemed to move through the forest more quickly than before. The hard leather bow case bumped Faile's side as she swayed, and she began to feel dizzy. Rolan's every long stride sent a jolt through her middle. Surreptitiously, she tried to find some position where she would not be poked and thudded quite so vigorously.

"bi stɪl, əɹ jəl fɔl," ɹoʊlən mʌɾɝd, pæɾɪŋ əɹ hɪp əz i maɪɾ əv pæɾəd ə hɔɹs tə suð ɪt.

"Be still, or you will fall," Rolan muttered, patting her hip as he might have patted a horse to soothe it.

ɹeɪzɪŋ əɹ hɛd, feɪl pɪɹd bæk əɾ æliændɝ, skaʊlɪŋ. ðəɹ wɑz nɑt mʌtʃ tə bi sin ə ðə kwin ʌv ɡildən, ən ðət kɹɪskɹɔs baɪ skɑɹlət wɛls fɹəm ðə tɑps ə hɝ hɪps ɔlmoʊs tə ðə bæks ə hɝ niz. kʌm tə θɪŋk ʌv ɪt, ə ʃɔɹt dɪleɪ ən ə fju stʃɹaɪps maɪt bi ə smɔl pɹaɪs tə peɪ fəɹ baɪɾɪŋ ə tʃʌŋk aʊɾ ə ðɪs ɑf toʊɾɪŋ əɹ laɪk ə sæk ʌv ɡɹeɪn. nɑɾ ɪz hænd, ðoʊ. hɪz θɹoʊt wəd bi əbaʊt ɹaɪt.

Raising her head, Faile peered back at Alliandre, scowling. There was not much to be seen of the Queen of Ghealdan, and that crisscrossed by scarlet welts from the tops of her hips almost to the backs of her knees. Come to think of it, a short delay and a few stripes might be a small price to pay for biting a chunk out of this oaf toting her like a sack of grain. Not his hand, though. His throat would be about right.

boʊl θɔts, ən wɝs ðən jusləs. fulɪʃ. ivən biɪŋ kæɹid, ʃi nu ʃi mʌs faɪt ðə koʊld. ɪn səm weɪz, ʃi bɪɡæn tə ɹilaɪz, biɪŋ kæɹid wɑz wɝs. wɔkɪŋ, ət list ʃi hæd hæd ðə stʃɹʌɡəl tə steɪ ɪɹɛkt ən ɑn əɹ fit tə kip əɹ əweɪk, bʌɾ əz ivnɪŋ keɪm ɑn ən dipən tə dɑɹknəs, ðə sweɪɪŋ moʊʃən ɑn ɹoʊlənz ʃoʊldɝ sim tə hæv ə lʌlɪŋ ɪfɛkt. noʊ. ɪt wɑz ðə koʊl ðət wɑz nʌmɪŋ əɹ maɪnd. meɪkɪŋ əɹ blʌd slʌɡɪʃ. ʃi hæd tə faɪɾ ɪt, əɹ ʃi wəd daɪ.

Bold thoughts, and worse than useless. Foolish. Even being carried, she knew she must fight the cold. In some ways, she began to realize, being carried was worse. Walking, at least she had had the struggle to stay erect and on her feet to keep her awake, but as evening came on and deepened to darkness, the swaying motion on Rolan's shoulder seemed to have a lulling effect. No. It was the cold that was numbing her mind. Making her blood sluggish. She had to fight it, or she would die.

ɹɪðmɪkli ʃi wɝkt əɹ hænz ən baʊn ɑɹmz, tɛnst əɹ lɛɡz ən ɹɪlæks ðɛm, tɛnst ən ɹɪlækst, fɔɹsɪŋ əɹ mʌsəlz tə wɝk əɹ blʌd. ʃi θɔɾ ə pɛɹɪn, sɑləd plænɪŋ θɔts ʌv wʌɾ i ʃəd də əbaʊt mæsimə, ən haʊ ʃi kəd kənvɪns ɪm ɪf i bɔkt. ʃi wɛn oʊvɝ ði ɑɹɡjəmən ðeɪ wəɾ əv wən i lɝnd ʃi bɪn juzɪŋ tʃɑ feɪl əz spaɪz, plæn haʊ ʃi wəd miɾ ɪz æŋɡɝ ən tɝn ɪt. ðəɹ wɑz ən ɑɹt tə ɡaɪɾɪŋ ə hʌzbənz æŋɡɝ ɪn ðə dɝɛkʃən jə wɑntəd, ən ʃi hæd lɝn fɹəm ən ɛkspɝt, hɝ mʌðɝ. ɪt wəd bi ə splɛndəɾ ɑɹɡjəmənt. ən ə splɛndəd meɪkɪŋ-ʌp, æftɝ.

Rhythmically she worked her hands and bound arms, tensed her legs and relaxed them, tensed and relaxed, forcing her muscles to work her blood. She thought of Perrin, solid planning thoughts of what he should do about Masema, and how she could convince him if he balked. She went over the argument they would have when he learned she been using Cha Faile as spies, planned how she would meet his anger and turn it. There was an art to guiding a husband's anger in the direction you wanted, and she had learned from an expert, her mother. It would be a splendid argument. And a splendid making-up, after.

θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt meɪkɪŋ ʌp wɪð ɪm meɪɾ əɹ fɝɡɛt tə wɝk əɹ mʌsəlz, soʊ ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾ ɑn ði ɑɹɡjəmənt, ɑn ðə plænɪŋ. koʊl dʌld əɹ θɔts, ðoʊ. ʃi bɪɡæn luzɪŋ ðə θɹɛd, hævɪŋ tə ʃeɪk əɹ hɛɾ ən stɑɹɾ oʊvɝ. ɹoʊlənz ɡɹaʊlz əɾ əɹ tə bi stɪl hɛlpt, ə vɔɪs tə foʊkəs ɑn, tə kip əɹ əweɪk. ivən ði əkʌmpəniɪŋ slæps ɑn əɹ ʌptɝn bɑɾəm hɛlpt, əz mʌtʃ əz ʃi heɪɾəd tə ədmɪt ðə fækt, itʃ wʌn ə ʃɑk ðət dʒoʊltɪɾ əɹ tə weɪkfəlnəs. æftɝ ə waɪl, ʃi bɪɡæn ʃɪftɪŋ mɔɹ, ðən stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ ɔlmoʊs tə ðə pɔɪn ə fɔlɪŋ, kɔɹɾɪŋ ðə ɹud smæks. ɛniθɪŋ tə steɪ əweɪk. ʃi kəd nɑɾ əv sɛd haʊ mʌtʃ taɪm pæst, bʌɾ əɹ twɪsts ən ɹɪəlz bɪɡæn tə wikən, əntɪl ɹoʊlən noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ɡɹaʊld, mʌtʃ lɛs ɡeɪv əɹ ə slæp. laɪt, ʃi wɑntəd ðə mæn tə pleɪ hɝ laɪk ə dʒɹʌm!

Thinking about making up with him made her forget to work her muscles, so she tried to concentrate on the argument, on the planning. Cold dulled her thoughts, though. She began losing the thread, having to shake her head and start over. Rolan's growls at her to be still helped, a voice to focus on, to keep her awake. Even the accompanying slaps on her upturned bottom helped, as much as she hated to admit the fact, each one a shock that jolted her to wakefulness. After a while, she began shifting more, then struggling almost to the point of falling, courting the rude smacks. Anything to stay awake. She could not have said how much time passed, but her twists and wriggles began to weaken, until Rolan no longer growled, much less gave her a slap. Light, she wanted the man to play her like a drum!

waɪ ɪn ðə laɪt wəɾ aɪ wɑn ə θɪŋ laɪk ðæt? ʃi θɔt dʌli, ən ə dɪm kɔɹnɝ ə hɝ maɪn ɹilaɪz ðə bæɾəl wɑz lɔst. ðə naɪt sim dɑɹkɝ ðən ɪt ʃəd bi. ʃi kəd nɑɾ ivən meɪk aʊt ðə ɡloʊ ʌv munlaɪɾ ɑn ðə snoʊ. ʃi kəd fil hɝsɛlf slaɪɾɪŋ, ðoʊ, slaɪɾɪŋ fæstɝ ən fæstɝ təwɔɹɾ ə dipɝ dɑɹk. weɪlɪŋ saɪlənli, ʃi sæŋk ɪndə ə stupɝ.

Why in the Light would I want a thing like that? she thought dully, and a dim corner of her mind realized the battle was lost. The night seemed darker than it should be. She could not even make out the glow of moonlight on the snow. She could feel herself sliding, though, sliding faster and faster toward a deeper dark. Wailing silently, she sank into a stupor.

dʒɹimz keɪm. ʃi wɑz sɪɾɪŋ ɑn pɛɹɪnz læp wɪð ɪz ɑɹmz soʊ taɪɾ ɝaʊn əɹ ʃi kəd bɛɹli muv, bɪfɔɹ ə ɡɹeɪt faɪɝ ɹɔɹɪŋ ɪn ə bɹɔd stoʊn faɪɝpleɪs. hɪz kɝli bɪɹd skɹætʃt əɹ tʃiks əz i nɪpt əɹ ɪɹz ɔlmoʊs peɪnfəli. sʌɾənli ə hjudʒ wɪn haʊl θɹu ðə ɹum, snʌfɪŋ ðə faɪɝ laɪk ə kændəl. ən pɛɹɪn tɝn tə smoʊk ðət vænɪʃt ɪn ðə ɡeɪl. əloʊn ɪn bɪɾɝ dɑɹknəs, ʃi fɔt ðə wɪnd, bʌɾ ɪt tʌmbəld əɹ ɛn oʊvɝ ɛn əntɪl ʃi wɑz soʊ dɪzi ʃi kəd nɑt tɛl ʌp fɹəm daʊn. əloʊn ən ɛnləsli tʌmbəlɪŋ ɪndə aɪsi dɑɹk, noʊɪŋ ʃi wəd nɛvɝ faɪn ɪm əɡɛn.

Dreams came. She was sitting on Perrin's lap with his arms so tight around her she could barely move, before a great fire roaring in a broad stone fireplace. His curly beard scratched her cheeks as he nipped her ears almost painfully. Suddenly a huge wind howled through the room, snuffing the fire like a candle. And Perrin turned to smoke that vanished in the gale. Alone in bitter darkness, she fought the wind, but it tumbled her end over end until she was so dizzy she could not tell up from down. Alone and endlessly tumbling into icy dark, knowing she would never find him again.

ʃi ɹæn əkɹɔs ə fɹoʊzən lænd, flaʊndɝɪŋ fɹəm snoʊdʒɹɪf tə snoʊdʒɹɪft, fɔlɪŋ, skɹæmbəlɪŋ ʌp tə ɹʌn ɑn ɪn pænɪk, ɡʌlpɪŋ ɛɹ soʊ koʊld ɪt slaɪst əɹ θɹoʊt laɪk ʃɑɹdz ʌv ɡlæs. aɪsɪkəlz spɑɹkəld ɑn stɑɹk bɹæntʃəz ɝaʊn hɝ, ən ə fɹɪdʒəd wɪn kin θɹu ðə lifləs fɔɹəst. pɛɹɪn wɑz vɛɹi æŋɡɹi, ən ʃi hæd tə ɡɛɾ əweɪ. sʌmhaʊ, ʃi kəd nɑt ɹikɔl ðə spɪsɪfɪks ə ði ɑɹɡjəmənt, dʒʌs ðət sʌmhaʊ ʃi hæd pʊʃt əɹ bjuɾəfəl wʊlf tə ɹil æŋɡɝ, tə ðə pɔɪn ə θɹoʊɪŋ θɪŋz. oʊnli, pɛɹɪn dɪd nɑt θɹoʊ θɪŋz. hi wɑz gɑnə tɝn əɹ oʊvɝ ɪz ni, əz i hæd dʌn wʌns, lɔŋ əɡoʊ. waɪ wɑz ʃi ɹʌnɪŋ fɹəm ðæt, ðoʊ? ðəɹ wəd stɪl bi ðə meɪkɪŋ-ʌp. ən ʃi wəd meɪk ɪm peɪ fəɹ ðə hjumɪlieɪʃən, ʌv kɔɹs. ɛniweɪ, ʃi hæd dʒɹɔn ə lɪɾəl blʌd fɹəm ɪm ə taɪm əɹ tu wɪð ə wɛl-eɪm boʊl əɹ pɪtʃɝ, nɑt ɹɪli minɪŋ tə, ən ʃi nu hi wəd nɛvɝ ɹɪli hɝt hɝ. bʌt ʃi ɔlsoʊ nu ðət ʃi hæd tə ɹʌn, tə kip muvɪŋ, əɹ ʃi wəd daɪ.

She ran across a frozen land, floundering from snowdrift to snowdrift, falling, scrambling up to run on in panic, gulping air so cold it sliced her throat like shards of glass. Icicles sparkled on stark branches around her, and a frigid wind keened through the leafless forest. Perrin was very angry, and she had to get away. Somehow, she could not recall the specifics of the argument, just that somehow she had pushed her beautiful wolf to real anger, to the point of throwing things. Only, Perrin did not throw things. He was going to turn her over his knee, as he had done once, long ago. Why was she running from that, though? There would still be the making-up. And she would make him pay for the humiliation, of course. Anyway, she had drawn a little blood from him a time or two with a well-aimed bowl or pitcher, not really meaning to, and she knew he would never really hurt her. But she also knew that she had to run, to keep moving, or she would die.

ɪf i kætʃəz mi, ʃi θɔt dʒɹaɪli, ət lis pɑɹɾ ə mi wɪl bi wɔɹm. ən ʃi bɪɡæn tə læf ət ðæt, əntɪl ðə dɛd waɪt læn spʌn ɝaʊn hɝ, ən ʃi nu ðət sun ʃi wəd bi dɛd, tu.

If he catches me, she thought dryly, at least part of me will be warm. And she began to laugh at that, until the dead white land spun around her, and she knew that soon she would be dead, too.

ðə mɑnstʃɹəs bɑnfaɪɝ lumd oʊvɝ hɝ, ə taʊɝɪŋ paɪl ə θɪk lɔɡz ɹɔɹɪŋ wɪð fleɪm. ʃi wɑz neɪkəd. ən koʊld, soʊ koʊld. noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ nɪɹ ðə faɪɝ ʃi ɛdʒd, hɝ boʊnz fɛl fɹoʊzən, hɝ flɛʃ ɹɛɾi tə ʃæɾɝ əɾ ə bloʊ. ʃi muv kloʊsɝ, kloʊsɝ. ðə hiɾ ə ðə bleɪz ɡɹu tɪl ʃi flɪntʃt əɾ ɪt, bʌt ðə bɪɾɝ koʊld ɹɪmeɪn tʃɹæpt ɪnsaɪɾ əɹ skɪn. kloʊsɝ. oʊ, laɪt, ɪt wɑz hɑt, tu hɑt! ən stɪl koʊld wɪðɪn. kloʊsɝ. ʃi bɪɡæn tə skɹim ət ðə bɝnɪŋ, ðə sɪɹɪŋ peɪn, bʌt ʃi wɑz stɪl aɪs ɪnsaɪd. kloʊsɝ. kloʊsɝ. ʃi wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ tə daɪ. ʃi ʃɹikt, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz oʊnli saɪləns, ən ðə koʊld.

The monstrous bonfire loomed over her, a towering pile of thick logs roaring with flame. She was naked. And cold, so cold. No matter how near the fire she edged, her bones felt frozen, her flesh ready to shatter at a blow. She moved closer, closer. The heat of the blaze grew till she flinched at it, but the bitter cold remained trapped inside her skin. Closer. Oh, Light, it was hot, too hot! And still cold within. Closer. She began to scream at the burning, the searing pain, but she was still ice inside. Closer. Closer. She was going to die. She shrieked, but there was only silence, and the cold.

ɪt wɑz deɪlaɪt, bʌt lɛɾən klaʊdz fɪl ðə skaɪ. snoʊ fɛl ɪn ə stɛɾi ʃaʊɝ, fɛðɝi fleɪks swɝlɪŋ ɪn ðə wɪn θɹu ðə tʃɹiz. nɑɾ ə fɪɹs wɪnd, bʌɾ ɪt lɪkt wɪð tʌŋz ʌv aɪs. ɹɪdʒəz ʌv waɪt bɪlt ɑn bɹæntʃəz əntɪl ðeɪ wɝ tɔl ɪnʌf tə kəlæps fɹəm ðɛɹ oʊn weɪɾ ən ðə wɪnd, sɛndɪŋ hɛviɝ ʃaʊɝz tə ðə ɡɹaʊn bɪloʊ. hʌŋɡɝ nɔɾ əɹ bɛli wɪð dʌl tiθ. ə vɛɹi tɔl, boʊni mæn wɪð ə waɪt wʊlən kaʊl ʃɛltɝɪŋ ɪz feɪs fɔɹst sʌmθɪŋ ɪndə hɝ maʊð, ðə ɹɪm ʌv ə lɑɹdʒ kleɪ mʌɡ. hɪz aɪz wɝ ə stɑɹtlɪŋ ɡɹin, laɪk ɛmɹəlz, ən sɝaʊndəd baɪ pʌkɝd skɑɹz. hi wɑz nilɪŋ ɑn ə lɑɹdʒ bɹaʊn wʊlən blæŋkət wɪð hɝ, ən ənʌðɝ blæŋkət, stʃɹaɪpt ɪn ɡɹeɪ, wɑz dʒɹeɪpt ɝaʊn əɹ neɪkədnəs. ðə teɪst ə hɑt ti θɪk wɪð hʌni ɪksploʊɾəd ɑn əɹ tʌŋ, ən ʃi siz ðə mænz sɪnjui ɹɪst wikli wɪð boʊθ hænz ɪn keɪs i tʃɹaɪd tə teɪk ðə mʌɡ əweɪ. hɝ tiθ tʃæɾɝd əɡɛns ðə mʌɡ, bʌt ʃi ɡʌlp ðə stimɪŋ sɪɹəpi lɪkwəd ɡɹiɾəli.

It was daylight, but leaden clouds filled the sky. Snow fell in a steady shower, feathery flakes swirling in the wind through the trees. Not a fierce wind, but it licked with tongues of ice. Ridges of white built on branches until they were tall enough to collapse from their own weight and the wind, sending heavier showers to the ground below. Hunger gnawed her belly with dull teeth. A very tall, bony man with a white woolen cowl sheltering his face forced something into her mouth, the rim of a large clay mug. His eyes were a startling green, like emeralds, and surrounded by puckered scars. He was kneeling on a large brown woolen blanket with her, and another blanket, striped in gray, was draped around her nakedness. The taste of hot tea thick with honey exploded on her tongue, and she seized the man's sinewy wrist weakly with both hands in case he tried to take the mug away. Her teeth chattered against the mug, but she gulped the steaming syrupy liquid greedily.

"nɑt tu fæst; jə mʌs nɑt spɪl ɛni," ðə ɡɹin-aɪd mæn sɛd mikli. miknəs saʊndəɾ ɑd fɹəm ðət fɪɹs feɪs, ən ɪn ə ɡɹævəli vɔɪs. "ðeɪ əfɛndəd jəɹ ɑnɝ. bʌt jə ɑɹ ə wɛtləndɝ, soʊ meɪbi ɪt dʌz nɑt kaʊnt wɪð ju."

"Not too fast; you must not spill any," the green-eyed man said meekly. Meekness sounded odd from that fierce face, and in a gravelly voice. "They offended your honor. But you are a wetlander, so maybe it does not count with you."

sloʊli ɪt dɔn ɑn əɹ ðət ðɪs wɑz noʊ dʒɹim. θɔt keɪm ɪn ə tʃɹɪkəl ə ʃædoʊz ðət mɛltəɾ ɪf ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə hoʊld əm tu hɑɹd. ðə waɪt-ɹoʊbd bɹut wɑz ɡeɪʃeɪn. hɝ liʃ ən bɑnz wɝ ɡɔn. hi pʊld ɪz ɹɪst əweɪ fɹəm əɹ fibəl ɡɹɪp, bʌɾ oʊnli tə pɔɹ ə dɑɹk stʃɹim fɹəm ə lɛðɝ wɔɾɝ bæɡ hæŋɪŋ fɹəm ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. stim ɹoʊz fɹəm ðə mʌɡ, ən ði ɝoʊmə ʌv ti.

Slowly it dawned on her that this was no dream. Thought came in a trickle of shadows that melted if she tried to hold them too hard. The white-robed brute was gai'shain. Her leash and bonds were gone. He pulled his wrist away from her feeble grip, but only to pour a dark stream from a leather water bag hanging from his shoulder. Steam rose from the mug, and the aroma of tea.

ʃɪvɝɪŋ soʊ hɑɹd ʃi ɔlmoʊs fɛl oʊvɝ, ʃi klʌtʃt ðə θɪk stʃɹaɪp blæŋkəɾ ɝaʊn hɝ. faɪɝi peɪn wɑz blɑsəmɪŋ ɪn əɹ fit. ʃi kəd nɑɾ əv stʊd hæd ʃi tʃɹaɪd. nɑt ðət ʃi wɑntəd tə. ðə blæŋkət mænədʒ tə kʌvɝ ɛvɹiθɪŋ bʌɾ əɹ fit soʊ lɔŋ əz ʃi ɹɪmeɪn ɪn ə kɹaʊtʃ; stændɪŋ wʊɾə bɛɹɾ əɹ lɛɡz ən meɪbi mɔɹ. ɪt wɑz wɔɹmθ ʃi θɔɾ ʌv, nɑt disənsi, ðoʊ ðəɹ wɑz lɪɾəl ʌv iðɝ tə bi hæd. hʌŋɡɝz tiθ ɡɹu ʃɑɹp, ən ʃi kəd nɑt stɑp ʃeɪkɪŋ. ʃi wɑz fɹoʊzən ɪnsaɪd, ðə tiz hiɾ ɔlɹɛɾi dʒʌst ə mɛmɹi. hɝ mʌsəlz wɝ wik-oʊl kəndʒil pʊɾɪŋ. ʃi wɑntəd tə stɛɹ ət ðə fɪlɪŋ mʌɡ, kʌvəɾɪŋ ðə kɑntɛns, bʌt ʃi meɪd hɝsɛlf lʊk fəɹ əɹ kəmpænjənz.

Shivering so hard she almost fell over, she clutched the thick striped blanket around her. Fiery pain was blossoming in her feet. She could not have stood had she tried. Not that she wanted to. The blanket managed to cover everything but her feet so long as she remained in a crouch; standing would have bared her legs and maybe more. It was warmth she thought of, not decency, though there was little of either to be had. Hunger's teeth grew sharp, and she could not stop shaking. She was frozen inside, the tea's heat already just a memory. Her muscles were week-old congealed pudding. She wanted to stare at the filling mug, coveting the contents, but she made herself look for her companions.

ðeɪ wɝ ɔl ðəɹ ɪn ə laɪn wɪð hɝ, meɪaɪɡdɪn ən æliændɝ ən ɛvɹiwʌn, slʌmpt ɑn ðɛɹ niz ətɑp blæŋkəts, ʃɪvɝɪŋ ɪnsaɪd blæŋkəts spɛkəld wɪð snoʊ. ɪn fɹʌn ʌv itʃ ə ɡeɪʃeɪn nɛlt wɪð ə bʌlʒɪŋ wɔɾɝ bæɡ ən ə mʌɡ əɹ kʌp, ən ivən beɪn ən kiæd dʒɹæŋk laɪk wɪmən hæf-dɛɾ ə θɝst. sʌmwʌn hæd klin ðə blʌd fɹəm beɪnz feɪs, bʌɾ ənlaɪk ðə læs taɪm feɪl hæd sin ðɛm, ðə tu meɪɾənz wɝ əz dʒɹɔn ən ənstɛɾi əz ɛniwʌn ɛls. fɹəm æliændɝ tə lətʃəl, hɝ kəmpænjənz lʊkt - wʌt wɑz pɛɹɪnz fɹeɪz? - əz ɪf ðeɪ hæd bɪn dʒɹæɡd θɹu ə nɑthoʊl bækwɝd. bʌɾ ɛvɹiwʌn wɑz stɪl əlaɪv; ðət wɑz ði ɪmpɔɹɾənt θɪŋ. oʊnli ðə lɪvɪŋ kəɾ ɪskeɪp.

They were all there in a line with her, Maighdin and Alliandre and everyone, slumped on their knees atop blankets, shivering inside blankets speckled with snow. In front of each a gai'shain knelt with a bulging water bag and a mug or cup, and even Bain and Chiad drank like women half-dead of thirst. Someone had cleaned the blood from Bain's face, but unlike the last time Faile had seen them, the two Maidens were as drawn and unsteady as anyone else. From Alliandre to Lacile, her companions looked - what was Perrin's phrase? - as if they had been dragged through a knothole backward. But everyone was still alive; that was the important thing. Only the living could escape.

ɹoʊlən ən ði ʌðɝ ælɡeɪdsɪswaɪ hu hæd hæd tʃɑɹdʒ ə ðɛm meɪɾ ə klʌstɝ ət ðə fɑɹ ɛn ə ðə nilɪŋ laɪn. faɪv mɛn ən θɹi wɪmən, ðə snoʊ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd nɪɹli ni-dip ɑn ðə meɪɾənz. blæk veɪlz hæŋɪŋ daʊn ðɛɹ tʃɛsts, ðeɪ wɑtʃt ðɛɹ pɹɪznɝz ən ðə ɡeɪʃeɪn ɪmpæsɪvli. fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ʃi fɹaʊn ət ðɛm, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɡɹæsp ə slɪpɝi θɔt. jɛs; ʌv kɔɹs. wɛɹ wɝ ði ʌðɝz? ɪskeɪp wəd bi iziɝ ɪf ðə ɹɛs hæd ɡɔn fəɹ səm ɹizən. ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ mɔɹ, ənʌðɝ mɪsti kwɛstʃən ʃi kəd nɑt kwaɪt kætʃ.

Rolan and the other algai'd'siswai who had had charge of them made a cluster at the far end of the kneeling line. Five men and three women, the snow on the ground nearly knee-deep on the Maidens. Black veils hanging down their chests, they watched their prisoners and the gai'shain impassively. For a moment, she frowned at them, trying to grasp a slippery thought. Yes; of course. Where were the others? Escape would be easier if the rest had gone for some reason. There was something more, another misty question she could not quite catch.

sʌɾənli wʌt leɪ bɪɑn ði eɪɾ il lɛpt aʊɾ ət hɝ, ən kwɛstʃən ən ænsɝ keɪm ət ðə seɪm taɪm. wɛɹ hæd ðə ɡeɪʃeɪn kʌm fɹʌm? ə hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz əɹ soʊ dɪstənt, veɪl baɪ ðə skæɾɝd tʃɹiz ən fɔlɪŋ snoʊ, ə stɛɾi stʃɹim ə pipəl ən pæk ænəməlz, wæɡənz ən kɑɹts, wɑz floʊɪŋ baɪ. nɑɾ ə stʃɹim. ə flʌɾ ʌv il ɑn ðə muv. ɪnstɛɾ ʌv ə hʌnʒɹəd ən fɪfti ʃeɪɾoʊ, ʃi hæd ðə hoʊl klæn tə kəntɛnd wɪð. ɪt simd ɪmpɑsəbəl ðət soʊ mɛni pipəl kəd pæs wɪðɪn ə deɪ əɹ tu ʌv ɑbilə wɪθaʊt ɹeɪzɪŋ səm əlɑɹm, ivən wɪð ðə kʌntʃɹisaɪɾ ɪn ænɝki, bʌt ðə pɹuf wɑz ɹaɪɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ aɪz. ɪnsaɪd, ʃi fɛlt lɛɾən. meɪbi ɪskeɪp wəd bi noʊ hɑɹɾɝ, bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt bɪliv ɪt.

Suddenly what lay beyond the eight Aiel leaped out at her, and question and answer came at the same time. Where had the gai'shain come from? A hundred paces or so distant, veiled by the scattered trees and falling snow, a steady stream of people and pack animals, wagons and carts, was flowing by. Not a stream. A flood of Aiel on the move. Instead of a hundred and fifty Shaido, she had the whole clan to contend with. It seemed impossible that so many people could pass within a day or two of Abila without raising some alarm, even with the countryside in anarchy, but the proof was right in front of her eyes. Inside, she felt leaden. Maybe escape would be no harder, but she did not believe it.

"haʊ dɪd ðeɪ əfɛn mi?" ʃi æsk dʒɝkəli, ðən klæmpt əɹ maʊθ ʃʌt tə stɑp tʃæɾɝɪŋ. ən oʊpən ɪɾ əɡɛn əz ðə ɡeɪʃeɪn ɹeɪz ðə mʌɡ tə hɝ wʌns mɔɹ. ʃi ɡʌlp ðə pɹɛʃəs hit, tʃoʊkɪŋ, ən fɔɹs hɝsɛlf tə swɑloʊ mɔɹ sloʊli. ðə hʌni, soʊ θɪk ɪt wʊɾə bɪn klɔɪɪŋ ɛni ʌðɝ taɪm, dʌld əɹ hʌŋɡɝ ə lɪɾəl.

"How did they offend me?" she asked jerkily, then clamped her mouth shut to stop chattering. And opened it again as the gai'shain raised the mug to her once more. She gulped the precious heat, choking, and forced herself to swallow more slowly. The honey, so thick it would have been cloying any other time, dulled her hunger a little.

"ju wɛtləndɝz noʊ nʌθɪŋ," ðə skɑɹd mæn sɛd dɪsmɪsɪvli. "ɡeɪʃeɪn ɑɹ nɑt kloʊðd ɪn ɛni weɪ əntɪl ðeɪ kən bi ɡɪvən pɹɑpɝ ɹoʊbz. bʌt ðeɪ fɪɹd jə wəd fɹiz tə dɛθ, ən ɔl ðeɪ hæd tə ɹæp jə wɑz ðɛɹ koʊts. jə wɝ ʃeɪmd, neɪmd əz wik, ɪf wɛtləndɝz əv ʃeɪm. ɹoʊlən ən mɛni ʌv ði ʌðɝz ɑɹ mɛɝeɪɾɪn, jɛɾ ɛfɑlɪn ən ðə ɹɛst ʃəd noʊ bɛɾɝ. ɛfɑlɪn ʃəd nɑɾ əv əlaʊɾ ɪt."

"You wetlanders know nothing," the scarred man said dismissively. "Gai'shain are not clothed in any way until they can be given proper robes. But they feared you would freeze to death, and all they had to wrap you was their coats. You were shamed, named as weak, if wetlanders have shame. Rolan and many of the others are Mera'din, yet Efalin and the rest should know better. Efalin should not have allowed it."

ʃeɪmd? ɪnfjʊɹieɪɾəd wɑz mɔɹ laɪk ɪt. ənwɪlɪŋ tə tɝn əɹ hɛd fɹəm ðə blɛsɪd mʌɡ, ʃi ɹoʊld əɹ aɪz təwɔɹd ðə hʌlkɪŋ dʒaɪən u hæd kæɹiɾ əɹ laɪk ə sæk ʌv ɡɹeɪn ən smækt əɹ ənmɝsɪfəli. veɪɡli ʃi sim tə ɹikɔl wɛlkəmɪŋ ðoʊz spæŋks, bʌt ðət wɑz ɪmpɑsəbəl. ʌv kɔɹs ɪt wɑz ɪmpɑsəbəl! ɹoʊlən dɪd nɑt lʊk laɪk ə mæn u hæd hæf-tʃɹɑɾəd θɹu moʊst ʌv ə deɪ ən ə naɪt bɪsaɪdz, kæɹiɪŋ sʌmwʌn. hɪz waɪt-mɪstɪd bɹɛθ keɪm izəli. mɛɝeɪɾɪn? ʃi θɔt ðət wəd min bɹʌðɝləs ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, wɪtʃ toʊld əɹ nʌθɪŋ, bʌt ðəɹ hæd bɪn ə noʊɾ ə skɔɹn ɪn ðə ɡeɪʃeɪnz vɔɪs. ʃi wəɾ əv tə æsk beɪn ən kiæd, ən hoʊp ɪt wɑz nɑt wʌn ə ðoʊz θɪŋz il wəd nɑt tɔk əbaʊt tə wɛtləndɝz, nɑɾ ivən wɛtləndɝz u wɝ kloʊs fɹɛnz. ɛni pis ə nɑlədʒ maɪɾ eɪɾ ɪskeɪp.

Shamed? Infuriated was more like it. Unwilling to turn her head from the blessed mug, she rolled her eyes toward the hulking giant who had carried her like a sack of grain and smacked her unmercifully. Vaguely she seemed to recall welcoming those spanks, but that was impossible. Of course it was impossible! Rolan did not look like a man who had half-trotted through most of a day and a night besides, carrying someone. His white-misted breath came easily. Mera'din? She thought that would mean Brotherless in the Old Tongue, which told her nothing, but there had been a note of scorn in the gai'shain's voice. She would have to ask Bain and Chiad, and hope it was not one of those things Aiel would not talk about to wetlanders, not even wetlanders who were close friends. Any piece of knowledge might aid escape.

soʊ ðeɪ hæd ɹæp ðɛɹ pɹɪznɝz ʌp əɡɛns ðə koʊld, hæd ðeɪ? wɛl, noʊ wʌn wʊɾə bɪn ɪn ɛni deɪnʒɝ ə fɹizɪŋ ɪksɛp fəɹ ɹoʊlən ən ði ʌðɝz. stɪl, ʃi maɪɾ oʊ hɪm ə smɔl feɪvɝ. vɛɹi smɔl, kənsɪɾɝɪŋ ɛvɹiθɪŋ. pɝhæps ʃi wəɾ oʊnli slaɪs ɔf ɪz ɪɹz. ɪf ʃi ɛvɝ ɡɑt ðə tʃæns, sɝaʊndəd baɪ θaʊzənz ə ʃeɪɾoʊ. θaʊzənz? ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ nʌmbɝɾ ɪn ðə hʌnʒɹədz ə θaʊzənz, ən tɛnz ə θaʊzənz ə ðoʊz wɝ ælɡeɪdsɪswaɪ. fjʊɹiəs wɪð hɝsɛlf, ʃi fɔt dɪspɛɹ. ʃi wəɾ ɪskeɪp; ðeɪ wəɾ ɔl ɪskeɪp, ən ʃi wəd teɪk ðə mænz ɪɹz wɪð hɝ!

So they had wrapped their prisoners up against the cold, had they? Well, no one would have been in any danger of freezing except for Rolan and the others. Still, she might owe him a small favor. Very small, considering everything. Perhaps she would only slice off his ears. If she ever got the chance, surrounded by thousands of Shaido. Thousands? The Shaido numbered in the hundreds of thousands, and tens of thousands of those were algai'd'siswai. Furious with herself, she fought despair. She would escape; they would all escape, and she would take the man's ears with her!

"aɪ wɪl si ɹoʊlənz ɹipeɪɾ əz i dɪzɝvz," ʃi mʌɾɝd wən ðə ɡeɪʃeɪn tʊk ðə mʌɡ əweɪ fəɹ ɹifɪlɪŋ əɡɛn. hi ɡeɪv əɹ ə nɛɹoʊ-aɪd səspɪʃəs stɛɹ, ən ʃi hɝid. "æz jə seɪ, aɪm ə wɛtləndɝ. moʊst ʌv əs ɑɹ. wi doʊn fɑloʊ dʒiɾoʊ. baɪ jəɹ kʌstəmz, wi ʃʊdn bi meɪd ɡeɪʃeɪn əɾ ɔl, ɪz ðət nɑt ɹaɪt?" ðə mænz skɑɹd feɪs dɪd nɑt tʃeɪnʒ, nɑt baɪ soʊ mʌtʃ əz ðə twɪtʃ ʌv ən aɪləd. ə dɪm θɔt sɛɾ ɪt wɑz tu sun, ʃi dɪd nɑt noʊ ðə ɡɹaʊn jɛt, bʌt θɔts ɡɛləd wɪð koʊl kəd nɑt kætʃ əɹ tʌŋ. "wʌɾ ɪf ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ dɪsaɪd tə bɹeɪk ʌðɝ kʌstəmz? ðeɪ maɪt dɪsaɪd nɑt tə lɛt jə ɡoʊ wən jəɹ taɪm ɪz dʌn."

"I will see Rolan's repaid as he deserves," she muttered when the gai'shain took the mug away for refilling again. He gave her a narrow-eyed suspicious stare, and she hurried. "As you say, I am a wetlander. Most of us are. We don't follow ji'e'toh. By your customs, we shouldn't be made gai'shain at all, is that not right?" The man's scarred face did not change, not by so much as the twitch of an eyelid. A dim thought said it was too soon, she did not know the ground yet, but thoughts gelid with cold could not catch her tongue. "What if the Shaido decide to break other customs? They might decide not to let you go when your time is done."

"ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ bɹeɪk mɛni kʌstəmz," hi toʊld əɹ plɑtʃədli, "bʌɾ aɪ də nɑt. aɪ hæv oʊvɝ hæf ə jɪɹ jɛt tə wɛɹ waɪt. əntɪl ðɛn, əl sɝv əz kʌstəm dɪmænz. ɪf jə kən tɔk soʊ mʌtʃ, meɪbi juv hæɾ ɪnʌf ti?"

"The Shaido break many customs," he told her placidly, "but I do not. I have over half a year yet to wear white. Until then, I will serve as custom demands. If you can talk so much, maybe you have had enough tea?"

feɪl klʌmsəli snætʃt ðə mʌɡ fɹəm hɪm. hɪz aɪbɹaʊz lɪftəd, ən ʃi ɹiɝeɪnʒd əɹ dʒɹeɪpɝiz wʌn-hændəɾ əz kwɪkli əz ʃi kəd mænədʒ, hɝ tʃiks hiɾɪŋ. hi sɝɾənli nu hi wɑz lʊkɪŋ əɾ ə wʊmən. laɪt, ʃi wɑz blʌndɝɪŋ əbaʊt laɪk ə blaɪn ɑks! ʃi hæd tə θɪŋk, tə kɑnsəntʃɹeɪt. hɝ bɹeɪn wɑz ði oʊnli wɛpən ʃi hæd. ən ət ðə moʊmənt, ɪt maɪɾ əz wɛl əv bɪn fɹoʊzən tʃiz. dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ dip ə ðə hɑt swit ti, ʃi sɛt hɝsɛlf tə θɪŋkɪŋ ə səm weɪ ðət biɪŋ sɝaʊndəd baɪ θaʊzənz ə ʃeɪɾoʊ kəd bi tɝn tə ædvæntɪdʒ. nʌθɪŋ keɪm tə hɝ, ðoʊ. nʌθɪŋ əɾ ɔl.

Faile clumsily snatched the mug from him. His eyebrows lifted, and she rearranged her draperies one-handed as quickly as she could manage, her cheeks heating. He certainly knew he was looking at a woman. Light, she was blundering about like a blind ox! She had to think, to concentrate. Her brain was the only weapon she had. And at the moment, it might as well have been frozen cheese. Drinking deep of the hot sweet tea, she set herself to thinking of some way that being surrounded by thousands of Shaido could be turned to advantage. Nothing came to her, though. Nothing at all.


tʃæptɝ fɔɹ


CHAPTER 4

ɔfɝz


Offers

"wʌɾ əv wi hɪɹ?" ə wʊmənz hɑɹd vɔɪs sɛd. feɪl lʊkt ʌp, ən stɛɹd, hɑt ti ɡɔn fɹəm əɹ θɔts fəɹ ðə moʊmənt.

"What have we here?" a woman's hard voice said. Faile looked up, and stared, hot tea gone from her thoughts for the moment.

tu il wɪmən wɪð ə mʌtʃ ʃɔɹɾɝ ɡeɪʃeɪn wʊmən bɪtwin əm keɪm aʊɾ ə ðə swɝlɪŋ snoʊ, sɪŋkɪŋ hæfweɪ ʌp ðɛɹ kævz ɪn ðə waɪt kɑɹpət ðət kʌvɝd ðə ɡɹaʊn bʌt stɪl mænɪdʒɪŋ paʊɝfəl stʃɹaɪdz. ðə tɔlɝ wɪmən dɪd, ɛniweɪ; ðə ɡeɪʃeɪn stʌmbəld ən flaʊndɝd tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kip ʌp, ən wʌn ə ði ʌðɝz hæɾ ə hæn ɑn əɹ ʃoʊldɝ tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ʃi dɪd. ɔl θɹi wɝ wɝθ ə stɛɹ. ðə wʊmən ɪn waɪt kɛpt əɹ hɛd mikli daʊn əz mʌtʃ əz ʃi kəɾ ən əɹ hænz foʊldəɾ ɪn əɹ waɪd slivz əz ə ɡeɪʃeɪn wɑz səpoʊz tə, bʌɾ əɹ ɹoʊbz hæd ðə ʃin ə hɛvi sɪlk, ʌv ɔl θɪŋz. ɡeɪʃeɪn wɝ fɔɹbɪɾən dʒuəlɹi, jɛɾ ə waɪd, ɪlæbɹət bɛlt ʌv ɡoʊld ən faɪɝdʒɹɑps sɪntʃt əɹ weɪst ən ə mætʃɪŋ kɑlɝ wɑz dʒʌs vɪzəbəl ɪnsaɪɾ əɹ kaʊl, nɪɹli kʌvɝɪŋ əɹ nɛk. vɛɹi fju bɪsaɪdz ɹɔɪəlti kəɾ əfɔɹd ðə laɪk. stʃɹeɪnʒ əz ðə ɡeɪʃeɪn wɑz, haʊɛvɝ, ɪt wɑz ði ʌðɝz feɪl stʌɾid. sʌmθɪŋ toʊld əɹ ðeɪ wɝ waɪz wʌnz. ðəɹ wɑz tu mʌtʃ əθɔɹəɾi əbaʊɾ əm fəɹ ɛniθɪŋ ɛls; ðiz wɝ wɪmən juz tə ɡɪvɪŋ ɔɹɾɝz ən biɪŋ oʊbeɪd. bɪɑn ðæt, ðoʊ, ðɛɹ sɪmpəl pɹɛzəns kɑt ði aɪ. ðə wʊmən pʊʃɪŋ ðə ɡeɪʃeɪn əlɔŋ, ə stɝn blu-aɪɾ iɡəl wɪð ə dɑɹk ɡɹeɪ ʃɔl ɹæpt ɝaʊn əɹ hɛd, stʊɾ ə ɡʊd spæn ɪn haɪt, əz mʌtʃ əz moʊst ilmɛn, waɪl ði ʌðɝ wɑz ət lis hæf ə hæn tɔlɝ ðən pɛɹɪn! ʃi wɑz nɑt bʌlki, ðoʊ, ɪksɛpt ɪn wʌn pɝtɪkjəlɝ. sændi jɛloʊ hɛɹ floʊd tə hɝ weɪst, hɛl bæk fɹəm əɹ feɪs baɪ ə waɪd dɑɹk kɝtʃəf, ən əɹ bɹaʊn ʃɔl leɪ əkɹɔs əɹ ʃoʊldɝz, oʊpən ɪnʌf tə ʃoʊ ən ɪnkɹɛɾəbəl əmaʊn ə bʊzəm θɹʌstɪŋ hæf aʊɾ ə hɝ peɪl blaʊs. haʊ dɪd ʃi əvɔɪd fɹizɪŋ, ɪkspoʊzɪŋ soʊ mʌtʃ skɪn ɪn ðɪs wɛðɝ? ɔl ðoʊz hɛvi nɛkləsɪz ʌv aɪvɝi ən ɡoʊl mʌs fil laɪk bænz ʌv aɪs!

Two Aiel women with a much shorter gai'shain woman between them came out of the swirling snow, sinking halfway up their calves in the white carpet that covered the ground but still managing powerful strides. The taller women did, anyway; the gai'shain stumbled and floundered trying to keep up, and one of the others had a hand on her shoulder to make sure she did. All three were worth a stare. The woman in white kept her head meekly down as much as she could and her hands folded in her wide sleeves as a gai'shain was supposed to, but her robes had the sheen of heavy silk, of all things. Gai'shain were forbidden jewelry, yet a wide, elaborate belt of gold and firedrops cinched her waist and a matching collar was just visible inside her cowl, nearly covering her neck. Very few besides royalty could afford the like. Strange as the gai'shain was, however, it was the others Faile studied. Something told her they were Wise Ones. There was too much authority about them for anything else; these were women used to giving orders and being obeyed. Beyond that, though, their simple presence caught the eye. The woman pushing the gai'shain along, a stern blue-eyed eagle with a dark gray shawl wrapped around her head, stood a good span in height, as much as most Aielmen, while the other was at least half a hand taller than Perrin! She was not bulky, though, except in one particular. Sandy yellow hair flowed to her waist, held back from her face by a wide dark kerchief, and her brown shawl lay across her shoulders, open enough to show an incredible amount of bosom thrusting half out of her pale blouse. How did she avoid freezing, exposing so much skin in this weather? All those heavy necklaces of ivory and gold must feel like bands of ice!

əz ðeɪ stɑpt ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə nilɪŋ pɹɪznɝz, ði iɡəl-feɪst wʊmən fɹaʊn dɪsəpɹuvɪŋli ət ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ hu hæd kæptʃɝd ðɛm, ən meɪɾ ə kɝt dʒɛstʃɝ ə dɪsmɪsəl wɪð əɹ fɹi hænd. fəɹ səm ɹizən, ʃi kəntɪnjud tə hoʊld ɑn tə ðə ɡeɪʃeɪnz ʃoʊldɝ taɪtli. ðə θɹi meɪɾənz tɝn ɪmiɾiətli, hɝiɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə pæsɪŋ θɹɔŋ ə ʃeɪɾoʊ. wʌn ə ðə mɛn dɪd, əz wɛl, bʌt ɹoʊlən ən ðə ɹɛst ɪkstʃeɪnʒd flæt-aɪd lʊks bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ fɑloʊd. pɝhæps ɪt mɛn sʌmθɪŋ, pɝhæps nʌθɪŋ. feɪl sʌɾənli nu haʊ sʌmwʌn ɪn ə wɝlpul fɛlt, ɡɹæbɪŋ dɛspɝətli ət stʃɹɔz.

As they stopped in front of the kneeling prisoners, the eagle-faced woman frowned disapprovingly at the Shaido who had captured them, and made a curt gesture of dismissal with her free hand. For some reason, she continued to hold on to the gai'shain's shoulder tightly. The three Maidens turned immediately, hurrying toward the passing throng of Shaido. One of the men did, as well, but Rolan and the rest exchanged flat-eyed looks before they followed. Perhaps it meant something, perhaps nothing. Faile suddenly knew how someone in a whirlpool felt, grabbing desperately at straws.

"wʌt wɪv ɪz mɔɹ ɡeɪʃeɪn fəɹ sɪvænə," ði ɪnkɹɛɾəbli tɔl wʊmən sɛɾ ɪn əmjuz toʊnz. ʃi hæɾ ə stʃɹɔŋ feɪs ðət səm maɪt kɔl pɹɪɾi, bʌɾ əlɔŋsaɪd ði ʌðɝ waɪz wʌn, ʃi sim sɑft. "sɪvænə wɪl nɑt bi sæɾəsfaɪd əntɪl ði ɪntaɪɝ wɝld ɪz ɡeɪʃeɪn, θɛɝɑvə. nɑt ðəɾ aɪ wəɾ əbdʒɛk tə ðət maɪsɛlf," ʃi fɪnɪʃt wɪð ə læf.

"What we have is more gai'shain for Sevanna," the incredibly tall woman said in amused tones. She had a strong face that some might call pretty, but alongside the other Wise One, she seemed soft. "Sevanna will not be satisfied until the entire world is gai'shain, Therava. Not that I would object to that myself," she finished with a laugh.

ði iɡəl-aɪd waɪz wʌn dɪd nɑt læf. hɝ feɪs wɑz stoʊn. hɝ vɔɪs wɑz stoʊn. "sɪvænə hæz tu mɛni ɡeɪʃeɪn ɔlɹɛɾi, sʌmɛɝɪn. wɪv tu mɛni ɡeɪʃeɪn. ðeɪ sloʊ əs tə ə kɹɔl wən wi ʃəd ɹeɪs." hɝ aɪɝn stɛɹ ɹæn əlɔŋ ðə nilɪŋ laɪn.

The eagle-eyed Wise One did not laugh. Her face was stone. Her voice was stone. "Sevanna has too many gai'shain already, Someryn. We have too many gai'shain. They slow us to a crawl when we should race." Her iron stare ran along the kneeling line.

feɪl flɪntʃt wən ðət ɡeɪz tʌtʃt hɝ, ən hɝidli bɛɹiɾ əɹ feɪs ɪn ðə mʌɡ. ʃi hæd nɛvɝ sin θɛɝɑvə bɪfɔɹ, bʌɾ ɪn ðət ɡlæns ʃi nu ðə wʊmənz sɔɹt, iɡɝ tə kɹʌʃ ɛni tʃælənʒ ʌɾɝli ən keɪpəbəl ə siɪŋ tʃælənʒ ɪn ə kæʒəwəl ɡlæns. bæɾ ɪnʌf wən ɪt wɑz oʊnli ə ful noʊbəl ət kɔɹt, əɹ sʌmwʌn ɪnkaʊntɝɾ ɑn ðə ɹoʊd, bʌɾ ɪskeɪp kəd bɪkʌm mɔɹ ðən dɪfəkəlt ɪf ðɪs iɡəl tʊk ə pɝsənəl ɪntʃɹəst. dʒʌs ðə seɪm, ʃi wɑtʃt ðə wʊmən fɹəm ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɝ aɪ. ɪt fɛlt laɪk wɑtʃɪŋ ə bændɪɾ æɾɝ, skeɪlz ɡlɪɾɝɪŋ ɪn ðə sʌn, kɔɪld ə fʊt fɹəm əɹ feɪs.

Faile flinched when that gaze touched her, and hurriedly buried her face in the mug. She had never seen Therava before, but in that glance she knew the woman's sort, eager to crush any challenge utterly and capable of seeing challenge in a casual glance. Bad enough when it was only a fool noble at court, or someone encountered on the road, but escape could become more than difficult if this eagle took a personal interest. Just the same, she watched the woman from the corner of her eye. It felt like watching a banded adder, scales glittering in the sun, coiled a foot from her face.

mik, ʃi θɔt. aɪm nilɪŋ hɪɹ mikli, wɪð noʊ θɔɾ ɪn maɪ hɛd bʌt dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ maɪ ti. noʊ nid tə lʊk ət mi twaɪs, jə koʊld-aɪd wɪtʃ. ʃi hoʊp ði ʌðɝz sɔ wʌt ʃi dɪd.

Meek, she thought. I am kneeling here meekly, with no thought in my head but drinking my tea. No need to look at me twice, you cold-eyed witch. She hoped the others saw what she did.

æliændɝ dɪd nɑt. ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə ɹaɪz tə hɝ swoʊlən fit, tɑɾɝd, ðən sæŋk bæk tə hɝ niz wɪð ə wɪns. ivən soʊ, ʃi nɛlt əpɹaɪɾ ɪn ðə fɔlɪŋ snoʊ, hɛd haɪ, ə ɹɛd-stʃɹaɪp blæŋkət hɛld ɝaʊn əɹ əz ɪf ɪt wɝ ə faɪn sɪlk ʃɔl oʊvɝ ə splɛndəd ɡaʊn. bɛɹd lɛɡz ən wɪnbloʊn hɛɹ spɔɪl ði ɪfɛk sʌmwʌt, jɛt ʃi wɑz stɪl ɛɹəɡəns ɑn ə pɛɾəstəl.

Alliandre did not. She tried to rise to her swollen feet, tottered, then sank back to her knees with a wince. Even so, she knelt upright in the falling snow, head high, a red-striped blanket held around her as if it were a fine silk shawl over a splendid gown. Bared legs and windblown hair spoiled the effect somewhat, yet she was still arrogance on a pedestal.

"aɪ æm æliændɝ mɛɹɪðə kɪɡɑɝɪn, kwin ʌv ɡildən," ʃi ənaʊns laʊdli, vɛɹi mʌtʃ kwin ədʒɹɛsɪŋ ɹʌfaɪən væɡəbɑnz. "ju wəd bi waɪz tə tʃɹit mi ən maɪ kəmpænjənz wɛl, ən pʌnɪʃ ðoʊz u hæv hændəld əs soʊ kɹudli. jə kən ɡeɪn ə lɑɹdʒ ɹænsəm fəɹ ʌs, lɑɹdʒɝ ðən jə kən ɪmædʒən, ən pɑɹɾən fəɹ jəɹ kɹaɪmz. maɪ lidʒ leɪɾi ən əl ɹikwaɪɝ suɾəbəl əkɑmədeɪʃən fəɹ aʊɝsɛlvz əntɪl ɝeɪnʒmənts kən bi meɪd, ən fəɹ əɹ meɪd. lɛsɝ wɪl də fəɹ ði ʌðɝz, soʊ lɔŋ əz ðeɪ ɑɹ nɑt hɑɹmd. əl peɪ noʊ ɹænsəm ɪf jə ɪl-tʃɹit ðə list ə maɪ lidʒ leɪɾiz sɝvəns."

"I am Alliandre Maritha Kigarin, Queen of Ghealdan," she announced loudly, very much queen addressing ruffian vagabonds. "You would be wise to treat me and my companions well, and punish those who have handled us so crudely. You can gain a large ransom for us, larger than you can imagine, and pardon for your crimes. My liege lady and I will require suitable accommodation for ourselves until arrangements can be made, and for her maid. Lesser will do for the others, so long as they are not harmed. I will pay no ransom if you ill-treat the least of my liege lady's servants."

feɪl cʊɾə ɡɹoʊnd - dɪd ði ɪɾiət wʊmən θɪŋk ðiz pipəl wɝ sɪmpəl bændəts? - oʊnli ʃi hæd noʊ taɪm tə.

Faile could have groaned - did the idiot woman think these people were simple bandits? - only she had no time to.

"ɪz ðət tʃɹu, ɡəlinə? ɪz ʃi ə wɛtləndɝ kwin?" ənʌðɝ wʊmən ɹoʊɾ aʊt fɹəm bɪhaɪn ðə pɹɪznɝz, hɝ tɔl blæk ɡɛldɪŋ wɔkɪŋ sɔfli ɪn ðə snoʊ. feɪl θɔt ʃi mʌs bi il, bʌt ʃi wɑz ənʃʊɹ. ɪt wɑz dɪfəkəl tə seɪ fəɹ sɝɾən wɪð ði ʌðɝ wʊmən ɑn hɔɹsbæk, bʌt ʃi simd ət list əz tɔl əz feɪl hɝsɛlf, ən fju wɪmən wɝ ɪksɛpt əmʌŋ ði il, sɝɾənli nɑt wɪð ðoʊz ɡɹin aɪz ɪn ə sʌn-dɑɹk feɪs. ən jɛt . . . ðət waɪd, dɑɹk skɝt lʊk laɪk ði il wɪmənz əɾ ə ɡlæns, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz dɪvaɪɾəd fəɹ ɹaɪɾɪŋ ən əpɪɹd tə bi sɪlk, əz wɑz əɹ kɹimi blaʊs, ən ðə hɛm ɹɪvild ɹɛd buts ɪn əɹ stɝəps. ðə waɪd foʊldəd kɝtʃəf ðət hɛl bæk əɹ lɔŋ ɡoʊldən hɛɹ wɑz bɹoʊkeɪɾɪd ɹɛd sɪlk, ən ə θʌm-θɪk sɝkləɾ ʌv ɡoʊld ən faɪɝdʒɹɑps nɛsəld oʊvɝ ɪt. ɪn kɑntʃɹæs tə ðə waɪz wʌnz' wɝkt ɡoʊld ən kɑɹvd aɪvɝi, hɝ ɹoʊps ə fæt pɝlz ən nɛkləsɪz ʌv ɛmɹəlz ən sæfaɪɝz ən ɹubiz hæf hɪd nɪɹli əz mʌtʃ bʊzəm əz sʌmɛɝɪn hæɾ ɑn dɪspleɪ. ðə bɹeɪslɪts klaɪmɪŋ ɔlmoʊs tə hɝ ɛlboʊz dɪfɝd fɹəm ðoʊz wɔɹn baɪ ðə tu waɪz wʌnz ɪn ðə seɪm weɪ, ən il dɪd nɑt wɛɹ ɹɪŋz, bʌt dʒɛmz spɑɹkəld ɑn ɛvɹi fɪŋɡɝ. ɪnstɛɾ ʌv ə dɑɹk ʃɔl, ə bɹaɪt kɹɪmzən kloʊk, bɔɹɾɝd wɪð ɡoʊldən ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi ən laɪnd wɪð waɪt fɝ, flɛɹɾ ɝaʊn əɹ ɪn ðə stɪf bɹiz. ʃi dɪd sɪɾ əɹ sæɾəl wɪð ði ɔkwɝdnəs ʌv il ɑn hɔɹsbæk, ðoʊ. "æn ə kwinz," hɝ tʌŋ tʃɹɪpt ənfəmɪljɹli, "lidʒ leɪɾi? ðət minz ðə kwin swɔɹ oʊθ tə hɝ? ə tʃɹuli paʊɝfəl wʊmən, ðɛn. ænsɝ mi, ɡəlinə!"

"Is that true, Galina? Is she a wetlander queen?" Another woman rode out from behind the prisoners, her tall black gelding walking softly in the snow. Faile thought she must be Aiel, but she was unsure. It was difficult to say for certain with the other woman on horseback, but she seemed at least as tall as Faile herself, and few women were except among the Aiel, certainly not with those green eyes in a sun-dark face. And yet . . . That wide, dark skirt looked like the Aiel women's at a glance, but it was divided for riding and appeared to be silk, as was her creamy blouse, and the hem revealed red boots in her stirrups. The wide folded kerchief that held back her long golden hair was brocaded red silk, and a thumb-thick circlet of gold and firedrops nestled over it. In contrast to the Wise Ones' worked gold and carved ivory, her ropes of fat pearls and necklaces of emeralds and sapphires and rubies half hid nearly as much bosom as Someryn had on display. The bracelets climbing almost to her elbows differed from those worn by the two Wise Ones in the same way, and Aiel did not wear rings, but gems sparkled on every finger. Instead of a dark shawl, a bright crimson cloak, bordered with golden embroidery and lined with white fur, flared around her in the stiff breeze. She did sit her saddle with the awkwardness of Aiel on horseback, though. "And a queen's," her tongue tripped unfamiliarly, "liege lady? That means the Queen swore oath to her? A truly powerful woman, then. Answer me, Galina!"

ðə sɪlk-klæd ɡeɪʃeɪn hʌntʃt əɹ ʃoʊldɝz ən feɪvɝd ðə maʊntəd wʊmən wɪð ə ɡɹɔvəlɪŋ smaɪl. "ə tʃɹuli paʊɝfəl wʊmən, tə hæv ə kwin swɛɹ fiəlti, sɪvænə," ʃi sɛɾ iɡɝli. "aɪv nɛvɝ hɝɾ ə ðə laɪk. jɛɾ aɪ θɪŋk ʃiz u ʃi kleɪmz. aɪ sɔ æliændɝ wʌns, jɪɹz əɡoʊ, ən ðə ɡɝl aɪ ɹikɔl kəd wɛl əv ɡɹoʊn ɪndə ðɪs wʊmən. ən ʃi wɑz kɹaʊn kwin ʌv ɡildən. wʌt ʃiz duɪŋ ɪn ɑmɑdɪʃiə, aɪ doʊnt noʊ. ðə waɪtkloʊks əɹ eɪlɹən iðɝ wʌn wəd snæp əɹ ʌp ɪn ən ɪnstən ɪf ðeɪ - "

The silk-clad gai'shain hunched her shoulders and favored the mounted woman with a groveling smile. "A truly powerful woman, to have a queen swear fealty, Sevanna," she said eagerly. "I've never heard of the like. Yet I think she is who she claims. I saw Alliandre once, years ago, and the girl I recall could well have grown into this woman. And she was crowned Queen of Ghealdan. What she is doing in Amadicia, I don't know. The Whitecloaks or Ailron either one would snap her up in an instant if they - "

"ɪnʌf, linə," θɛɝɑvə sɛd fɝmli. ðə hæn ɑn ɡəlinəz ʃoʊldɝ taɪɾənd vɪzəbli. "ju noʊ aɪ heɪɾ ɪt wən jə næɾɝ."

"Enough, Lina," Therava said firmly. The hand on Galina's shoulder tightened visibly. "You know I hate it when you natter."

ðə ɡeɪʃeɪn flɪntʃt əz ɪf stʃɹʌk, ən əɹ maʊθ snæpt ʃʌt. pɹæktəkli ɹaɪðɪŋ, ʃi smaɪld ʌp ət θɛɝɑvə, fɔnɪŋ ivən mɔɹ ɹɛtʃɪdli ðən ʃi hæd fəɹ sɪvænə. ɡoʊl flæʃt ɑn wʌn ə hɝ fɪŋɡɝz əz ʃi ɹʌŋ əɹ hænz. fɪɹ flæʃt ɪn əɹ aɪz, tu. dɑɹk aɪz. dɛfənətli nɑɾ il. θɛɝɑvə simd əblɪviəs tə ðə wʊmənz tʃɹʌklɪŋ; ə dɔɡ hæd bɪn kɔl tə hil ən hæɾ oʊbeɪd. hɝ ətɛnʃən wɑz ɔl ɑn sɪvænə. sʌmɛɝɪn aɪd ðə ɡeɪʃeɪn saɪdweɪz, hɝ lɪps twɪstɪŋ wɪð kəntɛmpt, bʌt ʃi foʊldəɾ əɹ ʃɔl əkɹɔs əɹ bʊzəm ən lʊk tə sɪvænə əz wɛl. il dɪd nɑt ɡɪv əweɪ mʌtʃ ɑn ðɛɹ feɪsəz, jɛt pleɪnli ʃi dɪslaɪk sɪvænə, ən wɑz wɛɹi ʌv əɹ ət ðə seɪm taɪm.

The gai'shain flinched as if struck, and her mouth snapped shut. Practically writhing, she smiled up at Therava, fawning even more wretchedly than she had for Sevanna. Gold flashed on one of her fingers as she wrung her hands. Fear flashed in her eyes, too. Dark eyes. Definitely not Aiel. Therava seemed oblivious to the woman's truckling; a dog had been called to heel and had obeyed. Her attention was all on Sevanna. Someryn eyed the gai'shain sideways, her lips twisting with contempt, but she folded her shawl across her bosom and looked to Sevanna as well. Aiel did not give away much on their faces, yet plainly she disliked Sevanna, and was wary of her at the same time.

feɪlz aɪz fɑloʊd ðə maʊntəd wʊmən, tu, oʊvɝ ði ɛdʒ ə hɝ mʌɡ. ɪn ə weɪ, ɪt wɑz laɪk siɪŋ lɑɡən, əɹ mæzɹim teɪm. sɪvænə ɔlsoʊ hæd peɪntəɾ əɹ neɪm əkɹɔs ðə skaɪ ɪn blʌɾ ən faɪɝ. kɛɹhin wəd nid jɪɹz tə ɹɪkʌvɝ fɹəm wʌt ʃi hæd ɹɔt ðɛɹ, ən ðə ɹɪpəlz hæd spɹɛd tə ændɝ ən tiɹ ən bɪɑnd. pɛɹɪn leɪd ðə bleɪm tə ə mæn kɔl kaʊulɑɾɪn, bʌt feɪl hæd hɝɾ ɪnʌf ə ðɪs wʊmən tə hæv ə ʃɹuɾ aɪdiə huz hæn hæd bɪn bɪhaɪn ɪɾ ɔl. ən noʊ wʌn dɪspjuɾəd ðət ðə slɔɾɝ ət dəməaɪz wɛlz wɑz sɪvænəz fɔlt. pɛɹɪn hæɾ ɔlmoʊs daɪd ðɛɹ. ʃi hæɾ ə pɝsənəl kleɪm ɑn sɪvænə fəɹ ðæt. ʃi maɪt bi wɪlɪŋ tə lɛt ɹoʊlən kip ɪz ɪɹz ɪf ʃi kəd sɛɾəl ðət kleɪm.

Faile's eyes followed the mounted woman, too, over the edge of her mug. In a way, it was like seeing Logain, or Mazrim Taim. Sevanna also had painted her name across the sky in blood and fire. Cairhien would need years to recover from what she had wrought there, and the ripples had spread to Andor and Tear and beyond. Perrin laid the blame to a man called Couladin, but Faile had heard enough of this woman to have a shrewd idea whose hand had been behind it all. And no one disputed that the slaughter at Dumai's Wells was Sevanna's fault. Perrin had almost died there. She had a personal claim on Sevanna for that. She might be willing to let Rolan keep his ears if she could settle that claim.

ðə flæmbɔɪənli ɡɑɹbd wʊmən wɔkt əɹ maʊn sloʊli əlɔŋ ðə laɪn ə nilɪŋ wɪmən, hɝ stɛɾi ɡɹin aɪz ɔlmoʊst əz koʊld əz θɛɝɑvəz. ðə saʊn ə snoʊ kɹʌntʃɪŋ bɪniθ ðə blæks hʊvz sʌɾənli sim laʊd. "wɪtʃ ə jə ɪz ðə meɪd?" ən ɑd kwɛstʃən. meɪaɪɡdɪn hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, taɪt-dʒɔd, bɪfɔɹ ɹeɪzɪŋ ə hæn fɹəm bɪniθ əɹ blæŋkət. sɪvænə nɑɾəd θɔtfəli. "æn ðə . . . lidʒ leɪɾi?"

The flamboyantly garbed woman walked her mount slowly along the line of kneeling women, her steady green eyes almost as cold as Therava's. The sound of snow crunching beneath the black's hooves suddenly seemed loud. "Which of you is the maid?" An odd question. Maighdin hesitated, tight-jawed, before raising a hand from beneath her blanket. Sevanna nodded thoughtfully. "And the . . . liege lady?"

feɪl kənsɪɾɝd hoʊldɪŋ bæk, bʌt wʌn weɪ əɹ ənʌðɝ, sɪvænə wəd lɝn wʌt ʃi wɑntəd tə noʊ. ɹɪlʌktənli, ʃi lɪftəɾ əɹ hænd. ən ʃɪvɝd fɹəm mɔɹ ðən ðə koʊld. θɛɝɑvə wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ wɪð ðoʊz kɹuəl aɪz, peɪɪŋ kloʊs ətɛnʃən. tə sɪvænə, ən tə ðoʊz ʃi mɑɹkt aʊt.

Faile considered holding back, but one way or another, Sevanna would learn what she wanted to know. Reluctantly, she lifted her hand. And shivered from more than the cold. Therava was watching with those cruel eyes, paying close attention. To Sevanna, and to those she marked out.

haʊ ɛniwʌn kəd bi ʌnəwɛɹ ə ðəɾ ɔdʒɝɪŋ ɡeɪz, feɪl dɪd nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd, jɛt sɪvænə sim soʊ əz ʃi tɝn əɹ ɡɛldɪŋ daʊn ðə bæk ə ðə laɪn. "ðeɪ kænɑt wɔk ɑn ðoʊz fit," ʃi sɛɾ æftɝ ə moʊmənt. "aɪ də nɑt si waɪ ðeɪ ʃəd ɹaɪd wɪð ðə tʃɪlʒɹən. hil ðɛm, ɡəlinə."

How anyone could be unaware of that augering gaze, Faile did not understand, yet Sevanna seemed so as she turned her gelding down the back of the line. "They cannot walk on those feet," she said after a moment. "I do not see why they should ride with the children. Heal them, Galina."

feɪl ɡeɪv ə stɑɹɾ ən ɔlmoʊs dʒɹɑp ðə kleɪ mʌɡ. ʃi pʊʃt ɪt təwɔɹd ðə ɡeɪʃeɪn, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə meɪk aʊt ðət ðət wɑz wʌt ʃi hæd bɪn duɪŋ ɔl əlɔŋ. ɪt wɑz ɛmpti ɛniweɪ. ðə skɑɹd fɛloʊ kɑmli bɪɡæn fɪlɪŋ ɪɾ ʌp əɡɛn fɹəm ɪz wɔɾɝ bæɡ ʌv ti. hil? ʃʊɹli ʃi kəd nɑt min . . .

Faile gave a start and almost dropped the clay mug. She pushed it toward the gai'shain, trying to make out that that was what she had been doing all along. It was empty anyway. The scarred fellow calmly began filling it up again from his water bag of tea. Heal? Surely she could not mean . . .

"vɛɹi wɛl," θɛɝɑvə sɛd, ɡɪvɪŋ ðə ɡeɪʃeɪn wʊmən ə ʃʌv ðət stæɡɝd hɝ. "du ɪt kwɪkli, lɪɾəl linə. aɪ noʊ jə də nɑt wɑnə dɪsəpɔɪn mi."

"Very well," Therava said, giving the gai'shain woman a shove that staggered her. "Do it quickly, little Lina. I know you do not want to disappoint me."

ɡəlinə kɑt hɝsɛlf fɹəm fɔlɪŋ, bʌɾ oʊnli tə stʃɹʌɡəl ɑn təwɔɹd ðə pɹɪznɝz. ʃi sæŋk əbʌv əɹ niz ɪn pleɪsəz, hɝ ɹoʊbz dʒɹæɡɪŋ ɪn ðə snoʊ, bʌt ʃi wɑz ɪntɛn ɑn ɹitʃɪŋ əɹ ɡoʊl. waɪd-aɪd fɪɹ ən ɹɪvʌlʃən mɪŋɡəld ɑn əɹ ɹaʊn feɪs wɪð . . . kəɾ ɪt bi, iɡɝnəs? ɔl ɪn ɔl, ɪt wɑz ə sɪkənɪŋ kɑmbəneɪʃən.

Galina caught herself from falling, but only to struggle on toward the prisoners. She sank above her knees in places, her robes dragging in the snow, but she was intent on reaching her goal. Wide-eyed fear and revulsion mingled on her round face with . . . could it be, eagerness? All in all, it was a sickening combination.

sɪvænə kəmpliɾəd əɹ sɝkət, kʌmɪŋ bæk tə wɛɹ feɪl kəd si hɝ klɪɹli, ən ɹeɪn ɪn feɪsɪŋ ðə waɪz wʌnz. ðə wʊmənz fʊl maʊθ wɑz taɪt. ði aɪsi bɹiz ɹɪpəld əɹ kloʊk, bʌt ʃi simd ʌnəwɛɹ ʌv ɪt, əɹ ə ðə snoʊ fɔlɪŋ ɑn əɹ hɛd. "aɪ hæv dʒʌst ɹəsivd wɝd, θɛɝɑvə." hɝ vɔɪs wɑz kɑm, ðoʊ laɪtnɪŋ boʊls ʃʊɾə bɪn flæʃɪŋ fɹəm əɹ aɪz. "tənaɪt wi kæmp wɪð ðə dʒoʊnaɪn."

Sevanna completed her circuit, coming back to where Faile could see her clearly, and reined in facing the Wise Ones. The woman's full mouth was tight. The icy breeze rippled her cloak, but she seemed unaware of it, or of the snow falling on her head. "I have just received word, Therava." Her voice was calm, though lightning bolts should have been flashing from her eyes. "Tonight we camp with the Jonine."

"ə fɪfθ sɛpt," θɛɝɑvə ɹɪplaɪd flætli. fəɹ hɝ, ɔlsoʊ, wɪn ən snoʊ maɪɾ əz wɛl nɑɾ əv ɪɡzɪstəd. "faɪv, waɪl sɛvənti-eɪt ɹɪmeɪn skæɾɝd ɑn ðə wɪnd. wɛl ðət jə ɹɪmɛmbɝ jəɹ plɛdʒ tə ɹiunaɪt ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ, sɪvænə. wɪl nɑt weɪt fɝɛvɝ."

"A fifth sept," Therava replied flatly. For her, also, wind and snow might as well not have existed. "Five, while seventy-eight remain scattered on the wind. Well that you remember your pledge to reunite the Shaido, Sevanna. We will not wait forever."

nɑt laɪtnɪŋ boʊls, naʊ. sɪvænəz aɪz wɝ ɡɹin vɑlkeɪnoʊz ɪɹʌptɪŋ. "aɪ ɔlweɪz də wʌɾ aɪ seɪ, θɛɝɑvə. wɛl ðət jə ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðæt. ən ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðət jə ædvaɪz mi. aɪ spik fəɹ ðə klæn tʃif."

Not lightning bolts, now. Sevanna's eyes were green volcanoes erupting. "I always do what I say, Therava. Well that you remember that. And remember that you advise me. I speak for the clan chief."

wilɪŋ əɹ ɡɛldɪŋ, ʃi dʒɹʌmd əɹ hilz ɑn ði ænəməlz ɹɪbz, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə meɪk ɪm ɡæləp bæk təwɔɹd ðə ɹɪvɝ ə pipəl ən wæɡənz, ðoʊ noʊ hɔɹs kəd də soʊ ɪn ðət dɛpθ ə snoʊ. ðə blæk mænədʒ sʌmθɪŋ fæstɝ ðən ə wɔk, bʌt nɑt mʌtʃ. ðɛɹ feɪsəz ɪkspɹɛʃənləs əz mæsks, θɛɝɑvə ən sʌmɛɝɪn wɑtʃt hɔɹs ən ɹaɪɾɝ feɪɾ ɪndə ðə fɔlɪŋ waɪt veɪl.

Wheeling her gelding, she drummed her heels on the animal's ribs, trying to make him gallop back toward the river of people and wagons, though no horse could do so in that depth of snow. The black managed something faster than a walk, but not much. Their faces expressionless as masks, Therava and Someryn watched horse and rider fade into the falling white veil.

ən ɪmpɔɹɾənt ɪkstʃeɪnʒ, ət lis tə feɪl. ʃi nu tɛnʃən taɪɾ əz ə hɑɹpstʃɹɪŋ wən ʃi sɔ ɪt, ən mjutʃəwəl heɪtʃɹəd. ə wiknəs ðət maɪt bi ɛksplɔɪɾəd, ɪf ʃi kəd pʌzəl aʊt haʊ. ən ɪt sim ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ wɝ nɑɾ ɔl hɪɹ æftɝ ɔl. ðoʊ mɔɹ ðən ɪnʌf sim tə bi, dʒʌdʒɪŋ baɪ ði ənɛndɪŋ ɹɪvɝ ə ðɛm pæsɪŋ baɪ. ɡəlinə ɹitʃt əɹ ðɛn, ən ɛniθɪŋ ɛls flɛd fɹəm əɹ maɪnd.

An important exchange, at least to Faile. She knew tension tight as a harpstring when she saw it, and mutual hatred. A weakness that might be exploited, if she could puzzle out how. And it seemed the Shaido were not all here after all. Though more than enough seemed to be, judging by the unending river of them passing by. Galina reached her then, and anything else fled from her mind.

smuðɪŋ əɹ feɪs tə ə ɹæɡəd sɛmbləns ə kəmpoʊʒɝ, ɡəlinə klʌtʃt feɪlz hɛɾ ɪn boʊθ hænz wɪθaʊt spikɪŋ ə wɝd. feɪl maɪɾ əv ɡæspt; ʃi kəd nɑt bi ʃʊɹ. ðə wɝl sim tə flaɪ baɪ əz ʃi dʒɝk hæfweɪ tə hɝ fit. aʊɝz stʃɹik baɪ, əɹ hɑɹtbits kɹɔld. ðə waɪt-klæd wʊmən stɛp bæk, ən feɪl kəlæpst ɑn əɹ feɪs ətɑp ðə bɹaʊn blæŋkət tə laɪ pæntɪŋ əɡɛns ðə ɹʌf wʊl. hɝ fit noʊ lɔŋɡɝ hɝt, bʌt hilɪŋ ɔlweɪz bɹɔɾ ɪts oʊn hʌŋɡɝ, ən ʃi hæɾ iɾən nʌθɪŋ sɪns jɛstɝdeɪz bɹɛkfəst. ʃi cʊɾə wʊlf daʊn pleɪts ʌv ɛniθɪŋ ðəɾ ivən lʊk laɪk fud. ʃi noʊ lɔŋɡɝ fɛl taɪɝd, bʌɾ əɹ mʌsəlz wɝ wɔɾɝ ɪnstɛɾ ə pʊɾɪŋ. pʊʃɪŋ hɝsɛlf ʌp wɪð ɑɹmz ðət wɑntəd tə foʊld ʌndɝ əɹ weɪt, ʃi ənstɛɾəli ɡæðɝd ðə ɡɹeɪ-stʃɹaɪp blæŋkəɾ əɡɛn. ʃi fɛl stʌn əz mʌtʃ baɪ wʌt ʃi hæd sin ɑn ɡəlinəz hæn dʒʌs bɪfɔɹ ɡəlinə sizd əɹ əz ʃi dɪd baɪ ðə hilɪŋ. ɡɹeɪtfəli ʃi lɛt ðə skɑɹd mæn hoʊl ðə stimɪŋ mʌɡ tə hɝ maʊθ. ʃi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ əɹ fɪŋɡɝz cʊɾə hɛld ɑn tə ɪt.

Smoothing her face to a ragged semblance of composure, Galina clutched Faile's head in both hands without speaking a word. Faile might have gasped; she could not be sure. The world seemed to fly by as she jerked halfway to her feet. Hours streaked by, or heartbeats crawled. The white-clad woman stepped back, and Faile collapsed on her face atop the brown blanket to lie panting against the rough wool. Her feet no longer hurt, but Healing always brought its own hunger, and she had eaten nothing since yesterday's breakfast. She could have wolfed down plates of anything that even looked like food. She no longer felt tired, but her muscles were water instead of pudding. Pushing herself up with arms that wanted to fold under her weight, she unsteadily gathered the gray-striped blanket again. She felt stunned as much by what she had seen on Galina's hand just before Galina seized her as she did by the Healing. Gratefully she let the scarred man hold the steaming mug to her mouth. She was not sure her fingers could have held on to it.

ɡəlinə wɑz weɪstɪŋ noʊ taɪm. ə deɪzd æliændɝ wɑz dʒʌst ətɛmptɪŋ tə ɹaɪz fɹəm flæɾ ɑn əɹ feɪs, hɝ stʃɹaɪp kʌvɝɪŋ blæŋkət slaɪɾɪŋ tə ðə ɡɹaʊn ənnoʊɾɪst. hɝ wɛls wɝ ɡɔn, ʌv kɔɹs. meɪaɪɡdɪn stɪl leɪ spɹɔl bɪtwin əɹ tu blæŋkəts, lus lɪmz poʊkɪŋ aʊɾ ɪn ɛvɹi dɝɛkʃən ən twɪtʃɪŋ əz ʃi fibli tʃɹaɪd tə kəlɛk hɝsɛlf. kiæd, wɪð ɡəlinəz hænz ɑn əɹ hɛd, lɝtʃt ɔl ðə weɪ tə hɝ fit, ɑɹmz flʌŋ waɪd, bɹɛθ livɪŋ əɹ ɪn ə laʊd ɹʌʃ. ðə jɛloʊd swɛlɪŋ ɑn əɹ feɪs feɪɾəd əweɪ ivən əz feɪl wɑtʃt. ðə meɪɾən dʒɹɑpt əz ɪf pɑliækst wən ɡəlinə muvd ɑn tə beɪn, ðoʊ ʃi bɪɡæn stɝɪŋ ɔlmoʊst ət wʌns.

Galina was wasting no time. A dazed Alliandre was just attempting to rise from flat on her face, her striped covering blanket sliding to the ground unnoticed. Her welts were gone, of course. Maighdin still lay sprawled between her two blankets, loose limbs poking out in every direction and twitching as she feebly tried to collect herself. Chiad, with Galina's hands on her head, lurched all the way to her feet, arms flung wide, breath leaving her in a loud rush. The yellowed swelling on her face faded away even as Faile watched. The Maiden dropped as if poleaxed when Galina moved on to Bain, though she began stirring almost at once.

feɪl ətɛndəd tə hɝ ti, ən fjʊɹiəs θɔt. ðə ɡoʊld ɑn ɡəlinəz fɪŋɡɝ wɑz ə ɡɹeɪt sɝpən ɹɪŋ. ʃi maɪɾ əv θɔɾ ɪɾ ə stʃɹeɪnʒ pɹɛzən fɹəm huɛvɝ ɡeɪv ðə wʊmən əɹ ʌðɝ dʒuəlz ɪf nɑt fəɹ ðə hilɪŋ. ɡəlinə wɑz ɛɛs sədaɪ. ʃi mʌs bi. bʌt wʌt wɑz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ duɪŋ hɪɹ, ɪn ɡeɪʃeɪn ɹoʊbz? nɑt tə mɛnʃən əpɛɹənli ɹɛɾi tə lɪk sɪvænəz ɹɪst ən kɪs θɛɝɑvəz fit! ən ɛɛs sədaɪ!

Faile attended to her tea, and furious thought. The gold on Galina's finger was a Great Serpent ring. She might have thought it a strange present from whoever gave the woman her other jewels if not for the Healing. Galina was Aes Sedai. She must be. But what was an Aes Sedai doing here, in gai'shain robes? Not to mention apparently ready to lick Sevanna's wrist and kiss Therava's feet! An Aes Sedai!

stændɪŋ oʊvɝ ə lɪmp ɹɛlə, ðə læst ɪn ðə laɪn, ɡəlinə pæntɪd slaɪtli fɹəm ði ɛfɝɾ ə hilɪŋ soʊ mɛni soʊ kwɪkli, ən ɡeɪzd ət θɛɝɑvə əz ðoʊ hoʊpfəl fəɹ ə wɝɾ ə pɹeɪz. wɪθaʊt soʊ mʌtʃ əz ə lʊk ət hɝ, ðə tu waɪz wʌnz stɑɹɾəd təwɔɹd ðə ɹɪvɝ ə ʃeɪɾoʊ, ðɛɹ hɛdz təɡɛðɝ, tɔkɪŋ. æftɝ ə moʊmənt, ði ɛɛs sədaɪ skaʊld ən lɪftəɾ əɹ ɹoʊbz, hɝiɪŋ æftɝ əm əz kwɪkli əz ʃi kʊd. ʃi ɡlæns bæk mɔɹ ðən wʌns, ðoʊ. feɪl hæd ðə filɪŋ ðət ʃi dɪd soʊ ivən æftɝ ðə fɔlɪŋ snoʊ pʊɾ ə kɝɾən bɪtwin ðɛm.

Standing over a limp Arrela, the last in the line, Galina panted slightly from the effort of Healing so many so quickly, and gazed at Therava as though hopeful for a word of praise. Without so much as a look at her, the two Wise Ones started toward the river of Shaido, their heads together, talking. After a moment, the Aes Sedai scowled and lifted her robes, hurrying after them as quickly as she could. She glanced back more than once, though. Faile had the feeling that she did so even after the falling snow put a curtain between them.

mɔɹ ɡeɪʃeɪn keɪm ði ʌðɝ weɪ, ə dʌzən mɛn ən wɪmən, ən oʊnli wʌn wɑz il, ə læŋki ɹɛdhɛd wɪð ə θɪn waɪt skɑɹ fɹəm hɛɹlaɪn tə dʒɔ. feɪl ɹɛkəɡnaɪzd ʃɔɹt, pæləd kɛɹhinɪn, ən ʌðɝz ʃi θɔt maɪt bi ɑmɑdɪʃən əɹ ɔltɑɹən, tɔlɝ ən dɑɹkɝ, ən ivən ə bɹɑnz-skɪn dəmɑni. ðə dəmɑni ən wʌn ə ði ʌðɝ wɪmən wɔɹ waɪd bɛls ə ʃaɪni ɡoʊldən tʃeɪn taɪɾ ɝaʊn ðɛɹ weɪsts, ən kɑlɝz ə ðə flæt lɪŋks ɝaʊn ðɛɹ nɛks. soʊ dɪd wʌn ə ðə mɛn! ɪn ɛni keɪs, dʒuəlɹi ɑn ɡeɪʃeɪn simd ənɪmpɔɹɾənt ɪksɛpt əz ən ɑɾəti, ɪspɛʃli əlɔŋsaɪd ðə fuɾ ən kloʊðɪŋ ðeɪ bɹɔt.

More gai'shain came the other way, a dozen men and women, and only one was Aiel, a lanky redhead with a thin white scar from hairline to jaw. Faile recognized short, pallid Cairhienin, and others she thought might be Amadician or Altaran, taller and darker, and even a bronze-skinned Domani. The Domani and one of the other women wore wide belts of shiny golden chain tight around their waists, and collars of the flat links around their necks. So did one of the men! In any case, jewelry on gai'shain seemed unimportant except as an oddity, especially alongside the food and clothing they brought.

səm ə ðə nukʌmɝz kæɹid bæskəts wɪð loʊvz ə bɹɛɾ ən jɛloʊ tʃiz ən dʒɹaɪd bif, ən ðə ɡeɪʃeɪn ɔlɹɛɾi ðəɹ wɪð ðɛɹ wɔɾɝ bæɡz ə ti pɹəvaɪɾəd dʒɹɪŋk tə wɑʃ ɪt daʊn. feɪl wɑz nɑɾ əloʊn ɪn stʌfɪŋ əɹ maʊθ wɪð ənsimli heɪst ivən waɪl ʃi dʒɹɛst, klʌmsəli ən wɪð mɔɹ maɪn tə spid ðən mɑɾəsti. ðə hʊɾɪd waɪt ɹoʊb ən tu θɪk ʌndɝ-ɹoʊbz simd wɑnʒɹəsli wɔɹm, dʒʌs tə kip ði ɛɹ ɔf, ən soʊ wɝ hɛvi wʊlən stɑkɪŋz ən sɑft il buts ðət leɪs tə hɝ niz - ivən ðə buts hæd bɪn blitʃt waɪt! - bʌt ðeɪ dɪd nɑt fɪl ʌp ðə hoʊl ɪn əɹ mɪɾəl. ðə mit wɑz tʌf əz but lɛðɝ, ðə tʃiz nɪɹli ɹɑk hɑɹɾ ən ðə bɹɛd nɑt mʌtʃ sɑftɝ, jɛt ðeɪ teɪstəd laɪk ə fist! hɝ maʊθ wɔɾɝd fəɹ ɛvɹi baɪt.

Some of the newcomers carried baskets with loaves of bread and yellow cheese and dried beef, and the gai'shain already there with their water bags of tea provided drink to wash it down. Faile was not alone in stuffing her mouth with unseemly haste even while she dressed, clumsily and with more mind to speed than modesty. The hooded white robe and two thick under-robes seemed wondrously warm, just to keep the air off, and so were heavy woolen stockings and soft Aiel boots that laced to her knees - even the boots had been bleached white! - but they did not fill up the hole in her middle. The meat was tough as boot leather, the cheese nearly rock hard and the bread not much softer, yet they tasted like a feast! Her mouth watered for every bite.

tʃuɪŋ ə maʊθfʊl ə tʃiz, ʃi nɑɾɪd ðə læs butleɪs ən stʊd, smuðɪŋ daʊn əɹ ɹoʊbz. əz ʃi ɹitʃt fəɹ səm mɔɹ bɹɛd, wʌn ə ðə wɪmən wɛɹɪŋ ɡoʊld, plʌmp ən pleɪn ən wɪɹi-aɪd, tʊk ənʌðɝ bɛlt ʌv ɡoʊldən tʃeɪn aʊɾ ʌv ə klɔθ sæk hæŋɪŋ fɹəm əɹ ʃoʊldɝ. heɪstəli swɑloʊɪŋ, feɪl stɛp bæk. "aɪ wəd ɹæðɝ nɑɾ əv ðæt, θæŋk ju." ʃi hæɾ ə sɪŋkɪŋ filɪŋ ʃi hæd bɪn ɹɔŋ tə dɪsmɪs ði ədɔɹnməns əz ənɪmpɔɹɾənt.

Chewing a mouthful of cheese, she knotted the last bootlace and stood, smoothing down her robes. As she reached for some more bread, one of the women wearing gold, plump and plain and weary-eyed, took another belt of golden chain out of a cloth sack hanging from her shoulder. Hastily swallowing, Faile stepped back. "I would rather not have that, thank you." She had a sinking feeling she had been wrong to dismiss the adornments as unimportant.

"wʌt jə wɑn dʌz nɑt mæɾɝ," ðə plʌmp wʊmən ɹɪplaɪd taɪɹədli. hɝ æksɛnt wɑz ɑmɑdɪʃən, ən kʌltʃɝd. "ju sɝv ðə leɪɾi sɪvænə, naʊ. jəl wɛɹ wʌt jə ɑɹ ɡɪvən ən də əz jə ɑɹ toʊld, əɹ jəl bi pʌnɪʃt əntɪl jə si ði ɛɹɝ ə jəɹ weɪz."

"What you want does not matter," the plump woman replied tiredly. Her accent was Amadician, and cultured. "You serve the Lady Sevanna, now. You will wear what you are given and do as you are told, or you will be punished until you see the error of your ways."

ə fju peɪsɪz əweɪ, meɪaɪɡdɪn wɑz fɛndɪŋ ɔf ðə dəmɑni, ɹɪzɪstɪŋ biɪŋ fɪɾəd wɪð ə kɑlɝ. æliændɝ wɑz bækɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm ðə mæn u wɔɹ ɡoʊldən tʃeɪnz, hɝ hænz ɹeɪzd ən ə sɪkli ɪkspɹɛʃən ɑn əɹ feɪs. hi hɛld aʊt wʌn ə ðə bɛls təwɔɹd hɝ. θæŋkfəli, ðeɪ wɝ boʊθ lʊkɪŋ tə feɪl, ðoʊ. pɝhæps ðət swɪtʃɪŋ ɪn ðə fɔɹəs hæd dʌn səm ɡʊd.

A few paces away, Maighdin was fending off the Domani, resisting being fitted with a collar. Alliandre was backing away from the man who wore golden chains, her hands raised and a sickly expression on her face. He held out one of the belts toward her. Thankfully, they were both looking to Faile, though. Perhaps that switching in the forest had done some good.

ɪkshəlɪŋ hɛvəli, feɪl nɑɾəd tə ðɛm, ðən əlaʊd ðə plʌmp ɡeɪʃeɪn tə fæsən ðə waɪd bɛlt ɝaʊn hɝ. wɪð əɹ ɪɡzæmpəl, ði ʌðɝ tu lɛt ðɛɹ hænz fɔl. ɪt simd wʌn bloʊ tu mɛni fəɹ æliændɝ, hu stʊd stɛɹɪŋ ət nʌθɪŋ əz ʃi wɑz bɛltəɾ ən kɑlɝd. meɪaɪɡdɪn dɪɾ əɹ bɛs tə ɡlɛɹ ə hoʊl θɹu ðə slɪm dəmɑni. feɪl tʃɹaɪd smaɪlɪŋ ɛnkɝɪdʒmənt, bʌt smaɪlɪŋ wɑz dɪfəkəlt. tə hɝ, ðə kɑlɝz kætʃ snæpɪŋ ʃʌt saʊndəd laɪk ə pɹɪzən dɔɹ biɪŋ lɑkt. bɛlt ən kɑlɝ kəd bi ɹimuvd əz izəli əz ðeɪ hæd bɪn pʊɾ ɑn, bʌt ɡeɪʃeɪn sɝvɪŋ "ðə leɪɾi sɪvænə" ʃʊɹli wəd bi wɑtʃt vɛɹi kloʊsli. dɪzæstɝ wɑz paɪlɪŋ ɑn dɪzæstɝ. θɪŋz hæd tə ɡɛt bɛɾɝ fɹəm hɪɹ ɑn. ðeɪ hæd tə.

Exhaling heavily, Faile nodded to them, then allowed the plump gai'shain to fasten the wide belt around her. With her example, the other two let their hands fall. It seemed one blow too many for Alliandre, who stood staring at nothing as she was belted and collared. Maighdin did her best to glare a hole through the slim Domani. Faile tried smiling encouragement, but smiling was difficult. To her, the collar's catch snapping shut sounded like a prison door being locked. Belt and collar could be removed as easily as they had been put on, but gai'shain serving "the Lady Sevanna" surely would be watched very closely. Disaster was piling on disaster. Things had to get better from here on. They had to.

sun, feɪl faʊn hɝsɛlf tʃɹæmpɪŋ ðoʊ ðə snoʊ ɑn wɑbəli lɛɡz wɪð ə stʌmbəlɪŋ, dʌl-aɪɾ æliændɝ ən ə skaʊlɪŋ meɪaɪɡdɪn, sɝaʊndəd baɪ ɡeɪʃeɪn liɾɪŋ pæk ænəməlz, kæɹiɪŋ lɑɹdʒ kʌvɝd bæskəts ɑn ðɛɹ bæks, dʒɹæɡɪŋ loʊɾəd bæɹoʊz wɪð ðə wilz læʃt tə wʊɾən slɛdz. ðə kɑɹts ən wæɡənz hæd slɛdz əɹ bɹɔd ɹʌnɝz, tu, wɪð ðə wilz taɪɾ ɑn tɑp ə ðə snoʊ-ʃɹaʊɾɪd kɑɹɡoʊ. snoʊ maɪt bi ʌnfəmɪljɝ tə ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ, bʌt ðeɪ hæd lɝn sʌmθɪŋ ə tʃɹævlɪŋ ɪn ɪt. niðɝ feɪl nɔɹ ði ʌðɝ tu bɔɹ ɛni bɝɾənz, ðoʊ ðə plʌmp ɑmɑdɪʃən wʊmən meɪd klɪɹ ðət ðeɪ wəd bi ɪkspɛktəd tə kæɹi əɹ hɔl təmɑɹoʊ ən fɹəm ðən ɑn. haʊɛvɝ mɛni ʃeɪɾoʊ wɝ ɪn ðə kɑləm, ɪt simd ə ɡɹeɪt sɪɾi ɑn ðə muv, ɪf nɑɾ ə neɪʃən. tʃɪlʒɹən ʌp tə twɛlv əɹ θɝtin ɹoʊɾ ɑn ðə kɑɹts ən wæɡənz, bʌɾ ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls wɔkt. ɔl ə ðə mɛn wɔɹ ðə keɪɾɪnsɝ, bʌt moʊst wɪmən wɔɹ skɝts ən blaʊsəz ən ʃɔlz laɪk ðə waɪz wʌnz, ən moʊst ə ðə mɛn kæɹiɾ oʊnli ə sɪŋɡəl spɪɹ əɹ noʊ wɛpən əɾ ɔl ən lʊk sɑftɝ ðən ði ʌðɝz. sɑf minɪŋ ðət ðəɹ wɝ stoʊnz sɑftɝ ðən ɡɹænət.

Soon, Faile found herself tramping though the snow on wobbly legs with a stumbling, dull-eyed Alliandre and a scowling Maighdin, surrounded by gai'shain leading pack animals, carrying large covered baskets on their backs, dragging loaded barrows with the wheels lashed to wooden sleds. The carts and wagons had sleds or broad runners, too, with the wheels tied on top of the snow-shrouded cargo. Snow might be unfamiliar to the Shaido, but they had learned something of traveling in it. Neither Faile nor the other two bore any burdens, though the plump Amadician woman made clear that they would be expected to carry or haul tomorrow and from then on. However many Shaido were in the column, it seemed a great city on the move, if not a nation. Children up to twelve or thirteen rode on the carts and wagons, but everyone else walked. All of the men wore the cadin'sor, but most women wore skirts and blouses and shawls like the Wise Ones, and most of the men carried only a single spear or no weapon at all and looked softer than the others. Soft meaning that there were stones softer than granite.

baɪ ðə taɪm ði ɑmɑdɪʃən lɛft, wɪθaʊt ɡɪvɪŋ əɹ neɪm əɹ seɪɪŋ mʌtʃ mɔɹ ðən oʊbeɪ əɹ bi pʌnɪʃt, feɪl ɹilaɪz ðət ʃi hæd lɔst saɪɾ ə beɪn ən ðə ɹɛst sʌmwɛɹ ɪn ðə fɔlɪŋ snoʊ. noʊ wʌn tʃɹaɪd tə meɪk əɹ kip ə pɝtɪkjəlɝ pleɪs, soʊ ʃi tʃɹæmpt wɛɹəli bæk ən fɔɹθ əkɹɔs ðə kɑləm, əkʌmpənid baɪ æliændɝ ən meɪaɪɡdɪn. kipɪŋ əɹ hænz foʊldəd təɡɛðɝ ɪn əɹ slivz meɪd wɔkɪŋ dɪfəkəlt, ɪspɛʃli weɪɾɪŋ θɹu snoʊ, bʌɾ ɪt dɪd kip əm wɔɹm. wɔɹmɝ ðən ði ɔltɝnəɾɪv, ət list. ðə wɪn meɪd ʃʊɹ ðeɪ kɛp ðɛɹ hʊdz wɛl ʌp. dɪspaɪt ði aɪdɛntəfaɪɪŋ ɡoʊldən bɛls, niðɝ ɡeɪʃeɪn nɔɹ ʃeɪɾoʊ lʊkt əɾ əm twaɪs. dɪspaɪt kɹɔsɪŋ ðə kɑləm ə dʌzən taɪmz əɹ mɔɹ, haʊɛvɝ, ðə sɝtʃ pɹuv fɹutləs. ðəɹ wɝ pipəl ɪn waɪt ɹoʊbz ɛvɹiwɛɹ, mɔɹ ðən wɪθaʊt, ən ɛni ʌv ðoʊz dip kaʊlz cʊɾə hɪɾən əɹ ʌðɝ kəmpænjənz.

By the time the Amadician left, without giving her name or saying much more than obey or be punished, Faile realized that she had lost sight of Bain and the rest somewhere in the falling snow. No one tried to make her keep a particular place, so she tramped wearily back and forth across the column, accompanied by Alliandre and Maighdin. Keeping her hands folded together in her sleeves made walking difficult, especially wading through snow, but it did keep them warm. Warmer than the alternative, at least. The wind made sure they kept their hoods well up. Despite the identifying golden belts, neither gai'shain nor Shaido looked at them twice. Despite crossing the column a dozen times or more, however, the search proved fruitless. There were people in white robes everywhere, more than without, and any of those deep cowls could have hidden her other companions.

"wi wɪl əv tə faɪn əm tənaɪt," meɪaɪɡdɪn sɛd faɪnəli. ʃi æktʃəli  mænədʒ tə stɔk θɹu ðə dip snoʊ, ɪf ɪn ən ənɡeɪnli fæʃən. hɝ blu aɪz wɝ fɪɹs ɪnsaɪd ðə kævɝn ə hɝ hʊd, ən ʃi ɡɹɪp ðə bɹɔd ɡoʊldən tʃeɪn ɝaʊn əɹ nɛk wɪð wʌn hæn əz ɪf wɑntɪŋ tə ɹɪp ɪɾ ɔf. "æz ɪɾ ɪz, wɝ teɪkɪŋ tɛn stɛps tə wʌn fəɹ ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls. twɛnti fəɹ ɪɾəl wɪl də əs lɪɾəl ɡʊd tə ɝaɪv ət tənaɪts kæmp tu ɪɡzɔstəd tə muv."

"We will have to find them tonight," Maighdin said finally. She actually managed to stalk through the deep snow, if in an ungainly fashion. Her blue eyes were fierce inside the cavern of her hood, and she gripped the broad golden chain around her neck with one hand as if wanting to rip it off. "As it is, we're taking ten steps to one for everyone else. Twenty for one. It will do us little good to arrive at tonight's camp too exhausted to move."

ɑn feɪlz ʌðɝ saɪd, æliændɝ ɹaʊz fɹəm əɹ nʌmnəs ɪnʌf tə ɹeɪz ən aɪbɹaʊ ət ðə dɪsaɪsɪvnəs ɪn meɪaɪɡdɪnz vɔɪs. feɪl mɪɹli lʊkt əɾ əɹ meɪd, bʌt ðət wɑz ɪnʌf tə sɛt meɪaɪɡdɪn blʌʃɪŋ ən stæmɝɪŋ. wʌt hæd ɡɑɾən ɪndə ðə wʊmən? stɪl, ɪt maɪt nɑt bi wʌt ʃi ɪkspɛktəd fɹəm ə sɝvɪŋ wʊmən, bʌt ʃi kəd nɑt fɔl meɪaɪɡdɪnz spɪɹəɾ ɪn ə kəmpænjən fəɹ ɪskeɪp. ə pɪɾi ðə wʊmən kəd nɑt tʃænəl mɔɹ. feɪl hæd hæd ɡɹeɪt hoʊps ə ðət wʌns, əntɪl ʃi lɝn ðət meɪaɪɡdɪn pəzɛst soʊ lɪɾəl əbɪləɾi ɪt wɑz jusləs.

On Faile's other side, Alliandre roused from her numbness enough to raise an eyebrow at the decisiveness in Maighdin's voice. Faile merely looked at her maid, but that was enough to set Maighdin blushing and stammering. What had gotten into the woman? Still, it might not be what she expected from a serving woman, but she could not fault Maighdin's spirit in a companion for escape. A pity the woman could not channel more. Faile had had great hopes of that once, until she learned that Maighdin possessed so little ability it was useless.

"tənaɪɾ ɪt mʌs bi, meɪaɪɡdɪn," ʃi əɡɹid. əɹ haʊɛvɝ mɛni naɪts ɪt tʊk. ʃi dɪd nɑt mɛnʃən ðæt. hɝidli ʃi sɝveɪd ðə pipəl nɪɹəst əm tə meɪk ʃʊɹ noʊ wʌn wɑz kloʊs ɪnʌf tə oʊvɝhɪɹ. ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ, wɛðɝ ɪn keɪɾɪnsɝ əɹ nɑt, muv θɹu ðə fɔlɪŋ snoʊ pɝpəsfəli, pɹɛsɪŋ fɔɹwɝd təwɔɹɾ ən ənsin ɡoʊl. ðə ɡeɪʃeɪn - ði ʌðɝ ɡeɪʃeɪn - muvd wɪð ə dɪfɹən pɝpəs. oʊbeɪ əɹ bi pʌnɪʃt. "ðə weɪ ðeɪ ɪɡnɔɹ ʌs," ʃi wɛn ɑn, "ɪt ʃəd bi pɑsəbəl tə dʒʌs fɔl baɪ ðə weɪsaɪd, soʊ lɔŋ əz jə doʊn tʃɹaɪ ʌndɝ ə ʃeɪɾoʊz noʊz. ɪf iðɝ ə jə faɪnz ə tʃæns, teɪk ɪt. ðiz ɹoʊbz wɪl hɛlp jə haɪɾ ɪn ðə snoʊ, ən wʌns jə faɪn ə vɪlədʒ, ðə ɡoʊl ðeɪv soʊ ɡɹeɪʃəsli ɡɪvən əs wɪl si jə bæk tə maɪ hʌzbənd. hɪl bi fɑloʊɪŋ." nɑt tu kwɪkli, ʃi hoʊpt. nɑt tu kloʊsli, ət list. ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ hæɾ ən ɑɹmi hɪɹ. ə smɔl ɑɹmi, pɝhæps, kəmpɛɹd tə sʌm, bʌt lɑɹdʒɝ ðən pɛɹɪnz.

"Tonight it must be, Maighdin," she agreed. Or however many nights it took. She did not mention that. Hurriedly she surveyed the people nearest them to make sure no one was close enough to overhear. The Shaido, whether in cadin'sor or not, moved through the falling snow purposefully, pressing forward toward an unseen goal. The gai'shain - the other gai'shain - moved with a different purpose. Obey or be punished. "The way they ignore us," she went on, "it should be possible to just fall by the wayside, so long as you don't try under a Shaido's nose. If either of you finds a chance, take it. These robes will help you hide in the snow, and once you find a village, the gold they've so graciously given us will see you back to my husband. He will be following." Not too quickly, she hoped. Not too closely, at least. The Shaido had an army here. A small army, perhaps, compared to some, but larger than Perrin's.

æliændɝz feɪs hɑɹɾənd ɪn dɪtɝməneɪʃən. "aɪ wɪl nɑt liv wɪθaʊt ju," ʃi sɛd sɔfli. sɔfli, jɛɾ ɪn fɝm toʊnz. "aɪ wɪl nɑt teɪk maɪ oʊθ ə fiəlti laɪtli, maɪ leɪɾi. əl ɪskeɪp wɪð ju, əɹ nɑɾ əɾ ɔl!"

Alliandre's face hardened in determination. "I will not leave without you," she said softly. Softly, yet in firm tones. "I will not take my oath of fealty lightly, my Lady. I will escape with you, or not at all!"

"ʃi spiks fəɹ boʊθ ʌv ʌs," meɪaɪɡdɪn sɛd. "aɪ meɪ bi oʊnli ə sɪmpəl meɪd," ʃi ɹʌŋ ðə wɝd wɪð skɔɹn, "bʌɾ aɪ woʊn liv ɛniwʌn bɪhaɪn tə ðiz . . . ðiz bændəts!" hɝ vɔɪs wɑz nɑt sɪmpli fɝm; ɪt bɹʊk noʊ ɑpəzɪʃən. ɹɪli, æftɝ ðɪs, lini wəɾ əv tə hæv ə vɛɹi lɔŋ tɔk wɪð əɹ bɪfɔɹ ʃi wɑz fɪt tə hoʊld əɹ pəzɪʃən!

"She speaks for both of us," Maighdin said. "I may be only a simple maid," she wrung the word with scorn, "but I won't leave anyone behind to these . . . these bandits!" Her voice was not simply firm; it brooked no opposition. Really, after this, Lini would have to have a very long talk with her before she was fit to hold her position!

feɪl oʊpən əɹ maʊθ tə ɑɹɡju - noʊ, tə kəmænd; æliændɝ wɑz əɹ swɔɹn wʊmən, ən meɪaɪɡdɪn əɹ meɪd, haʊɛvɝ faɪɝ-bɹeɪn kæptɪvəɾi hæd meɪd hɝ! ðeɪ wəd fɑloʊ hɝ ɔɹɾɝz! - bʌt ʃi lɛt ðə wɝdz daɪ ɑn əɹ tʌŋ.

Faile opened her mouth to argue - no, to command; Alliandre was her sworn woman, and Maighdin her maid, however fire-brained captivity had made her! They would follow her orders! - but she let the words die on her tongue.

dɑɹk ʃeɪps əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ θɹu ðə taɪɾ ə ʃeɪɾoʊ ən ðə fɔlɪŋ snoʊ ɹizɑlvd ɪndə ə klʌstɝ ʌv il-wɪmən wɪð ðɛɹ ʃɔlz fɹeɪmɪŋ ðɛɹ feɪsəz. θɛɝɑvə lɛd ðɛm. ə mɝmɝd wɝd fɹəm hɝ, ən ði ʌðɝz sloʊd tə kip peɪs bɪhaɪnd waɪl θɛɝɑvə dʒɔɪn feɪl ən əɹ kəmpænjənz. ðət wɑz tə seɪ, ʃi wɔkt əlɔŋsaɪd ðɛm. hɝ fɪɹs aɪz sim tə tʃɪl ivən meɪaɪɡdɪnz ɪnθuziæzəm, nɑt ðət ʃi ɡeɪv əm mɔɹ ðən ə ɡlæns. tə hɝ, ðeɪ wɝ nɑt wɝθ lʊkɪŋ æt.

Dark shapes approaching through the tide of Shaido and the falling snow resolved into a cluster of Aiel-women with their shawls framing their faces. Therava led them. A murmured word from her, and the others slowed to keep pace behind while Therava joined Faile and her companions. That was to say, she walked alongside them. Her fierce eyes seemed to chill even Maighdin's enthusiasm, not that she gave them more than a glance. To her, they were not worth looking at.

"ju ɑɹ θɪŋkɪŋ ʌv ɪskeɪp," ʃi bɪɡæn. noʊ wʌn ɛls oʊpən əɹ maʊθ, bʌt ðə waɪz wʌn æɾəd, "du nɑt tʃɹaɪ dɪnaɪɪŋ ɪt!" ɪn ə skɔɹnfəl vɔɪs.

"You are thinking of escape," she began. No one else opened her mouth, but the Wise One added, "Do not try denying it!" in a scornful voice.

"wi wɪl tʃɹaɪ tə sɝv əz wi ʃʊd, waɪz wʌn," feɪl sɛd kɛɹfəli. ʃi kɛpt əɹ hɛd daʊn ɪn əɹ kaʊl ən meɪd ʃʊɹ nɑt tə mit ðə tɔlɝ wʊmənz aɪz.

"We will try to serve as we should, Wise One," Faile said carefully. She kept her head down in her cowl and made sure not to meet the taller woman's eyes.

"ju noʊ sʌmθɪŋ ʌv əɹ weɪz." θɛɝɑvə saʊndəd sɝpɹaɪzd, bʌɾ ɪt vænɪʃt kwɪkli. "ɡʊd. bʌt jə teɪk mi fəɹ ə ful ɪf jə θɪŋk aɪ bɪliv jəl sɝv mikli. aɪ si spɪɹəɾ ɪn ðə θɹi ʌv ju, fəɹ wɛtləndɝz. səm nɛvɝ tʃɹaɪ tə ɪskeɪp, bʌɾ oʊnli ðə dɛd səksid. ðə lɪvɪŋ ɑɹ ɔlweɪz bɹɔt bæk. ɔlweɪz."

"You know something of our ways." Therava sounded surprised, but it vanished quickly. "Good. But you take me for a fool if you think I believe you will serve meekly. I see spirit in the three of you, for wetlanders. Some never try to escape, but only the dead succeed. The living are always brought back. Always."

"aɪ wɪl hid jəɹ wɝdz, waɪz wʌn," feɪl sɛd hʌmbli. ɔlweɪz? wɛl, ðəɹ hæd tə bi ə fɝs taɪm. "wi ɔl wɪl."

"I will heed your words, Wise One," Faile said humbly. Always? Well, there had to be a first time. "We all will."
