"oʊ, vɛɹi ɡʊd," θɛɝɑvə mɝmɝd. "ju maɪɾ ivən kənvɪns sʌmwʌn əz blaɪn əz sɪvænə. noʊ ðɪs, haʊɛvɝ, ɡeɪʃeɪn. wɛtləndɝz ɑɹ nɑɾ əz ʌðɝz u wɛɹ waɪt. ɹæðɝ ðən biɪŋ ɹilist ət ði ɛn ʌv ə jɪɹ ən ə deɪ, jəl sɝv əntɪl jə ɑɹ tu bɛn ən wɪðɝd tə wɝk. aɪm jəɹ oʊnli hoʊp ʌv əvɔɪɾɪŋ ðət feɪt."

"Oh, very good," Therava murmured. "You might even convince someone as blind as Sevanna. Know this, however, gai'shain. Wetlanders are not as others who wear white. Rather than being released at the end of a year and a day, you will serve until you are too bent and withered to work. I am your only hope of avoiding that fate."

feɪl stʌmbəld ɪn ðə snoʊ, ən ɪf æliændɝ ən meɪaɪɡdɪn hæd nɑt kɑɾ əɹ wɪndmɪlɪŋ ɑɹmz, ʃi wəɾ əv fɔlən. θɛɝɑvə dʒɛstʃɝɾ ɪmpeɪʃənli fəɹ əm tə kip muvɪŋ. feɪl fɛl sɪk. θɛɝɑvə wəd hɛlp əm ɪskeɪp? kiæɾ ən beɪn kleɪm ði il nu nʌθɪŋ ə ðə ɡeɪm ə haʊsəz ən skɔɹnd wɛtləndɝz fəɹ pleɪɪŋ ɪt, bʌt feɪl ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðə kɝəns swɝlɪŋ ɝaʊn əɹ naʊ. kɝəns ðət wəd pʊl ɔl ə ðɛm ʌndɝ ɪf ʃi mɪsstɛpt.

Faile stumbled in the snow, and if Alliandre and Maighdin had not caught her windmilling arms, she would have fallen. Therava gestured impatiently for them to keep moving. Faile felt sick. Therava would help them escape? Chiad and Bain claimed the Aiel knew nothing of the Game of Houses and scorned wetlanders for playing it, but Faile recognized the currents swirling around her now. Currents that would pull all of them under if she misstepped.

"aɪ də nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd, waɪz wʌn." ʃi wɪʃt əɹ vɔɪs dɪd nɑt saʊn soʊ hɔɹs, sʌɾənli.

"I do not understand, Wise One." She wished her voice did not sound so hoarse, suddenly.

pɝhæps ðət vɛɹi hɔɹsnəs kənvɪns θɛɝɑvə, ðoʊ. pipəl laɪk əɹ bɪlivd ɪn fɪɹ əz ə moʊɾəveɪʃən bɪfɔɹ ɛni ʌðɝ. əɾ ɛni ɹeɪt, ʃi smaɪld. ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ə wɔɹm smaɪl, dʒʌst ə kɝvɪŋ ə θɪn lɪps, ən ði oʊnli ɪmoʊʃən ɪt kənveɪd wɑz sæɾəsfækʃən. "ɔl θɹi ʌv jəl wɑtʃ ən lɪsən waɪl jə sɝv sɪvænə. itʃ deɪ ə waɪz wʌn wɪl kwɛstʃən ju, ən jəl ɹɪpiɾ ɛvɹi wɝd sɪvænə sɛd, ən u ʃi spoʊk tə. ɪf ʃi tɔks ɪn əɹ slip, jəl ɹɪpit wʌt ʃi mʌmbəlz. pliz mi, ən əl si ðət jə ɑɹ lɛf bɪhaɪnd."

Perhaps that very hoarseness convinced Therava, though. People like her believed in fear as a motivation before any other. At any rate, she smiled. It was not a warm smile, just a curving of thin lips, and the only emotion it conveyed was satisfaction. "All three of you will watch and listen while you serve Sevanna. Each day a Wise One will question you, and you will repeat every word Sevanna said, and who she spoke to. If she talks in her sleep, you will repeat what she mumbles. Please me, and I will see that you are left behind."

feɪl wɑntəd noʊ pɑɹɾ ə ðɪs, bʌt ɹəfjuzəl wɑz aʊɾ ə ðə kwɛstʃən. ɪf ʃi ɹəfjuzd, nʌn ə ðɛm wəd sɝvaɪv ðə naɪt. ʃi wɑz sɝɾən ə ðæt. θɛɝɑvə wəd teɪk noʊ tʃænsəz. ðeɪ maɪt nɑɾ ivən sɝvaɪv əntɪl naɪtfɔl; ðɪs snoʊ wəd haɪd θɹi waɪt-klæd kɔɹpsəz kwɪkli, ən ʃi vɛɹi mʌtʃ daʊɾɪd ðəɾ ɛniwʌn wɪðɪn saɪt wəd soʊ mʌtʃ əz pɹoʊɾɛst ɪf θɛɝɑvə dɪsaɪɾɪd tə slɪɾ ə fju θɹoʊts ðən ən ðɛɹ. ɛvɹiwʌn wɑz foʊkəst ɑn muvɪŋ fɔɹwɝd θɹu ðə snoʊ ɪn ɛni keɪs. ðeɪ maɪt nɑɾ ivən si.

Faile wanted no part of this, but refusal was out of the question. If she refused, none of them would survive the night. She was certain of that. Therava would take no chances. They might not even survive until nightfall; this snow would hide three white-clad corpses quickly, and she very much doubted that anyone within sight would so much as protest if Therava decided to slit a few throats then and there. Everyone was focused on moving forward through the snow in any case. They might not even see.

"ɪf ʃi lɝnz ʌv ɪt. . . ." feɪl swɑloʊd. ðə wʊmən wɑz æskɪŋ əm tə wɔk aʊɾ ɑn ə kɹʌmbəlɪŋ klɪf. noʊ, ʃi wɑz ɔɹɾɝɪŋ əm tə. dɪd ði il kɪl spaɪz? ʃi hæd nɛvɝ θɔt tə æsk kiæɾ əɹ beɪn ðæt. "wɪl jə pɹətɛkt ʌs, waɪz wʌn?"

"If she learns of it. . . ." Faile swallowed. The woman was asking them to walk out on a crumbling cliff. No, she was ordering them to. Did the Aiel kill spies? She had never thought to ask Chiad or Bain that. "Will you protect us, Wise One?"

ðə hɑɹd-feɪst wʊmən kɑt feɪlz tʃɪn wɪð stili fɪŋɡɝz, pʊlɪŋ əɹ tə ə hɔlt, pʊlɪŋ əɹ ʌp ɑn əɹ toʊz. θɛɝɑvəz aɪz kɑt hɝz dʒʌst əz taɪtli. feɪlz maʊθ wɛn dʒɹaɪ. ðət stɛɹ pɹɑməs peɪn. "ɪf ʃi lɝnz ʌv ɪt, ɡeɪʃeɪn, əl tʃɹaɪs jə ʌp fəɹ kʊkɪŋ maɪsɛlf. soʊ meɪk ʃʊɹ ʃi dʌz nɑt. tənaɪt jəl sɝv ɪn əɹ tɛns. jə ən ə hʌnʒɹəd ʌðɝz, soʊ jəl nɑɾ əv mɛni leɪbɝz tə dɪstʃɹæk jə fɹəm wʌɾ ɪz ɪmpɔɹɾənt."

The hard-faced woman caught Faile's chin with steely fingers, pulling her to a halt, pulling her up on her toes. Therava's eyes caught hers just as tightly. Faile's mouth went dry. That stare promised pain. "If she learns of it, gai'shain, I will trice you up for cooking myself. So make sure she does not. Tonight you will serve in her tents. You and a hundred others, so you will not have many labors to distract you from what is important."

ə moʊməns kɛɹfəl stʌɾi ʌv ðə θɹi ʌv ðɛm, ən θɛɝɑvə ɡeɪv ə sæɾəsfaɪd nɑd. ʃi sɔ θɹi sɑft wɛtləndɝz, tu wik tə də ɛniθɪŋ bʌɾ oʊbeɪ. wɪθaʊɾ ənʌðɝ wɝd ʃi ɹilis feɪl ən tɝn əweɪ, ən ɪn moʊməns ʃi ən ði ʌðɝ waɪz wʌnz wɝ swɑloʊd baɪ ðə snoʊ.

A moment's careful study of the three of them, and Therava gave a satisfied nod. She saw three soft wetlanders, too weak to do anything but obey. Without another word she released Faile and turned away, and in moments she and the other Wise Ones were swallowed by the snow.

fəɹ ə taɪm, ðə θɹi wɪmən stʃɹʌɡəld ɑn ɪn saɪləns. feɪl dɪd nɑt bɹɪŋ ʌp ɛniwʌn ɪskeɪpɪŋ əloʊn, mʌtʃ lɛs ɡɪv ɔɹɾɝz. ʃi wɑz sɝɾən ðəɾ ɪf ʃi dɪd, ði ʌðɝz wəd bɔk əɡɛn. əsaɪd fɹəm ɛniθɪŋ ɛls, kəmplaɪɪŋ naʊ wəd meɪk ɪt sim θɛɝɑvə hæd tʃeɪnʒd ðɛɹ maɪnz, ðət fɪɹ ə hɝ hæd. feɪl nu ɪnʌf ə ði ʌðɝ tu wɪmən tə bi ʃʊɹ ðeɪ wəd daɪ bɪfɔɹ ædmɪɾɪŋ ðət ðə wʊmən fɹaɪɾənd ðɛm. θɛɝɑvə sɝɾənli fɹaɪɾənd hɝ. ən aɪd swɑloʊ maɪ tʌŋ bɪfɔɹ ædmɪɾɪŋ ɪɾ əlaʊd, ʃi θɔt ɹaɪli.

For a time, the three women struggled on in silence. Faile did not bring up anyone escaping alone, much less give orders. She was certain that if she did, the others would balk again. Aside from anything else, complying now would make it seem Therava had changed their minds, that fear of her had. Faile knew enough of the other two women to be sure they would die before admitting that the woman frightened them. Therava certainly frightened her. And I'd swallow my tongue before admitting it aloud, she thought wryly.

"aɪ wʌndɝ wʌt ʃi mɛn baɪ . . . kʊkɪŋ," æliændɝ sɛd faɪnəli. "waɪtkloʊk kwɛstʃənɝz səmtaɪmz tɝn pɹɪznɝz oʊvɝ ə faɪɝ ɑn ə spɪt, aɪv hɝd." meɪaɪɡdɪn ɹæpt əɹ ɑɹmz ɝaʊn hɝsɛlf, ʃʌɾɝɪŋ, ən æliændɝ fɹiɾ ə hæn fɹəm əɹ slivz lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə pæt ði ʌðɝ wʊmənz ʃoʊldɝ. "du nɑt wɝi. ɪf sɪvænə hæz ə hʌnʒɹəd sɝvəns, wi meɪ nɛvɝ ɡɛt kloʊs ɪnʌf tə hɪɹ ɛniθɪŋ. ən wi kən tʃuz wʌt wi ɹipɔɹt, soʊ ɪt kænɑt bi tʃɹeɪs bæk tə ʌs."

"I wonder what she meant by . . . cooking," Alliandre said finally. "Whitecloak Questioners sometimes turn prisoners over a fire on a spit, I've heard." Maighdin wrapped her arms around herself, shuddering, and Alliandre freed a hand from her sleeves long enough to pat the other woman's shoulder. "Do not worry. If Sevanna has a hundred servants, we may never get close enough to hear anything. And we can choose what we report, so it cannot be traced back to us."

meɪaɪɡdɪn læf bɪɾɝli ɪnsaɪɾ əɹ waɪt hʊd. "ju θɪŋk wi stɪl əv smɔl tʃɔɪsəz. wɪv nʌn. jə nid tə lɝn əbaʊt hævɪŋ noʊ tʃɔɪsəz. ðət wʊmən dɪdn pɪk əs aʊt kəz wɪv spɪɹət." ʃi ɔlmoʊst spæt ðə wɝd. "aɪl weɪdʒɝ ɛvɹi wʌn ə sɪvænəz ʌðɝ sɝvəns əz hæd ðət lɛktʃɝ fɹəm θɛɝɑvə, tu. ɪf wi mɪs ə wɝd wi ʃəɾ əv hɝd, jə kən bi ʃʊɹ ʃɪl noʊ ʌv ɪt."

Maighdin laughed bitterly inside her white hood. "You think we still have small choices. We have none. You need to learn about having no choices. That woman didn't pick us out because we have spirit." She almost spat the word. "I'll wager every one of Sevanna's other servants has had that lecture from Therava, too. If we miss a word we should have heard, you can be sure she'll know of it."

"ju meɪ bi ɹaɪt," æliændɝ əlaʊɾ æftɝ ə moʊmənt. "bʌt jəl nɑt spik tə mi əɡɛn ɪn ðət fæʃən, meɪaɪɡdɪn. əɹ sɝkəmstænsəz ɑɹ tʃɹaɪɪŋ, tə seɪ ðə list, bʌt jəl ɹɪmɛmbɝ u aɪ æm."

"You may be right," Alliandre allowed after a moment. "But you will not speak to me again in that fashion, Maighdin. Our circumstances are trying, to say the least, but you will remember who I am."

"əntɪl wi ɪskeɪp," meɪaɪɡdɪn ɹɪplaɪd, "ju ɑɹ sɪvænəz sɝvənt. ɪf jə doʊn θɪŋk ə jɝsɛlf əz ə sɝvən ɛvɹi mɪnət, ðən jə maɪɾ əz wɛl klaɪm ɑntu ðət spɪt. ən liv ɹum fəɹ ðə ɹɛst ʌv ʌs, kəz jəl pʊɾ əs ɑn ɪt, əz wɛl."

"Until we escape," Maighdin replied, "you are Sevanna's servant. If you don't think of yourself as a servant every minute, then you might as well climb onto that spit. And leave room for the rest of us, because you will put us on it, as well."

æliændɝz kaʊl hɪɾ əɹ feɪs, bʌɾ əɹ bæk ɡɹu stɪfɝ wɪð ɛvɹi wɝd. ʃi wɑz ɪntɛlədʒənt, ən nu haʊ tə də wʌt ʃi mʌst, bʌt ʃi hæɾ ə kwinz tɛmpɝ wən ʃi dɪd nɑt kəntʃɹoʊl ɪt.

Alliandre's cowl hid her face, but her back grew stiffer with every word. She was intelligent, and knew how to do what she must, but she had a queen's temper when she did not control it.

feɪl spoʊk bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəɾ ɪɹʌpt. "əntɪl wi mænədʒ tə ɡɛɾ əweɪ, wəɹ ɔl sɝvəns," ʃi sɛd fɝmli. laɪt, ðə læs θɪŋ ʃi niɾəd wɑz ðə pɛɹ ə ðɛm skwɑbəlɪŋ. "bʌt jəl əpɑlədʒaɪz, meɪaɪɡdɪn. naʊ!" hɛɾ əvɝɾəd, hɝ sɝvɪŋ wʊmən mʌmbəl sʌmθɪŋ ðət maɪɾ əv bɪn ən əpɑlədʒi. ʃi lɛɾ ɪt pæs fəɹ wʌn, ɪn ɛni keɪs. "æz fəɹ ju, æliændɝ, aɪ ɪkspɛk jə tə bi ə ɡʊd sɝvənt." æliændɝ meɪɾ ə nɔɪz, ə hæf-pɹoʊɾɛst, ðət feɪl ɪɡnɔɹd. "ɪf wəɹ tə hæv ɛni tʃæns ʌv ɪskeɪp, wi mʌs də əz wəɹ toʊld, wɝk hɑɹd, ən ətʃɹækt əz lɪɾəl ətɛnʃən əz pɑsəbəl." əz ɪf ðeɪ hæd nɑɾ ɔlɹɛɾi ətʃɹæktəd wʌt simd ɔl ði ətɛnʃən ɪn ðə wɝld. "ænd wɪl tɛl θɛɝɑvə ɛvɹi taɪm sɪvænə snizɪz. aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌt sɪvænə wɪl də ɪf ʃi faɪnz aʊt, bʌɾ aɪ θɪŋk wi ɔl əv ə ɡʊɾ aɪdiə ʌv wʌt θɛɝɑvə wɪl də ɪf wi dɪspliz hɝ."

Faile spoke before she could erupt. "Until we manage to get away, we are all servants," she said firmly. Light, the last thing she needed was the pair of them squabbling. "But you will apologize, Maighdin. Now!" Head averted, her serving woman mumbled something that might have been an apology. She let it pass for one, in any case. "As for you, Alliandre, I expect you to be a good servant." Alliandre made a noise, a half-protest, that Faile ignored. "If we are to have any chance of escape, we must do as we are told, work hard, and attract as little attention as possible." As if they had not already attracted what seemed all the attention in the world. "And we will tell Therava every time Sevanna sneezes. I don't know what Sevanna will do if she finds out, but I think we all have a good idea of what Therava will do if we displease her."

ðət wɑz ɪnʌf tə sɛɾəl əm ɔl bæk ɪndə mjutnəs. ðeɪ dɪɾ ɔl əv ə ɡʊɾ aɪdiə ʌv wʌt θɛɝɑvə wəd du, ən kɪlɪŋ maɪt nɑt bi ðə wɝst ʌv ɪt.

That was enough to settle them all back into muteness. They did all have a good idea of what Therava would do, and killing might not be the worst of it.

ðə snoʊ feɪɾəd əweɪ tə ə fju skæɾɝd fleɪks baɪ mɪddeɪ. dɑɹk ɹɔɪlɪŋ klaʊdz stɪl hɪd ðə sʌn, bʌt feɪl dɪsaɪɾɪd ɪt mʌs bi nɪɹ ɪnʌf mɪddeɪ, kəz ðeɪ wɝ fɛd. noʊ wʌn stɑp muvɪŋ, bʌt hʌnʒɹədz ʌv ɡeɪʃeɪn meɪd ðɛɹ weɪ θɹu ðə kɑləm wɪð bæskəts ən skɹəps fʊl ə bɹɛɾ ən dʒɹaɪd bif, ən wɔɾɝ bæɡz ðət kənteɪnd wɔɾɝ ðɪs taɪm, koʊld ɪnʌf tə meɪk əɹ tiθ eɪk. stʃɹeɪnʒli, ʃi fɛl noʊ mɔɹ hʌŋɡɹi ðən aʊɝz ʌv wɔkɪŋ θɹu snoʊ wəɾ əkaʊn fɔɹ. pɛɹɪn hæd bɪn hild wʌns, ʃi nu, ən i hæd bɪn ɹævənəs fəɹ tu deɪz. pɝhæps ɪt wɑz kəz əɹ ɪnʒɝiz hæd bɪn soʊ mʌtʃ lɛs ðən hɪz. ʃi noʊɾəst ðəɾ æliændɝ ən meɪaɪɡdɪn eɪt noʊ mɔɹ ðən ʃi.

The snow faded away to a few scattered flakes by midday. Dark roiling clouds still hid the sun, but Faile decided it must be near enough midday, because they were fed. No one stopped moving, but hundreds of gai'shain made their way through the column with baskets and scrips full of bread and dried beef, and water bags that contained water this time, cold enough to make her teeth ache. Strangely, she felt no more hungry than hours of walking through snow would account for. Perrin had been Healed once, she knew, and he had been ravenous for two days. Perhaps it was because her injuries had been so much less than his. She noticed that Alliandre and Maighdin ate no more than she.

hilɪŋ meɪɾ əɹ θɪŋk ʌv ɡəlinə, ɔl ðə seɪm kwɛstʃənz ðət bɔɪl daʊn tə ən ɪnkɹɛdʒələs waɪ? waɪ wəɾ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ - ʃi mʌs bi ɛɛs sədaɪ - waɪ wəd ʃi toʊɾi fəɹ sɪvænə ən θɛɝɑvə? fəɹ ɛniwʌn? ən ɛɛs sədaɪ maɪt hɛlp əm ɪskeɪp. əɹ ʃi maɪt nɑt. ʃi maɪt bɪtʃɹeɪ ðɛm, ɪf ɪt suɾəd əɹ pɝpəsəz. ɛɛs sədaɪ dɪd wʌt ðeɪ dɪd, ən jə hæd noʊ ɔltɝnəɾɪv bʌt tə æksɛp ðəɾ ənlɛs jə wɝ ɹænd ælθɹ. bʌɾ i wɑz tɑvɝən, ən ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn ɑn tɑp ʌv ɪt; ʃi wɑz ə wʊmən wɪð vɛɹi fju ɹisɔɹsɪz ət ðə moʊmənt, ən ə kənsɪɾɝəbəl deɪnʒɝ hæŋɪŋ oʊvɝ əɹ hɛd. nɑt tə mɛnʃən ðə hɛdz ə ðoʊz ʃi wɑz ɹispɑnsəbəl fɔɹ. ɛni hɛlp wəd bi wɛlkəm, fɹəm ɛniwʌn. ðə bɹɪsk bɹiz feɪld waɪl ʃi pɹɑɾɪd ət ɡəlinə fɹəm ɛvɹi æŋɡəl ʃi kəd θɪŋk ʌv, ən ðə snoʊ keɪm əɡɛn, ɡɹoʊɪŋ hɛviɝ, əntɪl ʃi kəd nɑt si tɛn peɪsɪz. ʃi kəd nɑt dɪsaɪd wɛðɝ tə tʃɹʌs ðə wʊmən.

Healing made her think of Galina, all the same questions that boiled down to an incredulous why? Why would an Aes Sedai - she must be Aes Sedai - why would she toady for Sevanna and Therava? For anyone? An Aes Sedai might help them escape. Or she might not. She might betray them, if it suited her purposes. Aes Sedai did what they did, and you had no alternative but to accept that unless you were Rand al'Thor. But he was ta'veren, and the Dragon Reborn on top of it; she was a woman with very few resources at the moment, and a considerable danger hanging over her head. Not to mention the heads of those she was responsible for. Any help would be welcome, from anyone. The brisk breeze failed while she prodded at Galina from every angle she could think of, and the snow came again, growing heavier, until she could not see ten paces. She could not decide whether to trust the woman.

əbɹʌpli ʃi bɪkeɪm əwɛɹ ʌv ənʌðɝ waɪt-ɹoʊbd wʊmən wɑtʃɪŋ hɝ, ɔlmoʊs hɪɾən baɪ ðə snoʊ. nɑɾ ɪnʌf snoʊ tə mæsk ðət waɪd, dʒuəl bɛlt, ðoʊ. feɪl tʌtʃt əɹ kəmpænjənz ɑn ði ɑɹm ən nɑɾəd təwɔɹd ɡəlinə.

Abruptly she became aware of another white-robed woman watching her, almost hidden by the snow. Not enough snow to mask that wide, jeweled belt, though. Faile touched her companions on the arm and nodded toward Galina.

wən ɡəlinə sɔ ʃi hæd bɪn sin, ʃi keɪm tə tʃɹʌdʒ əlɔŋ bɪtwin feɪl ən æliændɝ. ʃi stɪl dɪd nɑt muv wɪð ɛni ɡɹeɪs ɪn ðə snoʊ, bʌt ʃi simd mɔɹ juz tə wɔkɪŋ ɪn ɪt ðən ðeɪ. ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ ə fɔnɪŋ əbaʊt hɝ, naʊ. hɝ ɹaʊn feɪs wɑz hɑɹd wɪðɪn əɹ hʊd, hɝ aɪz ʃɑɹp. bʌt ʃi dɪd kip tɝnɪŋ əɹ hɛd, dɑɹɾɪŋ wɛɹi ɡlænsɪz tə si hu ɛls wɑz nɪɹbaɪ. ʃi lʊk laɪk ə haʊsəkæt pɹitɛndɪŋ tə bi ə lɛpɝd. "ju noʊ hu aɪ æm?" ʃi dɪmændəd, bʌɾ ɪn ə vɔɪs ðət wʊɾə bɪn ɪnɔɾəbəl tɛn fiɾ ɔf. "wʌɾ aɪ æm?"

When Galina saw she had been seen, she came to trudge along between Faile and Alliandre. She still did not move with any grace in the snow, but she seemed more used to walking in it than they. There was nothing of fawning about her, now. Her round face was hard within her hood, her eyes sharp. But she did keep turning her head, darting wary glances to see who else was nearby. She looked like a housecat pretending to be a leopard. "You know who I am?" she demanded, but in a voice that would have been inaudible ten feet off. "What I am?"

"ju sim tə bi ɛɛs sədaɪ," feɪl sɛd kɛɹfəli. "ɑn ði ʌðɝ hænd, juv ə vɛɹi pəkjuljɝ pleɪs hɪɹ fəɹ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ." niðɝ æliændɝ nɔɹ meɪaɪɡdɪn ɡeɪv ðə slaɪɾəst stɑɹɾ ə sɝpɹaɪz. pleɪnli ðeɪ hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi sin ðə ɡɹeɪt sɝpən ɹɪŋ ðət ɡəlinə wɑz θʌmɪŋ nɝvəsli.

"You seem to be Aes Sedai," Faile said carefully. "On the other hand, you have a very peculiar place here for an Aes Sedai." Neither Alliandre nor Maighdin gave the slightest start of surprise. Plainly they had already seen the Great Serpent ring that Galina was thumbing nervously.

kʌlɝ blumd ɪn ɡəlinəz tʃiks, ən ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə meɪk ɪɾ aʊɾ əz æŋɡɝ. "wʌɾ aɪ də hɪɹ ɪz ʌv ɡɹeɪɾ ɪmpɔɹɾəns tə ðə taʊɝ, tʃaɪld," ʃi sɛd koʊldli. hɝ ɪkspɹɛʃən sɛd ʃi hæd ɹizənz ðeɪ kəd nɑt bɪɡɪn tə kɑmpɹihɛnd. hɝ aɪz dɑɹɾɪd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pɪɹs ðə fɔlɪŋ snoʊ. "aɪ mʌs nɑt feɪl. ðəɾ ɪz ɔl jə nid tə noʊ."

Color bloomed in Galina's cheeks, and she tried to make it out as anger. "What I do here is of great importance to the Tower, child," she said coldly. Her expression said she had reasons they could not begin to comprehend. Her eyes darted, trying to pierce the falling snow. "I must not fail. That is all you need to know."

"wi nid tə noʊ wɛðɝ wi kən tʃɹʌs ju," æliændɝ sɛd kɑmli. "ju mʌst əv tʃɹeɪn ɪn ðə taʊɝ əɹ jə wəd nɑt noʊ hilɪŋ, bʌt wɪmən ɝn ðə ɹɪŋ wɪθaʊɾ ɝnɪŋ ðə ʃɔl, ən aɪ kænɑt bɪliv jə ɑɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ." ɪt sim feɪl hæd nɑt bɪn ði oʊnli wʌn pʌzəlɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə wʊmən.

"We need to know whether we can trust you," Alliandre said calmly. "You must have trained in the Tower or you would not know Healing, but women earn the ring without earning the shawl, and I cannot believe you are Aes Sedai." It seemed Faile had not been the only one puzzling over the woman.

ɡəlinəz plʌmp maʊθ hɑɹɾənd, ən ʃi klɛntʃt ə fɪst əɾ æliændɝ, tə θɹɛɾən əɹ ʃoʊ hɝ ɹɪŋ, əɹ boʊθ. "ju θɪŋk ðəl tʃɹit jə dɪfɹənli kəz jə wɛɹ ə kɹaʊn? kəz jə juz tə wɛɹ wʌn?" ðəɹ wɑz noʊ daʊɾ ə hɝ æŋɡɝ, naʊ. ʃi fɝɡɑt tə kip lʊkaʊt fəɹ lɪsənɝz, ən əɹ vɔɪs wɑz æsəd. spɪɾəl flu wɪð ðə fɔɹs ə hɝ taɪɹeɪd. "ju wɪl bɹɪŋ sɪvænə waɪn ən wɑʃ əɹ bæk dʒʌs laɪk ðə ɹɛst. hɝ sɝvəns ɑɹ ɔl noʊbəlz, əɹ ɹɪtʃ mɝtʃəns, əɹ mɛn ən wɪmən u noʊ haʊ tə sɝv noʊbəlz. ɛvɹi deɪ ʃiz faɪv ə ðɛm stʃɹæpt, tə ɛnkɝɪdʒ ðə ɹɛst, soʊ ðeɪ ɔl kæɹi teɪlz tə hɝ hoʊpɪŋ tə kʌɹi feɪvɝ. ðə fɝs taɪm jə tʃɹaɪ tə ɪskeɪp, ðəl swɪtʃ ðə soʊlz ə jəɹ fiɾ əntɪl jə kænɑt wɔk, ən taɪ jə twɪstəɾ ʌp laɪk ə blæksmɪθs pʌzəl tə kæɹi ɑn ə kɑɹɾ əntɪl jə kæn. ðə sɛkən taɪm wɪl bi wɝs, ən ðə θɝd wɝs əɡɛn. ðəɹ ɪz ə fɛloʊ hɪɹ u juz tə bi ə waɪtkloʊk. hi tʃɹaɪd tə ɪskeɪp naɪn taɪmz. ə hɑɹd mæn, bʌt ðə læs taɪm ðeɪ bɹɔɾ ɪm bæk, hi wɑz bɛɡɪŋ ən kɹaɪɪŋ bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ ivən bɪɡæn stʃɹɪpɪŋ ɪm fəɹ pʌnɪʃmənt."

Galina's plump mouth hardened, and she clenched a fist at Alliandre, to threaten or show her ring, or both. "You think they will treat you differently because you wear a crown? Because you used to wear one?" There was no doubt of her anger, now. She forgot to keep lookout for listeners, and her voice was acid. Spittle flew with the force of her tirade. "You will bring Sevanna wine and wash her back just like the rest. Her servants are all nobles, or rich merchants, or men and women who know how to serve nobles. Every day she has five of them strapped, to encourage the rest, so they all carry tales to her hoping to curry favor. The first time you try to escape, they will switch the soles of your feet until you cannot walk, and tie you twisted up like a blacksmith's puzzle to carry on a cart until you can. The second time will be worse, and the third worse again. There is a fellow here who used to be a Whitecloak. He tried to escape nine times. A hard man, but the last time they brought him back, he was begging and crying before they even began stripping him for punishment."

æliændɝ dɪd nɑt teɪk ðə hɝæŋ wɛl. ʃi pʌft ʌp ɪndɪɡnənli, ən meɪaɪɡdɪn ɡɹaʊld, "wɑz ðət wʌt hæpən tə ju? wɛðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ əɹ æksɛptɪd, jə ɑɹ ə dɪsɡɹeɪs tə ðə taʊɝ!"

Alliandre did not take the harangue well. She puffed up indignantly, and Maighdin growled, "Was that what happened to you? Whether Aes Sedai or Accepted, you are a disgrace to the Tower!"

"bi saɪlənt wən jəɹ bɛɾɝz spik, waɪldɝ!" ɡəlinə snæpt.

"Be silent when your betters speak, wilder!" Galina snapped.

laɪt, ɪf ðɪs wɛn ɛni fɝðɝ, ðeɪ wəd bi skɹimɪŋ ət wʌn ənʌðɝ nɛkst. "ɪf jə min tə hɛlp əs ɪskeɪp, ðən seɪ soʊ," feɪl toʊl ðə sɪlk-klæɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ. ʃi dɪd nɑt ɹɪli daʊt ðəɾ əbaʊt ðə wʊmən. dʒʌst ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɛls. "ɪf nɑt, wʌt dʒju wɑnt wɪð ʌs?"

Light, if this went any further, they would be screaming at one another next. "If you mean to help us escape, then say so," Faile told the silk-clad Aes Sedai. She did not really doubt that about the woman. Just everything else. "If not, what do you want with us?"

əhɛɾ ə ðɛm ə wæɡən lumd aʊɾ ə ðə snoʊ, linɪŋ wɛɹ wʌn ə ðə slɛdz hæd kʌm lus. dɝɛktəd baɪ ə ʃeɪɾoʊ wɪð ði ɑɹmz ən ʃoʊldɝz ʌv ə blæksmɪθ, ɡeɪʃeɪn wɝ ɹɪɡɪŋ ə lɛvɝ tə hɔɪs ðə wæɡən ɪnʌf fəɹ ðə slɛd tə bi læʃt bæk ɪn pleɪs. feɪl ən ði ʌðɝz kɛp saɪlən əz ðeɪ pæst.

Ahead of them a wagon loomed out of the snow, leaning where one of the sleds had come loose. Directed by a Shaido with the arms and shoulders of a blacksmith, gai'shain were rigging a lever to hoist the wagon enough for the sled to be lashed back in place. Faile and the others kept silent as they passed.

"ɪz ðɪs ɹɪli jəɹ lidʒ leɪɾi, æliændɝ?" ɡəlinə dɪmændəd wʌns ðeɪ wɝ aʊɾ ʌv ɪɹʃɑɾ ə ðə mɛn ɝaʊn ðə wæɡən. hɝ feɪs wɑz stɪl flʌʃt wɪð æŋɡɝ, hɝ toʊn slaɪsɪŋ. "hu ɪz ʃi ðət jə wəd swɛɹ tə hɝ?"

"Is this really your liege lady, Alliandre?" Galina demanded once they were out of earshot of the men around the wagon. Her face was still flushed with anger, her tone slicing. "Who is she that you would swear to her?"

"ju kən æsk mi," feɪl sɛd koʊldli. bɝn ɛɛs sədaɪ ən ðɛɹ blʌɾi sikɹəsi! səmtaɪmz ʃi θɔɾ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ wəd nɑt tɛl jə ðə skaɪ wɑz blu ənlɛs ʃi sɔ ædvæntɪdʒ ɪn ɪt. "aɪ æm ðə leɪɾi feɪl teɪbɑɹə, ən ðæts əz mʌtʃ əz jə nid tə noʊ. dʒju min tə hɛlp ʌs?"

"You can ask me," Faile said coldly. Burn Aes Sedai and their bloody secrecy! Sometimes she thought an Aes Sedai would not tell you the sky was blue unless she saw advantage in it. "I am the Lady Faile t'Aybara, and that's as much as you need to know. Do you mean to help us?"

ɡəlinə stʌmbəl tə wʌn ni, piɹɪŋ ət feɪl soʊ hɑɹd ðət ʃi bɪɡæn tə wʌndɝ wɛðɝ ʃi hæd meɪɾ ə mɪsteɪk. ə moʊmən leɪɾɝ, ʃi nu ʃi hæd.

Galina stumbled to one knee, peering at Faile so hard that she began to wonder whether she had made a mistake. A moment later, she knew she had.

ɹɪɡeɪnɪŋ əɹ fit, ði ɛɛs sədaɪ smaɪld ənplɛzənli. ʃi noʊ lɔŋɡɝ simd æŋɡɹi. ɪn fækt, ʃi lʊkt əz plizd əz θɛɝɑvə hæd, ən wɝs, ɪn mʌtʃ ðə seɪm weɪ. "teɪbɑɹə," ʃi mjuzd. "ju ɑɹ sɑldəiən. ðəɹ ɪz ə jʌŋ mæn, pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə. jəɹ hʌzbənd? jɛs, aɪ si aɪv hɪt ðə tɑɹɡət. ðət wəɾ ɪkspleɪn æliændɝz oʊθ, sɝɾənli. sɪvænə hæz ɡɹændioʊs plænz fəɹ ə mæn huz neɪm ɪz lɪŋk tə jəɹ hʌzbənd. ɹænd ælθɹ. ɪf ʃi nu ʃi hæd jə ɪn əɹ hænz . . . oʊ, nɛvɝ fɪɹ ʃɪl lɝn fɹəm mi." hɝ ɡeɪz hɑɹɾənd, ən sʌɾənli ʃi simd ə lɛpɝɾ ɪn tʃɹuθ. ə stɑɹvɪŋ lɛpɝd. "nɑɾ ɪf jə ɔl də əz aɪ tɛl ju. əl ivən hɛlp jə ɡɛɾ əweɪ."

Regaining her feet, the Aes Sedai smiled unpleasantly. She no longer seemed angry. In fact, she looked as pleased as Therava had, and worse, in much the same way. "t'Aybara," she mused. "You are Saldaean. There is a young man, Perrin Aybara. Your husband? Yes, I see I've hit the target. That would explain Alliandre's oath, certainly. Sevanna has grandiose plans for a man whose name is linked to your husband. Rand al'Thor. If she knew she had you in her hands . . . Oh, never fear she will learn from me." Her gaze hardened, and suddenly she seemed a leopard in truth. A starving leopard. "Not if you all do as I tell you. I will even help you get away."

"wʌt dʒju wɑn ʌv ʌs?" feɪl sɛd, mɔɹ ɪnsɪstənli ðən ʃi fɛlt. laɪt, ʃi hæd bɪn æŋɡɹi əɾ æliændɝ fəɹ dʒɹɔɪŋ ətɛnʃən tə ðɛm baɪ neɪmɪŋ hɝsɛlf, ən naʊ ʃi hæd dʌn ðə seɪm. əɹ wɝs. ən aɪ θɔɾ aɪ wɑz kənsilɪŋ maɪsɛlf baɪ haɪɾɪŋ maɪ fɑðɝz neɪm, ʃi θɔt bɪɾɝli.

"What do you want of us?" Faile said, more insistently than she felt. Light, she had been angry at Alliandre for drawing attention to them by naming herself, and now she had done the same. Or worse. And I thought I was concealing myself by hiding my father's name, she thought bitterly.

"nʌθɪŋ tu tʃɹaɪɪŋ," ɡəlinə ɹɪplaɪd. "ju mɑɹk θɛɝɑvə, ʌv kɔɹs? ʌv kɔɹs, jə dɪd. ɛvɹiwʌn noʊɾəsəz θɛɝɑvə. ʃi kips sʌmθɪŋ ɪn əɹ tɛnt, ə smuð waɪt ɹɑɾ əbaʊɾ ə fʊt lɔŋ. ɪts ɪn ə ɹɛd tʃɛst wɪð bɹæs bændɪŋ ðəɾ ɪz nɛvɝ lɑkt. bɹɪŋ ɪt tə mi, ən əl teɪk jə wɪð mi wən aɪ ɡoʊ."

"Nothing too trying," Galina replied. "You marked Therava, of course? Of course, you did. Everyone notices Therava. She keeps something in her tent, a smooth white rod about a foot long. It is in a red chest with brass banding that is never locked. Bring it to me, and I will take you with me when I go."

"ə smɔl θɪŋ tə du, ɪt simz," æliændɝ sɛd daʊtfəli. "bʌɾ ɪf soʊ, waɪ dʒju nɑt teɪk ɪt jɝsɛlf?"

"A small thing to do, it seems," Alliandre said doubtfully. "But if so, why do you not take it yourself?"

"bɪkɔz aɪ hæv jə tə fɛtʃ ɪt fəɹ mi!" ɹilaɪzɪŋ ʃi hæd ʃaʊɾəd, ɡəlinə hʌɾəld ɪn ɑn hɝsɛlf, ən əɹ kaʊl swʌŋ əz ʃi sɝtʃt fəɹ ivzdʒɹɑpɝz əmʌŋ ðə snoʊ-veɪl θɹɔŋ. noʊ wʌn sim tə bi soʊ mʌtʃ əz ɡlænsɪŋ ðɛɹ weɪ, bʌɾ əɹ vɔɪs dʒɹɑp tə ə fɛɹəl hɪs. "ɪf jə də nɑt, əl liv jə hɪɹ əntɪl jə ɑɹ ɡɹeɪ ən ɹɪŋkəld. ən sɪvænə wɪl hɪɹ ə pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə."

"Because I have you to fetch it for me!" Realizing she had shouted, Galina huddled in on herself, and her cowl swung as she searched for eavesdroppers among the snow-veiled throng. No one seemed to be so much as glancing their way, but her voice dropped to a feral hiss. "If you do not, I will leave you here until you are gray and wrinkled. And Sevanna will hear of Perrin Aybara."

"ɪt meɪ teɪk taɪm," feɪl sɛd dɛspɝətli. "wi woʊn bi fɹi tə dʒʌst snik ɪndə θɛɝɑvəz tɛnt wɛnɛvɝ wi wɑnt." laɪt, ðə læs θɪŋ ɪn ðə wɝld ʃi wɑntəd wɑz tə ɡoʊ ɛniwɛɹ nɪɹ θɛɝɑvəz tɛnt. bʌt ɡəlinə hæd sɛd ʃi wəd hɛlp ðɛm. vaɪl ʃi maɪt bi, bʌɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ kəd nɑt laɪ.

"It may take time," Faile said desperately. "We won't be free to just sneak into Therava's tent whenever we want." Light, the last thing in the world she wanted was to go anywhere near Therava's tent. But Galina had said she would help them. Vile she might be, but Aes Sedai could not lie.

"ju hæv ɔl ðə taɪm jə nid," ɡəlinə ɹɪplaɪd. "ðə ɹɛst ə jəɹ laɪf, leɪɾi feɪl teɪbɑɹə, ɪf jə ɑɹ nɑt kɛɹfəl. də nɑt feɪl mi." ʃi ɡeɪv feɪl ə læs hɑɹd stɛɹ, ðən tɝn tə leɪbɝ əweɪ ɪndə ðə snoʊ, hoʊldɪŋ əɹ ɑɹmz əz ɪf tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə haɪɾ əɹ dʒuəl bɛl bɪhaɪn əɹ waɪd slivz.

"You have all the time you need," Galina replied. "The rest of your life, Lady Faile t'Aybara, if you are not careful. Do not fail me." She gave Faile a last hard stare, then turned to labor away into the snow, holding her arms as if trying to hide her jeweled belt behind her wide sleeves.

feɪl stʃɹʌɡəld ɔnwɝɾ ɪn saɪləns. niðɝ ə hɝ kəmpænjənz hæɾ ɛniθɪŋ tə seɪ, iðɝ. ðəɹ dɪd nɑt sim tə bi ɛniθɪŋ tə seɪ. æliændɝ əpɪɹd sʌŋk ɪn θɔt, hænz ɪn əɹ slivz, piɹɪŋ stʃɹeɪɾ əhɛɾ əz ɪf siɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ bɪɑn ðə blɪzɝd. meɪaɪɡdɪn hæd ɡɔn bæk tə ɡɹɪpɪŋ əɹ ɡoʊldən kɑlɝ ɪn ə taɪt fɪst. ðeɪ wɝ kɑɾ ɪn θɹi snɛɹz, nɑt wʌn, ən ɛni ʌv ðə θɹi maɪt kɪl. ɹɛskju sʌɾənli sim vɛɹi ətʃɹæktɪv. sʌmhaʊ, ðoʊ, feɪl ɪntɛndəd tə faɪn əɹ weɪ aʊɾ ə ðɪs tʃɹæp. pʊlɪŋ əɹ hæn əweɪ fɹəm əɹ oʊn kɑlɝ, ʃi fɔt θɹu ðə snoʊstɔɹm, plænɪŋ.

Faile struggled onward in silence. Neither of her companions had anything to say, either. There did not seem to be anything to say. Alliandre appeared sunk in thought, hands in her sleeves, peering straight ahead as if seeing something beyond the blizzard. Maighdin had gone back to gripping her golden collar in a tight fist. They were caught in three snares, not one, and any of the three might kill. Rescue suddenly seemed very attractive. Somehow, though, Faile intended to find her way out of this trap. Pulling her hand away from her own collar, she fought through the snowstorm, planning.

hi ɹæn əkɹɔs ðə snoʊ-kʌvɝd pleɪn, noʊz ɪndə ðə wɪnd, hʌntɪŋ fəɹ ə sɛnt, fəɹ ðət wʌn pɹɛʃəs sɛnt. ðə fɔlɪŋ snoʊ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ mɛltəɾ ɑn ɪz tʃɪl fɝ, bʌt koʊl kəd nɑt dɪtɝ hɪm. ðə pædz ə hɪz pɔz wɝ nʌm, jɛɾ ɪz bɝnɪŋ lɛɡz wɝk fjʊɹiəsli, kæɹiɪŋ ɪm ɑn, fæstɝ ən fæstɝ, tɪl ðə læn blɝɾ ɪn ɪz aɪz. hi hæd tə faɪn hɝ.

He ran across the snow-covered plain, nose into the wind, hunting for a scent, for that one precious scent. The falling snow no longer melted on his chilled fur, but cold could not deter him. The pads of his paws were numb, yet his burning legs worked furiously, carrying him on, faster and faster, till the land blurred in his eyes. He had to find her.

sʌɾənli ə ɡɹeɪt ɡɹɪzəld ɡɹeɪ wʊlf, ɹæɡəd-ɪɹɾ ən skɑɹd fɹəm mɛni faɪts, sɛɾəld daʊn aʊɾ ə ðə skaɪ tə ɹeɪs ðə sʌn bɪsaɪd hɪm. ənʌðɝ ɡɹeɪt ɡɹeɪ wʊlf, bʌt nɑt soʊ lɑɹdʒ əz hɪmsɛlf. hɪz tiθ wəd tɛɹ ðə θɹoʊts ə ðoʊz u hæd teɪkən hɝ. hɪz dʒɔz wəd kɹʌʃ ðɛɹ boʊnz!

Suddenly a great grizzled gray wolf, ragged-eared and scarred from many fights, settled down out of the sky to race the sun beside him. Another great gray wolf, but not so large as himself. His teeth would tear the throats of those who had taken her. His jaws would crush their bones!

jəɹ ʃiz nɑt hɪɹ, hɑpɝ sɛn tə hɪm, bʌt jə ɑɹ hɪɹ tu stʃɹɔŋli, ən tu lɔŋ fɹəm jəɹ bɑɾi. jə mʌst ɡoʊ bæk, jʌŋ bʊl, əɹ jəl daɪ.

Your she is not here, Hopper sent to him, but you are here too strongly, and too long from your body. You must go back, Young Bull, or you will die.

aɪ mʌs faɪn hɝ. ivən ɪz θɔts sim tə pænt. hi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ə hɪmsɛlf əz pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə. hi wɑz jʌŋ bʊl. wʌns, hi hæd faʊn ðə fælkən hɪɹ, ən i kəɾ əɡɛn. hi hæd tə faɪn hɝ. bɪsaɪd ðət nid, dɛθ wɑz nʌθɪŋ.

I must find her. Even his thoughts seemed to pant. He did not think of himself as Perrin Aybara. He was Young Bull. Once, he had found the falcon here, and he could again. He had to find her. Beside that need, death was nothing.

ɪn ə flæʃ ʌv ɡɹeɪ ði ʌðɝ wʊlf lʌnʒd əɡɛnst ɪz saɪd, ən ðoʊ jʌŋ bʊl wɑz ðə lɑɹdʒɝ, hi wɑz taɪɝd, ən i fɛl hɛvəli. skɹæmbəlɪŋ tə hɪz fiɾ ɪn ðə snoʊ, hi snɑɹəld ən lɔntʃt hɪmsɛlf ət hɑpɝz θɹoʊt. nʌθɪŋ mæɾɝd mɔɹ ðən ðə fælkən.

In a flash of gray the other wolf lunged against his side, and though Young Bull was the larger, he was tired, and he fell heavily. Scrambling to his feet in the snow, he snarled and launched himself at Hopper's throat. Nothing mattered more than the falcon.

ðə skɑɹd wʊlf flu ɪndə ði ɛɹ laɪk ə bɝd, ən jʌŋ bʊl wɛn spɹɔlɪŋ. hɑpɝ laɪɾəd ɑn ðə snoʊ bɪhaɪn hɪm.

The scarred wolf flew into the air like a bird, and Young Bull went sprawling. Hopper lighted on the snow behind him.

hɪɹ mi, kʌb! hɑpɝ θɔɾ əɾ ɪm fɪɹsli. jəɹ maɪn ɪz twɪstəd wɪð fɪɹ! ʃiz nɑt hɪɹ, ən jəl daɪ ɪf jə ɹɪmeɪn lɔŋɡɝ. faɪn əɹ ɪn ðə weɪkɪŋ wɝld. jə kən oʊnli faɪn əɹ ðɛɹ. ɡoʊ bæk, ən faɪn hɝ!

Hear me, cub! Hopper thought at him fiercely. Your mind is twisted with fear! She is not here, and you will die if you remain longer. Find her in the waking world. You can only find her there. Go back, and find her!

pɛɹɪnz aɪz snæpt oʊpən. hi wɑz boʊn taɪɝɾ ən ɪz mɪɾəl fɛl hɑloʊ, bʌt hʌŋɡɝ wɑz ə ʃædoʊ bɪsaɪd ðə hɑloʊnəs ɪn ɪz tʃɛst. hi wɑz ɔl hɑloʊ, ən dɪstənst ivən fɹəm hɪmsɛlf, əz ɪf i wɝ ənʌðɝ pɝsən wɑtʃɪŋ pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə sʌfɝ. əbʌv hɪm, ə blu-ænd-ɡoʊld-stʃɹaɪp tɛn ɹuf ɹɪpəld ɪn ðə wɪnd. ði ɪntɪɹiɝ ə ðə tɛnt wɑz dɪm ən ʃæɾoʊd, bʌt sʌnlaɪt meɪd ðə bɹaɪt kænvəs ɡloʊ sɔfli. ən jɛstɝdeɪ hæd nɑt bɪn ə naɪtmɛɹ ɛni mɔɹ ðən hɑpɝ wɑz. laɪt, hi hæd tʃɹaɪd tə kɪl hɑpɝ. ɪn ðə wʊlf dʒɹim, dɛθ wɑz . . . faɪnəl. ði ɛɹ wɑz wɔɹm, bʌɾ i ʃɪvɝd. hi wɑz laɪɪŋ ɑn ə fɛðɝ mætʃɹəs, ɪn ə lɑɹdʒ bɛd wɪð hɛvi kɔɹnɝpoʊsts θɪkli kɑɹvd ən ɡɪldɪd. θɹu ðə sɛn ə tʃɑɹkoʊl bɝnɪŋ ɪn ðə bɹeɪʒɝz i smɛl mʌski pɝfjum, ən ðə wʊmən wɛɹɪŋ ɪt. noʊ wʌn ɛls wɑz pɹɛzənt.

Perrin's eyes snapped open. He was bone tired and his middle felt hollow, but hunger was a shadow beside the hollowness in his chest. He was all hollow, and distanced even from himself, as if he were another person watching Perrin Aybara suffer. Above him, a blue-and-gold-striped tent roof rippled in the wind. The interior of the tent was dim and shadowed, but sunlight made the bright canvas glow softly. And yesterday had not been a nightmare any more than Hopper was. Light, he had tried to kill Hopper. In the wolf dream, death was . . . final. The air was warm, but he shivered. He was lying on a feather mattress, in a large bed with heavy cornerposts thickly carved and gilded. Through the scent of charcoal burning in the braziers he smelled musky perfume, and the woman wearing it. No one else was present.

wɪθaʊt ɹeɪzɪŋ ɪz hɛd fɹəm ðə pɪloʊ, hi sɛd, "hæv ðeɪ faʊn əɹ jɛt, bɹəleɪn?" hɪz hɛd fɛl tu hɛvi tə lɪft.

Without raising his head from the pillow, he said, "Have they found her yet, Berelain?" His head felt too heavy to lift.

wʌn ə hɝ kæmp tʃɛɹz skwik feɪnli əz ʃi ʃɪftəd. hi hæd bɪn hɪɹ bɪfɔɹ ɔfən, wɪð feɪl, tə dɪskʌs plænz. ðə tɛnt wɑz bɪɡ ɪnʌf tə haʊs ə fæmli, ən bɹəleɪnz ɪlæbɹət fɝnɪʃɪŋz wəd nɑɾ əv lʊkt aʊɾ ə pleɪs ɪn ə pæləs, ɔl ɪntʃɹəkət kɑɹvɪŋ ən ɡɪlt, ðoʊ ɛvɹiθɪŋ, teɪbəlz ən tʃɛɹz ən ðə bɛɾ ɪtsɛlf, wɑz hɛl təɡɛðɝ wɪð pɛɡz. ðeɪ kəd bi dɪsəsɛmbəl fəɹ stɔɹədʒ ɑn ə kɑɹt, bʌt ðə pɛɡz dɪd nɑt meɪk fəɹ tʃɹu stɝɾinəs.

One of her camp chairs squeaked faintly as she shifted. He had been here before often, with Faile, to discuss plans. The tent was big enough to house a family, and Berelain's elaborate furnishings would not have looked out of place in a palace, all intricate carving and gilt, though everything, tables and chairs and the bed itself, was held together with pegs. They could be disassembled for storage on a cart, but the pegs did not make for true sturdiness.

ʌndɝ ðə pɝfjum, bɹəleɪn smɛld ə sɝpɹaɪz ðəɾ i nu ʃi wɑz ðɛɹ, jɛɾ əɹ vɔɪs wɑz kəmpoʊzd. "noʊ. jəɹ skaʊts hævən ɹɪtɝn jɛt, ən maɪn . . . wən ðeɪ dɪdn ɹɪtɝn baɪ naɪtfɔl, aɪ sɛn ə fʊl kʌmpəni. ðeɪ faʊn maɪ mɛn dɛɾ ɪn ən æmbʊʃ, kɪl bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ hæd ɡɔn mɔɹ ðən faɪv əɹ sɪks maɪlz. aɪ ɔɹɾɝd lɔɹd ɡælɛn tə kip ə taɪt wɑtʃ ɝaʊn ðə kæmps. ɑɹɡændə hæz ə stʃɹɔŋ ɡɑɹd maʊntəd, tu, bʌɾ i sɛn pətʃɹoʊlz aʊt. əɡɛns maɪ ædvaɪs. ðə mænz ə ful. hi θɪŋks noʊ wʌn kən faɪn æliændɝ bʌt hɪm. aɪm nɑt ʃʊɹ i bɪlivz ɛniwʌn ɛls ɪz ɹɪli tʃɹaɪɪŋ. sɝɾənli nɑt ði il."

Under the perfume, Berelain smelled of surprise that he knew she was there, yet her voice was composed. "No. Your scouts haven't returned yet, and mine . . . When they didn't return by nightfall, I sent a full company. They found my men dead in an ambush, killed before they had gone more than five or six miles. I ordered Lord Gallenne to keep a tight watch around the camps. Arganda has a strong guard mounted, too, but he sent patrols out. Against my advice. The man's a fool. He thinks no one can find Alliandre but him. I am not sure he believes anyone else is really trying. Certainly not the Aiel."

pɛɹɪnz hænz taɪɾənd ɑn ðə sɑft wʊl blæŋkəts kʌvɝɪŋ hɪm. ɡɔl wəd nɑt bi kɑt baɪ sɝpɹaɪz, əɹ dʒɑndɪn, nɑɾ ivən baɪ il. ðeɪ wɝ stɪl hʌntɪŋ, ən ðət mɛn feɪl wɑz əlaɪv. ðeɪ wʊɾə bɪn bæk lɔŋ sɪns ɪf ðeɪ hæd faʊn əɹ bɑɾi. hi hæd tə bɪliv ðæt. hi lɪftəd wʌn ə ðə blu blæŋkəts ə tʃɹaɪfəl. bɪniθ ðɛm, hi wɑz bɛɹ. "ɪz ðəɹ ən ɛkspləneɪʃən fəɹ ðɪs?"

Perrin's hands tightened on the soft wool blankets covering him. Gaul would not be caught by surprise, or Jondyn, not even by Aiel. They were still hunting, and that meant Faile was alive. They would have been back long since if they had found her body. He had to believe that. He lifted one of the blue blankets a trifle. Beneath them, he was bare. "Is there an explanation for this?"

hɝ vɔɪs dɪd nɑt tʃeɪnʒ, bʌt kɑʃən ʃɪmɝɾ ɪn əɹ sɛnt. "ju ən jəɹ ɑɹmsmən maɪɾ əv fɹoʊzən tə dɛθ ɪf aɪ hædnt ɡɔn lʊkɪŋ fəɹ jə wən nɹɛl ɹɪtɝnd wɪð nuz ə maɪ skaʊts. noʊ wʌn ɛls hæd ðə nɝv tə dɪstɝb ju; əpɛɹənli jə snɑɹəld laɪk ə wʊlf əɾ ɛvɹiwʌn u dɪd. wən aɪ faʊn ju, jə wɝ soʊ nʌm jə kʊdn hɪɹ ɛniwʌn spik tə ju, ən ði ʌðɝ mæn wɑz ɹɛɾi tə fɔl ɑn ɪz feɪs. jəɹ wʊmən lini kɛpt ɪm - ɔl i niɾəd wɑz hɑt sup ən blæŋkəts - bʌɾ aɪ hæd jə kæɹid hɪɹ. jə maɪɾ əv lɔst səm toʊz ət bɛst wɪθaʊɾ ənʊɹə. ʃi . . . ʃi simd əfɹeɪd jə maɪt daɪ ivən æftɝ ʃi hil ju. jə slɛp laɪk ə mæn ɔlɹɛɾi dɛd. ʃi sɛd jə ɔlmoʊs fɛlt laɪk sʌmwʌn u hæd lɔst ɪz soʊl, koʊl noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ mɛni blæŋkəts wɝ paɪld ɑn ju. aɪ fɛlt ɪt, əz wɛl, wən aɪ tʌtʃt ju."

Her voice did not change, but caution shimmered in her scent. "You and your armsman might have frozen to death if I hadn't gone looking for you when Nurelle returned with news of my scouts. No one else had the nerve to disturb you; apparently you snarled like a wolf at everyone who did. When I found you, you were so numb you couldn't hear anyone speak to you, and the other man was ready to fall on his face. Your woman Lini kept him - all he needed was hot soup and blankets - but I had you carried here. You might have lost some toes at best without Annoura. She . . . She seemed afraid you might die even after she Healed you. You slept like a man already dead. She said you almost felt like someone who had lost his soul, cold no matter how many blankets were piled on you. I felt it, as well, when I touched you."

tu mʌtʃ ɛkspləneɪʃən, ən nɑɾ ɪnʌf. æŋɡɝ flɛɹd, ə dɪstən æŋɡɝ, bʌɾ i hæmɝɾ ɪt daʊn. feɪl wɑz ɔlweɪz dʒɛləs wən i ɹeɪzd ɪz vɔɪs tə bɹəleɪn. ðə wʊmən wəd ɡɛt noʊ ʃaʊts fɹəm hɪm. "ɡɹeɪɾi əɹ nild cʊɾə dʌn wʌtɛvɝ wɑz nɛsəsɛɹi," hi sɛɾ ɪn ə flæt vɔɪs. "ivən siɑnɪɾ ən mɑsʊɝi wɝ kloʊsɝ."

Too much explanation, and not enough. Anger flared, a distant anger, but he hammered it down. Faile was always jealous when he raised his voice to Berelain. The woman would get no shouts from him. "Grady or Neald could have done whatever was necessary," he said in a flat voice. "Even Seonid and Masuri were closer."

"maɪ oʊn ædvaɪzɝ keɪm tə maɪn fɝst. aɪ nɛvɝ θɔɾ ə ði ʌðɝz tɪl aɪ wɑz ɔlmoʊs bæk hɪɹ. ɛniweɪ, dʌz ɪt mæɾɝ u dɪd ðə hilɪŋ?"

"My own advisor came to mind first. I never thought of the others till I was almost back here. Anyway, does it matter who did the Healing?"

soʊ plɔzəbəl. ən ɪf i æskt waɪ ðə fɝst ə min hɝsɛlf wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ oʊvɝ ɪm ɪn ə hæf-dɑɹk tɛn ɪnstɛɾ ə hɝ sɝvɪŋ wɪmən, əɹ səm ə hɝ soʊlʒɝz, əɹ ivən ənʊɹə, ʃi wəɾ əv ənʌðɝ plɔzəbəl ænsɝ. hi dɪd nɑt wɑnə hɪɹ ɪt.

So plausible. And if he asked why the First of Mayene herself was watching over him in a half-dark tent instead of her serving women, or some of her soldiers, or even Annoura, she would have another plausible answer. He did not want to hear it.

"wɛɹ ɑɹ maɪ kloʊðz?" hi æskt, pɹɑpɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ʌp ɑn ɪz ɛlboʊz. hɪz vɔɪs stɪl hæd noʊ ɪkspɹɛʃən.

"Where are my clothes?" he asked, propping himself up on his elbows. His voice still had no expression.

ə sɪŋɡəl kændəl ɑn ə smɔl teɪbəl bɪsaɪd bɹəleɪnz tʃɛɹ ɡeɪv ði oʊnli ɹil laɪɾ ɪn ðə tɛnt, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz mɔɹ ðən ɪnʌf fəɹ ɪz aɪz, ivən ɡɹeɪni wɪð taɪɹədnəs əz ðeɪ wɝ. ʃi wɑz ɡɑɹb dɪmjʊɹli ɪnʌf, ɪn ə dɑɹk ɡɹin ɹaɪɾɪŋ dʒɹɛs wɪð ə haɪ nɛk ðət nɛsəld əɹ tʃɪn ɪn ə θɪk ɹʌf ə leɪs. pʊɾɪŋ dɪmjʊɹ ɑn bɹəleɪn wɑz laɪk pʊɾɪŋ ə ʃipskɪn ɑn ə ɹɪdʒɛkæt. hɝ feɪs wɑz feɪnli ʃæɾoʊd, bjuɾəfəl ən əntʃɹʌstwɝði. ʃi wəd də wʌt ʃi pɹɑməst, bʌt laɪk ən ɛɛs sədaɪ, fəɹ əɹ oʊn ɹizənz, ən ðə θɪŋz ʃi hæd meɪd noʊ pɹɑməsəz əbaʊt kəd stæb jə ɪn ðə bæk.

A single candle on a small table beside Berelain's chair gave the only real light in the tent, but it was more than enough for his eyes, even grainy with tiredness as they were. She was garbed demurely enough, in a dark green riding dress with a high neck that nestled her chin in a thick ruff of lace. Putting demure on Berelain was like putting a sheepskin on a ridgecat. Her face was faintly shadowed, beautiful and untrustworthy. She would do what she promised, but like an Aes Sedai, for her own reasons, and the things she had made no promises about could stab you in the back.

"ɑn ðə tʃɛst oʊvɝ ðɛɹ," ʃi sɛd, dʒɛstʃɝɪŋ wɪð ə ɡɹeɪsfəl hænd nɪɹli hɪɾən ɪn peɪl leɪs. "aɪ hæd ɹɑsin ən nænə klin ðɛm, bʌt jə nid ɹɛst ən fud mɔɹ ðən kloʊðɪŋ. ən bɪfɔɹ wi ɡɛt tə fud, ən bɪznəs, aɪ wɑn jə tə noʊ ðət noʊ wʌn hoʊps feɪl ɪz əlaɪv mɔɹ ðən aɪ." hɝ ɪkspɹɛʃən wɑz soʊ oʊpən ən ɑnəst, hi cʊɾə bɪlivd əɹ hæd ʃi bɪn ɛniwʌn ɛls. ʃi ivən mænədʒ tə smɛl ɑnəst!

"On the chest over there," she said, gesturing with a graceful hand nearly hidden in pale lace. "I had Rosene and Nana clean them, but you need rest and food more than clothing. And before we get to food, and business, I want you to know that no one hopes Faile is alive more than I." Her expression was so open and honest, he could have believed her had she been anyone else. She even managed to smell honest!

"aɪ nid maɪ kloʊðz naʊ." hi twɪstəɾ ɝaʊn tə sɪɾ ʌp ɑn ðə saɪɾ ə ðə bɛd wɪð ðə blæŋkəts pʊld əkɹɔs ɪz lɛɡz. ðə kloʊðz i hæd bɪn wɛɹɪŋ leɪ nitli foʊldəɾ ɑn ə bændɪd tʃɹævəl tʃɛs ðət wɑz kɑɹvd ən ɡɪldɪd wɪðɪn ən ɪntʃ ʌv ɪts laɪf. hɪz fɝ-laɪn kloʊk wɑz dʒɹeɪpt əkɹɔs wʌn ɛn ə ðə tʃɛst, ən ɪz æks lind nɛks tə hɪz buts ɑn ðə bɹaɪtli flaʊɝd kɑɹpəts leɪɝd fəɹ ə flɔɹ. laɪt, hi wɑz taɪɝd. hi dɪd nɑt noʊ haʊ lɔŋ i hæd bɪn ɪn ðə wʊlf dʒɹim, bʌɾ əweɪk ðəɹ wɑz əweɪk, əz fɑɹ əz jəɹ bɑɾi wɑz kənsɝnd. hɪz stʌmək ɹʌmbəld laʊdli. "æn fud."

"I need my clothes now." He twisted around to sit up on the side of the bed with the blankets pulled across his legs. The clothes he had been wearing lay neatly folded on a banded travel chest that was carved and gilded within an inch of its life. His fur-lined cloak was draped across one end of the chest, and his axe leaned next to his boots on the brightly flowered carpets layered for a floor. Light, he was tired. He did not know how long he had been in the wolf dream, but awake there was awake, as far as your body was concerned. His stomach rumbled loudly. "And food."

bɹəleɪn meɪɾ ən ɪɡzæspɝeɪɾɪd saʊn ɪn əɹ θɹoʊɾ ən ɹoʊz, smuðɪŋ əɹ skɝts, hɝ tʃɪn lɪftəd haɪ wɪð dɪsəpɹuvəl. "ənʊɹə wɪl nɑt bi plizd wɪð jə wən ʃi kʌmz bæk fɹəm tɔkɪŋ wɪð ðə waɪz wʌnz," ʃi sɛd fɝmli. "ju kæn dʒʌst ɪɡnɔɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ. jə ɑɹ nɑt ɹænd ælθɹ, əz ðəl pɹuv tə jə sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ."

Berelain made an exasperated sound in her throat and rose, smoothing her skirts, her chin lifted high with disapproval. "Annoura will not be pleased with you when she comes back from talking with the Wise Ones," she said firmly. "You can't just ignore Aes Sedai. You are not Rand al'Thor, as they will prove to you sooner or later."

bʌt ʃi lɛf ðə tɛnt, lɛɾɪŋ ɪn ə swɝl ə koʊld ɛɹ. ɪn əɹ dɪsplɛʒɝ, ʃi dɪd nɑɾ ivən bɑðɝ tə teɪk ə kloʊk. θɹu ðə moʊməntɛɹi ɡæp ɪn ði ɛntʃɹi flæps, hi sɔ ðəɾ ɪt wɑz stɪl snoʊɪŋ. nɑɾ əz hɑɹɾ əz læs naɪt, bʌt waɪt fleɪks dʒɹɪzəl daʊn stɛɾəli. ivən dʒɑndɪn wəɾ əv dɪfəkəlti faɪndɪŋ saɪn æftɝ læs naɪt. hi tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə θɪŋk əbaʊt ðæt.

But she left the tent, letting in a swirl of cold air. In her displeasure, she did not even bother to take a cloak. Through the momentary gap in the entry flaps, he saw that it was still snowing. Not as hard as last night, but white flakes drizzled down steadily. Even Jondyn would have difficulty finding sign after last night. He tried not to think about that.

fɔɹ bɹeɪʒɝz wɔɹm ði ɛɹ ɪn ðə tɛnt, bʌɾ aɪs sipt ɪndə hɪz fiɾ əz sun əz ðeɪ hɪt ðə kɑɹpəts, ən i hɝid tə hɪz kloʊðz. tɑɾɝd tə ðɛm, ɹɪli, ðoʊ nɑt dæliɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪt. hi wɑz soʊ taɪɝɾ i cʊɾə leɪn daʊn ɑn ðə kɑɹpəts ən ɡɔn tə slip əɡɛn. ɑn tɑp ə ðæt, hi fɛlt wik əz ə nubɔɹn læm. pɝhæps ðə wʊlf dʒɹim hæd sʌmθɪŋ tə də wɪð ðæt, tu - ɡoʊɪŋ ðəɹ əz stʃɹɔŋli əz i hæd, əbændənɪŋ ɪz bɑɾi - bʌt hilɪŋ laɪkli hæɾ ɪɡzæsɝbeɪɾəd mæɾɝz. wɪð nʌθɪŋ tə it sɪns jɛstɝdeɪz bɹɛkfəst ən ə naɪt spɛn stændɪŋ ɪn ðə snoʊ, hi hæd hæd noʊ ɹɪzɝv tə dʒɹɔ ɑn. naʊ hɪz hænz fʌmbəld wɪð ðə sɪmpəl tæsk ə pʊɾɪŋ ɑn ɪz smɔlkloʊðz. dʒɑndɪn wəd faɪn hɝ. əɹ ɡɔl wʊd. faɪn əɹ əlaɪv. nʌθɪŋ ɛls ɪn ðə wɝl mæɾɝd. hi fɛl nʌm.

Four braziers warmed the air in the tent, but ice seeped into his feet as soon as they hit the carpets, and he hurried to his clothes. Tottered to them, really, though not dallying about it. He was so tired he could have lain down on the carpets and gone to sleep again. On top of that, he felt weak as a newborn lamb. Perhaps the wolf dream had something to do with that, too - going there as strongly as he had, abandoning his body - but Healing likely had exacerbated matters. With nothing to eat since yesterday's breakfast and a night spent standing in the snow, he had had no reserve to draw on. Now his hands fumbled with the simple task of putting on his smallclothes. Jondyn would find her. Or Gaul would. Find her alive. Nothing else in the world mattered. He felt numb.

hi hæd nɑɾ ɪkspɛktəd bɹəleɪn tə ɹɪtɝn hɝsɛlf, bʌɾ ə ɡʌst ə koʊld ɛntɝd kæɹiɪŋ əɹ pɝfjum waɪl i wɑz stɪl dʒɹɔɪŋ ɑn ɪz bɹitʃɪz. hɝ ɡeɪz ɑn ɪz bæk wɑz laɪk stʃɹoʊkɪŋ fɪŋɡɝz, bʌɾ i meɪd hɪmsɛlf ɡoʊ ɑn əz ɪf əloʊn. ʃi wəd nɑɾ əv ðə sæɾəsfækʃən ə siɪŋ ɪm hɝi kəz ʃi wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ. hi dɪd nɑt lʊk ət hɝ.

He had not expected Berelain to return herself, but a gust of cold entered carrying her perfume while he was still drawing on his breeches. Her gaze on his back was like stroking fingers, but he made himself go on as if alone. She would not have the satisfaction of seeing him hurry because she was watching. He did not look at her.

"ɹɑsin ɪz bɹɪŋɪŋ hɑt fud," ʃi sɛd. "ðɛɹ ɪz oʊnli mʌɾən stu, aɪm əfɹeɪd, bʌɾ aɪ toʊld əɹ ɪnʌf fəɹ θɹi mɛn." ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ən i hɝɾ əɹ slɪpɝz ʃɪft ɑn ðə kɑɹpəts. ʃi saɪd sɔfli. "pɛɹɪn, aɪ noʊ jə ɑɹ hɝɾɪŋ. ðəɹ ɑɹ θɪŋz jə maɪt wɑnə seɪ ðət jə kæn tə ənʌðɝ mæn. aɪ kæn si jə kɹaɪɪŋ ɑn liniz ʃoʊldɝ, soʊ aɪ ɔfɝ maɪn. wi kən kɔl ə tʃɹus əntɪl feɪl ɪz faʊnd."

"Rosene is bringing hot food," she said. "There is only mutton stew, I'm afraid, but I told her enough for three men." She hesitated, and he heard her slippers shift on the carpets. She sighed softly. "Perrin, I know you are hurting. There are things you might want to say that you can't to another man. I can't see you crying on Lini's shoulder, so I offer mine. We can call a truce until Faile is found."

"ə tʃɹus?" hi sɛd, kɛɹfəli bɛndɪŋ tə tʌɡ ɑn ə but. kɛɹfəli soʊ hi dɪd nɑt fɔl oʊvɝ. staʊt wʊl stɑkɪŋz ən θɪk lɛðɝ soʊlz wəɾ əv ɪz fit wɔɹm sun ɪnʌf. "waɪ də wi niɾ ə tʃɹus?" ʃi wɑz saɪlənt waɪl i dɑn ði ʌðɝ buɾ ən foʊldəd ðə tɝndaʊnz bɪloʊ hɪz niz, nɑt spikɪŋ əntɪl i hæd dʌn ʌp ðə leɪsəz ə hɪz ʃɝɾ ən wɑz stʌfɪŋ ɪɾ ɪndə hɪz bɹitʃɪz.

"A truce?" he said, carefully bending to tug on a boot. Carefully so he did not fall over. Stout wool stockings and thick leather soles would have his feet warm soon enough. "Why do we need a truce?" She was silent while he donned the other boot and folded the turndowns below his knees, not speaking until he had done up the laces of his shirt and was stuffing it into his breeches.

"vɛɹi wɛl, pɛɹɪn. ɪf ðəɾ ɪz haʊ jə wɑn ɪt." wʌtɛvɝ ðət wɑz səpoʊz tə min, ʃi saʊndəd vɛɹi dɪtɝmənd. sʌɾənli hi wʌndɝd wɛðɝ ɪz noʊz hæd feɪl hɪm. hɝ sɛnt wɑz əfɹʌntɪd, ʌv ɔl θɪŋz! wən i lʊkt ət hɝ, ðoʊ, ʃi wɔɹ ə feɪn smaɪl. ɑn ði ʌðɝ hænd, ðoʊz bɪɡ aɪz hɛld ə ɡlɪn ʌv æŋɡɝ. "ðə pɹɑfəts mɛn bɪɡæn ɝaɪvɪŋ bɪfɔɹ deɪlaɪt," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn ə bɹɪsk vɔɪs, "bʌɾ əz aɪ fɑɹ əz aɪ noʊ, hi hæzən kʌm hɪmsɛlf, jɛt. bɪfɔɹ jə si hɪm əɡɛn - "

"Very well, Perrin. If that is how you want it." Whatever that was supposed to mean, she sounded very determined. Suddenly he wondered whether his nose had failed him. Her scent was affronted, of all things! When he looked at her, though, she wore a faint smile. On the other hand, those big eyes held a glint of anger. "The Prophet's men began arriving before daylight," she said in a brisk voice, "but as I far as I know, he hasn't come himself, yet. Before you see him again - "

"bɪɡæn ɝaɪvɪŋ?" hi bɹoʊk ɪn. "mæsimə əɡɹid tə bɹɪŋ oʊnli ən ɑnɝ ɡɑɹd, ə hʌnʒɹəd mɛn."

"Began arriving?" he broke in. "Masema agreed to bring only an honor guard, a hundred men."

"wʌtɛvɝ i əɡɹid, ðəɹ wɝ θɹi əɹ fɔɹ θaʊzən ðə læst aɪ lʊkt - ən ɑɹmi ʌv ɹʌfaɪənz, ɛvɹi mæn wɪðɪn maɪlz u kəd kæɹi ə spɪɹ, ɪt simd - ən mɔɹ kʌmɪŋ fɹəm ɛvɹi dɝɛkʃən."

"Whatever he agreed, there were three or four thousand the last I looked - an army of ruffians, every man within miles who could carry a spear, it seemed - and more coming from every direction."

hɝidli, hi ʃɹʌɡd ɪndə hɪz koʊɾ ən bʌkəld ɪz bɛlt oʊvɝ ɪt, sɛɾəlɪŋ ðə weɪɾ ə ði æks əɾ ɪz hɪp. ɪɾ ɔlweɪz fɛl hɛviɝ ðən ɪt ʃʊd. "wi wɪl si əbaʊt ðæt! bɝn mi, aɪ woʊn bi lʌmbɝd wɪð ɪz mɝɾɝəs vɝmɪn!"

Hurriedly, he shrugged into his coat and buckled his belt over it, settling the weight of the axe at his hip. It always felt heavier than it should. "We will see about that! Burn me, I won't be lumbered with his murderous vermin!"

"hɪz vɝmɪn ɑɹ ən ənɔɪəns kəmpɛɹd tə ðə mæn hɪmsɛlf. ðə deɪnʒɝ laɪz wɪð mæsimə." hɝ vɔɪs wɑz kul, bʌt taɪtli liʃt fɪɹ kwɪvɝɾ ɪn əɹ sɛnt. ɪɾ ɔlweɪz dɪd wən ʃi spoʊk ə mæsimə. "ðə sɪstɝz ən ðə waɪz wʌnz ɑɹ ɹaɪɾ əbaʊt ðæt. ɪf jə nid mɔɹ pɹuf ʌv ɪt ðən jəɹ oʊn aɪz, hiz bɪn miɾɪŋ wɪð ðə sintʃæn."

"His vermin are an annoyance compared to the man himself. The danger lies with Masema." Her voice was cool, but tightly leashed fear quivered in her scent. It always did when she spoke of Masema. "The sisters and the Wise Ones are right about that. If you need more proof of it than your own eyes, he has been meeting with the Seanchan."

ðət hɪɾ ɪm laɪk ə hæmɝ, ɪspɛʃli æftɝ beɪlwɝz nuz ə ðə faɪɾɪŋ ɪn ɔltɑɹə. "haʊ dʒju noʊ?" hi dɪmændəd. "jɔɹ θif-kætʃɝz?" ʃi hæɾ ə pɛɹ, bɹɔt fɹəm min, ən ʃi sɛn əm ɔf tə lɝn wʌt ðeɪ kəɾ əɾ ɛvɹi taʊn əɹ vɪlədʒ. bɪtwin əm ðeɪ nɛvɝ dɪskʌvɝd hæf ʌv wʌt beɪlwɝ dɪd. nɑt ðət ʃi toʊl hɪm, ɛniweɪ.

That hit him like a hammer, especially after Balwer's news of the fighting in Altara. "How do you know?" he demanded. "Your thief-catchers?" She had a pair, brought from Mayene, and she sent them off to learn what they could at every town or village. Between them they never discovered half of what Balwer did. Not that she told him, anyway.

bɹəleɪn ʃʊk əɹ hɛd slaɪtli, ɹɪɡɹɛtfəli. "feɪlz . . . ɹɪteɪnɝz. θɹi ʌv əm faʊn əs dʒʌs bɪfɔɹ ði il ətækt. ðeɪ hæd tɔkt wɪð mɛn u sɔ ə hjudʒ flaɪɪŋ kɹitʃɝ lænd." ʃi ʃɪvɝɾ ə lɪɾəl tu ɑstənteɪʃəsli, bʌt baɪ hɝ smɛl, ɪt wɑz ə tʃɹu ɹiækʃən. noʊ sɝpɹaɪz; hi hæd sin səm ə ðə bists wʌns, ən ə tʃɹɑlɑk dɪd nɑt lʊk mɔɹ laɪk ʃæɾoʊzpɔn. "ə kɹitʃɝ kæɹiɪŋ ə pæsənʒɝ. ðeɪ tʃɹeɪst əɹ tə ɑbilə, tə mæsimə. aɪ doʊn bɪliv ɪt wɑz ə fɝs miɾɪŋ. ɪt hæd ðə saʊn ə pɹæktəs, tə mi."

Berelain shook her head slightly, regretfully. "Faile's . . . retainers. Three of them found us just before the Aiel attacked. They had talked with men who saw a huge flying creature land." She shivered a little too ostentatiously, but by her smell, it was a true reaction. No surprise; he had seen some of the beasts once, and a Trolloc did not look more like Shadowspawn. "A creature carrying a passenger. They traced her to Abila, to Masema. I don't believe it was a first meeting. It had the sound of practice, to me."

sʌɾənli hɝ lɪps kɝvd ɪn ə smaɪl, slaɪtli mɑkɪŋ, flɝteɪʃəs. ðɪs taɪm, hɝ sɛn mætʃt əɹ feɪs. "ɪt wɑz nɑt vɛɹi naɪs ə jə tə meɪk mi θɪŋk ðət dʒɹaɪd-ʌp lɪɾəl sɛkɹətɛɹi ʌv jʊɹz wɑz faɪndɪŋ aʊt mɔɹ ðən maɪ θif-kætʃɝz wən juv tu dʌzən aɪz-ænd-ɪɹz mæskɝeɪɾɪŋ əz feɪlz ɹɪteɪnɝz. aɪ mʌst ədmɪt, jə hæd mi fuld. ðəɹ ɑɹ ɔlweɪz nu sɝpɹaɪzəz tə faɪn ɪn ju. waɪ dʒju lʊk soʊ stɑɹɾəld? dɪd jə ɹɪli θɪŋk jə kəd tʃɹʌs mæsimə æftɝ ɔl wiv sin ən hɝd?"

Suddenly her lips curved in a smile, slightly mocking, flirtatious. This time, her scent matched her face. "It was not very nice of you to make me think that dried-up little secretary of yours was finding out more than my thief-catchers when you have two dozen eyes-and-ears masquerading as Faile's retainers. I must admit, you had me fooled. There are always new surprises to find in you. Why do you look so startled? Did you really think you could trust Masema after all we've seen and heard?"

pɛɹɪnz stɛɹ hæd lɪɾəl tə də wɪð mæsimə. ðət nuz kəd min ə ɡɹeɪt dil əɹ nʌθɪŋ əɾ ɔl. pɝhæps ðə mæn θɔɾ i kəd bɹɪŋ ðə sintʃæn tə ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən, tu. hi wɑz mæɾ ɪnʌf fəɹ ɪt. bʌt . . . feɪl hæd ðoʊz fulz spaɪɪŋ? snikɪŋ ɪndə ɑbilə? ən ðə laɪt nu wɛɹ ɛls. ʌv kɔɹs, ʃi ɔlweɪz sɛd spaɪɪŋ wɑz ə waɪfs wɝk, bʌt lɪsnɪŋ tə ɡɑsəp ɝaʊn ə pæləs wɑz wʌn θɪŋ; ðɪs wɑz ɔltəɡɛðɝ dɪfɹənt. ʃi cʊɾə toʊl hɪm, ət list. əɹ hæd ʃi kɛp kwaɪət kəz əɹ ɹɪteɪnɝz wɝ nɑt ði oʊnli wʌnz poʊkɪŋ ðɛɹ noʊzɪz wɛɹ ðeɪ ʃəd nɑt? ɪt wəd bi dʒʌs laɪk hɝ. feɪl tʃɹuli dɪd pəzɛs ə fælkənz spɪɹət. ʃi maɪt θɪŋk ɪt fʌn tə spaɪ hɝsɛlf. noʊ, hi wɑz nɑt gɑnə ɡɛɾ æŋɡɹi wɪð hɝ, sɝɾənli nɑt naʊ. laɪt, ʃi wəd θɪŋk ɪt wɑz fʌn.

Perrin's stare had little to do with Masema. That news could mean a great deal or nothing at all. Perhaps the man thought he could bring the Seanchan to the Lord Dragon, too. He was mad enough for it. But . . . Faile had those fools spying? Sneaking into Abila? And the Light knew where else. Of course, she always said spying was a wife's work, but listening to gossip around a palace was one thing; this was altogether different. She could have told him, at least. Or had she kept quiet because her retainers were not the only ones poking their noses where they should not? It would be just like her. Faile truly did possess a falcon's spirit. She might think it fun to spy herself. No, he was not going to get angry with her, certainly not now. Light, she would think it was fun.

"aɪ æm ɡlæd tə noʊ jə kən bi dɪskɹit," bɹəleɪn mɝmɝd. "aɪ wəd nɑɾ əv θɔɾ ɪɾ ɪn jəɹ neɪtʃɝ, bʌt dɪskɹɛʃən kən bi ə faɪn θɪŋ. ɪspɛʃli naʊ. maɪ mɛn wɝ nɑt kɪl baɪ il, ənlɛs il əv teɪkən tə juzɪŋ kɹɔsboʊz ən æksiz."

"I am glad to know you can be discreet," Berelain murmured. "I would not have thought it in your nature, but discretion can be a fine thing. Especially now. My men were not killed by Aiel, unless Aiel have taken to using crossbows and axes."

hɪz hɛd dʒɝkt ʌp, ən dɪspaɪɾ ɪz bɛst ɪntɛntʃənz, hi ɡlɛɹɾ ət hɝ. "ju dʒʌst slɪp ðəɾ ɪn? ɪz ðəɹ ɛniθɪŋ ɛls juv fɝɡɑɾən tə tɛl mi, ɛniθɪŋ ðəɾ ɪskeɪp jəɹ maɪnd?"

His head jerked up, and despite his best intentions, he glared at her. "You just slip that in? Is there anything else you've forgotten to tell me, anything that escaped your mind?"

"haʊ kən jə æsk?" ʃi ɔlmoʊs læft. "aɪ wəɾ əv tə stʃɹɪp maɪsɛlf neɪkəd tə ɹɪvil mɔɹ ðən aɪ ɔlɹɛɾi hæv." spɹɛɾɪŋ əɹ ɑɹmz waɪd, ʃi twɪstəd slaɪtli laɪk ə sneɪk əz ɪf tə dɛmənstʃɹeɪt.

"How can you ask?" she almost laughed. "I would have to strip myself naked to reveal more than I already have." Spreading her arms wide, she twisted slightly like a snake as if to demonstrate.

pɛɹɪn ɡɹaʊld ɪn dɪsɡʌst. feɪl wɑz mɪsɪŋ, ðə laɪɾ oʊnli nu wɛðɝ ʃi wɑz əlaɪv - laɪt, lɛɾ əɹ bi əlaɪv! - ən bɹəleɪn tʃoʊz naʊ tə flɔn hɝsɛlf wɝs ðən ʃi ɛvɝ hæd bɪfɔɹ? bʌt ʃi wɑz u ʃi wɑz. hi ʃəd bi ɡɹeɪtfəl ʃi hæd klʌŋ tə disənsi lɔŋ ɪnʌf fəɹ ɪm tə dʒɹɛs.

Perrin growled in disgust. Faile was missing, the Light only knew whether she was alive - Light, let her be alive! - and Berelain chose now to flaunt herself worse than she ever had before? But she was who she was. He should be grateful she had clung to decency long enough for him to dress.

aɪɪŋ ɪm θɔtfəli, ʃi ɹæn ə fɪŋɡɝɾɪp əlɔŋ əɹ loʊɝ lɪp. "dɪspaɪt wʌt jə meɪ hæv hɝd, jəl bi oʊnli ðə θɝd mæn tə ʃɛɹ maɪ bɛd." hɝ aɪz wɝ . . . smoʊki . . . jɛt ʃi maɪɾ əv bɪn seɪɪŋ i wɑz ðə θɝd mæn ʃi hæd spoʊkən tə ðət deɪ. hɝ sɛnt . . . ði oʊnli θɪŋ ðət keɪm tə maɪnd wɑz ə wʊlf aɪɪŋ ə dɪɹ kɑɾ ɪn bɹæmbəlz. "ði ʌðɝ tu wɝ pɑlətɪks. jəl bi plɛʒɝ. ɪn mɔɹ weɪz ðən wʌn," ʃi fɪnɪʃt wɪð ə sɝpɹaɪzɪŋ tʌtʃ ə baɪt.

Eyeing him thoughtfully, she ran a fingertip along her lower lip. "Despite what you may have heard, you will be only the third man to share my bed." Her eyes were . . . smoky . . . yet she might have been saying he was the third man she had spoken to that day. Her scent . . . The only thing that came to mind was a wolf eyeing a deer caught in brambles. "The other two were politics. You will be pleasure. In more ways than one," she finished with a surprising touch of bite.

dʒʌs ðən ɹɑsin bʌsəld ɪndə ðə tɛn ɪn ə bɪloʊ ʌv aɪsi ɛɹ, hɝ blu kloʊk θɹoʊn bæk ən kæɹiɪŋ ən oʊvəl sɪlvɝ tʃɹeɪ kʌvɝd wɪð ə waɪt lɪnən klɔθ. pɛɹɪn snæpt ɪz maʊθ ʃʌt, pɹeɪɪŋ ʃi hæd nɑɾ oʊvɝhɝd. smaɪlɪŋ, bɹəleɪn sim nɑt tə kɛɹ. sɛɾɪŋ ðə tʃɹeɪ ɑn ðə lɑɹdʒəs teɪbəl, ðə staʊt sɝvɪŋ wʊmən spɹɛɾ əɹ blu-ænd-ɡoʊld-stʃɹaɪp skɝts ɪn ə dip kɝtsi fəɹ bɹəleɪn ən ənʌðɝ, ʃɔɹɾɝ, fəɹ hɪm. hɝ dɑɹk aɪz lɪŋɡɝɾ ɑn ɪm ə moʊmənt, ən ʃi smaɪld, əz plizd əz əɹ mɪstʃɹəs, bɪfɔɹ ɡæðɝɪŋ əɹ kloʊk təɡɛðɝ ən hɝiɪŋ aʊɾ əɡɛn əɾ ə kwɪk dʒɛstʃɝ fɹəm bɹəleɪn. ʃi hæɾ oʊvɝhɝd, ɔl ɹaɪt. ðə tʃɹeɪ ɡeɪv ɔf ðə smɛlz ə mʌɾən stu ən spaɪst waɪn ðət meɪd pɛɹɪnz bɛli ɹʌmbəl əɡɛn, bʌɾ i wəd nɑɾ əv steɪd tə iɾ ɪf ɪz lɛɡz hæd bɪn bɹoʊkən.

Just then Rosene bustled into the tent in a billow of icy air, her blue cloak thrown back and carrying an oval silver tray covered with a white linen cloth. Perrin snapped his mouth shut, praying she had not overheard. Smiling, Berelain seemed not to care. Setting the tray on the largest table, the stout serving woman spread her blue-and-gold-striped skirts in a deep curtsy for Berelain and another, shorter, for him. Her dark eyes lingered on him a moment, and she smiled, as pleased as her mistress, before gathering her cloak together and hurrying out again at a quick gesture from Berelain. She had overheard, all right. The tray gave off the smells of mutton stew and spiced wine that made Perrin's belly rumble again, but he would not have stayed to eat if his legs had been broken.

flɪŋɪŋ ɪz kloʊk ɝaʊn ɪz ʃoʊldɝz, hi stɔkt aʊɾ ɪndə ðə sɑf snoʊfɔl, tʌɡɪŋ ɑn ɪz ɡɔnləts. hɛvi klaʊdz ʃɹaʊɾɪd ðə sʌn, bʌt dɔn wɑz ə fju aʊɝz pæst, baɪ ðə laɪt. pæðz hæd bɪn biɾən θɹu ðə snoʊ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, jɛt ðə waɪt dʒɹɪftɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə skaɪ wɑz paɪlɪŋ ʌp ɑn bɛɹ bɹæntʃəz ən ɡɪvɪŋ ði ɛvɝɡɹinz nu koʊts. ðɪs stɔɹm wɑz fɑɹ fɹəm fɪnɪʃt. laɪt, haʊ kəd ðə wʊmən tɔk tə hɪm ðət weɪ? waɪ wəd ʃi tɔk ðət weɪ, ən naʊ?

Flinging his cloak around his shoulders, he stalked out into the soft snowfall, tugging on his gauntlets. Heavy clouds shrouded the sun, but dawn was a few hours past, by the light. Paths had been beaten through the snow on the ground, yet the white drifting out of the sky was piling up on bare branches and giving the evergreens new coats. This storm was far from finished. Light, how could the woman talk to him that way? Why would she talk that way, and now?

"ɹɪmɛmbɝ," bɹəleɪn kɔld æftɝ hɪm, meɪkɪŋ noʊ ɛfɝt tə mjuɾ əɹ vɔɪs. "dɪskɹɛʃən." wɪð ə wɪns, hi kwɪkən ɪz stɛp.

"Remember," Berelain called after him, making no effort to mute her voice. "Discretion." With a wince, he quickened his step.

ə dʌzən peɪsɪz fɹəm ðə ɡɹeɪt stʃɹaɪp tɛn i ɹilaɪzd i hæd fɝɡɑɾən tə æsk ðə loʊkeɪʃən ə mæsiməz mɛn. ɔl ɝaʊn ɪm ðə wɪŋd ɡɑɹdz wɝ wɔɹmɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz ət kæmpfaɪɝz, ɑɹmɝɾ ən kloʊkt ən nɪɹ tə ðɛɹ sæɾəld maʊns ɑn ðə hɔɹslaɪnz. ðɛɹ lænsɪz stʊd kloʊs ət hæn ɪn stil-tɪp koʊnz ðət tʃɹeɪld ɹɛd stʃɹimɝz ɪn ðə wɪnd. dɪspaɪt ðə tʃɹiz, ə stʃɹeɪt laɪn cʊɾə bɪn dʒɹɔn θɹu ɛni ɹoʊ ʌv ðoʊz faɪɝz, ən ðeɪ wɝ ivən əz nɪɹ ðə seɪm saɪz əz hjumənli pɑsəbəl. ðə səplaɪ kɑɹts ðeɪ hæɾ əkwaɪɝd kʌmɪŋ saʊθ wɝ ɔl loʊɾəd, ðə hɔɹsəz hɑɹnəst, ən ðeɪ wɝ ɝeɪɾ ɪn ɹɪdʒəd laɪnz, tu.

A dozen paces from the great striped tent he realized he had forgotten to ask the location of Masema's men. All around him the Winged Guards were warming themselves at campfires, armored and cloaked and near to their saddled mounts on the horselines. Their lances stood close at hand in steel-tipped cones that trailed red streamers in the wind. Despite the trees, a straight line could have been drawn through any row of those fires, and they were even as near the same size as humanly possible. The supply carts they had acquired coming south were all loaded, the horses harnessed, and they were arrayed in rigid lines, too.

ðə tʃɹiz dɪd nɑt haɪd ðə kɹɛst ə ðə hɪl kəmplitli. tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn stɪl stʊd ɡɑɹɾ ʌp ðɛɹ, bʌt ðə tɛns wɝ daʊn, ən i kəd meɪk aʊt loʊɾəd pækhɔɹsɪz. hi θɔɾ i sɔ ə blæk koʊt, tu; wʌn ə ði æʃəmən, ðoʊ hi kəd nɑt si wɪtʃ. əmʌŋ ðə ɡildænɪn, nɑts ə mɛn stʊd stɛɹɪŋ ʌp ðə hɪl, jɛɾ ɔl ɪn ɔl, ðeɪ əpɪɹɾ əz ɹɛɾi əz ðə minɝz. ðə tu kæmps wɝ ivən leɪɾ aʊɾ əlaɪk. bʌt noʊwɛɹ wɑz ðəɹ ɛni saɪn ðət θaʊzənz ə mɛn wɝ ɡæðɝɪŋ, noʊ bɹɔd tʃɹæmpəl pæðz ɪn ðə snoʊ tə fɑloʊ. fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, ðəɹ wɝ noʊ fʊtpɹɪns bɪtwin ðə θɹi kæmps əɾ ɔl. ɪf ənʊɹə wɑz wɪð ðə waɪz wʌnz, ʃi hæd bɪn ɑn ðə hɪl fəɹ səm taɪm. wʌt wɝ ðeɪ tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt? pɹɑbli haʊ tə kɪl mæsimə wɪθaʊɾ ɪm faɪndɪŋ aʊt ðeɪ wɝ ɹispɑnsəbəl. hi ɡlænst ət bɹəleɪnz tɛnt, bʌt ðə θɔɾ ʌv ɡoʊɪŋ bæk ɪn ðəɹ wɪð əɹ meɪɾ ɪz hækəlz ɹaɪz.

The trees did not hide the crest of the hill completely. Two Rivers men still stood guard up there, but the tents were down, and he could make out loaded packhorses. He thought he saw a black coat, too; one of the Asha'man, though he could not see which. Among the Ghealdanin, knots of men stood staring up the hill, yet all in all, they appeared as ready as the Mayeners. The two camps were even laid out alike. But nowhere was there any sign that thousands of men were gathering, no broad trampled paths in the snow to follow. For that matter, there were no footprints between the three camps at all. If Annoura was with the Wise Ones, she had been on the hill for some time. What were they talking about? Probably how to kill Masema without him finding out they were responsible. He glanced at Berelain's tent, but the thought of going back in there with her made his hackles rise.

wʌn ʌðɝ tɛn ɹɪmeɪn ʌp, nɑt fɑɹ əweɪ, ðə smɔlɝ stʃɹaɪp tɛn bɪlɔŋɪŋ tə bɹəleɪnz tu sɝvɪŋ wɪmən. dɪspaɪt ðə dʒɹɪzəlɪŋ snoʊ, ɹɑsin ən nænə sæɾ ɑn kæmp stulz ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə smɔlɝ tɛnt, kloʊkt ən hʊɾɪd ən wɔɹmɪŋ ðɛɹ hænz oʊvɝ ə smɔl faɪɝ. əlaɪk əz tu piz ɪn ðə pɑd, niðɝ wɑz pɹɪɾi, bʌt ðeɪ hæd kʌmpəni, laɪkli ðə ɹizən ðeɪ wɝ nɑt hʌɾəld ɝaʊn ə bɹeɪziɝ ɪnsaɪd. daʊtləs bɹəleɪn ɪnsɪstəɾ ɑn mɔɹ pɹəpɹaɪəɾi ɪn əɹ sɝvɪŋ wɪmən ðən ʃi mænədʒ fəɹ hɝsɛlf. nɔɹməli bɹəleɪnz θif-kætʃɝz sɛldəm sim tə spik mɔɹ ðən θɹi wɝdz təɡɛðɝ, ət list ɪn pɛɹɪnz hɪɹɪŋ, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ ænəmeɪɾəd ən læfɪŋ wɪð ɹɑsin ən nænə. pleɪnli dʒɹɛst, ðə pɛɹ wɑz soʊ nɑndɪskɹɪp jə wəd nɑt noʊɾəs wʌn bʌmpɪŋ ɪndə hɪm ɑn ðə stʃɹit. pɛɹɪn wɑz stɪl nɑt ʃʊɹ wɪtʃ wɑz sɑns ən wɪtʃ dʒɛnʒɹ. ə smɔl kɛɾəl sɛɾ ɔf tə wʌn saɪɾ ə ðə faɪɝ smɛld ə mʌɾən stu; hi tʃɹaɪd tə ɪɡnɔɹ ɪt, bʌɾ ɪz stʌmək ɡɹaʊld ɛniweɪ.

One other tent remained up, not far away, the smaller striped tent belonging to Berelain's two serving women. Despite the drizzling snow, Rosene and Nana sat on camp stools in front of the smaller tent, cloaked and hooded and warming their hands over a small fire. Alike as two peas in the pod, neither was pretty, but they had company, likely the reason they were not huddled around a brazier inside. Doubtless Berelain insisted on more propriety in her serving women than she managed for herself. Normally Berelain's thief-catchers seldom seemed to speak more than three words together, at least in Perrin's hearing, but they were animated and laughing with Rosene and Nana. Plainly dressed, the pair was so nondescript you would not notice one bumping into him on the street. Perrin was still not sure which was Santes and which Gendar. A small kettle set off to one side of the fire smelled of mutton stew; he tried to ignore it, but his stomach growled anyway.

tɔk stɑpt əz i əpɹoʊtʃt, ən bɪfɔɹ i ɹitʃt ðə faɪɝ, sɑns ən dʒɛnʒɹ ɡlæns fɹəm ɪm tə bɹəleɪnz tɛnt, feɪsəz æbsəlutli blæŋk, ðən pʊl ðɛɹ kloʊks ɝaʊn əm ən hɝiɾ əweɪ, əvɔɪɾɪŋ ɪz aɪz. ɹɑsin ən nænə lʊk fɹəm pɛɹɪn tə ðə tɛnt, ən tɪɾɝd bɪhaɪn kʌp hænz. pɛɹɪn dɪd nɑt noʊ wɛðɝ tə blʌʃ əɹ haʊl.

Talk stopped as he approached, and before he reached the fire, Santes and Gendar glanced from him to Berelain's tent, faces absolutely blank, then pulled their cloaks around them and hurried away, avoiding his eyes. Rosene and Nana looked from Perrin to the tent, and tittered behind cupped hands. Perrin did not know whether to blush or howl.

"wʊd jə baɪ ɛni tʃæns noʊ wɛɹ ðə pɹɑfəts mɛn ɑɹ ɡæðɝɪŋ?" hi æskt. kipɪŋ ɪz vɔɪs lɛvəl wɑz hɑɹd wɪð ɔl ðɛɹ ɑɹtʃt aɪbɹaʊz ən smɝks. "jɔɹ mɪstʃɹəs fɝɡɑt tə tɛl mi ɪɡzækli." ðə pɛɹ ɪkstʃeɪnʒd lʊks hɪɾən baɪ ðɛɹ hʊdz ən ɡɪɡəl bɪhaɪn ðɛɹ hænz əɡɛn. hi wʌndɝd wɛðɝ ðeɪ wɝ bɹeɪnləs, bʌɾ i daʊɾɪd bɹəleɪn wəd tɑlɝeɪt flʌf-bɹeɪnz ɝaʊn əɹ fəɹ lɔŋ.

"Would you by any chance know where the Prophet's men are gathering?" he asked. Keeping his voice level was hard with all their arched eyebrows and smirks. "Your mistress forgot to tell me exactly." The pair exchanged looks hidden by their hoods and giggled behind their hands again. He wondered whether they were brainless, but he doubted Berelain would tolerate fluff-brains around her for long.

æftɝ ə ɡɹeɪt dil ə tɪɾɝɪŋ ɪntɝspɝst wɪð kwɪk ɡlænsɪz ət hɪm, əɾ itʃ ʌðɝ, ət bɹəleɪnz tɛnt, nænə əlaʊɾ əz haʊ ʃi wɑz nɑt ɹɪli ʃʊɹ bʌt θɔɾ ɪt wɑz ðət weɪ, weɪvɪŋ ə hæn veɪɡli təwɔɹd ðə saʊθwɛst. ɹɑsin wɑz sɝɾən ʃi hæd hɝɾ əɹ mɪstʃɹəs seɪ ɪt wɑz noʊ mɔɹ ðən tu maɪlz. əɹ meɪbi θɹi. ðeɪ wɝ stɪl ɡɪɡəlɪŋ wən i stʃɹoʊɾ əweɪ. meɪbi ðeɪ ɹɪli wɝ ɡus-bɹeɪnd.

After a great deal of tittering interspersed with quick glances at him, at each other, at Berelain's tent, Nana allowed as how she was not really sure but thought it was that way, waving a hand vaguely toward the southwest. Rosene was certain she had heard her mistress say it was no more than two miles. Or maybe three. They were still giggling when he strode away. Maybe they really were goose-brained.

wɛɹəli hi tʃɹæmpt ɝaʊn ðə hɪl θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt wʌɾ i hæd tə du. ðə dɛpθ ə snoʊ hi hæd tə weɪd θɹu wʌns i lɛf ðə minɝ kæmp meɪɾ ɪz faʊl mud noʊ bɛɾɝ. nɔɹ dɪd ðə dɪsɪʒənz i ɹitʃt. ɪɾ oʊnli ɡɑt faʊlɝ æftɝ i ɝaɪvd wɛɹ ɪz oʊn pipəl wɝ kæmpt.

Wearily he tramped around the hill thinking about what he had to do. The depth of snow he had to wade through once he left the Mayener camp made his foul mood no better. Nor did the decisions he reached. It only got fouler after he arrived where his own people were camped.

ɛvɹiθɪŋ wɑz əz i hæɾ ɔɹɾɝd. kloʊkt kɛɹhinɪn sæɾ ɑn loʊɾəd kɑɹts wɪð ðə ɹeɪnz lupt ɝaʊn ə ɹɪst əɹ tʌkt ʌndɝ ə hɔntʃ, ən ʌðɝ ʃɔɹt fɪɡjɝz muvd əlɔŋ ðə lɛd laɪnz ə ɹimaʊns, suðɪŋ ðə hɔltɝd hɔɹsəz. ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn nɑɾ ɑn ðə hɪltɑp skwɑɾɪd ɝaʊn dʌzənz ə smɔl faɪɝz skæɾɝd θɹu ðə tʃɹiz, dʒɹɛs tə ɹaɪɾ ən hoʊldɪŋ ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz' ɹeɪnz. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɔɹɾɝ tə ðɛm, nɑt laɪk ðə soʊlʒɝz ɪn ði ʌðɝ kæmps, bʌt ðeɪ hæd feɪs tʃɹɑləks, ən il. ɛvɹi mæn hæɾ ɪz baʊ slʌŋ əkɹɔs ɪz bæk ən ə fʊl kwɪvɝ ɑn ɪz hɪp, səmtaɪmz bæləns baɪ ə sɔɹɾ əɹ ʃɔɹt-sɔɹɾ əz wɛl. fəɹ ə wʌndɝ, ɡɹeɪɾi wɑz ət wʌn ə ðə faɪɝz. ðə tu æʃəmən juʒəwəli kɛpt ə lɪɾəl əpɑɹt fɹəm ði ʌðɝ mɛn, ən ði ʌðɝ weɪ ɝaʊn əz wɛl. noʊ wʌn wɑz tɔkɪŋ, dʒʌs kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾɪŋ ɑn steɪɪŋ wɔɹm. ðə ɡlʌm feɪsəz toʊl pɛɹɪn ðət dʒɑndɪn hæd nɑt ɹɪtɝn jɛt, nɔɹ ɡɔl, nɔɹ ɛlaɪəs əɹ ɛnibəɾi ɛls. ðəɹ wɑz stɪl ə tʃæns ðeɪ wəd bɹɪŋ əɹ bæk. əɹ ət lis faɪnd wɛɹ ʃi wɑz hɛld. fəɹ ə taɪm, ɪt sim ðoʊz wɝ ðə læst ɡʊd θɔts i wəɾ əv fəɹ ðə deɪ. ðə ɹɛɾ iɡəl ə meɪnɛðɝən ən ɪz oʊn wʊlfzhɛd bænɝ hʌŋ lɪmp ɪn ðə fɔlɪŋ snoʊ, ɑn tu stæfs linɪŋ əɡɛnst ə kɑɹt.

Everything was as he had ordered. Cloaked Cairhienin sat on loaded carts with the reins looped around a wrist or tucked under a haunch, and other short figures moved along the lead lines of remounts, soothing the haltered horses. The Two Rivers men not on the hilltop squatted around dozens of small fires scattered through the trees, dressed to ride and holding their horses' reins. There was no order to them, not like the soldiers in the other camps, but they had faced Trollocs, and Aiel. Every man had his bow slung across his back and a full quiver on his hip, sometimes balanced by a sword or short-sword as well. For a wonder, Grady was at one of the fires. The two Asha'man usually kept a little apart from the other men, and the other way around as well. No one was talking, just concentrating on staying warm. The glum faces told Perrin that Jondyn had not returned yet, nor Gaul, nor Elyas or anybody else. There was still a chance they would bring her back. Or at least find where she was held. For a time, it seemed those were the last good thoughts he would have for the day. The Red Eagle of Manetheren and his own Wolfshead banner hung limp in the falling snow, on two staffs leaning against a cart.

hi hæd plæn tə juz ðoʊz flæɡz wɪð mæsimə ɪn ðə seɪm weɪ hi hæd tə kʌm saʊθ, haɪɾɪŋ ɪn ði oʊpən. ɪf ə mæn wɑz mæɾ ɪnʌf tə tʃɹaɪ ɹikleɪmɪŋ meɪnɛðɝənz eɪntʃənt ɡlɔɹiz, noʊ wʌn lʊk fɝðɝ, tə ɛni ʌðɝ ɹizən fəɹ ɪm mɑɹtʃɪŋ wɪð ə smɔl ɑɹmi, ən soʊ lɔŋ əz i dɪd nɑt lɪŋɡɝ, ðeɪ wɝ fɑɹ tu pliz tə si ðə mædmæn ɹaɪɾ ɑn tə tʃɹaɪ stɑpɪŋ hɪm. ðəɹ wɝ ɪnʌf tʃɹʌbəlz ɪn ðə lænd wɪθaʊt kɔlɪŋ mɔɹ daʊn ɑn jəɹ hɛd. lɛt sʌmwʌn ɛls faɪɾ ən bliɾ ən luz mɛn u wəd bi niɾəd kʌm spɹɪŋ plæntɪŋ. meɪnɛðɝənz bɔɹɾɝz hæd ɹʌn ɔlmoʊs tə wɛɹ mʊɹændi naʊ stʊd, ən wɪð lʌk, hi cʊɾə bɪn ɪndə ændɝ, wɛɹ ɹænd hæɾ ə fɝm ɡɹɪp, bɪfɔɹ hævɪŋ tə ɡɪv ʌp ðə dɪsɛpʃən. ðət wɑz tʃeɪnʒd, naʊ, ən i nu ðə pɹaɪs ə tʃeɪnʒɪŋ. ə vɛɹi lɑɹdʒ pɹaɪs. hi wɑz pɹipɛɹd tə peɪ, oʊnli ɪt wəd nɑt bi hi hu peɪd. hi wəɾ əv naɪtmɛɹz əbaʊɾ ɪt, ðoʊ.

He had planned to use those flags with Masema in the same way he had to come south, hiding in the open. If a man was mad enough to try reclaiming Manetheren's ancient glories, no one looked further, to any other reason for him marching with a small army, and so long as he did not linger, they were far too pleased to see the madman ride on to try stopping him. There were enough troubles in the land without calling more down on your head. Let someone else fight and bleed and lose men who would be needed come spring planting. Manetheren's borders had run almost to where Murandy now stood, and with luck, he could have been into Andor, where Rand had a firm grip, before having to give up the deception. That was changed, now, and he knew the price of changing. A very large price. He was prepared to pay, only it would not be he who paid. He would have nightmares about it, though.


tʃæptɝ sɪks


CHAPTER 6

ðə sɛn ə mædnəs


The Scent of Madness

sikɪŋ θɹu ðə fɔlɪŋ snoʊ fəɹ dænɪl, pɛɹɪn faʊn ɪm ət wʌn ə ðə faɪɝz ən pʊʃt bɪtwin ðə hɔɹsəz. ði ʌðɝ mɛn stʃɹeɪɾənd ən bækt əweɪ ɪnʌf tə ɡɪv ɪm ɹum. nɑt noʊɪŋ wɛðɝ tə ɔfɝ sɪmpəθi, ðeɪ bɛɹli lʊkt ət hɪm, ən dʒɝk ðɛɹ aɪz əweɪ wən ðeɪ dɪd, haɪɾɪŋ ðɛɹ feɪsəz ɪn ðɛɹ kaʊlz. "du jə noʊ wɛɹ mæsiməz pipəl ɑɹ?" hi æskt, ðən hæd tə kənsil ə jɔn bɪhaɪn ɪz hænd. hɪz bɑɾi wɑntəd slip, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ taɪm.

Seeking through the falling snow for Dannil, Perrin found him at one of the fires and pushed between the horses. The other men straightened and backed away enough to give him room. Not knowing whether to offer sympathy, they barely looked at him, and jerked their eyes away when they did, hiding their faces in their cowls. "Do you know where Masema's people are?" he asked, then had to conceal a yawn behind his hand. His body wanted sleep, but there was no time.

"əbaʊt θɹi maɪlz saʊθ ən wɛst," dænɪl ɹɪplaɪɾ ɪn ə saʊɝ vɔɪs, ən tʌɡd ɪɹɪɾəbli əɾ ɪz mʌstæʃ. soʊ ðə ɡus-bɹeɪnz hæd bɪn ɹaɪɾ æftɝ ɔl. "flɑkɪŋ ɪn laɪk dʌks ɪndə ðə wɔɾɝwʊd ɪn ɔɾəm, ən ðə lɑɾ ə ðɛm lʊk laɪk ðeɪd skɪn ðɛɹ oʊn mʌðɝz." hɔɹs-feɪs lɛm ɑldaɪ spæɾ ɪn dɪsɡʌs θɹu ðə ɡæp ɪn ɪz tiθ i hæd ɡɑɾən tʌslɪŋ wɪð ə wʊl mɝtʃəns ɡɑɹd lɔŋ əɡoʊ. lɛm laɪk tə faɪt wɪð ɪz fɪsts; hi lʊkt iɡɝ tə pɪk ə skɹæp wɪð səm ə mæsiməz fɑloʊɝz.

"About three miles south and west," Dannil replied in a sour voice, and tugged irritably at his mustache. So the goose-brains had been right after all. "Flocking in like ducks into the Waterwood in autumn, and the lot of them look like they'd skin their own mothers." Horse-faced Lem al'Dai spat in disgust through the gap in his teeth he had gotten tussling with a wool merchant's guard long ago. Lem liked to fight with his fists; he looked eager to pick a scrap with some of Masema's followers.

"ðeɪ wʊd, ɪf mæsimə sɛd tə," pɛɹɪn sɛd kwaɪətli. "bɛs jə meɪk ʃʊɹ ɛvɹibɑɾi ɹɪmɛmbɝz ðæt. juv hɝd haʊ bɹəleɪnz mɛn daɪd?" dænɪl ɡeɪv ə ʃɑɹp nɑd, ən səm ə ði ʌðɝz ʃɪftəd ðɛɹ buts ən mʌɾɝd æŋɡɹəli ʌndɝ ðɛɹ bɹɛθ. "dʒʌst soʊ jə noʊ. ðɛɹz noʊ pɹuf ʌv ɛniθɪŋ, jɛt." lɛm snɔɹɾɪd, ən ðə ɹɛs lʊkt əbaʊɾ əz blik əz dænɪl. ðeɪ hæd sin ðə kɔɹpsəz mæsiməz fɑloʊɝz lɛf bɪhaɪnd.

"They would, if Masema said to," Perrin said quietly. "Best you make sure everybody remembers that. You've heard how Berelain's men died?" Dannil gave a sharp nod, and some of the others shifted their boots and muttered angrily under their breath. "Just so you know. There's no proof of anything, yet." Lem snorted, and the rest looked about as bleak as Dannil. They had seen the corpses Masema's followers left behind.

ðə snoʊ wɑz pɪkɪŋ ʌp, fæt fleɪks ðət dɑɾəd ðə mɛnz kloʊks. ðə hɔɹsəz kɛp ðɛɹ teɪlz tʌkt ɪn əɡɛns ðə koʊld. ɪt wəd bi ə fʊl blɪzɝɾ əɡɛn ɪn ə fju aʊɝz, ɪf nɑt sunɝ. noʊ wɛðɝ tə bi livɪŋ ðə faɪɝz' wɔɹmθ. noʊ wɛðɝ tə bi ɑn ðə muv.

The snow was picking up, fat flakes that dotted the men's cloaks. The horses kept their tails tucked in against the cold. It would be a full blizzard again in a few hours, if not sooner. No weather to be leaving the fires' warmth. No weather to be on the move.

"bɹɪŋ ɛvɹibɑɾi ɔf ðə hɪl ən stɑɹt təwɔɹd wɛɹ ði æmbʊʃ wɑz," hi ɔɹɾɝd. ðət wɑz wʌn ə ðə dɪsɪʒənz i hæd meɪd, wɔkɪŋ bæk. hi hæd dɪleɪd tu lɔŋ ɔlɹɛɾi, noʊ mæɾɝ u əɹ wʌt wɑz aʊt ðɛɹ. ðə ɹɛnəɡeɪɾ il hæd tu mʌtʃ lɛɾ əz ɪt wɑz, ən ɪf ðeɪ wɝ hɛɾəd ɪn ɛni dɝɛkʃən bʌt saʊθ əɹ ist, sʌmwʌn wʊɾə bɹɔt wɝd baɪ ðɪs taɪm. baɪ ðɪs taɪm, ðeɪ wəɾ ɪkspɛkt ɪm tə bi fɑloʊɪŋ. "wil ɹaɪɾ əntɪl aɪ hæv ə bɛɾɝ aɪdiə wɛɹ wɝ hɛɾɪŋ, ðən ɡɹeɪɾi əɹ nild wɪl teɪk əs ðəɹ θɹu ə ɡeɪtweɪ. sɛn mɛn tə bɹəleɪn ən ɑɹɡændə. aɪ wɑn ðə minɝz ən ɡildænɪn muvɪŋ, tu. pʊt skaʊts aʊt, ən flæŋkɝz, ən tɛl əm nɑt tə lʊk fəɹ il soʊ hɑɹd ðeɪ fɝɡɛt ðəɹ ɑɹ ʌðɝz u maɪt wɑnə kɪl ʌs. aɪ doʊnt wɑnə stʌmbəl ɪndə ɛniθɪŋ bɪfɔɹ aɪ noʊ ɪts ðɛɹ. ən æsk ðə waɪz wʌnz tə steɪ kloʊs tə ʌs." hi wəd nɑt pʊɾ ɪt pæst ɑɹɡændə tə tʃɹaɪ pʊɾɪŋ əm tə ðə kwɛstʃən ɪn spaɪɾ ə hɪz ɔɹɾɝz. ɪf ðə waɪz wʌnz kɪl səm ə ðə ɡildænɪn dɪfɛndɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz, ðə fɛloʊ maɪt stʃɹaɪk aʊɾ ɪntaɪɝli ɑn ɪz oʊn, fiəlti əɹ noʊ. hi hæd ðə filɪŋ i wɑz gɑnə niɾ ɛvɹi faɪɾɪŋ mæn i kəd faɪnd. "bi əz fɝm əz jə dɛɹ."

"Bring everybody off the hill and start toward where the ambush was," he ordered. That was one of the decisions he had made, walking back. He had delayed too long already, no matter who or what was out there. The renegade Aiel had too much lead as it was, and if they were headed in any direction but south or east, someone would have brought word by this time. By this time, they would expect him to be following. "We'll ride until I have a better idea where we're heading, then Grady or Neald will take us there through a gateway. Send men to Berelain and Arganda. I want the Mayeners and Ghealdanin moving, too. Put scouts out, and flankers, and tell them not to look for Aiel so hard they forget there are others who might want to kill us. I don't want to stumble into anything before I know it's there. And ask the Wise Ones to stay close to us." He would not put it past Arganda to try putting them to the question in spite of his orders. If the Wise Ones killed some of the Ghealdanin defending themselves, the fellow might strike out entirely on his own, fealty or no. He had the feeling he was going to need every fighting man he could find. "Be as firm as you dare."

dænɪl tʊk ɪn ðə flʌɾ ʌv ɔɹɾɝz kɑmli, bʌɾ ət ðə læst ɪz maʊθ twɪstəɾ ɪn ə sɪkli ɡɹɪmɑs. laɪkli, hi wəɾ əz sun tʃɹaɪ tə bi fɝm wɪð ðə wɪmənz sɝkəl bæk hoʊm. "æz jə seɪ, lɔɹd pɛɹɪn," hi sɛd stɪfli, tʌtʃɪŋ ə nʌkəl tə hɪz fɔɹhɛd bɪfɔɹ i swʌŋ ɪndə hɪz haɪ-kæntəl sæɾəl ən bɪɡæn kɔlɪŋ aʊɾ ɔɹɾɝz.

Dannil took in the flood of orders calmly, but at the last his mouth twisted in a sickly grimace. Likely, he would as soon try to be firm with the Women's Circle back home. "As you say, Lord Perrin," he said stiffly, touching a knuckle to his forehead before he swung into his high-cantled saddle and began calling out orders.

sɝaʊndəd baɪ mɛn skɹæmbəlɪŋ tə maʊnt, pɛɹɪn kɑt kɛnli mɹɪnz sliv waɪl ðə jʌŋ mæn stɪl hæd wʌn fʊɾ ɪn ɪz stɝəp ən æskt ɪm tə hæv stɛpɝ sæɾəld ən bɹɔt. wɪð ə waɪd ɡɹɪn, kɛnli nʌkəld ɪz fɔɹhɛd. "æz jə seɪ, lɔɹd pɛɹɪn. ɹaɪɾ əweɪ."

Surrounded by men scrambling to mount, Perrin caught Kenly Maerin's sleeve while the young man still had one foot in his stirrup and asked him to have Stepper saddled and brought. With a wide grin, Kenly knuckled his forehead. "As you say, Lord Perrin. Right away."

pɛɹɪn ɡɹaʊld ɪnsaɪɾ ɪz hɛɾ əz kɛnli tʃɹæmp təwɔɹd ðə hɔɹslaɪnz pʊlɪŋ ɪz bɹaʊn ɡɛldɪŋ bɪhaɪnd. ðə jʌŋ wɛlp ʃəd nɑt ɡɹoʊ ə bɪɹɾ ɪf i wɑz gɑnə skɹætʃ əɾ ɪɾ ɔl ðə taɪm. ðə θɪŋ wɑz stʃɹæɡɡli, ɛniweɪ.

Perrin growled inside his head as Kenly tramped toward the horselines pulling his brown gelding behind. The young whelp should not grow a beard if he was going to scratch at it all the time. The thing was straggly, anyway.

weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ɪz hɔɹs, hi muv kloʊs tə ðə bleɪz. feɪl sɛɾ i hæd tə lɪv wɪð ɔl ðə lɔɹd pɝɹaɪnɪŋ ən boʊɪŋ ən skɹeɪpɪŋ, ən moʊst ə ðə taɪm i mænədʒ tə ɪɡnɔɹ ɪt, bʌt tədeɪ ɪt wɑz ənʌðɝ dʒɹɑp ə baɪl. hi kəd fil ə kæzəm ɡɹoʊɪŋ waɪɾɝ bɪtwin ɪm ən ði ʌðɝ mɛn fɹəm hoʊm, ən i sim tə bi ði oʊnli wʌn u wɑntəd tə bɹɪdʒ ɪt. ɡɪl faʊn ɪm mʌɾɝɪŋ tə hɪmsɛlf əz i hɛld ɪz hænz aʊt tə ðə fleɪmz.

Waiting for his horse, he moved close to the blaze. Faile said he had to live with all the Lord Perrining and bowing and scraping, and most of the time he managed to ignore it, but today it was another drop of bile. He could feel a chasm growing wider between him and the other men from home, and he seemed to be the only one who wanted to bridge it. Gill found him muttering to himself as he held his hands out to the flames.

"fɝɡɪv mi fəɹ bɑðɝɪŋ ju, maɪ lɔɹd," ɡɪl sɛd, boʊɪŋ ən bɹifli snætʃɪŋ ɔf ɪz flɑpi hæt tə ɹɪvil ə θɪnli θætʃt skælp. ðə hæt wɛn ɹaɪt bæk ɑn ɪz hɛɾ əɡɛn tə kip ɔf ðə snoʊ. sɪɾi bɹɛd, hi fɛl ðə koʊl bædli. ðə staʊt mæn wɑz nɑɾ əbsikwiəs - fju keɪɛmlɪn ɪnkipɝz wɝ - bʌɾ i sim tə ɛndʒɔɪ ə sɝɾən əmaʊn ə fɔɹmæləɾi. hi hæd sɝɾənli fɪɾəd ɪndə hɪz nu dʒɑb wɛl ɪnʌf tə pliz feɪl. "ɪts jʌŋ tɑlænvɝ. ət fɝs laɪt, hi sæɾəld ɪz hɔɹs ən wɛn ɔf. hi sɛd jə ɡeɪv ɪm pɝmɪʃən, ɪf . . . ɪf ðə sɝtʃ pɑɹɾiz hædnt ɡɑɾən bæk baɪ ðɛn, bʌɾ aɪ wʌndɝd, sɪns jə wʊdn lɛɾ ɛniwʌn ɛls ɡoʊ."

"Forgive me for bothering you, my Lord," Gill said, bowing and briefly snatching off his floppy hat to reveal a thinly thatched scalp. The hat went right back on his head again to keep off the snow. City bred, he felt the cold badly. The stout man was not obsequious - few Caemlyn innkeepers were - but he seemed to enjoy a certain amount of formality. He had certainly fitted into his new job well enough to please Faile. "It's young Tallanvor. At first light, he saddled his horse and went off. He said you gave him permission, if . . . if the search parties hadn't gotten back by then, but I wondered, since you wouldn't let anyone else go."

ðə ful. ɛvɹiθɪŋ əbaʊt tɑlænvɝ mɑɹkt ɪm ən ɪkspɪɹiənst soʊlʒɝ, ðoʊ hi hæd nɛvɝ bɪn vɛɹi klɪɹ əbaʊɾ ɪz bækɡɹaʊnd, bʌɾ əloʊn əɡɛnst il, hi wɑz ə hɛɹ tʃeɪsɪŋ wizəlz. laɪt, aɪ wɑnə bi ɹaɪɾɪŋ wɪð hɪm! aɪ ʃʊdn əv lɪsən tə bɹəleɪn əbaʊɾ æmbʊʃɪz. bʌt ðəɹ hæd bɪn ənʌðɝ æmbʊʃ. ɑɹɡændəz skaʊts maɪɾ ɛn ðə seɪm weɪ. bʌɾ i hæd tə muv. hi hæd tə.

The fool. Everything about Tallanvor marked him an experienced soldier, though he had never been very clear about his background, but alone against Aiel, he was a hare chasing weasels. Light, I want to be riding with him! I shouldn't have listened to Berelain about ambushes. But there had been another ambush. Arganda's scouts might end the same way. But he had to move. He had to.

"jɛs," hi sɛɾ əlaʊd. "aɪ toʊld ɪm i kʊd." ɪf i sɛɾ ʌðɝwaɪz, hi maɪɾ əv tə teɪk noʊɾəs leɪɾɝ. lɔɹdz hæd tə də ðət sɔɹɾ ə θɪŋ. ɪf i ɛvɝ sɔ ðə mæn əlaɪv əɡɛn. "ju saʊn əz ðoʊ jə wɑnə ɡoʊ hʌntɪŋ jɝsɛlf."

"Yes," he said aloud. "I told him he could." If he said otherwise, he might have to take notice later. Lords had to do that sort of thing. If he ever saw the man alive again. "You sound as though you want to go hunting yourself."

"aɪ æm . . . vɛɹi fɑn ə meɪaɪɡdɪn, maɪ lɔɹd," ɡɪl ɹɪplaɪd. kwaɪət dɪɡnəɾi mɑɹkt ɪz vɔɪs, ən ə dɪɡɹi ʌv stɪfnəs, əz ðoʊ pɛɹɪn hæd sɛɾ i wɑz tu oʊld ən fæt fəɹ ðə tæsk. hi sɝɾənli smɛld ə vɛkseɪʃən, ɔl pɹɪkli ən dʒɪnʒɝ, ðoʊ hɪz koʊld-ɹɛɾənd feɪs wɑz smuð. "nɑt laɪk tɑlænvɝ - nʌθɪŋ laɪk ðæt, ʌv kɔɹs - bʌt vɛɹi fɑn ɔl ðə seɪm. ən ə ðə leɪɾi feɪl, ʌv kɔɹs," hi æɾəd heɪstəli. "ɪts dʒʌs ðəɾ ɪt simz aɪv noʊn meɪaɪɡdɪn maɪ hoʊl laɪf. ʃi dɪzɝvz bɛɾɝ."

"I am . . . very fond of Maighdin, my Lord," Gill replied. Quiet dignity marked his voice, and a degree of stiffness, as though Perrin had said he was too old and fat for the task. He certainly smelled of vexation, all prickly and ginger, though his cold-reddened face was smooth. "Not like Tallanvor - nothing like that, of course - but very fond all the same. And of the Lady Faile, of course," he added hastily. "It's just that it seems I've known Maighdin my whole life. She deserves better."

pɛɹɪnz saɪ mɪstɪɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪz maʊθ. "aɪ ʌndɝstænd, mæstɝ ɡɪl." hi dɪd. hi hɪmsɛlf wɑntəd tə ɹɛskju ɛvɹiwʌn, bʌɾ i nu ɪf i hæd tə tʃuz, hi wəd teɪk feɪl ən lɛt ði ʌðɝz ɡoʊ. ɛvɹiθɪŋ kəd ɡoʊ, tə seɪv hɝ. hɔɹs-sɛnt wɑz hɛvi ɪn ði ɛɹ, bʌɾ i smɛl sʌmwʌn ɛls u wɑz ɪɹəteɪɾəd, ən lʊkt oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ.
