Perrin's sigh misted in front of his mouth. "I understand, Master Gill." He did. He himself wanted to rescue everyone, but he knew if he had to choose, he would take Faile and let the others go. Everything could go, to save her. Horse-scent was heavy in the air, but he smelled someone else who was irritated, and looked over his shoulder.

lini wɑz ɡlɛɹɪŋ əɾ ɪm fɹəm ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə tɝmɔɪl, ʃɪftɪŋ əɹ ɡɹaʊn dʒʌst ɪnʌf tə kip fɹəm biɪŋ ɹɪɾən daʊn æksədɛntəli baɪ mɛn dʒɑsəlɪŋ tə fɔɹm ɹæɡəd faɪlz. wʌn boʊni hænd ɡɹɪp ði ɛdʒ ə hɝ kloʊk, ən ði ʌðɝ hɛld ə bɹæs-stʌɾɪd kʌdʒəl, nɪɹli əz lɔŋ əz əɹ ɑɹm. ɪt wɑz ə wʌndɝ ʃi hæd nɑt ɡɔn wɪð tɑlænvɝ.

Lini was glaring at him from the middle of the turmoil, shifting her ground just enough to keep from being ridden down accidentally by men jostling to form ragged files. One bony hand gripped the edge of her cloak, and the other held a brass-studded cudgel, nearly as long as her arm. It was a wonder she had not gone with Tallanvor.

"jul hɪɹ əz sun əz aɪ du," hi pɹɑməs hɝ. ə ɹʌmbəlɪŋ ɪn ɪz mɪɾəl ɹimaɪndəɾ ɪm sʌɾənli ən fɔɹsfəli ʌv ðət stu hi hæd skɔɹnd. hi kəɾ ɔlmoʊs teɪs ðə mʌɾən ən lɛntəlz. ənʌðɝ jɔn kɹækt ɪz dʒɔz. "fɝɡɪv mi, lini," hi sɛd wən i kəd tɔk. "aɪ dɪdnt ɡɛt mʌtʃ slip læs naɪt. əɹ ə baɪt tə it. ɪz ðəɹ ɛniθɪŋ? səm bɹɛd, ən wʌtɛvɝz tə hænd?"

"You'll hear as soon as I do," he promised her. A rumbling in his middle reminded him suddenly and forcefully of that stew he had scorned. He could almost taste the mutton and lentils. Another yawn cracked his jaws. "Forgive me, Lini," he said when he could talk. "I didn't get much sleep last night. Or a bite to eat. Is there anything? Some bread, and whatever's to hand?"

"ɛvɹiwʌnz iɾən lɔŋ sɪns," ʃi snæpt. "ðə skɹæps ɑɹ ɡɔn, ən ðə kɛɾəlz klin ən stɔɹɾ əweɪ. sʌp fɹəm tu mɛni dɪʃəz, ən jə dɪzɝv ə bɛlieɪk ðæɾəl splɪt jə oʊpən. ɪspɛʃli wən ðəɹ nɑt jəɹ dɪʃəz." tʃɹeɪlɪŋ ɔf ɪndə dɪsæɾəsfaɪd mʌɾɝz, ʃi skaʊld əɾ ɪm ə moʊmən lɔŋɡɝ bɪfɔɹ stɔkɪŋ əweɪ, ɡlɛɹɪŋ ət ðə wɝld.

"Everyone's eaten long since," she snapped. "The scraps are gone, and the kettles cleaned and stored away. Sup from too many dishes, and you deserve a bellyache that'll split you open. Especially when they're not your dishes." Trailing off into dissatisfied mutters, she scowled at him a moment longer before stalking away, glaring at the world.

"tu mɛni dɪʃəz?" pɛɹɪn mʌɾɝd. "aɪ hævən hæɾ ə wʌn; ðæts maɪ tʃɹʌbəl, nɑɾ ə bɛlieɪk." lini wɑz meɪkɪŋ əɹ weɪ əkɹɔs ðə kæmpɡɹaʊnd, θɹɛɾɪŋ əɹ weɪ bɪtwin hɔɹsəz ən kɑɹts. θɹi əɹ fɔɹ mɛn spoʊk tə hɝ ɪn pæsɪŋ, ən ʃi bɑɹkt əɾ ɛvɹi wʌn, ivən ʃeɪkɪŋ əɹ kʌdʒəl ɪf ðeɪ feɪl tə teɪk ðə hɪnt. ðə wʊmən mʌs bi aʊɾ ə hɝ maɪn oʊvɝ meɪaɪɡdɪn. "ɔɹəɡən wɑz ðət wʌn ə hɝ seɪɪŋz? ðeɪ juʒəwəli meɪk mɔɹ sɛns ðən ðæt."

"Too many dishes?" Perrin muttered. "I haven't had a one; that's my trouble, not a bellyache." Lini was making her way across the campground, threading her way between horses and carts. Three or four men spoke to her in passing, and she barked at every one, even shaking her cudgel if they failed to take the hint. The woman must be out of her mind over Maighdin. "Or was that one of her sayings? They usually make more sense than that."

"ɑ . . . wɛl, əz tə ðæt, naʊ. . . ." ɡɪl snætʃt ɪz hæɾ ɔf əɡɛn ən pɪɹɾ ɪnsaɪd, ðən stʌft ɪt bæk ɑn. "aɪ . . . ɑ . . . aɪ hæv tə si tə ðə kɑɹts, maɪ lɔɹd. nid tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ɔlz ɹɛɾi."

"Ah . . . well, as to that, now. . . ." Gill snatched his hat off again and peered inside, then stuffed it back on. "I . . . ah . . . I have to see to the carts, my Lord. Need to make sure all's ready."

"ə blaɪn mæn kəd si ðə kɑɹts ɑɹ ɹɛɾi," pɛɹɪn toʊl hɪm. "wʌɾ ɪz ɪt?"

"A blind man could see the carts are ready," Perrin told him. "What is it?"

ɡɪlz hɛd swʌŋ waɪldli ɪn sɝtʃ ʌv ənʌðɝ ɪkskjus. faɪndɪŋ nʌn, hi wɪltɪd. "aɪ . . . aɪ səpoʊz jəl hɪɹ sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ," hi mʌmbəld. "ju si, maɪ lɔɹd, lini . . ." hi dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ. "ʃi wɔkt oʊvɝ tə ðə minɝ kæmp ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ, bɪfɔɹ sʌnɹaɪz, tə si haʊ jə wɝ ən . . . ɑ . . . waɪ jə hædn kʌm bæk. ðə fɝsts tɛnt wɑz dɑɹk, bʌt wʌn ə hɝ meɪdz wɑz əweɪk, ən ʃi toʊld lini . . . ʃi ɪmplaɪd . . . aɪ min tə seɪ . . . doʊn lʊk ət mi ðət weɪ, maɪ lɔɹd."

Gill's head swung wildly in search of another excuse. Finding none, he wilted. "I . . . I suppose you'll hear sooner or later," he mumbled. "You see, my Lord, Lini . . ." He drew a deep breath. "She walked over to the Mayener camp this morning, before sunrise, to see how you were and . . . ah . . . why you hadn't come back. The First's tent was dark, but one of her maids was awake, and she told Lini . . . She implied . . . I mean to say . . . Don't look at me that way, my Lord."

pɛɹɪn smuðd ðə snɑɹl fɹəm ɪz feɪs. tʃɹaɪd tə, əɾ ɛni ɹeɪt. ɪt steɪɾ ɪn ɪz vɔɪs. "bɝn mi, aɪ slɛpt ɪn ðət tɛnt, mæn. ðəɾ ɪz ɔl aɪ dɪd! jə tɛl əɹ ðæt!"

Perrin smoothed the snarl from his face. Tried to, at any rate. It stayed in his voice. "Burn me, I slept in that tent, man. That is all I did! You tell her that!"

ə vaɪələn kɑfɪŋ fɪt ɹæk ðə staʊt mæn. "mi?" ɡɪl wizd wʌns i kəd tɔk. "ju wɑn mi tə tɛl hɝ? ʃɪl kɹæk maɪ peɪɾ ɪf aɪ mɛnʃən ə θɪŋ laɪk ðæt! aɪ θɪŋk ðə wʊmən wɑz bɔɹn ɪn fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ ɪn ə θʌndɝstɔɹm. ʃi pɹɑbli toʊl ðə θʌndɝ tə bi kwaɪət. ɪt pɹɑbli dɪd."

A violent coughing fit wracked the stout man. "Me?" Gill wheezed once he could talk. "You want me to tell her? She'll crack my pate if I mention a thing like that! I think the woman was born in Far Madding in a thunderstorm. She probably told the thunder to be quiet. It probably did."

"jɔɹ ʃæmbaɪən," pɛɹɪn toʊl hɪm. "ɪt kæn ɔl bi loʊɾɪŋ kɑɹts ɪn ðə snoʊ." hi wɑntəd tə baɪt sʌmwʌn!

"You're shambayan," Perrin told him. "It can't all be loading carts in the snow." He wanted to bite someone!

ɡɪl sim tə sɛns ɪt. mʌmbəlɪŋ ɪz kɝɾəsiz, hi meɪɾ ə dʒɝki baʊ ən skɝiɾ əweɪ klʌtʃɪŋ ɪz kloʊk kloʊs. nɑt tə faɪn lini, pɛɹɪn wɑz ʃʊɹ. ɡɪl ɔɹɾɝd ðə haʊshoʊld, sətʃ əz ɪt wɑz, bʌt nɛvɝ hɝ. noʊ wʌn ɔɹɾɝd lini ɪksɛp feɪl.

Gill seemed to sense it. Mumbling his courtesies, he made a jerky bow and scurried away clutching his cloak close. Not to find Lini, Perrin was sure. Gill ordered the household, such as it was, but never her. No one ordered Lini except Faile.

ɡlʌmli pɛɹɪn wɑtʃt ðə skaʊts ɹaɪɾ aʊt θɹu ðə fɔlɪŋ snoʊ, tɛn mɛn ɔlɹɛɾi wɑtʃɪŋ ðə tʃɹiz ɝaʊn əm bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ wɝ bɪɑn saɪɾ ə ðə kɑɹts. laɪt, wɪmən wəd bɪliv ɛniθɪŋ əbaʊɾ ə mæn soʊ lɔŋ əz ɪt wɑz bæd. ən ðə wɝs ɪt wɑz, ðə mɔɹ ðeɪ hæd tə tɔk əbaʊɾ ɪt. hi hæd θɔt ɹɑsin ən nænə wɝ ɔl i hæd tə wɝi əbaʊt. laɪkli lini hæd toʊl bɹin, feɪlz ʌðɝ meɪd, fɝs θɪŋ ɑn ɡɛɾɪŋ bæk, ən baɪ ðɪs taɪm, bɹin ʃʊɹli hæd toʊld ɛvɹi wʊmən ɪn ðə kæmp. ðəɹ wɝ plɛnti əmʌŋ ðə hɔɹs hænlɝz ən kɑɹt dʒɹaɪvɝz, ən kɛɹhinɪn biɪŋ kɛɹhinɪn, ðeɪ pɹɑbli hæd bɪn iɡɝ tə pæs ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɑn tə ðə mɛn, tu. ðət sɔɹɾ ə θɪŋ wɑz nɑt sin wɪð tʃɛɹɪɾi ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. wʌns jə ɡeɪn ðə ɹɛpjəteɪʃən, luzɪŋ ɪt wɑz nɑɾ izi. sʌɾənli ðə mɛn bækɪŋ əweɪ tə ɡɪv ɪm ɹum tʊk ɑn ə nu laɪt, ən ði ənsɝɾən weɪ ðeɪ hæd lʊkt ət hɪm, ən ivən lɛm spɪɾɪŋ. ɪn mɛmɹi, kɛnliz ɡɹɪn bɪkeɪm ə smɝk. ðə wʌn bɹaɪt spɑt wɑz ðət feɪl wəd nɑt bɪliv ɪt. ʌv kɔɹs ʃi wəd nɑt. sɝɾənli nɑt.

Glumly Perrin watched the scouts ride out through the falling snow, ten men already watching the trees around them before they were beyond sight of the carts. Light, women would believe anything about a man so long as it was bad. And the worse it was, the more they had to talk about it. He had thought Rosene and Nana were all he had to worry about. Likely Lini had told Breane, Faile's other maid, first thing on getting back, and by this time, Breane surely had told every woman in the camp. There were plenty among the horse handlers and cart drivers, and Cairhienin being Cairhienin, they probably had been eager to pass everything on to the men, too. That sort of thing was not seen with charity in the Two Rivers. Once you gained the reputation, losing it was not easy. Suddenly the men backing away to give him room took on a new light, and the uncertain way they had looked at him, and even Lem spitting. In memory, Kenly's grin became a smirk. The one bright spot was that Faile would not believe it. Of course she would not. Certainly not.

kɛnli ɹɪtɝn əɾ ə stʌmbəlɪŋ tʃɹɑt θɹu ðə snoʊ, dʒɹɔɪŋ stɛpɝ ən ɪz oʊn ɹeɪnʒi ɡɛldɪŋ bɪhaɪnd. boʊθ hɔɹsəz wɝ mɪzɝəbəl wɪð ðə koʊld, ðɛɹ ɪɹz foʊldəd bæk ən teɪlz taɪt, ən ðə dʌn stæljən meɪd noʊ ɛfɝt tə baɪɾ ət kɛnliz maʊnt, əz i juʒəwəli wəd hæv.

Kenly returned at a stumbling trot through the snow, drawing Stepper and his own rangy gelding behind. Both horses were miserable with the cold, their ears folded back and tails tight, and the dun stallion made no effort to bite at Kenly's mount, as he usually would have.

"doʊnt ʃoʊ jəɹ tiθ ɔl ðə taɪm," pɛɹɪn snæpt, snætʃɪŋ stɛpɝz ɹeɪnz. ðə bɔɪ aɪɾ ɪm daʊtfəli, ðən slʌŋk əweɪ ɡlænsɪŋ bæk oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ.

"Don't show your teeth all the time," Perrin snapped, snatching Stepper's reins. The boy eyed him doubtfully, then slunk away glancing back over his shoulder.

ɡɹoʊlɪŋ ʌndɝ ɪz bɹɛθ, pɛɹɪn tʃɛk ðə stæljənz sæɾəl ɡɝθ. ɪt wɑz taɪm tə faɪn mæsimə, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt maʊnt. hi toʊl hɪmsɛlf ɪt wɑz kəz i wɑz taɪɝɾ ən hʌŋɡɹi, ðəɾ i wɑntəd dʒʌst ə bɪɾ ə ɹɛst ən sʌmθɪŋ ɪn ɪz bɛli, ɪf i kəd faɪn ɛniθɪŋ. hi toʊl hɪmsɛlf ðæt, bʌɾ i kɛp siɪŋ bɝn fɑɹmz ən bɑɾiz hæŋɪŋ baɪ ðə saɪɾ ə ðə ɹoʊd, mɛn ən wɪmən ən ivən tʃɪlʒɹən. ivən ɪf ɹænd wɑz stɪl ɪn ɔltɑɹə, ɪt wɑz ə lɔŋ weɪ. ə lɔŋ weɪ, ən i hæd noʊ tʃɔɪs. nʌn i kəd meɪk hɪmsɛlf teɪk.

Growling under his breath, Perrin checked the stallion's saddle girth. It was time to find Masema, but he did not mount. He told himself it was because he was tired and hungry, that he wanted just a bit of rest and something in his belly, if he could find anything. He told himself that, but he kept seeing burned farms and bodies hanging by the side of the road, men and women and even children. Even if Rand was still in Altara, it was a long way. A long way, and he had no choice. None he could make himself take.

hi wɑz stændɪŋ wɪð ɪz fɔɹhɛd sʌŋk əɡɛnst stɛpɝz sæɾəl wən ə dɛləɡeɪʃən ə ðə jʌŋ fulz u hæɾ ətætʃt ðɛmsɛlvz tə feɪl sɔɾ ɪm aʊt, nɪɹ ə dʌzən ə ðɛm. hi stʃɹeɪɾənd wɛɹəli, wɪʃɪŋ ðə snoʊ wəd bɛɹi ðɛm ɔl.

He was standing with his forehead sunk against Stepper's saddle when a delegation of the young fools who had attached themselves to Faile sought him out, near a dozen of them. He straightened wearily, wishing the snow would bury them all.

sɛlən plæntəd hɝsɛlf əlɔŋsaɪd stɛpɝz haɪndkɔɹɾɝz, ə ʃɔɹt slɛndɝ wʊmən wɪð ɡɹin-ɡlʌv fɪsts ɑn əɹ hɪps ən ən æŋɡɹi skaʊl kɹisɪŋ əɹ fɔɹhɛd. ʃi mænədʒ tə swæɡɝ stændɪŋ stɪl. dɪspaɪt ðə fɔlɪŋ snoʊ, wʌn saɪɾ ə hɝ kloʊk wɑz θɹoʊn bæk tə ɡɪv izi æksɛs tə hɝ sɔɹd, ɪkspoʊzɪŋ sɪks bɹaɪt slæʃɪz əkɹɔs ðə fɹʌn ə hɝ dɑɹk blu koʊt. ɔl ðə wɪmən wɔɹ mɛnz kloʊðɪŋ ən sɔɹdz, ən juʒəwəli ðeɪ wɝ twaɪs əz ɹɛɾi tə juz əm əz ðə mɛn, wɪtʃ wɑz seɪɪŋ kwaɪɾ ə bɪt. mɛn ən wɪmən əlaɪk, ðeɪ wɝ tʌtʃi wɪð ɛvɹiwʌn, ən wʊɾə bɪn faɪɾɪŋ duəlz ɛvɹi deɪ hæd nɑt feɪl pʊɾ ə stɑp tə ɪt. mɛn ən wɪmən əlaɪk, ðə lɑt wɪð sɛlən smɛld æŋɡɹi, sʌlən, sʌlki ən pɛtʃələnt, ɔl dʒʌmbəl təɡɛðɝ, ə sɛn ðət twɪtʃt ənkʌmftəbli ɪn ɪz noʊz.

Selande planted herself alongside Stepper's hindquarters, a short slender woman with green-gloved fists on her hips and an angry scowl creasing her forehead. She managed to swagger standing still. Despite the falling snow, one side of her cloak was thrown back to give easy access to her sword, exposing six bright slashes across the front of her dark blue coat. All the women wore men's clothing and swords, and usually they were twice as ready to use them as the men, which was saying quite a bit. Men and women alike, they were touchy with everyone, and would have been fighting duels every day had not Faile put a stop to it. Men and women alike, the lot with Selande smelled angry, sullen, sulky and petulant, all jumbled together, a scent that twitched uncomfortably in his nose.

"aɪ si ju, maɪ lɔɹd pɛɹɪn," sɛlən sɛd fɔɹməli ɪn ðə kɹɪsp æksɛns ə kɛɹhin. "pɹɛpɝeɪʃənz ɑɹ biɪŋ meɪd tə muv aʊt, bʌt stɪl wəɹ ɹəfjuzd əɹ hɔɹsəz. wɪl juv ðɪs meɪd ɹaɪt?" ʃi meɪɾ ɪt saʊn ə dɪmænd.

"I see you, my Lord Perrin," Selande said formally in the crisp accents of Cairhien. "Preparations are being made to move out, but still we are refused our horses. Will you have this made right?" She made it sound a demand.

ʃi sɔ hɪm, dɪd ʃi? hi wɪʃt i dɪd nɑt si hɝ. "il wɔk," hi ɡɹaʊld, ən staɪfəld ə jɔn, nɑt kɛɹɪŋ ə wɪt fəɹ ðə fjʊɹiəs ɡlɛɹz ðəɾ ɝn hɪm. hi tʃɹaɪd tə pʊt slip aʊɾ ə hɪz maɪnd. "ɪf jə woʊnt wɔk, ɹaɪɾ ɑn ðə kɑɹts."

She saw him, did she? He wished he did not see her. "Aiel walk," he growled, and stifled a yawn, not caring a whit for the furious glares that earned him. He tried to put sleep out of his mind. "If you won't walk, ride on the carts."

"ju kænɑt də ðæt!" wʌn ə ðə tɛɹən wɪmən ənaʊns hɔɾəli, wʌn hæn taɪɾ ɑn ði ɛdʒ ə hɝ kloʊk, ði ʌðɝ ɑn əɹ sɔɹd hɪlt. mɛdɔɹ wɑz tɔl, wɪð bɹaɪt blu aɪz ɪn ə dɑɹk feɪs, ən ɪf ʃi mɪs bjuɾəfəl, ɪt wɑz nɑt baɪ mʌtʃ. ðə fæt, ɹɛd-stʃɹaɪp slivz ə hɝ koʊt lʊk dɪsaɪɾədli ɑd wɪð əɹ fʊl bʊzəm. "ɹɛdwɪŋ ɪz maɪ feɪvɹɪt maʊnt! aɪ woʊn bi dɪnaɪd hɝ!"

"You cannot do that!" one of the Tairen women announced haughtily, one hand tight on the edge of her cloak, the other on her sword hilt. Medore was tall, with bright blue eyes in a dark face, and if she missed beautiful, it was not by much. The fat, red-striped sleeves of her coat looked decidedly odd with her full bosom. "Redwing is my favorite mount! I won't be denied her!"

"θɝd taɪm," sɛlən sɛd kɹɪptɪkli. "wɛn wi stɑp tənaɪt, wɪl dɪskʌs jəɹ toʊ, mɛdɔɹ dɑmɑɹə."

"Third time," Selande said cryptically. "When we stop tonight, we will discuss your toh, Medore Damara."

səpoʊzədli, mɛdɔɹz fɑðɝ wɑz ən eɪdʒɪŋ mæn u hæd ɹɪtaɪɹd tə hɪz kʌntʃɹi ɪsteɪts jɪɹz əɡoʊ, bʌɾ əstɔɹəl wɑz stɪl ə haɪ lɔɹd fəɹ ɔl ðæt. əz ðoʊz θɪŋz wɝ ɹɛkənd, ðət pʊɾ ɪz dɔɾɝ wɛl əbʌv sɛlənd, oʊnli ə maɪnɝ noʊbəl ɪn kɛɹhin. jɛt mɛdɔɹ swɑloʊd hɑɹd, ən əɹ aɪz waɪɾənd tɪl ʃi lʊkt əz ðoʊ ʃi ɪkspɛktəd tə bi skɪn əlaɪv.

Supposedly, Medore's father was an aging man who had retired to his country estates years ago, but Astoril was still a High Lord for all that. As those things were reckoned, that put his daughter well above Selande, only a minor noble in Cairhien. Yet Medore swallowed hard, and her eyes widened till she looked as though she expected to be skinned alive.

əbɹʌpli pɛɹɪn hæd hæɾ ɔl i kəd teɪk ə ðiz ɪɾiəts ən ðɛɹ dɔɡz dɪnɝ ʌv il bɪts ən pisəz ən pjʊɹ haɪbɹn dʒækfulɝi. "wɛn dɪd jə stɑɹt spaɪɪŋ fəɹ maɪ waɪf?" hi dɪmændəd. ðeɪ kəd nɑɾ əv ɡɔn stɪfɝ hæd ðɛɹ bækboʊnz fɹoʊzən.

Abruptly Perrin had had all he could take of these idiots and their dog's dinner of Aiel bits and pieces and pure highborn jacfoolery. "When did you start spying for my wife?" he demanded. They could not have gone stiffer had their backbones frozen.

"wi kæɹi aʊt sətʃ smɔl tæsks ən ɛɹənz əz ðə leɪɾi feɪl maɪt ɹikwaɪɝ ʌv əs fɹəm taɪm tə taɪm," sɛlən sɛɾ æftɝ ə lɔŋ moʊmənt, ɪn vɛɹi kɛɹfəl toʊnz. wɛɹinɪs wɑz θɪk ɪn əɹ sɛnt. ðə hoʊl ɡæɡəl ə ðɛm smɛld laɪk fɑksəz wʌndɝɪŋ wɛðɝ ə bædʒɝ hæd teɪkən oʊvɝ ðɛɹ dɛn.

"We carry out such small tasks and errands as the Lady Faile might require of us from time to time," Selande said after a long moment, in very careful tones. Wariness was thick in her scent. The whole gaggle of them smelled like foxes wondering whether a badger had taken over their den.

"dɪd maɪ waɪf ɹɪli ɡoʊ hʌntɪŋ, sɛlənd?" hi ɡɹaʊl hiɾɪdli. "ʃiz nɛvɝ wɑntəd tə bɪfɔɹ." æŋɡɝ ɹɔɹɾ ɪn hɪm, fleɪmz fæn baɪ ɔl ði ɪvɛns ə ðə deɪ. hi pʊʃt stɛpɝ əweɪ wɪð wʌn hæn ən stɛp kloʊsɝ tə ðə wʊmən, lumɪŋ oʊvɝ hɝ. ðə stæljən tɔst ɪz hɛd, sɛnsɪŋ pɛɹɪnz hjumɝ. hɪz fɪst ætʃt ɪn ɪz ɡɔnlət fɹəm ɪts ɡɹɪp ɑn ðə ɹeɪnz. "ɔɹ dɪd ʃi ɹaɪɾ aʊt tə mit səm ə ju, fɹɛʃ fɹəm ɑbilə? wɑz ʃi kɪdnæp kəz ə jəɹ blʌɾi spaɪɪŋ?"

"Did my wife really go hunting, Selande?" he growled heatedly. "She's never wanted to before." Anger roared in him, flames fanned by all the events of the day. He pushed Stepper away with one hand and stepped closer to the woman, looming over her. The stallion tossed his head, sensing Perrin's humor. His fist ached in his gauntlet from its grip on the reins. "Or did she ride out to meet some of you, fresh from Abila? Was she kidnapped because of your bloody spying?"

ðət meɪd noʊ sɛns, ən i nu ɪɾ əz ðə wɝdz lɛft ɪz maʊθ. feɪl cʊɾə tɔkt wɪð əm ɛniwɛɹ. ən ʃi wəd nɛvɝ əv ɝeɪnʒd tə miɾ əɹ aɪz-ænd-ɪɹz - laɪt, hɝ spaɪz! - ɪn kʌmpəni wɪð bɹəleɪn. ɪt wɑz ɔlweɪz ə mɪsteɪk tə spik wɪθaʊt θɪŋkɪŋ. hi nu əbaʊt mæsimə ən ðə sintʃæn kəz ə ðɛɹ spaɪɪŋ. bʌɾ i wɑntəd tə læʃ aʊt, hi niɾəd tə læʃ aʊt, ən ðə mɛn i wɑntəd tə hæmɝ ɪndə nʌθɪŋnəs wɝ maɪlz əweɪ. wɪð feɪl.

That made no sense, and he knew it as the words left his mouth. Faile could have talked with them anywhere. And she would never have arranged to meet her eyes-and-ears - Light, her spies! - in company with Berelain. It was always a mistake to speak without thinking. He knew about Masema and the Seanchan because of their spying. But he wanted to lash out, he needed to lash out, and the men he wanted to hammer into nothingness were miles away. With Faile.

sɛlən dɪd nɑt bæk əweɪ fɹəm ɪz æŋɡɝ. hɝ aɪz nɛɹoʊd tə slɪts. hɝ fɪŋɡɝz oʊpən ən kloʊzd ɑn ðə hɪlt ə hɝ sɔɹd, ən ʃi wɑz nɑɾ əloʊn. "wi wəd daɪ fəɹ ðə leɪɾi feɪl!" ʃi spæt. "nʌθɪŋ wɪv dʌn əz pʊɾ əɹ ɪn deɪnʒɝ! wəɹ swɔɹn tə hɝ baɪ wɔɾɝ oʊθ!" tə feɪl ən nɑt tə hɪm, hɝ toʊn æɾəd.

Selande did not back away from his anger. Her eyes narrowed to slits. Her fingers opened and closed on the hilt of her sword, and she was not alone. "We would die for the Lady Faile!" she spat. "Nothing we have done has put her in danger! We are sworn to her by water oath!" To Faile and not to him, her tone added.

hi ʃəɾ əpɑlədʒaɪz. hi nu hi ʃʊd. ɪnstɛd, hi sɛd, "ju kən əv jəɹ hɔɹsəz ɪf jə ɡɪmi jəɹ wɝd jəl də əz aɪ seɪ ən nɑt tʃɹaɪ ɛniθɪŋ ɹæʃ." "ɹæʃ" wɑz nɑt ðə wɝd fəɹ ðɪs lɑt. ðeɪ wɝ keɪpəbəl ə ɹʌʃɪŋ ɔf əloʊn əz sun əz ðeɪ lɝnd wɛɹ feɪl wɑz. ðeɪ wɝ keɪpəbəl ʌv ɡɛɾɪŋ feɪl kɪld. "wɛn wi faɪn hɝ, əl dɪsaɪd haʊ tə ɹɛskju hɝ. ɪf jəɹ wɔɾɝ oʊθ sɛz dɪfɹənt, taɪ ə nɑɾ ɪn ɪt, əɹ əl taɪ jə ɪn nɑts."

He should apologize. He knew he should. Instead, he said, "You can have your horses if you give me your word you'll do as I say and not try anything rash." "Rash" was not the word for this lot. They were capable of rushing off alone as soon as they learned where Faile was. They were capable of getting Faile killed. "When we find her, I will decide how to rescue her. If your water oath says different, tie a knot in it, or I'll tie you in knots."

hɝ dʒɔ taɪɾənd ən əɹ skaʊl dipənd, bʌt faɪnəli ʃi sɛd "aɪ əɡɹi!" əz ðoʊ ðə wɝdz wɝ biɪŋ pɹaɪɾ aʊɾ ə hɝ. wʌn ə ðə tɛɹənz, ə lɔŋ-noʊz fɛloʊ neɪm kɑɹlən, ɡɹʌntɪɾ ɪn pɹoʊɾɛst, bʌt sɛlən ɹeɪzd wʌn fɪŋɡɝ, ən i ʃʌɾ ɪz maʊθ. wɪð ðət nɛɹoʊ tʃɪn, hi pɹɑbli ɹɪɡɹɛɾɪd ʃeɪvɪŋ ɔf ɪz bɪɹd. ðə lɪɾəl wʊmən hæd ðə ɹɛst ə ðiz fulz ɪn ðə pɑm ə hɝ hænd, wɪtʃ dɪd nɑt meɪk əɹ ɛni lɛs ə ful hɝsɛlf. wɔɾɝ oʊθ, ɪndid! ʃi dɪd nɑt teɪk əɹ aɪz fɹəm pɛɹɪnz. "wi wɪl oʊbeɪ jə əntɪl ðə leɪɾi feɪl ɪz ɹɪtɝnd. ðɛn, wəɹ hɝz əɡɛn. ən ʃi kən dɪsaɪɾ əɹ toʊ." ðət læst simd mɔɹ fəɹ ði ʌðɝz ðən hɪm.

Her jaw tightened and her scowl deepened, but finally she said "I agree!" as though the words were being pried out of her. One of the Tairens, a long-nosed fellow named Carlon, grunted in protest, but Selande raised one finger, and he shut his mouth. With that narrow chin, he probably regretted shaving off his beard. The little woman had the rest of these fools in the palm of her hand, which did not make her any less a fool herself. Water oath, indeed! She did not take her eyes from Perrin's. "We will obey you until the Lady Faile is returned. Then, we are hers again. And she can decide our toh." That last seemed more for the others than him.

"ɡʊɾ ɪnʌf," hi toʊl hɝ. hi ətɛmptəd tə mɑɾɝeɪt ɪz toʊn, bʌɾ ɪz vɔɪs wɑz stɪl ɹʌf. "aɪ noʊ jə ɑɹ lɔɪəl tə hɝ, ɔl ə ju. aɪ ɹɪspɛk ðæt." ðət wɑz əbaʊɾ ɔl i dɪd ɹɪspɛkt ɪn ðɛm. əz ən əpɑlədʒi ɪt wɑz nɑt vɛɹi mʌtʃ, ən ðət wɑz dʒʌs haʊ ðeɪ tʊk ɪt. ə ɡɹʌn fɹəm sɛlənd wɑz ði oʊnli ɹɪplaɪ hi ɡɑt, ðəɾ ən ɡlaʊɝz fɹəm ðə ɹɛst əz ðeɪ stɔkt ɔf. soʊ bi ɪt. əz lɔŋ əz ðeɪ kɛp ðɛɹ wɝd. ðə hoʊl bʌntʃ hæd nɛvɝ dʌn ən ɑnəs deɪz wɝk bɪtwin ðɛm.

"Good enough," he told her. He attempted to moderate his tone, but his voice was still rough. "I know you are loyal to her, all of you. I respect that." That was about all he did respect in them. As an apology it was not very much, and that was just how they took it. A grunt from Selande was the only reply he got, that and glowers from the rest as they stalked off. So be it. As long as they kept their word. The whole bunch had never done an honest day's work between them.

ðə kæmp wɑz ɛmptiɪŋ aʊt. ðə kɑɹts hæd bɪɡʌn muvɪŋ saʊθ, slaɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðɛɹ slɛdz bɪhaɪn ðə kɑɹθɔɹsɪz. ðə hɔɹsəz lɛf dip tʃɹæks, bʌt ðə slɛdz meɪɾ oʊnli ʃæloʊ ɹʌts ðət ðə fɔlɪŋ snoʊ bɪɡæn tə bɛɹi ɪmiɾiətli. ðə læst ə ðə mɛn fɹəm ðə hɪl wɝ skɹæmbəlɪŋ ɪndə ðɛɹ sæɾəlz ən dʒɔɪnɪŋ ði ʌðɝz ɔlɹɛɾi ɹaɪɾɪŋ wɪð ðə kɑɹts. dʒʌst ɔf tə wʌn saɪd, ðə waɪz wʌnz' pɑɹɾi bɪɡæn tə pæs, ivən ðə ɡeɪʃeɪn liɾɪŋ ðə pæk ænəməlz ðɛmsɛlvz maʊntəd. haʊɛvɝ fɝm dænɪl hæd dɛɹd tə bi, əɹ nɑɾ əz wɑz mɔɹ laɪkli, əpɛɹənli ɪt hæd bɪn ɪnʌf. ðə waɪz wʌnz lʊk pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli ɑkwɝɾ ɑn hɔɹsbæk kəmpɛɹd tə ðə ɡɹeɪs ə siɑnɪɾ ən mɑsʊɝi, ðoʊ nɑt soʊ bæɾ əz ðə ɡeɪʃeɪn. ðə waɪt-ɹoʊb mɛn ən wɪmən hæɾ ɔl bɪn ɹaɪɾɪŋ sɪns ðə θɝd deɪ ɪn snoʊ, jɛt ðeɪ kɹaʊtʃt loʊ oʊvɝ ðə tɔl pɑməlz ə ðɛɹ sæɾəlz ən klʌŋ tə nɛk əɹ meɪn əz ɪf ɪkspɛktɪŋ tə fɔl ɔf ət ðə nɛkst stɛp. ɡɛɾɪŋ əm maʊntəɾ ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs hæd ɹikwaɪɝd dɝɛkt kəmænz fɹəm ðə waɪz wʌnz, ən səm wəd stɪl slaɪd daʊn ən wɔk ɪf ðeɪ wɝ nɑt wɑtʃt.

The camp was emptying out. The carts had begun moving south, sliding on their sleds behind the carthorses. The horses left deep tracks, but the sleds made only shallow ruts that the falling snow began to bury immediately. The last of the men from the hill were scrambling into their saddles and joining the others already riding with the carts. Just off to one side, the Wise Ones' party began to pass, even the gai'shain leading the pack animals themselves mounted. However firm Dannil had dared to be, or not as was more likely, apparently it had been enough. The Wise Ones looked particularly awkward on horseback compared to the grace of Seonid and Masuri, though not so bad as the gai'shain. The white-robed men and women had all been riding since the third day in snow, yet they crouched low over the tall pommels of their saddles and clung to neck or mane as if expecting to fall off at the next step. Getting them mounted in the first place had required direct commands from the Wise Ones, and some would still slide down and walk if they were not watched.

pɛɹɪn pʊl hɪmsɛlf ʌp ɑntu stɛpɝ. hi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ i maɪt nɑt fɔl ɔf hɪmsɛlf. ɪt wɑz taɪm tə meɪk ðɪs ɹaɪɾ i dɪd nɑt wɑnə meɪk, ðoʊ. hi wʊɾə kɪl fəɹ ə pis ə bɹɛd. əɹ səm tʃiz. əɹ ə naɪs ɹæbət.

Perrin pulled himself up onto Stepper. He was not sure he might not fall off himself. It was time to make this ride he did not want to make, though. He would have killed for a piece of bread. Or some cheese. Or a nice rabbit.

"il kʌmɪŋ!" sʌmwʌn ʃaʊɾəd fɹəm ðə hɛɾ ə ðə kɑləm, ən ɛvɹiθɪŋ keɪm tə ə hɔlt. mɔɹ ʃaʊts ɹæŋ aʊt, pæsɪŋ ðə wɝɾ əz ɪf ɛvɹiwʌn hæd nɑɾ ɔlɹɛɾi hɝd, ən mɛn ənlɪmbɝd baʊz fɹəm ðɛɹ bæks. kɑɹt dʒɹaɪvɝz stʊɾ ʌp ɑn ðɛɹ sits, piɹɪŋ əhɛd, əɹ lɛp daʊn tə kɹaʊtʃ bɪsaɪd ðə kɑɹt. ɡɹoʊlɪŋ ʌndɝ ɪz bɹɛθ, pɛɹɪn hil stɛpɝ ɪn ðə flæŋks.

"Aiel coming!" someone shouted from the head of the column, and everything came to a halt. More shouts rang out, passing the word as if everyone had not already heard, and men unlimbered bows from their backs. Cart drivers stood up on their seats, peering ahead, or leaped down to crouch beside the cart. Growling under his breath, Perrin heeled Stepper in the flanks.

ət ðə fɹʌn ə ðə kɑləm, dænɪl wɑz stɪl ɪn ɪz sæɾəl, ən ðə tu mɛn kæɹiɪŋ ðoʊz blʌɾi bænɝz, bʌɾ ə ɡʊd θɝɾi wɝ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, kʌvɝɪŋz stʃɹɪp fɹəm ðɛɹ bɑstʃɹɪŋz ən æɹoʊz nɑkt. ðə mɛn hoʊldɪŋ ðə hɔɹsəz fəɹ ðə dɪsmaʊntɪd mɛn dʒɑsəld əbaʊt, pɔɪntɪŋ ən tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɡɛɾ ə klɪɹ vju. ɡɹeɪɾi ən nild wɝ ðɛɹ, əz wɛl, piɹɪŋ əhɛd wɪð ɪntɛn feɪsəz bʌt sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz kɑmli. ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls ɹikt ʌv ædʒəteɪʃən. ði æʃəmən oʊnli smɛld . . . ɹɛɾi.

At the front of the column, Dannil was still in his saddle, and the two men carrying those bloody banners, but a good thirty were on the ground, coverings stripped from their bowstrings and arrows nocked. The men holding the horses for the dismounted men jostled about, pointing and trying to get a clear view. Grady and Neald were there, as well, peering ahead with intent faces but sitting on their horses calmly. Everyone else reeked of agitation. The Asha'man only smelled . . . ready.

pɛɹɪn kəd meɪk aʊt wʌt ðeɪ wɝ stɛɹɪŋ ət θɹu ðə tʃɹiz ə ɡʊd dil mɔɹ klɪɹli ðən ðeɪ. tɛn veɪld il tʃɹɑɾɪŋ təwɔɹɾ əm θɹu ðə fɔlɪŋ snoʊ, wʌn liɾɪŋ ə tɔl waɪt hɔɹs. ə lɪɾəl bɪhaɪn əm ɹoʊd θɹi mɛn, kloʊkt ən hʊɾɪd. ðəɹ sim tə bi sʌmθɪŋ ɑɾ ɪn ðə weɪ ði il muvd. ən ðəɹ wɑz ə bʌndəl taɪd tə ðə waɪts sæɾəl. ə fɪst ɡɹɪpt pɛɹɪnz hɑɹɾ əntɪl i ɹilaɪzd ɪt wɑz nɑt nɪɹli lɑɹdʒ ɪnʌf tə bi ə bɑɾi.

Perrin could make out what they were staring at through the trees a good deal more clearly than they. Ten veiled Aiel trotting toward them through the falling snow, one leading a tall white horse. A little behind them rode three men, cloaked and hooded. There seemed to be something odd in the way the Aiel moved. And there was a bundle tied to the white's saddle. A fist gripped Perrin's heart until he realized it was not nearly large enough to be a body.

"pʊɾ ʌp jəɹ baʊz," hi sɛd. "ðæts æliændɝz ɡɛldɪŋ. ɪt mʌs bi əɹ pipəl. kæn jə si ði il ɑɹ ɔl meɪɾənz?" nɑɾ ə wʌn wɑz tɔl ɪnʌf tə bi ən ilmən.

"Put up your bows," he said. "That's Alliandre's gelding. It must be our people. Can't you see the Aiel are all Maidens?" Not a one was tall enough to be an Aielman.

"aɪ kən bɛɹli meɪk aʊt ðəɹ il," dænɪl mʌɾɝd, ɡɪvɪŋ ɪm ə saɪɾɛlɔŋ lʊk. ðeɪ ɔl tʊk ɪt fəɹ ɡɹæntəd ðəɾ ɪz aɪz wɝ ɡʊd, ivən tʊk pɹaɪɾ ɪn ɪt - əɹ juz tə - bʌɾ i tʃɹaɪd tə kip əm fɹəm noʊɪŋ haʊ ɡʊd. ɹaɪt ðɛn, hi dɪd nɑt kɛɹ, ðoʊ.

"I can barely make out they're Aiel," Dannil muttered, giving him a sidelong look. They all took it for granted that his eyes were good, even took pride in it - or used to - but he tried to keep them from knowing how good. Right then, he did not care, though.

"ðeɪ ɑɹ aʊɝz," hi toʊl dænɪl. "ɛvɹibɑɾi steɪ hɪɹ."

"They are ours," he told Dannil. "Everybody stay here."

sloʊli hi ɹoʊɾ aʊt tə mit ðə ɹɪtɝnɪŋ pɑɹɾi. ðə meɪɾənz bɪɡæn ənveɪlɪŋ əz i əpɹoʊtʃt. ɪn wʌn ə ðə dip kaʊlz ɑn ðə maʊntəd mɛn, hi meɪɾ aʊt fʊɹən ælhæɹəz blæk feɪs. ðə θɹi wɔɹɾɝz, ðɛn; ðeɪ wʊɾə kʌm bæk tɑɡðɝ. ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz lʊkt əz taɪɝɾ əz i fɛlt, nɪɹ ɪɡzɔstʃən. hi wɑntəd tə fɔɹs stɛpɝ tə ɹʌn, tə hɪɹ wʌt ðeɪ hæd tə ɹipɔɹt. hi dʒɹɛɾɪd hɪɹɪŋ. ɹeɪvənz wʊɾə bɪn ət ðə bɑɾiz, ən fɑksəz, bædʒɝz meɪbi, ən ðə laɪɾ əloʊn nu wʌt bɪsaɪdz. meɪbi ðeɪ θɔt ðeɪ wɝ spɛɹɪŋ ɪm baɪ nɑt bɹɪŋɪŋ bæk wʌt ðeɪ hæd faʊnd. noʊ! feɪl hæd tə bi əlaɪv. hi tʃɹaɪd tə fɪks ðət θɔɾ ɪn ɪz hɛd, bʌɾ ɪt hɝt laɪk ɡɹɪpɪŋ ə ʃɑɹp bleɪd bæɹhændɪd.

Slowly he rode out to meet the returning party. The Maidens began unveiling as he approached. In one of the deep cowls on the mounted men, he made out Furen Alharra's black face. The three Warders, then; they would have come back togther. Their horses looked as tired as he felt, near exhaustion. He wanted to force Stepper to run, to hear what they had to report. He dreaded hearing. Ravens would have been at the bodies, and foxes, badgers maybe, and the Light alone knew what besides. Maybe they thought they were sparing him by not bringing back what they had found. No! Faile had to be alive. He tried to fix that thought in his head, but it hurt like gripping a sharp blade barehanded.

dɪsmaʊntɪŋ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðɛm, hi stʌmbəld ən hæd tə hoʊld ɑn tə ðə sæɾəl tə kip fɹəm fɔlɪŋ. hi fɛl nʌm ɝaʊn ðə bɹaɪt peɪn ə hoʊldɪŋ ɑn tə ðət wʌn θɔt. ʃi hæd tə bi əlaɪv. lɪɾəl dɪteɪlz lum lɑɹdʒ, fəɹ səm ɹizən. nɑt wʌn bʌndəl fæsən tə ði ɪlæbɹətli tul sæɾəl, bʌɾ ə nʌmbɝ ə smɔl bʌndəlz ðət lʊk laɪk ɡæðɝd ɹæɡz. ðə meɪɾənz wɔɹ snoʊʃuz, ɹʌf-meɪɾ ə vaɪnz ən sʌpəl paɪn bɹæntʃəz wɪð ðə niɾəlz stɪl ɑn. ðət wɑz waɪ ðeɪ sim tə bi muvɪŋ ɑdli. dʒɑndɪn mʌst əv ʃoʊn əm haʊ tə meɪk ðɛm. hi tʃɹaɪd tə foʊkəs. hi θɔɾ ɪz hɑɹt wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ tə paʊn θɹu hɪz ɹɪbz.

Dismounting in front of them, he stumbled and had to hold on to the saddle to keep from falling. He felt numb around the bright pain of holding on to that one thought. She had to be alive. Little details loomed large, for some reason. Not one bundle fastened to the elaborately tooled saddle, but a number of small bundles that looked like gathered rags. The Maidens wore snowshoes, rough-made of vines and supple pine branches with the needles still on. That was why they seemed to be moving oddly. Jondyn must have shown them how to make them. He tried to focus. He thought his heart was going to pound through his ribs.

ɡɹɪpɪŋ spɪɹz ən bʌkəlɝ ɪn əɹ lɛf hænd, səlɪn tʊk wʌn ə ðə smɔl bʌndəlz ə klɔθ fɹəm ðə sæɾəl bɪfɔɹ ʃi keɪm tə hɪm. ðə pɪŋk skɑɹ ɹʌnɪŋ daʊn əɹ lɛðɝi tʃik twɪstəɾ əz ʃi smaɪld. "ɡʊd nuz, pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə," ʃi sɛd sɔfli, hændɪŋ ɪm ðə dɑɹk blu klɔθ. "jɔɹ waɪf laɪvz." ælhæɹə ɪkstʃeɪnʒd ɡlænsɪz wɪð siɑnɪdz ʌðɝ wɔɹɾɝ, tɛɹəl wɪntɝ, hu fɹaʊnd. mɑsʊɝiz mæn, ɹoʊvɛɹ kɝklɪn, stɛɹd stʃɹeɪɾ əhɛd stɑnəli. ɪt wɑz əz pleɪn əz wɪntɝz kɝl mʌstæʃɪz ðət ðeɪ wɝ nɑt ʃʊɹ ɪt wɑz ɡʊd nuz. "ði ʌðɝz pɹɛs ɑn tə si wʌt mɔɹ ðeɪ kən faɪnd," ʃi wɛn ɑn. "ðoʊ wi ɔlɹɛɾi hæv faʊn ɑɾətiz ɪnʌf."

Gripping spears and buckler in her left hand, Sulin took one of the small bundles of cloth from the saddle before she came to him. The pink scar running down her leathery cheek twisted as she smiled. "Good news, Perrin Aybara," she said softly, handing him the dark blue cloth. "Your wife lives." Alharra exchanged glances with Seonid's other Warder, Teryl Wynter, who frowned. Masuri's man, Rovair Kirklin, stared straight ahead stonily. It was as plain as Wynter's curled mustaches that they were not sure it was good news. "The others press on to see what more they can find," she went on. "Though we already have found oddities enough."

pɛɹɪn lɛt ðə bʌndəl fɔl oʊpən ɪn ɪz hænz. ɪt wɑz feɪlz dʒɹɛs, slaɪs daʊn ðə fɹʌn ən əlɔŋ ði ɑɹmz. hi ɪnheɪl dipli, pʊlɪŋ feɪlz sɛn ɪndə hɪm, ə feɪn tʃɹeɪs ə hɝ flaʊɝi soʊp, ə tʌtʃ ə hɝ swit pɝfjum, bʌt moʊst ʌv ɔl, ðə smɛl ðət wɑz hɝ. ən noʊ hɪn ə blʌd. ðə ɹɛst ə ðə meɪɾənz ɡæðɝɾ ɝaʊn hɪm, moʊsli oʊldɝ wɪmən wɪð hɑɹd feɪsəz, ðoʊ nɑɾ əz hɑɹɾ əz səlɪnz. ðə wɔɹɾɝz klaɪm daʊn, ʃoʊɪŋ noʊ saɪn ðət ðeɪ hæd bɪn ɔl naɪɾ ɪn ðə sæɾəl, bʌt ðeɪ hɛl bæk bɪhaɪn ðə meɪɾənz.

Perrin let the bundle fall open in his hands. It was Faile's dress, sliced down the front and along the arms. He inhaled deeply, pulling Faile's scent into him, a faint trace of her flowery soap, a touch of her sweet perfume, but most of all, the smell that was her. And no hint of blood. The rest of the Maidens gathered around him, mostly older women with hard faces, though not as hard as Sulin's. The Warders climbed down, showing no sign that they had been all night in the saddle, but they held back behind the Maidens.

"ɔl ə ðə mɛn wɝ kɪld," ðə wɪɹi wʊmən sɛd, "bʌt baɪ ðə ɡɑɹməns wi faʊnd, æliændɝ kɪɡɑɝɪn, meɪaɪɡdɪn dɔɹleɪn, lətʃəl ɑldɔɹwɪn, ɹɛlə ʃiɡoʊ, ən tu mɔɹ ɔlsoʊ wɝ meɪd ɡeɪʃeɪn." ði ʌðɝ tu mʌst əv bɪn beɪn ən kiæd; mɛnʃənɪŋ əm baɪ neɪm, ðət ðeɪ hæd bɪn teɪkən, wʊɾə ʃeɪm ðɛm. hi hæd lɝn ə lɪɾəl əbaʊɾ il. "ðɪs ɡoʊz əɡɛns kʌstəm, bʌɾ ɪt pɹətɛks ðɛm." wɪntɝ fɹaʊn ɪn daʊt, ðən tʃɹaɪd tə haɪɾ ɪt baɪ ədʒʌstɪŋ ɪz hʊd.

"All of the men were killed," the wiry woman said, "but by the garments we found, Alliandre Kigarin, Maighdin Dorlain, Lacile Aldorwin, Arrela Shiego, and two more also were made gai'shain." The other two must have been Bain and Chiad; mentioning them by name, that they had been taken, would have shamed them. He had learned a little about Aiel. "This goes against custom, but it protects them." Wynter frowned in doubt, then tried to hide it by adjusting his hood.

ðə nit kʌts wɝ laɪk ðoʊz meɪd skɪnɪŋ ən ænəməl. ɪt hɪt pɛɹɪn sʌɾənli. sʌmwʌn hæd kʌt feɪlz kloʊðz ɔf! hɪz vɔɪs ʃʊk. "ðeɪ oʊnli tʊk wɪmən?"

The neat cuts were like those made skinning an animal. It hit Perrin suddenly. Someone had cut Faile's clothes off! His voice shook. "They only took women?"

ə ɹaʊnd-feɪs jʌŋ meɪɾən neɪm bɹieɪn ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "θɹi mɛn wʊɾə bɪn meɪd ɡeɪʃeɪn, aɪ θɪŋk, bʌt ðeɪ fɔt tu hɑɹɾ ən wɝ kɪld wɪð naɪf əɹ spɪɹ. ɔl ðə ɹɛs daɪd baɪ æɹoʊ."

A round-faced young Maiden named Briain shook her head. "Three men would have been made gai'shain, I think, but they fought too hard and were killed with knife or spear. All the rest died by arrow."

"ɪɾ ɪz nɑt laɪk ðæt, pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə," ɛləəndə sɛd hɝidli, saʊndɪŋ ʃɑkt. ə tɔl wʊmən wɪð waɪd ʃoʊldɝz, ʃi mænədʒ tə lʊk ɔlmoʊs mʌðɝli, ðoʊ hi hæd sin əɹ nɑk ə mæn daʊn wɪð əɹ fɪst. "hɑɹmɪŋ ə ɡeɪʃeɪn ɪz laɪk hɑɹmɪŋ ə tʃaɪld, əɹ ə blæksmɪθ. ɪt wɑz ɹɔŋ tə teɪk wɛtləndɝz, bʌɾ aɪ kænɑt bɪliv ðəl bɹeɪk kʌstəm ðət fɑɹ. aɪm ʃʊɹ ðəl nɑɾ ivən bi pʌnɪʃt, ɪf ðeɪ kən bi mik əntɪl ðeɪ ɑɹ ɹəkʌvɝd. ðəɹ ɑɹ ʌðɝz u wɪl ʃoʊ ðɛm." ʌðɝz; beɪn ən kiæɾ əɡɛn.

"It is not like that, Perrin Aybara," Elienda said hurriedly, sounding shocked. A tall woman with wide shoulders, she managed to look almost motherly, though he had seen her knock a man down with her fist. "Harming a gai'shain is like harming a child, or a blacksmith. It was wrong to take wetlanders, but I cannot believe they will break custom that far. I am sure they will not even be punished, if they can be meek until they are recovered. There are others who will show them." Others; Bain and Chiad again.

"wʌt dɝɛkʃən dɪd ðeɪ ɡoʊ?" hi æskt. kəd feɪl bi mik? hi kəd nɑt pɪktʃɝ əɹ ðət weɪ. ət lis lɛɾ əɹ tʃɹaɪ, tɪl i kəd faɪn hɝ.

"What direction did they go?" he asked. Could Faile be meek? He could not picture her that way. At least let her try, till he could find her.

"ɔlmoʊst saʊθ," səlɪn ɹɪplaɪd. "mʌtʃ nɪɹɝ saʊθ ðən ist. æftɝ ðə snoʊ hɪd ðɛɹ tʃɹæks, dʒɑndɪn bæɹən sɔ ʌðɝ tʃɹeɪsəz. wʌt ði ʌðɝz ɑɹ fɑloʊɪŋ. aɪ bɪliv hɪm. hi siz əz mʌtʃ əz ɛlaɪəs mækɛɹə. ðəɹ ɪz mʌtʃ tə si." θɹʌstɪŋ əɹ spɪɹz bɪhaɪn ðə baʊ keɪs ɑn əɹ bæk, ʃi hʌŋ əɹ bʌkəlɝ fɹəm ðə hɪlt ə hɝ hɛvi bɛl naɪf. hɝ fɪŋɡɝz flæʃt hæntɔk, ən ɛləəndə ənfæsən ə sɛkənd, lɑɹdʒɝ bʌndəl ən hændəɾ ɪt tə hɝ. "mɛni pipəl ɑɹ muvɪŋ aʊt ðɛɹ, pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə, ən stʃɹeɪnʒ θɪŋz. ðɪs jə mʌst si fɝst, aɪ θɪŋk." səlɪn ənfoʊldəɾ ənʌðɝ kʌt dʒɹɛs, ðɪs wʌn ɡɹin. hi θɔɾ i ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ ɪɾ ɑn æliændɝ. "ðiz, wi ɹəkʌvɝd wɛɹ jəɹ waɪf wɑz teɪkən." ɪnsaɪd, fɔɹɾi əɹ fɪfti il æɹoʊz ʃɪftəɾ ɪn ə hip. ðəɹ wɝ dɑɹk steɪnz ɑn ðə ʃæfs, ən i kɑt ðə sɛn ə dʒɹaɪd blʌd.

"Almost south," Sulin replied. "Much nearer south than east. After the snow hid their tracks, Jondyn Barran saw other traces. What the others are following. I believe him. He sees as much as Elyas Machera. There is much to see." Thrusting her spears behind the bow case on her back, she hung her buckler from the hilt of her heavy belt knife. Her fingers flashed handtalk, and Elienda unfastened a second, larger bundle and handed it to her. "Many people are moving out there, Perrin Aybara, and strange things. This you must see first, I think." Sulin unfolded another cut dress, this one green. He thought he remembered it on Alliandre. "These, we recovered where your wife was taken." Inside, forty or fifty Aiel arrows shifted in a heap. There were dark stains on the shafts, and he caught the scent of dried blood.

"tɑɹdæd," səlɪn sɛd, pɪkɪŋ aʊɾ ən æɹoʊ ən ɪmiɾiətli θɹoʊɪŋ ɪt tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd. "maɪæɡoʊmə." ʃi tɔs tu mɔɹ əsaɪd. "ɡoʊʃin." ðoʊz bɹɔɾ ə ɡɹɪmɑs tə hɝ feɪs; ʃi wɑz ɡoʊʃin. klæn baɪ klæn, ʃi neɪmd əm ɔl ɪksɛp ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ, dʒɹɑpɪŋ æɹoʊz əntɪl dʒʌst oʊvɝ hæf leɪ skæɾɝd ɝaʊn hɝ. ʃi hɛld ʌp ðə kʌt dʒɹɛs hoʊldɪŋ ðə ɹɪmeɪndɝ ɪn boʊθ hænz, ðən spɪl ðɛm. "ʃeɪɾoʊ," ʃi sɛd sɪɡnɪfɪkənli.

"Taardad," Sulin said, picking out an arrow and immediately throwing it to the ground. "Miagoma." She tossed two more aside. "Goshien." Those brought a grimace to her face; she was Goshien. Clan by clan, she named them all except the Shaido, dropping arrows until just over half lay scattered around her. She held up the cut dress holding the remainder in both hands, then spilled them. "Shaido," she said significantly.

klʌtʃɪŋ feɪlz dʒɹɛs tə hɪz tʃɛst - hɝ sɛn iz ðə peɪn ɪn ɪz hɑɹt, ən meɪɾ ɪt wɝs ət ðə seɪm taɪm - pɛɹɪn fɹaʊn ət ði æɹoʊz dʒʌmbəld ɑn ðə snoʊ. ɔlɹɛɾi, səm wɝ hæf bɛɹiɾ ɪn ðə fɹɛʃ fɔl. "tu mɛni ʃeɪɾoʊ," hi sɛɾ ət læst. ðeɪ ʃəɾ ɔl bi bɑɾəld ʌp ɪn kɪnsleɪɝz dæɡɝ, faɪv hʌnʒɹəd liɡz dɪstənt. bʌɾ ɪf səm ə ðɛɹ waɪz wʌnz hæd lɝn tə tʃɹævəl . . . meɪbi ivən wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən . . . laɪt, hi wɑz ɹæmblɪŋ laɪk ə ful - wʌt wəd ðə fɔɹseɪkən əv tə də wɪð ðɪs? - ɹæmblɪŋ wən i hæd tə θɪŋk. hɪz bɹeɪn fɛlt əz wɪɹi əz ðə ɹɛst ə hɪm. "ði ʌðɝz ɑɹ mɛn u wʊdn æksɛpt ɹænd əz ðə kɑɹəkɑɹn." ðoʊz kɝs kʌlɝz flæʃt ɪn ɪz hɛd. hi hæd noʊ taɪm fəɹ ɛniθɪŋ bʌt feɪl. "ðeɪ dʒɔɪn ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ." səm ə ðə meɪɾənz əvɝɾəd ðɛɹ aɪz. ɛləəndə ɡlɛɹɾ ət hɪm. ðeɪ nu ðət səm hæd dʌn wʌɾ i sɛd, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz wʌn ə ðoʊz θɪŋz ðeɪ dɪd nɑt laɪk tə hɪɹ sɛɾ əlaʊd. "haʊ mɛni ɔltəɡɛðɝ, dʒju ɹɛkən? nɑt ðə hoʊl klæn, ʃʊɹli?" ɪf ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ wɝ hɪɹ ɪn ə bɑɾi, ðəɹ wəd bi mɔɹ ðən ɹumɝz ə dɪstən ɹeɪdz. ivən əmʌŋ ɔl ði ʌðɝ tʃɹʌbəlz, ɔl ʌv ɑmɑdɪʃiə wəd noʊ.

Clutching Faile's dress to his chest - her scent eased the pain in his heart, and made it worse at the same time - Perrin frowned at the arrows jumbled on the snow. Already, some were half buried in the fresh fall. "Too many Shaido," he said at last. They should all be bottled up in Kinslayer's Dagger, five hundred leagues distant. But if some of their Wise Ones had learned to Travel . . . Maybe even one of the Forsaken . . . Light, he was rambling like a fool - what would the Forsaken have to do with this? - rambling when he had to think. His brain felt as weary as the rest of him. "The others are men who wouldn't accept Rand as the car'a'carn." Those cursed colors flashed in his head. He had no time for anything but Faile. "They joined the Shaido." Some of the Maidens averted their eyes. Elienda glared at him. They knew that some had done what he said, but it was one of those things they did not like to hear said aloud. "How many altogether, do you reckon? Not the whole clan, surely?" If the Shaido were here in a body, there would be more than rumors of distant raids. Even among all the other troubles, all of Amadicia would know.

"nɪɹ ɪnʌf tə bi ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn wɪð, aɪm θɪŋkɪŋ," wɪntɝ mʌɾɝd ʌndɝ ɪz bɹɛθ. pɛɹɪn wɑz nɑt mɛn tə hɪɹ.

"Near enough to be going on with, I'm thinking," Wynter muttered under his breath. Perrin was not meant to hear.

ɹitʃɪŋ ɪn əmʌŋ ðə bʌndəlz taɪd tə ði ɔɹneɪt sæɾəl, səlɪn dʒɹu aʊɾ ə ɹæɡ dɑl dʒɹɛst ɪn keɪɾɪnsɝ. "ɛlaɪəs mækɛɹə faʊn ðɪs dʒʌs bɪfɔɹ wi tɝn bæk, əbaʊt fɔɹɾi maɪlz fɹəm hɪɹ." ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd, ən fəɹ ə moʊmən əɹ vɔɪs ən sɛn bɪkeɪm . . . stɑɹɾəld. "hi sɛɾ i smɛld ɪt bɪniθ ðə snoʊ. hi ən dʒɑndɪn bæɹən faʊn skɹeɪps ɑn ðə tʃɹiz ðeɪ sɛd wɝ kɑz baɪ kɑɹts. vɛɹi mɛni kɑɹts. ɪf ðəɹ ɑɹ tʃɪlʒɹən . . . aɪ θɪŋk ɪt meɪ bi ə hoʊl sɛpt, pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə. pɝhæps mɔɹ ðən wʌn. ivən ə sɪŋɡəl sɛpt wɪl əv ət list ə θaʊzən spɪɹz, ən mɔɹ ət nid. ɛvɹi mæn bʌt ðə blæksmɪθs wɪl pɪk ʌp ə spɪɹ ət nid. ðeɪ ɑɹ deɪz saʊθ ʌv ʌs. pɝhæps mɔɹ deɪz ðən aɪ θɪŋk, ɪn ðɪs snoʊ. bʌɾ aɪ bɪliv ðoʊz u tʊk jəɹ waɪf ɑɹ gɑnə mit ðɛm."

Reaching in among the bundles tied to the ornate saddle, Sulin drew out a rag doll dressed in cadin'sor. "Elyas Machera found this just before we turned back, about forty miles from here." She shook her head, and for a moment her voice and scent became . . . startled. "He said he smelled it beneath the snow. He and Jondyn Barran found scrapes on the trees they said were caused by carts. Very many carts. If there are children . . . I think it may be a whole sept, Perrin Aybara. Perhaps more than one. Even a single sept will have at least a thousand spears, and more at need. Every man but the blacksmiths will pick up a spear at need. They are days south of us. Perhaps more days than I think, in this snow. But I believe those who took your wife are going to meet them."

"ðɪs blæksmɪθ əz pɪkt ʌp ə spɪɹ," pɛɹɪn mɝmɝd. ə θaʊzənd, meɪbi mɔɹ. hi hæɾ oʊvɝ tu θaʊzənd, kaʊntɪŋ ðə wɪŋd ɡɑɹdz ən ɑɹɡændəz mɛn. əɡɛnst il, ðoʊ, ðə nʌmbɝz wəd feɪvɝ ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ. hi fɪŋɡɝd ðə dɑl ɪn səlɪnz sɪnjui hænd. wɑz ə ʃeɪɾoʊ tʃaɪld wipɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə lɔs ə hɝ dɑl? "wi ɡoʊ saʊθ."

"This blacksmith has picked up a spear," Perrin murmured. A thousand, maybe more. He had over two thousand, counting the Winged Guards and Arganda's men. Against Aiel, though, the numbers would favor the Shaido. He fingered the doll in Sulin's sinewy hand. Was a Shaido child weeping over the loss of her doll? "We go south."

hi wɑz tɝnɪŋ tə maʊn stɛpɝ wən səlɪn tʌtʃt ɪz ɑɹm tə stɑp hɪm. "aɪ toʊl jə wi sɔ ʌðɝ θɪŋz. twaɪs, ɛlaɪəs mækɛɹə faʊn hɔɹs dʒɹɑpɪŋz ən kæmpfaɪɝz ʌndɝ ðə snoʊ. mɛni hɔɹsəz, ən mɛni kæmpfaɪɝz."

He was turning to mount Stepper when Sulin touched his arm to stop him. "I told you we saw other things. Twice, Elyas Machera found horse droppings and campfires under the snow. Many horses, and many campfires."

"θaʊzənz," ælhæɹə pʊɾ ɪn; hɪz blæk aɪz mɛt pɛɹɪnz lɛvəli, ən ɪz vɔɪs wɑz mæɾɝ-ʌv-fækt. hi wɑz sɪmpli ɹipɔɹɾɪŋ wʌt wɑz. "faɪv, meɪbi tɛn əɹ mɔɹ; ɪts hɑɹd tə tɛl. bʌt soʊlʒɝz' kæmps. ðə seɪm mɛn boʊθ pleɪsəz, aɪ θɪŋk. mækɛɹə ən bæɹən əɡɹi. huɛvɝ ɪɾ ɪz, ðəɹ hɛɾɪŋ nɪɹ ɪnʌf saʊθ, tu. meɪbi ðeɪv nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð ði il, bʌt ðeɪ kəd bi fɑloʊɪŋ."

"Thousands," Alharra put in; His black eyes met Perrin's levelly, and his voice was matter-of-fact. He was simply reporting what was. "Five, maybe ten or more; it's hard to tell. But soldiers' camps. The same men both places, I think. Machera and Barran agree. Whoever it is, they're heading near enough south, too. Maybe they have nothing to do with the Aiel, but they could be following."

səlɪn ɡeɪv ðə wɔɹɾɝ ən ɪmpeɪʃən fɹaʊn ən kəntɪnjud wɪð bɛɹli ə pɔz fəɹ ɪz ɪntɝʌpʃən. "θɹi taɪmz wi sɔ flaɪɪŋ kɹitʃɝz laɪk ðoʊz jə seɪ ðə sintʃæn juz, hjudʒ θɪŋz wɪð ɹɪbd wɪŋz ən pipəl ɹaɪɾɪŋ ðɛɹ bæks. ən twaɪs wi sɔ tʃɹæks laɪk ðɪs." bɛndɪŋ, ʃi pɪkt ʌp wʌn ə ði æɹoʊz ən dʒɹu ə ɹaʊndəd ʃeɪp ə lɪɾəl laɪk ə lɑɹdʒ bɛɹz pɔ ɪn ðə snoʊ, bʌt wɪð sɪks toʊz lɔŋɡɝ ðən ə mænz fɪŋɡɝz. "səmtaɪmz ɪt ʃoʊz klɔz," ʃi sɛd, mɑɹkɪŋ ðɛm, lɔŋɡɝ ivən ðən wʌn ə ðə bɪɡ bɛɹz ɪn ðə maʊntənz ə mɪst. "ɪɾ əz ə lɔŋ stʃɹaɪd. aɪ θɪŋk ɪt ɹʌnz vɛɹi fæst. dʒju noʊ wʌɾ ɪɾ ɪz?"

Sulin gave the Warder an impatient frown and continued with barely a pause for his interruption. "Three times we saw flying creatures like those you say the Seanchan use, huge things with ribbed wings and people riding their backs. And twice we saw tracks like this." Bending, she picked up one of the arrows and drew a rounded shape a little like a large bear's paw in the snow, but with six toes longer than a man's fingers. "Sometimes it shows claws," she said, marking them, longer even than one of the big bears in the Mountains of Mist. "It has a long stride. I think it runs very fast. Do you know what it is?"

hi dɪd nɑt - hi hæd nɛvɝ hɝɾ ʌv ɛniθɪŋ wɪð sɪks toʊz ɪksɛp ðə kæts ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz; hi hæd bɪn sɝpɹaɪz tə faɪn kæts ɛlswɛɹ oʊnli hæd faɪv - bʌɾ i kəd meɪk ə seɪf ɡɛs. "ənʌðɝ sintʃæn ænəməl." soʊ ðəɹ wɝ sintʃæn tə ðə saʊθ əz wɛl əz ʃeɪɾoʊ, ən - wʌt? - waɪtkloʊks, əɹ ə sintʃæn ɑɹmi. ɪt kəd nɑt bi ɛniwʌn ɛls. hi tʃɹʌstɪd beɪlwɝz ɪnfɝmeɪʃən. "wi stɪl ɡoʊ saʊθ." ðə meɪɾənz stɛɹɾ əɾ ɪm əz ɪf i hæd toʊld əm ɪt wɑz snoʊɪŋ.

He did not - he had never heard of anything with six toes except the cats in the Two Rivers; he had been surprised to find cats elsewhere only had five - but he could make a safe guess. "Another Seanchan animal." So there were Seanchan to the south as well as Shaido, and - what? - Whitecloaks, or a Seanchan army. It could not be anyone else. He trusted Balwer's information. "We still go south." The Maidens stared at him as if he had told them it was snowing.

pʊlɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ʌp ɪndə stɛpɝz sæɾəl, hi tɝn bæk təwɔɹd ðə kɑləm. ðə wɔɹɾɝz wɔkt, liɾɪŋ ðɛɹ wɪɹi hɔɹdz. ðə meɪɾənz tʊk æliændɝz ɡɛldɪŋ wɪð əm əz ðeɪ tʃɹɑɾəd tə wɛɹ ðə waɪz wʌnz wɝ stændɪŋ. mɑsʊɝi ən siɑnɪd wɝ ɹaɪɾɪŋ tə mit ðɛɹ wɔɹɾɝz. hi wʌndɝd waɪ ðeɪ ɔl hæd nɑt kʌm tə stɪk ðɛɹ noʊzɪz ɪn. pɝhæps ɪt wɑz əz sɪmpəl əz lɛɾɪŋ ɪm bi əloʊn wɪð ɪz ɡɹif ɪf ðə nuz tɝn aʊt bæd. pɝhæps. ɪn ɪz hɛd, hi tʃɹaɪd tə fɪɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ təɡɛðɝ. ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ, haʊɛvɝ mɛni ðeɪ wɝ. ðə sintʃæn. ðə maʊntəɾ ɑɹmi, wɛðɝ waɪtkloʊk əɹ sintʃæn. ɪt wɑz laɪk ðə pʌzəlz mæstɝ luhən hæd tɔɾ ɪm tə meɪk, ɪntʃɹəkət twɪsts ə mɛɾəl ðət slɪɾ əpɑɹɾ ən slɪp bæk təɡɛðɝ laɪk ə dʒɹim, ɪf jə nu ðə tʃɹɪk. oʊnli, hɪz hɛd fɛl mʌɾəld, ɡɹoʊpɪŋ ət pisəz ðət wəd nɑt slaɪɾ ɛniwɛɹ.

Pulling himself up into Stepper's saddle, he turned back toward the column. The Warders walked, leading their weary hordes. The Maidens took Alliandre's gelding with them as they trotted to where the Wise Ones were standing. Masuri and Seonid were riding to meet their Warders. He wondered why they all had not come to stick their noses in. Perhaps it was as simple as letting him be alone with his grief if the news turned out bad. Perhaps. In his head, he tried to fit everything together. The Shaido, however many they were. The Seanchan. The mounted army, whether Whitecloak or Seanchan. It was like the puzzles Master Luhhan had taught him to make, intricate twists of metal that slid apart and slipped back together like a dream, if you knew the trick. Only, his head felt muddled, groping at pieces that would not slide anywhere.

ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn wɝ ɔl maʊntəɾ əɡɛn wən i ɹitʃt ðɛm. ðoʊz u hæd bɪn ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd wɪð ðɛɹ baʊz ɹɛɾi lʊkt ə lɪɾəl əbæʃt. ðeɪ ɔl aɪɾ ɪm ənizəli, tɛntəɾɪvli.

The Two Rivers men were all mounted again when he reached them. Those who had been on the ground with their bows ready looked a little abashed. They all eyed him uneasily, tentatively.

"ʃiz əlaɪv," hi sɛd, ən ɪt wɑz əz ɪf ɛvɹi mæn ə ðɛm stɑɹɾəd bɹiðɪŋ əɡɛn. ðeɪ tʊk ðə ɹɛst ə hɪz nuz wɪð ə stʃɹeɪnʒ ɪmpæsɪvnəs, səm ivən nɑɾɪŋ əz ðoʊ ðeɪ hæɾ ɪkspɛktəd noʊ lɛs.

"She's alive," he said, and it was as if every man of them started breathing again. They took the rest of his news with a strange impassiveness, some even nodding as though they had expected no less.

"woʊn bi ðə fɝs taɪm wiv feɪs lɔŋ ɑdz," dænɪl sɛd. "wʌt də wi du, maɪ lɔɹd?"

"Won't be the first time we've faced long odds," Dannil said. "What do we do, my Lord?"

pɛɹɪn ɡɹɪməst. ðə mæn wɑz stɪl stɪf əz ən oʊk. "fɔɹ stɑɹɾɝz, wɝ tʃɹævlɪŋ fɔɹɾi maɪlz du saʊθ. æftɝ ðæt, əl si. nild, jə ɡoʊ əhɛɾ ən faɪn ɛlaɪəs ən ði ʌðɝz. tɛl əm wʌɾ aɪm duɪŋ. ðəl bi ə ɡʊd dil fɝðɝ ɑn, baɪ ðɪs taɪm. ən əv ə kɛɹ. jə kæn faɪt tɛn əɹ ə dʌzən waɪz wʌnz." ə hoʊl sɛpt ʃəɾ əv ət lis ðət mɛni hu kəd tʃænəl. ən ɪf ɪt wɑz mɔɹ ðən wʌn? ə bɑɡ hi hæd tə kɹɔs wən i keɪm tə ɪt.

Perrin grimaced. The man was still stiff as an oak. "For starters, we're Traveling forty miles due south. After that, I will see. Neald, you go ahead and find Elyas and the others. Tell them what I'm doing. They will be a good deal further on, by this time. And have a care. You can't fight ten or a dozen Wise Ones." A whole sept should have at least that many who could channel. And if it was more than one? A bog he had to cross when he came to it.

nil nɑɾəd bɪfɔɹ tɝnɪŋ ɪz ɡɛldɪŋ bæk təwɔɹd ðə kæmp, wɛɹ i hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi mɛmɝaɪz ðə ɡɹaʊnd. ðəɹ wɝ oʊnli ə fju mɔɹ ɔɹɾɝz tə ɡɪv. ɹaɪɾɝz hæd tə bi sɛn tə faɪn ðə minɝz ən ɡildænɪn, hu wəd bi muvɪŋ əpɑɹɾ əz ðeɪ kæmpt əpɑɹt. ɡɹeɪɾi θɔɾ i kəd mɛmɝaɪz ðə ɡɹaʊn ɹaɪt ðəɹ bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ kəd dʒɔɪn ʌp, soʊ ðəɹ wɑz noʊ nid tə tɝn ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɝaʊn ən fɑloʊ nil bæk. ən ðət lɛft oʊnli wʌn θɪŋ.

Neald nodded before turning his gelding back toward the camp, where he had already memorized the ground. There were only a few more orders to give. Riders had to be sent to find the Mayeners and Ghealdanin, who would be moving apart as they camped apart. Grady thought he could memorize the ground right there before they could join up, so there was no need to turn everything around and follow Neald back. And that left only one thing.

"aɪ nid tə faɪn mæsimə, dænɪl," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "sʌmbɑɾi hu kən ɡɪv ɪm ə mɛsədʒ, ɛniweɪ. wɪð lʌk, aɪ woʊn bi lɔŋ."

"I need to find Masema, Dannil," Perrin said. "Somebody who can give him a message, anyway. With luck, I won't be long."

"ju ɡoʊ əmʌŋ ðət fɪlθ əloʊn, maɪ lɔɹd, ən jəl nid lʌk," dænɪl ɹɪplaɪd. "aɪ hɝd səm ə ðɛm tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt ju. sɛd jəɹ ʃæɾoʊzpɔn, kəz ə jəɹ aɪz." hɪz ɡeɪz mɛt pɛɹɪnz ɡoʊldən aɪz ən slɪd saɪdweɪz. "sɛd jud bɪn teɪm baɪ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, bʌt stɪl ʃæɾoʊzpɔn. jə ɔt tə teɪk ə fju dʌzən mɛn tə wɑtʃ jəɹ bæk."

"You go among that filth alone, my Lord, and you'll need luck," Dannil replied. "I heard some of them talking about you. Said you're Shadowspawn, because of your eyes." His gaze met Perrin's golden eyes and slid sideways. "Said you'd been tamed by the Dragon Reborn, but still Shadowspawn. You ought to take a few dozen men to watch your back."

pɛɹɪn hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, pæɾɪŋ stɛpɝz nɛk. ə fju dʌzən mɛn wəd nɑt bi ɪnʌf ɪf mæsiməz pipəl ɹɪli θɔɾ i wɑz ʃæɾoʊzpɔn ən dɪsaɪɾɪd tə teɪk mæɾɝz ɪndə ðɛɹ oʊn hænz. ɔl ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn təɡɛðɝ maɪt nɑt bi ɪnʌf. meɪbi hi dɪd nɑt nid tə tɛl mæsimə, dʒʌs lɛɾ ɪm lɝn fəɹ hɪmsɛlf.

Perrin hesitated, patting Stepper's neck. A few dozen men would not be enough if Masema's people really thought he was Shadowspawn and decided to take matters into their own hands. All the Two Rivers men together might not be enough. Maybe he did not need to tell Masema, just let him learn for himself.

hɪz ɪɹz kɑɾ ə bluəɾɪts tʃɹɪl fɹəm ðə tʃɹiz tə ðə wɛst, fɑloʊɾ ə moʊmən leɪɾɝ baɪ ə sɛkən ðəɾ ɛvɹiwʌn kəd hɪɹ, ən ðə dɪsɪʒən wɑz teɪkən əweɪ fɹəm hɪm. hi wɑz ʃʊɹ ʌv ɪt, ən wʌndɝd wɛðɝ ðɪs wɑz pɑɹɾ ə biɪŋ tɑvɝən. hi ɹeɪn stɛpɝ ɝaʊn ən weɪɾəd.

His ears caught a bluetit's trill from the trees to the west, followed a moment later by a second that everyone could hear, and the decision was taken away from him. He was sure of it, and wondered whether this was part of being ta'veren. He reined Stepper around and waited.

ðə tu ɹɪvɝz mɛn nu wʌɾ ɪt mɛnt, hɪɹɪŋ ðət pɝtɪkjəlɝ bɝd fɹəm bæk hoʊm. mɛn kʌmɪŋ, mɔɹ ðən ə hændfʊl, ən nɑt nɛsəsɛɹəli pisfəl. ɪt wʊɾə bɪn ə kɹʊkbɪl tʃɹɪlɪŋ ɪf ðeɪ wɝ fɹɛnz, ən ə mɑkɝz kɹaɪ ʌv əlɑɹm hæd ðeɪ bɪn klɪɹli ənfɹɛnli. ðɪs taɪm, ðeɪ bɪheɪv bɛɾɝ. əlɔŋ ðə wɛst saɪɾ ə ðə kɑləm, ɛvɹi sɛkən mæn əz fɑɹ əz pɛɹɪn kəd si ɪn ðə snoʊ dɪsmaʊntɪɾ ən hændəɾ ɪz ɹeɪnz tə ðə mæn nɛks tə hɪm, ðən ɹɛɾid ɪz baʊ.

The Two Rivers men knew what it meant, hearing that particular bird from back home. Men coming, more than a handful, and not necessarily peaceful. It would have been a crookbill trilling if they were friends, and a mocker's cry of alarm had they been clearly unfriendly. This time, they behaved better. Along the west side of the column, every second man as far as Perrin could see in the snow dismounted and handed his reins to the man next to him, then readied his bow.

ðə stʃɹeɪnʒɝz əpɪɹd θɹu ðə skæɾɝd tʃɹiz spɹɛɾ aʊɾ ɪn ə laɪn əz ɪf tə ɪnkɹis ði ɪmpɹɛʃən ə ðɛɹ nʌmbɝz. ðeɪ wɝ pɝhæps ə hʌnʒɹəd, wɪð tu ɪn ədvæns, bʌt ðɛɹ sloʊ ədvæns dɪd sim ɑmənəs. hæf kæɹid lænsɪz, nɑt kaʊtʃt bʌt hɛld əz ðoʊ ɹɛɾi bi tʌkt ʌndɝ ən ɑɹm. əɾ ə stɛɾi wɔk ðeɪ keɪm ɑn. səm wɔɹ ɑɹmɝ, ə bɹɛstpleɪɾ əɹ ə hɛlmət bʌt ɹɛɹli boʊθ. stɪl, ðeɪ wɝ bɛɾɝ ɑɹm ðən ðə dʒɛnɝəl ɹʌn ə mæsiməz fɑloʊɝz. wʌn ə ðə pɛɹ aʊt fɹʌnt wɑz mæsimə hɪmsɛlf, hɪz zɛləts feɪs stɛɹɪŋ aʊɾ ə hɪz kloʊks kaʊl laɪk ə ɹæbɪd maʊntən kæt stɛɹɪŋ aʊɾ ʌv ə keɪv. haʊ mɛni ʌv ðoʊz lænsɪz hæd bɔɹn ə ɹɛd stʃɹimɝ jɛstɝdeɪ mɔɹnɪŋ?

The strangers appeared through the scattered trees spread out in a line as if to increase the impression of their numbers. They were perhaps a hundred, with two in advance, but their slow advance did seem ominous. Half carried lances, not couched but held as though ready be tucked under an arm. At a steady walk they came on. Some wore armor, a breastplate or a helmet but rarely both. Still, they were better armed than the general run of Masema's followers. One of the pair out front was Masema himself, his zealot's face staring out of his cloak's cowl like a rabid mountain cat staring out of a cave. How many of those lances had borne a red streamer yesterday morning?

mæsimə stɑpt ɪz mɛn wɪð ə ɹeɪz hæn oʊnli wən i wɑz dʒʌst ə fju peɪsɪz fɹəm pɛɹɪn. pʊʃɪŋ bæk ɪz hʊd, hi ɹæn ɪz ɡeɪz əlɔŋ ðə dɪsmaʊntɪd mɛn wɪð ðɛɹ baʊz. hi simd ʌnəwɛɹ ə ðə snoʊ hɪɾɪŋ ɪz bɛɹ skælp. hɪz kəmpænjən, ə bɪɡɝ mæn wɪð ə sɔɹɾ ɑn ɪz bæk ən ənʌðɝ əɾ ɪz sæɾəlboʊ, kɛpt ɪz kaʊl ʌp, bʌt pɛɹɪn θɔɾ ɪz hɛd wɑz ʃeɪvd, tu. ðət wʌn mænədʒ tə stʌɾi ðə kɑləm ən wɑtʃ mæsimə wɪð ikwəl ɪntɛnsəɾi. hɪz dɑɹk aɪz bɝn ɔlmoʊst əz mʌtʃ əz mæsiməz. pɛɹɪn θɔɾ əbaʊt tɛlɪŋ əm ðəɾ ət ðɪs ɹeɪnʒ, ə tu ɹɪvɝz lɔŋboʊ wəd pʊɾ ə paɪl ʃæft ɹaɪt θɹu ə bɹɛstpleɪt, ən aʊt ðə wɛɹɝz bæk bɪsaɪdz. hi kənsɪɾɝd mɛnʃənɪŋ sintʃæn. dɪskɹɛʃən, bɹəleɪn hæd kaʊnsəld. pɝhæps ɪt wɑz ə faɪn θɪŋ, ɪn ðə sɝkəmstænsəz.

Masema stopped his men with a raised hand only when he was just a few paces from Perrin. Pushing back his hood, he ran his gaze along the dismounted men with their bows. He seemed unaware of the snow hitting his bare scalp. His companion, a bigger man with a sword on his back and another at his saddlebow, kept his cowl up, but Perrin thought his head was shaved, too. That one managed to study the column and watch Masema with equal intensity. His dark eyes burned almost as much as Masema's. Perrin thought about telling them that at this range, a Two Rivers longbow would put a pile shaft right through a breastplate, and out the wearer's back besides. He considered mentioning Seanchan. Discretion, Berelain had counseled. Perhaps it was a fine thing, in the circumstances.

"ju wɝ kʌmɪŋ tə mit mi?" mæsimə sɛɾ əbɹʌpli. ivən ðə mænz vɔɪs siðd wɪð ɪntɛnsəɾi. nʌθɪŋ wɑz ɛvɝ kæʒəwəl ɑn ɪz tʌŋ. ɛniθɪŋ i hæd tə seɪ wɑz ɪmpɔɹɾənt. ðə peɪl tʃɹaɪæŋɡjəlɝ skɑɹ ɑn ɪz tʃik pʊld ɪz sʌɾən smaɪl kɹʊkəd. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ wɔɹmθ ɪn ɪɾ ɛniweɪ. "noʊ mæɾɝ. aɪm hɪɹ, naʊ. əz jə noʊ daʊt noʊ baɪ naʊ, ðoʊz u fɑloʊ ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn - ðə laɪɾ ɪlumin ɪz neɪm! - ɹəfjuz tə bi lɛf bɪhaɪnd. aɪ kænɑt dɪmæn ɪɾ ə ðɛm. ðeɪ sɝv ɪm əz aɪ du."

"You were coming to meet me?" Masema said abruptly. Even the man's voice seethed with intensity. Nothing was ever casual on his tongue. Anything he had to say was important. The pale triangular scar on his cheek pulled his sudden smile crooked. There was no warmth in it anyway. "No matter. I am here, now. As you no doubt know by now, those who follow the Lord Dragon Reborn - the Light illumine his name! - refuse to be left behind. I cannot demand it of them. They serve him as I do."

pɛɹɪn sɔ ə taɪɾ ə fleɪm ɹoʊlɪŋ əkɹɔs ɑmɑdɪʃiə ɪndə ɔltɑɹə ən pɝhæps bɪɑnd, livɪŋ dɛθ ən dɛvəsteɪʃən bɪhaɪnd. hi tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ, sʌkɪŋ koʊld ɪndə hɪz lʌŋz. feɪl wɑz mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt ðən ɛniθɪŋ. ɛniθɪŋ! ɪf i bɝn fəɹ ɪt, ðən i bɝnd. "teɪk jəɹ mɛn ist." hi wɑz ʃɑkt ət haʊ stɛɾi hɪz vɔɪs wɑz. "aɪ wɪl kætʃ ʌp wən aɪ kæn. maɪ waɪf əz bɪn kɪdnæp baɪ il, ən aɪm hɛɾɪŋ saʊθ tə ɡɛɾ əɹ bæk." fəɹ wʌns, hi sɔ mæsimə sɝpɹaɪzd.

Perrin saw a tide of flame rolling across Amadicia into Altara and perhaps beyond, leaving death and devastation behind. He took a deep breath, sucking cold into his lungs. Faile was more important than anything. Anything! If he burned for it, then he burned. "Take your men east." He was shocked at how steady his voice was. "I will catch up when I can. My wife has been kidnapped by Aiel, and I'm heading south to get her back." For once, he saw Masema surprised.

"il? soʊ ðeɪ ɑɹ mɔɹ ðən ɹumɝ?" hi fɹaʊn ət ðə waɪz wʌnz ɑn ðə fɑɹ saɪɾ ə ðə kɑləm. "saʊθ, jə seɪ?" foʊldɪŋ ɪz ɡlʌv hænz ɑn ðə pɑməl ə hɪz sæɾəl, hi tɝn ɪz stʌɾi tə pɛɹɪn. ɪnsænəɾi fɪl ðə mænz sɛnt; pɛɹɪn kəd nɑt faɪn ɛniθɪŋ bʌt mædnəs ɪn ɪt. "aɪ wɪl kʌm wɪð ju," mæsimə sɛɾ ət læst, əz ɪf ɹitʃɪŋ ə dɪsɪʒən. ɑd, hi hæd bɪn ɪmpeɪʃən tə ɹitʃ ɹænd wɪθaʊt dɪleɪ. soʊ lɔŋ əz i dɪd nɑɾ əv tə bi tʌtʃt baɪ ðə paʊɝ tə də soʊ, ət list. "ɔl ðoʊz u fɑloʊ ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn - ðə laɪɾ ɪlumin ɪz neɪm! - wɪl kʌm. kɪlɪŋ il sævədʒəz ɪz duɪŋ ðə laɪts wɝk." hɪz aɪz flɪkɝd təwɔɹd ðə waɪz wʌnz, ən ɪz smaɪl wɑz ivən koʊldɝ ðən bɪfɔɹ.

"Aiel? So they are more than rumor?" He frowned at the Wise Ones on the far side of the column. "South, you say?" Folding his gloved hands on the pommel of his saddle, he turned his study to Perrin. Insanity filled the man's scent; Perrin could not find anything but madness in it. "I will come with you," Masema said at last, as if reaching a decision. Odd, he had been impatient to reach Rand without delay. So long as he did not have to be touched by the Power to do so, at least. "All those who follow the Lord Dragon Reborn - the Light illumine his name! - will come. Killing Aiel savages is doing the Light's work." His eyes flickered toward the Wise Ones, and his smile was even colder than before.

"aɪ wəɾ əpɹiʃieɪt ðə hɛlp," pɛɹɪn laɪd. ðət ɹæbəl wəd bi jusləs əɡɛnst il. stɪl, ðeɪ nʌmbɝɾ ɪn ðə θaʊzənz. ən ðeɪ hæd hɛld ɔf ɑɹmiz, ɪf nɑɾ ɑɹmiz ʌv il. ə pis ə ðət pʌzəl ɪn ɪz hɛd ʃɪftəd. ɹɛɾi tə dʒɹɑp wɪð fətiɡ, hi kəd nɑt meɪk aʊɾ ɪɡzækli haʊ, dʒʌs ðəɾ ɪt hæd. ɪn ɛni keɪs, ɪt wɑz nɑt ɡoʊɪŋ tə hæpən. "ðeɪ hæv ə lɔŋ lɛɾ ɑn mi, ðoʊ. aɪ ɪntɛn tə tʃɹævəl, tə juz ðə wʌn paʊɝ, tə kætʃ ʌp. aɪ noʊ haʊ jə fil əbaʊt ðæt."

"I would appreciate the help," Perrin lied. That rabble would be useless against Aiel. Still, they numbered in the thousands. And they had held off armies, if not armies of Aiel. A piece of that puzzle in his head shifted. Ready to drop with fatigue, he could not make out exactly how, just that it had. In any case, it was not going to happen. "They have a long lead on me, though. I intend to Travel, to use the One Power, to catch up. I know how you feel about that."

ənizi mɝmɝz ɹæn θɹu ðə mɛn bɪhaɪn mæsimə, ən ðeɪ aɪd wʌn ənʌðɝ ən ʃɪftəd wɛpənz. pɛɹɪn kɑt mʌɾɝd kɝsɪz ən ɔlsoʊ "jɛloʊ aɪz" ən "ʃæɾoʊzpɔn." ðə sɛkənd ʃeɪvən-hɛɾəd mæn ɡlɛɹɾ ət pɛɹɪn əz ðoʊ hi hæd blæsfimd, bʌt mæsimə dʒʌst stɛɹd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə bɔɹ ə hoʊl ɪndə pɛɹɪnz hɛɾ ən si wʌt leɪ ɪnsaɪd.

Uneasy murmurs ran through the men behind Masema, and they eyed one another and shifted weapons. Perrin caught muttered curses and also "yellow eyes" and "Shadowspawn." The second shaven-headed man glared at Perrin as though he had blasphemed, but Masema just stared, trying to bore a hole into Perrin's head and see what lay inside.

"hi wəd bi ɡɹivd ɪf hɑɹm keɪm tə jəɹ waɪf," ðə mædmæn sɛɾ ət læst. ði ɛmfəsəs neɪmd ɹænd əz klɪɹli əz ðə neɪm mæsimə dɪd nɑɾ əlaʊ tə bi spoʊkən. "ðɛɹ wɪl bi ə . . . dɪspənseɪʃən, ɪn ðɪs wʌn ɪnstəns. oʊnli tə faɪn jəɹ waɪf, kəz jə ɑɹ ɪz fɹɛnd. oʊnli ðɪs." hi spoʊk kɑmli - kɑmli fəɹ ɪm - bʌɾ ɪz dip-sɛɾ aɪz wɝ dɑɹk faɪɝ, hɪz feɪs kəntɔɹɾəd wɪð ənnoʊɪŋ ɹeɪdʒ.

"He would be grieved if harm came to your wife," the madman said at last. The emphasis named Rand as clearly as the name Masema did not allow to be spoken. "There will be a . . . dispensation, in this one instance. Only to find your wife, because you are his friend. Only this." He spoke calmly - calmly for him - but his deep-set eyes were dark fire, his face contorted with unknowing rage.

pɛɹɪn oʊpən ɪz maʊθ, ðən kloʊzd ɪt wɪθaʊt spikɪŋ. ðə sʌn maɪɾ əz wɛl ɹaɪz ɪn ðə wɛst əz mæsimə seɪ wʌɾ i dʒʌs hæd. sʌɾənli pɛɹɪn θɔt ðət feɪl maɪt bi seɪfɝ wɪð ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ ðən i wɑz hɪɹ ən naʊ.

Perrin opened his mouth, then closed it without speaking. The sun might as well rise in the west as Masema say what he just had. Suddenly Perrin thought that Faile might be safer with the Shaido than he was here and now.


tʃæptɝ sɛvən


CHAPTER 7

ðə stʃɹits ə keɪɛmlɪn


The Streets of Caemlyn

ɪleɪnz ɑntʊɹɑʒ ətʃɹæktəd plɛnti ʌv ətɛnʃən əz ɪt ɹoʊd θɹu keɪɛmlɪn, əlɔŋ stʃɹits ðət ɹoʊz ən fɛl wɪð ðə hɪlz ə ðə sɪɾi. ðə ɡoʊldən lɪli ɑn ðə bɹɛst ə hɝ fɝ-laɪn kɹɪmzən kloʊk wɑz səfɪʃən tə aɪdɛntəfaɪ hɝ fəɹ sɪɾəzənz ə ðə kæpəɾəl, bʌt ʃi kɛpt əɹ hʊd bæk, fɹeɪmɪŋ əɹ feɪs soʊ ðə sɪŋɡəl ɡoʊldən ɹoʊz ɑn ðə kɔɹənɛɾ ə ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ wɑz klɪɹli vɪzəbəl. nɑt dʒʌst ɪleɪn, haɪ siɾ ə haʊs tʃɹəkənd, bʌɾ ɪleɪn ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ. lɛɾ ɛvɹiwʌn si, ən noʊ.

Elayne's entourage attracted plenty of attention as it rode through Caemlyn, along streets that rose and fell with the hills of the city. The Golden Lily on the breast of her fur-lined crimson cloak was sufficient to identify her for citizens of the capital, but she kept her hood back, framing her face so the single golden rose on the coronet of the Daughter-Heir was clearly visible. Not just Elayne, High Seat of House Trakand, but Elayne the Daughter-Heir. Let everyone see, and know.

ðə doʊmz ə ðə nu sɪɾi ɡlɪntɪd waɪɾ ən ɡoʊld ɪn ðə peɪl mɔɹnɪŋ laɪt, ən aɪsɪkəlz spɑɹkəld ɑn ðə bɛɹ bɹæntʃəz ə ðə tʃɹiz daʊn ðə sɛntɝ ə ðə meɪn stʃɹits. ivən nɪɹɪŋ ɪts zinəθ ðə sʌn lækt wɔɹmθ, dɪspaɪɾ ə blɛsədli klaʊdləs skaɪ. lʌkəli, ðəɹ wɑz noʊ wɪn tədeɪ. ði ɛɹ wɑz koʊld ɪnʌf tə fɹɔst əɹ bɹɛθ, jɛt wɪð ðə peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz klɪɹɾ ə snoʊ ivən ɑn ðə nɛɹoʊɝ, twɪstɪŋ weɪz, ðə sɪɾi wɑz əlaɪv əɡɛn, ðə stʃɹits fʊl ən bʌsəlɪŋ. kɑɹɾɝz ən wæɡən dʒɹaɪvɝz, hɑɹnəs baɪ ðɛɹ wɝk əz ʃʊɹli əz ðə hɔɹsəz bɪtwin ðə ʃæfs, klʌtʃt ðɛɹ kloʊks ɪn ɹɛzəɡneɪʃən əz ðeɪ meɪd sloʊ pæsədʒ θɹu ðə θɹɔŋ. ə hjudʒ wɔɾɝ wæɡən ɹʌmbəl baɪ, ɛmpti baɪ ðə saʊnd, ɑn ɪts weɪ tə bi ɹifɪl fəɹ faɪɾɪŋ ðə tu-fɹikwən ɑɹsənz. ə fju hɔkɝz ən stʃɹit pɛdlɝz bɹeɪv ðə tʃɪl tə kɹaɪ ðɛɹ wɛɹz, bʌt moʊs foʊk hɝiɾ əbaʊt ðɛɹ tæsks, iɡɝ tə bi ɪndɔɹz əz sun əz pɑsəbəl. nɑt ðət hɝiɪŋ mɛn muvɪŋ vɛɹi fæst. ðə sɪɾi bʌlʒd, ɪts pɑpjəleɪʃən swoʊlən bɪɑn ðəɾ ə tɑɹ vəlɑn. ɪn sətʃ ə swɔɹm, ivən ðə fju hu wɝ maʊntəd muv noʊ fæstɝ ðən ə mæn kəd wɔk. ɪn ðə hoʊl mɔɹnɪŋ ʃi hæd sin oʊnli tu əɹ θɹi kæɹɪdʒɪz ɪntʃɪŋ əlɔŋ ðə stʃɹits. ɪf ðɛɹ pæsənʒɝz wɝ nɑɾ ɪnvələdz əɹ feɪsɪŋ maɪlz əhɛd, ðeɪ wɝ fulz.

The domes of the New City glinted white and gold in the pale morning light, and icicles sparkled on the bare branches of the trees down the center of the main streets. Even nearing its zenith the sun lacked warmth, despite a blessedly cloudless sky. Luckily, there was no wind today. The air was cold enough to frost her breath, yet with the paving stones cleared of snow even on the narrower, twisting ways, the city was alive again, the streets full and bustling. Carters and wagon drivers, harnessed by their work as surely as the horses between the shafts, clutched their cloaks in resignation as they made slow passage through the throng. A huge water wagon rumbled by, empty by the sound, on its way to be refilled for fighting the too-frequent arsons. A few hawkers and street peddlers braved the chill to cry their wares, but most folk hurried about their tasks, eager to be indoors as soon as possible. Not that hurrying meant moving very fast. The city bulged, its population swollen beyond that of Tar Valon. In such a swarm, even the few who were mounted moved no faster than a man could walk. In the whole morning she had seen only two or three carriages inching along the streets. If their passengers were not invalids or facing miles ahead, they were fools.

ɛvɹiwʌn u sɔ hɝ ən əɹ pɑɹɾi pɔzd ət ðə vɛɹi list, səm pɔɪntɪŋ əɹ aʊt tə ʌðɝz, əɹ hɔɪstɪŋ ə tʃaɪl fəɹ ə bɛɾɝ vju soʊ wʌn deɪ ðeɪ kəd tɛl ðɛɹ oʊn tʃɪlʒɹən ðeɪ hæd sin hɝ. wɛðɝ ðeɪ sɛd ðeɪ hæd sin ðə fjutʃɝ kwin əɹ sɪmpli ə wʊmən u hɛl ðə sɪɾi fəɹ ə taɪm wɑz ðə kwɛstʃən. moʊs pipəl sɪmpli stɛɹd, bʌt naʊ ən ðən ə hændfʊl ə vɔɪsəz kɹaɪɾ aʊt "tʃɹəkənd! tʃɹəkənd!" əɹ ivən "ɪleɪn ən ændɝ!" əz ʃi pæst. bɛɾɝ ɪf ðəɹ hæd bɪn mɔɹ tʃɪɹɪŋ, jɛt saɪləns wɑz pɹɛfɝəbəl tə dʒiɹz. ændɔɹənz wɝ aʊtspoʊkən foʊk, nʌn mɔɹ soʊ ðən keɪɛmlaɪnɝz. ɹɪbɛljənz hæd bɪɡʌn ən kwinz lɔs ðɛɹ θɹoʊnz kəz keɪɛmlaɪnɝz vɔɪs ðɛɹ dɪsplɛʒɝ ɪn ðə stʃɹits.

Everyone who saw her and her party paused at the very least, some pointing her out to others, or hoisting a child for a better view so one day they could tell their own children they had seen her. Whether they said they had seen the future Queen or simply a woman who held the city for a time was the question. Most people simply stared, but now and then a handful of voices cried out "Trakand! Trakand!" or even "Elayne and Andor!" as she passed. Better if there had been more cheering, yet silence was preferable to jeers. Andorans were outspoken folk, none more so than Caemlyners. Rebellions had begun and queens lost their thrones because Caemlyners voiced their displeasure in the streets.

ən aɪsi θɔt meɪɾ ɪleɪn ʃɪvɝ. hu hoʊlz keɪɛmlɪn hoʊlz ændɝ, ði eɪntʃən seɪɪŋ wɛnt; ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ɪɡzækli tʃɹu, əz ɹænd hæd dɛmənstʃɹeɪɾəd, jɛt keɪɛmlɪn wɑz ændɝz hɑɹt. ʃi hæd leɪd kleɪm tə ðə sɪɾi - ðə laɪən bænɝ ən tʃɹəkənz sɪlvɝ kistoʊn ʃɛɹd pɹaɪɾ ə pleɪs ɑn ðə taʊɝz ə ði aʊɾɝ wɔl - bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt jɛt hoʊl ðə hɑɹɾ ə keɪɛmlɪn, ən ðət wɑz fɑɹ mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt ðən hoʊldɪŋ stoʊn ən mɔɹɾɝ.

An icy thought made Elayne shiver. Who holds Caemlyn holds Andor, the ancient saying went; it was not exactly true, as Rand had demonstrated, yet Caemlyn was Andor's heart. She had laid claim to the city - the Lion Banner and Trakand's Silver Keystone shared pride of place on the towers of the outer wall - but she did not yet hold the heart of Caemlyn, and that was far more important than holding stone and mortar.

ðəl ɔl tʃɪɹ mi, wʌn deɪ, ʃi pɹɑməs hɝsɛlf. əl ɝn ðɛɹ əkleɪm. tədeɪ, ðoʊ, ðə kɹaʊɾəd weɪz fɛlt loʊnli bɪtwin ðoʊz fju əpɹeɪz vɔɪsəz. ʃi wɪʃt eɪvinhə wɝ ðɛɹ, dʒʌs fəɹ əɹ kʌmpəni, bʌɾ eɪvinhə sɔ noʊ ɹizən tə klaɪm ɑntu ə hɔɹs sɪmpli tə muv əbaʊt ðə sɪɾi. ɛniweɪ, ɪleɪn kəd fil hɝ. ɪt wɑz dɪfɹən fɹəm ðə bɑnd wɪð bɝdʒɪt, jɛt ʃi kəd fil əɹ sɪstɝz pɹɛzəns ɪn ðə sɪɾi, laɪk sɛnsɪŋ ən ənsin pɝsən ɪn ðə seɪm ɹum, ən ɪt wɑz kʌmfɝɾɪŋ.

They will all cheer me, one day, she promised herself. I will earn their acclaim. Today, though, the crowded ways felt lonely between those few upraised voices. She wished Aviendha were there, just for her company, but Aviendha saw no reason to climb onto a horse simply to move about the city. Anyway, Elayne could feel her. It was different from the bond with Birgitte, yet she could feel her sister's presence in the city, like sensing an unseen person in the same room, and it was comforting.

hɝ kəmpænjənz dʒɹu ðɛɹ oʊn ʃɛɹ ʌv ətɛnʃən. æftɝ bɛɹli θɹi jɪɹz əz ɛɛs sədaɪ, sɝaɪðəz dɑɹk skwɛɹ feɪs hæd nɑt jɛɾ ətʃivd eɪɡləsnəs, ən ʃi lʊkt ə pɹɑspɝəs mɝtʃən ɪn əɹ faɪn bɹɑnz-kʌlɝd wʊlənz wɪð ə lɑɹdʒ sɪlvɝ-ænd-sæfaɪɝz bɹutʃ hoʊldɪŋ əɹ kloʊk. hɝ wɔɹɾɝ, nɛd jɑɹmən, ɹoʊɾ əɾ əɹ hilz, ən i sɝɾənli kɑɾ aɪz. ə tɔl, bɹɔd-ʃoʊldɝd jʌŋ mæn wɪð bɹaɪt blu aɪz ən kɔɹn-jɛloʊ hɛɹ kɝlɪŋ tə hɪz ʃoʊldɝz, hi wɔɹ ə ʃɪmɝɪŋ wɔɹɾɝz kloʊk ðət meɪɾ ɪm əpɪɹ ə dɪsɪbɑɾid hɛd floʊɾɪŋ əbʌv ə tɔl ɡɹeɪ ɡɛldɪŋ ðət wɑz nɑɾ ɪntaɪɝli ðəɹ iðɝ, wɛɹ ðə kloʊk dʒɹeɪpt ɪts hɔntʃɪz. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ mɪsteɪkɪŋ wʌɾ i wɑz, əɹ ðəɾ ɪz pɹɛzəns ənaʊnst ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. ði ʌðɝz, meɪnteɪnɪŋ ə sɝkəl ɝaʊn ɪleɪn əz ðeɪ meɪɾ ə weɪ θɹu ðə kɹaʊd, ətʃɹæktəd dʒʌst əz mɛni aɪz, ðoʊ. eɪt wɪmən ɪn ðə ɹɛd koʊts ən bɝnɪʃt hɛlməts ən bɹɛstpleɪts ə ðə kwinz ɡɑɹd wɝ nɑt sʌmθɪŋ sin ɛvɹi deɪ. əɹ ɛvɝ bɪfɔɹ, kʌm tə ðæt. ʃi hæd tʃoʊzən əm aʊt fɹəm ðə nu ɹəkɹuts hɝsɛlf fəɹ ðət vɛɹi ɹizən.

Her companions drew their own share of attention. After barely three years as Aes Sedai, Sareitha's dark square face had not yet achieved agelessness, and she looked a prosperous merchant in her fine bronze-colored woolens with a large silver-and-sapphires brooch holding her cloak. Her Warder, Ned Yarman, rode at her heels, and he certainly caught eyes. A tall, broad-shouldered young man with bright blue eyes and corn-yellow hair curling to his shoulders, he wore a shimmering Warder's cloak that made him appear a disembodied head floating above a tall gray gelding that was not entirely there either, where the cloak draped its haunches. There was no mistaking what he was, or that his presence announced an Aes Sedai. The others, maintaining a circle around Elayne as they made a way through the crowd, attracted just as many eyes, though. Eight women in the red coats and burnished helmets and breastplates of the Queen's Guard were not something seen every day. Or ever before, come to that. She had chosen them out from the new recruits herself for that very reason.

ðɛɹ ʌndɝ-lutɛnənt, keɪsil ɹɑskɑvni, lin ən hɑɹɾ əz ɛni il meɪɾən, wɑz ðət ɹɛɹəɾi ʌv ɹɛɹɪɾiz, ə wʊmən mɝtʃəns ɡɑɹd, nɪɹli twɛnti jɪɹz ɪn ðə tʃɹeɪd, əz ʃi pʊɾ ɪt. sɪlvɝ bɛlz ɪn əɹ stɑki ɹoʊn ɡɛldɪŋz meɪn neɪmd əɹ ɝæfɛlɪn, ðoʊ ʃi wɑz veɪɡ əbaʊɾ əɹ pæst. ði oʊnli ændɔɝən əmʌŋ ði eɪt wɑz ə ɡɹeɪɪŋ, plæsəd-feɪst wʊmən wɪð waɪd ʃoʊldɝz, dɪni koʊlfɝd, hu hæd kɛpt ɔɹɾɝ ɪn ə wæɡən dʒɹaɪvɝz' tævɝn ɪn loʊ keɪɛmlɪn, aʊtsaɪd ðə wɔlz, ənʌðɝ ɹʌf ən sɪŋɡjəlɝ dʒɑb fəɹ ə wʊmən. dɪni dɪd nɑt jɛt noʊ haʊ tə juz ðə sɔɹɾ əɾ əɹ hɪp, bʌt bɝdʒɪt sɛd ʃi hæd vɛɹi kwɪk hænz ən kwɪkɝ aɪz, ən ʃi wɑz kwaɪɾ ədɛpt wɪð ðə peɪs-lɔŋ kʌdʒəl ðət hʌŋ ɑpəzəɾ əɹ sɔɹd. ðə ɹɪmeɪndɝ wɝ hʌntɝz fəɹ ðə hɔɹn, dɪspɝɪt wɪmən, tɔl ən ʃɔɹt, slɛndɝ ən waɪd, dui-aɪɾ ən ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd, wɪð bækɡɹaʊnz əz vɛɹid, ðoʊ səm wɝ əz dɪskɹiɾ əz keɪsil ən ʌðɝz klɪɹli ɪnfleɪɾəd ðɛɹ fɔɹmɝ steɪʃən ɪn laɪf. niðɝ æɾətud wɑz ənkɑmən əmʌŋ hʌntɝz. ðeɪ hæd lɛpt ət ðə tʃæns tə bi lɪstəɾ ɑn ðə ɡɑɹdz' ɹoʊl, ðoʊ. mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt, ðeɪ hæd pæs bɝdʒɪts kloʊs ɪnspɛkʃən.

Their under-lieutenant, Caseille Raskovni, lean and hard as any Aiel Maiden, was that rarity of rarities, a woman merchant's guard, nearly twenty years in the trade, as she put it. Silver bells in her stocky roan gelding's mane named her Arafellin, though she was vague about her past. The only Andoran among the eight was a graying, placid-faced woman with wide shoulders, Deni Colford, who had kept order in a wagon drivers' tavern in Low Caemlyn, outside the walls, another rough and singular job for a woman. Deni did not yet know how to use the sword at her hip, but Birgitte said she had very quick hands and quicker eyes, and she was quite adept with the pace-long cudgel that hung opposite her sword. The remainder were Hunters for the Horn, disparate women, tall and short, slender and wide, dewy-eyed and gray-haired, with backgrounds as varied, though some were as discreet as Caseille and others clearly inflated their former station in life. Neither attitude was uncommon among Hunters. They had leaped at the chance to be listed on the Guards' roll, though. More important, they had passed Birgitte's close inspection.

"ðiz stʃɹits ɑɹ nɑt seɪf fəɹ ju," sɝaɪðə sɛd sʌɾənli, hilɪŋ əɹ tʃɛsnʌɾ ʌp bɪsaɪɾ ɪleɪnz blæk ɡɛldɪŋ. faɪɹhɑɹɾ ɔlmoʊs mænədʒ tə nɪp ðə slik mɛɹ bɪfɔɹ ɪleɪn ɹeɪn ɪz hɛɾ əweɪ. ðə stʃɹit wɑz nɛɹoʊ hɪɹ, kəmpɹɛsɪŋ ðə kɹaʊɾ ən fɔɹsɪŋ ðə ɡɑɹdzwɪmən ɪn kloʊsɝ ɝaʊn ðɛm. ðə bɹaʊn sɪstɝz feɪs pɪktʃɝɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ kəmpoʊʒɝ, bʌɾ əpɛɹən kənsɝn ʃɑɹpən əɹ toʊn. "ɛniθɪŋ maɪt hæpən ɪn ə kɹʌʃ laɪk ðɪs. ɹɪmɛmbɝ u ɪz steɪɪŋ ət ðə sɪlvɝ swɑn, lɛs ðən tu maɪlz fɹəm ðɪs spɑt. tɛn sɪstɝz ət wʌn ɪn ɑɹ nɑt sɪmpli sikɪŋ ðɛɹ oʊn fəɹ kʌmpəni. ɪleɪɾə maɪt wɛl əv sɛn ðɛm."

"These streets are not safe for you," Sareitha said suddenly, heeling her chestnut up beside Elayne's black gelding. Fireheart almost managed to nip the sleek mare before Elayne reined his head away. The street was narrow here, compressing the crowd and forcing the Guardswomen in closer around them. The Brown sister's face pictured Aes Sedai composure, but apparent concern sharpened her tone. "Anything might happen in a crush like this. Remember who is staying at the Silver Swan, less than two miles from this spot. Ten sisters at one inn are not simply seeking their own for company. Elaida might well have sent them."

"ʃi maɪt nɑt hæv, tu," ɪleɪn ɹɪplaɪd kɑmli. mɔɹ kɑmli ðən ʃi fɛlt. ə ɡɹeɪt mɛni sɪstɝz sim tə bi weɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðə saɪɾ əntɪl ðə stʃɹʌɡəl bɪtwin ɪleɪɾə ən ɛɡwin wɑz oʊvɝ. tu hæd dɪpɑɹɾəd ðə sɪlvɝ swɑn ən θɹi mɔɹ kʌm dʒʌst sɪns əɹ ɝaɪvəl ɪn keɪɛmlɪn. ðət dɪd nɑt saʊn laɪk ə pɑɹɾi sɛn ɑn ə mɪʃən. ən nʌn wɝ ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ; ʃʊɹli ɪleɪɾə wəɾ ɪnklud ɹɛdz. stɪl, ðeɪ wɝ biɪŋ wɑtʃt əz wɛl əz ʃi kəɾ ɝeɪnʒ, ðoʊ ʃi dɪd nɑt tɛl sɝaɪðə ðæt. ɪleɪɾə vɛɹi mʌtʃ wɑntəd hɝ, mʌtʃ mɔɹ ðən ʃi wəd wɑn ə ɹʌnəweɪ æksɛptɪd, əɹ wʌn kənɛktəd tə ɛɡwin ən ðoʊz ɪleɪɾə kɔld ɹɛbəlz. waɪ, ʃi kəd nɑt kwaɪɾ ʌndɝstænd. ə kwin u wɑz ɛɛs sədaɪ wəd bi ə ɡɹeɪt pɹaɪz fəɹ ðə waɪt taʊɝ, bʌt ʃi wəd nɑt bɪkʌm kwin ɪf ʃi wɑz snætʃt bæk tə tɑɹ vəlɑn. fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, ɪleɪɾə hæɾ ɪʃud ði ɔɹɾɝ tə bɹɪŋ əɹ bæk baɪ ɛni minz nɛsəsɛɹi lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ ðəɹ simd ɛni pɑsəbɪləɾi ʃi wəɾ əsum ðə θɹoʊn fəɹ mɛni jɪɹz tə kʌm. ɪt wɑz ə pʌzəl ʃi hæd fɹɛɾɪd oʊvɝ mɔɹ ðən wʌns sɪns ɹɑn məkʊə slɪpt əɹ ðət faʊl bɹu ðət dʌld ə wʊmənz əbɪləɾi tə tʃænəl. ə vɛɹi wɝiɪŋ pʌzəl, ɪspɛʃli naʊ ʃi wɑz ənaʊnsɪŋ əɹ loʊkeɪʃən tə ðə wɝld.

"She might not have, too," Elayne replied calmly. More calmly than she felt. A great many sisters seemed to be waiting on the side until the struggle between Elaida and Egwene was over. Two had departed the Silver Swan and three more come just since her arrival in Caemlyn. That did not sound like a party sent on a mission. And none were Red Ajah; surely Elaida would include Reds. Still, they were being watched as well as she could arrange, though she did not tell Sareitha that. Elaida very much wanted her, much more than she would want a runaway Accepted, or one connected to Egwene and those Elaida called rebels. Why, she could not quite understand. A queen who was Aes Sedai would be a great prize for the White Tower, but she would not become queen if she was snatched back to Tar Valon. For that matter, Elaida had issued the order to bring her back by any means necessary long before there seemed any possibility she would assume the throne for many years to come. It was a puzzle she had fretted over more than once since Ronde Macura slipped her that foul brew that dulled a woman's ability to channel. A very worrying puzzle, especially now she was announcing her location to the world.

hɝ aɪz lɪŋɡɝɾ ə moʊmən ɑn ə blæk-hɛɹd wʊmən ɪn ə blu kloʊk wɪð əɹ hʊd θɹoʊn bæk. ðə wʊmən bɛɹli ɡlænst əɾ əɹ bɪfɔɹ tɝnɪŋ ɪndə ə kændəlmeɪkɝz ʃɑp. ə weɪɾɪd klɔθ bæɡ hʌŋ fɹəm əɹ ʃoʊldɝ. nɑɾ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ, ɪleɪn dɪsaɪɾɪd. mɪɹli ənʌðɝ wʊmən u eɪdʒd wɛl, laɪk zeɪɾə. "ɪn ɛni keɪs," ʃi wɛn ɑn fɝmli, "aɪ woʊn bi pɛn ʌp baɪ fɪɹ ʌv ɪleɪɾə." wʌt wɝ ðoʊz sɪstɝz ət ðə sɪlvɝ swɑn ʌp tə?

Her eyes lingered a moment on a black-haired woman in a blue cloak with her hood thrown back. The woman barely glanced at her before turning into a candlemaker's shop. A weighted cloth bag hung from her shoulder. Not an Aes Sedai, Elayne decided. Merely another woman who aged well, like Zaida. "In any case," she went on firmly, "I won't be penned up by fear of Elaida." What were those sisters at the Silver Swan up to?

sɝaɪðə snɔɹɾɪd, ən nɑt vɛɹi sɔfli; ʃi simd əbaʊt tə ɹoʊl əɹ aɪz, ðən θɔt bɛɾɝ ʌv ɪt. əkeɪʒənəli ɪleɪn kɑɾ ən ɑd lʊk fɹəm wʌn ə ði ʌðɝ sɪstɝz ɪn ðə pæləs, daʊtləs θɪŋkɪŋ ə haʊ ʃi hæd bɪn ɹeɪzd, jɛɾ ɑn ðə sɝfəs, ət list, ðeɪ æksɛptɪɾ əɹ əz ɛɛs sədaɪ, æknɑlɪdʒ ðət ʃi stʊd haɪɝ əmʌŋ əm ðən ɛni ɪksɛp nɪneɪiv. ðət wɑz nɑɾ ɪnʌf tə stɑp əm spikɪŋ ðɛɹ maɪnz, ɔfən mɔɹ blʌnli ðət ðeɪ wəɾ əv wɪð ə sɪstɝ u stʊd wɛɹ ʃi dɪɾ ən hæɾ ətʃiv ðə ʃɔl ɪn mɔɹ juʒəwəl fæʃən. "fɝɡɛɾ ɪleɪɾə, ðɛn," sɝaɪðə sɛd, "æn ɹɪmɛmbɝ u ɛls wəd laɪk tə hæv jə ɪn hænd. wʌn wɛl-eɪmd ɹɑk, ən jə ɑɹ ən ʌnkɑnʃəs bʌndəl, izəli kæɹiɾ əweɪ ɪn ðə kənfjuʒən."

Sareitha snorted, and not very softly; she seemed about to roll her eyes, then thought better of it. Occasionally Elayne caught an odd look from one of the other sisters in the Palace, doubtless thinking of how she had been raised, yet on the surface, at least, they accepted her as Aes Sedai, acknowledged that she stood higher among them than any except Nynaeve. That was not enough to stop them speaking their minds, often more bluntly that they would have with a sister who stood where she did and had achieved the shawl in more usual fashion. "Forget Elaida, then," Sareitha said, "and remember who else would like to have you in hand. One well-aimed rock, and you are an unconscious bundle, easily carried away in the confusion."

dɪd sɝaɪðə ɹɪli hæv tə tɛl əɹ wɔɾɝ wɑz wɛt? kɪdnæpɪŋ ʌðɝ kleɪməns tə ðə θɹoʊn wɑz ɔlmoʊs kʌstəmɛɹi, æftɝ ɔl. ɛvɹi haʊs ðət stʊɾ əɡɛnst əɹ hæd səpɔɹɾɝz ɪn keɪɛmlɪn wɑtʃɪŋ fəɹ ən ɑpɝtunəɾi, əɹ ʃi wəɾ əv əɹ slɪpɝz fəɹ əɹ mɪddeɪ mil. nɑt ðət ðeɪ kəd səksid, nɑt soʊ lɔŋ əz ʃi kəd tʃænəl, bʌt ðeɪ wəd meɪk ði ətɛmpt ɡɪvən ə tʃæns. ʃi hæd nɛvɝ θɔt ðət sɪmpli ɹitʃɪŋ keɪɛmlɪn pɹəvaɪɾəd seɪfti.

Did Sareitha really have to tell her water was wet? Kidnapping other claimants to the throne was almost customary, after all. Every House that stood against her had supporters in Caemlyn watching for an opportunity, or she would have her slippers for her midday meal. Not that they could succeed, not so long as she could channel, but they would make the attempt given a chance. She had never thought that simply reaching Caemlyn provided safety.

"ɪf aɪ doʊn dɛɹ liv ðə pæləs, sɝaɪðə, əl nɛvɝ ɡɛt ðə pipəl bɪhaɪn mi," ʃi sɛd kwaɪətli. "aɪ mʌs bi sin, aʊɾ ən əbaʊɾ ən ʌnəfɹeɪd." ðət wɑz waɪ ʃi hæɾ eɪt ɡɑɹdz ɪnstɛɾ ə ðə fɪfti bɝdʒɪt hæd wɑntəd. ðə wʊmən ɹəfjuz tə ɡɹæsp ðə ɹiæləɾiz ə pɑlətɪks. "bɪsaɪdz, ðeɪ wəd nid tu wɛl-eɪmd ɹɑks wɪð jə hɪɹ."

"If I don't dare leave the Palace, Sareitha, I will never get the people behind me," she said quietly. "I must be seen, out and about and unafraid." That was why she had eight Guards instead of the fifty Birgitte had wanted. The woman refused to grasp the realities of politics. "Besides, they would need two well-aimed rocks with you here."

sɝaɪðə snɔɹɾɪd əɡɛn, bʌɾ ɪleɪn dɪɾ əɹ bɛs tə ɪɡnɔɹ ði ʌðɝz ɑbstənəsi. ʃi wɪʃt ʃi kəɾ ɪɡnɔɹ ðə wʊmənz pɹɛzəns, bʌt ðət wɑz ɪmpɑsəbəl. ʃi hæd mɔɹ ɹizən fəɹ ðɪs ɹaɪd ðən biɪŋ sin. hælwɪn nɔɹi ɡeɪv əɹ fæks ən fɪɡjɝz baɪ ðə ɹim, ðoʊ ðə fɝs klɝks dʒɹoʊnɪŋ vɔɪs ɔlmoʊs pʊɾ əɹ tə slip, jɛt ʃi wɑntəd tə si fəɹ hɝsɛlf. nɔɹi kəd meɪk ə ɹaɪət saʊn əz laɪfləs əz ə ɹipɔɹɾ ɑn ðə steɪɾ ə ðə sɪɾiz sɪstɝnz əɹ ði ɪkspɛns ə klinɪŋ ðə suɝz.

Sareitha snorted again, but Elayne did her best to ignore the other's obstinacy. She wished she could ignore the woman's presence, but that was impossible. She had more reason for this ride than being seen. Halwin Norry gave her facts and figures by the ream, though the First Clerk's droning voice almost put her to sleep, yet she wanted to see for herself. Norry could make a riot sound as lifeless as a report on the state of the city's cisterns or the expense of cleaning the sewers.

ðə kɹaʊdz wɝ θɪk wɪð fɔɹənɝz, kændɔɹi wɪð fɔɹk bɪɹdz ən ɪliɑnɝz wɪð bɪɹdz ðət lɛf ðɛɹ ʌpɝ lɪps bɛɹ ən ɝæfɛlɪn wɪð sɪlvɝ bɛlz ɪn ðɛɹ bɹeɪdz, kɑpɝ-skɪn dəmɑni, ɑləv-skɪn ɔltɑɹənz ən dɑɹk tɛɹənz, kɛɹhinɪn u stʊɾ aʊt fəɹ ðɛɹ ʃɔɹt stætʃɝ ən peɪl skɪnz. səm wɝ mɝtʃəns, kɑt baɪ ðə sʌɾən ɑnsɛɾ ʌv wɪntɝ əɹ hoʊpɪŋ tə stil ə dʒʌmp ɑn ðɛɹ kɑmpətɪʃən, smuð-feɪs pʌft-ʌp foʊk u nu ðət tʃɹeɪd wɑz ðə laɪfs blʌɾ ə neɪʃənz, ən ɛvɹi wʌn ə ðɛm kleɪmɪŋ tə bi ə meɪdʒɝ ɑɹɾɝi ivən wən bɪtʃɹeɪd baɪ ə pʊɹli daɪd koʊɾ əɹ ə bɹutʃ ə bɹæs ən ɡlæs. mɛni ʌv ðə pipəl əfʊt hæd wɔɹn ən ɹæɡəd koʊts, bɹitʃɪz aʊɾ ət ðə ni, dʒɹɛsəz wɪð tæɾɝd hɛmz, ən θɹɛdbɛɹ kloʊks əɹ nʌn əɾ ɔl. ðoʊz wɝ ɹɛfjudʒiz, iðɝ hɛɹid fɹəm ðɛɹ hoʊmz baɪ wɔɹ əɹ sɛnt wɑndɝɪŋ baɪ ðə bɪlif ðət ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn hæd bɹoʊkən ɛvɹi bɑn ðət hɛl ðɛm. ðeɪ hʌntʃt əɡɛns ðə koʊld, feɪsəz hæɡɝɾ ən dɪfiɾəd, ən lɛt ðɛmsɛlvz bi bəfeɪd baɪ ðə floʊ ʌv ʌðɝz ɝaʊn ðɛm.

The crowds were thick with foreigners, Kandori with forked beards and Illianers with beards that left their upper lips bare and Arafellin with silver bells in their braids, copper-skinned Domani, olive-skinned Altarans and dark Tairens, Cairhienin who stood out for their short stature and pale skins. Some were merchants, caught by the sudden onset of winter or hoping to steal a jump on their competition, smooth-faced puffed-up folk who knew that trade was the life's blood of nations, and every one of them claiming to be a major artery even when betrayed by a poorly dyed coat or a brooch of brass and glass. Many of the people afoot had worn and ragged coats, breeches out at the knee, dresses with tattered hems, and threadbare cloaks or none at all. Those were refugees, either harried from their homes by war or sent wandering by the belief that the Dragon Reborn had broken every bond that held them. They hunched against the cold, faces haggard and defeated, and let themselves be buffeted by the flow of others around them.
