wɑtʃɪŋ ə dʌl-aɪd wʊmən stæɡɝ θɹu ðə kɹaʊd klʌtʃɪŋ ə smɔl tʃaɪld ɑn əɹ ʃoʊldɝ, ɪleɪn fʌmbəld ə kɔɪn fɹəm əɹ pɝs ən hændəɾ ɪt tə wʌn ə ðə ɡɑɹdz, ən æpəl-tʃikt wʊmən wɪð koʊld aɪz. zɪɡən kleɪm tə bi fɹəm ɡildən, ðə dɔɾɝ ʌv ə maɪnɝ noʊbəl; wɛl, ʃi maɪt bi ɡildænɪn, ət list. wən ðə ɡɑɹdzwʊmən lin daʊn tə pɹɑfɝ ðə kɔɪn, ðə wʊmən wɪð əɹ tʃaɪl stæɡɝɾ ɑn baɪ ənhiɾɪŋ, ənsiɪŋ. ðəɹ wɝ tu mɛni ɪn ðə sɪɾi laɪk ðæt. ðə pæləs fɛd θaʊzənz ɛvɹi deɪ, ət kɪtʃənz sɛɾ ʌp θɹuaʊt ðə sɪɾi, bʌt tu mɛni kəd nɑɾ ivən sʌmən ði ɛnɝdʒi tə kəlɛk ðɛɹ bɹɛɾ ən sup. ɪleɪn ɔfɝɾ ə pɹɛɹ fəɹ mʌðɝ ən tʃaɪld əz ʃi dʒɹɑp ðə kɔɪn bæk ɪndə hɝ pɝs.

Watching a dull-eyed woman stagger through the crowd clutching a small child on her shoulder, Elayne fumbled a coin from her purse and handed it to one of the Guards, an apple-cheeked woman with cold eyes. Tzigan claimed to be from Ghealdan, the daughter of a minor noble; well, she might be Ghealdanin, at least. When the Guardswoman leaned down to proffer the coin, the woman with her child staggered on by unheeding, unseeing. There were too many in the city like that. The Palace fed thousands every day, at kitchens set up throughout the city, but too many could not even summon the energy to collect their bread and soup. Elayne offered a prayer for mother and child as she dropped the coin back into her purse.

"ju kænɑt fiɾ ɛvɹiwʌn," sɝaɪðə ɔfɝd kwaɪətli.

"You cannot feed everyone," Sareitha offered quietly.

"tʃɪlʒɹən ɑɹ nɑɾ əlaʊd tə stɑɹv ɪn ændɝ," ɪleɪn sɛd, əz ɪf ɪʃuɪŋ ə dɪkɹi. bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt noʊ haʊ tə stɑp ɪt. fud wɑz stɪl plɛntəfəl ɪn ðə sɪɾi, bʌt noʊ kəmæn kəd fɔɹs pipəl tə it.

"Children are not allowed to starve in Andor," Elayne said, as if issuing a decree. But she did not know how to stop it. Food was still plentiful in the city, but no command could force people to eat.

səm ə ði ʌðɝ fɔɹənɝz hæd kʌm tə keɪɛmlɪn ðət weɪ, tu, mɛn ən wɪmən u noʊ lɔŋɡɝ wɔɹ ɹæɡz ən hɔntəd feɪsəz. wʌtɛvɝ hæd sɛn əm flaɪɪŋ fɹəm ðɛɹ hoʊmz, ðeɪ hæd bɪɡʌn θɪŋkɪŋ ðət ðeɪ hæd tʃɹævəl fɑɹ ɪnʌf, θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt ðə tʃɹeɪdz ðeɪ hæɾ əbændənd, ɔfən əlɔŋ wɪð ɛvɹiθɪŋ ðeɪ pəzɛst. ɪn keɪɛmlɪn, ðoʊ, ɛniwʌn wɪð skɪl ɪn ə kɹæft ən ə lɪɾəl dʒɹaɪv kəɾ ɔlweɪz faɪn ə bæŋkɝ wɪð ɹɛɾi kɔɪn. ðəɹ wɝ nu tʃɹeɪdz biɪŋ fɑloʊɾ ɪn ðə sɪɾi ðiz deɪz. ʃi hæd sin θɹi klɑkmeɪkɝz' ʃɑps ɔlɹɛɾi ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ! wɪðɪn əɹ saɪt wɝ tu ʃɑps sɛlɪŋ bloʊn ɡlæs, ən nɪɹli θɝɾi mænjəfæktɝiz hæd bɪn bɪl nɔɹθ ə ðə sɪɾi. fɹəm naʊ ɑn, keɪɛmlɪn wəɾ ɪkspɔɹt ɡlæs, nɑɾ ɪmpɔɹɾ ɪt, ən kɹɪstəl əz wɛl. ðə sɪɾi hæd leɪsmeɪkɝz, naʊ, pɹədusɪŋ əz faɪn əz luɡɹɾ ɛvɝ hæd, ən noʊ wʌndɝ sɪns nɪɹli ɔl ə ðɛm hæd kʌm fɹəm ðɛɹ.

Some of the other foreigners had come to Caemlyn that way, too, men and women who no longer wore rags and haunted faces. Whatever had sent them flying from their homes, they had begun thinking that they had traveled far enough, thinking about the trades they had abandoned, often along with everything they possessed. In Caemlyn, though, anyone with skill in a craft and a little drive could always find a banker with ready coin. There were new trades being followed in the city these days. She had seen three clockmakers' shops already this morning! Within her sight were two shops selling blown glass, and nearly thirty manufactories had been built north of the city. From now on, Caemlyn would export glass, not import it, and crystal as well. The city had lacemakers, now, producing as fine as Lugard ever had, and no wonder since nearly all of them had come from there.

ðət bɹaɪɾənd əɹ muɾ ə lɪɾəl - ðə tæksəz ðoʊz nu kɹæfs peɪd wəd hɛlp, ðoʊ ɪt wəd teɪk taɪm bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ peɪd mʌtʃ - jɛɾ ɪt wɑz stɪl ʌðɝz ɪn ðə kɹaʊdz ʃi noʊɾəst moʊst. fɔɹən əɹ ændɔɝən, ðə mɝsənɛɹiz wɝ izəli pɪkt aʊt, hɑɹd-feɪs mɛn wɛɹɪŋ sɔɹdz, swæɡɝɪŋ ivən wən sloʊd tə ə kɹɔl baɪ ðə pɹɛs. mɝtʃəns' ɡɑɹdz ɔlsoʊ wɛn ɑɹmd, ɹʌf fɛloʊz ʃoʊldɝɪŋ əsaɪd moʊs mɛn u ɡɑɾ ɪn ðɛɹ weɪ, bʌt ðeɪ sim səbduɾ ən soʊbɝ kəmpɛɹd tə ðə sɛl-sɔɹdz. ən ɑn ðə hoʊl, ðeɪ dɪspleɪd fjuɝ skɑɹz. mɝsənɛɹiz dɑɾəd ðə kɹaʊd laɪk ɹeɪzənz ɪn ə keɪk. wɪð sətʃ ə lɑɹdʒ pul tə dʒɹɔ ɑn, ən wɪð wɪntɝ ɛmplɔɪmən fəɹ ðɛɹ skɪlz ɔlweɪz ɪn ʃɔɹt səplaɪ, ʃi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ðeɪ wəd kʌm tu dɪɹ. ənlɛs, əz daɪɛlɪn fɪɹd, ðeɪ kɑst əɹ ændɝ. sʌmhaʊ, ʃi hæd tə faɪn ɪnʌf mɛn ðət fɔɹənɝz wɝ nɑɾ ə mədʒɔɹəɾi ɪn ðə ɡɑɹdz. ən ðə mʌni tə peɪ ðɛm.

That brightened her mood a little - the taxes those new crafts paid would help, though it would take time before they paid much - yet it was still others in the crowds she noticed most. Foreign or Andoran, the mercenaries were easily picked out, hard-faced men wearing swords, swaggering even when slowed to a crawl by the press. Merchants' guards also went armed, rough fellows shouldering aside most men who got in their way, but they seemed subdued and sober compared to the sell-swords. And on the whole, they displayed fewer scars. Mercenaries dotted the crowd like raisins in a cake. With such a large pool to draw on, and with winter employment for their skills always in short supply, she did not think they would come too dear. Unless, as Dyelin feared, they cost her Andor. Somehow, she had to find enough men that foreigners were not a majority in the Guards. And the money to pay them.

əbɹʌpli, ʃi bɪkeɪm əwɛɹ ə bɝdʒɪt. ði ʌðɝ wʊmən wɑz æŋɡɹi - ʃi ɔfən wɑz, ʌv leɪt - ən kʌmɪŋ kloʊsɝ. vɛɹi æŋɡɹi, ən kʌmɪŋ vɛɹi kwɪkli. ən ɑmənəs kɑmbəneɪʃən ðət sɛɾ əlɑɹm ɡɔŋz ɹɪŋɪŋ ɪn ɪleɪnz hɛd.

Abruptly, she became aware of Birgitte. The other woman was angry - she often was, of late - and coming closer. Very angry, and coming very quickly. An ominous combination that set alarm gongs ringing in Elayne's head.

ɪmiɾiətli ʃi ɔɹɾɝd ə ɹɪtɝn tə ðə pæləs baɪ ðə moʊs dɝɛkt ɹut - ðət wəd bi haʊ bɝdʒɪt wɑz kʌmɪŋ; ðə bɑnd wəd lɛɾ əɹ stʃɹeɪt tə ɪleɪn - ən ðeɪ tʊk ðə nɛks tɝn saʊθ, ɑntu niɾəl stʃɹit. ɪt wɑz æktʃəli  ə ɹæðɝ waɪd stʃɹit, ðoʊ ɪt miændɝd laɪk ə ɹɪvɝ, daʊn wʌn hɪl ən ʌp ðə nɛkst, bʌt dʒɛnɝeɪʃənz əɡoʊ ɪt hæd bɪn fʊl ə niɾəlmeɪkɝz. naʊ ə fju smɔl ɪnz ən tævɝnz wɝ dʒæmd əmʌŋ kʌtlɝz ən teɪlɝz ən ɛvɹi sɔɹɾ ə ʃɑp ɪksɛp niɾəlmeɪkɝz.

Immediately she ordered a return to the Palace by the most direct route - that would be how Birgitte was coming; the bond would lead her straight to Elayne - and they took the next turn south, onto Needle Street. It was actually a rather wide street, though it meandered like a river, down one hill and up the next, but generations ago it had been full of needlemakers. Now a few small inns and taverns were jammed among cutlers and tailors and every sort of shop except needlemakers.

bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ hæɾ ivən ɹitʃt ði ɪnɝ sɪɾi, bɝdʒɪt faʊn əm klaɪmɪŋ pɛɹmənz leɪn, wɛɹ ə hændfʊl ə fɹut-sɛlɝz stɪl klʌŋ tə ʃɑps hændəd daʊn sɪns ðə deɪz ʌv ɪʃɑɹə, ðoʊ ðəɹ wɑz pɹɛʃəs lɪɾəl tə bi sin ɪn ðɛɹ wɪndoʊz ðɪs taɪm ə jɪɹ. dɪspaɪt ðə kɹaʊd bɝdʒɪt kæntɝɾ ɪndə saɪt, ɹɛd kloʊk flɛɹɪŋ bɪhaɪnd, skæɾɝɪŋ pipəl bɪfɔɹ əɹ lɛft ən ɹaɪt, ən oʊnli sloʊɾ əɹ ɹeɪnʒi ɡɹeɪ wən ʃi sɔ ðɛm əhɛd.

Before they had even reached the Inner City, Birgitte found them climbing Pearman's Lane, where a handful of fruit-sellers still clung to shops handed down since the days of Ishara, though there was precious little to be seen in their windows this time of year. Despite the crowd Birgitte cantered into sight, red cloak flaring behind, scattering people before her left and right, and only slowed her rangy gray when she saw them ahead.

əz ɪf tə meɪk ʌp fəɹ əɹ hɝi, ʃi tʊk ə moʊmən tə stʌɾi ðə ɡɑɹdzwɪmən ən ɹɪtɝn keɪsilz səlut bɪfɔɹ tɝnɪŋ əɹ maʊn tə wɔk bɪsaɪɾ ɪleɪnz. ənlaɪk ðɛm, ʃi wɔɹ niðɝ sɔɹd nɔɹ ɑɹmɝ. ðə mɛmɹiz ə hɝ pæs laɪvz wɝ feɪɾɪŋ - ʃi sɛd ʃi kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ nʌθɪŋ əɾ ɔl klɪɹli bɪfɔɹ ðə faʊndɪŋ ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ, naʊ, ðoʊ fɹæɡməns stɪl floʊɾəd ʌp - bʌt wʌn θɪŋ ʃi kleɪm tə ɹikɔl æbsəlutli. ɛvɹi taɪm ʃi hæd tʃɹaɪd tə juz ə sɔɹd, ʃi hæd nɪɹli ɡɑɾən hɝsɛlf kɪld, ən hæɾ ivən dʌn soʊ mɔɹ ðən wʌns. hɝ stʃɹʌŋ baʊ wɑz ɪn ə lɛðɝ sæɾəl-keɪs, ðoʊ, wɪð ə bɹɪsəlɪŋ kwɪvɝ ʌv æɹoʊz ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪd. æŋɡɝ bɔɪld ɪn hɝ, ən ʃi wɔɹ ə fɹaʊn ðəɾ oʊnli dipən əz ʃi spoʊk.

As if to make up for her hurry, she took a moment to study the Guardswomen and return Caseille's salute before turning her mount to walk beside Elayne's. Unlike them, she wore neither sword nor armor. The memories of her past lives were fading - she said she could remember nothing at all clearly before the founding of the White Tower, now, though fragments still floated up - but one thing she claimed to recall absolutely. Every time she had tried to use a sword, she had nearly gotten herself killed, and had even done so more than once. Her strung bow was in a leather saddle-case, though, with a bristling quiver of arrows on the other side. Anger boiled in her, and she wore a frown that only deepened as she spoke.

"ə hæf-fɹoʊzən pɪdʒən flu ɪndə ðə pæləs koʊɾ ə lɪɾəl waɪl əɡoʊ wɪð wɝd fɹəm ɑɹɪŋɡəl. ðə mɛn ɛskɔɹɾɪŋ nɑiən ən ɛləniə wɝ æmbʊʃt ən kɪl nɑt faɪv maɪlz aʊɾ ə ðə taʊn. lʌkəli, wʌn ə ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz keɪm bæk wɪð blʌɾ ɑn ðə sæɾəl, əɹ wiɾ əv noʊn nʌθɪŋ fəɹ wiks jɛt. aɪ daʊɾ əɹ lʌk ɪkstɛnz tə ðət pɛɹ biɪŋ hɛl fəɹ ɹænsəm baɪ bɹɪɡænz."

"A half-frozen pigeon flew into the Palace cote a little while ago with word from Aringill. The men escorting Naean and Elenia were ambushed and killed not five miles out of the town. Luckily, one of their horses came back with blood on the saddle, or we'd have known nothing for weeks yet. I doubt our luck extends to that pair being held for ransom by brigands."

faɪɹhɑɹt pɹænst ə fju stɛps, ən ɪleɪn ɹeɪn ɪm ɪn ʃɑɹpli. sʌmwʌn ɪn ðə kɹaʊd ʃaʊɾəd wʌt maɪɾ əv bɪn ə kɹaɪ fəɹ tʃɹəkənd. əɹ nɑt. ʃɑpkipɝz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ətʃɹækt kʌstəm ɹeɪzd ɪnʌf dɪn tə mʌfəl ðə wɝdz. "soʊ wɪv ə spaɪ ɪn ðə pæləs," ʃi sɛd, ðən kəmpɹɛst əɹ lɪps, wɪʃɪŋ ʃi hæd hɛld əɹ tʌŋ ɪn fɹʌn ə sɝaɪðə.

Fireheart pranced a few steps, and Elayne reined him in sharply. Someone in the crowd shouted what might have been a cry for Trakand. Or not. Shopkeepers trying to attract custom raised enough din to muffle the words. "So we have a spy in the Palace," she said, then compressed her lips, wishing she had held her tongue in front of Sareitha.

bɝdʒɪt dɪd nɑt sim tə kɛɹ. "ənlɛs ðɛɹz ə tɑvɝən tʃɹɑɾɪŋ ɝaʊnd wi doʊnt noʊ əbaʊt," ʃi ɹɪplaɪd dʒɹaɪli. "meɪbi naʊ jəl lemi əsaɪn ə bɑɾiɡɑɹd. dʒʌst ə fju ɡɑɹdz, wɛl tʃoʊzən ən - "

Birgitte did not seem to care. "Unless there's a ta'veren trotting around we don't know about," she replied dryly. "Maybe now you'll let me assign a bodyguard. Just a few Guards, well chosen and - "

"noʊ!" ðə pæləs wɑz əɹ hoʊm. ʃi wəd nɑt bi ɡɑɹɾəd ðɛɹ. ɡlænsɪŋ ət ðə bɹaʊn, ʃi saɪd. sɝaɪðə wɑz lɪsnɪŋ vɛɹi ətɛntɪvli. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ pɔɪn ɪn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə haɪd θɪŋz naʊ. nɑt ðɪs. "ju lɛt ðə fɝs meɪd noʊ?"

"No!" The Palace was her home. She would not be guarded there. Glancing at the Brown, she sighed. Sareitha was listening very attentively. There was no point in trying to hide things now. Not this. "You let the First Maid know?"

bɝdʒɪt ɡeɪv əɹ ə saɪɾɛlɔŋ lʊk ðæt, kəmbaɪnd wɪð ə bɝst ə maɪld aʊtʃɹeɪdʒ θɹu ðɛɹ ʃɛɹd bɑnd, toʊld əɹ tə ɡoʊ titʃ əɹ ɡɹændmʌðɝ tə nɪt. "ʃi ɪntɛnz tə kwɛstʃən ɛvɹi sɝvən u dɪdn sɝv jəɹ mʌðɝ ət lis faɪv jɪɹz. aɪm nɑt ʃʊɹ ʃi dʌzn min tə pʊɾ əm tə ðə kwɛstʃən. ðə lʊk ɑn əɹ feɪs wən aɪ toʊl hɝ, aɪ wɑz ɡlæd tə ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ə hɝ stʌɾi wɪð ə hoʊl skɪn. aɪm lʊkɪŋ əɾ ʌðɝz, maɪsɛlf." ʃi mɛn ðə ɡɑɹdz, bʌt ʃi wəd nɑt seɪ soʊ ɪn hɪɹɪŋ ə keɪsil ən ði ʌðɝz. ɪleɪn dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ɪt laɪkli. ɔl ðə ɹəkɹuɾɪŋ ɡeɪv ɛniwʌn ə pɝfəkt ɑpɝtunəɾi tə slɪp ɪn aɪz-ænd-ɪɹz, jɛt wɪθaʊɾ ɛni əʃʊɹəns ðeɪ wəɾ ɛvɝ bi wɛɹ ðeɪ kəd lɝn ɛniθɪŋ jusfəl.

Birgitte gave her a sidelong look that, combined with a burst of mild outrage through their shared bond, told her to go teach her grandmother to knit. "She intends to question every servant who didn't serve your mother at least five years. I'm not sure she doesn't mean to put them to the question. The look on her face when I told her, I was glad to get out of her study with a whole skin. I'm looking at others, myself." She meant the Guards, but she would not say so in hearing of Caseille and the others. Elayne did not think it likely. All the recruiting gave anyone a perfect opportunity to slip in eyes-and-ears, yet without any assurance they would ever be where they could learn anything useful.

"ɪf ðəɹ ɑɹ spaɪz ɪn ðə pæləs," sɝaɪðə sɛd kwaɪətli, "ðɛɹ meɪ bi wɝs. pɝhæps jə ʃəɾ æksɛp ðə leɪɾi bɝdʒɪts sədʒɛstʃən ʌv ə bɑɾiɡɑɹd. ðəɹ ɪz pɹɛsɪɾənt." bɝdʒɪt ʃoʊd ðə bɹaʊn sɪstɝ əɹ tiθ; əz ə smaɪl, ɪt wɑz ə mɪzɝəbəl feɪljɝ. haʊɛvɝ mʌtʃ ʃi dɪslaɪk biɪŋ ədʒɹɛs baɪ hɝ taɪɾəl, haʊɛvɝ, ʃi tɝn hoʊpfəl aɪz ɑn ɪleɪn.

"If there are spies in the Palace," Sareitha said quietly, "there may be worse. Perhaps you should accept the Lady Birgitte's suggestion of a bodyguard. There is precedent." Birgitte showed the Brown sister her teeth; as a smile, it was a miserable failure. However much she disliked being addressed by her title, however, she turned hopeful eyes on Elayne.

"aɪ sɛd noʊ, ən aɪ min noʊ!" ɪleɪn snæpt. ə bɛɡɝ, əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ ðə sloʊ-muvɪŋ sɝkəl ə hɔɹsəz wɪð ə waɪd, ɡæp-tuθt ɡɹɪn ən ɪz kæp ɪn ɪz hænd, flɪntʃt ən skɝiɾ əweɪ ɪndə ðə θɹɔŋ bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəɾ ivən θɪŋk ə ɹitʃɪŋ fəɹ əɹ pɝs. ʃi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ haʊ mʌtʃ ə hɝ æŋɡɝ wɑz əɹ oʊn ən haʊ mʌtʃ bɝdʒɪts, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz əpɹoʊpɹiət.

"I said no, and I mean no!" Elayne snapped. A beggar, approaching the slow-moving circle of horses with a wide, gap-toothed grin and his cap in his hand, flinched and scurried away into the throng before she could even think of reaching for her purse. She was not sure how much of her anger was her own and how much Birgitte's, but it was appropriate.

"aɪ ʃʊɾə ɡɔn tə ɡɛɾ əm maɪsɛlf," ʃi ɡɹaʊl bɪɾɝli. ɪnstɛd, ʃi hæd woʊvən ə ɡeɪtweɪ fəɹ ðə mɛsənʒɝ ən spɛn ðə ɹɛst ə ðə deɪ miɾɪŋ wɪð mɝtʃəns ən bæŋkɝz. "æt ðə list, aɪ ʃʊɾə stʃɹɪp ðə ɡɛɹɪsən əɾ ɑɹɪŋɡəl fəɹ ɛskɔɹt. tɛn mɛn dɛd kəz aɪ blʌndɝd! wɝs - ðə laɪt hɛlp mi, ɪts wɝs! - aɪv lɔst ɛləniə ən nɑiən kəz ʌv ɪt!"

"I should have gone to get them myself," she growled bitterly. Instead, she had woven a gateway for the messenger and spent the rest of the day meeting with merchants and bankers. "At the least, I should have stripped the garrison at Aringill for escort. Ten men dead because I blundered! Worse - the Light help me, it is worse! - I've lost Elenia and Naean because of it!"

bɝdʒɪts θɪk ɡoʊldən bɹeɪd, hæŋɪŋ aʊtsaɪɾ əɹ kloʊk, swʌŋ əz ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛɾ ɛmfæɾɪkli. "ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs, kwinz doʊnt ɡoʊ ɹʌnɪŋ ɔf tə də ɛvɹiθɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz. ðəɹ blʌɾi kwinz!" hɝ æŋɡɝ wɑz daɪɪŋ daʊn, ə lɪɾəl, bʌɾ ɪɹɪteɪʃən flɛɹɾ ɑn tɑp ʌv ɪt, ən əɹ toʊn ɹəflɛktəd boʊθ. ʃi ɹɪli wɑntəɾ ɪleɪn tə hæv ə bɑɾiɡɑɹd, vɛɹi laɪkli ivən ɪn əɹ bæθ. "jɔɹ ædvɛntʊɹɪŋ deɪz ɑɹ dʌn. ðə nɛks θɪŋ, jud bi snikɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə pæləs ɪn dɪsɡaɪz, meɪbi ivən wɑndɝɪŋ ɝaʊn æftɝ naɪtfɔl, wən jə maɪt ɡɛt jəɹ skʌl kɹækt oʊpən baɪ səm tʌf jə nɛvɝ ivən sɔ."

Birgitte's thick golden braid, hanging outside her cloak, swung as she shook her head emphatically. "In the first place, queens don't go running off to do everything themselves. They're bloody queens!" Her anger was dying down, a little, but irritation flared on top of it, and her tone reflected both. She really wanted Elayne to have a bodyguard, very likely even in her bath. "Your adventuring days are done. The next thing, you'd be sneaking out of the Palace in disguise, maybe even wandering around after nightfall, when you might get your skull cracked open by some tough you never even saw."

ɪleɪn sæɾ ʌp stʃɹeɪɾ ɪn əɹ sæɾəl. bɝdʒɪt nu, ʌv kɔɹs - ʃi dɪd nɑt noʊ ɛni weɪ tə ɡɛɾ ɝaʊn ðə bɑnd, ðoʊ ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ ðəɹ mʌs bi wʌn - bʌt ðə wʊmən hæd noʊ ɹaɪt tə bɹɪŋ ɪɾ ʌp naʊ. ɪf bɝdʒɪɾ ɔfɝɾ ɪnʌf hɪns, ʃi wəɾ əv ʌðɝ sɪstɝz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə fɑloʊ hɝ wɪð ðɛɹ wɔɹɾɝz ən laɪkli skwɑdz ʌv ɡɑɹdzmɪn əz wɛl. ɛvɹiwʌn wɑz soʊ ɹɪdɪkjələs əbaʊt kipɪŋ əɹ seɪf. jə wəd θɪŋk ʃi hæd nɛvɝ bɪn ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ, mʌtʃ lɛs tæntʃəkoʊ, əɹ fɑlm. bɪsaɪdz, ʃi hæɾ oʊnli dʌn ɪt wʌns. soʊ fɑɹ. ən eɪvinhə wɛnt wɪð hɝ.

Elayne sat up straight in her saddle. Birgitte knew, of course - she did not know any way to get around the bond, though she was sure there must be one - but the woman had no right to bring it up now. If Birgitte offered enough hints, she would have other sisters trying to follow her with their Warders and likely squads of Guardsmen as well. Everyone was so ridiculous about keeping her safe. You would think she had never been in Ebou Dar, much less Tanchico, or Falme. Besides, she had only done it once. So far. And Aviendha went with her.

"koʊl dɑɹk stʃɹits doʊn kəmpɛɹ tə ə wɔɹm faɪɝ ən ən ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ bʊk," sɝaɪðə pʊɾ ɪn aɪdli, əz ɪf tɔkɪŋ tə hɝsɛlf. stʌɾiɪŋ ðə ʃɑps ðeɪ wɝ pæsɪŋ, ʃi simd ɪntɛn ɑn ðɛm. "aɪ vɛɹi mʌtʃ dɪslaɪk wɔkɪŋ ɑn aɪsi peɪvmənt, maɪsɛlf, ɪspɛʃli ɪn ðə dɑɹk, wɪθaʊt soʊ mʌtʃ əz ə kændəl. jʌŋ, pɹɪɾi wɪmən ɔfən θɪŋk pleɪn kloʊðz ən ə dɝɾi feɪs meɪk əm ɪnvɪzəbəl." ðə ʃɪft wɑz soʊ sʌɾən, wɪð noʊ tʃeɪnʒ ɪn toʊn, ðəɾ ət fɝst ɪleɪn dɪd nɑt ɹilaɪz wʌt ʃi wɑz hɪɹɪŋ. "biɪŋ nɑk daʊn ən dʒɹæɡd ɪndə ən æli baɪ dʒɹʌŋkən ɹaʊɾiz ɪz ə hɑɹd weɪ tə lɝn dɪfɹənli. ʌv kɔɹs, ɪf jə ɑɹ lʌki ɪnʌf tə hæv ə fɹɛnd wɪð jə hu ɔlsoʊ kən tʃænəl, ɪf ʃiz lʌki ɪnʌf ðət ðə tʌf feɪlz tə hɪɾ əɹ əz hɑɹɾ əz i ʃəd . . . wɛl, jə kænɑt bi lʌki ɛvɹi taɪm. wʊdn jə əɡɹi, leɪɾi bɝdʒɪt?"

"Cold dark streets don't compare to a warm fire and an interesting book," Sareitha put in idly, as if talking to herself. Studying the shops they were passing, she seemed intent on them. "I very much dislike walking on icy pavement, myself, especially in the dark, without so much as a candle. Young, pretty women often think plain clothes and a dirty face make them invisible." The shift was so sudden, with no change in tone, that at first Elayne did not realize what she was hearing. "Being knocked down and dragged into an alley by drunken rowdies is a hard way to learn differently. Of course, if you are lucky enough to have a friend with you who also can channel, if she's lucky enough that the tough fails to hit her as hard as he should . . . Well, you cannot be lucky every time. Wouldn't you agree, Lady Birgitte?"

ɪleɪn kloʊzd əɹ aɪz fəɹ ə moʊmənt. eɪvinhə hæd sɛd sʌmwʌn wɑz fɑloʊɪŋ ðɛm, bʌt ʃi hæd bɪn ʃʊɹ ɪt wɑz oʊnli ə fʊtpæd. ɛniweɪ, ɪt hæd nɑt bɪn laɪk ðæt. nɑɾ ɪɡzækli. bɝdʒɪts ɡlɛɹ pɹɑməst ə tɔkɪŋ tə, leɪɾɝ. ʃi ɹəfjuz tə ʌndɝstæn ðəɾ ə wɔɹɾɝ dʒʌs dɪd nɑt dʒɹɛs daʊn əɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ.

Elayne closed her eyes for a moment. Aviendha had said someone was following them, but she had been sure it was only a footpad. Anyway, it had not been like that. Not exactly. Birgitte's glare promised a talking to, later. She refused to understand that a Warder just did not dress down her Aes Sedai.

"ɪn ðə sɛkən pleɪs," bɝdʒɪt wɛn ɑn ɡɹɪmli, "tɛn mɛn əɹ nɪɹli θɹi hʌnʒɹəd, ðə blʌɾi aʊtkʌm wʊɾə bɪn ðə blʌɾi seɪm. bɝn mi, ɪt wɑz ə ɡʊd plæn. ə fju mɛn cʊɾə bɹɔt nɑiən ən ɛləniə tə keɪɛmlɪn ənnoʊɾɪst. ɛmptiɪŋ aʊt ðə ɡɛɹɪsən wʊɾə pʊld ɛvɹi fleɪmɪŋ aɪ ɪn ði ist ʌv ændɝ, ən huɛvɝ tʊk əm wʊɾə bɹɔɾ ɪnʌf ɑɹmmɪn tə bi ʃʊɹ. vɛɹi laɪkli, ðeɪd hoʊld ɑɹɪŋɡəl naʊ ɑn tɑp ʌv ɪt. smɔl əz ðə ɡɛɹɪsən ɪz, ɑɹɪŋɡəl kips ɛnibəɾi hu wɑns tə muv əɡɛns jə ɪn ði ist ɔf bæləns, ən ðə mɔɹ ɡɑɹdz u kʌm aʊɾ ə kɛɹhin, ðə bɛɾɝ ðət ɡɛts, sɪns ðəɹ nɪɹli ɔl lɔɪəl tə ju." fəɹ sʌmwʌn u kleɪm tə bi ə sɪmpəl ɑɹtʃɝ, ʃi hæɾ ə ɡʊd ɡɹæsp ə ðə sɪtʃueɪʃən. ði oʊnli θɪŋ ʃi hæd lɛft aʊt wɑz ðə lɔs ə ðə kʌstəmz duɾiz fɹəm ðə ɹɪvɝ tʃɹeɪd.

"In the second place," Birgitte went on grimly, "ten men or nearly three hundred, the bloody outcome would have been the bloody same. Burn me, it was a good plan. A few men could have brought Naean and Elenia to Caemlyn unnoticed. Emptying out the garrison would have pulled every flaming eye in the east of Andor, and whoever took them would have brought enough armsmen to be sure. Very likely, they'd hold Aringill now on top of it. Small as the garrison is, Aringill keeps anybody who wants to move against you in the east off balance, and the more Guards who come out of Cairhien, the better that gets, since they're nearly all loyal to you." For someone who claimed to be a simple archer, she had a good grasp of the situation. The only thing she had left out was the loss of the customs duties from the river trade.

"hu dɪd teɪk ðɛm, leɪɾi bɝdʒɪt?" sɝaɪðə æskt, linɪŋ tə lʊk pæst ɪleɪn. "ʃʊɹli ðəɾ ɪz ə vɛɹi ɪmpɔɹɾənt kwɛstʃən." bɝdʒɪt saɪd laʊdli, ɔlmoʊst ə wɪmpɝ.

"Who did take them, Lady Birgitte?" Sareitha asked, leaning to look past Elayne. "Surely that is a very important question." Birgitte sighed loudly, almost a whimper.

"wi wɪl noʊ sun ɪnʌf, aɪ fɪɹ," ɪleɪn sɛd. ðə bɹaʊn kwɝkt ə daʊɾɪŋ aɪbɹaʊ ət hɝ, ən ʃi tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə ɡɹaɪn əɹ tiθ. ʃi sim tə bi duɪŋ ðət kwaɪɾ ə lɑt sɪns kʌmɪŋ hoʊm.

"We will know soon enough, I fear," Elayne said. The Brown quirked a doubting eyebrow at her, and she tried not to grind her teeth. She seemed to be doing that quite a lot since coming home.

eɪ tæɹɑbənɝ wʊmən ɪn ə ɡɹin sɪlk kloʊk stɛpt aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ ʌv ðə hɔɹsəz ən meɪɾ ə dip kɝtsi, hɝ θɪn, biɾɪd bɹeɪdz swɪŋɪŋ aʊɾ ə hɝ kaʊl. hɝ meɪd, ə dɪmɪnjəɾɪv wʊmən wɪð əɹ ɑɹmz fʊl ə smɔl pækədʒəz, ɪməteɪɾɪd əɹ mɪstʃɹəs ɔkwɝdli. ðə tu waɪd mɛn kloʊs bɪhaɪnd, ɡɑɹdz kæɹiɪŋ bɹæs-fɹul kɔɹɾɝstɑfs, ɹɪmeɪn əpɹaɪɾ ən əlɝt. ðɛɹ lɔŋ hɛvi lɛðɝ koʊts wəd tɝn ɔl bʌt ðə moʊs dɪtɝmən θɹʌst ʌv ə naɪf.

A Taraboner woman in a green silk cloak stepped out of the way of the horses and made a deep curtsy, her thin, beaded braids swinging out of her cowl. Her maid, a diminutive woman with her arms full of small packages, imitated her mistress awkwardly. The two wide men close behind, guards carrying brass-ferruled quarterstaffs, remained upright and alert. Their long heavy leather coats would turn all but the most determined thrust of a knife.

ɪleɪn ɪnklaɪn əɹ hɛɾ əz ðeɪ ɹoʊd baɪ tə æknɑlɪdʒ ðə tæɹɑbənɝz kɝɾəsi. ʃi hæd nɑt ɹəsivd əz mʌtʃ fɹəm ɛni ændɔɝən ɪn ðə stʃɹits, soʊ fɑɹ. ðə hænsəm feɪs bɪhaɪn ðə wʊmənz ʃɪɹ veɪl ʃoʊd tu mʌtʃ eɪdʒ tə bi ɛɛs sədaɪ. laɪt, ʃi hæd tu mʌtʃ ɑn əɹ pleɪt tə bi wɝiɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪleɪɾə naʊ!

Elayne inclined her head as they rode by to acknowledge the Taraboner's courtesy. She had not received as much from any Andoran in the streets, so far. The handsome face behind the woman's sheer veil showed too much age to be Aes Sedai. Light, she had too much on her plate to be worrying about Elaida now!

"ɪɾ ɪz vɛɹi sɪmpəl, sɝaɪðə," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn ə kɛɹfəli kəntʃɹoʊl vɔɪs. "ɪf dʒɑɝɪd sɑɝən tʊk ðɛm, ɛləniə wɪl ɡɪv nɑiən ə tʃɔɪs. dɪklɛɹ ɑɝɔn fəɹ ɛləniə, wɪð səm swiɾənɪŋ ʌv ɪsteɪts fəɹ nɑiən ɪn ɹɪtɝn, əɹ ɛls əv əɹ θɹoʊt slɪɾ ɪn ə kwaɪət sɛl sʌmwɛɹ ən əɹ kɔɹps bɛɹid bɪhaɪn ə bɑɹn. nɑiən woʊnt ɡɪv ɪn izəli, bʌɾ əɹ haʊs ɪz ɑɹɡjuɪŋ oʊvɝ u ɪz ɪn tʃɑɹdʒ əntɪl ʃi ɹɪtɝnz, soʊ ðəl dɪðɝ, ɛləniə wɪl θɹɛɾən tɔɹtʃɝ ən meɪbi juz ɪt, ən ɪvɛntʃəwəli ɑɝɔn wɪl stæn bɪhaɪn sɑɝən fəɹ ɛləniə. sun tə bi dʒɔɪn baɪ ænʃɝ ən bɛɹɪn; ðəl ɡoʊ wɛɹ ðeɪ si stʃɹɛŋkθ. ɪf nɑiənz pipəl əv ðɛm, ʃɪl ɔfɝ ðə seɪm tʃɔɪsəz tə ɛləniə, bʌt dʒɑɝɪd wɪl ɡoʊ ɑn ə ɹæmpeɪdʒ əɡɛnst ɑɝɔn ənlɛs ɛləniə tɛlz ɪm nɑt tə, ən ʃi woʊn ɪf ʃi θɪŋks hiz ɛni hoʊp ə ɹɛskjuɪŋ hɝ. soʊ wi mʌs hoʊp tə hɪɹ ɪn ðə nɛks fju wiks ðəɾ ɑɝɔn ɪsteɪts ɑɹ biɪŋ bɝnd." ɪf nɑt, ʃi θɔt, aɪ hæv fɔɹ haʊsəz junaɪɾəd tə feɪs, ən aɪ stɪl doʊnt noʊ wɛðɝ aɪ ɹɪli hæv ivən tu!

"It is very simple, Sareitha," she said in a carefully controlled voice. "If Jarid Sarand took them, Elenia will give Naean a choice. Declare Arawn for Elenia, with some sweetening of estates for Naean in return, or else have her throat slit in a quiet cell somewhere and her corpse buried behind a barn. Naean won't give in easily, but her House is arguing over who is in charge until she returns, so they'll dither, Elenia will threaten torture and maybe use it, and eventually Arawn will stand behind Sarand for Elenia. Soon to be joined by Anshar and Baryn; they will go where they see strength. If Naean's people have them, she will offer the same choices to Elenia, but Jarid will go on a rampage against Arawn unless Elenia tells him not to, and she won't if she thinks he has any hope of rescuing her. So we must hope to hear in the next few weeks that Arawn estates are being burned." If not, she thought, I have four houses united to face, and I still don't know whether I really have even two!

"ðæɾ ɪz . . . vɛɹi naɪsli ɹizən aʊt," sɝaɪðə sɛd, saʊndɪŋ feɪnli sɝpɹaɪzd.

"That is . . . very nicely reasoned out," Sareitha said, sounding faintly surprised.

"aɪm ʃʊɹ jə kəd hæv, tu, wɪð taɪm," ɪleɪn sɛd, tu switli, ən fɛlt ə stæb ə plɛʒɝ wən ði ʌðɝ sɪstɝ blɪŋkt. laɪt, hɝ mʌðɝ wʊɾə ɪkspɛktəɾ əɹ tə si ðət mʌtʃ wən ʃi wɑz tɛn!

"I'm sure you could have, too, with time," Elayne said, too sweetly, and felt a stab of pleasure when the other sister blinked. Light, her mother would have expected her to see that much when she was ten!

ðə ɹɛst ə ðə ɹaɪd bæk tə ðə pæləs pæst ɪn saɪləns, ən ʃi bɛɹli noʊɾəst ðə bɹaɪt moʊzeɪɪk taʊɝz ən ɡɹæn vɪstəz ə ði ɪnɝ sɪɾi. ɪnstɛd, ʃi θɔɾ əbaʊɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn keɪɛmlɪn ən spaɪz ɪn ðə ɹɔɪəl pæləs, əbaʊɾ u hæɾ ɛləniə ən nɑiən ən haʊ mʌtʃ bɝdʒɪt kəd stɛp ʌp ɹəkɹuɾɪŋ, əbaʊt wɛðɝ ɪt wɑz taɪm tə sɛl ðə pæləsəz pleɪɾ ən ðə ɹɛst ə hɝ dʒɛmz. ə ɡlumi lɪs tə kənsɪɾɝ, bʌt ʃi kɛpt əɹ feɪs smuð ən sɝinəli æknɑlɪdʒ ðə skæn tʃɪɹz ðət fɑloʊd hɝ. ə kwin kəd nɑt ʃoʊ hɝsɛlf əfɹeɪd, ɪspɛʃli wən ʃi wɑz.

The rest of the ride back to the Palace passed in silence, and she barely noticed the bright mosaic towers and grand vistas of the Inner City. Instead, she thought about Aes Sedai in Caemlyn and spies in the Royal Palace, about who had Elenia and Naean and how much Birgitte could step up recruiting, about whether it was time to sell the Palace's plate and the rest of her gems. A gloomy list to consider, but she kept her face smooth and serenely acknowledged the scant cheers that followed her. A queen could not show herself afraid, especially when she was.

ðə ɹɔɪəl pæləs wɑz ə pjʊɹ waɪt kənfɛkʃən ʌv ɪntʃɹəkətli wɝk bælkəniz ən kɑləmd wɔks ətɑp ðə haɪəs hɪl ə ði ɪnɝ sɪɾi, ðə haɪəst ɪn keɪɛmlɪn. ɪts slɛndɝ spaɪɹz ən ɡɪldɪd doʊmz lumd əɡɛns ðə mɪddeɪ skaɪ, vɪzəbəl fəɹ maɪlz, pɹoʊkleɪmɪŋ ðə paʊɝ ʌv ændɝ. ɡɹæn ɛntʃɹənsəz ən dɪpɑɹtʃɝz wɝ meɪɾ ət ðə fɹʌnt, ət ðə kwinz plɑzə, wɛɹ ɪn ðə pæst ɡɹeɪt kɹaʊdz hæd ɡæðɝd tə hɪɹ ðə pɹɑkləmeɪʃənz ə kwinz ən ʃaʊt ðɛɹ əkleɪm fəɹ ændɝz ɹulɝz. ɪleɪn ɛntɝɾ ət ðə ɹɪɹ ə ðə pæləs, faɪɹhɑɹts stil-ʃɑd hʊvz ɹɪŋɪŋ ɑn ðə peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz əz ʃi tʃɹɑɾəd ɪndə ðə meɪn steɪbliɑɹd. ɪt wɑz ə bɹɔd speɪs fɹʌntɪɾ ɑn tu saɪdz baɪ ðə ɹoʊz ə tɔl ɑɹtʃt dɔɹz ə ðə steɪbəlz, oʊvɝlʊk baɪ ə sɪŋɡəl lɔŋ waɪt stoʊn bælkəni, pleɪn ən stɝɾi. sɛvɹəl ə ðə haɪ, kɑləmd wɔks ɔfɝd pɑɹʃəl vjuz fɹəm əbʌv, bʌt ðɪs wɑz ə wɝkɪŋ pleɪs. ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə sɪmpəl kɑləneɪd ðət ɡeɪv ɛntʃɹi tə ðə pæləs ɪtsɛlf ə dʌzən ɡɑɹdzmɪn pɹipɛɹɪŋ tə ɹipleɪs ðoʊz ɑn duɾi ɪn ðə plɑzə stʊd ɹɪdʒɪdli bɪsaɪd ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz, biɪŋ ɪnspɛktɪd baɪ ðɛɹ ʌndɝ-lutɛnənt, ə ɡɹɪzəl fɛloʊ wɪð ə lɪmp u hæd bɪn ə bænɝmən ʌndɝ ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn. əlɔŋ ði aʊɾɝ wɔl, θɝɾi mɔɹ wɝ maʊntɪŋ, ɹɛɾi tə bɪɡɪn pətʃɹoʊlz ə ði ɪnɝ sɪɾi ɪn pɛɹz. ɪn nɔɹməl deɪz, ðəɹ wʊɾə bɪn ɡɑɹdzmɪn huz meɪn duɾi wɑz pəlisɪŋ ðə stʃɹits, bʌt wɪð nʌmbɝz soʊ ɹədust, ðoʊz u pɹətɛktəd ðə pæləs hæd tə də ðəɾ əz wɛl. kɛɝin fɹænzi wɑz ðɛɹ, əz wɛl, ə stɑki wʊmən ɪn ən ɛləɡənt ɡɹin-stʃɹaɪpt ɹaɪɾɪŋ dʒɹɛs ən blu-ɡɹin kloʊk, sɪɾɪŋ əɹ ɡɹeɪ ɡɛldɪŋ waɪl wʌn ə hɝ wɔɹɾɝz, ɛnɝ koʊsən, klaɪmd ɑntu hɪz beɪ. dɑɹk, wɪð tʌtʃəz ʌv ɡɹeɪ ɪn ɪz taɪt-kɝl hɛɹ ən bɪɹd, ðə bleɪd-slɪm mæn wɔɹ ə pleɪn bɹaʊn kloʊk. əpɛɹənli ðeɪ dɪd nɑt min tə ædvɝtaɪz u ðeɪ wɝ.

The Royal Palace was a pure white confection of intricately worked balconies and columned walks atop the highest hill of the Inner City, the highest in Caemlyn. Its slender spires and gilded domes loomed against the midday sky, visible for miles, proclaiming the power of Andor. Grand entrances and departures were made at the front, at the Queen's Plaza, where in the past great crowds had gathered to hear the proclamations of queens and shout their acclaim for Andor's rulers. Elayne entered at the rear of the Palace, Fireheart's steel-shod hooves ringing on the paving stones as she trotted into the main stableyard. It was a broad space fronted on two sides by the rows of tall arched doors of the stables, overlooked by a single long white stone balcony, plain and sturdy. Several of the high, columned walks offered partial views from above, but this was a working place. In front of the simple colonnade that gave entry to the Palace itself a dozen Guardsmen preparing to replace those on duty in the Plaza stood rigidly beside their horses, being inspected by their under-lieutenant, a grizzled fellow with a limp who had been a bannerman under Gareth Bryne. Along the outer wall, thirty more were mounting, ready to begin patrols of the Inner City in pairs. In normal days, there would have been Guardsmen whose main duty was policing the streets, but with numbers so reduced, those who protected the Palace had to do that as well. Careane Fransi was there, as well, a stocky woman in an elegant green-striped riding dress and blue-green cloak, sitting her gray gelding while one of her Warders, Venr Kosaan, climbed onto his bay. Dark, with touches of gray in his tight-curled hair and beard, the blade-slim man wore a plain brown cloak. Apparently they did not mean to advertise who they were.

ɪleɪnz ɝaɪvəl bɑɾ ə flæʃ ə sɝpɹaɪz tə ðə steɪbliɑɹd. nɑt tə kɛɝin əɹ koʊsən, ʌv kɔɹs. ðə ɡɹin sɪstɝ mɪɹli lʊk θɔtfəl ɪn ðə ʃɛltɝɪŋ kaʊl ə hɝ kloʊk, ən koʊsən nɑɾ ivən ðæt. hi sɪmpli nɑɾəd tə bɝdʒɪɾ ən jɑɹmən, wɔɹɾɝ tə wɔɹɾɝ. wɪθaʊɾ ənʌðɝ ɡlæns ðeɪ ɹoʊɾ aʊɾ əz sun əz ðə læst ʌv ɪleɪnz ɛskɔɹt klɪɹd ði aɪɝn-stʃɹæpt ɡeɪts. bʌt səm ə ðoʊz maʊntɪŋ əlɔŋ ðə wɔl pɔzd wɪð wʌn fʊɾ ɪn ə stɝəp, stɛɹɪŋ, ən hɛdz wɪp təwɔɹd ðə nu ɝaɪvəlz əmʌŋ ðə mɛn stændɪŋ ɪnspɛkʃən. ʃi hæd nɑt bɪn ɪkspɛktəd bæk fəɹ ənʌðɝ aʊɝ ət list, ən ɛksɛptɪŋ ə fju hu nɛvɝ θɔt bɪɑnd wʌt ðɛɹ hænz wɝ duɪŋ, ɛvɹiwʌn ɪn ðə pæləs nu ðə sɪtʃueɪʃən wɑz vɑləɾəl. ɹumɝz spɹɛɾ əmʌŋ soʊlʒɝz ivən fæstɝ ðən əmʌŋ ʌðɝ mɛn, ən ðə laɪt nu, ðət wɑz seɪɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ, ðə weɪ mɛn ɡɑsaɪpt. ðiz hæd tə noʊ ðət bɝdʒɪt hæd dɪpɑɹɾəd ɪn ə hɝi, ən naʊ ʃi ɹɪtɝnd wɪð ɪleɪn, əhɛɾ ə taɪm. wɑz wʌn ə ði ʌðɝ haʊsəz mɑɹtʃɪŋ ɑn keɪɛmlɪn? ɹɛɾi tə ətæk? wɝ ðeɪ tə bi ɔɹɾɝd tə ðə wɔlz ðət ðeɪ kəd nɑt mæn kəmplitli, ivən wɪð wʌt daɪɛlɪn hæɾ ɪn ðə sɪɾi? moʊməns ə sɝpɹaɪz ən wɝi, ðən ðə lɛðɝi ʌndɝ-lutɛnən bɑɹkt ə kəmænd, ən aɪz snæp stʃɹeɪɾ əhɛd, ɑɹmz swɛpt əkɹɔs tʃɛsts ɪn səlut. oʊnli θɹi bɪsaɪdz ðə fɔɹmɝ bænɝmən hæd bɪn ɑn ðə ɹoʊlz ə fju deɪz ɡɔn, bʌt ðəɹ wɝ noʊ ɹɔ ɹəkɹuts hɪɹ.

Elayne's arrival bought a flash of surprise to the stableyard. Not to Careane or Kosaan, of course. The Green sister merely looked thoughtful in the sheltering cowl of her cloak, and Kosaan not even that. He simply nodded to Birgitte and Yarman, Warder to Warder. Without another glance they rode out as soon as the last of Elayne's escort cleared the iron-strapped gates. But some of those mounting along the wall paused with one foot in a stirrup, staring, and heads whipped toward the new arrivals among the men standing inspection. She had not been expected back for another hour at least, and excepting a few who never thought beyond what their hands were doing, everyone in the Palace knew the situation was volatile. Rumors spread among soldiers even faster than among other men, and the Light knew, that was saying something, the way men gossiped. These had to know that Birgitte had departed in a hurry, and now she returned with Elayne, ahead of time. Was one of the other Houses marching on Caemlyn? Ready to attack? Were they to be ordered to the walls that they could not man completely, even with what Dyelin had in the city? Moments of surprise and worry, then the leathery under-lieutenant barked a command, and eyes snapped straight ahead, arms swept across chests in salute. Only three besides the former bannerman had been on the rolls a few days gone, but there were no raw recruits here.

ɡɹumz ɪn ɹɛd koʊts wɪð ðə waɪt laɪən ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd ɑn wʌn ʃoʊldɝ keɪm ɹʌʃɪŋ aʊt fɹəm ðə steɪbəl, ðoʊ ɪn fæk ðəɹ wɑz lɪɾəl fəɹ əm tə du. ðə ɡɑɹdzwɪmən kwaɪətli dɪsmaʊntɪɾ ət bɝdʒɪts ɔɹɾɝ ən bɪɡæn liɾɪŋ ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz θɹu ðə tɔl dɔɹz. ʃi hɝsɛlf lɛp fɹəm əɹ sæɾəl ən tɔst əɹ ɹeɪnz tə wʌn ə ðə ɡɹumz, ən ʃi wɑz noʊ kwɪkɝ ðən jɑɹmən, hu hɝid tə hoʊl sɝaɪðəz bɹaɪɾəl waɪl ʃi klaɪm daʊn. hi wɑz wʌt səm sɪstɝz kɔld "fɹɛʃ kɑt," bɑndəd lɛs ðən ə jɪɹ - ðə tɝm deɪɾɪd fɹəm ə taɪm wən wɔɹɾɝz hæd nɑɾ ɔlweɪz bɪn æskt wɛðɝ ðeɪ wɑntəd ðə bɑnd - ən i wɑz vɛɹi əsɪdwəs ɪn ɪz duɾiz. bɝdʒɪt dʒʌst stʊd skaʊlɪŋ, fɪsts ɑn əɹ hɪps, əpɛɹənli wɑtʃɪŋ ðə mɛn u wəd pətʃɹoʊl ði ɪnɝ sɪɾi fəɹ ðə nɛks fɔɹ aʊɝz ɹaɪɾ aʊɾ ɪn ə kɑləm ə tuz. ɪleɪn wʊɾə bɪn sɝpɹaɪzd ɪf ðoʊz mɛn mɔɹ ðən kɹɔs bɝdʒɪts maɪnd, ðoʊ.

Grooms in red coats with the White Lion embroidered on one shoulder came rushing out from the stable, though in fact there was little for them to do. The Guardswomen quietly dismounted at Birgitte's order and began leading their horses through the tall doors. She herself leaped from her saddle and tossed her reins to one of the grooms, and she was no quicker than Yarman, who hurried to hold Sareitha's bridle while she climbed down. He was what some sisters called "fresh caught," bonded less than a year - the term dated from a time when Warders had not always been asked whether they wanted the bond - and he was very assiduous in his duties. Birgitte just stood scowling, fists on her hips, apparently watching the men who would patrol the Inner City for the next four hours ride out in a column of twos. Elayne would have been surprised if those men more than crossed Birgitte's mind, though.

ɪn ɛni ɪvɛnt, ʃi hæɾ əɹ oʊn wɝiz. tʃɹaɪɪŋ nɑt tə bi ɑbviəs əbaʊɾ ɪt, ʃi stʌɾid ðə wɪɹi wʊmən u hɛl faɪɹhɑɹts bɹaɪɾəl, ən ðə stɑki fɛloʊ hu pʊt daʊn ə lɛðɝ-kʌvɝd maʊntɪŋ stul ən hɛld əɹ stɝəp əz ʃi dɪsmaʊntɪd. hi wɑz ənsməlɪŋli stɑləɾ ən dɪlɪbɝɪt, waɪl ʃi wɑz ɹæpt ʌp ɪn stʃɹoʊkɪŋ ðə ɡɛldɪŋz noʊz ən wɪspɝɪŋ tə hɪm. niðɝ ɹɪli lʊkt əɾ ɪleɪn bɪɑn ə ɹɪspɛkfəl baʊ ʌv ðə hɛd; kɝɾəsiz keɪm sɛkən tə meɪkɪŋ ʃʊɹ ʃi wɑz nɑt tɔs fɹəm ðə sæɾəl baɪ ə hɔɹs meɪd skɪɾɪʃ baɪ bɑbɪŋ pipəl. noʊ mæɾɝ ðət ʃi hæd noʊ niɾ ə ðɛɹ hɛlp. ʃi wɑz nɑɾ ɪn ðə kʌntʃɹi ɛni lɔŋɡɝ, ən ðəɹ wɝ fɔɹmz tə bi fɑloʊd. ivən soʊ, ʃi tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə fɹaʊn. livɪŋ əm əz ðeɪ lɛd faɪɹhɑɹɾ əweɪ, ʃi dɪd nɑt lʊk bæk. bʌt ʃi wɑntəd tə.

In any event, she had her own worries. Trying not to be obvious about it, she studied the wiry woman who held Fireheart's bridle, and the stocky fellow who put down a leather-covered mounting stool and held her stirrup as she dismounted. He was unsmilingly stolid and deliberate, while she was wrapped up in stroking the gelding's nose and whispering to him. Neither really looked at Elayne beyond a respectful bow of the head; courtesies came second to making sure she was not tossed from the saddle by a horse made skittish by bobbing people. No matter that she had no need of their help. She was not in the country any longer, and there were forms to be followed. Even so, she tried not to frown. Leaving them as they led Fireheart away, she did not look back. But she wanted to.

ðə wɪndoʊləs ɛntʃɹi hɔl bɪɑn ðə kɑləneɪd sim dɪm, ðoʊ ə fju ʌv ðə mɪɹɝd stænd-læmps wɝ lɪt. pleɪn læmps hɪɹ, ði aɪɝn wɝkt ɪndə sɪmpəl skɹoʊlz. ɛvɹiθɪŋ wɑz jutɪlətɛɹiən, ðə plæstɝd kɔɹnɪsəz ʌnədɔɹnd, ðə waɪt stoʊn wɔlz bɛɹ ən smuð. wɝɾ ə ðɛɹ ɝaɪvəl hæd spɹɛd, ən bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ wɝ wɛl ɪnsaɪd, hæf ə dʌzən mɛn ən wɪmən əpɪɹd, boʊɪŋ ən kɝtsiɪŋ, tə teɪk kloʊks ən ɡlʌvz. ðɛɹ lɪvɝi dɪfɝd fɹəm ðə steɪbəlfoʊks ɪn hævɪŋ waɪt kɑlɝz ən kʌfs, ən ðə laɪən ʌv ændɝ ɑn ðə lɛf bɹɛst ɹæðɝ ðən ʃoʊldɝ. ɪleɪn dɪd nɑt ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ɛniwʌn ɑn duɾi tədeɪ. moʊst sɝvəns ɪn ðə pæləs wɝ nu, ən ʌðɝz hæd kʌm aʊɾ ə ɹitaɪɝmən tə teɪk ðə pleɪsəz ə ðoʊz fɹaɪɾənd ɔf wən ɹænd kæptʃɝd ðə sɪɾi. ə bɔld, blʌf-feɪs fɛloʊ dɪd nɑt kwaɪt miɾ əɹ aɪz, bʌɾ i maɪɾ əv fɪɹɾ ɪt wəd bi tu fɔɹwɝd. ə slɛndɝ jʌŋ wʊmən wɪð ə skwɪn pʊt tu mʌtʃ ɪnθuziæzəm ɪndə hɝ kɝtsi, ən əɹ smaɪl, bʌt pɝhæps ʃi sɪmpli wɑntəd tə ʃoʊ iɡɝnəs. ɪleɪn wɔkt əweɪ, fɑloʊd baɪ bɝdʒɪt, bɪfɔɹ ʃi bɪɡæn ɡlɛɹɪŋ ət ðɛm. səspɪʃən hæɾ ə bɪɾɝ teɪst.

The windowless entry hall beyond the colonnade seemed dim, though a few of the mirrored stand-lamps were lit. Plain lamps here, the iron worked into simple scrolls. Everything was utilitarian, the plastered cornices unadorned, the white stone walls bare and smooth. Word of their arrival had spread, and before they were well inside, half a dozen men and women appeared, bowing and curtsying, to take cloaks and gloves. Their livery differed from the stablefolk's in having white collars and cuffs, and the Lion of Andor on the left breast rather than shoulder. Elayne did not recognize anyone on duty today. Most servants in the Palace were new, and others had come out of retirement to take the places of those frightened off when Rand captured the city. A bald, bluff-faced fellow did not quite meet her eyes, but he might have feared it would be too forward. A slender young woman with a squint put too much enthusiasm into her curtsy, and her smile, but perhaps she simply wanted to show eagerness. Elayne walked away, followed by Birgitte, before she began glaring at them. Suspicion had a bitter taste.

sɝaɪðə ən əɹ wɔɹɾɝ lɛft əm æftɝ ə fju peɪsɪz, ðə bɹaʊn mɝmɝɪŋ ən ɪkskjus əbaʊt bʊks ʃi wɑntəd tə si ɪn ðə laɪbɹɛɹi. ðə kəlɛkʃən wɑz nɑt smɔl, ðoʊ nʌθɪŋ ɪn kəmpɛɹəsən tə ðə ɡɹeɪt laɪbɹɛɹiz, ən ʃi spɛn aʊɝz ðəɹ ɛvɹi deɪ, fɹikwənli pʊlɪŋ ʌp eɪdʒ-wɔɹn vɑljumz ʃi sɛd wɝ ənnoʊn ɛlswɛɹ. jɑɹmən hild əɹ əz ʃi ɡlaɪɾɪd ɔf daʊn ə kɹɔsɪŋ hɔlweɪ, ə dɑɹk stɑki swɑn dʒɹɔɪŋ ə stʃɹeɪnʒli ɡɹeɪsfəl stɔɹk ɪn əɹ weɪk. hi stɪl kæɹiɾ ɪz dɪstɝbɪŋ kloʊk, kɛɹfəli foʊldəɾ oʊvɝ wʌn ɑɹm. wɔɹɾɝz ɹɛɹli lɛt ðoʊz aʊɾ ə ðɛɹ oʊn hænz fəɹ lɔŋ. koʊsənz laɪkli wɑz ɪn ɪz sæɾəlbæɡz.

Sareitha and her Warder left them after a few paces, the Brown murmuring an excuse about books she wanted to see in the library. The collection was not small, though nothing in comparison to the great libraries, and she spent hours there every day, frequently pulling up age-worn volumes she said were unknown elsewhere. Yarman heeled her as she glided off down a crossing hallway, a dark stocky swan drawing a strangely graceful stork in her wake. He still carried his disturbing cloak, carefully folded over one arm. Warders rarely let those out of their own hands for long. Kosaan's likely was in his saddlebags.

"wʊd jə laɪk ə wɔɹɾɝz kloʊk, bɝdʒɪt?" ɪleɪn æskt, wɔkɪŋ ɑn. nɑt fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm, ʃi ɛnvid bɝdʒɪɾ əɹ vəlumənəs tʃɹaʊzɝz. ivən dɪvaɪɾəd skɝts meɪɾ ən ɛfɝɾ ʌv ɛniθɪŋ bɪɑn ə sɪdeɪt peɪs. ət list ʃi hæɾ ɑn ɹaɪɾɪŋ buts ɪnstɛɾ ə slɪpɝz. ðə bɛɹ ɹɛd-ænd-waɪt flɔɹ taɪlz wʊɾə bɪn fɹizɪŋ ɪn slɪpɝz. ðəɹ wɝ nɑɾ ɪnʌf kɑɹpəts tə leɪɝ ɪn ðə hɔlz əz wɛl əz ɪn ðə ɹumz; ðeɪ wʊɾə bɪn wɔɹn aʊɾ ɪn noʊ taɪm, ɛniweɪ, dʒʌs fɹəm ðə kɑnstən tʃɹæfɪk ə sɝvəns kipɪŋ ʌp ðə pæləs. "æz sun əz ɛɡwin əz ðə taʊɝ, əl əv wʌn meɪd fəɹ ju. jə ʃəɾ əv wʌn."

"Would you like a Warder's cloak, Birgitte?" Elayne asked, walking on. Not for the first time, she envied Birgitte her voluminous trousers. Even divided skirts made an effort of anything beyond a sedate pace. At least she had on riding boots instead of slippers. The bare red-and-white floor tiles would have been freezing in slippers. There were not enough carpets to layer in the halls as well as in the rooms; they would have been worn out in no time, anyway, just from the constant traffic of servants keeping up the Palace. "As soon as Egwene has the Tower, I will have one made for you. You should have one."

"aɪ doʊn kɛɹ əbaʊt fleɪmɪŋ kloʊks," bɝdʒɪt ɹɪplaɪd ɡɹɪmli. ə fɔɹboʊɾɪŋ skaʊl sɛɾ əɹ maʊθ ɪn ə hɑɹd laɪn. "ɪt wɑz oʊvɝ soʊ fæst, aɪ θɔt jud dʒʌs blʌɾi stʌmbəld ən hɪt jəɹ blʌɾi hɛd. blʌɾ ən æʃəz! nɑk daʊn baɪ stʃɹit tʌfs! ðə laɪɾ oʊnli noʊz wʌt maɪɾ əv hæpənd!"

"I don't care about flaming cloaks," Birgitte replied grimly. A foreboding scowl set her mouth in a hard line. "It was over so fast, I thought you'd just bloody stumbled and hit your bloody head. Blood and ashes! Knocked down by street toughs! The Light only knows what might have happened!"

"ðɛɹ ɪz noʊ nid tə əpɑlədʒaɪz, bɝdʒɪt." aʊtʃɹeɪdʒ ən ɪndɪɡneɪʃən bɪɡæn flʌɾɪŋ θɹu ðə bɑnd, bʌt ʃi mɛn tə siz ði ædvæntɪdʒ. bɝdʒɪts tʃaɪɾɪŋ wɑz bæɾ ɪnʌf ɪn pɹaɪvət; ʃi wɑz nɑɾ əbaʊt tə pʊɾ ʌp wɪð ɪɾ ɪn ðə hɔlz, wɪð sɝvəns ɔl ɝaʊnd, skɝiɪŋ baɪ ɑn ɛɹənz, pɑlɪʃɪŋ ðə kɑɹvd wɔl pænəlz, tɛndɪŋ stænd-læmps ðət wɝ ɡɪldɪd hɪɹ. ðeɪ bɛɹli pɔz tə ɔfɝ saɪlən kɝɾəsiz tə bɝdʒɪɾ ən hɝ, bʌt daʊtləs ɛvɹi wʌn wɑz wʌndɝɪŋ waɪ ðə kæptən-dʒɛnɝəl lʊk laɪk ə θʌndɝhɛɾ ən hæd ðɛɹ ɪɹz waɪd tə kætʃ wʌtɛvɝ ðeɪ kʊd. "ju wɝ nɑt ðəɹ kəz aɪ dɪdnt wɑn jə ðɛɹ. əl weɪdʒɝ sɝaɪðə dɪdn əv nɛd wɪð hɝ." ɪt hɑɹdli sim pɑsəbəl ðət bɝdʒɪts feɪs kəd dɑɹkən mɔɹ. pɝhæps mɛnʃənɪŋ sɝaɪðə wɑz ə mɪsteɪk. ɪleɪn tʃeɪnʒd ðə sʌbʒɪkt. "ju ɹɪli mʌs də sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt jəɹ læŋɡwədʒ. jə ɑɹ bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə saʊn laɪk ðə wɝst sɔɹɾ ə laɪəbaʊt."

"There is no need to apologize, Birgitte." Outrage and indignation began flooding through the bond, but she meant to seize the advantage. Birgitte's chiding was bad enough in private; she was not about to put up with it in the halls, with servants all around, scurrying by on errands, polishing the carved wall panels, tending stand-lamps that were gilded here. They barely paused to offer silent courtesies to Birgitte and her, but doubtless every one was wondering why the Captain-General looked like a thunderhead and had their ears wide to catch whatever they could. "You were not there because I didn't want you there. I'll wager Sareitha didn't have Ned with her." It hardly seemed possible that Birgitte's face could darken more. Perhaps mentioning Sareitha was a mistake. Elayne changed the subject. "You really must do something about your language. You are beginning to sound like the worst sort of layabout."

"maɪ . . . læŋɡwədʒ," bɝdʒɪt mɝmɝd deɪnʒɝəsli. ivən əɹ stʃɹaɪdz tʃeɪnʒd, tə sʌmθɪŋ laɪk ə peɪsɪŋ lɛpɝd. "ju tɔk əbaʊt maɪ læŋɡwədʒ? ət list aɪ ɔlweɪz noʊ wʌt ðə wɝdz aɪ juz min. ət list aɪ noʊ wʌt fɪts wɛɹ, ən wʌt dʌznt." ɪleɪn kʌlɝd, ən əɹ nɛk stɪfənd. ʃi dɪd noʊ! moʊst ə ðə taɪm. ɔfən ɪnʌf, ət list. "æz fəɹ jɑɹmən," bɝdʒɪt wɛn ɑn, hɝ vɔɪs stɪl sɑft, ən stɪl deɪnʒɝəs, "hiz ə ɡʊd mæn, bʌɾ i ɪzən oʊvɝ biɪŋ ɡɑɡəl-aɪd ðət hiz ə wɔɹɾɝ jɛt. hi pɹɑbli dʒʌmps wən sɝaɪðə snæps əɹ fɪŋɡɝz. aɪ wɑz nɛvɝ ɡɑɡəl-aɪd, ən aɪ doʊn dʒʌmp. ɪz ðət waɪ jə sæɾəld mi wɪð ə taɪɾəl? dɪd jə θɪŋk ɪt wəd ɹeɪn mi ɪn? wʊdn əv bɪn ðə fɝst sɪli θɔɾ ɪn ðət hɛɾ ə jʊɹz. fəɹ sʌmwʌn u θɪŋks soʊ klɪɹli moʊst ə ðə taɪm . . . wɛl. aɪ hæv ə ɹaɪɾɪŋ dɛsk bɛɹiɾ ɪn fleɪmɪŋ ɹɪpɔɹts aɪ hæv tə ʃʌvəl θɹu ɪf jəɹ gɑnə ɡɛɾ ivən hæf ðə ɡɑɹdz jə wɑnt, bʌt wɪl əv ə ɡʊd lɔŋ tɔk tənaɪt. maɪ leɪɾi," ʃi æɾəd, mʌtʃ tu fɝmli. hɝ baʊ wɑz ɔlmoʊs mɑkəŋli fɔɹməl. ʃi stɔkt əweɪ, ən əɹ lɔŋ ɡoʊldən bɹeɪd ʃʊɾə bɪn bɹɪsəlɪŋ laɪk ən æŋɡɹi kæts teɪl.

"My . . . language," Birgitte murmured dangerously. Even her strides changed, to something like a pacing leopard. "You talk about my language? At least I always know what the words I use mean. At least I know what fits where, and what doesn't." Elayne colored, and her neck stiffened. She did know! Most of the time. Often enough, at least. "As for Yarman," Birgitte went on, her voice still soft, and still dangerous, "he's a good man, but he isn't over being goggle-eyed that he's a Warder yet. He probably jumps when Sareitha snaps her fingers. I was never goggle-eyed, and I don't jump. Is that why you saddled me with a title? Did you think it would rein me in? Wouldn't have been the first silly thought in that head of yours. For someone who thinks so clearly most of the time . . . Well. I have a writing desk buried in flaming reports I have to shovel through if you're going to get even half the Guards you want, but we'll have a good long talk tonight. My Lady," she added, much too firmly. Her bow was almost mockingly formal. She stalked away, and her long golden braid should have been bristling like an angry cat's tail.

ɪleɪn stæmpt əɹ fʊɾ ɪn fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən. bɝdʒɪts taɪɾəl wɑz ə wɛl-ɝn ɹɪwɔɹd, ɝn tɛn taɪmz oʊvɝ dʒʌst sɪns ʃi bɑndəd ðə wʊmən! ən tɛn θaʊzən taɪmz oʊvɝ bɪfɔɹ ðæt. wɛl, ʃi hæd θɔɾ ə ði ʌðɝ, bʌt nɑɾ əntɪl æftɝwɝdz. mʌtʃ ɡʊɾ ɪt hæd dʌn, ɛniweɪ. wɛðɝ fɹəm lidʒ leɪɾi əɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ, bɝdʒɪt tʃoʊz wɪtʃ kəmænz ʃi oʊbeɪd. nɑt wən ɪt wɑz ɪmpɔɹɾənt - nɑt wən ʃi θɔɾ ɪt wɑz ɪmpɔɹɾənt, ɛniweɪ - bʌɾ oʊvɝ ɛniθɪŋ ɛls, ɪspɛʃli wʌt ʃi kɔld ənnɛsəsɛɹi ɹɪsks, əɹ ɪmpɹɑpɝ bɪheɪvjɝ. əz ɪf bɝdʒɪt sɪlvɝboʊ kəd tɔk tə ɛniwʌn əbaʊt teɪkɪŋ ɹɪsks! ən əz fəɹ pɹɑpɝ bɪheɪvjɝ, bɝdʒɪt kɛɹzd ɪn tævɝnz! ʃi dʒɹæŋk ən ɡæmbəld, ən oʊɡəl pɹɪɾi mɛn tə but! ʃi ɛndʒɔɪd lʊkɪŋ ət ðə pɹɪɾi wʌnz ivən ɪf ʃi dɪd pɹəfɝ ðoʊz u lʊkt əz ɪf ðeɪ hæd bɪn biɾən əbaʊt ðə hɛɾ ɔfən. ɪleɪn dɪd nɑt wɑnə tʃeɪnʒ əɹ - ʃi ədmaɪɝd ðə wʊmən, laɪk hɝ, kaʊntəɾ əɹ ə fɹɛnd - bʌt ʃi wɪʃt ðəɹ wɝ ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ ʌv wɔɹɾɝ tə ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn ðɛɹ ɹileɪʃənʃɪp. ən mʌtʃ lɛs ə noʊɪŋ oʊldɝ sɪstɝ tə skæmpɪʃ jʌŋɡɝ.

Elayne stamped her foot in frustration. Birgitte's title was a well-earned reward, earned ten times over just since she bonded the woman! And ten thousand times over before that. Well, she had thought of the other, but not until afterwards. Much good it had done, anyway. Whether from liege lady or Aes Sedai, Birgitte chose which commands she obeyed. Not when it was important - not when she thought it was important, anyway - but over anything else, especially what she called unnecessary risks, or improper behavior. As if Birgitte Silverbow could talk to anyone about taking risks! And as for proper behavior, Birgitte caroused in taverns! She drank and gambled, and ogled pretty men to boot! She enjoyed looking at the pretty ones even if she did prefer those who looked as if they had been beaten about the head often. Elayne did not want to change her - she admired the woman, liked her, counted her a friend - but she wished there were a little more of Warder to Aes Sedai in their relationship. And much less of knowing older sister to scampish younger.

əbɹʌpli ʃi ɹilaɪz ðət ʃi wɑz stændɪŋ ðəɹ skaʊlɪŋ ət nʌθɪŋ. sɝvəns hɛzɪteɪɾɪd əz ðeɪ wɛn baɪ, ən tʌk ðɛɹ hɛdz daʊn əz ɪf əfɹeɪd ʃi maɪt bi ɡlɛɹɪŋ ət ðɛm. smuðɪŋ əɹ feɪs, ʃi dʒɛstʃɝd tə ə ɡæŋɡəlɪŋ, pɪmpli-feɪs bɔɪ kʌmɪŋ daʊn ðə hɔl. hi baʊd soʊ ɔkwɝdli ən soʊ dipli ðəɾ i stæɡɝɾ ən ɔlmoʊs fɛl oʊvɝ.

Abruptly she realized that she was standing there scowling at nothing. Servants hesitated as they went by, and tucked their heads down as if afraid she might be glaring at them. Smoothing her face, she gestured to a gangling, pimply-faced boy coming down the hall. He bowed so awkwardly and so deeply that he staggered and almost fell over.

"faɪn mɪstʃɹəs hɑɹfɝ ən æsk əɹ tə si mi ɪmiɾiətli ɪn maɪ əpɑɹtməns," ʃi toʊl hɪm, ðən æɾəd ɪn ə nɑɾ əŋkinli vɔɪs, "æn jə maɪt ɹɪmɛmbɝ, jəɹ supɪɹiɝz woʊn bi plizd ɪf ðeɪ faɪn jə ɡɔkɪŋ ət ðə pæləs wən jə ʃəd bi wɝkɪŋ." hɪz maʊθ dʒɹɑpt oʊpən əz ðoʊ ʃi hæd ɹɛɾ ɪz maɪnd. pɝhæps i θɔt ʃi hæd. hɪz waɪɾ aɪz flæʃt tə hɝ ɡɹeɪt sɝpən ɹɪŋ, ən i skwikt ən meɪɾ ən ivən dipɝ baʊ bɪfɔɹ dɑɹɾɪŋ əweɪ əɾ ə dɛd ɹʌn.

"Find Mistress Harfor and ask her to see me immediately in my apartments," she told him, then added in a not unkindly voice, "And you might remember, your superiors won't be pleased if they find you gawking at the Palace when you should be working." His mouth dropped open as though she had read his mind. Perhaps he thought she had. His wide eyes flashed to her Great Serpent ring, and he squeaked and made an even deeper bow before darting away at a dead run.

ʃi smaɪld ɪn spaɪɾ ə hɝsɛlf. ɪt hæd bɪn ə waɪl stæb, bʌɾ i wɑz tu jʌŋ tə bi ɛniwʌnz spaɪ, ən tu nɝvəs nɑt tə bi ʌp tə sʌmθɪŋ i ʃəd nɑt. ɑn ði ʌðɝ hænd . . . hɝ smaɪl feɪɾəd. ɑn ði ʌðɝ hænd, hi wɑz nɑt ðət mʌtʃ jʌŋɡɝ ðən ʃi.

She smiled in spite of herself. It had been a wild stab, but he was too young to be anyone's spy, and too nervous not to be up to something he should not. On the other hand . . . Her smile faded. On the other hand, he was not that much younger than she.


tʃæptɝ eɪt


CHAPTER 8

si foʊk ən kɪn


Sea Folk and Kin

ɪt wɑz noʊ sɝpɹaɪz tə ɪleɪn wən ʃi ɪnkaʊntɝd ðə fɝs meɪd bɪfɔɹ ɹitʃɪŋ əɹ əpɑɹtməns. æftɝ ɔl, ðeɪ wɝ boʊθ hɛɾɪŋ fəɹ ðə seɪm pleɪs. mɪstʃɹəs hɑɹfɝ meɪɾ əɹ kɝtsi ən fɛl ɪn wɪð hɝ, kæɹiɪŋ ən ɪmbɔs lɛðɝ foʊldɝ bɪniθ wʌn ɑɹm. ʃi hæd sɝɾənli bɪn ʌp əz ɝli əz ɪleɪn ɪf nɑɾ ɝliɝ, bʌɾ əɹ skɑɹlət tɑbɝɾ əpɪɹd fɹɛʃli aɪɝnd, ðə waɪt laɪən ɑn əɹ fɹʌn əz klin ən peɪl əz nu-fɔlən snoʊ. ðə sɝvəns skɝid fæstɝ ən pɑlɪʃt hɑɹɾɝ wən ðeɪ sɔ hɝ. ɹɪn hɑɹfɝ wɑz nɑt hɑɹʃ, bʌt ʃi kɛpt əz taɪɾ ə dɪsəplən oʊvɝ ðə pæləs əz ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn ɛvɝ hæɾ oʊvɝ ðə ɡɑɹdz.

It was no surprise to Elayne when she encountered the First Maid before reaching her apartments. After all, they were both heading for the same place. Mistress Harfor made her curtsy and fell in with her, carrying an embossed leather folder beneath one arm. She had certainly been up as early as Elayne if not earlier, but her scarlet tabard appeared freshly ironed, the White Lion on her front as clean and pale as new-fallen snow. The servants scurried faster and polished harder when they saw her. Reene Harfor was not harsh, but she kept as tight a discipline over the Palace as Gareth Bryne ever had over the Guards.

"aɪ fɪɹ aɪ hævən kɑɾ ɛni spaɪz jɛt, maɪ leɪɾi," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn ɹɪspɑns tə ɪleɪnz kwɛstʃən, hɝ vɔɪs pɪtʃt tə ɹitʃ ɪleɪnz ɪɹz əloʊn, "bʌɾ aɪ bɪliv aɪ ənkʌvɝɾ ə pɛɹ. ə wʊmən ən ə mæn, boʊθ teɪkən ɪn sɝvəs dʊɹɪŋ ðə læs mʌnθs ə ðə leɪt kwin jəɹ mʌðɝz ɹeɪn. ðeɪ lɛf ðə pæləs əz sun əz wɝd spɹɛd ðəɾ aɪ wɑz kwɛstʃənɪŋ ɛvɹiwʌn. wɪθaʊt weɪɾɪŋ tə ɡæðɝ ə skɹæp ə ðɛɹ bɪlɔŋɪŋz, nɑt soʊ mʌtʃ əz ə kloʊk. ðæts əz ɡʊɾ əz ən ædmɪʃən, aɪd seɪ. ənlɛs ðeɪ wɝ əfɹeɪɾ ə biɪŋ kɑɾ aʊɾ ɪn səm ʌðɝ mɪstʃəf," ʃi æɾəd ɹɪlʌktənli. "ðɛɹ əv bɪn keɪsəz ə pɪlfɝɪŋ, aɪm əfɹeɪd."

"I fear I haven't caught any spies yet, my Lady," she said in response to Elayne's question, her voice pitched to reach Elayne's ears alone, "but I believe I uncovered a pair. A woman and a man, both taken in service during the last months of the late Queen your mother's reign. They left the Palace as soon as word spread that I was questioning everyone. Without waiting to gather a scrap of their belongings, not so much as a cloak. That's as good as an admission, I'd say. Unless they were afraid of being caught out in some other mischief," she added reluctantly. "There have been cases of pilfering, I'm afraid."

ɪleɪn nɑɾəd θɔtfəli. nɑiən ən ɛləniə hæd bɪn mʌtʃ ɪn ðə pæləs dʊɹɪŋ ðə læs mʌnθs ə hɝ mʌðɝz ɹeɪn. mɔɹ ðən ɪnʌf ɑpɝtunəɾi tə sɛɾəl aɪz-ænd-ɪɹz ɪn pleɪs. ðoʊz tu hæd bɪn ɪn ðə pæləs, ən mɔɹ u hæɾ əpoʊz mɔɹɡeɪs tʃɹəkənz kleɪm tə ðə θɹoʊn, æksɛptɪɾ əɹ æmnəsti wʌns ʃi hæɾ ɪt, ðən bɪtʃɹeɪd hɝ. ʃi wəd nɑt meɪk əɹ mʌðɝz mɪsteɪk. oʊ, ðəɹ mʌs bi æmnəsti wɛɹɛvɝ pɑsəbəl - ɛniθɪŋ ɛls wɑz plæntɪŋ ðə sidz fəɹ ə sɪvəl wɔɹ - bʌt ʃi plæn tə wɑtʃ ðoʊz u tʊk əɹ pɑɹɾən vɛɹi kloʊsli. laɪk ə kæt wɑtʃɪŋ ə ɹæt ðət kleɪm tə hæv ɡɪvən ʌp ɪntʃɹəst ɪn ðə ɡɹeɪn bɑɹnz. "ðeɪ wɝ spaɪz," ʃi sɛd. "æn ðəɹ meɪ wɛl bi ʌðɝz. nɑt dʒʌs fəɹ haʊzɪz. ðə sɪstɝz ət ðə sɪlvɝ swɑn meɪ hæv bɑɾ aɪz-ænd-ɪɹz ɪn ðə pæləs, tu."

Elayne nodded thoughtfully. Naean and Elenia had been much in the Palace during the last months of her mother's reign. More than enough opportunity to settle eyes-and-ears in place. Those two had been in the Palace, and more who had opposed Morgase Trakand's claim to the throne, accepted her amnesty once she had it, then betrayed her. She would not make her mother's mistake. Oh, there must be amnesty wherever possible - anything else was planting the seeds for a civil war - but she planned to watch those who took her pardon very closely. Like a cat watching a rat that claimed to have given up interest in the grain barns. "They were spies," she said. "And there may well be others. Not just for Houses. The sisters at the Silver Swan may have bought eyes-and-ears in the Palace, too."

"aɪ wɪl kəntɪnju tə lʊk, maɪ leɪɾi," ɹɪn ɹɪplaɪd, ɪnklaɪnɪŋ əɹ hɛd slaɪtli. hɝ toʊn wɑz pɝfəkli ɹɪspɛkfəl; ʃi dɪd nɑt soʊ mʌtʃ əz ɹeɪz ən aɪbɹaʊ, bʌt wʌns əɡɛn ɪleɪn faʊn hɝsɛlf θɪŋkɪŋ ə titʃɪŋ əɹ ɡɹændmʌðɝ tə nɪt. ɪf oʊnli bɝdʒɪt kəd hændəl mæɾɝz ðə weɪ mɪstʃɹəs hɑɹfɝ dɪd.

"I will continue to look, my Lady," Reene replied, inclining her head slightly. Her tone was perfectly respectful; she did not so much as raise an eyebrow, but once again Elayne found herself thinking of teaching her grandmother to knit. If only Birgitte could handle matters the way Mistress Harfor did.

"æz wɛl jə ɹɪtɝn ɝli," ðə plʌmp wʊmən wɛn ɑn. "ju hæv ə bɪzi æftɝnun, aɪ fɪɹ. tə bɪɡɪn, mæstɝ nɔɹi wɪʃɪz tə spik wɪð ju. ɑn ən ɝdʒən mæɾɝ, hi sɛz." hɝ maʊθ hɑɹɾənd fəɹ ən ɪnstənt. ʃi ɔlweɪz ɹikwaɪɝd tə noʊ waɪ pipəl wɑntəd tə əpɹoʊtʃ ɪleɪn, soʊ ʃi kəd wɪnoʊ aʊt ðə tʃæf ɹæðɝ ðən lɛɾ ɪleɪn bi bɛɹiɾ ʌndɝ ɪt, bʌt ðə fɝs klɝk nɛvɝ sɔ fɪt tə ɡɪv əɹ ivən ə hɪn ə hɪz bɪznəs. ɛni mɔɹ ðən ʃi toʊld ɪm hɝz. boʊθ wɝ dʒɛləs ə ðɛɹ fifs. wɪð ə ʃeɪk ə hɝ hɛd, ʃi dɪsmɪs hælwɪn nɔɹi. "æftɝ hɪm, ə dɛləɡeɪʃən ə təbæk mɝtʃəns əz pətɪʃən tə si ju, ən ənʌðɝ ʌv wivɝz, boʊθ æskɪŋ ɹimɪʃən ə tæksəz kəz taɪmz ɑɹ hɑɹd. maɪ leɪɾi dʌz nɑt nid maɪ ædvaɪs tə tɛl əm taɪmz ɑɹ hɑɹd fəɹ ɛvɹiwʌn. ə ɡɹup ə fɔɹən mɝtʃəns ɪz weɪɾɪŋ əz wɛl; ɹæðɝ ə lɑɹdʒ ɡɹup. mɪɹli tə wɪʃ jə wɛl ɪn ə weɪ ðət dʌzn ɛnkʌmbɝ ðɛm, ʌv kɔɹs - ðeɪ wɪʃ tə bi ɑn jəɹ ɡʊd saɪd wɪθaʊɾ æntæɡənaɪzɪŋ ɛniwʌn ɛls - bʌɾ aɪ sədʒɛs miɾɪŋ əm bɹifli." ʃi leɪd plʌmp fɪŋɡɝz ɑn ðə foʊldɝ ʌndɝ əɹ ɑɹm. "ɔlsoʊ, ðə pæləs əkaʊns ɹikwaɪɝ jəɹ sɪɡnətʃɝ bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ kən ɡoʊ tə mæstɝ nɔɹi. ðəl meɪk ɪm saɪ, aɪ fɪɹ. aɪ hɑɹdli ɪkspɛktəɾ ɪɾ ɪn wɪntɝ, bʌt mʌtʃ ə ðə flaʊɝ ɪz fʊl ʌv wivəlz ən mɔθs, ən hæf ðə kjʊɹd hæmz əv tɝnd, əz wɛl əz moʊst ə ðə smoʊk fɪʃ." kwaɪt ɹɪspɛkfəl. ən kwaɪt fɝm.

"As well you returned early," the plump woman went on. "You have a busy afternoon, I fear. To begin, Master Norry wishes to speak with you. On an urgent matter, he says." Her mouth hardened for an instant. She always required to know why people wanted to approach Elayne, so she could winnow out the chaff rather than let Elayne be buried under it, but the First Clerk never saw fit to give her even a hint of his business. Any more than she told him hers. Both were jealous of their fiefs. With a shake of her head, she dismissed Halwin Norry. "After him, a delegation of tabac merchants has petitioned to see you, and another of weavers, both asking remission of taxes because times are hard. My Lady does not need my advice to tell them times are hard for everyone. A group of foreign merchants is waiting as well; rather a large group. Merely to wish you well in a way that doesn't encumber them, of course - they wish to be on your good side without antagonizing anyone else - but I suggest meeting them briefly." She laid plump fingers on the folder under her arm. "Also, the Palace accounts require your signature before they can go to Master Norry. They'll make him sigh, I fear. I hardly expected it in winter, but much of the flour is full of weevils and moths, and half the cured hams have turned, as well as most of the smoked fish." Quite respectful. And quite firm.

aɪ ɹul ændɝ, ɪleɪnz mʌðɝ hæd toʊld əɹ wʌns, ɪn pɹaɪvət, bʌɾ ət taɪmz aɪ θɪŋk ɹɪn hɑɹfɝ ɹulz mi. hɝ mʌðɝ hæd bɪn læfɪŋ, bʌt ʃi saʊndəɾ əz ɪf ʃi mɛn ɪt, tu. kʌm tə θɪŋk ɑn ɪt, mɪstʃɹəs hɑɹfɝ əz ə wɔɹɾɝ wəd bi tɛn taɪmz wɝs ðən bɝdʒɪt.

I rule Andor, Elayne's mother had told her once, in private, but at times I think Reene Harfor rules me. Her mother had been laughing, but she sounded as if she meant it, too. Come to think on it, Mistress Harfor as a Warder would be ten times worse than Birgitte.

ɪleɪn dɪd nɑt wɑnə mit wɪð hælwɪn nɔɹi əɹ wɪð mɝtʃəns. ʃi wɑntəd tə sɪt kwaɪətli ən θɪŋk əbaʊt spaɪz, ən u hæd nɑiən ən ɛləniə, ən haʊ ʃi kəd kaʊntɝ ðɛm. ɪksɛpt . . . mæstɝ nɔɹi hæd kɛp keɪɛmlɪn əlaɪv sɪns əɹ mʌðɝ daɪd. ɪn tʃɹuθ, baɪ wʌt ʃi kəd si ɪn ði oʊld əkaʊns, hi hæd dʌn soʊ ɔlmoʊs fɹəm ðə deɪ ʃi hæd fɔlən ɪndə ɹɑvɪnz klʌtʃəz, ðoʊ nɔɹi wɑz veɪɡ əbaʊt ðæt. hi simd əfɛndəd baɪ ði ɪvɛns ə ðoʊz deɪz, ɪn ə ɹæðɝ dʌsti weɪ. ʃi kəd nɑt sɪmpli ʃʌfəl ɪm ɔf. bɪsaɪdz, hi nɛvɝ ɪkspɹɛst ɝdʒənsi oʊvɝ ɛniθɪŋ. ən ðə ɡʊdwɪl ə mɝtʃəns wɑz nɑt tə bi snɪɹɾ æt, ivən fɔɹən mɝtʃəns. ən ði əkaʊns dɪd nid tə bi saɪnd. wivəlz ən mɔθs? ən hæmz spɔɪlɪŋ? ɪn wɪntɝ? ðət wɑz dɪsaɪɾədli ɑd.

Elayne did not want to meet with Halwin Norry or with merchants. She wanted to sit quietly and think about spies, and who had Naean and Elenia, and how she could counter them. Except . . . Master Norry had kept Caemlyn alive since her mother died. In truth, by what she could see in the old accounts, he had done so almost from the day she had fallen into Rahvin's clutches, though Norry was vague about that. He seemed offended by the events of those days, in a rather dusty way. She could not simply shuffle him off. Besides, he never expressed urgency over anything. And the goodwill of merchants was not to be sneered at, even foreign merchants. And the accounts did need to be signed. Weevils and moths? And hams spoiling? In winter? That was decidedly odd.

ðeɪ hæd ɹitʃt ðə tɔl, laɪən-kɑɹv dɔɹz ə hɝ əpɑɹtməns. smɔlɝ laɪənz ðən ɑn ðə dɔɹz tə ðoʊz əɹ mʌðɝ hæd juzd, ən smɔlɝ əpɑɹtməns, bʌt ʃi nɛvɝ kənsɪɾɝd juzɪŋ ðə kwinz tʃeɪmbɝz. ðət wʊɾə bɪn əz pɹɪzʌmptʃəwəs əz sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðə laɪən θɹoʊn bɪfɔɹ əɹ ɹaɪt tə ðə ɹoʊz kɹaʊn wɑz æknɑlɪdʒd.

They had reached the tall, lion-carved doors of her apartments. Smaller lions than on the doors to those her mother had used, and smaller apartments, but she never considered using the Queen's chambers. That would have been as presumptuous as sitting on the Lion Throne before her right to the Rose Crown was acknowledged.

wɪð ə saɪ, ʃi ɹitʃt fəɹ ðə foʊldɝ.

With a sigh, she reached for the folder.

daʊn ðə hɔlweɪ ʃi kɑt saɪɾ ə soʊlən mɔɹɡəlɪn ən kɛɹeɪl sɝtɑvni, hɝiɪŋ əlɔŋ əz kwɪkli əz ðeɪ kəd wɪθaʊɾ əpɪɹɪŋ tə ɹʌn. flæʃɪz ə sɪlvɝ ʃoʊɾ ət ðə nɛk ə ðə sʌlən wʊmən skwiz bɪtwin ðɛm, ðoʊ ðə kɪnswɪmən hæd dʒɹeɪpt ə lɔŋ ɡɹin skɑɹf ɝaʊn əɹ tə haɪd ði æɾəmz liʃ. ðət wəd kɑz tɔk, ən ɪt wəd bi sin sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ. bɛɾɝ ɪf ʃi ən ði ʌðɝz dɪd nɑɾ əv tə bi muvd, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ weɪ tə əvɔɪɾ ɪt. bɪtwin kɪnswɪmən ən si foʊk wɪndfɪndɝz, ɹumz ɪn ðə sɝvəns' kɔɹɾɝz hæd bɪn niɾəd tə hoʊl ði oʊvɝfloʊ ivən wɪð tu ən θɹi tə ə bɛd, ən ðə pæləs hæd beɪsməns fəɹ stɔɹədʒ, nɑt dʌnʒənz. haʊ dɪd ɹænd ɔlweɪz mænədʒ tə də ðə ɹɔŋ θɪŋ? biɪŋ meɪl dʒʌst wɑz nɑɾ ɪkskjuz ɪnʌf. soʊlən ən kɛɹeɪl vænɪʃt ɝaʊn ə kɔɹnɝ wɪð ðɛɹ pɹɪznɝ.

Down the hallway she caught sight of Solain Morgeillin and Keraille Surtovni, hurrying along as quickly as they could without appearing to run. Flashes of silver showed at the neck of the sullen woman squeezed between them, though the Kinswomen had draped a long green scarf around her to hide the a'dam's leash. That would cause talk, and it would be seen sooner or later. Better if she and the others did not have to be moved, but there was no way to avoid it. Between Kinswomen and Sea Folk Windfinders, rooms in the servants' quarters had been needed to hold the overflow even with two and three to a bed, and the Palace had basements for storage, not dungeons. How did Rand always manage to do the wrong thing? Being male just was not excuse enough. Solain and Keraille vanished around a corner with their prisoner.

"mɪstʃɹəs kɔɹli æsk tə si jə ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ, maɪ leɪɾi." ɹɪnz vɔɪs wɑz kɛɹfəli nutʃɹəl. ʃi hæd bɪn wɑtʃɪŋ ðə kɪnswɪmən, tu, ən ə tʃɹeɪs ə fɹaʊn ɹɪmeɪn ɑn əɹ bɹɔd feɪs. ðə si foʊk wɝ ɑd, jɛt ʃi kəd fɪɾ ə klæn weɪvməstʃɹəs ən əɹ ɑntʊɹɑʒ ɪndə hɝ vju ʌv ðə wɝld ivən ɪf ʃi dɪd nɑt noʊ pɹɪsaɪsli wʌɾ ə klæn weɪvməstʃɹəs wɑz. ə haɪ-ɹæŋkɪŋ fɔɹənɝ wɑz ə haɪ-ɹæŋkɪŋ fɔɹənɝ, ən fɔɹənɝz wɝ ɪkspɛktəd tə bi ɑd. bʌt ʃi kəd nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd waɪ ɪleɪn hæd ɡɪvən ʃɛltɝ tə nɪɹli ə hʌnʒɹəd ən fɪfti mɝtʃəns ən kɹæftswɪmən. niðɝ "ðə kɪn" nɔɹ "ðə nɪɾɪŋ sɝkəl" wʊɾə mɛn ɛniθɪŋ tə hɝ hæd ʃi hɝd ðɛm, ən ʃi dɪd nɑɾ ʌndɝstæn ðə pəkjuljɝ tɛntʃənz bɪtwin ðoʊz wɪmən ən ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. nɔɹ dɪd ʃi ʌndɝstæn ðə wɪmən ði æʃəmən hæd bɹɔt, pɹɪznɝz ɪn tʃɹuθ ɪf nɑt kənfaɪn ɪn sɛlz, kɛp sɪkluɾɪd ən nɛvɝ əlaʊd tə spik tə ɛniwʌn bʌt ðə wɪmən u ɛskɔɹɾɪd əm θɹu ðə hɔlz. ðə fɝs meɪd nu wən nɑt tə æsk kwɛstʃənz, jɛt ʃi dɪslaɪk nɑɾ ʌndɝstændɪŋ wʌt wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn ɪn ðə pæləs. hɝ vɔɪs dɪd nɑt tʃeɪnʒ baɪ ə hɛɹ. "ʃi sɛd ʃi hæd ɡʊd nuz fəɹ ju. ʌv ə sɔɹt, ʃi sɛd. ʃi dɪd nɑt pətɪʃən fəɹ ən ɑɾiəns, ðoʊ."

"Mistress Corly asked to see you this morning, my Lady." Reene's voice was carefully neutral. She had been watching the Kinswomen, too, and a trace of frown remained on her broad face. The Sea Folk were odd, yet she could fit a clan Wavemistress and her entourage into her view of the world even if she did not know precisely what a clan Wavemistress was. A high-ranking foreigner was a high-ranking foreigner, and foreigners were expected to be odd. But she could not understand why Elayne had given shelter to nearly a hundred and fifty merchants and craftswomen. Neither "the Kin" nor "the Knitting Circle" would have meant anything to her had she heard them, and she did not understand the peculiar tensions between those women and the Aes Sedai. Nor did she understand the women the Asha'man had brought, prisoners in truth if not confined in cells, kept secluded and never allowed to speak to anyone but the women who escorted them through the halls. The First Maid knew when not to ask questions, yet she disliked not understanding what was going on in the Palace. Her voice did not change by a hair. "She said she had good news for you. Of a sort, she said. She did not petition for an audience, though."

ɡʊd nuz ʌv ɛni sɔɹt wɑz bɛɾɝ ðən ɡoʊɪŋ oʊvɝ ði əkaʊns, ən ʃi hæd hoʊps ʌv wʌt ðɪs nuz maɪt bi. ɹilɪŋkwɪʃɪŋ ðə foʊldɝ ɪn ðə fɝs meɪdz hænz, ʃi sɛd, "liv ðəɾ ɑn maɪ ɹaɪɾɪŋ teɪbəl, pliz. ən tɛl mæstɝ nɔɹi ðəɾ əl si hɪm ʃɔɹtli."

Good news of any sort was better than going over the accounts, and she had hopes of what this news might be. Relinquishing the folder in the First Maid's hands, she said, "Leave that on my writing table, please. And tell Master Norry that I will see him shortly."

sɛɾɪŋ aʊɾ ɪn ðə dɝɛkʃən ðə kɪn hæd kʌm fɹəm wɪð ðɛɹ pɹɪznɝ, ʃi wɔkt kwɪkli ɪn spaɪɾ ə hɝ skɝts. ɡʊd nuz əɹ noʊ ɡʊd nuz, nɔɹi ən ðə mɝtʃəns dɪɾ əv tə bi sin, ən ðə mɝtʃəns, nɑt tə mɛnʃən ði əkaʊns ɡɔn oʊvɝ ən saɪnd. ɹulɪŋ mɛn ɛnləs wiks ə dʒɹʌdʒɝi ən ɹɛɹ aʊɝz ə duɪŋ wʌt jə wɑntəd. vɛɹi ɹɛɹ aʊɝz. bɝdʒɪt leɪ ɪn ðə bæk ə hɝ hɛd, ə taɪt bɔl ə ðə pjʊɹəst ɪɹɪteɪʃən ən fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən. noʊ daʊt, ʃi wɑz dɪɡɪŋ θɹu ðət teɪbəl paɪld wɪð peɪpɝz. wɛl, hɝ oʊn ɹilækseɪʃən ðɪs deɪ wəd bi wʌtɛvɝ taɪm wɑz ɹikwaɪɝd tə tʃeɪnʒ aʊɾ ə ɹaɪɾɪŋ kloʊðz ən snætʃ ə heɪsti mil. soʊ ʃi wɔk vɛɹi kwɪkli, lɔst ɪn θɔɾ ən hɑɹdli siɪŋ wʌt wɑz ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ. wʌd nɔɹi faɪn ɝdʒənt? ʃʊɹli nɑt stʃɹit ɹɪpɛɹz. haʊ mɛni spaɪz? smɔl tʃæns mɪstʃɹəs hɑɹfɝ wəd kætʃ əm ɔl.

Setting out in the direction the Kin had come from with their prisoner, she walked quickly in spite of her skirts. Good news or no good news, Norry and the merchants did have to be seen, and the merchants, not to mention the accounts gone over and signed. Ruling meant endless weeks of drudgery and rare hours of doing what you wanted. Very rare hours. Birgitte lay in the back of her head, a tight ball of the purest irritation and frustration. No doubt, she was digging through that table piled with papers. Well, her own relaxation this day would be whatever time was required to change out of riding clothes and snatch a hasty meal. So she walked very quickly, lost in thought and hardly seeing what was in front of her. What did Norry find urgent? Surely not street repairs. How many spies? Small chance Mistress Harfor would catch them all.

əz ʃi ɹaʊndəɾ ə kɔɹnɝ, oʊnli ðə sʌɾən əwɛɹnəs ʌv ʌðɝ wɪmən u kəd tʃænəl kɛpt əɹ fɹəm ɹʌnɪŋ hɛdlɔŋ ɪndə vændin kʌmɪŋ ði ʌðɝ weɪ. ðeɪ ɹikɔɪl fɹəm wʌn ənʌðɝ ɪn stɑɹɾəlmənt. əpɛɹənli ðə ɡɹin hæd bɪn dip ɪn θɔt, tu. hɝ tu kəmpænjənz ɹeɪzd ɪleɪnz aɪbɹaʊz.

As she rounded a corner, only the sudden awareness of other women who could channel kept her from running headlong into Vandene coming the other way. They recoiled from one another in startlement. Apparently the Green had been deep in thought, too. Her two companions raised Elayne's eyebrows.

kɝstʃən ən zɛɹjə wɔɹ pleɪn waɪɾ ən steɪɾ ə kɛɹfəl peɪs bɪhaɪn vændin, hænz foʊldəd mikli ət ðɛɹ weɪsts. ðɛɹ hɛɹ wɑz baʊn bæk sɪmpli, ən ðeɪ wɔɹ noʊ dʒuəlɹi. dʒuəlɹi wɑz stʃɹɔŋli dɪskɝədʒd əmʌŋ nɑvəsɪz. ðeɪ hæd bɪn kɪnswɪmən - kɝstʃən hæɾ æktʃəli  bɪn ɪn ðə nɪɾɪŋ sɝkəl ɪtsɛlf - bʌt ðeɪ wɝ ɹʌnəweɪz fɹəm ðə taʊɝ, ən ðəɹ wɝ pɹiskɹaɪbd weɪz ə dilɪŋ wɪð ðoʊz, sɛɾ ɪn taʊɝ lɔ, noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ lɔŋ ðeɪ hæd bɪn ɡɔn. ɹɪtɝn ɹʌnəweɪz wɝ ɹikwaɪɝd tə bi æbsəlutli pɝfəkt ɪn ɛvɹiθɪŋ ðeɪ dɪd, ðə vɛɹi mɑɾəl ʌv ən ɪnɪʃiət stʃɹaɪvɪŋ fəɹ ðə ʃɔl, ən smɔl slɪps ðət maɪt bi oʊvɝlʊkt ɪn ʌðɝz wɝ pʌnɪʃt swɪfli ən stʃɹɔŋli. ðeɪ feɪst ə mʌtʃ stʃɹɔŋɝ pʌnɪʃmənt wən ðeɪ ɹitʃt ðə taʊɝ, ɪn ədɪʃən, ə pʌblɪk bɝtʃɪŋ, ən ivən ðən ðeɪ wəd bi hɛl tə ðɛɹ stʃɹeɪɾ ən peɪnfəl pæθ fəɹ ət list ə jɪɹ. ə ɹɪtɝn ɹʌnəweɪ wɑz meɪd tə noʊ ɪn əɹ hɑɹt ðət ʃi nɛvɝ, ɛvɝ wɑntəd tə ɹʌn əweɪ əɡɛn. nɑɾ ɛvɝ! hæf-tʃɹeɪnd wɪmən wɝ dʒʌs tu deɪnʒɝəs tə bi lɛf lus.

Kirstian and Zarya wore plain white and stayed a careful pace behind Vandene, hands folded meekly at their waists. Their hair was bound back simply, and they wore no jewelry. Jewelry was strongly discouraged among novices. They had been Kinswomen - Kirstian had actually been in the Knitting Circle itself - but they were runaways from the Tower, and there were prescribed ways of dealing with those, set in Tower law, no matter how long they had been gone. Returned runaways were required to be absolutely perfect in everything they did, the very model of an initiate striving for the shawl, and small slips that might be overlooked in others were punished swiftly and strongly. They faced a much stronger punishment when they reached the Tower, in addition, a public birching, and even then they would be held to their straight and painful path for at least a year. A returned runaway was made to know in her heart that she never, ever wanted to run away again. Not ever! Half-trained women were just too dangerous to be left loose.

ɪleɪn hæd tʃɹaɪd tə bi liniənt, ðə fju taɪmz ʃi wɑz wɪð əm - ðə kɪnswɪmən wɝ nɑt ɹɪli hæf-tʃɹeɪnd; ðeɪ hæɾ əz mʌtʃ ɪkspɪɹiəns wɪð ðə wʌn paʊɝ əz ɛni ɛɛs sədaɪ, ɪf nɑt ðə tʃɹeɪnɪŋ - ʃi hæd tʃɹaɪd, oʊnli tə dɪskʌvɝ ðəɾ ivən moʊst ə ði ʌðɝ kɪnswɪmən dɪsəpɹuvd. ɡɪvən ənʌðɝ tʃæns tə bɪkʌm ɛɛs sədaɪ - ðoʊz u kʊd, ət list - ðeɪ ɛmbɹeɪst ɔl ə ðə taʊɝz lɔz ən kʌstəmz wɪð ʃɑkɪŋ fɝvɝ. ʃi wɑz nɑt sɝpɹaɪzd ət ðə səbduɾ iɡɝnəs ɪn ðə tu wɪmənz aɪz əɹ ðə weɪ ðeɪ sim tə ɹeɪɾiət ə pɹɑməs ʌv ɡʊd bɪheɪvjɝ - ðeɪ wɑntəd ðət tʃæns əz bædli əz ɛniwʌn - dʒʌs ðət ðeɪ wɝ wɪð vændin əɾ ɔl. əntɪl naʊ, ʃi hæɾ ɪɡnɔɹd ðə pɛɹ ɪntaɪɝli.

Elayne had tried to be lenient, the few times she was with them - the Kinswomen were not really half-trained; they had as much experience with the One Power as any Aes Sedai, if not the training - she had tried, only to discover that even most of the other Kinswomen disapproved. Given another chance to become Aes Sedai - those who could, at least - they embraced all of the Tower's laws and customs with shocking fervor. She was not surprised at the subdued eagerness in the two women's eyes or the way they seemed to radiate a promise of good behavior - they wanted that chance as badly as anyone - just that they were with Vandene at all. Until now, she had ignored the pair entirely.

"aɪ wɑz lʊkɪŋ fəɹ ju, ɪleɪn," vændin sɛd wɪθaʊt pɹiæmbəl. hɝ waɪt hɛɹ, ɡæðɝɾ ət ðə neɪp ə nɛk wɪð ə dɑɹk ɡɹin ɹɪbən, hæɾ ɔlweɪz ɡɪvən əɹ ən ɛɹ ʌv eɪdʒ dɪspaɪɾ əɹ smuð tʃiks. hɝ sɪstɝz mɝɾɝ hæɾ æɾəd ɡɹɪmnəs, soʊkt ɪɾ ɪndə ðə boʊn, soʊ ʃi sim laɪk ən ɪmplækəbəl dʒʌdʒ. ʃi hæd bɪn slɛndɝ; naʊ ʃi wɑz boʊni, hɝ tʃiks hɑloʊ. "ðiz tʃɪlʒɹən - " ʃi kʌɾ ɔf, ə feɪnt ɡɹɪmɑs θɪnɪŋ əɹ maʊθ.

"I was looking for you, Elayne," Vandene said without preamble. Her white hair, gathered at the nape of neck with a dark green ribbon, had always given her an air of age despite her smooth cheeks. Her sister's murder had added grimness, soaked it into the bone, so she seemed like an implacable judge. She had been slender; now she was bony, her cheeks hollow. "These children - " She cut off, a faint grimace thinning her mouth.

ɪt wɑz ðə pɹɑpɝ weɪ tə ɹəfɝ tə nɑvəsɪz - ðə wɝs moʊmən fəɹ ə wʊmən u wɛn tə ðə taʊɝ wɑz nɑt wən ʃi dɪskʌvɝd ʃi wəd nɑt bi kənsɪɾɝd fʊli ədʌlt əntɪl ʃi ɝn ðə ʃɔl, bʌt wən ʃi ɹilaɪz ðət soʊ lɔŋ əz ʃi wɔɹ nɑvəs waɪt, ʃi ɹɪli wɑz ə tʃaɪld, wʌn u maɪɾ ɪnʒɝ hɝsɛlf əɹ ʌðɝz θɹu ɪɡnɝəns ən blʌndɝɪŋ - ðə pɹɑpɝ weɪ, jɛɾ ivən tə vændin ɪt mʌst əv sim stʃɹeɪnʒ hɪɹ. moʊs nɑvəsɪz keɪm tə ðə taʊɝ ət fɪftin əɹ sɪkstin, ən əntɪl ɹisənli, nʌn oʊvɝ eɪtin, ɪksɛp fəɹ ə hændfʊl u hæd mænədʒ tə kæɹi ɔf ə laɪ. ənlaɪk ɛɛs sədaɪ, ðə kɪn juzd eɪdʒ tə sɛt ðɛɹ haɪɝɑɹki, ən zɛɹjə - ʃi hæd bɪn kɔlɪŋ hɝsɛlf ɡæɹiniə ɹoʊsɔɪnd, bʌt zɛɹjə ælkeɪis wɑz ðə neɪm ɪn ðə nɑvəs bʊk, ən zɛɹjə ælkeɪis ʃi wəɾ ænsɝ tə - zɛɹjə, wɪð əɹ stʃɹɔŋ noʊz ən waɪd maʊθ, wɑz mɔɹ ðən naɪnti jɪɹz oʊld, ðoʊ ʃi əpɪɹd wɛl ʃɔɹɾ ə hɝ mɪɾəl jɪɹz. niðɝ wʊmən hæd ði eɪɡləsnəs dɪspaɪt ðɛɹ jɪɹz ə juzɪŋ ðə paʊɝ, ən pɹɪɾi, blæk-aɪd kɝstʃən lʊkt ə lɪɾəl oʊldɝ, pɝhæps θɝɾi əɹ soʊ. ʃi wɑz oʊvɝ θɹi hʌnʒɹəd, oʊldɝ ðən vændin hɝsɛlf, ɪleɪn wɑz ʃʊɹ. kɝstʃən hæd bɪn ɡɔn fɹəm ðə taʊɝ soʊ lɔŋ ðət ʃi hæd fɛl seɪf juzɪŋ əɹ tʃɹu neɪm əɡɛn, əɹ pɑɹɾ ʌv ɪt. nɑɾ əɾ ɔl ðə juʒəwəl ɹʌn ə nɑvəsɪz.

It was the proper way to refer to novices - the worst moment for a woman who went to the Tower was not when she discovered she would not be considered fully adult until she earned the shawl, but when she realized that so long as she wore novice white, she really was a child, one who might injure herself or others through ignorance and blundering - the proper way, yet even to Vandene it must have seemed strange here. Most novices came to the Tower at fifteen or sixteen, and until recently, none over eighteen, except for a handful who had managed to carry off a lie. Unlike Aes Sedai, the Kin used age to set their hierarchy, and Zarya - she had been calling herself Garenia Rosoinde, but Zarya Alkaese was the name in the novice book, and Zarya Alkaese she would answer to - Zarya, with her strong nose and wide mouth, was more than ninety years old, though she appeared well short of her middle years. Neither woman had the agelessness despite their years of using the Power, and pretty, black-eyed Kirstian looked a little older, perhaps thirty or so. She was over three hundred, older than Vandene herself, Elayne was sure. Kirstian had been gone from the Tower so long that she had felt safe using her true name again, or part of it. Not at all the usual run of novices.

"ðiz tʃɪlʒɹən," vændin wɛn ɑn mɔɹ fɝmli, ə dip fɹaʊn kɹisɪŋ əɹ fɔɹhɛd, "hæv bɪn θɪŋkɪŋ oʊvɝ ɪvɛns ɪn hɑɹlən bɹɪdʒ." ðət wɑz wɛɹ əɹ sɪstɝ hæd bɪn mɝɾɝd. ən ɪspæn ʃɛfɹ, bʌɾ əz fɑɹ əz vændin wɑz kənsɝnd, ðə dɛθ ʌv ə blæk sɪstɝ kaʊntəd wɪð ðə dɛθ ʌv ə ɹæbɪd dɔɡ. "ənfɔɹtʃənətli, ɹæðɝ ðən kipɪŋ saɪlən əbaʊt ðɛɹ kənkluʒənz, ðeɪ keɪm tə mi. ət lis ðeɪ hævən blæðɝd wɛɹ ɛniwʌn kəd hɪɹ."

"These children," Vandene went on more firmly, a deep frown creasing her forehead, "have been thinking over events in Harlon Bridge." That was where her sister had been murdered. And Ispan Shefar, but as far as Vandene was concerned, the death of a Black sister counted with the death of a rabid dog. "Unfortunately, rather than keeping silent about their conclusions, they came to me. At least they haven't blathered where anyone could hear."

ɪleɪn fɹaʊn slaɪtli. ɛvɹiwʌn ɪn ðə pæləs nu ʌv ðə mɝɾɝz baɪ ðɪs taɪm. "aɪ doʊn ʌndɝstænd," ʃi sɛd sloʊli. ən kɛɹfəli. ʃi dɪd nɑt wɑnə ɡɪv ðə pɛɹ hɪns ɪf ðeɪ hæd nɑt ɹɪli dʌɡ ʌp peɪnsteɪkɪŋli hɪɾən sikɹəts. "hæv ðeɪ wɝkt aʊt ðəɾ ɪt wɑz dɑɹkfɹɛnz ɪnstɛɾ ə ɹɑbɝi?" ðət wɑz ðə teɪl ðeɪ hæd pʊɾ əbaʊt, tu wɪmən ɪn ən aɪsəleɪɾəd haʊs, kɪl fəɹ ðɛɹ dʒuəlɹi. oʊnli ʃi, vændin, nɪneɪiv ən læn nu ɛni ɹil mɛʒɝ ə ðə tʃɹuθ. əntɪl naʊ ɛniweɪ, ɪt simd. ðeɪ mʌst əv ɡɑɾən ðət fɑɹ, əɹ vændin wʊɾə sɛn əm əweɪ wɪð ə fli ɪn ðɛɹ kəlɛktɪv ɪɹ.

Elayne frowned slightly. Everyone in the Palace knew of the murders by this time. "I don't understand," she said slowly. And carefully. She did not want to give the pair hints if they had not really dug up painstakingly hidden secrets. "Have they worked out that it was Darkfriends instead of robbery?" That was the tale they had put about, two women in an isolated house, killed for their jewelry. Only she, Vandene, Nynaeve and Lan knew any real measure of the truth. Until now anyway, it seemed. They must have gotten that far, or Vandene would have sent them away with a flea in their collective ear.

"wɝs." vændin lʊkt ɝaʊnd, ðən muvd ə fju peɪsɪz tə ðə sɛntɝ ʌv wɛɹ ðə hɔlweɪz kɹɔst, fɔɹsɪŋ ɪleɪn tə fɑloʊ. fɹəm ðət væntədʒ, ðeɪ kəd si ɛniwʌn kʌmɪŋ əlɔŋ iðɝ kɔɹəɾɝ. ðə nɑvəsɪz ətɛntɪvli meɪnteɪn ðɛɹ pəzɪʃənz ɹɛləɾɪv tə ðə ɡɹin. meɪbi ðeɪ hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi ɡɑɾən ðət fli, fəɹ ɔl ðɛɹ iɡɝnəs. ðəɹ wɝ plɛnti ʌv sɝvəns ɪn saɪt, bʌt noʊ wʌn əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ, noʊ wʌn kloʊs ɪnʌf tə oʊvɝhɪɹ. vændin loʊɝɾ əɹ vɔɪs ɛniweɪ. kwaɪətnəs dɪd nʌθɪŋ tə mæsk əɹ dɪsplɛʒɝ. "ðeɪ ɹizən aʊt ðət ðə kɪlɝ mʌs bi mɛɝɪlɪl, sɝaɪðə əɹ kɛɝin. ɡʊd θɪŋkɪŋ ɑn ðɛɹ pɑɹt, aɪ səpoʊz, bʌt ðeɪ ʃʊdn əv bɪn θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪɾ ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs. ðeɪ ʃʊɾə bɪn kɛpt ət ðɛɹ lɛsənz soʊ hɑɹd ðeɪ hæd noʊ taɪm tə θɪŋk ʌv ɛniθɪŋ ɛls." dɪspaɪt ðə skaʊl ʃi dɝɛktəɾ ət kɝstʃən ən zɛɹjə, ðə tu oʊvɝɪdʒ nɑvəsɪz bimd wɪð dɪlaɪt. ðəɹ hæd bɪn ə kɑmpləmən bɛɹiɾ ɪn ðə skoʊldɪŋ, ən vændin wɑz spɛɹɪŋ ə kɑmpləməns.

"Worse." Vandene looked around, then moved a few paces to the center of where the hallways crossed, forcing Elayne to follow. From that vantage, they could see anyone coming along either corridor. The novices attentively maintained their positions relative to the Green. Maybe they had already gotten that flea, for all their eagerness. There were plenty of servants in sight, but no one approaching, no one close enough to overhear. Vandene lowered her voice anyway. Quietness did nothing to mask her displeasure. "They reasoned out that the killer must be Merilille, Sareitha or Careane. Good thinking on their part, I suppose, but they shouldn't have been thinking about it in the first place. They should have been kept at their lessons so hard they had no time to think of anything else." Despite the scowl she directed at Kirstian and Zarya, the two overaged novices beamed with delight. There had been a compliment buried in the scolding, and Vandene was sparing of compliments.

ɪleɪn dɪd nɑt pɔɪn aʊt ðət ðə pɛɹ maɪɾ əv bɪn kɛpt ə lɪɾəl bɪziɝ ɪf vændin hæd bɪn wɪlɪŋ tə teɪk pɑɹɾ ə ðɛɹ lɛsənz. ɪleɪn hɝsɛlf ən nɪneɪiv hæd tu mɛni ʌðɝ duɾiz, ən sɪns ðeɪ hæɾ æɾəd deɪli lɛsənz fəɹ ðə wɪndfɪndɝz - ɛvɹiwʌn bʌt nɪneɪiv hæd, ɛniweɪ - noʊ wʌn əɾ ɔl hæd ði ɛnɝdʒi fəɹ mʌtʃ taɪm wɪð ðə tu nɑvəsɪz. titʃɪŋ ði æθɑn maɪɹ wɪmən wɑz laɪk biɪŋ fɛd θɹu ə lɔnʒɹɪsəz mæŋɡəl! ðeɪ hæd lɪɾəl ɹɪspɛk fəɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ. ən ivən lɛs fəɹ ɹæŋk əmʌŋ "ðə ʃɔɹbaʊnd."

Elayne did not point out that the pair might have been kept a little busier if Vandene had been willing to take part of their lessons. Elayne herself and Nynaeve had too many other duties, and since they had added daily lessons for the Windfinders - everyone but Nynaeve had, anyway - no one at all had the energy for much time with the two novices. Teaching the Atha'an Miere women was like being fed through a laundress's mangle! They had little respect for Aes Sedai. And even less for rank among "the shorebound."

"æt lis ðeɪ dɪdn spik tə ɛniwʌn ɛls," ʃi mɝmɝd. ə blɛsɪŋ, ɪf smɔl.

"At least they didn't speak to anyone else," she murmured. A blessing, if small.

ɪt hæd bɪn ɑbviəs wən ðeɪ faʊn æɾɪliz ən ɪspæn ðət ðɛɹ kɪlɝ mʌs bi ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. ðeɪ hæd bɪn pɛɹəlaɪzd wɪð kɹɪmsɑnθɝn bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ wɝ kɪld, ən ɪt wɑz ɔl bʌɾ ɪmpɑsəbəl ðət ðə wɪndfɪndɝz nu ʌv ən ɝb oʊnli faʊn fɑɹ fɹəm ðə si. ən ivən vændin wɑz ʃʊɹ ðə kɪn nʌmbɝd noʊ dɑɹkfɹɛnz əmʌŋ ðɛm. ɪspæn hæd ɹʌn əweɪ hɝsɛlf əz ə nɑvəs, ən ivən ɡɑɾən əz fɑɹ əz ɛbu dɑɹ, bʌt ʃi hæd bɪn ɹəteɪkən bɪfɔɹ ðə kɪn ɹɪvil ðɛmsɛlvz tə hɝ, ðət ðeɪ wɝ mɔɹ ðən ə fju wɪmən pʊɾ aʊɾ ə ðə taʊɝ u hæd dɪsaɪɾɪd ɑn ə wɪm tə hɛlp hɝ. ʌndɝ kwɛstʃənɪŋ baɪ vændin ən æɾɪliz, ʃi hæd ɹɪvild ə ɡɹeɪt dil. sʌmhaʊ ʃi hæd mænədʒ tə ɹɪzɪst seɪɪŋ ɛniθɪŋ əbaʊt ðə blæk ədʒɑ ɪtsɛlf ɪksɛp fəɹ ɪkspoʊzɪŋ oʊl skimz lɔŋ kæɹiɾ aʊt, bʌt ʃi hæd bɪn iɡɝ tə tɛl ɛniθɪŋ ɛls wʌns vændin ən əɹ sɪstɝ wɝ dʌn wɪð hɝ. ðeɪ hæd nɑt bɪn dʒɛntəl, ən ðeɪ hæd plʌmd əɹ dɛpθs, jɛt ʃi nu noʊ mɔɹ ə ðə kɪn ðən ɛni ʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ. ɪf ðəɹ wɝ ɛni dɑɹkfɹɛnz əmʌŋ ðə kɪn, ðə blæk ədʒɑ wʊɾə noʊn ɛvɹiθɪŋ. soʊ əz mʌtʃ əz ðeɪ kəd wɪʃ ʌðɝwaɪz, ðə kɪlɝ wɑz wʌn ə θɹi wɪmən ðeɪ hæɾ ɔl ɡɹoʊn tə laɪk. eɪ blæk sɪstɝ ɪn ðɛɹ mɪdst. əɹ mɔɹ ðən wʌn. ðeɪ hæɾ ɔl bɪn fɹæntɪk tə kip ðət nɑlədʒ sikɹət, ət list əntɪl ðə mɝɾɝɝ wɑz ənkʌvɝd. ðə nuz wəd θɹoʊ ði ɪntaɪɝ pæləs ɪndə ə pænɪk, meɪbi ði ɪntaɪɝ sɪɾi. laɪt, hu ɛls hæd bɪn θɪŋkɪŋ oʊvɝ ɪvɛns ɪn hɑɹlən bɹɪdʒ? wəd ðeɪv ðə sɛns tə hoʊl saɪləns?

It had been obvious when they found Adeleas and Ispan that their killer must be an Aes Sedai. They had been paralyzed with crimsonthorn before they were killed, and it was all but impossible that the Windfinders knew of an herb only found far from the sea. And even Vandene was sure the Kin numbered no Darkfriends among them. Ispan had run away herself as a novice, and even gotten as far as Ebou Dar, but she had been retaken before the Kin revealed themselves to her, that they were more than a few women put out of the Tower who had decided on a whim to help her. Under questioning by Vandene and Adeleas, she had revealed a great deal. Somehow she had managed to resist saying anything about the Black Ajah itself except for exposing old schemes long carried out, but she had been eager to tell anything else once Vandene and her sister were done with her. They had not been gentle, and they had plumbed her depths, yet she knew no more of the Kin than any other Aes Sedai. If there were any Darkfriends among the Kin, the Black Ajah would have known everything. So as much as they could wish otherwise, the killer was one of three women they had all grown to like. A Black sister in their midst. Or more than one. They had all been frantic to keep that knowledge secret, at least until the murderer was uncovered. The news would throw the entire Palace into a panic, maybe the entire city. Light, who else had been thinking over events in Harlon Bridge? Would they have the sense to hold silence?

"sʌmwʌn hæd tə teɪk əm ɪn hænd," vændin sɛd fɝmli, "tə kip əm aʊɾ ə fɝðɝ mɪstʃəf. ðeɪ nid ɹɛɡjəlɝ lɛsənz ən hɑɹd wɝk," ðə pɛɹz bimɪŋ feɪsəz hæd teɪkən ɑn ə hɪn ə smʌɡnəs, bʌɾ ɪt feɪɾəd ə lɪɾəl ət ðæt. ðɛɹ lɛsənz hæd bɪn fju, bʌt vɛɹi hɑɹd, ðə dɪsəplən vɛɹi stʃɹɪkt. "ðæt minz ju, ɪleɪn, əɹ nɪneɪiv."

"Someone had to take them in hand," Vandene said firmly, "to keep them out of further mischief. They need regular lessons and hard work," The pair's beaming faces had taken on a hint of smugness, but it faded a little at that. Their lessons had been few, but very hard, the discipline very strict. "That means you, Elayne, or Nynaeve."

ɪleɪn klɪkt əɹ tʌŋ ɪn ɛksæspɝeɪʃən. "vændin, aɪ hɑɹdli hæv ə moʊmən fəɹ maɪsɛlf tə θɪŋk. aɪm ɔlɹɛɾi stʃɹeɪnɪŋ tə ɡɪv əm ən aʊɝ naʊ ən ðɛn. ɪɾəl əv tə bi nɪneɪiv."

Elayne clicked her tongue in exasperation. "Vandene, I hardly have a moment for myself to think. I'm already straining to give them an hour now and then. It will have to be Nynaeve."

"wʌt wɪl əv tə bi nɪneɪiv?" ðə wʊmən hɝsɛlf dɪmændəd tʃɪɹfəli, dʒɔɪnɪŋ ðɛm. sʌmhaʊ ʃi hæɾ əkwaɪɝɾ ə lɔŋ, jɛloʊ-fɹɪnd ʃɔl ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd wɪð livz ən bɹaɪt flaʊɝz, bʌɾ ɪt leɪ lupt oʊvɝ əɹ ɛlboʊz. dɪspaɪt ðə tɛmpɹətʃɝz ʃi wɔɹ ə blu ɡaʊn wɪð kwaɪɾ ə loʊ nɛklaɪn fəɹ ændɝ, ðoʊ ðə θɪk, dɑɹk bɹeɪd pʊld oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ ən nɛsəld ɪn əɹ klivədʒ kɛp ði ɪkspoʊʒɝ fɹəm biɪŋ tu ɡɹeɪt. ðə smɔl ɹɛd dɑt, ðə kɪsən, ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə hɝ fɔɹhɛd dɪd lʊk kwaɪt stʃɹeɪnʒ. əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə mɔlkɪɹi kʌstəm, ə ɹɛd kɪsən mɑɹkt ə mɛɹid wʊmən, ən ʃi hæɾ ɪnsɪstəɾ ɑn wɛɹɪŋ ɪɾ əz sun əz ʃi lɝnd. tɔɪɪŋ aɪdli wɪð ði ɛn ə hɝ bɹeɪd, ʃi lʊkt . . . kɑntɛnt . . . nɑɾ ən ɪmoʊʃən ɛniwʌn juʒəwəli əsoʊsieɪɾəd wɪð nɪneɪiv ɑlmɹə.

"What will have to be Nynaeve?" the woman herself demanded cheerfully, joining them. Somehow she had acquired a long, yellow-fringed shawl embroidered with leaves and bright flowers, but it lay looped over her elbows. Despite the temperatures she wore a blue gown with quite a low neckline for Andor, though the thick, dark braid pulled over her shoulder and nestled in her cleavage kept the exposure from being too great. The small red dot, the ki'sain, in the middle of her forehead did look quite strange. According to Malkieri custom, a red ki'sain marked a married woman, and she had insisted on wearing it as soon as she learned.
