Toying idly with the end of her braid, she looked . . . content . . . not an emotion anyone usually associated with Nynaeve al'Meara.

ɪleɪn ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt wən ʃi noʊɾəst læn, ə fju peɪsɪz ɔf, stʃɹoʊlɪŋ ə sɝkəl ɝaʊn əm ən kipɪŋ wɑtʃ daʊn boʊθ hɔlweɪz. əz tɔl əz ən ilmən ɪn ɪz dɑɹk ɡɹin koʊt, wɪð ʃoʊldɝz bɪlɔŋɪŋ ɑn ə blæksmɪθ, ðə hɑɹd-feɪs mæn stɪl mænədʒ tə muv laɪk ə ɡoʊst. hɪz sɔɹd wɑz bʌkəld əɾ ɪz weɪst ivən hɪɹ ɪn ðə pæləs. hi ɔlweɪz meɪɾ ɪleɪn ʃɪvɝ. dɛθ ɡeɪz fɹəm ɪz koʊl blu aɪz. ɪksɛpt wən i lʊkt ət nɪneɪiv, ɛniweɪ.

Elayne gave a start when she noticed Lan, a few paces off, strolling a circle around them and keeping watch down both hallways. As tall as an Aielman in his dark green coat, with shoulders belonging on a blacksmith, the hard-faced man still managed to move like a ghost. His sword was buckled at his waist even here in the Palace. He always made Elayne shiver. Death gazed from his cold blue eyes. Except when he looked at Nynaeve, anyway.

kəntɛnmənt vænɪʃt fɹəm nɪneɪivz feɪs əz sun əz ʃi lɝnd wʌt wəɾ əv tə bi hɝ tæsk. ʃi stɑp fɪŋɡɝɪŋ əɹ bɹeɪd, ən sizd ɪɾ ɪn ə taɪt fɪst. "naʊ jə lɪsən tə mi. ɪleɪn maɪt bi eɪbəl tə lɑl ɝaʊn pleɪɪŋ pɑlətɪks, bʌɾ aɪ hæv maɪ hænz fʊl. mɔɹ ðən hæf ðə kɪn wʊɾə vænɪʃt baɪ naʊ ɪf æləz wɑzn hoʊldɪŋ əm baɪ ðə skɹʌf ə ðə nɛk, ən sɪns ʃi hæzən ə hoʊp ə ɹitʃɪŋ ðə ʃɔl hɝsɛlf, aɪm nɑt ʃʊɹ haʊ mʌtʃ lɔŋɡɝ ʃɪl hoʊld ɛnibəɾi. ðə ɹɛs θɪŋk ðeɪ kən ɑɹɡju wɪð mi! jɛstɝdeɪ, sumeɪkoʊ kɔl mi . . . ɡɝl!"

Contentment vanished from Nynaeve's face as soon as she learned what would have to be her task. She stopped fingering her braid, and seized it in a tight fist. "Now you listen to me. Elayne might be able to loll around playing politics, but I have my hands full. More than half the Kin would have vanished by now if Alise wasn't holding them by the scruff of the neck, and since she hasn't a hope of reaching the shawl herself, I'm not sure how much longer she'll hold anybody. The rest think they can argue with me! Yesterday, Sumeko called me . . . girl!"

ʃi bɛɹɾ əɹ tiθ, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ɔl əɹ oʊn fɔlt, wʌn weɪ ən ənʌðɝ. æftɝ ɔl, ʃi wɑz ðə wʌn u hæd hæmɝɾ ət ðə kɪn ðət ðeɪ ɔt tə ʃoʊ səm bækboʊn ɪnstɛɾ ʌv ɡɹɔvəlɪŋ tə ɛɛs sədaɪ. wɛl, ðeɪ sɝɾənli hæd stɑpt ɡɹɔvəlɪŋ. ɪnstɛd, ðeɪ wɝ ɔl tu laɪkli tə hoʊl sɪstɝz ʌp tə ðə stændɝɾ ə ðɛɹ ɹul. ən faɪn ðə sɪstɝ wɑntɪŋ! ɪt maɪt nɑt bi nɪneɪivz fɔlt, ɪɡzækli, ðət ʃi əpɪɹd tə bi lɪɾəl mɔɹ ðən twɛnti - ʃi hæd sloʊɾ ɝli - bʌɾ eɪdʒ wɑz ɪmpɔɹɾənt tə ðə kɪn, ən ʃi hæd tʃoʊzən tə spɛn moʊst ə hɝ taɪm wɪð ðɛm. ʃi wɑz nɑt dʒɝkɪŋ əɹ bɹeɪd, dʒʌs pʊlɪŋ əɾ ɪt soʊ stɛɾəli ɪt mʌs bi ɹɛɾi tə pʊl fɹi ʌv əɹ skælp.

She bared her teeth, but it was all her own fault, one way and another. After all, she was the one who had hammered at the Kin that they ought to show some backbone instead of groveling to Aes Sedai. Well, they certainly had stopped groveling. Instead, they were all too likely to hold sisters up to the standard of their Rule. And find the sister wanting! It might not be Nynaeve's fault, exactly, that she appeared to be little more than twenty - she had slowed early - but age was important to the Kin, and she had chosen to spend most of her time with them. She was not jerking her braid, just pulling at it so steadily it must be ready to pull free of her scalp.

"æn ðoʊz kɝst si foʊk! ɹɛtʃɪd wɪmən! ɹɛtʃɪd; ɹɛtʃɪd; ɹɛtʃɪd! ɪf ɪt wɑzn fəɹ ðət blʌɾi bɑɹɡən . . . ! ðə læs θɪŋ aɪ niɾ ɑn maɪ hænz ɪz ə kʌpəl ʌv waɪnɪŋ, bliɾɪŋ nɑvəsɪz!" kɝstʃənz lɪps θɪn fəɹ ən ɪnstənt, ən zɛɹjəz dɑɹk aɪz flæʃt ɪndɪɡneɪʃən bɪfɔɹ ʃi mænədʒ tə əsum miknəs əɡɛn. ə sɛmbləns ʌv ɪt. ðeɪ hæd sɛns ɪnʌf tə noʊ ðət nɑvəsɪz dɪd nɑɾ oʊpən ðɛɹ maʊðz tə ɛɛs sədaɪ, ðoʊ.

"And those cursed Sea Folk! Wretched women! Wretched; wretched; wretched! If it wasn't for that bloody bargain . . . ! The last thing I need on my hands is a couple of whining, bleating novices!" Kirstian's lips thinned for an instant, and Zarya's dark eyes flashed indignation before she managed to assume meekness again. A semblance of it. They had sense enough to know that novices did not open their mouths to Aes Sedai, though.

ɪleɪn ʃʌv daʊn ðə dɪzaɪɝ tə smuð ɛvɹiθɪŋ oʊvɝ. ʃi wɑntəd tə slæp kɝstʃən ən zɛɹjə boʊθ. ðeɪ hæd kɑmpləkeɪɾəd ɛvɹiθɪŋ baɪ nɑt kipɪŋ ðɛɹ maʊðz ʃʌɾ ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs. ʃi wɑntəd tə slæp nɪneɪiv. soʊ ʃi faɪnəli hæd bɪn kɔɹnɝd baɪ ðə wɪndfɪndɝz, hæd ʃi? ðəɾ ɝnd noʊ sɪmpəθi. "aɪm nɑt pleɪɪŋ əɾ ɛniθɪŋ, nɪneɪiv, ən jə wɛl noʊ ɪt! aɪ hæv æsk jəɹ ædvaɪs ɔfən ɪnʌf!" dʒɹɔɪŋ ə dip bɹɛθ, ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə kɑm hɝsɛlf. ðə sɝvəns ʃi kəd si bɪɑn vændin ən ðə tu nɑvəsɪz hæd pɔzd ɪn ðɛɹ wɝk tə ɡɑɡəl ət ðə klʌstɝ ʌv wɪmən. ʃi daʊɾɪd ðeɪ mɔɹ ðən noʊɾəst læn, ɪmpɹɛsɪv əz i wɑz. ɑɹɡjuɪŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ sʌmθɪŋ tə wɑtʃ, ən steɪ klɪɹ ʌv. "sʌmwʌn əz tə teɪk tʃɑɹdʒ ə ðɛm," ʃi sɛd mɔɹ kwaɪətli. "ɔɹ dʒju θɪŋk jə kən dʒʌs tɛl əm tə fɝɡɛɾ ɔl ðɪs? lʊk ət ðɛm, nɪneɪiv. lɛf tə ðɛmsɛlvz, ðəl bi tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə faɪn aʊɾ u ɪts ɪn ə hɑɹtbit. ðeɪ wʊdn əv ɡɔn tə vændin ənlɛs ðeɪ θɔt ʃi wəd lɛɾ əm hɛlp." ðə pɛɹ bɪkeɪm pɪktʃɝz ʌv waɪd-aɪd nɑvəs ɪnəsəns, wɪð dʒʌst ə hɪn ʌv əfɛns əɾ ən əndʒʌst ækjəzeɪʃən. ɪleɪn dɪd nɑt bɪliv ɪt. ðeɪ hæd hæɾ ə laɪftaɪm tə wɝk ɑn dɪsɡaɪzɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz.

Elayne shoved down the desire to smooth everything over. She wanted to slap Kirstian and Zarya both. They had complicated everything by not keeping their mouths shut in the first place. She wanted to slap Nynaeve. So she finally had been cornered by the Windfinders, had she? That earned no sympathy. "I'm not playing at anything, Nynaeve, and you well know it! I have asked your advice often enough!" Drawing a deep breath, she tried to calm herself. The servants she could see beyond Vandene and the two novices had paused in their work to goggle at the cluster of women. She doubted they more than noticed Lan, impressive as he was. Arguing Aes Sedai were something to watch, and stay clear of. "Someone has to take charge of them," she said more quietly. "Or do you think you can just tell them to forget all this? Look at them, Nynaeve. Left to themselves, they will be trying to find out who it is in a heartbeat. They wouldn't have gone to Vandene unless they thought she would let them help." The pair became pictures of wide-eyed novice innocence, with just a hint of offense at an unjust accusation. Elayne did not believe it. They had had a lifetime to work on disguising themselves.

"ænd waɪ nɑt?" nɪneɪiv sɛɾ æftɝ ə moʊmənt, ʃɪftɪŋ əɹ ʃɔl. "laɪt, ɪleɪn, juv tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðeɪ ɑɹənt wʌt wi nɔɹməli ɪkspɛkt ɪn nɑvəsɪz." ɪleɪn oʊpən əɹ maʊθ ɪn pɹoʊɾɛst - wʌt wi nɔɹməli ɪkspɛkt, ɪndid! - nɪneɪiv maɪt nɛvɝ əv bɪn ə nɑvəs, bʌt ʃi hæd bɪn æksɛptɪd nɑɾ ɔl ðət lɔŋ əɡoʊ; ə waɪnɪŋ, bliɾɪŋ æksɛptɪd, ɔfən ɪnʌf, tu! - ʃi oʊpən əɹ maʊθ, ən nɪneɪiv wɛn ɹaɪɾ ɑn. "vændin kən meɪk ɡʊd jus ə ðɛm, aɪm ʃʊɹ," ʃi sɛd. "ænd wən ʃi ɪzənt, ʃi kən ɡɪv əm ɹɛɡjəlɝ lɛsənz. aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ sʌmwʌn tɛlɪŋ mi juv tɔt nɑvəsɪz bɪfɔɹ, vændin. ðɛɹ. ɪts sɛɾəld."

"And why not?" Nynaeve said after a moment, shifting her shawl. "Light, Elayne, you have to remember they aren't what we normally expect in novices." Elayne opened her mouth in protest - what we normally expect, indeed! - Nynaeve might never have been a novice, but she had been Accepted not all that long ago; a whining, bleating Accepted, often enough, too! - she opened her mouth, and Nynaeve went right on. "Vandene can make good use of them, I'm sure," she said. "And when she isn't, she can give them regular lessons. I remember someone telling me you've taught novices before, Vandene. There. It's settled."

ðə tu nɑvəsɪz smaɪl bɹɔd, iɡɝ smaɪlz ʌv æntɪsəpeɪʃən - ðeɪ ɔl bʌt ɹʌb ðɛɹ hænz təɡɛðɝ ɪn sæɾəsfækʃən - bʌt vændin skaʊld. "aɪ də nɑt nid nɑvəsɪz ɡɛɾɪŋ ʌndɝ maɪ fit waɪl aɪ - "

The two novices smiled broad, eager smiles of anticipation - they all but rubbed their hands together in satisfaction - but Vandene scowled. "I do not need novices getting under my feet while I - "

"jɔɹ dʒʌst əz blaɪn əz ɪleɪn," nɪneɪiv bɹoʊk ɪn. "ðeɪ hæv ɪkspɪɹiəns meɪkɪŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ teɪk əm fəɹ sʌmθɪŋ ʌðɝ ðən wʌt ðeɪ ɑɹ. ðeɪ kən wɝk ət jəɹ dɝɛkʃən, ən ðət wɪl ɡɪv jə taɪm tə slip ən it. aɪ doʊn bɪliv jəɹ duɪŋ iðɝ." ʃi dʒɹu hɝsɛlf ʌp, dʒɹeɪpɪŋ əɹ ʃɔl əkɹɔs əɹ ʃoʊldɝz ən əlɔŋ əɹ ɑɹmz. ɪt wɑz kwaɪɾ ə pɝfɔɹməns. ʃɔɹɾ əz ʃi wɑz, noʊ tɔlɝ ðən zɛɹjə ən mɑɹkədli ʃɔɹɾɝ ðən vændin əɹ kɝstʃən, ʃi mænədʒ tə sim ðə tɔlɪst wʌn ðəɹ baɪ ɪntʃəz. ɪt wɑz ə skɪl ɪleɪn wɪʃt ʃi kəd mæstɝ. ɔlðoʊ ʃi wəd nɑt tʃɹaɪ ɪn ə dʒɹɛs kʌt ðət weɪ. nɪneɪiv wɑz ɪn deɪnʒɝ ə kʌmɪŋ ɹaɪɾ aʊt. stɪl, ðət dɪd nɑt dɪmɪnɪʃ əɹ pɹɛzəns. ʃi wɑz ði ɛsəns ə kəmænd. "ju wɪl də ɪt, vændin," ʃi sɛd fɝmli.

"You're just as blind as Elayne," Nynaeve broke in. "They have experience making Aes Sedai take them for something other than what they are. They can work at your direction, and that will give you time to sleep and eat. I don't believe you're doing either." She drew herself up, draping her shawl across her shoulders and along her arms. It was quite a performance. Short as she was, no taller than Zarya and markedly shorter than Vandene or Kirstian, she managed to seem the tallest one there by inches. It was a skill Elayne wished she could master. Although she would not try in a dress cut that way. Nynaeve was in danger of coming right out. Still, that did not diminish her presence. She was the essence of command. "You will do it, Vandene," she said firmly.

vændinz skaʊl feɪɾəd sloʊli, bʌt feɪɾ ɪt dɪd. nɪneɪiv stʊd haɪɝ ɪn ðə paʊɝ ðən ʃi, ən ivən ɪf ʃi nɛvɝ kɑnʃəsli θɔɾ ə ðə fækt, dipli ɪnɡɹeɪn kʌstəm meɪɾ əɹ jild, haʊɛvɝ ənwɪlɪŋli. baɪ ðə taɪm ʃi tɝn tə ðə tu wɪmən ɪn waɪt, hɝ feɪs wɑz əz nɪɹ kəmpoʊzd əz ɪt hæd bɪn sɪns æɾɪliz' mɝɾɝ. wɪtʃ dʒʌs mɛn ðət ðə dʒʌdʒ maɪt nɑɾ ɔɹɾɝ ən ɛksəkjuʃən ɹaɪt naʊ. leɪɾɝ, pɝhæps. hɝ ɡɔn feɪs wɑz kɑm, ən stɑɹkli ɡɹɪm.

Vandene's scowl faded slowly, but fade it did. Nynaeve stood higher in the Power than she, and even if she never consciously thought of the fact, deeply ingrained custom made her yield, however unwillingly. By the time she turned to the two women in white, her face was as near composed as it had been since Adeleas' murder. Which just meant that the judge might not order an execution right now. Later, perhaps. Her gaunt face was calm, and starkly grim.

"aɪ dɪd titʃ nɑvəsɪz fəɹ ə taɪm," ʃi sɛd. "ə ʃɔɹt taɪm. ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə nɑvəsɪz θɔɾ aɪ wɑz tu hɑɹɾ ɑn maɪ stuɾənts." ðə pɛɹz iɡɝnəs kuld ə bɪt. "hɝ neɪm wɑz sɛɝl beɪɡənd." zɛɹjəz feɪs wɛn əz peɪl əz kɝstʃənz, ən kɝstʃən sweɪɾ əz ɪf sʌɾənli dɪzi. əz mɪstʃɹəs ə nɑvəsɪz ən leɪɾɝ æmɪɝlɪn sit, sɛɝl wɑz ə lɛdʒənd. ðə sɔɹɾ ə lɛdʒən ðət meɪd jə weɪk ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə naɪt swɛɾɪŋ. "aɪ də it," vændin sɛd tə nɪneɪiv. "bʌɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ teɪsts laɪk æʃəz." wɪð ə kɝt dʒɛstʃɝ ət ðə tu nɑvəsɪz, ʃi lɛɾ əm əweɪ pæs læn. ðeɪ wɝ stæɡɝɪŋ slaɪtli əz ðeɪ fɑloʊd.

"I did teach novices for a time," she said. "A short time. The Mistress of Novices thought I was too hard on my students." The pair's eagerness cooled a bit. "Her name was Sereille Bagand." Zarya's face went as pale as Kirstian's, and Kirstian swayed as if suddenly dizzy. As Mistress of Novices and later Amyrlin Seat, Sereille was a legend. The sort of legend that made you wake in the middle of the night sweating. "I do eat," Vandene said to Nynaeve. "But everything tastes like ashes." With a curt gesture at the two novices, she led them away past Lan. They were staggering slightly as they followed.

"stʌbɝn wʊmən," nɪneɪiv ɡɹʌmbəld, fɹaʊnɪŋ ət ðə ɹitʃɹiɾɪŋ bæks, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz mɔɹ ðən ə hɪn ə sɪmpəθi ɪn əɹ vɔɪs. "aɪ noʊ ə dʌzən ɝbz ðət wəd hɛlp əɹ slip, bʌt ʃi woʊn tʌtʃ ðɛm. aɪv hæf ə maɪn tə slɪp sʌmθɪŋ ɪndə hɝ ivnɪŋ waɪn."

"Stubborn woman," Nynaeve grumbled, frowning at the retreating backs, but there was more than a hint of sympathy in her voice. "I know a dozen herbs that would help her sleep, but she won't touch them. I've half a mind to slip something into her evening wine."

ə waɪz ɹulɝ, ɪleɪn θɔt, noʊz wən tə spik ən wən nɑt. wɛl, ðət wɑz wɪzdəm ɪn ɛniwʌn. ʃi dɪd nɑt seɪ ðət nɪneɪiv kɔlɪŋ ɛniwʌn stʌbɝn wɑz ðə ɹustɝ kɔlɪŋ ðə fɛzən pɹaʊd. "du jə noʊ wʌt ɹinz nuz ɪz?" ʃi sɛɾ ɪnstɛd. "ɡʊd nuz - 'ʌv ə sɔɹt' - soʊ aɪ ʌndɝstænd."

A wise ruler, Elayne thought, knows when to speak and when not. Well, that was wisdom in anyone. She did not say that Nynaeve calling anyone stubborn was the rooster calling the pheasant proud. "Do you know what Reanne's news is?" she said instead. "Good news - 'of a sort' - so I understand."

"aɪ hævən sin əɹ ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ," ði ʌðɝ wʊmən mʌɾɝd, stɪl piɹɪŋ æftɝ vændin. "aɪ hævən bɪn aʊɾ ə maɪ ɹumz." əbɹʌpli ʃi ɡeɪv hɝsɛlf ə ʃeɪk, ən fəɹ səm ɹizən fɹaʊn səspɪʃəsli əɾ ɪleɪn. ən ðən ət læn, ʌv ɔl θɪŋz. ʌnpɝtɝbd, hi kəntɪnjud tə stænd ɡɑɹd.

"I haven't seen her this morning," the other woman muttered, still peering after Vandene. "I haven't been out of my rooms." Abruptly she gave herself a shake, and for some reason frowned suspiciously at Elayne. And then at Lan, of all things. Unperturbed, he continued to stand guard.

nɪneɪiv kleɪmd əɹ mɛɹɪdʒ wɑz ɡlɔɹiəs - ʃi kəd bi ʃɑkɪŋli fɹæŋk əbaʊɾ ɪt wɪð ʌðɝ wɪmən - bʌɾ ɪleɪn θɔt ʃi mʌs bi laɪɪŋ tə kʌvɝ ʌp dɪsəpɔɪnmənt. vɛɹi laɪkli læn wɑz ɹɛɾi fəɹ ən ətæk, ɹɛɾi tə faɪt, ivən wən əslip. ɪt wəd bi laɪk laɪɪŋ daʊn bɪsaɪɾ ə hʌŋɡɹi laɪən. bɪsaɪdz, ðət stoʊn feɪs wɑz ɪnʌf tə tʃɪl ɛni mɛɹɪdʒ bɛd. lʌkəli, nɪneɪiv hæd noʊ aɪdiə wʌt ʃi θɔt. ðə wʊmən æktʃəli  smaɪld. ən əmjuz smaɪl, ɑdli. əmjuzd, ən . . . kəɾ ɪt bi kɑndɪsɛndɪŋ? ʌv kɔɹs nɑt. ɪmædʒəneɪʃən.

Nynaeve claimed her marriage was glorious - she could be shockingly frank about it with other women - but Elayne thought she must be lying to cover up disappointment. Very likely Lan was ready for an attack, ready to fight, even when asleep. It would be like lying down beside a hungry lion. Besides, that stone face was enough to chill any marriage bed. Luckily, Nynaeve had no idea what she thought. The woman actually smiled. An amused smile, oddly. Amused, and . . . could it be condescending? Of course not. Imagination.

"aɪ noʊ wɛɹ ɹin ɪz," nɪneɪiv sɛd, sɛɾəlɪŋ əɹ ʃɔl bæk daʊn tə hɝ ɛlboʊz. "kʌm wɪð mi. əl teɪk jə tə hɝ."

"I know where Reanne is," Nynaeve said, settling her shawl back down to her elbows. "Come with me. I'll take you to her."

ɪleɪn nu ɪɡzækli wɛɹ ɹin wəd bi, sɪns ʃi wɑz nɑt klɑzəɾɪd wɪð nɪneɪiv, bʌt wʌns əɡɛn ʃi skuld əɹ tʌŋ, ən lɛt nɪneɪiv lɛd hɝ. ə sɔɹɾ ə pɛnəns fəɹ ɑɹɡjuɪŋ ɝliɝ, wən ʃi ʃʊɾə tʃɹaɪd tə meɪk pis. læn fɑloʊd, ðoʊz koʊld aɪz skænɪŋ ðə hɔlz. ðə sɝvəns ðeɪ pæs flɪntʃt wən lænz ɡeɪz fɛl ɑn ðɛm. ə jʌnʒɪʃ, peɪl-hɛɹd wʊmən æktʃəli  ɡæðɝɾ əɹ skɝts ən ɹæn, bʌmpɪŋ ɪndə ə stænd-læmp ən sɛɾɪŋ ɪt ɹɑkɪŋ ɪn əɹ flaɪt.

Elayne knew exactly where Reanne would be, since she was not closeted with Nynaeve, but once again she schooled her tongue, and let Nynaeve lead her. A sort of penance for arguing earlier, when she should have tried to make peace. Lan followed, those cold eyes scanning the halls. The servants they passed flinched when Lan's gaze fell on them. A youngish, pale-haired woman actually gathered her skirts and ran, bumping into a stand-lamp and setting it rocking in her flight.

ðət ɹimaɪndəɾ ɪleɪn tə tɛl nɪneɪiv əbaʊɾ ɛləniə ən nɑiən, ən əbaʊt ðə spaɪz. nɪneɪiv tʊk ɪt kwaɪt kɑmli. ʃi əɡɹid wɪð ɪleɪn ðət ðeɪ wəd noʊ sun ɪnʌf u hæd ɹɛskjud ðə tu wɪmən, wɪð ə dɪsmɪsɪv snɪf fəɹ sɝaɪðəz daʊts. fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, ʃi ɪkspɹɛst sɝpɹaɪz ðət ðeɪ hæd nɑt bɪn teɪkən ɹaɪt fɹəm ɑɹɪŋɡəl lɔŋ sɪns. "aɪ kʊdn bɪliv ðeɪ wɝ stɪl ðəɹ wən wi ɝaɪvd ɪn keɪɛmlɪn. ɛni ful kəd si ðeɪ wəd bi bɹɔt hɪɹ sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ. mʌtʃ iziɝ tə ɡɛɾ əm aʊɾ ʌv ə smɔl taʊn." ə smɔl taʊn. ɑɹɪŋɡəl wʊɾə simd ə ɡɹeɪt sɪɾi tə hɝ, wʌns. "æz fəɹ spaɪz . . ." ʃi fɹaʊn əɾ ə læŋki, ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd mæn fɪlɪŋ ə ɡoʊld-wɝk stænd-læmp wɪð ɔɪl, ən ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "ʌv kɔɹs ðəɹ ɑɹ spaɪz. aɪ nu ðəɹ mʌs bi, ɹaɪt fɹəm ðə stɑɹt. jə dʒʌst əv tə wɑtʃ wʌt jə seɪ, ɪleɪn. doʊn seɪ ɛniθɪŋ tə ɛniwʌn jə doʊnt noʊ wɛl ənlɛs jə doʊn maɪn ɛvɹiwʌn noʊɪŋ."

That reminded Elayne to tell Nynaeve about Elenia and Naean, and about the spies. Nynaeve took it quite calmly. She agreed with Elayne that they would know soon enough who had rescued the two women, with a dismissive sniff for Sareitha's doubts. For that matter, she expressed surprise that they had not been taken right from Aringill long since. "I couldn't believe they were still there when we arrived in Caemlyn. Any fool could see they would be brought here sooner or later. Much easier to get them out of a small town." A small town. Aringill would have seemed a great city to her, once. "As for spies . . ." She frowned at a lanky, gray-haired man filling a gold-worked stand-lamp with oil, and shook her head. "Of course there are spies. I knew there must be, right from the start. You just have to watch what you say, Elayne. Don't say anything to anyone you don't know well unless you don't mind everyone knowing."

wən tə spik ən wən nɑt, ɪleɪn θɔt, pɝsɪŋ əɹ lɪps. səmtaɪmz ðət kəd bi ə tʃɹu pɛnəns, wɪð nɪneɪiv.

When to speak and when not, Elayne thought, pursing her lips. Sometimes that could be a true penance, with Nynaeve.

nɪneɪiv hæɾ əɹ oʊn ɪnfɝmeɪʃən tə ɪmpɑɹt. eɪtin ə ðə kɪn u hæɾ əkʌmpəniɾ əm tə keɪɛmlɪn wɝ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ɪn ðə pæləs. ðeɪ hæd nɑt ɹʌn əweɪ, ðoʊ. sɪns nʌn wɑz stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf tə tʃɹævəl, nɪneɪiv hæd woʊvən ðə ɡeɪtweɪz hɝsɛlf, sɛndɪŋ əm dip ɪndə ɔltɑɹə ən ɑmɑdɪʃiə ən tæɹɑbən, ɪndə ðə sintʃæn-hɛld lænz wɛɹ ðeɪ wəd tʃɹaɪ tə faɪn ɛni ʌv ðə kɪn u hæd nɑɾ ɔlɹɛɾi flɛɾ ən bɹɪŋ əm bæk tə keɪɛmlɪn.

Nynaeve had her own information to impart. Eighteen of the Kin who had accompanied them to Caemlyn were no longer in the Palace. They had not run away, though. Since none was strong enough to Travel, Nynaeve had woven the gateways herself, sending them deep into Altara and Amadicia and Tarabon, into the Seanchan-held lands where they would try to find any of the Kin who had not already fled and bring them back to Caemlyn.

ɪt wʊɾə bɪn naɪs ɪf nɪneɪiv hæd θɔt tə ɪnfɔɹm əɹ jɛstɝdeɪ, wən ðeɪ lɛft, əɹ bɛɾɝ jɛt, wən ʃi ən ɹin ɹitʃt ðə dɪsɪʒən tə sɛn ðɛm, bʌɾ ɪleɪn dɪd nɑt mɛnʃən ðæt. ɪnstɛd, ʃi sɛd, "ðæts vɛɹi bɹeɪv ə ðɛm. əvɔɪɾɪŋ kæptʃɝ woʊn bi izi."

It would have been nice if Nynaeve had thought to inform her yesterday, when they left, or better yet, when she and Reanne reached the decision to send them, but Elayne did not mention that. Instead, she said, "That's very brave of them. Avoiding capture won't be easy."

"bɹeɪv, jɛs," nɪneɪiv sɛd, saʊndɪŋ ɪɹəteɪɾəd. hɝ hæn kɹɛpt ʌp tə hɝ bɹeɪɾ əɡɛn. "bʌt ðəɾ ɪzənt waɪ wi tʃoʊz ðɛm. æləz θɔt ðeɪ wɝ ðə moʊs laɪkli tə ɹʌn ɪf wi dɪdnt ɡɪv əm sʌmθɪŋ tə du." ɡlænsɪŋ oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ ət læn, ʃi snætʃt əɹ hæn bæk daʊn. "aɪ doʊn si haʊ ɛɡwin minz tə də ɪt," ʃi saɪd. "ɔl vɛɹi wɛl tə seɪ ɛvɹi wʌn ə ðə kɪn wɪl bi 'əsoʊsieɪɾəd' wɪð ðə taʊɝ sʌmhaʊ, bʌt haʊ? moʊst ɑɹən stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf tə ɝn ðə ʃɔl. mɛni kæn ivən ɹitʃ æksɛptɪd. ən ðeɪ sɝɾənli woʊn stæn fəɹ biɪŋ nɑvəsɪz əɹ æksɛptɪd ðə ɹɛst ə ðɛɹ laɪvz."

"Brave, yes," Nynaeve said, sounding irritated. Her hand crept up to her braid again. "But that isn't why we chose them. Alise thought they were the most likely to run if we didn't give them something to do." Glancing over her shoulder at Lan, she snatched her hand back down. "I don't see how Egwene means to do it," she sighed. "All very well to say every one of the Kin will be 'associated' with the Tower somehow, but how? Most aren't strong enough to earn the shawl. Many can't even reach Accepted. And they certainly won't stand for being novices or Accepted the rest of their lives."

ðɪs taɪm ɪleɪn sɛd nʌθɪŋ kəz ʃi dɪd nɑt noʊ wʌt tə seɪ. ðə pɹɑməs hæd tə bi kɛpt; ʃi hæd meɪɾ ɪt hɝsɛlf. ɪn ɛɡwinz neɪm, tʃɹu, ən əɾ ɛɡwinz ɔɹɾɝ, bʌt ʃi hæd spoʊkən ðə wɝdz hɝsɛlf, ən ʃi wəd nɑt bɹeɪk əɹ wɝd. oʊnli, ʃi dɪd nɑt si haʊ tə kip ɪɾ ənlɛs ɛɡwin keɪm ʌp wɪð sʌmθɪŋ tʃɹuli wʌndɝfəl.

This time Elayne said nothing because she did not know what to say. The promise had to be kept; she had made it herself. In Egwene's name, true, and at Egwene's order, but she had spoken the words herself, and she would not break her word. Only, she did not see how to keep it unless Egwene came up with something truly wonderful.

ɹin kɔɹli wɑz dʒʌst wɛɹ ɪleɪn hæd noʊn ʃi wəd bi, ɪn ə smɔl ɹum wɪð tu nɛɹoʊ wɪndoʊz lʊkɪŋ daʊn ɑn ə smɔl, faʊnteɪn kɔɹtʃjɑɹd dip ɪn ðə pæləs, ðoʊ ðə faʊntən wɑz dʒɹaɪ, ðɪs taɪm ə jɪɹ, ən ðə ɡlæs keɪsməns meɪd ðə ɹum ə lɪɾəl stʌfi. ðə flɔɹ wɑz pleɪn dɑɹk taɪl wɪð noʊ kɑɹpət, ən fəɹ fɝnɪʃɪŋz ðəɹ wɝ oʊnli ə nɛɹoʊ teɪbəl ən tu tʃɛɹz. ðəɹ wɝ tu pipəl wɪð ɹin wən ɪleɪn ɛntɝd. æləz tɛndʒaɪl, ɪn sɪmpəl haɪ-nɛkt ɡɹeɪ, lʊkt ʌp fɹəm wɛɹ ʃi stʊɾ ət ði ɛn ə ðə teɪbəl. simɪŋli ɪn əɹ mɪɾəl jɪɹz, ʃi wɑz ə wʊmən ə plɛzənt, ənɹɪmɑɹkəbəl əpɪɹəns u wɑz kwaɪt ɹɪmɑɹkəbəl ɪndid wʌns jə keɪm tə noʊ hɝ ən kəd bi vɛɹi ənplɛzən ɪndid wən ɪt wɑz kɔl fɔɹ. ə sɪŋɡəl ɡlæns, ən ʃi ɹɪtɝn tə hɝ stʌɾi ʌv wʌt wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn ət ðə teɪbəl. ɛɛs sədaɪ, wɔɹɾɝz ən dɔɾɝ-ɛɹz dɪd nɑɾ ɪmpɹɛs æləz, nɑɾ ɛni lɔŋɡɝ. ɹin hɝsɛlf wɑz sɪɾɪŋ ɑn wʌn saɪɾ ə ðə teɪbəl, hɝ feɪs kɹist ən əɹ hɛɹ mɔɹ ɡɹeɪ ðən nɑt, ɪn ə ɡɹin dʒɹɛs mɔɹ ɪlæbɹət ðən æləzəz; ʃi hæd bɪn pʊɾ aʊɾ ə ðə taʊɝ æftɝ feɪlɪŋ əɹ tɛs fəɹ æksɛptɪd, ən ɔfɝɾ ə sɛkən tʃæns, ʃi hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi ədɑptəd ðə kʌlɝz ə hɝ pɹəfɝɾ ədʒɑ. əkɹɔs fɹəm əɹ sæɾ ə plʌmp wʊmən ɪn pleɪn bɹaʊn wʊl, hɝ feɪs sɛɾ ɪn stʌbɝn dɪfaɪəns ən əɹ dɑɹk aɪz lɑkt ɑn ɹin, əvɔɪɾɪŋ ðə sɪlvɝi sɛɡmɛntɪɾ æɾəm laɪɪŋ laɪk ə sneɪk bɪtwin əm ɑn ðə teɪbəl. hɝ hænz stʃɹoʊk ði ɛdʒ ə ðə teɪbəltɑp, ðoʊ, ən ɹin wɔɹ ə kɑnfəɾənt smaɪl ðət dipən ðə faɪn laɪnz ət ðə kɔɹnɝz ə hɝ aɪz.

Reanne Corly was just where Elayne had known she would be, in a small room with two narrow windows looking down on a small, fountained courtyard deep in the Palace, though the fountain was dry, this time of year, and the glass casements made the room a little stuffy. The floor was plain dark tile with no carpet, and for furnishings there were only a narrow table and two chairs. There were two people with Reanne when Elayne entered. Alise Tenjile, in simple high-necked gray, looked up from where she stood at the end of the table. Seemingly in her middle years, she was a woman of pleasant, unremarkable appearance who was quite remarkable indeed once you came to know her and could be very unpleasant indeed when it was called for. A single glance, and she returned to her study of what was going on at the table. Aes Sedai, Warders and Daughter-Heirs did not impress Alise, not any longer. Reanne herself was sitting on one side of the table, her face creased and her hair more gray than not, in a green dress more elaborate than Alise's; she had been put out of the Tower after failing her test for Accepted, and offered a second chance, she had already adopted the colors of her preferred Ajah. Across from her sat a plump woman in plain brown wool, her face set in stubborn defiance and her dark eyes locked on Reanne, avoiding the silvery segmented a'dam lying like a snake between them on the table. Her hands stroked the edge of the tabletop, though, and Reanne wore a confident smile that deepened the fine lines at the corners of her eyes.

"doʊn tɛl mi juv meɪd wʌn ə ðɛm si ɹizən," nɪneɪiv sɛd bɪfɔɹ læn hæɾ ivən ʃʌt ðə dɔɹ bɪhaɪn ðɛm. ʃi skaʊld ət ðə wʊmən ɪn bɹaʊn əz ðoʊ ʃi wɑntəd tə bɑks əɹ ɪɹz ɪf nɑt wɝs, ðən ɡlænst əɾ æləz. ɪleɪn θɔt nɪneɪiv wɑz ə lɪɾəl ɪn ɑ ʌv æləz. ðə wʊmən wɑz fɑɹ fɹəm stʃɹɔŋ ɪn ðə paʊɝ - ʃi wəd nɛvɝ əteɪn ðə ʃɔl - bʌt ʃi hæɾ ə weɪ ʌv teɪkɪŋ tʃɑɹdʒ wən ʃi wɑntəd tə ən meɪkɪŋ ɛvɹiwʌn ɝaʊn əɹ æksɛpt ɪt. ɪnkluɾɪŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ. ɪleɪn θɔt ʃi maɪt bi dʒʌst ə lɪɾəl ɪn ɑ ʌv æləz hɝsɛlf.

"Don't tell me you have made one of them see reason," Nynaeve said before Lan had even shut the door behind them. She scowled at the woman in brown as though she wanted to box her ears if not worse, then glanced at Alise. Elayne thought Nynaeve was a little in awe of Alise. The woman was far from strong in the Power - she would never attain the shawl - but she had a way of taking charge when she wanted to and making everyone around her accept it. Including Aes Sedai. Elayne thought she might be just a little in awe of Alise herself.

"ðeɪ stɪl dɪnaɪ ðeɪ kən tʃænəl," æləz mʌɾɝd, foʊldɪŋ əɹ ɑɹmz bɪniθ əɹ bɹɛsts, ən fɹaʊn ət ðə wʊmən feɪsɪŋ ɹin. "ðeɪ kænt, ɹɪli, aɪ səpoʊz, bʌɾ aɪ kən fil . . . sʌmθɪŋ. nɑt kwaɪt ðə spɑɹk ʌv ə wʊmən bɔɹn tə ɪt, bʌɾ ɔlmoʊst. ɪts əz ɪf ʃi wɝ ɹaɪɾ ət ðə bɹɪŋk ə biɪŋ eɪbəl tə tʃænəl, wʌn fʊt pɔɪz tə stɛp oʊvɝ. aɪ hæv nɛvɝ sɛnst ɛniθɪŋ laɪk ɪt bɪfɔɹ. wɛl. ət lis ðeɪ doʊn tʃɹaɪ tə ətæk əs wɪð ðɛɹ fɪsts ɛnimɔɹ. aɪ θɪŋk aɪ pʊɾ əm stʃɹeɪɾ ɑn ðæt, ət list!" ðə wʊmən ɪn bɹaʊn flæʃt ə sʌlən, æŋɡɹi ɡlɛɹ ət hɝ, bʌt dʒɝkt əɹ aɪz əweɪ fɹəm æləzəz fɝm ɡeɪz, hɝ maʊθ twɪstɪŋ ɪn ə sɪkli ɡɹɪmɑs. wən æləz sɛt sʌmbɑɾi stʃɹeɪt, ðeɪ wɝ sɛt vɛɹi stʃɹeɪɾ ɪndid. hɝ hænz kəntɪnjud tə ʃɪft əlɔŋ ðə teɪbəltɑp; ɪleɪn dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ʃi wɑz əwɛɹ ʌv ɪt.

"They still deny they can channel," Alise muttered, folding her arms beneath her breasts, and frowned at the woman facing Reanne. "They can't, really, I suppose, but I can feel . . . something. Not quite the spark of a woman born to it, but almost. It's as if she were right at the brink of being able to channel, one foot poised to step over. I have never sensed anything like it before. Well. At least they don't try to attack us with their fists anymore. I think I put them straight on that, at least!" The woman in brown flashed a sullen, angry glare at her, but jerked her eyes away from Alise's firm gaze, her mouth twisting in a sickly grimace. When Alise set somebody straight, they were set very straight indeed. Her hands continued to shift along the tabletop; Elayne did not think she was aware of it.

"ðeɪ stɪl dɪnaɪ siɪŋ ðə floʊz, tu, bʌt ðəɹ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kənvɪns ðɛmsɛlvz," ɹin sɛɾ ɪn əɹ haɪ, mjuzɪkəl vɔɪs. ʃi kəntɪnjud tə mit ði ʌðɝz ɑbstənət stɛɹ wɪð ə smaɪl. ɛni sɪstɝ maɪɾ əv ɛnvid ɹinz sɝɛnəɾi ən pɹɛzəns. ʃi hæd bɪn ɛldəst ə ðə nɪɾɪŋ sɝkəl, ðə haɪəst əθɔɹəɾi əmʌŋ ðə kɪn. əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə ðɛɹ ɹul, ðə nɪɾɪŋ sɝkəl ɪɡzɪstəɾ oʊnli ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ, bʌt ʃi wɑz stɪl ði oʊldəst əmʌŋ ðoʊz ɪn keɪɛmlɪn, ə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz oʊldɝ ðən ɛni ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn lɪvɪŋ mɛmɹi, ən ʃi kəd mætʃ ɛni sɪstɝ wɪð əɹ ɛɹ ə kɑm kəmænd. "ðeɪ kleɪm wi tʃɹɪk əm wɪð ðə paʊɝ, juz ɪt tə meɪk əm bɪliv ði æɾəm kən hoʊl ðɛm. sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ, ðəl ɹʌn aʊɾ ə laɪz." dʒɹɔɪŋ ði æɾəm tə hɝ, ʃi oʊpən ðə kɑlɝz kætʃ wɪð ə dɛf moʊʃən. "ʃæl wi tʃɹaɪ əɡɛn, mɑɹli?" ðə wʊmən ɪn bɹaʊn - mɑɹli - stɪl əvɔɪɾəd lʊkɪŋ ət ðə lɛŋθ ə sɪlvɝ mɛɾəl ɪn ɹinz hænz, bʌt ʃi stɪfən ən əɹ hænz flʌɾɝd ɑn ðə teɪbəlz ɛdʒ.

"They still deny seeing the flows, too, but they're trying to convince themselves," Reanne said in her high, musical voice. She continued to meet the other's obstinate stare with a smile. Any sister might have envied Reanne's serenity and presence. She had been Eldest of the Knitting Circle, the highest authority among the Kin. According to their Rule, the Knitting Circle existed only in Ebou Dar, but she was still the oldest among those in Caemlyn, a hundred years older than any Aes Sedai in living memory, and she could match any sister with her air of calm command. "They claim we trick them with the Power, use it to make them believe the a'dam can hold them. Sooner or later, they will run out of lies." Drawing the a'dam to her, she opened the collar's catch with a deft motion. "Shall we try again, Marli?" The woman in brown - Marli - still avoided looking at the length of silver metal in Reanne's hands, but she stiffened and her hands fluttered on the table's edge.

ɪleɪn saɪd. wʌɾ ə ɡɪft ɹænd hæd sɛn hɝ. ə ɡɪft! twɛnti-naɪn sintʃæn sʌldəm nitli hɛl baɪ æɾəm, ən faɪv deɪmeɪn - ʃi heɪɾəd ðət wɝd; ɪt mɛn liʃt wʌn, əɹ sɪmpli liʃt; bʌt ðət wɑz wʌt ðeɪ wɝ - faɪv deɪmeɪn u kəd nɑt bi ʌnkɑlɹd fəɹ ðə sɪmpəl ɹizən ðət ðeɪ wəd tʃɹaɪ tə fɹi ðə sintʃæn wɪmən u hæd hɛld əm pɹɪznɝ. lɛpɝdz taɪd wɪð stʃɹɪŋ wʊɾə bɪn ə bɛɾɝ ɡɪft. ət lis lɛpɝdz kəd nɑt tʃænəl. ðeɪ hæd bɪn ɡɪvən ɪndə ðə kɪnz kipɪŋ kəz noʊ wʌn ɛls hæd ðə taɪm.

Elayne sighed. What a gift Rand had sent her. A gift! Twenty-nine Seanchan sul'dam neatly held by a'dam, and five damane - she hated that word; it meant Leashed One, or simply Leashed; but that was what they were - five damane who could not be uncollared for the simple reason that they would try to free the Seanchan women who had held them prisoner. Leopards tied with string would have been a better gift. At least leopards could not channel. They had been given into the Kin's keeping because no one else had the time.

stɪl, ʃi hæd sin ɹaɪɾ əweɪ wʌt tə də wɪð ðə sʌldəm. kənvɪns əm ðət ðeɪ kəd lɝn tə tʃænəl, ðən sɛn əm bæk tə ðə sintʃæn. əpɑɹt fɹəm nɪneɪiv, oʊnli ɛɡwin, eɪvinhə ən ə fju ʌv ðə kɪn nu hɝ plæn. nɪneɪiv ən ɛɡwin wɝ daʊtfəl, bʌt haʊɛvɝ hɑɹd ðə sʌldəm tʃɹaɪd tə haɪd wʌt ðeɪ wɝ wʌns ðeɪ wɝ ɹɪtɝnd, ɪvɛntʃəwəli wʌn wəd slɪp. ɪf ðeɪ dɪd nɑt dʒʌst ɹipɔɹɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɹaɪɾ əweɪ. sintʃæn wɝ pəkjuljɝ; ivən ðə sintʃæn əmʌŋ ðə deɪmeɪn tʃɹuli bɪliv ðəɾ ɛni wʊmən u kəd tʃænəl hæd tə bi kɑlɝd fəɹ ðə seɪfti ʌv ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls. sʌldəm, wɪð ðɛɹ əbɪləɾi tə kəntʃɹoʊl wɪmən wɛɹɪŋ ði æɾəm, wɝ haɪli ɹɪspɛktɪɾ əmʌŋ ðə sintʃæn. ðə nɑlədʒ ðət sʌldəm ðɛmsɛlvz wɝ eɪbəl tə tʃænəl wəd ʃeɪk ðə sintʃæn tə ðɛɹ kɔɹ, meɪbi ivən bɹeɪk əm əpɑɹt. ɪt hæd sim soʊ sɪmpəl, ɪn ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ.

Still, she had seen right away what to do with the sul'dam. Convince them that they could learn to channel, then send them back to the Seanchan. Apart from Nynaeve, only Egwene, Aviendha and a few of the Kin knew her plan. Nynaeve and Egwene were doubtful, but however hard the sul'dam tried to hide what they were once they were returned, eventually one would slip. If they did not just report everything right away. Seanchan were peculiar; even the Seanchan among the damane truly believed that any woman who could channel had to be collared for the safety of everyone else. Sul'dam, with their ability to control women wearing the a'dam, were highly respected among the Seanchan. The knowledge that sul'dam themselves were able to channel would shake the Seanchan to their core, maybe even break them apart. It had seemed so simple, in the beginning.

"ɹin, aɪ ʌndɝstʊd ðət jə hæd ɡʊd nuz," ʃi sɛd. "ɪf ðə sʌldəm hævən stɑɹɾəd bɹeɪkɪŋ daʊn, wʌɾ ɪz ɪt?" æləz fɹaʊn ət læn, hu stʊd saɪlənt ɡɑɹɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə dɔɹ - ʃi dɪsəpɹuvd ə hɪm noʊɪŋ ðɛɹ plænz - bʌt ʃi sɛd nʌθɪŋ.

"Reanne, I understood that you had good news," she said. "If the sul'dam haven't started breaking down, what is it?" Alise frowned at Lan, who stood silent guard in front of the door - she disapproved of him knowing their plans - but she said nothing.

"ə moʊmənt, ɪf jə pliz," ɹin mɝmɝd. ɪt wɑz nɑt ɹɪli ə ɹɪkwɛst. nɪneɪiv tʃɹuli hæd dʌn əɹ dʒɑb tu wɛl. "ðɛɹ ɪz noʊ nid fəɹ əɹ tə lɪsən." ðə ɡloʊ ʌv seɪaɪdɑɹ sʌɾənli ʃoʊn ɝaʊn hɝ. ʃi muvd əɹ fɪŋɡɝz əz ʃi tʃænəld, əz ðoʊ ɡaɪɾɪŋ ðə floʊz ʌv ɛɹ ðət baʊn mɑɹli tə hɝ tʃɛɹ, ðən taɪɾ əm ɔf ən kʌpt əɹ hænz əz ðoʊ ʃeɪpɪŋ ɪn əɹ saɪt ðə wɔɹɾ əɡɛnst saʊn ðət ʃi woʊv ɝaʊn ðə wʊmən. ðə dʒɛstʃɝz wɝ noʊ pɑɹɾ ə tʃænəlɪŋ, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌt nɛsəsɛɹi tə hɝ, sɪns ʃi hæd lɝn ðə wivz ðət weɪ. ðə sʌldəmz lɪps twɪstəd slaɪtli ɪn kəntɛmpt. ðə wʌn paʊɝ dɪd nɑt fɹaɪɾən əɹ əɾ ɔl.

"A moment, if you please," Reanne murmured. It was not really a request. Nynaeve truly had done her job too well. "There is no need for her to listen." The glow of saidar suddenly shone around her. She moved her fingers as she channeled, as though guiding the flows of air that bound Marli to her chair, then tied them off and cupped her hands as though shaping in her sight the ward against sound that she wove around the woman. The gestures were no part of channeling, of course, but necessary to her, since she had learned the weaves that way. The sul'dam's lips twisted slightly in contempt. The One Power did not frighten her at all.

"teɪk jəɹ taɪm," nɪneɪiv pʊɾ ɪn æsədli, plæntɪŋ əɹ hænz ɑn əɹ hɪps. "ðɛɹz noʊ hɝi." ɹin dɪd nɑɾ ɪntɪmɪdeɪɾ əɹ ðə weɪ æləz dɪd.

"Take your time," Nynaeve put in acidly, planting her hands on her hips. "There's no hurry." Reanne did not intimidate her the way Alise did.

ðən əɡɛn, nɪneɪiv noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ɪntɪmɪdeɪɾɪd ɹin, iðɝ. ɹin dɪd teɪk əɹ taɪm, stʌɾiɪŋ əɹ hændiwɝk, ðən nɑɾəd wɪð sæɾəsfækʃən bɪfɔɹ ɹaɪzɪŋ. ðə kɪn hæɾ ɔlweɪz tʃɹaɪd tə tʃænəl əz lɪɾəl əz wɑz nɛsəsɛɹi, ən ʃi tʊk ɡɹeɪt plɛʒɝ ɪn ðə fɹiɾəm tə juz seɪaɪdɑɹ əz ɔfən əz ʃi wɪʃt, əz wɛl əz pɹaɪɾ ɪn wivɪŋ wɛl.

Then again, Nynaeve no longer intimidated Reanne, either. Reanne did take her time, studying her handiwork, then nodded with satisfaction before rising. The Kin had always tried to channel as little as was necessary, and she took great pleasure in the freedom to use saidar as often as she wished, as well as pride in weaving well.

"ðə ɡʊd nuz," ʃi sɛd, stændɪŋ ən smuðɪŋ əɹ skɝts, "ɪz ðət θɹi ʌv ðə deɪmeɪn sim ɹɛɾi tə bi lɛɾ aʊɾ ə ðɛɹ kɑlɝz. pɝhæps."

"The good news," she said, standing and smoothing her skirts, "is that three of the damane seem ready to be let out of their collars. Perhaps."

ɪleɪnz aɪbɹaʊz ɹoʊz, ən ʃi ɪkstʃeɪnʒd sɝpɹaɪz lʊks wɪð nɪneɪiv. ʌv ðə faɪv deɪmeɪn teɪm hæd hændəɾ oʊvɝ tə ðɛm, wʌn hæd bɪn teɪkən baɪ ðə sintʃæn ɑn toʊmən hɛɾ ən ənʌðɝ ɪn tæntʃəkoʊ. ði ʌðɝz hæd kʌm fɹəm sintʃæn.

Elayne's eyebrows rose, and she exchanged surprised looks with Nynaeve. Of the five damane Taim had handed over to them, one had been taken by the Seanchan on Toman Head and another in Tanchico. The others had come from Seanchan.

"tu ʌv ðə sintʃæn wɪmən, mɑɹɪl ən dʒɪlɑɹi, stɪl seɪ ðeɪ dɪzɝv tə bi kɑlɝd, nid tə bi kɑlɝd." ɹinz maʊθ taɪɾənd wɪð dɪsteɪst, bʌt ʃi pɔz fəɹ oʊnli ə moʊmənt. "ðeɪ tʃɹuli sim hɔɹəfaɪɾ ət ðə pɹɑspɛkt ə fɹiɾəm. əliviə hæz stɑp ðæt. naʊ ʃi sɛz ɪt wɑz oʊnli kəz ʃi wɑz əfɹeɪd ʃi wəd bi ɹəteɪkən. ʃi sɛz ʃi heɪts ɔl ðə sʌldəm, ən ʃi sɝɾənli meɪks ə ɡʊd ʃoʊ ʌv ɪt, snɑɹlɪŋ əɾ əm ən kɝsɪŋ ðɛm, bʌt . . ." ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd sloʊli ɪn daʊt. "ʃi wɑz kɑlɝɾ ət θɝtin əɹ fɔɹtin, ɪleɪn, ʃiz nɑt sɝɾən wɪtʃ, ən ʃiz bɪn deɪmeɪn fəɹ fɔɹ hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz! ən əsaɪd fɹəm ðæt, ʃiz . . . ʃiz . . . əliviə ɪz kənsɪɾɝəbli stʃɹɔŋɝ ðən nɪneɪiv," ʃi fɪnɪʃt ɪn ə ɹʌʃ. eɪdʒ, ðə kɪn maɪt dɪskʌs oʊpənli, bʌt ðeɪ hæɾ ɔl ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɹɛɾɪsəns əbaʊt spikɪŋ ə stʃɹɛŋkθ ɪn ðə paʊɝ. "du wi dɛɹ lɛɾ əɹ fɹi? eɪ sintʃæn waɪldɝ u kəd tɛɹ ði ɪntaɪɝ pæləs əpɑɹt?" ðə kɪn ʃɛɹd ði ɛɛs sədaɪ vju ʌv waɪldɝz, tu. moʊs dɪd.

"Two of the Seanchan women, Marille and Jillari, still say they deserve to be collared, need to be collared." Reanne's mouth tightened with distaste, but she paused for only a moment. "They truly seem horrified at the prospect of freedom. Alivia has stopped that. Now she says it was only because she was afraid she would be retaken. She says she hates all the sul'dam, and she certainly makes a good show of it, snarling at them and cursing them, but . . ." She shook her head slowly in doubt. "She was collared at thirteen or fourteen, Elayne, she's not certain which, and she's been damane for four hundred years! And aside from that, she is . . . she's . . . Alivia is considerably stronger than Nynaeve," she finished in a rush. Age, the Kin might discuss openly, but they had all the Aes Sedai reticence about speaking of strength in the Power. "Do we dare let her free? A Seanchan wilder who could tear the entire Palace apart?" The Kin shared the Aes Sedai view of wilders, too. Most did.

sɪstɝz u nu nɪneɪiv hæd lɝn tə teɪk kɛɹ wɪð ðət wɝɾ ɝaʊn hɝ. ʃi kəd bɪkʌm kwaɪt snæpɪʃ wən ɪt wɑz juzd ɪn ə dɪspɛɹɪdʒɪŋ toʊn. naʊ, ʃi dʒʌst stɛɹɾ ət ɹin. pɝhæps ʃi wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə faɪn ði ænsɝ. ɪleɪn nu wʌɾ əɹ oʊn ænsɝ wəd bi, bʌt ðɪs hæd nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð kleɪmɪŋ ðə θɹoʊn, əɹ ændɝ. ɪt wɑz ə dɪsɪʒən fəɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən hɪɹ, ðət mɛn ɪt wɑz nɪneɪivz tə meɪk.

Sisters who knew Nynaeve had learned to take care with that word around her. She could become quite snappish when it was used in a disparaging tone. Now, she just stared at Reanne. Perhaps she was trying to find the answer. Elayne knew what her own answer would be, but this had nothing to do with claiming the throne, or Andor. It was a decision for Aes Sedai, and here, that meant it was Nynaeve's to make.

"ɪf jə doʊnt," læn sɛd kwaɪətli fɹəm ðə dɔɹ, "ðɛn jə maɪɾ əz wɛl ɡɪv əɹ bæk tə ðə sintʃæn." hi wɑz nɑɾ əɾ ɔl əbæʃt baɪ ðə dɑɹk lʊks ɡɪvən ɪm baɪ ðə fɔɹ wɪmən u hɝɾ ɪz dip vɔɪs toʊl ðoʊz wɝdz laɪk ə fjunɝəl ɡɔŋ. "ju wɪl əv tə wɑtʃ əɹ kloʊsli, bʌt kip əɹ kɑlɝd wən ʃi wɑns tə bi fɹi, ən jə ɑɹ noʊ bɛɾɝ ðən ðeɪ ɑɹ."

"If you don't," Lan said quietly from the door, "then you might as well give her back to the Seanchan." He was not at all abashed by the dark looks given him by the four women who heard his deep voice toll those words like a funeral gong. "You will have to watch her closely, but keep her collared when she wants to be free, and you are no better than they are."

"ðæɾ ɪzən fəɹ jə tə seɪ, wɔɹɾɝ," æləz sɛd fɝmli. hi mɛɾ əɹ stɝn stɛɹ wɪð kul ikwənɪmɪɾi, ən ʃi ɡeɪv ə smɔl dɪsɡʌstəd ɡɹʌn ən θɹu ʌp əɹ hænz. "ju ʃəd ɡɪv ɪm ə ɡʊd tɔkɪŋ-tə wən jə ɡɛɾ ɪm əloʊn, nɪneɪiv."

"That isn't for you to say, Warder," Alise said firmly. He met her stern stare with cool equanimity, and she gave a small disgusted grunt and threw up her hands. "You should give him a good talking-to when you get him alone, Nynaeve."

nɪneɪiv mʌst əv bɪn filɪŋ əɹ ɑ ʌv ðə wɪmən pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli stʃɹɔŋli, kəz əɹ tʃiks kʌlɝd. "doʊn θɪŋk ðəɾ əl nɑt," ʃi sɛd laɪtli. ʃi dɪd nɑt lʊk ət læn əɾ ɔl. faɪnəli kɑndɪsɛndɪŋ tə noʊɾəs ðə tʃɪl, ʃi pʊld əɹ ʃɔl ʌp ɑntu hɝ ʃoʊldɝz, ən klɪɹɾ əɹ θɹoʊt. "hi ɪz ɹaɪt, ðoʊ. ət list wi doʊn əv tə wɝi əbaʊt ði ʌðɝ tu. aɪm dʒʌst sɝpɹaɪzd ɪt tʊk əm ðɪs lɔŋ tə stɑp ɪməteɪɾɪŋ ðoʊz ful sintʃæn."

Nynaeve must have been feeling her awe of the women particularly strongly, because her cheeks colored. "Don't think that I will not," she said lightly. She did not look at Lan at all. Finally condescending to notice the chill, she pulled her shawl up onto her shoulders, and cleared her throat. "He is right, though. At least we don't have to worry about the other two. I'm just surprised it took them this long to stop imitating those fool Seanchan."

"aɪ æm nɑt soʊ ʃʊɹ," ɹin saɪd. "kɛɹə wɑz ə sɔɹɾ ʌv waɪz wʊmən ɑn toʊmən hɛd, jə noʊ. vɛɹi ɪnfluɛntʃəl ɪn əɹ vɪlədʒ. ə waɪldɝ, ʌv kɔɹs. jə wəd θɪŋk ʃid heɪt ðə sintʃæn, bʌt ʃi dʌznt, nɑɾ ɔl ə ðɛm. ʃiz vɛɹi fɑn ə ðə sʌldəm kæptʃɝd wɪð hɝ, ən vɛɹi æŋkʃəs ðət wi ʃʊdn hɝɾ ɛni ʌv ðə sʌldəm. lɛmɔɹ ɪz dʒʌs naɪntin, ə pæmpɝd noʊbəlwʊmən wɪð ði ɪkstʃɹim bæd lʌk tə hæv ðə spɑɹk mænəfɛst ɪtsɛlf ɪn əɹ ɑn ðə vɛɹi deɪ tæntʃəkoʊ fɛl. ʃi sɛz ʃi heɪts ðə sintʃæn ən wɑns tə meɪk əm peɪ fəɹ wʌt ðeɪ dɪd tə tæntʃəkoʊ, bʌt ʃi ænsɝz tə lɑɝi, hɝ deɪmeɪn neɪm, əz ɹɛɾəli əz tə lɛmɔɹ, ən ʃi smaɪlz ət ðə sʌldəm ən lɛts əm pɛt hɝ. aɪ doʊn mɪstʃɹʌs ðɛm, nɑt ðə weɪ aɪ də əliviə, bʌɾ aɪ daʊɾ iðɝ wʌn kəd stæn ʌp tə ə sʌldəm. aɪ θɪŋk ɪf ə sʌldəm ɔɹɾɝd iðɝ tə hɛlp əɹ ɪskeɪp, ʃi wʊd, ən aɪ fɪɹ ʃi maɪt nɑt faɪt tu hɑɹɾ ɪf ðə sʌldəm tʃɹaɪd tə kɑlɝ əɹ əɡɛn."

"I am not so sure," Reanne sighed. "Kara was a sort of wise woman on Toman Head, you know. Very influential in her village. A wilder, of course. You would think she'd hate the Seanchan, but she doesn't, not all of them. She is very fond of the sul'dam captured with her, and very anxious that we shouldn't hurt any of the sul'dam. Lemore is just nineteen, a pampered noblewoman with the extreme bad luck to have the spark manifest itself in her on the very day Tanchico fell. She says she hates the Seanchan and wants to make them pay for what they did to Tanchico, but she answers to Larie, her damane name, as readily as to Lemore, and she smiles at the sul'dam and lets them pet her. I don't mistrust them, not the way I do Alivia, but I doubt either one could stand up to a sul'dam. I think if a sul'dam ordered either to help her escape, she would, and I fear she might not fight too hard if the sul'dam tried to collar her again."

æftɝ ʃi stɑp spikɪŋ, ðə saɪləns stʃɹɛtʃt.

After she stopped speaking, the silence stretched.

nɪneɪiv sim tə lʊk ɪnwɝd, stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ wɪð hɝsɛlf. ʃi ɡɹɪpt əɹ bɹeɪd, ðən lɛt ɡoʊ ən foʊldəɾ əɹ ɑɹmz taɪɾ əkɹɔs əɹ tʃɛst, ðə fɹɪnʒ ə hɝ ʃɔl sweɪɪŋ əz ʃi hʌɡd hɝsɛlf. ʃi ɡlɛɹɾ əɾ ɛvɹiwʌn ɪksɛp læn. hɪm, ʃi dɪd nɑt soʊ mʌtʃ əz ɡlæns æt.

Nynaeve seemed to look inward, struggling with herself. She gripped her braid, then let go and folded her arms tight across her chest, the fringe of her shawl swaying as she hugged herself. She glared at everyone except Lan. Him, she did not so much as glance at.

faɪnəli ʃi tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ, ən skwɛɹd hɝsɛlf tə feɪs ɹin ən æləz. "wi mʌst ɹimuv ði æɾəm. wɪl hoʊld ɑn tə ðɛm əntɪl wi kən bi ʃʊɹ - ən lɛmɔɹ æftɝ; ʃi nidz tə bi pʊɾ ɪn waɪt! - ən wɪl meɪk ʃʊɹ ðeɪ ɑɹ nɛvɝ lɛft əloʊn, ɪspɛʃli wɪð ðə sʌldəm, bʌt ði æɾəm kʌm ɔf!" ʃi spoʊk fɪɹsli, əz ɪf ɪkspɛktɪŋ ɑpəzɪʃən, bʌɾ ə bɹɔd smaɪl ʌv əpɹuvəl spɹɛɾ əkɹɔs ɪleɪnz feɪs. ði ədɪʃən ə θɹi mɔɹ wɪmən ðeɪ kəd nɑt bi ʃʊɹ ə hɑɹdli kaʊntəɾ əz ɡʊd nuz, bʌt ðəɹ hæd bɪn noʊ ʌðɝ tʃɔɪs.

Finally she took a deep breath, and squared herself to face Reanne and Alise. "We must remove the a'dam. We will hold on to them until we can be sure - and Lemore after; she needs to be put in white! - and we will make sure they are never left alone, especially with the sul'dam, but the a'dam come off!" She spoke fiercely, as if expecting opposition, but a broad smile of approval spread across Elayne's face. The addition of three more women they could not be sure of hardly counted as good news, but there had been no other choice.

ɹin mɪɹli nɑɾəd æksɛptəns - æftɝ ə moʊmənt - bʌɾ ə smaɪlɪŋ æləz keɪm ɝaʊn ðə teɪbəl tə pæt nɪneɪivz ʃoʊldɝ, ən nɪneɪiv æktʃəli  blʌʃt. ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə haɪɾ ɪt bɪhaɪn klɪɹɪŋ əɹ θɹoʊt ɹʌfli ən ɡɹɪmæsɪŋ ət ðə sintʃæn wʊmən ɪn əɹ keɪdʒ ə seɪaɪdɑɹ, bʌɾ əɹ ɛfɝts wɝ nɑt vɛɹi ɪfɛktʃuəl, ən læn spɔɪld əm ɪn ɛni keɪs.

Reanne merely nodded acceptance - after a moment - but a smiling Alise came around the table to pat Nynaeve's shoulder, and Nynaeve actually blushed. She tried to hide it behind clearing her throat roughly and grimacing at the Seanchan woman in her cage of saidar, but her efforts were not very effectual, and Lan spoiled them in any case.

"teɪʃɝ meɪnɛðɝən," hi sɛd sɔfli.

"Tai'shar Manetheren," he said softly.

nɪneɪivz maʊθ fɛl oʊpən, ðən kɝld ɪndə ə tʃɹɛmjələs smaɪl. sʌɾən tɪɹz ɡlɪsən ɪn əɹ aɪz əz ʃi spʌn tə feɪs hɪm, hɝ feɪs dʒɔɪəs. hi smaɪl bæk ət hɝ, ən ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ koʊld ɪn ɪz aɪz.

Nynaeve's mouth fell open, then curled into a tremulous smile. Sudden tears glistened in her eyes as she spun to face him, her face joyous. He smiled back at her, and there was nothing cold in his eyes.

ɪleɪn stʃɹʌɡəl nɑt tə ɡeɪp. laɪt! meɪbi hi dɪd nɑt tʃɪl ðɛɹ mɛɹɪdʒ bɛɾ æftɝ ɔl. ðə θɔt meɪɾ əɹ tʃiks wɔɹm. tʃɹaɪɪŋ nɑt tə lʊk ət ðɛm, hɝ aɪz fɛl ɑn mɑɹli, stɪl fæsən ɪn əɹ tʃɛɹ. ðə sintʃæn wʊmən wɑz stɛɹɪŋ stʃɹeɪɾ əhɛd, tɪɹz floʊɪŋ daʊn əɹ plʌmp tʃiks. stʃɹeɪɾ əhɛd. ət ðə wivz hoʊldɪŋ saʊn əweɪ fɹəm hɝ. ʃi kəd nɑt dɪnaɪ siɪŋ ðə wivz naʊ. bʌt wən ʃi sɛɾ əz mʌtʃ, ɹin ʃʊk əɹ hɛd.

Elayne struggled not to gape. Light! Maybe he did not chill their marriage bed after all. The thought made her cheeks warm. Trying not to look at them, her eyes fell on Marli, still fastened in her chair. The Seanchan woman was staring straight ahead, tears flowing down her plump cheeks. Straight ahead. At the weaves holding sound away from her. She could not deny seeing the weaves now. But when she said as much, Reanne shook her head.

"ðeɪ ɔl wip ɪf ðeɪ ɑɹ meɪd tə lʊk ət wivz vɛɹi lɔŋ, ɪleɪn," ʃi sɛd wɛɹəli. ən ə tʌtʃ sædli. "bʌt wʌns ðə wivz ɑɹ ɡɔn, ðeɪ kənvɪns ðɛmsɛlvz wi tʃɹɪk ðɛm. ðeɪv tə, jə ʌndɝstænd. ɛls ðeɪd bi deɪmeɪn, nɑt sʌldəm. noʊ, ɪɾəl teɪk taɪm tə kənvɪns ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə haʊnz ðət ʃiz ɹɪli ə haʊn hɝsɛlf. aɪm əfɹeɪɾ aɪ ɹɪli hævənt ɡɪvən jə ɛni ɡʊd nuz əɾ ɔl, hæv aɪ?"

"They all weep if they are made to look at weaves very long, Elayne," she said wearily. And a touch sadly. "But once the weaves are gone, they convince themselves we tricked them. They have to, you understand. Else they'd be damane, not sul'dam. No, it will take time to convince the Mistress of the Hounds that she is really a hound herself. I am afraid I really haven't given you any good news at all, have I?"

"nɑt vɛɹi mʌtʃ," ɪleɪn toʊl hɝ. nʌn, ɹɪli. dʒʌst ənʌðɝ pɹɑbləm tə stæk ʌp ɑn ɔl ðə ɹɛst. haʊ mʌtʃ bæd nuz kəd bi stæk bɪfɔɹ ðə paɪl bɛɹid ju? ʃi hæd tə ɡɛt səm ɡʊd, sun.

"Not very much," Elayne told her. None, really. Just another problem to stack up on all the rest. How much bad news could be stacked before the pile buried you? She had to get some good, soon.


tʃæptɝ naɪn


CHAPTER 9

eɪ kʌp ə ti


A Cup of Tea

wʌns ɪn əɹ dʒɹɛsɪŋ ɹum, ɪleɪn hɝidli tʃeɪnʒd aʊɾ ə hɝ ɹaɪɾɪŋ kloʊðz wɪð ðə hɛlp ʌv ɛsænd, ðə waɪt-hɛɹd pɛnʃənɝ ʃi hæd tʃoʊzən fəɹ əɹ meɪd. ðə slɛndɝ, dɪɡnəfaɪd wʊmən wɑz ə tʃɹaɪfəl sloʊ-muvɪŋ, bʌt ʃi nu hɝ dʒɑb ən dɪd nɑt weɪs taɪm tʃæɾɝɪŋ. ɪn fækt, ʃi sɛldəm sɛɾ ə wɝd bɪɑn sədʒɛstʃənz ɑn kloʊðɪŋ, ən ðə kɑmɛnt ɡɪvən ɛvɹi deɪ, ðəɾ ɪleɪn lʊk laɪk əɹ mʌðɝ. fleɪmz dænst ətɑp θɪk lɔɡz ɑn ə waɪd mɑɹbəl hɑɹθ ət wʌn ɛn ə ðə ɹum, bʌt ðə faɪɝ dɪd lɪɾəl tə teɪk ðə tʃɪl ɔf ði ɛɹ. kwɪkli ʃi pʊɾ ɑn ə faɪn blu wʊl wɪð pæɾɝnz ə sid pɝlz ɑn ðə haɪ nɛk ən daʊn ðə slivz, hɝ sɪlvɝ-wɝk bɛlt wɪð ə smɔl sɪlvɝ-ʃið dæɡɝ, ən ðə sɪlvɝ-ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd blu vɛlvət slɪpɝz. ðəɹ maɪt bi noʊ taɪm tə tʃeɪnʒ əɡɛn bɪfɔɹ siɪŋ ðə mɝtʃəns, ən ðeɪ mʌs bi ɪmpɹɛst ət ðə saɪɾ ə hɝ. ʃi wəɾ əv tə bi ʃʊɹ bɝdʒɪt wɑz ðɛɹ; bɝdʒɪt wɑz moʊst ɪmpɹɛsɪv ɪn əɹ junəfɔɹm. ən bɝdʒɪt wəd teɪk ivən lɪsnɪŋ tə mɝtʃəns əz ə bɹeɪk. baɪ ðə hiɾəd nɑɾ ʌv ɪɹɪteɪʃən ɹɛstɪŋ ɪn ðə bæk ʌv ɪleɪnz hɛd, ðə kæptən-dʒɛnɝəl ə ðə kwinz ɡɑɹd wɑz faɪndɪŋ ðoʊz ɹɪpɔɹts hɛvi ɡoʊɪŋ.

Once in her dressing room, Elayne hurriedly changed out of her riding clothes with the help of Essande, the white-haired pensioner she had chosen for her maid. The slender, dignified woman was a trifle slow-moving, but she knew her job and did not waste time chattering. In fact, she seldom said a word beyond suggestions on clothing, and the comment given every day, that Elayne looked like her mother. Flames danced atop thick logs on a wide marble hearth at one end of the room, but the fire did little to take the chill off the air. Quickly she put on a fine blue wool with patterns of seed pearls on the high neck and down the sleeves, her silver-worked belt with a small silver-sheathed dagger, and the silver-embroidered blue velvet slippers. There might be no time to change again before seeing the merchants, and they must be impressed at the sight of her. She would have to be sure Birgitte was there; Birgitte was most impressive in her uniform. And Birgitte would take even listening to merchants as a break. By the heated knot of irritation resting in the back of Elayne's head, the Captain-General of the Queen's Guard was finding those reports heavy going.

fæsənɪŋ klʌstɝz ə pɝlz ɪn əɹ ɪɹz, ʃi dɪsmɪst ɛsæn tə hɝ oʊn faɪɝ, ɪn ðə pɛnʃənɝz' kɔɹɾɝz. ðə wʊmən hæd dɪnaɪɾ ɪt wən ɔfɝd hilɪŋ, bʌɾ ɪleɪn səspɛktəɾ əɹ dʒɔɪns ætʃt. ɪn ɛni keɪs, ʃi hɝsɛlf wɑz ɹɛɾi. ʃi wəd nɑt wɛɹ ðə kɔɹənɛɾ ə ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ; ɪt kəd steɪ ətɑp ðə smɔl aɪvɝi dʒuəlɹi tʃɛst ɑn əɹ dʒɹɛsɪŋ teɪbəl. ʃi dɪd nɑɾ əv mɛni dʒɛmz; moʊs hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi bɪn pʊɾ ɪn pɔn, ən ðə ɹɛs maɪɾ əv tə ɡoʊ wən ðə pleɪt dɪd. noʊ pɔɪnt wɝiɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪt naʊ. ə fju moʊməns tə hɝsɛlf, ən ʃi wəɾ əv tə lip bæk tə duɾi.

Fastening clusters of pearls in her ears, she dismissed Essande to her own fire, in the pensioners' quarters. The woman had denied it when offered Healing, but Elayne suspected her joints ached. In any case, she herself was ready. She would not wear the coronet of the Daughter-Heir; it could stay atop the small ivory jewelry chest on her dressing table. She did not have many gems; most had already been put in pawn, and the rest might have to go when the plate did. No point worrying about it now. A few moments to herself, and she would have to leap back to duty.

hɝ dɑɹk-pænəl sɪɾɪŋ ɹum wɪð ɪts waɪd kɔɹnɪsəz ə kɑɹv bɝdz kənteɪn tu tɔl faɪɝpleɪsəz wɪð ɪlæbɹət mæntəlz, wʌn əɾ iðɝ ɛnd, wɪtʃ dɪɾ ə bɛɾɝ dʒɑb ʌv wɔɹmɪŋ ðən ðə wʌn ɪn ðə dʒɹɛsɪŋ ɹum, ðoʊ hɪɹ, tu, ðə kɑɹpəts leɪɝɾ ɑn ðə waɪt-taɪl flɔɹ wɝ nɛsəsɛɹi. tə hɝ sɝpɹaɪz, ðə ɹum ɔlsoʊ kənteɪn hælwɪn nɔɹi. duɾi hæd lɛpt ət hɝ, ɪt simd.

Her dark-paneled sitting room with its wide cornices of carved birds contained two tall fireplaces with elaborate mantels, one at either end, which did a better job of warming than the one in the dressing room, though here, too, the carpets layered on the white-tiled floor were necessary. To her surprise, the room also contained Halwin Norry. Duty had leaped at her, it seemed.

ðə fɝs klɝk stʃɹɛtʃt ʌp aʊɾ ʌv ə loʊ-bæk tʃɛɹ əz ʃi ɛntɝd, klʌtʃɪŋ ə lɛðɝ foʊldɝ tə hɪz nɛɹoʊ tʃɛst, ən lɝtʃt ɝaʊn ðə skɹoʊl-ɛdʒ teɪbəl ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə ɹum tə meɪk ən ɑkwɝd lɛɡ. nɔɹi wɑz tɔl ən lin, wɪð ə lɔŋ noʊz, hɪz spɑɹs fɹɪnʒ ə hɛɹ ɹaɪzɪŋ bɪhaɪn ɪz ɪɹz laɪk spɹeɪz ʌv waɪt fɛðɝz. hi ɔfən ɹimaɪndəɾ əɹ ʌv ə hɛɹən. ɛni nʌmbɝ ə klɝks ʌndɝ ɪm æktʃəli  wildɪd ðə pɛnz, jɛɾ ə smɔl ɪŋksteɪn mɑɹd wʌn ɛdʒ ə hɪz skɑɹlət tɑbɝd. ðə steɪn lʊkt oʊld, ðoʊ, ən ʃi wʌndɝd wɛðɝ ðə foʊldɝ hɪɾ ʌðɝz. hi hæɾ oʊnli teɪkən tə hoʊldɪŋ ɪɾ əɡɛnst ɪz tʃɛst wən i dɑn fɔɹməl dʒɹɛs, tu deɪz æftɝ mɪstʃɹəs hɑɹfɝ. wɛðɝ i hæd dʌn soʊ əz ən ɪkspɹɛʃən ə lɔɪəlti, əɹ sɪmpli kəz ðə fɝs meɪd hæd, wɑz stɪl ɪn kwɛstʃən.

The First Clerk stretched up out of a low-backed chair as she entered, clutching a leather folder to his narrow chest, and lurched around the scroll-edged table in the middle of the room to make an awkward leg. Norry was tall and lean, with a long nose, his sparse fringe of hair rising behind his ears like sprays of white feathers. He often reminded her of a heron. Any number of clerks under him actually wielded the pens, yet a small inkstain marred one edge of his scarlet tabard. The stain looked old, though, and she wondered whether the folder hid others. He had only taken to holding it against his chest when he donned formal dress, two days after Mistress Harfor. Whether he had done so as an expression of loyalty, or simply because the First Maid had, was still in question.

"fɝɡɪv mi fəɹ biɪŋ pɹɪsɪpɪteɪt, maɪ leɪɾi," hi sɛd, "bʌɾ aɪ də bɪliv aɪ hæv mæɾɝz ə səm ɪmpɔɹɾəns, ɪf nɑɾ æktʃəwəl heɪst, tə leɪ bɪfɔɹ ju." ɪmpɔɹɾənt əɹ nɑt, hɪz vɔɪs stɪl dʒɹoʊnd.

"Forgive me for being precipitate, my Lady," he said, "but I do believe I have matters of some importance, if not actual haste, to lay before you." Important or not, his voice still droned.

"ʌv kɔɹs, mæstɝ nɔɹi. aɪ wəd nɑt wɑnə pɹɛs jə tə heɪst." hi blɪŋkt ət hɝ, ən ʃi tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə saɪ. ʃi θɔɾ i maɪt bi mɔɹ ðən ə lɪɾəl dɛf, fɹəm ðə weɪ hi tɪltəɾ ɪz hɛd ðɪs weɪ ən ðəɾ əz ɪf tə kætʃ saʊn bɛɾɝ. meɪbi ðət wɑz waɪ hɪz vɔɪs ɔlmoʊs nɛvɝ tʃeɪnʒd pɪtʃ. ʃi ɹeɪz hɝz ə lɪɾəl. hi maɪt dʒʌs bi ə bɔɹ, æftɝ ɔl. "sɪt, ən tɛl mi ðiz mæɾɝz ʌv ɪmpɔɹɾəns."

"Of course, Master Norry. I would not want to press you to haste." He blinked at her, and she tried not to sigh. She thought he might be more than a little deaf, from the way he tilted his head this way and that as if to catch sound better. Maybe that was why his voice almost never changed pitch. She raised hers a little. He might just be a bore, after all. "Sit, and tell me these matters of importance."

ʃi tʊk wʌn ə ðə kɑɹv tʃɛɹz əweɪ fɹəm ðə teɪbəl ən moʊʃən ɪm tə ənʌðɝ, bʌɾ i ɹɪmeɪn stændɪŋ. hi ɔlweɪz dɪd. ʃi sɛɾəld bæk tə lɪsən, kɹɔsɪŋ əɹ niz ən ədʒʌstɪŋ əɹ skɝts.

She took one of the carved chairs away from the table and motioned him to another, but he remained standing. He always did. She settled back to listen, crossing her knees and adjusting her skirts.

hi dɪd nɑt ɹəfɝ tə hɪz foʊldɝ. ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɑn ðə peɪpɝz ɪn ɪt wəd bi ɪnsaɪɾ ɪz hɛd, ðə peɪpɝz ðəɹ oʊnli ɪn keɪs ʃi ɹikwaɪɝd tə si wɪð əɹ oʊn aɪz. "moʊst ɪmiɾiət, maɪ leɪɾi, ən pɝhæps moʊst ɪmpɔɹɾənt, lɑɹdʒ dəpɑzɪts ʌv æləm əv bɪn dɪskʌvɝɾ ɑn jəɹ ɪsteɪts ət dɑnəbɑɹ. ðə fɝs kwɑləɾi ʌv æləm. aɪ bɪliv ðə bæŋkɝz wɪl bi . . . ʌm . . . lɛs hɛzɪɾənt ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ maɪ ɪnkwaɪɝiz ɑn jəɹ bɪhæf wʌns ðeɪ lɝn ə ðɪs." hi smaɪl bɹifli, ə moʊməntɛɹi kɝvɪŋ ə θɪn lɪps. fəɹ hɪm, ðət wɑz nɪɹ tə keɪpɝɪŋ.

He did not refer to his folder. Everything on the papers in it would be inside his head, the papers there only in case she required to see with her own eyes. "Most immediate, my Lady, and perhaps most important, large deposits of alum have been discovered on your estates at Danabar. The first quality of alum. I believe the bankers will be . . . umm . . . less hesitant regarding my inquiries on your behalf once they learn of this." He smiled briefly, a momentary curving of thin lips. For him, that was near to capering.

ɪleɪn sæɾ ʌp stʃɹeɪɾ əz sun əz i mɛnʃən æləm, ən ʃi smaɪl mʌtʃ mɔɹ bɹɔdli. ʃi fɛlt ə lɪɾəl laɪk keɪpɝɪŋ hɝsɛlf. hæɾ əɹ kəmpænjən bɪn ɛniwʌn bʌt nɔɹi, ʃi maɪt hæv. hɝ ɪleɪʃən wɑz soʊ stʃɹɔŋ ðət fəɹ ə moʊmənt ʃi fɛl bɝdʒɪts ɪɹɪɾəbɪlɪti weɪn. daɪɝz ən wivɝz dɪvaʊɝɾ æləm, ən soʊ dɪd ɡlæsmeɪkɝz ən peɪpɝmeɪkɝz əmʌŋ ʌðɝz. ði oʊnli sɔɹs fəɹ fɝs kwɑləɾi æləm wɑz ɡildən - əɹ hæd bɪn tɪl naʊ - ən dʒʌs ðə tæksəz ɑn ðə tʃɹeɪd hæd bɪn səfɪʃən tə səpɔɹt ðə θɹoʊn ʌv ɡildən fəɹ dʒɛnɝeɪʃənz. wʌt keɪm fɹəm tiɹ ən ɝæfəl wɑz nɑt nɪɹli soʊ faɪn, jɛɾ ɪt pʊɾ əz mʌtʃ kɔɪn ɪn ðoʊz kʌntʃɹiz' kɑfɝz əz ɑləv ɔɪl əɹ dʒɛmz.

Elayne sat up straight as soon as he mentioned alum, and she smiled much more broadly. She felt a little like capering herself. Had her companion been anyone but Norry, she might have. Her elation was so strong that for a moment she felt Birgitte's irritability wane. Dyers and weavers devoured alum, and so did glassmakers and papermakers among others. The only source for first quality alum was Ghealdan - or had been till now - and just the taxes on the trade had been sufficient to support the throne of Ghealdan for generations. What came from Tear and Arafel was not nearly so fine, yet it put as much coin in those countries' coffers as olive oil or gems.

"ðæɾ ɪz ɪmpɔɹɾənt nuz, mæstɝ nɔɹi. ðə bɛst aɪv hæd tədeɪ." ðə bɛst sɪns ɹitʃɪŋ keɪɛmlɪn, vɛɹi laɪkli, bʌt sɝɾənli ðə bɛs tədeɪ. "haʊ kwɪkli kən jə oʊvɝkʌm ðə bæŋkɝz' 'hɛzəteɪʃən'?" ɪt hæd bɪn mɔɹ laɪk slæmɪŋ ðə dɔɹ ɪn əɹ feɪs, oʊnli nɑt soʊ ɹud. ðə bæŋkɝz nu tə ə mæn haʊ mɛni sɔɹdz stʊd bɪhaɪn əɹ ət ðə moʊmənt, ən haʊ mɛni bɪhaɪn əɹ əpoʊnəns. ivən soʊ, ʃi hæd noʊ daʊts ðə ɹɪtʃəz ʌv æləm wəd bɹɪŋ əm ɝaʊnd. niðɝ dɪd nɔɹi.

"That is important news, Master Norry. The best I've had today." The best since reaching Caemlyn, very likely, but certainly the best today. "How quickly can you overcome the bankers' 'hesitation'?" It had been more like slamming the door in her face, only not so rude. The bankers knew to a man how many swords stood behind her at the moment, and how many behind her opponents. Even so, she had no doubts the riches of alum would bring them around. Neither did Norry.

"kwaɪt kwɪkli, maɪ leɪɾi, ən ɑn vɛɹi ɡʊd tɝmz, aɪ bɪliv. aɪ ʃæl tɛl əm ɪf ðɛɹ bɛst ɔfɝz ɑɹ ɪnsəfɪʃənt, əl əpɹoʊtʃ tɛɹ əɹ kɛɹhin. ðəl nɑt ɹɪsk luzɪŋ ðə kʌstəm, maɪ leɪɾi." ɔl ɪn ðət dʒɹaɪ, flæt vɔɪs, wɪθaʊɾ ə hɪn ə ðə sæɾəsfækʃən ɛni ʌðɝ mæn wəd hæv. "ɪt wɪl bi loʊnz əɡɛns fjutʃɝ ɪnkʌm, ʌv kɔɹs, ən ðəɹ wɪl bi ɪkspɛnsəz. ðə maɪnɪŋ ɪtsɛlf. tʃɹænspɝteɪʃən. dɑnəbɑɹ ɪz ɪn maʊntənəs kʌntʃɹi, ən səm dɪstəns fɹəm ðə luɡɹd ɹoʊd. stɪl, ðəɹ ʃəd bi səfɪʃən tə mit jəɹ æmbɪʃənz fəɹ ðə ɡɑɹdz, maɪ leɪɾi. ən fəɹ jəɹ əkæɾəmi."

"Quite quickly, my Lady, and on very good terms, I believe. I shall tell them if their best offers are insufficient, I will approach Tear or Cairhien. They will not risk losing the custom, my Lady." All in that dry, flat voice, without a hint of the satisfaction any other man would have. "It will be loans against future income, of course, and there will be expenses. The mining itself. Transportation. Danabar is in mountainous country, and some distance from the Lugard Road. Still, there should be sufficient to meet your ambitions for the Guards, my Lady. And for your Academy."

"səfɪʃən ɪz hɑɹdli ðə wɝd, ɪf juv ɡɪvən oʊvɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə tɔk mi aʊɾ ə maɪ plænz fəɹ ði əkæɾəmi, mæstɝ nɔɹi," ʃi sɛd, nɪɹli læfɪŋ. hi wɑz əz dʒɛləs ʌv ændɝz tʃɹɛʒɝi əz ə hɛn wɪð wʌn tʃɪk, ən i hæd bɪn æɾəməntli əpoʊz tə hɝ teɪkɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə skul ɹænd hæɾ ɔɹɾɝd faʊndəɾ ɪn keɪɛmlɪn, ɹɪtɝnɪŋ tə hɪz ɑɹɡjəməns taɪm ən əɡɛn əntɪl ɪz vɔɪs simd ə dʒɹɪl bɔɹɪŋ ɪndə hɝ skʌl. soʊ fɑɹ ðə skul kənsɪstəɾ ʌv oʊnli ə fju dʌzən skɑlɝz wɪð ðɛɹ stuɾənts, skæɾɝd əbaʊt ðə nu sɪɾi ɪn vɛɹiəs ɪnz, bʌɾ ivən ɪn wɪntɝ mɔɹ ɝaɪvd ɛvɹi deɪ, ən ðeɪ hæd bɪɡʌn tə klæmɝ fəɹ mɔɹ speɪs. ʃi dɪd nɑt pɹəpoʊz ɡɪvɪŋ əm ə pæləs, sɝɾənli, jɛt ðeɪ niɾəd sʌmθɪŋ. nɔɹi wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə hʌzbən ændɝz ɡoʊld, bʌt ʃi wɑz lʊkɪŋ tə ændɝz fjutʃɝ. tɑɹmən ɡdən wɑz kʌmɪŋ, jɛt ʃi hæd tə bɪliv ðəɹ wəd bi ə fjutʃɝ æftɝwɝd, wɛðɝ əɹ nɑt ɹænd bɹoʊk ðə wɝld əɡɛn. ʌðɝwaɪz, ðəɹ wɑz noʊ pɔɪn ɪn ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn wɪð ɛniθɪŋ, ən ʃi kəd nɑt si dʒʌst sɪɾɪŋ daʊn tə weɪt. ivən ɪf ʃi nu fəɹ ə fæk ðət ðə læs bæɾəl wəɾ ɛn ɛvɹiθɪŋ, ʃi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ʃi kəd sɪɾ ɑn əɹ hænz. ɹænd stɑɹɾəd skulz ɪn keɪs i dɪɾ ɛn bɹeɪkɪŋ ðə wɝld, ɪn ðə hoʊp ə seɪvɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ, bʌt ðɪs skul wəd bi ændɝz, nɑt ɹænd ælθɹz. ði əkæɾəmi ʌv ðə ɹoʊz, dɛɾəkeɪtəd tə ðə mɛmɹi ʌv mɔɹɡeɪs tʃɹəkənd. ðəɹ wəd bi ə fjutʃɝ, ən ðə fjutʃɝ wəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ əɹ mʌðɝ. "ɔɹ əv jə dɪsaɪɾɪd ðə kɛɹhinɪn ɡoʊl kən bi tʃɹeɪs tə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn æftɝ ɔl?"

"Sufficient is hardly the word, if you've given over trying to talk me out of my plans for the Academy, Master Norry," she said, nearly laughing. He was as jealous of Andor's treasury as a hen with one chick, and he had been adamantly opposed to her taking over the school Rand had ordered founded in Caemlyn, returning to his arguments time and again until his voice seemed a drill boring into her skull. So far the school consisted of only a few dozen scholars with their students, scattered about the New City in various inns, but even in winter more arrived every day, and they had begun to clamor for more space. She did not propose giving them a palace, certainly, yet they needed something. Norry was trying to husband Andor's gold, but she was looking to Andor's future. Tarmon Gai'don was coming, yet she had to believe there would be a future afterward, whether or not Rand broke the world again. Otherwise, there was no point in going on with anything, and she could not see just sitting down to wait. Even if she knew for a fact that the Last Battle would end everything, she did not think she could sit on her hands. Rand started schools in case he did end breaking the world, in the hope of saving something, but this school would be Andor's, not Rand al'Thor's. The Academy of the Rose, dedicated to the memory of Morgase Trakand. There would be a future, and the future would remember her mother. "Or have you decided the Cairhienin gold can be traced to the Dragon Reborn after all?"

"aɪ stɪl bɪliv ðə ɹɪsk tə bi vɛɹi smɔl, maɪ leɪɾi, bʌt noʊ lɔŋɡɝ wɝθ teɪkɪŋ ɪn vju ʌv wʌɾ aɪ hæv dʒʌs lɝn fɹəm tɑɹ vəlɑn." hɪz toʊn dɪd nɑɾ ɔltɝ, bʌt klɪɹli hi wɑz ædʒəteɪɾəd. hɪz fɪŋɡɝz dʒɹʌm ðə lɛðɝ foʊldɝ əɡɛnst ɪz tʃɛst, spaɪɾɝz dænsɪŋ, ðən stɪl. "ði . . . ʌm . . . waɪt taʊɝ əz ɪʃuɾ ə pɹɑkləmeɪʃən æknɑlɪdʒɪŋ . . . ʌm . . . lɔɹd ɹænd əz ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn ən ɔfɝɪŋ ɪm . . . ʌm . . . pɹətɛkʃən ən ɡaɪɾəns. ɪɾ ɔlsoʊ pɹənaʊnsɪz ənæθəmə ɑn ɛniwʌn əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ ɪm seɪv θɹu ðə taʊɝ. ɪts waɪz tə bi wɛɹi ʌv tɑɹ vəlɑnz æŋɡɝ, maɪ leɪɾi, əz jə jɝsɛlf ɑɹ əwɛɹ." hi lʊk sɪɡnɪfɪkənli ət ðə ɡɹeɪt sɝpən ɹɪŋ ɑn əɹ hæn ɹɛstɪŋ ɑn ðə kɑɹvd ɑɹm ə ðə tʃɛɹ. hi nu ʌv ðə splɪɾ ɪn ðə taʊɝ, ʌv kɔɹs - meɪbi ə kɹɔftɝ ɪn seɪlaɪzɪn dɪd nɑt; noʊ wʌn ɛls kəd feɪl tə, baɪ naʊ - bʌɾ i hæd bɪn tu dɪskɹit tə æsk əɹ əlidʒəns. ðoʊ pleɪnli hi hæd bɪn əbaʊt tə seɪ "ði æmɪɝlɪn sit" ɪnstɛɾ ʌv "ðə waɪt taʊɝ." ən ðə laɪɾ əloʊn nu wʌɾ ɪn pleɪs ʌv "lɔɹd ɹænd." ʃi dɪd nɑt hoʊl ðəɾ əɡɛns hɪm. hi wɑz ə kɔʃəs mæn, ə kwɑləɾi niɾəd ɪn ɪz poʊst.

"I still believe the risk to be very small, my Lady, but no longer worth taking in view of what I have just learned from Tar Valon." His tone did not alter, but clearly he was agitated. His fingers drummed the leather folder against his chest, spiders dancing, then still. "The . . . umm . . . White Tower has issued a proclamation acknowledging . . . umm . . . Lord Rand as the Dragon Reborn and offering him . . . umm . . . protection and guidance. It also pronounces anathema on anyone approaching him save through the Tower. It is wise to be wary of Tar Valon's anger, my Lady, as you yourself are aware." He looked significantly at the Great Serpent ring on her hand resting on the carved arm of the chair. He knew of the split in the Tower, of course - maybe a crofter in Seleisin did not; no one else could fail to, by now - but he had been too discreet to ask her allegiance. Though plainly he had been about to say "the Amyrlin Seat" instead of "the White Tower." And the Light alone knew what in place of "Lord Rand." She did not hold that against him. He was a cautious man, a quality needed in his post.

ɪleɪɾəz pɹɑkləmeɪʃən stʌn hɝ, ðoʊ. fɹaʊnɪŋ, ʃi θʌmd əɹ ɹɪŋ θɔtfəli. ɪleɪɾə hæd wɔɹn ðət ɹɪŋ lɔŋɡɝ ðən ʃi hɝsɛlf hæd lɪvd. ðə wʊmən wɑz ɛɹəɡənt, ɹɔŋ-hɛɾəd, blaɪn tə ɛni vju ɪksɛpt əɹ oʊn, bʌt ʃi wɑz nɑt stupəd. fɑɹ fɹəm ɪt. "kæn ʃi pɑsəbli θɪŋk hɪl æksɛp sətʃ ən ɔfɝ?" ʃi mjuzd, hæf tə hɝsɛlf. "pɹətɛkʃən ən ɡaɪɾəns? aɪ kæn ɪmædʒən ə bɛɾɝ weɪ tə pʊɾ ɪz bæk ʌp!" ɡaɪɾəns? noʊ wʌn kəd ɡaɪd ɹænd wɪð ə bɑɹdʒ poʊl!

Elaida's proclamation stunned her, though. Frowning, she thumbed her ring thoughtfully. Elaida had worn that ring longer than she herself had lived. The woman was arrogant, wrong-headed, blind to any view except her own, but she was not stupid. Far from it. "Can she possibly think he will accept such an offer?" she mused, half to herself. "Protection and guidance? I can't imagine a better way to put his back up!" Guidance? No one could guide Rand with a barge pole!

"hi meɪ pɑsəbli hæv æksɛptɪɾ ɔlɹɛɾi, maɪ leɪɾi, əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə maɪ kɔɹəspɑndən ɪn kɛɹhin." nɔɹi wʊɾə ʃʌɾɝəd ət ðə sədʒɛstʃən i wɑz ɪn ɛni weɪ ə spaɪmæstɝ. wɛl, hi wʊɾə twɪstəɾ ɪz maʊθ ɪn dɪsteɪst, ɛniweɪ. ðə fɝs klɝk ədmɪnəstɝd ðə tʃɹɛʒɝi, kəntʃɹoʊl ðə klɝks u ɹæn ðə kæpəɾəl, ən ædvaɪz ðə θɹoʊn ɑn mæɾɝz ə steɪt. hi sɝɾənli hæd noʊ nɛtwɝk ʌv aɪz-ænd-ɪɹz, laɪk ði ədʒəz ən ivən səm ɪndəvɪdʒəwəl sɪstɝz dɪd. bʌɾ i dɪɾ ɪkstʃeɪnʒ ɹɛɡjəlɝ lɛɾɝz wɪð nɑlədʒəbəl ən ɔfən wɛl-kənɛktəd pipəl ɪn ʌðɝ kæpəɾəlz, soʊ hɪz ædvaɪs kəd bi kɝənt wɪð ɪvɛns. "ʃi sɛnz ə pɪdʒən oʊnli wʌns ə wik, ən ɪt simz ðət ɹaɪɾ æftɝ əɹ læst, sʌmwʌn ətæk ðə sʌn pæləs juzɪŋ ðə wʌn paʊɝ."

"He may possibly have accepted already, my Lady, according to my correspondent in Cairhien." Norry would have shuddered at the suggestion he was in any way a spymaster. Well, he would have twisted his mouth in distaste, anyway. The First Clerk administered the treasury, controlled the clerks who ran the capital, and advised the throne on matters of state. He certainly had no network of eyes-and-ears, like the Ajahs and even some individual sisters did. But he did exchange regular letters with knowledgeable and often well-connected people in other capitals, so his advice could be current with events. "She sends a pigeon only once a week, and it seems that right after her last, someone attacked the Sun Palace using the One Power."

"ðə paʊɝ?" ʃi ɪkskleɪmd, dʒɝkɪŋ fɔɹwɝɾ ɪn ʃɑk.

"The Power?" she exclaimed, jerking forward in shock.

nɔɹi nɑɾəd wʌns. hi maɪɾ əv bɪn ɹipɔɹɾɪŋ ðə kɝən steɪɾ ə stʃɹit ɹɪpɛɹz. "soʊ maɪ kɔɹəspɑndən ɹɪpɔɹts, maɪ leɪɾi. ɛɛs sədaɪ, pɝhæps, əɹ æʃəmən, əɹ ivən ðə fɔɹseɪkən. ʃi ɹɪpits ɡɑsəp hɪɹ, aɪ fɪɹ. ðə wɪŋ haʊzɪŋ ði əpɑɹtməns ə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn wɑz lɑɹdʒli dɪstʃɹɔɪd, ən i hɪmsɛlf əz vænɪʃt. ɪts waɪdli bɪliv ðət hiz ɡɔn tə tɑɹ vəlɑn tə nil bɪfɔɹ ði æmɪɝlɪn sit. səm də bɪliv ɪm dɛɾ ɪn ði ətæk, bʌt nɑɾ ə ɡɹeɪt mɛni. aɪ ædvaɪz duɪŋ nʌθɪŋ əntɪl juv ə klɪɹɝ pɪktʃɝ." hi pɔzd, hɛd tɪltəɾ ɪn θɔt. "fɹʌm wʌɾ aɪ sɔ ʌv hɪm, maɪ leɪɾi," hi sɛd sloʊli, "aɪ maɪsɛlf wəd nɑt bɪliv ɪm dɛɾ ənlɛs aɪ sæt θɹi deɪz wɪð ðə kɔɹps."

Norry nodded once. He might have been reporting the current state of street repairs. "So my correspondent reports, my Lady. Aes Sedai, perhaps, or Asha'man, or even the Forsaken. She repeats gossip here, I fear. The wing housing the apartments of the Dragon Reborn was largely destroyed, and he himself has vanished. It is widely believed that he has gone to Tar Valon to kneel before the Amyrlin Seat. Some do believe him dead in the attack, but not a great many. I advise doing nothing until you have a clearer picture." He paused, head tilted in thought. "From what I saw of him, my Lady," he said slowly, "I myself would not believe him dead unless I sat three days with the corpse."

ʃi ɔlmoʊst stɛɹd. ðət wɑz vɛɹi nɪɹli ə dʒoʊk. ə ɹʌf wɪɾəsɪzəm, ət list. fɹəm hælwɪn nɔɹi! ʃi dɪd nɑt bɪliv ɹænd wɑz dɛd, iðɝ. ʃi wəd nɑt bɪliv i wɑz dɛd. əz fəɹ nilɪŋ tə ɪleɪɾə, ðə mæn wɑz tu stʌbɝn tə səbmɪt tə ɛniwʌn. ə ɡɹeɪt mɛni dɪfəkəltiz kəd bi sɝmaʊntɪɾ ɪf oʊnli hi kəd bɹɪŋ hɪmsɛlf tə nil tə ɛɡwin, bʌɾ i wəd nɑt də ɪt, ən ʃi wɑz ɪz tʃaɪldhʊd fɹɛnd. ɪleɪɾə stʊɾ əz mʌtʃ tʃæns əz ə ɡoʊɾ əɾ ə kɔɹt bɔl, pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli wʌns i lɝn ə hɝ pɹɑkləmeɪʃən. hu hæɾ ətæk hɪm, ðoʊ? ʃʊɹli ðə sintʃæn kəd nɑɾ əv ɹitʃt aʊt tə kɛɹhin. ɪf ðə fɔɹseɪkən hæd dɪsaɪɾɪd tə muv oʊpənli, ðət kəd min wɝs keɪɑs ən dɪstʃɹʌkʃən ðən ɔlɹɛɾi feɪs ðə wɝld, bʌt ðə wɝst wəd bi æʃəmən. ɪf ɪz oʊn kɹieɪʃənz tɝn ɑn ɪm . . . noʊ! ʃi kəd nɑt pɹətɛk hɪm, haʊɛvɝ mʌtʃ i niɾəd ɪt. hi wəd dʒʌst əv tə fɛn fəɹ hɪmsɛlf.

She almost stared. That was very nearly a joke. A rough witticism, at least. From Halwin Norry! She did not believe Rand was dead, either. She would not believe he was dead. As for kneeling to Elaida, the man was too stubborn to submit to anyone. A great many difficulties could be surmounted if only he could bring himself to kneel to Egwene, but he would not do it, and she was his childhood friend. Elaida stood as much chance as a goat at a court ball, particularly once he learned of her proclamation. Who had attacked him, though? Surely the Seanchan could not have reached out to Cairhien. If the Forsaken had decided to move openly, that could mean worse chaos and destruction than already faced the world, but the worst would be Asha'man. If his own creations turned on him . . . No! She could not protect him, however much he needed it. He would just have to fend for himself.

ful mæn! ʃi mʌɾɝd ɪn əɹ hɛd. hiz pɹɑbli mɑɹtʃɪŋ ɝaʊnd wɪð bænɝz, dʒʌst əz ɪf noʊ wʌn tʃɹaɪd tə kɪl ɪm əɾ ɔl! jə hæd bɛɾɝ fɛn fəɹ jɝsɛlf, ɹænd ælθɹ, əɹ əl slæp jə sɪli wən aɪ ɡɛt maɪ hænz ɑn ju!

Fool man! she muttered in her head. He's probably marching around with banners, just as if no one tried to kill him at all! You had better fend for yourself, Rand al'Thor, or I'll slap you silly when I get my hands on you!

"wʌɾ ɛls də jəɹ kɔɹəspɑndəns əv tə seɪ, mæstɝ nɔɹi?" ʃi æskt əlaʊd, pʊɾɪŋ ɹænd əsaɪd. ʃi dɪd nɑɾ əv əɹ hænz ɑn ɪm jɛt, ən ʃi niɾəd tə kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾ ɑn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə hoʊld ɑn tə ændɝ.

"What else do your correspondents have to say, Master Norry?" she asked aloud, putting Rand aside. She did not have her hands on him yet, and she needed to concentrate on trying to hold on to Andor.

hɪz kɔɹəspɑndəns hæɾ ə ɡɹeɪt dil tə seɪ, ðoʊ səm ʌv ɪt wɑz kwaɪɾ oʊld. nɑɾ ɔl ðə ɹaɪɾɝz juz pɪdʒənz, ən lɛɾɝz ɡɪvən tə ðə moʊs tʃɹʌstwɝði mɝtʃən kəd teɪk mʌnθs tə kʌm əkɹɔs læn ɪn ðə bɛst ə taɪmz. əntʃɹʌstwɝði mɝtʃəns æksɛptɪd ðə poʊs fi ən nɛvɝ bɑðɝd tə dɪlɪvɝ ðə lɛɾɝ. fju pipəl kəɾ əfɔɹd tə haɪɝ kɝiɝz. ɪleɪn hæɾ ə maɪn tə stɑɹɾ ə ɹɔɪəl poʊst, ɪf ðə sɪtʃueɪʃən ɛvɝ əlaʊd. nɔɹi ləmɛntɪd ðə fæk ðəɾ ɪz leɪɾəst fɹəm ɛbu dɑɹ ən æmədɔɹ wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi oʊvɝteɪkən baɪ ɪvɛns ðət hæd bɪn ðə tɔk ə ðə stʃɹits fəɹ wiks.

His correspondents had a great deal to say, though some of it was quite old. Not all the writers used pigeons, and letters given to the most trustworthy merchant could take months to come across land in the best of times. Untrustworthy merchants accepted the post fee and never bothered to deliver the letter. Few people could afford to hire couriers. Elayne had a mind to start a Royal Post, if the situation ever allowed. Norry lamented the fact that his latest from Ebou Dar and Amador were already overtaken by events that had been the talk of the streets for weeks.

nɑɾ ɔl ðə nuz wɑz ɪmpɔɹɾənt, iðɝ. hɪz lɛɾɝ ɹaɪɾɝz ɹɪli wɝ nɑɾ aɪz-ænd-ɪɹz; ðeɪ dʒʌst ɹoʊt ðə nuz ə ðɛɹ sɪɾi, ðə tɔk ə ðə kɔɹt. ðə tɔk ə tiɹ wɑz ʌv ɪnkɹisɪŋ nʌmbɝz ə si foʊk ʃɪps ðət meɪd ðɛɹ weɪ θɹu ðə fɪŋɡɝz ə ðə dʒɹæɡən wɪθaʊt paɪləts ən naʊ kɹaʊɾəd ðə ɹɪvɝ ət ðə sɪɾi, ʌv ɹumɝz ðət si foʊk vɛsəlz hæd fɔt ðə sintʃæn ət si, ðoʊ ðət wɑz pjʊɹli ɹumɝ. ɪljən wɑz kwaɪət, ən fʊl ə ɹændz soʊlʒɝz, ɹəkʌvɝɪŋ fɹəm ə bæɾəl əɡɛns ðə sintʃæn; noʊ mɔɹ wɑz noʊn; ivən wɛðɝ ɹænd hæd bɪn ɪn ðə sɪɾi wɑz ɪn kwɛstʃən. ðə kwin ə sɑldɑiə wɑz stɪl ɑn əɹ lɔŋ ɹitʃɹiɾ ɪn ðə kʌntʃɹi, wɪtʃ ɪleɪn ɔlɹɛɾi nu əbaʊt, bʌɾ ɪt sim ðə kwin ə kændɝ hæd nɑt bɪn sin ɪn tʃeɪkɪn fəɹ mʌnθs, iðɝ, ən ðə kɪŋ ə ʃaɪnɝ wɑz səpoʊzədli stɪl ɑn ən ɪkstɛndəɾ ɪnspɛkʃən ə ðə blaɪtbɔɹɾɝ, ðoʊ ðə blaɪt wɑz ɹipɔɹɾəd kwaɪəɾɝ ðən ɛni taɪm ɪn mɛmɹi. ɪn luɡɹd, kɪŋ ɹɔdʒɹən wɑz ɡæðɝɪŋ ɛvɹi noʊbəl u wəd bɹɪŋ ɑɹmmɪn, ən ə sɪɾi ɔlɹɛɾi wɝiɾ əbaʊt tu ɡɹeɪɾ ɑɹmiz kæmp nɪɹ ðə bɔɹɾɝ wɪð ændɝ, wʌn fʊl ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ ən ði ʌðɝ fʊl ʌv ændɔɹənz, naʊ ɔlsoʊ wɝiɾ əbaʊt wʌɾ ə dɪsəlut weɪstʃɹəl laɪk ɹɔdʒɹən ɪntɛndəd.

Not all the news was important, either. His letter writers really were not eyes-and-ears; they just wrote the news of their city, the talk of the court. The talk of Tear was of increasing numbers of Sea Folk ships that made their way through the Fingers of the Dragon without pilots and now crowded the river at the city, of rumors that Sea Folk vessels had fought the Seanchan at sea, though that was purely rumor. Illian was quiet, and full of Rand's soldiers, recovering from a battle against the Seanchan; no more was known; even whether Rand had been in the city was in question. The Queen of Saldaea was still on her long retreat in the country, which Elayne already knew about, but it seemed the Queen of Kandor had not been seen in Chachin for months, either, and the King of Shienar was supposedly still on an extended inspection of the Blightborder, though the Blight was reported quieter than any time in memory. In Lugard, King Roedran was gathering every noble who would bring armsmen, and a city already worried about two great armies camped near the border with Andor, one full of Aes Sedai and the other full of Andorans, now also worried about what a dissolute wastrel like Roedran intended.

"æn jəɹ kaʊnsəl hɪɹ?" ʃi æskt wən i wɑz dʌn, ðoʊ ʃi dɪd nɑt niɾ ɪt. ɪn tʃɹuθ, ʃi hæd nɑt niɾəd ɪɾ ɪn ði ʌðɝz. ði ɪvɛns wɝ tu fɑɹ əweɪ tə əfɛkt ændɝ, əɹ ɛls ənɪmpɔɹɾənt, dʒʌst ə vju ʌv wʌt wɑz əkɝɪŋ ɪn ʌðɝ lænz. stɪl, ʃi wɑz ɪkspɛktəd tə æsk ivən wən ðeɪ boʊθ nu ʃi ɔlɹɛɾi hæd ði ænsɝ - "du nʌθɪŋ" - ən i hæd bɪn pɹɑmpt wɪð ɪz ɹɪplaɪz. mʊɹændi wɑz niðɝ fɑɹ əweɪ nɔɹ ənɪmpɔɹɾənt, jɛt ðɪs taɪm i hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, pɝsɪŋ ɪz lɪps. nɔɹi wɑz sloʊ ən məθɑɾəkəl, bʌt sɛldəm hɛzɪɾənt.

"And your counsel here?" she asked when he was done, though she did not need it. In truth, she had not needed it in the others. The events were too far away to affect Andor, or else unimportant, just a view of what was occurring in other lands. Still, she was expected to ask even when they both knew she already had the answer - "do nothing" - and he had been prompt with his replies. Murandy was neither far away nor unimportant, yet this time he hesitated, pursing his lips. Norry was slow and methodical, but seldom hesitant.

"nʌn, ɪn ðɪs ɹəɡɑɹd, maɪ leɪɾi," hi sɛɾ ət læst. "nɔɹməli, aɪ wəɾ ædvaɪz ən ɛməsɛɹi tə ɹɔdʒɹən tə ətɛmp saʊndɪŋ aʊɾ ɪz ɡoʊlz ən ɹizənz. hi meɪ bi fɪɹfəl ʌv ɪvɛns nɔɹθ ə hɪm, əɹ ə ði il ɹeɪdz wi hɪɹ soʊ mʌtʃ əbaʊt. ðən əɡɛn, ðoʊ hiz ɔlweɪz bɪn ənəmbɪʃəs, hi meɪ hæv səm ɛntɝpɹaɪz ɪn nɔɹðɝn ɔltɑɹə. əɹ ɪn ændɝ, ʌndɝ ðə sɝkəmstænsəz. ənfɔɹtʃənətli . . ." stɪl pɹɛsɪŋ ðə foʊldɝ tə hɪz tʃɛst, hi spɹɛɾ ɪz hænz slaɪtli ən saɪd, pɝhæps ɪn əpɑlədʒi, pɝhæps dɪstʃɹɛs.

"None, in this regard, my Lady," he said at last. "Normally, I would advise an emissary to Roedran to attempt sounding out his goals and reasons. He may be fearful of events north of him, or of the Aiel raids we hear so much about. Then again, though he has always been unambitious, he may have some enterprise in northern Altara. Or in Andor, under the circumstances. Unfortunately . . ." Still pressing the folder to his chest, he spread his hands slightly and sighed, perhaps in apology, perhaps distress.

ənfɔɹtʃənətli, ʃi wɑz nɑt kwin jɛt, ən noʊ ɛməsɛɹi fɹəm əɹ wəd ɡɛt nɪɹ ɹɔdʒɹən. ɪf əɹ kleɪm feɪld, ən i hæd ɹəsivd əɹ ɛnvɔɪ, ðə səksɛsfəl kleɪmən maɪt siz ə swɑθ ə mʊɹændi tə titʃ ɪm ə lɛsən, ən lɔɹd lwɑn ən ði ʌðɝz hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi siz tɛɹɪtɔɹi. ʃi hæd bɛɾɝ ɪnfɝmeɪʃən ðən ðə fɝs klɝk, ðoʊ, fɹəm ɛɡwin. ʃi hæd noʊ ɪntɛntʃən ə ɹɪvilɪŋ əɹ sɔɹs, bʌt ʃi dɪsaɪɾɪd tə iz ɪz dɪstʃɹɛs. ðət mʌs bi wʌt hæɾ ɪz maʊθ ɹɪŋkəld: noʊɪŋ wʌt ʃəd bi dʌn ən nɑt biɪŋ eɪbəl tə si haʊ tə də ɪt.

Unfortunately, she was not queen yet, and no emissary from her would get near Roedran. If her claim failed, and he had received her envoy, the successful claimant might seize a swath of Murandy to teach him a lesson, and Lord Luan and the others had already seized territory. She had better information than the First Clerk, though, from Egwene. She had no intention of revealing her source, but she decided to ease his distress. That must be what had his mouth wrinkled: knowing what should be done and not being able to see how to do it.

"aɪ noʊ ɹɔdʒɹənz eɪmz, mæstɝ nɔɹi, ən i eɪmz ət mʊɹændi ɪtsɛlf. ði ændɔɹənz ɪn mʊɹændi hæv æksɛptɪɾ oʊðz fɹəm mʊɹændiən noʊbəlz ɪn ðə nɔɹθ, wɪtʃ meɪk ðə ɹɛs nɝvəs. ən ðəɹ ɪz ə lɑɹdʒ bæn ə mɝsənɛɹiz - dʒɹæɡənzɔɹn, ɹɪli, bʌt ɹɔdʒɹən θɪŋks ðeɪ ɑɹ mɝsənɛɹiz - hu hiz haɪɝɾ ɪn sikɹət, tə sɪɾ ən pɹəvaɪɾ ə mɛnəs æftɝ ði ʌðɝ ɑɹmiz ɑɹ ɡɔn. hi plænz tə juz ðoʊz θɹɛts tə baɪnd noʊbəlz tə hɪm taɪtli ɪnʌf ðəɾ itʃ ɪz əfɹeɪd tə bi ðə fɝs tə bɹeɪk əweɪ wən ðə θɹɛts ɑɹ ɔl ɡɔn. hi meɪ bi ə pɹɑbləm ɪn ðə fjutʃɝ, ɪf ɪz plæn səksidz - fəɹ wʌn θɪŋ, hɪl wɑn ðoʊz nɔɹðɝn lænz bæk - bʌɾ i pɹizɛns noʊ ɪmiɾiət pɹɑbləmz fəɹ ændɝ."

"I know Roedran's aims, Master Norry, and he aims at Murandy itself. The Andorans in Murandy have accepted oaths from Murandian nobles in the north, which make the rest nervous. And there is a large band of mercenaries - Dragonsworn, really, but Roedran thinks they are mercenaries - who he has hired in secret, to sit and provide a menace after the other armies are gone. He plans to use those threats to bind nobles to him tightly enough that each is afraid to be the first to break away when the threats are all gone. He may be a problem in the future, if his plan succeeds - for one thing, he will want those northern lands back - but he presents no immediate problems for Andor."

nɔɹiz aɪz waɪɾənd, ən i tɪltəɾ ɪz hɛd fɝs tə wʌn saɪd ðən ʌðɝ, stʌɾiɪŋ hɝ. hi wɛɾ ɪz lɪps bɪfɔɹ spikɪŋ. "ðæt wəɾ ɪkspleɪn mʌtʃ, maɪ leɪɾi. jɛs. jɛs, ɪt wʊd." hɪz tʌŋ tʌtʃt ɪz lɪps əɡɛn. "ðɛɹ wɑz wʌn ʌðɝ pɔɪn mɛnʃən baɪ maɪ kɔɹəspɑndən ɪn kɛɹhin wɪtʃ aɪ . . . ʌm . . . fɝɡɑt tə mɛnʃən. əz jə meɪ bi əwɛɹ, jəɹ ɪntɛntʃən tə kleɪm ðə sʌn θɹoʊn ɪz wɛl noʊn ðɛɹ, ən əz lɑɹdʒ səpɔɹt. ɪt simz ðət mɛni kɛɹhinɪn spik oʊpənli ʌv kʌmɪŋ tə ændɝ, tə eɪd jə ɪn ɡeɪnɪŋ ðə laɪən θɹoʊn soʊ jə kən teɪk ðə sʌn θɹoʊn sunɝ. aɪ θɪŋk pɝhæps jə də nɑt nid maɪ ædvaɪs kənsɝnɪŋ ɛni sətʃ ɔfɝz?"

Norry's eyes widened, and he tilted his head first to one side then other, studying her. He wet his lips before speaking. "That would explain much, my Lady. Yes. Yes, it would." His tongue touched his lips again. "There was one other point mentioned by my correspondent in Cairhien which I . . . umm . . . forgot to mention. As you may be aware, your intention to claim the Sun Throne is well known there, and has large support. It seems that many Cairhienin speak openly of coming to Andor, to aide you in gaining the Lion Throne so you can take the Sun Throne sooner. I think perhaps you do not need my advice concerning any such offers?"

ʃi nɑɾəd, kwaɪt ɡɹeɪʃəsli ɪn ðə sɝkəmstænsəz, ʃi θɔt. eɪd fɹəm kɛɹhin wəd bi wɝs ðən ðə mɝsənɛɹiz, fəɹ ðəɹ hæd bɪn tu mɛni wɔɹz bɪtwin ændɝ ən kɛɹhin. hi hæd nɑt fɝɡɑɾən. hælwɪn nɔɹi nɛvɝ fɝɡɑɾ ɛniθɪŋ. soʊ waɪ hæɾ i dɪsaɪɾɪd tə tɛl hɝ, ɹæðɝ ðən lɛɾ əɹ bi kɑt baɪ sɝpɹaɪz, pɝhæps baɪ ði ɝaɪvəl ə hɝ kɛɹhin səpɔɹɾɝz? hæɾ əɹ dɪspleɪ ʌv nɑlədʒ ɪmpɹɛs hɪm? əɹ meɪɾ ɪm fɪɹfəl ʃi maɪt lɝn i hæd hɛl bæk? hi weɪɾəd ɑn əɹ peɪʃənli, ə dʒɹaɪd-ʌp hɛɹən weɪɾɪŋ . . . ɑn ə fɪʃ?

She nodded, quite graciously in the circumstances, she thought. Aid from Cairhien would be worse than the mercenaries, for there had been too many wars between Andor and Cairhien. He had not forgotten. Halwin Norry never forgot anything. So why had he decided to tell her, rather than let her be caught by surprise, perhaps by the arrival of her Cairhien supporters? Had her display of knowledge impressed him? Or made him fearful she might learn he had held back? He waited on her patiently, a dried-up heron waiting . . . on a fish?

"hæv ə lɛɾɝ pɹipɛɹd fəɹ maɪ sɪɡnətʃɝ ən sil, mæstɝ nɔɹi, tə bi sɛn tə ɛvɹi meɪdʒɝ haʊs ɪn kɛɹhin. bɪɡɪn wɪð sɛɾɪŋ aʊt maɪ ɹaɪt tə ðə sʌn θɹoʊn əz ðə dɔɾɝ ə tɑɹɪŋɡeɪl dəmədʒɹd, ən seɪ ðəɾ əl kʌm tə pʊt fɔɹwɝd maɪ kleɪm wən ɪvɛns ɪn ændɝ ɑɹ mɔɹ sɛɾəld. seɪ ðəɾ əl bɹɪŋ noʊ soʊlʒɝz wɪð mi, əz aɪ noʊ ðəɾ ændɔɝən soʊlʒɝz ɑn kɛɹhinɪn sɔɪl wəɾ ɪnsaɪɾ ɔl ə kɛɹhin əɡɛns mi, ən ɹaɪtli soʊ. fɪnɪʃ wɪð maɪ əpɹiʃieɪʃən ə ðə səpɔɹɾ ɔfɝd tə maɪ kɑz baɪ mɛni kɛɹhinɪn, ən maɪ hoʊp ðəɾ ɛni dɪvɪʒənz wɪðɪn kɛɹhin kən bi hil pisfəli." ði ɪntɛlədʒənt wəd si ðə mɛsədʒ bɪhaɪn ðə wɝdz, ən wɪð lʌk, ɪkspleɪn ɪt tə ɛni hu wɝ nɑt bɹaɪɾ ɪnʌf.

"Have a letter prepared for my signature and seal, Master Norry, to be sent to every major House in Cairhien. Begin with setting out my right to the Sun Throne as the daughter of Taringail Damodred, and say that I will come to put forward my claim when events in Andor are more settled. Say that I will bring no soldiers with me, as I know that Andoran soldiers on Cairhienin soil would incite all of Cairhien against me, and rightly so. Finish with my appreciation of the support offered to my cause by many Cairhienin, and my hope that any divisions within Cairhien can be healed peacefully." The intelligent would see the message behind the words, and with luck, explain it to any who were not bright enough.

"ə dɛft ɹɪspɑns, maɪ leɪɾi," nɔɹi sɛd, hʌntʃɪŋ ɪz ʃoʊldɝz ɪn ə sɛmbləns ʌv ə baʊ. "aɪ ʃæl meɪk ɪt soʊ. ɪf aɪ meɪ æsk, maɪ leɪɾi, hæv jə hæd taɪm tə saɪn ði əkaʊns? ɑ. noʊ mæɾɝ. əl sɛn sʌmwʌn fəɹ əm leɪɾɝ." boʊɪŋ pɹɑpɝli, ɪf noʊ lɛs ɔkwɝdli ðən bɪfɔɹ, hi pɹipɛɹd tə ɡoʊ, ðən pɔzd. "fɝɡɪv mi fəɹ biɪŋ soʊ boʊld, maɪ leɪɾi, bʌt jə ɹimaɪn mi vɛɹi mʌtʃ ə ðə leɪt kwin jəɹ mʌðɝ."

"A deft response, my Lady," Norry said, hunching his shoulders in a semblance of a bow. "I shall make it so. If I may ask, my Lady, have you had time to sign the accounts? Ah. No matter. I will send someone for them later." Bowing properly, if no less awkwardly than before, he prepared to go, then paused. "Forgive me for being so bold, my Lady, but you remind me very much of the late Queen your mother."

wɑtʃɪŋ ðə dɔɹ kloʊs bɪhaɪn hɪm, ʃi wʌndɝd wɛðɝ ʃi kəd kaʊn ɪm ɪn əɹ kæmp. ædmɪnɪstɝɪŋ keɪɛmlɪn wɪθaʊt klɝks, mʌtʃ lɛs ændɝ, wɑz ɪmpɑsəbəl, ən ðə fɝs klɝk hæd ðə paʊɝ tə bɹɪŋ ə kwin tə hɝ niz ɪf əntʃɛkt. ə kɑmpləmənt wɑz nɑt ðə seɪm əz ə dɛklɝeɪʃən ə fiəlti.

Watching the door close behind him, she wondered whether she could count him in her camp. Administering Caemlyn without clerks, much less Andor, was impossible, and the First Clerk had the power to bring a queen to her knees if unchecked. A compliment was not the same as a declaration of fealty.

ʃi dɪd nɑɾ əv lɔŋ tə mʌl ðə kwɛstʃən, fəɹ oʊnli moʊməns æftɝ i dɪpɑɹɾəd, θɹi lɪvɹid meɪdz ɛntɝd, bɛɹɪŋ sɪlvɝ-doʊm tʃɹeɪz ðət ðeɪ pleɪst ɪn ə ɹoʊ ɑn ðə lɔŋ saɪd teɪbəl stændɪŋ əɡɛnst wʌn wɔl.

She did not have long to mull the question, for only moments after he departed, three liveried maids entered, bearing silver-domed trays that they placed in a row on the long side table standing against one wall.

"ðə fɝs meɪd sɛd maɪ leɪɾi fɝɡɑt tə sɛn fəɹ əɹ mɪddeɪ mil," ə ɹaʊnd, ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd wʊmən sɛd, kɝtsiɪŋ əz ʃi dʒɛstʃɝd fəɹ əɹ jʌŋɡɝ kəmpænjən tə ɹimuv ðə tɔl doʊmz, "soʊ ʃi sɛn ə tʃɔɪs fəɹ maɪ leɪɾi."

"The First Maid said my Lady forgot to send for her midday meal," a round, gray-haired woman said, curtsying as she gestured for her younger companion to remove the tall domes, "so she sent a choice for my Lady."
