"ju noʊ wʌɾ ɪt dʌz; ðə kɪn ɑɹ pɹuf! haʊ mɛni ɛɛs sədaɪ laɪv pæs θɹi hʌnʒɹəd? əɹ ɹitʃ ɪt? ən doʊn tɛl mi aɪ ʃʊdn tɔk əbaʊɾ eɪdʒ. ðæts ə ɹɪdɪkjələs kʌstəm, ən jə noʊ ɪt. ɛɡwin, ɹin wɑz kɔld ɛldəs kəz ʃi wɑz ði oʊldəs kɪnswʊmən ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ. ði oʊldəst ɛniwɛɹ ɪz ə wʊmən kɔld ɑlɔɪsiə nimoʊsni, ən ɔɪl mɝtʃən ɪn tɛɹ. ɛɡwin, ʃiz nɪɹli sɪks . . . hʌnʒɹəd . . . jɪɹz . . . oʊld! wən ðə hɔl hɪɹz ðæt, aɪ weɪdʒɝ ðəl bi ɹɛɾi tə pʊt ði oʊθ ɹɑɾ ɑn ə ʃɛlf."

"That's madness!" Nynaeve burst out, leaning forward in her chair. Surprisingly, still the same chair. And still the same dress. Very surprising. Her hands were fists resting on her lap. "You know what it does; the Kin are proof! How many Aes Sedai live past three hundred? Or reach it? And don't tell me I shouldn't talk about age. That's a ridiculous custom, and you know it. Egwene, Reanne was called Eldest because she was the oldest Kinswoman in Ebou Dar. The oldest anywhere is a woman called Aloisia Nemosni, an oil merchant in Tear. Egwene, she's nearly six . . . hundred . . . years . . . old! When the Hall hears that, I wager they'll be ready to put the Oath Rod on a shelf."

"ðə laɪt noʊz θɹi hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz ɪz ə lɔŋ taɪm," ɪleɪn pʊɾ ɪn, "bʌɾ aɪ kæn seɪ aɪm hæpi maɪsɛlf ət ðə pɹɑspɛkt ə pɝhæps kʌɾɪŋ maɪ laɪf ɪn hæf, ɛɡwin. ən wʌɾ ə ði oʊθ ɹɑɾ ən jəɹ pɹɑməs tə ðə kɪn? ɹin wɑns tə bi ɛɛs sədaɪ, bʌt wʌt hæpənz wən ʃi swɛɹz? wʌɾ əbaʊɾ ɑlɔɪsiə? wɪl ʃi fɔl oʊvɝ dɛd? jə kæn æsk əm tə swɛɹ, nɑt noʊɪŋ."

"The Light knows three hundred years is a long time," Elayne put in, "but I can't say I'm happy myself at the prospect of perhaps cutting my life in half, Egwene. And what of the Oath Rod and your promise to the Kin? Reanne wants to be Aes Sedai, but what happens when she swears? What about Aloisia? Will she fall over dead? You can't ask them to swear, not knowing."

"aɪ doʊn æsk ɛniθɪŋ." ɛɡwinz feɪs wɑz stɪl smuð, bʌɾ əɹ bæk hæd stʃɹeɪɾənd, hɝ vɔɪs kuld. ən hɑɹɾənd. hɝ aɪz ɔɡɝd dip. "ɛni wʊmən u wɑns tə bi ə sɪstɝ wɪl swɛɹ. ən ɛniwʌn u ɹəfjuzəz ən stɪl kɔlz hɝsɛlf ɛɛs sədaɪ wɪl fil ðə fʊl weɪɾ ə taʊɝ dʒʌstəs."

"I don't ask anything." Egwene's face was still smooth, but her back had straightened, her voice cooled. And hardened. Her eyes augered deep. "Any woman who wants to be a sister will swear. And anyone who refuses and still calls herself Aes Sedai will feel the full weight of Tower justice."

ɪleɪn swɑloʊd hɑɹɾ ʌndɝ ðət stɛɾi ɡeɪz. nɪneɪivz feɪs peɪld. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ mɪsteɪkɪŋ ɛɡwinz minɪŋ. ðeɪ wɝ nɑt hɪɹɪŋ ə fɹɛnd naʊ, bʌt ði æmɪɝlɪn sit, ən ði æmɪɝlɪn sit hæd noʊ fɹɛnz wən ɪt keɪm taɪm tə pɹənaʊns dʒʌdʒmənt.

Elayne swallowed hard under that steady gaze. Nynaeve's face paled. There was no mistaking Egwene's meaning. They were not hearing a friend now, but the Amyrlin Seat, and the Amyrlin Seat had no friends when it came time to pronounce judgment.

əpɛɹənli sæɾəsfaɪd wɪð wʌt ʃi sɔ ɪn ðɛm, ɛɡwin ɹɪlækst. "aɪ də noʊ ðə pɹɑbləm," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn ə mɔɹ nɔɹməl toʊn. mɔɹ nɔɹməl, bʌt stɪl nɑɾ ɪnvaɪɾɪŋ ɑɹɡjəmənt. "aɪ ɪkspɛkt ɛni wʊmən huz neɪm ɪz ɪn ðə nɑvəs bʊk tə ɡoʊ əz fɑɹ əz ʃi kæn, tə ɝn ðə ʃɔl ɪf ʃi kæn, ən sɝv əz ɛɛs sədaɪ, bʌɾ aɪ doʊnt wɑn ɛniwʌn tə daɪ fəɹ ɪt wən ðeɪ kəd lɪv. wʌns ðə hɔl lɝnz əbaʊt ðə kɪn - wʌns ðəɹ oʊvɝ pɪtʃɪŋ fɪts - aɪ θɪŋk aɪ kən ɡɛɾ əm tə əɡɹi ðəɾ ə sɪstɝ u wɑns tə ɹɪtaɪɹ ʃəd bi eɪbəl tə. wɪð ði oʊðz ɹimuvd." ðeɪ hæd dɪsaɪɾɪd lɔŋ əɡoʊ ðət ðə ɹɑd kəd bi juz tə ənbaɪn əz wɛl əz baɪnd, ɛls haʊ kəd blæk sɪstɝz laɪ?

Apparently satisfied with what she saw in them, Egwene relaxed. "I do know the problem," she said in a more normal tone. More normal, but still not inviting argument. "I expect any woman whose name is in the novice book to go as far as she can, to earn the shawl if she can, and serve as Aes Sedai, but I don't want anyone to die for it when they could live. Once the Hall learns about the Kin - once they're over pitching fits - I think I can get them to agree that a sister who wants to retire should be able to. With the Oaths removed." They had decided long ago that the Rod could be used to unbind as well as bind, else how could Black sisters lie?

"aɪ səpoʊz ðət wəd bi ɔl ɹaɪt," nɪneɪiv əlaʊd dʒudɪʃɪsli. ɪleɪn sɪmpli nɑɾəd; ʃi wɑz sɝɾən ðəɹ wɑz mɔɹ.

"I suppose that would be all right," Nynaeve allowed judiciously. Elayne simply nodded; she was certain there was more.

"ɹɪtaɪɹ ɪndə ðə kɪn, nɪneɪiv," ɛɡwin sɛd dʒɛnli. "ðæt weɪ, ðə kɪn ɑɹ baʊn tə ðə taʊɝ, tu. ðə kɪn wɪl kip ðɛɹ oʊn weɪz, ʌv kɔɹs, ðɛɹ ɹul, bʌt ðəl əv tə əɡɹi ðət ðɛɹ nɪɾɪŋ sɝkəl ɪz bɪniθ ði æmɪɝlɪn, ɪf nɑt ðə hɔl, ən ðət kɪnswɪmən stæn bɪloʊ sɪstɝz. aɪ də min əm tə bi pɑɹɾ ə ðə taʊɝ, nɑt ɡoʊ ðɛɹ oʊn weɪ. bʌɾ aɪ θɪŋk ðəl æksɛpt."

"Retire into the Kin, Nynaeve," Egwene said gently. "That way, the Kin are bound to the Tower, too. The Kin will keep their own ways, of course, their Rule, but they will have to agree that their Knitting Circle is beneath the Amyrlin, if not the Hall, and that Kinswomen stand below sisters. I do mean them to be part of the Tower, not go their own way. But I think they will accept."

nɪneɪiv nɑɾəd əɡɛn, hæpəli, bʌɾ əɹ smaɪl feɪɾəd əz ðə fʊl ɪmpɔɹt ɹitʃt hɝ. ʃi spləɾɝd ɪndɪɡnənli. "bʌt . . . ! stændɪŋ əmʌŋ ðə kɪn ɪz baɪ eɪdʒ! jəl əv sɪstɝz teɪkɪŋ ɔɹɾɝz fɹəm wɪmən u kʊdn ivən ɹitʃ æksɛptɪd!"

Nynaeve nodded again, happily, but her smile faded as the full import reached her. She spluttered indignantly. "But . . . ! Standing among the Kin is by age! You'll have sisters taking orders from women who couldn't even reach Accepted!"

"fɔɹmɝ sɪstɝz, nɪneɪiv." ɛɡwin fɪŋɡɝd ðə ɡɹeɪt sɝpən ɹɪŋ ɑn əɹ ɹaɪt hæn ən saɪd feɪnli. "ivən kɪnswɪmən u ɝn ðə ɹɪŋ doʊnt wɛɹ ɪt. soʊ wɪl əv tə ɡɪv ɪɾ ʌp, tu. wɪl bi kɪnswɪmən, nɪneɪiv, nɑɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ ɛni lɔŋɡɝ." ʃi saʊndəɾ əz ɪf ʃi kəɾ ɔlɹɛɾi fil ðət dɪstən deɪ, ðət dɪstən lɔs, bʌt ʃi tʊk əɹ hæn fɹəm ðə ɹɪŋ ən tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ. "naʊ. ɪz ðəɹ ɛniθɪŋ ɛls? aɪ hæv ə lɔŋ naɪɾ əhɛɾ ə mi, ən aɪ wəd laɪk tə ɡɛɾ ə lɪɾəl ɹil slip bɪfɔɹ aɪ hæv tə feɪs ðə sɪɾɝz əɡɛn."

"Former sisters, Nynaeve." Egwene fingered the Great Serpent ring on her right hand and sighed faintly. "Even Kinswomen who earned the ring don't wear it. So we will have to give it up, too. We will be Kinswomen, Nynaeve, not Aes Sedai any longer." She sounded as if she could already feel that distant day, that distant loss, but she took her hand from the ring and took a deep breath. "Now. Is there anything else? I have a long night ahead of me, and I would like to get a little real sleep before I have to face the Sitters again."

fɹaʊnɪŋ, nɪneɪiv hæd klɛntʃt əɹ fɪs taɪɾ ən leɪɾ əɹ ʌðɝ hæn oʊvɝ ɪt tə kʌvɝ əɹ ɹɪŋz, bʌt ʃi əpɪɹd ɹɛɾi tə ɡɪv ʌp ɑɹɡjuɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə kɪn. fəɹ ðə taɪm biɪŋ. "du jəɹ hɛdeɪks stɪl tʃɹʌbəl ju? aɪd θɪŋk ɪf ðət wʊmənz məsɑʒɪz dɪɾ ɛni ɡʊd, jud stɑp hævɪŋ ðɛm."

Frowning, Nynaeve had clenched her fist tight and laid her other hand over it to cover her rings, but she appeared ready to give up arguing over the Kin. For the time being. "Do your headaches still trouble you? I'd think if that woman's massages did any good, you'd stop having them."

"hɑliməz məsɑʒɪz wɝk wʌndɝz, nɪneɪiv. aɪ kʊdn slip əɾ ɔl wɪθaʊt hɝ. naʊ, ɪz ðəɹ . . . ?" ʃi tʃɹeɪld ɔf, stɛɹɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə dɔɹz ət ði ɛntʃɹəns ə ðə θɹoʊn ɹum, ən ɪleɪn tɝn tə lʊk.

"Halima's massages work wonders, Nynaeve. I couldn't sleep at all without her. Now, is there . . . ?" She trailed off, staring toward the doors at the entrance of the throne room, and Elayne turned to look.

ə mæn wɑz stændɪŋ ðəɹ wɑtʃɪŋ, ə mæn əz tɔl əz ən ilmən, wɪð dɑɹk ɹɛd hɛɹ feɪnli stʃɹikt wɪð waɪt, bʌɾ ɪz haɪ-kɑlɝd blu koʊt wəd nɛvɝ bi wɔɹn baɪ ən il. hi əpɪɹd mʌskjəlɝ, ən ɪz hɑɹd feɪs sim sʌmhaʊ fəmɪljɝ. wən i sɔ ðɛm lʊkɪŋ, hi tɝn ən ɹæn daʊn ðə kɔɹəɾɝ aʊɾ ə saɪt.

A man was standing there watching, a man as tall as an Aielman, with dark red hair faintly streaked with white, but his high-collared blue coat would never be worn by an Aiel. He appeared muscular, and his hard face seemed somehow familiar. When he saw them looking, he turned and ran down the corridor out of sight.

fəɹ ən ɪnstənt, ɪleɪn ɡeɪpt. hi hæd nɑt dʒʌst æksədɛntəli dʒɹim hɪmsɛlf ɪndə tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd, əɹ i wʊɾə vænɪʃt baɪ naʊ, bʌt ʃi kəd stɪl hɪɹ ɪz buts, laʊɾ ɑn ðə flɔɹ taɪlz. iðɝ i wɑz ə dʒɹimwɔkɝ - ɹɛɹ əmʌŋ mɛn, soʊ ðə waɪz wʌnz sɛd - əɹ i hæɾ ə tɛɹæŋɡɹil ə hɪz oʊn.

For an instant, Elayne gaped. He had not just accidentally dreamed himself into Tel'aran'rhiod, or he would have vanished by now, but she could still hear his boots, loud on the floor tiles. Either he was a dreamwalker - rare among men, so the Wise Ones said - or he had a ter'angreal of his own.

lipɪŋ tə hɝ fit, ʃi ɹæn æftɝ hɪm, bʌɾ əz fæst əz ʃi wɑz, ɛɡwin wɑz fæstɝ. wʌn ɪnstən ɛɡwin wɑz bɪhaɪnd, ðə nɛkst ʃi wɑz stændɪŋ ɪn ðə dɔɹweɪ, piɹɪŋ ðə weɪ ðə mæn hæd ɡɔn. ɪleɪn tʃɹaɪd θɪŋkɪŋ ə hɝsɛlf stændɪŋ bɪsaɪɾ ɛɡwin, ən ʃi wɑz. ðə kɔɹəɾɝ wɑz saɪlənt, naʊ, ən ɛmpti ɪksɛp fəɹ stænd-læmps ən tʃɛsts ən tæpəstʃɹiz, ɔl flɪkɝɪŋ ən ʃɪftɪŋ.

Leaping to her feet, she ran after him, but as fast as she was, Egwene was faster. One instant Egwene was behind, the next she was standing in the doorway, peering the way the man had gone. Elayne tried thinking of herself standing beside Egwene, and she was. The corridor was silent, now, and empty except for stand-lamps and chests and tapestries, all flickering and shifting.

"haʊ dɪd jə də ðæt?" nɪneɪiv dɪmændəd, ɹʌnɪŋ ʌp wɪð əɹ skɝts hɔɪstəɾ əbʌv əɹ niz. hɝ stɑkɪŋz wɝ sɪlk, ən fɛd! heɪstəli lɛɾɪŋ əɹ skɝts fɔl wən ʃi ɹilaɪzd ɪleɪn hæd noʊɾəst əɹ stɑkɪŋz, ʃi pɪɹd daʊn ðə hɔlweɪ. "wɛɹ dɪɾ i ɡoʊ? hi cʊɾə hɝɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ! dɪd jə ɹɛkəɡnaɪz hɪm? hi ɹimaɪndəd mi ʌv sʌmwʌn; aɪ doʊnt noʊ hu."

"How did you do that?" Nynaeve demanded, running up with her skirts hoisted above her knees. Her stockings were silk, and fed! Hastily letting her skirts fall when she realized Elayne had noticed her stockings, she peered down the hallway. "Where did he go? He could have heard everything! Did you recognize him? He reminded me of someone; I don't know who."

"ɹænd," ɛɡwin sɛd. "hi cʊɾə bɪn ɹændz ʌŋkəl."

"Rand," Egwene said. "He could have been Rand's uncle."

ʌv kɔɹs, ɪleɪn θɔt. ɪf ɹænd hæɾ ə min ʌŋkəl.

Of course, Elayne thought. If Rand had a mean uncle.

ə mətælɪk klɪk ɛkoʊd fɹəm ðə fɑɹ ɛn ə ðə θɹoʊn ɹum. ðə dɔɹ ɪndə ðə dʒɹɛsɪŋ ɹumz bɪhaɪn ðə deɪz, kloʊzɪŋ. dɔɹz wɝ oʊpən əɹ kloʊzd əɹ səmtaɪmz ɪn bɪtwin ɪn tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd; ðeɪ dɪd nɑt swɪŋ ʃʌt.

A metallic click echoed from the far end of the throne room. The door into the dressing rooms behind the dais, closing. Doors were open or closed or sometimes in between in Tel'aran'rhiod; they did not swing shut.

"laɪt!" nɪneɪiv mʌɾɝd. "haʊ mɛni pipəl əv bɪn ivzdʒɹɑpɪŋ ɑn ʌs? nɑt tə mɛnʃən hu, ən waɪ?"

"Light!" Nynaeve muttered. "How many people have been eavesdropping on us? Not to mention who, and why?"

"huɛvɝ ðeɪ ɑɹ," ɛɡwin ɹɪplaɪd kɑmli, "ðeɪ əpɛɹənli doʊnt noʊ tɛlɝɑnɹhiəɾ əz wɛl əz wi du. nɑt fɹɛnz, seɪf tə seɪ, əɹ ðeɪ wʊdn bi ivzdʒɹɑpɪŋ. ən aɪ θɪŋk ðeɪ meɪ nɑt bi fɹɛnz tə wʌn ənʌðɝ, ʌðɝwaɪz, waɪ lɪsən fɹəm ɑpəzəɾ ɛnz ə ðə ɹum? ðət mæn wɑz wɛɹɪŋ ə ʃaɪnɝən koʊt. ðəɹ ɑɹ ʃaɪnɝənz ɪn maɪ ɑɹmi, bʌt jə boʊθ noʊ ðɛm ɔl. nʌn ɹɪzɛmbəl ɹænd."

"Whoever they are," Egwene replied calmly, "they apparently don't know Tel'aran'rhiod as well as we do. Not friends, safe to say, or they wouldn't be eavesdropping. And I think they may not be friends to one another, otherwise, why listen from opposite ends of the room? That man was wearing a Shienaran coat. There are Shienarans in my army, but you both know them all. None resemble Rand."

nɪneɪiv snɪft. "wɛl, huɛvɝ i ɪz, ðəɹ ɑɹ tu mɛni pipəl lɪsnɪŋ ət kɔɹnɝz. ðæts wʌɾ aɪ θɪŋk. aɪ wɑnə bi bæk ɪn maɪ oʊn bɑɾi, wɛɹ ɔl aɪ hæv tə wɝi əbaʊɾ ɑɹ spaɪz ən pɔɪzən dæɡɝz."

Nynaeve sniffed. "Well, whoever he is, there are too many people listening at corners. That's what I think. I want to be back in my own body, where all I have to worry about are spies and poisoned daggers."

ʃaɪnɝənz, ɪleɪn θɔt. bɔɹɾɝləndɝz. haʊ kəd ðəɾ əv slɪpt əɹ maɪnd? wɛl, ðəɹ hæd bɪn ðə lɪɾəl mæɾɝ ə fɔkɹut. "ðɛɹ ɪz wʌn mɔɹ θɪŋ," ʃi sɛɾ əlaʊd, ðoʊ ɪn ə kɛɹfəl vɔɪs ʃi hoʊpt wəd nɑt kæɹi, ən ɹɪleɪɾɪd daɪɛlɪnz nuz ə bɔɹɾɝləndɝz ɪn bɹəm wʊd. ʃi æɾəd mæstɝ nɔɹiz kɔɹəspɑndəns, tu, ɔl ðə waɪl tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə wɑtʃ boʊθ weɪz əlɔŋ ðə kɔɹəɾɝ ən ðə θɹoʊn ɹum əz wɛl. ʃi dɪd nɑt wɑnə bi kɑt næpɪŋ baɪ ənʌðɝ spaɪ. "aɪ θɪŋk ðoʊz ɹulɝz ɑɹ ɪn bɹəm wʊd," ʃi fɪnɪʃt, "ɔl fɔɹ ə ðɛm."

Shienarans, Elayne thought. Borderlanders. How could that have slipped her mind? Well, there had been the little matter of forkroot. "There is one more thing," she said aloud, though in a careful voice she hoped would not carry, and related Dyelin's news of Borderlanders in Braem Wood. She added Master Norry's correspondence, too, all the while trying to watch both ways along the corridor and the throne room as well. She did not want to be caught napping by another spy. "I think those rulers are in Braem Wood," she finished, "all four of them."

"ɹænd," ɛɡwin bɹiðd, saʊndɪŋ ɪɹəteɪɾəd. "ivən wən i kæn bi faʊn i kɑmplɪkeɪts θɪŋz. juv ɛni aɪdiə wɛðɝ ðeɪ keɪm tə ɔfɝ ɪm əlidʒəns əɹ tʃɹaɪ tə hæn ɪm oʊvɝ tə ɪleɪɾə? aɪ kæn θɪŋk ʌv ɛni ʌðɝ ɹizənz fəɹ əm tə mɑɹtʃ ə θaʊzən liɡz. ðeɪ mʌs bi bɔɪlɪŋ ʃuz fəɹ sup baɪ naʊ! juv ɛni aɪdiə haʊ hɑɹɾ ɪts tə kip ən ɑɹmi səplaɪɾ ɑn ðə mɑɹtʃ?"

"Rand," Egwene breathed, sounding irritated. "Even when he can't be found he complicates things. Do you have any idea whether they came to offer him allegiance or try to hand him over to Elaida? I can't think of any other reasons for them to march a thousand leagues. They must be boiling shoes for soup by now! Do you have any idea how hard it is to keep an army supplied on the march?"

"aɪ θɪŋk aɪ kən faɪn aʊt," ɪleɪn sɛd. "waɪ, aɪ min. ən ət ðə seɪm taɪm. . . . jə ɡeɪv mi ði aɪdiə, ɛɡwin." ʃi kəd nɑt hɛlp smaɪlɪŋ. sʌmθɪŋ ɡʊd hæd kʌm ə tədeɪ. "aɪ θɪŋk aɪ maɪt dʒʌs bi eɪbəl tə juz əm tə sɪkjʊɹ ðə laɪən θɹoʊn."

"I think I can find out," Elayne said. "Why, I mean. And at the same time. . . . You gave me the idea, Egwene." She could not help smiling. Something good had come of today. "I think I might just be able to use them to secure the Lion Throne."

æn ɪɡzæmən ðə tɔl ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi fɹeɪm ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ ən ɡeɪv ə saɪ ðət tɝn ɪndə ə jɔn. ðə flɪkɝɪŋ læmps ɡeɪv ə pʊɹ laɪt fəɹ ðɪs, bʌt ðət wɑz nɑt ðə ɹizən əɹ bɝdz ɔl sim lɑpsaɪɾɪd. ʃi wɑntəd tə bi ɪn əɹ bɛd, ən ʃi dɪspaɪzd ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi. bʌt ʃi hæd tə bi əweɪk, ən ðɪs wɑz ði oʊnli weɪ tə əvɔɪd kɑnvɝseɪʃən wɪð tʃɛzməl. wʌt tʃɛzməl kɔl kɑnvɝseɪʃən. ðə smʌɡli ɛɹəɡən jɛloʊ wɑz ɪntɛn ɑn əɹ oʊn ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi, ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə ɹum, ən ʃi əsum ðəɾ ɛniwʌn u tʊk ʌp ə niɾəl hæɾ əɹ oʊn kin ɪntʃɹəst ɪn ðə wɝk. ɑn ði ʌðɝ hænd, æn nu, ɪf ʃi ɹoʊz fɹəm əɹ tʃɛɹ, tʃɛzməl wəd sun stɑɹt ɹɪɡeɪlɪŋ əɹ wɪð teɪlz ə hɝ oʊn ɪmpɔɹɾəns. ɪn ðə mʌnθs sɪns mɑɡiɾin vænɪʃt, ʃi hæd hɝd tʃɛzməlz pɑɹɾ ɪn pʊɾɪŋ tæmɹə ɑspɪnjə tə ðə kwɛstʃən ət lis twɛnti taɪmz, ən haʊ tʃɛzməl hæɾ ɪndus ðə ɹɛdz tə mɝɾɝ siɹɪn veɪu bɪfɔɹ siɹɪn kəɾ ɔɹɾɝ əɹ ɝɛs pɝhæps fɪfti! tə hɪɹ tʃɛzməl tɛl ɪt, ʃi hæd seɪv ðə blæk ədʒɑ sɪŋɡəl-hændəd, ən ʃi wəd tɛl ɪt, ɡɪvən hæf ə tʃæns. ðət sɔɹɾ ə tɔk wɑz nɑɾ oʊnli bɔɹɪŋ, ɪt wɑz deɪnʒɝəs. ivən dɛdli, ɪf ðə səpɹim kaʊnsəl lɝn ʌv ɪt. soʊ æn staɪfəld ənʌðɝ jɔn, skwɪntɪɾ əɾ əɹ wɝk, ən pʊʃt ðə niɾəl θɹu ðə taɪtli stʃɹɛtʃt lɪnən. pɝhæps ɪf ʃi meɪd ðə ɹɛdbɝd lɑɹdʒɝ, ʃi kəɾ ivən ʌp ðə wɪŋz.

Asne examined the tall embroidery frame in front of her and gave a sigh that turned into a yawn. The flickering lamps gave a poor light for this, but that was not the reason her birds all seemed lopsided. She wanted to be in her bed, and she despised embroidery. But she had to be awake, and this was the only way to avoid conversation with Chesmal. What Chesmal called conversation. The smugly arrogant Yellow was intent on her own embroidery, on the other side of the room, and she assumed that anyone who took up a needle had her own keen interest in the work. On the other hand, Asne knew, if she rose from her chair, Chesmal would soon start regaling her with tales of her own importance. In the months since Moghedien vanished, she had heard Chesmal's part in putting Tamra Ospenya to the question at least twenty times, and how Chesmal had induced the Reds to murder Sierin Vayu before Sierin could order her arrest perhaps fifty! To hear Chesmal tell it, she had saved the Black Ajah single-handed, and she would tell it, given half a chance. That sort of talk was not only boring, it was dangerous. Even deadly, if the Supreme Council learned of it. So Asne stifled another yawn, squinted at her work, and pushed the needle through the tightly stretched linen. Perhaps if she made the redbird larger, she could even up the wings.

ðə klɪk ə ðə dɔɹlætʃ bɹɔt boʊθ wɪmənz hɛdz ʌp. ðə tu sɝvəns nu nɑt tə bɑðɝ ðɛm, ən ɪn ɛni keɪs, ðə wʊmən ən əɹ hʌzbənd ʃəd bi fæst əslip. æn ɛmbɹeɪst seɪaɪdɑɹ, ɹɛɾiɪŋ ə wiv ðət wəd sɪɹ ən ɪntʃɹuɾɝ tə ðə boʊn, ən ðə ɡloʊ sɝaʊndəd tʃɛzməl, tu. ɪf ðə ɹɔŋ pɝsən stɛp θɹu ðət dɔɹ, ðeɪ wəd ɹəɡɹɛɾ ɪɾ əntɪl ðeɪ daɪd.

The click of the doorlatch brought both women's heads up. The two servants knew not to bother them, and in any case, the woman and her husband should be fast asleep. Asne embraced saidar, readying a weave that would sear an intruder to the bone, and the glow surrounded Chesmal, too. If the wrong person stepped through that door, they would regret it until they died.

ɪt wɑz ɛlʒɹɪθ, ɡlʌvz ɪn hænd, wɪð əɹ dɑɹk kloʊk stɪl hæŋɪŋ daʊn əɹ bæk. ðə plʌmp bɹaʊnz dʒɹɛs wɑz dɑɹk, tu, ən ʌnədɔɹnd. æn heɪɾəd wɛɹɪŋ pleɪn wʊlənz, bʌt ðeɪ dɪd nid tə əvɔɪd noʊɾəs. ðə dʒɹæb kloʊðz suɾəd ɛlʒɹɪθ.

It was Eldrith, gloves in hand, with her dark cloak still hanging down her back. The plump Brown's dress was dark, too, and unadorned. Asne hated wearing plain woolens, but they did need to avoid notice. The drab clothes suited Eldrith.

ʃi stɑpt ət ðə saɪɾ ə ðɛm, blɪŋkɪŋ, ə moʊməntɛɹi lʊk ə kənfjuʒən ɑn əɹ ɹaʊn feɪs. "oʊ, maɪ," ʃi sɛd. "hu dɪd jə θɪŋk aɪ wɑz?" θɹoʊɪŋ əɹ ɡlʌvz ɑntu ðə smɔl teɪbəl baɪ ðə dɔɹ, ʃi sʌɾənli bɪkeɪm əwɛɹ ə hɝ kloʊk ən fɹaʊn əz ɪf dʒʌst ɹilaɪzɪŋ ʃi hæd wɔɹn ɪɾ əpstɛɹz. kɛɹfəli ənpɪnɪŋ ðə sɪlvɝ bɹutʃ əɾ əɹ nɛk, ʃi tɔs ðə kloʊk ɑntu ə tʃɛɹ ɪn ə tʌmbəl hip.

She stopped at the sight of them, blinking, a momentary look of confusion on her round face. "Oh, my," she said. "Who did you think I was?" Throwing her gloves onto the small table by the door, she suddenly became aware of her cloak and frowned as if just realizing she had worn it upstairs. Carefully unpinning the silver brooch at her neck, she tossed the cloak onto a chair in a tumbled heap.

ðə laɪɾ ə seɪaɪdɑɹ wɪŋkt aʊɾ ɝaʊn tʃɛzməl əz ʃi twɪstəɾ əɹ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi fɹeɪm əsaɪd soʊ ʃi kəd stænd. hɝ stɝn feɪs meɪɾ əɹ sim tɔlɝ ðən ʃi wɑz, ən ʃi wɑz ə tɔl wʊmən. ðə bɹaɪtli kʌlɝd flaʊɝz ʃi hæɾ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd maɪɾ əv bɪn ɪn ə ɡɑɹɾən. "wɛɹ əv jə bɪn?" ʃi dɪmændəd. ɛlʒɹɪθ stʊd haɪəst əmʌŋ ðɛm, ən mɑɡiɾin hæd lɛft əɹ ɪn tʃɑɹdʒ bɪsaɪdz, bʌt tʃɛzməl hæd bɪɡʌn teɪkɪŋ oʊnli kɝsɝi noʊɾəs ɪf ðæt. "ju wɝ səpoʊz tə bi bæk baɪ æftɝnun, ən ðə naɪɾ ɪz hæf ɡɔn!"

The light of saidar winked out around Chesmal as she twisted her embroidery frame aside so she could stand. Her stern face made her seem taller than she was, and she was a tall woman. The brightly colored flowers she had embroidered might have been in a garden. "Where have you been?" she demanded. Eldrith stood highest among them, and Moghedien had left her in charge besides, but Chesmal had begun taking only cursory notice if that. "You were supposed to be back by afternoon, and the night is half gone!"

"aɪ lɔs tʃɹæk ə ði aʊɝ, tʃɛzməl," ɛlʒɹɪθ ɹɪplaɪɾ æbsənli, əpɪɹɪŋ lɔst ɪn θɔt. "ɪɾ əz bɪn ə lɔŋ taɪm sɪns aɪ wɑz læst ɪn keɪɛmlɪn. ði ɪnɝ sɪɾi ɪz fæsəneɪɾɪŋ, ən aɪ hæɾ ə dɪlaɪtfəl mil əɾ ən ɪn aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝd. ðoʊ aɪ mʌst seɪ, ðəɹ wɝ fjuɝ sɪstɝz əbaʊt ðɛn. noʊ wʌn ɹɛkəɡnaɪz mi, haʊɛvɝ." ʃi pɪɹɾ əɾ əɹ bɹutʃ əz ðoʊ wʌndɝɪŋ wɛɹ ɪt hæd kʌm fɹʌm, ðən tʌkt ɪɾ ɪndə hɝ bɛl paʊtʃ.

"I lost track of the hour, Chesmal," Eldrith replied absently, appearing lost in thought. "It has been a long time since I was last in Caemlyn. The Inner City is fascinating, and I had a delightful meal at an inn I remembered. Though I must say, there were fewer sisters about then. No one recognized me, however." She peered at her brooch as though wondering where it had come from, then tucked it into her belt pouch.

"ju lɔs tʃɹæk," tʃɛzməl sɛd flætli, lɑsɪŋ əɹ fɪŋɡɝz təɡɛðɝ əɾ əɹ weɪst. pɝhæps tə kip əm fɹəm ɛlʒɹɪθs θɹoʊt. hɝ aɪz ɡlɪɾɝd wɪð æŋɡɝ. "ju lɔs tʃɹæk."

"You lost track," Chesmal said flatly, lacing her fingers together at her waist. Perhaps to keep them from Eldrith's throat. Her eyes glittered with anger. "You lost track."

wʌns mɔɹ ɛlʒɹɪθ blɪŋkt, əz ɪf stɑɹɾəld tə bi ədʒɹɛst. "oʊ. wɝ jə əfɹeɪd kɛnɪt hæd faʊn mi əɡɛn? aɪ əʃʊɹ ju, sɪns sæmɝə aɪ hæv bɪn kwaɪt kɛɹfəl ət kipɪŋ ðə bɑn mæskt."

Once more Eldrith blinked, as if startled to be addressed. "Oh. Were you afraid Kennit had found me again? I assure you, since Samara I have been quite careful at keeping the bond masked."

ət taɪmz, æn wʌndɝd haʊ mʌtʃ ʌv ɛlʒɹɪθs əpɛɹən veɪɡnɪs wɑz ɹil. noʊ wʌn soʊ ʌnəwɛɹ ə ðə wɝld ɝaʊn əɹ cʊɾə sɝvaɪv ðɪs lɔŋ. ɑn ði ʌðɝ hænd, ʃi hæd bɪn ənfoʊkəst ɪnʌf tə lɛt ðə mæskɪŋ slɪp mɔɹ ðən wʌns bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ ɹitʃt sæmɝə, ɪnʌf fəɹ əɹ wɔɹɾɝ tə tʃɹæk hɝ. oʊbiɾiənt tə mɑɡiɾinz ɔɹɾɝz tə əweɪɾ əɹ ɹɪtɝn, ðeɪ hæd hɪɾən θɹu ðə ɹaɪəts æftɝ əɹ dɪpɑɹtʃɝ, weɪɾəd waɪl ðə soʊ-kɔl pɹɑfəts mɑbz swɛp saʊθ ɪndə ɑmɑdɪʃiə, steɪɾ ɪn ðət ɹɛtʃɪd, ɹuən taʊn ivən æftɝ æn bɪkeɪm kənvɪns ðət mɑɡiɾin hæɾ əbændən ðɛm. hɝ lɪp kɝld ət ðə mɛmɹi. wʌt hæd spɑɹk ðə dɪsɪʒən tə liv wɑz ði ɝaɪvəl ʌv ɛlʒɹɪθs kɛnɪɾ ɪn ðə taʊn, ʃʊɹ ðət ʃi wɑz ə mɝɾɝɝ, hæf kənvɪnst ʃi wɑz blæk ədʒɑ, ən dɪtɝmən tə kɪl əɹ noʊ mæɾɝ ðə kɑnsəkwɛnsəz tə hɪmsɛlf. nɑt sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli, ʃi hæd bɪn ənwɪlɪŋ tə feɪs ðoʊz kɑnsəkwɛnsəz hɝsɛlf, ən ɹəfjuz tə lɛɾ ɛniwʌn kɪl ðə mæn. ði oʊnli ɔltɝnəɾɪv wɑz tə fli. ðən əɡɛn, ɛlʒɹɪθ wɑz ðə wʌn u hæd pɔɪntəɾ aʊt keɪɛmlɪn əz ðɛɹ oʊnli hoʊp.

At times, Asne wondered how much of Eldrith's apparent vagueness was real. No one so unaware of the world around her could have survived this long. On the other hand, she had been unfocused enough to let the masking slip more than once before they reached Samara, enough for her Warder to track her. Obedient to Moghedien's orders to await her return, they had hidden through the riots after her departure, waited while the so-called Prophet's mobs swept south into Amadicia, stayed in that wretched, ruined town even after Asne became convinced that Moghedien had abandoned them. Her lip curled at the memory. What had sparked the decision to leave was the arrival of Eldrith's Kennit in the town, sure that she was a murderer, half convinced she was Black Ajah, and determined to kill her no matter the consequences to himself. Not surprisingly, she had been unwilling to face those consequences herself, and refused to let anyone kill the man. The only alternative was to flee. Then again, Eldrith was the one who had pointed out Caemlyn as their only hope.

"dɪd jə lɝn ɛniθɪŋ, ɛlʒɹɪθ?" æn æsk pəlaɪtli. tʃɛzməl wɑz ə ful. haʊɛvɝ tæɾɝd ðə wɝl simd ət ðə moʊmənt, əfɛɹz wəd ɹaɪt ðɛmsɛlvz. wʌn weɪ əɹ ənʌðɝ.

"Did you learn anything, Eldrith?" Asne asked politely. Chesmal was a fool. However tattered the world seemed at the moment, affairs would right themselves. One way or another.

"wʌt? oʊ. oʊnli ðət ðə pɛpɝ sɔs wɑzn əz ɡʊɾ əz aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝd. ʌv kɔɹs, ðət wɑz fɪfti jɪɹz əɡoʊ."

"What? Oh. Only that the pepper sauce wasn't as good as I remembered. Of course, that was fifty years ago."

æn səpɹɛst ə saɪ. pɝhæps æftɝ ɔl ɪt wɑz taɪm fəɹ ɛlʒɹɪθ tə hæv ən æksəɾənt.

Asne suppressed a sigh. Perhaps after all it was time for Eldrith to have an accident.

ðə dɔɹ oʊpən ən təmeɪl slɪpt ɪndə ðə ɹum soʊ saɪlənli ðeɪ wɝ ɔl kɑt baɪ sɝpɹaɪz. ðə dɪmɪnjəɾɪv fɑks-feɪst ɡɹeɪ hæd tɔst ə ɹoʊb ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd wɪð laɪənz oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝz, bʌɾ ɪt ɡeɪp daʊn ðə fɹʌnt, ɪkspoʊzɪŋ ə kɹim-kʌlɝd sɪlk naɪtdʒɹɛs ðət moʊldəɾ ɪtsɛlf tə hɝ ɪndɪsənli. dʒɹeɪpt oʊvɝ wʌn hænd ʃi kæɹiɾ ə bɹeɪslət meɪɾ ə twɪstəd ɡlæs ɹɪŋz. ðeɪ lʊkt ən fɛlt laɪk ɡlæs, ət list, bʌɾ ə hæmɝ kəd nɑɾ əv tʃɪpt wʌn.

The door opened and Temaile slipped into the room so silently they were all caught by surprise. The diminutive fox-faced Gray had tossed a robe embroidered with lions over her shoulders, but it gaped down the front, exposing a cream-colored silk nightdress that molded itself to her indecently. Draped over one hand she carried a bracelet made of twisted glass rings. They looked and felt like glass, at least, but a hammer could not have chipped one.

"juv bɪn tə tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd," ɛlʒɹɪθ sɛd, fɹaʊnɪŋ ət ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil. ʃi dɪd nɑt spik fɔɹsfəli, ðoʊ. ðeɪ wɝ ɔl ə lɪɾəl əfɹeɪɾ ə təmeɪl sɪns mɑɡiɾin hæd meɪɾ əm əbzɝv ðə læst ə liɑnʒɹɪn biɪŋ bɹoʊkən. æn hæd lɔs tʃɹæk ə haʊ ɔfən ʃi hæd kɪld əɹ tɔɹtʃɝɾ ɪn ðə hʌnʒɹəd ən θɝɾi-ɑd jɪɹz sɪns ʃi ɡeɪn ðə ʃɔl, bʌt ʃi hæd sɛldəm sin ɛniwʌn soʊ . . . ɪnθuziæstɪk . . . əz təmeɪl. wɑtʃɪŋ təmeɪl ən tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pɹitɛnd nɑt tə, tʃɛzməl simd ʌnəwɛɹ ðət ʃi wɑz lɪkɪŋ əɹ lɪps nɝvəsli. æn hɝidli pʊɾ əɹ oʊn tʌŋ bæk bɪhaɪn əɹ tiθ ən hoʊp noʊ wʌn hæd noʊɾəst. ɛlʒɹɪθ sɝɾənli hæd nɑt. "wi əɡɹid nɑt tə juz ðoʊz," ʃi sɛd, nɑt vɛɹi fɑɹ ʃɔɹɾ ə pliɾɪŋ. "aɪm sɝɾən ɪt wɑz nɪneɪiv u wundəd mɑɡiɾin, ən ɪf ʃi kən bɛst wʌn ə ðə tʃoʊzən ɪn tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd, wʌt tʃæns də wi hæv?" ɹaʊndɪŋ ɑn ði ʌðɝz, ʃi ətɛmptəɾ ə skoʊldɪŋ toʊn. "dɪd jə tu noʊ əbaʊt ðɪs?" ʃi hæd mænədʒ tə saʊn pivɪʃ.

"You've been to Tel'aran'rhiod," Eldrith said, frowning at the ter'angreal. She did not speak forcefully, though. They were all a little afraid of Temaile since Moghedien had made them observe the last of Liandrin being broken. Asne had lost track of how often she had killed or tortured in the hundred and thirty-odd years since she gained the shawl, but she had seldom seen anyone so . . . enthusiastic . . . as Temaile. Watching Temaile and trying to pretend not to, Chesmal seemed unaware that she was licking her lips nervously. Asne hurriedly put her own tongue back behind her teeth and hoped no one had noticed. Eldrith certainly had not. "We agreed not to use those," she said, not very far short of pleading. "I'm certain it was Nynaeve who wounded Moghedien, and if she can best one of the Chosen in Tel'aran'rhiod, what chance do we have?" Rounding on the others, she attempted a scolding tone. "Did you two know about this?" She had managed to sound peevish.

tʃɛzməl mɛɾ ɛlʒɹɪθs stɛɹ ɪndɪɡnənli, waɪl æn ɡeɪv əɹ sɝpɹaɪzd ɪnəsəns. ðeɪ hæd noʊn, bʌɾ u wɑz gɑnə stæn ɪn təmeɪlz weɪ? ʃi daʊɾɪd vɛɹi mʌtʃ ðəɾ ɛlʒɹɪθ wʊɾə meɪd mɔɹ ðən ə toʊkən pɹoʊɾɛst hæd ʃi bɪn ðɛɹ.

Chesmal met Eldrith's stare indignantly, while Asne gave her surprised innocence. They had known, but who was going to stand in Temaile's way? She doubted very much that Eldrith would have made more than a token protest had she been there.

təmeɪl nu ɪɡzækli hɝ ɪfɛkt ɑn ðɛm. ʃi ʃəɾ əv hʌŋ əɹ hɛɾ əɾ ɛlʒɹɪθs lɛktʃɝ, feɪnthɑɹɾɪd əz ɪt wɑz, ən əpɑlədʒaɪz fəɹ ɡoʊɪŋ əɡɛnst əɹ wɪʃɪz. ɪnstɛd, ʃi smaɪld. ðət smaɪl nɛvɝ ɹitʃt əɹ aɪz, ðoʊ, lɑɹdʒ ən dɑɹk ən mʌtʃ tu bɹaɪt. "ju wɝ ɹaɪt, ɛlʒɹɪθ. ɹaɪt ðəɾ ɪleɪn wəd kʌm hɪɹ, ən ɹaɪt ðət nɪneɪiv wəd kʌm wɪð hɝ, ɪt simz. ðeɪ wɝ təɡɛðɝ, ən ɪts klɪɹ ðeɪ ɑɹ boʊθ ɪn ðə pæləs."

Temaile knew exactly her effect on them. She should have hung her head at Eldrith's lecture, fainthearted as it was, and apologized for going against her wishes. Instead, she smiled. That smile never reached her eyes, though, large and dark and much too bright. "You were right, Eldrith. Right that Elayne would come here, and right that Nynaeve would come with her, it seems. They were together, and it is clear they are both in the Palace."

"jɛs," ɛlʒɹɪθ sɛd, skwɝmɪŋ slaɪtli ʌndɝ təmeɪlz ɡeɪz. "wɛl." ən ʃi lɪkt əɹ lɪps, ən ʃɪftəɾ əɹ fit, tu. "ivən soʊ, əntɪl wi kən si haʊ tə ɡɛɾ əɾ əm pæst ɔl ðoʊz waɪldɝz - "

"Yes," Eldrith said, squirming slightly under Temaile's gaze. "Well." And she licked her lips, and shifted her feet, too. "Even so, until we can see how to get at them past all those wilders - "

"ðeɪ ɑɹ waɪldɝz, ɛlʒɹɪθ." təmeɪl θɹu hɝsɛlf daʊn ɪn ə tʃɛɹ, lɪmz spɹɔlɪŋ kɛɹləsli, ən əɹ toʊn hɑɹɾənd. nɑɾ ɪnʌf tə sim kəmændɪŋ, bʌt stɪl mɔɹ ðən mɪɹli fɝm. "ðɛɹ ɑɹ oʊnli θɹi sɪstɝz tə tʃɹʌbəl ʌs, ən wi kən dɪspoʊz ə ðɛm. wi kən teɪk nɪneɪiv, ən pɝhæps ɪleɪn ɪn ðə bɑɹɡən." əbɹʌpli ʃi lin fɔɹwɝd, hænz ɑn ði ɑɹmz ə ðə tʃɛɹ. dɪsɹeɪd kloʊðɪŋ əɹ nɑt, ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ʃɹɛɾ ʌv ɪndələns əbaʊɾ əɹ naʊ. ɛlʒɹɪθ stɛp bæk əz ðoʊ pʊʃt baɪ təmeɪlz aɪz. "ɛls waɪ ɑɹ wi hɪɹ, ɛlʒɹɪθ? ɪts wʌt wi keɪm fɔɹ."

"They are wilders, Eldrith." Temaile threw herself down in a chair, limbs sprawling carelessly, and her tone hardened. Not enough to seem commanding, but still more than merely firm. "There are only three sisters to trouble us, and we can dispose of them. We can take Nynaeve, and perhaps Elayne in the bargain." Abruptly she leaned forward, hands on the arms of the chair. Disarrayed clothing or not, there was no shred of indolence about her now. Eldrith stepped back as though pushed by Temaile's eyes. "Else why are we here, Eldrith? It is what we came for."

noʊ wʌn hæɾ ɛniθɪŋ tə seɪ tə ðæt. bɪhaɪn əm leɪ ə stʃɹɪŋ ə feɪljɝz - ɪn tiɹ, ɪn tæntʃəkoʊ - ðət maɪt wɛl kɑst əm ðɛɹ laɪvz wən ðə səpɹim kaʊnsəl leɪd hænz ɑn ðɛm. bʌt nɑɾ ɪf ðeɪ hæd wʌn ə ðə tʃoʊzən fəɹ ə peɪtʃɹən, ən ɪf mɑɡiɾin hæd wɑntəd nɪneɪiv soʊ bædli, pɝhæps ənʌðɝ ə ðɛm wʊd, tu. ðə ɹil dɪfəkəlti wəd bi faɪndɪŋ wʌn ə ðə tʃoʊzən tə pɹizɛnt wɪð ðɛɹ ɡɪft. noʊ wʌn bʌɾ æn sim tə hæv kənsɪɾɝd ðət pɑɹɾ ʌv ɪt.

No one had anything to say to that. Behind them lay a string of failures - in Tear, in Tanchico - that might well cost them their lives when the Supreme Council laid hands on them. But not if they had one of the Chosen for a patron, and if Moghedien had wanted Nynaeve so badly, perhaps another of them would, too. The real difficulty would be finding one of the Chosen to present with their gift. No one but Asne seemed to have considered that part of it.

"ðɛɹ wɝ ʌðɝz, ðɛɹ," təmeɪl wɛn ɑn, linɪŋ bæk wʌns mɔɹ. ʃi saʊndəɾ ɔlmoʊs bɔɹd. "spaɪɪŋ ɑn əɹ tu æksɛptɪd. ə mæn u lɛɾ əm si hɪm, ən sʌmwʌn ɛls aɪ kəd nɑt si." ʃi paʊɾɪd ɪɹɪɾəbli. ət list, ɪt wʊɾə bɪn ə paʊɾ ɪksɛp fəɹ əɹ aɪz. "aɪ hæd tə steɪ bɪhaɪn ə kɑləm soʊ ðə ɡɝlz wəd nɑt si mi. ðət ʃəd pliz ju, ɛlʒɹɪθ. ðət ðeɪ dɪd nɑt si mi. ɑɹ jə plizd?"

"There were others, there," Temaile went on, leaning back once more. She sounded almost bored. "Spying on our two Accepted. A man who let them see him, and someone else I could not see." She pouted irritably. At least, it would have been a pout except for her eyes. "I had to stay behind a column so the girls would not see me. That should please you, Eldrith. That they did not see me. Are you pleased?"

ɛlʒɹɪθ ɔlmoʊst stæmɝd ɡɛɾɪŋ aʊt haʊ plizd ʃi wɑz.

Eldrith almost stammered getting out how pleased she was.

æn lɛt hɝsɛlf fil əɹ fɔɹ wɔɹɾɝz, kʌmɪŋ ɛvɝ kloʊsɝ. ʃi hæd stɑp mæskɪŋ hɝsɛlf wən ðeɪ lɛf sæmɝə. oʊnli paʊl wɑz ə fɹɛn ə ðə dɑɹk, ʌv kɔɹs, jɛt ði ʌðɝz wəd də wʌtɛvɝ ʃi sɛd, bɪliv wʌtɛvɝ ʃi toʊl ðɛm. ɪt wəd bi nɛsəsɛɹi tə kip əm kənsil fɹəm ði ʌðɝz ənlɛs æbsəlutli nɛsəsɛɹi, bʌt ʃi wɑntəɾ ɑɹmd mɛn kloʊs ət hænd. mʌsəlz ən stil wɝ vɛɹi jusfəl. ən ɪf wɝs keɪm tə wɝst, ʃi kəɾ ɔlweɪz ɹɪvil ðə lɔŋ, fluɾəd ɹɑd ðət mɑɡiɾin hæd nɑt hɪɾən soʊ wɛl əz ʃi θɔt ʃi hæd.

Asne let herself feel her four Warders, coming ever closer. She had stopped masking herself when they left Samara. Only Powl was a Friend of the Dark, of course, yet the others would do whatever she said, believe whatever she told them. It would be necessary to keep them concealed from the others unless absolutely necessary, but she wanted armed men close at hand. Muscles and steel were very useful. And if worse came to worst, she could always reveal the long, fluted rod that Moghedien had not hidden so well as she thought she had.

ði ɝli mɔɹnɪŋ laɪɾ ɪn ðə sɪɾɪŋ ɹumz wɪndoʊz wɑz ɡɹeɪ, ən ɝliɝ aʊɝ ðən ðə leɪɾi ʃieɪn juʒəwəli ɹoʊz, bʌt ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ ʃi hæd bɪn dʒɹɛst waɪl ɪt wɑz stɪl fʊl dɑɹk. ðə leɪɾi ʃieɪn wɑz haʊ ʃi θɔɾ ə hɝsɛlf, naʊ. mili skeɪn, ðə sæɾəlɝz dɔɾɝ, wɑz ɔlmoʊs kəmplitli fɝɡɑɾən. ɪn ɛvɹi weɪ ðət mæɾɝd, ʃi ɹɪli wɑz ðə leɪɾi ʃieɪn əvɑɹhən, ən hæd bɪn fəɹ jɪɹz. lɔɹd wɪlɪm əvɑɹhən hæd bɪn ɪmpɑvɹɪʃt, ɹədus tə lɪvɪŋ ɪn ə ɹæmʃækəl fɑɹmhaʊs ən əneɪbəl tə kip ivən ðəɾ ɪn ɡʊd ɹɪpɛɹ. hi ən ɪz oʊnli dɔɾɝ, ðə læst ʌv ə dɪklaɪnɪŋ laɪn, hæd steɪɾ ɪn ðə kʌntʃɹi, fɑɹ fɹəm ɛniwɛɹ ðɛɹ pɪnɹi maɪt bi ɪkspoʊzd, ən naʊ ðeɪ wɝ oʊnli boʊnz bɛɹiɾ ɪn ðə fɔɹəs nɪɹ ðət fɑɹmhaʊs, ən ʃi wɑz ðə leɪɾi ʃieɪn, ən ɪf ðɪs tɔl, wɛl-əpɔɪntəd stoʊn haʊs wɑz nɑɾ ə mænɝ, ɪt stɪl hæd bɪn ðə pɹɑpɝɾi ʌv ə wɛl-tə-du mɝtʃənt. ʃi wɑz lɔŋ dɛd, tu, æftɝ saɪnɪŋ oʊvɝ əɹ ɡoʊl tə hɝ "ɛɹ." ðə fɝnɪʃɪŋz wɝ wɛl meɪd, ðə kɑɹpəts kɑsli, ðə tæpəstʃɹiz ən ivən ðə sit kʊʃənz ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd wɪð θɹɛd-ʌv-ɡoʊld, ən ðə faɪɝ ɹɔɹɾ ɪn ə waɪd blu-veɪn mɑɹbəl faɪɝpleɪs. ʃi hæd hæd ðə wʌns-pleɪn lɪntəl kɑɹvd wɪð əvɑɹhənz hɑɹɾ ən hæn ɹoʊ ɑn ɹoʊ.

The early morning light in the sitting room's windows was gray, an earlier hour than the Lady Shiaine usually rose, but this morning she had been dressed while it was still full dark. The Lady Shiaine was how she thought of herself, now. Mili Skane, the saddler's daughter, was almost completely forgotten. In every way that mattered, she really was the Lady Shiaine Avarhin, and had been for years. Lord Willim Avarhin had been impoverished, reduced to living in a ramshackle farmhouse and unable to keep even that in good repair. He and his only daughter, the last of a declining line, had stayed in the country, far from anywhere their penury might be exposed, and now they were only bones buried in the forest near that farmhouse, and she was the Lady Shiaine, and if this tall, well-appointed stone house was not a manor, it still had been the property of a well-to-do merchant. She was long dead, too, after signing over her gold to her "heir." The furnishings were well made, the carpets costly, the tapestries and even the seat cushions embroidered with thread-of-gold, and the fire roared in a wide blue-veined marble fireplace. She had had the once-plain lintel carved with Avarhin's Heart and Hand row on row.

"mɔɹ waɪn, ɡɝl," ʃi sɛd kɝtli, ən fæljən skɝid wɪð ðə tɔl-nɛk sɪlvɝ pɪtʃɝ tə ɹifɪl əɹ ɡɑblət wɪð stimɪŋ spaɪst waɪn. ðə lɪvɝi ʌv ə meɪd, wɪð ðə ɹɛd hɑɹɾ ən ɡoʊldən hæn ɑn əɹ bɹɛst, suɾəd fæljən. hɝ lɔŋ feɪs wɑz ə stɪf mæsk əz ʃi hɝid tə ɹipleɪs ðə pɪtʃɝ ɑn ðə dʒɹɔɝd haɪtʃəst ən teɪk ʌp əɹ pleɪs bɪsaɪd ðə dɔɹ.

"More wine, girl," she said curtly, and Falion scurried with the tall-necked silver pitcher to refill her goblet with steaming spiced wine. The livery of a maid, with the Red Heart and Golden Hand on her breast, suited Falion. Her long face was a stiff mask as she hurried to replace the pitcher on the drawered highchest and take up her place beside the door.

"ju pleɪ ə deɪnʒɝəs ɡeɪm," mɑɹilɪn ɡəmɑlfɪn sɛd, ɹoʊlɪŋ əɹ oʊn ɡɑblət bɪtwin əɹ pɑmz. ə skɪni wʊmən wɪð laɪfləs peɪl bɹaʊn hɛɹ, ðə bɹaʊn sɪstɝ dɪd nɑt lʊk ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. hɝ nɛɹoʊ feɪs ən waɪd noʊz wʊɾə fɪɾəd bɛɾɝ əbʌv fæljənz lɪvɝi ðən ɪt dɪɾ əbʌv əɹ faɪn blu wʊl, ən ðət wɑz suɾəbəl oʊnli fəɹ ə mɪɾəlɪŋ mɝtʃənt. "ʃi ɪz ʃildɪd sʌmhaʊ, aɪ noʊ, bʌt wən ʃi kən tʃænəl əɡɛn, ʃɪl meɪk jə haʊl fəɹ ðɪs." hɝ θɪn lɪps kwɝkt ɪn ə hjumɝləs smaɪl. "ju meɪ faɪn jɝsɛlf wɪʃɪŋ jə kəd haʊl."

"You play a dangerous game," Marillin Gemalphin said, rolling her own goblet between her palms. A skinny woman with lifeless pale brown hair, the Brown sister did not look an Aes Sedai. Her narrow face and wide nose would have fitted better above Falion's livery than it did above her fine blue wool, and that was suitable only for a middling merchant. "She is shielded somehow, I know, but when she can channel again, she will make you howl for this." Her thin lips quirked in a humorless smile. "You may find yourself wishing you could howl."

"mɔɹaɪɾɪn tʃoʊz ðɪs fəɹ hɝ," ʃieɪn ɹɪplaɪd. "ʃi feɪld ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ, ən i ɔɹɾɝd əɹ pʌnɪʃt. aɪ doʊnt noʊ ðə dɪteɪlz ən doʊnt wɑn tə, bʌɾ ɪf mɔɹaɪɾɪn wɑns əɹ noʊz ɡɹaʊn ɪn ðə mʌd, əl pʊʃ ɪt soʊ dip ʃiz bɹiðɪŋ mʌɾ ə jɪɹ fɹəm naʊ. əɹ dʒju sədʒɛst aɪ dɪsəbeɪ wʌn ə ðə tʃoʊzən?" ʃi bɛɹli səpɹɛst ə ʃʌɾɝ ət ðə vɛɹi θɔt. mɑɹilɪn tʃɹaɪd tə haɪɾ əɹ ɪkspɹɛʃən ɪn dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ, bʌɾ əɹ aɪz taɪɾənd. "wʌɾ əbaʊt ju, fæljən?" ʃieɪn æskt. "wʊd jə laɪk mi tə æsk mɔɹaɪɾɪn tə teɪk jə əweɪ? hi maɪt faɪn jə sʌmθɪŋ lɛs oʊnɝəs." mjulz maɪt sɪŋ laɪk naɪɾɪŋɡəlz, tu.

"Moridin chose this for her," Shiaine replied. "She failed in Ebou Dar, and he ordered her punished. I don't know the details and don't want to, but if Moridin wants her nose ground in the mud, I'll push it so deep she is breathing mud a year from now. Or do you suggest I disobey one of the Chosen?" She barely suppressed a shudder at the very thought. Marillin tried to hide her expression in drinking, but her eyes tightened. "What about you, Falion?" Shiaine asked. "Would you like me to ask Moridin to take you away? He might find you something less onerous." Mules might sing like nightingales, too.

fæljən dɪd nɑɾ ivən hɛzəteɪt. ʃi bɑbd ə meɪdz stʃɹeɪt-bækt kɝtsi, hɝ feɪs ɡoʊɪŋ ivən pəlɝ ðən ɪɾ ɔlɹɛɾi wɑz. "noʊ, mɪstʃɹəs," ʃi sɛd heɪstəli. "aɪ æm kəntɛnt wɪð maɪ sɪtʃueɪʃən, mɪstʃɹəs."

Falion did not even hesitate. She bobbed a maid's straight-backed curtsy, her face going even paler than it already was. "No, mistress," she said hastily. "I am content with my situation, mistress."

"ju si?" ʃieɪn sɛd tə ði ʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ. ʃi daʊɾɪd vɛɹi mʌtʃ ðət fæljən wɑz ɛniθɪŋ əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ kɑntɛnt, bʌt ðə wʊmən wəɾ æksɛpt wʌtɛvɝ wɑz hændəɾ aʊt ɹæðɝ ðən feɪs mɔɹaɪɾɪnz dɪsplɛʒɝ dɝɛkli. fəɹ ðə seɪm ɹizən, ʃieɪn wəd ɹul əɹ wɪð ə vɛɹi hɛvi hænd. jə nɛvɝ nu wʌt wʌn ə ðə tʃoʊzən maɪt lɝn ʌv, ən teɪk əmɪs. ʃi hɝsɛlf θɔɾ əɹ oʊn feɪljɝ wɑz bɛɹid dip, bʌt ʃi wəd teɪk noʊ tʃænsəz. "wɛn ʃi kən tʃænəl əɡɛn, ʃi woʊn əv tə bi ə meɪɾ ɔl ðə taɪm, mɑɹilɪn." ɛniweɪ, mɔɹaɪɾɪn hæd sɛd ʃieɪn kəd kɪl əɹ ɪf ʃi wɪʃt. ðəɹ wɑz ɔlweɪz ðæt, ɪf əɹ pəzɪʃən bɪɡæn tə tʃeɪf tu mʌtʃ. hi hæd sɛd ʃi kəd kɪl boʊθ sɪstɝz, ɪf ʃi wɪʃt.

"You see?" Shiaine said to the other Aes Sedai. She doubted very much that Falion was anything approaching content, but the woman would accept whatever was handed out rather than face Moridin's displeasure directly. For the same reason, Shiaine would rule her with a very heavy hand. You never knew what one of the Chosen might learn of, and take amiss. She herself thought her own failure was buried deep, but she would take no chances. "When she can channel again, she won't have to be a maid all the time, Marillin." Anyway, Moridin had said Shiaine could kill her if she wished. There was always that, if her position began to chafe too much. He had said she could kill both sisters, if she wished.

"ðæts əz meɪ bi," mɑɹilɪn sɛd dɑɹkli. ʃi kæst ə saɪɾɛlɔŋ ɡlæns ət fæljən ən ɡɹɪməst. "naʊ, mɑɡiɾin ɪnstʃɹʌktəd mi tə ɔfɝ jə wʌɾ əsɪstəns aɪ θɔɾ aɪ kəd ɡɪv, bʌɾ əl tɛl jə ɹaɪt naʊ, aɪ woʊn ɛntɝ ðə ɹɔɪəl pæləs. ðə hoʊl sɪɾi hæz tu mɛni sɪstɝz ɪn ɪt fəɹ maɪ teɪst, bʌt ðə pæləs ɪz stʌft wɪð waɪldɝz ɑn tɑp. aɪ wʊdnt ɡɛt tɛn fit wɪθaʊt sʌmwʌn noʊɪŋ aɪ wɑz ðɛɹ."

"That's as may be," Marillin said darkly. She cast a sidelong glance at Falion and grimaced. "Now, Moghedien instructed me to offer you what assistance I thought I could give, but I'll tell you right now, I won't enter the Royal Palace. The whole city has too many sisters in it for my taste, but the Palace is stuffed with wilders on top. I wouldn't get ten feet without someone knowing I was there."

saɪɪŋ, ʃieɪn lin bæk ən kɹɔst əɹ lɛɡz, aɪdli kɪkɪŋ ə slɪpɝd fʊt. waɪ dɪd pipəl ɔlweɪz θɪŋk jə dɪd nɑt noʊ əz mʌtʃ əz ðeɪ? ðə wɝld wɑz fʊl ə fulz! "mɑɡiɾin ɔɹɾɝd jə tə oʊbeɪ mi, mɑɹilɪn. aɪ noʊ, kəz mɔɹaɪɾɪn toʊl mi. hi dɪd nɑt seɪ soʊ ɹaɪɾ aʊt, bʌɾ aɪ θɪŋk wən i snæps ɪz fɪŋɡɝz, mɑɡiɾin dʒʌmps." tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt ðə tʃoʊzən ðɪs weɪ wɑz deɪnʒɝəs, bʌt ʃi hæd tə meɪk mæɾɝz klɪɹ. "du jə wɑnə tɛl mi əɡɛn wʌt jə woʊn du?"

Sighing, Shiaine leaned back and crossed her legs, idly kicking a slippered foot. Why did people always think you did not know as much as they? The world was full of fools! "Moghedien ordered you to obey me, Marillin. I know, because Moridin told me. He did not say so right out, but I think when he snaps his fingers, Moghedien jumps." Talking about the Chosen this way was dangerous, but she had to make matters clear. "Do you want to tell me again what you won't do?"

ðə nɛɹoʊ-feɪst ɛɛs sədaɪ lɪkt əɹ lɪps, dɑɹɾɪŋ ənʌðɝ ɡlæns ət fæljən. dɪd ðə wʊmən fɪɹ ʃi wəɾ ɛn ʌp ðət weɪ? tʃɹuθ tə tɛl, ʃieɪn wʊɾə tʃɹeɪɾɪd fæljən fəɹ ə pɹɑpɝ leɪɾiz meɪɾ ɪn ə hɑɹtbit. wɛl, əz lɔŋ əz ʃi kəd ɹɪteɪn əɹ ʌðɝ sɝvəsəz. vɛɹi laɪkli, ðeɪ boʊθ wəɾ əv tə daɪ wən ðɪs wɑz fɪnɪʃt. ʃieɪn dɪd nɑt laɪk livɪŋ lus ɛnz.

The narrow-faced Aes Sedai licked her lips, darting another glance at Falion. Did the woman fear she would end up that way? Truth to tell, Shiaine would have traded Falion for a proper lady's maid in a heartbeat. Well, as long as she could retain her other services. Very likely, they both would have to die when this was finished. Shiaine did not like leaving loose ends.

"aɪ wɑzn laɪɪŋ əbaʊt ðæt," mɑɹilɪn sɛd sloʊli. "aɪ ɹɪli wʊdnt ɡɛt tɛn fit. bʌt ðɛɹz ə wʊmən ɔlɹɛɾi ɪn ðə pæləs. ʃi kən də wʌt jə nid. ɪt meɪ teɪk taɪm tə meɪk kɑntækt, ðoʊ."

"I wasn't lying about that," Marillin said slowly. "I really wouldn't get ten feet. But there's a woman already in the Palace. She can do what you need. It may take time to make contact, though."

"dʒʌs meɪk ʃʊɹ ɪts nɑt tu lɔŋ ə taɪm, mɑɹilɪn." soʊ. wʌn ə ðə sɪstɝz ɪn ðə pæləs wɑz blæk ədʒɑ, wɑz ʃi? ʃi wəɾ əv tə bi ɛɛs sədaɪ, nɑt dʒʌst ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd, tə də wʌt ʃieɪn niɾəd.

"Just make sure it's not too long a time, Marillin." So. One of the sisters in the Palace was Black Ajah, was she? She would have to be Aes Sedai, not just a Darkfriend, to do what Shiaine needed.

ðə dɔɹ oʊpənd, ən mɹɛlɪn lʊkt ɪn kwɛstʃənɪŋli, hɪz hɛvəli mʌsəl bʌlk ɔlmoʊs fɪlɪŋ ðə dɔɹweɪ. bɪɑn hɪm, ʃi kəd meɪk aʊɾ ənʌðɝ mæn. əɾ əɹ nɑd, mɹɛlɪn stɛpt əsaɪɾ ən moʊʃən dɑv hænlən tə ɛntɝ, kloʊzɪŋ ðə dɔɹ bɪhaɪn hɪm. hænlən wɑz swɑðd ɪn ə dɑɹk kloʊk, bʌɾ i sneɪkt aʊt wʌn hæn tə kʌp fæljənz bɑɾəm θɹu hɝ dʒɹɛs. ʃi ɡlɛɹɾ əɾ ɪm bɪɾɝli, bʌt dɪd nɑt muv əweɪ. hænlən wɑz pɑɹɾ ə hɝ pʌnɪʃmənt. stɪl, ʃieɪn hæd noʊ wɪʃ tə wɑtʃ ɪm fɑndəl ðə wʊmən.

The door opened, and Murellin looked in questioningly, his heavily muscled bulk almost filling the doorway. Beyond him, she could make out another man. At her nod, Murellin stepped aside and motioned Daved Hanlon to enter, closing the door behind him. Hanlon was swathed in a dark cloak, but he snaked out one hand to cup Falion's bottom through her dress. She glared at him bitterly, but did not move away. Hanlon was part of her punishment. Still, Shiaine had no wish to watch him fondle the woman.

"du ðət leɪɾɝ," ʃi ɔɹɾɝd. "dɪɾ ɪt ɡoʊ wɛl?"

"Do that later," she ordered. "Did it go well?"

ə bɹɔd smaɪl splɪɾ ɪz æks-laɪk feɪs. "ɪt wɛn ɪɡzækli əz aɪ plæn ɪt, ʌv kɔɹs." hi θɹu wʌn saɪɾ ə ðə dɑɹk kloʊk oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ, ɹɪvilɪŋ ɡoʊldən nɑts ə ɹæŋk ɑn ɪz ɹɛd koʊt. "ju ɑɹ spikɪŋ tə ðə kæptən ə ðə kwinz bɑɾiɡɑɹd."

A broad smile split his axe-like face. "It went exactly as I planned it, of course." He threw one side of the dark cloak over his shoulder, revealing golden knots of rank on his red coat. "You are speaking to the Captain of the Queen's Bodyguard."


tʃæptɝ ɪlɛvən


CHAPTER 11

aɪdiəz ʌv ɪmpɔɹɾəns


Ideas of Importance

wɪθaʊɾ ivən teɪkɪŋ ə lʊk, ɹænd stɛp θɹu ðə ɡeɪtweɪ ɪndə ə lɑɹdʒ dɑɹk ɹum. ðə stʃɹeɪn ə hoʊldɪŋ ðə wiv, ʌv faɪɾɪŋ seɪɾɪn, meɪɾ ɪm sweɪ; hi wɑntəd tə ɡæɡ, tə dʌbəl oʊvɝ ən spju ʌp ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɪn hɪm. hoʊldɪŋ hɪmsɛlf əpɹaɪt wɑz ən ɛfɝt. ə lɪɾəl laɪt kɹɛp θɹu kɹæks bɪtwin ðə ʃʌɾɝz ɑn ə fju smɔl wɪndoʊz sɛt haɪ ɪn wʌn wɔl, dʒʌst ɪnʌf tə si baɪ wɪð ðə paʊɝ ɪn hɪm. fɝnɪtʃɝ ən lɑɹdʒ klɔθ-kʌvɝd ʃeɪps nɪɹli fɪl ðə ɹum, ɪntɝspɝst wɪð waɪd bæɹəlz ə ðə sɔɹt juz tə stɔɹ kɹɑkɝi, tʃɛsts ʌv ɔl ʃeɪps ən saɪzəz, bɑksəz ən kɹeɪts ən nɪknæks. lɪɾəl mɔɹ ðən wɔkweɪz ə peɪs əɹ tu waɪd ɹɪmeɪn klɪɹ. hi hæd bɪn ʃʊɹ i wəd nɑt faɪn sɝvəns hʌntɪŋ fəɹ sʌmθɪŋ, əɹ klinɪŋ ʌp. ðə haɪəs flɔɹ ə ðə ɹɔɪəl pæləs hæd sɛvɹəl sətʃ stɔɹɹumz, lʊkɪŋ laɪk ði æɾɪks ə hjudʒ fɑɹmhaʊsəz ən dʒʌst əbaʊt fɝɡɑɾən. bɪsaɪdz, hi wɑz tɑvɝən, æftɝ ɔl. ə ɡʊd θɪŋ noʊ wʌn hæd bɪn ðəɹ wən ðə ɡeɪtweɪ oʊpənd. wʌn ɛdʒ ʌv ɪt hæd slaɪs ðə kɔɹnɝ ɔf ən ɛmpti tʃɛs baʊn ɪn kɹækt, ɹɑɾɪŋ lɛðɝ, ən ði ʌðɝ hæd teɪkən ə ɡlæs-smuð ʃeɪvɪŋ daʊn ðə lɛŋθ ʌv ə lɔŋ, ɪnleɪd teɪbəl stækt wɪð veɪsəz ən wʊɾən bɑksəz. meɪbi səm kwin ʌv ændɝ hæɾ iɾən ət ðət teɪbəl, ə sɛntʃɝi əɹ tu ɡɔn.

Without even taking a look, Rand stepped through the gateway into a large dark room. The strain of holding the weave, of fighting saidin, made him sway; he wanted to gag, to double over and spew up everything in him. Holding himself upright was an effort. A little light crept through cracks between the shutters on a few small windows set high in one wall, just enough to see by with the Power in him. Furniture and large cloth-covered shapes nearly filled the room, interspersed with wide barrels of the sort used to store crockery, chests of all shapes and sizes, boxes and crates and knickknacks. Little more than walkways a pace or two wide remained clear. He had been sure he would not find servants hunting for something, or cleaning up. The highest floor of the Royal Palace had several such storerooms, looking like the attics of huge farmhouses and just about forgotten. Besides, he was ta'veren, after all. A good thing no one had been there when the gateway opened. One edge of it had sliced the corner off an empty chest bound in cracked, rotting leather, and the other had taken a glass-smooth shaving down the length of a long, inlaid table stacked with vases and wooden boxes. Maybe some Queen of Andor had eaten at that table, a century or two gone.

ə sɛntʃɝi əɹ tu, luz θɝɪn læf θɪkli ɪn ɪz hɛd. ə vɛɹi lɔŋ taɪm. fəɹ ðə lʌv ə ðə laɪt, lɛt ɡoʊ! ðɪs ɪz ðə pɪɾ ə dum! ðə vɔɪs dwɪndəld əz ðə mæn flɛɾ ɪndə ðə ɹisɛsəz ə ɹændz maɪnd.

A century or two, Lews Therin laughed thickly in his head. A very long time. For the love of the Light, let go! This is the Pit of Doom! The voice dwindled as the man fled into the recesses of Rand's mind.

fəɹ wʌns, hi hæɾ ɪz oʊn ɹizənz tə lɪsən tə luz θɝɪnz kəmpleɪns. heɪstəli hi moʊʃən mɪn tə fɑloʊ hɪm fɹəm ðə fɔɹəs klɪɹɪŋ ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə ɡeɪtweɪ, ən əz sun əz ʃi dɪd, hi lɛɾ ɪt kloʊs bɪhaɪn əɹ ɪn ə kwɪk vɝɾɪkəl slæʃ ə laɪt baɪ ɹilisɪŋ seɪɾɪn. blɛsədli, ðə nɔziə wɛnt wɪð ɪt. hɪz hɛd stɪl spʌn ə lɪɾəl, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt fil əz ɪf i wɝ gɑnə vɑməɾ əɹ fɔl oʊvɝ əɹ boʊθ. ðə fil ə fɪlθ ɹɪmeɪnd, ðoʊ, ðə dɑɹk wʌnz teɪn uzɪŋ ɪndə hɪm fɹəm ðə wivz i hæd taɪɾ ɔf ɝaʊn hɪmsɛlf. ʃɪftɪŋ ðə stʃɹæp ə hɪz lɛðɝ skɹɪp fɹəm wʌn ʃoʊldɝ tə ði ʌðɝ, hi tʃɹaɪd tə juz ðə moʊʃən tə haɪd waɪpɪŋ swɛt fɹəm ɪz feɪs wɪð ɪz sliv. hi dɪd nɑɾ əv tə wɝi əbaʊt mɪn noʊɾɪsɪŋ æftɝ ɔl, haʊɛvɝ.

For once, he had his own reasons to listen to Lews Therin's complaints. Hastily he motioned Min to follow him from the forest clearing on the other side of the gateway, and as soon as she did, he let it close behind her in a quick vertical slash of light by releasing saidin. Blessedly, the nausea went with it. His head still spun a little, but he did not feel as if he were going to vomit or fall over or both. The feel of filth remained, though, the Dark One's taint oozing into him from the weaves he had tied off around himself. Shifting the strap of his leather scrip from one shoulder to the other, he tried to use the motion to hide wiping sweat from his face with his sleeve. He did not have to worry about Min noticing after all, however.

hɝ blu, hil buts stɝd ðə dʌst ɑn ðə flɔɹ əɾ əɹ fɝst stɛp, ən əɹ sɛkən meɪɾ ɪt ɹaɪz. ʃi pʊld ə leɪs-ɛdʒ hæŋkɝtʃɪf fɹəm əɹ koʊtsliv dʒʌst ɪn taɪm tə kætʃ ə vaɪələn sniz, fɑloʊd baɪ ə sɛkən ən θɝd, itʃ wɝs ðən ðə læst. hi wɪʃt ʃi hæd bɪn wɪlɪŋ tə steɪ ɪn ə dʒɹɛs. ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd waɪt flaʊɝz dɛkɝeɪɾəd ðə slivz ən ləpɛlz ə hɝ blu koʊt, ən pəlɝ blu bɹitʃɪz moʊldəɾ əɹ lɛɡz snʌɡli. wɪð jɛloʊ-ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd bɹaɪt blu ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɡlʌvz tʌk bɪhaɪn əɹ bɛlt, ən ə kloʊk ɛdʒd wɪð jɛloʊ skɹɑlwɝk ən hɛl baɪ ə ɡoʊldən pɪn ɪn ðə ʃeɪp ʌv ə ɹoʊz, ʃi dɪd lʊk əz ɪf ʃi hæɾ ɝaɪv baɪ mɔɹ nɔɹməl minz, bʌt ʃi wəd dʒɹɔ ɛvɹi aɪ. hi wɑz ɪn kɔɹs bɹaʊn wʊlənz ɛni leɪbɝɝ maɪt wɛɹ. moʊs pleɪsəz ɪn ðə læs fju deɪz, hi hæd bɪn bleɪɾənt wɪð ɪz pɹɛzəns; ðɪs taɪm i dɪd nɑt wɑn dʒʌs tə bi ɡɔn bɪfɔɹ ɛniwʌn nu hi hæd bɪn hɪɹ, hi dɪd nɑt wɑn ɛniwʌn bʌɾ ə spɛʃəl fju tə ɛvɝ noʊ hi hæd bɪn.

Her blue, heeled boots stirred the dust on the floor at her first step, and her second made it rise. She pulled a lace-edged handkerchief from her coatsleeve just in time to catch a violent sneeze, followed by a second and third, each worse than the last. He wished she had been willing to stay in a dress. Embroidered white flowers decorated the sleeves and lapels of her blue coat, and paler blue breeches molded her legs snugly. With yellow-embroidered bright blue riding gloves tucked behind her belt, and a cloak edged with yellow scrollwork and held by a golden pin in the shape of a rose, she did look as if she had arrived by more normal means, but she would draw every eye. He was in coarse brown woolens any laborer might wear. Most places in the last few days, he had been blatant with his presence; this time he did not want just to be gone before anyone knew he had been here, he did not want anyone but a special few to ever know he had been.

"waɪ ɑɹ jə ɡɹɪnɪŋ ət mi ən θʌmɪŋ jəɹ ɪɹ laɪk ə lubi?" ʃi dɪmændəd, stʌfɪŋ ðə hæŋkɝtʃɪf bæk ɪndə hɝ sliv. səspɪʃən fɪld əɹ bɪɡ, dɑɹk aɪz.

"Why are you grinning at me and thumbing your ear like a loobie?" she demanded, stuffing the handkerchief back into her sleeve. Suspicion filled her big, dark eyes.

"aɪ wɑz dʒʌs θɪŋkɪŋ haʊ bjuɾəfəl jə ɑɹ," hi sɛd kwaɪətli. ʃi wɑz. hi kəd nɑt lʊk əɾ əɹ wɪθaʊt θɪŋkɪŋ soʊ. əɹ wɪθaʊt ɹɪɡɹɛɾɪŋ ðəɾ i wɑz tu wik tə sɛn əɹ əweɪ tə seɪfti.

"I was just thinking how beautiful you are," he said quietly. She was. He could not look at her without thinking so. Or without regretting that he was too weak to send her away to safety.

ʃi dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ, ən sniz bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəɾ ivən klæp ə hæn oʊvɝ əɹ maʊθ, ðən ɡlɛɹɾ əɾ ɪm əz ɪf ɪt wɝ sʌmhaʊ hɪz fɔlt. "aɪ əbændən maɪ hɔɹs fəɹ ju, ɹænd ælθɹ. aɪ kɝl maɪ hɛɹ fəɹ ju. aɪ ɡeɪv ʌp maɪ laɪf fəɹ ju! əl nɑt ɡɪv ʌp maɪ koʊɾ ən bɹitʃɪz! bɪsaɪdz, noʊ wʌn hɪɹ əz ɛvɝ sin mi ɪn ə dʒɹɛs fəɹ mɔɹ taɪm ðən ɪt tʊk mi tə tʃeɪnʒ aʊɾ ʌv ɪt. jə noʊ ðɪs woʊnt wɝk ənlɛs aɪm ɹɛkəɡnaɪzd. jə sɝɾənli kæn pɹitɛn jə wɑndɝɾ ɪn ɔf ðə stʃɹit wɪð ðət feɪs."

She drew a deep breath, and sneezed before she could even clap a hand over her mouth, then glared at him as if it were somehow his fault. "I abandoned my horse for you, Rand al'Thor. I curled my hair for you. I gave up my life for you! I will not give up my coat and breeches! Besides, no one here has ever seen me in a dress for more time than it took me to change out of it. You know this won't work unless I'm recognized. You certainly can't pretend you wandered in off the street with that face."

ənθɪŋkɪŋ, hi ɹæn ə hæn əkɹɔs ɪz dʒɔ, filɪŋ ɪz oʊn feɪs, bʌt ðət wɑz nɑt wʌt mɪn sɔ. ɛniwʌn lʊkɪŋ əɾ ɪm wəd si ə mæn ɪntʃəz ʃɔɹɾɝ ən jɪɹz oʊldɝ ðən ɹænd ælθɹ, wɪð læŋk blæk hɛɹ, dʌl bɹaʊn aɪz ən ə wɔɹɾ ɑn ɪz bʌlbəs noʊz. oʊnli sʌmwʌn u tʌtʃt ɪm kəd pɪɹs ðə mæsk ə mɪɹɝz. ivən ən æʃəmən wəd nɑt si ɪt, wɪð ðə wivz ɪnvɝɾɪd. ðoʊ ɪf ðəɹ wɝ æʃəmən ɪn ðə pæləs, ɪt maɪt min ɪz plænz hæd ɡɔn fɝðɝ ɝaɪ ðən i bɪlivd. ðɪs vɪzət kəd nɑt, mʌs nɑt, kʌm tə kɪlɪŋ. ɪn ɛni keɪs, ʃi wɑz ɹaɪt; ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ə feɪs ðət wʊɾə bɪn əlaʊɾ ɪndə ðə ɹɔɪəl pæləs ʌv ændɝ ənɛkɔɹɾɪd.

Unthinking, he ran a hand across his jaw, feeling his own face, but that was not what Min saw. Anyone looking at him would see a man inches shorter and years older than Rand al'Thor, with lank black hair, dull brown eyes and a wart on his bulbous nose. Only someone who touched him could pierce the Mask of Mirrors. Even an Asha'man would not see it, with the weaves inverted. Though if there were Asha'man in the Palace, it might mean his plans had gone further awry than he believed. This visit could not, must not, come to killing. In any case, she was right; it was not a face that would have been allowed into the Royal Palace of Andor unescorted.

"æz lɔŋ əz wi kən fɪnɪʃ ðɪs ən bi ɡɔn kwɪkli," hi sɛd. "bɪfɔɹ ɛniwʌn əz taɪm tə θɪŋk ðəɾ ɪf jəɹ hɪɹ, meɪbi aɪ æm, tu."

"As long as we can finish this and be gone quickly," he said. "Before anyone has time to think that if you're here, maybe I am, too."

"ɹænd," ʃi sɛd, hɝ vɔɪs sɑft, ən i aɪɾ əɹ wɛɹəli. ɹɛstɪŋ ə hæn ɑn ɪz tʃɛst, ʃi lʊkt ʌp əɾ ɪm wɪð ə sɪɹiəs ɪkspɹɛʃən. "ɹænd, jə ɹɪli nid tə si ɪleɪn. ən eɪvinhə, aɪ səpoʊz; jə noʊ ʃiz pɹɑbli hɪɹ, tu. ɪf jə - "

"Rand," she said, her voice soft, and he eyed her warily. Resting a hand on his chest, she looked up at him with a serious expression. "Rand, you really need to see Elayne. And Aviendha, I suppose; you know she's probably here, too. If you - "

hi ʃʊk ɪz hɛd, ən wɪʃt i hæd nɑt. ðə dɪzinəs hæd stɪl nɑt ɡɔn kəmplitli. "noʊ!" hi sɛd kɝtli. laɪt! noʊ mæɾɝ wʌt mɪn sɛd, hi dʒʌs kəd nɑt bɪliv ðəɾ ɪleɪn ən eɪvinhə boʊθ lʌv hɪm. əɹ ðət ðə fæk ðeɪ dɪd, ɪf ɪt wɑz ə fækt, dɪd nɑɾ əpsɛt hɝ. wɪmən wɝ nɑt ðət stʃɹeɪnʒ! ɪleɪn ən eɪvinhə hæd ɹizən tə heɪt hɪm, nɑt lʌv hɪm, ən ɪleɪn, ət list, hæd meɪd hɝsɛlf klɪɹ. wɝs, hi wɑz ɪn lʌv wɪð boʊθ ə ðɛm, əz wɛl əz wɪð mɪn! hi hæd tə bi əz hɑɹɾ əz stil, bʌɾ i θɔɾ i maɪt ʃæɾɝ ɪf i hæd tə feɪs ɔl θɹi ət wʌns. "wi faɪnd nɪneɪiv ən mæt, ən ɡoʊ, əz fæst əz wi kæn." ʃi oʊpən əɹ maʊθ, bʌɾ i ɡeɪv əɹ noʊ tʃæns tə spik. "doʊn ɑɹɡju wɪð mi, mɪn. ðɪs ɪz noʊ taɪm fəɹ ɪt!"

He shook his head, and wished he had not. The dizziness had still not gone completely. "No!" he said curtly. Light! No matter what Min said, he just could not believe that Elayne and Aviendha both loved him. Or that the fact they did, if it was a fact, did not upset her. Women were not that strange! Elayne and Aviendha had reason to hate him, not love him, and Elayne, at least, had made herself clear. Worse, he was in love with both of them, as well as with Min! He had to be as hard as steel, but he thought he might shatter if he had to face all three at once. "We find Nynaeve and Mat, and go, as fast as we can." She opened her mouth, but he gave her no chance to speak. "Don't argue with me, Min. This is no time for it!"

tɪltɪŋ əɹ hɛd tə wʌn saɪd, mɪn pʊɾ ɑn ə smɔl, əmjuz smaɪl. "wɛn də aɪ ɛvɝ ɑɹɡju wɪð ju? doʊn aɪ ɔlweɪz də ɪɡzækli əz jə tɛl mi?" ɪf ðət laɪ wɝ nɑt bæɾ ɪnʌf, ʃi æɾəd, "aɪ wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ tə seɪ, ɪf jə wɑnə hɝi, waɪ ɑɹ wi stændɪŋ ɪn ðɪs dʌsti stɔɹɹum ɔl deɪ?" fəɹ pʌŋktʃueɪʃən, ʃi snizd əɡɛn.

Tilting her head to one side, Min put on a small, amused smile. "When do I ever argue with you? Don't I always do exactly as you tell me?" If that lie were not bad enough, she added, "I was going to say, if you want to hurry, why are we standing in this dusty storeroom all day?" For punctuation, she sneezed again.

ʃi wɑz ðə lis laɪkli tə kɑz kɑmɛnt, ivən dʒɹɛst əz ʃi wɑz, soʊ ʃi pʊɾ əɹ hɛɾ aʊɾ ə ðə ɹum fɝst. əpɛɹənli ðə stɔɹɹum wɑz nɑɾ ɪntaɪɝli fɝɡɑɾən; ðə hɛvi dɔɹz hɪnʒɪz bɛɹli kɹikt. ə kwɪk lʊk boʊθ weɪz, ən ʃi hɝiɾ aʊt, dʒɛstʃɝɪŋ ɪm tə fɑloʊ. tɑvɝən əɹ noʊ, hi wɑz ɹɪliv tə faɪn ðə lɔŋ kɔɹəɾɝ ɛmpti. ðə moʊs tɪmɪd sɝvən maɪɾ əv wʌndɝɾ ət siɪŋ əm ɪmɝdʒ fɹəm ə stɔɹɹum ɪn ði ʌpɝ ɹitʃəz ə ðə pæləs. stɪl, ðeɪ wəɾ ɪnkaʊntɝ pipəl sun ɪnʌf. ðə ɹɔɪəl pæləs dɪd nɑt ɹʌn əz hɛvəli tə sɝvəns əz ðə sʌn pæləs əɹ ðə stoʊn ə tiɹ, bʌt ðəɹ wɝ stɪl hʌnʒɹədz ə ðɛm ɪn ə pleɪs ðɪs saɪz. wɔkɪŋ əlɔŋ bɪsaɪd mɪn, hi tʃɹaɪd tə ʃæmbəl ən ɡɔk ət bɹaɪt tæpəstʃɹiz ən kɑɹvd wɔl pænəlz ən pɑlɪʃt haɪtʃəsts. nʌn wɝ soʊ faɪn ðɪs haɪ əz ðeɪ wəd bi loʊɝ daʊn, bʌɾ ə kɑmən wɝkmən wəd ɡɔk.

She was the least likely to cause comment, even dressed as she was, so she put her head out of the room first. Apparently the storeroom was not entirely forgotten; the heavy door's hinges barely creaked. A quick look both ways, and she hurried out, gesturing him to follow. Ta'veren or no, he was relieved to find the long corridor empty. The most timid servant might have wondered at seeing them emerge from a storeroom in the upper reaches of the Palace. Still, they would encounter people soon enough. The Royal Palace did not run as heavily to servants as the Sun Palace or the Stone of Tear, but there were still hundreds of them in a place this size. Walking along beside Min, he tried to shamble and gawk at bright tapestries and carved wall panels and polished highchests. None were so fine this high as they would be lower down, but a common workman would gawk.

"wi nid tə ɡɛt daʊn tə ə loʊɝ flɔɹ əz fæst əz wi kæn," hi mɝmɝd. ðəɹ wɑz stɪl noʊ wʌn ɪn saɪt, bʌt ðəɹ maɪt bi tɛn pipəl ɝaʊn ðə nɛks kɔɹnɝ. "ɹɪmɛmbɝ, dʒʌst æsk ðə fɝst sɝvənt wi si wɛɹ tə faɪnd nɪneɪiv ən mæt. doʊn ɪlæbɹəɾ ənlɛs juv tə."

"We need to get down to a lower floor as fast as we can," he murmured. There was still no one in sight, but there might be ten people around the next corner. "Remember, just ask the first servant we see where to find Nynaeve and Mat. Don't elaborate unless you have to."

"waɪ, θæŋk jə fəɹ ɹimaɪndɪŋ mi, ɹænd. aɪ nu sʌmθɪŋ hæd slɪp maɪ maɪnd, ən aɪ dʒʌs kʊdn ɪmædʒən wʌt." hɝ bɹif smaɪl wɑz mʌtʃ tu taɪt, ən ʃi mʌɾɝd sʌmθɪŋ ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛθ.

"Why, thank you for reminding me, Rand. I knew something had slipped my mind, and I just couldn't imagine what." Her brief smile was much too tight, and she muttered something under her breath.

ɹænd saɪd. ðɪs wɑz tu ɪmpɔɹɾənt fəɹ əɹ tə pleɪ ɡeɪmz, bʌt ʃi wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ tə, ɪf i lɛt hɝ. nɑt ðət ʃi sɔ ɪt ðət weɪ. səmtaɪmz, ðoʊ, hɝ aɪdiəz ʌv ɪmpɔɹɾənt dɪfɝd waɪdli fɹəm hɪz. vɛɹi waɪdli. hi wəɾ əv tə kip ə kloʊs aɪ ɑn hɝ.

Rand sighed. This was too important for her to play games, but she was going to, if he let her. Not that she saw it that way. Sometimes, though, her ideas of important differed widely from his. Very widely. He would have to keep a close eye on her.

"waɪ, mɪstʃɹəs fɑɹʃɔ," ə wʊmənz vɔɪs sɛd bɪhaɪn ðɛm. "ɪɾ ɪz mɪstʃɹəs fɑɹʃɔ, ɪzən ɪt?"

"Why, Mistress Farshaw," a woman's voice said behind them. "It is Mistress Farshaw, isn't it?"

ðə skɹɪp swʌŋ ən θʌmpt ɹændz bæk hɛvəli əz i spʌn ɝaʊnd. ðə plʌmp ɡɹeɪɪŋ wʊmən stɛɹɪŋ ət mɪn ɪn əstɑnɪʃmənt wɑz pɝhæps ðə læs pɝsən i wɑntəd tə mit, bɪsaɪdz ɪleɪn əɹ eɪvinhə. wʌndɝɪŋ waɪ ʃi wɑz wɛɹɪŋ ə ɹɛd tɑbɝd wɪð ðə waɪt laɪən lɑɹdʒ ɑn ðə fɹʌnt, hi slaʊtʃt ən əvɔɪɾəd lʊkɪŋ əɾ əɹ dɝɛkli. dʒʌst ə wɝkmən duɪŋ ɪz dʒɑb. noʊ ɹizən tə ɡlæns əɾ ɪm twaɪs.

The scrip swung and thumped Rand's back heavily as he spun around. The plump graying woman staring at Min in astonishment was perhaps the last person he wanted to meet, besides Elayne or Aviendha. Wondering why she was wearing a red tabard with the White Lion large on the front, he slouched and avoided looking at her directly. Just a workman doing his job. No reason to glance at him twice.

"mɪstʃɹəs hɑɹfɝ?" mɪn ɪkskleɪmd, bimɪŋ dɪlaɪɾɪdli. "jɛs, ɪts mi. ən jə ɑɹ dʒʌs ðə wʊmən aɪ wɑz lʊkɪŋ fɔɹ. aɪm əfɹeɪɾ aɪm lɔst. kən jə tɛl mi wɛɹ tə faɪnd nɪneɪiv ɑlmɹə? ən mæt kɔθən? ðɪs fɛloʊ hæz sʌmθɪŋ nɪneɪiv æskt ɪm tə dɪlɪvɝ."

"Mistress Harfor?" Min exclaimed, beaming delightedly. "Yes, it's me. And you are just the woman I was looking for. I'm afraid I am lost. Can you tell me where to find Nynaeve al'Meara? And Mat Cauthon? This fellow has something Nynaeve asked him to deliver."

ðə fɝs meɪd fɹaʊn slaɪtli ət ɹænd bɪfɔɹ ɹɪtɝnɪŋ əɹ ətɛnʃən tə mɪn. ʃi ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ ət mɪnz ɡɑɹməns, əɹ meɪbi ət ðə dʌst ɑn ðɛm, bʌt ʃi mɛnʃənd niðɝ. "mæt kɔθən? aɪ doʊn bɪliv aɪ noʊ hɪm. ənlɛs hiz wʌn ə ðə nu sɝvəns əɹ ɡɑɹdzmɪn?" ʃi æɾəd daʊtfəli. "æz fəɹ nɪneɪiv sədaɪ, ʃiz vɛɹi bɪzi. aɪ səpoʊz ɪɾəl bi ɔl ɹaɪt wɪð əɹ ɪf aɪ æksɛpt wʌtɛvɝ ɪts ən pʊɾ ɪɾ ɪn əɹ ɹum."

The First Maid frowned slightly at Rand before returning her attention to Min. She raised an eyebrow at Min's garments, or maybe at the dust on them, but she mentioned neither. "Mat Cauthon? I don't believe I know him. Unless he's one of the new servants or Guardsmen?" she added doubtfully. "As for Nynaeve Sedai, she's very busy. I suppose it will be all right with her if I accept whatever it is and put it in her room."

ɹænd dʒɝkt əpɹaɪt. nɪneɪiv sədaɪ? waɪ wəd ði ʌðɝz - ðə ɹil ɛɛs sədaɪ - lɛɾ əɹ pleɪ ət ðət stɪl? ən mæt wɑz nɑt hɪɹ? hæd nɛvɝ bɪn hɪɹ, əpɛɹənli. kʌlɝz wɝld ɪn ɪz hɛd, ɔlmoʊst ən ɪmədʒ i kəd meɪk aʊt. ɪn ə hɑɹtbiɾ ɪt vænɪʃt, bʌɾ i stæɡɝd. mɪstʃɹəs hɑɹfɝ fɹaʊn əɾ ɪm əɡɛn, ən snɪft. laɪkli ʃi θɔɾ ɪm dʒɹʌŋk.

Rand jerked upright. Nynaeve Sedai? Why would the others - the real Aes Sedai - let her play at that still? And Mat was not here? Had never been here, apparently. Colors whirled in his head, almost an image he could make out. In a heartbeat it vanished, but he staggered. Mistress Harfor frowned at him again, and sniffed. Likely she thought him drunk.

mɪn fɹaʊnd, tu, bʌɾ ɪn θɔt, tæpɪŋ ə fɪŋɡɝ ɑn əɹ tʃɪn, ən ðəɾ oʊnli læstəɾ ə moʊmənt. "aɪ θɪŋk nɪneɪiv . . . sədaɪ wɑns tə si hɪm." ðə hɛzəteɪʃən wɑz bɛɹli noʊɾəsəbəl. "kʊd juv ɪm ʃoʊn tə hɝ ɹumz, mɪstʃɹəs hɑɹfɝ? aɪ hæv ənʌðɝ ɛɹən bɪfɔɹ aɪ ɡoʊ. jə maɪn jəɹ mænɝz, naʊ, nuli, ən də əz jəɹ toʊld. ðɛɹz ə ɡʊd fɛloʊ."

Min frowned, too, but in thought, tapping a finger on her chin, and that only lasted a moment. "I think Nynaeve . . . Sedai wants to see him." The hesitation was barely noticeable. "Could you have him shown to her rooms, Mistress Harfor? I have another errand before I go. You mind your manners, now, Nuli, and do as you're told. There's a good fellow."

ɹænd oʊpən ɪz maʊθ, bʌt bɪfɔɹ i kəd ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ə wɝd ʃi dɑɹɾɪd əweɪ daʊn ðə kɔɹəɾɝ, ɔlmoʊst ɹʌnɪŋ. hɝ kloʊk flɛɹd bɪhaɪn hɝ, ʃi wɑz muvɪŋ soʊ kwɪkli. bɝn hɝ, ʃi wɑz gɑnə tʃɹaɪ faɪndɪŋ ɪleɪn! ʃi kəd ɹuən ɛvɹiθɪŋ!

Rand opened his mouth, but before he could get out a word she darted away down the corridor, almost running. Her cloak flared behind her, she was moving so quickly. Burn her, she was going to try finding Elayne! She could ruin everything!

jəɹ plænz feɪl kəz jə wɑnə lɪv, mædmæn. luz θɝɪnz vɔɪs wɑz ə ɹʌf, swɛɾi wɪspɝ. æksɛp ðət jə ɑɹ dɛd. æksɛpt ɪt, ən stɑp tɔɹməntɪŋ mi, mædmæn! ɹænd səpɹɛs ðə vɔɪs tə ə mjuɾɪd bʌz, ə baɪtim bʌzɪŋ ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs ə hɪz hɛd. nuli? wʌt kaɪndə neɪm wɑz nuli?

Your plans fail because you want to live, madman. Lews Therin's voice was a rough, sweaty whisper. Accept that you are dead. Accept it, and stop tormenting me, madman! Rand suppressed the voice to a muted buzz, a biteme buzzing in the darkness of his head. Nuli? What kind of name was Nuli?

mɪstʃɹəs hɑɹfɝ ɡeɪpt æftɝ mɪn əntɪl ʃi vænɪʃt ɝaʊn ə kɔɹnɝ, ðən ɡeɪv əɹ tɑbɝɾ ən ədʒʌstɪŋ tʌɡ ɪt dɪd nɑt nid. ʃi tɝn əɹ dɪsəpɹuvəl ɑn ɹænd. ivən wɪð ðə mæsk ə mɪɹɝz ʃi sɔ ə mæn u taʊɝɾ oʊvɝ hɝ, bʌt ɹɪn hɑɹfɝ wɑz nɑɾ ə wʊmən tə lɛɾ ə smɔl θɪŋ laɪk ðət pʊɾ əɹ ɔf stʃɹaɪd fəɹ ən ɪnstənt. "aɪ mɪstʃɹʌs ðə lʊks ə ju, nuli," ʃi sɛd, hɝ aɪbɹaʊz dʒɹɔn daʊn ʃɑɹpli, "soʊ jə wɑtʃ jəɹ stɛp. jəl wɑtʃ ɪt vɛɹi kɛɹfəli, ɪf juv ɛni bɹeɪn əɾ ɔl."

Mistress Harfor gaped after Min until she vanished around a corner, then gave her tabard an adjusting tug it did not need. She turned her disapproval on Rand. Even with the Mask of Mirrors she saw a man who towered over her, but Reene Harfor was not a woman to let a small thing like that put her off stride for an instant. "I mistrust the looks of you, Nuli," she said, her eyebrows drawn down sharply, "so you watch your step. You'll watch it very carefully, if you have any brain at all."

hoʊldɪŋ ðə skɹɪps ʃoʊldɝ stʃɹæp wɪð wʌn hænd, hi tʌɡd ɪz fɔɹlɑk wɪð ði ʌðɝ. "jɛs, mɪstʃɹəs," hi mʌɾɝd ɡɹʌflaɪ. ðə fɝs meɪd maɪt ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ɪz ɹil vɔɪs. mɪn hæd bɪn səpoʊz tə də ɔl ðə tɔkɪŋ əntɪl ðeɪ faʊnd nɪneɪiv ən mæt. wʌɾ ɪn ðə laɪt wɑz i gɑnə də ɪf ʃi dɪd bɹɪŋ ɪleɪn? ən meɪbi eɪvinhə. ʃi pɹɑbli wɑz hɪɹ, tu. laɪt! "pɑɹɾən, mɪstʃɹəs, bʌt wi ɔt tə hɝi. ɪts ɝdʒən aɪ si nɪneɪiv əz sun əz pɑsəbəl." hi hɛftəd ðə skɹɪp slaɪtli. "ʃi wɑntəd ðɪs ɹil ɪmpɔɹɾənt laɪk." ɪf i wɑz dʌn wən mɪn ɹɪtɝnd, hi maɪt bi eɪbəl tə ɡɛɾ əweɪ wɪð əɹ bɪfɔɹ i hæd tə feɪs ði ʌðɝ tu.

Holding the scrip's shoulder strap with one hand, he tugged his forelock with the other. "Yes, Mistress," he muttered gruffly. The First Maid might recognize his real voice. Min had been supposed to do all the talking until they found Nynaeve and Mat. What in the Light was he going to do if she did bring Elayne? And maybe Aviendha. She probably was here, too. Light! "Pardon, Mistress, but we ought to hurry. It's urgent I see Nynaeve as soon as possible." He hefted the scrip slightly. "She wanted this real important like." If he was done when Min returned, he might be able to get away with her before he had to face the other two.

"ɪf nɪneɪiv sədaɪ θɔɾ ɪt wɑz ɝdʒənt," ðə plʌmp wʊmən toʊld ɪm tɑɹtli, pleɪsɪŋ hɛvi ɛmfəsəs ɑn ði ɑnɝɪfɪk i hæɾ oʊmɪɾəd, "ʃi wʊɾə lɛft wɝd jə wɝ ɪkspɛktəd. naʊ, fɑloʊ mi, ən kip jəɹ kɑmɛns ən əpɪnjənz tə jɝsɛlf."

"If Nynaeve Sedai thought it was urgent," the plump woman told him tartly, placing heavy emphasis on the honorific he had omitted, "she would have left word you were expected. Now, follow me, and keep your comments and opinions to yourself."

ʃi stɑɹɾəd ɔf wɪθaʊt weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ə ɹɪplaɪ, wɪθaʊt lʊkɪŋ bæk, ɡlaɪɾɪŋ əlɔŋ wɪð ə steɪtli ɡɹeɪs. æftɝ ɔl, wʌt kəɾ i də ɪksɛpt əz i hæd bɪn toʊld? əz i ɹɪkɔld, ðə fɝs meɪd wɑz əkʌstəm tə ɛvɹiwʌn duɪŋ əz ðeɪ wɝ toʊld. stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ tə kætʃ ʌp, hi tʊk oʊnli wʌn stɛp əɾ əɹ saɪd bɪfɔɹ əɹ stɑɹɾəld lʊk meɪɾ ɪm dʒɹɑp bæk, tʌɡɪŋ ɪz fɔɹlɑk ən mʌmbəlɪŋ əpɑlədʒiz. hi wɑz nɑt juz tə hævɪŋ tə wɔk bɪhaɪn ɛniwʌn. ɪt wɑz nɑt kælkjəleɪɾəd tə mɑɾɝeɪt ɪz mud. ðə tæɡ ɛn ə dɪzinəs hʌŋ ɑn, tu, ən ðə fɪlθ ə ðə teɪnt. hi sim tə bi ɪn ə faʊl mud mɔɹ ɔfən ðən nɑɾ ə leɪt, ənlɛs mɪn wɑz wɪð hɪm.

She started off without waiting for a reply, without looking back, gliding along with a stately grace. After all, what could he do except as he had been told? As he recalled, the First Maid was accustomed to everyone doing as they were told. Striding to catch up, he took only one step at her side before her startled look made him drop back, tugging his forelock and mumbling apologies. He was not used to having to walk behind anyone. It was not calculated to moderate his mood. The tag end of dizziness hung on, too, and the filth of the taint. He seemed to be in a foul mood more often than not of late, unless Min was with him.

bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ hæd ɡɔn vɛɹi fɑɹ, lɪvɹid sɝvəns bɪɡæn tə əpɪɹ ɪn ðə hɔlweɪ, pɑlɪʃɪŋ ən dʌstɪŋ ən kæɹiɪŋ, skɝiɪŋ ɛvɹi wɪtʃ weɪ. pleɪnli ði æbsəns ə pipəl wən i ən mɪn lɛf ðə stɔɹɹum wɑz ə ɹɛɹ əkɝəns. tɑvɝən əɡɛn. daʊn ə flaɪɾ ə nɛɹoʊ sɝvəs stɛɹz bɪlt ɪndə ðə wɔl, ən ðəɹ wɝ ivən mɔɹ. ən sʌmθɪŋ ɛls, ə ɡɹeɪt mɛni wɪmən u wɝ nɑɾ ɪn lɪvɝi. kɑpɝ-skɪn dəmɑni wɪmən, ʃɔɹt peɪl kɛɹhinɪn, wɪmən wɪð ɑləv skɪnz ən dɑɹk aɪz u wɝ sɝɾənli nɑɾ ændɔɝən. ðeɪ meɪɾ ɪm smaɪl, ə taɪt sæɾəsfaɪd smaɪl. nʌn hæd wʌɾ i kəd kɔl ən eɪdʒləs feɪs, ən ə nʌmbɝ ivən bɔɹ laɪnz ən ɹɪŋkəlz ðət nɛvɝ dɛkɝeɪɾəd ɛni ɛɛs sədaɪz feɪs, bʌt səmtaɪmz ɡus bʌmps dænst ɑn ɪz skɪn wən i keɪm nɪɹ wʌn ə ðɛm. ðeɪ wɝ tʃænəlɪŋ, əɹ lis hoʊldɪŋ seɪaɪdɑɹ. mɪstʃɹəs hɑɹfɝ lɛɾ ɪm pæs kloʊz dɔɹz wɛɹ ðət pɹɪklɪŋ ɹeɪst, tu. bɪhaɪn ðoʊz dɔɹz, stɪl ʌðɝ wɪmən hæd tə bi tʃænəlɪŋ.

Before they had gone very far, liveried servants began to appear in the hallway, polishing and dusting and carrying, scurrying every which way. Plainly the absence of people when he and Min left the storeroom was a rare occurrence. Ta'veren again. Down a flight of narrow service stairs built into the wall, and there were even more. And something else, a great many women who were not in livery. Copper-skinned Domani women, short pale Cairhienin, women with olive skins and dark eyes who were certainly not Andoran. They made him smile, a tight satisfied smile. None had what he could call an ageless face, and a number even bore lines and wrinkles that never decorated any Aes Sedai's face, but sometimes goose bumps danced on his skin when he came near one of them. They were channeling, or least holding saidar. Mistress Harfor led him past closed doors where that prickling raced, too. Behind those doors, still other women had to be channeling.

"pɑɹɾən, mɪstʃɹəs," hi sɛɾ ɪn ðə kɔɹs vɔɪs i hæɾ ədɑptəd fəɹ nuli. "haʊ mɛni ɛɛs sədaɪ ɑɹ ðəɹ ɪn ðə pæləs?"

"Pardon, Mistress," he said in the coarse voice he had adopted for Nuli. "How many Aes Sedai are there in the Palace?"

"ðæɾ ɪz noʊ kənsɝn ə jʊɹz," ʃi snæpt. ɡlænsɪŋ oʊvɝ wʌn ʃoʊldɝ ət hɪm, ðoʊ, ʃi saɪɾ ən ɹɪlɛntɪd. "aɪ doʊn səpoʊz ðəɹ ɪz ɛni hɑɹm ɪn jə noʊɪŋ. faɪv, kaʊntɪŋ ðə leɪɾi ɪleɪn ən nɪneɪiv sədaɪ." ə tʌtʃ ə pɹaɪɾ ɛntɝɾ əɹ vɔɪs. "ɪɾ əz bɪn ə lɔŋ taɪm sɪns ðət mɛni ɛɛs sədaɪ kleɪmd ɡɛstʃɹaɪt hɪɹ ət wʌn taɪm."

"That is no concern of yours," she snapped. Glancing over one shoulder at him, though, she sighed and relented. "I don't suppose there is any harm in you knowing. Five, counting the Lady Elayne and Nynaeve Sedai." A touch of pride entered her voice. "It has been a long time since that many Aes Sedai claimed guestright here at one time."

ɹænd kəɾ əv læft, ðoʊ wɪθaʊɾ əmjuzmənt. faɪv? noʊ, ðəɾ ɪnkluɾəd nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn. θɹi ɹil ɛɛs sədaɪ. θɹi! huɛvɝ ðə ɹɛst wɝ dɪd nɑt ɹɪli mæɾɝ. hi hæd bɪɡʌn tə bɪliv ðət ðə ɹumɝz ə hʌnʒɹədz ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ muvɪŋ təwɔɹd keɪɛmlɪn wɪð ən ɑɹmi mɛn ðəɹ ɹɪli maɪt bi ðət mɛni ɹɛɾi tə fɑloʊ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. ɪnstɛd, ivən ɪz ɝɪdʒənəl hoʊp fəɹ ə dʌbəl hændfʊl ə ðɛm hæd bɪn waɪldli ɑptəmɪstɪk. ðə ɹumɝz wɝ oʊnli ɹumɝz. əɹ ɛls səm skim ʌv ɪleɪɾəz meɪkɪŋ. laɪt, wɛɹ wɑz mæt? kʌlɝ flæʃt ɪn ɪz hɛd - fəɹ ən ɪnstən i θɔɾ ɪt wɑz mæts feɪs - ən i stʌmbəld.

Rand could have laughed, though without amusement. Five? No, that included Nynaeve and Elayne. Three real Aes Sedai. Three! Whoever the rest were did not really matter. He had begun to believe that the rumors of hundreds of Aes Sedai moving toward Caemlyn with an army meant there really might be that many ready to follow the Dragon Reborn. Instead, even his original hope for a double handful of them had been wildly optimistic. The rumors were only rumors. Or else some scheme of Elaida's making. Light, where was Mat? Color flashed in his head - for an instant he thought it was Mat's face - and he stumbled.

"ɪf jə keɪm hɪɹ dʒɹʌŋk, nuli," mɪstʃɹəs hɑɹfɝ sɛd fɝmli, "ju wɪl liv ɹɪɡɹɛɾɪŋ ɪt bɪɾɝli. əl si tə ɪt maɪsɛlf!"

"If you came here drunk, Nuli," Mistress Harfor said firmly, "you will leave regretting it bitterly. I will see to it myself!"

"jɛs, mɪstʃɹəs," ɹænd mʌɾɝd, dʒɝkɪŋ əɾ ɪz fɔɹlɑk. ɪnsaɪɾ ɪz hɛd, luz θɝɪn kækəld ɪn mæd, wipɪŋ læftɝ. hi hæd hæd tə kʌm hɪɹ - ɪt wɑz nɛsəsɛɹi - bʌɾ i wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə ɹəɡɹɛɾ ɪt.

"Yes, Mistress," Rand muttered, jerking at his forelock. Inside his head, Lews Therin cackled in mad, weeping laughter. He had had to come here - it was necessary - but he was already beginning to regret it.

sɝaʊndəd baɪ ðə laɪɾ ə seɪaɪdɑɹ, nɪneɪiv ən tɑlɑn feɪst wʌn ənʌðɝ ət fɔɹ peɪsɪz ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə faɪɝpleɪs, wɛɹ ə bɹɪsk bleɪz hæd mænədʒ tə teɪk ɔl tʃɪl aʊɾ ə ði ɛɹ. əɹ meɪbi ɪt wɑz ɛfɝt ðət hæd wɔɹm hɝ, nɪneɪiv θɔt saʊɝli. ðɪs lɛsən hæd læstəɾ ən aʊɝ ɔlɹɛɾi, baɪ ði ɔɹneɪt klɑk ɑn ðə kɑɹv mæntəl. ən aʊɝ ə tʃænəlɪŋ wɪθaʊt ɹɛst wəd wɔɹm ɛniwʌn. sɝaɪðə wɑz səpoʊz tə bi hɪɹ, nɑt hɝ, bʌt ðə bɹaʊn hæd slɪpt aʊɾ ə ðə pæləs livɪŋ ə noʊɾ əbaʊɾ ən ɝdʒən ɛɹən ɪn ðə sɪɾi. kɛɝin hæd ɹəfjuz tə teɪk tu deɪz ɪn ə ɹoʊ, ən vændin stɪl ɹəfjuz tə teɪk ɛni, ɑn ðə ɹɪdɪkjələs ɡɹaʊnz ðət titʃɪŋ kɝstʃən ən zɛɹjə lɛft əɹ noʊ taɪm.

Surrounded by the light of saidar, Nynaeve and Talaan faced one another at four paces in front of the fireplace, where a brisk blaze had managed to take all chill out of the air. Or maybe it was effort that had warmed her, Nynaeve thought sourly. This lesson had lasted an hour already, by the ornate clock on the carved mantel. An hour of channeling without rest would warm anyone. Sareitha was supposed to be here, not her, but the Brown had slipped out of the Palace leaving a note about an urgent errand in the city. Careane had refused to take two days in a row, and Vandene still refused to take any, on the ridiculous grounds that teaching Kirstian and Zarya left her no time.

"laɪk ðɪs," ʃi sɛd, wɪpɪŋ əɹ floʊ ʌv spɪɹəɾ ɝaʊn ðə bɔɪ-slɪm si foʊk əpɹɛntəsəz ətɛmpt ət fɛndɪŋ əɹ ɔf. æɾɪŋ ðə fɔɹs ə hɝ oʊn floʊ, ʃi pʊʃt ðə ɡɝlz fɝðɝ əweɪ ən ət ðə seɪm taɪm tʃænəld ɛɹ ɪn θɹi sɛpɹət wivz. wʌn tɪkəl tɑlɑnz ɹɪbz θɹu hɝ blu lɪnən blaʊs. ə sɪmpəl plɔɪ, bʌt ðə ɡɝl ɡæspt ɪn sɝpɹaɪz, ən fəɹ ən ɪnstən əɹ ɛmbɹeɪs ə ðə sɔɹs lɛsən dʒʌst ə hɛɹ, ðə feɪntəs flɪkɝ ɪn ðə paʊɝ fɪlɪŋ hɝ. ɪn ðət hɑɹtbit nɪneɪiv stɑp ðə pʊʃɪŋ ʃi hæd dʒʌs bɪɡʌn ɑn ði ʌðɝz floʊ ən snæpt əɹ oʊn bæk tə ɪts ɝɪdʒənəl tɑɹɡət. fɔɹsɪŋ ðə ʃild ɑntu tɑlɑn stɪl fɛl mʌtʃ laɪk slæpɪŋ ə wɔl - ɪksɛp ðə stɪŋ wɑz spɹɛɾ ivənli əkɹɔs əɹ skɪn ɹæðɝ ðən dʒʌst ɪn əɹ pɑm, hɑɹdli ən ɪmpɹuvmənt - bʌt ðə ɡloʊ ʌv seɪaɪdɑɹ vænɪʃt dʒʌst əz ðə læs tu floʊz ʌv ɛɹ tʃɹæp tɑlɑnz ɑɹmz əɾ əɹ saɪdz ən pʊld əɹ niz təɡɛðɝ ɪn ðɛɹ waɪd, dɑɹk tʃɹaʊzɝz.

"Like this," she said, whipping her flow of Spirit around the boy-slim Sea Folk apprentice's attempt at fending her off. Adding the force of her own flow, she pushed the girl's further away and at the same time channeled Air in three separate weaves. One tickled Talaan's ribs through her blue linen blouse. A simple ploy, but the girl gasped in surprise, and for an instant her embrace of the Source lessened just a hair, the faintest flicker in the Power filling her. In that heartbeat Nynaeve stopped the pushing she had just begun on the other's flow and snapped her own back to its original target. Forcing the shield onto Talaan still felt much like slapping a wall - except the sting was spread evenly across her skin rather than just in her palm, hardly an improvement - but the glow of saidar vanished just as the last two flows of Air trapped Talaan's arms at her sides and pulled her knees together in their wide, dark trousers.

vɛɹi nitli dʌn, ɪf nɪneɪiv dɪd θɪŋk soʊ hɝsɛlf. ðə ɡɝl wɑz vɛɹi ædʒəl, vɛɹi dɛft wɪð əɹ wivz. bɪsaɪdz, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ʃil sʌmwʌn u hɛl ðə paʊɝ wɑz tʃænsi ət bɛst ən fjuɾəl ət wɝst, ənlɛs jə wɝ vɛɹi mʌtʃ stʃɹɔŋɝ ðən ðeɪ - səmtaɪmz ɪf jə wɝ - ən tɑlɑn mætʃt əɹ əz kloʊsli əz meɪd noʊ dɪfɝəns. ðət hɛlp kip ə sæɾəsfaɪd smaɪl fɹəm əɹ feɪs. ɪt simd ə vɛɹi ʃɔɹt taɪm əɡoʊ ðət sɪstɝz hæd bɪn stɑɹɾəld əɾ əɹ stʃɹɛŋkθ ən bɪliv ðəɾ oʊnli səm ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən pəzɛst ɡɹeɪɾɝ. tɑlɑn hæd nɑt sloʊd, jɛt; ʃi wɑz lɪɾəl mɔɹ ðən ə tʃaɪld. fɪftin? meɪbi jʌŋɡɝ! ðə laɪɾ əloʊn nu wʌɾ əɹ pətɛnʃəl wɑz. ət list, nʌn ə ðə wɪndfɪndɝz hæd mɛnʃən ɪt, ən nɪneɪiv wɑz nɑɾ əbaʊt tə æsk. ʃi hæd noʊ ɪntʃɹəst ɪn noʊɪŋ haʊ mʌtʃ stʃɹɔŋɝ ðən ʃi ə si foʊk ɡɝl wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ tə bi. nʌn əɾ ɔl.

Very neatly done, if Nynaeve did think so herself. The girl was very agile, very deft with her weaves. Besides, trying to shield someone who held the Power was chancy at best and futile at worst, unless you were very much stronger than they - sometimes if you were - and Talaan matched her as closely as made no difference. That helped keep a satisfied smile from her face. It seemed a very short time ago that sisters had been startled at her strength and believed that only some of the Forsaken possessed greater. Talaan had not slowed, yet; she was little more than a child. Fifteen? Maybe younger! The Light alone knew what her potential was. At least, none of the Windfinders had mentioned it, and Nynaeve was not about to ask. She had no interest in knowing how much stronger than she a Sea Folk girl was going to be. None at all.

bɛɹ fit ʃʌflɪŋ ɑn ðə pæɾɝnd ɡɹin kɑɹpət, tɑlɑn meɪd wʌn fjuɾəl ətɛmp tə bɹeɪk ðə ʃil ðət nɪneɪiv hɛld izəli, ðən saɪɾ ɪn dɪfiɾ ən loʊɝɾ əɹ aɪz. ivən wən ʃi hæd səksiɾəd ɪn fɑloʊɪŋ nɪneɪivz ɪnstʃɹʌkʃən, ʃi bɪheɪvd əz ɪf ʃi hæd feɪld, ən naʊ ʃi slʌmp soʊ dɪdʒɛktɪdli jə maɪɾ əv θɔt ðə wivz ʌv ɛɹ wɝ ɔl ðət hɛld əɹ əpɹaɪt.

Bare feet shuffling on the patterned green carpet, Talaan made one futile attempt to break the shield that Nynaeve held easily, then sighed in defeat and lowered her eyes. Even when she had succeeded in following Nynaeve's instruction, she behaved as if she had failed, and now she slumped so dejectedly you might have thought the weaves of Air were all that held her upright.

lɛɾɪŋ əɹ floʊz dɪsəpeɪt, nɪneɪiv ədʒʌstəɾ əɹ ʃɔl ən oʊpən əɹ maʊθ tə tɛl tɑlɑn wʌt ʃi hæd dʌn ɹɔŋ. ən tə pɔɪn aʊt - wʌns əɡɛn - ðəɾ ɪt wɑz jusləs tə tʃɹaɪ bɹeɪkɪŋ fɹi ənlɛs jə wɝ mʌtʃ stʃɹɔŋɝ ðən huɛvɝ hæd ʃildɪd ju. ðə si foʊk hɑɹdli sim tə bɪliv ɛniθɪŋ ʃi toʊld əm əntɪl ʃi toʊld əm tɛn taɪmz ən ʃoʊɾ əm twɛnti.

Letting her flows dissipate, Nynaeve adjusted her shawl and opened her mouth to tell Talaan what she had done wrong. And to point out - once again - that it was useless to try breaking free unless you were much stronger than whoever had shielded you. The Sea Folk hardly seemed to believe anything she told them until she told them ten times and showed them twenty.

"ʃi juz jəɹ oʊn fɔɹs əɡɛns ju," sɛnaɪn dɪn ɹiɑl sɛd blʌnli bɪfɔɹ nɪneɪiv kəd spik. "æn dɪstʃɹækʃən, əɡɛn. ɪts laɪk ɹɛslɪŋ, ɡɝl. jə noʊ haʊ tə ɹɛsəl."

"She used your own force against you," Senine din Ryal said bluntly before Nynaeve could speak. "And distraction, again. It is like wrestling, girl. You know how to wrestle."

"tʃɹaɪ əɡɛn," zeɪɾə kəmændəd wɪð ə bɹɪsk dʒɛstʃɝ ʌv wʌn dɑɹk, tætud hænd.

"Try again," Zaida commanded with a brisk gesture of one dark, tattooed hand.

ɔl ə ðə tʃɛɹz ɪn ðə ɹum hæd bɪn muvd əɡɛns ðə wɔl, ðoʊ ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɹil nid fəɹ ə klɪɹ speɪs, ən zeɪɾə sæt wɑtʃɪŋ ðə lɛsən flæŋk baɪ sɪks wɪndfɪndɝz, ə ɹaɪəɾ ə ɹɛdz ən jɛloʊz ən bluz ɪn bɹoʊkeɪɾɪd sɪlks ən bɹaɪtli daɪd lɪnənz, ə flɪntʃ-ɪndusɪŋ dɪspleɪ ʌv ɪɹɪŋz ən noʊz ɹɪŋz ən mədæljən-leɪɾən tʃeɪnz. ðət wɑz ɔlweɪz ðə weɪ; wʌn ə ðə tu əpɹɛntəsɪz wɑz juz fəɹ ði æktʃəwəl lɛsən - əɹ mɛɝɪlɪl, nɪneɪiv hæd hɝd, æktʃəli  fɔɹs tə teɪk ðə pɑɹɾ ʌv ən əpɹɛntəs ənlɛs ʃi hɝsɛlf wɑz titʃɪŋ - waɪl zeɪɾə ən wʌn ɡɹup əɹ ənʌðɝ ʌv wɪndfɪndɝz wɑtʃt. ðə weɪvməstʃɹəs kəd nɑt tʃænəl, ʌv kɔɹs, ðoʊ ʃi wɑz ɔlweɪz pɹɛzənt, ən nʌn ə ðə wɪndfɪndɝz wəɾ æktʃəli  stup tə pɑɹtɪsəpeɪɾɪŋ pɝsənəli. oʊ, nɛvɝ ðæt.

All of the chairs in the room had been moved against the wall, though there was no real need for a clear space, and Zaida sat watching the lesson flanked by six Windfinders, a riot of reds and yellows and blues in brocaded silks and brightly dyed linens, a flinch-inducing display of earrings and nose rings and medallion-laden chains. That was always the way; one of the two apprentices was used for the actual lesson - or Merilille, Nynaeve had heard, actually forced to take the part of an apprentice unless she herself was teaching - while Zaida and one group or another of Windfinders watched. The Wavemistress could not channel, of course, though she was always present, and none of the Windfinders would actually stoop to participating personally. Oh, never that.

ɪn nɪneɪivz ɛstəmeɪʃən, tədeɪz ɡɹupɪŋ wɑz vɛɹi ɑd, kənsɪɾɝɪŋ ðə si foʊks' əbsɛʃən wɪð ɹæŋk. zeɪɾəz oʊn wɪndfɪndɝ, ʃilɪn, sæɾ ɑn əɹ ɹaɪt, ə slɛndɝ, kuli ɹɪzɝvd wʊmən ɔlmoʊst əz tɔl əz eɪvinhə ən taʊɝɪŋ oʊvɝ zeɪɾə. ðət wɑz pɹɑpɝ, əz fɑɹ əz nɪneɪiv ʌndɝstʊd, bʌɾ ət zeɪɾəz lɛft wɑz sɛnaɪn, ən ʃi sɝvd ɑn ə sɔɹɝ, wʌn ə ðə si foʊks smɔlɝ vɛsəlz, ən hɝz əmʌŋ ðə smɔləst ə ðoʊz. ʌv kɔɹs, ðə wɛðɝd wʊmən, wɪð əɹ kɹis feɪs ən hɛɹ θɪk wɪð ɡɹeɪ, hæd wɔɹn mɔɹ ðən əɹ pɹɛzən sɪks ɪɹɪŋz ɪn ðə pæst, ən mɔɹ ɡoʊldən mədæljənz ɑn ðə tʃeɪn əkɹɔs əɹ dɑɹk lɛf tʃik. ʃi hæd bɪn wɪndfɪndɝ tə ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps bɪfɔɹ nɛstə dɪn ɹiz wɑz ɪlɛktəd tə ðə poʊst, bʌt baɪ ðɛɹ lɔ, wən ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps əɹ ə weɪvməstʃɹəs daɪd, hɝ wɪndfɪndɝ hæd tə bɪɡɪn əɡɛn ət ðə loʊəs lɛvəl. ðəɹ wɑz mɔɹ tə ɪt ðən ɹɪspɛk fəɹ sɛnaɪnz fɔɹmɝ pəzɪʃən, ðoʊ, nɪneɪiv wɑz sɝɾən. ɹeɪnɪn, ən æpəl-tʃik jʌŋ wʊmən u sɝvd ɑn ə dɑɹɾɝ, ɑkjəpaɪd ðə tʃɛɹ nɛks tə sɛnaɪn, ən stoʊn-feɪst, flæt-aɪd kɹɪn sæt bɪsaɪd ʃilɪn laɪk ə blæk kɑɹvɪŋ. ðɪs ɹɛləɡeɪɾɪd kɛɹ ən tɛbɹl tə ði aʊɾɝmoʊst tʃɛɹz, ən ðeɪ wɝ boʊθ wɪndfɪndɝz tə weɪvməstʃɹɛsəz ðɛmsɛlvz, wɪð fɔɹ fæɾ ɪɹɪŋz ɪn itʃ ɪɹ ən nɪɹli əz mɛni mədæljənz əz zeɪɾə hɝsɛlf. pɝhæps ɪt wɑz dʒʌs tə kip ðə hɔɾi-aɪd sɪstɝz əpɑɹt, ðoʊ. ðeɪ heɪɾəd wʌn ənʌðɝ wɪð ə pæʃən oʊnli blʌd kɪn kəɾ ətʃiv. pɝhæps ðət wɑz ɪt. ʌndɝstændɪŋ ði æθɑn maɪɹ wɑz wɝs ðən tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ʌndɝstæn mɛn. ə wʊmən kəd ɡoʊ mæd tʃɹaɪɪŋ.

In Nynaeve's estimation, today's grouping was very odd, considering the Sea Folks' obsession with rank. Zaida's own Windfinder, Shielyn, sat on her right, a slender, coolly reserved woman almost as tall as Aviendha and towering over Zaida.
