That was proper, as far as Nynaeve understood, but at Zaida's left was Senine, and she served on a soarer, one of the Sea Folk's smaller vessels, and hers among the smallest of those. Of course, the weathered woman, with her creased face and hair thick with gray, had worn more than her present six earrings in the past, and more golden medallions on the chain across her dark left cheek. She had been Windfinder to the Mistress of the Ships before Nesta din Reas was elected to the post, but by their law, when the Mistress of the Ships or a Wavemistress died, her Windfinder had to begin again at the lowest level. There was more to it than respect for Senine's former position, though, Nynaeve was certain. Rainyn, an apple-cheeked young woman who served on a darter, occupied the chair next to Senine, and stone-faced, flat-eyed Kurin sat beside Shielyn like a black carving. This relegated Caire and Tebreille to the outermost chairs, and they were both Windfinders to Wavemistresses themselves, with four fat earrings in each ear and nearly as many medallions as Zaida herself. Perhaps it was just to keep the haughty-eyed sisters apart, though. They hated one another with a passion only blood kin could achieve. Perhaps that was it. Understanding the Atha'an Miere was worse than trying to understand men. A woman could go mad trying.

mʌɾɝɪŋ tə hɝsɛlf, nɪneɪiv ɡeɪv əɹ ʃɔl ə dʒɝk ən pɹipɛɹd hɝsɛlf, ɹɛɾiɪŋ əɹ floʊz. ðə pjʊɹ dʒɔɪ ʌv hoʊldɪŋ seɪaɪdɑɹ kəd hɑɹdli kəmpit wɪð əɹ vɛkseɪʃən. tʃɹaɪ əɡɛn, nɪneɪiv. wʌn mɔɹ taɪm, nɪneɪiv. də ɪt naʊ, nɪneɪiv. ət list ɹɪneɪl wɑz nɑt ðɛɹ. ɔfən ðeɪ wɑntəɾ əɹ tə titʃ θɪŋz ʃi dɪd nɑt noʊ əz wɛl əz ʌðɝz - tu ɔfən, θɪŋz ʃi bɛɹli nu əɾ ɔl, ʃi ədmɪɾəd ɹɪlʌktənli; ʃi hæd nɑt ɹɪli hæd mʌtʃ tʃɹeɪnɪŋ ɪn ðə taʊɝ - ən wɛnɛvɝ ʃi fʌmbəld ɪn ðə slaɪɾəst, ɹɪneɪl pɑzəɾɪvli dɪlaɪɾəd ɪn meɪkɪŋ əɹ swɛt. ði ʌðɝz meɪɾ əɹ swɛt, tu, bʌt ðeɪ dɪd nɑt sim tə teɪk soʊ mʌtʃ plɛʒɝ ɪn ɪt. ɛniweɪ, æftɝ ə sɑləɾ aʊɝ, ʃi wɑz taɪɝd. dʒɹæt sɝaɪðə ən əɹ ɛɹənd!

Muttering to herself, Nynaeve gave her shawl a jerk and prepared herself, readying her flows. The pure joy of holding saidar could hardly compete with her vexation. Try again, Nynaeve. One more time, Nynaeve. Do it now, Nynaeve. At least Renaile was not there. Often they wanted her to teach things she did not know as well as others - too often, things she barely knew at all, she admitted reluctantly; she had not really had much training in the Tower - and whenever she fumbled in the slightest, Renaile positively delighted in making her sweat. The others made her sweat, too, but they did not seem to take so much pleasure in it. Anyway, after a solid hour, she was tired. Drat Sareitha and her errand!

ʃi stʃɹʌk aʊɾ əɡɛn, bʌt ðɪs taɪm tɑlɑnz floʊ ʌv spɪɹət mɛt hɝz mʌtʃ mɔɹ laɪtli ðən ʃi ɪkspɛktəd, ən əɹ oʊn floʊ swɛp ði ʌðɝ fɝðɝ əsaɪd ðən ʃi hæd mɛnt. əbɹʌpli sɪks wivz ʌv ɛɹ ʃɑɾ aʊt fɹəm ðə ɡɝl, dɑɹɾɪŋ təwɔɹd nɪneɪiv, ən nɪneɪiv kwɪkli slaɪst əm wɪð faɪɝ. ðə sɛvɝd floʊz snæp bæk ɪndə tɑlɑn, dʒoʊltɪŋ əɹ vɪzəbli, bʌt bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ hæd vænɪʃt pɹɑpɝli, sɪks mɔɹ əpɪɹd, fæstɝ ðən bɪfɔɹ. nɪneɪiv slæʃt. ən ɡeɪpt əz tɑlɑnz wiv ə spɪɹət flɪkɝɾ ɝaʊn hɝz ən ɹæpt ɝaʊn hɝ, kʌɾɪŋ ɔf seɪaɪdɑɹ. ʃi wɑz ʃildɪd! tɑlɑn hæd ʃildɪd hɝ! fəɹ ðə faɪnəl ɪndɪɡnəɾi, floʊz ʌv ɛɹ pɪnjən əɹ ɑɹmz ən lɛɡz taɪtli, kɹʌʃɪŋ əɹ skɝts. ɪf ʃi hæd nɑt bɪn soʊ əpsɛɾ ət sɝaɪðə, ɪt nɛvɝ wəɾ əv hæpənd.

She struck out again, but this time Talaan's flow of Spirit met hers much more lightly than she expected, and her own flow swept the other further aside than she had meant. Abruptly six weaves of Air shot out from the girl, darting toward Nynaeve, and Nynaeve quickly sliced them with Fire. The severed flows snapped back into Talaan, jolting her visibly, but before they had vanished properly, six more appeared, faster than before. Nynaeve slashed. And gaped as Talaan's weave of Spirit flickered around hers and wrapped around her, cutting off saidar. She was shielded! Talaan had shielded her! For the final indignity, flows of Air pinioned her arms and legs tightly, crushing her skirts. If she had not been so upset at Sareitha, it never would have happened.

"ðə ɡɝl əz hɝ," kɛɹ sɛd, saʊndɪŋ sɝpɹaɪzd. noʊ wʌn wəd θɪŋk ʃi wɑz tɑlɑnz mʌðɝ baɪ ðə koʊld lʊk ʃi ɡeɪv hɝ. ɪndid, tɑlɑn simd ɪmbɛɹəs baɪ hɝ oʊn səksɛs, ɹilisɪŋ ðə floʊz ɪmiɾiətli ən dʒɹɑpɪŋ əɹ aɪz tə ðə flɔɹ.

"The girl has her," Caire said, sounding surprised. No one would think she was Talaan's mother by the cold look she gave her. Indeed, Talaan seemed embarrassed by her own success, releasing the flows immediately and dropping her eyes to the floor.

"vɛɹi ɡʊd, tɑlɑn," nɪneɪiv sɛd, sɪns noʊ wʌn ɛls wɑz ɔfɝɪŋ ə wɝɾ ə pɹeɪz əɹ ɛnkɝɪdʒmənt. ɪɹɪɾəbli ʃi ʃʊk aʊɾ əɹ ʃɔl bɪhaɪn əɹ ən sɛɾəld ɪɾ ɪndə ðə kɹʊks ə hɝ ɛlboʊz. noʊ nid tə tɛl ðə ɡɝl ʃi hæd bɪn lʌki. ʃi wɑz kwɪk, tʃɹu, bʌt nɪneɪiv wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ ʃi hɝsɛlf kəd kip tʃænəlɪŋ mʌtʃ lɔŋɡɝ. ʃi sɝɾənli wɑz nɑɾ əɾ əɹ bɛs naʊ. "aɪm əfɹeɪd ðəɾ ɪz ɔl ðə taɪm aɪ hæv tədeɪ, soʊ - "

"Very good, Talaan," Nynaeve said, since no one else was offering a word of praise or encouragement. Irritably she shook out her shawl behind her and settled it into the crooks of her elbows. No need to tell the girl she had been lucky. She was quick, true, but Nynaeve was not sure she herself could keep channeling much longer. She certainly was not at her best now. "I'm afraid that is all the time I have today, so - "

"tʃɹaɪ əɡɛn," zeɪɾə kəmændəd, linɪŋ fɔɹwɝɾ ɪntɛnli. "aɪ wɑnə si sʌmθɪŋ." ðət wɑz nɑɾ ən ɛkspləneɪʃən, əɹ ɛniθɪŋ nɪɹ əpɑlədʒi, sɪmpli ə steɪtmən ə fækt. zeɪɾə nɛvɝ ɪkspleɪn əɹ əpɑlədʒaɪzd. ʃi dʒʌst ɪkspɛktəɾ oʊbiɾiəns.

"Try again," Zaida commanded, leaning forward intently. "I want to see something." That was not an explanation, or anything near apology, simply a statement of fact. Zaida never explained or apologized. She just expected obedience.

nɪneɪiv kənsɪɾɝd tɛlɪŋ ðə wʊmən ʃi kəd nɑt si ɛniθɪŋ ðeɪ wɝ duɪŋ ɛniweɪ, bʌt ʃi ɹɪdʒɛktɪd ðə θɔɾ ɪmiɾiətli. nɑt wɪð sɪks wɪndfɪndɝz ɪn ðə ɹum. tu deɪz ɝliɝ ʃi hæd vɔɪst əɹ əpɪnjənz fɹili, ən ʃi sɝɾənli dɪd nɑt wɑn ə ɹɪpiɾ ə ðæt. ʃi hæd tʃɹaɪd θɪŋkɪŋ ʌv ɪɾ əz ə pɛnəns, fəɹ spikɪŋ wɪθaʊt θɪŋkɪŋ, bʌt ðət dɪd nɑt hɛlp vɛɹi mʌtʃ. ʃi wɪʃt ʃi hæd nɛvɝ tɔɾ əm tə lɪŋk.

Nynaeve considered telling the woman she could not see anything they were doing anyway, but she rejected the thought immediately. Not with six Windfinders in the room. Two days earlier she had voiced her opinions freely, and she certainly did not want a repeat of that. She had tried thinking of it as a penance, for speaking without thinking, but that did not help very much. She wished she had never taught them to link.

"wʌn mɔɹ taɪm," ʃi sɛd taɪtli, tɝnɪŋ bæk tə tɑlɑn, "æn ðən aɪ mʌst ɡoʊ."

"One more time," she said tightly, turning back to Talaan, "and then I must go."

ʃi wɑz ɹɛɾi fəɹ ðə ɡɝlz tʃɹɪk ðɪs taɪm. tʃænəlɪŋ, ʃi mɛt tɑlɑnz wiv mɔɹ dɛkstɝəsli, ən wɪθaʊt soʊ mʌtʃ fɔɹs. ðə ɡɝl smaɪld əɾ əɹ ənsɝteɪnli. θɪŋkɪŋ nɪneɪiv wəd nɑt bi dɪstʃɹæktəd baɪ ɛkstʃɹeɪniəs floʊz ʌv ɛɹ ðɪs taɪm, wɑz ʃi? tɑlɑnz wiv bɪɡæn tə kɝl ɝaʊn hɝz, ən ʃi nɪmbli spʌn əɹ oʊn tə kætʃ ɪt. ʃi wəd bi ɹɛɾi wən ðə wʊmən pɹədust əɹ floʊz ʌv ɛɹ. əɹ meɪbi nɑɾ ɛɹ, ðɪs taɪm. nʌθɪŋ deɪnʒɝəs ʃʊɹli. ðɪs wɑz pɹæktəs. oʊnli, tɑlɑnz floʊ ʌv spɪɹət dɪd nɑt kəmplit ðət kɝl, ən nɪneɪivz swʌŋ waɪd waɪl tɑlɑnz stʃɹʌk stʃɹeɪɾ əɾ əɹ ən lætʃt ɑn. wʌns əɡɛn, seɪaɪdɑɹ wɪŋkt aʊɾ ə hɝ, ən bɑnz ʌv ɛɹ snæpt əɹ ɑɹmz tə hɝ saɪdz, fæsən əɹ niz.

She was ready for the girl's trick this time. Channeling, she met Talaan's weave more dexterously, and without so much force. The girl smiled at her uncertainly. Thinking Nynaeve would not be distracted by extraneous flows of Air this time, was she? Talaan's weave began to curl around hers, and she nimbly spun her own to catch it. She would be ready when the woman produced her flows of Air. Or maybe not Air, this time. Nothing dangerous surely. This was practice. Only, Talaan's flow of Spirit did not complete that curl, and Nynaeve's swung wide while Talaan's struck straight at her and latched on. Once again, saidar winked out of her, and bonds of Air snapped her arms to her sides, fastened her knees.

kɛɹfəli, ʃi dʒɹu bɹɛθ. ʃi wəɾ əv tə kənɡɹætʃəleɪt ðə jʌŋ wʊmən. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɡɛɾɪŋ aʊɾ ʌv ɪt. ɪf ʃi hæd hæɾ ə hæn fɹi, ʃi wʊɾə jæŋkt əɹ bɹeɪd ɹaɪɾ aʊɾ ə hɝ skælp.

Carefully, she drew breath. She would have to congratulate the young woman. There was no getting out of it. If she had had a hand free, she would have yanked her braid right out of her scalp.

"hoʊld!" zeɪɾə kəmændəd, ɹaɪzɪŋ tə stʃɹaɪd ɡɹeɪsfəli təwɔɹd nɪneɪiv, hɝ ɹɛd sɪlk tʃɹaʊzɝz wɪskɪŋ sɔfli əbʌv əɹ bɛɹ fit, ɪntʃɹəkətli nɑɾɪd ɹɛd sæʃ sweɪɪŋ əɡɛnst əɹ θaɪ. ðə wɪndfɪndɝz stʊd wɪð əɹ ən fɑloʊd, ɪn ɔɹɾɝ ə ɹæŋk. kɛɹ ən tɛbɹl aɪsɪli ɪɡnɔɹd wʌn ənʌðɝ əz ðeɪ hɝid tə teɪk pleɪsəz nɪɹəs ðə weɪvməstʃɹəs waɪl sɛnaɪn ən ɹeɪnɪn fɛl ə peɪs tə ðə ɹɪɹ.

"Hold!" Zaida commanded, rising to stride gracefully toward Nynaeve, her red silk trousers whisking softly above her bare feet, intricately knotted red sash swaying against her thigh. The Windfinders stood with her and followed, in order of rank. Caire and Tebreille icily ignored one another as they hurried to take places nearest the Wavemistress while Senine and Rainyn fell a pace to the rear.

oʊbiɾiəntli, tɑlɑn hɛl ðə ʃild ɑn nɪneɪiv, ən ðə bɑnz, livɪŋ əɹ stændɪŋ laɪk ə stætʃu. ən fjumɪŋ laɪk ə kɛɾəl tu lɔŋ ɑn ðə bɔɪl. ʃi ɹəfjuz tə ʃʌfəl əbaʊt, ə bɹoʊkən pʌpət, ən ðət wɑz ɔl ðət wɑz lɛf tə hɝ ɪksɛp stændɪŋ stɪl. kɛɹ ən tɛbɹl stʌɾid əɹ wɪð aɪsi dɪsdeɪn, kɹɪn wɪð ðə hɑɹd kəntɛmpt ʃi hæd fəɹ ɔl læn dwɛlɝz. ðə stoʊn-aɪd wʊmən dɪd nɑt snɪɹ əɹ ɡɹɪmɑs əɹ wɛɹ ɛni ɹil ɪkspɹɛʃən əɾ ɔl, bʌt jə kəd nɑt bi wɪð əɹ lɔŋ wɪθaʊt bɪkʌmɪŋ əwɛɹ ə hɝ əpɪnjən. oʊnli ɹeɪnɪn dɪspleɪd ðə smɔləs tʌtʃ ə sɪmpəθi, ə slaɪt ɹufəl smaɪl.

Obediently, Talaan held the shield on Nynaeve, and the bonds, leaving her standing like a statue. And fuming like a kettle too long on the boil. She refused to shuffle about, a broken puppet, and that was all that was left to her except standing still. Caire and Tebreille studied her with icy disdain, Kurin with the hard contempt she had for all land dwellers. The stone-eyed woman did not sneer or grimace or wear any real expression at all, but you could not be with her long without becoming aware of her opinion. Only Rainyn displayed the smallest touch of sympathy, a slight rueful smile.

zeɪɾəz aɪz mɛt nɪneɪivz lɛvəli. ðeɪ wɝ mʌtʃ ðə seɪm haɪt. "ʃi ɪz hɛld əz taɪtli əz jə kæn, əpɹɛntəs?"

Zaida's eyes met Nynaeve's levelly. They were much the same height. "She is held as tightly as you can, apprentice?"

tɑlɑn baʊd dipli, pɛɹəlɛl tə ðə flɔɹ, tʌtʃɪŋ əɹ fɔɹhɛd, lɪps ən hɑɹt. "æz jə kəmændəd, weɪvməstʃɹəs," ʃi ɔl bʌt wɪspɝd.

Talaan bowed deeply, parallel to the floor, touching her forehead, lips and heart. "As you commanded, Wavemistress," she all but whispered.

"wʌɾ ɪz ðə minɪŋ ə ðɪs?" nɪneɪiv dɪmændəd. "lɛt mi ɡoʊ. jə meɪ ɡɛɾ əweɪ wɪð tʃɹiɾɪŋ mɛɝɪlɪl ðɪs weɪ, bʌɾ ɪf jə θɪŋk fəɹ wʌn mɪnət - !"

"What is the meaning of this?" Nynaeve demanded. "Let me go. You may get away with treating Merilille this way, but if you think for one minute - !"

"ju seɪ ðəɹ ɪz noʊ weɪ tə bɹeɪk ðɪs ʃild ənlɛs jə ɑɹ mʌtʃ stʃɹɔŋɝ," zeɪɾə kʌɾ əɹ ɔf. hɝ toʊn wɑz nɑt hɑɹʃ, bʌt ʃi mɛn tə bi hɝd, nɑt tə lɪsən. "ðə laɪt wɪlɪŋ, wɪl lɝn wɛðɝ jə toʊld əs kɝɛkli. ɪts wɛl noʊn haʊ ɛɛs sədaɪ meɪk tʃɹuθ spɪn laɪk ə wɝlpul. wɪndfɪndɝz, jəl fɔɹm ə sɝkəl. kɹɪn, jəl lid. ɪf ʃi dʌz bɹeɪk fɹi, si ðət ʃi kɑzəz noʊ hɑɹm. fəɹ ɪnsɛntɪv . . . əpɹɛntəs, pɹipɛɹ tə tɝn əɹ ʌpsaɪd daʊn ət maɪ kaʊn ə faɪv. wʌn."

"You say there is no way to break this shield unless you are much stronger," Zaida cut her off. Her tone was not harsh, but she meant to be heard, not to listen. "The Light willing, we will learn whether you told us correctly. It is well known how Aes Sedai make truth spin like a whirlpool. Windfinders, you will form a circle. Kurin, you will lead. If she does break free, see that she causes no harm. For incentive . . . Apprentice, prepare to turn her upside down at my count of five. One."

ðə laɪɾ ə seɪaɪdɑɹ ɛnvɛləp ðə wɪndfɪndɝz, ɔl ə ðɛm təɡɛðɝ, əz ðeɪ lɪŋkt. kɹɪn stʊd wɪð əɹ fiɾ əpɑɹɾ ən əɹ hænz ɑn əɹ hɪps, əz ɪf bælənsɪŋ ɑn ðə dɛk ʌv ə ʃɪp. hɝ vɛɹi læk ʌv ɪkspɹɛʃən sim tə kənveɪ ðət ʃi wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi kənvɪns ðeɪ wəɾ ənkʌvɝ pɹɛvɝəkeɪʃən ɪf nɑɾ ən aʊtʃɹaɪt laɪ. tɑlɑn dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ, ən fəɹ wʌns stʊd vɛɹi stʃɹeɪt, nɑɾ ivən blɪŋkɪŋ əz ʃi kɛpt əɹ æŋkʃəs aɪz ɑn zeɪɾə.

The light of saidar enveloped the Windfinders, all of them together, as they linked. Kurin stood with her feet apart and her hands on her hips, as if balancing on the deck of a ship. Her very lack of expression seemed to convey that she was already convinced they would uncover prevarication if not an outright lie. Talaan drew a deep breath, and for once stood very straight, not even blinking as she kept her anxious eyes on Zaida.

nɪneɪiv blɪŋkt. noʊ! ðeɪ kəd nɑt də ðɪs tə hɝ! nɑɾ əɡɛn! "aɪ æm tɛlɪŋ ju," ʃi sɛd, mʌtʃ mɔɹ kɑmli ðən ʃi fɛlt, "ðɛɹ ɪz noʊ weɪ fəɹ mi tə bɹeɪk ðə ʃild. tɑlɑn ɪz tu stʃɹɔŋ."

Nynaeve blinked. No! They could not do this to her! Not again! "I am telling you," she said, much more calmly than she felt, "there is no way for me to break the shield. Talaan is too strong."

"tu," zeɪɾə sɛd, foʊldɪŋ əɹ ɑɹmz bɪniθ əɹ bɹɛsts ən stɛɹɪŋ ət nɪneɪiv əz ðoʊ ʃi ɹɪli kəd si ðə wivz.

"Two," Zaida said, folding her arms beneath her breasts and staring at Nynaeve as though she really could see the weaves.

nɪneɪiv pʊʃt tɛntəɾɪvli ət ðə ʃild. ʃi maɪɾ əz wɛl pʊʃ əɾ ə stoʊn wɔl fəɹ ɔl ðə ɡɪv ɪn ɪt. "lɪsən tə mi, zɑ . . . ʌ . . . weɪvməstʃɹəs." ðəɹ wɑz sɝɾənli noʊ nid tə æntæɡənaɪz ðə wʊmən fɝðɝ. ðeɪ wɝ stɪklɝz fəɹ pɹɑpɝ fɔɹmz ʌv ədʒɹɛs. stɪklɝz fəɹ ɔl tu mɛni θɪŋz. "aɪm ʃʊɹ mɛɝɪlɪl əz toʊl jə sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt ʃildɪŋ, ət list. ʃi swɔɹ ðə θɹi oʊðz. ʃi kæn laɪ." meɪbi ɛɡwin wɑz ɹaɪɾ əbaʊt ði oʊθ ɹɑd.

Nynaeve pushed tentatively at the shield. She might as well push at a stone wall for all the give in it. "Listen to me, Za . . . uh . . . Wavemistress." There was certainly no need to antagonize the woman further. They were sticklers for proper forms of address. Sticklers for all too many things. "I'm sure Merilille has told you something about shielding, at least. She swore the Three Oaths. She can't lie." Maybe Egwene was right about the Oath Rod.

zeɪɾəz ɡeɪz nɛvɝ weɪvɝd, hɝ ɪkspɹɛʃən nɛvɝ tʃeɪnʒd. "θɹi."

Zaida's gaze never wavered, her expression never changed. "Three."

"lɪsən tə mi," nɪneɪiv sɛd, nɑt kɛɹɪŋ əɾ ɔl ɪf ʃi saʊndəɾ ə bɪt dɛspɹɪt. meɪbi mɔɹ ðən dʒʌst ə bɪt. ʃi pʊʃt əɡɛns ðə ʃil hɑɹɾɝ, ðən əz hɑɹɾ əz ʃi kʊd. ʃi maɪɾ əz wɛl əv biɾ əɹ hɛɾ əɡɛnst ə boʊldɝ fəɹ ɔl ði ɪfɛkt ɪt hæd. ɪnstɪŋktɪvli, jusləsli, ʃi stʃɹʌɡəld ɪn ðə bɑnz ʌv ɛɹ hoʊldɪŋ hɝ, ðə fɹɪnʒ ən lus foʊlz ə hɝ ʃɔl dænsɪŋ ɝaʊn hɝ. ʃi hæɾ əz mʌtʃ tʃæns ə bɹeɪkɪŋ fɹi ʌv ðoʊz bɑnz əz ʃi dɪɾ ə bɹeɪkɪŋ θɹu ðə ʃild, bʌt ʃi kəd nɑt stɑp hɝsɛlf. nɑɾ əɡɛn! ʃi kəd nɑt feɪs ðæt! "ju hæv tə lɪsən!"

"Listen to me," Nynaeve said, not caring at all if she sounded a bit desperate. Maybe more than just a bit. She pushed against the shield harder, then as hard as she could. She might as well have beat her head against a boulder for all the effect it had. Instinctively, uselessly, she struggled in the bonds of Air holding her, the fringe and loose folds of her shawl dancing around her. She had as much chance of breaking free of those bonds as she did of breaking through the shield, but she could not stop herself. Not again! She could not face that! "You have to listen!"

"fɔɹ."

"Four."

noʊ! noʊ! nɑɾ əɡɛn! fɹæntəkəli ʃi skɹæbəld ət ðə ʃild. ɪt maɪt bi əz hɑɹɾ əz stoʊn, bʌɾ ɪt fɛl mɔɹ laɪk ɡlæs, slik ən slɪpɝi. ʃi kəd fil ðə sɔɹs bɪɑn ɪt, ɔlmoʊst si ðə sɔɹs, laɪk laɪɾ ən wɔɹmθ dʒʌs bɪɑn ðə kɔɹnɝ ə vɪʒən. ɪn dɛspɝeɪʃən, pæntɪŋ, ʃi fɛlt əɹ weɪ əkɹɔs ðə smuð sɝfəs. ɪt hæɾ ən ɛdʒ, laɪk ə sɝkəl ət wʌns smɔl ɪnʌf tə hoʊld ɪn əɹ hænz ən lɑɹdʒ ɪnʌf tə kʌvɝ ðə wɝld, bʌt wən ʃi ətɛmptəd tə slɪp ɝaʊn ðəɾ ɛdʒ, ʃi faʊn hɝsɛlf ɹaɪt bæk ɪn ðə sɛntɝ ə ðə slɪk hɑɹd sɝkəl əɡɛn. ðɪs wɑz jusləs. ʃi hæd lɝn ɔl ðɪs lɔŋ əɡoʊ, tʃɹaɪɾ ɪɾ ɔl lɔŋ əɡoʊ. hɝ hɑɹt paʊndɪd fɪt tə bɝst aʊɾ ə hɝ ɹɪbz. stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ veɪnli fəɹ kɑm, ʃi hɝidli fɛlt əɹ weɪ bæk tə ði ɛdʒ, fɛlt əlɔŋ ɪt wɪθaʊt tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɡoʊ ɝaʊnd. ðəɹ wɑz wʌn pleɪs wɛɹ ɪt fɛlt . . . sɑftɝ. ʃi hæd nɛvɝ noʊɾəst ðət bɪfɔɹ. ðə sɑf pɔɪnt - ə slaɪt lʌmp? - sim noʊ dɪfɹən ɪn ɛni ʌðɝ weɪ fɹəm ðə ɹɛst, ən ɪt wɑz nɑt mʌtʃ sɑftɝ, bʌt ʃi hɝl hɝsɛlf əɾ ɪt. ən faʊn hɝsɛlf bæk ɪn ðə sɛntɝ. ɪn ə fɹɛnzi, ʃi flʌŋ ɔl ə hɝ stʃɹɛŋkθ ət ðə sɑf spɑt, əɡɛn ən əɡɛn, biɪŋ hɝl bæk tə ðə sɛntɝ, nɑɾ ivən pɔzɪŋ bɪfɔɹ lɔntʃɪŋ hɝsɛlf əɾ ɪɾ əɡɛn. əɡɛn. oʊ, laɪt! pliz! ʃi hæd tə, bɪfɔɹ . . . !

No! No! Not again! Frantically she scrabbled at the shield. It might be as hard as stone, but it felt more like glass, sleek and slippery. She could feel the Source beyond it, almost see the Source, like light and warmth just beyond the corner of vision. In desperation, panting, she felt her way across the smooth surface. It had an edge, like a circle at once small enough to hold in her hands and large enough to cover the world, but when she attempted to slip around that edge, she found herself right back in the center of the slick hard circle again. This was useless. She had learned all this long ago, tried it all long ago. Her heart pounded fit to burst out of her ribs. Struggling vainly for calm, she hurriedly felt her way back to the edge, felt along it without trying to go around. There was one place where it felt . . . softer. She had never noticed that before. The soft point - a slight lump? - seemed no different in any other way from the rest, and it was not much softer, but she hurled herself at it. And found herself back in the center. In a frenzy, she flung all of her strength at the soft spot, again and again, being hurled back to the center, not even pausing before launching herself at it again. Again. Oh, Light! Please! She had to, before . . . !

əbɹʌpli ʃi ɹilaɪz ðət zeɪɾə stɪl hæd nɑt sɛd faɪv. ɡʌlpɪŋ ɛɹ əz ɪf ʃi hæd ɹʌn tɛn maɪlz, ʃi stɛɹd. swɛt ɹoʊl daʊn əɹ feɪs, hɝ bæk. ɪt tʃɹɪkəl bɪtwin əɹ bɹɛsts, slɪd daʊn əɹ bɛli. hɝ lɛɡz wɑbəld. ðə weɪvməstʃɹəs lʊk stʃɹeɪɾ ɪndə hɝ aɪz, θɔtfəli tæpɪŋ fʊl lɪps wɪð ə slɪm fɪŋɡɝ. ðə ɡloʊ stɪl ɛnvɛləp ðə sɝkəl ə sɪks, kɹɪn stɪl cʊɾə bɪn ə skɔɹnfəli stoʊni stætʃu, bʌt zeɪɾə hæd nɑt sɛd faɪv.

Abruptly she realized that Zaida still had not said five. Gulping air as if she had run ten miles, she stared. Sweat rolled down her face, her back. It trickled between her breasts, slid down her belly. Her legs wobbled. The Wavemistress looked straight into her eyes, thoughtfully tapping full lips with a slim finger. The glow still enveloped the circle of six, Kurin still could have been a scornfully stony statue, but Zaida had not said five.

"dɪd ʃi tʃɹuli tʃɹaɪ əz hɑɹɾ əz ɪt simd, kɹɪn," ðə weɪvməstʃɹəs æsk faɪnəli, "ɔɹ wɑz ɔl ðət θɹæʃɪŋ əbaʊɾ ən wɪmpɝɪŋ dʒʌst ə ʃoʊ?" nɪneɪiv tʃɹaɪd tə sʌmən ən ɪndɪɡnənt ɡlɛɹ. ʃi hæd nɑt wɪmpɝd! hæd ʃi? hɝ skaʊl, sətʃ əz ɪt wɑz, meɪd noʊ mɔɹ ɪmpɹɛʃən ɑn zeɪɾə ðən ɹeɪn ɑn ə ɹɑk.

"Did she truly try as hard as it seemed, Kurin," the Wavemistress asked finally, "or was all that thrashing about and whimpering just a show?" Nynaeve tried to summon an indignant glare. She had not whimpered! Had she? Her scowl, such as it was, made no more impression on Zaida than rain on a rock.

"wɪð ðət mʌtʃ ɛfɝt, weɪvməstʃɹəs," kɹɪn sɛd ɹɪlʌktənli, "ʃi cʊɾə kæɹiɾ ə ɹeɪkɝ ɑn əɹ bæk." ðə flæt blæk pɛbəlz ə hɝ aɪz stɪl hɛl kəntɛmpt, ðoʊ. oʊnli ðoʊz u lɪvd ət si ɡɑɾ ɛni ɹɪspɛk fɹəm hɝ.

"With that much effort, Wavemistress," Kurin said reluctantly, "she could have carried a raker on her back." The flat black pebbles of her eyes still held contempt, though. Only those who lived at sea got any respect from her.

"ɹilis hɝ, tɑlɑn," zeɪɾə kəmændəd, ən ʃild ən bɑnz vænɪʃt əz ʃi tɝn əweɪ, stɑɹɾɪŋ bæk təwɔɹd ðə tʃɛɹz wɪθaʊɾ ənʌðɝ ɡlæns ət nɪneɪiv. "wɪndfɪndɝz, əl əv wɝdz wɪð jə æftɝ ʃi ɡoʊz. əl si jə ət ðə seɪm aʊɝ təmɑɹoʊ, nɪneɪiv sədaɪ."

"Release her, Talaan," Zaida commanded, and shield and bonds vanished as she turned away, starting back toward the chairs without another glance at Nynaeve. "Windfinders, I will have words with you after she goes. I will see you at the same hour tomorrow, Nynaeve Sedai."

smuðɪŋ əɹ ɹʌmpəl skɝts ən ɪɹɪɾəbli ʃeɪkɪŋ aʊɾ əɹ ʃɔl əɡɛn, nɪneɪiv ətɛmptəd tə ɹiɡɑðɝ ə lɪɾəl dɪɡnəɾi. ɪt wɑz nɑɾ izi, swɛt-slɪkt ən tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ. ʃi sɝɾənli hæd nɑt wɪmpɝd! ʃi tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə lʊk ət ðə wʊmən u hæd ʃildɪd hɝ. twaɪs! stændɪŋ ðəɹ mik əz bʌɾɝ, wɪð əɹ aɪz fɪkst ɑn ðə kɑɹpət. hɑ! nɪneɪiv dʒɝkt əɹ ʃɔl ɝaʊn əɹ ʃoʊldɝz. "sɝaɪðə sədaɪ wɪl teɪk əɹ tɝn təmɑɹoʊ, weɪvməstʃɹəs." ət list əɹ vɔɪs wɑz stɛɾi. "aɪ wɪl bi bɪzi əntɪl - "

Smoothing her rumpled skirts and irritably shaking out her shawl again, Nynaeve attempted to regather a little dignity. It was not easy, sweat-slicked and trembling. She certainly had not whimpered! She tried not to look at the woman who had shielded her. Twice! Standing there meek as butter, with her eyes fixed on the carpet. Ha! Nynaeve jerked her shawl around her shoulders. "Sareitha Sedai will take her turn tomorrow, Wavemistress." At least her voice was steady. "I will be busy until - "

"jɔɹ ɪnstʃɹʌkʃən ɪz mɔɹ ɛɾəfaɪɪŋ ðən ðəɾ ə ði ʌðɝz," zeɪɾə sɛd, stɪl nɑt bɑðɝɪŋ tə lʊk ət hɝ. "æt ðə seɪm aʊɝ, əɹ əl sɛn jəɹ pjupəlz tə bɹɪŋ ju. jə meɪ liv naʊ." ən ðət hæd ðə saʊn ə jəl liv naʊ.

"Your instruction is more edifying than that of the others," Zaida said, still not bothering to look at her. "At the same hour, or I will send your pupils to bring you. You may leave now." And that had the sound of you will leave now.

wɪð ən ɛfɝt, nɪneɪiv swɑloʊɾ əɹ ɑɹɡjəməns. ðeɪ hæɾ ə bɪɾɝ teɪst. mɔɹ ɛɾəfaɪɪŋ? wʌd ðət min? ʃi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ʃi ɹɪli wɑntəd tə noʊ.

With an effort, Nynaeve swallowed her arguments. They had a bitter taste. More edifying? What did that mean? She did not think she really wanted to know.

əntɪl ʃi æktʃəli  lɛf ðə ɹum, ʃi wɑz stɪl ðə titʃɝ - ðə si foʊk wɝ ɹɪdʒəɾ ɪn ðɛɹ ɹulz; nɪneɪiv səpoʊz ðət læks ɹulz ɑn ʃɪps kəd lid tə tʃɹʌbəl, bʌt ʃi wɪʃt ðeɪ wəd ɹilaɪz ðeɪ wɝ nɑɾ ɑn ə ʃɪp - ʃi wɑz stɪl ðə titʃɝ, ən ðət mɛnt ʃi kəd nɑt sɪmpli stɔk aʊt, haʊɛvɝ mʌtʃ ʃi wɑntəd tə. wɝs, ðɛɹ ɹulz wɝ kwaɪt spəsɪfɪk əbaʊt titʃɝz fɹəm əmʌŋ ðə ʃɔɹbaʊnd. ʃi kəd sɪmpli hæv ɹəfjuz tə koʊɑpɝeɪt, ʃi səpoʊzd, bʌɾ ɪf ʃi vaɪəleɪɾɪd ðɛɹ bɑɹɡən baɪ ə hɛɹ, ðiz wɪmən wəd spɹɛɾ ɪt fɹəm tiɹ tə ðə laɪt nu wɛɹ! ðə hoʊl wɝld wəd noʊ ðəɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ hæd bɹoʊkən ðɛɹ wɝd. wʌt ðət wəd də tə ɛɛs sədaɪ stændɪŋ dɪd nɑt bɛɹ θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt. blʌɾ ən blʌɾi æʃəz! ɛɡwin wɑz ɹaɪt, ən bɝn əɹ fəɹ ɪt!

Until she actually left the room, she was still the teacher - the Sea Folk were rigid in their rules; Nynaeve supposed that lax rules on ships could lead to trouble, but she wished they would realize they were not on a ship - she was still the teacher, and that meant she could not simply stalk out, however much she wanted to. Worse, their rules were quite specific about teachers from among the shorebound. She could simply have refused to cooperate, she supposed, but if she violated their bargain by a hair, these women would spread it from Tear to the Light knew where! The whole world would know that Aes Sedai had broken their word. What that would do to Aes Sedai standing did not bear thinking about. Blood and bloody ashes! Egwene was right, and burn her for it!

"θæŋk ju, weɪvməstʃɹəs, fəɹ əlaʊɪŋ mi tə ɪnstʃɹʌk ju," ʃi sɛd, boʊɪŋ ən tʌtʃɪŋ fɪŋɡɝz tə fɔɹhɛd, lɪps ən hɑɹt. nɑɾ ə vɛɹi dip baʊ, bʌɾ ə kwɪk bɑb wɑz ɔl ðeɪ wɝ ɡɛɾɪŋ tədeɪ. wɛl, tu. ðə wɪndfɪndɝz hæd tə hæv wʌn. "θæŋk ju, wɪndfɪndɝz, fəɹ əlaʊɪŋ mi tə ɪnstʃɹʌk ju." ðə sɪstɝz u faɪnəli wɛn tə ði æθɑn maɪɹ wəɾ ɪksploʊd wən ðeɪ lɝn ðət ðɛɹ pjupəlz kəd tɛl əm wʌt tə titʃ ən wɛn, ən ivən ɔɹɾɝ wʌt ðeɪ dɪd wən nɑt titʃɪŋ. ɑn ə si foʊk vɛsəl, ə lænd-dwɛlɪŋ titʃɝ aʊtʃɹæŋk ðə kɑmən dɛkhənz, bʌɾ oʊnli dʒʌst. ən ðə sɪstɝz wəd nɑɾ ivən ɡɛt ðə fæt pɝsɪz ʌv ɡoʊl juz tə lʊɹ ʌðɝ titʃɝz ɑn bɔɹd.

"Thank you, Wavemistress, for allowing me to instruct you," she said, bowing and touching fingers to forehead, lips and heart. Not a very deep bow, but a quick bob was all they were getting today. Well, two. The Windfinders had to have one. "Thank you, Windfinders, for allowing me to instruct you." The sisters who finally went to the Atha'an Miere would explode when they learned that their pupils could tell them what to teach and when, and even order what they did when not teaching. On a Sea Folk vessel, a land-dwelling teacher outranked the common deckhands, but only just. And the sisters would not even get the fat purses of gold used to lure other teachers on board.

zeɪɾə ən ðə wɪndfɪndɝz ɹiæktəd vɛɹi mʌtʃ əz ɪf ðə loʊəs dɛkhæn hæɾ ənaʊnst əɹ dɪpɑɹtʃɝ. ðəɾ ɪz, ðeɪ stʊɾ ɪn ə saɪlən klʌstɝ, pleɪnli weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ əɹ tə ɡoʊ, ən nɑt vɛɹi peɪʃən əbaʊɾ ɪt. oʊnli ɹeɪnɪn feɪvɝɾ əɹ wɪð əz mʌtʃ əz ə ɡlæns. ən ɪmpeɪʃənt ɡlæns. ʃi wɑz ə wɪndfɪndɝ, æftɝ ɔl wɑz sɛɾ ən dʌn. tɑlɑn stɪl stʊd wɛɹ ʃi hæd bɪn lɛft, ə mik fɪɡjɝ ɡeɪzɪŋ ət ðə kɑɹpəɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ bɛɹ fit.

Zaida and the Windfinders reacted very much as if the lowest deckhand had announced her departure. That is, they stood in a silent cluster, plainly waiting for her to go, and not very patient about it. Only Rainyn favored her with as much as a glance. An impatient glance. She was a Windfinder, after all was said and done. Talaan still stood where she had been left, a meek figure gazing at the carpet in front of her bare feet.

hɛd haɪ ən bæk stʃɹeɪt, nɪneɪiv lɛf ðə ɹum wɪð ɛvɹi ʃɹɛɾ ə dɪɡnəɾi ʃi kəd ɹæp ɝaʊn hɝsɛlf. swɛɾi, ɹʌmpəld ʃɹɛdz. ɪn ðə hɔl, ʃi siz ðə dɔɹ ɪn boʊθ hænz ən slæmd ɪɾ əz hɑɹɾ əz ʃi kʊd. ðə ɡɹeɪt, ɛkoʊɪŋ kɹæʃ wɑz vɛɹi sæɾɪsfaɪɪŋ. ʃi kəɾ ɔlweɪz seɪ ɪt hæd slɪpt aʊɾ ə hɝ hænz, ɪf ɛniwʌn kəmpleɪnd. ɪt ɹɪli hæd, wʌns ʃi ɡɑɾ ə ɡʊd swɪŋ ɡoʊɪŋ.

Head high and back straight, Nynaeve left the room with every shred of dignity she could wrap around herself. Sweaty, rumpled shreds. In the hall, she seized the door in both hands and slammed it as hard as she could. The great, echoing crash was very satisfying. She could always say it had slipped out of her hands, if anyone complained. It really had, once she got a good swing going.

tɝnɪŋ fɹəm ðə dɔɹ, ʃi dʌstɪɾ əɹ hænz wɪð sæɾəsfækʃən. ən ɡeɪv ə stɑɹɾ əɾ u wɑz weɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə kɔɹəɾɝ fəɹ hɝ.

Turning from the door, she dusted her hands with satisfaction. And gave a start at who was waiting in the corridor for her.

ɪn ə sɪmpəl dɑɹk blu dʒɹɛs pɹəvaɪɾəd baɪ wʌn ə ðə kɪnswɪmən, əliviə dɪd nɑt lʊk əɾ ɔl ənjuʒəwəl ət fɝst ɡlæns, ə wʊmən ə lɪɾəl tɔlɝ ðən nɪneɪiv, wɪð faɪn laɪnz ət ðə kɔɹnɝz ə hɝ blu aɪz ən θɹɛdz ʌv waɪɾ ɪn əɹ ɡoʊldən jɛloʊ hɛɹ. ðoʊz blu aɪz kɹækəld wɪð ɪntɛnsəɾi, ðoʊ, laɪk ði aɪz ʌv ə hɔk foʊkəst ɑn pɹeɪ.

In a simple dark blue dress provided by one of the Kinswomen, Alivia did not look at all unusual at first glance, a woman a little taller than Nynaeve, with fine lines at the corners of her blue eyes and threads of white in her golden yellow hair. Those blue eyes crackled with intensity, though, like the eyes of a hawk focused on prey.

"mɪstʃɹəs kɔɹli sɛn mi tə tɛl jə ʃid laɪk tə si jə ət dɪnɝ tənaɪt," ðə blu-aɪd hɔk sɛɾ ɪn ə sloʊ sintʃæn dʒɹɔl. "mɪstʃɹəs kɛɹɪstoʊvən, mɪstʃɹəs ɑɹmən, ən mɪstʃɹəs wɑɹd wɪl bi ðɛɹ."

"Mistress Corly sent me to tell you she'd like to see you at dinner tonight," the blue-eyed hawk said in a slow Seanchan drawl. "Mistress Karistovan, Mistress Arman, and Mistress Juarde will be there."

"wʌɾ ɑɹ jə duɪŋ hɪɹ əloʊn?" nɪneɪiv dɪmændəd. ʃi wɪʃt ʃi kəd bi laɪk moʊst ʌðɝ sɪstɝz, əwɛɹ ʌv ənʌðɝ wʊmənz stʃɹɛŋkθ wɪθaʊɾ ɛvɝ ɹɪli θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪt, bʌt ðət wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ɛls ʃi hæd nɑt hæd taɪm tə lɝn. meɪbi səm ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən tɑpt əliviə, bʌt ʃʊɹli noʊ wʌn ɛls. ən ʃi wɑz sintʃæn. nɪneɪiv wɪʃt ðəɹ wɑz sʌmwʌn ɛls ðəɹ bɪsaɪdz ðə tu ʌv ðɛm. ivən læn, ən ʃi hæɾ ɔɹɾɝd ɪm tə steɪ əweɪ fɹəm əɹ lɛsənz wɪð ðə si foʊk. ʃi wɑz nɑt sɝɾən i bɪlivd əɹ stɔɹi əbaʊt slɪpɪŋ ɑn ðə stɛɹz ði ʌðɝ deɪ. "ju ɑɹən səpoʊz tə ɡoʊ ɛniwɛɹ wɪθaʊɾ ən ɛskɔɹt!"

"What are you doing here alone?" Nynaeve demanded. She wished she could be like most other sisters, aware of another woman's strength without ever really thinking about it, but that was something else she had not had time to learn. Maybe some of the Forsaken topped Alivia, but surely no one else. And she was Seanchan. Nynaeve wished there was someone else there besides the two of them. Even Lan, and she had ordered him to stay away from her lessons with the Sea Folk. She was not certain he believed her story about slipping on the stairs the other day. "You aren't supposed to go anywhere without an escort!"

əliviə ʃɹʌɡd, ə slaɪt muvmən ʌv wʌn ʃoʊldɝ. ə fju deɪz əɡoʊ, ʃi hæd bɪn ə bʌndəl ə sɪmpɝz ðət meɪd tɑlɑn lʊk boʊld. ʃi dɪd nɑt sɪmpɝ fəɹ ɛnibəɾi, naʊ. "ðɛɹ wɑzn ɛniwʌn fɹi, soʊ aɪ slɪpt aʊt baɪ maɪsɛlf. ɛniweɪ, ɪf jə ɔlweɪz ɡɑɹd mi, jəl nɛvɝ kʌm tə tʃɹʌs mi, ən əl nɛvɝ ɡɛt tə kɪl sʌldəm." sʌmhaʊ ðət saʊndəɾ ivən mɔɹ tʃɪlɪŋ, dɪlɪvɝɾ ɪn sətʃ ə kæʒəwəl toʊn. "ju ɔt tə bi lɝnɪŋ fɹəm mi. ðoʊz æʃəmən seɪ ðəɹ wɛpənz, ən ðeɪ ɑɹən bæd, aɪ noʊ fəɹ ə fækt, bʌɾ aɪm bɛɾɝ."

Alivia shrugged, a slight movement of one shoulder. A few days ago, she had been a bundle of simpers that made Talaan look bold. She did not simper for anybody, now. "There wasn't anyone free, so I slipped out by myself. Anyway, if you always guard me, you'll never come to trust me, and I'll never get to kill sul'dam." Somehow that sounded even more chilling, delivered in such a casual tone. "You ought to be learning from me. Those Asha'man say they're weapons, and they aren't bad, I know for a fact, but I'm better."

"ðæts əz meɪ bi," nɪneɪiv ɹɪplaɪd ʃɑɹpli, ʃɪftɪŋ əɹ ʃɔl. "æn meɪbi wi noʊ mɔɹ ðən jə θɪŋk wi du." ʃi wəd nɑt maɪn dɛmənstʃɹeɪɾɪŋ ə fju ʌv ðə wivz ʃi hæd lɝn fɹəm mɑɡiɾin fəɹ ðɪs wʊmən. ɪnkluɾɪŋ ə fju ðeɪ hæɾ ɔl əɡɹid wɝ tu næsti tə də tə ɛniwʌn. ɪksɛpt . . . ʃi wɑz fɛɹli sɝɾən ði ʌðɝ wʊmən kəɾ oʊvɝpaʊɝ əɹ izəli, wʌtɛvɝ ʃi dɪd. kipɪŋ əɹ fit fɹəm ʃɪftɪŋ ʌndɝ ðəɾ ɪntɛns stɛɹ wɑz nɑɾ izi. "əntɪl - ənlɛs! - wi dɪsaɪd dɪfɹənli, jə woʊn lemi si jə wɪθaʊt tu əɹ θɹi kɪnswɪmən əɡɛn, ɪf jə noʊ wʌts ɡʊd fəɹ ju."

"That's as may be," Nynaeve replied sharply, shifting her shawl. "And maybe we know more than you think we do." She would not mind demonstrating a few of the weaves she had learned from Moghedien for this woman. Including a few they had all agreed were too nasty to do to anyone. Except . . . She was fairly certain the other woman could overpower her easily, whatever she did. Keeping her feet from shifting under that intense stare was not easy. "Until - unless! - we decide differently, you won't let me see you without two or three Kinswomen again, if you know what's good for you."

"ɪf jə seɪ soʊ," əliviə sɛd, nɑɾ əɾ ɔl əbæʃt. "wʌt mɛsədʒ dʒju wɑn mi tə teɪk bæk tə mɪstʃɹəs kɔɹli?"

"If you say so," Alivia said, not at all abashed. "What message do you want me to take back to Mistress Corly?"

"tɛl mɪstʃɹəs kɔɹli aɪ hæv tə dɪklaɪn əɹ kaɪn ɪnvɪteɪʃən. ən ɹɪmɛmbɝ wʌɾ aɪ toʊl ju!"

"Tell Mistress Corly I have to decline her kind invitation. And remember what I told you!"

"aɪl tɛl hɝ," ðə sintʃæn wʊmən dʒɹɔld, kəmplitli ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ði ædmənɪʃən. "bʌɾ aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ɪt wɑz ɪɡzækli ən ɪnvɪteɪʃən. ən aʊɝ æftɝ fɝs dɑɹk, ʃi sɛd. jə maɪt wɑnə ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðæt." wɪð ə slaɪt, noʊɪŋ smaɪl, ʃi wɔkt əweɪ, nɑt hɝiɪŋ əɾ ɔl tə ɹɪtɝn wɛɹ ʃi bɪlɔŋd.

"I'll tell her," the Seanchan woman drawled, completely ignoring the admonition. "But I don't think it was exactly an invitation. An hour after first dark, she said. You might want to remember that." With a slight, knowing smile, she walked away, not hurrying at all to return where she belonged.

nɪneɪiv ɡlɛɹɾ ət ðə ɹitʃɹiɾɪŋ wʊmənz bæk, ən nɑt kəz ə hɝ læk ʌv ə kɝtsi. wɛl, nɑɾ oʊnli ðæt. ə pɪɾi ʃi hæd nɑt hʌŋ ɑn tə ə fju ʌv əɹ sɪmpɝz, fəɹ sɪstɝz, ɛniweɪ. wɪð ə ɡlæns ət ðə dɔɹ ðət hɪd ði æθɑn maɪɹ, nɪneɪiv kənsɪɾɝd fɑloʊɪŋ əliviə tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ʃi dɪɾ əz ʃi hæd bɪn toʊld. ɪnstɛd, ʃi wɛn ɪn ði ɑpəzət dɝɛkʃən. ʃi dɪd nɑt hɝi. ɪt wəd bi ənplɛzən ɪf ðə si foʊk keɪm aʊɾ ən dɪsaɪɾɪd ʃi hæd bɪn ivzdʒɹɑpɪŋ, bʌt ʃi dɛfənətli dɪd nɑt hɝi. ʃi mɪɹli wɑntəd tə wɔk bɹɪskli. ðət wɑz ɔl.

Nynaeve glared at the retreating woman's back, and not because of her lack of a curtsy. Well, not only that. A pity she had not hung on to a few of her simpers, for sisters, anyway. With a glance at the door that hid the Atha'an Miere, Nynaeve considered following Alivia to make sure she did as she had been told. Instead, she went in the opposite direction. She did not hurry. It would be unpleasant if the Sea Folk came out and decided she had been eavesdropping, but she definitely did not hurry. She merely wanted to walk briskly. That was all.

ði æθɑn maɪɹ wɝ hɑɹdli ði oʊnli wʌnz ɪn ðə pæləs ʃi wɑntəd tə əvɔɪd. nɑɾ ɪɡzækli ən ɪnvɪteɪʃən, wɑz ɪt? sumeɪkoʊ kɛɹɪstoʊvən, tʃɪlɛɹz ɑɹmən ən feɪmɛl wɑɹd hæd bɪn ɪn ðə nɪɾɪŋ sɝkəl wɪð ɹin kɔɹli. dɪnɝ wɑz oʊnli ən ɪkskjus. ðeɪ wəd wɑnə tɔk tə hɝ əbaʊt ðə wɪndfɪndɝz. mɔɹ spəsɪfɪkli, əbaʊt ðə ɹileɪʃənʃɪp bɪtwin ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn ðə pæləs ən ðə si foʊk "waɪldɝz." ðeɪ wəd nɑt kwaɪɾ ʌpbɹeɪɾ əɹ fəɹ feɪlɪŋ tə meɪnteɪn ðə dɪɡnəɾi ʌv ðə waɪt taʊɝ. ðeɪ hæd nɑt ɡɔn ðət fɑɹ; nɑt jɛt, ðoʊ ðeɪ sim tə bi kʌmɪŋ kloʊsɝ. bʌt ðə hoʊl dɪnɝ wəd bi fʊl ə pɔɪntəd kwɛstʃənz ən ʃɑɹpɝ kɑmɛns. nʌθɪŋ ʃi kəd sɪmpli ɔɹɾɝ əm tə stɑp. ʃi daʊɾɪd ðeɪ wəd fəɹ lɛs ðən ə kəmænd. ən ðeɪ wɝ kwaɪt keɪpəbəl ə kʌmɪŋ tə faɪn əɹ ɪf ʃi dɪd nɑt ɡoʊ tə ðɛm. tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə titʃ əm tə ʃoʊ bækboʊn hæd bɪn ə tɛɹəbəl mɪsteɪk. ət list ʃi wɑz nɑt ði oʊnli wʌn u hæd tə pʊɾ ʌp wɪð ɪt, ðoʊ ʃi θɔɾ ɪleɪn hæd mænədʒ tə əvɔɪd ðə wɝst. oʊ, haʊ ʃi lʊk fɔɹwɝd tə siɪŋ əm bæk ɪn nɑvəs waɪɾ əɹ æksɛptɪdz dʒɹɛsəz. haʊ ʃi lʊk fɔɹwɝd tə siɪŋ ðə læst ə ði æθɑn maɪɹ!

The Atha'an Miere were hardly the only ones in the Palace she wanted to avoid. Not exactly an invitation, was it? Sumeko Karistovan, Chilares Arman and Famelle Juarde had been in the Knitting Circle with Reanne Corly. Dinner was only an excuse. They would want to talk to her about the Windfinders. More specifically, about the relationship between the Aes Sedai in the Palace and the Sea Folk "wilders." They would not quite upbraid her for failing to maintain the dignity of the White Tower. They had not gone that far; not yet, though they seemed to be coming closer. But the whole dinner would be full of pointed questions and sharper comments. Nothing she could simply order them to stop. She doubted they would for less than a command. And they were quite capable of coming to find her if she did not go to them. Trying to teach them to show backbone had been a terrible mistake. At least she was not the only one who had to put up with it, though she thought Elayne had managed to avoid the worst. Oh, how she looked forward to seeing them back in novice white or Accepted's dresses. How she looked forward to seeing the last of the Atha'an Miere!

"nɪneɪiv!" keɪm ə stʃɹeɪnʒli mjuɾɪd kɹaɪ bɪhaɪn hɝ. ɪn si foʊk æksɛns. "nɪneɪiv!"

"Nynaeve!" came a strangely muted cry behind her. In Sea Folk accents. "Nynaeve!"

fɔɹsɪŋ əɹ hæn əweɪ fɹəm əɹ bɹeɪd, nɪneɪiv spʌn ɑn əɹ hil, ɹɛɾi tə dɪlɪvɝ ə tʌŋ-læʃɪŋ. ʃi wɑz nɑt titʃɪŋ naʊ, ðeɪ wɝ nɑɾ ɑn ə ʃɪp, ən ðeɪ kəd blʌɾi wɛl liv əɹ əloʊn!

Forcing her hand away from her braid, Nynaeve spun on her heel, ready to deliver a tongue-lashing. She was not teaching now, they were not on a ship, and they could bloody well leave her alone!

tɑlɑn skɪɾəd tə ə hɔlt ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ, bɛɹ fit slaɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðə dɑɹk ɹɛd flɔɹ taɪlz. pæntɪŋ, ðə jʌŋ wʊmən swɪvəld əɹ hɛɾ əz ɪf əfɹeɪd sʌmwʌn wəd snik ʌp ɑn hɝ. ʃi flɪntʃt ɛvɹi taɪm ə lɪvɹid sɝvən muv dʒʌst ɑn ði ɛdʒ ə hɝ saɪt, ən oʊnli bɹiðd əɡɛn wən ʃi sɔ ɪt wɑz dʒʌst ə sɝvənt. "kæn aɪ ɡoʊ tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ?" ʃi æsk bɹɛθləsli, ɹɪŋɪŋ əɹ hænz ən dænsɪŋ fɹəm fʊt tə fʊt. "aɪ wɪl nɛvɝ bi tʃoʊzən. ə sækɹəfaɪs, ðeɪ kɔl ɪt, livɪŋ ðə si fɝɛvɝ, bʌɾ aɪ dʒɹim ə bɪkʌmɪŋ ə nɑvəs. əl mɪs maɪ mʌðɝ tɛɹəbli, bʌt . . . pliz. jə mʌs teɪk mi tə ðə taʊɝ. jə mʌst!"

Talaan skidded to a halt in front of her, bare feet sliding on the dark red floor tiles. Panting, the young woman swiveled her head as if afraid someone would sneak up on her. She flinched every time a liveried servant moved just on the edge of her sight, and only breathed again when she saw it was just a servant. "Can I go to the White Tower?" she asked breathlessly, wringing her hands and dancing from foot to foot. "I will never be chosen. A sacrifice, they call it, leaving the sea forever, but I dream of becoming a novice. I will miss my mother terribly, but . . . Please. You must take me to the Tower. You must!"

nɪneɪiv blɪŋkt ət ði ɔnslɔt. mɛni wɪmən dʒɹimd ə bɪkʌmɪŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ, bʌt ʃi hæd nɛvɝ bɪfɔɹ hɝd wʌn seɪ ʃi dʒɹimd ə bɪkʌmɪŋ ə nɑvəs. bɪsaɪdz . . . ði æθɑn maɪɹ ɹəfjuz pæsədʒ tə ɛɛs sədaɪ ɑn ɛni ʃɪp huz wɪndfɪndɝ kəd tʃænəl, bʌt tə kip sɪstɝz fɹəm tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə lʊk dipɝ, ɛvɹi soʊ ɔfən ən əpɹɛntəs wɑz tʃoʊzən tə ɡoʊ tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ. ɛɡwin sɛd ðəɹ wɝ oʊnli θɹi sɪstɝz fɹəm əmʌŋ ðə si foʊk ət pɹizɛnt, ɔl wik ɪn ðə paʊɝ. fəɹ θɹi θaʊzən jɪɹz ðət hæd bɪn ɪnʌf tə kənvɪns ðə taʊɝ ðət ði əbɪləɾi wɑz ɹɛɹ ən smɔl wɪð æθɑn maɪɹ wɪmən, nɑt wɝθ ɪnvɛstəɡeɪɾɪŋ. tɑlɑn wɑz ɹaɪt; noʊ wʌn əz stʃɹɔŋ əz ʃi wəɾ ɛvɝ bi əlaʊd tə ɡoʊ tə ðə taʊɝ, ivən naʊ ðət ðɛɹ sʌbtɝfjudʒ wɑz kʌmɪŋ tə ən ɛnd. ɪn fækt, ɪt wɑz pɑɹɾ ə ðə bɑɹɡən wɪð əm ðəɾ æθɑn maɪɹ sɪstɝz bi əlaʊd tə ɡɪv ʌp biɪŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ ən ɹɪtɝn tə ðə ʃɪps. ðə hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ wəd nɑt hæf haʊl əbaʊt ðæt!

Nynaeve blinked at the onslaught. Many women dreamed of becoming Aes Sedai, but she had never before heard one say she dreamed of becoming a novice. Besides . . . The Atha'an Miere refused passage to Aes Sedai on any ship whose Windfinder could channel, but to keep sisters from trying to look deeper, every so often an apprentice was chosen to go to the White Tower. Egwene said there were only three sisters from among the Sea Folk at present, all weak in the Power. For three thousand years that had been enough to convince the Tower that the ability was rare and small with Atha'an Miere women, not worth investigating. Talaan was right; no one as strong as she would ever be allowed to go to the Tower, even now that their subterfuge was coming to an end. In fact, it was part of the bargain with them that Atha'an Miere sisters be allowed to give up being Aes Sedai and return to the ships. The Hall of the Tower would not half howl about that!

"wɛl, ðə tʃɹeɪnɪŋ ɪz vɛɹi hɑɹd, tɑlɑn," ʃi sɛd dʒɛnli, "æn jə mʌs bi ət lis fɪftin. bɪsaɪdz . . ." sʌmθɪŋ ɛls ðə jʌŋ wʊmən æd sɛd stʃɹʌk əɹ sʌɾənli. "ju wɪl mɪs jəɹ mʌðɝ?" ʃi sɛɾ ɪnkɹɛdʒjələsli, nɑt kɛɹɪŋ haʊ ɪt saʊndəd.

"Well, the training is very hard, Talaan," she said gently, "and you must be at least fifteen. Besides . . ." Something else the young woman ad said struck her suddenly. "You will miss your mother?" she said incredulously, not caring how it sounded.

"aɪ æm naɪntin!" tɑlɑn ɹɪplaɪɾ ɪndɪɡnənli. lʊkɪŋ ət ðət bɔɪɪʃ feɪs ən fɔɹm, nɪneɪiv wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ ʃi bɪlivd. "æn ə kɔɹs əl mɪs maɪ mʌðɝ. də aɪ lʊk ənnætʃɹəl? oʊ; aɪ si. jə də nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd. wəɹ vɛɹi əfɛkʃənəɾ ɪn pɹaɪvət, bʌt ʃi mʌst əvɔɪɾ ɛni saɪn ə feɪvɝ ɪn pʌblɪk. ðəɾ ɪz ə sɪɹiəs kɹaɪm, wɪð ʌs. ɪt kəɾ əv mʌðɝ stʃɹɪpt ə hɝ ɹæŋk, ən boʊθ ʌv əs hʌŋ ʌpsaɪd daʊn ɪn ðə ɹɪɡɪŋ tə bi flɑɡd."

"I am nineteen!" Talaan replied indignantly. Looking at that boyish face and form, Nynaeve was not sure she believed. "And of course I will miss my mother. Do I look unnatural? Oh; I see. You do not understand. We are very affectionate in private, but she must avoid any sign of favor in public. That is a serious crime, with us. It could have mother stripped of her rank, and both of us hung upside down in the rigging to be flogged."

nɪneɪiv ɡɹɪməst ət ðə mɛnʃən ʌv ʌpsaɪd daʊn. "aɪ sɝɾənli kən si wɛɹ jə wəd wɑnə əvɔɪd ðæt," ʃi sɛd. "ivən soʊ - "

Nynaeve grimaced at the mention of upside down. "I certainly can see where you would want to avoid that," she said. "Even so - "

"ɛvɹiwʌn tʃɹaɪz tə əvɔɪɾ ivən ə hɪn ə feɪvɝ, bʌɾ ɪts wɝs fəɹ mi, nɪneɪiv!" ɹɪli, ðə ɡɝl - wʊmən - jʌŋ wʊmən - wəɾ əv tə lɝn nɑt tə stɛp ɑn wʌɾ ə sɪstɝ wɑz seɪɪŋ ɪf ʃi dɪd bɪkʌm ə nɑvəs. nɑt ðət ʃi kʊd, ʌv kɔɹs. nɪneɪiv tʃɹaɪd tə ɹɪɡeɪn ði ɪnɪʃəɾɪv, bʌt wɝdz pɔɹɾ aʊɾ ə tɑlɑn ɪn ə tɔɹənt. "maɪ ɡɹændmʌðɝ ɪz wɪndfɪndɝ tə ðə weɪvməstʃɹəs ə klæn ɹoʊseɪn, maɪ ɡɹeɪt-ɡɹændmʌðɝ ɪz wɪndfɪndɝ tə klæn dɑkən, ən əɹ sɪstɝ tə klæn tɑkænə. maɪ fæmli ɪz ɑnɝd ðət faɪv ʌv əs əv ɹɪzən soʊ haɪ. ən ɛvɹiwʌn wɑtʃəz fəɹ saɪnz ðət ɡɛlɪn əbjuzɪz ɪts ɪnfluəns. ɹaɪtli soʊ, aɪ noʊ - feɪvɝ kænɑt bi əlaʊd - bʌt maɪ sɪstɝ wɑz kɛpt ən əpɹɛntəs faɪv jɪɹz lɔŋɡɝ ðən nɔɹməl, ən maɪ kʌzən sɪks! dʒʌst soʊ noʊ wʌn kən kleɪm ðeɪ wɝ feɪvɝd. wən aɪ kæs ðə stɑɹz ən ɡɪv əɹ pəzɪʃən kɝɛkli, aɪm pʌnɪʃt fəɹ biɪŋ sloʊ ivən wən aɪ hæv ði ænsɝ əz fæst əz wɪndfɪndɝ ɛvən! wən aɪ teɪs ðə si ən neɪm ðə koʊst wəɹ əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ, aɪm pʌnɪʃt kəz ðə teɪst aɪ neɪm ɪz nɑt kwaɪt wʌt wɪndfɪndɝ ɛvən teɪsts! aɪ ʃildɪd jə twaɪs, bʌt tənaɪɾ əl hæŋ baɪ maɪ æŋkəlz fəɹ nɑt duɪŋ soʊ sunɝ! aɪm pʌnɪʃt fəɹ flɔz ɪɡnɔɹɾ ɪn ʌðɝz, fəɹ flɔz aɪ nɛvɝ meɪk, kəz aɪ maɪt! wɑz jəɹ nɑvəs tʃɹeɪnɪŋ ɛni hɑɹɾɝ ðən ðæt, nɪneɪiv?"

"Everyone tries to avoid even a hint of favor, but it is worse for me, Nynaeve!" Really, the girl - woman - young woman - would have to learn not to step on what a sister was saying if she did become a novice. Not that she could, of course. Nynaeve tried to regain the initiative, but words poured out of Talaan in a torrent. "My grandmother is Windfinder to the Wavemistress of Clan Rossaine, my great-grandmother is Windfinder to Clan Dacan, and her sister to Clan Takana. My family is honored that five of us have risen so high. And everyone watches for signs that Gelyn abuses its influence. Rightly so, I know - favor cannot be allowed - but my sister was kept an apprentice five years longer than normal, and my cousin six! Just so no one can claim they were favored. When I cast the stars and give our position correctly, I am punished for being slow even when I have the answer as fast as Windfinder Ehvon! When I taste the sea and name the coast we are approaching, I am punished because the taste I name is not quite what Windfinder Ehvon tastes! I shielded you twice, but tonight I will hang by my ankles for not doing so sooner! I am punished for flaws ignored in others, for flaws I never make, because I might! Was your novice training any harder than that, Nynaeve?"

"maɪ nɑvəs tʃɹeɪnɪŋ," nɪneɪiv sɛd feɪnli. ʃi wɪʃt ðə wʊmən wəd nɑt kip bɹɪŋɪŋ ʌp biɪŋ hʌŋ baɪ ði æŋkəlz. "jɛs. wɛl. jə ɹɪli doʊnt wɑnə hɪɹ əbaʊt ðæt." fɔɹ dʒɛnɝeɪʃənz ʌv wɪmən wɪð ði əbɪləɾi? laɪt! ivən dɔɾɝ fɑloʊɪŋ mʌðɝ wɑz ɹɛɹ ɪnʌf. ðə taʊɝ ɹɪli wəd wɑn tɑlɑn. ðət wɑz nɑt ɡoʊɪŋ tə hæpən, ðoʊ. "aɪ səpoʊz kɛɹ ən tɛbɹl ɹɪli lʌv wʌn ənʌðɝ, tu?" ʃi sɛd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə tʃeɪnʒ ðə sʌbʒɪkt.

"My novice training," Nynaeve said faintly. She wished the woman would not keep bringing up being hung by the ankles. "Yes. Well. You really don't want to hear about that." Four generations of women with the ability? Light! Even daughter following mother was rare enough. The Tower really would want Talaan. That was not going to happen, though. "I suppose Caire and Tebreille really love one another, too?" she said, trying to change the subject.

tɑlɑn snɪɹd. "maɪ æn ɪz slaɪ ən dəsitfəl. ʃi sɛləbɹeɪts ɛni hjumɪlieɪʃən ʃi kən kɑz maɪ mʌðɝ. bʌt maɪ mʌðɝ wɪl bɹɪŋ əɹ loʊ, əz ʃi dɪzɝvz. wʌn deɪ, tɛbɹl wɪl faɪn hɝsɛlf sɝvɪŋ ɑn ə sɔɹɝ, bɪniθ ə seɪlməstʃɹəs wɪð ən aɪɝn hæn ən sɔɹ tiθ!" ʃi ɡeɪv ə ɡɹɪm, sæɾəsfaɪd nɑɾ ət ðə θɔt. ən ðən dʒʌmpt, waɪd-aɪɾ əz ə fɔn, wən ə sɝvɪŋ mæn hɝid baɪ bɪhaɪn hɝ. ðət ɹɪkɔld əɹ tə hɝ pɝpəs. ʃi wɛn bæk tə tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə lʊk ɛvɹi weɪ ət wʌns əz ʃi spoʊk heɪstəli. "ju kænɑt spik aʊt dʊɹɪŋ ðə lɛsənz, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌɾ ɛni ʌðɝ taɪm wɪl du. ənaʊns ðəɾ aɪm tə ɡoʊ tə ðə taʊɝ, ən ðəl nɑt bi eɪbəl tə dɪnaɪ ju. jə ɑɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ!"

Talaan sneered. "My aunt is sly and deceitful. She celebrates any humiliation she can cause my mother. But my mother will bring her low, as she deserves. One day, Tebreille will find herself serving on a soarer, beneath a Sailmistress with an iron hand and sore teeth!" She gave a grim, satisfied nod at the thought. And then jumped, wide-eyed as a fawn, when a serving man hurried by behind her. That recalled her to her purpose. She went back to trying to look every way at once as she spoke hastily. "You cannot speak out during the lessons, of course, but any other time will do. Announce that I am to go to the Tower, and they will not be able to deny you. You are Aes Sedai!"

nɪneɪiv ɡɑɡəld ət ðə ɡɝl. ən ðeɪ wʊɾə fɝɡɑɾən ɔl əbaʊɾ ɪt baɪ ðə nɛks taɪm ʃi ɡeɪv ə lɛsən? ðə ful hæd sin wʌt ðeɪ dɪd tə hɝ! "aɪ kən si haʊ mʌtʃ jə wɑnə ɡoʊ, tɑlɑn," ʃi sɛd, "bʌt - "

Nynaeve goggled at the girl. And they would have forgotten all about it by the next time she gave a lesson? The fool had seen what they did to her! "I can see how much you want to go, Talaan," she said, "but - "

"θæŋk ju," tɑlɑn bɹoʊk ɪn, meɪkɪŋ ə kwɪk baʊ. "θæŋk ju!" ən ʃi dɑɹɾɪd bæk ðə weɪ ʃi hæd kʌm əɾ ə dɛd ɹʌn.

"Thank you," Talaan broke in, making a quick bow. "Thank you!" And she darted back the way she had come at a dead run.

"weɪt!" nɪneɪiv ʃaʊɾəd, teɪkɪŋ ə fju stɛps æftɝ hɝ. "kʌm bæk! aɪ dɪdn pɹɑməs ɛniθɪŋ!"

"Wait!" Nynaeve shouted, taking a few steps after her. "Come back! I didn't promise anything!"

sɝvəns tɝn tə stɛɹ ət hɝ, ən kəntɪnjud tə ʃut wʌndɝɪŋ ɡlænsɪz ɪn əɹ dɝɛkʃən ivən æftɝ ɹɪtɝnɪŋ tə ðɛɹ tæsks. ʃi wʊɾə ɹʌn æftɝ ði ɪɾiət ɪksɛp ðət ʃi wɑz əfɹeɪd ʃi wəɾ əv tə fɑloʊ hɝ stʃɹeɪt tə zeɪɾə ən ði ʌðɝz. ən ðə ful wəd pɹɑbli ɡʌʃ aʊt ðət ʃi wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ tə ðə taʊɝ, ðət nɪneɪiv hæd pɹɑməst. laɪt, ʃi wəd pɹɑbli tɛl əm ɛniweɪ!

Servants turned to stare at her, and continued to shoot wondering glances in her direction even after returning to their tasks. She would have run after the idiot except that she was afraid she would have to follow her straight to Zaida and the others. And the fool would probably gush out that she was going to the Tower, that Nynaeve had promised. Light, she would probably tell them anyway!

"ju lʊk əz ɪf jə dʒʌst swɑloʊɾ ə ɹɑɾən plʌm," læn sɛd, əpɪɹɪŋ əɾ əɹ saɪd, tɔl ən stɑɹkli hænsəm ɪn ɪz wɛl-fɪɾɪŋ ɡɹin koʊt. ʃi wʌndɝd haʊ lɔŋ i hæd bɪn ðɛɹ. ɪt dɪd nɑt sim pɑsəbəl ðəɾ ə mæn soʊ lɑɹdʒ, soʊ kəmændɪŋ ɪn ɪz pɹɛzəns, kəd stæn stɪl ɪnʌf ðət jə feɪl tə noʊɾəs hɪm, ivən wɪθaʊɾ ə wɔɹɾɝz kloʊk.

"You look as if you just swallowed a rotten plum," Lan said, appearing at her side, tall and starkly handsome in his well-fitting green coat. She wondered how long he had been there. It did not seem possible that a man so large, so commanding in his presence, could stand still enough that you failed to notice him, even without a Warder's cloak.

"ə bæskətfəl ə ðɛm," ʃi mɝmɝd, pɹɛsɪŋ əɹ feɪs əɡɛnst əɹ hʌzbənz bɹɔd tʃɛst. ɪt fɛl vɛɹi ɡʊd tə lin əɡɛnst ɪz stʃɹɛŋkθ, dʒʌs fəɹ ə moʊmənt, waɪl i stʃɹoʊkt əɹ hɛɹ sɔfli. ivən ɪf ʃi dɪɾ əv tə ʃɪft ɪz sɔɹd hɪlt aʊɾ ə hɝ ɹɪbz. ən ɛniwʌn u wɑntəd tə stɛɹ ət sətʃ ə pʌblɪk dɪspleɪ ʌv əfɛkʃən kəd ɡoʊ hæŋ ðɛmsɛlvz. ʃi kəd si dɪzæstɝ paɪlɪŋ ʌp ɑn dɪzæstɝ. ivən ɪf ʃi toʊl zeɪɾə ən ði ʌðɝz ʃi hæd noʊ ɪntɛntʃən ə teɪkɪŋ tɑlɑn ɛniwɛɹ, ðeɪ wɝ gɑnə skɪn hɝ. ðəɹ wəd bi noʊ haɪɾɪŋ ɪt fɹəm læn ðɪs taɪm. ɪf ʃi hæd mænədʒ tə ðə fɝst. ɹin ən ði ʌðɝz wəd lɝn ʌv ɪt. ən æləz! ðeɪ wəd stɑɹt tʃɹiɾɪŋ əɹ ðə weɪ ðeɪ dɪd mɛɝɪlɪl, ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ əɹ ɔɹɾɝz, ɡɪvɪŋ əɹ əbaʊɾ əz mʌtʃ ɹɪspɛkt əz ðə wɪndfɪndɝz dɪd tɑlɑn. sʌmhaʊ ʃi wəd bi sæɾəld wɪð ɡɑɹɾɪŋ əliviə, ən səm kətæstʃɹəfi wəd kʌm ʌv ɪt, səm ʌɾɝ hjumɪlieɪʃən. ðət wɑz ɔl ʃi sim fɪt tə du, leɪtli; faɪn ənʌðɝ weɪ tə bi hjumɪlieɪɾɪd. ən ɛvɹi fɔɹθ deɪ, ʃi wəd stɪl əv tə feɪs zeɪɾə ən ðə wɪndfɪndɝz.

"A basketful of them," she murmured, pressing her face against her husband's broad chest. It felt very good to lean against his strength, just for a moment, while he stroked her hair softly. Even if she did have to shift his sword hilt out of her ribs. And anyone who wanted to stare at such a public display of affection could go hang themselves. She could see disaster piling up on disaster. Even if she told Zaida and the others she had no intention of taking Talaan anywhere, they were going to skin her. There would be no hiding it from Lan this time. If she had managed to the first. Reanne and the others would learn of it. And Alise! They would start treating her the way they did Merilille, ignoring her orders, giving her about as much respect as the Windfinders did Talaan. Somehow she would be saddled with guarding Alivia, and some catastrophe would come of it, some utter humiliation. That was all she seemed fit to do, lately; find another way to be humiliated. And every fourth day, she would still have to face Zaida and the Windfinders.

"du jə ɹɪmɛmbɝ haʊ jə kɛp mi ɪn əɹ ɹumz jɛstɝdeɪ mɔɹnɪŋ?" ʃi mɝmɝd, lʊkɪŋ ʌp ɪn taɪm tə kætʃ ə ɡɹɪn ɹɪpleɪsɪŋ kənsɝn ɑn ɪz feɪs. ʌv kɔɹs i ɹɪmɛmbɝd. hɝ feɪs ɡɹu hɑt. tɔkɪŋ tə fɹɛnz wɑz wʌn θɪŋ, bʌt biɪŋ fɔɹwɝd wɪð əɹ oʊn hʌzbən stɪl sim kwaɪɾ ənʌðɝ. "wɛl, aɪ wɑn jə tə teɪk mi bæk ðəɹ ɹaɪt naʊ ən kip mi fɹəm pʊɾɪŋ ɑn ɛni kloʊðz fəɹ əbaʊɾ ə jɪɹ!" ʃi hæd bɪn kwaɪt fjʊɹiəs əbaʊt ðæt, ət fɝst. bʌɾ i hæd weɪz tə meɪk əɹ fɝɡɛt tə bi fjʊɹiəs.

"Do you remember how you kept me in our rooms yesterday morning?" she murmured, looking up in time to catch a grin replacing concern on his face. Of course he remembered. Her face grew hot. Talking to friends was one thing, but being forward with her own husband still seemed quite another. "Well, I want you to take me back there right now and keep me from putting on any clothes for about a year!" She had been quite furious about that, at first. But he had ways to make her forget to be furious.

hi θɹu bæk ɪz hɛɾ ən læft, ə ɡɹeɪt bumɪŋ saʊnd, ən æftɝ ə moʊmənt, ʃi ɛkoʊd hɪm. ʃi wɑntəd tə wip, ðoʊ. ʃi hæd nɑt ɹɪli bɪn dʒoʊkɪŋ.

He threw back his head and laughed, a great booming sound, and after a moment, she echoed him. She wanted to weep, though. She had not really been joking.

hævɪŋ ə hʌzbən mɛn ðət ʃi dɪd nɑɾ əv tə ʃɛɹ ə bɛd wɪð ənʌðɝ wʊmən, əɹ tu, ən ɪt ɡeɪn əɹ ə sɪɾɪŋ ɹum. ɪt wɑz nɑt lɑɹdʒ, bʌɾ ɪɾ ɔlweɪz sim snʌɡ, wɪð ə ɡʊd faɪɝpleɪs ən ə smɔl teɪbəl wɪð fɔɹ tʃɛɹz. sɝɾənli əz mʌtʃ əz ʃi ən læn niɾəd. hɝ hoʊps fəɹ pɹaɪvəsi wɝ dæʃt əz sun əz ðeɪ ɛntɝd ðə sɪɾɪŋ ɹum, ðoʊ. ðə fɝs meɪd wɑz weɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə flaʊɝd kɑɹpət, əz steɪtli əz ə kwin, əz nitli tɝn aʊɾ əz ɪf ʃi hæd dʒʌs fɪnɪʃt dʒɹɛsɪŋ, ən nɑɾ əɾ ɔl plizd. ən ɪn wʌn kɔɹnɝ ə ðə ɹum wɑz ə ɹʌfli dʒɹɛst, lʌmpi fɛloʊ wɪð ə hɔɹəbəl wɔɹɾ ɑn ɪz noʊz ən ə skɹɪp dæŋɡəlɪŋ hɛvəli fɹəm ɪz ʃoʊldɝ.

Having a husband meant that she did not have to share a bed with another woman, or two, and it gained her a sitting room. It was not large, but it always seemed snug, with a good fireplace and a small table with four chairs. Certainly as much as she and Lan needed. Her hopes for privacy were dashed as soon as they entered the sitting room, though. The First Maid was waiting in the middle of the flowered carpet, as stately as a queen, as neatly turned out as if she had just finished dressing, and not at all pleased. And in one corner of the room was a roughly dressed, lumpy fellow with a horrible wart on his nose and a scrip dangling heavily from his shoulder.

"ðɪs mæn kleɪmz hiz sʌmθɪŋ jə wɑn ɝdʒənli," mɪstʃɹəs hɑɹfɝ sɛd wʌns ʃi hæd meɪd bɹif kɝɾəsiz. vɛɹi bɹif, ɪf pɹɑpɝ; ʃi dɪd nɑt weɪst əm ɑn ɛniwʌn ɪksɛpt ɪleɪn. ʃi saʊndəɾ ikwəli dɪsəpɹuvɪŋ ə nɪneɪiv ən ðə fɛloʊ wɪð ðə wɔɹt. "aɪ doʊn maɪn tɛlɪŋ ju, aɪ də nɑt laɪk ðə lʊks ə hɪm."

"This man claims he has something you want urgently," Mistress Harfor said once she had made brief courtesies. Very brief, if proper; she did not waste them on anyone except Elayne. She sounded equally disapproving of Nynaeve and the fellow with the wart. "I don't mind telling you, I do not like the looks of him."

taɪɝɾ əz nɪneɪiv wɑz, ɛmbɹeɪsɪŋ ðə sɔɹs wɑz ɔlmoʊs bɪɑn hɝ, bʌt ʃi mænədʒd ɪɾ ɪn ə flæʃ, spɝd baɪ θɔts ʌv əsæsənz ən ðə laɪt nu wʌt. læn mʌst əv kɑt səm tʃeɪnʒ ɪn əɹ feɪs, kəz i tʊk ə stɛp təwɔɹd ðə wɔɹɾi fɛloʊ; hi dɪd nɑt tʌtʃ ɪz sɔɹd, bʌt sʌɾənli hɪz hoʊl stæns simd əz ɪf ðə bleɪd wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi dʒɹɔn. haʊ hi səmtaɪmz mænədʒ tə ɹiɾ əɹ maɪnd wən ənʌðɝ hɛld ɪz bɑnd, ʃi kəd nɑt seɪ, bʌt ʃi wɑz plizd. ʃi hæd mænədʒ tə mætʃ tɑlɑn - ɪn stʃɹɛŋkθ, ət list! - bʌt ʃi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ ʃi kəd tʃænəl ɪnʌf ɹaɪt ðən tə nɑk oʊvɝ ə tʃɛɹ. "aɪ nɛvɝ," ʃi bɪɡæn.

Tired as Nynaeve was, embracing the Source was almost beyond her, but she managed it in a flash, spurred by thoughts of assassins and the Light knew what. Lan must have caught some change in her face, because he took a step toward the warty fellow; he did not touch his sword, but suddenly his whole stance seemed as if the blade were already drawn. How he sometimes managed to read her mind when another held his bond, she could not say, but she was pleased. She had managed to match Talaan - in strength, at least! - but she was not sure she could channel enough right then to knock over a chair. "I never," she began.

"pɑɹɾən, mɪstʃɹəs," ðə lʌmpi fɛloʊ mʌɾɝd hɝidli, tʌɡɪŋ ɪz ɡɹisi fɔɹlɑk. "mɪstʃɹəs θeɪn sɛd jə wɑntəd tə si mi ɹaɪɾ əweɪ. wɪmənz sɝkəl bɪznəs, ʃi sɛd. sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt sɛn bui."

"Pardon, Mistress," the lumpy fellow muttered hurriedly, tugging his greasy forelock. "Mistress Thane said you wanted to see me right away. Women's Circle business, she said. Something about Cenn Buie."

nɪneɪiv ɡeɪv hɝsɛlf ə ʃeɪk, ən æftɝ ə moʊmən ɹɪmɛmbɝd tə kloʊz əɹ maʊθ. "jɛs," ʃi sɛd sloʊli, stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə fɛloʊ. siɪŋ ɛniθɪŋ bʌt ðəɾ ɑfəl wɔɹt wɑz dɪfəkəlt, bʌt ʃi wɑz sɝɾən ʃi hæd nɛvɝ leɪɾ aɪz ɑn ɪm bɪfɔɹ. wɪmənz sɝkəl bɪznəs. noʊ mæn wəd bi əlaʊɾ ə snɪf ə ðæt. ɪt wɑz sikɹət. ʃi hɛld ɑn tə seɪaɪdɑɹ, ðoʊ. "aɪ . . . ɹɪmɛmbɝ, naʊ. θæŋk ju, mɪstʃɹəs hɑɹfɝ. aɪm ʃʊɹ juv ɔl sɔɹts ə θɪŋz tə si tə."

Nynaeve gave herself a shake, and after a moment remembered to close her mouth. "Yes," she said slowly, staring at the fellow. Seeing anything but that awful wart was difficult, but she was certain she had never laid eyes on him before. Women's Circle business. No man would be allowed a sniff of that. It was secret. She held on to saidar, though. "I . . . remember, now. Thank you, Mistress Harfor. I'm sure you have all sorts of things to see to."

ɹæðɝ ðən teɪk ðə hɪnt, ðə fɝs meɪd hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, fɹaʊnɪŋ əɾ əɹ səspɪʃəsli. ðət fɹaʊn slɪɾ ɝaʊn tə ðə lʌmpi mæn, ðən sɛɾəld ɑn læn ən vænɪʃt. ʃi nɑɾəd tə hɝsɛlf, əz ɪf ɪz pɹɛzəns sʌmhaʊ meɪd ðə dɪfɝəns! "aɪ wɪl liv ju, ðɛn. aɪm ʃʊɹ lɔɹd læn kən hændəl ðɪs fɛloʊ."

Rather than take the hint, the First Maid hesitated, frowning at her suspiciously. That frown slid around to the lumpy man, then settled on Lan and vanished. She nodded to herself, as if his presence somehow made the difference! "I will leave you, then. I'm sure Lord Lan can handle this fellow."

staɪflɪŋ əɹ ɪndɪɡneɪʃən, nɪneɪiv bɛɹli weɪɾəd fəɹ ðə dɔɹ tə kloʊz bɪfɔɹ ɹaʊndɪŋ ɑn ðə lʌmpi fɛloʊ ən ɪz wɔɹt. "hu ɑɹ ju?" ʃi dɪmændəd. "haʊ dʒju noʊ ðoʊz neɪmz? jəɹ noʊ tu ɹɪv - "

Stifling her indignation, Nynaeve barely waited for the door to close before rounding on the lumpy fellow and his wart. "Who are you?" she demanded. "How do you know those names? You're no Two Riv - "

ðə mæn . . . ɹɪpəld. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ʌðɝ wɝd fəɹ ɪt. hi ɹɪpəld ən stʃɹɛtʃt tɔlɝ, ən sʌɾənli ɪt wɑz ɹænd, ɡɹɪmæsɪŋ ən swɑloʊɪŋ, ɪn ɹʌmpəld wʊlənz wɪð ðoʊz ɑfəl hɛdz ɡlɪɾɝɪŋ ɹɛd-ænd-ɡoʊld ɑn ðə bæks ə hɪz hænz ən ə lɛðɝ skɹɪp ɑn ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. wɛɹ hæɾ i lɝn ðæt? hu hæd tɔt hɪm? ʃi ɹɪzɪstɪd ði aɪdiə ʌv dɪsɡaɪzɪŋ hɝsɛlf, dʒʌs fəɹ ə moʊmənt, tə ʃoʊ hɪm ʃi kəd də əz mʌtʃ.

The man . . . rippled. There was no other word for it. He rippled and stretched taller, and suddenly it was Rand, grimacing and swallowing, in rumpled woolens with those awful heads glittering red-and-gold on the backs of his hands and a leather scrip on his shoulder. Where had he learned that? Who had taught him? She resisted the idea of disguising herself, just for a moment, to show him she could do as much.

"aɪ si jə dɪdn teɪk jəɹ oʊn ædvaɪs," ɹænd sɛd tə læn, dʒʌst əz ɪf ʃi wɝ nɑt ðɛɹ. "bʌt waɪ dʒju lɛɾ əɹ pɹitɛn tə bi ɛɛs sədaɪ? ivən ɪf ðə ɹil ɛɛs sədaɪ lɛt hɝ, ʃi kən ɡɛt hɝt."

"I see you didn't take your own advice," Rand said to Lan, just as if she were not there. "But why do you let her pretend to be Aes Sedai? Even if the real Aes Sedai let her, she can get hurt."

"bɪkɔz ʃiz ɛɛs sədaɪ, ʃifɝɾɝ," læn ɹɪplaɪd kwaɪətli. hi dɪd nɑt lʊk əɾ əɹ iðɝ! ən i stɪl simd ɹɛɾi tə dʒɹɔ hɪz sɔɹɾ ɪn ə hɑɹtbit. "æz fəɹ ði ʌðɝ . . . səmtaɪmz, ʃiz stʃɹɔŋɝ ðən ju. dɪd jə teɪk ɪt?"

"Because she is Aes Sedai, sheepherder," Lan replied quietly. He did not look at her either! And he still seemed ready to draw his sword in a heartbeat. "As for the other . . . Sometimes, she is stronger than you. Did you take it?"

ɹænd lʊkt əɾ əɹ ðɛn. tə fɹaʊn dɪsbɪlivɪŋli. ivən wən ʃi pɔɪntɪdli ədʒʌstəɾ əɹ ʃɔl soʊ ðə jɛloʊ fɹɪnʒ sweɪd. wʌɾ i sɛd ðoʊ, ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛd sloʊli, wɑz "noʊ. jəɹ ɹaɪt. səmtaɪmz jəɹ dʒʌs tu wik tə də wʌt jə ʃʊd."

Rand looked at her then. To frown disbelievingly. Even when she pointedly adjusted her shawl so the yellow fringe swayed. What he said though, shaking his head slowly, was "No. You're right. Sometimes you're just too weak to do what you should."

"wʌɾ ɑɹ jə tu blæðɝɪŋ əbaʊt?" ʃi sɛd ʃɑɹpli.

"What are you two blathering about?" she said sharply.

"dʒʌs θɪŋz ðət mɛn tɔk əbaʊt," læn ɹɪplaɪd.

"Just things that men talk about," Lan replied.

"ju wʊdn ʌndɝstænd," ɹænd sɛd.

"You wouldn't understand," Rand said.

ʃi snɪft ət ðæt. ɡɑsəp ən aɪɾəl tʃæɾɝ, ðət wɑz wʌt mɛnz tɔk wɑz, naɪn taɪmz ɪn tɛn. ət bɛst. wɛɹəli, ʃi lɛt ɡoʊ ʌv seɪaɪdɑɹ. ɹɪlʌktənli. ʃi dɪd nɑt nid tə pɹətɛk hɝsɛlf əɡɛnst ɹænd, sɝɾənli, bʌt ʃi wʊɾə laɪk tə hoʊld ɑn ə lɪɾəl lɔŋɡɝ, dʒʌs tə tʌtʃ ɪt, taɪɝɾ əɹ nɑt.

She sniffed at that. Gossip and idle chatter, that was what men's talk was, nine times in ten. At best. Wearily, she let go of saidar. Reluctantly. She did not need to protect herself against Rand, certainly, but she would have liked to hold on a little longer, just to touch it, tired or not.

"wi noʊ əbaʊt kɛɹhin, ɹænd," ʃi sɛd, sɪŋkɪŋ ɡɹeɪtfəli ɪndə ə tʃɛɹ. ðoʊz kɝst si foʊk hæd wɔɹn əɹ aʊt! "ɪz ðət waɪ jəɹ hɪɹ, dʒɹɛs ðət weɪ? ɪf jəɹ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə haɪd fɹəm huɛvɝ ɪt wɑz . . ." hi lʊk taɪɝd. hɑɹɾɝ ðən ʃi ɹɪmɛmbɝd, bʌt vɛɹi taɪɝd. hi ɹɪmeɪn stændɪŋ, ðoʊ. stʃɹeɪnʒli, hi simd mʌtʃ laɪk læn, ɹɛɾi tə dʒɹɔ ə sɔɹɾ i wɑz nɑt wɛɹɪŋ. meɪbi ðəɾ ətɛmp tə kɪl ɪm wəd bi ɪnʌf tə meɪk ɪm si sɛns. "ɹænd, ɛɡwin kən hɛlp ju."

"We know about Cairhien, Rand," she said, sinking gratefully into a chair. Those cursed Sea Folk had worn her out! "Is that why you're here, dressed that way? If you're trying to hide from whoever it was . . ." He looked tired. Harder than she remembered, but very tired. He remained standing, though. Strangely, he seemed much like Lan, ready to draw a sword he was not wearing. Maybe that attempt to kill him would be enough to make him see sense. "Rand, Egwene can help you."

"aɪm nɑt haɪɾɪŋ ɪɡzækli," hi sɛd. "æt list, dʒʌst əntɪl aɪ kɪl səm mɛn u nid kɪlɪŋ." laɪt, hi wɑz əz mæɾɝ ə fækt əbaʊɾ ɪɾ əz əliviə! waɪ dɪɾ i ən læn kip aɪɪŋ wʌn ənʌðɝ ən pɹitɛndɪŋ ðeɪ wɝ nɑt? "ɛniweɪ, haʊ kəɾ ɛɡwin hɛlp?" hi wɛn ɑn, sɛɾɪŋ ðə skɹɪp ɑn ðə teɪbəl. ɪt meɪɾ ə sɑf bʌt sɑləd saʊn ʌv weɪɾ ɪnsaɪd. "aɪ səpoʊz ʃiz ɛɛs sədaɪ, tu?" hi saʊndəɾ əmjuzd! "ɪz ʃi hɪɹ, əz wɛl? jə θɹi, ən tu ɹil ɛɛs sədaɪ. oʊnli tu! noʊ. aɪ doʊn əv taɪm fəɹ ðæt. aɪ nid jə tə kip sʌmθɪŋ əntɪl - "

"I'm not hiding exactly," he said. "At least, just until I kill some men who need killing." Light, he was as matter of fact about it as Alivia! Why did he and Lan keep eyeing one another and pretending they were not? "Anyway, how could Egwene help?" he went on, setting the scrip on the table. It made a soft but solid sound of weight inside. "I suppose she's Aes Sedai, too?" He sounded amused! "Is she here, as well? You three, and two real Aes Sedai. Only two! No. I don't have time for that. I need you to keep something until - "

"ɛɡwin ɪz ði æmɪɝlɪn sit, jə ful wʊlhɛd," ʃi ɡɹaʊld. ɪt wɑz naɪs tə bi eɪbəl tə ɪntɝʌp sʌmwʌn ɛls fəɹ ə tʃeɪnʒ. "ɪleɪɾə ɪz ə jusɝpɝ. aɪ hoʊp juv hæd sɛns ɪnʌf nɑt tə ɡoʊ nɪɹ hɝ! jə wʊdn liv ðət miɾɪŋ ɑn jəɹ oʊn tu lɛɡz, aɪ kən tɛl ju! ðəɹ ɑɹ faɪv ɹil ɛɛs sədaɪ hɪɹ, ɪnkluɾɪŋ mi, ən θɹi hʌnʒɹəd mɔɹ wɪð ɛɡwin ən ən ɑɹmi, ɹɛɾi tə pʊl ɪleɪɾə daʊn. lʊk ət jɝsɛlf! wʌtɛvɝ jəɹ bɹeɪv tɔk, sʌmbɑɾi ɔlmoʊs kɪl ju, ən jəɹ snikɪŋ ɝaʊn dʒɹɛs laɪk ə steɪbəlmən! wʌt seɪfɝ pleɪs fəɹ jə ðən wɪð ɛɡwin? ivən ðoʊz æʃəmən ə jʊɹz wʊdn dɛɹ ɡoʊ əɡɛns θɹi hʌnʒɹəd sɪstɝz!" oʊ, jɛs; vɛɹi naɪs ɪndid. hi tʃɹaɪd tə mæsk ɪz sɝpɹaɪz, bʌɾ i meɪɾ ə pʊɹ dʒɑb ʌv ɪt, stɛɹɪŋ ət hɝ.

"Egwene is the Amyrlin Seat, you fool woolhead," she growled. It was nice to be able to interrupt someone else for a change. "Elaida is a usurper. I hope you've had sense enough not to go near her! You wouldn't leave that meeting on your own two legs, I can tell you! There are five real Aes Sedai here, including me, and three hundred more with Egwene and an army, ready to pull Elaida down. Look at yourself! Whatever your brave talk, somebody almost killed you, and you're sneaking around dressed like a stableman! What safer place for you than with Egwene? Even those Asha'man of yours wouldn't dare go against three hundred sisters!" Oh, yes; very nice indeed. He tried to mask his surprise, but he made a poor job of it, staring at her.

"jud bi sɝpɹaɪzd wʌt maɪ æʃəmən wəd dɛɹ," hi sɛd dʒɹaɪli æftɝ ə mɪnət. "aɪ səpoʊz mæt ɪz wɪð ɛɡwinz ɑɹmi?" pʊɾɪŋ ə hæn tə hɪz hɛd, hi stæɡɝd.

"You'd be surprised what my Asha'man would dare," he said dryly after a minute. "I suppose Mat is with Egwene's army?" Putting a hand to his head, he staggered.

oʊnli hæf ə stɛp, bʌt ʃi wɑz aʊɾ ə hɝ tʃɛɹ bɪfɔɹ i kəd ɹaɪt hɪmsɛlf. ɛmbɹeɪsɪŋ seɪaɪdɑɹ wɪð ən ɛfɝt, ʃi ɹitʃt ʌp tə klæsp ɪz hɛd bɪtwin əɹ hænz, ən ləbɔɹiəsli woʊv ə dɛlvɪŋ ɝaʊn hɪm. ʃi hæd tʃɹaɪd faɪndɪŋ ə bɛɾɝ weɪ tə faɪnd wʌɾ eɪl sʌmwʌn, soʊ fɑɹ wɪθaʊt səksɛs. ɪt wɑz ɪnʌf. noʊ sunɝ hæd ðə wiv sɛɾəld ɑn ɪm ðən əɹ bɹɛθ kɑt. ʃi hæd noʊn əbaʊt ðə waʊn ɪn ɪz saɪd fɹəm fɑlm, nɛvɝ hilɪŋ kəmplitli, ɹɪzɪstɪŋ ɔl ðə hilɪŋ ʃi nu, laɪk ə pʌstʃul ʌv ivəl ɪn ɪz flɛʃ. naʊ ðəɹ wɑz ənʌðɝ hæf-hild waʊn ətɑp ði oʊld, ən ðət pʌlsd wɪð ivəl, tu. ə dɪfɹən sɔɹɾ ʌv ivəl, sʌmhaʊ, laɪk ə mɪɹɝ ə ði ʌðɝ, jɛt dʒʌst əz vɪɹələnt. ən ʃi kəd nɑt tʌtʃ iðɝ wɪð ðə paʊɝ. ʃi dɪd nɑt ɹɪli wɑnə - dʒʌs θɪŋkɪŋ ʌv ɪt meɪɾ əɹ skɪn kɹɔl! - bʌt ʃi tʃɹaɪd. ən sʌmθɪŋ ənsin hɛld əɹ əweɪ. laɪk ə wɔɹd. ə wɔɹd ʃi kəd nɑt si. ə wɔɹɾ ə seɪɾɪn?

Only half a step, but she was out of her chair before he could right himself. Embracing saidar with an effort, she reached up to clasp his head between her hands, and laboriously wove a Delving around him. She had tried finding a better way to find what ailed someone, so far without success. It was enough. No sooner had the weave settled on him than her breath caught. She had known about the wound in his side from Falme, never healing completely, resisting all the Healing she knew, like a pustule of evil in his flesh. Now there was another half-healed wound atop the old, and that pulsed with evil, too. A different sort of evil, somehow, like a mirror of the other, yet just as virulent. And she could not touch either with the Power. She did not really want to - just thinking of it made her skin crawl! - but she tried. And something unseen held her away. Like a ward. A ward she could not see. A ward of saidin?

ðət meɪɾ əɹ stɑp tʃænəlɪŋ ən stɛp bæk. ʃi klʌŋ tə ðə sɔɹs; noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ taɪɝd ʃi wɑz, ʃi wʊɾə hæd tə fɔɹs hɝsɛlf tə lɛt ɡoʊ. noʊ sɪstɝ kəd θɪŋk ə ðə meɪl hæf ə ðə paʊɝ wɪθaʊɾ ət list ə tʌtʃ ə fɪɹ. hi lʊk daʊn əɾ əɹ kɑmli, ən ðət meɪɾ əɹ ʃɪvɝ. hi simd ənʌðɝ mæn ɪntaɪɝli fɹəm ðə ɹænd ælθɹ ʃi hæd wɑtʃt ɡɹoʊ ʌp. ʃi wɑz vɛɹi ɡlæd ðət læn wɑz ðɛɹ, hɑɹɾ əz ðət wɑz tə ədmɪt. sʌɾənli ʃi ɹilaɪz ðəɾ i hæd nɑt ɹɪlæks baɪ ə wɪskɝ. hi maɪt tʃæɾɝ wɪð ɹænd laɪk tu mɛn oʊvɝ paɪps ən eɪl, bʌɾ i θɔt ɹænd wɑz deɪnʒɝəs. ən ɹænd lʊkt ət læn əz ɪf i nu ɪt, ən æksɛptɪɾ ɪt.

That made her stop channeling and step back. She clung to the Source; no matter how tired she was, she would have had to force herself to let go. No sister could think of the male half of the Power without at least a touch of fear. He looked down at her calmly, and that made her shiver. He seemed another man entirely from the Rand al'Thor she had watched grow up. She was very glad that Lan was there, hard as that was to admit. Suddenly she realized that he had not relaxed by a whisker. He might chatter with Rand like two men over pipes and ale, but he thought Rand was dangerous. And Rand looked at Lan as if he knew it, and accepted it.

"nʌn ə ðəɾ ɪz ɪmpɔɹɾənt naʊ," ɹænd sɛd, tɝnɪŋ tə ðə skɹɪp ɑn ðə teɪbəl. ʃi dɪd nɑt noʊ wɛðɝ i mɛn ɪz wunz əɹ wɛɹ mæt wɑz. fɹəm ðə skɹɪp i pɹədus tu stætʃuɛts ə fʊt haɪ, ə waɪz-lʊkɪŋ, bɪɹɾəd mæn ən ən ikwəli waɪz ən sɝin wʊmən, itʃ ɪn floʊɪŋ ɹoʊbz ən hoʊldɪŋ əlɔft ə klɪɹ kɹɪstəl sfɪɹ. fɹəm ðə weɪ hi hændəl ðɛm, ðeɪ wɝ hɛviɝ ðən ðeɪ əpɪɹd. "aɪ wɑn jə tə kip ðiz hɪɾən fəɹ mi əntɪl aɪ sɛn fəɹ ðɛm, nɪneɪiv." wʌn hæn ɑn ðə fɪɡjɝ ə ðə wʊmən, hi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "æn fəɹ ju. əl nid jə wən aɪ juz ðɛm. wən wi juz ðɛm. æftɝ aɪ teɪk kɛɹ ə ðoʊz mɛn. ðəɾ əz tə kʌm fɝst."

"None of that is important now," Rand said, turning to the scrip on the table. She did not know whether he meant his wounds or where Mat was. From the scrip he produced two statuettes a foot high, a wise-looking, bearded man and an equally wise and serene woman, each in flowing robes and holding aloft a clear crystal sphere. From the way he handled them, they were heavier than they appeared. "I want you to keep these hidden for me until I send for them, Nynaeve." One hand on the figure of the woman, he hesitated. "And for you. I'll need you when I use them. When we use them. After I take care of those men. That has to come first."

"juz ðɛm?" ʃi sɛd səspɪʃəsli. waɪ dɪd kɪlɪŋ ɛniwʌn əv tə kʌm fɝst? ðət wɑz hɑɹdli ði ɪmpɔɹɾənt kwɛstʃən, ðoʊ. "fɔɹ wʌt? ɑɹ ðeɪ tɛɹæŋɡɹil?"

"Use them?" she said suspiciously. Why did killing anyone have to come first? That was hardly the important question, though. "For what? Are they ter'angreal?"

hi nɑɾəd. "wɪð ðɪs, jə kən tʌtʃ ðə ɡɹeɪɾəst sɑŋɡɹil ɛvɝ meɪd fəɹ ə wʊmən. ɪts bɛɹiɾ ɑn tʃɹɛmælkɪŋ, aɪ ʌndɝstænd, bʌt ðət dʌzn mæɾɝ." hɪz hæn muv tə ðə fɪɡjɝ ə ðə mæn. "wɪð ðɪs wʌn, aɪ kən tʌtʃ ɪts meɪl twɪn. aɪ wɑz toʊl baɪ . . . sʌmwʌn . . . wʌns, ðəɾ ə mæn ən wʊmən juzɪŋ ðoʊz sɑŋɡɹil kəd tʃælənʒ ðə dɑɹk wʌn. ðeɪ maɪɾ əv tə bi juz fəɹ ðæt, wʌn deɪ, bʌɾ ɪn ðə mintaɪm, aɪ hoʊp ðəɹ ɪnʌf tə klɛnz ðə meɪl hæf ə ðə sɔɹs."

He nodded. "With this, you can touch the greatest sa'angreal ever made for a woman. It's buried on Tremalking, I understand, but that doesn't matter." His hand moved to the figure of the man. "With this one, I can touch its male twin. I was told by . . . someone . . . once, that a man and woman using those sa'angreal could challenge the Dark One. They might have to be used for that, one day, but in the meantime, I hope they're enough to cleanse the male half of the Source."

"ɪf ɪt kəd bi dʌn, wʊdn ðeɪv dʌn ɪɾ ɪn ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz?" læn sɛd kwaɪətli. kwaɪət ðə weɪ stil slaɪɾɪŋ fɹəm ə skæbɝd wɑz kwaɪət. "ju sɛd wʌns ðəɾ aɪ kəd ɡɛɾ əɹ hɝt." ɪt simd ɪmpɑsəbəl ɪz vɔɪs kəd ɡɹoʊ ɛni hɑɹɾɝ, bʌɾ ɪt dɪd. "ju kəd kɪl hɝ, ʃifɝɾɝ." ən ɪz toʊn meɪd klɪɹ ðəɾ i wəd nɑɾ əlaʊ ðæt.

"If it could be done, wouldn't they have done it in the Age of Legends?" Lan said quietly. Quiet the way steel sliding from a scabbard was quiet. "You said once that I could get her hurt." It seemed impossible his voice could grow any harder, but it did. "You could kill her, sheepherder." And his tone made clear that he would not allow that.

ɹænd mɛt lænz koʊl blu stɛɹ wɪð wʌn dʒʌst əz koʊld. "aɪ doʊnt noʊ waɪ ðeɪ dɪdnt. aɪ doʊn kɛɹ waɪ. ɪts tə bi tʃɹaɪd."

Rand met Lan's cold blue stare with one just as cold. "I don't know why they didn't. I don't care why. It has to be tried."

nɪneɪiv bɪɾ əɹ loʊɝ lɪp. ʃi səpoʊzd ɹænd meɪd ðɪs ə pʌblɪk əkeɪʒən - ʃɪftɪŋ fɹəm pʌblɪk tə pɹaɪvət, dəsaɪɾɪŋ wɪtʃ wɑz wɪtʃ, meɪɾ əɹ dɪzi səmtaɪmz - bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt kɛɹ ðət læn hæd spoʊkən aʊɾ ə tɝn. hi wɑz bæd ðət weɪ, ɪn ɛni keɪs, bʌt ʃi laɪkt ən aʊtspoʊkən mæn. ʃi niɾəd tə θɪŋk. nɑɾ əbaʊɾ əɹ dɪsɪʒən. ʃi hæd meɪd ðæt. əbaʊt haʊ tə ɪmpləmɛn ɪt. ɹænd maɪt nɑt laɪk ɪt. læn sɝɾənli wəd nɑt. wɛl, mɛn ɔlweɪz wɑntəd ðɛɹ oʊn weɪ. səmtaɪmz jə dʒʌs hæd tə titʃ əm ðeɪ kəd nɑɾ ɔlweɪz əv ɪt.

Nynaeve bit her lower lip. She supposed Rand made this a public occasion - shifting from public to private, deciding which was which, made her dizzy sometimes - but she did not care that Lan had spoken out of turn. He was bad that way, in any case, but she liked an outspoken man. She needed to think. Not about her decision. She had made that. About how to implement it. Rand might not like it. Lan certainly would not. Well, men always wanted their own way. Sometimes you just had to teach them they could not always have it.

"aɪ θɪŋk ɪts ə wʌndɝfəl aɪdiə," ʃi sɛd. ðət wɑz nɑɾ ɪɡzækli ə laɪ. ɪt wɑz wʌndɝfəl, kəmpɛɹd tə ði ɔltɝnəɾɪvz. "bʌɾ aɪ doʊn si waɪ aɪ ʃəd sɪt hɪɹ weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ jəɹ sʌmənz laɪk ə sɝvɪŋ meɪd. əl də ɪt, bʌt wi ɔl ɡoʊ təɡɛðɝ."

"I think it is a wonderful idea," she said. That was not exactly a lie. It was wonderful, compared to the alternatives. "But I don't see why I should sit here waiting for your summons like a serving maid. I'll do it, but we all go together."

ʃi hæd bɪn ɹaɪt. ðeɪ dɪd nɑt laɪk ɪt wʌn bɪt.

She had been right. They did not like it one bit.


tʃæptɝ twɛlv


CHAPTER 12

eɪ lɪli ɪn wɪntɝ


A Lily in Winter

ənʌðɝ sɝvɪŋ mæn nɪɹli fɛl ɑn ɪz noʊz boʊɪŋ, ən ɪleɪn saɪɾ əz ʃi ɡlaɪɾɪd pæst əlɔŋ ðə pæləs kɔɹəɾɝ. ət list, ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə ɡlaɪd. ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ ʌv ændɝ, steɪtli ən sɝin. ʃi wɑntəd tə ɹʌn, ðoʊ hɝ dɑɹk blu skɝts pɹɑbli wʊɾə tʃɹɪpt əɹ hæd ʃi tʃɹaɪd. ʃi kəɾ ɔlmoʊs fil ðə staʊt mænz ɡɑəlɪŋ aɪz fɑloʊɪŋ əɹ ən əɹ kəmpænjənz. ə maɪnɝ ɪɹəɾənt, ən wʌn ðət wəd pæs; ə ɡɹeɪn ə sæn ɪn əɹ slɪpɝ. ɹænd blʌɾi θɪŋks-hi-noʊz-bɛst-fɔɹ-ɛvɹibɑɾi ælθɹ ɪz ɪtʃhoʊk daʊn maɪ bæk! ʃi θɔt. ɪf i mænədʒ tə ɡɛɾ əweɪ fɹəm əɹ ðɪs taɪm . . . !

Another serving man nearly fell on his nose bowing, and Elayne sighed as she glided past along the Palace corridor. At least, she tried to glide. The Daughter-Heir of Andor, stately and serene. She wanted to run, though her dark blue skirts probably would have tripped her had she tried. She could almost feel the stout man's goggling eyes following her and her companions. A minor irritant, and one that would pass; a grain of sand in her slipper. Rand bloody thinks-he-knows-best-for-everybody al'Thor is itchoak down my back! she thought. If he managed to get away from her this time . . . !

"dʒʌst ɹɪmɛmbɝ," ʃi sɛd fɝmli. "hi hɪɹz nʌθɪŋ əbaʊt spaɪz, əɹ fɔkɹut, əɹ ɛni ʌv ðæt!" ðə vɛɹi læs θɪŋ ʃi niɾəd wɑz ɪm dəsaɪɾɪŋ tə "ɹɛskju" hɝ. mɛn dɪd ðət sɔɹɾ ə nɑnsɛns; nɪneɪiv kɔld ɪt "θɪŋkɪŋ wɪð ðə hɛɹ ɑn ðɛɹ tʃɛsts." laɪt, hi wəd pɹɑbli tʃɹaɪ tə muv ði il ən ðə sɑldəiənz bæk ɪndə ðə sɪɾi! ɪndə ðə pæləs ɪtsɛlf! bɪɾɝ əz ɪt wɑz tə ədmɪt, ʃi kəd nɑt stɑp ɪm ɪf i dɪd, nɑt ʃɔɹɾ ʌv oʊpən wɔɹ, ən ivən ðət maɪt nɑt bi ɪnʌf.

"Just remember," she said firmly. "He hears nothing about spies, or forkroot, or any of that!" The very last thing she needed was him deciding to "rescue" her. Men did that sort of nonsense; Nynaeve called it "thinking with the hair on their chests." Light, he would probably try to move the Aiel and the Saldaeans back into the city! Into the Palace itself! Bitter as it was to admit, she could not stop him if he did, not short of open war, and even that might not be enough.

"aɪ doʊn tɛl ɪm θɪŋz i dʌznt nid tə noʊ," mɪn sɛd, fɹaʊnɪŋ əɾ ə læŋki, waɪd-aɪd sɝvɪŋ wʊmən huz kɝtsi nɪɹli kəlæpst ɪndə ə spɹɔl ɑn ðə ɹɛd-bɹaʊn flɔɹ taɪlz. aɪɪŋ mɪn saɪdweɪz, ɪleɪn ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ əɹ oʊn taɪm wɛɹɪŋ bɹitʃɪz, ən wʌndɝd wɛðɝ ʃi maɪt nɑt tʃɹaɪ əɡɛn. ðeɪ wɝ sɝɾənli fɹiɝ ðən skɝts. nɑt ðə hil buts, ðoʊ, ʃi dɪsaɪɾɪd dʒudɪʃɪsli. ðeɪ meɪd mɪn ɔlmoʊst əz tɔl əz eɪvinhə, bʌɾ ivən bɝdʒɪt sweɪɾ ɪn ðoʊz, ən wɪð mɪnz snʌɡ bɹitʃɪz ən ə koʊt ðət bɛɹli kʌvɝɾ əɹ hɪps, ɪt lʊk pɑzəɾɪvli skændələs.

"I don't tell him things he doesn't need to know," Min said, frowning at a lanky, wide-eyed serving woman whose curtsy nearly collapsed into a sprawl on the red-brown floor tiles. Eyeing Min sideways, Elayne remembered her own time wearing breeches, and wondered whether she might not try again. They were certainly freer than skirts. Not the heeled boots, though, she decided judiciously. They made Min almost as tall as Aviendha, but even Birgitte swayed in those, and with Min's snug breeches and a coat that barely covered her hips, it looked positively scandalous.

"ju laɪ tə hɪm?" səspɪʃən lɑɹɾɪd eɪvinhəz toʊn. ivən ðə weɪ ʃi ədʒʌstəɾ əɹ dɑɹk ʃɔl ɑn əɹ ʃoʊldɝz kæɹid dɪsəpɹuvəl, ən ʃi ɡlɛɹd pæst ɪleɪn ət mɪn.

"You lie to him?" Suspicion larded Aviendha's tone. Even the way she adjusted her dark shawl on her shoulders carried disapproval, and she glared past Elayne at Min.

"ʌv kɔɹs nɑt," mɪn ɹɪplaɪd ʃɑɹpli, ɡlɛɹɪŋ ɹaɪt bæk. "nɑɾ ənlɛs ɪts nɛsəsɛɹi." eɪvinhə tʃʌkəld, ðən lʊk stɑɹɾəld ðət ʃi hæd, ən pʊɾ ɑn ə stoʊni feɪs.

"Of course not," Min replied sharply, glaring right back. "Not unless it's necessary." Aviendha chuckled, then looked startled that she had, and put on a stony face.

wʌt wɑz ʃi tə də əbaʊt ðɛm? ðeɪ hæd tə laɪk wʌn ənʌðɝ. ðeɪ dʒʌs hæd tə. bʌt ðə tu wɪmən hæd bɪn stɛɹɪŋ əɾ itʃ ʌðɝ laɪk stʃɹeɪnʒ kæts ɪn ə smɔl ɹum ɛvɝ sɪns ðeɪ mɛt. oʊ, ðeɪ hæɾ əɡɹid tə ɛvɹiθɪŋ - ðəɹ ɹɪli hæd bɪn noʊ tʃɔɪs, nɑt wən nʌn ə ðɛm kəd ɡɛs wən ðeɪ wəɾ ɔl əv ðə mæn ət hæn əɡɛn - bʌt ʃi hoʊp ðeɪ dɪd nɑt ʃoʊ wʌn ənʌðɝ əɡɛn haʊ skɪlfəli ðeɪ hændəl ðɛɹ naɪvz. vɛɹi kæʒəwəli, nɑɾ æktʃəli  ɪmplaɪɪŋ ɛni θɹɛt, bʌt vɛɹi oʊpən əbaʊɾ ɪt, tu. ɑn ði ʌðɝ hænd, eɪvinhə hæd bɪn kwaɪɾ ɪmpɹɛst wɪð ðə nʌmbɝ ə naɪvz mɪn kæɹiɾ əbaʊɾ əɹ pɝsən.

What was she to do about them? They had to like one another. They just had to. But the two women had been staring at each other like strange cats in a small room ever since they met. Oh, they had agreed to everything - there really had been no choice, not when none of them could guess when they would all have the man at hand again - but she hoped they did not show one another again how skillfully they handled their knives. Very casually, not actually implying any threat, but very open about it, too. On the other hand, Aviendha had been quite impressed with the number of knives Min carried about her person.

ə ɡæŋli jʌŋ sɝvɪŋ mæn kæɹiɪŋ ə tʃɹeɪ ʌv tɔl mæntəlz fəɹ ðə stænd-læmps baʊɾ əz ʃi swɛp baɪ. ənfɔɹtʃənətli, hi wɑz stɛɹɪŋ soʊ hɑɹd ðəɾ i fɝɡɑt tə peɪ ətɛnʃən tə hɪz bɝɾən. ðə kɹæʃ ʌv ɡlæs ʃæɾɝɪŋ ɑn ðə flɔɹ taɪlz fɪl ðə kɔɹəɾɝ.

A gangly young serving man carrying a tray of tall mantles for the stand-lamps bowed as she swept by. Unfortunately, he was staring so hard that he forgot to pay attention to his burden. The crash of glass shattering on the floor tiles filled the corridor.

ɪleɪn saɪɾ əɡɛn. ʃi dɪd hoʊp ɛvɹiwʌn bɪkeɪm juz tə ðə nu ɔɹɾɝ ə θɪŋz sun. ʃi wɑz nɑt ði əbdʒɛkt ʌv ɔl ðət ɡeɪpɪŋ, ʌv kɔɹs, əɹ eɪvinhə, əɹ ivən mɪn, ðoʊ ʃi pɹɑbli dʒɹu sʌm. noʊ, ɪt wɑz keɪsil ən dɪni, fɑloʊɪŋ kloʊs bɪhaɪnd, hu wɝ meɪkɪŋ aɪz pɑp ən sɝvəns stʌmbəl. ʃi hæɾ eɪt bɑɾiɡɑɹdz, naʊ, ən ðoʊz tu hæd bɪn stændɪŋ ɡɑɹɾ əɾ əɹ dɔɹ wən ʃi woʊk.

Elayne sighed again. She did hope everyone became used to the new order of things soon. She was not the object of all that gaping, of course, or Aviendha, or even Min, though she probably drew some. No, it was Caseille and Deni, following close behind, who were making eyes pop and servants stumble. She had eight bodyguards, now, and those two had been standing guard at her door when she woke.

vɛɹi laɪkli səm ə ðə ɡeɪpɪŋ wɑz dʒʌs ðəɾ ɪleɪn hæd ɡɑɹdzwɪmən tʃɹeɪlɪŋ bɪhaɪn əɹ əɾ ɔl, ən ɔlmoʊst sɝɾənli ðət ðeɪ wɝ wɪmən. noʊ wʌn wɑz juz tə ðæt, jɛt. bʌt bɝdʒɪt hæd sɛd ʃi wəd meɪk əm əpɪɹ sɛɹəmoʊniəl, ən ʃi hæd. ʃi mʌst əv sɛɾ ɛvɹi simstʃɹɪs ən mɪlɪnɝ ɪn ðə pæləs wɝkɪŋ əz sun əz ʃi lɛft ɪleɪnz ɹumz ðə naɪt bɪfɔɹ. itʃ wʊmən wɔɹ ə bɹaɪt ɹɛd hæt wɪð ə lɔŋ waɪt plum laɪɪŋ flæɾ əlɔŋ ðə waɪd bɹɪm, ən ə waɪd ɹɛd sæʃ ɛdʒd ɪn snoʊi leɪi əkɹɔs əɹ tʃɛst wɪð ɹæmpənt waɪt laɪənz mɑɹtʃɪŋ ʌp ɪt. ðɛɹ waɪt-kɑlɝd kɹɪmzən koʊts wɝ sɪlk, ən ðə kʌt hæd bɪn ɔltɝɾ ə lɪɾəl, soʊ ðeɪ fɪt bɛɾɝ ən hʌŋ ɔlmoʊs tə ðə ni əbʌv skɑɹlət bɹitʃɪz wɪð ə waɪt stʃɹaɪp ʌp ði aʊtsaɪdz ə ðə lɛɡz. peɪl leɪs hʌŋ θɪkli ət ðɛɹ ɹɪsts ən nɛks, ən ðɛɹ blæk buts hæd bɪn wæks tɪl ðeɪ ʃoʊn. ðeɪ lʊkt kwaɪt dæʃɪŋ, ən ivən plæsəd-aɪd dɪni swæɡɝd dʒʌst ə lɪɾəl. ɪleɪn səspɛktəd ðeɪ wəd bi ivən pɹaʊɾɝ wʌns ðə sɔɹd bɛls ən skæbɝdz wɪð ɡoʊl tulɪŋ wɝ ɹɛɾi, ən ðə lækɝd hɛlməts ən bɹɛstpleɪts. bɝdʒɪt wɑz hævɪŋ bɹɛstpleɪts meɪd tə fɪt wɪmən, wɪtʃ ɪleɪn səspɛktəd hæd sɝɾənli meɪd ðə pæləs ɑɹmɔɹɝz aɪz pɑp!

Very likely some of the gaping was just that Elayne had Guardswomen trailing behind her at all, and almost certainly that they were women. No one was used to that, yet. But Birgitte had said she would make them appear ceremonial, and she had. She must have set every seamstress and milliner in the Palace working as soon as she left Elayne's rooms the night before. Each woman wore a bright red hat with a long white plume lying flat along the wide brim, and a wide red sash edged in snowy laee across her chest with rampant White Lions marching up it. Their white-collared crimson coats were silk, and the cut had been altered a little, so they fit better and hung almost to the knee above scarlet breeches with a white stripe up the outsides of the legs. Pale lace hung thickly at their wrists and necks, and their black boots had been waxed till they shone. They looked quite dashing, and even placid-eyed Deni swaggered just a little. Elayne suspected they would be even prouder once the sword belts and scabbards with gold tooling were ready, and the lacquered helmets and breastplates. Birgitte was having breastplates made to fit women, which Elayne suspected had certainly made the Palace armorer's eyes pop!

ət ðə moʊmənt, bɝdʒɪt wɑz bɪzi ɪntɝvjuɪŋ wɪmən tə ɹaʊn aʊt ðə twɛnti fəɹ ðə bɑɾiɡɑɹd. ɪleɪn kəd fil əɹ kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾɪŋ, wɪð noʊ saɪn ə fɪzɪkəl æktɪvəɾi, soʊ ɪt mʌs bi ðæt, ənlɛs ʃi wɑz ɹiɾɪŋ, əɹ pleɪɪŋ stoʊnz, ən ʃi sɛldəm tʊk ə moʊmən əweɪ fɹəm əɹ duɾiz fəɹ hɝsɛlf. ɪleɪn hoʊpt ʃi wəd kip ɪt tə dʒʌs twɛnti. ʃi hoʊp bɝdʒɪt wɑz bɪzi ɪnʌf ðət ʃi dɪd nɑt noʊɾəs əntɪl tu leɪt wən ʃi mæsk ðə bɑnd. tə θɪŋk ðət ʃi hæd bɪn soʊ wɝiɾ əbaʊt bɝdʒɪt sɛnsɪŋ wʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt wɑn əɹ tə wən ðə səluʃən leɪ ɪn ə sɪmpəl kwɛstʃən tə vændin. ði ænsɝ hæd bɪn ə ɹufəl ɹimaɪndɝ haʊ lɪɾəl ʃi æktʃəli  nu əbaʊt biɪŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ, ɪspɛʃli ðə pɑɹts ʌðɝ sɪstɝz tʊk fəɹ ɡɹæntəd. əpɛɹənli, ɛvɹi sɪstɝ u hæɾ ə wɔɹɾɝ nu haʊ, ivən ðoʊz u ɹɪmeɪn sɛləbət.

At the moment, Birgitte was busy interviewing women to round out the twenty for the bodyguard. Elayne could feel her concentrating, with no sign of physical activity, so it must be that, unless she was reading, or playing stones, and she seldom took a moment away from her duties for herself. Elayne hoped she would keep it to just twenty. She hoped Birgitte was busy enough that she did not notice until too late when she masked the bond. To think that she had been so worried about Birgitte sensing what she did not want her to when the solution lay in a simple question to Vandene. The answer had been a rueful reminder how little she actually knew about being Aes Sedai, especially the parts other sisters took for granted. Apparently, every sister who had a Warder knew how, even those who remained celibate.

ɪt wɑz ɑd haʊ θɪŋz keɪm əbaʊt, səmtaɪmz. ɪf nɑt fəɹ ðə bɑɾiɡɑɹdz, ɪf nɑt fəɹ wʌndɝɪŋ haʊ ʃi kəd mænədʒ tə ɪluɾ əm ən bɝdʒɪt, ʃi wəd nɛvɝ əv θɔt tə æsk, wəd nɛvɝ əv lɝn ðə mæskɪŋ ɪn taɪm fəɹ ðɪs. nɑt ðət ʃi plæn tə ɪluɾ əɹ ɡɑɹdz ɛni taɪm sun, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz bɛs tə bi pɹipɛɹɾ ɪn ədvæns ə nid. bɝdʒɪt sɝɾənli wɑz nɑt gɑnə əlaʊ hɝ ən eɪvinhə tə wɑndɝ ðə sɪɾi əloʊn, deɪ əɹ naɪt, nɑɾ ɛni lɔŋɡɝ.

It was odd how things came about, sometimes. If not for the bodyguards, if not for wondering how she could manage to elude them and Birgitte, she would never have thought to ask, would never have learned the masking in time for this. Not that she planned to elude her guards any time soon, but it was best to be prepared in advance of need.
