ðə sʌn pæləsəz sʌnɹum wɑz koʊl dɪspaɪt faɪɝz ɹɔɹɪŋ ɑn hɑɹθs əɾ iðɝ ɛn ə ðə ɹum, θɪkli leɪɝd kɑɹpəts, ən ə slæntəd ɡlæs ɹuf ðət lɛɾ ɪn bɹaɪt mɔɹnɪŋ laɪt wɛɹ snoʊ kɑɾ ɑn ðə θɪn mʌntɪnz dɪd nɑt ʃild ɪt, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz suɾəbəl fəɹ hoʊldɪŋ ɑɾiənsəz. kædzueɪn hæd θɔɾ ɪt bɛs nɑt tə əpɹoʊpɹieɪt ðə θɹoʊn ɹum. soʊ fɑɹ, lɔɹd dɑbɹeɪn hæd ɹɪmeɪn kwaɪəɾ əbaʊɾ əɹ hoʊldɪŋ kæɹɑlin dəmədʒɹɾ ən dɑɹlɪn sɪsnɛɹə - ʃi sɔ noʊ bɛɾɝ weɪ tə kip əm fɹəm ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn wɪð ðɛɹ mɪstʃəf ðən kipɪŋ əm ɪn ə fɝm ɡɹɪp - bʌt dɑbɹeɪn maɪt bɪɡɪn tə fʌs oʊvɝ ðəɾ ɪf ʃi pʊʃt bɪɑnd wʌɾ i kənsɪɾɝd pɹɑpɝ. hi wɑz tu kloʊz tə ðə bɔɪ fəɹ əɹ tə wɑnə fɔɹs hɪm, ən feɪθfəl tə hɪz oʊðz. ʃi kəd lʊk bæk ɑn əɹ laɪf ən ɹikɔl feɪljɝz, səm bɪɾɝli ɹɪɡɹɛɾɪd, ən mɪsteɪks ðət hæd kɑs laɪvz, bʌt ʃi kəd nɑɾ əfɔɹd mɪsteɪks əɹ feɪljɝ hɪɹ. moʊs dɛfənətli nɑt feɪljɝ. laɪt, ʃi wɑntəd tə baɪt sʌmwʌn!

The Sun Palace's sunroom was cold despite fires roaring on hearths at either end of the room, thickly layered carpets, and a slanted glass roof that let in bright morning light where snow caught on the thin muntins did not shield it, but it was suitable for holding audiences. Cadsuane had thought it best not to appropriate the throne room. So far, Lord Dobraine had remained quiet about her holding Caraline Damodred and Darlin Sisnera - she saw no better way to keep them from going on with their mischief than keeping them in a firm grip - but Dobraine might begin to fuss over that if she pushed beyond what he considered proper. He was too close to the boy for her to want to force him, and faithful to his oaths. She could look back on her life and recall failures, some bitterly regretted, and mistakes that had cost lives, but she could not afford mistakes or failure here. Most definitely not failure. Light, she wanted to bite someone!

"aɪ dɪmæn ðə ɹɪtɝn ə maɪ wɪndfɪndɝ, ɛɛs sədaɪ!" hɑɹɪn dɪn toʊɡɑɹə, ɔl ɪn ɡɹin bɹoʊkeɪɾɪd sɪlk, sæt ɹɪdʒɪdli ɪn fɹʌn ə kædzueɪn, hɝ fʊl maʊθ taɪt. dɪspaɪɾ ən ənlaɪn feɪs, waɪt stʃɹikt əɹ stʃɹeɪt blæk hɛɹ. weɪvməstʃɹəs ə hɝ klæn fəɹ tɛn jɪɹz, ʃi hæd kəmændəɾ ə lɑɹdʒ vɛsəl lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ ðæt. hɝ seɪlməstʃɹəs, dɪɹə dɪn sɛlɑn, ə jʌŋɡɝ wʊmən ɔl ɪn blu, sæɾ ɑn ə tʃɛɹ pleɪst ə kɛɹfəl fʊt fɑɹðɝ bæk ɪn əkɔɹɾəns wɪð ðɛɹ noʊʃənz ə pɹəpɹaɪəɾi. ðə pɛɹ maɪɾ əv bɪn dɑɹk kɑɹvɪŋz ʌv aʊtʃɹeɪdʒ, ən ðɛɹ aʊtlændɪʃ dʒuəlɹi sʌmhaʊ æɾəd tə ði ɪfɛkt. niðɝ soʊ mʌtʃ əz flɪkɝɾ ən aɪ təwɔɹɾ ɛbən wən i baʊɾ ən ɔfɝd sɪlvɝ ɡoʊbləts ə hɑt spaɪst waɪn ɑn ə tʃɹeɪ.

"I demand the return of my Windfinder, Aes Sedai!" Harine din Togara, all in green brocaded silk, sat rigidly in front of Cadsuane, her full mouth tight. Despite an unlined face, white streaked her straight black hair. Wavemistress of her clan for ten years, she had commanded a large vessel long before that. Her Sailmistress, Derah din Selaan, a younger woman all in blue, sat on a chair placed a careful foot farther back in accordance with their notions of propriety. The pair might have been dark carvings of outrage, and their outlandish jewelry somehow added to the effect. Neither so much as flickered an eye toward Eben when he bowed and offered silver goblets of hot spiced wine on a tray.

ðə bɔɪ dɪd nɑt sim tə noʊ wʌt tə də nɛkst wən ðeɪ tʊk nʌθɪŋ. fɹaʊnɪŋ ənsɝteɪnli, hi ɹɪmeɪn bɛn əntɪl deɪdʒiən plʌkt əɾ ɪz ɹɛd koʊɾ ən lɛɾ ɪm əweɪ smaɪlɪŋ, ən əmjuz paʊɾɝ pɪdʒən ɪn dɑɹk blu slæʃt wɪð waɪt. ə slɛndɝ læd wɪð ə bɪɡ noʊz ən lɑɹdʒ ɪɹz, nɛvɝ tə bi kɔl hænsəm mʌtʃ lɛs pɹɪɾi, bʌt ʃi wɑz vɛɹi pəzɛsɪv ə hɪm. ðeɪ tʊk sits kloʊs təɡɛðɝ ɑn ə pæɾəd bɛntʃ ɪn fɹʌn ʌv wʌn ə ðə faɪɝpleɪsəz ən bɪɡæn pleɪɪŋ kæts kɹeɪɾəl.

The boy did not seem to know what to do next when they took nothing. Frowning uncertainly, he remained bent until Daigian plucked at his red coat and led him away smiling, an amused pouter pigeon in dark blue slashed with white. A slender lad with a big nose and large ears, never to be called handsome much less pretty, but she was very possessive of him. They took seats close together on a padded bench in front of one of the fireplaces and began playing cat's cradle.

"jɔɹ sɪstɝ ɪz əsɪstɪŋ əs ɪn lɝnɪŋ wʌt hæpən ɑn ði ənfɔɹtʃənət deɪ," kædzueɪn sɛd smuðli, ən sʌmwʌɾ æbsənli. teɪkɪŋ ə swɑloʊ ʌv əɹ oʊn spaɪst waɪn, ʃi weɪɾəd, ənkɛɹɪŋ wɛðɝ ðeɪ sɔ hɝ ɪmpeɪʃəns. noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ dɑbɹeɪn ɡɹʌmbəld əbaʊt haʊ ɪmpɑsəbəl ɪt wɑz tə mit ðə tɝmz ə ðəɾ ɪnkɹɛɾəbəl bɑɹɡən ɹæfɛlə ən mɛɹænə hæd meɪɾ ɑn bɪhæf ə ði ælθɹ bɔɪ, hi stɪl maɪɾ əv hændəl ðə si foʊk hɪmsɛlf. ʃi kəd hɑɹdli ɡɪv əm hæf ə hɝ maɪnd. pɹɑbli ðət wɑz dʒʌst əz wɛl fəɹ ðɛm. ɪf ʃi foʊkəst ɑn ði æθɑn maɪɹ, ʃi wəd bi hɑɹd-pɹɛs nɑt tə swɑɾ əm laɪk baɪtmz, ðoʊ ðeɪ wɝ nɑt ðə ɹil sɔɹs ə hɝ ɛksæspɝeɪʃən.

"Your sister is assisting us in learning what happened on the unfortunate day," Cadsuane said smoothly, and somewhat absently. Taking a swallow of her own spiced wine, she waited, uncaring whether they saw her impatience. No matter how Dobraine grumbled about how impossible it was to meet the terms of that incredible bargain Rafela and Merana had made on behalf of the al'Thor boy, he still might have handled the Sea Folk himself. She could hardly give them half of her mind. Probably that was just as well for them. If she focused on the Atha'an Miere, she would be hard-pressed not to swat them like bitemes, though they were not the real source of her exasperation.

faɪv sɪstɝz wɝ ɝeɪɾ ɝaʊn ðə faɪɝpleɪs ət ði ʌðɝ ɛn ə ðə sʌnɹum fɹəm deɪdʒiən ən ɛbən. nɛsun hæɾ ə lɑɹdʒ wʊd baʊn vɑljum fɹəm ðə pæləs laɪbɹɛɹi spɹɛɾ ɑn ə ɹɛɾɪŋ stæn ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ tʃɛɹ. laɪk ði ʌðɝz, ʃi wɔɹ ə pleɪn wʊlən dʒɹɛs mɔɹ suɾəd tə ə mɝtʃən ðən ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. ɪf ɛni ɹɪɡɹɛɾɪd ðə læk ə sɪlks, əɹ mʌni fəɹ sɪlks, ðeɪ dɪd nɑt ʃoʊ ɪt. sɝin, wɪð əɹ θɪn, biɾɪd bɹeɪdz, stʊd wɝkɪŋ əɾ ə lɑɹdʒ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi fɹeɪm, hɝ niɾəl meɪkɪŋ ðə taɪni stɪtʃɪz ə jɛɾ ənʌðɝ flaʊɝ ɪn ə fild ə blɑsəmz. ɛɹiən ən bɛldaɪn wɝ pleɪɪŋ stoʊnz, wɑtʃt baɪ ɛlzə, hu weɪɾəd əɹ tɝn tə teɪk ɑn ðə wɪnɝ. baɪ ɔl əpɪɹənsəz ðeɪ wɝ ɛndʒɔɪɪŋ ən aɪɾəl mɔɹnɪŋ, wɪθaʊɾ ə kɛɹ ɪn ðə wɝld. pɝhæps ðeɪ nu ðeɪ wɝ hɪɹ kəz ʃi wɑntəd tə stʌɾi ðɛm. waɪ hæd ðeɪ swɔɹn fiəlti tə ði ælθɹ bɔɪ? ət lis kaɪɹunə ən ði ʌðɝz hæd bɪn ɪn ɪz pɹɛzəns wən ðeɪ dɪsaɪɾɪd tə swɛɹ. ʃi wɑz wɪlɪŋ tə ədmɪt ðət noʊ wʌn kəd ɹɪzɪs ði ɪnfluəns ʌv ə tɑvɝən wən ɪt kɑt ju. bʌt ðiz faɪv hæd teɪkən ə hɑɹʃ pɛnəns fəɹ kɪdnæpɪŋ ɪm ən ɹitʃt ðɛɹ dɪsɪʒən tə ɔfɝ oʊθ bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ wɝ bɹɔt nɪɹ hɪm. ɪn ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ ʃi hæd bɪn ɪnklaɪn tə æksɛp ðɛɹ vɛɹiəs ɛkspləneɪʃənz, bʌɾ oʊvɝ ðə læs fju deɪz ðəɾ ɪnkləneɪʃən hæd teɪkən hɑɹd nɑks. dɪstɝbɪŋli hɑɹd nɑks.

Five sisters were arrayed around the fireplace at the other end of the sunroom from Daigian and Eben. Nesune had a large wood bound volume from the Palace library spread on a reading stand in front of her chair. Like the others, she wore a plain woolen dress more suited to a merchant than an Aes Sedai. If any regretted the lack of silks, or money for silks, they did not show it. Sarene, with her thin, beaded braids, stood working at a large embroidery frame, her needle making the tiny stitches of yet another flower in a field of blossoms. Erian and Beldeine were playing stones, watched by Elza, who waited her turn to take on the winner. By all appearances they were enjoying an idle morning, without a care in the world. Perhaps they knew they were here because she wanted to study them. Why had they sworn fealty to the al'Thor boy? At least Kiruna and the others had been in his presence when they decided to swear. She was willing to admit that no one could resist the influence of a ta'veren when it caught you. But these five had taken a harsh penance for kidnapping him and reached their decision to offer oath before they were brought near him. In the beginning she had been inclined to accept their various explanations, but over the last few days that inclination had taken hard knocks. Disturbingly hard knocks.

"maɪ wɪndfɪndɝ ɪz nɑt sʌbʒɪkt tə jəɹ əθɔɹəɾi, ɛɛs sədaɪ," hɑɹɪn sɛd ʃɑɹpli, əz ɪf dɪnaɪɪŋ ðə blʌd kənɛkʃən. "ʃələn mʌst ən wɪl bi ɹɪtɝn tə mi ət wʌns." dɪɹə nɑɾəd kɝɾ əɡɹimənt. kædzueɪn θɔt ðə seɪlməstʃɹəs maɪt də ðə seɪm ɪf hɑɹɪn ɔɹɾɝd əɹ tə dʒʌmp fɹəm ə klɪf. ɪn ði æθɑn maɪɹz haɪɝɑɹki, dɪɹə stʊɾ ə lɔŋ dɪstəns bɪloʊ hɑɹɪn. ən ðət wɑz ɔlmoʊst əz mʌtʃ əz kædzueɪn nu ʌv ðɛm. ðə si foʊk maɪt pɹuv jusfəl əɹ maɪt nɑt, bʌt ʃi kəd faɪn ə weɪ tə ɡɛɾ ə ɡɹɪp ɑn əm ɪn ɛni keɪs.

"My Windfinder is not subject to your authority, Aes Sedai," Harine said sharply, as if denying the blood connection. "Shalon must and will be returned to me at once." Derah nodded curt agreement. Cadsuane thought the Sailmistress might do the same if Harine ordered her to jump from a cliff. In the Atha'an Miere's hierarchy, Derah stood a long distance below Harine. And that was almost as much as Cadsuane knew of them. The Sea Folk might prove useful or might not, but she could find a way to get a grip on them in any case.

"ðɪs ɪz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪnkwaɪɹi," ʃi ɹɪplaɪd blænli. "wi mʌs fɑloʊ taʊɝ lɔ." lusli ɪntɝpɹəɾəd, tə bi ʃʊɹ. ʃi hæɾ ɔlweɪz bɪliv ðə spɪɹəɾ ə ðə lɔ wɑz fɑɹ mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt ðən ðə lɛɾɝ.

"This is an Aes Sedai inquiry," she replied blandly. "We must follow Tower law." Loosely interpreted, to be sure. She had always believed the spirit of the law was far more important than the letter.

hɑɹɪn pʌft ʌp laɪk ən æɾɝ ən bɪɡæn jɛɾ ənʌðɝ hɝæŋ lɪstɪŋ əɹ ɹaɪts ən dɪmænz, bʌt kædzueɪn lɪsənd wɪð hæf ən ɪɹ.

Harine puffed up like an adder and began yet another harangue listing her rights and demands, but Cadsuane listened with half an ear.

ʃi kəɾ ɔlmoʊst ʌndɝstæn ɛɹiən, ə peɪl, blæk-hɛɹɾ ɪliɑnɝ, fɪɹsli ɪnsɪstɪŋ ðət ʃi mʌs bi ət ðə bɔɪz saɪd wən i fɔt ðə læs bæɾəl. ən bɛldaɪn, soʊ nu tə ðə ʃɔl ðət ʃi hæd nɑt jɛɾ ətʃivd eɪɡləsnəs, soʊ dɪtɝmən tə bi ɛvɹiθɪŋ ðəɾ ə ɡɹin ʃəd bi. ən ɛlzə, ə plɛzənt-feɪst ændɔɝən huz aɪz ɔlmoʊst ɡloʊd wən ʃi spoʊk ə meɪkɪŋ sɝɾən ðəɾ i lɪv tə feɪs ðə dɑɹk wʌn. ənʌðɝ ɡɹin, ən ivən mɔɹ ɪntɛns ðən moʊst. nɛsun, hʌntʃt fɔɹwɝd tə pɪɹ əɾ əɹ bʊk, lʊk laɪk ə blæk-aɪd bɝɾ ɪɡzæmɪnɪŋ ə wɝm. eɪ bɹaʊn, ʃi wəd klaɪm ɪndə ə bɑks wɪð ə skɔɹpiən ɪf ʃi wɑntəd tə stʌɾi ɪt. sɝin maɪt bi ful ɪnʌf tə bi stɑɹɾəld ðəɾ ɛniwʌn θɔɾ əɹ pɹɪɾi, mʌtʃ lɛs stʌnɪŋ, bʌt ðə waɪɾ ɪnsɪstəɾ ɑn ðə kul pɹisɪʒən ə hɝ lɑdʒɪk; ælθɹ wɑz ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, ən lɑdʒɪkli, ʃi mʌs fɑloʊ hɪm. tɛmpɛstʃuəs ɹizənz, ɪɾiɑtɪk ɹizənz, jɛt ʃi cʊɾə æksɛptɪd ðɛm, ɪf nɑt fəɹ ði ʌðɝz.

She could almost understand Erian, a pale, black-haired Illianer, fiercely insisting that she must be at the boy's side when he fought the Last Battle. And Beldeine, so new to the shawl that she had not yet achieved agelessness, so determined to be everything that a Green should be. And Elza, a pleasant-faced Andoran whose eyes almost glowed when she spoke of making certain that he lived to face the Dark One. Another Green, and even more intense than most. Nesune, hunched forward to peer at her book, looked like a black-eyed bird examining a worm. A Brown, she would climb into a box with a scorpion if she wanted to study it. Sarene might be fool enough to be startled that anyone thought her pretty, much less stunning, but the White insisted on the cool precision of her logic; al'Thor was the Dragon Reborn, and logically, she must follow him. Tempestuous reasons, idiotic reasons, yet she could have accepted them, if not for the others.

ðə dɔɹ tə ðə hɔl oʊpən tə ədmɪt vɛɹɪn ən sɔɹɪliə. ðə lɛðɝi, waɪt-hɛɹɾ il wʊmən hændəd sʌmθɪŋ smɔl tə vɛɹɪn ðət ðə bɹaʊn tʌkt ɪndə hɝ bɛl paʊtʃ. vɛɹɪn wɑz wɛɹɪŋ ə flaʊɝd bɹutʃ ɑn əɹ sɪmpəl bɹɑnz-kʌlɝd dʒɹɛs, ðə fɝs dʒuəlɹi kædzueɪn hæɾ ɛvɝ sin ɑn əɹ əsaɪd fɹəm əɹ ɡɹeɪt sɝpən ɹɪŋ.

The door to the hall opened to admit Verin and Sorilea. The leathery, white-haired Aiel woman handed something small to Verin that the Brown tucked into her belt pouch. Verin was wearing a flowered brooch on her simple bronze-colored dress, the first jewelry Cadsuane had ever seen on her aside from her Great Serpent ring.

"ðæt wɪl hɛlp jə slip," sɔɹɪliə sɛd, "bʌt ɹɪmɛmbɝ, dʒʌs θɹi dʒɹɑps ɪn wɔɾɝ əɹ wʌn ɪn waɪn. ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ, ən jə maɪt slip ə deɪ əɹ lɔŋɡɝ. mʌtʃ mɔɹ, ən jəl nɑt weɪk. ðəɹ ɪz noʊ teɪs tə wɔɹn ju, soʊ jə mʌs bi kɛɹfəl."

"That will help you sleep," Sorilea said, "but remember, just three drops in water or one in wine. A little more, and you might sleep a day or longer. Much more, and you will not wake. There is no taste to warn you, so you must be careful."

soʊ vɛɹɪn wɑz hævɪŋ tʃɹʌbəl slipɪŋ, tu. kædzueɪn hæd nɑt hæɾ ə ɡʊd naɪts ɹɛst sɪns ðə bɔɪ flɛd ðə sʌn pæləs. ɪf ʃi dɪd nɑt faɪnd wʌn sun, ʃi θɔt ʃi maɪt baɪt sʌmwʌn. nɛsun ən ði ʌðɝz wɝ aɪɪŋ sɔɹɪliə ənizəli. ðə bɔɪ hæd meɪɾ əm əpɹɛntəs ðɛmsɛlvz tə ðə waɪz wʌnz, ən ðeɪ hæd lɝn ðət ði il wɪmən tʊk ðət vɛɹi sɪɹiəsli. wʌn snæp ə sɔɹɪliəz boʊni fɪŋɡɝz kəɾ ɛn ðɛɹ aɪɾəl mɔɹnɪŋ.

So Verin was having trouble sleeping, too. Cadsuane had not had a good night's rest since the boy fled the Sun Palace. If she did not find one soon, she thought she might bite someone. Nesune and the others were eyeing Sorilea uneasily. The boy had made them apprentice themselves to the Wise Ones, and they had learned that the Aiel women took that very seriously. One snap of Sorilea's bony fingers could end their idle morning.

hɑɹɪn lin fɔɹwɝɾ aʊɾ ə hɝ tʃɛɹ ən ɡeɪv kædzueɪnz tʃik ə ʃɑɹp tæp wɪð əɹ fɪŋɡɝz! "ju ɑɹ nɑt lɪsnɪŋ tə mi," ʃi sɛd hɑɹʃli. hɝ feɪs wɑz ə θʌndɝhɛd, ən ðəɾ ə hɝ seɪlməstʃɹəs skɛɹsli lɛs stɔɹmi. "ju wɪl lɪsən!"

Harine leaned forward out of her chair and gave Cadsuane's cheek a sharp tap with her fingers! "You are not listening to me," she said harshly. Her face was a thunderhead, and that of her Sailmistress scarcely less stormy. "You will listen!"

kædzueɪn pʊɾ əɹ hænz təɡɛðɝ ən ɹəɡɑɹɾəd ðə wʊmən oʊvɝ əɹ fɪŋɡɝtɪps. noʊ. ʃi wəd nɑt stæn ðə weɪvməstʃɹəs ɑn əɹ hɛd hɪɹ ən naʊ. ʃi wəd nɑt sɛn ðə wʊmən bæk tə hɝ əpɑɹtməns wipɪŋ. ʃi wəd bi əz dɪpləmæɾɪk əz kɔɪɹən kəd wɪʃ. heɪstəli ʃi skæn θɹu wʌt ʃi hæd hɝd. "ju spik fəɹ ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps tə ði æθɑn maɪɹ, wɪð ɔl ə hɝ əθɔɹəɾi, wɪtʃ ɪz mɔɹ ðən aɪ kən ɪmædʒən," ʃi sɛd maɪldli. "ɪf jəɹ wɪndfɪndɝ ɪz nɑt ɹɪtɝn tə jə wɪðɪn ði aʊɝ, jəl si ðət ðə kɔɹəmʊɹ pʌnɪʃəz mi səvɪɹli. jə ɹikwaɪɝ ən əpɑlədʒi fəɹ jəɹ wɪndfɪndɝz ɪmpɹɪzənmənt. ən jə ɹikwaɪɝ mi tə meɪk lɔɹd dɑbɹeɪn sɛɾ əsaɪd ðə læn pɹɑməs baɪ ðə kɔɹəmʊɹ ɪmiɾiətli. aɪ bɪliv ðət kʌvɝz ði ɪsɛnʃəl pɔɪns." ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə wʌn əbaʊt hævɪŋ əɹ flɑɡd!

Cadsuane put her hands together and regarded the woman over her fingertips. No. She would not stand the Wavemistress on her head here and now. She would not send the woman back to her apartments weeping. She would be as diplomatic as Coiren could wish. Hastily she scanned through what she had heard. "You speak for the Mistress of the Ships to the Atha'an Miere, with all of her authority, which is more than I can imagine," she said mildly. "If your Windfinder is not returned to you within the hour, you will see that the Coramoor punishes me severely. You require an apology for your Windfinder's imprisonment. And you require me to make Lord Dobraine set aside the land promised by the Coramoor immediately. I believe that covers the essential points." Except for the one about having her flogged!

"ɡʊd," hɑɹɪn sɛd, linɪŋ bæk kʌmfɝɾəbli, ɪn kəmænd naʊ. hɝ smaɪl wɑz sɪkənɪŋli sɛlf-sæɾəsfaɪd. "ju wɪl lɝn ðət - "

"Good," Harine said, leaning back comfortably, in command now. Her smile was sickeningly self-satisfied. "You will learn that - "

"ɪf jə ɛvɝ tʌtʃ mi əɡɛn wɪθaʊt pɝmɪʃən, əl əv jə stʃɹɪpt, stʃɹaɪpt, baʊn ən kæɹid bæk tə jəɹ ɹumz ɪn ə sæk." wɛl, dɪploʊməsi hæd nɛvɝ bɪn əɹ stʃɹɔŋɡəs pɔɪnt. "ɪf jə də nɑt sis pɛstɝɪŋ mi əbaʊt jəɹ sɪstɝ . . . wɛl, aɪ maɪɾ æktʃəli  ɡɹoʊ æŋɡɹi." stændɪŋ, ʃi ɪɡnɔɹd ðə si foʊk wʊmənz ɪndɪɡnən pʌfɪŋ ən ɡeɪpɪŋ ən ɹeɪzd əɹ vɔɪs tə bi hɝɾ ət ði ɛn ə ðə ɹum. "sɝin!"

"I do not care a fig for your Coramoor," Cadsuane continued, her voice still mild. All the figs in the world for the Dragon Reborn, but not one for the Coramoor. She did not alter her tone by a hair. "If you ever touch me again without permission, I will have you stripped, striped, bound and carried back to your rooms in a sack." Well, diplomacy had never been her strongest point. "If you do not cease pestering me about your sister . . . Well, I might actually grow angry." Standing, she ignored the Sea Folk woman's indignant puffing and gaping and raised her voice to be heard at the end of the room. "Sarene!"

ðə slɛndɝ tæɹɑbənɝ wɝl fɹəm əɹ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi, biɾɪd bɹeɪdz klɪkɪŋ, ən hɝid tə kædzueɪnz saɪd, bɛɹli hɛzəteɪɾɪŋ bɪfɔɹ spɹɛɾɪŋ əɹ dɑɹk ɡɹeɪ skɝts ɪn ə kɝtsi. ðə waɪz wʌnz hæd hæd tə titʃ əm tə lip wən ə waɪz wʌn spoʊk, bʌt mɔɹ ðən kʌstəm meɪɾ əm lip fəɹ hɝ. ðəɹ tʃɹuli wɝ ædvæntɪdʒɪz tə biɪŋ ə lɛdʒənd, ɪspɛʃli ən ʌnpɹɪdɪktəbəl lɛdʒənd.

The slender Taraboner whirled from her embroidery, beaded braids clicking, and hurried to Cadsuane's side, barely hesitating before spreading her dark gray skirts in a curtsy. The Wise Ones had had to teach them to leap when a Wise One spoke, but more than custom made them leap for her. There truly were advantages to being a legend, especially an unpredictable legend.

"ɛskɔɹt ðiz tu tə ðɛɹ ɹumz," kædzueɪn kəmændəd. "ðeɪ wɪʃ tə fæst ən mɛɾəteɪt ɑn səvɪləɾi. si ðət ðeɪ du. ən ɪf ðeɪ ɔfɝ wʌn ʌnsɪvəl wɝd, spæŋk əm boʊθ. bʌt bi dɪpləmæɾɪk əbaʊɾ ɪt."

"Escort these two to their rooms," Cadsuane commanded. "They wish to fast and meditate on civility. See that they do. And if they offer one uncivil word, spank them both. But be diplomatic about it."

sɝin ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt, hæf oʊpənɪŋ əɹ maʊθ əz ɪf tə pɹoʊtɛs ði ɪlɑdʒɪk ə ðæt, bʌt wʌn ɡlæns ət kædzueɪnz feɪs ən ʃi kwɪkli tɝn tə ði æθɑn maɪɹ wɪmən, dʒɛstʃɝɪŋ fəɹ əm tə ɹaɪz.

Sarene gave a start, half opening her mouth as if to protest the illogic of that, but one glance at Cadsuane's face and she quickly turned to the Atha'an Miere women, gesturing for them to rise.

hɑɹɪn spɹæŋ tə hɝ fit, hɝ dɑɹk feɪs hɑɹɾ ən skaʊlɪŋ. bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəɾ ʌɾɝ ə wɝɾ ə hɝ noʊ daʊt fjʊɹiəs taɪɹeɪd, ðoʊ, dɪɹə tʌtʃt əɹ ɑɹm ən lin kloʊs tə wɪspɝ ɪndə hɝ ɹɪŋ-hɛvi ɪɹ bɪhaɪn ə kʌp hæn kʌvɝd wɪð dɑɹk tætuz. wʌtɛvɝ ðə seɪlməstʃɹəs hæd tə seɪ, hɑɹɪn kloʊzd əɹ maʊð. hɝ ɪkspɹɛʃən sɝɾənli dɪd nɑt sɑfən, jɛt ʃi aɪd ðə sɪstɝz ət ðə fɑɹ ɛn ə ðə ɹum ən æftɝ ə moʊmən kɝtli moʊʃən sɝin tə lid ðə weɪ. hɑɹɪn maɪt pɹitɛn ðəɾ ɪt wɑz əɹ dɪsɪʒən tə liv, bʌt dɪɹə fɑloʊd soʊ kloʊs ɑn əɹ hilz ʃi əpɪɹd tə bi hɝɾɪŋ əɹ ən ʃɑɾ ən ənizi ɡlæns bæk oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ bɪfɔɹ ðə dɔɹ ʃʌɾ əɹ fɹəm saɪt.

Harine sprang to her feet, her dark face hard and scowling. Before she could utter a word of her no doubt furious tirade, though, Derah touched her arm and leaned close to whisper into her ring-heavy ear behind a cupped hand covered with dark tattoos. Whatever the Sailmistress had to say, Harine closed her mouth. Her expression certainly did not soften, yet she eyed the sisters at the far end of the room and after a moment curtly motioned Sarene to lead the way. Harine might pretend that it was her decision to leave, but Derah followed so close on her heels she appeared to be herding her and shot an uneasy glance back over her shoulder before the door shut her from sight.

kædzueɪn ɔlmoʊst ɹɪɡɹɛɾɪd ɡɪvɪŋ ðət fɹɪvələs ɔɹɾɝ. sɝin wəd də ɪɡzækli əz ʃi hæd bɪn toʊld. ðə si foʊk wɪmən wɝ ən ɪɹəɾənt, ən jusləs ðʌs fɑɹ, bɪsaɪdz. ði ɪɹɪteɪʃən mʌs bi ɹimuv soʊ ʃi kəd kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾ ɑn wʌt wɑz ɪmpɔɹɾənt, ən ɪf ʃi faʊn ə jus fəɹ ðɛm, tulz niɾəd tə bi ʃeɪpt wʌn weɪ əɹ ənʌðɝ. ʃi wɑz tu æŋɡɹi wɪð əm tə kɛɹ haʊ ðət wɑz dʌn, ən ɪt maɪɾ əz wɛl bɪɡɪn naʊ əz leɪɾɝ. noʊ, ʃi wɑz æŋɡɹi wɪð ðə bɔɪ, bʌt ʃi kəd nɑt leɪ hænz ɑn ɪm jɛt.

Cadsuane almost regretted giving that frivolous order. Sarene would do exactly as she had been told. The Sea Folk women were an irritant, and useless thus far, besides. The irritation must be removed so she could concentrate on what was important, and if she found a use for them, tools needed to be shaped one way or another. She was too angry with them to care how that was done, and it might as well begin now as later. No, she was angry with the boy, but she could not lay hands on him yet.

wɪð ə laʊd hæɹəmf, sɔɹɪliə tɝn fɹəm wɑtʃɪŋ sɝin ən ði æθɑn maɪɹ ɡoʊ ən dɝɛktəɾ əɹ skaʊl ət ðə sɪstɝz ɡæðɝɾ ət ði ɛn ə ðə soʊlɝ. bɹeɪslɪts klæɾɝd ɑn əɹ ɹɪsts əz ʃi ədʒʌstəɾ əɹ ʃɔl. ənʌðɝ wʊmən nɑɾ ɪn əɹ bɛs tɛmpɝ. ðə si foʊk hæd pəkjuljɝ noʊʃənz ʌv "il sævədʒəz" - ðoʊ ɪn tʃɹuθ nɑt ðət mʌtʃ stʃɹeɪnʒɝ ðən səm kædzueɪn hɝsɛlf hæd bɪliv bɪfɔɹ miɾɪŋ sɔɹɪliə - ən ðə waɪz wʌn dɪd nɑt laɪk əm ə hɛɹ.

With a loud harrumph, Sorilea turned from watching Sarene and the Atha'an Miere go and directed her scowl at the sisters gathered at the end of the solar. Bracelets clattered on her wrists as she adjusted her shawl. Another woman not in her best temper. The Sea Folk had peculiar notions of "Aiel savages" - though in truth not that much stranger than some Cadsuane herself had believed before meeting Sorilea - and the Wise One did not like them a hair.

kædzueɪn wɛn tə miɾ əɹ wɪð ə smaɪl. sɔɹɪliə wɑz nɑɾ ə wʊmən jə meɪd kʌm tə ju. ɛvɹiwʌn θɔt ðeɪ wɝ bɪkʌmɪŋ fɹɛnz - wɪtʃ ðeɪ maɪt jɛt, ʃi ɹilaɪzd ɪn sɝpɹaɪz - bʌt noʊ wʌn nu ʌv ðɛɹ əlaɪəns. ɛbən əpɪɹd wɪð ɪz tʃɹeɪ, ən əpɪɹd ɹɪlivd wən ʃi sɛɾ əɹ hæf-ɛmpti ɡɑbləɾ ɑn ɪt.

Cadsuane went to meet her with a smile. Sorilea was not a woman you made come to you. Everyone thought they were becoming friends - which they might yet, she realized in surprise - but no one knew of their alliance. Eben appeared with his tray, and appeared relieved when she set her half-empty goblet on it.

"leɪt læs naɪt," sɔɹɪliə sɛɾ əz ðə ɹɛd-koʊɾəd bɔɪ hɝid bæk tə deɪdʒiən, "tʃɪseɪn nɝbaɪə æsk tə sɝv ðə kɑɹəkɑɹn." dɪsəpɹuvəl leɪ hɛvi ɪn əɹ vɔɪs. "bɪfɔɹ fɝs laɪt, dʒənin pævlɑɹə æskt, ðən ɪninə dɛɹənhoʊld, ðən veɪɛl kæmsə. ðeɪ hæd nɑt bɪn əlaʊd tə spik tə wʌn ənʌðɝ. ðəɹ kəd bi noʊ kəluʒən. aɪ æksɛptɪd ðɛɹ pliz."

"Late last night," Sorilea said as the red-coated boy hurried back to Daigian, "Chisaine Nurbaya asked to serve the Car'a'carn." Disapproval lay heavy in her voice. "Before first light, Janine Pavlara asked, then Innina Darenhold, then Vayelle Kamsa. They had not been allowed to speak to one another. There could be no collusion. I accepted their pleas."

kædzueɪn meɪɾ ə vɛkst saʊnd. "aɪ səpoʊz jə ɔlɹɛɾi hæv əm sɝvɪŋ pɛnəns," ʃi mɝmɝd, θɪŋkɪŋ hɑɹd. naɪntin sɪstɝz hæd bɪn pɹɪznɝz ɪn ði il kæmp, naɪntin sɪstɝz sɛn baɪ ðət ful ɪleɪɾə tə kɪdnæp ðə bɔɪ, ən naʊ ðeɪ ɔl hæd swɔɹn tə fɑloʊ hɪm! ðiz læst wɝ ðə wɝst. "wʌt kəd meɪk ɹɛd sɪstɝz swɛɹ fiəlti tə ə mæn u kən tʃænəl?"

Cadsuane made a vexed sound. "I suppose you already have them serving penance," she murmured, thinking hard. Nineteen sisters had been prisoners in the Aiel camp, nineteen sisters sent by that fool Elaida to kidnap the boy, and now they all had sworn to follow him! These last were the worst. "What could make Red sisters swear fealty to a man who can channel?"

vɛɹɪn bɪɡæn tə meɪk ən ɑbzɝveɪʃən, bʌt fɛl saɪlən fəɹ ði il wʊmən. stʃɹeɪnʒli, vɛɹɪn hæd teɪkən tə hɝ oʊn ɛnfɔɹst əpɹɛntəsʃɪp laɪk ə hɛɹən tə ðə mɑɹʃ. ʃi spɛn mɔɹ taɪm ɪn ði il kæmp ðən aʊɾ ʌv ɪt.

Verin began to make an observation, but fell silent for the Aiel woman. Strangely, Verin had taken to her own enforced apprenticeship like a heron to the marsh. She spent more time in the Aiel camp than out of it.

"nɑt pɛnəns, kædzueɪn məleɪdʒɹɪn." sɔɹɪliə meɪɾ ə dɪsmɪsɪv dʒɛstʃɝ wɪð wʌn sɪnjui hæn ɪn ənʌðɝ ɹæɾəl ʌv ɡoʊld ən aɪvɝi bɹeɪslɪts. "ðeɪ ɑɹ ətɛmptɪŋ tə mit toʊ ðət kænɑt bi mɛt. əz fulɪʃ ɪn ɪts weɪ əz əɹ neɪmɪŋ əm dætsæŋ ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs, bʌt pɝhæps ðeɪ ɑɹ nɑt bɪɑn ɹɪdɛmpʃən ɪf ðeɪ ɑɹ wɪlɪŋ tə tʃɹaɪ," ʃi əlaʊd ɡɹʌdʒɪŋli. sɔɹɪliə mɔɹ ðən mɪɹli dɪslaɪk ðoʊz naɪntin sɪstɝz. ʃi ɡeɪv ə θɪn smaɪl. "ɪn ɛni ɪvɛnt, wɪl titʃ əm mʌtʃ ðeɪ nid tə lɝn." ðə wʊmən sim tə bɪliv ɔl ɛɛs sədaɪ kəd də wɪð taɪm əpɹɛntɪsɪŋ ʌndɝ ðə waɪz wʌnz.

"Not penance, Cadsuane Melaidhrin." Sorilea made a dismissive gesture with one sinewy hand in another rattle of gold and ivory bracelets. "They are attempting to meet toh that cannot be met. As foolish in its way as our naming them da'tsang in the first place, but perhaps they are not beyond redemption if they are willing to try," she allowed grudgingly. Sorilea more than merely disliked those nineteen sisters. She gave a thin smile. "In any event, we will teach them much they need to learn." The woman seemed to believe all Aes Sedai could do with time apprenticing under the Wise Ones.

"aɪ hoʊp jəl kəntɪnju tə wɑtʃ əm ɔl kloʊsli," kædzueɪn sɛd. "ɪspɛʃli ðiz læs fɔɹ." ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ ðeɪ wəd kip ðət ɹɪdɪkjələs oʊθ, ɪf nɑɾ ɔlweɪz ɪn weɪz ðə bɔɪ wəd laɪk, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz ɔlweɪz ðə pɑsəbɪləɾi ðət wʌn əɹ tu maɪt bi blæk ədʒɑ. wʌns ʃi hæd θɔt hɝsɛlf ɑn ðə pɔɪn ə ɹuɾɪŋ aʊt ðə blæk oʊnli tə wɑtʃ əɹ kwɔɹi slɪp θɹu hɝ fɪŋɡɝz laɪk smoʊk, hɝ bɪɾɝəst feɪljɝ ɪksɛpt pɑsəbli fəɹ feɪlɪŋ tə lɝn wʌt kæɹɑlin dəmədʒɹdz kʌzən hæd bɪn ʌp tə ɪn ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz əntɪl ðə nɑlədʒ wɑz jɪɹz tu leɪt tə də ɛni ɡʊd. naʊ, ivən ðə blæk ədʒɑ simd ə daɪvɝʒən fɹəm wʌt wɑz tʃɹuli ɪmpɔɹɾənt.

"I hope you will continue to watch them all closely," Cadsuane said. "Especially these last four." She was sure they would keep that ridiculous oath, if not always in ways the boy would like, but there was always the possibility that one or two might be Black Ajah. Once she had thought herself on the point of rooting out the Black only to watch her quarry slip through her fingers like smoke, her bitterest failure except possibly for failing to learn what Caraline Damodred's cousin had been up to in the Borderlands until the knowledge was years too late to do any good. Now, even the Black Ajah seemed a diversion from what was truly important.

"əpɹɛntəsɪz ɑɹ ɔlweɪz wɑtʃt kloʊsli," ðə wɛðɝd wʊmən ɹɪplaɪd. "aɪ θɪŋk aɪ mʌst ɹimaɪn ðiz ʌðɝz tə bi ɡɹeɪtfəl fəɹ biɪŋ əlaʊd tə lɑl əbaʊt laɪk klæn tʃifs."

"Apprentices are always watched closely," the weathered woman replied. "I think I must remind these others to be grateful for being allowed to loll about like clan chiefs."

ðə ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ fɔɹ sɪstɝz ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə faɪɝpleɪs ɹoʊz wɪð əlækɹəɾi əɾ əɹ əpɹoʊtʃ, meɪd dip kɝtsiz, ən lɪsən kɛɹfəli tə wʌt ʃi toʊld əm ɪn ə loʊ vɔɪs wɪð mʌtʃ fɪŋɡɝ ʃeɪkɪŋ. sɔɹɪliə maɪt θɪŋk ʃi hæd mʌtʃ tə titʃ ðɛm, bʌt ðeɪ hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi lɝn ðəɾ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ʃɔl ɔfɝd noʊ pɹətɛkʃən tə ə waɪz wʌnz əpɹɛntəs. toʊ simd ə ɡɹeɪt dil laɪk pɛnəns tə kædzueɪn.

The remaining four sisters in front of the fireplace rose with alacrity at her approach, made deep curtsies, and listened carefully to what she told them in a low voice with much finger shaking. Sorilea might think she had much to teach them, but they had already learned that an Aes Sedai shawl offered no protection to a Wise One's apprentice. Toh seemed a great deal like penance to Cadsuane.

"ʃi ɪz . . . fɔɹməɾəbəl," vɛɹɪn mɝmɝd. "aɪ æm vɛɹi ɡlæd ʃiz ɑn əɹ saɪd. ɪf ʃi ɪz."

"She is . . . formidable," Verin murmured. "I am very glad she is on our side. If she is."

kædzueɪn ɡeɪv əɹ ə ʃɑɹp lʊk. "ju hæv ði əpɪɹəns ʌv ə wʊmən wɪð sʌmθɪŋ tə seɪ ðət jə doʊnt wɑn tə. əbaʊt sɔɹɪliə?" ðəɾ əlaɪəns wɑz vɛɹi veɪɡli dɪfaɪnd. fɹɛndʃɪp əɹ noʊ fɹɛndʃɪp, ʃi ən ðə waɪz wʌn stɪl maɪt tɝn aʊt tə bi eɪmɪŋ ət dɪfɹənt ɡoʊlz.

Cadsuane gave her a sharp look. "You have the appearance of a woman with something to say that you don't want to. About Sorilea?" That alliance was very vaguely defined. Friendship or no friendship, she and the Wise One still might turn out to be aiming at different goals.

"nɑt ðæt," ðə staʊt lɪɾəl wʊmən saɪd. dɪspaɪɾ ə skwɛɹ feɪs, tɪltɪŋ əɹ hɛd tə wʌn saɪd meɪɾ əɹ lʊk laɪk ə vɛɹi plʌmp spɛɹoʊ. "aɪ noʊ ɪt wɑz nɑt maɪ bɪznəs, kædzueɪn, bʌt bɛɹə ən kaɪɹunə wɝ ɡɛɾɪŋ noʊwɛɹ wɪð əɹ ɡɛsts, soʊ aɪ hæɾ ə lɪɾəl tɔk əloʊn wɪð ʃələn. æftɝ ə lɪɾəl dʒɛntəl kwɛstʃənɪŋ, ʃi spɪld aʊt ðə hoʊl stɔɹi, ən eɪlɪl kənfɝmd ɛvɹiθɪŋ wʌns ʃi ɹilaɪzd aɪ ɔlɹɛɾi nu. sun æftɝ ðə si foʊk fɝst ɝaɪv hɪɹ, eɪlɪl əpɹoʊtʃt ʃələn hoʊpɪŋ tə lɝn wʌt ðeɪ wɑntəd wɪð jʌŋ ælθɹ. fəɹ əɹ pɑɹt, ʃələn wɑntəd tə lɝn wʌtɛvɝ ʃi kəɾ əbaʊt hɪm, ən əbaʊt ðə sɪtʃueɪʃən hɪɹ. ðət lɛd tə miɾɪŋz, wɪtʃ lɛd tə fɹɛndʃɪp, wɪtʃ lɛd tə ðɛm bɪkʌmɪŋ pɪloʊ fɹɛnz. əz mʌtʃ fɹəm loʊnlinəs əz ɛniθɪŋ ɛls, aɪ səspɛkt. ɪn ɛni keɪs, ðət wɑz wʌt ðeɪ wɝ haɪɾɪŋ mɔɹ ðən ðɛɹ mjutʃəwəl snupɪŋ."

"Not that," the stout little woman sighed. Despite a square face, tilting her head to one side made her look like a very plump sparrow. "I know it was not my business, Cadsuane, but Bera and Kiruna were getting nowhere with our guests, so I had a little talk alone with Shalon. After a little gentle questioning, she spilled out the whole story, and Ailil confirmed everything once she realized I already knew. Soon after the Sea Folk first arrived here, Ailil approached Shalon hoping to learn what they wanted with young al'Thor. For her part, Shalon wanted to learn whatever she could about him, and about the situation here. That led to meetings, which led to friendship, which led to them becoming pillow friends. As much from loneliness as anything else, I suspect. In any case, that was what they were hiding more than their mutual snooping."

"ðeɪ pʊɾ ʌp wɪð deɪz ʌndɝ ðə kwɛstʃən tə haɪd ðæt?" kædzueɪn sɛɾ ɪnkɹɛdʒjələsli. bɛɹə ən kaɪɹunə hæd hæd ðə pɛɹ haʊlɪŋ!

"They put up with days under the question to hide that?" Cadsuane said incredulously. Bera and Kiruna had had the pair howling!

vɛɹɪnz aɪz twɪŋkəld wɪð səpɹɛs mɝθ. "kɛɹhinɪn ɑɹ pɹɪm ən pɹuɾɪʃ, kædzueɪn, ɪn pʌblɪk ət list. ðeɪ maɪt kæɹi ɑn laɪk ɹæbəts wən ðə kɝɾənz ɑɹ dʒɹɔn, bʌt ðeɪ wʊdn ədmɪt tə tʌtʃɪŋ ðɛɹ oʊn hʌzbənz ɪf ɛniwʌn maɪɾ oʊvɝhɪɹ! ən ðə si foʊk ɑɹ ɔlmoʊst əz stʃɹeɪtleɪsd. ət list, ʃələn ɪz mɛɹid tə ə mæn wɪð duɾiz ɛlswɛɹ, ən bɹeɪkɪŋ mɛɹɪdʒ vaʊz ɪz ə vɛɹi sɪɹiəs kɹaɪm. ə bɹitʃ ə pɹɑpɝ dɪsəplən, ɪt simz. ɪf əɹ sɪstɝ faʊn aʊt, ʃələn wəd bi - 'wɪndfɪndɝ ɑn ə ɹoʊboʊt,' aɪ θɪŋk əɹ ɪɡzækt wɝdz wɝ."

Verin's eyes twinkled with suppressed mirth. "Cairhienin are prim and prudish, Cadsuane, in public at least. They might carry on like rabbits when the curtains are drawn, but they wouldn't admit to touching their own husbands if anyone might overhear! And the Sea Folk are almost as straitlaced. At least, Shalon is married to a man with duties elsewhere, and breaking marriage vows is a very serious crime. A breach of proper discipline, it seems. If her sister found out, Shalon would be - 'Windfinder on a rowboat,' I think her exact words were."

kædzueɪn wɑz əwɛɹ ə hɝ hɛɹ ɔɹnəməns sweɪɪŋ əz ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. wən ðə tu wɪmən hæd bɪn dɪskʌvɝd ɹaɪɾ æftɝ ði ətæk ɑn ðə pæləs, baʊn ən ɡæɡd ən stʌft ʌndɝ eɪlɪlz bɛd, ʃi hæd səspɛktəd ðeɪ nu mɔɹ ə ði ətæk ðən ðeɪ wɝ ædmɪɾɪŋ. wʌns ðeɪ ɹəfjuz tə seɪ waɪ ðeɪ hæd bɪn miɾɪŋ ɪn sikɹət, ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ. pɝhæps ivən ðət ðeɪ wɝ ɪnvɑlvd ɪn səm weɪ, ðoʊ ði ətæk əpɛɹənli wɑz ðə wɝk ə ɹɛnəɡeɪɾ æʃəmən. səpoʊzədli ɹɛnəɡeɪd, ət list. ɔl ðət taɪm ən ɛfɝt weɪstəɾ ɑn nʌθɪŋ. əɹ pɝhæps nɑt kwaɪt nʌθɪŋ, ɪf ðeɪ wɝ soʊ dɛspɹɪt tə kip θɪŋz hɪɾən.

Cadsuane was aware of her hair ornaments swaying as she shook her head. When the two women had been discovered right after the attack on the Palace, bound and gagged and stuffed under Ailil's bed, she had suspected they knew more of the attack than they were admitting. Once they refused to say why they had been meeting in secret, she was sure. Perhaps even that they were involved in some way, though the attack apparently was the work of renegade Asha'man. Supposedly renegade, at least. All that time and effort wasted on nothing. Or perhaps not quite nothing, if they were so desperate to keep things hidden.

"ɹɪtɝn ðə leɪɾi eɪlɪl tə hɝ əpɑɹtməns wɪð əpɑlədʒiz fəɹ əɹ tʃɹitmənt, vɛɹɪn. ɡɪv əɹ vɛɹi . . . tɛnjəwəs . . . əʃʊɹənsɪz ðəɾ əɹ kɑnfəɾənsɪz wɪl bi kɛpt. bi ʃʊɹ ʃiz əwɛɹ dʒʌs haʊ tɛnjəwəs. ən sədʒɛst stʃɹɔŋli ðət ʃi maɪt wɪʃ tə kip mi əbɹɛst ʌv ɛniθɪŋ ʃi hɪɹz kənsɝnɪŋ əɹ bɹʌðɝ." blækmeɪl wɑz ə tul ʃi dɪslaɪk juzɪŋ, bʌt ʃi hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi juzd ɪɾ ɑn ðə θɹi æʃəmən, ən tɔɹæm ɹieɪɾən maɪt stɪl kɑz tʃɹʌbəl ivən ɪf ɪz ɹɪbɛljən dɪd sim tə hæv ɪvæpɝeɪɾəd. ɪn tʃɹuθ, ʃi kɛɹd lɪɾəl u sæɾ ɑn ðə sʌn θɹoʊn, jɛt ðə plɑts ən skimz ə ðoʊz u kənsɪɾɝd θɹoʊnz ɪmpɔɹɾənt ɔfən hæɾ ə weɪ ʌv ɪntɝfɪɹɪŋ wɪð mɔɹ səɡnɪfɪkən mæɾɝz.

"Return the Lady Ailil to her apartments with apologies for her treatment, Verin. Give her very . . . tenuous . . . assurances that her confidences will be kept. Be sure she is aware just how tenuous. And suggest strongly that she might wish to keep me abreast of anything she hears concerning her brother." Blackmail was a tool she disliked using, but she had already used it on the three Asha'man, and Toram Riatin might still cause trouble even if his rebellion did seem to have evaporated. In truth, she cared little who sat on the Sun Throne, yet the plots and schemes of those who considered thrones important often had a way of interfering with more significant matters.

vɛɹɪn smaɪld, hɝ bʌn bɑbɪŋ əz ʃi nɑɾəd. "oʊ, jɛs, aɪ θɪŋk ðət wɪl wɝk vɛɹi naɪsli. ɪspɛʃli sɪns ʃi dɪslaɪks əɹ bɹʌðɝ ɪntɛnsli. ðə seɪm fəɹ ʃələn, aɪ səpoʊz? ɪksɛp ðət jəl wɑnə hɪɹ ʌv ɪvɛns əmʌŋ ði æθɑn maɪɹ? aɪm nɑt sɝɾən haʊ fɑɹ ʃɪl bɪtʃɹeɪ hɑɹɪn, noʊ mæɾɝ ðə kɑnsəkwɛnsəz tə hɝsɛlf."

Verin smiled, her bun bobbing as she nodded. "Oh, yes, I think that will work very nicely. Especially since she dislikes her brother intensely. The same for Shalon, I suppose? Except that you will want to hear of events among the Atha'an Miere? I'm not certain how far she will betray Harine, no matter the consequences to herself."

"ʃi wɪl bɪtʃɹeɪ wʌɾ aɪ ɹikwaɪɝ əɹ tə bɪtʃɹeɪ," kædzueɪn sɛd ɡɹɪmli. "kip əɹ əntɪl təmɑɹoʊ, leɪt." hɑɹɪn mʌs nɑt bi əlaʊd tə θɪŋk fəɹ ə moʊmən ðəɾ əɹ dɪmænz wɝ biɪŋ mɛt. ðə si foʊk wɝ ənʌðɝ tul tə bi juzd ɑn ðə bɔɪ, noʊ mɔɹ. ɛvɹiwʌn ən ɛvɹiθɪŋ hæd tə bi vjuɾ ɪn ðət laɪt.

"She will betray what I require her to betray," Cadsuane said grimly. "Keep her until tomorrow, late." Harine must not be allowed to think for a moment that her demands were being met. The Sea Folk were another tool to be used on the boy, no more. Everyone and everything had to be viewed in that light.

bɪɑn vɛɹɪn, kɔɹəl slɪpt ɪndə ðə sʌnɹum ən ʃʌt ðə dɔɹ kɛɹfəli bɪhaɪn əɹ əz ɪf hoʊpɪŋ nɑt tə dɪstɝb ɛniwʌn. ðət wɑz nɑɾ əɹ weɪ. bɔɪɪʃli slɪm, wɪð θɪk blæk aɪbɹaʊz ən ə mæs ʌv ɡlɔsi blæk hɛɹ floʊɪŋ daʊn əɹ bæk ðət ɡeɪv əɹ ə waɪld əpɪɹəns noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ niɾ əɹ kloʊðz wɝ, ðə jɛloʊ wɑz mʌtʃ mɔɹ laɪkli tə swip ɪndə ə ɹum læfɪŋ. ɹʌbɪŋ ði ɛn ə hɝ ʌptɝnd noʊz, ʃi lʊkt ət kædzueɪn hɛzɪɾəntli, wɪð nʌn ə ðə juʒəwəl spɑɹkəl ɪn əɹ blu aɪz.

Beyond Verin, Corele slipped into the sunroom and shut the door carefully behind her as if hoping not to disturb anyone. That was not her way. Boyishly slim, with thick black eyebrows and a mass of glossy black hair flowing down her back that gave her a wild appearance no matter how neat her clothes were, the Yellow was much more likely to sweep into a room laughing. Rubbing the end of her upturned nose, she looked at Cadsuane hesitantly, with none of the usual sparkle in her blue eyes.

kædzueɪn meɪɾ ə pɝɛmptɝi dʒɛstʃɝ ət hɝ, ən kɔɹəl dʒɹu ə bɹɛθ ən ɡlaɪɾɪd əkɹɔs ðə kɑɹpəts ɡɹɪpɪŋ əɹ jɛloʊ-slæʃt blu skɝts wɪð boʊθ hænz. aɪɪŋ ðə sɪstɝz klʌstɝɾ ɝaʊn sɔɹɪliə ət ðə fɑɹ ɛn ə ðə ɹum, ən deɪdʒiən pleɪɪŋ kæts kɹeɪɾəl wɪð ɛbən ət ði ʌðɝ ɛnd, ʃi spoʊk ɪn ə sɑf vɔɪs ðət kæɹid ðə lɪltɪŋ æksɛns ə mʊɹændi.

Cadsuane made a peremptory gesture at her, and Corele drew a breath and glided across the carpets gripping her yellow-slashed blue skirts with both hands. Eyeing the sisters clustered around Sorilea at the far end of the room, and Daigian playing cat's cradle with Eben at the other end, she spoke in a soft voice that carried the lilting accents of Murandy.

"aɪ hæv ðə moʊst wʌndɝfəl nuz, kædzueɪn." baɪ ðə saʊn ə hɝ, ʃi wɑz nɑɾ ɔl sɝɾən haʊ wʌndɝfəl ɪt wɑz. "aɪ noʊ jə sɛɾ aɪ ʃəd kip deɪmɝ bɪzi hɪɹ ɪn ðə pæləs, bʌɾ i ɪnsɪstəɾ ɑn lʊkɪŋ ət ðə sɪstɝz stɪl ɪn ði il kæmp. maɪld-tɛmpɝɾ əz i ɪz, hiz vɛɹi ɪnsɪstənt wən i wɑns tə bi, ən ʃʊɹ əz ðə sʌn ðɛɹz nʌθɪŋ kæn bi hild. ænd, wɛl, ðə fækt ʌv ɪɾ ɪz, hiz ɡɔn ən hild ɝɡən. kædzueɪn, ɪts əz ɪf ʃid nɛvɝ bɪn . . ." ʃi tʃɹeɪld ɔf, əneɪbəl tə seɪ ðə wɝd. ɪt hʌŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ ivən soʊ. stɪld.

"I have the most wonderful news, Cadsuane." By the sound of her, she was not all certain how wonderful it was. "I know you said I should keep Damer busy here in the Palace, but he insisted on looking at the sisters still in the Aiel camp. Mild-tempered as he is, he's very insistent when he wants to be, and sure as the sun there's nothing can't be Healed. And, well, the fact of it is, he's gone and Healed Irgain. Cadsuane, it's as if she'd never been . . ." She trailed off, unable to say the word. It hung in the air even so. Stilled.

"wʌndɝfəl nuz," kædzueɪn sɛd flætli. ɪt wɑz. ɛvɹi sɪstɝ kæɹid ðə fɪɹ sʌmwɛɹ dip ɪnsaɪd ðət ʃi maɪt bi kʌɾ ɔf fɹəm ðə paʊɝ. ən naʊ ə weɪ tə hil wʌt kəd nɑt bi hil hæd bɪn dɪskʌvɝd. baɪ ə mæn. ðəɹ wəd bi tɛɹz ən ɹɪkɹɪmɪneɪʃənz bɪfɔɹ ðɪs wɑz dʌn wɪð. ɪn ɛni keɪs, waɪl ɛvɹi sɪstɝ u hɝd wəd kənsɪɾɝ ɪɾ ə wɝld-ʃeɪkɪŋ dɪskʌvɝi - ɪn mɔɹ weɪz ðən wʌn; ə mæn! - ɪt wɑz ə stɔɹm ɪn ə tikʌp kəmpɛɹd tə ɹænd ælθɹ. "aɪ səpoʊz ʃiz ɔfɝɪŋ hɝsɛlf ʌp tə bi biɾən laɪk ði ʌðɝz?"

"Wonderful news," Cadsuane said flatly. It was. Every sister carried the fear somewhere deep inside that she might be cut off from the Power. And now a way to Heal what could not be Healed had been discovered. By a man. There would be tears and recriminations before this was done with. In any case, while every sister who heard would consider it a world-shaking discovery - in more ways than one; a man! - it was a storm in a teacup compared to Rand al'Thor. "I suppose she is offering herself up to be beaten like the others?"

"ʃi woʊnt nid tə," vɛɹɪn sɛɾ æbsənli. ʃi wɑz fɹaʊnɪŋ əɾ ən ɪŋksteɪn ɑn əɹ fɪŋɡɝ, bʌt ʃi sim tə bi stʌɾiɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ bɪɑnd. "ðə waɪz wʌnz əpɛɹənli dɪsaɪɾɪd ðət ɹænd hæd pʌnɪʃt ɝɡən ən ði ʌðɝ tu səfɪʃənli wən i . . . dɪd wʌɾ i dɪd. ət ðə seɪm taɪm ðeɪ wɝ tʃɹiɾɪŋ ði ʌðɝz laɪk wɝθləs ænəməlz, ðeɪv bɪn wɝkɪŋ tə kip ðoʊz θɹi əlaɪv. aɪ hɝd tɔk əbaʊt faɪndɪŋ ɹɑneɪl ə hʌzbənd."

"She won't need to," Verin said absently. She was frowning at an inkstain on her finger, but she seemed to be studying something beyond. "The Wise Ones apparently decided that Rand had punished Irgain and the other two sufficiently when he . . . did what he did. At the same time they were treating the others like worthless animals, they have been working to keep those three alive. I heard talk about finding Ronaille a husband."

"ɝɡən noʊz ɔl əbaʊt ði oʊðz ði ʌðɝz swɔɹ." kɔɹəlz vɔɪs tʊk ɑn toʊnz ʌv əmeɪzmənt. "ʃi stɑɹɾəd wipɪŋ fəɹ ðə lɔs ə hɝ wɔɹɾɝz ɔlmoʊst əz sun əz deɪmɝ fɪnɪʃt wɪð hɝ, bʌt ʃiz ɹɛɾi tə swɛɹ, tu. ðə θɪŋ ʌv ɪɾ ɪz, deɪmɝ wɑns tə tʃɹaɪ wɪð sæʃəl ən ɹɑneɪl, tu." sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli, ʃi dʒɹu hɝsɛlf ʌp ɔlmoʊs dɪfaɪənli. ʃi hæɾ ɔlweɪz bɪn əz ɛɹəɡən əz ɛni ʌðɝ jɛloʊ, bʌt ʃi hæɾ ɔlweɪz noʊn wɛɹ ʃi stʊd wɪð kædzueɪn. "aɪ kæn si lɛɾɪŋ ə sɪstɝ ɹɪmeɪn ɪn ðət kəndɪʃən ɪf ðɛɹz ə weɪ aʊt, kædzueɪn. aɪ wɑnə lɛt deɪmɝ tʃɹaɪ hɪz hænd wɪð ðɛm."

"Irgain knows all about the oaths the others swore." Corele's voice took on tones of amazement. "She started weeping for the loss of her Warders almost as soon as Damer finished with her, but she's ready to swear, too. The thing of it is, Damer wants to try with Sashalle and Ronaille, too." Surprisingly, she drew herself up almost defiantly. She had always been as arrogant as any other Yellow, but she had always known where she stood with Cadsuane. "I can't see letting a sister remain in that condition if there's a way out, Cadsuane. I want to let Damer try his hand with them."

"ʌv kɔɹs, kɔɹəl." ɪt sim səm ə deɪmɝz ɪnsɪstəns wɑz ɹʌbɪŋ ɔf ɑn hɝ. kædzueɪn wɑz wɪlɪŋ tə lɛt ðət ɡoʊ, soʊ lɔŋ əz ɪt dɪd nɑt ɡoʊ tu fɑɹ. ʃi hæd bɪɡʌn ɡæðɝɪŋ sɪstɝz ʃi tʃɹʌstɪd, ðoʊz hɪɹ wɪð əɹ ən ʌðɝz, ðə deɪ ʃi fɝs hɝɾ ə stʃɹeɪnʒ ɪvɛns ɪn ʃaɪnɝ - hɝ aɪz ən ɪɹz hæd kɛpt wɑtʃ ɑn sɪuən sɑntʃ ən mɔɪɹeɪn dəmədʒɹd fəɹ jɪɹz wɪθaʊt lɝnɪŋ ɛniθɪŋ jusfəl əntɪl ðən - jɛt dʒʌs kəz ʃi tʃɹʌstɪɾ əm dɪd nɑt min ʃi ɪntɛndəd tə lɛɾ əm stɑɹt ɡoʊɪŋ ðɛɹ oʊn weɪ. tu mʌtʃ leɪ ət steɪk. bʌɾ ɪn ɛni keɪs, ʃi kəd nɑt liv ə sɪstɝ laɪk ðæt, iðɝ.

"Of course, Corele." It seemed some of Damer's insistence was rubbing off on her. Cadsuane was willing to let that go, so long as it did not go too far. She had begun gathering sisters she trusted, those here with her and others, the day she first heard of strange events in Shienar - her eyes and ears had kept watch on Siuan Sanche and Moiraine Damodred for years without learning anything useful until then - yet just because she trusted them did not mean she intended to let them start going their own way. Too much lay at stake. But in any case, she could not leave a sister like that, either.

ðə dɔɹ bæŋd oʊpən tə ədmɪt dʒɑhɹ əɾ ə ɹʌn, ðə sɪlvɝ bɛlz ɑn ði ɛnz ə hɪz dɑɹk bɹeɪdz dʒæŋɡəlɪŋ. hɛdz tɝn tə lʊk ət ðə juθ ɪn ðə wɛl-fɪɾəd blu koʊt mɛɹaɪs hæd tʃoʊzən fəɹ ɪm - ivən sɔɹɪliə ən sɝin stɛɹd - bʌt ðə wɝdz ðət keɪm aʊɾ ə hɪm ɪn ə ɹʌʃ dʒɹoʊv əweɪ θɔts ə haʊ pɹɪɾi hɪz sʌn-dɑɹk feɪs wɑz.

The door banged open to admit Jahar at a run, the silver bells on the ends of his dark braids jangling. Heads turned to look at the youth in the well-fitted blue coat Merise had chosen for him - even Sorilea and Sarene stared - but the words that came out of him in a rush drove away thoughts of how pretty his sun-dark face was.

"ɑlɑnəz ʌnkɑnʃəs, kædzueɪn. ʃi dʒʌs kəlæpst ɪn ðə hɔlweɪ. mɛɹaɪs hæɾ əɹ teɪkən tə ə bɛdtʃeɪmbɝ ən sɛn mi fəɹ ju."

"Alanna's unconscious, Cadsuane. She just collapsed in the hallway. Merise had her taken to a bedchamber and sent me for you."

ɹaɪɾɪŋ oʊvɝ ɛkskləmeɪʃənz ə ʃɑk, kædzueɪn ɡæðɝd kɔɹəl ən sɔɹɪliə - hu kəd nɑt bi lɛf bɪhaɪn ɪn ðɪs - ən ɔɹɾɝd dʒɑhɹ tə lid ðə weɪ. vɛɹɪn keɪm əz wɛl, ən kædzueɪn dɪd nɑt stɑp hɝ. vɛɹɪn hæɾ ə weɪ ʌv noʊɾɪsɪŋ wʌɾ ʌðɝz mɪst.

Riding over exclamations of shock, Cadsuane gathered Corele and Sorilea - who could not be left behind in this - and ordered Jahar to lead the way. Verin came as well, and Cadsuane did not stop her. Verin had a way of noticing what others missed.

ðə blæk-lɪvɹid sɝvəns hæd noʊ aɪdiə hu əɹ wʌt dʒɑhɹ wɑz, bʌt ðeɪ stɛp laɪvli tə ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ə kædzueɪnz weɪ əz ʃi wɔkt kwɪkli əlɔŋ bɪhaɪn hɪm. ʃi wʊɾə toʊld ɪm tə bi kwɪkɝ əbaʊɾ ɪt, bʌɾ ɛni fæstɝ, ən ʃi wʊɾə hæd tə ɹʌn. bɪfɔɹ ʃi hæd ɡɔn vɛɹi fɑɹ, ə ʃɔɹt mæn wɪð ðə fɹʌn ə hɪz hɛd ʃeɪvd, ɪn ə dɑɹk koʊt wɪð hɔɹəzɑntəl stʃɹaɪps ə kʌlɝ daʊn ðə fɹʌnt, stɛpt ɪndə hɝ pæθ ən baʊd. ʃi hæd tə stɑp fəɹ hɪm.

The black-liveried servants had no idea who or what Jahar was, but they stepped lively to get out of Cadsuane's way as she walked quickly along behind him. She would have told him to be quicker about it, but any faster, and she would have had to run. Before she had gone very far, a short man with the front of his head shaved, in a dark coat with horizontal stripes of color down the front, stepped into her path and bowed. She had to stop for him.

"ɡɹeɪs feɪvɝ ju, kædzueɪn sədaɪ," hi sɛd smuðli, "fɝɡɪv mi fəɹ bɑðɝɪŋ jə wən jə ɑɹ ɪn sətʃ ə hɝi, bʌɾ aɪ θɔɾ aɪ ʃəd tɛl jə ðət ðə leɪɾi kæɹɑlin ən ðə haɪ lɔɹd dɑɹlɪn ɑɹ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ɪn ðə leɪɾi ɑɹɪlɪnz pæləs. ðeɪ ɑɹ ɑn ə ɹɪvɝʃɪp baʊn fəɹ tɛɹ. bɪɑn jəɹ ɹitʃ baɪ ðɪs taɪm, aɪ fɪɹ."

"Grace favor you, Cadsuane Sedai," he said smoothly, "Forgive me for bothering you when you are in such a hurry, but I thought I should tell you that the Lady Caraline and the High Lord Darlin are no longer in the Lady Arilyn's palace. They are on a rivership bound for Tear. Beyond your reach by this time, I fear."

"ju maɪt bi sɝpɹaɪzd wʌɾ ɪz wɪðɪn maɪ ɹitʃ, lɔɹd dɑbɹeɪn," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn ə koʊl vɔɪs. ʃi ʃʊɾə lɛft ət list wʌn sɪstɝ əɾ ɑɹɪlɪnz pæləs, bʌt ʃi hæd bɪn sɝɾən ðə pɛɹ wɑz sɪkjʊɹ. "wɑz ðɪs waɪz?" ʃi hæd noʊ daʊɾ ɪt wɑz ɪz wɝk, ðoʊ ʃi daʊɾɪd i hæd ðə nɝv tə ədmɪɾ ɪt. noʊ wʌndɝ i hæd nɑt pɹɛst əɹ oʊvɝ ðɛm.

"You might be surprised what is within my reach, Lord Dobraine," she said in a cold voice. She should have left at least one sister at Arilyn's palace, but she had been certain the pair was secure. "Was this wise?" She had no doubt it was his work, though she doubted he had the nerve to admit it. No wonder he had not pressed her over them.

hɝ toʊn meɪd noʊ ɪmpɹɛʃən ɑn ðə fɛloʊ. ən i sɝpɹaɪz hɝ. "ðə haɪ lɔɹd dɑɹlɪn ɪz tə bi ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡənz stuɝɾ ə tiɹ, ən ɪt dɪd sim waɪz tə sɛn ðə leɪɾi kæɹɑlin aʊɾ ə ðə kʌntʃɹi. ʃiz fɔɹ-swɔɹn əɹ ɹɪbɛljən ən əɹ kleɪmz tə ðə sʌn θɹoʊn, bʌɾ ʌðɝz stɪl maɪt tʃɹaɪ tə juz hɝ. pɝhæps, kædzueɪn sədaɪ, ɪt wɑz ənwaɪz tə liv əm ɪn ðə tʃɑɹdʒ ə sɝvəns. ʌndɝ ðə laɪt, jə mʌs nɑt hoʊld əm ət fɔlt. ðeɪ wɝ eɪbəl tə hoʊl tu . . . ɡɛsts . . . bʌt nɑt tə stæn ʌp tə maɪ ɑɹmmɪn."

Her tone made no impression on the fellow. And he surprised her. "The High Lord Darlin is to be the Lord Dragon's Steward of Tear, and it did seem wise to send the Lady Caraline out of the country. She has fore-sworn her rebellion and her claims to the Sun Throne, but others still might try to use her. Perhaps, Cadsuane Sedai, it was unwise to leave them in the charge of servants. Under the Light, you must not hold them at fault. They were able to hold two . . . guests . . . but not to stand up to my armsmen."

dʒɑhɹ wɑz ɔl bʌt dænsɪŋ wɪð æŋzaɪəɾi tə ɡoʊ ɑn. mɛɹaɪs hæɾ ə fɝm hænd. kædzueɪn hɝsɛlf wɑz æŋkʃəs tə ɹitʃ ɑlɑnə.

Jahar was all but dancing with anxiety to go on. Merise had a firm hand. Cadsuane herself was anxious to reach Alanna.

"aɪ hoʊp juv ðə seɪm əpɪnjən ɪn ə jɪɹ," ʃi sɛd. dɑbɹeɪn mɪɹli baʊd.

"I hope you have the same opinion in a year," she said. Dobraine merely bowed.

ðə bɛdtʃeɪmbɝ wɛɹ ɑlɑnə hæd bɪn teɪkən wɑz ðə nɪɹəs ðət hæd bɪn əveɪləbəl, ən ɪt wɑz nɑt lɑɹdʒ, əpɪɹɪŋ smɔlɝ fəɹ ðə dɑɹk pænəlɪŋ ðət kɛɹhinɪn laɪk soʊ mʌtʃ. ɪt sim kwaɪt kɹaʊɾəd wʌns ɛvɹiwʌn wɑz ɪnsaɪd. mɛɹaɪs snæpt əɹ fɪŋɡɝz ən pɔɪntəd, ən dʒɑhɹ ɹitʃɹiɾəd tə ə kɔɹnɝ, bʌt ðət hɛlp lɪɾəl.

The bedchamber where Alanna had been taken was the nearest that had been available, and it was not large, appearing smaller for the dark paneling that Cairhienin liked so much. It seemed quite crowded once everyone was inside. Merise snapped her fingers and pointed, and Jahar retreated to a corner, but that helped little.

ɑlɑnə wɑz laɪɪŋ ɑn ðə bɛd, hɝ aɪz kloʊzd, wɪð əɹ wɔɹɾɝ, ɪvɑn, nilɪŋ bɪsaɪɾ ɪt tʃeɪfɪŋ əɹ ɹɪst. "ʃi simz əfɹeɪd tə weɪk," ðə tɔl, slɛndɝ mæn sɛd. "ðɛɹz nʌθɪŋ ɹɔŋ wɪð əɹ ðəɾ aɪ kən tɛl, bʌt ʃi simz əfɹeɪd."

Alanna was lying on the bed, her eyes closed, with her Warder, Ihvon, kneeling beside it chafing her wrist. "She seems afraid to wake," the tall, slender man said. "There's nothing wrong with her that I can tell, but she seems afraid."

kɔɹəl bɹʌʃt ɪm əsaɪd soʊ ʃi kəd kʌp ɑlɑnəz feɪs ɪn əɹ hænz. ðə ɡloʊ ʌv seɪaɪdɑɹ sɝaʊndəd ðə jɛloʊ, ən ðə wiv ə hilɪŋ sɛɾəld ɑn ɑlɑnə, bʌt ðə slɪm ɡɹin dɪd nɑɾ ivən twɪtʃ. kɔɹəl dʒɹu bæk, ʃeɪkɪŋ əɹ hɛd.

Corele brushed him aside so she could cup Alanna's face in her hands. The glow of saidar surrounded the Yellow, and the weave of Healing settled on Alanna, but the slim Green did not even twitch. Corele drew back, shaking her head.

"maɪ skɪl wɪð hilɪŋ, ɪt meɪ nɑɾ ikwəl jʊɹz, kɔɹəl," mɛɹaɪs sɛd dʒɹaɪli, "bʌɾ aɪ dɪd tʃɹaɪ." ði æksɛns ə tæɹɑbən wɝ stɪl stʃɹɔŋ ɪn əɹ vɔɪs æftɝ ɔl ðiz jɪɹz, bʌt ʃi wɔɹ əɹ dɑɹk hɛɹ dʒɹɔn bæk səvɪɹli fɹəm əɹ stɝn feɪs. kædzueɪn tʃɹʌstɪɾ əɹ pɝhæps mɔɹ ðən ɛni ʌv ði ʌðɝz. "wʌt də wi də naʊ, kædzueɪn?"

"My skill with Healing, it may not equal yours, Corele," Merise said dryly, "but I did try." The accents of Tarabon were still strong in her voice after all these years, but she wore her dark hair drawn back severely from her stern face. Cadsuane trusted her perhaps more than any of the others. "What do we do now, Cadsuane?"

sɔɹɪliə stɛɹɾ ət ðə wʊmən stʃɹɛtʃt aʊɾ ɑn ðə bɛd wɪð noʊ ɪkspɹɛʃən bɪɑn ə θɪnɪŋ ə hɝ lɪps. kædzueɪn wʌndɝd wɛðɝ ʃi wɑz ɹiɪvæljueɪɾɪŋ ðɛɹ əlaɪəns. vɛɹɪn wɑz stɛɹɪŋ əɾ ɑlɑnə, tu, ən ʃi lʊkt æbsəlutli tɛɹəfaɪd. kædzueɪn hæd nɑt θɔɾ ɛniθɪŋ kəd fɹaɪɾən vɛɹɪn ðət fɑɹ. bʌt ʃi fɛlt ə θɹɪl ə tɛɹɝ hɝsɛlf. ɪf ʃi lɔs ðɪs kənɛkʃən tə ðə bɔɪ naʊ . . .

Sorilea stared at the woman stretched out on the bed with no expression beyond a thinning of her lips. Cadsuane wondered whether she was reevaluating their alliance. Verin was staring at Alanna, too, and she looked absolutely terrified. Cadsuane had not thought anything could frighten Verin that far. But she felt a thrill of terror herself. If she lost this connection to the boy now . . .

"wi sɪt daʊn ən weɪt fəɹ əɹ tə weɪk," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn ə kɑm vɔɪs. ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ ɛls tə du. nʌθɪŋ.

"We sit down and wait for her to wake," she said in a calm voice. There was nothing else to do. Nothing.

"wɛɹ ɪz hi?" dɪmɑndɝd ɡɹaʊld, klɛntʃɪŋ ɪz fɪsts bɪhaɪn ɪz bæk. stændɪŋ wɪð ɪz fiɾ əpɑɹt, hi wɑz əwɛɹ ðəɾ i dɑməneɪɾəd ðə ɹum. hi ɔlweɪz dɪd. ivən soʊ, hi wɪʃt sɛmɝhɪdʒ əɹ mɛsænə wɝ pɹɛzənt. ðɛɹ əlaɪəns wɑz dɛləkət - ə sɪmpəl əɡɹimən ðət ðeɪ wəd nɑt tɝn ɑn wʌn ənʌðɝ əntɪl ði ʌðɝz hæd bɪn ɪlɪməneɪɾəd - jɛɾ ɪt hæd hɛld ɔl ðɪs taɪm. wɝkɪŋ təɡɛðɝ, ðeɪ hæɾ ənbælənst əpoʊnən æftɝ əpoʊnənt, tɑpəlɪŋ mɛni tə ðɛɹ dɛθs əɹ wɝs. bʌɾ ɪt wɑz dɪfəkəl fəɹ sɛmɝhɪdʒ tə ətɛn ðiz miɾɪŋz, ən mɛsænə hæd bɪn ʃaɪ, ʌv leɪt. ɪf ʃi wɑz θɪŋkɪŋ ʌv ɛndɪŋ ði əlaɪəns . . . "ælθɹ əz bɪn sin ɪn faɪv sɪɾiz, ɪnkluɾɪŋ ðət kɝs pleɪs ɪn ðə weɪst, ən ə dʌzən taʊnz sɪns ðoʊz blaɪn fulz - ðoʊz ɪɾiəts! - feɪld ɪn kɛɹhin. ən ðəɾ oʊnli ɪnkludz ðə ɹɪpɔɹts wi hæv! ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹɾ oʊnli noʊz wʌɾ ɛls ɪz kɹɔlɪŋ təwɔɹɾ əs baɪ hɔɹs, əɹ ʃip, əɹ wʌtɛvɝ ɛls ðiz sævədʒəz kən faɪn tə kæɹi ə mɛsədʒ."

"Where is he?" Demandred growled, clenching his fists behind his back. Standing with his feet apart, he was aware that he dominated the room. He always did. Even so, he wished Semirhage or Mesaana were present. Their alliance was delicate - a simple agreement that they would not turn on one another until the others had been eliminated - yet it had held all this time. Working together, they had unbalanced opponent after opponent, toppling many to their deaths or worse. But it was difficult for Semirhage to attend these meetings, and Mesaana had been shy, of late. If she was thinking of ending the alliance . . . "Al'Thor has been seen in five cities, including that cursed place in the Waste, and a dozen towns since those blind fools - those idiots! - failed in Cairhien. And that only includes the reports we have! The Great Lord only knows what else is crawling toward us by horse, or sheep, or whatever else these savages can find to carry a message."

ɡɹeɪndəl hæd tʃoʊzən ðə sɛɾɪŋ, sɪns ʃi hæd bɪn fɝs tə ɝaɪv, ən ɪɾ ɪɹəteɪɾəd hɪm. vju-wɔlz meɪd ðə stʃɹaɪpt wʊɾən flɔɹ əpɪɹ tə bi sɝaʊndəd baɪ ə fɔɹəs fʊl ə bɹaɪtli flaʊɝd vaɪnz ən flʌɾɝɪŋ bɝdz ðət wɝ ivən mɔɹ kʌlɝfəl. swit sɛns ən sɑf bɝdkɔlz fɪl ði ɛɹ. oʊnli ði ɑɹtʃ ə ðə dɔɹweɪ spɔɪl ði ɪluʒən. waɪ dɪd ʃi wɑn ə ɹimaɪndɝ ʌv wʌt wɑz lɔst? ðeɪ kəɾ əz sun meɪk ʃɑklənsɪz əɹ ʃoʊɪŋz əz ə vju-wɔl aʊtsaɪɾ ə ðɪs pleɪs, kloʊs tə ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl. ɪn ɛni keɪs, ʃi dɪspaɪzd ɛniθɪŋ tə də wɪð neɪtʃɝ, əz i ɹɪkɔld.

Graendal had chosen the setting, since she had been first to arrive, and it irritated him. View-walls made the striped wooden floor appear to be surrounded by a forest full of brightly flowered vines and fluttering birds that were even more colorful. Sweet scents and soft birdcalls filled the air. Only the arch of the doorway spoiled the illusion. Why did she want a reminder of what was lost? They could as soon make shocklances or showings as a view-wall outside of this place, close to Shayol Ghul. In any case, she despised anything to do with nature, as he recalled.

oʊsɑnɡɝ fɹaʊn ət "ɪɾiəts" ən "blaɪn fulz," əz wɛl i maɪt, bʌɾ i kwɪkli smuðd ðət pleɪn, kɹis feɪs, soʊ ənlaɪk ðə wʌn i hæd bɪn bɔɹn wɪð. baɪ wʌtɛvɝ neɪm i wɑz kɔld, hi hæɾ ɔlweɪz noʊn u hi dɛɹd tʃælənʒ ən u nɑt. "ə mæɾɝ ə tʃæns," hi sɛd kɑmli, ðoʊ hi dɪd bɪɡɪn dʒɹaɪ-wɑʃɪŋ ɪz hænz. ən oʊl hæbət. hi wɑz ɡɑɹb laɪk səm ɹulɝ ə ðɪs eɪdʒ, ɪn ə koʊt soʊ hɛvi wɪð ɡoʊldən ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi ðəɾ ɪɾ ɔlmoʊs hɪd ðə ɹɛɾ ə ðə klɔθ, ən buts fɹɪnd wɪð ɡoʊldən tæsəlz. ðəɹ wɑz ɪnʌf waɪt leɪs əɾ ɪz nɛk ən ɹɪsts tə kloʊð ə tʃaɪld. ðə mæn hæd nɛvɝ noʊn ðə minɪŋ ʌv ɛksɛs. ɪf nɑt fəɹ ɪz pɝtɪkjəlɝ skɪlz, hi nɛvɝ wʊɾə bɪn tʃoʊzən. ɹilaɪzɪŋ wʌɾ ɪz hænz wɝ duɪŋ, oʊsɑnɡɝ snætʃt ðə tɔl kwəndɪlɝ wɪnɛɡlæs fɹəm ðə ɹaʊn teɪbəl bɪsaɪɾ ɪz tʃɛɹ ən ɪnheɪl ðə dɑɹk waɪnz ɝoʊmə dipli. "sɪmpli pɹɑbəbɪləɾiz," hi mɝmɝd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə saʊn ɔfhænd. "nɛks taɪm, hɪl bi kɪld əɹ teɪkən. tʃæns kæn pɹətɛkt ɪm fɝɛvɝ."

Osan'gar frowned at "idiots" and "blind fools," as well he might, but he quickly smoothed that plain, creased face, so unlike the one he had been born with. By whatever name he was called, he had always known who he dared challenge and who not. "A matter of chance," he said calmly, though he did begin dry-washing his hands. An old habit. He was garbed like some ruler of this Age, in a coat so heavy with golden embroidery that it almost hid the red of the cloth, and boots fringed with golden tassels. There was enough white lace at his neck and wrists to clothe a child. The man had never known the meaning of excess. If not for his particular skills, he never would have been Chosen. Realizing what his hands were doing, Osan'gar snatched the tall cuendillar wineglass from the round table beside his chair and inhaled the dark wine's aroma deeply. "Simply probabilities," he murmured, trying to sound offhand. "Next time, he will be killed or taken. Chance can't protect him forever."

"ju ɑɹ gɑnə dɪpɛn ɑn tʃæns?" ɝæŋɡɝ wɑz stʃɹɛtʃt aʊɾ ɪn ə lɔŋ, floʊɪŋ tʃɛɹ əz ðoʊ ɪt wɝ ə bɛdtʃɛɹ. dɝɛktɪŋ ə smoʊki smaɪl əɾ oʊsɑnɡɝ, ʃi ɑɹtʃt wʌn lɛɡ ɑn bɛɹ toʊz soʊ ðə slɪɾ ɪn əɹ bɹaɪt ɹɛd skɝts ɪkspoʊzd əɹ tə ðə hɪp. ɛvɹi bɹɛθ θɹɛɾənd tə fɹi hɝ fɹəm ðə ɹɛd sæɾən ðət dʒʌs kənteɪn əɹ fʊl bɹɛsts. ɔl ə hɝ mænɝɪzəmz hæd tʃeɪnʒd sɪns ʃi bɪkeɪm ə wʊmən, bʌt nɑt ðə kɔɹ ʌv wʌt hæd bɪn pleɪst ɪndə ðət fimeɪl bɑɾi. dɪmɑndɝd hɑɹdli skɔɹn flɛʃli plɛʒɝz, bʌt wʌn deɪ hɝ kɹeɪvɪŋz wəd bi ðə dɛθ ə hɝ. əz ðeɪ ɔlɹɛɾi hæd bɪn wʌns. nɑt ðəɾ i wəd mɔɹn, ʌv kɔɹs, ɪf ðə nɛks taɪm wɑz faɪnəl. "ju wɝ ɹispɑnsəbəl fəɹ wɑtʃɪŋ hɪm, oʊsɑnɡɝ," ʃi wɛn ɑn, hɝ vɔɪs kɝɛsɪŋ ɛvɹi sɪləbəl. "ju, ən dɪmɑndɝd." oʊsɑnɡɝ flɪntʃt, flɪkɪŋ ɪz tʌŋ əɡɛnst ɪz lɪps, ən ʃi læf θɹoʊəɾəli. "maɪ oʊn tʃɑɹdʒ ɪz . . ." ʃi pɹɛst ə θʌm daʊn ɑn ði ɛdʒ ə ðə tʃɛɹ əz ɪf pɪnɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ ən læft əɡɛn.

"You are going to depend on chance?" Aran'gar was stretched out in a long, flowing chair as though it were a bedchair. Directing a smoky smile at Osan'gar, she arched one leg on bare toes so the slit in her bright red skirts exposed her to the hip. Every breath threatened to free her from the red satin that just contained her full breasts. All of her mannerisms had changed since she became a woman, but not the core of what had been placed into that female body. Demandred hardly scorned fleshly pleasures, but one day her cravings would be the death of her. As they already had been once. Not that he would mourn, of course, if the next time was final. "You were responsible for watching him, Osan'gar," she went on, her voice caressing every syllable. "You, and Demandred." Osan'gar flinched, flicking his tongue against his lips, and she laughed throatily. "My own charge is . . ." She pressed a thumb down on the edge of the chair as if pinning something and laughed again.

"aɪ ʃəd θɪŋk jə wəd bi mɔɹ wɝid, ɝæŋɡɝ," ɡɹeɪndəl mɝmɝɾ oʊvɝ əɹ waɪn. ʃi kənsild əɹ kəntɛmpt əbaʊɾ əz wɛl əz ði ɔlmoʊs tʃɹænspɛɹən sɪlvɝi mɪst ə hɝ stʃɹaɪθ ɡaʊn kənsild əɹ ɹaɪp kɝvz. "ju, ən oʊsɑnɡɝ, ən dɪmɑndɝd. ən mɔɹaɪɾɪn, wɛɹɛvɝ i ɪz. pɝhæps jə ʃəd fɪɹ ælθɹz səksɛs əz mʌtʃ əz ɪz feɪljɝ."

"I should think you would be more worried, Aran'gar," Graendal murmured over her wine. She concealed her contempt about as well as the almost transparent silvery mist of her streith gown concealed her ripe curves. "You, and Osan'gar, and Demandred. And Moridin, wherever he is. Perhaps you should fear al'Thor's success as much as his failure."

læfɪŋ, ɝæŋɡɝ kɑt ðə stændɪŋ wʊmənz hæn ɪn wʌn ə hɝz. hɝ ɡɹin aɪz spɑɹkəld. "æn pɝhæps jə kəɾ ɪkspleɪn wʌt jə min bɛɾɝ ɪf wi wɝ əloʊn?"

Laughing, Aran'gar caught the standing woman's hand in one of hers. Her green eyes sparkled. "And perhaps you could explain what you mean better if we were alone?"

ɡɹeɪndəlz ɡaʊn tɝn tə stɑɹk blæk kənsilɪŋ smoʊk. dʒɝkɪŋ əɹ hæn fɹi wɪð ə kɔɹs oʊθ, ʃi stɔkt əweɪ fɹəm ðə tʃɛɹ. ɝæŋɡɝ . . . ɡɪɡəld.

Graendal's gown turned to stark black concealing smoke. Jerking her hand free with a coarse oath, she stalked away from the chair. Aran'gar . . . giggled.

"wʌt dʒju min?" oʊsɑnɡɝ sɛd ʃɑɹpli, stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ aʊɾ ə hɪz tʃɛɹ. wʌns ɑn ɪz fit, hi stʃɹʌk ə lɛktʃɝɝz poʊz, ɡɹɪpɪŋ ɪz ləpɛlz, ən ɪz toʊn bɪkeɪm pədæntɪk. "ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs, maɪ dɪɹ ɡɹeɪndəl, aɪ daʊt ðəɾ ivən aɪ kəd dɪvaɪz ə mɛθəd tə ɹimuv ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹdz ʃædoʊ fɹəm seɪɾɪn. ælθɹ ɪz ə pɹɪməɾɪv. ɛniθɪŋ i tʃɹaɪz ɪnɛvəɾəbli wɪl pɹuv ɪnsəfɪʃənt, ən aɪ, fəɹ wʌn, kænɑt bɪliv i kən ivən ɪmædʒən haʊ tə bɪɡɪn. ɪn ɛni ɪvɛnt, wɪl stɑp ɪm tʃɹaɪɪŋ kəz ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd kəmænz ɪt. aɪ kən ʌndɝstæn fɪɹ ə ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹdz dɪsplɛʒɝ ɪf wi sʌmhaʊ feɪld, ənlaɪkli əz ðət maɪt bi, bʌt waɪ ʃəd ðoʊz ʌv əs jə neɪmd əv ɛni spɛʃəl fɪɹ?"

"What do you mean?" Osan'gar said sharply, struggling out of his chair. Once on his feet, he struck a lecturer's pose, gripping his lapels, and his tone became pedantic. "In the first place, my dear Graendal, I doubt that even I could devise a method to remove the Great Lord's shadow from saidin. Al'Thor is a primitive. Anything he tries inevitably will prove insufficient, and I, for one, cannot believe he can even imagine how to begin. In any event, we will stop him trying because the Great Lord commands it. I can understand fear of the Great Lord's displeasure if we somehow failed, unlikely as that might be, but why should those of us you named have any special fear?"

"blaɪn əz ɛvɝ, ən dʒɹaɪ əz ɛvɝ," ɡɹeɪndəl mɝmɝd. wɪð ðə ɹɪtɝn ə kəmpoʊʒɝ, hɝ ɡaʊn wɑz klɪɹ mɪst əɡɛn, ðoʊ ɹɛd. pɝhæps ʃi wɑz nɑt soʊ kɑm əz ʃi pɹitɛndəd. əɹ pɝhæps ʃi wɑntəɾ əm tə bɪliv ʃi wɑz kəntʃɹoʊlɪŋ səm ædʒəteɪʃən. ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə stʃɹaɪθ, hɝ ədɔɹnməns ɔl keɪm fɹəm ðɪs eɪdʒ, faɪɝdʒɹɑps ɪn əɹ ɡoʊldən hɛɹ, ə lɑɹdʒ ɹubi dæŋɡəlɪŋ bɪtwin əɹ bɹɛsts, ɔɹneɪt ɡoʊldən bɹeɪslɪts ɑn boʊθ ɹɪsts. ən sʌmθɪŋ kwaɪt stʃɹeɪnʒ, ðət dɪmɑndɝd wʌndɝd wɛðɝ ɛniwʌn ɛls hæd noʊɾəst. ə sɪmpəl ɹɪŋ ʌv ɡoʊld ɑn ðə lɪɾəl fɪŋɡɝ ə hɝ lɛf hænd. sɪmpəl wɑz nɛvɝ əsoʊsieɪɾəd wɪð ɡɹeɪndəl. "ɪf ðə jʌŋ mæn dʌz sʌmhaʊ ɹimuv ðə ʃædoʊ, wɛl . . . jə hu tʃænəl seɪɾɪn wɪl noʊ lɔŋɡɝ nid ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹdz spɛʃəl pɹətɛkʃən. wɪl i tʃɹʌs jəɹ . . . lɔɪəlti . . . ðɛn?" smaɪlɪŋ, ʃi sɪpt əɹ waɪn.

"Blind as ever, and dry as ever," Graendal murmured. With the return of composure, her gown was clear mist again, though red. Perhaps she was not so calm as she pretended. Or perhaps she wanted them to believe she was controlling some agitation. Except for the streith, her adornments all came from this age, firedrops in her golden hair, a large ruby dangling between her breasts, ornate golden bracelets on both wrists. And something quite strange, that Demandred wondered whether anyone else had noticed. A simple ring of gold on the little finger of her left hand. Simple was never associated with Graendal. "If the young man does somehow remove the shadow, well . . . You who channel saidin will no longer need the Great Lord's special protection. Will he trust your . . . loyalty . . . then?" Smiling, she sipped her wine.

oʊsɑnɡɝ dɪd nɑt smaɪl. hɪz feɪs peɪld, ən i skɹʌbd ə hæn əkɹɔs ɪz maʊθ. ɝæŋɡɝ sæɾ ʌp ɑn ði ɛdʒ ə hɝ lɔŋ tʃɛɹ, noʊ lɔŋɡɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə bi sɛntʃəwəs. hɝ hænz fɔɹm klɔz ɑn əɹ læp, ən ʃi ɡlɛɹɾ ət ɡɹeɪndəl əz ɪf ɹɛɾi tə ɡoʊ fəɹ əɹ θɹoʊt.

Osan'gar did not smile. His face paled, and he scrubbed a hand across his mouth. Aran'gar sat up on the edge of her long chair, no longer trying to be sensuous. Her hands formed claws on her lap, and she glared at Graendal as if ready to go for her throat.

dɪmɑndɝdz fɪsts ənklɛntʃt. ɪt wɑz aʊɾ ɪn ði oʊpən ət læst. hi hæd hoʊp tə hæv ælθɹ dɛd - əɹ feɪlɪŋ ðæt, kæptɪv - bɪfɔɹ ðɪs səspɪʃən ɹɪɹɾ ɪts hɛd. dʊɹɪŋ ðə wɔɹ ə paʊɝ, mɔɹ ðən ə dʌzən ə ðə tʃoʊzən hæd daɪɾ ə ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹdz səspɪʃən.

Demandred's fists unclenched. It was out in the open at last. He had hoped to have al'Thor dead - or failing that, captive - before this suspicion reared its head. During the War of Power, more than a dozen of the Chosen had died of the Great Lord's suspicion.

"ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹɾ ɪz ʃʊɹ jə ɑɹ ɔl feɪθfəl," mɔɹaɪɾɪn ənaʊnst, stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ ɪn əz ðoʊ hi wɝ ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹɾ ə ðə dɑɹk hɪmsɛlf. hi hæɾ ɔfən sim tə bɪliv i wɑz, ən ðə bɔɪz feɪs i wɔɹ naʊ hæd nɑt tʃeɪnʒd ðæt. ɪn spaɪɾ ə hɪz wɝdz, ðət feɪs wɑz ɡɹɪm, ən ɪz ʌnɹiliv blæk meɪɾ ɪz neɪm, dɛθ, fɪt. "ju nid nɑt wɝi əntɪl i stɑps biɪŋ ʃʊɹ." ðə ɡɝl, sɪndeɪn, tʃɹɑɾəd əɾ ɪz hilz laɪk ə boʊsəmi lɪɾəl sɪlvɝ-hɛɹd pɛɾ ɪn ɹɛd-ænd-blæk. fəɹ səm ɹizən, mɔɹaɪɾɪn hæɾ ə ɹæt ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ, peɪl noʊz snɪfɪŋ ði ɛɹ, blæk aɪz stʌɾiɪŋ ðə ɹum wɛɹəli. əɹ fəɹ noʊ ɹizən, pɝhæps. ə juθfəl feɪs hæd nɑt meɪɾ ɪm ɛni seɪnɝ, iðɝ.

"The Great Lord is sure you are all faithful," Moridin announced, striding in as though he were the Great Lord of the Dark himself. He had often seemed to believe he was, and the boy's face he wore now had not changed that. In spite of his words, that face was grim, and his unrelieved black made his name, Death, fit. "You need not worry until he stops being sure." The girl, Cyndane, trotted at his heels like a bosomy little silver-haired pet in red-and-black. For some reason, Moridin had a rat riding his shoulder, pale nose sniffing the air, black eyes studying the room warily. Or for no reason, perhaps. A youthful face had not made him any saner, either.

"waɪ hæv jə kɔld əs hɪɹ?" dɪmɑndɝd dɪmændəd. "aɪ hæv mʌtʃ tə du, ən noʊ taɪm fəɹ aɪɾəl tɔk." ʌnkɑnʃəsli hi tʃɹaɪd tə stæn tɔlɝ, tə mætʃ ði ʌðɝ mæn.

"Why have you called us here?" Demandred demanded. "I have much to do, and no time for idle talk." Unconsciously he tried to stand taller, to match the other man.

"mɛsænə ɪz æbsən əɡɛn?" mɔɹaɪɾɪn sɛɾ ɪnstɛɾ ʌv ænsɝɪŋ. "ə pɪɾi. ʃi ʃəd hɪɹ wʌɾ aɪ hæv tə seɪ." plʌkɪŋ ðə ɹæt fɹəm ɪz ʃoʊldɝ baɪ ɪts teɪl, hi wɑtʃt ði ænəməl weɪv ɪts lɛɡz fjuɾɪlli. nʌθɪŋ ɪksɛp ðə ɹæt sim tə ɪɡzɪs fəɹ hɪm. "smɔl, əpɛɹənli ənɪmpɔɹɾənt mæɾɝz kən bɪkʌm vɛɹi ɪmpɔɹɾənt," hi mɝmɝd. "ðɪs ɹæt. wɛðɝ ɪsəm səksidz ɪn faɪndɪŋ ən kɪlɪŋ ðəɾ ʌðɝ vɝmɪn, feɪn. ə wɝd wɪspɝɾ ɪn ðə ɹɔŋ ɪɹ, əɹ nɑt spoʊkən tə ðə ɹaɪt. ə bʌɾɝflaɪ stɝz ɪts wɪŋz ɑn ə bɹæntʃ, ən ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə wɝld ə maʊntən kəlæpsɪz." sʌɾənli ðə ɹæt twɪstəd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə sɪŋk ɪts tiθ ɪndə hɪz ɹɪst. kæʒəwəli, hi flʌŋ ðə kɹitʃɝ əweɪ. ɪn mɪdɛɹ, ðəɹ wɑz ə bɝst ə fleɪm, sʌmθɪŋ hɑɾɝ ðən fleɪm, ən ðə ɹæt wɑz ɡɔn. mɔɹaɪɾɪn smaɪld.

"Mesaana is absent again?" Moridin said instead of answering. "A pity. She should hear what I have to say." Plucking the rat from his shoulder by its tail, he watched the animal wave its legs futilely. Nothing except the rat seemed to exist for him. "Small, apparently unimportant matters can become very important," he murmured. "This rat. Whether Isam succeeds in finding and killing that other vermin, Fain. A word whispered in the wrong ear, or not spoken to the right. A butterfly stirs its wings on a branch, and on the other side of the world a mountain collapses." Suddenly the rat twisted, trying to sink its teeth into his wrist. Casually, he flung the creature away. In midair, there was a burst of flame, something hotter than flame, and the rat was gone. Moridin smiled.

dɪmɑndɝd flɪntʃt ɪn spaɪɾ ə hɪmsɛlf. ðət hæd bɪn ðə tʃɹu paʊɝ; hi hæd fɛl nʌθɪŋ. ə blæk spɛk floʊɾəd əkɹɔs mɔɹaɪɾɪnz blu aɪz, ðən ənʌðɝ, ɪn ə stɛɾi stʃɹim. ðə mæn mʌst əv bɪn juzɪŋ ðə tʃɹu paʊɝ ɪksklusɪvli sɪns i læst sɔ hɪm tə ɡeɪn soʊ mɛni sæɑ soʊ kwɪkli. hi hɪmsɛlf hæd nɛvɝ tʌtʃt ðə tʃɹu paʊɝ ɪksɛpt ət nid. ɡɹeɪt nid. ʌv kɔɹs, oʊnli mɔɹaɪɾɪn hæd ðət pɹɪvlədʒ naʊ, sɪns ɪz . . . ænɔɪntɪŋ. ðə mæn tʃɹuli wɑz ɪnseɪn tə juz ɪt soʊ fɹili. ɪt wɑz ə dʒɹʌɡ mɔɹ ədɪktɪv ðən seɪɾɪn, mɔɹ dɛdli ðən pɔɪzən.

Demandred flinched in spite of himself. That had been the True Power; he had felt nothing. A black speck floated across Moridin's blue eyes, then another, in a steady stream. The man must have been using the True Power exclusively since he last saw him to gain so many saa so quickly. He himself had never touched the True Power except at need. Great need. Of course, only Moridin had that privilege now, since his . . . anointing. The man truly was insane to use it so freely. It was a drug more addictive than saidin, more deadly than poison.

kɹɔsɪŋ ðə stʃɹaɪp flɔɹ, mɔɹaɪɾɪn leɪɾ ə hæn ɑn oʊsɑnɡɝz ʃoʊldɝ, hɪz smaɪl meɪd mɔɹ ɑmənəs baɪ ðə sæɑ. ðə ʃɔɹɾɝ mæn swɑloʊd, ən ɡeɪv ə weɪvɝɪŋ smaɪl ɪn ɹɪtɝn. "ɪɾ ɪz wɛl juv nɛvɝ kənsɪɾɝd haʊ tə ɹimuv ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹdz ʃædoʊ," mɔɹaɪɾɪn sɛd kwaɪətli. haʊ lɔŋ hæɾ i bɪn aʊtsaɪd? oʊsɑnɡɝz smaɪl ɡɹu ivən mɔɹ sɪkli. "ælθɹ ɪz nɑɾ əz waɪz əz ju. tɛl ðɛm, sɪndeɪn."

Crossing the striped floor, Moridin laid a hand on Osan'gar's shoulder, his smile made more ominous by the saa. The shorter man swallowed, and gave a wavering smile in return. "It is well you've never considered how to remove the Great Lord's shadow," Moridin said quietly. How long had he been outside? Osan'gar's smile grew even more sickly. "Al'Thor is not as wise as you. Tell them, Cyndane."

ðə lɪɾəl wʊmən dʒɹu hɝsɛlf ʌp. baɪ feɪs ən fɔɹm ʃi wɑz ə lʌʃəs plʌm, ɹɛɾi fəɹ plʌkɪŋ, bʌɾ əɹ bɪɡ blu aɪz wɝ ɡleɪʃəl. ə pitʃ, pɝhæps. pitʃəz wɝ pɔɪzənəs, hɪɹ ən naʊ. "ju ɹikɔl ðə tʃoʊɾən kæl, aɪ səpoʊz." noʊ əmaʊn ʌv ɛfɝt kəd meɪk ðət loʊ, bɹɛθi vɔɪs ɛniθɪŋ ɪksɛp sʌltʃɹi, bʌt ʃi mænədʒ tə ɪndʒɛk sɑɹkæzəm. "luz θɝɪn əz tu ʌv ði æksɛs kiz, wʌn fəɹ itʃ. ən i noʊz ə wʊmən stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf tə juz ðə fimeɪl ə ðə pɛɹ. hi plænz tə juz ðə tʃoʊɾən kæl fəɹ ɪz did."

The little woman drew herself up. By face and form she was a luscious plum, ready for plucking, but her big blue eyes were glacial. A peach, perhaps. Peaches were poisonous, here and now. "You recall the Choedan Kal, I suppose." No amount of effort could make that low, breathy voice anything except sultry, but she managed to inject sarcasm. "Lews Therin has two of the access keys, one for each. And he knows a woman strong enough to use the female of the pair. He plans to use the Choedan Kal for his deed."

nɪɹli ɛvɹiwʌn bɪɡæn tə tɔk ət wʌns.

Nearly everyone began to talk at once.

"aɪ θɔt ðə kiz wɝ ɔl dɪstʃɹɔɪd!" ɝæŋɡɝ ɪkskleɪmd, sɝdʒɪŋ tə hɝ fit. hɝ aɪz wɝ waɪd wɪð fɪɹ. "hi kəd ʃæɾɝ ðə wɝl dʒʌs tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə juz ðə tʃoʊɾən kæl!"

"I thought the keys were all destroyed!" Aran'gar exclaimed, surging to her feet. Her eyes were wide with fear. "He could shatter the world just trying to use the Choedan Kal!"

"ɪf jə hæɾ ɛvɝ ɹɛɾ ɛniθɪŋ bɪsaɪdz ə hɪstɝi bʊk, jə wəd noʊ ðəɹ ɔlmoʊst ɪmpɑsəbəl tə dɪstʃɹɔɪ!" oʊsɑnɡɝ snɑɹəld ət hɝ. bʌɾ i wɑz tʌɡɪŋ əɾ ɪz kɑlɝ əz ɪf ɪt wɝ tu taɪt, ən ɪz aɪz simd ɹɛɾi tə fɔl aʊɾ ə hɪz feɪs. "haʊ kən ðɪs ɡɝl noʊ hiz ðɛm? haʊ?"

"If you had ever read anything besides a history book, you would know they're almost impossible to destroy!" Osan'gar snarled at her. But he was tugging at his collar as if it were too tight, and his eyes seemed ready to fall out of his face. "How can this girl know he has them? How?"

ɡɹeɪndəlz wɪnɛɡlæs hæd dʒɹɑp fɹəm əɹ hæn əz sun ðə wɝdz wɝ aʊɾ ə sɪndeɪnz maʊθ, baʊnsɪŋ ɛn oʊvɝ ɛn əkɹɔs ðə flɔɹ. hɝ ɡaʊn tɝn əz kɹɪmzən əz fɹɛʃ blʌd, ən əɹ maʊθ twɪstəɾ əz ɪf ʃi wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ tə vɑmət. "æn juv dʒʌs bɪn hoʊpɪŋ tə blʌndɝ ɪndə hɪm!" ʃi skɹimd ət dɪmɑndɝd. "hoʊpɪŋ sʌmwʌn wɪl faɪn ɪm fəɹ ju! ful! ful!"

Graendal's wineglass had dropped from her hand as soon the words were out of Cyndane's mouth, bouncing end over end across the floor. Her gown turned as crimson as fresh blood, and her mouth twisted as if she were going to vomit. "And you've just been hoping to blunder into him!" she screamed at Demandred. "Hoping someone will find him for you! Fool! Fool!"

dɪmɑndɝd θɔt ɡɹeɪndəl hæd bɪn ə tʌtʃ flæmbɔɪən ivən fəɹ hɝ. hi wəd weɪdʒɝ ði ənaʊnsmən hæd bɪn noʊ sɝpɹaɪz tə hɝ. ɪt simd ʃi bɔɹ wɑtʃɪŋ. hi sɛd nʌθɪŋ.

Demandred thought Graendal had been a touch flamboyant even for her. He would wager the announcement had been no surprise to her. It seemed she bore watching. He said nothing.

pʊɾɪŋ ə hæn oʊvɝ ɪz hɑɹt, fəɹ ɔl ðə wɝld laɪk ə lʌvɝ, mɔɹaɪɾɪn tɪltəɾ ʌp sɪndeɪnz tʃɪn ɑn ɪz fɪŋɡɝtɪps. ɹɪzɛnmənt bɝn ɪn əɹ aɪz, bʌɾ əɹ feɪs maɪɾ əv bɪn ə dɑlz əntʃeɪnʒɪŋ feɪs. ʃi sɝɾənli æksɛptɪɾ ɪz ətɛnʃənz laɪk ə plaɪəbəl dɑl. "sɪndeɪn noʊz mɛni θɪŋz," mɔɹaɪɾɪn sɛd sɔfli, "ænd ʃi tɛlz mi ɛvɹiθɪŋ ʃi noʊz. ɛvɹiθɪŋ." ðə taɪni wʊmənz ɪkspɹɛʃən nɛvɝ ɔltɝd, bʌt ʃi tʃɹɛmbəl vɪzəbli.

Putting a hand over his heart, for all the world like a lover, Moridin tilted up Cyndane's chin on his fingertips. Resentment burned in her eyes, but her face might have been a doll's unchanging face. She certainly accepted his attentions like a pliable doll. "Cyndane knows many things," Moridin said softly, "and she tells me everything she knows. Everything." The tiny woman's expression never altered, but she trembled visibly.

ʃi wɑz ə pʌzəl tə dɪmɑndɝd. ət fɝst i hæd θɔt ʃi wɑz lænfɝ ɹiɪnkɑɹneɪɾɪd. bɑɾiz fəɹ tʃɹænsməɡɹeɪʃən səpoʊzədli wɝ tʃoʊzən baɪ wʌt wɑz əveɪləbəl, jɛɾ oʊsɑnɡɝ ən ɝæŋɡɝ wɝ pɹuf ə ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹdz kɹuəl sɛns ə hjumɝ. hi hæd bɪn ʃʊɹ, əntɪl mɛsænə toʊld ɪm ðə ɡɝl wɑz wikɝ ðən lænfɝ. mɛsænə ən ðə ɹɛs θɔt ʃi wɑz ə ðɪs eɪdʒ. jɛt ʃi spoʊk ʌv ælθɹ əz luz θɝɪn, dʒʌst əz lænfɝ hæd, ən spoʊk ə ðə tʃoʊɾən kæl əz wʌn fəmɪljɝ wɪð ðə tɛɹɝ ðeɪ hæɾ ɪnspaɪɝd dʊɹɪŋ ðə wɔɹ ə paʊɝ. oʊnli bɑlfaɪɝ hæd bɪn mɔɹ fɪɹd, ən oʊnli dʒʌst. əɹ hæd mɔɹaɪɾɪn tɔɾ əɹ fəɹ pɝpəsəz ə hɪz oʊn? ɪf i hæɾ ɛni ɹil pɝpəsəz. ðəɹ hæɾ ɔlweɪz bɪn taɪmz wən ðə mænz ækʃənz hæd bɪn ʃɪɹ mædnəs.

She was a puzzle to Demandred. At first he had thought she was Lanfear reincarnated. Bodies for transmigration supposedly were chosen by what was available, yet Osan'gar and Aran'gar were proof of the Great Lord's cruel sense of humor. He had been sure, until Mesaana told him the girl was weaker than Lanfear. Mesaana and the rest thought she was of this Age. Yet she spoke of al'Thor as Lews Therin, just as Lanfear had, and spoke of the Choedan Kal as one familiar with the terror they had inspired during the War of Power. Only balefire had been more feared, and only just. Or had Moridin taught her for purposes of his own? If he had any real purposes. There had always been times when the man's actions had been sheer madness.

"soʊ ɪt simz i mʌs bi kɪld æftɝ ɔl," dɪmɑndɝd sɛd. haɪɾɪŋ ɪz sæɾəsfækʃən wɑz nɑɾ izi. ɹænd ælθɹ əɹ luz θɝɪn tɛləmən, hi wəd ɹɛst iziɝ wən ðə fɛloʊ wɑz dɛd. "bɪfɔɹ i kən dɪstʃɹɔɪ ðə wɝld, ən ʌs. wɪtʃ meɪks faɪndɪŋ ɪm ɔl ðə mɔɹ ɝdʒənt."

"So it seems he must be killed after all," Demandred said. Hiding his satisfaction was not easy. Rand al'Thor or Lews Therin Telamon, he would rest easier when the fellow was dead. "Before he can destroy the world, and us. Which makes finding him all the more urgent."

"kɪld?" mɔɹaɪɾɪn muvd ɪz hænz əz ðoʊ weɪɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ. "ɪf ɪt kʌmz tə ðæt, jɛs," hi sɛd faɪnəli. "bʌt faɪndɪŋ ɪm ɪz noʊ pɹɑbləm. wən i tʌtʃəz ðə tʃoʊɾən kæl, jəl noʊ wɛɹ i ɪz. ən jəl ɡoʊ ðəɹ ən teɪk hɪm. əɹ kɪl hɪm, ɪf nɛsəsɛɹi. ðə nɛbli hæz spoʊkən."

"Killed?" Moridin moved his hands as though weighing something. "If it comes to that, yes," he said finally. "But finding him is no problem. When he touches the Choedan Kal, you will know where he is. And you will go there and take him. Or kill him, if necessary. The Nae'blis has spoken."

"æz ðə nɛbli kəmænz," sɪndeɪn sɛɾ iɡɝli, boʊɪŋ əɹ hɛd, ən ɛkoʊz ə hɝ ɹæn ɝaʊn ðə ɹum, ðoʊ ɝæŋɡɝ saʊndəd sʌlən, oʊsɑnɡɝ dɛspɹɪt, ən ɡɹeɪndəl ɑdli θɔtfəl.

"As the Nae'blis commands," Cyndane said eagerly, bowing her head, and echos of her ran around the room, though Aran'gar sounded sullen, Osan'gar desperate, and Graendal oddly thoughtful.

bɛndɪŋ ɪz nɛk hɝt dɪmɑndɝɾ əz mʌtʃ əz spikɪŋ ðoʊz wɝdz. soʊ ðeɪ wəd teɪk ælθɹ - waɪl i wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə juz ðə tʃoʊɾən kæl, noʊ lɛs, hi ən səm wʊmən dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ ɪnʌf ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ tə mɛl kɑntənəns! - bʌt ðəɹ hæd bɪn noʊ ɪndəkeɪʃən ðət mɔɹaɪɾɪn wəd bi wɪð ðɛm. əɹ ɪz twɪn pɛts, mɑɡiɾin ən sɪndeɪn. ðə mæn wɑz nɛbli fəɹ naʊ, bʌt pɝhæps mæɾɝz kəd bi ɝeɪnʒd soʊ hi dɪd nɑt ɡɛɾ ənʌðɝ bɑɾi ðə nɛks taɪm i daɪd. pɝhæps ɪt kəd bi ɝeɪnʒd sun.

Bending his neck hurt Demandred as much as speaking those words. So they would take al'Thor - while he was trying to use the Choedan Kal, no less, he and some woman drinking enough of the One Power to melt continents! - but there had been no indication that Moridin would be with them. Or his twin pets, Moghedien and Cyndane. The man was Nae'blis for now, but perhaps matters could be arranged so he did not get another body the next time he died. Perhaps it could be arranged soon.


tʃæptɝ fɔɹtin


CHAPTER 14

wʌɾ ə veɪl haɪdz


What a Veil Hides

ðə vɪktɝi ʌv kɪdʒɹɑn ɹoʊld ɑn lɔŋ si swɛlz, meɪkɪŋ ðə ɡɪldɪd læmps ɪn ðə stɝn kæbən swɪŋ ɑn ðɛɹ ɡɪmbəlz, bʌt tuɑn sæt kɑmli əz ðə ɹeɪzɝ ɪn sɪlutʃəz ʃʊɹ hæn slɪɾ əkɹɔs əɹ skælp. θɹu ðə tɔl stɝn wɪndoʊz ʃi kəd si ʌðɝ ɡɹieɪtʃɪps kɹæʃɪŋ θɹu ðə ɡɹeɪ-ɡɹin swɛlz ɪn spɹeɪz ʌv waɪt, hʌnʒɹədz ə ðɛm ɹoʊ ɑn ɹoʊ, stʃɹɛtʃɪŋ tə ðə hɝaɪzən. fɔɹ taɪmz əz mɛni hæd bɪn lɛft ət tæntʃəkoʊ. ðə ɹaɪædʒɛl, ðoʊz u kʌm hoʊm. ðə kɔɝɪn, ðə ɹɪtɝn, hæd bɪɡʌn.

The Victory of Kidron rolled on long sea swells, making the gilded lamps in the stern cabin swing on their gimbals, but Tuon sat calmly as the razor in Selucia's sure hand slid across her scalp. Through the tall stern windows she could see other greatships crashing through the gray-green swells in sprays of white, hundreds of them row on row, stretching to the horizon. Four times as many had been left at Tanchico. The Rhyagelle, Those Who Come Home. The Corenne, the Return, had begun.

ə sɔɹɪŋ ælbətʃɹɑs sim tə bi fɑloʊɪŋ ðə kɪdʒɹɑn, ən oʊmən ə vɪktɝi ɪndid, ðoʊ ðə bɝdz lɔŋ wɪŋz wɝ blæk ɪnstɛɾ ʌv waɪt. ɪt mʌst stɪl min ðə seɪm θɪŋ. oʊmənz dɪd nɑt tʃeɪnʒ əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə loʊkeɪʃən. ən aʊl kɔlɪŋ ət dɔn mɛn ə dɛθ ən ɹeɪn wɪθaʊt klaʊdz ən ʌnɪkspɛktɪd vɪzəɾɝ wɛðɝ ɪn ɪmfɹəl əɹ nɔɹən ɹ.

A soaring albatross seemed to be following the Kidron, an omen of victory indeed, though the bird's long wings were black instead of white. It must still mean the same thing. Omens did not change according to location. An owl calling at dawn meant a death and rain without clouds an unexpected visitor whether in Imfaral or Noren M'Shar.

ðə mɔɹnɪŋ ɹɪtʃuəl wɪð əɹ dʒɹɛsɝz ɹeɪzɝ wɑz suðɪŋ, ən ʃi niɾəd ðət tədeɪ. læs naɪt, ʃi hæd ɡɪvən ə kəmæn ɪn æŋɡɝ. noʊ kəmænd ʃəd bi ɪʃuɾ ɪn æŋɡɝ. ʃi fɛlt ɔlmoʊst siməsiv, əz ɪf ʃi hæd lɔst ɑnɝ. hɝ bæləns wɑz dɪstɝbd, ən ðət boʊɾɪd əz ɪl fəɹ ðə ɹɪtɝn əz ə lɔs ə seɪaɪtɑɹ, ælbətʃɹɑs əɹ noʊ ælbətʃɹɑs.

The morning ritual with her dresser's razor was soothing, and she needed that today. Last night, she had given a command in anger. No command should be issued in anger. She felt almost sei'mosiev, as if she had lost honor. Her balance was disturbed, and that boded as ill for the Return as a loss of sei'taer, albatross or no albatross.

sɪlutʃə waɪpt əweɪ ðə læst ə ðə læðɝ wɪð ə wɔɹm dæmp klɔθ, ðən juzd ə dʒɹaɪ klɔθ, ən faɪnəli paʊɾɝd əɹ smuð skælp laɪtli wɪð ə bɹʌʃ. wən əɹ dʒɹɛsɝ stɛp bæk, tuɑn ɹoʊz ən lɛɾ əɹ ɪlæbɹətli ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd blu sɪlk dʒɹɛsɪŋ ɡaʊn slaɪd tə ðə ɡoʊld-ænd-blu pæɾɝnd kɑɹpət. ɪnstənli ðə kul ɛɹ pɛbəld əɹ dɑɹk bɛɹ skɪn. fɔɹ ə hɝ tɛn meɪdz ɹoʊz ɡɹeɪsfəli fɹəm wɛɹ ðeɪ hæd bɪn nilɪŋ əɡɛns ðə wɔlz, klin-lɪmd ən kʌmli ɪn ðɛɹ fɪlmi waɪt ɹoʊbz. ɔl hæd bɪn pɝtʃəs fəɹ ðɛɹ əpɪɹəns əz mʌtʃ əz ðɛɹ skɪlz, ən ðeɪ wɝ vɛɹi skɪld. ðeɪ hæd bɪkʌm juz tə ðə moʊʃənz ə ðə ʃɪp dʊɹɪŋ ðə lɔŋ vɔɪədʒ fɹəm sintʃæn, ən ðeɪ skɝid tə fɛtʃ ðə ɡɑɹməns ðət hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi bɪn leɪɾ aʊɾ ətɑp ðə kɑɹv tʃɛsts ən bɹɪŋ əm tə sɪlutʃə. sɪlutʃə nɛvɝ əlaʊd ðə dækoʊvæl tə æktʃəli  dʒɹɛs hɝ, nɑt soʊ mʌtʃ əz stɑkɪŋz əɹ slɪpɝz.

Selucia wiped away the last of the lather with a warm damp cloth, then used a dry cloth, and finally powdered her smooth scalp lightly with a brush. When her dresser stepped back, Tuon rose and let her elaborately embroidered blue silk dressing gown slide to the gold-and-blue patterned carpet. Instantly the cool air pebbled her dark bare skin. Four of her ten maids rose gracefully from where they had been kneeling against the walls, clean-limbed and comely in their filmy white robes. All had been purchased for their appearance as much as their skills, and they were very skilled. They had become used to the motions of the ship during the long voyage from Seanchan, and they scurried to fetch the garments that had already been laid out atop the carved chests and bring them to Selucia. Selucia never allowed the da'covale to actually dress her, not so much as stockings or slippers.

wən ʃi sɛɾəld ə pliɾɪd ɡaʊn ðə kʌlɝ ʌv wɛl-eɪdʒd aɪvɝi oʊvɝ tuɑnz hɛd, ðə jʌŋɡɝ wʊmən kəd nɑt hɛlp kəmpɛɹɪŋ ðə tu ʌv əm ɪn ðə tɔl mɪɹɝ fæsən tə ði ɪnɝ wɔl. ɡoʊldən-hɛɹd sɪlutʃə pəzɛst ə steɪtli, kɹim-skɪn bjuɾi ən kul blu aɪz. ɛniwʌn maɪɾ əv teɪkən əɹ fəɹ wʌn ə ðə blʌd, ən ə haɪ ɹæŋk, ɹæðɝ ðən sɔɪhɪn, ɪf ðə lɛf saɪɾ ə hɝ hɛd hæd nɑt bɪn ʃeɪvd. ə noʊʃən ðət wʊɾə ʃɑk ðə wʊmən tə ðə kwɪk, ɪkspɹɛst əlaʊd. ðə vɛɹi aɪdiə ʌv ɛni stɛpɪŋ əbʌv əɹ əpɔɪntəd steɪʃən hɔɹəfaɪd sɪlutʃə. tuɑn nu ʃi hɝsɛlf wəd nɛvɝ əv sətʃ ə kəmændɪŋ pɹɛzəns. hɝ aɪz wɝ tu lɑɹdʒ, ən ə lɪkwəd bɹaʊn. wən ʃi fɝɡɑt tə kip ə stɝn mæsk, hɝ hɑɹt-ʃeɪp feɪs bɪlɔŋd ɑn ə mɪstʃəvəs tʃaɪld. ðə tɑp ə hɝ hɛd bɛɹli keɪm tə sɪlutʃəz aɪz, ən əɹ dʒɹɛsɝ wɑz nɑɾ ə tɔl wʊmən. tuɑn kəd ɹaɪd wɪð ðə bɛst, ʃi ɪksɛld ət ɹɛslɪŋ ən ðə jus ə suɾəbəl wɛpənz, bʌt ʃi hæɾ ɔlweɪz hæd tə ɛksɝsaɪz əɹ maɪn tə ɪmpɹɛs. ʃi hæd tʃɹeɪn ðət tul əz hɑɹɾ əz ʃi hæd tʃɹeɪn əɾ ɛvɹi ʌðɝ tælən kəmbaɪnd. ət lis ðə waɪd, woʊvən bɛlt ʌv ɡoʊld ɛmfəsaɪzd əɹ weɪst ɪnʌf ðət ʃi wəd nɑt bi teɪkən fəɹ ə bɔɪ ɪn ə dʒɹɛs. mɛn wɑtʃt wən sɪlutʃə pæs baɪ, ən tuɑn hæɾ oʊvɝhɝd səm mɝmɝ əbaʊɾ əɹ fʊl bɹɛsts. pɝhæps ðət hæd nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð ə kəmændɪŋ pɹɛzəns, bʌɾ ɪt wʊɾə bɪn naɪs tə pəzɛs ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ bʊzəm.

When she settled a pleated gown the color of well-aged ivory over Tuon's head, the younger woman could not help comparing the two of them in the tall mirror fastened to the inner wall. Golden-haired Selucia possessed a stately, cream-skinned beauty and cool blue eyes. Anyone might have taken her for one of the Blood, and of high rank, rather than so'jhin, if the left side of her head had not been shaved. A notion that would have shocked the woman to the quick, expressed aloud. The very idea of any stepping above her appointed station horrified Selucia. Tuon knew she herself would never have such a commanding presence. Her eyes were too large, and a liquid brown. When she forgot to keep a stern mask, her heart-shaped face belonged on a mischievous child. The top of her head barely came to Selucia's eyes, and her dresser was not a tall woman. Tuon could ride with the best, she excelled at wrestling and the use of suitable weapons, but she had always had to exercise her mind to impress. She had trained that tool as hard as she had trained at every other talent combined. At least the wide, woven belt of gold emphasized her waist enough that she would not be taken for a boy in a dress. Men watched when Selucia passed by, and Tuon had overheard some murmur about her full breasts. Perhaps that had nothing to do with a commanding presence, but it would have been nice to possess a little more bosom.

"ðə laɪt bi əpɑn mi," sɪlutʃə mɝmɝd, saʊndɪŋ əmjuzd, əz ðə dækoʊvæl hɝid bæk tə nil əpɹaɪɾ əɡɛns ðə wɔlz. "juv dʌn ðəɾ ɛvɹi mɔɹnɪŋ sɪns ðə fɝs deɪ jəɹ hɛd wɑz ʃeɪvd. dʒju stɪl θɪŋk æftɝ θɹi jɪɹz ðəɾ əl liv ə pætʃ ə stʌbəl?"

"The Light be upon me," Selucia murmured, sounding amused, as the da'covale hurried back to kneel upright against the walls. "You've done that every morning since the first day your head was shaved. Do you still think after three years that I'll leave a patch of stubble?"

tuɑn ɹilaɪz ðət ʃi hæd ɹʌbd ə hæn əkɹɔs əɹ bɛɹ skælp. sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ stʌbəl, ʃi ədmɪɾəd tə hɝsɛlf ɹufəli. "ɪf jə dɪd," ʃi sɛd wɪð mɑk sɪvɛɹɪɾi, "aɪ wəɾ əv jə biɾən. ə ɹipeɪmən fəɹ ɔl ðə taɪmz jə juzd ə swɪtʃ ɑn mi."

Tuon realized that she had rubbed a hand across her bare scalp. Searching for stubble, she admitted to herself ruefully. "If you did," she said with mock severity, "I would have you beaten. A repayment for all the times you used a switch on me."

pleɪsɪŋ ə ɹoʊp ə ɹubiz ɝaʊn tuɑnz nɛk, sɪlutʃə læft. "ɪf jə peɪ mi bæk fəɹ ɔl ðæt, əl nɛvɝ bi eɪbəl tə sɪt daʊn əɡɛn."

Placing a rope of rubies around Tuon's neck, Selucia laughed. "If you pay me back for all that, I'll never be able to sit down again."
