tuɑn smaɪld. sɪlutʃəz mʌðɝ hæd ɡɪvən əɹ tə tuɑn fəɹ ə kɹeɪɾəl-ɡɪft, tə bi hɝ nɝsmeɪd, ən mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt, hɝ ʃædoʊ, ə bɑɾiɡɑɹd noʊ wʌn nu əbaʊt. ðə fɝs twɛnti-faɪv jɪɹz ə sɪlutʃəz laɪf hæd bɪn tʃɹeɪnɪŋ fəɹ ðoʊz dʒɑbz, tʃɹeɪnɪŋ ɪn sikɹət fəɹ ðə sɛkənd. ɑn tuɑnz sɪkstinθ neɪmɪŋ deɪ, wən əɹ hɛd wɑz fɝst ʃeɪvd, ʃi hæd meɪd ðə tʃɹədɪʃənəl ɡɪfs ə hɝ haʊs tə sɪlutʃə, ə smɔl ɪsteɪt fəɹ ðə kɛɹ ʃi hæd ʃoʊn, ə pɑɹɾən fəɹ ðə tʃæstaɪsməns ʃi hæd ɡɪvən, ə sæk ʌv wʌn hʌnʒɹəd ɡoʊldən θɹoʊnz fəɹ itʃ taɪm ʃi hæd niɾəd tə pʌnɪʃ əɹ tʃɑɹdʒ. ðə blʌɾ əsɛmbəl tə wɑtʃ əɹ pɹizɛntəɾ əz ən ədʌl fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm hæd bɪn ɪmpɹɛs baɪ ɔl ðoʊz sæks ə kɔɪn, mɔɹ ðən mɛni ʌv əm cʊɾə leɪd hæn ɑn ðɛmsɛlvz. ʃi hæd bɪn . . . ənɹuli . . . əz ə tʃaɪld, nɑt tə mɛnʃən hɛdstʃɹɔŋ. ən ðə læs tʃɹədɪʃənəl ɡɪft: ði ɔfɝ fəɹ sɪlutʃə tə tʃuz wɛɹ ʃi wəd bi əpɔɪntəd nɛkst. tuɑn wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ wɛðɝ ʃi əɹ ðə wɑtʃɪŋ kɹaʊd hæd bɪn mɔɹ əstɑnɪʃt wən ðə dɪɡnəfaɪd wʊmən tɝn əɹ bæk ɑn paʊɝ ən əθɔɹəɾi, ən æskt ɪnstɛd tə bi tuɑnz dʒɹɛsɝ, hɝ tʃif meɪd. ən əɹ ʃædoʊ stɪl, ʌv kɔɹs, ðoʊ ðət wɑz nɑt meɪd pʌblɪk. ʃi hɝsɛlf hæd bɪn dɪlaɪɾəd.

Tuon smiled. Selucia's mother had given her to Tuon for a cradle-gift, to be her nursemaid, and more important, her shadow, a bodyguard no one knew about. The first twenty-five years of Selucia's life had been training for those jobs, training in secret for the second. On Tuon's sixteenth naming day, when her head was first shaved, she had made the traditional gifts of her House to Selucia, a small estate for the care she had shown, a pardon for the chastisements she had given, a sack of one hundred golden thrones for each time she had needed to punish her charge. The Blood assembled to watch her presented as an adult for the first time had been impressed by all those sacks of coin, more than many of them could have laid hand on themselves. She had been . . . unruly . . . as a child, not to mention headstrong. And the last traditional gift: the offer for Selucia to choose where she would be appointed next. Tuon was not sure whether she or the watching crowd had been more astonished when the dignified woman turned her back on power and authority, and asked instead to be Tuon's dresser, her chief maid. And her shadow still, of course, though that was not made public. She herself had been delighted.

"pɝhæps ɪn smɔl doʊsəz, spɹɛɾ oʊvɝ sɪkstin jɪɹz," ʃi sɛd. kætʃɪŋ saɪɾ ə hɝsɛlf ɪn ðə mɪɹɝ, ʃi hɛld əɹ smaɪl lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ðəɹ wɑz noʊ stɪŋ ɪn əɹ wɝdz, ðən ɹipleɪst ɪt wɪð stɝnnəs. ʃi sɝɾənli fɛl mɔɹ əfɛkʃən fəɹ ðə wʊmən u hæd ɹeɪzd əɹ ðən fəɹ ðə mʌðɝ ʃi hæd sin oʊnli twaɪs ə jɪɹ bɪfɔɹ bɪkʌmɪŋ ən ədʌlt, əɹ ðə bɹʌðɝz ən sɪstɝz ʃi hæd bɪn tɔt fɹəm əɹ fɝst stɛps tə bæɾəl fəɹ ðɛɹ mʌðɝz feɪvɝ. tu ʌv əm hæd daɪɾ ɪn ðoʊz stʃɹʌɡəlz, soʊ fɑɹ, ən θɹi hæd tʃɹaɪd tə kɪl hɝ. ə sɪstɝ ən ə bɹʌðɝ hæd bɪn meɪd dækoʊvæl ən hæd ðɛɹ neɪmz stʃɹɪkən fɹəm ðə ɹɛkɝdz əz fɝmli əz ɪf ɪt hæd bɪn dɪskʌvɝd ðeɪ kəd tʃænəl. hɝ pleɪs wɑz fɑɹ fɹəm sɪkjʊɹ ivən naʊ. ə sɪŋɡəl mɪsstɛp kəd si hɝ dɛd, əɹ wɝs, stʃɹɪpt ən soʊld ɑn ðə pʌblɪk blɑk. blɛsɪŋz ə ðə laɪt, wən ʃi smaɪld, ʃi stɪl lʊk sɪkstin! ət bɛst!

"Perhaps in small doses, spread over sixteen years," she said. Catching sight of herself in the mirror, she held her smile long enough to make sure there was no sting in her words, then replaced it with sternness. She certainly felt more affection for the woman who had raised her than for the mother she had seen only twice a year before becoming an adult, or the brothers and sisters she had been taught from her first steps to battle for their mother's favor. Two of them had died in those struggles, so far, and three had tried to kill her. A sister and a brother had been made da'covale and had their names stricken from the records as firmly as if it had been discovered they could channel. Her place was far from secure even now. A single misstep could see her dead, or worse, stripped and sold on the public block. Blessings of the Light, when she smiled, she still looked sixteen! At best!

tʃʌklɪŋ, sɪlutʃə tɝn tə teɪk ðə kloʊs-fɪɾɪŋ kæp ʌv ɡoʊldən leɪs fɹəm ɪts ɹɛd-lækɝd stæn ɑn ðə dʒɹɛsɪŋ teɪbəl. ðə spɑɹs leɪs wəɾ ɪkspoʊz moʊst ə hɝ ʃeɪvən skælp, ən mɑɹk əɹ wɪð ðə ɹeɪvən-ænd-ɹoʊzɪz. pɝhæps ʃi wɑz nɑt siməsiv, bʌt fəɹ ðə seɪk ə ðə kɔɝɪn, ʃi hæd tə ɹɪstɔɹ əɹ bæləns. ʃi kəɾ æsk ænæθ, hɝ soʊfiə, tə ədmɪnəstɝ ə pɛnəns, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz lɛs ðən tu jɪɹz sɪns nɛfɛɹiz ʌnɪkspɛktɪd dɛθ, ən ʃi stɪl wɑz nɑɾ ɪntaɪɝli kʌmftəɹbəl wɪð əɹ ɹɪpleɪsmənt. sʌmθɪŋ toʊld əɹ ʃi mʌs də ðɪs ɑn əɹ oʊn. pɝhæps ʃi hæd sin ən oʊmən ʃi hæd nɑt ɹɛkəɡnaɪz kɑnʃəsli. æns wɝ nɑt laɪkli ɑn ə ʃɪp, bʌt sɛvɹəl sɔɹts ə biɾəl maɪt bi.

Chuckling, Selucia turned to take the close-fitting cap of golden lace from its red-lacquered stand on the dressing table. The sparse lace would expose most of her shaven scalp, and mark her with the Raven-and-Roses. Perhaps she was not sei'mosiev, but for the sake of the Corenne, she had to restore her balance. She could ask Anath, her Soe'feia, to administer a penance, but it was less than two years since Neferi's unexpected death, and she still was not entirely comfortable with her replacement. Something told her she must do this on her own. Perhaps she had seen an omen she had not recognized consciously. Ants were not likely on a ship, but several sorts of beetle might be.

"noʊ, sɪlutʃə," ʃi sɛd kwaɪətli. "ə veɪl."

"No, Selucia," she said quietly. "A veil."

sɪlutʃəz maʊθ taɪɾənd ɪn dɪsəpɹuvəl, bʌt ʃi ɹipleɪs ðə kæp ɑn ɪts stæn saɪlənli. ɪn pɹaɪvət, əz naʊ, ʃi hæd laɪsəns tə fɹi hɝ tʌŋ, jɛt ʃi nu wʌt kəd bi spoʊkən ən wʌt nɑt. tuɑn hæɾ oʊnli ɛvɝ hæd tə hæv əɹ pʌnɪʃt twaɪs, ən laɪts tʃɹuθ, ʃi hæd ɹɪɡɹɛɾɪd ɪɾ əz mʌtʃ əz sɪlutʃə. wɝdləsli, hɝ dʒɹɛsɝ pɹədust ə lɔŋ ʃɪɹ veɪl, dʒɹeɪpɪŋ ɪɾ oʊvɝ tuɑnz hɛɾ ən sɪkjʊɹɪŋ ɪt wɪð ə nɛɹoʊ bæn ʌv ɡoʊldən bɹeɪd sɛt wɪð ɹubiz. ivən mɔɹ tʃɹænspɛɹən ðən ðə dækoʊvælz ɹoʊbz, ðə veɪl dɪd nɑt haɪɾ əɹ feɪs əɾ ɔl. bʌɾ ɪt hɪd wʌt wɑz moʊst ɪmpɔɹɾənt.

Selucia's mouth tightened in disapproval, but she replaced the cap on its stand silently. In private, as now, she had license to free her tongue, yet she knew what could be spoken and what not. Tuon had only ever had to have her punished twice, and Light's truth, she had regretted it as much as Selucia. Wordlessly, her dresser produced a long sheer veil, draping it over Tuon's head and securing it with a narrow band of golden braid set with rubies. Even more transparent than the da'covale's robes, the veil did not hide her face at all. But it hid what was most important.

leɪɪŋ ə lɔŋ, ɡoʊld-ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd blu keɪp ɑn tuɑnz ʃoʊldɝz, sɪlutʃə stɛp bæk ən baʊd dipli, ði ɛn ə hɝ ɡoʊldən bɹeɪd tʌtʃɪŋ ðə kɑɹpət. ðə nilɪŋ dækoʊvæl baʊd ðɛɹ feɪsəz tə ðə dɛk. pɹaɪvəsi wɑz əbaʊt tə ɛnd. tuɑn lɛf ðə kæbən əloʊn.

Laying a long, gold-embroidered blue cape on Tuon's shoulders, Selucia stepped back and bowed deeply, the end of her golden braid touching the carpet. The kneeling da'covale bowed their faces to the deck. Privacy was about to end. Tuon left the cabin alone.

ɪn ðə sɛkən kæbən stʊd sɪks ə hɝ sʌldəm, θɹi tə iðɝ saɪd, wɪð ðɛɹ tʃɑɹdʒəz nilɪŋ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðɛm ɑn ðə waɪd, pɑlɪʃt plæŋks ə ðə dɛk. ðə sʌldəm stʃɹeɪɾənd wən ðeɪ sɔ hɝ, pɹaʊɾ əz ðə sɪlvɝ laɪtnɪŋ ɪn ðə ɹɛd pænəlz ɑn ðɛɹ skɝts. ðə ɡɹeɪ-klæd deɪmeɪn nɛlt ɪɹɛkt, fʊl ə ðɛɹ oʊn pɹaɪd. ɪksɛp fəɹ pʊɹ lɪdʒjə, hu kɹaʊtʃt oʊvɝ əɹ niz ən tʃɹaɪd tə pɹɛs əɹ tɝsteɪn feɪs əɡɛns ðə dɛk. iənɛl, hoʊldɪŋ ðə ɹɛd-hɛɹd deɪmeɪnz liʃ, skaʊl daʊn ət hɝ.

In the second cabin stood six of her sul'dam, three to either side, with their charges kneeling in front of them on the wide, polished planks of the deck. The sul'dam straightened when they saw her, proud as the silver lightning in the red panels on their skirts. The gray-clad damane knelt erect, full of their own pride. Except for poor Lidya, who crouched over her knees and tried to press her tearstained face against the deck. Ianelle, holding the red-haired damane's leash, scowled down at her.

tuɑn saɪd. lɪdʒjə hæd bɪn ɹispɑnsəbəl fəɹ əɹ æŋɡɝ læs naɪt. noʊ, ʃi hæd kɑzd ɪt, bʌt tuɑn hɝsɛlf wɑz ɹispɑnsəbəl fəɹ əɹ oʊn ɪmoʊʃənz. ʃi hæd kəmændəd ðə deɪmeɪn tə ɹiɾ əɹ fɔɹtʃən, ən ʃi ʃəd nɑɾ əv ɔɹɾɝd əɹ keɪn kəz ʃi dɪslaɪkt wʌt ʃi hɝd.

Tuon sighed. Lidya had been responsible for her anger last night. No, she had caused it, but Tuon herself was responsible for her own emotions. She had commanded the damane to read her fortune, and she should not have ordered her caned because she disliked what she heard.

bɛndɪŋ, ʃi kʌp lɪdʒjəz tʃɪn, leɪɪŋ lɔŋ ɹɛd-ɪnæməl fɪŋɡɝneɪlz əɡɛns ðə deɪmeɪnz fɹɛkəl tʃik, ən dʒɹu hɝ ʌp tə sɪɾ ɑn əɹ hilz. wɪtʃ pɹədust ə wɪns ən ə fɹɛʃ sɛɾ ə tɪɹz ðət tuɑn kɛɹfəli waɪpt əweɪ wɪð əɹ fɪŋɡɝz əz ʃi pʊl ðə deɪmeɪn əpɹaɪɾ ɑn əɹ niz. "lɪdʒjə ɪz ə ɡʊd deɪmeɪn, iənɛl," ʃi sɛd. "peɪn əɹ wɛls wɪð tɪŋktʃɝ ə sɔɹfə ən ɡɪv əɹ laɪənhɑɹt fəɹ ðə peɪn əntɪl ðə wɛls ɑɹ ɡɔn. ən əntɪl ðeɪ ɑɹ ɡɔn, ʃiz tə hæv ə swit kʌstɝd wɪð ɛvɹi mil."

Bending, she cupped Lidya's chin, laying long red-enameled fingernails against the damane's freckled cheek, and drew her up to sit on her heels. Which produced a wince and a fresh set of tears that Tuon carefully wiped away with her fingers as she pulled the damane upright on her knees. "Lidya is a good damane, Ianelle," she said. "Paint her welts with tincture of sorfa and give her lionheart for the pain until the welts are gone. And until they are gone, she is to have a sweet custard with every meal."

"æz ðə haɪ leɪɾi kəmænz," iənɛl ɹɪplaɪd fɔɹməli, bʌt ʃi smaɪl slaɪtli. ɔl ðə sʌldəm wɝ fɑn ə lɪdʒjə, ən ʃi hæd nɑt laɪk pʌnɪʃɪŋ ðə deɪmeɪn. "ɪf ʃi ɡɛts fæt, əl teɪk əɹ fəɹ ɹʌnz, haɪ leɪɾi."

"As the High Lady commands," Ianelle replied formally, but she smiled slightly. All the sul'dam were fond of Lidya, and she had not liked punishing the damane. "If she gets fat, I will take her for runs, High Lady."

lɪdʒjə twɪstəɾ əɹ hɛɾ ɝaʊn tə kɪs tuɑnz pɑm ən mɝmɝd, "lɪdʒjəz mɪstʃɹəs ɪz kaɪnd. lɪdʒjə wɪl nɑt ɡɛt fæt."

Lidya twisted her head around to kiss Tuon's palm and murmured, "Lidya's mistress is kind. Lidya will not get fat."

meɪkɪŋ əɹ weɪ əlɔŋ ðə tu laɪnz, tuɑn spoʊk ə fju wɝdz tə itʃ sʌldəm ən pɛɾəd itʃ ə ðə deɪmeɪn. ðə sɪks ʃi hæd bɹɔt wɪð əɹ wɝ əɹ bɛst, ən ðeɪ bimd əɾ əɹ wɪð ə fɑndnəs ikwəl tə hɝz fəɹ ðɛm. ðeɪ hæd kəmpiɾɪd iɡɝli tə bi tʃoʊzən. plʌmp, jɛloʊ-hɛɹd dɑli ən dɑni, sɪstɝz u hɑɹdli niɾəd ə sʌldəmz dɝɛkʃən. tʃæəl, hɝ hɛɹ əz ɡɹeɪ əz əɹ aɪz, bʌt stɪl ðə moʊst ædʒəl ɪn əɹ spɪnɪŋ. sɪɹə, wɪð ɹɛd ɹɪbənz ɪn əɹ taɪtli kɝl blæk hɛɹ, ðə stʃɹɔŋɡəst, ən pɹaʊɾ əz ə sʌldəm. taɪni maɪələn, ʃɔɹɾɝ ivən ðən tuɑn hɝsɛlf. maɪələn wɑz tuɑnz spɛʃəl pɹaɪɾ əmʌŋ ðə sɪks.

Making her way along the two lines, Tuon spoke a few words to each sul'dam and petted each of the damane. The six she had brought with her were her best, and they beamed at her with a fondness equal to hers for them. They had competed eagerly to be chosen. Plump, yellow-haired Dali and Dani, sisters who hardly needed a sul'dam's direction. Charral, her hair as gray as her eyes, but still the most agile in her spinning. Sera, with red ribbons in her tightly curled black hair, the strongest, and proud as a sul'dam. Tiny Mylen, shorter even than Tuon herself. Mylen was Tuon's special pride among the six.

mɛni hæd θɔɾ ɪɾ ɑd wən tuɑn tɛstəd fəɹ sʌldəm ɑn ɹitʃɪŋ ədʌlthʊd, ðoʊ nʌn kəd ɡeɪnseɪ hɝ, ðɛn. ɪksɛpt əɹ mʌðɝ, hu hæɾ əlaʊɾ ɪt baɪ ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ saɪlənt. æktʃəli  bɪkʌmɪŋ ə sʌldəm wɑz ənθɪŋkəbəl, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌt ʃi faʊn əz mʌtʃ ɛndʒɔɪmən ɪn tʃɹeɪnɪŋ deɪmeɪn əz ɪn tʃɹeɪnɪŋ hɔɹsəz, ən ʃi wɑz əz ɡʊɾ ət wʌn əz ði ʌðɝ. maɪələn wɑz ðə pɹuf ə ðæt. ðə peɪl lɪɾəl deɪmeɪn hæd bɪn hæf-dɛd wɪð ʃɑk ən fɪɹ, ɹəfjuzɪŋ tə iɾ əɹ dʒɹɪŋk, wən tuɑn bɑɾ əɹ ɑn ðə dɑks ət ʃɑn kɪfɑɹ. ðə dɝsʌldəm ɔl hæd dɪspɛɹd, seɪɪŋ ʃi wəd nɑt laɪv lɔŋ, bʌt naʊ maɪələn smaɪld ʌp ət tuɑn ən lin fɔɹwɝd tə kɪs əɹ hæn bɪfɔɹ ʃi ivən ɹitʃt tə stʃɹoʊk ðə deɪmeɪnz dɑɹk hɛɹ. wʌns skɪn ən boʊnz, ʃi wɑz bɪkʌmɪŋ ə tʃɹaɪfəl plʌmp. ɪnstɛɾ ə ɹibjukɪŋ hɝ, kætʃɹoʊnə, hu hɛld əɹ liʃ, lɛɾ ə smaɪl kɹis əɹ juʒəwəli stɝn blæk feɪs ən mɝmɝd ðət maɪələn wɑz ə pɝfək deɪmeɪn. ɪt wɑz tʃɹu, noʊ wʌn wəd bɪliv naʊ ðət wʌns ʃi hæd kɔl hɝsɛlf ɛɛs sədaɪ.

Many had thought it odd when Tuon tested for sul'dam on reaching adulthood, though none could gainsay her, then. Except her mother, who had allowed it by remaining silent. Actually becoming a sul'dam was unthinkable, of course, but she found as much enjoyment in training damane as in training horses, and she was as good at one as the other. Mylen was the proof of that. The pale little damane had been half-dead with shock and fear, refusing to eat or drink, when Tuon bought her on the docks at Shon Kifar. The der'sul'dam all had despaired, saying she would not live long, but now Mylen smiled up at Tuon and leaned forward to kiss her hand before she even reached to stroke the damane's dark hair. Once skin and bones, she was becoming a trifle plump. Instead of rebuking her, Catrona, who held her leash, let a smile crease her usually stern black face and murmured that Mylen was a perfect damane. It was true, no one would believe now that once she had called herself Aes Sedai.

bɪfɔɹ livɪŋ, tuɑn ɡeɪv ə fju ɔɹɾɝz kənsɝnɪŋ ðə deɪmeɪnz daɪəɾ ən ɛksɝsaɪz. ðə sʌldəm nu wʌt tə du, dʒʌs laɪk ði ʌðɝ twɛlv ɪn tuɑnz ɑntʊɹɑʒ, əɹ ðeɪ wəd nɑɾ əv bɪn ɪn əɹ sɝvəs, bʌt ʃi bɪliv noʊ wʌn ʃəd bi əlaʊd tə oʊn deɪmeɪn ənlɛs ðeɪ tʊk ən æktɪv ɪntʃɹəst. ʃi nu ðə kwɝks ʌv ɛvɹi wʌn ə hɝz əz wɛl əz ʃi nu hɝ oʊn feɪs.

Before leaving, Tuon gave a few orders concerning the damane's diet and exercise. The sul'dam knew what to do, just like the other twelve in Tuon's entourage, or they would not have been in her service, but she believed no one should be allowed to own damane unless they took an active interest. She knew the quirks of every one of hers as well as she knew her own face.

ɪn ði aʊɾɝ kæbən, ðə dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹdz, laɪnɪŋ ðə wɔlz ɪn ɑɹmɝ lækɝd blʌd ɹɛɾ ən nɪɹli blæk ɡɹin, stɪfən əɾ əɹ ɛntʃɹəns. ðəɾ ɪz, ðeɪ stɪfən ɪf stætʃuz kəd bi sɛd tə stɪfən. hɑɹd-feɪs mɛn, ðeɪ ən faɪv hʌnʒɹəd mɔɹ laɪk əm hæd bɪn tʃɑɹdʒ pɝsənəli wɪð tuɑnz seɪfti. ɛni əɹ ɔl wəd daɪ tə pɹətɛk hɝ. ðeɪ wəd daɪ ɪf ʃi dɪd. ɛvɹi mæn hæd vɑləntɪɹd, æsk tə bi ɪn əɹ ɡɑɹd. siɪŋ ðə veɪl, ɡɹɪzəl kæptən mjuzənʒ ɔɹɾɝd oʊnli tu tə əkʌmpəni hɝ ɑn dɛk, wɛɹ tu dʌzən oʊɡiɝ ɡɑɹɾənɝz ɪn ðə ɹɛd-ænd-ɡɹin meɪɾ ə laɪn tə iðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə dɔɹweɪ, ɡɹeɪt blæk-tæsɛld æksiz əpɹaɪɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðɛm ən ɡɹɪm aɪz wɑtʃɪŋ fəɹ ɛni deɪnʒɝ ivən hɪɹ. ðeɪ wəd nɑt daɪ ɪf ʃi dɪd, bʌt ðeɪ ɔlsoʊ hæɾ æsk tə bi ɪn əɹ ɡɑɹd, ən ʃi wəd ɹɛst əɹ laɪf ɪn ɛni ʌv ðoʊz hjudʒ hænz wɪθaʊɾ ə kwɑm.

In the outer cabin, the Deathwatch Guards, lining the walls in armor lacquered blood red and nearly black green, stiffened at her entrance. That is, they stiffened if statues could be said to stiffen. Hard-faced men, they and five hundred more like them had been charged personally with Tuon's safety. Any or all would die to protect her. They would die if she did. Every man had volunteered, asked to be in her guard. Seeing the veil, grizzled Captain Musenge ordered only two to accompany her on deck, where two dozen Ogier Gardeners in the red-and-green made a line to either side of the doorway, great black-tasseled axes upright in front of them and grim eyes watching for any danger even here. They would not die if she did, but they also had asked to be in her guard, and she would rest her life in any of those huge hands without a qualm.

ðə ɹɪb seɪlz ɑn ðə kɪdʒɹɑnz θɹi tɔl mæsts wɝ tɔt wɪð ðə koʊld wɪn ðət dʒɹoʊv ðə vɛsəl təwɔɹd ðə læn ðət leɪ əhɛd, ə dɑɹk ʃɔɹ nɪɹ ɪnʌf ðət ʃi kəd meɪk aʊt hɪlz ən hɛdlænz. mɛn ən wɪmən fɪl ðə dɛk, ɔl ə ðə blʌɾ ɑn ðə vɛsəl ɪn ðɛɹ faɪnəst sɪlks, ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ðə wɪn ðət wɪp ðɛɹ kloʊks əz ðeɪ ɪɡnɔɹd ðə bɛɹfʊt mɛn ən wɪmən ə ðə ʃɪps kɹu hu dɑɹɾɪd bɪtwin ðɛm. səm ə ðə noʊbəlz wɝ mʌtʃ tu ɑstənteɪʃəs əbaʊɾ ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ðə kɹu, əz ðoʊ ðeɪ kəd ɹʌn ðə ʃɪp waɪl nilɪŋ əɹ boʊɪŋ ɛvɹi tu peɪsɪz. pɹipɛɹd fəɹ pɹɑstʃɹeɪʃən, ðə blʌd meɪd slaɪt baʊz ɪnstɛd, wʌn ikwəl tə ənʌðɝ, wən ðeɪ sɔ hɝ veɪl. jʊɹəl, ðə ʃɑɹp-noʊz mæn ɛvɹiwʌn θɔt wɑz əɹ sɛkɹətɛɹi, wɛn tə wʌn ni. hi wɑz əɹ sɛkɹətɛɹi, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌɾ ɔlsoʊ hɝ hænd, kəmændɪŋ əɹ sikɝz. ðə məkʊə wʊmən flʌŋ hɝsɛlf daʊn pɹɑstʃɹeɪɾ ən kɪs ðə dɛk bɪfɔɹ ə fju kwaɪət wɝdz fɹəm jʊɹəl meɪɾ əɹ ɡɛt bæk tə hɝ fit blʌʃɪŋ ən smuðɪŋ əɹ pliɾɪd ɹɛd skɝts. tuɑn hæd bɪn ənsɝɾən əbaʊt teɪkɪŋ əɹ ɪndə sɝvəs, bæk ɪn tæntʃəkoʊ, bʌt ðə wʊmən hæd pliɾəd laɪk ə dækoʊvæl. ʃi heɪɾəd ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn əɹ boʊnz, fəɹ səm ɹizən, ən dɪspaɪt ðə ɹɪwɔɹdz ɔlɹɛɾi ɡɪvən fəɹ əɹ ɪkstʃɹimli væljəbəl ɪnfɝmeɪʃən, ʃi hoʊp tə də ðɛm mɔɹ ɪnʒɝi.

The ribbed sails on the Kidron's three tall masts were taut with the cold wind that drove the vessel toward the land that lay ahead, a dark shore near enough that she could make out hills and headlands. Men and women filled the deck, all of the Blood on the vessel in their finest silks, ignoring the wind that whipped their cloaks as they ignored the barefoot men and women of the ship's crew who darted between them. Some of the nobles were much too ostentatious about ignoring the crew, as though they could run the ship while kneeling or bowing every two paces. Prepared for prostration, the Blood made slight bows instead, one equal to another, when they saw her veil. Yuril, the sharp-nosed man everyone thought was her secretary, went to one knee. He was her secretary, of course, but also her Hand, commanding her Seekers. The Macura woman flung herself down prostrate and kissed the deck before a few quiet words from Yuril made her get back to her feet blushing and smoothing her pleated red skirts. Tuon had been uncertain about taking her into service, back in Tanchico, but the woman had pleaded like a da'covale. She hated Aes Sedai in her bones, for some reason, and despite the rewards already given for her extremely valuable information, she hoped to do them more injury.

boʊɪŋ əɹ hɛd tə ðə blʌd, tuɑn klaɪm tə ðə kɔɹɾɝdɛk fɑloʊd baɪ ðə tu dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹdz. ðə wɪn meɪd hænlɪŋ əɹ keɪp dɪfəkəlt, ən pɹɛst əɹ veɪl əɡɛnst əɹ feɪs wʌn moʊmənt, ðən fleɪld ɪɾ oʊvɝ əɹ hɛd ðə nɛkst. ɪt dɪd nɑt mæɾɝ; ðət ʃi wɔɹ ɪt wɑz səfɪʃənt. hɝ pɝsənəl bænɝ, tu ɡoʊldən laɪənz hɑɹnəs tə ən eɪntʃənt wɔɹ-kɑɹt, flu ət ðə stɝn əbʌv ðə sɪks hɛlmsmɪn stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ tə kəntʃɹoʊl ðə lɔŋ tɪlɝ. ðə ɹeɪvən-ænd-ɹoʊzɪz wʊɾə bɪn pækt əweɪ əz sun əz ðə fɝs kɹumən tə si hɝ veɪl kəd pæs ðə wɝd. kɪdʒɹɑnz kæptən, ə waɪd, wɛðɝd wʊmən wɪð waɪt hɛɹ ən ðə moʊst ɪnkɹɛɾəbəl ɡɹin aɪz, baʊɾ əz tuɑnz slɪpɝ tʌtʃt ðə kɔɹɾɝdɛk ðən ɪmiɾiətli ɹɪtɝn əɹ ətɛnʃən tə hɝ ʃɪp.

Bowing her head to the Blood, Tuon climbed to the quarterdeck followed by the two Deathwatch Guards. The wind made handling her cape difficult, and pressed her veil against her face one moment, then flailed it over her head the next. It did not matter; that she wore it was sufficient. Her personal banner, two golden lions harnessed to an ancient war-cart, flew at the stern above the six helmsmen struggling to control the long tiller. The Raven-and-Roses would have been packed away as soon as the first crewman to see her veil could pass the word. Kidron's captain, a wide, weathered woman with white hair and the most incredible green eyes, bowed as Tuon's slipper touched the quarterdeck then immediately returned her attention to her ship.

ænæθ wɑz stændɪŋ baɪ ðə ɹeɪlɪŋ, ɪn ʌnɹiliv blæk sɪlk, aʊtwɝdli ʌndɪstɝbd baɪ ðə tʃɪl wɪn ɪn spaɪɾ ə hɝ læk ʌv ə kloʊk əɹ keɪp. ə slɛndɝ wʊmən, ʃi wʊɾə bɪn tɔl ivən fəɹ ə mæn. hɝ tʃɑɹkoʊl-dɑɹk feɪs wɑz bjuɾəfəl, bʌɾ əɹ lɑɹdʒ blæk aɪz sim tə pɪɹs laɪk ɔlz. tuɑnz soʊfiə, hɝ tʃɹuθspikɝ, neɪm baɪ ði ɛmpɹɛs, maɪt ʃi laɪv fɝɛvɝ, wən nɛfɛɹi daɪd. ə sɝpɹaɪz, wɪð nɛfɛɹiz lɛf hæn tʃɹeɪn ən ɹɛɾi tə ɹipleɪs hɝ, bʌt wən ði ɛmpɹɛs spoʊk fɹəm ðə kɹɪstəl θɹoʊn, hɝ wɝd wɑz lɔ. jə sɝɾənli wɝ nɑt səpoʊz tə bi əfɹeɪɾ ə jəɹ soʊfiə, jɛt tuɑn wɑz, ə lɪɾəl. dʒɔɪnɪŋ ðə wʊmən, ʃi ɡɹɪp ðə ɹeɪlɪŋ, ən hæd tə lusən əɹ hænz bɪfɔɹ ʃi bɹoʊk ə lækɝd neɪl. ðət wʊɾə mɛn vɛɹi bæd lʌk.

Anath was standing by the railing, in unrelieved black silk, outwardly undisturbed by the chill wind in spite of her lack of a cloak or cape. A slender woman, she would have been tall even for a man. Her charcoal-dark face was beautiful, but her large black eyes seemed to pierce like awls. Tuon's Soe'feia, her Truthspeaker, named by the Empress, might she live forever, when Neferi died. A surprise, with Neferi's Left Hand trained and ready to replace her, but when the Empress spoke from the Crystal Throne, her word was law. You certainly were not supposed to be afraid of your Soe'feia, yet Tuon was, a little. Joining the woman, she gripped the railing, and had to loosen her hands before she broke a lacquered nail. That would have meant very bad luck.

"soʊ," ænæθ sɛd, ðə wɝd laɪk ə neɪl dʒɹɪvən ɪndə tuɑnz skʌl. ðə tɔl wʊmən fɹaʊn daʊn ət hɝ, ən kəntɛmp leɪ θɪk ɪn əɹ vɔɪs. "ju haɪd jəɹ feɪs - ɪn ə weɪ - ən naʊ jə ɑɹ dʒʌs ðə haɪ leɪɾi tuɑn. ɪksɛp ðəɾ ɛvɹiwʌn stɪl noʊz u jə ɹɪli ɑɹ, ivən ɪf ðeɪ woʊn mɛnʃən ɪt. haʊ lɔŋ dʒju ɪntɛn kæɹiɪŋ ɑn ðɪs fɑɹs?" ænæθs fʊl lɪps snɪɹd, ən ʃi meɪɾ ə kɝt, dɪsmɪsɪv dʒɛstʃɝ wɪð wʌn slɪm hænd. "aɪ səpoʊz ðɪs ɪɾiəsi ɪz oʊvɝ hævɪŋ ðə deɪmeɪn keɪnd. jə ɑɹ ə ful tə θɪŋk jəɹ aɪz ɑɹ daʊnkæs baɪ ə lɪɾəl θɪŋ laɪk ðæt. wʌd ʃi seɪ tə meɪk jə æŋɡɹi? noʊ wʌn simz tə noʊ, ɪksɛp ðət jə θɹu ə tæntʃɹəm aɪm sɑɹi tə hæv mɪst."

"So," Anath said, the word like a nail driven into Tuon's skull. The tall woman frowned down at her, and contempt lay thick in her voice. "You hide your face - in a way - and now you are just the High Lady Tuon. Except that everyone still knows who you really are, even if they won't mention it. How long do you intend carrying on this farce?" Anath's full lips sneered, and she made a curt, dismissive gesture with one slim hand. "I suppose this idiocy is over having the damane caned. You are a fool to think your eyes are downcast by a little thing like that. What did she say to make you angry? No one seems to know, except that you threw a tantrum I am sorry to have missed."

tuɑn meɪɾ əɹ hænz bi stɪl ɑn ðə ɹeɪlɪŋ. ðeɪ wɑntəd tə tʃɹɛmbəl. ʃi fɔɹst əɹ feɪs tə meɪnteɪn ə stɝn əpɪɹəns. "aɪ wɪl wɛɹ ðə veɪl əntɪl ən oʊmən tɛlz mi ðə taɪm əz kʌm tə ɹimuv ɪt, ænæθ," ʃi sɛd, skulɪŋ əɹ vɔɪs tə kɑm. oʊnli lʌk hæd kɛpt ɛniwʌn fɹəm oʊvɝhɪɹɪŋ lɪdʒjəz kɹɪptɪk wɝdz. ɛvɹiwʌn nu ðət deɪmeɪn kəd fɔɹtɛl ðə fjutʃɝ, ən ɪf ɛni ʌv ðə blʌd hæd hɝd, ðeɪ wəɾ ɔl əv bɪn tʃæɾɝɪŋ bɪhaɪn ðɛɹ hænz əbaʊɾ əɹ feɪt.

Tuon made her hands be still on the railing. They wanted to tremble. She forced her face to maintain a stern appearance. "I will wear the veil until an omen tells me the time has come to remove it, Anath," she said, schooling her voice to calm. Only luck had kept anyone from overhearing Lidya's cryptic words. Everyone knew that damane could foretell the future, and if any of the Blood had heard, they would all have been chattering behind their hands about her fate.

ænæθ læft ɹudli ən bɪɡæn tɛlɪŋ əɹ əɡɛn wʌɾ ə ful ʃi wɑz, ɪn ɡɹeɪɾɝ dɪteɪl ðɪs taɪm. mʌtʃ ɡɹeɪɾɝ dɪteɪl. ʃi dɪd nɑt bɑðɝ tə loʊɝ əɹ vɔɪs. kæptən teɪən wɑz stɛɹɪŋ stʃɹeɪɾ əhɛd, bʌɾ əɹ aɪz wɝ ɔlmoʊs fɔlɪŋ aʊɾ ə hɝ laɪn feɪs. tuɑn lɪsən ətɛntɪvli, ðoʊ hɝ tʃiks ɡɹu hɑɾɝ ən hɑɾɝ, əntɪl ʃi θɔɾ əɹ veɪl maɪt bɝst ɪndə fleɪm.

Anath laughed rudely and began telling her again what a fool she was, in greater detail this time. Much greater detail. She did not bother to lower her voice. Captain Tehan was staring straight ahead, but her eyes were almost falling out of her lined face. Tuon listened attentively, though her cheeks grew hotter and hotter, until she thought her veil might burst into flame.

mɛni ʌv ðə blʌd kɔl ðɛɹ vɔɪsəz soʊfiə, bʌt vɔɪsəz ə ðə blʌd wɝ sɔɪhɪn, ən nu ðeɪ kəd bi pʌnɪʃt ɪf ðɛɹ oʊnɝz wɝ dɪspliz baɪ wʌt ðeɪ sɛɾ ivən ɪf ðeɪ wɝ kɔl soʊfiə. eɪ spikɝ ə tʃɹuθ kəd nɑt bi kəmændəɾ əɹ koʊɝst əɹ pʌnɪʃt ɪn ɛni weɪ. eɪ tʃɹuθspikɝ wɑz ɹikwaɪɝd tə tɛl ðə stɑɹk tʃɹuθ wɛðɝ əɹ nɑt jə wɑntəd tə hɪɹ ɪt, ən tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ðət jə hɝd. ðoʊz blʌɾ u kɔl ðɛɹ vɔɪsəz soʊfiə θɔt ðəɾ ɑlɡwɪn, ðə læs mæn tə sɪɾ ɑn ðə kɹɪstəl θɹoʊn, ɔlmoʊst ə θaʊzən jɪɹz əɡoʊ, hæd bɪn ɪnseɪn kəz i lɛɾ ɪz soʊfiə lɪv ən kəntɪnju ɪn əɹ poʊst æftɝ ʃi slæpt ɪz feɪs bɪfɔɹ ði ɪntaɪɝ kɔɹt. ðeɪ dɪd nɑɾ ʌndɝstæn ðə tʃɹədɪʃənz ə hɝ fæmli ɛni mɔɹ ðən ðə ɡɑɡəl-aɪd kæptən dɪd. ðə dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹdz' ɪkspɹɛʃənz nɛvɝ ɔltɝd bɪhaɪn ðə hæf-kənsilɪŋ tʃik-pisəz ə ðɛɹ hɛlməts. ðeɪ ʌndɝstʊd.

Many of the Blood called their Voices Soe'feia, but Voices of the Blood were so'jhin, and knew they could be punished if their owners were displeased by what they said even if they were called Soe'feia. A Speaker of Truth could not be commanded or coerced or punished in any way. A Truthspeaker was required to tell the stark truth whether or not you wanted to hear it, and to make sure that you heard. Those Blood who called their Voices Soe'feia thought that Algwyn, the last man to sit on the Crystal Throne, almost a thousand years ago, had been insane because he let his Soe'feia live and continue in her post after she slapped his face before the entire court. They did not understand the traditions of her family any more than the goggle-eyed captain did. The Deathwatch Guards' expressions never altered behind the half-concealing cheek-pieces of their helmets. They understood.

"θæŋk ju, bʌɾ aɪ də nɑt niɾ ə pɛnəns," ʃi sɛd pəlaɪtli wən ænæθ faɪnəli sist əɹ hɝæŋ.

"Thank you, but I do not need a penance," she said politely when Anath finally ceased her harangue.

wʌns, æftɝ ʃi kɝs nɛfɛɹi fəɹ daɪɪŋ baɪ sʌmθɪŋ əz stupəɾ əz ə fɔl daʊn stɛɹz, ʃi hæɾ æskt əɹ nu soʊfiə tə pɝfɔɹm ðət sɝvəs fəɹ hɝ. kɝsɪŋ ðə dɛd wɑz ɪnʌf tə meɪk jə siməsiv fəɹ mʌnθs. ðə wʊmən hæd bɪn ɔlmoʊs tɛndɝ əbaʊɾ ɪt, ɪn ən ɑd fæʃən, ðoʊ ʃi lɛft əɹ wipɪŋ fəɹ deɪz, əneɪbəl tə dɑn ivən ə ʃɪft. ðət wɑz nɑt waɪ ʃi ɹəfjuz ði ɔfɝ, ðoʊ; ə pɛnəns mʌs bi səvɪɹ əɹ ɪt wɑz jusləs ɪn ɹidʒɹɛsɪŋ bæləns. noʊ, ʃi wəd nɑt teɪk ði iziɝ weɪ kəz ʃi hæd meɪɾ əɹ dɪsɪʒən. ænd, ʃi hæd tə ədmɪt, kəz ʃi wɑntəd tə ɹɪzɪst əɹ soʊfiəz ædvaɪs. wɑntəd nɑt tə lɪsən tə hɝ əɾ ɔl. əz sɪlutʃə sɛd, ʃi ɔlweɪz hæd bɪn hɛdstʃɹɔŋ. ɹəfjuzɪŋ tə lɪsən tə jəɹ tʃɹuθspikɝ wɑz əbɑmənəbəl. pɝhæps ʃi ʃəɾ æksɛpt æftɝ ɔl, tə ɹɪdʒɹɛs ðət bæləns. θɹi lɔŋ ɡɹeɪ pɔɹpəsəz ɹoʊz bɪsaɪd ðə ʃɪp ən saʊndəd. θɹi, ən ðeɪ dɪd nɑt ɹaɪz əɡɛn. hoʊl tə jəɹ tʃoʊzən kɔɹs.

Once, after she cursed Neferi for dying by something as stupid as a fall down stairs, she had asked her new Soe'feia to perform that service for her. Cursing the dead was enough to make you sei'mosiev for months. The woman had been almost tender about it, in an odd fashion, though she left her weeping for days, unable to don even a shift. That was not why she refused the offer, though; a penance must be severe or it was useless in redressing balance. No, she would not take the easier way because she had made her decision. And, she had to admit, because she wanted to resist her Soe'feia's advice. Wanted not to listen to her at all. As Selucia said, she always had been headstrong. Refusing to listen to your Truthspeaker was abominable. Perhaps she should accept after all, to redress that balance. Three long gray porpoises rose beside the ship and sounded. Three, and they did not rise again. Hold to your chosen course.

"wɛn wəɹ əʃɔɹ," ʃi sɛd, "ðə haɪ leɪɾi sjuɹɔθ mʌs bi kəmɛndɪd." hoʊl tə jəɹ tʃoʊzən kɔɹs. "æn əɹ æmbɪʃən mʌs bi lʊkt ɪntu. ʃiz dʌn mɔɹ wɪð ðə fɔɹʌnɝz ðən ði ɛmpɹɛs, meɪ ʃi laɪv fɝɛvɝ, dʒɹimd ʌv, bʌt səksɛs ɑn sətʃ ə skeɪl ɔfən bɹidz æmbɪʃənz tə mætʃ."

"When we are ashore," she said, "the High Lady Suroth must be commended." Hold to your chosen course. "And her ambition must be looked into. She has done more with the Forerunners than the Empress, may she live forever, dreamed of, but success on such a scale often breeds ambitions to match."

pivd ət ðə tʃeɪnʒ ə sʌbʒɪkt, ænæθ dʒɹu hɝsɛlf ʌp, lɪps kəmpɹɛsɪŋ. hɝ aɪz ɡlɪɾɝd. "aɪ æm ʃʊɹ sjuɹɔθ əz oʊnli ðə bɛst ɪntʃɹəsts ə ði ɛmpaɪɝ fəɹ æmbɪʃən," ʃi sɛd kɝtli.

Peeved at the change of subject, Anath drew herself up, lips compressing. Her eyes glittered. "I am sure Suroth has only the best interests of the Empire for ambition," she said curtly.

tuɑn nɑɾəd. ʃi hɝsɛlf wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ əɾ ɔl. ðət sɔɹɾ ə ʃʊɹnəs kəd lid tə ðə taʊɝ ə ðə ɹeɪvənz ivən fəɹ hɝ. pɝhæps ɪspɛʃli fəɹ hɝ. "aɪ mʌs faɪn ə weɪ tə meɪk kɑntækt wɪð ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn əz sun əz pɑsəbəl. hi mʌs nil bɪfɔɹ ðə kɹɪstəl θɹoʊn bɪfɔɹ tɑɹmən ɡdən, əɹ ɔl ɪz lɔst." ðə pɹɑfəsiz ə ðə dʒɹæɡən sɛd soʊ, klɪɹli.

Tuon nodded. She herself was not sure at all. That sort of sureness could lead to the Tower of the Ravens even for her. Perhaps especially for her. "I must find a way to make contact with the Dragon Reborn as soon as possible. He must kneel before the Crystal Throne before Tarmon Gai'don, or all is lost." The Prophecies of the Dragon said so, clearly.

ænæθs mud tʃeɪnʒd ɪn ə flæʃ. smaɪlɪŋ, ʃi leɪɾ ə hæn ɑn tuɑnz ʃoʊldɝ ɔlmoʊs pəzɛsɪvli. ðət wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ tu fɑɹ, bʌt ʃi wɑz soʊfiə, ən ðə fil ʌv oʊnɝʃɪp maɪɾ əv bɪn oʊnli ɪn tuɑnz maɪnd. "ju mʌs bi kɛɹfəl," ænæθ pɝd. "ju mʌs nɑt lɛɾ ɪm lɝn haʊ deɪnʒɝəs jə ɑɹ tə hɪm əntɪl ɪts tu leɪt fəɹ ɪm tə ɪskeɪp."

Anath's mood changed in a flash. Smiling, she laid a hand on Tuon's shoulder almost possessively. That was going too far, but she was Soe'feia, and the feel of ownership might have been only in Tuon's mind. "You must be careful," Anath purred. "You must not let him learn how dangerous you are to him until it is too late for him to escape."

ʃi hæd mɔɹ ædvaɪs, bʌt tuɑn lɛɾ ɪt wɑʃ oʊvɝ hɝ. ʃi lɪsən ɪnʌf tə hɪɹ, jɛɾ ɪt wɑz nʌθɪŋ ʃi hæd nɑt hɝɾ ə hʌnʒɹəd taɪmz bɪfɔɹ. əhɛɾ ə ðə ʃɪp ʃi kəd meɪk aʊt ðə maʊθ ʌv ə ɡɹeɪt hɑɹbɝ. ɛbu dɑɹ, fɹəm wɛɹ ðə kɔɝɪn wəd spɹɛd, əz ɪt wɑz spɹɛɾɪŋ fɹəm tæntʃəkoʊ. ðə θɔt ɡeɪv əɹ ə θɹɪl ə plɛʒɝ, ʌv əkɑmplɪʃmənt. bɪhaɪn əɹ veɪl, ʃi wɑz mɪɹli ðə haɪ leɪɾi tuɑn, ʌv hoʊ haɪɝ ɹæŋk ðən mɛni ʌðɝz ə ðə blʌd, bʌɾ ɪn əɹ hɑɹt, ɔlweɪz, ʃi wɑz tuɑn æθeɪɪm kɔɹ pɛndʒɹæɡ, dɔɾɝ ə ðə naɪn munz, ən ʃi hæd kʌm tə ɹikleɪm wʌt hæd bɪn stoʊlən fɹəm əɹ ænsɛstɝ.

She had more advice, but Tuon let it wash over her. She listened enough to hear, yet it was nothing she had not heard a hundred times before. Ahead of the ship she could make out the mouth of a great harbor. Ebou Dar, from where the Corenne would spread, as it was spreading from Tanchico. The thought gave her a thrill of pleasure, of accomplishment. Behind her veil, she was merely the High Lady Tuon, of ho higher rank than many others of the Blood, but in her heart, always, she was Tuon Athaem Kore Paendrag, Daughter of the Nine Moons, and she had come to reclaim what had been stolen from her ancestor.


tʃæptɝ fɪftin


CHAPTER 15

ɪn niɾ ʌv ə bɛlfndɝ


In Need of a Bellfounder

ðə bɑkslaɪk wæɡən ɹimaɪndəd mæt ə tɪŋkɝ wæɡənz i hæd sin, ə lɪɾəl haʊs ɑn wilz, ðoʊ ðɪs wʌn, fɪld wɪð kæbənəts ən wɝkbɛntʃɪz bɪlt ɪndə ðə wɔlz, wɑz nɑt meɪd fəɹ ə dwɛlɪŋ. ɹɪŋkəlɪŋ ɪz noʊz ət ði ɑd, ækɹɪd smɛlz ðət fɪl ði ɪntɪɹiɝ, hi ʃɪftəɾ ənkʌmftəbli ɑn ɪz θɹi-lɛɡəd stul, ði oʊnli pleɪs fəɹ ɛniwʌn tə sɪt. hɪz bɹoʊkən lɛɡ ən ɹɪbz wɝ nɪɹ ɪnʌf hild, ən ðə kʌts ðəɾ i hæd sʌfɝd wən ðət hoʊl blʌɾi bɪldɪŋ fɛl ɑn ɪz hɛd, bʌt ði ɪnʒɝiz stɪl peɪn ɪm naʊ ən ðɛn. bɪsaɪdz, hi wɑz hoʊpɪŋ fəɹ sɪmpəθi. wɪmən lʌv tə ʃoʊ sɪmpəθi, ɪf jə pleɪɾ ɪɾ aʊt ɹaɪt. hi meɪd hɪmsɛlf stɑp twɪstɪŋ ɪz lɔŋ sɪɡnɪt ɹɪŋ ɑn ɪz fɪŋɡɝ. lɛɾ ə wʊmən noʊ jə wɝ nɝvəs, ən ʃi pʊɾ əɹ oʊn kənstʃɹʌkʃən ɑn ɪt, ən sɪmpəθi wɛn ɹaɪɾ aʊt ðə wɪndoʊ.

The boxlike wagon reminded Mat of Tinker wagons he had seen, a little house on wheels, though this one, filled with cabinets and workbenches built into the walls, was not made for a dwelling. Wrinkling his nose at the odd, acrid smells that filled the interior, he shifted uncomfortably on his three-legged stool, the only place for anyone to sit. His broken leg and ribs were near enough healed, and the cuts that he had suffered when that whole bloody building fell on his head, but the injuries still pained him now and then. Besides, he was hoping for sympathy. Women loved to show sympathy, if you played it out right. He made himself stop twisting his long signet ring on his finger. Let a woman know you were nervous, and she put her own construction on it, and sympathy went right out the window.

"lɪsən, ɑlʌdʒɹə," hi sɛd, əsumɪŋ ɪz moʊst wɪnɪŋ smaɪl, "baɪ ðɪs taɪm jə mʌs noʊ ðə sintʃæn woʊn lʊk twaɪs ət faɪɹwɝks. ðoʊz deɪmeɪn də sʌmθɪŋ kɔl skaɪ laɪts ðət meɪks jəɹ bɛs faɪɹwɝks lʊk laɪk ə fju spɑɹks flaɪɪŋ ʌp ðə tʃɪmni, soʊ aɪ hɪɹ. noʊ əfɛns mɛnt."

"Listen, Aludra," he said, assuming his most winning smile, "by this time you must know the Seanchan won't look twice at fireworks. Those damane do something called Sky Lights that makes your best fireworks look like a few sparks flying up the chimney, so I hear. No offense meant."

"mi, aɪ hæv nɑt sin ðiz soʊ-kɔl skaɪ laɪts maɪsɛlf," ʃi ɹɪplaɪd dɪsmɪsɪvli ɪn əɹ stʃɹɔŋ tæɹɑbənɝ æksɛnt. hɝ hɛd wɑz bɛn oʊvɝ ə wʊɾən mɔɹɾɝ ðə saɪz ʌv ə lɑɹdʒ kɛɡ ɑn wʌn ə ðə wɝkbɛntʃɪz, ən dɪspaɪɾ ə waɪd blu ɹɪbən ɡæðɝɪŋ əɹ dɑɹk weɪst-lɛŋθ hɛɹ lusli ət ðə neɪp ə hɝ nɛk, ɪt fɛl fɔɹwɝd tə haɪɾ əɹ feɪs. ðə lɔŋ waɪɾ eɪpɹən wɪð ɪts dɑɹk smʌdʒɪz dɪd nʌθɪŋ tə kənsil haʊ wɛl əɹ dɑɹk ɡɹin dʒɹɛs fɪɾ oʊvɝ əɹ hɪps, bʌɾ i wɑz mɔɹ ɪntʃɹəstəɾ ɪn wʌt ʃi wɑz duɪŋ. wɛl, əz ɪntʃɹəstəd. ʃi wɑz ɡɹaɪndɪŋ əɾ ə kɔɹs blæk paʊɾɝ wɪð ə wʊɾən pɛsəl nɪɹli əz lɔŋ əz əɹ ɑɹm. ðə paʊɾɝ lʊkt ə lɪɾəl laɪk wʌɾ i hæd sin ɪnsaɪd faɪɹwɝks i hæd kʌɾ oʊpən, bʌɾ i stɪl dɪd nɑt noʊ wʌt wɛn ɪndə ɪt. "ɪn ɛni ɪvɛnt," ʃi wɛn ɑn, ʌnəwɛɹ ə hɪz skɹuɾəni, "aɪ wɪl nɑt ɡɪv jə ðə ɡɪl sikɹəts. jə mʌst ʌndɝstæn ðɪs, jɛs?"

"Me, I have not seen these so-called Sky Lights myself," she replied dismissively in her strong Taraboner accent. Her head was bent over a wooden mortar the size of a large keg on one of the workbenches, and despite a wide blue ribbon gathering her dark waist-length hair loosely at the nape of her neck, it fell forward to hide her face. The long white apron with its dark smudges did nothing to conceal how well her dark green dress fit over her hips, but he was more interested in what she was doing. Well, as interested. She was grinding at a coarse black powder with a wooden pestle nearly as long as her arm. The powder looked a little like what he had seen inside fireworks he had cut open, but he still did not know what went into it. "In any event," she went on, unaware of his scrutiny, "I will not give you the Guild secrets. You must understand this, yes?"

mæt wɪnst. hi hæd bɪn wɝkɪŋ ɑn əɹ fəɹ deɪz tə bɹɪŋ əɹ tə ðɪs pɔɪnt, ɛvɝ sɪns ə tʃæns vɪzət tə vɑlən lukəz tʃɹævlɪŋ ʃoʊ ɹɪvil ðət ʃi wɑz hɪɹ ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ, ən ɔl ðə waɪl i hæd dʒɹɛɾɪd ðət ʃi wəd mɛnʃən ði ɪluməneɪɾɝz' ɡɪld. "bʌt jə ɑɹən ən ɪluməneɪɾɝ ɛnimɔɹ, ɹɪmɛmbɝ? ðeɪ kɪkt . . . ɑ . . . jə sɛd jə lɛf ðə ɡɪld." nɑt fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm i kənsɪɾɝd ə smɔl ɹimaɪndɝ ðəɾ i hæd wʌns seɪvd əɹ fɹəm fɔɹ ɡɪl mɛmbɝz u wɑntəd tə kʌɾ əɹ θɹoʊt. ðət sɔɹɾ ə θɪŋ wɑz ɪnʌf tə meɪk moʊst wɪmən fɔl ɑn jəɹ nɛk wɪð kɪsəz ən ɔfɝz ʌv wʌtɛvɝ jə wɑntəd. bʌt ðəɹ hæd bɪn ə noʊɾəbəl læk ə kɪsəz wən i æktʃəli  seɪv hɝ, soʊ ɪt wɑz ənlaɪkli ʃi wəd bɪɡɪn naʊ. "ɛniweɪ," hi wɛn ɑn ɛɹəli, "ju doʊn əv tə wɝi əbaʊt ðə ɡɪld. juv bɪn meɪkɪŋ naɪtfloʊɝz fəɹ haʊ lɔŋ? ən noʊbɑdi hæz kʌm ɝaʊn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə stɑp ju. waɪ, əl weɪdʒɝ jə nɛvɝ si ənʌðɝ ɪluməneɪɾɝ."

Mat winced. He had been working on her for days to bring her to this point, ever since a chance visit to Valan Luca's traveling show revealed that she was here in Ebou Dar, and all the while he had dreaded that she would mention the Illuminators' Guild. "But you aren't an Illuminator anymore, remember? They kicked . . . ah . . . you said you left the Guild." Not for the first time he considered a small reminder that he had once saved her from four Guild members who wanted to cut her throat. That sort of thing was enough to make most women fall on your neck with kisses and offers of whatever you wanted. But there had been a notable lack of kisses when he actually saved her, so it was unlikely she would begin now. "Anyway," he went on airily, "you don't have to worry about the Guild. You've been making nightflowers for how long? And nobody has come around trying to stop you. Why, I'll wager you never see another Illuminator."

"wʌɾ əv jə hɝd?" ʃi æskt kwaɪətli, hɝ hɛd stɪl daʊn. ðə pɛsəlz ɹoʊteɪʃən sloʊɾ ɔlmoʊs tə ə stɑp. "tɛl mi."

"What have you heard?" she asked quietly, her head still down. The pestle's rotation slowed almost to a stop. "Tell me."

ðə hɛɹ ɑn ɪz skælp nɪɹli stʊɾ ɑn ɛnd. haʊ dɪd wɪmən də ðæt? haɪɾ ɛvɹi klu, ən ðeɪ stɪl wɛn stʃɹeɪt tə wʌt jə wɑntəd tə kənsil. "wʌt dʒju min? aɪ hɪɹ ðə seɪm ɡɑsəp jə du, aɪ səpoʊz. moʊsli əbaʊt ðə sintʃæn."

The hair on his scalp nearly stood on end. How did women do that? Hide every clue, and they still went straight to what you wanted to conceal. "What do you mean? I hear the same gossip you do, I suppose. Mostly about the Seanchan."

ʃi spʌn ɝaʊn soʊ fæs ðəɾ əɹ hɛɹ swʌŋ laɪk ə fleɪl, ən snætʃt ðə hɛvi pɛsəl ʌp ɪn boʊθ hænz, bɹændɪʃɪŋ ɪɾ oʊvɝhɛd. pɝhæps tɛn jɪɹz əɹ soʊ oʊldɝ ðən hi, ʃi hæd lɑɹdʒ dɑɹk aɪz ən ə smɔl plʌmp maʊθ ðət juʒəwəli simd ɹɛɾi tə bi kɪst. hi hæd θɔɾ əbaʊt kɪsɪŋ əɹ ə taɪm əɹ tu. moʊst wɪmən wɝ mɔɹ əmɛnəbəl æftɝ ə fju kɪsəz. naʊ, hɝ tiθ wɝ bɛɹd, ən ʃi lʊkt ɹɛɾi tə baɪɾ ɔf ɪz noʊz. "tɛl mi!" ʃi kəmændəd.

She spun around so fast that her hair swung like a flail, and snatched the heavy pestle up in both hands, brandishing it overhead. Perhaps ten years or so older than he, she had large dark eyes and a small plump mouth that usually seemed ready to be kissed. He had thought about kissing her a time or two. Most women were more amenable after a few kisses. Now, her teeth were bared, and she looked ready to bite off his nose. "Tell me!" she commanded.

"aɪ wɑz pleɪɪŋ ət daɪs wɪð səm sintʃæn daʊn nɪɹ ðə dɑks," hi sɛd ɹɪlʌktənli, kipɪŋ ə kɛɹfəl aɪ ɑn ði əpɹeɪz pɛsəl. ə mæn maɪt blʌf ən blʌstɝ ən wɔk əweɪ ɪf ðə mæɾɝ wɑz nɑt sɪɹiəs, bʌɾ ə wʊmən kəd kɹæk jəɹ skʌl ɑn ə wɪm. ən ɪz hɪp wɑz eɪkɪŋ ən stɪf fɹəm sɪɾɪŋ tu lɔŋ. hi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ haʊ kwɪkli hi kəd muv fɹəm ðə stul. "aɪ dɪdnt wɑnə bi ðə wʌn tə tɛl ju, bʌt . . . ðə ɡɪl dʌzn ɪɡzɪst ɛnimɔɹ, ɑlʌdʒɹə. ðə tʃæptɝ haʊs ɪn tæntʃəkoʊ ɪz ɡɔn." ðət hæd bɪn ði oʊnli ɹil tʃæptɝ haʊs ɪn ðə ɡɪld. ðə wʌn ɪn kɛɹhin wɑz lɔŋ əbændənd naʊ, ən fəɹ ðə ɹɛst, ɪluməneɪɾɝz oʊnli tʃɹævəl tə pʊɾ ɑn dɪspleɪz fəɹ ɹulɝz ən noʊbəlz. "ðeɪ ɹəfjuz tə lɛt sintʃæn soʊlʒɝz ɪnsaɪd ðə kɑmpaʊnd, ən fɔt, tʃɹaɪd tə, wən ðeɪ bɹoʊk ɪn ɛniweɪ. aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌt hæpənd - meɪbi ə soʊlʒɝ tʊk ə læntɝn wɛɹ i ʃʊdn əv - bʌt hæf ðə kɑmpaʊn ɪksploʊɾəd, əz aɪ ʌndɝstæn ɪt. pɹɑbli ɪɡzædʒɝeɪʃən. bʌt ðə sintʃæn bɪlivd wʌn ə ði ɪluməneɪɾɝz juz ðə wʌn paʊɝ, ən ðeɪ . . ." hi saɪd, ən tʃɹaɪd tə meɪk ɪz vɔɪs dʒɛntəl. blʌɾ ən æʃəz, hi dɪd nɑt wɑnə tɛl əɹ ðɪs! bʌt ʃi wɑz ɡlɛɹɪŋ ət hɪm, ðət blʌɾi klʌb pɔɪz tə splɪɾ ɪz skælp. "ɑlʌdʒɹə, ðə sintʃæn ɡæðɝɾ ʌp ɛvɹiwʌn lɛft əlaɪv ət ðə tʃæptɝ haʊs, ən səm ɪluməneɪɾɝz ðət hæd ɡɔn tə æmədɔɹ, ən ɛvɹibɑɾi ɪn bɪtwin u ivən lʊk laɪk ən ɪluməneɪɾɝ, ən ðeɪ meɪɾ əm ɔl dækoʊvæl. ðət minz - "

"I was playing at dice with some Seanchan down near the docks," he said reluctantly, keeping a careful eye on the upraised pestle. A man might bluff and bluster and walk away if the matter was not serious, but a woman could crack your skull on a whim. And his hip was aching and stiff from sitting too long. He was not sure how quickly he could move from the stool. "I didn't want to be the one to tell you, but . . . The Guild doesn't exist anymore, Aludra. The chapter house in Tanchico is gone." That had been the only real chapter house in the Guild. The one in Cairhien was long abandoned now, and for the rest, Illuminators only traveled to put on displays for rulers and nobles. "They refused to let Seanchan soldiers inside the compound, and fought, tried to, when they broke in anyway. I don't know what happened - maybe a soldier took a lantern where he shouldn't have - but half the compound exploded, as I understand it. Probably exaggeration. But the Seanchan believed one of the Illuminators used the One Power, and they . . ." He sighed, and tried to make his voice gentle. Blood and ashes, he did not want to tell her this! But she was glaring at him, that bloody club poised to split his scalp. "Aludra, the Seanchan gathered up everyone left alive at the chapter house, and some Illuminators that had gone to Amador, and everybody in between who even looked like an Illuminator, and they made them all da'covale. That means - "

"aɪ noʊ wʌɾ ɪt minz!" ʃi sɛd fɪɹsli. swɪŋɪŋ bæk tə ðə bɪɡ mɔɹɾɝ, ʃi bɪɡæn paʊndɪŋ əweɪ wɪð ðə pɛsəl soʊ hɑɹd ðəɾ i wɑz əfɹeɪd ðə θɪŋ maɪɾ ɪksploʊd, ɪf ðət paʊɾɝ ɹɪli wɑz wʌt wɛn ɪnsaɪd faɪɹwɝks. "fulz!" ʃi mʌɾɝd æŋɡɹəli, θʌmpɪŋ ðə pɛsəl laʊdli ɪn ðə mɔɹɾɝ. "ɡɹeɪt blaɪn fulz! wɪð ðə maɪɾi, jə mʌs bɛn jəɹ nɛk ə lɪɾəl ən wɔk ɑn, bʌt ðeɪ wəd nɑt si ɪt!" snɪfɪŋ, ʃi skɹʌbd əɾ əɹ tʃiks wɪð ðə bæk ə hɝ hænd. "ju ɑɹ ɹɔŋ, maɪ jʌŋ fɹɛnd. soʊ lɔŋ əz wʌn ɪluməneɪɾɝ lɪvz, ðə ɡɪld, ɪt laɪvz tu, ən mi, aɪ stɪl laɪv!" stɪl nɑt lʊkɪŋ ət hɪm, ʃi waɪpt əɹ tʃiks wɪð əɹ hæn əɡɛn. "ænd wʌt wəd jə də ɪf aɪ ɡeɪv jə ðə faɪɹwɝks? hɝl əm ət ðə sintʃæn fɹəm ðə kæɾəpʌlt, aɪ səpoʊz?" hɝ snɔɹt toʊld wʌt ʃi θɔɾ ə ðæt.

"I know what it means!" she said fiercely. Swinging back to the big mortar, she began pounding away with the pestle so hard that he was afraid the thing might explode, if that powder really was what went inside fireworks. "Fools!" she muttered angrily, thumping the pestle loudly in the mortar. "Great blind fools! With the mighty, you must bend your neck a little and walk on, but they would not see it!" Sniffing, she scrubbed at her cheeks with the back of her hand. "You are wrong, my young friend. So long as one Illuminator lives, the Guild, it lives too, and me, I still live!" Still not looking at him, she wiped her cheeks with her hand again. "And what would you do if I gave you the fireworks? Hurl them at the Seanchan from the catapult, I suppose?" Her snort told what she thought of that.

"ænd wʌts ɹɔŋ wɪð ði aɪdiə?" hi æsk dɪfɛnsɪvli. ə ɡʊd fil kæɾəpʌlt, ə skɔɹpiən, kəd θɹoʊ ə tɛn-paʊn stoʊn faɪv hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz, ən tɛn paʊnz ə faɪɹwɝks wəd də mɔɹ dæmədʒ ðən ɛni stoʊn. "ɛniweɪ, aɪ hæv ə bɛɾɝ aɪdiə. aɪ sɔ ðoʊz tubz jə jus tə tɔs naɪtfloʊɝz ɪndə ðə skaɪ. θɹi hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz əɹ mɔɹ, jə sɛd. tɪp wʌn ɑn ɪts saɪd mɔɹ əɹ lɛs, ən əl bɛɾ ɪt kəd tɔs ə naɪtfloʊɝ ə θaʊzən peɪsɪz."

"And what's wrong with the idea?" he asked defensively. A good field catapult, a scorpion, could throw a ten-pound stone five hundred paces, and ten pounds of fireworks would do more damage than any stone. "Anyway, I have a better idea. I saw those tubes you use to toss nightflowers into the sky. Three hundred paces or more, you said. Tip one on its side more or less, and I'll bet it could toss a nightflower a thousand paces."

piɹɪŋ ɪndə ðə mɔɹɾɝ, ʃi mʌɾɝd ɔlmoʊst ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛθ. "mi, aɪ tɔk tu mʌtʃ," hi θɔɾ ɪt wɑz, ən sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt pɹɪɾi aɪz ðət meɪd noʊ sɛns. hi hɝiɾ ɑn tə stɑp əɹ fɹəm stɑɹɾɪŋ ʌp əbaʊt ɡɪl sikɹəts əɡɛn. "ðoʊz tubz ɑɹ ə lɑt smɔlɝ ðən ə kæɾəpʌlt, ɑlʌdʒɹə. ɪf ðeɪ wɝ wɛl hɪɾən, ðə sintʃæn wəd nɛvɝ noʊ wɛɹ ðeɪ keɪm fɹʌm. jə kəd θɪŋk ʌv ɪɾ əz peɪɪŋ əm bæk fəɹ ðə tʃæptɝ haʊs."

Peering into the mortar, she muttered almost under her breath. "Me, I talk too much," he thought it was, and something about pretty eyes that made no sense. He hurried on to stop her from starting up about Guild secrets again. "Those tubes are a lot smaller than a catapult, Aludra. If they were well hidden, the Seanchan would never know where they came from. You could think of it as paying them back for the chapter house."

tɝnɪŋ əɹ hɛd, ʃi ɡeɪv ɪm ə lʊk ə ɹɪspɛkt. mɪŋɡəld wɪð sɝpɹaɪz, bʌɾ i mænədʒ tə ɪɡnɔɹ ðæt. hɝ aɪz wɝ ɹɛd-ɹɪmd, ən ðəɹ wɝ tɝsteɪnz ɑn əɹ tʃiks. meɪbi ɪf i pʊɾ ən ɑɹm ɝaʊn əɹ . . . wɪmən juʒəwəli əpɹiʃieɪɾɪd ə lɪɾəl kʌmfɝɾɪŋ wən ðeɪ kɹaɪd.

Turning her head, she gave him a look of respect. Mingled with surprise, but he managed to ignore that. Her eyes were red-rimmed, and there were tearstains on her cheeks. Maybe if he put an arm around her . . . Women usually appreciated a little comforting when they cried.

bɪfɔɹ i kəɾ ivən ʃɪft ɪz weɪt, ʃi swʌŋ ðə pɛsəl bɪtwin ðɛm, pɔɪntɪŋ ɪɾ əɾ ɪm laɪk ə sɔɹd wɪð wʌn hænd. ðoʊz slɛndɝ ɑɹmz mʌs bi stʃɹɔŋɝ ðən ðeɪ lʊkt; ðə wʊɾən klʌb nɛvɝ weɪvɝd. laɪt, hi θɔt, ʃi kʊdn əv noʊn wʌɾ aɪ wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ tə du!

Before he could even shift his weight, she swung the pestle between them, pointing it at him like a sword with one hand. Those slender arms must be stronger than they looked; the wooden club never wavered. Light, he thought, she couldn't have known what I was going to do!

"ðɪs ɪz nɑt bæd, fəɹ wʌn u oʊnli sɔ ðə lɑftɪŋ tubz ə fju deɪz əɡoʊ," ʃi sɛd, "bʌt mi, aɪ hæv θɔɾ əbaʊt ðɪs lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ ju. aɪ hæd ɹizən." fəɹ ə moʊmənt, hɝ vɔɪs wɑz bɪɾɝ, bʌɾ ɪt smuðd aʊɾ əɡɛn, ən bɪkeɪm ə lɪɾəl əmjuzd. "aɪ wɪl sɛt jə ðə pʌzəl, sɪns jə ɑɹ soʊ klɛvɝ, noʊ?" ʃi sɛd, ɑɹtʃɪŋ ən aɪbɹaʊ. oʊ, ʃi dɛfənətli wɑz əmjuz baɪ sʌmθɪŋ! "ju tɛl mi wʌt juz aɪ maɪɾ əv fəɹ ə bɛlfndɝ, ən əl tɛl jə ɔl ə maɪ sikɹəts. ivən ðə wʌnz ðət wɪl meɪk jə blʌʃ, jɛs?"

"This is not bad, for one who only saw the lofting tubes a few days ago," she said, "but me, I have thought about this long before you. I had reason." For a moment, her voice was bitter, but it smoothed out again, and became a little amused. "I will set you the puzzle, since you are so clever, no?" she said, arching an eyebrow. Oh, she definitely was amused by something! "You tell me what use I might have for a bellfounder, and I will tell you all of my secrets. Even the ones that will make you blush, yes?"

naʊ, ðət dɪd saʊn ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ. bʌt ðə faɪɹwɝks wɝ mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt ðən ən aʊɝ snʌɡəlɪŋ wɪð hɝ. wʌt sikɹəts dɪd ʃi hæv ðət kəd meɪk ɪm blʌʃ? hi maɪt sɝpɹaɪz hɝ, ðɛɹ. nɑɾ ɔl ə ðoʊz ʌðɝ mɛnz mɛmɹiz ðət hæd bɪn stʌft ɪndə hɪz hɛd hæd tə də wɪð bæɾəlz. "ə bɛlmeɪkɝ," hi mjuzd, wɪθaʊɾ ə noʊʃən ʌv wɛɹ tə ɡoʊ fɹəm ðɛɹ. nʌn ə ðoʊz oʊl mɛmɹiz ɡeɪv ivən ə hɪnt. "wɛl, aɪ səpoʊz . . . ə bɛlmeɪkɝ kəd . . . meɪbi . . ."

Now, that did sound interesting. But the fireworks were more important than an hour snuggling with her. What secrets did she have that could make him blush? He might surprise her, there. Not all of those other men's memories that had been stuffed into his head had to do with battles. "A bellmaker," he mused, without a notion of where to go from there. None of those old memories gave even a hint. "Well, I suppose . . . A bellmaker could . . . Maybe . . ."

"noʊ," ʃi sɛd, sʌɾənli bɹɪsk. "ju wɪl ɡoʊ, ən ɹɪtɝn ɪn tu əɹ θɹi deɪz. aɪ hæv ðə wɝk tə du, ən jə ɑɹ tu dɪstʃɹæktɪŋ wɪð ɔl ə jəɹ kwɛstʃənz ən widlɪŋ. noʊ; noʊ ɑɹɡjəməns! jəl ɡoʊ naʊ."

"No," she said, suddenly brisk. "You will go, and return in two or three days. I have the work to do, and you are too distracting with all of your questions and wheedling. No; no arguments! You will go now."

ɡlaʊɝɪŋ, hi ɹoʊz ən klæpt ɪz waɪd-bɹɪm blæk hæɾ ɑntu hɪz hɛd. widlɪŋ? widlɪŋ! blʌɾ ən blʌɾi æʃəz! hi hæd dʒɹɑpt ɪz kloʊk ɪn ə hip baɪ ðə dɔɹ ɑn ɛntɝɪŋ, ən i ɡɹʌntɪd sɔfli, bɛndɪŋ tə pɪk ɪɾ ʌp. hi hæd bɪn sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðət stul moʊst ə ðə deɪ. bʌt meɪbi hi hæd meɪɾ ə lɪɾəl hɛdweɪ wɪð hɝ. ɪf i kəd sɑlv əɹ pʌzəl, ɛniweɪ. əlɑɹm bɛlz. ɡɔŋz tə saʊn ði aʊɝ. ɪt meɪd noʊ sɛns.

Glowering, he rose and clapped his wide-brimmed black hat onto his head. Wheedling? Wheedling! Blood and bloody ashes! He had dropped his cloak in a heap by the door on entering, and he grunted softly, bending to pick it up. He had been sitting on that stool most of the day. But maybe he had made a little headway with her. If he could solve her puzzle, anyway. Alarm bells. Gongs to sound the hour. It made no sense.

"aɪ maɪt θɪŋk ə kɪsɪŋ sətʃ ə smɑɹt jʌŋ mæn əz jə ɪf jə dɪd nɑt bɪlɔŋ tə ənʌðɝ," ʃi mɝmɝɾ ɪn dɪsaɪɾədli wɔɹm toʊnz. "ju hæv sətʃ ə pɹɪɾi bɑɾəm."

"I might think of kissing such a smart young man as you if you did not belong to another," she murmured in decidedly warm tones. "You have such a pretty bottom."

hi dʒɝkt ɪɹɛkt, kipɪŋ ɪz bæk tə hɝ. ðə hiɾ ɪn ɪz feɪs wɑz pjʊɹ aʊtʃɹeɪdʒ, bʌt ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ tə seɪ hi wɑz blʌʃɪŋ. hi kəd juʒəwəli mænədʒ tə fɝɡɛt wʌɾ i wɑz wɛɹɪŋ ənlɛs sʌmwʌn bɹɔɾ ɪɾ ʌp. ðəɹ hæd bɪn ən ɪnsəɾənt əɹ θɹi ɪn tævɝnz. waɪl i wɑz flæɾ ɑn ɪz bæk wɪð ɪz lɛɡ ɪn splɪns ən ɪz ɹɪbz stʃɹæpt ən bændədʒəz dʒʌst əbaʊɾ ɛvɹiwɛɹ ɛls, taɪlɪn hæd hɪɾən ɔl ə hɪz kloʊðz. hi hæd nɑt faʊnd wɛɹ, jɛt, bʌt ʃʊɹli ðeɪ wɝ hɪɾən, nɑt bɝnd. æftɝ ɔl, ʃi kəd nɑt min tə hoʊld ɑn tə hɪm fɝɛvɝ. ɔl ðət ɹɪmeɪn ə hɪz oʊn wɝ ɪz hæɾ ən ðə blæk sɪlk skɑɹf taɪɾ ɝaʊn ɪz nɛk. ən ðə sɪlvɝi fɑkshɛd mədæljən, ʌv kɔɹs, hæŋɪŋ ɑn ə lɛðɝ kɔɹɾ ʌndɝ ɪz ʃɝt. ən ɪz naɪvz; hi ɹɪli wʊɾə fɛlt lɔst wɪθaʊt ðoʊz. wən i faɪnəli mænədʒ tə kɹɔl aʊɾ ə ðət blʌɾi bɛd, ðə blʌɾi wʊmən hæd hæd nu kloʊðz meɪd fəɹ hɪm, wɪð əɹ sɪɾɪŋ ðəɹ wɑtʃɪŋ ðə blʌɾi simstʃɹəsəz mɛʒɝ ən fɪt hɪm! snoʊi leɪs əɾ ɪz ɹɪsts ɔlmoʊs hɪɾ ɪz blʌɾi hænz ənlɛs i wɑz kɛɹfəl, ən mɔɹ spɪl fɹəm ɪz nɛk ɔlmoʊs tə hɪz fleɪmɪŋ weɪst. taɪlɪn laɪk leɪs ɑn ə mæn. hɪz kloʊk wɑz ə bɹɪljən skɑɹlət, əz ɹɛɾ əz ɪz tu-taɪt bɹitʃɪz, ən ɛdʒd wɪð ɡoʊldən skɹɑlwɝk ən waɪt ɹoʊzɪz, ʌv ɔl blʌɾi θɪŋz. nɑt tə mɛnʃən ə waɪɾ oʊvəl ɑn ɪz lɛft ʃoʊldɝ wɪð haʊs mɪtsoʊbɑɹz ɡɹin sɔɹɾ ən æŋkɝ. hɪz koʊt wɑz blu ɪnʌf fəɹ ə tɪŋkɝ, wɝkt ɪn ɹɛɾ ən ɡoʊl tɛɹən meɪzɪz əkɹɔs ðə tʃɛst ən daʊn ðə slivz fəɹ ɡʊd mɛʒɝ. hi dɪd nɑt laɪk ɹɪkɔlɪŋ wʌɾ i hæd bɪn fɔɹs tə ɡoʊ θɹu tə kənvɪns taɪlɪn tə liv ɔf ðə pɝlz ən sæfaɪɝz ən ðə laɪɾ əloʊn nu wʌɾ ɛls ʃi hæd wɑntəd. ən ɪt wɑz ʃɔɹt, tə but. ɪndɪsənli ʃɔɹt! taɪlɪn laɪkt ɪz blʌɾi bɑɾəm, tu, ən ʃi dɪd nɑt sim tə maɪn u sɔ ɪt!

He jerked erect, keeping his back to her. The heat in his face was pure outrage, but she was sure to say he was blushing. He could usually manage to forget what he was wearing unless someone brought it up. There had been an incident or three in taverns. While he was flat on his back with his leg in splints and his ribs strapped and bandages just about everywhere else, Tylin had hidden all of his clothes. He had not found where, yet, but surely they were hidden, not burned. After all, she could not mean to hold on to him forever. All that remained of his own were his hat and the black silk scarf tied around his neck. And the silvery foxhead medallion, of course, hanging on a leather cord under his shirt. And his knives; he really would have felt lost without those. When he finally managed to crawl out of that bloody bed, the bloody woman had had new clothes made for him, with her sitting there watching the bloody seamstresses measure and fit him! Snowy lace at his wrists almost hid his bloody hands unless he was careful, and more spilled from his neck almost to his flaming waist. Tylin liked lace on a man. His cloak was a brilliant scarlet, as red as his too-tight breeches, and edged with golden scrollwork and white roses, of all bloody things. Not to mention a white oval on his left shoulder with House Mitsobar's green Sword and Anchor. His coat was blue enough for a Tinker, worked in red and gold Tairen mazes across the chest and down the sleeves for good measure. He did not like recalling what he had been forced to go through to convince Tylin to leave off the pearls and sapphires and the Light alone knew what else she had wanted. And it was short, to boot. Indecently short! Tylin liked his bloody bottom, too, and she did not seem to mind who saw it!

sɛɾəlɪŋ ðə kloʊk ɝaʊn ɪz ʃoʊldɝz - ɪt wɑz səm kʌvɝɪŋ, ət list - hi ɡɹæbd ɪz ʃoʊldɝ-haɪ wɔkɪŋ stæf fɹəm wɛɹ ɪt wɑz linɪŋ bɪsaɪd ðə dɔɹ. hɪz hɪp ən lɛɡ wɝ gɑnə eɪk əntɪl i kəd wɔk ðə peɪn əweɪ. "ɪn tu əɹ θɹi deɪz, ðɛn," hi sɛd wɪð əz mʌtʃ dɪɡnəɾi əz i kəd mʌstɝ.

Settling the cloak around his shoulders - it was some covering, at least - he grabbed his shoulder-high walking staff from where it was leaning beside the door. His hip and leg were going to ache until he could walk the pain away. "In two or three days, then," he said with as much dignity as he could muster.

ɑlʌdʒɹə læf sɔfli. nɑt sɔfli ɪnʌf ðəɾ i kəd nɑt hɪɹ, ðoʊ. laɪt, bʌɾ ə wʊmən kəd də mɔɹ wɪð ə læf ðən ə dɑksaɪd bʊlɪbɔɪ wɪð ə stʃɹɪŋ ə kɝsɪz! ən dʒʌst əz dɪlɪbɝətli.

Aludra laughed softly. Not softly enough that he could not hear, though. Light, but a woman could do more with a laugh than a dockside bullyboy with a string of curses! And just as deliberately.

lɪmpɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə wæɡən, hi slæm ðə dɔɹ bɪhaɪn ɪm əz sun əz i wɑz fɑɹ ɪnʌf daʊn ðə wʊɾən stɛps ðət wɝ fæsən tə ðə wæɡən bɛd. ði æftɝnun skaɪ wɑz dʒʌs laɪk ðə mɔɹnɪŋ skaɪ hæd bɪn, ɡɹeɪ ən blʌstɝi, θætʃt wɪð sʌlən klaʊdz. ə ʃɑɹp wɪnd ɡʌstɪd fɪtfəli. ɔltɑɹə hæd noʊ tʃɹu wɪntɝ, bʌt wʌɾ ɪt dɪɾ əv wɑz ɪnʌf tə bi ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn wɪð. ɹæðɝ ðən snoʊ, ðəɹ wɝ aɪsi ɹeɪnz ən θʌndɝstɔɹmz ɹeɪsɪŋ ɪn ɔf ðə si, ən ɪn bɪtwin ɪt wɑz dæmp ɪnʌf tə meɪk ðə koʊl sim hɑɹɾɝ. ðə ɡɹaʊn hæɾ ə sɑɾən fil ʌndɝ jəɹ buts ivən wən ɪt wɑz dʒɹaɪ. skaʊlɪŋ, hi hɑbəld əweɪ fɹəm ðə wæɡən.

Limping out of the wagon, he slammed the door behind him as soon as he was far enough down the wooden steps that were fastened to the wagon bed. The afternoon sky was just like the morning sky had been, gray and blustery, thatched with sullen clouds. A sharp wind gusted fitfully. Altara had no true winter, but what it did have was enough to be going on with. Rather than snow, there were icy rains and thunderstorms racing in off the sea, and in between it was damp enough to make the cold seem harder. The ground had a sodden feel under your boots even when it was dry. Scowling, he hobbled away from the wagon.

wɪmən! ɑlʌdʒɹə wɑz pɹɪɾi, ðoʊ. ən ʃi dɪd noʊ haʊ tə meɪk faɪɹwɝks. ə bɛlfndɝ? meɪbi hi kəd meɪk ɪɾ ə ʃɔɹt tu deɪz. soʊ lɔŋ əz ɑlʌdʒɹə dɪd nɑt stɑɹt tʃeɪsɪŋ hɪm. ə ɡʊd mɛni wɪmən sim tə bi duɪŋ ðæt, ʌv leɪt. hæd taɪlɪn tʃeɪnʒd sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt hɪm, tə meɪk wɪmən pɝsu hɪm ðə weɪ ʃi hɝsɛlf dɪd? noʊ. ðət wɑz ɹɪdɪkjələs. ðə wɪn kɑɾ ɪz kloʊk, flɛɹɪŋ ɪt bɪhaɪn hɪm, bʌɾ i wɑz tu əbzɔɹb tə mæstɝ ɪt. ə pɛɹ ə slɛndɝ wɪmən - ækɹəbæts, hi θɔt - ɡeɪv ɪm slaɪ smaɪlz əz ðeɪ pæst, ən i smaɪld ən meɪɾ ɪz bɛs lɛɡ. taɪlɪn hæd nɑt tʃeɪnʒd hɪm. hi wɑz stɪl ðə seɪm mæn i hæɾ ɔlweɪz bɪn.

Women! Aludra was pretty, though. And she did know how to make fireworks. A bellfounder? Maybe he could make it a short two days. So long as Aludra did not start chasing him. A good many women seemed to be doing that, of late. Had Tylin changed something about him, to make women pursue him the way she herself did? No. That was ridiculous. The wind caught his cloak, flaring it behind him, but he was too absorbed to master it. A pair of slender women - acrobats, he thought - gave him sly smiles as they passed, and he smiled and made his best leg. Tylin had not changed him. He was still the same man he had always been.

lukəz ʃoʊ wɑz fɪfti taɪmz əz lɑɹdʒ əz wʌt tɑm hæd toʊld ɪm əbaʊt, meɪbi mɔɹ, ə spɹɔlɪŋ hɑdʒpɑdʒ ə tɛns ən wæɡənz ðə saɪz ʌv ə lɑɹdʒ vɪlədʒ. dɪspaɪt ðə wɛðɝ, ə nʌmbɝ ə pɝfɔɹmɝz wɝ pɹæktəsɪŋ wɛɹ i kəd si ðɛm. ə wʊmən ɪn ə floʊɪŋ waɪt blaʊs ən bɹitʃɪz əz taɪɾ əz ɪz swʌŋ bæk ən fɔɹθ ɑn ə sæɡɪŋ ɹoʊp slʌŋ bɪtwin tu tɔl poʊlz, ðən θɹu hɝsɛlf ɔf ən sʌmhaʊ kɑɾ əɹ fiɾ ɪn ðə ɹoʊp dʒʌs bɪfɔɹ ʃi hɝɾəld tə ðə ɡɹaʊn bɪloʊ. ðən ʃi twɪstəd tə kætʃ ðə ɹoʊp wɪð əɹ hænz, pʊl hɝsɛlf bæk tə hɝ siɾ ən bɪɡæn ðə seɪm θɪŋ əɡɛn. nɑt fɑɹ ɔf, ə fɛloʊ wɑz ɹʌnɪŋ ɑn tɑp ʌv ən ɛɡ-ʃeɪpt wil ðət mʌst əv bɪn ə ɡʊd twɛnti fit lɔŋ, maʊntəɾ ɑn ə plætfɔɹm ðət pʊɾ ɪm haɪɝ əbʌv ðə ɡɹaʊnd wən i dæʃt əkɹɔs ðə nɛɹoʊ ɛn ðən ðə wʊmən u wɑz gɑnə bɹeɪk əɹ ful nɛk sun. mæt aɪɾ ə bɛɹ-tʃɛstəd mæn u wɑz ɹoʊlɪŋ θɹi ʃaɪni bɔlz əlɔŋ ɪz ɑɹmz ən əkɹɔs ɪz ʃoʊldɝz wɪθaʊɾ ɛvɝ tʌtʃɪŋ əm wɪð ɪz hænz. ðət wɑz ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ. hi maɪt bi eɪbəl tə mænədʒ ðət hɪmsɛlf. ət lis ðoʊz bɔlz wəd nɑt liv jə bliɾɪŋ ən bɹoʊkən. hi hæd hæɾ ɪnʌf ə ðət tə suɾ ɪm ə laɪftaɪm.

Luca's show was fifty times as large as what Thom had told him about, maybe more, a sprawling hodgepodge of tents and wagons the size of a large village. Despite the weather, a number of performers were practicing where he could see them. A woman in a flowing white blouse and breeches as tight as his swung back and forth on a sagging rope slung between two tall poles, then threw herself off and somehow caught her feet in the rope just before she hurtled to the ground below. Then she twisted to catch the rope with her hands, pulled herself back to her seat and began the same thing again. Not far off, a fellow was running on top of an egg-shaped wheel that must have been a good twenty feet long, mounted on a platform that put him higher above the ground when he dashed across the narrow end than the woman who was going to break her fool neck soon. Mat eyed a bare-chested man who was rolling three shiny balls along his arms and across his shoulders without ever touching them with his hands. That was interesting. He might be able to manage that himself. At least those balls would not leave you bleeding and broken. He had had enough of that to suit him a lifetime.

wʌt ɹɪli kɑɾ ɪz aɪz, haʊɛvɝ, wɝ ðə hɔɹslaɪnz. lɔŋ hɔɹslaɪnz, wɛɹ tu dʌzən mɛn bʌndəld əɡɛns ðə koʊld wɝ ʃʌvlɪŋ dʌŋ ɪndə bæɹoʊz. hʌnʒɹədz ə hɔɹsəz. səpoʊzədli, lukə hæd ɡɪvən ʃɛltɝ tə səm sintʃæn ænəməl tʃɹeɪnɝ, ən ɪz ɹɪwɔɹd hæd bɪn ə wɔɹənt, saɪn baɪ ðə haɪ leɪɾi sjuɹɔθ hɝsɛlf, əlaʊɪŋ ɪm tə kip ɔl ə hɪz ænəməlz. mæts oʊn pɪps wɑz sɪkjʊɹ, seɪv fɹəm ðə lɑɾɝi ɔɹɾɝd baɪ sjuɹɔθ kəz i wɑz ɪn ðə tɑɹɑsɪn pæləs steɪbəlz, bʌt ɡɛɾɪŋ ðə ɡɛldɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðoʊz steɪbəlz wɑz bɪɑn hɪm. taɪlɪn əz ɡʊɾ əz hæɾ ə liʃ ɝaʊn ɪz nɛk, ən ʃi dɪd nɑɾ ɪntɛn tə lɛɾ ɪm ɡoʊ ɛni taɪm sun.

What really caught his eyes, however, were the horselines. Long horselines, where two dozen men bundled against the cold were shoveling dung into barrows. Hundreds of horses. Supposedly, Luca had given shelter to some Seanchan animal trainer, and his reward had been a warrant, signed by the High Lady Suroth herself, allowing him to keep all of his animals. Mat's own Pips was secure, saved from the lottery ordered by Suroth because he was in the Tarasin Palace stables, but getting the gelding out of those stables was beyond him. Tylin as good as had a leash around his neck, and she did not intend to let him go any time soon.

tɝnɪŋ əweɪ, hi kənsɪɾɝd hævɪŋ veɪnɪn stil səm ə ðə ʃoʊz hɔɹsəz ɪf ðə tɔks wɪð lukə wɛn bædli. fɹəm wʌt mæt nu ʌv veɪnɪn, ɪt wəd bi ən ivnɪŋ stʃɹoʊl fəɹ ði ənlaɪkli mæn. fæɾ əz i wɑz, veɪnɪn kəd stil, ən ɹaɪd, ɛni hɔɹs ɛvɝ foʊəld. ənfɔɹtʃənətli, mæt daʊɾɪd i hɪmsɛlf kəd sɪɾ ə sæɾəl fəɹ mɔɹ ðən ə maɪl. stɪl, ɪt wɑz sʌmθɪŋ tə kənsɪɾɝ. hi wɑz ɡɹoʊɪŋ dɛspɹɪt.

Turning away, he considered having Vanin steal some of the show's horses if the talks with Luca went badly. From what Mat knew of Vanin, it would be an evening stroll for the unlikely man. Fat as he was, Vanin could steal, and ride, any horse ever foaled. Unfortunately, Mat doubted he himself could sit a saddle for more than a mile. Still, it was something to consider. He was growing desperate.

lɪmpɪŋ əlɔŋ, aɪdli aɪɪŋ tʌmblɝz ən dʒʌɡəlɝz ən ækɹəbæts ət ðɛɹ pɹæktəs, hi wʌndɝd haʊ mæɾɝz hæd kʌm tə ðɪs pæs. blʌɾ ən æʃəz! hi wɑz tɑvɝən! hi wɑz səpoʊz tə ʃeɪp ðə wɝld ɝaʊn hɪm! bʌt hɪɹ i wɑz, stʌk ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ, taɪlɪnz pɛɾ ən tɔɪ - ðə wʊmən hæd nɑɾ ivən lɛɾ ɪm hil kəmplitli bɪfɔɹ lipɪŋ ɑn ɪm əɡɛn laɪk ə dʌk ɑn ə biɾəl! - waɪl ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls wɑz hævɪŋ ə faɪn taɪm ʌv ɪt. wɪð ðoʊz kɪnswɪmən fɔnɪŋ əɾ əɹ hilz, laɪkli nɪneɪiv wɑz lɔɹɾɪŋ ɪɾ oʊvɝ ɛvɹiwʌn ɪn saɪt. wʌns ɛɡwin ɹilaɪz ðoʊz stɑɹk ɹeɪvɪŋ mæɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ hu hæd neɪmd əɹ æmɪɝlɪn dɪd nɑt ɹɪli min ɪt, tælmɑnz ən ðə bæn ə ðə ɹɛd hænd wɝ ɹɛɾi tə spɪɹəɾ əɹ əweɪ. laɪt, ɪleɪn maɪt bi wɛɹɪŋ ðə ɹoʊz kɹaʊn baɪ naʊ, ɪf i nu hɝ! ɹænd ən pɛɹɪn pɹɑbli wɝ lɑlɪŋ ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ə faɪɝ ɪn səm pæləs, swɪlɪŋ waɪn ən tɛlɪŋ dʒoʊks.

Limping along, idly eyeing tumblers and jugglers and acrobats at their practice, he wondered how matters had come to this pass. Blood and ashes! He was ta'veren! He was supposed to shape the world around him! But here he was, stuck in Ebou Dar, Tylin's pet and toy - the woman had not even let him heal completely before leaping on him again like a duck on a beetle! - while everyone else was having a fine time of it. With those Kinswomen fawning at her heels, likely Nynaeve was lording it over everyone in sight. Once Egwene realized those stark raving mad Aes Sedai who had named her Amyrlin did not really mean it, Talmanes and the Band of the Red Hand were ready to spirit her away. Light, Elayne might be wearing the Rose Crown by now, if he knew her! Rand and Perrin probably were lolling in front of a fire in some palace, swilling wine and telling jokes.

hi ɡɹɪməst ən ɹʌbd əɾ ɪz fɔɹhɛɾ əz ə feɪn ɹʌʃ ə kʌlɝz sim tə swɝl ɪnsaɪɾ ɪz hɛd. ðət hæpən leɪtli wɛnɛvɝ i θɔɾ əbaʊɾ iðɝ mæn. hi dɪd nɑt noʊ waɪ, ən i dɪd nɑt wɑnə noʊ. hi dʒʌst wɑntəɾ ɪt tə stɑp. ɪf oʊnli hi kəd ɡɛɾ əweɪ fɹəm ɛbu dɑɹ. ən teɪk ðə sikɹəɾ ə faɪɹwɝks wɪð hɪm, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌɾ i wəd teɪk ɪskeɪp oʊvɝ ðə sikɹəɾ ɛni deɪ.

He grimaced and rubbed at his forehead as a faint rush of colors seemed to swirl inside his head. That happened lately whenever he thought about either man. He did not know why, and he did not want to know. He just wanted it to stop. If only he could get away from Ebou Dar. And take the secret of fireworks with him, of course, but he would take escape over the secret any day.

tɑm ən bɛslən wɝ stɪl wɛɹ i hæd lɛf ðɛm, dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ wɪð lukə ɪn fɹʌn ə lukəz ɪlæbɹətli dɛkɝeɪɾəd wæɡən, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt dʒɔɪn əm ɪmiɾiətli. fəɹ səm ɹizən, lukə hæd teɪkən ən ɪnstən dɪslaɪk tə mæt kɔθən. mæt ɹɪtɝn ðə feɪvɝ, bʌt wɪð ɹizən. lukə hæɾ ə smʌɡ, sɛlf-sæɾəsfaɪd feɪs, ən ə weɪ ʌv smɝkɪŋ əɾ ɛni wʊmən ɪn saɪt. ən i sim tə θɪŋk ɛvɹi wʊmən ɪn ðə wɝld ɛndʒɔɪd lʊkɪŋ ət hɪm. laɪt, ðə mæn wɑz mɛɹid!

Thom and Beslan were still where he had left them, drinking with Luca in front of Luca's elaborately decorated wagon, but he did not join them immediately. For some reason, Luca had taken an instant dislike to Mat Cauthon. Mat returned the favor, but with reason. Luca had a smug, self-satisfied face, and a way of smirking at any woman in sight. And he seemed to think every woman in the world enjoyed looking at him. Light, the man was married!

spɹɔld ɪn ə ɡɪldɪd tʃɛɹ i mʌst əv stoʊlən fɹəm ə pæləs, lukə wɑz læfɪŋ ən meɪkɪŋ ɪkspænsɪv, lɔɹdli dʒɛstʃɝz tə tɑm ən bɛslən, siɾəd ɑn bɛntʃɪz tə iðɝ saɪɾ ə hɪm. ɡoʊldən stɑɹz ən kɑməts kʌvɝd lukəz bɹɪljən ɹɛd koʊɾ ən kloʊk. eɪ tɪŋkɝ wəɾ əv blʌʃt! hɪz wæɡən wʊɾə meɪɾ ə tɪŋkɝ wip! mʌtʃ lɑɹdʒɝ ðən ɑlʌdʒɹəz wɝk-wæɡən, ðə θɪŋ əpɪɹd tə hæv bɪn lækɝd! ðə feɪzəz ə ðə mun ɹɪpiɾɪd ðɛmsɛlvz ɪn sɪlvɝ ɔl ðə weɪ ɝaʊn ðə wæɡən, ən ɡoʊldən stɑɹz ən kɑməts ɪn ɛvɹi saɪz kʌvɝd ðə ɹɛst ə ðə ɹɛd-ænd-blu sɝfəs. ɪn ðət sɛɾɪŋ, bɛslən lʊkt ɔlmoʊst ɔɹɾənɛɹi ɪn ə koʊɾ ən kloʊk wɝkt ɪn swupɪŋ bɝdz. tɑm, nʌklɪŋ waɪn fɹəm ɪz lɔŋ waɪt mʌstæʃɪz, sim pɑzəɾɪvli dʒɹæb ɪn pleɪn bɹɑnz-kʌlɝd wʊl ən ə dɑɹk kloʊk.

Sprawled in a gilded chair he must have stolen from a palace, Luca was laughing and making expansive, lordly gestures to Thom and Beslan, seated on benches to either side of him. Golden stars and comets covered Luca's brilliant red coat and cloak. A Tinker would have blushed! His wagon would have made a Tinker weep! Much larger than Aludra's work-wagon, the thing appeared to have been lacquered! The phases of the moon repeated themselves in silver all the way around the wagon, and golden stars and comets in every size covered the rest of the red-and-blue surface. In that setting, Beslan looked almost ordinary in a coat and cloak worked in swooping birds. Thom, knuckling wine from his long white mustaches, seemed positively drab in plain bronze-colored wool and a dark cloak.

wʌn pɝsən u ʃʊɾə bɪn ðəɹ wɑz nɑt, bʌɾ ə kwɪk ɡlæns ɝaʊn faʊn ə klʌstɝ ʌv wɪmən əɾ ə nɪɹbaɪ wæɡən. ðeɪ wɝ ɛvɹi eɪdʒ fɹəm ɪz oʊn ʌp tə ɡɹeɪɪŋ hɛɹ, bʌɾ ɛvɹi wʌn ə ðɛm wɑz ɡɪɡəlɪŋ ət wʌt ðeɪ sɝaʊndəd. saɪɪŋ, mæt meɪɾ ɪz weɪ ðɛɹ.

One person who should have been there was not, but a quick glance around found a cluster of women at a nearby wagon. They were every age from his own up to graying hair, but every one of them was giggling at what they surrounded. Sighing, Mat made his way there.

"oʊ, aɪ dʒʌs kænɑt dɪsaɪd," keɪm ə bɔɪz paɪpɪŋ vɔɪs fɹəm ðə sɛntɝ ə ðə wɪmən. "wɛn aɪ lʊk ət ju, mɛɝitʃi, jəɹ aɪz ɑɹ ðə pɹɪɾiəst aɪ hæv ɛvɝ sin. bʌt wən aɪ lʊk ət ju, nilɪn, jʊɹz ɑɹ. jəɹ lɪps ɑɹ ɹaɪp tʃɛɹiz, ɡɪlɪn, ən jʊɹz meɪk mi wɑnə kɪs ðɛm, ɑdʒɹiə. ən jəɹ nɛk, dʒəmaɪn, ɡɹeɪsfəl əz ə swɑnz. . . ."

"Oh, I just cannot decide," came a boy's piping voice from the center of the women. "When I look at you, Merici, your eyes are the prettiest I have ever seen. But when I look at you, Neilyn, yours are. Your lips are ripe cherries, Gillin, and yours make me want to kiss them, Adria. And your neck, Jameine, graceful as a swan's. . . ."

swɑloʊɪŋ ən oʊθ, mæt kwɪkən ɪz peɪs əz mʌtʃ əz i kəɾ ən pʊʃt θɹu ðə wɪmən mʌɾɝɪŋ əpɑlədʒiz lɛft ən ɹaɪt. oʊlvɝ wɑz ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðɛm, ə ʃɔɹt, peɪl bɔɪ pɑstʃɝɪŋ ən ɡɹɪnɪŋ ət wʌn wʊmən ðən ənʌðɝ. ðət tuθi ɡɹɪn əloʊn wɑz ɪnʌf ðəɾ ɛni ʌv əm maɪt dɪsaɪd tə slæp ɪz ɪɹz ɔf ɪn ə moʊmənt.

Swallowing an oath, Mat quickened his pace as much as he could and pushed through the women muttering apologies left and right. Olver was in the middle of them, a short, pale boy posturing and grinning at one woman then another. That toothy grin alone was enough that any of them might decide to slap his ears off in a moment.

"pliz fɝɡɪv hɪm," mæt mɝmɝd, teɪkɪŋ ðə bɔɪz hænd. "kʌm ɑn, oʊlvɝ; wɪv tə ɡɛt bæk tə ðə sɪɾi. stɑp weɪvɪŋ jəɹ kloʊk əbaʊt. hi dʌznt noʊ wʌt hiz seɪɪŋ, ɹɪli. aɪ doʊnt noʊ wɛɹ i pɪks ʌp ðət sɔɹɾ ə θɪŋ."

"Please forgive him," Mat murmured, taking the boy's hand. "Come on, Olver; we have to get back to the city. Stop waving your cloak about. He doesn't know what he's saying, really. I don't know where he picks up that sort of thing."

lʌkəli, ðə wɪmən læft ən ɹʌfəld oʊlvɝz hɛɹ əz mæt lɛɾ ɪm əweɪ. səm mɝmɝd ðəɾ i wɑz ə swit bɔɪ, ʌv ɔl θɪŋz! wʌn slɪpt əɹ hæn ʌndɝ mæts kloʊk ən pɪntʃt ɪz bɑɾəm. wɪmən!

Luckily, the women laughed and ruffled Olver's hair as Mat led him away. Some murmured that he was a sweet boy, of all things! One slipped her hand under Mat's cloak and pinched his bottom. Women!

wʌns klɪɹ, hi skaʊld ət ðə bɔɪ tʃɹɪpɪŋ əlɔŋ hæpəli əɾ ɪz saɪd. oʊlvɝ hæd ɡɹoʊn sɪns mæt fɝs mɛt hɪm, bʌɾ i wɑz stɪl ʃɔɹt fəɹ ɪz jɪɹz. ən wɪð ðət waɪd maʊθ ən ɪɹz tə mætʃ, hi wəd nɛvɝ bi hænsəm. "ju kəd ɡɛt jɝsɛlf ɪn dip tʃɹʌbəl tɔkɪŋ tə wɪmən ðət weɪ," mæt toʊl hɪm. "wɪmən laɪk ə mæn tə bi kwaɪət, ən wɛl-mænɝd. ən ɹɪzɝvd. ɹɪzɝvd, ən meɪbi ə lɪɾəl ʃaɪ. kʌltəveɪt ðoʊz kwɑləɾiz, ən jəl də wɛl."

Once clear, he scowled at the boy tripping along happily at his side. Olver had grown since Mat first met him, but he was still short for his years. And with that wide mouth and ears to match, he would never be handsome. "You could get yourself in deep trouble talking to women that way," Mat told him. "Women like a man to be quiet, and well-mannered. And reserved. Reserved, and maybe a little shy. Cultivate those qualities, and you'll do well."

oʊlvɝ ɡeɪv ɪm ə ɡeɪpɪŋ, ɪnkɹɛdʒələs stɛɹ, ən mæt saɪd. ðə læd hæɾ ə fɪsfəl ʌv ʌŋkəlz lʊkɪŋ æftɝ hɪm, ən ɛvɹi wʌn ɪksɛp mæt hɪmsɛlf wɑz ə bæɾ ɪnfluəns.

Olver gave him a gaping, incredulous stare, and Mat sighed. The lad had a fistful of uncles looking after him, and every one except Mat himself was a bad influence.

tɑm ən bɛslən wɝ ɪnʌf tə ɹɪstɔɹ oʊlvɝz ɡɹɪn. pʊlɪŋ ɪz hæn fɹi, hi ɹæn əhɛd tə ðɛm læfɪŋ. tɑm wɑz titʃɪŋ ɪm haʊ tə dʒʌɡəl ən pleɪ ðə hɑɹp ən ðə flut, ən bɛslən wɑz titʃɪŋ ɪm haʊ tə juz ə sɔɹd. hɪz ʌðɝ "ʌŋkəlz" ɡeɪv ɪm ʌðɝ lɛsənz, ɪn ə ɹɪmɑɹkəbli vɛɹid sɛɾ ə skɪlz. mæt ɪntɛndəd tə stɑɹt titʃɪŋ ɪm tə juz ə kɔɹɾɝstæf, ən ðə tu ɹɪvɝz baʊ, wʌns i hæɾ ɪz stʃɹɛŋkθ bæk. wʌt ðə bɔɪ wɑz lɝnɪŋ fɹəm tʃəl veɪnɪn, əɹ ðə ɹɛdʒɹmz, mæt dɪd nɑt wɑnə noʊ.

Thom and Beslan were enough to restore Olver's grin. Pulling his hand free, he ran ahead to them laughing. Thom was teaching him how to juggle and play the harp and the flute, and Beslan was teaching him how to use a sword. His other "uncles" gave him other lessons, in a remarkably varied set of skills. Mat intended to start teaching him to use a quarterstaff, and the Two Rivers bow, once he had his strength back. What the boy was learning from Chel Vanin, or the Redarms, Mat did not want to know.

lukə ɹoʊz fɹəm ɪz fænsi tʃɛɹ ət mæts əpɹoʊtʃ, hɪz fætʃəwəs smaɪl feɪɾɪŋ tə ə saʊɝ ɡɹɪmɑs. aɪɪŋ mæt ʌp ən daʊn, hi swɛp ðət ɹɪdɪkjələs kloʊk ɝaʊn hɪmsɛlf wɪð ə waɪd flɝɪʃ ən ənaʊnst ɪn ə bumɪŋ vɔɪs, "aɪ æm ə bɪzi mæn. aɪ hæv mʌtʃ tə du. ɪt meɪ bi ðəɾ aɪ sun wɪl əv ði ɑnɝ ʌv ɡɛstɪŋ ðə haɪ leɪɾi sjuɹɔθ fəɹ ə pɹaɪvət ʃoʊɪŋ." wɪθaʊɾ ənʌðɝ wɝɾ i stʃɹoʊɾ əweɪ hoʊldɪŋ ði ɔɹneɪt kloʊk wɪð dʒʌst wʌn hænd, soʊ ɡʌsts ɹɪpəld ɪt bɪhaɪn ɪm laɪk ə bænɝ.

Luca rose from his fancy chair at Mat's approach, his fatuous smile fading to a sour grimace. Eyeing Mat up and down, he swept that ridiculous cloak around himself with a wide flourish and announced in a booming voice, "I am a busy man. I have much to do. It may be that I soon will have the honor of guesting the High Lady Suroth for a private showing." Without another word he strode away holding the ornate cloak with just one hand, so gusts rippled it behind him like a banner.

mæt ɡæðɝɾ ɪz oʊn wɪð boʊθ hænz. ə kloʊk wɑz fəɹ wɔɹmθ. hi hæd sin sjuɹɔθ ɪn ðə pæləs, ðoʊ nɛvɝ kloʊsli. əz kloʊsli əz i wɑntəd, ðoʊ. hi kəd nɑɾ ɪmædʒən əɹ ɡɪvɪŋ ə moʊmən tə vɑlən lukəz ɡɹæn tʃɹævlɪŋ ʃoʊ ən mæɡnɪfəsən dɪspleɪ ʌv mɑɹvəlz ən wʌndɝz, əz ðə stʃɹimɝ stʃɹʌŋ bɪtwin tu tɔl poʊlz ət ði ɛntʃɹəns tə ðə ʃoʊ ənaʊnst ɪn ɹɛd lɛɾɝz ə peɪs haɪ. ɪf ʃi dɪd, laɪkli ʃi wəɾ it ðə laɪənz. əɹ fɹaɪɾən əm tə dɛθ.

Mat gathered his own with both hands. A cloak was for warmth. He had seen Suroth in the Palace, though never closely. As closely as he wanted, though. He could not imagine her giving a moment to Valan Luca's Grand Traveling Show and Magnificent Display of Marvels and Wonders, as the streamer strung between two tall poles at the entrance to the show announced in red letters a pace high. If she did, likely she would eat the lions. Or frighten them to death.

"hæz i əɡɹid jɛt, tɑm?" hi æskt kwaɪətli, fɹaʊnɪŋ æftɝ lukə.

"Has he agreed yet, Thom?" he asked quietly, frowning after Luca.

"wi kən tʃɹævəl wɪð ɪm wən i livz ɛbu dɑɹ," ðə wɛðɝd mæn ɹɪplaɪd. "fɔɹ ə pɹaɪs." hi snɔɹɾɪd, bloʊɪŋ aʊɾ ɪz mʌstæʃɪz, ən ɪɹɪɾəbli ɹeɪkt ə hæn θɹu hɪz waɪt hɛɹ. "wi ʃəɾ iɾ ən slip laɪk kɪŋz fəɹ wʌɾ i wɑns, bʌt noʊɪŋ hɪm, aɪ daʊt wi wɪl. hi dʌzn θɪŋk wəɹ kɹɪmənəlz, sɪns wɝ stɪl wɔkɪŋ fɹi, bʌɾ i noʊz wɝ ɹʌnɪŋ fɹəm sʌmθɪŋ, əɹ wi wəd tʃɹævəl səm ʌðɝ weɪ. ənfɔɹtʃənətli, hi dʌz nɑɾ ɪntɛn tə liv əntɪl spɹɪŋ ət ði ɝliəst."

"We can travel with him when he leaves Ebou Dar," the weathered man replied. "For a price." He snorted, blowing out his mustaches, and irritably raked a hand through his white hair. "We should eat and sleep like kings for what he wants, but knowing him, I doubt we will. He doesn't think we are criminals, since we're still walking free, but he knows we're running from something, or we would travel some other way. Unfortunately, he does not intend to leave until spring at the earliest."

mæt kənsɪɾɝd sɛvɹəl tʃɔɪs kɝsɪz. nɑɾ əntɪl spɹɪŋ. ðə laɪt nu wʌt taɪlɪn wʊɾə dʌn tə hɪm, wəɾ əv ɪm duɪŋ, baɪ spɹɪŋ. meɪbi veɪnɪn stilɪŋ hɔɹsəz wɑz nɑt sətʃ ə bæd noʊʃən. "ɡɪvz mi mɔɹ taɪm fəɹ daɪs," hi sɛd, əz ɪf ɪt dɪd nɑt mæɾɝ. "ɪf i wɑns əz mʌtʃ əz jə seɪ, aɪ nid tə fæɾən maɪ pɝs. wʌn θɪŋ jə kən seɪ fəɹ ðə sintʃæn, ðeɪ doʊn sim tə maɪn luzɪŋ." hi tʃɹaɪd tə bi kɛɹfəl haʊ lɔŋ i lɛɾ ɪz lʌk ɹʌn, ən i hæd nɑt feɪst ɛni θɹɛts ə hævɪŋ ɪz θɹoʊt slɪt fəɹ tʃiɾɪŋ, ət list sɪns i hæd bɪn eɪbəl tə liv ðə pæləs ɑn ɪz oʊn fit. ət fɝst, hi hæd bɪlivd ɪt wɑz ɪz lʌk spɹɛɾɪŋ, əɹ pɝhæps biɪŋ tɑvɝən faɪnəli kʌmɪŋ ɪn fəɹ sʌmθɪŋ jusfəl.

Mat considered several choice curses. Not until spring. The Light knew what Tylin would have done to him, would have him doing, by spring. Maybe Vanin stealing horses was not such a bad notion. "Gives me more time for dice," he said, as if it did not matter. "If he wants as much as you say, I need to fatten my purse. One thing you can say for the Seanchan, they don't seem to mind losing." He tried to be careful how long he let his luck run, and he had not faced any threats of having his throat slit for cheating, at least since he had been able to leave the Palace on his own feet. At first, he had believed it was his luck spreading, or perhaps being ta'veren finally coming in for something useful.

bɛslən ɹəɡɑɹɾəd ɪm ɡɹeɪvli. ə dɑɹk slɛndɝ mæn ə lɪɾəl jʌŋɡɝ ðən mæt, hi hæd bɪn blaɪθli ɹeɪkɪʃ wən mæt fɝs mɛt hɪm, ɔlweɪz ɹɛɾi fəɹ ə ɹaʊn ə ðə tævɝnz, ɪspɛʃli ɪf ɪɾ ɛndəd wɪð wɪmən əɹ ə faɪt. sɪns ðə sintʃæn keɪm, hi hæd ɡɹoʊn mɔɹ sɪɹiəs, ðoʊ. tə hɪm, ðeɪ wɝ vɛɹi sɪɹiəs bɪznəs. "maɪ mʌðɝ woʊn bi plizd ɪf ʃi lɝnz aɪm hɛlpɪŋ əɹ pɹɪɾi liv ɛbu dɑɹ, mæt. ʃɪl mɛɹi mi tə sʌmwʌn wɪð ə skwɪn ən ə mʌstæʃ laɪk ə tæɹɑbənɝ fʊt soʊlʒɝ."

Beslan regarded him gravely. A dark slender man a little younger than Mat, he had been blithely rakish when Mat first met him, always ready for a round of the taverns, especially if it ended with women or a fight. Since the Seanchan came, he had grown more serious, though. To him, they were very serious business. "My mother won't be pleased if she learns I am helping her pretty leave Ebou Dar, Mat. She will marry me to someone with a squint and a mustache like a Taraboner foot soldier."

æftɝ ɔl ðɪs taɪm, mæt stɪl wɪnst. hi kəd nɛvɝ ɡɛt juz tə taɪlɪnz sʌn θɪŋkɪŋ wʌɾ ɪz mʌðɝ wɑz duɪŋ wɪð mæt wɑz ɔl ɹaɪt. wɛl, bɛslən dɪd bɪliv ʃi hæd bɪkʌm ə lɪɾəl tu pəzɛsɪv - dʒʌst ə lɪɾəl, maɪnd! - bʌt ðət wɑz ði oʊnli ɹizən i wɑz wɪlɪŋ tə hɛlp. bɛslən kleɪmd mæt wɑz wʌɾ ɪz mʌðɝ niɾəd tə teɪk əɹ maɪn ɔf ði əɡɹiməns ʃi hæd bɪn fɔɹst ɪndə baɪ ðə sintʃæn! səmtaɪmz, mæt wɪʃt i wɑz bæk ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, wɛɹ ət lis jə nu haʊ ʌðɝ pipəl θɔt. səmtaɪmz i dɪd.

After all this time, Mat still winced. He could never get used to Tylin's son thinking what his mother was doing with Mat was all right. Well, Beslan did believe she had become a little too possessive - just a little, mind! - but that was the only reason he was willing to help. Beslan claimed Mat was what his mother needed to take her mind off the agreements she had been forced into by the Seanchan! Sometimes, Mat wished he was back in the Two Rivers, where at least you knew how other people thought. Sometimes he did.

"kæn wi ɹɪtɝn tə ðə pæləs naʊ?" oʊlvɝ sɛd, mɔɹ ə dɪmæn ðən ə kwɛstʃən. "aɪ hæv ə ɹɛɾɪŋ lɛsən wɪð ðə leɪɾi ɹaɪzɛl. ʃi lɛts mi ɹɛs maɪ hɛɾ ɑn əɹ bʊzəm waɪl ʃi ɹidz tə mi."

"Can we return to the Palace now?" Olver said, more a demand than a question. "I have a reading lesson with the Lady Riselle. She lets me rest my head on her bosom while she reads to me."

"ə noʊɾəbəl ətʃivmənt, oʊlvɝ," tɑm sɛd, stʃɹoʊkɪŋ ɪz mʌstæʃɪz tə haɪɾ ə smaɪl. linɪŋ kloʊsɝ tə ði ʌðɝ tu mɛn, hi pɪtʃt ɪz vɔɪs tə ɪskeɪp ðə bɔɪz ɪɹz. "ðə wʊmən meɪks mi pleɪ ðə hɑɹp fəɹ əɹ bɪfɔɹ ʃi lɛts mi ɹɛs maɪ hɛɾ ɑn ðət mæɡnɪfəsən pɪloʊ."

"A notable achievement, Olver," Thom said, stroking his mustaches to hide a smile. Leaning closer to the other two men, he pitched his voice to escape the boy's ears. "The woman makes me play the harp for her before she lets me rest my head on that magnificent pillow."

"ɹaɪzɛl meɪks ɛvɹiwʌn ɛntɝteɪn əɹ fɝst," bɛslən tʃʌkəld ɪn ə noʊɪŋ weɪ, ən tɑm stɛɹɾ əɾ ɪm ɪn əstɑnɪʃmənt.

"Riselle makes everyone entertain her first," Beslan chuckled in a knowing way, and Thom stared at him in astonishment.

mæt ɡɹoʊnd. ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ɪz lɛɡ, ðɪs taɪm, əɹ ðə fæk ðəɾ ɛvɹi mæn ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ sim tə bi tʃuzɪŋ ðə bʊzəm ðeɪ ɹɛstəd ðɛɹ hɛdz ɑn ɪksɛp fəɹ mæt kɔθən. ðoʊz blʌɾi daɪs hæd dʒʌst stɑɹɾəd tʌmbəlɪŋ ɪn ɪz hɛɾ əɡɛn. sʌmθɪŋ bæd wɑz kʌmɪŋ ɪz weɪ. sʌmθɪŋ vɛɹi bæd.

Mat groaned. It was not his leg, this time, or the fact that every man in Ebou Dar seemed to be choosing the bosom they rested their heads on except for Mat Cauthon. Those bloody dice had just started tumbling in his head again. Something bad was coming his way. Something very bad.


tʃæptɝ sɪkstin


CHAPTER 16

ən ʌnɪkspɛktɪɾ ɪnkaʊntɝ


An Unexpected Encounter

ðə wɔk bæk tə ðə sɪɾi wɑz bɛɾɝ ðən tu maɪlz, əkɹɔs loʊ hɪlz ðət wɝk ði eɪk aʊɾ ə mæts lɛɡ ən pʊɾ ɪt bæk əɡɛn bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ tɑpt ə ɹaɪz ən sɔ ɛbu dɑɹ əhɛd, bɪhaɪn ɪts ɛkstʃɹævəɡənli θɪk, waɪt-plæstɝd wɔl ðət noʊ sidʒ kæɾəpʌlt hæɾ ɛvɝ bɪn eɪbəl tə bɹeɪk daʊn. ðə sɪɾi wɪðɪn wɑz waɪt, tu, ðoʊ hɪɹ ən ðəɹ pɔɪntəd doʊmz bɔɹ θɪn stʃɹaɪps ə kʌlɝ. ðə waɪt-plæstɝd bɪldɪŋz, waɪt spaɪɹz ən taʊɝz, waɪt pæləsəz, ɡlimd ivən ɑn ə ɡɹeɪ wɪntɝ deɪ. hɪɹ ən ðəɹ ə taʊɝ ɛndəɾ ɪn ə dʒæɡd tɑp əɹ ə ɡæp ʃoʊd wɛɹ ə bɪldɪŋ hæd bɪn dɪstʃɹɔɪd, bʌɾ ɪn tʃɹuθ, ðə sintʃæn kɑŋkwɛs hæɾ əkeɪʒən lɪɾəl dæmədʒ. ðeɪ hæd bɪn tu fæst, tu stʃɹɔŋ, ən ɪn kəntʃɹoʊl ə ðə sɪɾi bɪfɔɹ mɔɹ ðən skæɾɝd ɹɪzɪstəns kəd fɔɹm.

The walk back to the city was better than two miles, across low hills that worked the ache out of Mat's leg and put it back again before they topped a rise and saw Ebou Dar ahead, behind its extravagantly thick, white-plastered wall that no siege catapult had ever been able to break down. The city within was white, too, though here and there pointed domes bore thin stripes of color. The white-plastered buildings, white spires and towers, white palaces, gleamed even on a gray winter day. Here and there a tower ended in a jagged top or a gap showed where a building had been destroyed, but in truth, the Seanchan conquest had occasioned little damage. They had been too fast, too strong, and in control of the city before more than scattered resistance could form.

sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli, sətʃ tʃɹeɪɾ əz ðəɹ wɑz ðɪs taɪm ə jɪɹ hæd hɑɹdli fɔltɝd wɪð ðə sɪɾiz fɔl. ðə sintʃæn ɛnkɝɪdʒd ɪt, ðoʊ mɝtʃəns ən ʃɪp kæptənz ən kɹuz wɝ ɹikwaɪɝd tə teɪk ən oʊθ tə oʊbeɪ ðə fɔɹʌnɝz, əweɪt ðə ɹɪtɝn, ən sɝv ðoʊz u kʌm hoʊm. ɪn pɹæktəs, ðət mɛn lɑɹdʒli ɡoʊɪŋ əbaʊt jəɹ laɪf əz juʒəwəl, soʊ fju əbdʒɛktəd. ðə bɹɔd hɑɹbɝ wɑz mɔɹ kɹaʊɾəd wɪð ʃɪps ɛvɹi taɪm mæt lʊkt əɾ ɪt. ðɪs æftɝnun, ɪt simd i cʊɾə wɔk fɹəm ɛbu dɑɹ pɹɑpɝ əkɹɔs tə ðə ɹæhəd, ə ɹʌf kɔɹɾɝ i wəd dʒʌst əz sun nɛvɝ ɹivɪzɪt. ɔfən ɪn ðə deɪz æftɝ i fɝs mænədʒ tə wɔk əɡɛn, hi hæd ɡɔn daʊn tə ðə dɑks tə stɛɹ. nɑɾ ət ðə vɛsəlz wɪð ɹɪb seɪlz əɹ ðə si foʊk ʃɪps ðət ðə sintʃæn wɝ ɹeɪ-ɹɪɡɪŋ ən mænɪŋ wɪð ðɛɹ oʊn kɹuz, bʌɾ ət kɹæft flaɪɪŋ ðə ɡoʊldən biz ʌv ɪljən, əɹ ðə sɔɹɾ ən hæn ʌv ɑɹæd dumən, əɹ ðə kɹɛsəns ə tɛɹ. hi noʊ lɔŋɡɝ dɪd. tədeɪ, hi bɛɹli ɡlæns təwɔɹd ðə hɑɹbɝ. ðoʊz daɪs spɪnɪŋ ɪn ɪz hɛd sim tə ɹɔɹ laɪk θʌndɝ. wʌtɛvɝ wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ tə hæpən, hi vɛɹi mʌtʃ daʊɾɪd i wəd laɪk ɪt. hi sɛldəm dɪd, wən ðə daɪs ɡeɪv wɔɹnɪŋ.

Surprisingly, such trade as there was this time of year had hardly faltered with the city's fall. The Seanchan encouraged it, though merchants and ship captains and crews were required to take an oath to obey the Forerunners, await the Return, and serve Those Who Come Home. In practice, that meant largely going about your life as usual, so few objected. The broad harbor was more crowded with ships every time Mat looked at it. This afternoon, it seemed he could have walked from Ebou Dar proper across to the Rahad, a rough quarter he would just as soon never revisit. Often in the days after he first managed to walk again, he had gone down to the docks to stare. Not at the vessels with ribbed sails or the Sea Folk ships that the Seanchan were re-rigging and manning with their own crews, but at craft flying the Golden Bees of Illian, or the Sword and Hand of Arad Doman, or the Crescents of Tear. He no longer did. Today, he barely glanced toward the harbor. Those dice spinning in his head seemed to roar like thunder. Whatever was going to happen, he very much doubted he would like it. He seldom did, when the dice gave warning.
