ðoʊ ə stɛɾi stʃɹim ə tʃɹæfɪk floʊɾ aʊɾ ə ðə ɡɹeɪɾ ɑɹtʃt ɡeɪtweɪ, ən pipəl əfʊt sim tə bi skwizɪŋ θɹu tə ɡɛɾ ɪn, ə θɪk kɑləm ʌv wæɡənz ən ɑks-kɑɹts, stʃɹɛtʃɪŋ ɔl ðə weɪ bæk tə ðə ɹaɪz, wɑz weɪɾɪŋ tə ɛntɝ ən hɑɹdli muvɪŋ. ɛvɹiwʌn dɪpɑɹɾɪŋ ɑn ə hɔɹs wɑz sintʃæn, wɛðɝ wɪð skɪn əz dɑɹk əz wʌn ə ðə si foʊk əɹ peɪl əz ə kɛɹhinɪn, ən ðeɪ stʊɾ aʊt fəɹ mɔɹ ðən biɪŋ maʊntəd. səm ə ðə mɛn wɔɹ vəlumənəs tʃɹaʊzɝz ən ɑd, taɪt koʊts wɪð haɪ kɑlɝz ðət fɪt ðɛɹ nɛks snʌɡli ɹaɪt tə ðə tʃɪn ən ɹoʊz ə ʃaɪni mɛɾəl bʌɾənz daʊn ðə fɹʌnt, əɹ floʊɪŋ, ɪlæbɹətli ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd koʊts ɔlmoʊst əz lɔŋ əz ə wʊmənz dʒɹɛs. ðeɪ wɝ ə ðə blʌd, əz wɝ ðə wɪmən ɪn stʃɹeɪnʒli kʌt ɹaɪɾɪŋ dʒɹɛsəz ðət simd meɪɾ ə nɛɹoʊ plits, wɪð dɪvaɪɾəd skɝts kʌt tə ɪkspoʊz kʌlɝfli buɾɪd æŋkəlz ən waɪd slivz ðət hʌŋ tə ðɛɹ fiɾ ɪn ðə stɝəps. ə fju wɔɹ leɪs veɪlz ðət hɪɾ ɔl bʌt ðɛɹ aɪz, soʊ ðɛɹ feɪsəz wɝ nɑɾ ɪkspoʊz tə ðə loʊbɔɹn. moʊst ə ðə ɹaɪɾɝz baɪ fɑɹ, haʊɛvɝ, wɔɹ bɹaɪtli peɪntəɾ ɑɹmɝ ʌv oʊvɝlæpɪŋ pleɪts. səm ə ðə soʊlʒɝz wɝ wɪmən, tu, ðoʊ ðəɹ wɑz noʊ weɪ tə tɛl wɪtʃ wɪð ðoʊz peɪntəd hɛlməts laɪk ðə hɛdz ə mɑnstʃɹəs ɪnsɛks. ət lis nʌn wɔɹ ðə blæk-ænd-ɹɛɾ ə ðə dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹd. ivən ʌðɝ sintʃæn sim nɝvəs ɝaʊn ðɛm, ən ðət wɑz ɪnʌf tə wɔɹn mæt tə wɔk waɪɾ ɝaʊn ðɛm.

Though a steady stream of traffic flowed out of the great arched gateway, and people afoot seemed to be squeezing through to get in, a thick column of wagons and ox-carts, stretching all the way back to the rise, was waiting to enter and hardly moving. Everyone departing on a horse was Seanchan, whether with skin as dark as one of the Sea Folk or pale as a Cairhienin, and they stood out for more than being mounted. Some of the men wore voluminous trousers and odd, tight coats with high collars that fit their necks snugly right to the chin and rows of shiny metal buttons down the front, or flowing, elaborately embroidered coats almost as long as a woman's dress. They were of the Blood, as were the women in strangely cut riding dresses that seemed made of narrow pleats, with divided skirts cut to expose colorfully booted ankles and wide sleeves that hung to their feet in the stirrups. A few wore lace veils that hid all but their eyes, so their faces were not exposed to the lowborn. Most of the riders by far, however, wore brightly painted armor of overlapping plates. Some of the soldiers were women, too, though there was no way to tell which with those painted helmets like the heads of monstrous insects. At least none wore the black-and-red of the Deathwatch Guard. Even other Seanchan seemed nervous around them, and that was enough to warn Mat to walk wide around them.

ɪn ɛni keɪs, nʌn ə ðə sintʃæn spɛɹd soʊ mʌtʃ əz ə ɡlæns fəɹ θɹi mɛn ən ə bɔɪ sloʊli wɔkɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə sɪɾi əlɔŋ ðə kɑləm ʌv weɪɾɪŋ kɑɹts ən wæɡənz. wɛl, ðə mɛn wɔk sloʊli. oʊlvɝ skɪpt. mæts lɛɡ wɑz sɛɾɪŋ ðɛɹ peɪs, bʌɾ i tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə lɛt ði ʌðɝz si haʊ mʌtʃ i wɑz linɪŋ ɑn ɪz stæf. ðə daɪs juʒəwəli ənaʊnst ɪnsəɾənts i mænədʒ tə sɝvaɪv baɪ ðə skɪn ə hɪz tiθ, bæɾəlz, ə bɪldɪŋ dʒɹɑpɪŋ ɑn ɪz hɛd. taɪlɪn. hi dʒɹɛɾɪd wʌt wəd hæpən wən ðeɪ stɑp ðɪs taɪm.

In any case, none of the Seanchan spared so much as a glance for three men and a boy slowly walking toward the city along the column of waiting carts and wagons. Well, the men walked slowly. Olver skipped. Mat's leg was setting their pace, but he tried not to let the others see how much he was leaning on his staff. The dice usually announced incidents he managed to survive by the skin of his teeth, battles, a building dropping on his head. Tylin. He dreaded what would happen when they stopped this time.

nɪɹli ɔl ə ðə wæɡənz ən kɑɹts livɪŋ ðə sɪɾi hæd sintʃæn dʒɹaɪvɪŋ əɹ wɔkɪŋ əlɔŋsaɪd, mɔɹ pleɪnli dʒɹɛs ðən ðoʊz ɑn hɔɹsəz, hɑɹdli pəkjuljɝ lʊkɪŋ əɾ ɔl, bʌt ðoʊz ɪn ðə weɪɾɪŋ laɪn wɝ mɔɹ laɪkli tə bɪlɔŋ tə ɛbu dɑɹi əɹ foʊk fɹəm ðə sɝaʊndɪŋ ɛɹiə, mɛn ɪn lɔŋ vɛsts, wɪmən wɪð ðɛɹ skɝts soʊn ʌp ɑn wʌn saɪd tə ɪkspoʊz ə stɑkɪnɡd lɛɡ əɹ kʌlɝfəl pɛɾikoʊts, ðɛɹ wæɡənz əz wɛl əz ðɛɹ kɑɹts pʊl baɪ ɑksən. aʊtləndɝz dɑɾəd ðə kɑləm, mɝtʃəns wɪð smɔl tʃɹeɪnz ə hɔɹs-dʒɹɔn wæɡənz. ðəɹ wɑz mɔɹ tʃɹeɪɾ ɪn wɪntɝ hɪɹ ɪn ðə saʊθ ðən fɑɹðɝ nɔɹθ, wɛɹ mɝtʃəns hæd tə kəntɛnd wɪð snoʊ-kʌvɝd ɹoʊdz, ən ðeɪ keɪm fɹəm fɑɹ, səm ə ðɛm. ə staʊt dəmɑni wʊmən wɪð ə dɑɹk bjuɾi pætʃ ɑn əɹ kɑpɝ tʃik, ɹaɪɾɪŋ ðə lɛɾ ə fɔɹ wæɡənz, klʌtʃt əɹ flaʊɝd kloʊk ɝaʊn əɹ ən skaʊld əɾ ə mæn faɪv wæɡənz əhɛɾ ə hɝ ɪn ðə laɪn, ə ɡɹisi-lʊkɪŋ fɛloʊ, haɪɾɪŋ lɔŋ θɪk mʌstæʃɪz bɪhaɪn ə tæɹɑbənɝ veɪl, bɪsaɪd ðə wæɡən dʒɹaɪvɝ. ə kəmpɛɾətɝ, noʊ daʊt. ə lin kændɔɹi wɪð ə lɑɹdʒ pɝl ɪn əɹ lɛft ɪɹ ən sɪlvɝ tʃeɪnz əkɹɔs əɹ tʃɛst sæɾ əɹ sæɾəl kɑmli, ɡlʌv hæn foʊldəɾ ɑn ðə pɑməl, meɪbi stɪl ʌnəwɛɹ ðəɾ əɹ ɡɹeɪ ɡɛldɪŋ ən əɹ wæɡən timz əlaɪk wəd bi pʊɾ ɪndə ðə lɑɾɝi wʌns ʃi wɑz ɪndə ðə sɪɾi. wʌn hɔɹs ɪn faɪv hæd bɪn teɪkən fɹəm loʊkəlz, ən soʊ əz nɑt tə dɪskɝɪdʒ tʃɹeɪd, wʌn ɪn tɛn fɹəm aʊtləndɝz. peɪd fɔɹ, tʃɹu, ən ə fɛɹ pɹaɪs ɪn ʌðɝ deɪz, bʌt nɑt nɪɹli wʌt ðə mɑɹkət wəd bɛɹ, ɡɪvən ðə dɪmænd. mæt ɔlweɪz noʊɾəst hɔɹsəz, ivən ɪf wɪð oʊnli hæf ɪz maɪn əɹ lɛs. ə fæt kɛɹhinɪn ɪn ə koʊɾ əz dʒɹæb əz ðoʊz ə hɪz wæɡən dʒɹaɪvɝz wɑz ʃaʊɾɪŋ æŋɡɹəli əbaʊt ðə dɪleɪ ən lɛɾɪŋ ɪz faɪn beɪ mɛɹ dæns nɝvəsli. ə vɛɹi ɡʊd kənfɝmeɪʃən ɑn ðət mɛɹ. ʃi wəd ɡoʊ tə ən ɔfəsɝ, moʊs laɪkli. wʌt wɑz gɑnə hæpən wən ðə daɪs stɑpt?

Nearly all of the wagons and carts leaving the city had Seanchan driving or walking alongside, more plainly dressed than those on horses, hardly peculiar looking at all, but those in the waiting line were more likely to belong to Ebou Dari or folk from the surrounding area, men in long vests, women with their skirts sewn up on one side to expose a stockinged leg or colorful petticoats, their wagons as well as their carts pulled by oxen. Outlanders dotted the column, merchants with small trains of horse-drawn wagons. There was more trade in winter here in the south than farther north, where merchants had to contend with snow-covered roads, and they came from far, some of them. A stout Domani woman with a dark beauty patch on her copper cheek, riding the lead of four wagons, clutched her flowered cloak around her and scowled at a man five wagons ahead of her in the line, a greasy-looking fellow, hiding long thick mustaches behind a Taraboner veil, beside the wagon driver. A competitor, no doubt. A lean Kandori with a large pearl in her left ear and silver chains across her chest sat her saddle calmly, gloved hand folded on the pommel, maybe still unaware that her gray gelding and her wagon teams alike would be put into the lottery once she was into the city. One horse in five had been taken from locals, and so as not to discourage trade, one in ten from outlanders. Paid for, true, and a fair price in other days, but not nearly what the market would bear, given the demand. Mat always noticed horses, even if with only half his mind or less. A fat Cairhienin in a coat as drab as those of his wagon drivers was shouting angrily about the delay and letting his fine bay mare dance nervously. A very good conformation on that mare. She would go to an officer, most likely. What was going to happen when the dice stopped?

ðə waɪɾ ɑɹtʃt ɡeɪts ɪndə ðə sɪɾi hæd ðɛɹ ɡɑɹdz, ðoʊ ɪt wɑz laɪkli oʊnli ðə sintʃæn ɹɛkəɡnaɪzd əm əz sʌtʃ. sʌldəm ɪn ðɛɹ laɪtnɪŋ-pænəl blu dʒɹɛsəz θɹɛɾəd bæk ən fɔɹθ θɹu ðə stʃɹimz ə tʃɹæfɪk wɪð ɡɹeɪ-klæd deɪmeɪn ɑn sɪlvɝi æɾəm. dʒʌst wʌn ə ðoʊz pɛɹz wʊɾə bɪn səfɪʃən tə kwɛl ɛni dɪstɝbəns ʃɔɹɾ ʌv ə fʊl-skeɪl əsɔlt, ən meɪbi ivən ðæt, bʌt ðət wɑz nɑt ðə ɹil ɹizən fəɹ ðɛɹ pɹɛzəns. ɪn ðə fɝs deɪz æftɝ ɛbu dɑɹz fɔl, waɪl i wɑz stɪl kənfaɪn tə bɛd, ðeɪ hæd hɛɹɹoʊd ðə sɪɾi sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ ðə wɪmən ðeɪ kɔl mɛɹəθdəmeɪn, ən naʊ ðeɪ meɪd ʃʊɹ nʌn kəɾ ɛntɝ. ðə sʌldəm itʃ kæɹiɾ ən ɛkstʃɹə liʃ kɔɪld ɑn əɹ ʃoʊldɝ dʒʌst ɪn keɪs. pɛɹz pətʃɹoʊl ðə dɑks, tu, miɾɪŋ ɛvɹi ɝaɪvɪŋ ʃɪp ən boʊt.

The wide arched gates into the city had their guards, though it was likely only the Seanchan recognized them as such. Sul'dam in their lightning-paneled blue dresses threaded back and forth through the streams of traffic with gray-clad damane on silvery a'dam. Just one of those pairs would have been sufficient to quell any disturbance short of a full-scale assault, and maybe even that, but that was not the real reason for their presence. In the first days after Ebou Dar's fall, while he was still confined to bed, they had harrowed the city searching for the women they called Marath'damane, and now they made sure none could enter. The sul'dam each carried an extra leash coiled on her shoulder just in case. Pairs patrolled the docks, too, meeting every arriving ship and boat.

bɪsaɪd ðə waɪɾ ɑɹtʃt ɡeɪɾ ɪndə ðə sɪɾi, ə lɔŋ plætfɔɹm dɪspleɪd, ɑn spaɪks twɛnti fiɾ əbʌv ðə ɡɹaʊnd, ðə tɑɹd bʌt stɪl ɹɛkəɡnaɪzəbəl hɛdz ʌv oʊvɝ ə dʌzən mɛn ən tu wɪmən u hæd fɔlən əfaʊl ə sintʃæn dʒʌstəs. əbʌv əm hʌŋ ðə sɪmbəl fəɹ ðət dʒʌstəs, ə hɛdzmənz slænt-ɛdʒd æks wɪð ðə hæft ɹæpt ɪn ən ɪntʃɹəkətli nɑɾɪd waɪt kɔɹd. ə plækɝd bɪloʊ itʃ hɛɾ ənaʊns ðə kɹaɪm ðət hæd pleɪst ɪt ðɛɹ, mɝɾɝ əɹ ɹeɪp, ɹɑbɝi wɪð vaɪələns, əsɔlt ɑn wʌn ə ðə blʌd. lɛsɝ əfɛnsɪz bɹɔt faɪnz əɹ flɑɡɪŋ, əɹ biɪŋ meɪd dækoʊvæl. ðə sintʃæn wɝ ivənhændɪɾ əbaʊɾ ɪt. nʌn ə ðə blʌd ðɛmsɛlvz wɝ ɑn dɪspleɪ - wʌn ə ðoʊz u ɝn ɛksəkjuʃən wəd bi sɛn bæk tə sintʃæn, əɹ stʃɹæŋɡəld wɪð ðə waɪt kɔɹd - bʌt θɹi ʌv ðoʊz hɛdz hæd bɪn ətætʃt tə sintʃæn, ən ðə weɪɾ ə ðɛɹ dʒʌstəs fɛl ɑn haɪ əz wɛl əz loʊ. tu plækɝdz mɑɹkt ɹɪbɛljən hʌŋ bɪloʊ ðə hɛdz ə ðə wʊmən u hæd bɪn mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps tə ði æθɑn maɪɹ ən əɹ mæstɝ ə ðə bleɪdz.

Beside the wide arched gate into the city, a long platform displayed, on spikes twenty feet above the ground, the tarred but still recognizable heads of over a dozen men and two women who had fallen afoul of Seanchan justice. Above them hung the symbol for that justice, a headsman's slant-edged axe with the haft wrapped in an intricately knotted white cord. A placard below each head announced the crime that had placed it there, murder or rape, robbery with violence, assault on one of the Blood. Lesser offenses brought fines or flogging, or being made da'covale. The Seanchan were evenhanded about it. None of the Blood themselves were on display - one of those who earned execution would be sent back to Seanchan, or strangled with the white cord - but three of those heads had been attached to Seanchan, and the weight of their justice fell on high as well as low. Two placards marked rebellion hung below the heads of the woman who had been Mistress of the Ships to the Atha'an Miere and her Master of the Blades.

mæt hæd bɪn θɹu ðət ɡeɪɾ ɔfən ɪnʌf ðəɾ i bɛɹli noʊɾəst ðə dɪspleɪ, naʊ. oʊlvɝ skɪpt əlɔŋ sɪŋɪŋ ə ɹaɪmɪŋ sɔŋ. bɛslən ən tɑm wɔkt wɪð ðɛɹ hɛdz təɡɛðɝ, ən wʌns mæt kɑɾ ə sɑft "ɹɪski bɪznəs" fɹəm tɑm, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt kɛɹ wʌt ðeɪ wɝ tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt. ðən ðeɪ wɝ ɪndə ðə lɔŋ, dɪm tʌnəl ðət kæɹid ðə ɹoʊd θɹu ðə wɔl, ən ðə ɹʌmbəl ʌv wæɡənz pæsɪŋ θɹu wʊɾə meɪd lɪsnɪŋ ɪmpɑsəbəl ivən hæɾ i wɑntəd tə. kipɪŋ kloʊs tə ðə saɪd, wɛl əweɪ fɹəm ðə wæɡən wilz, tɑm ən bɛslən fɔɹdʒd əhɛd tɔkɪŋ ɪn loʊ mɝmɝz, oʊlvɝ dɑɹɾɪŋ æftɝ ðɛm, bʌt wən mæt ɪmɝdʒd ɪndə deɪlaɪɾ əɡɛn, hi wɔkt ɪndə tɑmz bæk bɪfɔɹ i ɹilaɪz ðəɾ ɔl ə ðɛm hæd stɑpt, hɑɹd bɪsaɪd ðə tʌnəlz maʊθ. ɑn ðə pɔɪn ə meɪkɪŋ ə kɑstɪk kɑmɛnt, hi sʌɾənli sɔ wʌt ðeɪ wɝ stɛɹɪŋ æt. pipəl əfʊt pʊʃɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə tʌnəl bɪhaɪn ɪm ʃʌvd əm əsaɪd, bʌɾ i dʒʌst stɛɹd, tu.

Mat had been through that gate often enough that he barely noticed the display, now. Olver skipped along singing a rhyming song. Beslan and Thom walked with their heads together, and once Mat caught a soft "risky business" from Thom, but he did not care what they were talking about. Then they were into the long, dim tunnel that carried the road through the wall, and the rumble of wagons passing through would have made listening impossible even had he wanted to. Keeping close to the side, well away from the wagon wheels, Thom and Beslan forged ahead talking in low murmurs, Olver darting after them, but when Mat emerged into daylight again, he walked into Thom's back before he realized that all of them had stopped, hard beside the tunnel's mouth. On the point of making a caustic comment, he suddenly saw what they were staring at. People afoot pushing out of the tunnel behind him shoved them aside, but he just stared, too.

ðə stʃɹits ʌv ɛbu dɑɹ wɝ ɔlweɪz fʊl ə pipəl, bʌt nɑt laɪk ðɪs, əz ðoʊ ə dæm hæd bɝst ən sɛn ə flʌɾ ə hjumænɪɾi ɪndə ðə sɪɾi. ðə θɹɔŋ pæk ðə stʃɹiɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm fɹəm wʌn saɪd tə ði ʌðɝ, sɝaʊndɪŋ pulz ə laɪvstɑk ðə laɪk ʌv wɪtʃ i hæd nɛvɝ sin bɪfɔɹ, spɑɾəd waɪt kæɾəl wɪð lɔŋ ʌp-swɛp hɔɹnz, peɪl bɹaʊn ɡoʊts kʌvɝɾ ɪn faɪn hɛɹ ðət hʌŋ tə ðə peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz, ʃip wɪð fɔɹ hɔɹnz. ɛvɹi stʃɹiɾ i kəd si lʊkt əz dʒæmd. wæɡənz ən kɑɹts ɪntʃt θɹu ðə mæs wɛɹ ðeɪ muvd əɾ ɔl, ðə ʃaʊts ən kɝsɪz ə ðə wæɡən dʒɹaɪvɝz ən kɑɹɾɝz ɔl bʌt dʒɹaʊn ɪn ðə bæbəl ə vɔɪsəz ən ðə nɔɪz ə ði ænəməlz. hi kəd nɑt meɪk aʊt wɝdz, bʌɾ i kəd dɪstɪŋɡwɪʃ æksɛns. sloʊ, dʒɹɔlɪŋ sintʃæn æksɛns. səm ə ðɛm nʌdʒd ə neɪbɝ ən pɔɪntəɾ əɾ ɪm ɪn ɪz bɹaɪt kloʊðɪŋ. ðeɪ wɝ ɡeɪpɪŋ ən pɔɪntɪŋ əɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ, əz ɪf ðeɪ hæd nɛvɝ sin ən ɪn əɹ ə kʌtlɝz ʃɑp bɪfɔɹ, bʌɾ i stɪl ɡɹaʊld ʌndɝ ɪz bɹɛθ ən dʒɝkt ɪz hæt bɹɪm loʊ oʊvɝ ɪz aɪz.

The streets of Ebou Dar were always full of people, but not like this, as though a dam had burst and sent a flood of humanity into the city. The throng packed the street in front of him from one side to the other, surrounding pools of livestock the like of which he had never seen before, spotted white cattle with long up-swept horns, pale brown goats covered in fine hair that hung to the paving stones, sheep with four horns. Every street he could see looked as jammed. Wagons and carts inched through the mass where they moved at all, the shouts and curses of the wagon drivers and carters all but drowned in the babble of voices and the noise of the animals. He could not make out words, but he could distinguish accents. Slow, drawling Seanchan accents. Some of them nudged a neighbor and pointed at him in his bright clothing. They were gaping and pointing at everything, as if they had never seen an inn or a cutler's shop before, but he still growled under his breath and jerked his hat brim low over his eyes.

"ðə ɹɪtɝn," tɑm mʌɾɝd, ən ɪf mæt hæd nɑt bɪn ɹaɪɾ əɾ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ i wəd nɑɾ əv hɝd. "waɪl wi wɝ teɪkɪŋ əɹ iz wɪð lukə, ðə kɔɝɪn əz ɝaɪvd."

"The Return," Thom muttered, and if Mat had not been right at his shoulder he would not have heard. "While we were taking our ease with Luca, the Corenne has arrived."

mæt hæd bɪn θɪŋkɪŋ ə ðɪs ɹɪtɝn ðət ðə sintʃæn kɛpt ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn əbaʊɾ əz ən ɪnveɪʒən, ən ɑɹmi. wʌn ə ðə wæɡən dʒɹaɪvɝz ʃaʊɾəd ən weɪvd əɹ lɔŋ-hændəld wɪp ət səm bɔɪz u hæd kɹɔld ʌp ɑn ðə saɪɾ ə ðə wæɡən bɑks tə poʊk ət wʌɾ əpɪɹd tə bi ɡɹeɪpvaɪnz ɪn wʊɾən tʌbz ə ɝθ. ənʌðɝ wæɡən hɛld ə lɔŋ pɹɪntɪŋ pɹɛs, ən stɪl ənʌðɝ, dʒʌs mænɪdʒɪŋ tə tɝn ɪndə ðə tʌnəl, kæɹid wʌt lʊk laɪk bɹuɝz' væts ən ə feɪn smɛl ə hɑps. kɹeɪts ə stʃɹeɪnʒli kʌlɝd tʃɪkənz ən dʌks ən ɡis dɛkɝeɪɾəd səm ə ðoʊz wæɡənz, nɑt bɝdz fəɹ seɪl, bʌɾ ə fɑɹmɝz stɑk. ɪt wɑz ən ɑɹmi ɔl ɹaɪt, oʊnli nɑt ðə sɔɹɾ i hæɾ ɪmædʒənd. ðɪs kaɪndə ɑɹmi wəd bi hɑɹɾɝ tə faɪt ðən soʊlʒɝz.

Mat had been thinking of this Return that the Seanchan kept going on about as an invasion, an army. One of the wagon drivers shouted and waved her long-handled whip at some boys who had crawled up on the side of the wagon box to poke at what appeared to be grapevines in wooden tubs of earth. Another wagon held a long printing press, and still another, just managing to turn into the tunnel, carried what looked like brewers' vats and a faint smell of hops. Crates of strangely colored chickens and ducks and geese decorated some of those wagons, not birds for sale, but a farmer's stock. It was an army all right, only not the sort he had imagined. This kind of army would be harder to fight than soldiers.

"stæb maɪ aɪz, wɪl əv tə weɪd tə ɡɛt ðoʊ ðɪs!" bɛslən ɡɹʌmbəld ɪn dɪsɡʌst, ɹaɪzɪŋ ɑn ɪz toʊz tə tʃɹaɪ piɹɪŋ fɑɹðɝ əhɛɾ oʊvɝ ðə kɹaʊd. "haʊ fɑɹ bɪfɔɹ wi faɪn ə klɪɹ stʃɹit?"

"Stab my eyes, we'll have to wade to get though this!" Beslan grumbled in disgust, rising on his toes to try peering farther ahead over the crowd. "How far before we find a clear street?"

mæt faʊn hɪmsɛlf ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ wʌɾ i hæd nɑt ɹɪli sin wən ɪt wɑz ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪz aɪz, ðə hɑɹbɝ fʊl ə ʃɪps. fʊl ə ʃɪps. meɪbi tu əɹ θɹi taɪmz ðə vɛsəlz ðət hæd bɪn ðəɹ wən ðeɪ lɛft fəɹ lukəz kæmp ət fɝs laɪt, kwaɪɾ ə fju ʌv əm stɪl mənuvɝɪŋ ʌndɝ seɪl. wɪtʃ mɛn ðəɹ maɪt bi mɔɹ stɪl weɪɾɪŋ tə ɛntɝ ðə hɑɹbɝ. laɪt! haʊ mɛni cʊɾə dɪsɡɔɹdʒ ðɛɹ kɑɹɡoʊ sɪns mɔɹnɪŋ? haʊ mɛni ɹɪmeɪn tə bi ənloʊɾəd? laɪt, haʊ mɛni pipəl kəd bi kæɹiɾ ɑn ðət nʌmbɝ ə ʃɪps? ən waɪ hæd ðeɪ ɔl kʌm hɪɹ ɪnstɛɾ ə tæntʃəkoʊ? ə ʃɪvɝ ɹæn daʊn ɪz spaɪn. meɪbi ðɪs wɑz nɑɾ ɔl ə ðɛm.

Mat found himself remembering what he had not really seen when it was in front of his eyes, the harbor full of ships. Full of ships. Maybe two or three times the vessels that had been there when they left for Luca's camp at first light, quite a few of them still maneuvering under sail. Which meant there might be more still waiting to enter the harbor. Light! How many could have disgorged their cargo since morning? How many remained to be unloaded? Light, how many people could be carried on that number of ships? And why had they all come here instead of Tanchico? A shiver ran down his spine. Maybe this was not all of them.

"ju hæd bɛs tʃɹaɪ tə faɪn jəɹ weɪ baɪ bæk stʃɹits ən æliz," hi sɛd, ɹeɪzɪŋ ɪz vɔɪs soʊ ðeɪ kəd hɪɹ oʊvɝ ðə kækɑfəni. "ju woʊn ɹitʃ ðə pæləs bɪfɔɹ naɪt, ʌðɝwaɪz."

"You had best try to find your way by back streets and alleys," he said, raising his voice so they could hear over the cacophony. "You won't reach the Palace before night, otherwise."

bɛslən tɝn ə fɹaʊn ɑn hɪm. "ju ɑɹən ɹɪtɝnɪŋ wɪð ʌs? mæt, ɪf jə tʃɹaɪ tə baɪ pæsədʒ ɑn ə ʃɪp əɡɛn . . . jə noʊ ʃi woʊnt ɡoʊ izi ɑn jə ðɪs taɪm."

Beslan turned a frown on him. "You aren't returning with us? Mat, if you try to buy passage on a ship again . . . You know she won't go easy on you this time."

mæt mætʃt ðə kwinz sʌn skaʊl fəɹ skaʊl. "aɪ dʒʌst wɑnə wɔk ɝaʊn ə lɪɾəl," hi laɪd. əz sun əz i ɹɪtɝn tə ðə pæləs, taɪlɪn wəd stɑɹt kɑsəɾɪŋ ən pɛɾɪŋ hɪm. ɪt wəd nɑɾ əv bɪn ðət bæd, ɹɪli - nɑt ɹɪli - ɪksɛp ðət ʃi dɪd nɑt kɛɹ u sɔ hɝ kɝɛs ɪz tʃiks ən wɪspɝ ɛndɪɹməns ɪn ɪz ɪɹ, ivən əɹ sʌn. bɪsaɪdz, wʌɾ ɪf ðə daɪs ɪn ɪz hɛd stɑpt wən i ɹitʃt hɝ? pəzɛsɪv wɑz hɑɹdli ðə wɝd fəɹ taɪlɪn ðiz deɪz. blʌɾ ən æʃəz, ðə wʊmən maɪɾ əv dɪsaɪɾɪd tə mɛɹi hɪm! hi dɪd nɑt wɑnə mɛɹi, nɑt jɛt, bʌɾ i nu hu hi wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ tə mɛɹi, ən ɪt wɑz nɑt taɪlɪn kwɪntɑɹə mɪtsoʊbɑɹ. oʊnli, wʌt kəɾ i də ɪf ʃi dɪsaɪɾɪd dɪfɹənli?

Mat matched the Queen's son scowl for scowl. "I just want to walk around a little," he lied. As soon as he returned to the Palace, Tylin would start cosseting and petting him. It would not have been that bad, really - not really - except that she did not care who saw her caress his cheeks and whisper endearments in his ear, even her son. Besides, what if the dice in his head stopped when he reached her? Possessive was hardly the word for Tylin these days. Blood and ashes, the woman might have decided to marry him! He did not want to marry, not yet, but he knew who he was going to marry, and it was not Tylin Quintara Mitsobar. Only, what could he do if she decided differently?

sʌɾənli hi ɹɪmɛmbɝd tɑmz mɝmɝ ʌv "ɹɪski bɪznəs." hi nu tɑm, ən i nu bɛslən. oʊlvɝ wɑz ɡeɪpɪŋ ət ðə sintʃæn əz hɑɹɾ əz ðeɪ ðɛmsɛlvz wɝ əɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɝaʊn ðɛm. hi stɑɹɾəd tə dɑɹɾ əweɪ fəɹ ə kloʊsɝ lʊk, ən mæt sizd ɪz ʃoʊldɝ dʒʌst ɪn taɪm ən pʊʃt hɪm, pɹətɛstɪŋ, ɪndə tɑmz hænz. "teɪk ðə bɔɪ bæk tə ðə pæləs ən ɡɪv ɪm ɪz lɛsənz wən ɹaɪzɛl ɪz dʌn wɪð hɪm. ən fɝɡɛt wʌtɛvɝ mædnəs juv ɪn maɪnd. jə kəd pʊt jəɹ hɛdz ɑn dɪspleɪ aʊtsaɪd ðə ɡeɪt, ən taɪlɪnz, tu." ən ɪz oʊn. nɛvɝ lɛt ðət bi fɝɡɑɾən!

Suddenly he remembered Thom's murmur of "risky business." He knew Thom, and he knew Beslan. Olver was gaping at the Seanchan as hard as they themselves were at everything around them. He started to dart away for a closer look, and Mat seized his shoulder just in time and pushed him, protesting, into Thom's hands. "Take the boy back to the Palace and give him his lessons when Riselle is done with him. And forget whatever madness you have in mind. You could put your heads on display outside the gate, and Tylin's, too." And his own. Never let that be forgotten!

ðə tu mɛn stɛɹd bæk əɾ ɪm wɪθaʊɾ ɛni ɪkspɹɛʃən, əz ɡʊɾ əz kənfɝmɪŋ ɪz səspɪʃənz.

The two men stared back at him without any expression, as good as confirming his suspicions.

"pɝhæps aɪ ʃəd wɔk wɪð ju," tɑm sɛɾ ət læst. "wi kəd tɔk. jəɹ ɹɪmɑɹkəbli lʌki, mæt, ən juv ə sɝɾən flɛɹ fɔɹ, ʃæl wi seɪ, ði ædvɛntʃɝəs?" bɛslən nɑɾəd. oʊlvɝ skwɝmd ɪn tɑmz ɡɹɪp, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə stɛɹ əɾ ɔl ðə stʃɹeɪnʒ pipəl ət wʌns ən ʌnkənsɝnd wɪð wʌɾ ɪz ɛldɝz wɝ tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt.

"Perhaps I should walk with you," Thom said at last. "We could talk. You're remarkably lucky, Mat, and you have a certain flair for, shall we say, the adventurous?" Beslan nodded. Olver squirmed in Thom's grip, trying to stare at all the strange people at once and unconcerned with what his elders were talking about.

mæt ɡɹʌntɪd saʊɝli. waɪ dɪd pipəl ɔlweɪz wɑn ɪm tə bi ə hɪɹoʊ? sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ ðət sɔɹɾ ə θɪŋ wɑz gɑnə ɡɛɾ ɪm kɪld. "aɪ doʊnt nid tə tɔk əbaʊɾ ɛniθɪŋ. ðeɪ ɑɹ hɪɹ, bɛslən. ɪf jə kʊdn stɑp əm ɡɛɾɪŋ ɪn, ʃʊɹ əz mɔɹnɪŋ, jə woʊn bi eɪbəl tə pʊʃ əm aʊt. ɹænd wɪl dil wɪð ðɛm, ɪf ðə ɹumɝz ɑɹ ɛniθɪŋ tə ɡoʊ baɪ." əɡɛn, ðoʊz wɝlɪŋ kʌlɝz spʌn θɹu hɪz hɛd, ɔlmoʊst əbliɾɝeɪtɪŋ ðə saʊn ə ðə daɪs fəɹ ən ɪnstənt. "ju tʊk ðət blʌɾi oʊθ tə weɪɾ ɑn ðə ɹɪtɝn; wi ɔl dɪd." ɹəfjuzəl hæd mɛn biɪŋ pʊɾ ɪn tʃeɪnz ən sɛt tə wɝk ɑn ðə dɑks, əɹ klɪɹɪŋ ðə kənælz ɪn ðə ɹæhəd. wɪtʃ meɪɾ ɪt noʊ oʊθ əɾ ɔl, ɪn ɪz bʊk. "weɪɾ ɑn ɹænd." ðə kʌlɝz keɪm wʌns mɔɹ ən vænɪʃt. blʌɾ ən æʃəz! hi dʒʌs hæd tə stɑp θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt . . . əbaʊt sɝɾən pipəl. əɡɛn ðeɪ swɝld. "ɪt maɪt kʌm aʊt ɹaɪt jɛt, ɪf jə ɡɪv ɪt taɪm."

Mat grunted sourly. Why did people always want him to be a hero? Sooner or later that sort of thing was going to get him killed. "I don't need to talk about anything. They are here, Beslan. If you couldn't stop them getting in, sure as morning, you won't be able to push them out. Rand will deal with them, if the rumors are anything to go by." Again, those whirling colors spun through his head, almost obliterating the sound of the dice for an instant. "You took that bloody oath to wait on the Return; we all did." Refusal had meant being put in chains and set to work on the docks, or clearing the canals in the Rahad. Which made it no oath at all, in his book. "Wait on Rand." The colors came once more and vanished. Blood and ashes! He just had to stop thinking about . . . About certain people. Again they swirled. "It might come out right yet, if you give it time."

"ju doʊn ʌndɝstænd, mæt," bɛslən sɛd fɪɹsli. "mʌðɝ stɪl sɪts ɑn ðə θɹoʊn, ən sjuɹɔθ sɛz ʃɪl ɹul ɔl ʌv ɔltɑɹə, nɑt dʒʌst wʌt wi hoʊld ɝaʊn ɛbu dɑɹ, ən meɪbi mɔɹ bɪsaɪdz, bʌt mʌðɝ hæd tə laɪ daʊn ɑn əɹ feɪs ən swɛɹ fiəlti tə səm wʊmən ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ði ɛɹɪθ oʊʃən. sjuɹɔθ sɛz aɪ ʃəd mɛɹi wʌn ə ðɛɹ blʌɾ ən ʃeɪv ðə saɪdz ə maɪ hɛd, ən mʌðɝ ɪz lɪsnɪŋ tə hɝ. sjuɹɔθ maɪt pɹitɛn ðeɪ ɑɹ ikwəlz, bʌt ʃiz tə lɪsən wən sjuɹɔθ spiks. noʊ mæɾɝ wʌt sjuɹɔθ sɛz, ɛbu dɑɹ ɪzən ɹɪli aʊɝz ɛnimɔɹ, ən ðə ɹɛst woʊn bi iðɝ. meɪbi wi kæn pʊʃ əm aʊt baɪ fɔɹs ʌv ɑɹmz, bʌt wi kən meɪk ðə kʌntʃɹi tu hɑt tə hoʊl ðɛm. ðə waɪtkloʊks faʊn aʊt. æsk əm wʌt ðeɪ min baɪ 'ði ɔltɑɹən nun.' "

"You don't understand, Mat," Beslan said fiercely. "Mother still sits on the throne, and Suroth says she will rule all of Altara, not just what we hold around Ebou Dar, and maybe more besides, but mother had to lie down on her face and swear fealty to some woman on the other side of the Aryth Ocean. Suroth says I should marry one of their Blood and shave the sides of my head, and mother is listening to her. Suroth might pretend they are equals, but she has to listen when Suroth speaks. No matter what Suroth says, Ebou Dar isn't really ours anymore, and the rest won't be either. Maybe we can't push them out by force of arms, but we can make the country too hot to hold them. The Whitecloaks found out. Ask them what they mean by 'the Altaran Noon.' "

mæt kəd ɡɛs wɪθaʊɾ æskɪŋ ɛniwʌn. hi bɪɾ ɪz tʌŋ tə kip fɹəm pɔɪntɪŋ aʊt ðət ðəɹ wɝ mɔɹ sintʃæn soʊlʒɝz ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ ðən ðəɹ hæd bɪn waɪtkloʊks ɪn ɔl ʌv ɔltɑɹə dʊɹɪŋ ðə waɪtkloʊk wɔɹ. ə stʃɹit fʊl ə sintʃæn wɑz noʊ pleɪs fəɹ ə flæpɪŋ tʌŋ, ivən ɪf moʊs dɪɾ əpɪɹ tə bi fɑɹmɝz ən kɹæftsfoʊk. "aɪ ʌndɝstæn jəɹ hɑt tə pʊt jəɹ hɛɾ ɑn ə spaɪk," hi sɛd kwaɪətli. əz kwaɪətli əz i kəɾ ən stɪl bi hɝɾ ɪn ðət dɪn ə vɔɪsəz ən kæɾəl loʊɪŋ ən ɡis hɔŋkɪŋ. "ju noʊ əbaʊt ðɛɹ lɪsənɝz. ðət fɛloʊ oʊvɝ ðəɹ u lʊks laɪk ə steɪbəlmən kəd bi wʌn, əɹ ðət skɪni wʊmən wɪð ðə bʌndəl ɑn əɹ bæk."

Mat could guess without asking anyone. He bit his tongue to keep from pointing out that there were more Seanchan soldiers in Ebou Dar than there had been Whitecloaks in all of Altara during the Whitecloak War. A street full of Seanchan was no place for a flapping tongue, even if most did appear to be farmers and craftsfolk. "I understand you're hot to put your head on a spike," he said quietly. As quietly as he could and still be heard in that din of voices and cattle lowing and geese honking. "You know about their Listeners. That fellow over there who looks like a stableman could be one, or that skinny woman with the bundle on her back."

bɛslən ɡlaʊɝd soʊ hɑɹɾ ət ðə pɛɹ mæt hæd pɔɪntəɾ aʊt ðəɾ ɪf ðeɪ ɹɪli wɝ lɪsənɝz, ðeɪ maɪt ɹipɔɹɾ ɪm fəɹ ðəɾ əloʊn. "meɪbi jəl sɪŋ ə dɪfɹən sɔŋ wən ðeɪ ɹitʃ ændɝ," hi ɡɹaʊld, ən pʊʃt ɪz weɪ ɪndə ðə θɹɔŋ, ʃʌvɪŋ ɛniwʌn u ɡɑɾ ɪn ɪz weɪ. mæt wʊɾə bɪn ənsɝpɹaɪz tə si ə faɪt bɹeɪk aʊt. hi səspɛktəd ðət wɑz wʌt ðə mæn wɑz lʊkɪŋ fɔɹ.

Beslan glowered so hard at the pair Mat had pointed out that if they really were Listeners, they might report him for that alone. "Maybe you'll sing a different song when they reach Andor," he growled, and pushed his way into the throng, shoving anyone who got in his way. Mat would have been unsurprised to see a fight break out. He suspected that was what the man was looking for.

tɑm tɝn tə fɑloʊ wɪð oʊlvɝ, bʌt mæt kɑɾ ɪz sliv. "kul ɪz tɛmpɝ ɪf jə kæn, tɑm. ən kul jəɹ oʊn waɪl jəɹ əbaʊɾ ɪt. aɪ wəd θɪŋk baɪ ðɪs taɪm juɾ əv hæɾ ɪnʌf ə ʃeɪvɪŋ blaɪnd."

Thom turned to follow with Olver, but Mat caught his sleeve. "Cool his temper if you can, Thom. And cool your own while you're about it. I would think by this time you'd have had enough of shaving blind."

"maɪ hɛɾ ɪz kul ən aɪm tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kul hɪz," tɑm sɛd dʒɹɪli. "hi kæn dʒʌst sɪt, ðoʊ; ɪts ɪz kʌntʃɹi." ə feɪn smaɪl kɹɔst ɪz lɛðɝi feɪs. "ju seɪ jə woʊn teɪk ɹɪsks, bʌt jə wɪl. ən wən jə du, jəl meɪk ɛniθɪŋ bɛslən ən aɪ maɪt tʃɹaɪ lʊk laɪk ən ivnɪŋ stʃɹoʊl ɪn ðə ɡɑɹɾən. wɪð jə ɝaʊnd, ivən ðə bɑɹbɝ ɪz blaɪnd. kʌm əlɔŋ, bɔɪ," hi sɛd, swɪŋɪŋ oʊlvɝ ʌp ɑntu hɪz ʃoʊldɝz. "ɹaɪzɛl maɪt nɑt lɛt jə ɹɛs jəɹ hɛɾ ɪf jəɹ leɪt fəɹ jəɹ lɛsən."

"My head is cool and I'm trying to cool his," Thom said drily. "He can't just sit, though; it is his country." A faint smile crossed his leathery face. "You say you won't take risks, but you will. And when you do, you'll make anything Beslan and I might try look like an evening stroll in the garden. With you around, even the barber is blind. Come along, boy," he said, swinging Olver up onto his shoulders. "Riselle might not let you rest your head if you're late for your lesson."

mæt fɹaʊn æftɝ ɪm əz i stʃɹoʊɾ əweɪ, meɪkɪŋ mʌtʃ bɛɾɝ pɹɑɡɹɛs wɪð oʊlvɝ stʃɹædlɪŋ ɪz nɛk ðən bɛslən hæd. wʌd tɑm min? hi nɛvɝ tʊk ɹɪsks ənlɛs ðeɪ wɝ fɔɹst ɑn hɪm. nɛvɝ. hi ɡlæns kæʒəwəli təwɔɹd ðə skɪni wʊmən, ən ðə fɛloʊ wɪð dʌŋ ɑn ɪz buts. laɪt, ðeɪ kəd bi lɪsənɝz. ɛnibəɾi kəd bi. ɪt wɑz ɪnʌf tə sɛɾ ə pɹɪkəl bɪtwin ɪz ʃoʊldɝz, əz ɪf i wɝ biɪŋ wɑtʃt.

Mat frowned after him as he strode away, making much better progress with Olver straddling his neck than Beslan had. What did Thom mean? He never took risks unless they were forced on him. Never. He glanced casually toward the skinny woman, and the fellow with dung on his boots. Light, they could be Listeners. Anybody could be. It was enough to set a prickle between his shoulders, as if he were being watched.

hi ɪntʃt ə ɡʊdli dɪstəns əlɔŋ stʃɹits ðəɾ æktʃəli  ɡɹu θɪkɝ wɪð pipəl ən ænəməlz ən wæɡənz ðə nɪɹɝ i keɪm tə ðə dɑks. ðə stɔlz ɑn ðə bɹɪdʒəz oʊvɝ ðə kənælz hæd ðɛɹ ʃʌɾɝz daʊn, ðə stʃɹit pɛdlɝz hæd pɪkt ʌp ðɛɹ blæŋkəts, ən ðə tʌmblɝz ən dʒʌɡəlɝz ðət juʒəwəli ɛntɝteɪn əɾ ɛvɹi stʃɹit wʊɾə əv hæd noʊ ɹum tə pɝfɔɹm ɪf ðeɪ hæd nɑt ɡɔn əweɪ, tu. ðəɹ wɝ tu mɛni sintʃæn, ðət wɑz haʊ mɛni ðəɹ wɝ, ən meɪbi wʌn ɪn faɪv ə soʊlʒɝ, pleɪn ɪnʌf baɪ ðɛɹ hɑɹɾ aɪz ən ðə sɛɾ ə ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz, soʊ dɪfɹən fɹəm fɑɹmɝ əɹ kɹæfsmən, ivən wən ðeɪ wɝ nɑt wɛɹɪŋ ɑɹmɝ. naʊ ən ðən ə ɡɹup sʌldəm ən deɪmeɪn muvd əlɔŋ ðə stʃɹiɾ ɪn ə lɪɾəl ɛɾi ʌv klɪɹ speɪs, mɔɹ ivən ðən soʊlʒɝz ɡɑt. ɪt wɑz nɑt ɡɪvən aʊɾ ə fɪɹ, ət lis nɑt baɪ ðə sintʃæn. ðeɪ baʊd ɹɪspɛkfəli tə ðə wɪmən wɪð laɪtnɪŋ-mɑɹkt ɹɛd pænəlz ɑn ðə blu dʒɹɛsəz, ən smaɪld wɪð əpɹuvəl əz ðə pɛɹz pæs baɪ. bɛslən wɑz aʊɾ ə hɪz maɪnd. ðə sintʃæn wɝ gɑnə tə bi dʒɹɪvən ɔf baɪ ɛniwʌn ɪksɛpt ən ɑɹmi wɪð æʃəmən, laɪk ðə wʌn ɹumɝ sɛd hæd fɔɾ əm tə ði ist ə wik əɡoʊ. əɹ wʌn ɑɹmd wɪð ði ɪluməneɪɾɝz sikɹəts. wʌɾ ɪn ðə laɪt kəɾ ɑlʌdʒɹə wɑnt wɪð ə bɛlfndɝ?

He inched a goodly distance along streets that actually grew thicker with people and animals and wagons the nearer he came to the docks. The stalls on the bridges over the canals had their shutters down, the street peddlers had picked up their blankets, and the tumblers and jugglers that usually entertained at every street crossing would have had no room to perform if they had not gone away, too. There were too many Seanchan, that was how many there were, and maybe one in five a soldier, plain enough by their hard eyes and the set of their shoulders, so different from farmer or craftsman, even when they were not wearing armor. Now and then a group sul'dam and damane moved along the street in a little eddy of clear space, more even than soldiers got. It was not given out of fear, at least not by the Seanchan. They bowed respectfully to the women with lightning-marked red panels on the blue dresses, and smiled with approval as the pairs passed by. Beslan was out of his mind. The Seanchan were not going to be driven off by anyone except an army with Asha'man, like the one rumor said had fought them to the east a week ago. Or one armed with the Illuminator's secrets. What in the Light could Aludra want with a bellfounder?

hi tʊk peɪnz nɑt tə kʌm ɪn saɪɾ ə ðə dɑks. hi hæd lɝn ɪz lɛsən ɑn ðæt. wʌɾ i ɹɪli wɑntəd wɑz ə ɡeɪm ə daɪs, wʌn ðət wəd læst wɛl ɪndə ðə naɪt. pɹɛfɝəbli leɪɾ ɪnʌf ðət taɪlɪn wəd bi əslip wən i ɹɪtɝn tə ðə pæləs. ʃi hæd teɪkən əweɪ hɪz daɪs, kleɪmɪŋ ʃi dɪd nɑt laɪk ɪm ɡæmbəlɪŋ, ðoʊ ʃi dɪɾ ɪɾ æftɝ i tɔkt əɹ ɪndə weɪdʒɝɪŋ fɔɹfaɪts, waɪl i wɑz stɪl kənfaɪn tə bɛd. fɔɹtʃənətli, daɪs kəɾ ɔlweɪz bi faʊnd, ən wɪð ɪz lʌk, ɪt wɑz ɔlweɪz bɛɾɝ tə juz ði ʌðɝ mɛnz daɪs ɛniweɪ. ənfɔɹtʃənətli, wʌns i dɪskʌvɝd ʃi wɑz nɑɾ əbaʊt tə peɪ ə fɔɹfɪɾ ə lɛɾɪŋ ɪm ɡoʊ - ðə wʊmən pɹitɛndəd nɑt tə noʊ wʌɾ i wɑz tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt! - hi hæd juzd əm tə ɡɪv əɹ bæk ə bɪɾ ə hɝ oʊn mɛɾəsən. ə ɡɹeɪv mɪsteɪk, haʊɛvɝ mʌtʃ fʌn ɪt hæd bɪn ət ðə taɪm. sɪns ðə fɔɹfaɪts ɹæn aʊt, ʃi hæd bɪn twaɪs əz bæɾ əz bɪfɔɹ.

He took pains not to come in sight of the docks. He had learned his lesson on that. What he really wanted was a game of dice, one that would last well into the night. Preferably late enough that Tylin would be asleep when he returned to the Palace. She had taken away his dice, claiming she did not like him gambling, though she did it after he talked her into wagering forfeits, while he was still confined to bed. Fortunately, dice could always be found, and with his luck, it was always better to use the other men's dice anyway. Unfortunately, once he discovered she was not about to pay a forfeit of letting him go - the woman pretended not to know what he was talking about! - he had used them to give her back a bit of her own medicine. A grave mistake, however much fun it had been at the time. Since the forfeits ran out, she had been twice as bad as before.

ðə tævɝnz ən kɑmən ɹumz i ɛntɝd wɝ əz pækt əz ðə stʃɹits, ðoʊ, wɪð bɛɹli ɹum tə lɪft ə mʌɡ, mʌtʃ lɛs tɔs daɪs, fʊl ə sintʃæn læfɪŋ ən sɪŋɪŋ, ən ɡlʌm-feɪst ɛbu dɑɹi hu aɪd ðə sintʃæn ɪn sʌlən saɪləns. hi stɪl kwɪɹid ði ɪnkipɝz ən tæpstɝz ɑn ðə tʃæns ðeɪ maɪɾ əv ə kʌbi hoʊl i kəd ɹɛnt, bʌt wʌn ən ɔl ðeɪ ʃʊk ðɛɹ hɛdz. hi hæd nɑt ɹɪli ɪkspɛktəɾ ɛniθɪŋ ɛls. ðəɹ hæd bɪn nʌθɪŋ əveɪləbəl ivən bɪfɔɹ ɔl ðə nu ɝaɪvəlz. stɪl, hi bɪɡæn tə fil əz ɡlumi əz ðə fɔɹən mɝtʃəns i sɔ piɹɪŋ ɪndə ðɛɹ waɪn ən wʌndɝɪŋ haʊ ðeɪ wɝ tə ɡɛt ðɛɹ ɡʊdz aʊɾ ə ðə sɪɾi wɪð noʊ hɔɹsəz. hi hæd ɡoʊl tə peɪ wʌtɛvɝ lukə wɑntəd, ən mɔɹ, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ɔl ɪn ə tʃɛst ɪn ðə tɑɹɑsɪn pæləs, ən i wɑz nɑɾ əbaʊt tə tʃɹaɪ teɪkɪŋ ɪnʌf aʊɾ ɪn wʌn ɡoʊ, nɑɾ æftɝ pæləs sɝvəns hæd kæɹiɾ ɪm bæk fɹəm ðə dɑks laɪk ə stæɡ teɪkən ɪn hʌnt. ɔl i hæd bɪn duɪŋ ðən wɑz tɔkɪŋ tə ʃɪp kæptənz; ɪf taɪlɪn lɝnd, ən ʃi wʊd, ðəɾ i wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə liv ðə pæləs wɪð mɔɹ ɡoʊl ðən i niɾəd fəɹ ən ivnɪŋ ʌv ɡæmbəlɪŋ . . . oʊ, noʊ! hi hæd tə hæv ə ɹum, ə ɡɛɹɪɾ ɪn səm ɪnz æɾɪk ðə saɪz ʌv ə wɔɹdʒɹoʊb, ɛniθɪŋ, wɛɹ i kəd haɪɾ əweɪ ɡoʊld ə lɪɾəl əɾ ə taɪm, əɹ i hæd tə hæv ə tʃæns wɪð ðə daɪs, wʌn əɹ ði ʌðɝ. lʌk əɹ noʊ lʌk, ðoʊ, hi ɪvɛntʃəwəli ɹilaɪz ðəɾ i wɑz gɑnə faɪnd niðɝ tədeɪ. ən ðoʊz blʌɾi daɪs wɝ stɪl tʌmbəlɪŋ ɪn ɪz hɛd, tʌmbəlɪŋ.

The taverns and common rooms he entered were as packed as the streets, though, with barely room to lift a mug, much less toss dice, full of Seanchan laughing and singing, and glum-faced Ebou Dari who eyed the Seanchan in sullen silence. He still queried the innkeepers and tapsters on the chance they might have a cubby hole he could rent, but one and all they shook their heads. He had not really expected anything else. There had been nothing available even before all the new arrivals. Still, he began to feel as gloomy as the foreign merchants he saw peering into their wine and wondering how they were to get their goods out of the city with no horses. He had gold to pay whatever Luca wanted, and more, but it was all in a chest in the Tarasin Palace, and he was not about to try taking enough out in one go, not after Palace servants had carried him back from the docks like a stag taken in hunt. All he had been doing then was talking to ship captains; if Tylin learned, and she would, that he was trying to leave the Palace with more gold than he needed for an evening of gambling . . . Oh, no! He had to have a room, a garret in some inn's attic the size of a wardrobe, anything, where he could hide away gold a little at a time, or he had to have a chance with the dice, one or the other. Luck or no luck, though, he eventually realized that he was going to find neither today. And those bloody dice were still tumbling in his head, tumbling.

hi dɪd nɑt steɪ ɪn ɛni wʌn pleɪs lɔŋ, ən nɑt dʒʌs fəɹ ðə læk ʌv ə ɡeɪm əɹ ə ɹum. hɪz kʌlɝfəl kloʊðz, hɪz ʃeɪm-ə-tɪŋkɝ-fɔɹ-bɹaɪtnəs kloʊðz, dʒɹu aɪz. səm ə ðə sintʃæn θɔɾ i wɑz ðəɹ fəɹ ɛntɝteɪnmənt, ən tʃɹaɪd tə peɪ hɪm tə sɪŋ! hi ɔlmoʊs lɛt ðɛm, wʌns əɹ twaɪs, bʌt wʌns ðeɪ hɝd hɪm, ðeɪ wʊɾə dɪmændəd ðə mʌni bæk. səm ə ði ɛbu dɑɹi mɛn, wɪð lɔŋ kɝv naɪvz tʌk bɪhaɪn ðɛɹ bɛls ən ə bɛlɪfəl ʌv æŋɡɝ ðeɪ kəd nɑt teɪk aʊɾ ɑn ðə sintʃæn, θɔt tə teɪk ɪɾ aʊɾ ɑn ðə bəfun u lækt oʊnli ə peɪntəd feɪs tə lʊk laɪk ə noʊbəlz ful. mæt dʌk bæk ɪndə ðə kɹaʊɾəd stʃɹit wɛnɛvɝ i sɔ sətʃ fɛloʊz aɪɪŋ hɪm. hi hæd lɝn ðə hɑɹd weɪ ðəɾ i wɑz ɪn noʊ kəndɪʃən fəɹ ə faɪt jɛt, ən ɪz kɪlɝz hɛd ɡoʊɪŋ ʌp bɪsaɪd ðə sɪɾi ɡeɪt wəd də hɪm noʊ ɡʊɾ əɾ ɔl.

He did not stay in any one place long, and not just for the lack of a game or a room. His colorful clothes, his shame-a-Tinker-for-brightness clothes, drew eyes. Some of the Seanchan thought he was there for entertainment, and tried to pay him to sing! He almost let them, once or twice, but once they heard him, they would have demanded the money back. Some of the Ebou Dari men, with long curved knives tucked behind their belts and a bellyful of anger they could not take out on the Seanchan, thought to take it out on the buffoon who lacked only a painted face to look like a noble's fool. Mat ducked back into the crowded street whenever he saw such fellows eyeing him. He had learned the hard way that he was in no condition for a fight yet, and his killer's head going up beside the city gate would do him no good at all.

mæt tʊk ɹɛst wɛɹ i kəd faɪn ɪt, ɑn ən ɛmpti bæɹəl əbændən bɪsaɪd ðə maʊθ ʌv ən æliweɪ, ɑn ðə ɹɛɹ bɪɾ ə bɛntʃ ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ə tævɝn ðət hæd ɹum fəɹ wʌn mɔɹ, ɑn ə stoʊn stɛp əntɪl ðə bɪldɪŋz oʊnɝ keɪm aʊɾ ən nɑkt ɪz hæɾ ɔf wɪð ə swaɪp ə hɝ bɹum. hɪz bɛli wɑz kɪsɪŋ ɪz bækboʊn, hi wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə fil ðəɾ ɛvɹiwʌn wɑz ɡeɪpɪŋ əɾ ɪz ɡɛɹɪʃ kloʊðz, ðə dæŋk koʊld wɑz sipɪŋ ɪndə hɪz boʊnz, ən ði oʊnli daɪs i wɑz gɑnə faɪnd wɝ ðoʊz stɪl θʌndɝɪŋ əweɪ ɪn ɪz hɛd laɪk hɔɹsəz hʊvz. hi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ðeɪ hæɾ ɛvɝ bɪn ðɪs laʊd bɪfɔɹ.

Mat took rest where he could find it, on an empty barrel abandoned beside the mouth of an alleyway, on the rare bit of bench in front of a tavern that had room for one more, on a stone step until the building's owner came out and knocked his hat off with a swipe of her broom. His belly was kissing his backbone, he was beginning to feel that everyone was gaping at his garish clothes, the dank cold was seeping into his bones, and the only dice he was going to find were those still thundering away in his head like horse's hooves. He did not think they had ever been this loud before.

"nʌθɪŋ fəɹ ɪt bʌt tə ɡoʊ bæk ən bi ðə kwinz blʌɾi pɛt!" hi ɡɹaʊld, juzɪŋ ɪz stæf tə lɛvɝ hɪmsɛlf ʌp ɔf ə kɹækt wʊɾən kɹeɪt laɪɪŋ ət ðə saɪɾ ə ðə stʃɹit. sɛvɹəl pæsɝzbi lʊkt əɾ ɪm əz ɪf ɪz feɪs wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi peɪntəd. hi ɪɡnɔɹd ðɛm. bɪniθ ɪz noʊɾəs, ðeɪ wɝ. hi wɑz nɑt biɾɪŋ əm oʊvɝ ðə hɛd wɪð ɪz stæf əz ðeɪ dɪzɝvd, ɡɑəlɪŋ əɾ ə mæn ðət weɪ.

"Nothing for it but to go back and be the Queen's bloody pet!" he growled, using his staff to lever himself up off a cracked wooden crate lying at the side of the street. Several passersby looked at him as if his face were already painted. He ignored them. Beneath his notice, they were. He was not beating them over the head with his staff as they deserved, goggling at a man that way.

ðə stʃɹits ɹɪli wɝ əz fʊl əz ɝliɝ, hi ɹilaɪzd, ən ɪt wəd bi wɛl æftɝ naɪtfɔl bɪfɔɹ i ɡɑt bæk tə ðə pæləs ɪf i tʃɹaɪd tə meɪk ɪz weɪ θɹu ðə kɹaʊdz. ʌv kɔɹs, taɪlɪn maɪt bi əslip baɪ ðɛn. meɪbi. hɪz stʌmək ɡɹaʊld, ɔlmoʊs laʊdli ɪnʌf tə dʒɹaʊn aʊt ðə daɪs. ʃi maɪɾ ɔɹɾɝ ðə kɪtʃənz nɑt tə fid hɪm, ɪf i wɑz tu leɪt.

The streets really were as full as earlier, he realized, and it would be well after nightfall before he got back to the Palace if he tried to make his way through the crowds. Of course, Tylin might be asleep by then. Maybe. His stomach growled, almost loudly enough to drown out the dice. She might order the kitchens not to feed him, if he was too late.

tɛn hɑɹd-wʌn peɪsɪz θɹu ðə pɹɛs, ən i tɝn daʊn ən æli, nɛɹoʊ ən dɑɹk. ðəɹ wɝ noʊ peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz. ðə waɪt plæstɝ ɑn ðə wɪndoʊləs wɔlz wɑz kɹækt ən fɔlɪŋ tə ɪkspoʊz ðə bɹɪk bɪniθ, ɔfən əz nɑt. ði ɛɹ wɑz ɹæŋk wɪð ðə fɛɾəd stɛntʃ ə dəkeɪ, ən i hoʊp ðət wʌt skwɪʃt ʌndɝ ɪz buts wɑz mʌɾ ivən wən ɪt ɡeɪv ɔf ə loʊðsəm oʊɾɝ. ðəɹ wɝ noʊ pipəl, iðɝ. hi kəd stɛp aʊt wɪð ə ɡʊd stʃɹaɪd. əɹ wʌt pæs fəɹ wʌn, tədeɪ. hi kəd hɑɹdli weɪt fəɹ ðə deɪ hi kəd wɔk ə fju maɪlz əɡɛn wɪθaʊt pæntɪŋ ən eɪkɪŋ ən niɾɪŋ tə lin ɑn ə stɪk. twɪstɪŋ æliz, moʊst soʊ nɛɹoʊ hɪz ʃoʊldɝz bɹʌʃt boʊθ saɪdz, kɹɪskɹɔs ðə sɪɾi ɪn ə meɪz ðət wɑz izi tə ɡɛt lɔst ɪn ɪf jə dɪd nɑt noʊ jəɹ weɪ. hi nɛvɝ tʊk ə ɹɔŋ tɝn, ivən wən ə nɛɹoʊ, kɹʊkəd pæsədʒ sʌɾənli fɔɹkt ɪndə θɹi əɹ ivən fɔɹ ðəɾ ɔl sim tə miændɝ ɪn ɹʌfli ðə seɪm dɝɛkʃən. ðəɹ hæd bɪn ə ɡʊd mɛni taɪmz ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ wən i niɾəd tə əvɔɪɾ aɪz, ən i nu ðiz æliz laɪk i nu hɪz oʊn hænd. ðoʊ, ɑdli ɪnʌf, hi stɪl hæd ðə filɪŋ i wɑz biɪŋ wɑtʃt. hi ɪkspɛktəd tə fil ðəɾ əz lɔŋ əz i hæd tə wɛɹ ðoʊz blʌɾi kloʊðz.

Ten hard-won paces through the press, and he turned down an alley, narrow and dark. There were no paving stones. The white plaster on the windowless walls was cracked and falling to expose the brick beneath, often as not. The air was rank with the fetid stench of decay, and he hoped that what squished under his boots was mud even when it gave off a loathsome odor. There were no people, either. He could step out with a good stride. Or what passed for one, today. He could hardly wait for the day he could walk a few miles again without panting and aching and needing to lean on a stick. Twisting alleys, most so narrow his shoulders brushed both sides, crisscrossed the city in a maze that was easy to get lost in if you did not know your way. He never took a wrong turn, even when a narrow, crooked passage suddenly forked into three or even four that all seemed to meander in roughly the same direction. There had been a good many times in Ebou Dar when he needed to avoid eyes, and he knew these alleys like he knew his own hand. Though, oddly enough, he still had the feeling he was being watched. He expected to feel that as long as he had to wear those bloody clothes.

ɪf i hæd tə stʃɹʌɡəl θɹu ə mæs ə pipəl ən ænəməlz fɹəm wʌn æli tə ənʌðɝ, ən əkeɪʒənəli ʃʌv ɪz weɪ əkɹɔs ə bɹɪdʒ ðət simd ə sɑləd wɔl ə hjumænɪɾi, hi wɑz stɪl ɔlmoʊs bæk tə ðə pæləs ɪn ðə taɪm ɪt wʊɾə teɪkən ɪm tə ɡoʊ θɹi stʃɹits ʌðɝwaɪz. hɝiɪŋ ɪndə ðə ʃæɾoʊd pæsədʒ bɪtwin ə wɛl-lɪt tævɝn ən ə ʃʌɾɝd lækɹwɛɹ ʃɑp, hi wʌndɝd wʌt ðə kɪtʃənz wəɾ əv ɹɛɾi. mɔɹ kəpeɪʃəs ðən moʊst, waɪɾ ɪnʌf fəɹ θɹi ɪf ðeɪ wɝ fɹɛnli, ðɪs æli lɛɾ aʊɾ ɑntu ðə mɔl hɛɹə skwɛɹ ɔlmoʊst ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə tɑɹɑsɪn pæləs. sjuɹɔθ wɑz lɪvɪŋ ðɛɹ, ən ðə kʊks hæd bɪn aʊtduɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz sɪns ʃi hæd hæd ðə lɑɾ ə ðɛm flɑɡd æftɝ əɹ fɝs mil. ðəɹ maɪt bi ɔɪstɝz wɪð kɹim, ən pɝhæps ɡɪldɪd fɪʃ, ən skwɪd wɪð pɛpɝz. tɛn stʃɹaɪdz ɪndə ðə ʃædoʊz, hɪz fʊt keɪm daʊn ɑn sʌmθɪŋ ðət dɪd nɑt skwɪʃ, ən i wɛn daʊn ɪn ðə fɹizɪŋ mʌd wɪð ə ɡɹʌnt, twɪstɪŋ ət ðə læst ɪnstən soʊ hi dɪd nɑt læn ɑn ɪz bæd lɛɡ. aɪsi lɪkwəɾ ɪmiɾiətli soʊk θɹu hɪz koʊt. hi hoʊpt ɪt wɑz wɔɾɝ.

If he had to struggle through a mass of people and animals from one alley to another, and occasionally shove his way across a bridge that seemed a solid wall of humanity, he was still almost back to the Palace in the time it would have taken him to go three streets otherwise. Hurrying into the shadowed passage between a well-lit tavern and a shuttered lacquerware shop, he wondered what the kitchens would have ready. More capacious than most, wide enough for three if they were friendly, this alley let out onto the Mol Hara Square almost in front of the Tarasin Palace. Suroth was living there, and the cooks had been outdoing themselves since she had had the lot of them flogged after her first meal. There might be oysters with cream, and perhaps gilded fish, and squid with peppers. Ten strides into the shadows, his foot came down on something that did not squish, and he went down in the freezing mud with a grunt, twisting at the last instant so he did not land on his bad leg. Icy liquid immediately soaked through his coat. He hoped it was water.

hi ɡɹʌntɪɾ əɡɛn wən buts lændəɾ ɑn ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. ðə fɛloʊ tɑpəld ɔf ə hɪm, kɝsɪŋ ən skɪɾɪŋ dipɝ ɪndə ði æli ɑn ðə mʌd, ən wɛn tə wʌn ni, dʒʌs mænɪdʒɪŋ tə kætʃ hɪmsɛlf əɡɛns ðə saɪɾ ə ðə tævɝn ʃɔɹɾ ə fɔlɪŋ flæt hɪmsɛlf. mæts aɪz wɝ əkʌstəm tə ðə dɪm laɪt, ɪnʌf fəɹ ɪm tə meɪk aʊɾ ə slɛndɝ, nɑndɪskɹɪp mæn. ə mæn wɪð wʌɾ əpɪɹd tə bi ə lɑɹdʒ skɑɹ ɑn ɪz tʃik. nɑɾ ə mæn, ðoʊ. ə kɹitʃɝ i hæd sin ɹɪp aʊɾ ɪz fɹɛnz θɹoʊt wɪð wʌn bɛɹ hæn ən teɪk ə naɪf aʊɾ ʌv ɪts oʊn tʃɛst ən θɹoʊ ɪt bæk ət hɪm. ən ðə θɪŋ wʊɾə lændəd ɹaɪɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm, ɪn izi ɹitʃ, ɪf i hæd nɑt tʃɹɪpt. meɪbi ə lɪɾəl twɪst ə tɑvɝən ʃeɪpɪŋ hæd wɝkt ɪn ɪz feɪvɝ, θæŋk ðə laɪt! ɔl ðət flæʃt θɹu hɪz hɛɾ ɪn ðə taɪm ɪt tʊk ðə ɡoʊləm tə kætʃ ɪtsɛlf əɡɛns ðə wɔl ən tɝn ɪts hɛd tə ɡlɛɹ ət hɪm.

He grunted again when boots landed on his shoulder. The fellow toppled off of him, cursing and skidding deeper into the alley on the mud, and went to one knee, just managing to catch himself against the side of the tavern short of falling flat himself. Mat's eyes were accustomed to the dim light, enough for him to make out a slender, nondescript man. A man with what appeared to be a large scar on his cheek. Not a man, though. A creature he had seen rip out his friend's throat with one bare hand and take a knife out of its own chest and throw it back at him. And the thing would have landed right in front of him, in easy reach, if he had not tripped. Maybe a little twist of ta'veren shaping had worked in his favor, thank the Light! All that flashed through his head in the time it took the gholam to catch itself against the wall and turn its head to glare at him.

wɪð ən oʊθ, mæt snætʃt ɪz fɔlən wɔkɪŋ stæf ən ɔkwɝdli hɝld ɪɾ ət ðə kɹitʃɝ laɪk ə spɪɹ. əɾ ɪts lɛɡz, hoʊpɪŋ tə tæŋɡəl ðɛm, ɡeɪn ə moʊmənt. ðə θɪŋ floʊɾ əsaɪd laɪk wɔɾɝ, əvɔɪɾɪŋ ðə stæf, buts slaɪɾɪŋ ə lɪɾəl ɪn ðə mʌd, ðən θɹu ɪtsɛlf təwɔɹd mæt. ðə dɪleɪ hæd bɪn ɪnʌf, ðoʊ. əz sun əz ðə stæf lɛft ɪz hænd, mæt fʌmbəld ɪnsaɪɾ ɪz ʃɝt fəɹ ðə fɑkshɛd mədæljən, bɹeɪkɪŋ ðə lɛðɝ kɔɹɾ əz i snætʃt ðə mədæljən aʊt. ðə ɡoʊləm θɹu ɪtsɛlf ət hɪm, ən i swʌŋ ðə mədæljən dɛspɝətli. sɪlvɝ ðət hæd leɪn kul ɑn ɪz tʃɛs bɹʌʃt əkɹɔs ən aʊtstʃɹɛtʃt hænd wɪð ə hɪs laɪk beɪkən fɹaɪɪŋ ən ə smɛl ə bɝnɪŋ flɛʃ. fluəɾ əz kwɪksɪlvɝ, snɑɹlɪŋ, ðə θɪŋ tʃɹaɪd tə dɑdʒ baɪ ðə wɝlɪŋ mədæljən, tə siz səm pɑɹɾ ə mæt. wʌns ɪt leɪd hænz ɑn hɪm, hi wɑz əz ɡʊɾ əz dɛd. ɪt wəd nɑt tʃɹaɪ tə tɔɪ wɪð ɪm ðɪs taɪm, əz ɪt hæɾ ɪn ðə ɹæhəd. fleɪlɪŋ kəntɪnjuəsli, hi kɑɾ ɪt wɪð ðə fɑkshɛɾ ɑn ði ʌðɝ hænd, əkɹɔs ðə feɪs, itʃ taɪm wɪð ə hɪs ən stɛntʃ ə bɝnɪŋ əz ɪf i hæd stʃɹʌk wɪð ə hɑɾ aɪɝn. tiθ bɛɹd, ðə ɡoʊləm bækt əweɪ, bʌɾ ɪn ə kɹaʊtʃ ɑn ðə bɔlz ʌv ɪts fit, hænz klɔd, ɹɛɾi tə dʒʌmp ət ðə slaɪɾəst wiknəs.

With an oath, Mat snatched his fallen walking staff and awkwardly hurled it at the creature like a spear. At its legs, hoping to tangle them, gain a moment. The thing flowed aside like water, avoiding the staff, boots sliding a little in the mud, then threw itself toward Mat. The delay had been enough, though. As soon as the staff left his hand, Mat fumbled inside his shirt for the foxhead medallion, breaking the leather cord as he snatched the medallion out. The gholam threw itself at him, and he swung the medallion desperately. Silver that had lain cool on his chest brushed across an outstretched hand with a hiss like bacon frying and a smell of burning flesh. Fluid as quicksilver, snarling, the thing tried to dodge by the whirling medallion, to seize some part of Mat. Once it laid hands on him, he was as good as dead. It would not try to toy with him this time, as it had in the Rahad. Flailing continuously, he caught it with the foxhead on the other hand, across the face, each time with a hiss and stench of burning as if he had struck with a hot iron. Teeth bared, the gholam backed away, but in a crouch on the balls of its feet, hands clawed, ready to jump at the slightest weakness.

nɑt lɛɾɪŋ ðə spɪnɪŋ mədæljən sloʊ, mæt pʊʃt ənstɛɾəli tə hɪz fit, wɑtʃɪŋ ðə θɪŋ ðət lʊkt ə laɪk ə mæn. hi wɑns jə dɛɾ əz mʌtʃ əz i wɑns hɝ, ɪt hæd toʊld ɪm ɪn ðə ɹæhəd, smaɪlɪŋ. ɪt wɑz nɑt tɔkɪŋ əɹ smaɪlɪŋ naʊ. hi dɪd nɑt noʊ hu ðə "hɝ" wɑz, əɹ ðə "hi," bʌt ðə ɹɛst wɑz klɪɹ əz ɡʊd ɡlæs. ən hɪɹ i wɑz, bɛɹli eɪbəl tə steɪ ɑn ɪz fit. hɪz lɛɡ ən hɪp ætʃt laɪk faɪɝ, ən ɪz ɹɪbz. nɑt tə mɛnʃən ðə ʃoʊldɝ ðə ɡoʊləm hæd lændəɾ ɑn. hi hæd tə ɡɛt bæk tə ðə stʃɹit, bæk əmʌŋ pipəl. meɪbi ɪnʌf pipəl wəd dɪtɝ ðə θɪŋ. ə smɔl hoʊp, bʌt ði oʊnli hoʊp i kəd si. ðə stʃɹit wɑz nɑt fɑɹ. hi kəd hɪɹ ðə bæbəl ə vɔɪsəz, hɑɹdli sɔfən baɪ dɪstəns əɾ ɔl.

Not letting the spinning medallion slow, Mat pushed unsteadily to his feet, watching the thing that looked a like a man. He wants you dead as much as he wants her, it had told him in the Rahad, smiling. It was not talking or smiling now. He did not know who the "her" was, or the "he," but the rest was clear as good glass. And here he was, barely able to stay on his feet. His leg and hip ached like fire, and his ribs. Not to mention the shoulder the gholam had landed on. He had to get back to the street, back among people. Maybe enough people would deter the thing. A small hope, but the only hope he could see. The street was not far. He could hear the babble of voices, hardly softened by distance at all.

hi tʊk ə kɛɹfəl stɛp bækwɝd. hɪz but slɪɾ ɪn sʌmθɪŋ ðət ɡeɪv ɔf ə faʊl smɛl ən θɹu hɪm əɡɛns ðə tævɝnz wɔl. oʊnli fɹæntɪk swɪŋz ə ðə sɪlvɝ fɑkshɛd kɛp ðə ɡoʊləm bæk. ðoʊz vɔɪsəz ɪn ðə stʃɹit wɝ soʊ tæntəlaɪzɪŋli kloʊs. ðeɪ maɪɾ əz wɛl əv bɪn ɪn bɑɹsaɪn. bɑɹsaɪn wɑz lɔŋ dɛd, ən i wəd bi tu, sun.

He took a careful step backward. His boot slid in something that gave off a foul smell and threw him against the tavern's wall. Only frantic swings of the silver foxhead kept the gholam back. Those voices in the street were so tantalizingly close. They might as well have been in Barsine. Barsine was long dead, and he would be too, soon.

"hiz daʊn ðɪs æli!" ə mæn ʃaʊɾəd. "fɑloʊ mi! hɝi! hɪl ɡɛɾ əweɪ!"

"He's down this alley!" a man shouted. "Follow me! Hurry! He'll get away!"

mæt kɛpt ɪz aɪz ɑn ðə ɡoʊləm. ɪts ɡeɪz flɪkɝd bɪɑn hɪm, təwɔɹd ðə stʃɹit, ən ɪt hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "aɪ æm ɔɹɾɝd tə əvɔɪd noʊɾəs, seɪv baɪ ðoʊz aɪ hɑɹvəst," ɪt spæɾ ət hɪm, "soʊ jəl lɪv ə lɪɾəl lɔŋɡɝ. ə lɪɾəl lɔŋɡɝ."

Mat kept his eyes on the gholam. Its gaze flickered beyond him, toward the street, and it hesitated. "I am ordered to avoid notice, save by those I harvest," it spat at him, "so you will live a little longer. A little longer."

spɪnɪŋ, ɪt ɹæn daʊn ði æli, slɪpɪŋ ə lɪɾəl ɪn ðə mʌd, jɛt stɪl simɪŋ tə floʊ əz ɪt dɑdʒd ɝaʊn bɪhaɪn ðə tævɝn.

Spinning, it ran down the alley, slipping a little in the mud, yet still seeming to flow as it dodged around behind the tavern.

mæt ɹæn æftɝ ɪt. hi kəd nɑɾ əv sɛd waɪ, ɪksɛp ðəɾ ɪt hæd tʃɹaɪd tə kɪl hɪm, wəd tʃɹaɪ əɡɛn, ən ɪz hækəlz wɝ stɪf. soʊ ɪt wɑz gɑnə kɪl ɪm ət lɛʒɝ, wɑz ɪt? ɪf ðə mədæljən kəd hɝɾ ɪt, meɪbi ðə mədæljən kəd kɪl ɪt.

Mat ran after it. He could not have said why, except that it had tried to kill him, would try again, and his hackles were stiff. So it was going to kill him at leisure, was it? If the medallion could hurt it, maybe the medallion could kill it.

ɹitʃɪŋ ðə kɔɹnɝ ə ðə tævɝn, hi sɔ ðə ɡoʊləm ət ðə seɪm taɪm ðəɾ ɪt ɡlæns bæk ən sɔ hɪm. əɡɛn, ðə θɪŋ hɛzɪteɪɾɪd fəɹ ən ɪnstənt. ðə tævɝnz bæk dɔɹ stʊɾ ədʒɑɹ, lɛɾɪŋ aʊt ðə saʊnz ə ɹɛvəlɹi. ðə kɹitʃɝ stʌk ɪts hænz ɪndə ə hoʊl lɛf baɪ ə mɪsɪŋ bɹɪk ɪn ðə bæk wɔl ə ðə bɪldɪŋ ɑpəzət ðə tævɝn, ən mæt stɪfənd. ɪt hɑɹdli sim tə nid wɛpənz, bʌɾ ɪf ɪt hæd hɪɾən wʌn ɪn ðəɹ . . . hi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk i wəd sɝvaɪv feɪsɪŋ ðət θɪŋ wɪð ɛni sɔɹɾ ʌv wɛpən. hænz fɑloʊɾ ɑɹmz, ən ðən ðə ɡoʊləmz hɛd wɛn ɪndə ðə hoʊl. mæts dʒɔ dʒɹɑpt. ðə ɡoʊləmz tʃɛst slaɪðɝd θɹu, ɪts lɛɡz, ən ɪt wɑz ɡɔn. θɹu ən oʊpənɪŋ meɪbi ðə saɪz ə mæts tu hænz.

Reaching the corner of the tavern, he saw the gholam at the same time that it glanced back and saw him. Again, the thing hesitated for an instant. The tavern's back door stood ajar, letting out the sounds of revelry. The creature stuck its hands into a hole left by a missing brick in the back wall of the building opposite the tavern, and Mat stiffened. It hardly seemed to need weapons, but if it had hidden one in there . . . He did not think he would survive facing that thing with any sort of weapon. Hands followed arms, and then the gholam's head went into the hole. Mat's jaw dropped. The gholam's chest slithered through, its legs, and it was gone. Through an opening maybe the size of Mat's two hands.

"aɪ doʊn θɪŋk aɪ hæv ɛvɝ sin ðə laɪk," sʌmwʌn sɛd kwaɪətli bɪsaɪd hɪm, ən mæt ɡeɪv ə stɑɹɾ ət ɹilaɪzɪŋ i wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ əloʊn. ðə spikɝ wɑz ə stup-ʃoʊldɝd, waɪt-hɛɹɾ oʊl mæn wɪð ə lɑɹdʒ hʊk noʊz plæntəɾ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ʌv ə sæd feɪs ən ə bʌndəl slʌŋ ɑn ɪz bæk. hi wɑz slaɪɾɪŋ ə vɛɹi lɔŋ dæɡɝ ɪndə ə ʃiθ bɪniθ ɪz koʊt.

"I don't think I have ever seen the like," someone said quietly beside him, and Mat gave a start at realizing he was no longer alone. The speaker was a stoop-shouldered, white-haired old man with a large hooked nose planted in the middle of a sad face and a bundle slung on his back. He was sliding a very long dagger into a sheath beneath his coat.

"aɪ hæv," mæt sɛd hɑloʊli. "ɪn ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ." səmtaɪmz bɪts ə hɪz oʊn mɛmɹi hi θɔt lɔs floʊɾəd ʌp aʊɾ ə noʊwɛɹ, ən ðət wʌn hæd dʒʌst sɝfɪst, wɑtʃɪŋ ðə ɡoʊləm. ɪt wɑz wʌn mɛmɹi hi wɪʃt hæd ɹɪmeɪn lɔst.

"I have," Mat said hollowly. "In Shadar Logoth." Sometimes bits of his own memory he thought lost floated up out of nowhere, and that one had just surfaced, watching the gholam. It was one memory he wished had remained lost.

"nɑt mɛni sɝvaɪv ə vɪzət ðɛɹ," ði oʊl mæn sɛd, piɹɪŋ ət hɪm. hɪz wɛðɝd feɪs lʊk fəmɪljɝ, sʌmhaʊ, bʌt mæt kəd nɑt pleɪs hɪm. "wʌtɛvɝ tʊk jə tə ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ?"

"Not many survive a visit there," the old man said, peering at him. His weathered face looked familiar, somehow, but Mat could not place him. "Whatever took you to Shadar Logoth?"

"wɛɹ ɑɹ jəɹ fɹɛnz?" mæt sɛd. "ðə pipəl jə wɝ ʃaʊɾɪŋ tə?" ði æliweɪ hɛld oʊnli ðə tu ʌv ðɛm. ðə saʊnz fɹəm ðə stʃɹit kəntɪnjuɾ ʌnəbeɪɾɪd, ən ʌndɪstɝbd baɪ ɛni kɹaɪz əbaʊɾ ɛniwʌn ɡɛɾɪŋ əweɪ ɪf ðeɪ dɪd nɑt hɝi.

"Where are your friends?" Mat said. "The people you were shouting to?" The alleyway held only the two of them. The sounds from the street continued unabated, and undisturbed by any cries about anyone getting away if they did not hurry.

ði oʊl mæn ʃɹʌɡd. "aɪm nɑt sɝɾən ɛniwʌn aʊt ðəɹ ʌndɝstʊd wʌɾ aɪ wɑz ʃaʊɾɪŋ. ɪts hɑɹɾ ɪnʌf ʌndɝstændɪŋ ðɛm. ɛniweɪ, aɪ θɔɾ ɪt maɪt skɛɹ ɔf ðə fɛloʊ. siɪŋ ðæt, ðoʊ . . ." dʒɛstʃɝɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə hoʊl ɪn ðə wɔl, hi læf mɝθləsli, ʃoʊɪŋ ɡæps ɪn ɪz tiθ. "aɪ θɪŋk meɪbi jə ən aɪ boʊθ əv ðə dɑɹk wʌnz oʊn lʌk."

The old man shrugged. "I'm not certain anyone out there understood what I was shouting. It's hard enough understanding them. Anyway, I thought it might scare off the fellow. Seeing that, though . . ." Gesturing toward the hole in the wall, he laughed mirthlessly, showing gaps in his teeth. "I think maybe you and I both have the Dark One's own luck."

mæt ɡɹɪməst. hi hæd hɝd ðət tu ɔfən əbaʊt hɪmsɛlf, ən i dɪd nɑt laɪk ɪt. meɪnli kəz i wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ ɪt wɑz nɑt tʃɹu. "meɪbi wi du," hi mʌɾɝd. "fɝɡɪv mi; aɪ ʃəɾ ɪntʃɹədus maɪsɛlf tə ðə mæn u seɪv maɪ nɛk. aɪm mæt kɔθən. ɑɹ jə nu-kʌm tə ɛbu dɑɹ?" ðət bʌndəl stʃɹæp tə ðə fɛloʊz bæk ɡeɪv ɪm ðə lʊk ʌv ə mæn ɑn ðə muv. "ju wɪl əv ə hɑɹd taɪm faɪndɪŋ ə pleɪs tə slip." hi tʊk kɛɹ wɪð ðə nɑɹl hæn ði ʌðɝ mæn pʊɾ ɪn hɪz. ɪt wɑz ɔl nɑbz, əz ɪf ɛvɹi boʊn hæd bɪn bɹoʊkən ət ðə seɪm taɪm ən hæd hil bædli. ɪt hæɾ ə stʃɹɔŋ ɡɹɪp, ðoʊ.

Mat grimaced. He had heard that too often about himself, and he did not like it. Mainly because he was not sure it was not true. "Maybe we do," he muttered. "Forgive me; I should introduce myself to the man who saved my neck. I'm Mat Cauthon. Are you new-come to Ebou Dar?" That bundle strapped to the fellow's back gave him the look of a man on the move. "You will have a hard time finding a place to sleep." He took care with the gnarled hand the other man put in his. It was all knobs, as if every bone had been broken at the same time and had healed badly. It had a strong grip, though.

"aɪ æm noʊl tʃɛɝɪn, mæt kɔθən. noʊ, aɪ hæv bɪn hɪɹ səm taɪm. bʌt maɪ pæləɾ ɪn ði æɾɪk ə ðə ɡoʊldən dʌks ɪz naʊ ɑkjəpaɪd baɪ ə fæɾ ɪliɑnɝ ɔɪl mɝtʃən u wɑz ɹstɪd fɹəm ɪz ɹum ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ ɪn feɪvɝ ʌv ə sintʃæn ɔfəsɝ. aɪ θɔɾ aɪd faɪn sʌmwɛɹ bæk ɪn ðɪs æli fəɹ tənaɪt." ɹʌbɪŋ ðə saɪɾ ə hɪz bɪɡ noʊz wɪð ə kɹʊkəd, nɑbi fɪŋɡɝ, hi tʃʌkəld əz ɪf slipɪŋ ɪn ən æli wɝ ə noʊ moʊmənt. "ɪt wɪl nɑt bi ðə fɝs taɪm aɪv slɛpt ɹʌf, ivən ɪn ə sɪɾi."

"I am Noal Charin, Mat Cauthon. No, I have been here some time. But my pallet in the attic of The Golden Ducks is now occupied by a fat Illianer oil merchant who was rousted from his room this morning in favor of a Seanchan officer. I thought I'd find somewhere back in this alley for tonight." Rubbing the side of his big nose with a crooked, knobby finger, he chuckled as if sleeping in an alley were of no moment. "It will not be the first time I've slept rough, even in a city."

"aɪ θɪŋk aɪ kən də bɛɾɝ fəɹ jə ðən ðæt," mæt toʊl hɪm, bʌt ðə ɹɛst ʌv wʌɾ i hæd bɪn gɑnə seɪ daɪɾ ɑn ɪz tʌŋ. ðə daɪs wɝ stɪl spɪnɪŋ ɪn ɪz hɛd, hi ɹilaɪzd. hi hæd mænədʒ tə fɝɡɛɾ əm wɪð ðə ɡoʊləm tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kɪl hɪm, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ stɪl baʊnsɪŋ, stɪl weɪɾɪŋ tə lænd. ɪf ðeɪ wɝ wɔɹnɪŋ ə sʌmθɪŋ wɝs ðən ðə ɡoʊləm, hi dɪd nɑt wɑnə noʊ. oʊnli, hi wʊd. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ daʊɾ ə ðæt. hi wʊd, wən ɪt wɑz tu leɪt.

"I think I can do better for you than that," Mat told him, but the rest of what he had been going to say died on his tongue. The dice were still spinning in his head, he realized. He had managed to forget them with the gholam trying to kill him, but they were still bouncing, still waiting to land. If they were warning of something worse than the gholam, he did not want to know. Only, he would. There was no doubt of that. He would, when it was too late.


tʃæptɝ sɛvəntin


CHAPTER 17

pɪŋk ɹɪbənz


Pink Ribbons

koʊld wɪnz ɡʌstɪd θɹu ðə mɔl hɛɹə, lɪftɪŋ mæts kloʊk ən θɹɛɾənɪŋ tə fɹiz ðə mʌd keɪkɪŋ ɪz kloʊðɪŋ əz i ən noʊl hɝiɾ aʊɾ ə ði æli. ðə sʌn sæɾ ɑn ðə ɹuftɑps, hæf-hɪɾən, ən ðə ʃædoʊz stʃɹɛtʃt lɔŋ. wɪð wʌn hæn fəɹ ɪz stæf ən ði ʌðɝ ɡɹɪpɪŋ ðə bɹoʊkən kɔɹɾ ə ðə fɑkshɛd, stʌft ɪndə ə koʊt pɑkət wɛɹ i kəd snætʃ ɪɾ aʊɾ ɪf nid bi, hi hæd tə lɛɾ ɪz kloʊk ɡoʊ wɛɹ ɪt wʊd. hi ætʃt fɹəm hɛd tə fʊt, ðə daɪs ɹæɾəld wɔɹnɪŋ ɪnsaɪɾ ɪz skʌl, ən i hɑɹdli noʊɾəst iðɝ θɪŋ. hi wɑz tu bɪzi tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə wɑtʃ ɛvɹi dɝɛkʃən ət wʌns, ən wʌndɝɪŋ dʒʌs haʊ smɔl ə hoʊl ðət θɪŋ kəd ɡɛt θɹu. hi faʊn hɪmsɛlf ənizəli aɪɪŋ kɹæks bɪtwin ðə skwɛɹz peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz. ðoʊ ɪt hɑɹdli sim laɪkli ðə θɪŋ wəd kʌm əɾ ɪm ɪn ði oʊpən.

Cold winds gusted through the Mol Hara, lifting Mat's cloak and threatening to freeze the mud caking his clothing as he and Noal hurried out of the alley. The sun sat on the rooftops, half-hidden, and the shadows stretched long. With one hand for his staff and the other gripping the broken cord of the foxhead, stuffed into a coat pocket where he could snatch it out if need be, he had to let his cloak go where it would. He ached from head to foot, the dice rattled warning inside his skull, and he hardly noticed either thing. He was too busy trying to watch every direction at once, and wondering just how small a hole that thing could get through. He found himself uneasily eyeing cracks between the square's paving stones. Though it hardly seemed likely the thing would come at him in the open.

ə hʌm kæɹid fɹəm sɝaʊndɪŋ stʃɹits, bʌt hɪɹ oʊnli ə slæt-ɹɪb dɔɡ muvd, ɹʌnɪŋ pæs ðə faʊnteɪn stætʃu ʌv lɔŋ-dɛd kwin nɑɹaɪn. səm sɛɾ əɹ ʌplɪftəd hæn pɔɪntəd tə ði oʊʃənz baʊnti ðət hæɾ ɛnɹɪtʃt ɛbu dɑɹ, ən səm ðəɾ ɪt pɔɪntəɾ ɪn wɔɹnɪŋ ə deɪnʒɝz. ʌðɝz sɛɾ əɹ səksɛsɝ hæd wɑntəd tə dʒɹɔ ətɛnʃən tə ðə fæk ðəɾ oʊnli wʌn ə ðə stætʃuz bɹɛsts wɑz ənkʌvɝd, pɹoʊkleɪmɪŋ ðət nɑɹaɪn hæɾ oʊnli bɪn ə mɪɾəlɪŋ ɑnəsti.

A hum carried from surrounding streets, but here only a slat-ribbed dog moved, running past the fountained statue of long-dead Queen Nariene. Some said her uplifted hand pointed to the ocean's bounty that had enriched Ebou Dar, and some that it pointed in warning of dangers. Others said her successor had wanted to draw attention to the fact that only one of the statue's breasts was uncovered, proclaiming that Nariene had only been of middling honesty.

ɪn ʌðɝ deɪz ðə mɔl hɛɹə wʊɾə bɪn fʊl ə stʃɹoʊlɪŋ lʌvɝz ən lɪŋɡɝɪŋ stʃɹit vɛndɝz ən hoʊpfəl bɛɡɝz ət ðɪs aʊɝ ivən ɪn wɪntɝ, bʌt bɛɡɝz faʊn ðɛmsɛlvz snætʃt ɔf ðə stʃɹits ən pʊt tə wɝk, sɪns ðə sintʃæn keɪm, ən ðə ɹɛst steɪɾ əweɪ ivən ɪn deɪlaɪt. ðə ɹizən wɑz ðə tɑɹɑsɪn pæləs, ðət ɡɹeɪt maʊn ʌv waɪt doʊmz ən mɑɹbəl spaɪɹz ən ɹɔt-aɪɝn bælkəniz, ðə ɹɛzəɾəns ə taɪlɪn kwɪntɑɹə mɪtsoʊbɑɹ, baɪ ðə ɡɹeɪs ə ðə laɪt, kwin ʌv ɔltɑɹə - əɹ əz mʌtʃ ʌv ɔltɑɹə əz leɪ wɪðɪn ə fju deɪz' ɹaɪɾ ʌv ɛbu dɑɹ - mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə fɔɹ wɪnz ən ɡɑɹɾiən ə ðə si ʌv stɔɹmz. ænd, pɝhæps mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt, ðə ɹɛzəɾəns ə ðə haɪ leɪɾi sjuɹɔθ səbəl mɛlʒɹəθ, kəmændɪŋ ðə fɔɹʌnɝz fəɹ ði ɛmpɹɛs ə ðə sintʃæn, maɪt ʃi laɪv fɝɛvɝ. ə pəzɪʃən ə mʌtʃ ɡɹeɪɾɝ ɛmənəns ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ, ət ðə moʊmənt. taɪlɪnz ɡɹin-buɾɪd ɡɑɹdz stʊɾ əɾ ɛvɹi ɛntʃɹəns ɪn ðɛɹ bæɡi waɪt tʃɹaʊzɝz ən ɡɪldɪd bɹɛstpleɪts wɔɹn oʊvɝ ɡɹin koʊts, ən soʊ dɪd mɛn ən wɪmən ɪn ðoʊz ɪnsɛktəl hɛlməts wɪð ɑɹmɝ stʃɹaɪpt ɪn blu-ænd-jɛloʊ əɹ ɡɹin-ænd-waɪɾ əɹ ɛni ʌðɝ kɑmbəneɪʃən jə maɪt hæpən tə θɪŋk ʌv. ðə kwin ʌv ɔltɑɹə ɹikwaɪɝd sɪkjʊɹəɾi ən saɪləns fəɹ əɹ ɹɛst. əɹ ɹæðɝ, sjuɹɔθ sɛd ʃi dɪd, ən wʌt sjuɹɔθ sɛd taɪlɪn wɑntəd, taɪlɪn sun dɪsaɪɾɪd ðət ʃi dɪɾ ɪndid wɑnt.

In other days the Mol Hara would have been full of strolling lovers and lingering street vendors and hopeful beggars at this hour even in winter, but beggars found themselves snatched off the streets and put to work, since the Seanchan came, and the rest stayed away even in daylight. The reason was the Tarasin Palace, that great mound of white domes and marble spires and wrought-iron balconies, the residence of Tylin Quintara Mitsobar, by the Grace of the Light, Queen of Altara - or as much of Altara as lay within a few days' ride of Ebou Dar - Mistress of the Four Winds and Guardian of the Sea of Storms. And, perhaps more important, the residence of the High Lady Suroth Sabelle Meldarath, commanding the Forerunners for the Empress of the Seanchan, might she live forever. A position of much greater eminence in Ebou Dar, at the moment. Tylin's green-booted guards stood at every entrance in their baggy white trousers and gilded breastplates worn over green coats, and so did men and women in those insectile helmets with armor striped in blue-and-yellow or green-and-white or any other combination you might happen to think of. The Queen of Altara required security and silence for her rest. Or rather, Suroth said she did, and what Suroth said Tylin wanted, Tylin soon decided that she did indeed want.

æftɝ ə moʊməns kənsɪɾɝeɪʃən, mæt lɛd noʊl tə wʌn ə ðə steɪbliɑɹd ɡeɪts. ðəɹ wɑz mɔɹ tʃæns ʌv ɡɛɾɪŋ ə stʃɹeɪnʒɝ ɪn ðəɹ ðən ɪf i juz ðə ɡɹæn mɑɹbəl stɛɹz ðət lɛd daʊn ɪndə ðə skwɛɹ. nɑt tə mɛnʃən ə mʌtʃ bɛɾɝ tʃæns ʌv ɡɛɾɪŋ ɔl ðə mʌɾ ɔf ɪm bɪfɔɹ i hæd tə feɪs taɪlɪn. ʃi hæd meɪɾ əɹ dɪsplɛʒɝ mɑɹkədli noʊn ðə læs taɪm i keɪm bæk dɪʃɛvəld, æftɝ ə tævɝn bɹɔl.

After a moment's consideration, Mat led Noal to one of the stableyard gates. There was more chance of getting a stranger in there than if he used the grand marble stairs that led down into the square. Not to mention a much better chance of getting all the mud off him before he had to face Tylin. She had made her displeasure markedly known the last time he came back disheveled, after a tavern brawl.

ə hændfʊl ʌv ɛbu dɑɹi ɡɑɹdz stʊd tə wʌn saɪɾ ə ði oʊpən ɡeɪts wɪð hælbɝdz, ən ðə seɪm nʌmbɝ ə sintʃæn ɑn ði ʌðɝ wɪð tæsɛl spɪɹz, ɔl əz stɪf əz nɑɹaɪnz stætʃu.

A handful of Ebou Dari guards stood to one side of the open gates with halberds, and the same number of Seanchan on the other with tasseled spears, all as stiff as Nariene's statue.

"ðə laɪts blɛsɪŋ ɑn ɔl hɪɹ," mæt mɝmɝd pəlaɪtli tə ði ɛbu dɑɹi ɡɑɹdz. ɪt wɑz ɔlweɪz bɛs tə bi pəlaɪt tə ɛbu dɑɹi əntɪl jə wɝ ʃʊɹ ə ðɛm. æftɝwɝdz, tu, fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ. ivən soʊ, ðeɪ wɝ mɔɹ . . . flɛksəbəl . . . ðən ðə sintʃæn.

"The Light's blessing on all here," Mat murmured politely to the Ebou Dari guards. It was always best to be polite to Ebou Dari until you were sure of them. Afterwards, too, for that matter. Even so, they were more . . . flexible . . . than the Seanchan.

"æn ɑn ju, maɪ lɔɹd," ðɛɹ stɑki ɔfəsɝ ɹɪplaɪd, æmbəlɪŋ fɔɹwɝd, ən mæt ɹɛkəɡnaɪz hɪm, sɝləvən sɑɹət, ə ɡʊd fɛloʊ, ɔlweɪz ɹɛɾi wɪð ə kwɪp ən pəzɛsɪŋ ə faɪn aɪ fəɹ hɔɹsəz. ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛd, sɝləvən tæp ðə saɪɾ ə hɪz pɔɪntəd hɛlmət wɪð ðə θɪn, ɡɪldɪd ɹɑɾ ə hɪz ɔfəs. "hæv jə bɪn ɪn ənʌðɝ faɪt, maɪ lɔɹd? ʃɪl ɡoʊ ʌp laɪk ə wɔɾɝspaʊt, wən ʃi siz ju."

"And on you, my Lord," their stocky officer replied, ambling forward, and Mat recognized him, Surlivan Sarat, a good fellow, always ready with a quip and possessing a fine eye for horses. Shaking his head, Surlivan tapped the side of his pointed helmet with the thin, gilded rod of his office. "Have you been in another fight, my Lord? She will go up like a waterspout, when she sees you."

skwɛɹɪŋ ɪz ʃoʊldɝz, ən tʃɹaɪɪŋ nɑt tə lin soʊ ɑbviəsli ɑn ɪz stæf, mæt bɹɪsəld. ɹɛɾi wɪð ə kwɪp? kʌm tə θɪŋk ɑn ɪt, ðə sʌn-dɑɹk mæn hæɾ ə tʌŋ laɪk ə ɹæsp. ən ɪz aɪ fəɹ hɔɹsəz wɑz nɑɾ ɔl ðət faɪn, iðɝ. "wɪl ðəɹ bi ɛni kwɛstʃənz ɪf maɪ fɹɛn hɪɹ bɛdz daʊn wɪð maɪ mɛn?" mæt æskt ɹʌfli. "ðɛɹ ʃʊdn bi. ðɛɹz ɹum fəɹ wʌn mɔɹ wɪð maɪ fɛloʊz." ɹum fəɹ mɔɹ ðən wʌn, tʃɹuθ bi toʊld. eɪt mɛn hæd daɪd soʊ fɑɹ, fəɹ fɑloʊɪŋ ɪm tə ɛbu dɑɹ.

Squaring his shoulders, and trying not to lean so obviously on his staff, Mat bristled. Ready with a quip? Come to think on it, the sun-dark man had a tongue like a rasp. And his eye for horses was not all that fine, either. "Will there be any questions if my friend here beds down with my men?" Mat asked roughly. "There shouldn't be. There's room for one more with my fellows." Room for more than one, truth be told. Eight men had died so far, for following him to Ebou Dar.

"nʌn fɹəm mi, maɪ lɔɹd," sɝləvən sɛd, ðoʊ hi aɪd ðə skɹɔni mæn ət mæts saɪɾ ən pɝst ɪz lɪps dʒudɪʃɪsli. noʊlz koʊɾ əpɪɹɾ ʌv ɡʊd kwɑləɾi, ðoʊ, ət list ɪn ðə dɪm laɪt, ən i dɪɾ əv ɪz leɪs, ən ɪn ə bɛɾɝ steɪt ðən mæts. pɝhæps ðət tɪp ðə bæləns. "ænd ʃi dʌznt nid tə noʊ ɛvɹiθɪŋ, soʊ nʌn fɹəm hɝ, iðɝ."

"None from me, my Lord," Surlivan said, though he eyed the scrawny man at Mat's side and pursed his lips judiciously. Noal's coat appeared of good quality, though, at least in the dim light, and he did have his lace, and in a better state than Mat's. Perhaps that tipped the balance. "And she doesn't need to know everything, so none from her, either."

mæt skaʊld, bʌt bɪfɔɹ ɪntɛmpɝət wɝdz kəd pʊt hɪmsɛlf ən noʊl ɪn ðə sup kɛɾəl, θɹi ɑɹmɝd sintʃæn ɡæləpt ʌp tə ðə ɡeɪt, ən sɝləvən tɝn tə feɪs ðɛm.

Mat scowled, but before intemperate words could put himself and Noal in the soup kettle, three armored Seanchan galloped up to the gate, and Surlivan turned to face them.

"ju ən jəɹ leɪɾi waɪf lɪv ɪn ðə kwinz pæləs?" noʊl ɛnkwaɪɝd, stɑɹɾɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə ɡeɪt.

"You and your lady wife live in the Queen's Palace?" Noal enquired, starting toward the gate.

mæt pʊld ɪm bæk. "weɪɾ ɑn ðɛm," hi sɛd, nɑɾɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə sintʃæn. hɪz leɪɾi waɪf? blʌɾi wɪmən! blʌɾi daɪs ɪn ɪz blʌɾi hɛd!

Mat pulled him back. "Wait on them," he said, nodding toward the Seanchan. His lady wife? Bloody women! Bloody dice in his bloody head!

"aɪ hæv dɪspætʃɪz fəɹ ðə haɪ leɪɾi sjuɹɔθ," wʌn ə ðə sintʃæn ənaʊnst, slæpɪŋ ə lɛðɝ sætʃəl hæŋɪŋ fɹəm wʌn ɑɹmɝd ʃoʊldɝ. hɝ hɛlmət bɔɹ ə sɪŋɡəl θɪn plum, mɑɹkɪŋ əɹ ə loʊ-ɹæŋkɪŋ ɔfəsɝ, jɛɾ əɹ hɔɹs wɑz ə tɔl dʌn ɡɛldɪŋ wɪð ə lʊk ə spid. ði ʌðɝ tu ænəməlz wɝ stɝɾi ɪnʌf, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ tə bi sɛd fəɹ əm bɪɑn ðæt.

"I have dispatches for the High Lady Suroth," one of the Seanchan announced, slapping a leather satchel hanging from one armored shoulder. Her helmet bore a single thin plume, marking her a low-ranking officer, yet her horse was a tall dun gelding with a look of speed. The other two animals were sturdy enough, but there was nothing to be said for them beyond that.

"ɛntɝ wɪð ðə blɛsɪŋz ə ðə laɪt," sɝləvən sɛd, boʊɪŋ slaɪtli.

"Enter with the blessings of the Light," Surlivan said, bowing slightly.

ðə sintʃæn wʊmənz baʊ fɹəm əɹ sæɾəl wɑz ə mɪɹɝ ə hɪz. "ðə blɛsɪŋz ə ðə laɪt bi ɑn jə ɔlsoʊ," ʃi dʒɹɔld, ən ðə θɹi ʌv əm klæɾɝd ɪndə ðə steɪbliɑɹd.

The Seanchan woman's bow from her saddle was a mirror of his. "The blessings of the Light be on you also," she drawled, and the three of them clattered into the stableyard.

"ɪɾ ɪz vɛɹi stʃɹeɪnʒ," sɝləvən mjuzd, piɹɪŋ æftɝ ðə θɹi. "ðeɪ ɔlweɪz æsk pɝmɪʃən ʌv ʌs, nɑt ðɛm." hi flɪkt ɪz ɹɑd təwɔɹd ðə sintʃæn ɡɑɹdz ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə ɡeɪts. ðeɪ hæd nɑt stɝɾ ən ɪntʃ fɹəm ðɛɹ ɹɪdʒəd stæns, əɹ ivən ɡlænst ət ði ɝaɪvəlz ðət mæt hæd noʊɾəst.

"It is very strange," Surlivan mused, peering after the three. "They always ask permission of us, not them." He flicked his rod toward the Seanchan guards on the other side of the gates. They had not stirred an inch from their rigid stance, or even glanced at the arrivals that Mat had noticed.

"ænd wʌt wəd ðeɪ də ɪf jə sɛd ðeɪ kʊdnt ɡoʊ ɪn?" noʊl æskt kwaɪətli, izɪŋ ðə bʌndəl ɑn ɪz bæk.

"And what would they do if you said they couldn't go in?" Noal asked quietly, easing the bundle on his back.

sɝləvən spʌn ɑn ɪz hil. "ɪɾ ɪz ɪnʌf ðəɾ aɪ hæv ɡɪvən oʊθ tə maɪ kwin," hi sɛɾ ɪn ən ɪkspɹɛʃənləs vɔɪs, "ænd ʃiz ɡɪvən hɝz . . . wɛɹ ʃiz ɡɪvən ɪt. ɡɪv jəɹ fɹɛn ə bɛd, maɪ lɔɹd. ən wɔɹn hɪm, ðəɹ ɑɹ θɪŋz bɛɾɝ lɛft ənsɛɾ ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ, kwɛstʃənz bɛɾɝ lɛft ʌnəskt."

Surlivan spun on his heel. "It is enough that I have given oath to my Queen," he said in an expressionless voice, "and she has given hers . . . where she has given it. Give your friend a bed, my Lord. And warn him, there are things better left unsaid in Ebou Dar, questions better left unasked."

noʊl lʊk bɪfʌɾəld ən bɪɡæn pɹətɛstɪŋ ðəɾ i wɑz sɪmpli kjʊɹiəs, bʌt mæt ɪkstʃeɪnʒd fɝðɝ bɛnɪsənz ən kɝɾəsiz wɪð ði ɔltɑɹən ɔfəsɝ - əz kwɪkli əz i kʊd, tə bi ʃʊɹ - ən hʌsəld ɪz nu-faʊn əkweɪntəns θɹu ðə ɡeɪts, ɪkspleɪnɪŋ əbaʊt lɪsənɝz ɪn ə loʊ vɔɪs. ðə mæn maɪɾ əv seɪvd ɪz haɪd fɹəm ðə ɡoʊləm, bʌt ðət dɪd nɑt min i wəd lɛt ðə fɛloʊ hæn ɪɾ oʊvɝ tə ðə sintʃæn. ðeɪ hæd pipəl kɔl sikɝz, tu, ən fɹəm ðə lɪɾəl i hæd hɝd - ivən pipəl u spoʊk fɹili əbaʊt ðə dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹd lɑk ðɛɹ tiθ wən ɪt keɪm tə ðə sikɝz - fɹəm ðə lɪɾəl i hæd hɝd, sikɝz meɪd waɪtkloʊk kwɛstʃənɝz lʊk laɪk bɔɪz tɔɹməntɪŋ flaɪz, næsti bʌt hɑɹdli ɛniθɪŋ tə wɝi ə mæn.

Noal looked befuddled and began protesting that he was simply curious, but Mat exchanged further benisons and courtesies with the Altaran officer - as quickly as he could, to be sure - and hustled his new-found acquaintance through the gates, explaining about Listeners in a low voice. The man might have saved his hide from the gholam, but that did not mean he would let the fellow hand it over to the Seanchan. They had people called Seekers, too, and from the little he had heard - even people who spoke freely about the Deathwatch Guard locked their teeth when it came to the Seekers - from the little he had heard, Seekers made Whitecloak Questioners look like boys tormenting flies, nasty but hardly anything to worry a man.

"aɪ si," ði oʊl mæn sɛd sloʊli. "aɪ hædnt noʊn ðæt." hi saʊndəɾ ɪɹəteɪɾəd wɪð hɪmsɛlf. "ju mʌst spɛn ə ɡʊd dil ə taɪm wɪð ðə sintʃæn. dʒju noʊ ðə haɪ leɪɾi sjuɹɔθ əz wɛl, ðɛn? aɪ mʌst seɪ, aɪ hæd noʊ aɪdiə jə hæd sətʃ haɪ kənɛkʃənz."

"I see," the old man said slowly. "I hadn't known that." He sounded irritated with himself. "You must spend a good deal of time with the Seanchan. Do you know the High Lady Suroth as well, then? I must say, I had no idea you had such high connections."

"aɪ spɛn taɪm wɪð soʊlʒɝz ɪn tævɝnz, wən aɪ kæn," mæt ɹɪplaɪd saʊɝli. wən taɪlɪn lɛt hɪm. laɪt, hi maɪɾ əz wɛl bi mɛɹid! "sjuɹɔθ dʌznt noʊ aɪm əlaɪv." ən i dɪvaʊtli hoʊpt ɪt ɹɪmeɪn ðət weɪ.

"I spend time with soldiers in taverns, when I can," Mat replied sourly. When Tylin let him. Light, he might as well be married! "Suroth doesn't know I'm alive." And he devoutly hoped it remained that way.

ðə θɹi sintʃæn wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi aʊɾ ə saɪt, ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz biɪŋ lɛɾ ɪndə ðə steɪbəlz, bʌt sɛvɹəl dʌzən sʌldəm wɝ ɡɪvɪŋ deɪmeɪn ðɛɹ ivnɪŋ ɛksɝsaɪz, wɔkɪŋ əm ɪn ə bɪɡ sɝkəl ɝaʊn ðə stoʊn-peɪv jɑɹd. nɪɹli hæf ðə ɡɹeɪ-klæd deɪmeɪn wɝ dɑɹk-skɪnd wɪmən, lækɪŋ ðə dʒuəlɹi ðeɪ hæd wɔɹn əz wɪndfɪndɝz. ðəɹ wɝ mɔɹ laɪk əm ɪn ðə pæləs ən ɛlswɛɹ; ðə sintʃæn hæd hæɾ ə ɹɪtʃ hɑɹvəs fɹəm si foʊk vɛsəlz ðət hæd feɪl tə ɪskeɪp. moʊst wɔɹ sʌlən ɹɛzəɡneɪʃən əɹ stoʊni feɪsəz, bʌt sɛvən əɹ eɪt stɛɹɾ əhɛɾ ə ðɛm, lɔst ən kənfjuzd, dɪsbɪlivɪŋ stɪl. itʃ ə ðoʊz hæɾ ə sintʃæn-bɔɹn deɪmeɪn əɾ əɹ saɪd, hoʊldɪŋ əɹ hæn əɹ wɪð ən ɑɹm ɝaʊn hɝ, smaɪlɪŋ ən wɪspɝɪŋ tə hɝ ʌndɝ ði əpɹuvɪŋ aɪz ə ðə wɪmən u wɔɹ ðə bɹeɪslɪts ətætʃt tə ðɛɹ sɪlvɝi kɑlɝz. ə fju ʌv ðoʊz deɪzd wɪmən klʌtʃt ðə deɪmeɪn wɔkɪŋ wɪð əm əz ɪf hoʊldɪŋ tə laɪflaɪnz. ɪt wʊɾə bɪn ɪnʌf tə meɪk mæt ʃɪvɝ, ɪf ɪz dæmp kloʊðz hæd nɑɾ ɔlɹɛɾi bɪn duɪŋ ðə dʒɑb.

The three Seanchan were already out of sight, their horses being led into the stables, but several dozen sul'dam were giving damane their evening exercise, walking them in a big circle around the stone-paved yard. Nearly half the gray-clad damane were dark-skinned women, lacking the jewelry they had worn as Windfinders. There were more like them in the Palace and elsewhere; the Seanchan had had a rich harvest from Sea Folk vessels that had failed to escape. Most wore sullen resignation or stony faces, but seven or eight stared ahead of them, lost and confused, disbelieving still. Each of those had a Seanchan-born damane at her side, holding her hand or with an arm around her, smiling and whispering to her under the approving eyes of the women who wore the bracelets attached to their silvery collars. A few of those dazed women clutched the damane walking with them as if holding to lifelines. It would have been enough to make Mat shiver, if his damp clothes had not already been doing the job.

hi tʃɹaɪd tə hɝi noʊl əkɹɔs ðə jɑɹd, bʌt ðə sɝkəl bɹɔɾ ə deɪmeɪn u wɑz niðɝ sintʃæn nɔɹ æθɑn maɪɹ nɪɹ hɪm, lɪŋk tə ə plʌmp, ɡɹeɪɪŋ sʌldəm, ən ɑləv-skɪnd wʊmən u maɪɾ əv pæs fəɹ ɔltɑɹən ən sʌmwʌnz mʌðɝ. ə stɝn mʌðɝ wɪð ə pɑsəbli fɹækʃəs tʃaɪld, fɹəm ðə weɪ ʃi ɹəɡɑɹɾəd əɹ tʃɑɹdʒ. tɛslɪn bɑɹədɑn hæd flɛʃt aʊɾ æftɝ ə mʌnθ ən ə hæf ɪn sintʃæn kæptɪvəɾi, jɛɾ əɹ eɪdʒləs feɪs stɪl lʊkt əz ɪf ʃi eɪt bɹaɪɹz θɹi milz ə deɪ. ɑn ði ʌðɝ hænd, ʃi wɔk plɑtʃədli ɑn əɹ liʃ ən oʊbeɪd ðə sʌldəmz mɝmɝd dɝɛkʃənz wɪθaʊt hɛzəteɪʃən, pɔzɪŋ tə baʊ vɛɹi dipli tə hɪm ən noʊl. fəɹ ən ɪnstənt, ðoʊ, hɝ dɑɹk aɪz flæʃt heɪtʃɹəɾ əɾ ɪm bɪfɔɹ ʃi ən ðə sʌldəm kəntɪnjud ðɛɹ sɝkəɾ ə ðə steɪbliɑɹd. plɑtʃədli, oʊbiɾiəntli. hi hæd sin deɪmeɪn ʌpɛndəɾ ən swɪtʃt tɪl ðeɪ haʊld ɪn ðɪs seɪm steɪbliɑɹd fəɹ meɪkɪŋ ɛni sɔɹɾ ə fʌs, tɛslɪn əmʌŋ ðɛm. ʃi hæd dʌn ɪm noʊ ɡʊd tɝnz, ən meɪbi ə fju bæd, bʌɾ i wəd nɑɾ əv wɪʃt ðɪs ɑn hɝ.

He tried to hurry Noal across the yard, but the circle brought a damane who was neither Seanchan nor Atha'an Miere near him, linked to a plump, graying sul'dam, an olive-skinned woman who might have passed for Altaran and someone's mother. A stern mother with a possibly fractious child, from the way she regarded her charge. Teslyn Baradon had fleshed out after a month and a half in Seanchan captivity, yet her ageless face still looked as if she ate briars three meals a day. On the other hand, she walked placidly on her leash and obeyed the sul'dam's murmured directions without hesitation, pausing to bow very deeply to him and Noal. For an instant, though, her dark eyes flashed hatred at him before she and the sul'dam continued their circuit of the stableyard. Placidly, obediently. He had seen damane upended and switched till they howled in this same stableyard for making any sort of fuss, Teslyn among them. She had done him no good turns, and maybe a few bad, but he would not have wished this on her.

"bɛɾɝ ðən biɪŋ dɛd, aɪ səpoʊz," hi mʌɾɝd, muvɪŋ ɑn. tɛslɪn wɑz ə hɑɹd wʊmən, laɪkli plɑɾɪŋ ɛvɹi moʊmən haʊ tə ɪskeɪp, jɛt hɑɹdnəs oʊnli tʊk jə soʊ fɑɹ. ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps ən əɹ mæstɝ ə ðə bleɪdz hæd daɪɾ ɑn ðə steɪk wɪθaʊɾ ɛvɝ skɹimɪŋ, bʌɾ ɪt hæd nɑt seɪv ðɛm.

"Better than being dead, I suppose," he muttered, moving on. Teslyn was a hard woman, likely plotting every moment how to escape, yet hardness only took you so far. The Mistress of the Ships and her Master of the Blades had died on the stake without ever screaming, but it had not saved them.

"du jə bɪliv ðæt?" noʊl æskt æbsənli, fʌmbəlɪŋ ɔkwɝdli wɪð ɪz bʌndəl əɡɛn. hɪz bɹoʊkən hænz hæd hændəl ðət naɪf wɛl ɪnʌf, bʌt ðeɪ sim klʌmzi əɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɛls.

"Do you believe that?" Noal asked absently, fumbling awkwardly with his bundle again. His broken hands had handled that knife well enough, but they seemed clumsy at everything else.

mæt fɹaʊn ət hɪm. noʊ; hi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ i bɪlivd ɪt. ðoʊz sɪlvɝ æɾəm sim tu mʌtʃ laɪk ði ɪnvɪzəbəl kɑlɝ taɪlɪn hæɾ ɑn hɪm. ðən əɡɛn, taɪlɪn kəd tɪkəl ɪm ʌndɝ ðə tʃɪn ðə ɹɛst ə hɪz laɪf ɪf ɪt kɛpt ɪm ɔf ðə steɪk. laɪt, hi wɪʃt ðoʊz blʌɾi daɪs ɪn ɪz hɛd wəd dʒʌst stɑp ən ɡɛɾ ɪɾ oʊvɝ wɪð! noʊ, ðət wɑz ə laɪ. sɪns i hæd faɪnəli ɹilaɪzd wʌt ðeɪ mɛnt, hi hæd nɛvɝ wɑntəd ðə daɪs tə stɑp.

Mat frowned at him. No; he was not sure he believed it. Those silver a'dam seemed too much like the invisible collar Tylin had on him. Then again, Tylin could tickle him under the chin the rest of his life if it kept him off the stake. Light, he wished those bloody dice in his head would just stop and get it over with! No, that was a lie. Since he had finally realized what they meant, he had never wanted the dice to stop.

ðə ɹum tʃəl veɪnɪn ən ðə sɝvaɪvɪŋ ɹɛdʒɹmz ʃɛɹd leɪ nɑt fɑɹ fɹəm ðə steɪbəlz, ə lɔŋ waɪt-plæstɝd tʃeɪmbɝ wɪð ə loʊ silɪŋ ən tu mɛni bɛdz fəɹ ðoʊz u ɹɪmeɪn əlaɪv. veɪnɪn, ə bɔldɪŋ suɾi hip, wɑz laɪɪŋ ɑn wʌn ɪn ɪz ʃɝtslivz, ən oʊpən bʊk pɹɑpt ɑn ɪz tʃɛst. mæt wɑz sɝpɹaɪz ðə mæn kəd ɹid. spɪɾɪŋ θɹu ə ɡæp ɪn ɪz tiθ, veɪnɪn aɪd mæts mʌd-smɪɹd kloʊðz. "ju bɪn faɪɾɪŋ əɡɛn?" hi æskt. "ʃi woʊn laɪk ðæt, aɪ ɹɛkən." hi dɪd nɑt ɹaɪz. wɪð ə fju stɑɹtlɪŋ ɪksɛpʃənz, veɪnɪn kənsɪɾɝd hɪmsɛlf əz ɡʊɾ əz ɛni lɔɹɾ əɹ leɪɾi.

The room Chel Vanin and the surviving Redarms shared lay not far from the stables, a long white-plastered chamber with a low ceiling and too many beds for those who remained alive. Vanin, a balding suety heap, was lying on one in his shirtsleeves, an open book propped on his chest. Mat was surprised the man could read. Spitting through a gap in his teeth, Vanin eyed Mat's mud-smeared clothes. "You been fighting again?" he asked. "She won't like that, I reckon." He did not rise. With a few startling exceptions, Vanin considered himself as good as any lord or lady.

"tʃɹʌbəl, lɔɹd mæt?" hɑɹnən ɡɹaʊld, lipɪŋ tə hɪz fit. hi wɑz ə sɑləd mæn, fɪzɪkəli ən baɪ tɛmpɹəmənt, bʌɾ ɪz hɛvi dʒɔ klɛntʃt, twɪstɪŋ ðə hɔk kɹudli tætuɾ ɑn ɪz tʃik. "bɛɡɪŋ jəɹ pɑɹɾən, bʌt jəɹ ɪn noʊ kəndɪʃən fəɹ ɪt. tɛl əs wʌɾ i lʊks laɪk, ən wɪl sɔɹɾ ɪm aʊt fəɹ ju."

"Trouble, Lord Mat?" Harnan growled, leaping to his feet. He was a solid man, physically and by temperament, but his heavy jaw clenched, twisting the hawk crudely tattooed on his cheek. "Begging your pardon, but you're in no condition for it. Tell us what he looks like, and we'll sort him out for you."

ðə læs θɹi ɡæðɝd bɪhaɪn ɪm wɪð iɡɝ ɪkspɹɛʃənz, tu ɡɹæbɪŋ fəɹ ðɛɹ koʊts waɪl stɪl tʌkɪŋ ɪn ʃɝteɪlz. mɛtwɪn, ə bɔɪɪʃ-əpɪɹɪŋ kɛɹhinɪn u wɑz tɛn jɪɹz oʊldɝ ðən mæt, ɪnstɛd pɪkt ʌp ɪz sɔɹd fɹəm wɛɹ ɪt wɑz pɹɑpt ət ðə fʊɾ ə hɪz bɛɾ ən izd ə lɪɾəl ə ðə bleɪɾ aʊɾ ə ðə skæbɝd tə tʃɛk ði ɛdʒ. hi wɑz ðə bɛst ə ðɛm wɪð ə sɔɹd, vɛɹi ɡʊɾ ɪndid, ðoʊ ɡɔɹɾɝən keɪm kloʊs fəɹ ɔl i lʊkt ə blæksmɪθ. ɡɔɹɾɝən wɑz nɑt nɪɹli əz sloʊ əz ɪz θɪk ʃoʊldɝz meɪɾ ɪm əpɪɹ. ə dʌzən ɹɛdʒɹmz hæd fɑloʊd mæt kɔθən tə ɛbu dɑɹ, eɪɾ ə ðoʊz wɝ dɛd, ən ðə ɹɛst wɝ stʌk hɪɹ ɪn ðə pæləs wɛɹ ðeɪ kəd nɑt pɪntʃ ðə meɪdz, ɡɛɾ ɪndə ə faɪɾ oʊvɝ daɪs, ən dʒɹɪŋk tɪl ðeɪ fɛl ɑn ðɛɹ feɪsəz, əz ðeɪ cʊɾə steɪɪŋ əɾ ən ɪn ən noʊɪŋ ði ɪnkipɝ wəd si ðɛm kæɹiɾ ʌp tə ðɛɹ bɛdz, ðoʊ meɪbi wɪð ðɛɹ pɝsɪz ə lɪɾəl laɪɾɝ ðən ðeɪ hæd bɪn.

The last three gathered behind him with eager expressions, two grabbing for their coats while still tucking in shirttails. Metwyn, a boyish-appearing Cairhienin who was ten years older than Mat, instead picked up his sword from where it was propped at the foot of his bed and eased a little of the blade out of the scabbard to check the edge. He was the best of them with a sword, very good indeed, though Gorderan came close for all he looked a blacksmith. Gorderan was not nearly as slow as his thick shoulders made him appear. A dozen Redarms had followed Mat Cauthon to Ebou Dar, eight of those were dead, and the rest were stuck here in the Palace where they could not pinch the maids, get into a fight over dice, and drink till they fell on their faces, as they could have staying at an inn and knowing the innkeeper would see them carried up to their beds, though maybe with their purses a little lighter than they had been.
