"noʊl hɪɹ kən tɛl jə wʌt hæpən bɛɾɝ ðən aɪ kæn," mæt ɹɪplaɪd, pʊʃɪŋ ɪz hæt bæk ɑn ɪz hɛd. "hil bi bɛɾɪŋ ɪn hɪɹ wɪð ju. hi seɪv maɪ laɪf tənaɪt."

"Noal here can tell you what happened better than I can," Mat replied, pushing his hat back on his head. "He'll be bedding in here with you. He saved my life tonight."

ðət bɹɔɾ ɛkskləmeɪʃənz ə ʃɑk, ən kɹaɪz ʌv æpɹəbeɪʃən fəɹ noʊl, nɑt tə mɛnʃən slæps ɑn ðə bæk ðəɾ ɔlmoʊs tɑpəl ði oʊl fɛloʊ. veɪnɪn wɛn soʊ fɑɹ əz tə mɑɹk ɪz pleɪs ɪn ðə bʊk wɪð ə fæt fɪŋɡɝ ən sɪɾ ʌp ɑn ðə saɪɾ ə hɪz θɪn mætʃɹəs.

That brought exclamations of shock, and cries of approbation for Noal, not to mention slaps on the back that almost toppled the old fellow. Vanin went so far as to mark his place in the book with a fat finger and sit up on the side of his thin mattress.

sɛɾɪŋ ɪz bʌndəl daʊn ɑn ə veɪkən bɛd, noʊl toʊl ðə teɪl wɪð ɪlæbɹət dʒɛstʃɝz, pleɪɪŋ daʊn ɪz oʊn ɹoʊl ən ivən meɪkɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ə bɪɾ ʌv ə bəfun, slɪpɪŋ ɪn ðə mʌɾ ən ɡeɪpɪŋ ət ðə ɡoʊləm waɪl mæt fɔt laɪk ə tʃæmpiən. ðə mæn wɑz ə nætʃɹəl stɔɹitɛlɝ, əz ɡʊɾ əz ə ɡlimən fəɹ meɪkɪŋ jə si wʌɾ i dɪskɹaɪbd. hɑɹnən ən ðə ɹɛdʒɹmz læf dʒiniəli, noʊɪŋ wʌɾ i wɑz əbaʊt, nɑt stilɪŋ ðɛɹ kæptənz θʌndɝ, ən əpɹuvɪŋ ʌv ɪt, bʌt læftɝ daɪd wən i keɪm tə mæts ətækɝ slɪpɪŋ əweɪ θɹu ə taɪni hoʊl ɪn ə wɔl. hi meɪd jə si ðæt, tu. veɪnɪn pʊt daʊn ɪz bʊk ən spæt θɹu hɪz tiθ əɡɛn. ðə ɡoʊləm hæd lɛf veɪnɪn ən hɑɹnən hæf-dɛɾ ɪn ðə ɹæhəd. hæf-dɛd kəz ɪt wɑz æftɝ ʌðɝ pɹeɪ.

Setting his bundle down on a vacant bed, Noal told the tale with elaborate gestures, playing down his own role and even making himself a bit of a buffoon, slipping in the mud and gaping at the gholam while Mat fought like a champion. The man was a natural storyteller, as good as a gleeman for making you see what he described. Harnan and the Redarms laughed genially, knowing what he was about, not stealing their captain's thunder, and approving of it, but laughter died when he came to Mat's attacker slipping away through a tiny hole in a wall. He made you see that, too. Vanin put down his book and spat through his teeth again. The gholam had left Vanin and Harnan half-dead in the Rahad. Half-dead because it was after other prey.

"ðə θɪŋ wɑns mi fəɹ səm ɹizən, ɪt simz," mæt sɛd laɪtli wən ði oʊl mæn fɪnɪʃt ən sæŋk ɑntu ðə bɛd wɪð ɪz bɪlɔŋɪŋz, simɪŋli ɪɡzɔstəd. "ɪt pɹɑbli pleɪɾ ət daɪs wɪð mi səm taɪm aɪ doʊn ɹikɔl. nʌn ə jə hæz tə wɝi, əz lɔŋ əz jə doʊnt ɡɛt bɪtwin ɪɾ ən mi." hi ɡɹɪnd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə meɪk ɪɾ ɔl ə dʒoʊk, bʌt noʊ wʌn soʊ mʌtʃ əz smaɪld. "ɪn ɛni keɪs, əl pɑɹsəl aʊt ɡoʊl tə jə ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ. jəl bʊk pæsədʒ ɑn ðə fɝst ʃɪp livɪŋ fəɹ ɪljən, ən teɪk oʊlvɝ wɪð ju. tɑm ən dʒulɪn, tu, ɪf ðəl ɡoʊ." hi ɪmædʒən ðə θif-kætʃɝ wʊd, ɛniweɪ. "ænd nɹɪm ən ləpɪn, ʌv kɔɹs." hi hæd ɡɑɾən juz tə hævɪŋ ə pɛɹ ə sɝvɪŋ mɛn lʊk æftɝ hɪm, bʌɾ i hɑɹdli niɾəd əm hɪɹ. "tælmɑnz mʌs bi sʌmwɛɹ kloʊz tə keɪɛmlɪn baɪ ðɪs taɪm. jə ʃʊdn əv mʌtʃ tʃɹʌbəl faɪndɪŋ hɪm." wən ðeɪ wɝ ɡɔn, hi wəd bi əloʊn wɪð taɪlɪn. laɪt, hi wəd ɹæðɝ feɪs ðə ɡoʊləm əɡɛn!

"The thing wants me for some reason, it seems," Mat said lightly when the old man finished and sank onto the bed with his belongings, seemingly exhausted. "It probably played at dice with me some time I don't recall. None of you has to worry, as long as you don't get between it and me." He grinned, trying to make it all a joke, but no one so much as smiled. "In any case, I'll parcel out gold to you in the morning. You'll book passage on the first ship leaving for Illian, and take Olver with you. Thom and Juilin, too, if they'll go." He imagined the thief-catcher would, anyway. "And Nerim and Lopin, of course." He had gotten used to having a pair of serving men look after him, but he hardly needed them here. "Talmanes must be somewhere close to Caemlyn by this time. You shouldn't have much trouble finding him." When they were gone, he would be alone with Tylin. Light, he would rather face the gholam again!

hɑɹnən ən ði ʌðɝ θɹi ɹɛdʒɹmz ɪkstʃeɪnʒd lʊks, fɝdʒɪn skɹætʃɪŋ ɪz hɛɾ əz ɪf i dɪd nɑt kwaɪɾ ʌndɝstænd. hi maɪt nɑt. ðə boʊni mæn wɑz ə ɡʊd soʊlʒɝ - nɑt ðə bɛst, maɪnd, bʌt ɡʊɾ ɪnʌf - jɛɾ i wɑz nɑt vɛɹi bɹaɪt wən ɪt keɪm tə ʌðɝ θɪŋz.

Harnan and the other three Redarms exchanged looks, Fergin scratching his head as if he did not quite understand. He might not. The bony man was a good soldier - not the best, mind, but good enough - yet he was not very bright when it came to other things.

"ðæt wʊdn bi ɹaɪt," hɑɹnən əlaʊd faɪnəli. "wʌn θɪŋ, lɔɹd tælmɑnzəɾ əv əɹ haɪdz ɪf wi keɪm bæk wɪθaʊt ju." ði ʌðɝ θɹi nɑɾəd. fɝdʒɪn kəɾ ʌndɝstæn ðæt.

"That wouldn't be right," Harnan allowed finally. "One thing, Lord Talmanes'd have our hides if we came back without you." The other three nodded. Fergin could understand that.

"æn ju, veɪnɪn?" mæt æskt.

"And you, Vanin?" Mat asked.

ðə fæt mæn ʃɹʌɡd. "aɪ teɪk ðət bɔɪ əweɪ fɹəm ɹaɪzɛl, ən hɪl ɡʌt mi laɪk ə tʃɹaʊt ðə fɝs taɪm aɪ ɡoʊ tə slip. aɪ wəd maɪsɛlf, ɪn ɪz buts. ɛniweɪ, aɪ ɡɑt taɪm tə ɹid, hɪɹ. doʊnt ɡɛt mʌtʃ tʃæns fəɹ ðət wɝkɪŋ əz ə fɛɹiɝ." ðət wɑz wʌn ə ði aɪtɪnɝən tʃɹeɪdz i kleɪm tə fɑloʊ. ði ʌðɝ wɑz steɪbəlmən. ɪn tʃɹuθ, hi wɑz ə hɔɹsɛθif ən poʊtʃɝ, ðə bɛst ɪn tu kʌntʃɹiz ən meɪbi mɔɹ.

The fat man shrugged. "I take that boy away from Riselle, and he'll gut me like a trout the first time I go to sleep. I would myself, in his boots. Anyway, I got time to read, here. Don't get much chance for that working as a farrier." That was one of the itinerant trades he claimed to follow. The other was stableman. In truth, he was a horsethief and poacher, the best in two countries and maybe more.

"jɔɹ ɔl mæd," mæt sɛd wɪð ə fɹaʊn. "dʒʌs kəz ɪt wɑns mi, dʌzn min ɪt woʊn kɪl jə ɪf jə ɡɛɾ ɪn ðə weɪ. ði ɔfɝ steɪz oʊpən. ɛniwʌn u kʌmz tə hɪz sɛnsɪz kən ɡoʊ."

"You're all mad," Mat said with a frown. "Just because it wants me, doesn't mean it won't kill you if you get in the way. The offer stays open. Anyone who comes to his senses can go."

"aɪ hæv sin jəɹ laɪk bɪfɔɹ," noʊl sɛd sʌɾənli. ðə stupt oʊl mæn wɑz ði ɪmədʒ ə hɑɹɾ eɪdʒ ən ɪɡzɔstʃən, bʌɾ ɪz aɪz wɝ bɹaɪɾ ən ʃɑɹp stʌɾiɪŋ mæt. "sʌm mɛn əv ən ɛɹ əbaʊɾ əm ðət meɪks ʌðɝ mɛn fɑloʊ wɛɹ ðeɪ lɛd. səm lɛd tə dɛvəsteɪʃən, ʌðɝz tə ɡlɔɹi. aɪ θɪŋk jəɹ neɪm meɪ ɡoʊ ɪndə ðə hɪstɝi bʊks."

"I have seen your like before," Noal said suddenly. The stooped old man was the image of hard age and exhaustion, but his eyes were bright and sharp studying Mat. "Some men have an air about them that makes other men follow where they lead. Some lead to devastation, others to glory. I think your name may go into the history books."

hɑɹnən lʊkt əz kənfjuzd əz fɝdʒɪn. veɪnɪn spæɾ ən leɪ bæk daʊn, oʊpənɪŋ ɪz bʊk.

Harnan looked as confused as Fergin. Vanin spat and lay back down, opening his book.

"ɪf ɔl maɪ lʌk ɡoʊz əweɪ, meɪbi," mæt mʌɾɝd. hi nu wʌɾ ɪt tʊk tə ɡɛɾ ɪndə ðə hɪstɝiz. ə mæn kəd ɡɛt kɪld, duɪŋ ðət sɔɹɾ ə θɪŋ.

"If all my luck goes away, maybe," Mat muttered. He knew what it took to get into the histories. A man could get killed, doing that sort of thing.

"bɛɾɝ klin ʌp bɪfɔɹ ʃi siz ju," fɝdʒɪn paɪpt ʌp sʌɾənli. "ɔl ðət mʌd wɪl pʊɾ ə bɝ ʌndɝ əɹ sæɾəl fəɹ ʃʊɹ."

"Better clean up before she sees you," Fergin piped up suddenly. "All that mud will put a burr under her saddle for sure."

snætʃɪŋ ɪz hæɾ ɔf æŋɡɹəli, mæt stɔkt aʊt wɪθaʊɾ ə wɝd. wɛl, hi stɔkt əz wɛl əz i kʊd, hɑbəlɪŋ ɑn ə wɔkɪŋ stæf. bɪfɔɹ ðə dɔɹ kloʊz bɪhaɪn hɪm, hi hɝd noʊl stɑɹɾɪŋ ə stɔɹi əbaʊt wʌn taɪm i seɪld ɑn ə si foʊk ʃɪp ən lɝn tə beɪð ɪn koʊl sɔlt wɔɾɝ. ət list, ðət wɑz haʊ ɪt bɪɡæn.

Snatching his hat off angrily, Mat stalked out without a word. Well, he stalked as well as he could, hobbling on a walking staff. Before the door closed behind him, he heard Noal starting a story about one time he sailed on a Sea Folk ship and learned to bathe in cold salt water. At least, that was how it began.

hi ɪntɛndəd tə ɡɛt hɪmsɛlf klin bɪfɔɹ taɪlɪn sɔ hɪm - hi dɪd - bʌɾ əz i lɪmp θɹu hɔlweɪz hʌŋ wɪð ðə flaʊɝd tæpəstʃɹiz ɛbu dɑɹi kɔl sʌmɝ-hæŋʒɪŋz, fəɹ ðə sizən ðeɪ ɪvoʊkt, fɔɹ sɝvɪŋ mɛn ɪn ðə pæləsəz ɡɹin-ænd-waɪt lɪvɝi ən noʊ fjuɝ ðən sɛvən meɪdz sədʒɛstəɾ i maɪt wɑnə beɪð ən tʃeɪnʒ ɪz kloʊðz bɪfɔɹ ðə kwin sɔ hɪm, ɔfɝɪŋ tə dʒɹɔ hɪm ə bæθ ən fɛtʃ klin ɡɑɹməns wɪθaʊɾ əɹ lɝnɪŋ ʌv ɪt. ðeɪ dɪd nɑt noʊ ɛvɹiθɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪm ən taɪlɪn, θæŋk ðə laɪt - noʊ wʌn bʌt taɪlɪn ən hɪmsɛlf nu ðə wɝs bɪts - bʌt ðeɪ nu tu blʌɾi mʌtʃ. wɝs, ðeɪ əpɹuvd, ɛvɹi læs fleɪmɪŋ sɝvən ɪn ðə hoʊl fleɪmɪŋ tɑɹɑsɪn pæləs. fəɹ wʌn θɪŋ, taɪlɪn wɑz kwin ən kəd də əz ʃi plizd, soʊ fɑɹ əz ðeɪ wɝ kənsɝnd. fəɹ ənʌðɝ, hɝ tɛmpɝ hæd bɪn ɑn ə ɹeɪzɝz ɛdʒ sɪns ðə sintʃæn kæptʃɝd ðə sɪɾi, ən ɪf mæt kɔθən skɹʌbd ən bɹaɪɾ ɪn leɪs kɛpt əɹ fɹəm snæpɪŋ ðɛɹ noʊzɪz ɔf fəɹ tʃɹaɪfəlz, ðən ðeɪ wəd skɹʌb bɪhaɪn ɪz ɪɹz ən ɹæp ɪm ɪn leɪs laɪk ə sʌndeɪ ɡɪft!

He intended to get himself clean before Tylin saw him - he did - but as he limped through hallways hung with the flowered tapestries Ebou Dari called summer-hangings, for the season they evoked, four serving men in the Palace's green-and-white livery and no fewer than seven maids suggested he might want to bathe and change his clothes before the Queen saw him, offering to draw him a bath and fetch clean garments without her learning of it. They did not know everything about him and Tylin, thank the Light - no one but Tylin and himself knew the worst bits - but they knew too bloody much. Worse, they approved, every last flaming servant in the whole flaming Tarasin Palace. For one thing, Tylin was Queen and could do as she pleased, so far as they were concerned. For another, her temper had been on a razor's edge since the Seanchan captured the city, and if Mat Cauthon scrubbed and bright in lace kept her from snapping their noses off for trifles, then they would scrub behind his ears and wrap him in lace like a Sunday gift!

"mʌd?" hi sɛd tə ə pɹɪɾi, smaɪlɪŋ meɪd spɹɛɾɪŋ əɹ skɝts ɪn ə kɝtsi. ðəɹ wɑz ə twɪŋkəl ɪn əɹ dɑɹk aɪz, ən ðə plʌnʒɪŋ nɛklaɪn ə hɝ bɑɾəs dɪspleɪɾ ə fɛɹ əmaʊn ə bʊzəm tə ɔlmoʊst ɹaɪvəl ɹaɪzɛlz. ɑn ənʌðɝ deɪ hi maɪɾ əv teɪkən ə lɪɾəl taɪm tə ɛndʒɔɪ lʊkɪŋ. "wʌt mʌd? aɪ doʊn si ɛni mʌd!" hɝ maʊθ dʒɹɑpt oʊpən, ən ʃi fɝɡɑt tə stʃɹeɪɾən, stɛɹɪŋ əɾ ɪm wɪð əɹ niz bɛn əz i hɑbəld əweɪ.

"Mud?" he said to a pretty, smiling maid spreading her skirts in a curtsy. There was a twinkle in her dark eyes, and the plunging neckline of her bodice displayed a fair amount of bosom to almost rival Riselle's. On another day he might have taken a little time to enjoy looking. "What mud? I don't see any mud!" Her mouth dropped open, and she forgot to straighten, staring at him with her knees bent as he hobbled away.

dʒulɪn sændɑɹ, ɹaʊndɪŋ ə kɔɹnɝ kwɪkli, nɪɹli wɔkt ɪndə hɪm. ðə tɛɹən θif-kætʃɝ lɛp bæk wɪð ə mʌfəld oʊθ, hɪz swɔɹði feɪs tɝnɪŋ ɡɹeɪ əntɪl i ɹilaɪzd u hæɾ ɔlmoʊst ɹʌn ɪm oʊvɝ. ðən i mʌɾɝd ən əpɑlədʒi ən stɑɹɾəd tə hɝi ɑn baɪ.

Juilin Sandar, rounding a corner quickly, nearly walked into him. The Tairen thief-catcher leaped back with a muffled oath, his swarthy face turning gray until he realized who had almost run him over. Then he muttered an apology and started to hurry on by.

"hæz tɑm ɡɑt jə mɪkst ɪndə hɪz fulɪʃnəs, dʒulɪn?" mæt sɛd. dʒulɪn ən tɑm ʃɛɹɾ ə ɹum dip ɪn ðə sɝvəns' kɔɹɾɝz, ən ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɪkskjus fəɹ ɪm tə bi ʌp hɪɹ. ɪn ðət dɑɹk tɛɹən koʊt, flɛɹɪŋ oʊvɝ ɪz but tɑps, dʒulɪn wəd stæn aʊɾ əmʌŋ ðə sɝvəns laɪk ə dʌk ɪn ə tʃɪkən kup. sjuɹɔθ wɑz stʃɹɪkt əbaʊt θɪŋz laɪk ðæt, stʃɹɪktɝ ðən taɪlɪn. ði oʊnli ɹizən fəɹ ɪt mæt kəd si wɑz wʌtɛvɝ tɑm ən bɛslən wɝ mɛɾəlɪŋ wɪð. "noʊ; doʊn bɑðɝ tɛlɪŋ mi. aɪv meɪɾ ən ɔfɝ tə hɑɹnən ən ði ʌðɝz, ən ɪts oʊpən tə ju, tu. ɪf jə wɑnə liv, əl ɡɪv jə ðə mʌni fəɹ ɪt."

"Has Thom got you mixed into his foolishness, Juilin?" Mat said. Juilin and Thom shared a room deep in the servants' quarters, and there was no excuse for him to be up here. In that dark Tairen coat, flaring over his boot tops, Juilin would stand out among the servants like a duck in a chicken coop. Suroth was strict about things like that, stricter than Tylin. The only reason for it Mat could see was whatever Thom and Beslan were meddling with. "No; don't bother telling me. I've made an offer to Harnan and the others, and it's open to you, too. If you want to leave, I'll give you the money for it."

æktʃəli , dʒulɪn dɪd nɑt lʊk ɹɛɾi tə tɛl ɪm ɛniθɪŋ. ðə θif-kætʃɝ tʌkt ɪz θʌmz bɪhaɪn ɪz bɛlt ən mɛt mæts ɡeɪz lɛvəli. "wʌt dɪd hɑɹnən ən ði ʌðɝz seɪ? ən wʌɾ ɪz tɑm duɪŋ ðət jə kɔl fulɪʃ? ðɪs ɪz wʌn sɛɾ ə ɹuftɑps i noʊz ɪz weɪ ɝaʊn bɛɾɝ ðən jə əɹ aɪ."

Actually, Juilin did not look ready to tell him anything. The thief-catcher tucked his thumbs behind his belt and met Mat's gaze levelly. "What did Harnan and the others say? And what is Thom doing that you call foolish? This is one set of rooftops he knows his way around better than you or I."

"ðə ɡoʊləm ɪz stɪl ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ, dʒulɪn." tɑm nu ðət ðə ɡeɪm ə haʊsəz wɑz wʌɾ i nu, ən i lʌv stɪkɪŋ ɪz noʊz ɪndə pɑlətɪks. "ðə θɪŋ tʃɹaɪd tə kɪl mi, ɝliɝ ðɪs ivnɪŋ."

"The gholam is still in Ebou Dar, Juilin." Thom knew that the Game of Houses was what he knew, and he loved sticking his nose into politics. "The thing tried to kill me, earlier this evening."

dʒulɪn ɡɹʌntɪɾ əz ɪf i hæd bɪn hɪɾ ɪn ðə pɪɾ ə hɪz bɛli, ən skɹʌbd ə hæn θɹu hɪz ʃɔɹt blæk hɛɹ. "aɪ hæv ə ɹizən tə steɪ ə waɪl lɔŋɡɝ," hi sɛd, "ivən soʊ." hɪz ɛɹ tʃeɪnʒd slaɪtli, tə sʌmθɪŋ stʌbɝn ən dɪfɛnsɪv ən tɪŋd wɪð ɡɪlt. hi hæd nɛvɝ ʃoʊn ə ɹoʊvɪŋ aɪ ðət mæt hæd sin, bʌt wən ə mæn lʊk laɪk ðæt, ɪt kəɾ oʊnli min wʌn θɪŋ.

Juilin grunted as if he had been hit in the pit of his belly, and scrubbed a hand through his short black hair. "I have a reason to stay a while longer," he said, "even so." His air changed slightly, to something stubborn and defensive and tinged with guilt. He had never shown a roving eye that Mat had seen, but when a man looked like that, it could only mean one thing.

"teɪk əɹ wɪð ju," mæt sɛd. "æn ɪf ʃi woʊnt ɡoʊ, wɛl, jəl nɑt bi ɪn tɛɹ ən aʊɝ bɪfɔɹ juv ə wʊmən ɑn itʃ ni. ðæts ðə θɪŋ əbaʊt wɪmən, dʒulɪn. ɪf wʌn sɛz noʊ, ðɛɹz ɔlweɪz ənʌðɝ wɪl seɪ jɛs."

"Take her with you," Mat said. "And if she won't go, well, you'll not be in Tear an hour before you have a woman on each knee. That's the thing about women, Juilin. If one says no, there's always another will say yes."

ə sɝvɪŋ mæn hɝiɪŋ baɪ wɪð ən ɑɹmloʊɾ ə lɪnən taʊəlz stɛɹɾ ət mæts mʌɾinəs ɪn əmeɪzmənt, bʌt dʒulɪn θɔɾ ɪt wɑz ət hɪm, ən snætʃt ɪz θʌmz fɹi ʌv ɪz bɛlt ən ətɛmptəd tə ədɑpt ə mɔɹ hʌmbəl stæns. wɪθaʊt mʌtʃ səksɛs. tɑm maɪt slip wɪð ðə sɝvəns, jɛt fɹəm ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ i hæd sʌmhaʊ meɪɾ ɪt sim tə bi hɪz oʊn tʃɔɪs, ən ɛksəntʃɹɪsəɾi, ən noʊ wʌn θɔɾ ɪɾ ɑd tə si hɪm ʌp hɪɹ, pɝhæps slɪpɪŋ ɪndə ɹaɪzɛlz ɹumz ðət hæd wʌns bɪn mæts. dʒulɪn hæd ɡɔn ɑn ət lɛŋθ əbaʊt biɪŋ ə θif-kætʃɝ - nɛvɝ ə θif-teɪkɝ - ən stɛɹd soʊ mɛni pɹɪkli lɔɹɾəlɪŋz ən kəmpleɪsən mɝtʃəns ɪn ði aɪ tə ʃoʊ hi wɑz əz ɡʊɾ əz ðeɪ ðəɾ ɛvɹiwʌn ɪn ðə pæləs nu hu ən wʌɾ i wɑz. ən wɛɹ i wɑz səpoʊz tə bi, wɪtʃ wɑz bɛləstɛɹz.

A serving man hurrying by with an armload of linen towels stared at Mat's muddiness in amazement, but Juilin thought it was at him, and snatched his thumbs free of his belt and attempted to adopt a more humble stance. Without much success. Thom might sleep with the servants, yet from the beginning he had somehow made it seem to be his own choice, an eccentricity, and no one thought it odd to see him up here, perhaps slipping into Riselle's rooms that had once been Mat's. Juilin had gone on at length about being a thief-catcher - never a thief-taker - and stared so many prickly lordlings and complacent merchants in the eye to show he was as good as they that everyone in the Palace knew who and what he was. And where he was supposed to be, which was belowstairs.

"maɪ lɔɹɾ ɪz waɪz," hi sɛd, tu laʊdli, ən meɪkɪŋ ə stɪf, dʒɝki baʊ. "maɪ lɔɹd noʊz ɔl əbaʊt wɪmən. ɪf maɪ lɔɹd wɪl fɝɡɪv ə hʌmbəl mæn, aɪ mʌst ɹɪtɝn tə maɪ pleɪs." tɝnɪŋ tə ɡoʊ, hi spoʊk oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ, stɪl ɪn ə kæɹiɪŋ vɔɪs. "aɪ hɝd tədeɪ ðəɾ ɪf maɪ lɔɹd kʌmz bæk wʌn mɔɹ taɪm lʊkɪŋ laɪk hiz bɪn dʒɹæɡd ɪn ðə stʃɹit, ðə kwin ɪntɛnz teɪkɪŋ ə swɪtʃ tə maɪ lɔɹdz pɝsən."

"My Lord is wise," he said, too loudly, and making a stiff, jerky bow. "My Lord knows all about women. If my Lord will forgive a humble man, I must return to my place." Turning to go, he spoke over his shoulder, still in a carrying voice. "I heard today that if my Lord comes back one more time looking like he's been dragged in the street, the Queen intends taking a switch to my Lord's person."

ən ðət wɑz ðə stoʊn ðət bɹoʊk ðə wæɡən klin ɪn tu.

And that was the stone that broke the wagon clean in two.

flɪŋɪŋ oʊpən ðə dɔɹz ə taɪlɪnz əpɑɹtməns, mæt stʃɹoʊɾ ɪn, seɪld ɪz hæɾ əkɹɔs ðə wɪdθ ə ðə ɹum . . . ən stɑp dɛd, hɪz maʊθ hæŋɪŋ oʊpən ən ɛvɹiθɪŋ i hæd plæn tə seɪ fɹoʊzən ɑn ɪz tʌŋ. hɪz hæt hɪt ðə kɑɹpəts ən ɹoʊld, hi dɪd nɑt si wɛɹ. ə ɡʌst ʌv wɪn ɹæɾəld ðə tɔl tʃɹɪpəl-ɑɹtʃt wɪndoʊz ðət lɛɾ aʊɾ ɑntu ə lɔŋ, skɹin bælkəni oʊvɝlʊkɪŋ ðə mɔl hɛɹə.

Flinging open the doors of Tylin's apartments, Mat strode in, sailed his hat across the width of the room . . . And stopped dead, his mouth hanging open and everything he had planned to say frozen on his tongue. His hat hit the carpets and rolled, he did not see where. A gust of wind rattled the tall triple-arched windows that let out onto a long, screened balcony overlooking the Mol Hara.

taɪlɪn tɝn ɪn ə tʃɛɹ kɑɹv tə lʊk laɪk ɡɪldɪd bæmbu ən stɛɹɾ əɾ ɪm oʊvɝ əɹ ɡoʊldən waɪnkʌp. weɪvz ʌv ɡlɔsi blæk hɛɹ tʌtʃt wɪð ɡɹeɪ ət ðə tɛmpəlz fɹeɪmd ə bjuɾəfəl feɪs wɪð ði aɪz ʌv ə bɝɾ ə pɹeɪ, ən nɑt wʌn bɛs plizd ət ðə moʊmənt. ɪŋkɑnsəkwɛntʃəl θɪŋz sim tə lip ət hɪm. ʃi kɪkt əɹ kɹɔs lɛɡ slaɪtli, ɹɪpəlɪŋ leɪɝd ɡɹin ən waɪt pɛɾikoʊts. peɪl ɡɹin leɪs tʃɹɪm ði oʊvəl oʊpənɪŋ ɪn əɹ ɡaʊn ðət hæf ɪkspoʊzd əɹ fʊl bɹɛsts, wɛɹ ðə dʒuəl hɪlt ə hɝ mɛɹɪdʒ naɪf dæŋɡəld. ʃi wɑz nɑɾ əloʊn. sjuɹɔθ sæt feɪsɪŋ hɝ, fɹaʊnɪŋ ɪndə hɝ waɪnkʌp ən tæpɪŋ lɔŋ fɪŋɡɝneɪlz ɑn ði ɑɹm ə hɝ tʃɛɹ, ə pɹɪɾi ɪnʌf wʊmən dɪspaɪɾ əɹ hɛɹ biɪŋ ʃeɪv tə ðət lɔŋ kɹɛst, ɪksɛp ðət ʃi meɪd taɪlɪn sim ə ɹæbət baɪ kəmpɛɹəsən. tu ʌv ðoʊz fɪŋɡɝneɪlz ɑn itʃ hænd wɝ lækɝd blu. siɾəd əɾ əɹ saɪd wɑz ə lɪɾəl ɡɝl, ʌv ɔl θɪŋz, ɔlsoʊ ɪn ən ɪlæbɹətli flaʊɝd ɹoʊb oʊvɝ pliɾɪd waɪt skɝts, bʌt wɪð ə ʃɪɹ veɪl kʌvɝɪŋ əɹ ɪntaɪɝ hɛd - ɪt sim tə bi ʃeɪv kəmplitli! - ən wɛɹɪŋ ə fɔɹtʃən ɪn ɹubiz. ivən ɪn ə steɪɾ ə ʃɑk, hi noʊɾəst ɹubiz ən ɡoʊld. ə slɛndɝ wʊmən, nɪɹli əz dɑɹk əz əɹ stɑɹk blæk ɡaʊn ən tɔl ivən hæd ʃi bɪn il, stʊd bɪhaɪn ðə ɡɝlz tʃɛɹ wɪð əɹ ɑɹmz foʊldəɾ ən ɪl-kənsild ɪmpeɪʃəns. hɝ weɪvi blæk hɛɹ wɑz ʃɔɹt, bʌt nɑt ʃeɪvd əɾ ɔl, soʊ ʃi wɑz niðɝ ə ðə blʌd nɔɹ sɔɪhɪn. ɪmpɪɹiəsli bjuɾəfəl, ʃi pʊt taɪlɪn ən sjuɹɔθ boʊθ ɪn ðə ʃeɪd. hi noʊɾəst bjuɾəfəl wɪmən, tu, ivən wən i dɪd fil hɪɾ ɪn ðə hɛd wɪð ə hæmɝ.

Tylin turned in a chair carved to look like gilded bamboo and stared at him over her golden winecup. Waves of glossy black hair touched with gray at the temples framed a beautiful face with the eyes of a bird of prey, and not one best pleased at the moment. Inconsequential things seemed to leap at him. She kicked her crossed leg slightly, rippling layered green and white petticoats. Pale green lace trimmed the oval opening in her gown that half exposed her full breasts, where the jeweled hilt of her marriage knife dangled. She was not alone. Suroth sat facing her, frowning into her winecup and tapping long fingernails on the arm of her chair, a pretty enough woman despite her hair being shaved to that long crest, except that she made Tylin seem a rabbit by comparison. Two of those fingernails on each hand were lacquered blue. Seated at her side was a little girl, of all things, also in an elaborately flowered robe over pleated white skirts, but with a sheer veil covering her entire head - it seemed to be shaved completely! - and wearing a fortune in rubies. Even in a state of shock, he noticed rubies and gold. A slender woman, nearly as dark as her stark black gown and tall even had she been Aiel, stood behind the girl's chair with her arms folded and ill-concealed impatience. Her wavy black hair was short, but not shaved at all, so she was neither of the Blood nor so'jhin. Imperiously beautiful, she put Tylin and Suroth both in the shade. He noticed beautiful women, too, even when he did feel hit in the head with a hammer.

ɪt wɑz nɑt ðə pɹɛzəns ə sjuɹɔθ əɹ ðə stʃɹeɪnʒɝz ðət dʒɝkt ɪm tə ə hɔlt, ðoʊ. ðə daɪs hæd stɑpt, lændɪŋ wɪð ə θʌndɝ ðət meɪɾ ɪz skʌl ɹɪŋ. ðət hæd nɛvɝ hæpən bɪfɔɹ. hi stʊd ðəɹ weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən tə lip aʊɾ ə ðə fleɪmz ɪn ðə mɑɹbəl faɪɝpleɪs, əɹ ði ɝθ tə swɑloʊ ðə pæləs bɪniθ hɪm.

It was not the presence of Suroth or the strangers that jerked him to a halt, though. The dice had stopped, landing with a thunder that made his skull ring. That had never happened before. He stood there waiting for one of the Forsaken to leap out of the flames in the marble fireplace, or the earth to swallow the Palace beneath him.

"ju ɑɹən lɪsnɪŋ tə mi, pɪdʒən," taɪlɪn koʊuɾ ɪn deɪnʒɝəs toʊnz. "aɪ sɛd, teɪk jɝsɛlf daʊn tə ðə kɪtʃənz ən əv ə peɪstʃɹi əntɪl aɪ hæv taɪm fəɹ ju. hæv ə bæθ waɪl jəɹ əbaʊɾ ɪt." hɝ dɑɹk aɪz ɡlɪɾɝd. "wi wɪl dɪskʌs jəɹ mʌd leɪɾɝ."

"You aren't listening to me, pigeon," Tylin cooed in dangerous tones. "I said, take yourself down to the kitchens and have a pastry until I have time for you. Have a bath while you're about it." Her dark eyes glittered. "We will discuss your mud later."

ɪn ə deɪz, hi ɹæn ɪt θɹu əɡɛn ɪn ɪz hɛd. hi hæd wɔkt ɪndə ðə ɹum, ðə daɪs hæd stɑpt, ən . . . nʌθɪŋ hæd hæpənd. nʌθɪŋ!

In a daze, he ran it through again in his head. He had walked into the room, the dice had stopped, and . . . Nothing had happened. Nothing!

"ðɪs mæn əz bɪn sɛɾ əpɑn," ðə taɪni, veɪl fɪɡjɝ sɛd, ɹaɪzɪŋ. hɝ toʊn tɝn koʊld əz ðə wɪn aʊtsaɪd. "ju toʊl mi ðə stʃɹits wɝ seɪf, sjuɹɔθ! aɪm dɪsplizd."

"This man has been set upon," the tiny, veiled figure said, rising. Her tone turned cold as the wind outside. "You told me the streets were safe, Suroth! I am displeased."

sʌmθɪŋ hæd tə hæpən! ɪɾ ɔlɹɛɾi ʃəd hæv! sʌmθɪŋ ɔlweɪz hæpənd wən ðə daɪs stɑpt.

Something had to happen! It already should have! Something always happened when the dice stopped.

"aɪ əʃʊɹ ju, tuɑn, ðə stʃɹits ʌv ɛbu dɑɹ ɑɹ əz seɪf əz ðə stʃɹits ə sindɑɹ ɪtsɛlf," sjuɹɔθ ɹɪplaɪd, ən ðət pʊl mæt aʊɾ ə hɪz stupɝ. ʃi saʊndəd . . . æŋkʃəs. sjuɹɔθ meɪɾ ʌðɝ pipəl æŋkʃəs.

"I assure you, Tuon, the streets of Ebou Dar are as safe as the streets of Seandar itself," Suroth replied, and that pulled Mat out of his stupor. She sounded . . . anxious. Suroth made other people anxious.

ə slɛndɝ, ɡɹeɪsfəl jʌŋ mæn ɪn ði ɔlmoʊs tʃɹænspɛɹən ɹoʊb ʌv ə dækoʊvæl əpɪɹɾ əɾ əɹ saɪd wɪð ə tɔl blu pɔɹsələn pɪtʃɝ, boʊɪŋ ɪz hɛɾ ən saɪlənli ɔfɝɪŋ tə ɹiplɛnɪʃ əɹ waɪn. ən ɡɪvɪŋ mæt ənʌðɝ stɑɹt. hi hæd nɑt ɹilaɪzd ɛniwʌn ɛls wɑz pɹɛzən ɪn ðə ɹum. ðə jɛloʊ-hɛɹd mæn ɪn ɪz ɪndisənt ɡɑɹmənt wɑz nɑt ði oʊnli wʌn, iðɝ. ə slɪm bʌt naɪsli ɹaʊndəd ɹɛd-hɛɹd wʊmən wɛɹɪŋ ðə seɪm ʃɪɹ ɹoʊb wɑz nilɪŋ bɪsaɪɾ ə teɪbəl ðət hɛl spaɪs bɑɾəlz ən mɔɹ faɪn si foʊk pɔɹsələn waɪn pɪtʃɝz ən ə smɔl ɡɪldɪd bɹæs bɹeɪziɝ wɪð ðə poʊkɝz niɾəd fəɹ hiɾɪŋ ðə waɪn, waɪl ə ɡɹeɪɪŋ nɝvəs-aɪd sɝvɪŋ wʊmən wɛɹɪŋ ɡɹin-ænd-waɪt haʊs mɪtsoʊbɑɹ lɪvɝi stʊɾ ət ði ʌðɝ ɛnd. ən ɪn wʌn kɔɹnɝ, soʊ moʊʃənləs ðəɾ i stɪl ɔlmoʊs mɪs hɝ, jɛɾ ənʌðɝ sintʃæn, ə ʃɔɹt wʊmən wɪð hæf əɹ ɡoʊldən hɛd ʃeɪvd ən ə bʊzəm ðət maɪɾ aʊtmætʃ ɹaɪzɛlz ɪf əɹ dʒɹɛs ə ɹɛd-ænd-jɛloʊ pænəlz hæd nɑt kʌvɝɾ əɹ nɛk tə ðə tʃɪn. nɑt ðəɾ i hæɾ ɛni ɹil dɪzaɪɝ tə faɪn aʊt. sintʃæn wɝ vɛɹi tʌtʃi əbaʊt ðɛɹ sɔɪhɪn. taɪlɪn wɑz tʌtʃi əbaʊɾ ɛni wʊmən. ðəɹ hæd nɑt bɪn ə sɝvɪŋ wʊmən jʌŋɡɝ ðən ɪz ɡɹændmʌðɝ ɪn əɹ əpɑɹtməns sɪns i wɑz eɪbəl tə ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ə bɛd.

A slender, graceful young man in the almost transparent robe of a da'covale appeared at her side with a tall blue porcelain pitcher, bowing his head and silently offering to replenish her wine. And giving Mat another start. He had not realized anyone else was present in the room. The yellow-haired man in his indecent garment was not the only one, either. A slim but nicely rounded red-haired woman wearing the same sheer robe was kneeling beside a table that held spice bottles and more fine Sea Folk porcelain wine pitchers and a small gilded brass brazier with the pokers needed for heating the wine, while a graying nervous-eyed serving woman wearing green-and-white House Mitsobar livery stood at the other end. And in one corner, so motionless that he still almost missed her, yet another Seanchan, a short woman with half her golden head shaved and a bosom that might outmatch Riselle's if her dress of red-and-yellow panels had not covered her neck to the chin. Not that he had any real desire to find out. Seanchan were very touchy about their so'jhin. Tylin was touchy about any woman. There had not been a serving woman younger than his grandmother in her apartments since he was able to get out of bed.

sjuɹɔθ lʊkt ət ðə ɡɹeɪsfəl mæn əz ðoʊ wʌndɝɪŋ wʌɾ i wɑz, ðən ʃʊk əɹ hɛd wɝdləsli ən tɝn əɹ ətɛnʃən bæk tə ðə tʃaɪld, tuɑn, hu weɪv ðə fɛloʊ əweɪ. ðə lɪvɹid sɝvɪŋ meɪd skɝid fɔɹwɝd tə teɪk ðə pɪtʃɝ fɹəm ɪm ən tʃɹaɪ tə ɹifɪl taɪlɪnz kʌp, bʌt ðə kwin meɪɾ ə vɛɹi smɔl dʒɛstʃɝ ðət sɛn əɹ bæk tə ðə wɔl. taɪlɪn wɑz sɪɾɪŋ vɛɹi, vɛɹi stɪl. lɪɾəl wʌndɝ ðət ʃi wɑntəd tə əvɔɪd noʊɾəs ɪf ðɪs tuɑn fɹaɪɾənd sjuɹɔθ, əz ʃi pleɪnli dɪd.

Suroth looked at the graceful man as though wondering what he was, then shook her head wordlessly and turned her attention back to the child, Tuon, who waved the fellow away. The liveried serving maid scurried forward to take the pitcher from him and try to refill Tylin's cup, but the Queen made a very small gesture that sent her back to the wall. Tylin was sitting very, very still. Little wonder that she wanted to avoid notice if this Tuon frightened Suroth, as she plainly did.

"aɪ æm dɪsplizd, sjuɹɔθ," ðə ɡɝl sɛɾ əɡɛn, stɝnli fɹaʊnɪŋ daʊn ət ði ʌðɝ wʊmən. ivən stændɪŋ, ʃi dɪd nɑɾ əv ɔl ðət fɑɹ daʊn tə stɛɹ ət ðə siɾəd haɪ leɪɾi. mæt səpoʊzd ʃi mʌs bi ə haɪ leɪɾi, tu, oʊnli haɪɝ ðən sjuɹɔθ. "ju hæv ɹəkʌvɝd mʌtʃ, ən ðət wɪl pliz ði ɛmpɹɛs, meɪ ʃi laɪv fɝɛvɝ, bʌt jəɹ ɪl-kənsɪɾɝd ətæk istwɝd wɑz ə dɪzæstɝ ðət mʌs nɑt bi ɹɪpiɾɪd. ən ɪf ðə stʃɹits ə ðɪs sɪɾi ɑɹ seɪf, haʊ kən i hæv bɪn sɛɾ əpɑn?"

"I am displeased, Suroth," the girl said again, sternly frowning down at the other woman. Even standing, she did not have all that far down to stare at the seated High Lady. Mat supposed she must be a High Lady, too, only Higher than Suroth. "You have recovered much, and that will please the Empress, may she live forever, but your ill-considered attack eastward was a disaster that must not be repeated. And if the streets of this city are safe, how can he have been set upon?"

sjuɹɔθs nʌkəlz wɝ waɪt fɹəm ɡɹɪpɪŋ ðə tʃɛɹ ɑɹm, ən əɹ waɪnkʌp. ʃi ɡlɛɹɾ ət taɪlɪn əz ðoʊ ðə lɛktʃɝ wɝ əɹ fɔlt, ən taɪlɪn ɡeɪv əɹ ən əpɑlədʒɛɾɪk smaɪl ən baʊɾ əɹ hɛd. oʊ, blʌɾ ən æʃəz, hi wɑz gɑnə peɪ fəɹ ðæt!

Suroth's knuckles were white from gripping the chair arm, and her winecup. She glared at Tylin as though the lecture were her fault, and Tylin gave her an apologetic smile and bowed her head. Oh, blood and ashes, he was going to pay for that!

"aɪ fɛl daʊn, ðæts ɔl." hɪz vɔɪs maɪɾ əz wɛl əv bɪn faɪɹwɝks fəɹ ðə weɪ hɛdz wɪpt ɝaʊnd. sjuɹɔθ ən tuɑn lʊkt ʃɑk ðəɾ i hæd spoʊkən. taɪlɪn lʊk laɪk ən iɡəl u wɑntəɾ əɹ ɹæbət fɹaɪd. "maɪ leɪɾiz," hi æɾəd, bʌt ðət dɪd nɑt sim tə ɪmpɹuv ɛniθɪŋ.

"I fell down, that's all." His voice might as well have been fireworks for the way heads whipped around. Suroth and Tuon looked shocked that he had spoken. Tylin looked like an eagle who wanted her rabbit fried. "My Ladies," he added, but that did not seem to improve anything.

ðə tɔl wʊmən sʌɾənli ɹitʃt aʊɾ ən snætʃt ðə waɪnkʌp fɹəm tuɑnz hænd, θɹoʊɪŋ ɪɾ ɪndə ðə faɪɝpleɪs. spɑɹks ʃaʊɝɾ ʌp ðə tʃɪmni. ðə sɝvɪŋ wʊmən stɝɾ əz ɪf tə ɹɪtʃɹiv ðə kʌp bɪfɔɹ ɪt kəd bi dæmədʒ fɝðɝ, ðən səbsaɪɾɪd əɾ ə tʌtʃ fɹəm ðə sɔɪhɪn.

The tall woman suddenly reached out and snatched the winecup from Tuon's hand, throwing it into the fireplace. Sparks showered up the chimney. The serving woman stirred as if to retrieve the cup before it could be damaged further, then subsided at a touch from the so'jhin.

"ju ɑɹ biɪŋ fulɪʃ, tuɑn," ðə tɔl wʊmən sɛd, ən əɹ vɔɪs meɪd ðə ɡɝlz stɝnnəs sim læftɝ. ðə tu-fəmɪljɝ sintʃæn dʒɹɔl simd ɔlmoʊst æbsən ɪntaɪɝli. "sjuɹɔθ əz ðə sɪtʃueɪʃən hɪɹ wɛl ɪn əɹ kəntʃɹoʊl. wʌt hæpən tə ði is kən hæpən ɪn ɛni bæɾəl. jə mʌst stɑp weɪstɪŋ taɪm ɑn ɹɪdɪkjələs tʃɹaɪfəlz."

"You are being foolish, Tuon," the tall woman said, and her voice made the girl's sternness seem laughter. The too-familiar Seanchan drawl seemed almost absent entirely. "Suroth has the situation here well in her control. What happened to the east can happen in any battle. You must stop wasting time on ridiculous trifles."

sjuɹɔθ ɡeɪpt əɾ əɹ ɪn əstɑnɪʃmən fəɹ ən ɪnstən bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəɾ əsum ə fɹoʊzən mæsk. mæt dɪɾ ə lɪɾəl ɡeɪpɪŋ ɑn ɪz oʊn pɑɹt. jus ðət toʊn ə vɔɪs tə wʌn ə ðə blʌd, ən jə wɝ lʌki tə ɪskeɪp wɪð ə tʃɹɪp tə ðə flɑɡɪŋ poʊst!

Suroth gaped at her in astonishment for an instant before she could assume a frozen mask. Mat did a little gaping on his own part. Use that tone of voice to one of the Blood, and you were lucky to escape with a trip to the flogging post!

ʃɑkɪŋli, tuɑn ɪnklaɪn əɹ hɛd slaɪtli. "ju meɪ bi ɹaɪt, ænæθ," ʃi sɛd kɑmli, ən ivən wɪð ə tʌtʃ ə dɛfɝəns. "taɪm ən ði oʊmənz wɪl tɛl. bʌt ðə jʌŋ mæn pleɪnli ɪz laɪɪŋ. pɝhæps i fɪɹz taɪlɪnz æŋɡɝ. bʌɾ ɪz ɪnʒɝiz klɪɹli ɑɹ mɔɹ ðən i kəd səsteɪn fɔlɪŋ daʊn ənlɛs ðəɹ ɑɹ klɪfs ɪn ðə sɪɾi aɪ hæv nɑt sin."

Shockingly, Tuon inclined her head slightly. "You may be right, Anath," she said calmly, and even with a touch of deference. "Time and the omens will tell. But the young man plainly is lying. Perhaps he fears Tylin's anger. But his injuries clearly are more than he could sustain falling down unless there are cliffs in the city I have not seen."

soʊ hi fɪɹd taɪlɪnz æŋɡɝ, dɪd hi? wɛl, kʌm tə ðæt, hi dɪd, ə lɪɾəl. oʊnli ə lɪɾəl, maɪnd. bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt laɪk biɪŋ ɹimaɪndəɾ ʌv ɪt. linɪŋ ɑn ɪz ʃoʊldɝ-haɪ stæf, hi tʃɹaɪd tə meɪk hɪmsɛlf kʌmftəɹbəl. ðeɪ kəɾ æsk ə mæn tə sɪt, æftɝ ɔl. "aɪ wɑz hɝt ðə deɪ jəɹ lædz tʊk ðə sɪɾi," hi sɛd wɪð ɪz tʃikiəst ɡɹɪn. "jɔɹ lɑt wɝ flɪŋɪŋ ɝaʊn laɪtnɪŋ ən bɔlz ə faɪɝ sʌmθɪŋ fɪɹs. aɪm dʒʌst əbaʊt hild, ðoʊ, θæŋk jə fəɹ æskɪŋ." taɪlɪn bɛɹiɾ əɹ feɪs ɪn əɹ waɪnkʌp, ən stɪl mænədʒ tə ʃuɾ ɪm ə lʊk oʊvɝ ðə ɹɪm ðət pɹɑməst ɹɛtʃɹəbjuʃən leɪɾɝ.

So he feared Tylin's anger, did he? Well, come to that, he did, a little. Only a little, mind. But he did not like being reminded of it. Leaning on his shoulder-high staff, he tried to make himself comfortable. They could ask a man to sit, after all. "I was hurt the day your lads took the city," he said with his cheekiest grin. "Your lot were flinging around lightning and balls of fire something fierce. I'm just about healed, though, thank you for asking." Tylin buried her face in her winecup, and still managed to shoot him a look over the rim that promised retribution later.

tuɑnz skɝts ɹʌsəld əz ʃi kɹɔs ðə kɑɹpəts tə hɪm. ðə dɑɹk feɪs bɪhaɪn ðət ʃɪɹ veɪl maɪɾ əv bɪn pɹɪɾi, wɪθaʊt ði ɪkspɹɛʃən ʌv ə dʒʌdʒ pæsɪŋ sɛntəns ə dɛθ. ən wɪð ə disən hɛɾ ə hɛɹ ɪnstɛɾ ʌv ə bɔl peɪt. hɝ aɪz wɝ lɑɹdʒ ən lɪkwəd, bʌɾ ʌɾɝli ɪmpɝsənəl. ɔl ə hɝ lɔŋ fɪŋɡɝneɪlz wɝ lækɝd, hi noʊɾəst, ə bɹaɪt ɹɛd. hi wʌndɝd wɛðɝ ðət sɪɡnəfaɪɾ ɛniθɪŋ. laɪt, ə mæn kəd lɪv ɪn lʌɡʒɝi fəɹ jɪɹz ɑn ðə pɹaɪs ə ðoʊz ɹubiz.

Tuon's skirts rustled as she crossed the carpets to him. The dark face behind that sheer veil might have been pretty, without the expression of a judge passing sentence of death. And with a decent head of hair instead of a bald pate. Her eyes were large and liquid, but utterly impersonal. All of her long fingernails were lacquered, he noticed, a bright red. He wondered whether that signified anything. Light, a man could live in luxury for years on the price of those rubies.

ʃi ɹitʃt ʌp wɪð wʌn hænd, pʊɾɪŋ əɹ fɪŋɡɝtɪps ʌndɝ ɪz tʃɪn, ən i stɑɹɾəd tə dʒɝk bæk. əntɪl taɪlɪn ɡlɛɹɾ əɾ ɪm oʊvɝ tuɑnz hɛd, pɹɑməsɪŋ ɹɛtʃɹəbjuʃən hɪɹ ən naʊ, ɪf i dɪɾ ɛni sətʃ θɪŋ. ɡlaʊɝɪŋ, hi lɛt ðə ɡɝl ʃɪft ɪz hɛd fəɹ əɹ stʌɾi.

She reached up with one hand, putting her fingertips under his chin, and he started to jerk back. Until Tylin glared at him over Tuon's head, promising retribution here and now, if he did any such thing. Glowering, he let the girl shift his head for her study.

"ju fɔɾ ʌs?" ʃi dɪmændəd. "ju hæv swɔɹn ði oʊðz?"

"You fought us?" she demanded. "You have sworn the oaths?"

"aɪ swɔɹ," hi mʌɾɝd. "fɔɹ ði ʌðɝ, aɪ hæd noʊ tʃæns."

"I swore," he muttered. "For the other, I had no chance."

"soʊ jə wəd hæv," ʃi mɝmɝd. sɝkəlɪŋ ɪm sloʊli, ʃi kəntɪnjuɾ əɹ stʌɾi, fɪŋɡɝɪŋ ðə leɪs əɾ ɪz ɹɪst, tʌtʃɪŋ ðə blæk sɪlk skɑɹf taɪɾ ɝaʊn ɪz nɛk, lɪftɪŋ ði ɛdʒ ə hɪz kloʊk tə ɪɡzæmɪn ði ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi. hi ɛndʒjʊɹɾ ɪt, ɹəfjuzɪŋ tə ʃɪft ɪz stæns, ɡlaʊɝɪŋ fɪt tə mætʃ taɪlɪn. laɪt, hi hæd bɑt hɔɹsəz wɪθaʊt soʊ θɝoʊ ən ɪɡzæməneɪʃən! nɛkst, ʃi wəd wɑnə lʊk əɾ ɪz tiθ!

"So you would have," she murmured. Circling him slowly, she continued her study, fingering the lace at his wrist, touching the black silk scarf tied around his neck, lifting the edge of his cloak to examine the embroidery. He endured it, refusing to shift his stance, glowering fit to match Tylin. Light, he had bought horses without so thorough an examination! Next, she would want to look at his teeth!

"ðə bɔɪ toʊl jə haʊ hi wɑz ɪnʒɝd," ænæθ sɛɾ ɪn fɹɔsti toʊnz ə kəmænd. "ɪf jə wɑn hɪm, ðən baɪ hɪm ən bi dʌn. ðə deɪ hæz bɪn lɔŋ, ən jə ʃəd bi ɪn jəɹ bɛd."

"The boy told you how he was injured," Anath said in frosty tones of command. "If you want him, then buy him and be done. The day has been long, and you should be in your bed."

tuɑn pɔzd, ɪɡzæmɪnɪŋ ðə lɔŋ sɪɡnɪt ɹɪŋ ɑn ɪz fɪŋɡɝ. ɪt hæd bɪn kɑɹvd əz ə tʃɹaɪ-pis, tə ʃoʊ ðə kɑɹvɝz skɪlz, ə ɹʌnɪŋ fɑks ən tu ɹeɪvənz ɪn flaɪt, ɔl sɝaʊndəd baɪ kɹɛsən munz, ən i hæd bɑɾ ɪt baɪ tʃæns, ðoʊ hi hæd kʌm tə laɪk ɪt. hi wʌndɝd wɛðɝ ʃi wɑntəɾ ɪt. stʃɹeɪɾənɪŋ, ʃi stɛɹɾ ʌp əɾ ɪz feɪs. "ɡʊɾ ædvaɪs, ænæθ," ʃi sɛd. "haʊ mʌtʃ fəɹ hɪm, taɪlɪn? ɪf hiz ə feɪvɹɪt, neɪm jəɹ pɹaɪs, ən əl dʌbəl ɪt."

Tuon paused, examining the long signet ring on his finger. It had been carved as a try-piece, to show the carver's skills, a running fox and two ravens in flight, all surrounded by crescent moons, and he had bought it by chance, though he had come to like it. He wondered whether she wanted it. Straightening, she stared up at his face. "Good advice, Anath," she said. "How much for him, Tylin? If he is a favorite, name your price, and I will double it."

taɪlɪn tʃoʊkt ɑn əɹ waɪn ən bɪɡæn kɑfɪŋ. mæt ɔlmoʊs fɛl ɔf ɪz stæf. ðə ɡɝl wɑntəd tə baɪ hɪm? wɛl, ʃi maɪɾ əz wɛl əv bɪn lʊkɪŋ əɾ ə hɔɹs fəɹ ɔl ði ɪkspɹɛʃən ɑn əɹ feɪs.

Tylin choked on her wine and began coughing. Mat almost fell off his staff. The girl wanted to buy him? Well, she might as well have been looking at a horse for all the expression on her face.

"hi ɪz ə fɹi mæn, haɪ leɪɾi," taɪlɪn sɛɾ ənstɛɾəli wən ʃi kəd spik. "aɪ . . . aɪ kænɑt sɛl hɪm." mæt kəɾ əv læft, ɪf taɪlɪn dɪd nɑt saʊn əz ðoʊ ʃi wɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kip əɹ tiθ fɹəm tʃæɾɝɪŋ, ɪf blʌɾi tuɑn hæd nɑt dʒʌst æskt ɪz pɹaɪs. ə fɹi mæn! hɑ!

"He is a free man, High Lady," Tylin said unsteadily when she could speak. "I . . . I cannot sell him." Mat could have laughed, if Tylin did not sound as though she were trying to keep her teeth from chattering, if bloody Tuon had not just asked his price. A free man! Ha!

ðə ɡɝl tɝn əweɪ fɹəm ɪm əz ðoʊ dɪsmɪsɪŋ ɪm fɹəm əɹ maɪnd. "ju ɑɹ əfɹeɪd, taɪlɪn, ən ʌndɝ ðə laɪt, jə ʃəd nɑt bi." ɡlaɪɾɪŋ tə taɪlɪnz tʃɛɹ, ʃi lɪftəɾ əɹ veɪl wɪð boʊθ hænz, bɛɹɪŋ ðə loʊɝ hæf ə hɝ feɪs, ən bɛn tə kɪs taɪlɪn laɪtli, wʌns ɑn itʃ aɪ ən wʌns ɑn ðə lɪps. taɪlɪn lʊkt əstaʊndɪd. "ju ɑɹ ə sɪstɝ tə mi, ən tə sjuɹɔθ," tuɑn sɛɾ ɪn ə sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli dʒɛntəl vɔɪs. "aɪ maɪsɛlf wɪl ɹaɪt jəɹ neɪm əz wʌn ə ðə blʌd. jəl bi ðə haɪ leɪɾi taɪlɪn əz wɛl əz kwin ʌv ɔltɑɹə, ən mɔɹ, əz wɑz pɹɑməs ju."

The girl turned away from him as though dismissing him from her mind. "You are afraid, Tylin, and under the Light, you should not be." Gliding to Tylin's chair, she lifted her veil with both hands, baring the lower half of her face, and bent to kiss Tylin lightly, once on each eye and once on the lips. Tylin looked astounded. "You are a sister to me, and to Suroth," Tuon said in a surprisingly gentle voice. "I myself will write your name as one of the Blood. You will be the High Lady Tylin as well as Queen of Altara, and more, as was promised you."

ænæθ snɔɹɾɪd, laʊdli.

Anath snorted, loudly.

"jɛs, ænæθ, aɪ noʊ," ðə ɡɝl saɪd, stʃɹeɪɾənɪŋ ən loʊɝɪŋ əɹ veɪl. "ðə deɪ hæz bɪn lɔŋ ən ɑɹdʒuəs, ən aɪm wɪɹi. bʌɾ əl ʃoʊ taɪlɪn wʌt lænz ɑɹ ɪn maɪn fəɹ hɝ, soʊ ʃɪl noʊ ən bi izi ɪn əɹ maɪnd. ðəɹ ɑɹ mæps ɪn maɪ tʃeɪmbɝz, taɪlɪn. jəl ɑnɝ mi baɪ əkʌmpəniɪŋ mi, ðɛɹ? aɪ hæv ɛksələn mæsaɪusɪz."

"Yes, Anath, I know," the girl sighed, straightening and lowering her veil. "The day has been long and arduous, and I am weary. But I will show Tylin what lands are in mind for her, so she will know and be easy in her mind. There are maps in my chambers, Tylin. You will honor me by accompanying me, there? I have excellent masseuses."

"ði ɑnɝ ɪz maɪn," taɪlɪn sɛd, saʊndɪŋ nɑɾ ɔl ðət mʌtʃ stɛɾiɝ ðən bɪfɔɹ.

"The honor is mine," Tylin said, sounding not all that much steadier than before.

əɾ ə dʒɛstʃɝ fɹəm ðə sɔɪhɪn, ðə jɛloʊ-hɛɹd mæn wɛn ɹʌnɪŋ tə oʊpən ðə dɔɹ ən nil hoʊldɪŋ ɪɾ oʊpən, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz stɪl ɔl ðə smuðɪŋ ən ədʒʌstɪŋ ə kloʊðz ðət wɪmən hæd tə də bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ wəd ɡoʊ ɛniwɛɹ, sintʃæn əɹ ɔltɑɹən əɹ fɹəm ɛniwɛɹ ɛls. ðoʊ, ðə ɹɛd-hɛɹd dækoʊvæl pɝfɔɹm ðə fʌŋkʃən fəɹ tuɑn ən sjuɹɔθ. mæt tʊk ði ɑpɝtunəɾi tə dʒɹɔ taɪlɪn ə lɪɾəl əsaɪd, fɑɹ ɪnʌf ðəɾ i wəd nɑt bi oʊvɝhɝd. ðə sɔɪhɪnz blu aɪz kɛp kʌmɪŋ bæk tə hɪm, hi ɹilaɪzd, bʌɾ ət lis tuɑn, æksɛptɪŋ ði ətɛnʃənz ə ðə slɛndɝ dækoʊvæl wʊmən, sim tə hæv fɝɡɑɾən i ɪɡzɪstəd.

At a gesture from the so'jhin, the yellow-haired man went running to open the door and kneel holding it open, but there was still all the smoothing and adjusting of clothes that women had to do before they would go anywhere, Seanchan or Altaran or from anywhere else. Though, the red-haired da'covale performed the function for Tuon and Suroth. Mat took the opportunity to draw Tylin a little aside, far enough that he would not be overheard. The so'jhin's blue eyes kept coming back to him, he realized, but at least Tuon, accepting the attentions of the slender da'covale woman, seemed to have forgotten he existed.

"aɪ dɪdn dʒʌs fɔl daʊn," hi toʊl taɪlɪn sɔfli. "ðə ɡoʊləm tʃɹaɪd tə kɪl mi nɑt mʌtʃ mɔɹ ðən ən aʊɝ əɡoʊ. ɪt maɪt bi bɛst ɪf aɪ lɛft. ðət θɪŋ wɑns mi, ən ɪɾəl kɪl ɛnibəɾi nɪɹ mi, tu." ðə plæn hæd dʒʌst əkɝd tə hɪm, bʌɾ i θɔɾ ɪt hæɾ ə ɡʊd tʃæns ə səksɛs.

"I didn't just fall down," he told Tylin softly. "The gholam tried to kill me not much more than an hour ago. It might be best if I left. That thing wants me, and it'll kill anybody near me, too." The plan had just occurred to him, but he thought it had a good chance of success.

taɪlɪn snɪft. "hi - ɪt - ɪt kænɑɾ əv ju, paɪɡlɛt." ʃi dɝɛktəɾ ə lʊk ət tuɑn ðət maɪɾ əv meɪd ðə ɡɝl fɝɡɛɾ əbaʊt taɪlɪn biɪŋ ə sɪstɝ hæd ʃi sin. "ænd niðɝ kən ʃi." ət list ʃi hæd sɛns ɪnʌf tə wɪspɝ.

Tylin sniffed. "He - it - it cannot have you, piglet." She directed a look at Tuon that might have made the girl forget about Tylin being a sister had she seen. "And neither can she." At least she had sense enough to whisper.

"hu ɪz ʃi?" hi æskt. wɛl, ɪt hæd nɛvɝ bɪn mɔɹ ðən ə tʃæns.

"Who is she?" he asked. Well, it had never been more than a chance.

"ðə haɪ leɪɾi tuɑn, ən jə noʊ əz mʌtʃ əz aɪ," taɪlɪn ɹɪplaɪd, dʒʌst əz kwaɪətli. "sjuɹɔθ dʒʌmps wən ʃi spiks, ən ʃi dʒʌmps wən ænæθ spiks, ðoʊ aɪ wəɾ ɔlmoʊst swɛɹ ðəɾ ænæθ ɪz səm sɔɹɾ ə sɝvənt. ðeɪ ɑɹ ə vɛɹi pəkjuljɝ pipəl, swiɾəlɪŋ." sʌɾənli ʃi fleɪk səm mʌd fɹəm ɪz tʃik wɪð wʌn fɪŋɡɝ. hi hæd nɔɹ ɹilaɪzd i hæd mʌɾ ɑn ɪz feɪs, tu. sʌɾənli, ði iɡəl wɑz stʃɹɔŋ ɪn əɹ aɪz. "du jə ɹikɔl ðə pɪŋk ɹɪbənz, swiɾəlɪŋ? wən aɪ kʌm bæk, wɪl si haʊ jə lʊk ɪn pɪŋk."

"The High Lady Tuon, and you know as much as I," Tylin replied, just as quietly. "Suroth jumps when she speaks, and she jumps when Anath speaks, though I would almost swear that Anath is some sort of servant. They are a very peculiar people, sweetling." Suddenly she flaked some mud from his cheek with one finger. He had nor realized he had mud on his face, too. Suddenly, the eagle was strong in her eyes. "Do you recall the pink ribbons, sweetling? When I come back, we'll see how you look in pink."

ʃi swɑn aʊɾ ə ðə ɹum wɪð tuɑn ən sjuɹɔθ, tʃɹeɪl baɪ ænæθ ən ðə sɔɪhɪn ən ðə dækoʊvæl, livɪŋ mæt wɪð ðə ɡɹændmʌðɝli sɝvɪŋ wʊmən u bɪɡæn tə klin ʌp ðə waɪn teɪbəl. hi sæŋk ɪndə wʌn ə ðə bæmbu kɑɹv tʃɛɹz ən ɹɛstəɾ ɪz hɛɾ ɪn ɪz hænz.

She swanned out of the room with Tuon and Suroth, trailed by Anath and the so'jhin and the da'covale, leaving Mat with the grandmotherly serving woman who began to clean up the wine table. He sank into one of the bamboo carved chairs and rested his head in his hands.

ɛni ʌðɝ taɪm, ðoʊz pɪŋk ɹɪbənz wʊɾə hæɾ ɪm ɡɪbɝɪŋ. hi nɛvɝ ʃʊɾə tʃɹaɪd tə ɡɛɾ ɪz oʊn bæk wɪð hɝ. ivən ðə ɡoʊləm dɪd nɑɾ ɑkjəpaɪ mʌtʃ ə hɪz θɔts. ðə daɪs hæd stɑpt ən . . . wʌt? hi hæd kʌm feɪs-tə-feɪs, əɹ nɪɹ ɪnʌf, wɪð θɹi pipəl i hæd nɑt mɛt bɪfɔɹ, bʌt ðət kəd nɑt bi ɪt. meɪbi ɪt wɑz sʌmθɪŋ tə də wɪð taɪlɪn bɪkʌmɪŋ wʌn ə ðə blʌd. bʌɾ ɔlweɪz bɪfɔɹ, wən ðə daɪs stɑpt, sʌmθɪŋ hæd hæpən tə hɪm, pɝsənəli.

Any other time, those pink ribbons would have had him gibbering. He never should have tried to get his own back with her. Even the gholam did not occupy much of his thoughts. The dice had stopped and . . . What? He had come face-to-face, or near enough, with three people he had not met before, but that could not be it. Maybe it was something to do with Tylin becoming one of the Blood. But always before, when the dice stopped, something had happened to him, personally.

hi sæt ðəɹ wɝiɪŋ oʊvɝ ɪt waɪl ðə sɝvɪŋ wʊmən kɔld ɪn ʌðɝz tə kæɹi ɛvɹiθɪŋ əweɪ, sæt ðəɹ əntɪl taɪlɪn ɹɪtɝnd. ʃi hæd nɑt fɝɡɑɾən əbaʊt ðə pɪŋk ɹɪbənz, ən ðət meɪɾ ɪm fɝɡɛɾ əbaʊɾ ɛniθɪŋ ɛls fəɹ kwaɪɾ ə lɔŋ taɪm.

He sat there worrying over it while the serving woman called in others to carry everything away, sat there until Tylin returned. She had not forgotten about the pink ribbons, and that made him forget about anything else for quite a long time.


tʃæptɝ eɪtin


CHAPTER 18

ən ɔfɝ


An Offer

ðə deɪz æftɝ ðə ɡoʊləm tʃɹaɪd tə kɪl ɪm sɛɾəld ɪndə ɹɪðəmz ðəɾ ɪɹəteɪɾəd mæt noʊ ɛnd. ðə ɡɹeɪ skaɪ nɛvɝ ɔltɝd, ɪksɛp tə ɡɪv ɹeɪn əɹ nɑt.

The days after the gholam tried to kill him settled into rhythms that irritated Mat no end. The gray sky never altered, except to give rain or not.

ðəɹ wɑz tɔk ɪn ðə stʃɹits ʌv ə mæn biɪŋ kɪl baɪ ə wʊlf nɑt fɑɹ aʊtsaɪd ðə sɪɾi, hɪz θɹoʊt ɹɪpt. noʊ wʌn wɑz wɝid, dʒʌs kjʊɹiəs; wʊlvz hæd nɑt bɪn sin kloʊs tə ɛbu dɑɹ ɪn jɪɹz. mæt wɝid. sɪɾi pipəl maɪt bɪliv ə wʊlf wəd kʌm ðət kloʊs tə sɪɾi wɔlz, bʌɾ i nu bɛɾɝ. ðə ɡoʊləm hæd nɑt ɡɔn əweɪ. hɑɹnən ən ði ʌðɝ ɹɛdʒɹmz stʌbɝnli ɹəfjuz tə liv, kleɪmɪŋ ðeɪ kəd wɑtʃ ɪz bæk, ən veɪnɪn ɹəfjuzd wɪθaʊt ɹizənz, ənlɛs ə mʌɾɝd kɑmɛn ðət mæt hæɾ ə ɡʊɾ aɪ fəɹ fæs hɔɹsəz wɑz səpoʊz tə bi wʌn. hi spæɾ æftɝ i sɛɾ ɪt, ðoʊ. ɹaɪzɛl, hɝ ɑləv feɪs pɹɪɾi ɪnʌf tə meɪk ə mæn swɑloʊ, hɝ bɪɡ dɑɹk aɪz noʊɪŋ ɪnʌf tə dʒɹaɪ hɪz tʌŋ, ɪnkwaɪɝɾ əbaʊɾ oʊlvɝz eɪdʒ, ən wən i sɛd kloʊs ɑn tɛn, ʃi lʊk sɝpɹaɪzd ən tæpt əɹ fʊl lɪps θɔtfəli, bʌɾ ɪf ʃi tʃeɪnʒd ɛniθɪŋ ɪn ðə bɔɪz lɛsənz, hi stɪl keɪm əweɪ fɹəm əm bʌbəlɪŋ ikwəli oʊvɝ əɹ bʊzəm ən ðə bʊks ʃi ɹɛd hɪm. mæt θɔɾ oʊlvɝ wəɾ ɔlmoʊst əv ɡɪvən ʌp ɪz naɪtli ɡeɪmz ə sneɪks ən fɑksəz fəɹ ɹaɪzɛl ən ðə bʊks. ən wən ðə læd ɹæn aʊɾ ə ðə ɹumz ðət wʌns hæd bɪn mæts, tɑm ɔfən slɪpt ɪn wɪð ɪz hɑɹp ʌndɝ ɪz ɑɹm. baɪ ɪtsɛlf ðət wɑz ɪnʌf tə meɪk mæt ɡɹaɪn ɪz tiθ, oʊnli ðət wɑz nɑt ðə hæf.

There was talk in the streets of a man being killed by a wolf not far outside the city, his throat ripped. No one was worried, just curious; wolves had not been seen close to Ebou Dar in years. Mat worried. City people might believe a wolf would come that close to city walls, but he knew better. The gholam had not gone away. Harnan and the other Redarms stubbornly refused to leave, claiming they could watch his back, and Vanin refused without reasons, unless a muttered comment that Mat had a good eye for fast horses was supposed to be one. He spat after he said it, though. Riselle, her olive face pretty enough to make a man swallow, her big dark eyes knowing enough to dry his tongue, inquired about Olver's age, and when he said close on ten, she looked surprised and tapped her full lips thoughtfully, but if she changed anything in the boy's lessons, he still came away from them bubbling equally over her bosom and the books she read him. Mat thought Olver would almost have given up his nightly games of Snakes and Foxes for Riselle and the books. And when the lad ran out of the rooms that once had been Mat's, Thom often slipped in with his harp under his arm. By itself that was enough to make Mat grind his teeth, only that was not the half.

tɑm ən bɛslən fɹikwənli wɛn aʊt təɡɛðɝ, nɑɾ ɪnvaɪɾɪŋ hɪm, ən wɝ ɡɔn fəɹ hæf ðə deɪ, əɹ hæf ðə naɪt. niðɝ wəd seɪ ə wɝd mɔɹ əbaʊt ðɛɹ skimz, ðoʊ tɑm hæd ðə ɡɹeɪs tə lʊk ɪmbɛɹəst. mæt hoʊp ðeɪ wɝ nɑt gɑnə ɡɛt pipəl kɪl fəɹ nʌθɪŋ, bʌt ðeɪ ʃoʊd lɪɾəl ɪntʃɹəst ɪn ɪz əpɪnjənz. bɛslən ɡlɛɹɾ ət ðə vɛɹi saɪɾ ə hɪm. dʒulɪn kəntɪnjud tə slɪp əbʌvstɛɹz ən wɑz sin baɪ sjuɹɔθ, wɪtʃ ɝn ɪm ə stʃɹæpɪŋ hʌŋ ʌp baɪ hɪz ɹɪsts fɹəm ə stɔlpoʊst ɪn ðə steɪbəlz. mæt sɔ hɪz wɛls tɛndəd baɪ veɪnɪn - ðə mæn kleɪm dɑktɝɪŋ mɛn wɑz ðə seɪm əz dɑktɝɪŋ hɔɹsəz - ən wɔɹn ɪm ɪt kəd bi wɝs nɛks taɪm, bʌt ðə ful wɑz bæk ɑn ði ʌpɝ flɔɹz ðət vɛɹi naɪt, stɪl wɪnsɪŋ fɹəm ðə weɪɾ ə hɪz ʃɝɾ ɑn ɪz bæk. ɪt hæd tə bi ə wʊmən, ðoʊ ðə θif-kætʃɝ ɹəfjuz tə seɪ. mæt səspɛktəd wʌn ə ðə sintʃæn noʊbəlwɪmən. wʌn ə ðə pæləs sɝvəns cʊɾə mɛɾ ɪm ɪn ɪz oʊn ɹum, wɪð tɑm aʊɾ ʌv ɪt soʊ mʌtʃ.

Thom and Beslan frequently went out together, not inviting him, and were gone for half the day, or half the night. Neither would say a word more about their schemes, though Thom had the grace to look embarrassed. Mat hoped they were not going to get people killed for nothing, but they showed little interest in his opinions. Beslan glared at the very sight of him. Juilin continued to slip abovestairs and was seen by Suroth, which earned him a strapping hung up by his wrists from a stallpost in the stables. Mat saw his welts tended by Vanin - the man claimed doctoring men was the same as doctoring horses - and warned him it could be worse next time, but the fool was back on the upper floors that very night, still wincing from the weight of his shirt on his back. It had to be a woman, though the thief-catcher refused to say. Mat suspected one of the Seanchan noblewomen. One of the Palace servants could have met him in his own room, with Thom out of it so much.

nɑt sjuɹɔθ əɹ tuɑn, tə bi ʃʊɹ, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ nɑt ði oʊnli sintʃæn haɪ blʌɾ ɪn ðə pæləs. moʊst ə ðə sintʃæn noʊbəlz ɹɛntəd ɹumz, əɹ mɔɹ ɔfən hoʊl haʊsəz, ɪn ðə sɪɾi, bʌt sɛvɹəl hæd kʌm wɪð sjuɹɔθ ən ə hændfʊl wɪð ðə ɡɝl, tu. mɔɹ ðən wʌn ə ðə wɪmən lʊkt ə plɛzən ɑɹmfəl ɪn spaɪɾ ə ðɛɹ kɹɛstəd hɛdz ən ðɛɹ weɪ ʌv stɛɹɪŋ daʊn ðɛɹ noʊzɪz əɾ ɛvɹibɑɾi wɪθaʊt ʃeɪv tɛmpəlz. ɪf ðeɪ noʊɾəst əm mɔɹ ðən ðeɪ dɪd ðə fɝnɪtʃɝ, ðət wɑz. ɪf ɪt simd ənlaɪkli ðət wʌn ə ðoʊz hɔɾi wɪmən wəd lʊk twaɪs əɾ ə mæn u slɛpt ɪn ðə sɝvəns kɔɹɾɝz, wɛl, ðə laɪt nu wɪmən hæd pəkjuljɝ teɪsts ɪn mɛn. hi hæd noʊ tʃɔɪs bʌt tə liv dʒulɪn əloʊn. huɛvɝ ðə wʊmən wɑz, ʃi maɪt ɡɛt ðə θif-kætʃɝ bɪhɛɾɪd jɛt, bʌt ðət sɔɹɾ ə fivɝ hæd tə bɝn ɪtsɛlf aʊt bɪfɔɹ ə mæn kəd θɪŋk stʃɹeɪt. wɪmən dɪd stʃɹeɪnʒ θɪŋz tə ə mænz hɛd.

Not Suroth or Tuon, to be sure, but they were not the only Seanchan High Blood in the Palace. Most of the Seanchan nobles rented rooms, or more often whole houses, in the city, but several had come with Suroth and a handful with the girl, too. More than one of the women looked a pleasant armful in spite of their crested heads and their way of staring down their noses at everybody without shaved temples. If they noticed them more than they did the furniture, that was. If it seemed unlikely that one of those haughty women would look twice at a man who slept in the servant's quarters, well, the Light knew women had peculiar tastes in men. He had no choice but to leave Juilin alone. Whoever the woman was, she might get the thief-catcher beheaded yet, but that sort of fever had to burn itself out before a man could think straight. Women did strange things to a man's head.

ðə nuli ɝaɪvd ʃɪps dɪsɡɔɹdʒ pipəl ən ænəməlz ən kɑɹɡoʊ fəɹ deɪz ɑn ɛnd, ɪnʌf ðət ðə sɪɾiz mæsɪv wɔlz wʊɾə bɝs fɹəm ði ɪnsaɪd hæd ðeɪ ɔl steɪd, bʌt ðeɪ floʊd θɹu ðə sɪɾi ən aʊɾ ɪndə ðə kʌntʃɹisaɪd wɪð ðɛɹ fæmliz ən ðɛɹ kɹæfs ən ðɛɹ laɪvstɑk, pɹipɛɹd tə pʊt daʊn ɹuts. soʊlʒɝz pæs θɹu ɪn θaʊzənz, tu, wɛl-ɔɹɾɝd ɪnfəntʃɹi ən kævəlɹi wɪð ðə flɛɹ ə vɛɾɝənz, muvɪŋ nɔɹθ ɪn bɹaɪt-kʌlɝɾ ɑɹmɝ, ən ist əkɹɔs ðə ɹɪvɝ. mæt ɡeɪv ʌp tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kaʊn ðɛm. səmtaɪmz i sɔ stʃɹeɪnʒ kɹitʃɝz, ðoʊ moʊst ə ðoʊz wɝ ənloʊɾəd əbʌv ðə sɪɾi tə əvɔɪd ðə stʃɹits. tɔɹm laɪk θɹi-aɪd bɹɑnz-skeɪl kæts ðə saɪz ə hɔɹsəz, sɛndɪŋ moʊst ɹil hɔɹsəz ɝaʊn əm ɪndə ə fɹɛnzi dʒʌs baɪ ðɛɹ pɹɛzəns, ən kɔɹlm, laɪk hɛɹi wɪŋɡləs bɝdz əz tɔl əz ə mæn, tɔl ɪɹz twɪtʃɪŋ kɑnstənli ən lɔŋ biks simɪŋ tə jɝn fəɹ flɛʃ tə ɹɛnd, ən hjudʒ sɹɛɾɪt wɪð ðɛɹ lɔŋ noʊzɪz ən lɔŋɡɝ tʌsks. ɹeɪkən ən ðə lɑɹdʒɝ tɔɹeɪkən flu fɹəm ðɛɹ lændɪŋ saɪt bɪloʊ ðə ɹæhəd, hjudʒ lɪzɝdz spɹɛɾɪŋ wɪŋz laɪk bæts ən kæɹiɪŋ mɛn ɑn ðɛɹ bæks. ðə neɪmz wɝ izi ɪnʌf tə pɪk ʌp; ɛni sintʃæn soʊlʒɝ wɑz iɡɝ tə dɪskʌs ðə nəsɛsəɾi ʌv skaʊts ɑn ɹeɪkən ən ði əbɪləɾiz ə kɔɹlm ət tʃɹækɪŋ, wɛðɝ sɹɛɾɪt wɝ jusfəl fəɹ mɔɹ ðən muvɪŋ hɛvi loʊdz ən tɔɹm tu ɪntɛlədʒən tə tʃɹʌst. hi lɝn ə ɡɹeɪt dil ʌv ɪntʃɹəs fɹəm mɛn u wɑntəd wʌt moʊst soʊlʒɝz dɪd, ə dʒɹɪŋk ən ə wʊmən ən ə bɪɾ ʌv ə ɡæmbəl, nɑt nɛsəsɛɹəli ɪn ɛni ɡɪvən ɔɹɾɝ. ðoʊz soʊlʒɝz wɝ ɪndid vɛɾɝənz. sintʃæn wɑz ən ɛmpaɪɝ lɑɹdʒɝ ðən ɔl ðə neɪʃənz bɪtwin ði ɛɹɪθ oʊʃən ən ðə spaɪn ə ðə wɝld, ɔl ʌndɝ wʌn ɛmpɹɛs, bʌt wɪð ə hɪstɝi ʌv ɔlmoʊs kɑnstən ɹɪbɛljənz ən ɹivoʊls ðət kɛpt ɪts soʊlʒɝz' skɪlz kin. ðə fɑɹmɝz wəd bi hɑɹɾɝ tə dɪɡ aʊt.

The newly arrived ships disgorged people and animals and cargo for days on end, enough that the city's massive walls would have burst from the inside had they all stayed, but they flowed through the city and out into the countryside with their families and their crafts and their livestock, prepared to put down roots. Soldiers passed through in thousands, too, well-ordered infantry and cavalry with the flair of veterans, moving north in bright-colored armor, and east across the river. Mat gave up trying to count them. Sometimes he saw strange creatures, though most of those were unloaded above the city to avoid the streets. Torm like three-eyed bronze-scaled cats the size of horses, sending most real horses around them into a frenzy just by their presence, and corlm, like hairy wingless birds as tall as a man, tall ears twitching constantly and long beaks seeming to yearn for flesh to rend, and huge s'redit with their long noses and longer tusks. Raken and the larger to'raken flew from their landing site below the Rahad, huge lizards spreading wings like bats and carrying men on their backs. The names were easy enough to pick up; any Seanchan soldier was eager to discuss the necessity of scouts on raken and the abilities of corlm at tracking, whether s'redit were useful for more than moving heavy loads and torm too intelligent to trust. He learned a great deal of interest from men who wanted what most soldiers did, a drink and a woman and a bit of a gamble, not necessarily in any given order. Those soldiers were indeed veterans. Seanchan was an Empire larger than all the nations between the Aryth Ocean and the Spine of the World, all under one Empress, but with a history of almost constant rebellions and revolts that kept its soldiers' skills keen. The farmers would be harder to dig out.

nɑɾ ɔl ðə soʊlʒɝz lɛft, ʌv kɔɹs. ə stʃɹɔŋ ɡɛɹɪsən ɹɪmeɪnd, nɑɾ oʊnli sintʃæn, bʌt stil-veɪl tæɹɑbənɝ lænsɝz ən ɑmɑdɪʃən pɪkmɛn wɪð ðɛɹ bɹɛstpleɪts peɪntəd tə ɹɪzɛmbəl sintʃæn ɑɹmɝ. ən ɔltɑɹənz, tu, bɪsaɪdz taɪlɪnz haʊs ɑɹmmɪn. əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə ðə sintʃæn, ði ɔltɑɹənz fɹəm ɪnlænd, wɪð ɹɛd slæʃɪz kɹɪskɹɔsɪŋ ðɛɹ bɹɛstpleɪts, wɝ taɪlɪnz əz mʌtʃ əz ðə fɛloʊz ɡɑɹɾɪŋ ðə tɑɹɑsɪn pæləs, wɪtʃ, stʃɹeɪnʒli, dɪd nɑt sim tə bɛs pliz hɝ. ɪt dɪd nɑt pliz ðə fɛloʊz fɹəm ɪnlæn vɛɹi mʌtʃ, iðɝ. ðeɪ ən ðə mɛn ɪn mɪtsoʊbɑɹz ɡɹin-ænd-waɪɾ aɪɾ itʃ ʌðɝ laɪk stʃɹeɪnʒ tɑmkæts ɪn ə smɔl ɹum. ðəɹ wɑz plɛnti ʌv ɡlɛɹɪŋ ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn, tæɹɑbənɝz əɾ ɑmɑdɪʃənz, ɑmɑdɪʃənz əɾ ɔltɑɹənz, ən ði ʌðɝ weɪ ɹaʊnd, wɛl-eɪdʒd, lɔŋ-stændɪŋ ænəmɑsəɾiz bʌbəlɪŋ tə ðə sɝfəs, bʌt noʊ wʌn wɛn fɝðɝ ðən ʃeɪkən fɪsts ən ə fju kɝsɪz. faɪv hʌnʒɹəd mɛn ə ðə dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹdz hæd kʌm ɔf ðə ʃɪps ən ɹɪmeɪn ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ fəɹ səm ɹizən. ði ɔɹɾənɛɹi sɔɹɾ ə kɹaɪm ɪkspɛktəɾ ɪn ɛni lɑɹdʒ sɪɾi hæd fɔlən ɔf dʒɹəmæɾɪkli ʌndɝ ðə sintʃæn, bʌt ðə ɡɑɹdz tʊk tə pətʃɹoʊlɪŋ ðə stʃɹits əz ɪf ðeɪ ɪkspɛktəd kʌtpɝsɪz, bʊlɪbɔɪz ən meɪbi fʊli ɑɹm bænz ə bɹɪɡænz tə spɹɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə peɪvmənt. ði ɔltɑɹənz ən ði ɑmɑdɪʃənz ən ðə tæɹɑbənɝz kɛp ðɛɹ tɛmpɝz ɹeɪn ɪn. noʊ wʌn bʌɾ ə ful ɑɹɡjud wɪð ðə dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹdz, nɑt mɔɹ ðən wʌns. ən ənʌðɝ kəntɪnʒənt ə ðə ɡɑɹdz hæd teɪkən ʌp ɹɛzəɾəns ɪn ðə sɪɾi, tu, ə hʌnʒɹəd oʊɡiɝ, ʌv ɔl θɪŋz, ɪn ðə ɹɛd-ænd-blæk. səmtaɪmz ðeɪ pətʃɹoʊld wɪð ði ʌðɝz, ən səmtaɪmz ðeɪ wɑndɝɾ əbaʊt wɪð ðɛɹ lɔŋ-hændəld æksiz ɑn ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz. ðeɪ wɝ nɑɾ əɾ ɔl laɪk mæts fɹɛn lɔɪəl. oʊ, ðeɪ hæd ðə seɪm waɪd noʊzɪz ən tʌftəɾ ɪɹz ən lɔŋ aɪbɹaʊz ðət dʒɹup tə ðɛɹ tʃiks bɪsaɪɾ aɪz ðə saɪz ə tikəps, bʌt ðə ɡɑɹɾənɝz lʊkt əɾ ə mæn əz ðoʊ wʌndɝɪŋ wɛðɝ i niɾəd pɹunɪŋ ʌv ə fju lɪmz. noʊbɑdi əɾ ɔl wɑz ful ɪnʌf tə ɑɹɡju ivən wʌns wɪð ðə ɡɑɹɾənɝz.

Not all the soldiers left, of course. A strong garrison remained, not only Seanchan, but steel-veiled Taraboner lancers and Amadician pikemen with their breastplates painted to resemble Seanchan armor. And Altarans, too, besides Tylin's House armsmen. According to the Seanchan, the Altarans from inland, with red slashes crisscrossing their breastplates, were Tylin's as much as the fellows guarding the Tarasin Palace, which, strangely, did not seem to best please her. It did not please the fellows from inland very much, either. They and the men in Mitsobar's green-and-white eyed each other like strange tomcats in a small room. There was plenty of glaring going on, Taraboners at Amadicians, Amadicians at Altarans, and the other way round, well-aged, long-standing animosities bubbling to the surface, but no one went further than shaken fists and a few curses. Five hundred men of the Deathwatch Guards had come off the ships and remained in Ebou Dar for some reason. The ordinary sort of crime expected in any large city had fallen off dramatically under the Seanchan, but the Guards took to patrolling the streets as if they expected cutpurses, bullyboys and maybe fully armed bands of brigands to spring out of the pavement. The Altarans and the Amadicians and the Taraboners kept their tempers reined in. No one but a fool argued with the Deathwatch Guards, not more than once. And another contingent of the Guards had taken up residence in the city, too, a hundred Ogier, of all things, in the red-and-black. Sometimes they patrolled with the others, and sometimes they wandered about with their long-handled axes on their shoulders. They were not at all like Mat's friend Loial. Oh, they had the same wide noses and tufted ears and long eyebrows that drooped to their cheeks beside eyes the size of teacups, but the Gardeners looked at a man as though wondering whether he needed pruning of a few limbs. Nobody at all was fool enough to argue even once with the Gardeners.

sintʃæn floʊɾ aʊt fɹəm ɛbu dɑɹ, ən nuz floʊɾ ɪn. ivən wən ðeɪ hæd tə slip ɪn ði æɾɪk, mɝtʃəns pɹin ɪn ðə kɑmən ɹumz ʌv ɪnz, smoʊkɪŋ ðɛɹ paɪps ən tɛlɪŋ wʌt ðeɪ nu ðət noʊ wʌn ɛls dɪd. soʊ lɔŋ əz ðə tɛlɪŋ dɪd nɑɾ əfɛk ðɛɹ pɹɑfəts. ðə mɝtʃəns' ɡɑɹdz kɛɹd lɪɾəl fəɹ pɹɑfəts ðeɪ wəd nɑt ʃɛɹ ən toʊld ɛvɹiθɪŋ, səm ʌv ɪt tʃɹu. simən spɹɛd teɪlz fəɹ ɛniwʌn u wəd baɪ ə mʌɡ ʌv eɪl, əɹ bɛɾɝ, hɑt spaɪst waɪn, ən wən ðeɪ hæd dʒɹʌŋk ɪnʌf, ðeɪ tɔkt ivən mɔɹ, ʌv pɔɹts ðeɪ hæd vɪzəɾəd, ən ɪvɛns ðeɪ hæd wɪtnəst, ən laɪkli dʒɹimz ðeɪ hæd hæɾ æftɝ ðə læs taɪm ðɛɹ hɛdz wɝ fʊl ə fjumz. stɪl, ɪt wɑz klɪɹ ðə wɝld aʊtsaɪɾ ɛbu dɑɹ wɑz siθɪŋ laɪk ðə si ʌv stɔɹmz. teɪlz ʌv il luɾɪŋ ən bɝnɪŋ keɪm fɹəm ɛvɹiwɛɹ, ən ɑɹmiz wɝ ɑn ðə muv ʌðɝ ðən ðə sintʃæn, ɑɹmiz ɪn tiɹ ən mʊɹændi, ɪn ɑɹæd dumən ən ændɝ, ɪn ɑmɑdɪʃiə, wɪtʃ wɑz nɑt jɛɾ ɪntaɪɝli ʌndɝ sintʃæn kəntʃɹoʊl, ən dʌzənz ʌv ɑɹmd ɡæðɝɪŋz tu smɔl tə bi kɔld ɑɹmiz ɪn ðə hɑɹtlæn ʌv ɔltɑɹə ɪtsɛlf. ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə mɛn ɪn ɔltɑɹə ən ɑmɑdɪʃiə, noʊ wʌn ɹɪli simd ʃʊɹ u ɪntɛndəd tə faɪt hum, ən ðəɹ wɑz səm daʊɾ əbaʊɾ ɔltɑɹə. ɔltɑɹənz hæɾ ə weɪ ʌv teɪkɪŋ ædvæntɪdʒ ə tʃɹʌbəlz tə tʃɹaɪ peɪɪŋ ɔf ɡɹivənsəz əɡɛns ðɛɹ neɪbɝz.

Seanchan flowed out from Ebou Dar, and news flowed in. Even when they had to sleep in the attic, merchants preened in the common rooms of inns, smoking their pipes and telling what they knew that no one else did. So long as the telling did not affect their profits. The merchants' guards cared little for profits they would not share and told everything, some of it true. Seamen spread tales for anyone who would buy a mug of ale, or better, hot spiced wine, and when they had drunk enough, they talked even more, of ports they had visited, and events they had witnessed, and likely dreams they had had after the last time their heads were full of fumes. Still, it was clear the world outside Ebou Dar was seething like the Sea of Storms. Tales of Aiel looting and burning came from everywhere, and armies were on the move other than the Seanchan, armies in Tear and Murandy, in Arad Doman and Andor, in Amadicia, which was not yet entirely under Seanchan control, and dozens of armed gatherings too small to be called armies in the heartland of Altara itself. Except for the men in Altara and Amadicia, no one really seemed sure who intended to fight whom, and there was some doubt about Altara. Altarans had a way of taking advantage of troubles to try paying off grievances against their neighbors.

ðə nuz ðət ʃʊk ðə sɪɾi moʊst, ðoʊ, wɑz ə ɹænd. mæt tʃɹaɪɾ ɪz bɛs nɑt tə θɪŋk ə hɪm, əɹ pɛɹɪn, bʌɾ əvɔɪɾɪŋ ðoʊz ɑd swɝlz ə kʌlɝ ɪn ɪz hɛd wɑz dɪfəkəlt wən ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn wɑz ɑn ɛvɹiwʌnz lɪps. ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn wɑz dɛd, səm kleɪmd, mɝɾɝd baɪ ɛɛs sədaɪ, baɪ ðə hoʊl waɪt taʊɝ dɪsɛndɪŋ ɑn ɪm ət wʌns ɪn kɛɹhin, əɹ meɪbi ɪt wɑz ɪn ɪljən, əɹ tɛɹ. noʊ, ðeɪ hæd kɪdnæp hɪm, ən i wɑz hɛl pɹɪznɝ ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ. noʊ, hi hæd ɡɔn tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ ɑn ɪz oʊn ən swɔɹn fiəlti tə ði æmɪɝlɪn sit. ðə læst ɡeɪnd ɡɹeɪt kɹiɾəns kəz ə nʌmbɝ ə mɛn kleɪm tə hæv sin ə pɹɑkləmeɪʃən, saɪn baɪ ɪleɪɾə hɝsɛlf, ðəɾ ənaʊnst əz mʌtʃ. mæt hæɾ ɪz daʊts, əbaʊt ɹænd biɪŋ dɛɾ əɹ swɛɹɪŋ fiəlti, ət list. fəɹ səm ɑd ɹizən, hi fɛlt ʃʊɹ i wəd noʊ ɪf ɹænd daɪd, ən əz fəɹ ði ʌðɝ, hi dɪd nɑt bɪliv ðə mæn wəd pʊt hɪmsɛlf wɪðɪn ə hʌnʒɹəd maɪlz ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ vɑləntɛɹəli. dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn əɹ noʊ dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, hi hæd tə hæv mɔɹ sɛns ðən ðæt.

The news that shook the city most, though, was of Rand. Mat tried his best not to think of him, or Perrin, but avoiding those odd swirls of color in his head was difficult when the Dragon Reborn was on everyone's lips. The Dragon Reborn was dead, some claimed, murdered by Aes Sedai, by the whole White Tower descending on him at once in Cairhien, or maybe it was in Illian, or Tear. No, they had kidnapped him, and he was held prisoner in the White Tower. No, he had gone to the White Tower on his own and sworn fealty to the Amyrlin Seat. The last gained great credence because a number of men claimed to have seen a proclamation, signed by Elaida herself, that announced as much. Mat had his doubts, about Rand being dead or swearing fealty, at least. For some odd reason, he felt sure he would know if Rand died, and as for the other, he did not believe the man would put himself within a hundred miles of the White Tower voluntarily. Dragon Reborn or no Dragon Reborn, he had to have more sense than that.

ðət nuz - ɔl ðə vɝʒənz ʌv ɪt - stɝd ðə sintʃæn ðə weɪ ə stɪk stɝz ən ænθip. haɪ-ɹæŋkɪŋ ɔfəsɝz stʃɹoʊd ðə hɔlz ə ðə tɑɹɑsɪn pæləs əɾ ɛvɹi aʊɝ ə ðə deɪ ən naɪt, ðɛɹ ɑd, plum hɛlməts bɪniθ ðɛɹ ɑɹmz, ðɛɹ buts ɹɪŋɪŋ ɑn ðə flɔɹ taɪlz, ðɛɹ feɪsəz sɛt. kɝiɝz ɹeɪst əweɪ fɹəm ɛbu dɑɹ, ɑn hɔɹsəz ən ɑn tɔɹeɪkən. sʌldəm ən deɪmeɪn bɪɡæn pətʃɹoʊlɪŋ ðə stʃɹits ɪnstɛɾ ə dʒʌst stændɪŋ ɡɑɹɾ ət ðə ɡeɪts, wʌns mɔɹ hʌntɪŋ fəɹ wɪmən u kəd tʃænəl. mæt kɛpt aʊɾ ə ði ɔfəsɝz' weɪ ən nɑɾəd pəlaɪtli tə ðə sʌldəm wən i pæst wʌn ɪn ðə stʃɹits. wʌtɛvɝ ɹændz sɪtʃueɪʃən wɑz, hi kəd də nʌθɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪɾ ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ. fɝst, hi hæd tə ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ə ðə sɪɾi.

That news - all the versions of it - stirred the Seanchan the way a stick stirs an antheap. High-ranking officers strode the halls of the Tarasin Palace at every hour of the day and night, their odd, plumed helmets beneath their arms, their boots ringing on the floor tiles, their faces set. Couriers raced away from Ebou Dar, on horses and on to'raken. Sul'dam and damane began patrolling the streets instead of just standing guard at the gates, once more hunting for women who could channel. Mat kept out of the officers' way and nodded politely to the sul'dam when he passed one in the streets. Whatever Rand's situation was, he could do nothing about it in Ebou Dar. First, he had to get out of the city.

ðə mɔɹnɪŋ æftɝ ðə ɡoʊləm tʃɹaɪd tə kɪl hɪm, mæt bɝn ɛvɹi læst wʌn ə ðə lɔŋ pɪŋk ɹɪbənz, ðə hoʊl ɡɹeɪt wɑɾ ə ðɛm, ɪn ðə faɪɝpleɪs əz sun əz taɪlɪn lɛft əɹ əpɑɹtməns. hi ɔlsoʊ bɝn ə pɪŋk koʊt ʃi hæd hæd meɪd fəɹ hɪm, tu pɛɹz ə pɪŋk bɹitʃɪz ən ə pɪŋk kloʊk. ə stɛntʃ ə bɝnɪŋ wʊl ən sɪlk fɪl ðə ɹumz, ən i oʊpən səm wɪndoʊz tə lɛɾ ɪɾ aʊt, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt ɹɪli kɛɹ. hi fɛlt ə ɡɹeɪt ɹɪlif dʒɹɛsɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ɪn bɹaɪt blu bɹitʃɪz ən ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd ɡɹin koʊt, ən ə blu kloʊk wɪð peɪnfəli ɔɹneɪt wɝkɪŋ. ivən ɔl ðə leɪs dɪd nɑt bɑðɝ hɪm. ət lis nʌn ʌv ɪt wɑz pɪŋk. hi nɛvɝ wɑntəd tə si ɛniθɪŋ ðət pɝtɪkjəlɝ kʌlɝ ɛvɝ əɡɛn!

The morning after the gholam tried to kill him, Mat burned every last one of the long pink ribbons, the whole great wad of them, in the fireplace as soon as Tylin left her apartments. He also burned a pink coat she had had made for him, two pairs of pink breeches and a pink cloak. A stench of burning wool and silk filled the rooms, and he opened some windows to let it out, but he did not really care. He felt a great relief dressing himself in bright blue breeches and embroidered green coat, and a blue cloak with painfully ornate working. Even all the lace did not bother him. At least none of it was pink. He never wanted to see anything that particular color ever again!

klæpɪŋ ɪz hæɾ ɑn ɪz hɛd, hi stʌmpt aʊɾ ə ðə tɑɹɑsɪn pæləs wɪð ə ɹɪnud dɪtɝməneɪʃən tə faɪn ðət kʌbihoʊl tə stɔɹ wʌɾ i niɾəd fəɹ ɪz ɪskeɪp, ɪf i hæd tə vɪzəɾ ɛvɹi tævɝn, ɪn ən seɪlɝz' daɪv ɪn ðə sɪɾi tɛn taɪmz oʊvɝ. ivən ðoʊz ɪn ðə ɹæhəd. ə hʌnʒɹəd taɪmz! ɡɹeɪ ɡʌlz ən blæk-wɪŋ skɪmɝz swɝld ɪn lɛɾən skaɪ ðət pɹɑməs mɔɹ ɹeɪn, ən ən aɪsi wɪn kæɹiɪŋ ðə tæŋ ə sɔlt wɪpt əkɹɔs ðə mɔl hɛɹə, fleɪlɪŋ kloʊks əbaʊt. hi θʌmp ðə peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz əz ðoʊ ɪntɛndɪŋ tə kɹæk ɛvɹi wʌn. laɪt, ɪf nid bi, hi wəd ɡoʊ wɪð lukə ɪn wʌɾ i wɔɹ. meɪbi lukə wəd lɛɾ ɪm wɝk ɪz weɪ əz ə bəfun! ðə mæn wəd pɹɑbli ɪnsɪst ɑn ɪt. ət lis ðət wəd kip ɪm kloʊs tə ɑlʌdʒɹə ən əɹ sikɹəts.

Clapping his hat on his head, he stumped out of the Tarasin Palace with a renewed determination to find that cubbyhole to store what he needed for his escape, if he had to visit every tavern, inn and sailors' dive in the city ten times over. Even those in the Rahad. A hundred times! Gray gulls and black-winged skimmers swirled in leaden sky that promised more rain, and an icy wind carrying the tang of salt whipped across the Mol Hara, flailing cloaks about. He thumped the paving stones as though intending to crack every one. Light, if need be, he would go with Luca in what he wore. Maybe Luca would let him work his way as a buffoon! The man would probably insist on it. At least that would keep him close to Aludra and her secrets.

hi stɔk ðə hoʊl wɪdθ ə ðə skwɛɹ bɪfɔɹ i ɹilaɪz ðəɾ i wɑz ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ə waɪd waɪt bɪldɪŋ i nu wɛl. ðə saɪn oʊvɝ ði ɑɹtʃt dɔɹ pɹoʊkleɪm ðə wɑndɝɪŋ wʊmən. ə tɔl fɛloʊ ɪn ɹɛd-ænd-blæk ɑɹmɝ stʃɹoʊɾ aʊt, θɹi θɪn blæk plumz ɑn ðə fɹʌn ə ðə hɛlməɾ ʌndɝ ɪz ɑɹm, ən stʊd weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ɪz hɔɹs tə bi bɹɔɾ ɝaʊnd. ə blʌf-feɪs mæn wɪð ɡɹeɪ əɾ ɪz tɛmpəlz, hi dɪd nɑt lʊk ət mæt, ən mæt əvɔɪɾəd lʊkɪŋ ət hɪm. noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ plɛzən ðə mæn maɪɾ əpɪɹ ɑn ðə sɝfəs, hi wɑz ə dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹd, æftɝ ɔl, ən ə bænɝ-dʒɛnɝəl tə but. ðə wɑndɝɪŋ wʊmən, soʊ nɪɹ ðə pæləs, hæɾ ɛvɹi ɹum ɹɛntəd baɪ haɪ sintʃæn ɔfəsɝz, ən fəɹ ðət ɹizən i hæd nɑt bɪn bæk sɪns i wɑz eɪbəl tə wɔk əɡɛn. ɔɹɾənɛɹi sintʃæn soʊlʒɝz wɝ nɑt sətʃ bæd fɛloʊz, ɹɛɾi tə ɡæmbəl hæf ðə naɪɾ ən baɪ ə ɹaʊnd wən ɪt keɪm ðɛɹ tɝn, bʌt haɪ-ɹæŋkɪŋ ɔfəsɝz maɪɾ əz wɛl bi noʊbəlz. stɪl, hi hæd tə stɑɹt sʌmwɛɹ.

He stalked the whole width of the square before he realized that he was in front of a wide white building he knew well. The sign over the arched door proclaimed The Wandering Woman. A tall fellow in red-and-black armor strode out, three thin black plumes on the front of the helmet under his arm, and stood waiting for his horse to be brought around. A bluff-faced man with gray at his temples, he did not look at Mat, and Mat avoided looking at him. No matter how pleasant the man might appear on the surface, he was a Deathwatch Guard, after all, and a banner-general to boot. The Wandering Woman, so near the Palace, had every room rented by high Seanchan officers, and for that reason he had not been back since he was able to walk again. Ordinary Seanchan soldiers were not such bad fellows, ready to gamble half the night and buy a round when it came their turn, but high-ranking officers might as well be nobles. Still, he had to start somewhere.

ðə kɑmən ɹum wɑz ɔlmoʊst əz i ɹɪmɛmbɝd, haɪ-silɪŋɡd ən wɛl-laɪɾəd baɪ læmps bɝnɪŋ ɑn ɔl ðə wɔlz dɪspaɪt ði ɝli aʊɝ. sɑləd ʃʌɾɝz kʌvɝd ðə tɔl ɑɹtʃt wɪndoʊz naʊ, fəɹ wɔɹmθ, ən faɪɝz kɹækəld ɪn boʊθ lɔŋ faɪɝpleɪsəz. ə feɪn heɪz ə paɪpsmoʊk fɪl ði ɛɹ, ən ðə smɛl ʌv ɡʊd kʊkɪŋ fɹəm ðə kɪtʃənz. tu wɪmən wɪð fluts ən ə fɛloʊ wɪð ə dʒɹʌm bɪtwin ɪz niz wɝ pleɪɪŋ ə kwɪk, ʃɹɪl ɛbu dɑɹi tun ðəɾ i nɑɾəd ɪn taɪm tə. nɑt soʊ dɪfɹən fɹəm wən i hæd steɪd ðɛɹ, soʊ fɑɹ əz ɪt wɛnt. bʌɾ ɔl ə ðə tʃɛɹz hɛl sintʃæn, naʊ, səm ɪn ɑɹmɝ, ʌðɝz ɪn lɔŋ, ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd koʊts, dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ, tɔkɪŋ, stʌɾiɪŋ mæps spɹɛɾ aʊɾ ɑn ðə teɪbəlz. ə ɡɹeɪɪŋ wʊmən wɪð ðə fleɪm ʌv ə dɝsʌldəm ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd ɑn əɹ ʃoʊldɝ sim tə bi meɪkɪŋ ə ɹipɔɹɾ ət wʌn teɪbəl, ən əɾ ənʌðɝ ə skɪni sʌldəm wɪð ə ɹaʊnd-feɪs deɪmeɪn əɾ əɹ hilz əpɪɹd tə bi ɡɛɾɪŋ ɔɹɾɝz. ə nʌmbɝ ə ðə sintʃæn hæd ðə saɪdz ən bæks ə ðɛɹ hɛdz ʃeɪv soʊ ðeɪ sim tə bi wɛɹɪŋ boʊlz, wɪð ðə hɛɹ ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ ət ðə bæk lɛf lɔŋ ɪn ə sɔɹɾ ʌv waɪd teɪl ðət hʌŋ tə ðə ʃoʊldɝz ɑn mɛn ən ɔfən tə ðə weɪst ɑn wɪmən. ðoʊz wɝ sɪmpəl lɔɹdz ən leɪɾiz, nɑt haɪ ɛniθɪŋ, bʌt ðət hɑɹdli mæɾɝd. ə lɔɹd wɑz ə lɔɹd, ən bɪsaɪdz, ðə mɛn ən wɪmən gɑnə fɛtʃ ə sɝvɪŋ meɪd fəɹ mɔɹ dʒɹɪŋks hæd ðə smuð-tʃik dɪsdeɪnfəl lʊk ʌv ɔfəsɝz ðɛmsɛlvz, wɪtʃ mɛn ðə foʊk ðeɪ wɝ fɛtʃɪŋ fəɹ hæd ɹæŋk tə kɑz ə mæn tʃɹʌbəl. sɛvɹəl noʊɾəst ɪm ən fɹaʊnd, ən i ɔlmoʊs lɛft.

The common room was almost as he remembered, high-ceilinged and well-lighted by lamps burning on all the walls despite the early hour. Solid shutters covered the tall arched windows now, for warmth, and fires crackled in both long fireplaces. A faint haze of pipesmoke filled the air, and the smell of good cooking from the kitchens. Two women with flutes and a fellow with a drum between his knees were playing a quick, shrill Ebou Dari tune that he nodded in time to. Not so different from when he had stayed there, so far as it went. But all of the chairs held Seanchan, now, some in armor, others in long, embroidered coats, drinking, talking, studying maps spread out on the tables. A graying woman with the flame of a der'sul'dam embroidered on her shoulder seemed to be making a report at one table, and at another a skinny sul'dam with a round-faced damane at her heels appeared to be getting orders. A number of the Seanchan had the sides and backs of their heads shaved so they seemed to be wearing bowls, with the hair remaining at the back left long in a sort of wide tail that hung to the shoulders on men and often to the waist on women. Those were simple lords and ladies, not High anything, but that hardly mattered. A lord was a lord, and besides, the men and women going to fetch a serving maid for more drinks had the smooth-cheeked disdainful look of officers themselves, which meant the folk they were fetching for had rank to cause a man trouble. Several noticed him and frowned, and he almost left.

ðən i sɔ ði ɪnkipɝ kʌmɪŋ daʊn ðə ɹeɪləs stɛɹz ət ðə bæk ə ðə ɹum, ə steɪtli heɪzəl-aɪd wʊmən wɪð lɑɹdʒ ɡoʊldən hups ɪn əɹ ɪɹz ən ə lɪɾəl ɡɹeɪ ɪn əɹ hɛɹ. sɛɾəl ɑnən wɑz nɑɾ ɛbu dɑɹi, əɹ ivən ɔltɑɹən i səspɛktəd, bʌt ʃi wɔɹ ðə mɛɹɪdʒ-naɪf, hæŋɪŋ hɪlt-daʊn fɹəm ə sɪlvɝ kɑlɝ ɪndə ə dip nɛɹoʊ nɛklaɪn, ən ə lɔŋ kɝv bleɪɾ əɾ əɹ weɪst. ʃi nu hi wɑz səpoʊz tə bi ə lɔɹd, bʌɾ i wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ haʊ fɑɹ ʃi bɪlivd ɛni lɔŋɡɝ əɹ wʌt ɡʊɾ ɪt wəd də ɪf ʃi stɪl swɑloʊd ðə hoʊl fɑɹædɪəl. ɪn ɛni keɪs, ʃi sɔ hɪm ət ðə seɪm ɪnstən ən smaɪld, ə fɹɛnli, wɛlkəmɪŋ smaɪl ðət meɪɾ əɹ feɪs ivən pɹɪɾiɝ. ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ fəɹ ɪt bʌt tə ɡoʊ ən ɡɹiɾ əɹ ən æsk æftɝ əɹ hɛlθ, nɑt tu ɪlæbɹətli. hɝ mʌskjəlɝ hʌzbənd wɑz ə fɪʃɪŋ-boʊt kæptən wɪð mɔɹ dulɪŋ skɑɹz ðən mæt wɑntəd tə θɪŋk əbaʊt. stʃɹeɪɾ ɔf ʃi wɑntəd tə noʊ əbaʊt nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn, ən tə hɪz sɝpɹaɪz, wɛðɝ i nu ɛniθɪŋ əbaʊt ðə kɪn. hi hæd hæd noʊ aɪdiə ʃi hæɾ ivən hɝɾ ə ðɛm.

Then he saw the innkeeper coming down the railless stairs at the back of the room, a stately hazel-eyed woman with large golden hoops in her ears and a little gray in her hair. Setalle Anan was not Ebou Dari, or even Altaran he suspected, but she wore the marriage-knife, hanging hilt-down from a silver collar into a deep narrow neckline, and a long curved blade at her waist. She knew he was supposed to be a lord, but he was not sure how far she believed any longer or what good it would do if she still swallowed the whole faradiddle. In any case, she saw him at the same instant and smiled, a friendly, welcoming smile that made her face even prettier. There was nothing for it but to go and greet her and ask after her health, not too elaborately. Her muscular husband was a fishing-boat captain with more dueling scars than Mat wanted to think about. Straight off she wanted to know about Nynaeve and Elayne, and to his surprise, whether he knew anything about the Kin. He had had no idea she had even heard of them.

"ðeɪ wɛnt wɪð nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn," hi wɪspɝd, kɔʃəsli kipɪŋ wɑtʃ tə meɪk ʃʊɹ noʊ sintʃæn wɑz peɪɪŋ əm ɛni maɪnd. hi dɪd nɑɾ ɪntɛn tə seɪ tu mʌtʃ, bʌt tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt ðə kɪn wɛɹ sintʃæn maɪt hɪɹ meɪd ðə bæk ə hɪz nɛk pɹɪkəl. "soʊ fɑɹ əz aɪ noʊ, ðəɹ ɔl seɪf."

"They went with Nynaeve and Elayne," he whispered, cautiously keeping watch to make sure no Seanchan was paying them any mind. He did not intend to say too much, but talking about the Kin where Seanchan might hear made the back of his neck prickle. "So far as I know, they're all safe."

"ɡʊd. aɪ wəd bi peɪn hæɾ ɛni ʌv əm bɪn kɑlɝd." ðə ful wʊmən dɪd nɑɾ ivən loʊɝ əɹ vɔɪs!

"Good. I would be pained had any of them been collared." The fool woman did not even lower her voice!

"jɛs; ðæts ɡʊd," hi mʌɾɝd, ən hɝidli ɪkspleɪn ɪz nidz bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəd stɑɹt ʃaʊɾɪŋ haʊ hæpi ʃi wɑz ðət wɪmən u kəd tʃænəl hæɾ ɪskeɪp ðə sintʃæn. hi wɑz hæpi, tu, dʒʌs nɑt hæpi ɪnʌf tə pʊt hɪmsɛlf ɪn tʃeɪnz fəɹ dʒɔɪ.

"Yes; that's good," he muttered, and hurriedly explained his needs before she could start shouting how happy she was that women who could channel had escaped the Seanchan. He was happy, too, just not happy enough to put himself in chains for joy.

ʃeɪkɪŋ əɹ hɛd, ʃi siɾəd hɝsɛlf ɑn ðə stɛps ən pʊɾ əɹ hænz ɑn əɹ niz. hɝ dɑɹk ɡɹin skɝts, soʊn ʌp ɑn ðə lɛf saɪd, ʃoʊd ɹɛd pɛɾikoʊts. ɛbu dɑɹi ɹɪli dɪd sim tə nɑk tɪŋkɝz ɑn ðɛɹ hilz wən ɪt keɪm tə tʃuzɪŋ kʌlɝz. ðə bʌz ə sintʃæn vɔɪsəz fɔt wɪð ðə haɪ-pɪtʃt mjuzɪk ɔl ɝaʊn ðɛm, ən ʃi sæt ðəɹ lʊkɪŋ əɾ ɪm stɝnli. "ju doʊnt noʊ əɹ weɪz, ðəɾ ɪz ðə tʃɹʌbəl," ʃi sɛd. "pɹɪɾiz ɑɹ ən oʊld ən ɑnɝd kʌstəm ɪn ɔltɑɹə. mɛni ə jʌŋ mæn əɹ wʊmən əz ə faɪnəl flɪŋ əz ə pɹɪɾi, pæmpɝɾ ən ʃaʊɝd wɪð pɹɛzəns, bɪfɔɹ sɛɾəlɪŋ daʊn. bʌt jə si, ə pɹɪɾi livz wən ʃi tʃuzəz. taɪlɪn ʃʊdn bi tʃɹiɾɪŋ jə əz aɪ hɪɹ ʃi ɪz. stɪl," ʃi æɾəd dʒudɪʃɪsli, "aɪ mʌst seɪ ʃi dʒɹɛsəz jə wɛl." ʃi meɪɾ ə sɝkəlɪŋ moʊʃən wɪð wʌn hænd. "hoʊld aʊt jəɹ kloʊk ən tɝn ɝaʊn soʊ aɪ kən ɡɛɾ ə bɛɾɝ lʊk."

Shaking her head, she seated herself on the steps and put her hands on her knees. Her dark green skirts, sewn up on the left side, showed red petticoats. Ebou Dari really did seem to knock Tinkers on their heels when it came to choosing colors. The buzz of Seanchan voices fought with the high-pitched music all around them, and she sat there looking at him sternly. "You don't know our ways, that is the trouble," she said. "Pretties are an old and honored custom in Altara. Many a young man or woman has a final fling as a pretty, pampered and showered with presents, before settling down. But you see, a pretty leaves when she chooses. Tylin shouldn't be treating you as I hear she is. Still," she added judiciously, "I must say she dresses you well." She made a circling motion with one hand. "Hold out your cloak and turn around so I can get a better look."

mæt dʒɹu ə dip, kɑmɪŋ bɹɛθ. ən ðən θɹi mɔɹ. ðə kʌlɝ flʌɾɪŋ ɪz feɪs wɑz ʃɪɹ fjʊɹi. hi wɑz nɑt blʌʃɪŋ. sɝɾənli nɑt! laɪt, dɪd ðə hoʊl sɪɾi noʊ? "du juv ə speɪs aɪ kən juz əɹ doʊn ju?" hi dɪmændəɾ ɪn ə stʃɹæŋɡəl vɔɪs.

Mat drew a deep, calming breath. And then three more. The color flooding his face was sheer fury. He was not blushing. Certainly not! Light, did the whole city know? "Do you have a space I can use or don't you?" he demanded in a strangled voice.

ɪt tɝn aʊt ðət ʃi dɪd. hi kəd juz ə ʃɛlf ɪn əɹ sɛlɝ, wɪtʃ ʃi sɛd steɪd dʒɹaɪ jɪɹ ɹaʊnd, ən ðəɹ wɑz ðə smɔl hɑloʊ ʌndɝ ðə kɪtʃənz stoʊn flɔɹ wɛɹ i wʌns hæd kɛpt ɪz tʃɛst ʌv ɡoʊld. ɪt tɝn aʊt ðə ɹɛntəl pɹaɪs wɑz fəɹ ɪm tə hoʊld aʊɾ ɪz kloʊk ən tɝn ɝaʊn soʊ ʃi kəd ɡɛɾ ə bɛɾɝ lʊk. ʃi ɡɹɪn laɪk ə kæt! wʌn ə ðə sintʃæn, ə bʌzɝd-feɪst wʊmən ɪn ɹɛd-ænd-blu ɑɹmɝ, ɛndʒɔɪd ðə ʃoʊ soʊ mʌtʃ ðət ʃi tɔst ɪm ə fæt sɪlvɝ kɔɪn wɪð stʃɹeɪnʒ mɑɹkɪŋz, ə fɝbɪɾɪŋ wʊmənz feɪs ɑn wʌn saɪɾ ən səm sɔɹɾ ə hɛvi tʃɛɹ ɑn ði ʌðɝ.

It turned out that she did. He could use a shelf in her cellar, which she said stayed dry year round, and there was the small hollow under the kitchen's stone floor where he once had kept his chest of gold. It turned out the rental price was for him to hold out his cloak and turn around so she could get a better look. She grinned like a cat! One of the Seanchan, a buzzard-faced woman in red-and-blue armor, enjoyed the show so much that she tossed him a fat silver coin with strange markings, a forbidding woman's face on one side and some sort of heavy chair on the other.

stɪl, hi hæɾ ɪz pleɪs tə stɔɹ kloʊðz ən mʌni, ən wʌns i ɹɪtɝn tə ðə pæləs, tə taɪlɪnz əpɑɹtməns, hi faʊn aʊɾ i hæd kloʊðz tə stɔɹ ɪn ɪt.

Still, he had his place to store clothes and money, and once he returned to the Palace, to Tylin's apartments, he found out he had clothes to store in it.

"aɪ fɪɹ maɪ lɔɹdz ɡɑɹməns ɑɹ ɪn ə tɛɹəbəl steɪt," nɹɪm sɛd luɡʌbɹiəsli. ðə skɪni, ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd kɛɹhinɪn wʊɾə bɪn əz doʊlɝəs ənaʊnsɪŋ ðə ɡɪft ʌv ə sæk ə faɪɝdʒɹɑps, ðoʊ. hɪz lɔŋ feɪs wɑz pɝpɛtʃuəli ɪn mɔɹnɪŋ. hi dɪd kip ən aɪ ɑn ðə dɔɹ əɡɛns taɪlɪnz ɹɪtɝn, haʊɛvɝ. "ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɪz kwaɪt fɪlθi, ən aɪm əfɹeɪd mɪldu hæz ɹuən sɛvɹəl ə maɪ lɔɹdz bɛs koʊts."

"I fear my Lord's garments are in a terrible state," Nerim said lugubriously. The skinny, gray-haired Cairhienin would have been as dolorous announcing the gift of a sack of firedrops, though. His long face was perpetually in mourning. He did keep an eye on the door against Tylin's return, however. "Everything is quite filthy, and I am afraid mildew has ruined several of my Lord's best coats."

"ðeɪ wɝ ɔl ɪn ə kʌbɝd wɪð pɹɪns bɛslənz tʃaɪldhʊd tɔɪz, maɪ lɔɹd," ləpɪn læft, tʌɡɪŋ ət ðə ləpɛlz ʌv ə dɑɹk koʊt laɪk dʒulɪnz. ðə bɔldɪŋ mæn wɑz ðə ɹɪvɝs ə nɹɪm, staʊɾ ɪnstɛɾ ə boʊni, dɑɹk ɪnstɛɾ ə peɪl, hɪz ɹaʊn bɛli ɔlweɪz ʃeɪkɪŋ wɪð læftɝ. fəɹ ə taɪm æftɝ neɪlzinz dɛθ ɪt hæd simd i ɪntɛndəd tə kəmpit wɪð nɹɪm ət saɪɪŋ, ðə weɪ ðeɪ dɪɾ oʊvɝ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɛls, bʌt ði ɪntɝvinɪŋ wiks hæd ɹəkʌvɝɾ ɪm tə hɪz nɔɹməl sɛlf. əz lɔŋ əz noʊ wʌn mɛnʃən ɪz fɔɹmɝ mæstɝ, ɛniweɪ. "ðeɪ ɑɹ dʌsti, ðoʊ, maɪ lɔɹd. aɪ daʊɾ ɛniwʌn əz bɪn ɪn ðət kʌbɝd sɪns ðə pɹɪns pʊɾ ɪz tɔɪ soʊlʒɝz əweɪ."

"They were all in a cupboard with Prince Beslan's childhood toys, my Lord," Lopin laughed, tugging at the lapels of a dark coat like Juilin's. The balding man was the reverse of Nerim, stout instead of bony, dark instead of pale, his round belly always shaking with laughter. For a time after Nalesean's death it had seemed he intended to compete with Nerim at sighing, the way they did over everything else, but the intervening weeks had recovered him to his normal self. As long as no one mentioned his former master, anyway. "They are dusty, though, my Lord. I doubt anyone has been in that cupboard since the Prince put his toy soldiers away."

filɪŋ ðəɾ ɪz lʌk wɑz ɹʌnɪŋ stʃɹɔŋ ət læst, mæt toʊld əm tə stɑɹt teɪkɪŋ ɪz kloʊðz əkɹɔs tə ðə wɑndɝɪŋ wʊmən ə fju pisəz əɾ ə taɪm, ən ə pɑkət fʊl ʌv ɡoʊld itʃ tʃɹɪp. hɪz blæk-hæftɪd spɪɹ, pɹɑpt ɪn ə kɔɹnɝ ə taɪlɪnz bɛdtʃeɪmbɝ wɪð ɪz ənstʃɹʌŋ tu ɹɪvɝz baʊ, wəɾ əv tə weɪt fəɹ læst. ɡɛɾɪŋ ðəɾ aʊt maɪt bi əz dɪfəkəlt əz ɡɛɾɪŋ hɪmsɛlf aʊt. hi kəɾ ɔlweɪz meɪk ə nu baʊ fəɹ hɪmsɛlf, bʌɾ i wɑz nɑt gɑnə əbændən ði æʃhændʒɹeɪ.

Feeling that his luck was running strong at last, Mat told them to start taking his clothes across to The Wandering Woman a few pieces at a time, and a pocket full of gold each trip. His black-hafted spear, propped in a corner of Tylin's bedchamber with his unstrung Two Rivers bow, would have to wait for last. Getting that out might be as difficult as getting himself out. He could always make a new bow for himself, but he was not going to abandon the ashandarei.

aɪ peɪd tu haɪ ə pɹaɪs fəɹ ðə blʌɾi θɪŋ tə liv ɪt, hi θɔt, fɪŋɡɝɪŋ ðə skɑɹ hɪɾən bɪniθ ðə skɑɹf ɝaʊn ɪz nɛk. wʌn ə ðə fɝst, əmʌŋ tu mɛni. laɪt, ɪt wəd bi naɪs tə θɪŋk ðəɾ i hæd mɔɹ tə lʊk fɔɹwɝd tə ðən skɑɹz ən bæɾəlz i dɪd nɑt wɑnt. ən ə waɪf i dɪd nɑt wɑn əɹ ivən noʊ. ðəɹ hæd tə bi mɔɹ ðən ðæt. fɝs keɪm ɡɛɾɪŋ aʊɾ ʌv ɛbu dɑɹ wɪð ə hoʊl haɪd, ðoʊ. ðəɾ əbʌv ɔl ɛls, fɝst.

I paid too high a price for the bloody thing to leave it, he thought, fingering the scar hidden beneath the scarf around his neck. One of the first, among too many. Light, it would be nice to think that he had more to look forward to than scars and battles he did not want. And a wife he did not want or even know. There had to be more than that. First came getting out of Ebou Dar with a whole hide, though. That above all else, first.

ləpɪn ən nɹɪm baʊd ðɛmsɛlvz aʊɾ ə hɪz pɹɛzəns wɪð ði ɪkwɪvələn ə tu fæt pɝsɪz spɹɛɾ əbaʊt ðɛɹ kloʊðɪŋ, soʊ əz nɑt tə kɹieɪɾ ɛni bʌlʒɪz, bʌt noʊ sunɝ hæd ðeɪ ɡɔn ðən taɪlɪn əpɪɹd, wɑntɪŋ tə noʊ waɪ hɪz bɑdaɪsɝvəns wɝ ɹʌnɪŋ ɪn ðə hɔlz əz ðoʊ ɹeɪsɪŋ itʃ ʌðɝ. ɪf i hæd bɪn filɪŋ suəsaɪɾəl i cʊɾə toʊld əɹ ðeɪ wɝ ɹeɪsɪŋ tə si hu wəd bi fɝs tə ɹitʃ ði ɪn wɪð ɪz ɡoʊld, əɹ meɪbi dʒʌs ðə fɝs tə stɑɹt klinɪŋ ɪz kloʊðz. ɪnstɛɾ i bɪzid hɪmsɛlf daɪvɝɾɪŋ hɝ, ən sun ɪnʌf ðət tʃeɪst ɛni ʌðɝ θɔts aʊɾ ə hɪz hɛd, ɪksɛp fəɹ ə ɡlɪmɝ ðəɾ ɪz lʌk hæd faɪnəli bɪɡʌn tə peɪ ɔf ət sʌmθɪŋ bɪsaɪdz ɡæmbəlɪŋ. ɔl ɪt niɾəd tə pʊt ðə kæp ɑn wəd bi fəɹ ɑlʌdʒɹə tə ɡɪv ɪm wʌɾ i wɑntəd bɪfɔɹ i lɛft. taɪlɪn pʊɾ əɹ maɪn tə wʌt ʃi wɑz duɪŋ, ən fəɹ ə taɪm i fɝɡɑt faɪɹwɝks ən ɑlʌdʒɹə ən ɪskeɪpɪŋ. fəɹ ə taɪm.

Lopin and Nerim bowed themselves out of his presence with the equivalent of two fat purses spread about their clothing, so as not to create any bulges, but no sooner had they gone than Tylin appeared, wanting to know why his bodyservants were running in the halls as though racing each other.
