That had been another man, a long time dead, but he remembered it, and it fit. Blood and bloody ashes! He did not know how to rescue one Aes Sedai, and she had him trying to rescue two!

hi stɔkt ɝaʊn ði ɪnɑkjuəs kɔɹnɝ ət ðə fʊɾ ə ðə stɛɹz ən ɔlmoʊst wɔkt ɪndə tuɑn.

He stalked around the innocuous corner at the foot of the stairs and almost walked into Tuon.

"deɪmeɪn kɛnəlz ɑɹ fɔɹbɪɾən tə mɛn," ʃi sɛd, piɹɪŋ ʌp əɾ ɪm koʊldli θɹu hɝ veɪl. "ju kəd bi pʌnɪʃt dʒʌs fəɹ ɛntɝɪŋ."

"Damane kennels are forbidden to men," she said, peering up at him coldly through her veil. "You could be punished just for entering."

"aɪ wɑz lʊkɪŋ fəɹ ə wɪndfɪndɝ, haɪ leɪɾi," hi sɛd heɪstəli, meɪkɪŋ ə lɛɡ ən θɪŋkɪŋ əz fæst əz i ɛvɝ hæɾ ɪn ɪz laɪf. "ʃi dɪd mi ə feɪvɝ wʌns, ən aɪ θɔt ʃi maɪt laɪk sʌmθɪŋ fɹəm ðə kɪtʃənz. səm peɪstʃɹiz, əɹ ðə laɪk. aɪ dɪdn si hɝ, ðoʊ. aɪ səpoʊz ʃi wɑzn kɑt wən . . ." hi tʃɹeɪld ɔf, stɛɹɪŋ. ðə stɝn dʒudɪʃəl mæsk ðə ɡɝl ɔlweɪz wɔɹ fəɹ ə feɪs hæd mɛltəɾ ɪndə ə smaɪl. ʃi ɹɪli wɑz bjuɾəfəl.

"I was looking for a Windfinder, High Lady," he said hastily, making a leg and thinking as fast as he ever had in his life. "She did me a favor once, and I thought she might like something from the kitchens. Some pastries, or the like. I didn't see her, though. I suppose she wasn't caught when . . ." He trailed off, staring. The stern judicial mask the girl always wore for a face had melted into a smile. She really was beautiful.

"ðæɾ ɪz vɛɹi kaɪndə ju," ʃi sɛd. "ɪts ɡʊd tə noʊ jə ɑɹ kaɪn tə deɪmeɪn. bʌt jə mʌs bi kɛɹfəl. ðəɹ ɑɹ mɛn u æktʃəli  teɪk deɪmeɪn tə ðɛɹ bɛdz." hɝ fʊl maʊθ twɪstəɾ ɪn dɪsɡʌst. "ju wəd nɑt wɑn ɛniwʌn tə θɪŋk jə ɑɹ pɝvɝɾɪd." ðət səvɪɹ ɪkspɹɛʃən sɛɾəld ɑn əɹ feɪs əɡɛn. ɔl pɹɪznɝz wəd bi ɛksəkjuɾəd ɪmiɾiətli.

"That is very kind of you," she said. "It's good to know you are kind to damane. But you must be careful. There are men who actually take damane to their beds." Her full mouth twisted in disgust. "You would not want anyone to think you are perverted." That severe expression settled on her face again. All prisoners would be executed immediately.

"θæŋk jə fəɹ ðə wɔɹnɪŋ, haɪ leɪɾi," hi sɛd, ə lɪɾəl ənstɛɾəli. wʌt kaɪndə mæn wɑntəd tə bɛɾ ə wʊmən u wɑz ɑn ə liʃ?

"Thank you for the warning, High Lady," he said, a little unsteadily. What kind of man wanted to bed a woman who was on a leash?

hi dɪsəpɪɹd ðɛn, əz fɑɹ əz ʃi wɑz kənsɝnd. ʃi dʒʌst ɡlaɪɾɪd əweɪ daʊn ðə hɔl əz ɪf ʃi sɔ noʊ wʌn. fəɹ wʌns, ðoʊ, ðə haɪ leɪɾi tuɑn dɪd nɑt kənsɝn ɪm əɾ ɔl. hi hæɾ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ haɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə sɛlɝ ə ðə wɑndɝɪŋ wʊmən ən tu wɛɹɪŋ deɪmeɪn liʃɪz u ɔl ɪkspɛktəd mæt blʌɾi kɔθən tə seɪv ðɛɹ nɛks. hi wɑz ʃʊɹ tɛslɪn wəɾ ɪnfɔɹm ðɪs idɛzinə ɔl əbaʊɾ ɪɾ əz sun əz ʃi wɑz eɪbəl. θɹi wɪmən u maɪt stɑɹt ɡɛɾɪŋ ɪmpeɪʃən ɪf i feɪl tə wɑft əm tə seɪfti sun ɪnʌf. wɪmən laɪk tə tɔk, ən wən ðeɪ tɔkt ɪnʌf, ðeɪ lɛt slɪp θɪŋz bɛɾɝ lɛft ənspoʊkən. ɪmpeɪʃənt wɪmən tɔkt ivən mɔɹ ðən ðə ɹɛst. hi kəd nɑt fil ðə daɪs ɪn ɪz hɛd, bʌɾ i kəɾ ɔlmoʊs hɪɹ ə klɑk tɪkɪŋ. ən ði aʊɝ maɪt bi stʃɹʌk baɪ ə hɛdzmənz æks. bæɾəlz i kəd plæn ɪn ɪz slip, bʌt ðoʊz oʊl mɛmɹiz dɪd nɑt sim mʌtʃ hɛlp hɪɹ. hi niɾəd ə skimɝ, sʌmwʌn juz tə plɑɾɪŋ ən kɹʊkəd weɪz ə θɪŋkɪŋ. ɪt wɑz taɪm tə meɪk tɑm sɪt daʊn ən tɔk. ən dʒulɪn.

He disappeared then, as far as she was concerned. She just glided away down the hall as if she saw no one. For once, though, the High Lady Tuon did not concern him at all. He had an Aes Sedai hiding in the cellar of The Wandering Woman and two wearing damane leashes who all expected Mat bloody Cauthon to save their necks. He was sure Teslyn would inform this Edesina all about it as soon as she was able. Three women who might start getting impatient if he failed to waft them to safety soon enough. Women liked to talk, and when they talked enough, they let slip things better left unspoken. Impatient women talked even more than the rest. He could not feel the dice in his head, but he could almost hear a clock ticking. And the hour might be struck by a headsman's axe. Battles he could plan in his sleep, but those old memories did not seem much help here. He needed a schemer, someone used to plotting and crooked ways of thinking. It was time to make Thom sit down and talk. And Juilin.

sɛɾɪŋ aʊɾ ɪn sɝtʃ ʌv iðɝ, hi ʌnkɑnʃəsli bɪɡæn hʌmɪŋ "aɪm daʊn ət ðə bɑɾəm ə ðə wɛl." wɛl, hi wɑz, ən naɪt wɑz fɔlɪŋ ən ðə ɹeɪn wɛl ən tʃɹuli kʌmɪŋ daʊn. əz ɔfən hæpənd, ənʌðɝ neɪm dʒɹɪftəɾ ʌp aʊɾ ə ðoʊz oʊl mɛmɹiz, ə sɔŋ ə ðə kɔɹɾ ə tɑkeɪɾoʊ, ɪn fɑɹɑʃɛl, kɹʌʃt ə θaʊzən jɪɹz əɡoʊ ən mɔɹ baɪ ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ. ði ɪntɝvinɪŋ jɪɹz hæd meɪd ɹɪmɑɹkəbli lɪɾəl tʃeɪnʒ ɪn ðə tun ɪtsɛlf, ðoʊ. ðɛn, ɪt hæd bɪn kɔld "ðə læst stæn ət mændənhɹ." iðɝ weɪ, ɪt fɪt tu blʌɾi wɛl.

Setting out in search of either, he unconsciously began humming "I'm Down at the Bottom of the Well." Well, he was, and night was falling and the rain well and truly coming down. As often happened, another name drifted up out of those old memories, a song of the Court of Takedo, in Farashelle, crushed a thousand years ago and more by Artur Hawkwing. The intervening years had made remarkably little change in the tune itself, though. Then, it had been called "The Last Stand at Mandenhar." Either way, it fit too bloody well.


tʃæptɝ twɛnti


CHAPTER 20

kwɛstʃənz ə tʃɹizən


Questions of Treason

klaɪmɪŋ tə ðə kɹæmp kɛnəlz ət ðə vɛɹi tɑp ə ðə tɑɹɑsɪn pæləs, bɛθəmən hɛld əɹ ɹaɪɾɪŋ bɔɹd kɛɹfəli. səmtaɪmz ði ɪŋk dʒɑɹz kɔɹk keɪm lus, ən ɪŋk spɑts wɝ dɪfəkəl tə ɹimuv fɹəm kloʊðɪŋ. ʃi kɛp hɝsɛlf əz pɹəzɛntəbəl əɾ ɔl taɪmz əz ɪf ʃi hæd bɪn kɔl tə əpɪɹ bɪfɔɹ wʌn ə ðə haɪ blʌd. ʃi dɪd nɑt tɔk tə ɹɛnə, hu hæd ði ɪnspɛkʃən duɾi wɪð əɹ tədeɪ, əz ðeɪ wɔkt ʌp ðə stɛɹz. ðeɪ wɝ səpoʊz tə bi duɪŋ ən əsaɪn tæsk, nɑt tʃæɾɝɪŋ aɪdli. ðət wɑz pɑɹɾ ə hɝ ɹizən. wɛɹ ʌðɝz dʒɑkeɪd tə bi kəmplit wɪð ðɛɹ feɪvɹɪt deɪmeɪn, ən ɡɑɡəld ət ðə stʃɹeɪnʒ saɪts ə ðɪs lænd, ən spɛkjəleɪɾəd ɑn ðə ɹɪwɔɹdz tə bi ɡeɪn hɪɹ, ʃi foʊkəst ɑn əɹ duɾiz, æskɪŋ fəɹ ðə moʊs dɪfəkəl mɛɹəθdəmeɪn tə teɪm tə ði æɾəm, wɝkɪŋ twaɪs əz hɑɹɾ ən twaɪs əz lɔŋ əz ɛniwʌn ɛls.

Climbing to the cramped kennels at the very top of the Tarasin Palace, Bethamin held her writing board carefully. Sometimes the ink jar's cork came loose, and ink spots were difficult to remove from clothing. She kept herself as presentable at all times as if she had been called to appear before one of the High Blood. She did not talk to Renna, who had the inspection duty with her today, as they walked up the stairs. They were supposed to be doing an assigned task, not chattering idly. That was part of her reason. Where others jockeyed to be complete with their favorite damane, and goggled at the strange sights of this land, and speculated on the rewards to be gained here, she focused on her duties, asking for the most difficult marath'damane to tame to the a'dam, working twice as hard and twice as long as anyone else.

ðə ɹeɪn hæd stɑpt, faɪnəli, livɪŋ ðə kɛnəlz ɪn saɪləns. ðə deɪmeɪn wəd ɡɛt səm ɛksɝsaɪz ət list, tədeɪ - moʊst ɡɹu sʌlki ɪf kənfaɪn tə ðə kɛnəlz tu lɔŋ, ən ðiz meɪkʃɪf kɛnəlz wɝ dɪsaɪɾədli kənfaɪnɪŋ - bʌt ɹɪɡɹɛɾəbli, ʃi wɑz nɑɾ əsaɪn tə wɔkɪŋ tədeɪ. ɹɛnə nɛvɝ wɑz, ðoʊ wʌns ʃi hæd bɪn sjuɹɔθs bɛs tʃɹeɪnɝ, ən wɛl ɹɪspɛktɪd. ə lɪɾəl hɑɹʃ, səmtaɪmz, bʌt haɪli skɪld. wʌns, ɛvɹiwʌn hæd sɛd ʃi wəd sun bi meɪd dɝsʌldəm ɪn spaɪɾ ə hɝ juθ. mæɾɝz hæd tʃeɪnʒd. ðəɹ wɝ ɔlweɪz mɔɹ sʌldəm ðən deɪmeɪn, jɛt noʊ wʌn kəd ɹikɔl ɹɛnə biɪŋ kəmplit sɪns fɑlm, hɝ əɹ sɛɾə, hum sjuɹɔθ hæd teɪkən ɪndə pɝsənəl sɝvəs æftɝ fɑlm. bɛθəmən ɛndʒɔɪd ɡɑsəpɪŋ oʊvɝ waɪn əbaʊt ðə blʌɾ ən ðoʊz u sɝvd əm əz mʌtʃ əz ɛniwʌn ɛls, jɛt ʃi nɛvɝ vɛntʃɝɾ ɛni əpɪnjən wən ðə tɔk tɝn tə ɹɛnə ən sɛɾə. ʃi θɔɾ ə ðɛm ɔfən, ðoʊ.

The rain had stopped, finally, leaving the kennels in silence. The damane would get some exercise at least, today - most grew sulky if confined to the kennels too long, and these makeshift kennels were decidedly confining - but regrettably, she was not assigned to walking today. Renna never was, though once she had been Suroth's best trainer, and well respected. A little harsh, sometimes, but highly skilled. Once, everyone had said she would soon be made der'sul'dam in spite of her youth. Matters had changed. There were always more sul'dam than damane, yet no one could recall Renna being complete since Falme, her or Seta, whom Suroth had taken into personal service after Falme. Bethamin enjoyed gossiping over wine about the Blood and those who served them as much as anyone else, yet she never ventured any opinion when the talk turned to Renna and Seta. She thought of them often, though.

"ju stɑɹɾ ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪd, ɹɛnə," ʃi ɔɹɾɝd. "wɛl? dʒju wɑnə bi ɹipɔɹɾəd tə ɛsən fəɹ leɪzinəs jɛɾ əɡɛn?"

"You start on the other side, Renna," she ordered. "Well? Do you want to be reported to Essonde for laziness yet again?"

bɪfɔɹ fɑlm, ðə ʃɔɹɾɝ wʊmən hæd bɪn nɪɹli oʊvɝpaʊɹɪŋ ɪn əɹ sɛlf-əʃʊɹəns, bʌɾ ə mʌsəl twɪtʃt ɪn əɹ peɪl tʃik, ən ʃi ɡeɪv bɛθəmən ə sɪkli, əbsikwiəs smaɪl bɪfɔɹ hɝiɪŋ ɪndə ðə kɛnəlz wɔɹən ə nɛɹoʊ pæsədʒəz pæɾɪŋ əɾ əɹ lɔŋ hɛɹ əz ðoʊ əfɹeɪɾ ɪt maɪt bi dɪsɔɹɾɝd. ɛvɹiwʌn ɪksɛpt ɹɛnəz kloʊsəs fɹɛnz bʊliɾ əɹ ət list ə lɪɾəl, ɹipeɪɪŋ əɹ fɔɹmɝ lɔfti pɹaɪd. tə də ʌðɝwaɪz wɑz tə mɑɹk jɝsɛlf aʊt, sʌmθɪŋ bɛθəmən əvɔɪɾəd ɪksɛpt ɪn kɛɹfəli tʃoʊzən weɪz. hɝ oʊn sikɹəts wɝ bɛɹiɾ əz dipli əz ʃi kəd bɛɹi ðɛm, ən ʃi hɛl saɪlən əbaʊt ðə sikɹəts noʊ wʌn nu ʃi wɑz əwɛɹ ʌv, bʌt ʃi wɑntəd tə fɪks ɪn ɛvɹiwʌnz maɪn ðət bɛθəmən zimi wɑz ði ɪmədʒ ə ðə pɝfək sʌldəm. æbsəlut pɝfɛkʃən wɑz wʌt ʃi stʃɹoʊv fɔɹ, ɪn hɝsɛlf ən ɪn ðə deɪmeɪn ʃi tʃɹeɪnd.

Before Falme, the shorter woman had been nearly overpowering in her self-assurance, but a muscle twitched in her pale cheek, and she gave Bethamin a sickly, obsequious smile before hurrying into the kennel's warren of narrow passages patting at her long hair as though afraid it might be disordered. Everyone except Renna's closest friends bullied her at least a little, repaying her former lofty pride. To do otherwise was to mark yourself out, something Bethamin avoided except in carefully chosen ways. Her own secrets were buried as deeply as she could bury them, and she held silent about the secrets no one knew she was aware of, but she wanted to fix in everyone's mind that Bethamin Zeami was the image of the perfect sul'dam. Absolute perfection was what she strove for, in herself and in the damane she trained.

ʃi sɛɾ əbaʊɾ əɹ ɪnspɛkʃən bɹɪskli ən ɪfɪʃənli, tʃɛkɪŋ ðət ðə deɪmeɪn hæd kɛp ðɛmsɛlvz ən ðɛɹ ɪndəvɪdʒəwəl kɛnəlz nit, meɪkɪŋ ə ʃɔɹt noʊteɪʃən ɪn əɹ nit hæn ɑn ðə tɑp peɪdʒ pɪn tə ðə ɹaɪɾɪŋ bɔɹd wən wʌn hæd feɪl tə, ən ʃi dɪd nɑt dɔɾəl, ɪksɛp tə ɡɪv aʊt hɑɹd kændiz tə ə fju hu wɝ duɪŋ pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli wɛl ɪn ðə tʃɹeɪnɪŋ. moʊst ə ðoʊz ʃi hæd bɪn kəmplit wɪð ɡɹiɾəd əɹ ɛntʃɹəns wɪð smaɪlz ivən əz ðeɪ nɛlt. wɛðɝ fɹəm ði ɛmpaɪɝ əɹ fɹəm ðɪs saɪɾ ə ði oʊʃən, ðeɪ nu ʃi wɑz fɝm jɛt fɛɹ. ʌðɝz dɪd nɑt smaɪl. fəɹ ðə moʊs pɑɹt, ði æθɑn maɪɹ deɪmeɪn mɛɾ əɹ wɪð stoʊni feɪsəz əz dɑɹk əz əɹ oʊn, əɹ sʌlən æŋɡɝ ðeɪ sim tə bɪliv ðeɪ wɝ kənsilɪŋ.

She set about her inspection briskly and efficiently, checking that the damane had kept themselves and their individual kennels neat, making a short notation in her neat hand on the top page pinned to the writing board when one had failed to, and she did not dawdle, except to give out hard candies to a few who were doing particularly well in the training. Most of those she had been complete with greeted her entrance with smiles even as they knelt. Whether from the Empire or from this side of the ocean, they knew she was firm yet fair. Others did not smile. For the most part, the Atha'an Miere damane met her with stony faces as dark as her own, or sullen anger they seemed to believe they were concealing.

ʃi dɪd nɑt mɑɹk ðɛɹ æŋɡɝ daʊn fəɹ pʌnɪʃmənt, əz səm wəd hæv. ðeɪ stɪl θɔt ðeɪ wɝ ɹɪzɪstɪŋ, bʌɾ ənsimli dɪmænz fəɹ ðə ɹɪtɝn ə ðɛɹ ɡɛɹɪʃ dʒuəlɹi ɔlɹɛɾi wɝ ə θɪŋ ə ðə pæst, ən ðeɪ nɛlt ən spoʊk pɹɑpɝli. ə nu neɪm wɑz ə jusfəl tul wɪð ðə moʊs dɪfəkəl keɪsəz, kɹieɪɾɪŋ ə bɹeɪk wɪð wʌt wɑz dʌn ən ɡɔn, ən ðeɪ ænsɝd tə ðɛɹz, haʊɛvɝ ɹɪlʌktənli. ɹɪlʌktəns wəd feɪd, əlɔŋ wɪð skaʊlz, ən ɪvɛntʃəwəli ðeɪ wəd hɑɹdli ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðeɪ ɛvɝ hæɾ ʌðɝ neɪmz. ɪt wɑz ə fəmɪljɝ pæɾɝn, ən ənfeɪlɪŋ əz sʌnɹaɪz. səm æksɛptɪɾ ɪmiɾiətli, ən səm wɛn ɪndə ʃɑk ət lɝnɪŋ wʌt ðeɪ wɝ. ɔlweɪz ðəɹ wɝ ə hændfʊl u ɡeɪv ɡɹaʊnd ɡɹʌdʒɪŋli oʊvɝ mʌnθs, waɪl wɪð ʌðɝz, wʌn deɪ ɪt wɑz ʃɹik pɹoʊɾɛsts ðəɾ ə tɛɹəbəl mɪsteɪk hæd bɪn meɪd, ðət ðeɪ kəd nɛvɝ əv feɪl ðə tɛsts, ən ðə nɛks deɪ keɪm æksɛptəns ən kɑm. ðə dɪteɪlz dɪfɝɾ ɑn ðɪs saɪɾ ə ði oʊʃən, bʌt hɪɹ əɹ ɪn ði ɛmpaɪɝ, ði ɛn ɹɪzʌlt ɹɪmeɪn ðə seɪm.

She did not mark their anger down for punishment, as some would have. They still thought they were resisting, but unseemly demands for the return of their garish jewelry already were a thing of the past, and they knelt and spoke properly. A new name was a useful tool with the most difficult cases, creating a break with what was done and gone, and they answered to theirs, however reluctantly. Reluctance would fade, along with scowls, and eventually they would hardly remember they ever had other names. It was a familiar pattern, and unfailing as sunrise. Some accepted immediately, and some went into shock at learning what they were. Always there were a handful who gave ground grudgingly over months, while with others, one day it was shrieked protests that a terrible mistake had been made, that they could never have failed the tests, and the next day came acceptance and calm. The details differed on this side of the ocean, but here or in the Empire, the end result remained the same.

fəɹ tu ʌv ðə deɪmeɪn ʃi meɪd noʊts ðət hæd nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð nitnəs. zʊʃi, ən æθɑn maɪɹ deɪmeɪn ivən tɔlɝ ðən ʃi hɝsɛlf, wɑz sɝɾənli mɑɹk fəɹ ə swɪtʃɪŋ. hɝ dʒɹɛs wɑz ɹʌmpəld, hɝ hɛɹ ʌnkoʊmd, hɝ bɛɾ ənmeɪd. bʌɾ əɹ feɪs wɑz swoʊlən fɹəm kɹaɪɪŋ, ən noʊ sunɝ hæd ʃi nɛl ðən ə nu sɛɾ ə sɑbz ɹæk hɝ, tɪɹz stʃɹimɪŋ daʊn əɹ tʃiks. ðə ɡɹeɪ dʒɹɛs ðət hæd bɪn fɪɾəd ɑn əɹ soʊ kɛɹfəli naʊ hʌŋ lusli, ən ʃi hæd nɑt bɪn plʌmp tə bɪɡɪn wɪð. bɛθəmən hæd neɪm zʊʃi hɝsɛlf, ən ʃi fɛlt ə spɛʃəl kənsɝn. ənklɪpɪŋ ðə stil-nɪb pɛn, ʃi dɪpt ɪɾ ən ɹoʊɾ ə sədʒɛstʃən ðət zʊʃi bi muv fɹəm ðə pæləs tə sʌmwɛɹ ʃi kəd bi kɛpt ɪn ə dʌbəl kɛnəl wɪð ə deɪmeɪn fɹəm ði ɛmpaɪɝ, pɹɛfɝəbli wʌn ɪkspɪɹiənst ɪn bɪkʌmɪŋ hɑɹt-fɹɛnz wɪð nuli kɑlɝd deɪmeɪn. sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ, ðəɾ ɔlweɪz pʊɾ ən ɛn tə tɛɹz.

For two of the damane she made notes that had nothing to do with neatness. Zushi, an Atha'an Miere damane even taller than she herself, was certainly marked for a switching. Her dress was rumpled, her hair uncombed, her bed unmade. But her face was swollen from crying, and no sooner had she knelt than a new set of sobs racked her, tears streaming down her cheeks. The gray dress that had been fitted on her so carefully now hung loosely, and she had not been plump to begin with. Bethamin had named Zushi herself, and she felt a special concern. Unclipping the steel-nibbed pen, she dipped it and wrote a suggestion that Zushi be moved from the Palace to somewhere she could be kept in a double kennel with a damane from the Empire, preferably one experienced in becoming heart-friends with newly collared damane. Sooner or later, that always put an end to tears.

ʃi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ sjuɹɔθ wəɾ əlaʊ ɪt, ðoʊ. sjuɹɔθ hæd kleɪm ðiz deɪmeɪn fəɹ ði ɛmpɹɛs, ʌv kɔɹs - ɛniwʌn u oʊn ə tɛnθ soʊ mɛni pɝsənəli wəd bi səspɛktəɾ ə plɑɾɪŋ ɹɪbɛljən, əɹ ivən əkjuzd aʊtʃɹaɪt - jɛt ʃi bɪheɪvd əz ðoʊ ðeɪ wɝ əɹ oʊn pɹɑpɝɾi. ɪf sjuɹɔθ dɪsəlaʊd, səm ʌðɝ weɪ wəɾ əv tə bi faʊnd. bɛθəmən ɹəfjuz tə luz ə deɪmeɪn tə dɪspɑndənsi. ʃi ɹəfjuz tə luz ə deɪmeɪn fəɹ ɛni ɹizən! ðə sɛkən tə ɹəsiv ə spɛʃəl kɑmɛnt wɑz tɛsi, ən ʃi ɪkspɛktəd noʊ əbdʒɛkʃənz ðɛɹ.

She was not sure Suroth would allow it, though. Suroth had claimed these damane for the Empress, of course - anyone who owned a tenth so many personally would be suspected of plotting rebellion, or even accused outright - yet she behaved as though they were her own property. If Suroth disallowed, some other way would have to be found. Bethamin refused to lose a damane to despondency. She refused to lose a damane for any reason! The second to receive a special comment was Tessi, and she expected no objections there.

ði ɪliɑnɝ deɪmeɪn nɛlt ɡɹeɪsfəli, hænz foʊldəɾ əɾ əɹ weɪst, əz sun əz bɛθəmən oʊpən ðə dɔɹ. hɝ bɛd wɑz meɪd, hɝ ɛkstʃɹə ɡɹeɪ dʒɹɛsəz hʌŋ nitli ɑn ðɛɹ pɛɡz, hɝ bɹʌʃ ən koʊm wɝ leɪɾ aʊt pɹɪsaɪsli ɑn əɹ wɑʃstænd, ən ðə flɔɹ hæd bɪn swɛpt. bɛθəmən ɪkspɛktəd noʊ lɛs. tɛsi hæd bɪn nit fɹəm ðə stɑɹt. ʃi wɑz flɛʃɪŋ aʊt naɪsli naʊ ðət ʃi hæd lɝn tə klin əɹ pleɪt. ʌðɝ ðən tʃɹits, deɪmeɪnz daɪɪts wɝ ɹɛɡjəleɪɾəd stʃɹɪkli; ən ənhɛlθi deɪmeɪn wɑz ə weɪst. tɛsi wəd nɛvɝ bi dɛkt ɪn ɹɪbənz ən ɛntɝɾ ɪn ðə kɑmpətɪʃənz fəɹ ðə pɹɪɾiəst deɪmeɪn, ðoʊ. hɝ feɪs sim pɝpɛtʃuəli æŋɡɹi ivən ɪn ɹipoʊz. bʌt tədeɪ ʃi wɔɹ ə slaɪt smaɪl ðət bɛθəmən wɑz ʃʊɹ hæd bɪn ɪn pleɪs bɪfɔɹ ʃi ɛntɝd. tɛsi wɑz nɑt wʌn ʃi ɪkspɛktəd smaɪlz fɹʌm, nɑt jɛt.

The Illianer damane knelt gracefully, hands folded at her waist, as soon as Bethamin opened the door. Her bed was made, her extra gray dresses hung neatly on their pegs, her brush and comb were laid out precisely on her washstand, and the floor had been swept. Bethamin expected no less. Tessi had been neat from the start. She was fleshing out nicely now that she had learned to clean her plate. Other than treats, damane's diets were regulated strictly; an unhealthy damane was a waste. Tessi would never be decked in ribbons and entered in the competitions for the prettiest damane, though. Her face seemed perpetually angry even in repose. But today she wore a slight smile that Bethamin was sure had been in place before she entered. Tessi was not one she expected smiles from, not yet.

"haʊ ɪz maɪ lɪɾəl tɛsi filɪŋ tədeɪ?" ʃi æskt.

"How is my little Tessi feeling today?" she asked.

"tɛsi də fil vɛɹi wɛl," ðə deɪmeɪn ɹɪplaɪd smuðli. ɔlweɪz bɪfɔɹ ʃi hæd hæd tə stʃɹʌɡəl tə spik pɹɑpɝli, ən hæɾ ɝn əɹ leɪɾəst swɪtʃɪŋ fəɹ aʊtʃɹaɪt ɹəfjuzəl oʊnli jɛstɝdeɪ.

"Tessi do feel very well," the damane replied smoothly. Always before she had had to struggle to speak properly, and had earned her latest switching for outright refusal only yesterday.

fɪŋɡɝɪŋ əɹ tʃɪn θɔtfəli, bɛθəmən stʌɾid ðə nilɪŋ deɪmeɪn. ʃi wɑz səspɪʃəs ʌv ɛni deɪmeɪn u hæd kɔl hɝsɛlf ɛɛs sədaɪ. hɪstɝi fæsəneɪɾəd hɝ, ən ʃi hæɾ ivən ɹɛd tʃɹænzleɪʃənz fɹəm ðə mɪɹiəɾ ə læŋɡwədʒəz ðət hæɾ ɪɡzɪstəd bɪfɔɹ ðə kənsɑlədeɪʃən bɪɡæn. ðoʊz eɪntʃən ɹulɝz ɹɛvəld ɪn ðɛɹ mɝɾɝəs, kəpɹɪʃəs ɹul, ən dɪlaɪɾəd ɪn sɛɾɪŋ daʊn haʊ ðeɪ keɪm tə paʊɝ ən haʊ ðeɪ kɹʌʃt neɪbɝɪŋ steɪts ən ʌndɝmaɪn ʌðɝ ɹulɝz. moʊs hæd daɪd baɪ əsæsəneɪʃən, ɔfən ət ðə hænz ə ðɛɹ oʊn ɛɹz əɹ fɑloʊɝz. ʃi nu vɛɹi wɛl wʌɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ laɪk.

Fingering her chin thoughtfully, Bethamin studied the kneeling damane. She was suspicious of any damane who had called herself Aes Sedai. History fascinated her, and she had even read translations from the myriad of languages that had existed before the Consolidation began. Those ancient rulers reveled in their murderous, capricious rule, and delighted in setting down how they came to power and how they crushed neighboring states and undermined other rulers. Most had died by assassination, often at the hands of their own heirs or followers. She knew very well what Aes Sedai were like.

"tɛsi ɪz ə ɡʊd deɪmeɪn," ʃi mɝmɝd wɔɹmli, teɪkɪŋ wʌn ə ðə hɑɹd kændiz fɹəm ðə twɪst ə peɪpɝ ɪn əɹ bɛl paʊtʃ. tɛsi lin fɔɹwɝd tə ɹəsiv ɪɾ ən kɪs əɹ hæn ɪn θæŋks, bʌt ðə smaɪl slɪpt ə lɪɾəl, ðoʊ ɪt wɑz bæk baɪ ðə taɪm ʃi stʌf ðə ɹɛd kændi ɪndə hɝ maʊθ. soʊ. ɪt wɑz laɪk ðæt, wɑz ɪt? pɹitɛndɪŋ tə æksɛpt ɪn ɔɹɾɝ tə lʌl ðə sʌldəm wɑz nɑɾ ənnoʊn, bʌt ɡɪvən wʌt tɛsi hæd bɪn, vɛɹi laɪkli ʃi wɑz plɑɾɪŋ ɪskeɪp əz wɛl.

"Tessi is a good damane," she murmured warmly, taking one of the hard candies from the twist of paper in her belt pouch. Tessi leaned forward to receive it and kiss her hand in thanks, but the smile slipped a little, though it was back by the time she stuffed the red candy into her mouth. So. It was like that, was it? Pretending to accept in order to lull the sul'dam was not unknown, but given what Tessi had been, very likely she was plotting escape as well.

bæk aʊɾ ɪn ðə nɛɹoʊ hɔlweɪ, bɛθəmən ɹoʊɾ ə stʃɹɔŋ sədʒɛstʃən ðət tɛsiz tʃɹeɪnɪŋ bi ɹidʌbəld, əlɔŋ wɪð əɹ pʌnɪʃməns, ən əɹ ɹɪwɔɹdz bi meɪd spɝæɾɪk, soʊ ʃi kəd nɛvɝ bi ʃʊɹ ðəɾ ivən pɝfɛkʃən wəɾ ɝn soʊ mʌtʃ əz ə pæɾ ɑn ðə hɛd. ɪt wɑz ə hɑɹʃ mɛθəd, wʌn ʃi nɔɹməli əvɔɪɾəd, bʌt fəɹ səm ɹizən ɪt tɝn ivən ðə moʊst ɹɪkælsɪtʃɹən mɛɹəθdəmeɪn ɪndə ə sʌpəl deɪmeɪn ɪn ə ɹɪmɑɹkəbli ʃɔɹt taɪm. ɪɾ ɔlsoʊ pɹədus ðə mikəst ə deɪmeɪn. ʃi dɪslaɪk bɹeɪkɪŋ ə deɪmeɪnz spɪɹət, jɛt tɛsi niɾəd tə bi bɹoʊkən tə ði æɾəm soʊ ʃi kəd fɝɡɛt ðə pæst. ʃi wəd bi hæpiɝ fəɹ ɪt, ɪn ði ɛnd.

Back out in the narrow hallway, Bethamin wrote a strong suggestion that Tessi's training be redoubled, along with her punishments, and her rewards be made sporadic, so she could never be sure that even perfection would earn so much as a pat on the head. It was a harsh method, one she normally avoided, but for some reason it turned even the most recalcitrant marath'damane into a supple damane in a remarkably short time. It also produced the meekest of damane. She disliked breaking a damane's spirit, yet Tessi needed to be broken to the a'dam so she could forget the past. She would be happier for it, in the end.

fɪnɪʃɪŋ əhɛɾ ə ɹɛnə, bɛθəmən weɪɾəd ət ðə fʊɾ ə ðə stɛɹz əntɪl ði ʌðɝ sʌldəm keɪm daʊn. "teɪk ðɪs tə ɛsənd wən jə teɪk jʊɹz," ʃi sɛd, θɹʌstɪŋ əɹ ɹaɪɾɪŋ bɔɹɾ ət ɹɛnə bɪfɔɹ ʃi klɪɹd ðə faɪnəl stɛp. ʌnsɝpɹaɪzɪŋli, ɹɛnə æksɛptɪd ðə tæsk əz mikli əz ʃi hæɾ æksɛptɪd ði ɝliɝ ɔɹɾɝ, ən hɝiɾ əweɪ aɪɪŋ ði ɛkstʃɹə ɹaɪɾɪŋ bɔɹɾ əz ðoʊ wʌndɝɪŋ wɛðɝ ðə peɪdʒəz hɛld ə ɹipɔɹɾ ɑn hɝ. ʃi wɑz ə vɛɹi dɪfɹənt wʊmən ðən ʃi hæd bɪn bɪfɔɹ fɑlm.

Finishing ahead of Renna, Bethamin waited at the foot of the stairs until the other sul'dam came down. "Take this to Essonde when you take yours," she said, thrusting her writing board at Renna before she cleared the final step. Unsurprisingly, Renna accepted the task as meekly as she had accepted the earlier order, and hurried away eyeing the extra writing board as though wondering whether the pages held a report on her. She was a very different woman than she had been before Falme.

fɛtʃɪŋ əɹ kloʊk ən livɪŋ ðə pæləs, bɛθəmən ɪntɛndəd tə ɹɪtɝn tə ði ɪn wɛɹ ʃi wɑz fɔɹs tə ʃɛɹ ə bɛd wɪð tu ʌðɝ sʌldəm, bʌɾ oʊnli lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə teɪk səm kɔɪn fɹəm əɹ lɑkbɑks. ði ɪnspɛkʃən hæd bɪn əɹ oʊnli duɾi tədeɪ, ən ðə ɹɛst ə ði aʊɝz wɝ əɹ oʊn. fəɹ ə tʃeɪnʒ, ɪnstɛɾ ə sikɪŋ ɛkstʃɹə əsaɪnməns, ʃi wəd spɛn əm baɪɪŋ suvənɪɹz. pɝhæps wʌn ə ðoʊz naɪvz ðə loʊkəl wɪmən wɔɹ ət ðɛɹ nɛks, ɪf ʃi kəd faɪnd wʌn wɪθaʊt ðə dʒɛmz ðeɪ sim tə laɪk ɑn ðə hɪlt. ən lækɹwɛɹ, ʌv kɔɹs; ðət wɑz əz ɡʊd hɪɹ əz ɛni ɪn ði ɛmpaɪɝ, ən ðə dɪzaɪnz wɝ soʊ . . . fɔɹən. ɪt wəd bi suðɪŋ tə ʃɑp. ʃi niɾəd suðɪŋ.

Fetching her cloak and leaving the Palace, Bethamin intended to return to the inn where she was forced to share a bed with two other sul'dam, but only long enough to take some coin from her lockbox. The inspection had been her only duty today, and the rest of the hours were her own. For a change, instead of seeking extra assignments, she would spend them buying souvenirs. Perhaps one of those knives the local women wore at their necks, if she could find one without the gems they seemed to like on the hilt. And lacquerware, of course; that was as good here as any in the Empire, and the designs were so . . . foreign. It would be soothing to shop. She needed soothing.

ðə peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz ə ðə mɔl hɛɹə stɪl ɡlɪsən dæmpli fɹəm ðə mɔɹnɪŋz ɹeɪn, ən ə plɛzən tæŋ ə sɔl fɪl ði ɛɹ, ɹimaɪndɪŋ əɹ ə ðə vɪlədʒ ɑn ðə si ʌv liaɪ wɛɹ ʃi hæd bɪn bɔɹn, ðoʊ ðə fɹizɪŋ koʊl meɪɾ əɹ klʌtʃ əɹ kloʊk ɝaʊn hɝsɛlf. ɪt hæd nɛvɝ bɪn koʊld ɪn əbunaɪ, ən ʃi hæd nɛvɝ bɪkʌm əkʌstəm tə ɪt noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ fɑɹ ʃi hæd tʃɹævəld. θɔts ə hoʊm wɝ noʊ kʌmfɝt, naʊ, ðoʊ. əz ʃi meɪɾ əɹ weɪ θɹu ðə kɹaʊɾəd stʃɹits, ɹɛnə ən sɛɾə fɪld əɹ hɛd tə ði ɪkstɛn ðət ʃi bʌmpt ɪndə pipəl ən wʌns ɔlmoʊst wɔkt ɹaɪɾ ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ə mɝtʃəns tʃɹeɪn ʌv wæɡənz livɪŋ ðə sɪɾi. ə ʃaʊt fɹəm ə wæɡən dʒɹaɪvɝ kɑɾ əɹ ətɛnʃən, ən ʃi lɛp bæk dʒʌst ɪn taɪm. ðə wæɡən ɹʌmbəld əkɹɔs ðə peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz wɛɹ ʃi wʊɾə bɪn stændɪŋ, ən ðə wʊmən wildɪŋ ðə wɪp dɪd nɑɾ ivən ɡlæns ət hɝ. ðiz fɔɹənɝz hæd noʊ aɪdiə ʌv ðə ɹɪspɛk du ə sʌldəm.

The paving stones of the Mol Hara still glistened damply from the morning's rain, and a pleasant tang of salt filled the air, reminding her of the village on the Sea of L'Heye where she had been born, though the freezing cold made her clutch her cloak around herself. It had never been cold in Abunai, and she had never become accustomed to it no matter how far she had traveled. Thoughts of home were no comfort, now, though. As she made her way through the crowded streets, Renna and Seta filled her head to the extent that she bumped into people and once almost walked right in front of a merchant's train of wagons leaving the city. A shout from a wagon driver caught her attention, and she leaped back just in time. The wagon rumbled across the paving stones where she would have been standing, and the woman wielding the whip did not even glance at her. These foreigners had no idea of the respect due a sul'dam.

ɹɛnə ən sɛɾə. ɛvɹiwʌn u hæd bɪn ət fɑlm hæd mɛmɹiz ðeɪ wɑntəd tə fɝɡɛt, mɛmɹiz ðeɪ wəd nɑt tɔk əbaʊɾ ɪksɛpt wən ðeɪ dʒɹæŋk tu mʌtʃ. ʃi dɪd, tu, oʊnli hɝz wɝ nɑɾ əbaʊt ðə ʃɑk ə bæɾəlɪŋ hæf-ɹɛkəɡnaɪzd ɡoʊsts aʊɾ ə lɛdʒənd, əɹ ðə hɔɹɝ ə dɪfit, əɹ mæd vɪʒənz ɪn ðə skaɪ. haʊ ɔfən hæd ʃi wɪʃt ʃi hæd nɑt ɡɔn əpstɛɹz ðət deɪ? ɪf oʊnli ʃi hæd nɑt wʌndɝd haʊ tuli wɑz duɪŋ, ðə deɪmeɪn u hæd ðə mɑɹvələs skɪl wɪð mɛɾəlz. bʌt ʃi hæd lʊkt ɪndə tuliz kɛnəl. ən ʃi hæd sin ɹɛnə ən sɛɾə fɹæntəkəli tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɹimuv æɾəm fɹəm itʃ ʌðɝz nɛks, ʃɹikɪŋ wɪð ðə peɪn, weɪvɝɪŋ ɑn ðɛɹ niz fɹəm ðə nɔziə, ən stɪl fʌmbəlɪŋ ət ðə kɑlɝz. vɑmət steɪn ðə fɹʌns ə ðɛɹ dʒɹɛsəz. ɪn ðɛɹ fɹɛnzi ðeɪ hæd nɑt noʊɾəst əɹ bækɪŋ əweɪ, hɔɹɝ-stʃɹɪkən.

Renna and Seta. Everyone who had been at Falme had memories they wanted to forget, memories they would not talk about except when they drank too much. She did, too, only hers were not about the shock of battling half-recognized ghosts out of legend, or the horror of defeat, or mad visions in the sky. How often had she wished she had not gone upstairs that day? If only she had not wondered how Tuli was doing, the damane who had the marvelous skill with metals. But she had looked into Tuli's kennel. And she had seen Renna and Seta frantically trying to remove a'dam from each other's necks, shrieking with the pain, wavering on their knees from the nausea, and still fumbling at the collars. Vomit stained the fronts of their dresses. In their frenzy they had not noticed her backing away, horror-stricken.

nɑt sɪmpli hɔɹɝ ət siɪŋ tu sʌldəm ɹɪvild əz mɛɹəθdəmeɪn, bʌɾ əɹ oʊn sʌɾən pɝsənəl tɛɹɝ. ɔfən ʃi θɔt ʃi kəɾ ɔlmoʊst si deɪmeɪnz wivz, ən ʃi kəɾ ɔlweɪz sɛns ə deɪmeɪnz pɹɛzəns ən noʊ haʊ stʃɹɔŋ ʃi wɑz. mɛni sʌldəm kʊd; ɛvɹiwʌn nu ɪt keɪm fɹəm lɔŋ ɪkspɪɹiəns ət hænlɪŋ ði æɾəm. jɛt ðə saɪɾ ə ðət dɛspɹɪt pɛɹ ɹaʊzd ənwɔntɪd θɔts, pʊɾɪŋ ə dɪfɹən ən fɹaɪɾənɪŋ kəmplɛkʃən ɑn wʌt ʃi hæɾ ɔlweɪz æksɛptɪd. dɪd ʃi ɔlmoʊst si ðə wivz, əɹ dɪd ʃi ɹɪli si? səmtaɪmz ʃi θɔt ʃi fɛl ðə tʃænəlɪŋ, tu. ivən sʌldəm hæd tə ʌndɝɡoʊ ðə jɪɹli tɛstɪŋ, əntɪl ðɛɹ twɛnti-fɪfθ neɪmɪŋ deɪ, ən ʃi hæd pæs baɪ feɪlɪŋ ɛvɹi taɪm. oʊnli . . . ðəɹ wəd bi ə nu tɛstɪŋ æftɝ ɹɛnə ən sɛɾə wɝ dɪskʌvɝd, ə nu tɛstɪŋ tə faɪn ðə mɛɹəθdəmeɪn u sʌmhaʊ hæɾ ɪveɪɾɪd ðə fɝst. ði ɛmpaɪɝ ɪtsɛlf maɪt tʃɹɛmbəl bɪfɔɹ sətʃ ə bloʊ. ən wɪð ði ɪmədʒ ə ɹɛnə ən sɛɾə bɝn ɪndə hɝ bɹeɪn, ʃi hæd noʊn wɪð toʊɾəl sɝɾənti ðəɾ æftɝ ðoʊz tɛsts, bɛθəmən zimi wəd noʊ lɔŋɡɝ bi ə ɹɪspɛktɪd sɪɾəzən. ɪnstɛd, ə deɪmeɪn kɔl bɛθəmən wəd sɝv ði ɛmpaɪɝ.

Not simply horror at seeing two sul'dam revealed as marath'damane, but her own sudden personal terror. Often she thought she could almost see damane's weaves, and she could always sense a damane's presence and know how strong she was. Many sul'dam could; everyone knew it came from long experience at handling the a'dam. Yet the sight of that desperate pair roused unwanted thoughts, putting a different and frightening complexion on what she had always accepted. Did she almost see the weaves, or did she really see? Sometimes she thought she felt the channeling, too. Even sul'dam had to undergo the yearly testing, until their twenty-fifth naming day, and she had passed by failing every time. Only . . . There would be a new testing after Renna and Seta were discovered, a new testing to find the marath'damane who somehow had evaded the first. The Empire itself might tremble before such a blow. And with the image of Renna and Seta burned into her brain, she had known with total certainty that after those tests, Bethamin Zeami would no longer be a respected citizen. Instead, a damane called Bethamin would serve the Empire.

ðə ʃeɪm kɝɾəld ɪn əɹ stɪl. ʃi hæd pleɪs pɝsənəl fɪɹz əhɛɾ ə ðə nidz ə ði ɛmpaɪɝ, əhɛɾ ʌv ɛvɹiθɪŋ ʃi nu tə bi ɹaɪɾ ən tʃɹu ən ɡʊd. bæɾəl keɪm tə fɑlm, ən naɪtmɛɹ, bʌt ʃi hæd nɑt ɹʌʃt tə kəmplit hɝsɛlf wɪð ə deɪmeɪn ən dʒɔɪn ðə bæɾəl laɪn. ɪnstɛd, ʃi hæd juz ðə kənfjuʒən tə sɪkjʊɹ ə hɔɹs ən fli, tə ɹʌn əz hɑɹɾ ən əz fɑɹ əz ʃi kʊd.

The shame curdled in her still. She had placed personal fears ahead of the needs of the Empire, ahead of everything she knew to be right and true and good. Battle came to Falme, and nightmare, but she had not rushed to complete herself with a damane and join the battle line. Instead, she had used the confusion to secure a horse and flee, to run as hard and as far as she could.

ʃi ɹilaɪzd ʃi hæd stɑpt, stɛɹɪŋ ɪndə ə simstʃɹɪsəz ʃɑp wɪndoʊ wɪθaʊt ɹɪli siɪŋ wʌt wɑz ɑn dɪspleɪ ɪnsaɪd. nɑt ðət ʃi wɑntəd tə si. ðə blu dʒɹɛs wɪð ɪts laɪtnɪŋ-mɑɹkt ɹɛd pænəlz wɑz ði oʊnli wʌn ʃi hæd θɔɾ ʌv wɛɹɪŋ ɪn jɪɹz. ən ʃi sɝɾənli wəd nɑt wɛɹ sʌmθɪŋ ðəɾ ɪkspoʊzd əɹ soʊ ɪndɪsənli. skɝts swɝlɪŋ əbaʊɾ əɹ æŋkəlz, ʃi wɔkt ɑn, bʌt ʃi kəd nɑt ʃeɪk ɹɛnə ən sɛɾə fɹəm əɹ θɔts, əɹ sjuɹɔθ.

She realized she had stopped, staring into a seamstress's shop window without really seeing what was on display inside. Not that she wanted to see. The blue dress with its lightning-marked red panels was the only one she had thought of wearing in years. And she certainly would not wear something that exposed her so indecently. Skirts swirling about her ankles, she walked on, but she could not shake Renna and Seta from her thoughts, or Suroth.

ɑbviəsli ælwɪn hæd faʊn ðə kɑlɝd pɛɹ ə sʌldəm ən ɹipɔɹɾəd əm tə sjuɹɔθ. ən sjuɹɔθ hæd ʃɛltɝd ði ɛmpaɪɝ baɪ pɹətɛktɪŋ ɹɛnə ən sɛɾə, deɪnʒɝəs əz ðət wɑz. wʌɾ ɪf ðeɪ sʌɾənli bɪɡæn tʃænəlɪŋ? bɛɾɝ pɝhæps fəɹ ði ɛmpaɪɝ ɪf ʃi hæɾ ɝeɪnʒd ðɛɹ dɛθs, ðoʊ kɪlɪŋ ə sʌldəm wɑz mɝɾɝ ivən fəɹ ðə haɪ blʌd. tu səspɪʃəs dɛθs əmʌŋ ðə sʌldəm wəd sɝɾənli hæv bɹɔɾ ɪn sikɝz. soʊ ɹɛnə ən sɛɾə wɝ fɹi, ɪf ɪt kəd bi kɔl ðət wən ðeɪ wɝ nɛvɝ əlaʊd tə bi kəmplit. ælwɪn hæd dʌn əɹ duɾi, ən bɪn ɑnɝd baɪ bɪkʌmɪŋ sjuɹɔθs vɔɪs. sjuɹɔθ hæd dʌn əɹ duɾi əz wɛl, haʊɛvɝ dɪsteɪsfəl. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ nu tɛstɪŋ. hɝ oʊn flaɪt hæd bɪn fəɹ nʌθɪŋ. ən ɪf ʃi hæd ɹɪmeɪnd, ʃi wəd nɑɾ əv ɛndəɾ ʌp ɪn tæntʃəkoʊ, ə naɪtmɛɹ ʃi wɑntəd tə fɝɡɛɾ ivən mɔɹ ðən ʃi dɪd fɑlm.

Obviously Alwhin had found the collared pair of sul'dam and reported them to Suroth. And Suroth had sheltered the Empire by protecting Renna and Seta, dangerous as that was. What if they suddenly began channeling? Better perhaps for the Empire if she had arranged their deaths, though killing a sul'dam was murder even for the High Blood. Two suspicious deaths among the sul'dam would certainly have brought in Seekers. So Renna and Seta were free, if it could be called that when they were never allowed to be complete. Alwhin had done her duty, and been honored by becoming Suroth's Voice. Suroth had done her duty as well, however distasteful. There was no new testing. Her own flight had been for nothing. And if she had remained, she would not have ended up in Tanchico, a nightmare she wanted to forget even more than she did Falme.

ə skwɑɾ ə ðə dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹdz mɑɹtʃt baɪ, ɹisplɛndən ɪn ðɛɹ ɑɹmɝ, ən bɛθəmən pɔz tə wɑtʃ əm pæs. ðeɪ lɛft ə weɪk θɹu ðə kɹaʊd laɪk ə ɡɹieɪtʃɪp ʌndɝ fʊl seɪl. ðəɹ wəd bi dʒɔɪ ɪn ðə sɪɾi, ɪn ðə lænd, wən tuɑn faɪnəli ɹɪvil hɝsɛlf, ən sɛləbɹeɪʃənz əz ðoʊ ʃi hæd dʒʌst ɝaɪvd. ʃi fɛlt ə ɡɪlti plɛʒɝ ət θɪŋkɪŋ ə ðə dɔɾɝ ə ðə naɪn munz soʊ, əz wən ʃi hæd dʌn sʌmθɪŋ fɔɹbɪɾən əz ə tʃaɪld, ðoʊ ʌv kɔɹs, əntɪl tuɑn ɹimuvd əɹ veɪl, ʃi wɑz mɪɹli ðə haɪ leɪɾi tuɑn, noʊ haɪɝ ðən sjuɹɔθ. ðə dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹdz tʃɹæmpt ɑn, dɛɾəkeɪtəd hɑɹɾ ən soʊl tə ɛmpɹɛs ən ɛmpaɪɝ, ən bɛθəmən wɛn ɪn ði ɑpəzət dɝɛkʃən. əpɹoʊpɹiɪtli, sɪns ʃi wɑz dɛɾəkeɪtəd hɑɹɾ ən soʊl tə pɹəzɝvɪŋ əɹ oʊn fɹiɾəm.

A squad of the Deathwatch Guards marched by, resplendent in their armor, and Bethamin paused to watch them pass. They left a wake through the crowd like a greatship under full sail. There would be joy in the city, in the land, when Tuon finally revealed herself, and celebrations as though she had just arrived. She felt a guilty pleasure at thinking of the Daughter of the Nine Moons so, as when she had done something forbidden as a child, though of course, until Tuon removed her veil, she was merely the High Lady Tuon, no higher than Suroth. The Deathwatch Guards tramped on, dedicated heart and soul to Empress and Empire, and Bethamin went in the opposite direction. Appropriately, since she was dedicated heart and soul to preserving her own freedom.

ðə ɡoʊldən swɑnz ə hɛvən wɑz ə ɡɹænd neɪm fəɹ ə taɪni ɪn skwiz bɪtwin ə pʌblɪk steɪbəl ən ə lækɹwɛɹ ʃɑp. ðə lækɹwɛɹ ʃɑp wɑz fʊl ə mɪlətɛɹi ɔfəsɝz baɪɪŋ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ðə ʃɑp kənteɪnd, ðə steɪbəl wɑz fʊl ə hɔɹsəz pɝtʃəst ɪn ðə lɑɾɝi ən nɑt jɛɾ əsaɪnd, ən ðə ɡoʊldən swɑnz wɑz fʊl ə sʌldəm. pækt wɪð ðɛm, ɪn fækt, ət list wʌns naɪt keɪm. bɛθəmən wɑz lʌki tə hæv oʊnli tu bɛdmeɪts. ɔɹɾɝd tə əkɑmədeɪɾ əz mɛni əz ʃi kʊd, ði ɪnkipɝ pʊʃt fɔɹ ən faɪv ɪndə ə bɛd wən ʃi θɔt ðeɪ wəd fɪt. stɪl, ðə bɛɾɪŋ wɑz klin ən ðə fud kwaɪt ɡʊd, ɪf pəkjuljɝ. ən ɡɪvən ðət ði ɔltɝnəɾɪv wɑz laɪkli ə heɪlɔft, ʃi wɑz ɡlæd tə ʃɛɹ.

The Golden Swans of Heaven was a grand name for a tiny inn squeezed between a public stable and a lacquerware shop. The lacquerware shop was full of military officers buying everything the shop contained, the stable was full of horses purchased in the lottery and not yet assigned, and The Golden Swans was full of sul'dam. Packed with them, in fact, at least once night came. Bethamin was lucky to have only two bedmates. Ordered to accommodate as many as she could, the innkeeper pushed four and five into a bed when she thought they would fit. Still, the bedding was clean and the food quite good, if peculiar. And given that the alternative was likely a hayloft, she was glad to share.

ət ðɪs aʊɝ, ðə ɹaʊn teɪbəlz ɪn ðə kɑmən ɹum wɝ ɛmpti. səm ə ðə sʌldəm lɪvɪŋ ðəɹ ʃʊɹli hæd duɾiz, ən ðə ɹɛst sɪmpli wɑntəd tə əvɔɪd ði ɪnkipɝ. ɑɹmz foʊldəd, fɹaʊnɪŋ, dɑɹnɛlə ʃɔɝən wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ sɛvɹəl sɝvɪŋ wɪmən swip ðə ɡɹin-taɪl flɔɹ ɪndʌstʃɹiəsli. ə skɪni wʊmən wɪð ɡɹeɪ hɛɹ wɔɹn ɹoʊld ɑn ðə neɪp ə hɝ nɛk ən ə lɔŋ dʒɔ ðət ɡeɪv əɹ ə bəlɪdʒɝən əpɪɹəns, ʃi maɪɾ əv bɪn ə dɝsʌldəm ɪn spaɪɾ ə ðə ɹɪdɪkjələs naɪf ʃi wɔɹ, ɪts hɪl stʌɾɪd wɪð tʃip ɹɛɾ ən waɪt dʒɛmz. səpoʊzədli ðə sɝvɪŋ wɪmən wɝ fɹi, bʌt ðeɪ dʒʌmp laɪk pɹɑpɝɾi wɛnɛvɝ ði ɪnkipɝ spoʊk.

At this hour, the round tables in the common room were empty. Some of the sul'dam living there surely had duties, and the rest simply wanted to avoid the innkeeper. Arms folded, frowning, Darnella Shoran was watching several serving women sweep the green-tiled floor industriously. A skinny woman with gray hair worn rolled on the nape of her neck and a long jaw that gave her a belligerent appearance, she might have been a der'sul'dam in spite of the ridiculous knife she wore, its hilt studded with cheap red and white gems. Supposedly the serving women were free, but they jumped like property whenever the innkeeper spoke.

bɛθəmən dʒʌmp slaɪtli hɝsɛlf wən ðə wʊmən ɹaʊndəɾ ɑn hɝ. "ju ɑɹ əwɛɹ ə maɪ ɹulz kənsɝnɪŋ mɛn, mɪstʃɹəs zimi?" ʃi dɪmændəd. æftɝ ɔl ðɪs taɪm, ðə sloʊ weɪ ðiz pipəl tɔk stɪl saʊndəɾ ɑd. "aɪv hɝɾ əbaʊt jəɹ fɔɹən weɪz, ən ɪf ðəɾ ɪz haʊ jə ɑɹ, ɪts jəɹ bɪznəs, bʌt nɑɾ ʌndɝ maɪ ɹuf. ɪf jə wɑnə mit wɪð mɛn, jəl də ɪɾ ɛlswɛɹ!"

Bethamin jumped slightly herself when the woman rounded on her. "You are aware of my rules concerning men, Mistress Zeami?" she demanded. After all this time, the slow way these people talked still sounded odd. "I've heard about your foreign ways, and if that is how you are, it is your business, but not under my roof. If you want to meet with men, you will do it elsewhere!"

"aɪ əʃʊɹ ju, aɪ hæv nɑt bɪn miɾɪŋ mɛn hɪɹ əɹ ɛniwɛɹ ɛls, mɪstʃɹəs ʃɔɝən."

"I assure you, I have not been meeting men here or anywhere else, Mistress Shoran."

ði ɪnkipɝ fɹaʊn əɾ əɹ ɪn səspɪʃən. "wɛl, hi keɪm ɝaʊn æskɪŋ fəɹ jə baɪ neɪm. ə pɹɪɾi, jɛloʊ-hɛɹd mæn. nɑɾ ə bɔɪ, bʌt nɑt vɛɹi oʊld, iðɝ. wʌn ə jəɹ lɑt, dʒɹæɡɪŋ ɪz wɝdz aʊt soʊ jə kəd hɑɹdli ʌndɝstæn hɪm."

The innkeeper frowned at her in suspicion. "Well, he came around asking for you by name. A pretty, yellow-haired man. Not a boy, but not very old, either. One of your lot, dragging his words out so you could hardly understand him."

meɪkɪŋ əɹ toʊn pleɪkeɪɾɪŋ, bɛθəmən dɪɾ əɹ bɛs tə kənvɪns ðə wʊmən ðət ʃi dɪd nɑt noʊ ɛniwʌn u mɛt ðət dɪskɹɪpʃən, ən ðət ʃi hæd noʊ taɪm fəɹ mɛn wɪð əɹ duɾiz. boʊθ wɝ tʃɹu, jɛt ʃi wʊɾə laɪɾ ɪf nɛsəsɛɹi. ðə ɡoʊldən swɑnz hæd nɑt bɪn kɑməndɪɹd, ən θɹi ɪn ə bɛd wɑz mʌtʃ pɹɛfɝəbəl tə ə heɪlɔft. ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə faɪn aʊt wɛðɝ ðə wʊmən maɪt laɪk səm smɔl ɡɪft wən ʃi wɛnt ʃɑpɪŋ, bʌt ðə wʊmən æktʃəli  simd əfɛndəd wən ʃi sədʒɛstəɾ ə naɪf wɪð mɔɹ kʌlɝfəl dʒɛmz. ʃi hæd nɑt mɛn ɛniθɪŋ ɪkspɛnsɪv, nʌθɪŋ ɪn ðə weɪ ʌv ə bɹaɪb - nɑt ɹɪli - jɛt mɪstʃɹəs ʃɔɝən sim tə teɪk ɪt soʊ, hʌfɪŋ ən fɹaʊnɪŋ ɪndɪɡnənli. ɪn ɛni keɪs, ʃi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ ʃi səksiɾəd ɪn tʃeɪnʒɪŋ ðə wʊmənz maɪn baɪ ə hɛɹ. fəɹ səm ɹizən, ði ɪnkipɝ sim tə bɪliv ðeɪ spɛn ɔl ðɛɹ fɹi aʊɝz ɛnɡeɪdʒd ɪn dəbɔtʃɝi. ʃi wɑz stɪl fɹaʊnɪŋ wən bɛθəmən stɑɹɾəd ʌp ðə ɹeɪləs stɛɹz ət ðə saɪɾ ə ðə kɑmən ɹum pɹitɛndɪŋ ðət ʃi hæd nɑɾ ə θɔɾ ɪn əɹ maɪn bɪɑnd ʃɑpɪŋ.

Making her tone placating, Bethamin did her best to convince the woman that she did not know anyone who met that description, and that she had no time for men with her duties. Both were true, yet she would have lied if necessary. The Golden Swans had not been commandeered, and three in a bed was much preferable to a hayloft. She tried to find out whether the woman might like some small gift when she went shopping, but the woman actually seemed offended when she suggested a knife with more colorful gems. She had not meant anything expensive, nothing in the way of a bribe - not really - yet Mistress Shoran seemed to take it so, huffing and frowning indignantly. In any case, she was not sure she succeeded in changing the woman's mind by a hair. For some reason, the innkeeper seemed to believe they spent all their free hours engaged in debauchery. She was still frowning when Bethamin started up the railless stairs at the side of the common room pretending that she had not a thought in her mind beyond shopping.

ðə mænz aɪdɛntəɾi dɪd kənsɝn hɝ, ðoʊ. ʃi sɝɾənli dɪd nɑt ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðə dɪskɹɪpʃən. ɪn ɔl laɪklihʊd, hi hæd kʌm əbaʊɾ əɹ ɪnkwaɪɝiz, bʌɾ ɪf ðət wɑz ðə keɪs, ɪf i hæd bɪn eɪbəl tə tʃɹeɪs əɹ hɪɹ, ðən ʃi hæd bɪn ɪnsəfɪʃənli dɪskɹit. pɝhæps deɪnʒɝəsli soʊ. stɪl, ʃi hoʊpt i keɪm bæk. ʃi niɾəd tə noʊ. ʃi niɾəd tə!

The man's identity did concern her, though. She certainly did not recognize the description. In all likelihood, he had come about her inquiries, but if that was the case, if he had been able to trace her here, then she had been insufficiently discreet. Perhaps dangerously so. Still, she hoped he came back. She needed to know. She needed to!

oʊpənɪŋ ðə dɔɹ tə hɝ ɹum, ʃi fɹoʊz. ɪmpɑsəbli, hɝ aɪɝn lɑkbɑks sæɾ ɑn ðə bɛd wɪð ɪts lɪd θɹoʊn oʊpən. ðət wɑz ə vɛɹi ɡʊd lɑk, ən ði oʊnli ki leɪ ət ðə bɑɾəm ə hɝ bɛl paʊtʃ. ðə θif wɑz stɪl ðɛɹ, ən ɑdli, hi wɑz θʌmɪŋ θɹu hɝ daɪɝi! haʊ ɪn ðə laɪt hæd ðə mæn ɡɑɾən pæs mɪstʃɹəs ʃɔɝənz sɝveɪləns?

Opening the door to her room, she froze. Impossibly, her iron lockbox sat on the bed with its lid thrown open. That was a very good lock, and the only key lay at the bottom of her belt pouch. The thief was still there, and oddly, he was thumbing through her diary! How in the Light had the man gotten past Mistress Shoran's surveillance?

pɝæləsəs læstəɾ oʊnli ən ɪnstənt. snætʃɪŋ əɹ bɛl naɪf fɹəm ɪts ʃiθ, ʃi oʊpən əɹ maʊθ tə skɹim fəɹ hɛlp.

Paralysis lasted only an instant. Snatching her belt knife from its sheath, she opened her mouth to scream for help.

ðə fɛloʊz ɪkspɹɛʃən nɛvɝ tʃeɪnʒd, ən i niðɝ tʃɹaɪd tə ɹʌn nɔɹ tə ətæk hɝ. hi dʒʌs tʊk sʌmθɪŋ smɔl fɹəm ɪz paʊtʃ ən hɛld ɪɾ ʌp wɛɹ ʃi kəd si ɪt, ən əɹ bɹɛθ tɝn tə liɾ ɪn əɹ θɹoʊt. nʌmbli ʃi fʌmbəld əɹ naɪf bæk ɪndə ɪts skæbɝɾ ən hɛld aʊɾ əɹ hænz tə ʃoʊ hɪm ʃi hɛl noʊ wɛpən ən wɑz nɑɾ ətɛmptɪŋ tə ɹitʃ wʌn. bɪtwin ɪz fɪŋɡɝz wɑz ə ɡoʊld-ɛdʒd aɪvɝi plæk, ɪnɡɹeɪvd wɪð ə ɹeɪvən ən ə taʊɝ. sʌɾənli ʃi ɹɪli sɔ ðə mæn, jɛloʊ-hɛɹɾ ən ɪn ɪz mɪɾəl jɪɹz. pɝhæps i wɑz pɹɪɾi, əz mɪstʃɹəs ʃɔɝən hæd sɛd, bʌɾ oʊnli ə mædwʊmən wəd θɪŋk ʌv ə sikɝ fəɹ tʃɹuθ ɪn ðət fæʃən. θæŋk ðə laɪt ʃi hæd nɑt ɹəkɔɹɾəd ɛniθɪŋ deɪnʒɝəs ɪn əɹ daɪɝi. bʌɾ i mʌs noʊ. hi hæɾ æsk fəɹ əɹ baɪ neɪm. oʊ, laɪt, hi mʌs noʊ!

The fellow's expression never changed, and he neither tried to run nor to attack her. He just took something small from his pouch and held it up where she could see it, and her breath turned to lead in her throat. Numbly she fumbled her knife back into its scabbard and held out her hands to show him she held no weapon and was not attempting to reach one. Between his fingers was a gold-edged ivory plaque, engraved with a raven and a tower. Suddenly she really saw the man, yellow-haired and in his middle years. Perhaps he was pretty, as Mistress Shoran had said, but only a madwoman would think of a Seeker for Truth in that fashion. Thank the Light she had not recorded anything dangerous in her diary. But he must know. He had asked for her by name. Oh, Light, he must know!

"kloʊz ðə dɔɹ," hi sɛd kwaɪətli, ɹɪtɝnɪŋ ðə plæk tə hɪz paʊtʃ, ən ʃi oʊbeɪd. ʃi wɑntəd tə ɹʌn. ʃi wɑntəd tə plid fəɹ mɝsi. bʌɾ i wɑz ə sikɝ, soʊ ʃi stʊd ðɛɹ, tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ. tə hɝ sɝpɹaɪz, hi dʒɹɑpt əɹ daɪɝi bæk ɪndə ðə lɑkbɑks ən dʒɛstʃɝd tə ðə ɹumz sɪŋɡəl tʃɛɹ. "sɪt. ðəɹ ɪz noʊ nid fəɹ jə tə bi ənkʌmftəɹbəl."

"Close the door," he said quietly, returning the plaque to his pouch, and she obeyed. She wanted to run. She wanted to plead for mercy. But he was a Seeker, so she stood there, trembling. To her surprise, he dropped her diary back into the lockbox and gestured to the room's single chair. "Sit. There is no need for you to be uncomfortable."

sloʊli, ʃi hʌŋ ʌp əɹ kloʊk ən sɛɾəld ɑntu ðə tʃɛɹ, fəɹ wʌns nɑt kɛɹɪŋ haʊ ənkʌmftəɹbəl ðə stʃɹeɪnʒ læɾɝlaɪk bæk wɑz. ʃi dɪd nɑt tʃɹaɪ tə haɪɾ əɹ ʃɪvɝz. ivən wʌn ə ðə blʌd, ivən wʌn ə ðə haɪ blʌd, maɪt, kweɪk ət biɪŋ kwɛstʃən baɪ ə sikɝ. ʃi hæɾ ə smɔl hoʊp. hi hæd nɑt sɪmpli ɔɹɾɝd əɹ tə əkʌmpəni hɪm. pɝhæps i dɪd nɑt noʊ æftɝ ɔl.

Slowly, she hung up her cloak and settled onto the chair, for once not caring how uncomfortable the strange ladderlike back was. She did not try to hide her shivers. Even one of the Blood, even one of the High Blood, might, quake at being questioned by a Seeker. She had a small hope. He had not simply ordered her to accompany him. Perhaps he did not know after all.

"ju hæv bɪn æskɪŋ kwɛstʃənz əbaʊɾ ə ʃɪp kæptən neɪmd ɛdʒiənɪn sɑɹnə," hi sɛd. "waɪ?"

"You have been asking questions about a ship captain named Egeanin Sarna," he said. "Why?"

hoʊp fɔltɝd wɪð ə θʌd ʃi kəd fil ɪn əɹ tʃɛst. "aɪ wɑz lʊkɪŋ fəɹ ən oʊl fɹɛnd," ʃi kweɪvɝd. ðə bɛs laɪz ɔlweɪz kənteɪn əz mʌtʃ tʃɹuθ əz pɑsəbəl. "wi wɝ ət fɑlm təɡɛðɝ. aɪ doʊnt noʊ wɛðɝ ʃi sɝvaɪvd." laɪɪŋ tə ə sikɝ wɑz tʃɹizən, bʌt ʃi hæd kəmɪɾəd əɹ fɝs tʃɹizən ɪn dɛzɝɾɪŋ dʊɹɪŋ ðə bæɾəl ət fɑlm.

Hope faltered with a thud she could feel in her chest. "I was looking for an old friend," she quavered. The best lies always contained as much truth as possible. "We were at Falme together. I don't know whether she survived." Lying to a Seeker was treason, but she had committed her first treason in deserting during the battle at Falme.

"ʃi lɪvz," hi sɛd kɝtli. hi sæt daʊn ɑn ði ɛn ə ðə bɛd wɪθaʊt teɪkɪŋ ɪz aɪz fɹəm hɝ. ðeɪ wɝ blu, ən meɪɾ əɹ wɑn əɹ kloʊk bæk. "ʃi ɪz ə hɪɹoʊ, ə kæptən ə ðə ɡɹin, ən ðə leɪɾi ɛdʒiənɪn tæmɝəθ, naʊ. hɝ ɹɪwɔɹd fɹəm ðə haɪ leɪɾi sjuɹɔθ. ʃiz ɔlsoʊ hɪɹ ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ. jəl ɹɪnu jəɹ fɹɛndʃɪp wɪð hɝ. ən ɹipɔɹt tə mi hu ʃi siz, wɛɹ ʃi ɡoʊz, wʌt ʃi sɛz. ɛvɹiθɪŋ."

"She lives," he said curtly. He sat down on the end of the bed without taking his eyes from her. They were blue, and made her want her cloak back. "She is a hero, a Captain of the Green, and the Lady Egeanin Tamarath, now. Her reward from the High Lady Suroth. She is also here in Ebou Dar. You will renew your friendship with her. And report to me who she sees, where she goes, what she says. Everything."

bɛθəmən klæmpt əɹ dʒɔz tə kip fɹəm læfɪŋ hɪstɛɹɪkli. hi wɑz æftɝ ɛdʒiənɪn, nɑt hɝ. ðə laɪt bi pɹeɪzd! ðə laɪt bi pɹeɪzd ɪn ɔl ɪts ɪnfənət mɝsi! ʃi hæɾ oʊnli wɑntəd tə noʊ ɪf ðə wʊmən stɪl lɪvd, ɪf ʃi hæd tə teɪk pɹikɔʃənz. ɛdʒiənɪn hæd fɹiɾ əɹ wʌns, jɛɾ ɪn ðə tɛn jɪɹz bɛθəmən hæd noʊn əɹ bɪfɔɹ ðæt, ʃi hæd bɪn ə mɑɾəl ə duɾi. ɪt hæɾ ɔlweɪz sim pɑsəbəl ʃi wəd ɹɪpɛn ðət wʌn æbɝeɪʃən noʊ mæɾɝ ðə kɑs tə hɝsɛlf, bʌt, wʌndɝ ʌv wʌndɝz, ʃi hæd nɑt. ən ðə sikɝ wɑz æftɝ hɝ, nɑt . . . ! pɑsəbɪləɾiz ɹɪɹɾ ʌp ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ, sɝɾəntiz, ən ʃi noʊ lɔŋɡɝ wɑntəd tə læf. ɪnstɛd, ʃi lɪkt əɹ lɪps.

Bethamin clamped her jaws to keep from laughing hysterically. He was after Egeanin, not her. The Light be praised! The Light be praised in all its infinite mercy! She had only wanted to know if the woman still lived, if she had to take precautions. Egeanin had freed her once, yet in the ten years Bethamin had known her before that, she had been a model of duty. It had always seemed possible she would repent that one aberration no matter the cost to herself, but, wonder of wonders, she had not. And the Seeker was after her, not . . . ! Possibilities reared up in front of her, certainties, and she no longer wanted to laugh. Instead, she licked her lips.

"haʊ . . . ? haʊ kən aɪ ɹɪnu əɹ fɹɛndʃɪp?" ɪt hæd nɛvɝ bɪn fɹɛndʃɪp ɛniweɪ, mɪɹli əkweɪntəns, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz tu leɪt tə seɪ ðət naʊ. "ju tɛl mi ʃiz bɪn ɹeɪz tə ðə blʌd. ɛni oʊvɝtʃɝ mʌs kʌm fɹəm hɝ." fɪɹ ɛmboʊldən hɝ. ən pænɪkt əɹ əz ɪt hæɾ ət fɑlm. "waɪ dʒju nid mi tə bi jəɹ lɪsənɝ? jə kən teɪk əɹ fəɹ kwɛstʃənɪŋ ɛni taɪm jə dɪsaɪd tə." ʃi bɪt ði ɪnsaɪɾ ə hɝ tʃik tə stɪl əɹ tʌŋ. laɪt, ʃi wɑntəd nʌθɪŋ lɛs ðən ʃi wɑntəɾ ɪm tə də ðæt. sikɝz wɝ ðə sikɹət hæn ə ði ɛmpɹɛs, maɪt ʃi laɪv fɝɛvɝ; ɪn ði ɛmpɹɛsəz neɪm, hi kəd pʊɾ ivən sjuɹɔθ tə ðə kwɛstʃən, əɹ tuɑn hɝsɛlf. tʃɹu, hi wəd daɪ hɔɹəbli ɪf ɪt tɝn aʊɾ i hæd bɪn ɪn ɛɹɝ, bʌt ðə ɹɪsk wɑz smɔl wɪð ɛdʒiənɪn. ʃi wɑz oʊnli ʌv ðə loʊ blʌd. ɪf i pʊɾ ɛdʒiənɪn tə ðə kwɛstʃən . . .

"How . . . ? How can I renew our friendship?" It had never been friendship anyway, merely acquaintance, but it was too late to say that now. "You tell me she's been raised to the Blood. Any overture must come from her." Fear emboldened her. And panicked her as it had at Falme. "Why do you need me to be your Listener? You can take her for questioning any time you decide to." She bit the inside of her cheek to still her tongue. Light, she wanted nothing less than she wanted him to do that. Seekers were the secret hand of the Empress, might she live forever; in the Empress's name, he could put even Suroth to the question, or Tuon herself. True, he would die horribly if it turned out he had been in error, but the risk was small with Egeanin. She was only of the low Blood. If he put Egeanin to the question . . .

tə hɝ ʃɑk, ɹæðɝ ðən sɪmpli tɛlɪŋ əɹ tə oʊbeɪ, hi sæt stʌɾiɪŋ hɝ. "aɪ wɪl ɪkspleɪn sɝɾən θɪŋz," hi sɛd, ən ðət wɑz ə ɡɹeɪɾɝ ʃɑk. sikɝz nɛvɝ ɪkspleɪnd, soʊ ʃi hæd hɝd. "ju ɑɹ noʊ jus tə mi, əɹ ði ɛmpaɪɝ, ənlɛs jə sɝvaɪv, ən jəl nɑt sɝvaɪv ɪf jə feɪl tə ʌndɝstænd wʌt jə feɪs. ɪf jə ɹɪvil ə wɝɾ ʌv wʌɾ aɪ tɛl jə tə ɛniwʌn, jəl dʒɹim ə ðə taʊɝ ə ðə ɹeɪvənz əz ə ɹɛspɪt fɹəm wɛɹ jəl faɪn jɝsɛlf. lɪsən, ən lɝn. ɛdʒiənɪn wɑz sɛn tə tæntʃəkoʊ bɪfɔɹ ðə sɪɾi fɛl tə ʌs, əmʌŋ ʌðɝ θɪŋz əz pɑɹɾ ə ði ɛfɝt tə faɪn sʌldəm u hæd bɪn lɛf bɪhaɪn ət fɑlm. stʃɹeɪnʒli, ʃi faʊnd nʌn, ðoʊ ʌðɝz dɪd, laɪk ðoʊz u eɪɾəd jəɹ oʊn ɹɪtɝn. ɪnstɛd, ɛdʒiənɪn mɝɾɝd ðə sʌldəm ʃi faʊnd. aɪ pʊt ðə tʃɑɹdʒ tə hɝ maɪsɛlf, ən ʃi dɪd nɑt bɑðɝ dɪnaɪɪŋ ɪt. ʃi dɪd nɑɾ ivən ʃoʊ aʊtʃɹeɪdʒ, əɹ ivən ɪndɪɡneɪʃən. əz bæd, ʃi kənsɔɹɾɪd ɪn sikɹət wɪð ɛɛs sədaɪ." hi sɛd ðə neɪm flætli, nɑt wɪð ðə nɔɹməl dɪsɡʌs bʌt ɹæðɝ laɪk ən ækjəzeɪʃən. "wɛn ʃi dɪpɑɹɾəd tæntʃəkoʊ, ʃi wɑz tʃɹævlɪŋ ɑn ə ʃɪp kəmændəd baɪ ə mæn neɪm beɪl doʊmən. hi meɪd səm dɪstɝbəns ət hævɪŋ ɪz ʃɪp bɔɹɾəd ən wɑz meɪd pɹɑpɝɾi. ʃi bɑɾ ɪm ən ɪmiɾiətli meɪɾ ɪm sɔɪhɪn, soʊ pleɪnli hiz ə səm ɪmpɔɹɾəns tə hɝ. ɪntɝɛstɪŋli, ʃi hæd bɹɔt ðə seɪm mæn tə ðə haɪ lɔɹd tʃɹɑk ɪn fɑlm. doʊmən ɛnɡeɪdʒ ðə haɪ lɔɹdz ɹəɡɑɹd tə ði ɪkstɛn ðət ðə fɛloʊ wɑz ɔfən ɪnvaɪɾəd tə kənvɝs wɪð hɪm." hi ɡɹɪməst. "du juv waɪn? əɹ bɹændi?"

To her shock, rather than simply telling her to obey, he sat studying her. "I will explain certain things," he said, and that was a greater shock. Seekers never explained, so she had heard. "You are no use to me, or the Empire, unless you survive, and you will not survive if you fail to understand what you face. If you reveal a word of what I tell you to anyone, you will dream of the Tower of the Ravens as a respite from where you will find yourself. Listen, and learn. Egeanin was sent to Tanchico before the city fell to us, among other things as part of the effort to find sul'dam who had been left behind at Falme. Strangely, she found none, though others did, like those who aided your own return. Instead, Egeanin murdered the sul'dam she found. I put the charge to her myself, and she did not bother denying it. She did not even show outrage, or even indignation. As bad, she consorted in secret with Aes Sedai." He said the name flatly, not with the normal disgust but rather like an accusation. "When she departed Tanchico, she was traveling on a ship commanded by a man named Bayle Domon. He made some disturbance at having his ship boarded and was made property. She bought him and immediately made him so'jhin, so plainly he is of some importance to her. Interestingly, she had brought the same man to the High Lord Turak in Falme. Domon engaged the High Lord's regard to the extent that the fellow was often invited to converse with him." He grimaced. "Do you have wine? Or brandy?"

bɛθəmən ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt. "aɪoʊnə hæz ə flæsk ə ðə loʊkəl bɹændi, aɪ θɪŋk. ɪts ə ɹʌf dʒɹɪŋk. . . ."

Bethamin gave a start. "Iona has a flask of the local brandy, I think. It's a rough drink. . . ."

hi ɔɹɾɝd əɹ tə pɔɹ ɪm ə kʌp ɛniweɪ, ən ʃi oʊbeɪd hɝidli. ʃi wɑntəd tə kip ɪm tɔkɪŋ, ɛniθɪŋ tə dɪleɪ ði ɪnɛvəɾəbəl. ʃi nu fəɹ ə fæk ðəɾ ɛdʒiənɪn hæd nɑt bɪn kɪlɪŋ sʌldəm, jɛɾ əɹ pɹuf wəd kəndɛm əɹ tə ʃɛɹ ɹɛnə ən sɛɾəz saʊɝ feɪt. ɪf ʃi wɑz lʌki. ɪf ðɪs sikɝ sɔ hɪz duɾi tə ði ɛmpaɪɝ əz sjuɹɔθ hæd. hi pɪɹɾ ɪndə ðə pjuɾɝ kʌp, swɝlɪŋ ðə dɑɹk æpəl bɹændi waɪl ʃi tʊk əɹ siɾ əɡɛn.

He ordered her to pour him a cup anyway, and she obeyed hurriedly. She wanted to keep him talking, anything to delay the inevitable. She knew for a fact that Egeanin had not been killing sul'dam, yet her proof would condemn her to share Renna and Seta's sour fate. If she was lucky. If this Seeker saw his duty to the Empire as Suroth had. He peered into the pewter cup, swirling the dark apple brandy while she took her seat again.

"ðə haɪ lɔɹd tʃɹɑk wɑz ə ɡɹeɪt mæn," hi mɝmɝd. "pɝhæps wʌn ə ðə ɡɹeɪɾəst ði ɛmpaɪɝ əz ɛvɝ sin. ə pɪɾi hɪz sɔɪhɪn dɪsaɪɾɪd tə fɑloʊ hɪm ɪndə dɛθ. ɑnɝəbəl ə ðɛm, bʌɾ ɪt meɪks ɪɾ ɪmpɑsəbəl tə bi ʃʊɹ doʊmən wɑz ɪn ðə bæn ðət mɝɾɝd ðə haɪ lɔɹd." bɛθəmən flɪntʃt. səmtaɪmz ðə blʌd daɪɾ ət wʌn ənʌðɝz hænz, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌt ðə wɝd mɝɾɝ wɑz nɛvɝ mɛnʃənd. ðə sikɝ kəntɪnjud, stɪl piɹɪŋ ɪndə hɪz kʌp wɪθaʊt dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ. "ðə haɪ lɔɹd hæɾ ɔɹɾɝd mi tə wɑtʃ sjuɹɔθ. hi səspɛktəd ʃi wɑz ə deɪnʒɝ tə ði ɛmpaɪɝ ɪtsɛlf. hɪz oʊn wɝdz. ən wɪð ɪz dɛθ, ʃi mænədʒ tə ɡeɪn kəmæn ə ðə fɔɹʌnɝz. aɪ hæv noʊ ɛvəɾəns ðət ʃi ɔɹɾɝd ɪz dɛθ, bʌt ðəɹ ɪz mʌtʃ ðəɾ ɪz sədʒɛstɪv. sjuɹɔθ bɹɔɾ ə deɪmeɪn tə fɑlm, ə jʌŋ wʊmən u wɑz ɛɛs sədaɪ," əɡɛn, ðə neɪm wɑz flæɾ ən hɑɹd, "æn u sʌmhaʊ ɪskeɪp ðə vɛɹi deɪ ðət tʃɹɑk daɪd. sjuɹɔθ ɔlsoʊ hæz ə deɪmeɪn ɪn əɹ ɑntʊɹɑʒ u wɑz wʌns ɛɛs sədaɪ. ʃiz nɛvɝ bɪn sin ʌnkɑlɹd, bʌt . . ." hi ʃɹʌɡd, əz ðoʊ ðət wɝ ə θɪŋ ə noʊ moʊmənt. bɛθəmənz aɪz pɑpt. hu wəɾ ʌnkɑlɝ ə deɪmeɪn? ə wɛl-tʃɹeɪn deɪmeɪn wɑz ə tʃɹiɾ ən ə dʒɔɪ, bʌɾ əz wɛl ənliʃ ə dʒɹʌŋkən ɡɹoʊm! "ɪt simz vɛɹi laɪkli ʃiz ə mɛɹəθdəmeɪn hɪɾən əmʌŋ əɹ pɹɑpɝɾi, tu," hi wɛn ɑn, dʒʌst əz ɪf i wɝ nɑt lɪstɪŋ kɹaɪmz lɪɾəl loʊɝ ðən tʃɹizən. "aɪ bɪliv sjuɹɔθ ɡeɪv ði ɔɹɾɝ fəɹ sʌldəm u mænədʒ tə ɹitʃ tæntʃəkoʊ tə bi kɪld, pɝhæps ɪn ɔɹɾɝ tə haɪɾ ɛdʒiənɪnz miɾɪŋz wɪð ɛɛs sədaɪ. jə sʌldəm ɔlweɪz seɪ jə kən tɛl ə mɛɹəθdəmeɪn ət saɪt, kɝɛkt?"

"The High Lord Turak was a great man," he murmured. "Perhaps one of the greatest the Empire has ever seen. A pity his so'jhin decided to follow him into death. Honorable of them, but it makes it impossible to be sure Domon was in the band that murdered the High Lord." Bethamin flinched. Sometimes the Blood died at one another's hands, of course, but the word murder was never mentioned. The Seeker continued, still peering into his cup without drinking. "The High Lord had ordered me to watch Suroth. He suspected she was a danger to the Empire itself. His own words. And with his death, she managed to gain command of the Forerunners. I have no evidence that she ordered his death, but there is much that is suggestive. Suroth brought a damane to Falme, a young woman who was Aes Sedai," again, the name was flat and hard, "and who somehow escaped the very day that Turak died. Suroth also has a damane in her entourage who was once Aes Sedai. She has never been seen uncollared, but . . ." He shrugged, as though that were a thing of no moment. Bethamin's eyes popped. Who would uncollar a damane? A well-trained damane was a treat and a joy, but as well unleash a drunken grolm! "It seems very likely she has a marath'damane hidden among her property, too," he went on, just as if he were not listing crimes little lower than treason. "I believe Suroth gave the order for sul'dam who managed to reach Tanchico to be killed, perhaps in order to hide Egeanin's meetings with Aes Sedai. You sul'dam always say you can tell a marath'damane at sight, correct?"

hi lʊkt ʌp sʌɾənli, ən sʌmhaʊ ʃi mænədʒ tə mit ðoʊz fɹoʊzən aɪz wɪð ə smaɪl. hɪz feɪs cʊɾə bɪlɔŋ tə ɛni mæn, bʌt ðoʊz aɪz . . . ʃi wɑz ɡlæd tə bi siɾəd. hɝ niz wɝ ʃeɪkɪŋ soʊ hɑɹd ʃi wɑz sɝpɹaɪzd ɪt dɪd nɑt ʃoʊ θɹu hɝ skɝts. "ɪɾ ɪz nɑt kwaɪt ðəɾ izi, aɪm əfɹeɪd." ʃi ɔlmoʊst səksiɾəd ɪn kipɪŋ əɹ vɔɪs stɛɾi. "ju . . . ʃʊɹli jə noʊ ɪnʌf tə tʃɑɹdʒ sjuɹɔθ wɪð ðə haɪ lɔɹd tʃɹɑks ɛm-ɛm-mɝɾɝ." ɪf i tʊk sjuɹɔθ, ðəɹ wəd bi noʊ nid tə ɪnvɑlv hɝ, əɹ ɛdʒiənɪn.

He looked up suddenly, and somehow she managed to meet those frozen eyes with a smile. His face could have belonged to any man, but those eyes . . . She was glad to be seated. Her knees were shaking so hard she was surprised it did not show through her skirts. "It is not quite that easy, I'm afraid." She almost succeeded in keeping her voice steady. "You . . . Surely you know enough to charge Suroth with the High Lord Turak's m-m-murder." If he took Suroth, there would be no need to involve her, or Egeanin.

"tʃɹɑk wɑz ə ɡɹeɪt mæn, bʌt maɪ duɾi ɪz tə ði ɛmpɹɛs, meɪ ʃi laɪv fɝɛvɝ, ən θɹu hɝ, tə ði ɛmpaɪɝ." hi dʒɹæŋk ðə bɹændi daʊn ɪn wʌn lɔŋ swɑloʊ, ən ɪz feɪs bɪkeɪm əz hɑɹɾ əz ɪz vɔɪs. "tʃɹɑks dɛθ ɪz dʌs bɪsaɪd ðə deɪnʒɝ feɪsɪŋ ði ɛmpaɪɝ. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ʌv ðiz lænz sik paʊɝ ɪn ði ɛmpaɪɝ, ə ɹɪtɝn tə ðə deɪz ə keɪɑs ən mɝɾɝ wən noʊ mæn kəd kloʊz ɪz aɪz ət naɪt noʊɪŋ i wəd weɪk, ən ðeɪ ɑɹ eɪɾəd baɪ ə vɛnəməs wɝm ə tʃɹɛtʃɝi bɔɹɪŋ fɹəm wɪðɪn. sjuɹɔθ meɪ nɑɾ ivən bi ðət wɝmz hɛd. fəɹ ði ɛmpaɪɝz seɪk, aɪ dɛɹ nɑt teɪk əɹ əntɪl aɪ kən kɪl ðə hoʊl wɝm. ɛdʒiənɪn ɪz ə θɹɛɾ aɪ kən fɑloʊ tə ðə wɝm, ən jə ɑɹ ə θɹɛd tə ɛdʒiənɪn. soʊ jəl ɹɪnu jəɹ fɹɛndʃɪp wɪð hɝ, wʌtɛvɝ ɪt teɪks. dʒju ʌndɝstæn mi?"

"Turak was a great man, but my duty is to the Empress, may she live forever, and through her, to the Empire." He drank the brandy down in one long swallow, and his face became as hard as his voice. "Turak's death is dust beside the danger facing the Empire. The Aes Sedai of these lands seek power in the Empire, a return to the days of chaos and murder when no man could close his eyes at night knowing he would wake, and they are aided by a venomous worm of treachery boring from within. Suroth may not even be that worm's head. For the Empire's sake, I dare not take her until I can kill the whole worm. Egeanin is a thread I can follow to the worm, and you are a thread to Egeanin. So you will renew your friendship with her, whatever it takes. Do you understand me?"

"aɪ ʌndɝstænd, ən əl oʊbeɪ." hɝ vɔɪs ʃʊk, bʌt wʌɾ ɛls kəd ʃi seɪ? ðə laɪt seɪv hɝ, wʌɾ ɛls kəd ʃi seɪ?

"I understand, and I will obey." Her voice shook, but what else could she say? The Light save her, what else could she say?


tʃæptɝ twɛntiwʌn


CHAPTER 21

eɪ mæɾɝ ə pɹɑpɝɾi


A Matter of Property

ɛdʒiənɪn leɪ ɑn əɹ bæk ɑn ðə bɛd wɪð əɹ hænz ɹeɪzd, pɑmz təwɔɹd ðə silɪŋ ən fɪŋɡɝz spɹɛd. hɝ peɪl blu skɝts meɪɾ ə fæn əkɹɔs əɹ lɛɡz, ən ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə laɪ vɛɹi stɪl soʊ əz nɑt tə ɹɪŋkəl ðə nɛɹoʊ plits tu mʌtʃ. ðə weɪ dʒɹɛsəz kənfaɪn muvmənt, ðeɪ mʌs bi ən ɪnvɛnʃən ə ðə dɑɹk lɔɹd. laɪɪŋ ðɛɹ, ʃi stʌɾid fɪŋɡɝneɪlz tu lɔŋ fəɹ əɹ tə leɪ hænz ɑn ə laɪn wɪθaʊt bɹeɪkɪŋ ət lis hæf. nɑt ðət ʃi hæd pɝsənəli hændəld laɪnz ɪn kwaɪɾ ə fju jɪɹz, bʌt ʃi hæɾ ɔlweɪz bɪn ɹɛɾi ən eɪbəl tə, ət nid.

Egeanin lay on her back on the bed with her hands raised, palms toward the ceiling and fingers spread. Her pale blue skirts made a fan across her legs, and she tried to lie very still so as not to wrinkle the narrow pleats too much. The way dresses confined movement, they must be an invention of the Dark Lord. Lying there, she studied fingernails too long for her to lay hands on a line without breaking at least half. Not that she had personally handled lines in quite a few years, but she had always been ready and able to, at need.

". . . pleɪn fulhɛɾədnəs!" beɪl ɡɹaʊld, poʊkɪŋ ət ðə bleɪzɪŋ lɔɡz ɪn ðə bɹɪk faɪɝpleɪs. "fɔɹtʃən pɹɪk mi, sihɔk kəd seɪl nɪɹɝ ðə wɪnd, ən fæstɝ, ðən ɛni sintʃæn ʃɪp ɛvɝ meɪd. ðəɹ dɪd bi skwɔlz əhɛd, tu, ən . . ." ʃi lɪsən oʊnli ɪnʌf tə noʊ hi hæd stɑpt ɡɹʌmbəlɪŋ əbaʊt ðə ɹum ən teɪkən ʌp ðə seɪm oʊld ɑɹɡjəmənt. ðə dɑɹk-pænəl tʃeɪmbɝ wɑz nɑt ðə bɛst ət ðə wɑndɝɪŋ wʊmən, əɹ ivən kloʊs, jɛɾ ɪt mɛɾ ɪz ɹɪkwaɪɹməns ɛksɛptɪŋ ðə vju. ðə tu wɪndoʊz lʊkt aʊɾ ɑn ðə steɪbliɑɹd. eɪ kæptən ə ðə ɡɹin ɹæŋkt wɪð ə bænɝ-dʒɛnɝəl, bʌɾ ɪn ðɪs pleɪs, moʊst ə ðoʊz ʃi aʊtʃɹæŋkt wɝ eɪdz əɹ sɛkɹətɛɹiz tə sinjɝ ɔfəsɝz ə ði ɛvɝ vɪktɔɹiəs ɑɹmi. əmʌŋ ði ɑɹmi əz ət si, biɪŋ ə ðə blʌɾ æɾəd lɪɾəl ənlɛs ɪt wɑz ðə haɪ blʌd.

". . . plain foolheadedness!" Bayle growled, poking at the blazing logs in the brick fireplace. "Fortune prick me, Seahawk could sail nearer the wind, and faster, than any Seanchan ship ever made. There did be squalls ahead, too, and . . ." She listened only enough to know he had stopped grumbling about the room and taken up the same old argument. The dark-paneled chamber was not the best at The Wandering Woman, or even close, yet it met his requirements excepting the view. The two windows looked out on the stableyard. A Captain of the Green ranked with a banner-general, but in this place, most of those she outranked were aides or secretaries to senior officers of the Ever Victorious Army. Among the army as at sea, being of the Blood added little unless it was the High Blood.

ðə si-ɡɹin lækɝ ɑn ðə neɪlz ə hɝ lɪɾəl fɪŋɡɝz spɑɹkəld. ʃi hæɾ ɔlweɪz hoʊp tə ɹaɪz, ɪvɛntʃəwəli pɝhæps tə kæptən ə ðə ɡoʊld, kəmændɪŋ flits, əz əɹ mʌðɝ hæd. əz ə ɡɝl, ʃi hæɾ ivən dʒɹimd ə biɪŋ neɪm ðə hæn ə ði ɛmpɹɛs ət si dʒʌs laɪk əɹ mʌðɝ, tə stæn ət ðə lɛf hæn ə ðə kɹɪstəl θɹoʊn, sɔɪhɪn tə ði ɛmpɹɛs hɝsɛlf, maɪt ʃi laɪv fɝɛvɝ, əlaʊd tə spik dɝɛkli tə hɝ. jʌŋ wɪmən hæd fulɪʃ dʒɹimz. ən ʃi hæd tə ədmɪt ðət wʌns tʃoʊzən fəɹ ðə fɔɹʌnɝz, ʃi kənsɪɾɝd ðə pɑsəbɪləɾi ʌv ə nu neɪm. nɑt hoʊpɪŋ fəɹ ɪt, sɝɾənli - ðət wʊɾə bɪn ɡɛɾɪŋ əbʌv hɝsɛlf - jɛɾ ɛvɹiwʌn hæd noʊn ðə ɹəkʌvɝi ʌv ðə stoʊlən lænz wəd min nu ədɪʃənz tə ðə blʌd. naʊ ʃi wɑz kæptən ə ðə ɡɹin, tɛn jɪɹz bɪfɔɹ ʃi ʃʊɾə hæɾ ɛni hoʊp ʌv ɪt, ən stʊɾ ɑn ðə sloʊps ə ðət stip maʊntən ðət ɹoʊz θɹu ðə klaʊdz tə ðə səblaɪm pɪnəkəl ə ði ɛmpɹɛs, maɪt ʃi laɪv fɝɛvɝ.

The sea-green lacquer on the nails of her little fingers sparkled. She had always hoped to rise, eventually perhaps to Captain of the Gold, commanding fleets, as her mother had. As a girl, she had even dreamed of being named the Hand of the Empress at Sea just like her mother, to stand at the left hand of the Crystal Throne, so'jhin to the Empress herself, might she live forever, allowed to speak directly to her. Young women had foolish dreams. And she had to admit that once chosen for the Forerunners, she considered the possibility of a new name. Not hoping for it, certainly - that would have been getting above herself - yet everyone had known the recovery of the stolen lands would mean new additions to the Blood. Now she was Captain of the Green, ten years before she should have had any hope of it, and stood on the slopes of that steep mountain that rose through the clouds to the sublime pinnacle of the Empress, might she live forever.

ʃi daʊɾɪd ʃi wəd bi ɡɪvən kəmæn ʌv wʌn ɡɹieɪtʃɪp, haʊɛvɝ, mʌtʃ lɛs ə skwɑdʒɹən. sjuɹɔθ kleɪm tə æksɛpt əɹ stɔɹi, bʌɾ ɪf soʊ, waɪ hæd ʃi bɪn lɛf sɪɾɪŋ ət kæntʃɹɪn? waɪ, wən ɔɹɾɝz faɪnəli keɪm, wɝ ðeɪ tə ɹipɔɹt hɪɹ ən nɑt tə ə ʃɪp? ʌv kɔɹs, ðəɹ wɝ oʊnli soʊ mɛni kəmænz əveɪləbəl, ivən fəɹ ə kæptən ə ðə ɡɹin. ɪt maɪt bi ðæt. ʃi maɪɾ əv bɪn tʃoʊzən fəɹ ə pəzɪʃən nɪɹ sjuɹɔθ, ðoʊ hɝ ɔɹɾɝz sɛɾ oʊnli ðət ʃi wɑz tə tʃɹævəl tə ɛbu dɑɹ baɪ ðə fɝst əveɪləbəl minz ən əweɪt fɝðɝ ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz. meɪbi. ðə haɪ blʌd maɪt spik tə ðə loʊ wɪθaʊt ði ɪntɝvɛntʃən ʌv ə vɔɪs, bʌɾ ɪt sim tə hɝ ðət sjuɹɔθ hæd fɝɡɑɾən əɹ əz sun əz ʃi wɑz dɪsmɪst æftɝ ɹəsivɪŋ əɹ ɹɪwɔɹdz. wɪtʃ ɔlsoʊ maɪt min sjuɹɔθ wɑz səspɪʃəs. ɑɹɡjəməns ðət ɹæn ɪn sɝkəlz. ɪn ɛni keɪs, ʃi kəd lɪv ɑn siwɑɾɝ ɪf ðət sikɝ hæd ɡɪvən oʊvɝ ɪz səspɪʃənz. hi hæd noʊ mɔɹ, əɹ ʃi wəɾ ɔlɹɛɾi bi ɪn ə dʌnʒən ʃɹikɪŋ, jɛɾ ɪf i wɑz ɪn ðə sɪɾi, tu, hi wəd bi wɑtʃɪŋ hɝ, weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ wʌn mɪsstɛp. hi kəd nɑt ʃɛd soʊ mʌtʃ əz ə sɪŋɡəl dʒɹɑp ə hɝ blʌd, naʊ, bʌt ðə sikɝz wɝ ɪkspɪɹiənst ət dilɪŋ wɪð ðət maɪnɝ dɪfəkəlti. soʊ lɔŋ əz i lɛft ɪt tə wɑtʃɪŋ, ðoʊ, hi kəd stɛɹ əɾ əɹ əntɪl ɪz aɪz ʃɹɪvəld. ʃi hæɾ ə steɪbəl dɛk ʌndɝ əɹ fit, naʊ, ən fɹəm hɪɹ ɑn ʃi wəd teɪk ɡɹeɪt kɛɹ haʊ ʃi stɛpt. kæptən ə ðə ɡoʊl maɪt noʊ lɔŋɡɝ bi pɑsəbəl, jɛt ɹɪtaɪɹɪŋ əz kæptən ə ðə ɡɹin wɑz ɑnɝəbəl.

She doubted she would be given command of one greatship, however, much less a squadron. Suroth claimed to accept her story, but if so, why had she been left sitting at Cantorin? Why, when orders finally came, were they to report here and not to a ship? Of course, there were only so many commands available, even for a Captain of the Green. It might be that. She might have been chosen for a position near Suroth, though her orders said only that she was to travel to Ebou Dar by the first available means and await further instructions. Maybe. The High Blood might speak to the low without the intervention of a Voice, but it seemed to her that Suroth had forgotten her as soon as she was dismissed after receiving her rewards. Which also might mean Suroth was suspicious. Arguments that ran in circles. In any case, she could live on seawater if that Seeker had given over his suspicions. He had no more, or she would already be in a dungeon shrieking, yet if he was in the city, too, he would be watching her, waiting for one misstep. He could not shed so much as a single drop of her blood, now, but the Seekers were experienced at dealing with that minor difficulty. So long as he left it to watching, though, he could stare at her until his eyes shriveled. She had a stable deck under her feet, now, and from here on she would take great care how she stepped. Captain of the Gold might no longer be possible, yet retiring as Captain of the Green was honorable.

"wɛl?" beɪl dɪmændəd. "wʌɾ əbaʊt ðæt?"

"Well?" Bayle demanded. "What about that?"

waɪɾ ən sɑləɾ ən stʃɹɔŋ, dʒʌs ðə sɔɹɾ ə mæn ʃi hæɾ ɔlweɪz feɪvɝd, hi wɑz stændɪŋ bɪsaɪd ðə bɛɾ ɪn ɪz ʃɝtslivz, ə fɹaʊn ɑn ɪz feɪs ən ɪz fɪsts ɑn ɪz hɪps. nɑɾ ə poʊz ə sɔɪhɪn ʃəd teɪk wɪð ɪz mɪstʃɹəs. wɪð ə saɪ, ʃi lɛɾ əɹ hænz dʒɹɑp ɑntu hɝ stʌmək. beɪl dʒʌst wəd nɑt lɝn haʊ ə sɔɪhɪn wɑz səpoʊz tə bɪheɪv. hi tʊk ɪɾ ɔl əz ə dʒoʊk, əɹ pleɪ, əz ðoʊ nʌn ʌv ɪt wɝ ɹil. səmtaɪmz i ivən sɛɾ i wɑntəd tə bi hɝ vɔɪs, noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ ɔfən ʃi ɪkspleɪnd ʃi wɑz nɑɾ ə ðə haɪ blʌd. wʌns, ʃi hæd hæɾ ɪm biɾən, ən æftɝwɝdz i hæd ɹəfjuz tə slip ɪn ðə seɪm bɛd wɪð əɹ əntɪl ʃi əpɑlədʒaɪzd. əpɑlədʒaɪzd!

Wide and solid and strong, just the sort of man she had always favored, he was standing beside the bed in his shirtsleeves, a frown on his face and his fists on his hips. Not a pose a so'jhin should take with his mistress. With a sigh, she let her hands drop onto her stomach. Bayle just would not learn how a so'jhin was supposed to behave. He took it all as a joke, or play, as though none of it were real. Sometimes he even said he wanted to be her Voice, no matter how often she explained she was not of the High Blood. Once, she had had him beaten, and afterwards he had refused to sleep in the same bed with her until she apologized. Apologized!

heɪstəli, ʃi ɹæn θɹu wʌt ʃi hæd hæf-hɝɾ ə hɪz ɡɹoʊlɪŋ. jɛs; stɪl ðə seɪm ɑɹɡjəməns æftɝ ɔl ðɪs taɪm. nʌθɪŋ nu. swɪŋɪŋ əɹ lɛɡz oʊvɝ ðə saɪɾ ə ðə bɛd, ʃi sæɾ ʌp ən tɪk pɔɪns ɔf ɑn əɹ fɪŋɡɝz. ʃi hæd dʌn ɪt soʊ ɔfən, ʃi kəd dɪlɪvɝ əm baɪ ɹoʊt. "hæd jə tʃɹaɪd tə ɹʌn, ðə deɪmeɪn ɑn ði ʌðɝ ʃɪp wʊɾə snæp jəɹ mæsts laɪk twɪɡz. ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ə tʃæns stɑp, beɪl, ən jə noʊ ɪt; ðɛɹ fɝs heɪl wɑz ə dɪmæn tə noʊ wɛðɝ jə wɝ sihɔk. baɪ bɹɪŋɪŋ jə ɪndə ðə wɪn ən ənaʊnsɪŋ wi wɝ ɑn əɹ weɪ tə kæntʃɹɪn wɪð ə ɡɪft fəɹ ði ɛmpɹɛs, meɪ ʃi laɪv fɝɛvɝ, aɪ əleɪd ðɛɹ səspɪʃənz. ɛniθɪŋ ɛls - ɛniθɪŋ! - ən wi wəɾ ɔl əv bɪn tʃeɪn ɪn ðə hoʊld ən soʊld əz sun əz wi ɹitʃt kæntʃɹɪn. aɪ daʊt wiɾ əv bɪn lʌki ɪnʌf tə feɪs ðə hɛdzmən ɪnstɛd." ʃi hɛld ʌp əɹ θʌm. "æn læst, ɪf jə hæd kɛp kɑm əz aɪ toʊl jə tə, jə wəd nɑɾ əv ɡɔn tə ðə blɑk, iðɝ. jə kɑs mi ə ɡɹeɪt dil!" sɛvɹəl ʌðɝ wɪmən ɪn kæntʃɹɪn əpɛɹənli hæɾ əɹ seɪm teɪst ɪn mɛn. ðeɪ hæd pʊʃt ðə bɪɾɪŋ ʌp ɛkstʃɹævəɡənli.

Hastily, she ran through what she had half-heard of his growling. Yes; still the same arguments after all this time. Nothing new. Swinging her legs over the side of the bed, she sat up and ticked points off on her fingers. She had done it so often, she could deliver them by rote. "Had you tried to run, the damane on the other ship would have snapped your masts like twigs. It was not a chance stop, Bayle, and you know it; their first hail was a demand to know whether you were Seahawk. By bringing you into the wind and announcing we were on our way to Cantorin with a gift for the Empress, may she live forever, I allayed their suspicions. Anything else - anything! - and we would all have been chained in the hold and sold as soon as we reached Cantorin. I doubt we'd have been lucky enough to face the headsman instead." She held up her thumb. "And last, if you had kept calm as I told you to, you would not have gone to the block, either. You cost me a great deal!" Several other women in Cantorin apparently had her same taste in men. They had pushed the bidding up extravagantly.

stʌbɝn mæn ðəɾ i wɑz, hi skaʊld ən skɹʌbd əɾ ɪz ʃɔɹt bɪɹɾ ɪɹɪɾəbli. "aɪ də stɪl seɪ wi cʊɾə dʒɹɑpt ɪɾ ɔl oʊvɝ ðə saɪd," hi mʌɾɝd. "ðæt sikɝ hæd noʊ pɹuf aɪ dɪɾ əv ɪɾ əbɔɹd."

Stubborn man that he was, he scowled and scrubbed at his short beard irritably. "I do still say we could have dropped it all over the side," he muttered. "That Seeker had no proof I did have it aboard."

"sikɝz də noʊ nid pɹuf," ʃi sɛd, mɑkɪŋ ɪz æksɛnt. "sikɝz də faɪn pɹuf, ən ðə faɪndɪŋ də bi peɪnfəl." ɪf i wɑz ɹədus tə bɹɪŋɪŋ ʌp wʌɾ ivən i hæd kənsiɾɪd lɔŋ sɪns, meɪbi ʃi wɑz faɪnəli nɪɹɪŋ ði ɛn ə ðə hoʊl θɪŋ. "ɪn ɛni keɪs, beɪl, juv ɔlɹɛɾi ədmɪɾəd ðəɹ ɪz noʊ hɑɹm ɪn sjuɹɔθ hævɪŋ ðət kɑlɝ ən bɹeɪslɪts. ðeɪ kæn bi pʊɾ ɑn ɪm ənlɛs sʌmwʌn ɡɛts kloʊs ɪnʌf, ən aɪv hɝd nʌθɪŋ ðət sədʒɛsts ɛniwʌn əz əɹ wɪl." ʃi ɹɪfɹeɪn fɹəm æɾɪŋ ðəɾ ɪt wəd nɑt mæɾɝ ɪf sʌmwʌn dɪd. beɪl wɑz nɑt ɹɪli fəmɪljɝ wɪð ivən ðə vɝʒənz ə ðə pɹɑfəsiz ðeɪ hæɾ ɑn ðɪs saɪɾ ə ðə wɝl si, bʌɾ i wɑz æɾəmənt ðət nʌn mɛnʃən ðə nəsɛsəɾi ʌv ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn nilɪŋ tə ðə kɹɪstəl θɹoʊn. ɪt maɪt pɹuv nɛsəsɛɹi fəɹ ɪm tə bi fɪɾəd wɪð ðɪs meɪl æɾəm, bʌt beɪl wəd nɛvɝ si ɪt. "wʌɾ ɪz dʌn ɪz dʌn, beɪl. ɪf ðə laɪt ʃaɪnz ɑn ʌs, wɪl lɪv lɔŋ ɪn ðə sɝvəs ə ði ɛmpaɪɝ. naʊ, jə noʊ ðɪs sɪɾi, soʊ jə seɪ. wʌɾ ɪz ðəɹ ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ tə si əɹ du?"

"Seekers do no need proof," she said, mocking his accent. "Seekers do find proof, and the finding do be painful." If he was reduced to bringing up what even he had conceded long since, maybe she was finally nearing the end of the whole thing. "In any case, Bayle, you have already admitted there is no harm in Suroth having that collar and bracelets. They can't be put on him unless someone gets close enough, and I've heard nothing that suggests anyone has or will." She refrained from adding that it would not matter if someone did. Bayle was not really familiar with even the versions of the Prophecies they had on this side of the World Sea, but he was adamant that none mentioned the necessity of the Dragon Reborn kneeling to the Crystal Throne. It might prove necessary for him to be fitted with this male a'dam, but Bayle would never see it. "What is done is done, Bayle. If the Light shines on us, we will live long in the service of the Empire. Now, you know this city, so you say. What is there interesting to see or do?"

"ðɛɹ ɔlweɪz də bi fɛstəvəlz ə səm sɔɹt," hi sɛd sloʊli, ɡɹʌdʒɪŋli. hi nɛvɝ laɪkt ɡɪvɪŋ ʌp ɪz ɑɹɡjəmənt, noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ fjuɾəl. "sʌm meɪ bi tə jəɹ teɪst. səm nɑt, aɪ də θɪŋk. jə də bi . . . pɪki." wʌɾ i min baɪ ðæt? sʌɾənli hi ɡɹɪnd. "wi kəd faɪn ə waɪz wʊmən. ðeɪ də hɪɹ mɛɹɪdʒ vaʊz, hɪɹ." hi ɹæn ɪz fɪŋɡɝz əkɹɔs ðə ʃeɪvən saɪɾ ə hɪz skælp, ɹoʊlɪŋ ɪz aɪz ʌpwɝɾ əz ðoʊ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə si ɪt. "ʌv kɔɹs, ɪf aɪ də ɹikɔl ðə lɛktʃɝ jə dɪd ɡɪmi ɑn ðə 'ɹaɪts ən pɹɪvlədʒəz' ʌv maɪ pəzɪʃən, sɔɪhɪn kən oʊnli mɛɹi ʌðɝ sɔɪhɪn, soʊ jə də nid tə fɹi mi, fɝst. fɔɹtʃən pɹɪk mi, jə də noʊ hæv ə fʊɾ ə ðoʊz pɹɑməst ɪsteɪts, jɛt. aɪ kən teɪk ʌp maɪ oʊl tʃɹeɪɾ ən ɡɪv jə ən ɪsteɪt sun ɪnʌf."

"There always do be festivals of some sort," he said slowly, grudgingly. He never liked giving up his argument, no matter how futile. "Some may be to your taste. Some not, I do think. You do be . . . picky." What did he mean by that? Suddenly he grinned. "We could find a Wise Woman. They do hear marriage vows, here." He ran his fingers across the shaven side of his scalp, rolling his eyes upward as though trying to see it. "Of course, if I do recall the lecture you did give me on the 'rights and privileges' of my position, so'jhin can only marry other so'jhin, so you do need to free me, first. Fortune prick me, you do no have a foot of those promised estates, yet. I can take up my old trade and give you an estate soon enough."

hɝ maʊθ fɛl oʊpən. ðɪs wɑz nɑt sʌmθɪŋ oʊld. ðɪs wɑz vɛɹi, vɛɹi nu. ʃi hæɾ ɔlweɪz pɹaɪɾɪd hɝsɛlf ɑn biɪŋ lɛvəl-hɛɾəd. ʃi hæd ɹɪzən tə kəmæn baɪ skɪl ən dɛɹɪŋ, ə vɛɾɝən ə si bæɾəlz ən stɔɹmz ən ʃɪpɹɪk. ən ɹaɪt ðət moʊmənt ʃi fɛlt laɪk ə fɝst-vɔɪədʒ fɪŋɡɝlɪŋ lʊkɪŋ daʊn fɹəm ðə meɪn pik, pænɪkt ən dɪzi, wɪð ðə hoʊl wɝl spɪnɪŋ ɝaʊn əɹ ən ə simɪŋli ɪnɛvəɾəbəl fɔl tə ðə si fɪlɪŋ əɹ aɪz.

Her mouth fell open. This was not something old. This was very, very new. She had always prided herself on being level-headed. She had risen to command by skill and daring, a veteran of sea battles and storms and shipwreck. And right that moment she felt like a first-voyage fingerling looking down from the main peak, panicked and dizzy, with the whole world spinning around her and a seemingly inevitable fall to the sea filling her eyes.

"ɪɾ ɪz nɑt soʊ sɪmpəl," ʃi sɛd, sɝdʒɪŋ tə hɝ fit soʊ hi wɑz fɔɹs tə stɛp bæk. laɪts tʃɹuθ, ʃi heɪɾəd saʊndɪŋ bɹɛθləs! "mænumɪʃən ɹikwaɪɝz mi tə pɹəvaɪd fəɹ jəɹ laɪvlihʊɾ əz ə fɹi mæn, tə si jə kən səpɔɹt jɝsɛlf." laɪt! wɝdz flʌɾɪŋ aʊɾ ɪn ə ɹʌʃ wɝ əz bæɾ əz biɪŋ bɹɛθləs. ʃi ɪmædʒən hɝsɛlf ɑn ə dɛk. ɪt hɛlpt, ə lɪɾəl. "ɪn jəɹ keɪs, ðət minz baɪɪŋ ə ʃɪp, aɪ səpoʊz," ʃi sɛd, saʊndɪŋ ənɹʌfəld, ət list, "æn əz jə ɹimaɪndəd mi, aɪ hæv noʊ ɪsteɪts jɛt. bɪsaɪdz, aɪ kəd nɑɾ əlaʊ jə tə ɹɪtɝn tə smʌɡəlɪŋ, ən jə noʊ ɪt." ðət mʌtʃ wɑz sɪmpəl tʃɹuθ, ən ðə ɹɛs nɑt ɹɪli ə laɪ. hɝ jɪɹz ət si hæd bɪn pɹɑfəɾəbəl, ən ɪf ðə ɡoʊld ʃi kəd kɔl ɑn wɑz smɔl ɡlinɪŋz tə wʌn ə ðə blʌd, ʃi kəd baɪ ə ʃɪp, soʊ lɔŋ əz i dɪd nɑt wɑn ə ɡɹieɪtʃɪp, bʌt ʃi hæd nɑɾ æktʃəli  dɪnaɪd biɪŋ eɪbəl tə əfɔɹd wʌn.

"It is not so simple," she said, surging to her feet so he was forced to step back. Light's truth, she hated sounding breathless! "Manumission requires me to provide for your livelihood as a free man, to see you can support yourself." Light! Words flooding out in a rush were as bad as being breathless. She imagined herself on a deck. It helped, a little. "In your case, that means buying a ship, I suppose," she said, sounding unruffled, at least, "and as you reminded me, I have no estates yet. Besides, I could not allow you to return to smuggling, and you know it." That much was simple truth, and the rest not really a lie. Her years at sea had been profitable, and if the gold she could call on was small gleanings to one of the Blood, she could buy a ship, so long as he did not want a greatship, but she had not actually denied being able to afford one.

hi spɹɛɾ ɪz ɑɹmz, ənʌðɝ θɪŋ i wɑz nɑt səpoʊz tə du, ən æftɝ ə moʊmənt ʃi leɪɾ əɹ tʃik əɡɛnst ɪz bɹɔd ʃoʊldɝ ən lɛɾ ɪm ɪnfoʊl hɝ. "ɪt wɪl bi wɛl, læs," hi mɝmɝd dʒɛnli. "sʌmhaʊ, ɪɾəl bi wɛl."

He spread his arms, another thing he was not supposed to do, and after a moment she laid her cheek against his broad shoulder and let him enfold her. "It will be well, lass," he murmured gently. "Somehow, it will be well."

"ju mʌs nɑt kɔl mi 'læs,' beɪl," ʃi tʃaɪɾɪd, stɛɹɪŋ bɪɑn ɪz ʃoʊldɝ təwɔɹd ðə faɪɝpleɪs. ɪt wəd nɑt sim tə kʌm ɪndə foʊkəs. bɪfɔɹ livɪŋ tæntʃəkoʊ ʃi hæd dɪsaɪɾɪd tə mɛɹi hɪm, wʌn ə ðoʊz laɪtnɪŋ dɪsɪʒənz ðət hæd meɪɾ əɹ ɹɛpjəteɪʃən. smʌɡəlɝ i maɪt bi, bʌt ʃi cʊɾə pʊɾ ə stɑp tə ðæt, ən i wɑz stɛdfæst, stʃɹɔŋ ən ɪntɛlədʒənt, ə sifɛɹɝ. ðət læs hæɾ ɔlweɪz bɪn ə nəsɛsəɾi, tə hɝ. oʊnli, ʃi hæd nɑt noʊn ɪz kʌstəmz. səm pleɪsəz ɪn ði ɛmpaɪɝ, mɛn dɪd ði æskɪŋ, ən wɝ æktʃəli  əfɛndəɾ ɪf ə wʊmən ivən sədʒɛstəd. ʃi nu nʌθɪŋ ʌv ɛntaɪsɪŋ ə mæn, iðɝ. hɝ fju lʌvɝz hæɾ ɔl bɪn mɛn ʌv ikwəl ɹæŋk, mɛn ʃi kəɾ əpɹoʊtʃ oʊpənli ən bɪd fɛɹwɛl wən wʌn əɹ ði ʌðɝ ə ðɛm wɑz ɔɹɾɝd tə ənʌðɝ ʃɪp əɹ pɹəmoʊɾəd. ən naʊ hi wɑz sɔɪhɪn. ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ ɹɔŋ wɪð bɛɾɪŋ jəɹ oʊn sɔɪhɪn, ʌv kɔɹs, soʊ lɔŋ əz jə dɪd nɑt flɔn ðə fækt. hi wəd meɪk ʌp ə pæləɾ ət ðə fʊɾ ə ðə bɛɾ əz juʒəwəl, ivən ɪf i nɛvɝ slɛpt ɑn ɪt. bʌt fɹiɪŋ ə sɔɪhɪn, kæstɪŋ ɪm ɔf fɹəm ðə ɹaɪts ən pɹɪvlədʒəz beɪl snɪɹɾ æt, wɑz ðə haɪɾ ə kɹulti. noʊ, ʃi wɑz laɪɪŋ baɪ əvɔɪɾəns əɡɛn, ən wɝs, laɪɪŋ tə hɝsɛlf. ʃi wɑntəd hoʊlhɑɹɾɪdli tə mɛɹi ðə mæn beɪl doʊmən. ʃi wɑz bɪɾɝli ənʃʊɹ ʃi kəd bɹɪŋ hɝsɛlf tə mɛɹi mænumɪɾɪd pɹɑpɝɾi.

"You must not call me 'lass,' Bayle," she chided, staring beyond his shoulder toward the fireplace. It would not seem to come into focus. Before leaving Tanchico she had decided to marry him, one of those lightning decisions that had made her reputation. Smuggler he might be, but she could have put a stop to that, and he was steadfast, strong and intelligent, a seafarer. That last had always been a necessity, to her. Only, she had not known his customs. Some places in the Empire, men did the asking, and were actually offended if a woman even suggested. She knew nothing of enticing a man, either. Her few lovers had all been men of equal rank, men she could approach openly and bid farewell when one or the other of them was ordered to another ship or promoted. And now he was so'jhin. There was nothing wrong with bedding your own so'jhin, of course, so long as you did not flaunt the fact. He would make up a pallet at the foot of the bed as usual, even if he never slept on it. But freeing a so'jhin, casting him off from the rights and privileges Bayle sneered at, was the height of cruelty. No, she was lying by avoidance again, and worse, lying to herself. She wanted wholeheartedly to marry the man Bayle Domon. She was bitterly unsure she could bring herself to marry manumitted property.

"æz maɪ leɪɾi də kəmænd, soʊ ʃæl ɪt bi," hi sɛɾ ɪn ə blaɪð mɑkɝi ʌv fɔɹmæləɾi.

"As my Lady do command, so shall it be," he said in a blithe mockery of formality.

ʃi pʌntʃt ɪm ʌndɝ ðə ɹɪbz. nɑt hɑɹd. dʒʌst ɪnʌf tə meɪk ɪm ɡɹʌnt. hi hæd tə lɝn! ʃi dɪd nɑt wɑnə si ðə saɪts ʌv ɛbu dɑɹ ɛni lɔŋɡɝ. ʃi dʒʌst wɑntəd tə steɪ wɛɹ ʃi wɑz, ɹæpt ɪn beɪlz ɑɹmz, nɑt niɾɪŋ tə meɪk dɪsɪʒənz, steɪ ɹaɪt wɛɹ ðeɪ stʊd fɝɛvɝ.

She punched him under the ribs. Not hard. Just enough to make him grunt. He had to learn! She did not want to see the sights of Ebou Dar any longer. She just wanted to stay where she was, wrapped in Bayle's arms, not needing to make decisions, stay right where they stood forever.

ə ʃɑɹp nɑk saʊndəɾ ət ðə dɔɹ, ən ʃi pʊʃt ɪm əweɪ. ət list i nu ɪnʌf nɑt tə pɹoʊtɛs ðæt. waɪl i tʌɡd ɑn ɪz koʊt, ʃi ʃʊk aʊt ðə plits ə hɝ dʒɹɛs ən ətɛmptəd tə smuð əweɪ ðə ɹɪŋkəlz fɹəm laɪɪŋ ɑn ðə bɛd. ðəɹ sim tə bi ə ɡʊd mɛni, dɪspaɪt haʊ stɪl ʃi hæd bɪn. ðɪs nɑk maɪt bi ə sʌmənz fɹəm sjuɹɔθ əɹ ə meɪd siɪŋ wɛðɝ ʃi niɾəd ɛniθɪŋ, bʌt huɛvɝ ɪt wɑz, ʃi wɑz nɑt gɑnə lɛɾ ɛniwʌn si hɝ lʊkɪŋ əz ɪf ʃi hæd bɪn ɹoʊlɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɑn ðə dɛk.

A sharp knock sounded at the door, and she pushed him away. At least he knew enough not to protest that. While he tugged on his coat, she shook out the pleats of her dress and attempted to smooth away the wrinkles from lying on the bed. There seemed to be a good many, despite how still she had been. This knock might be a summons from Suroth or a maid seeing whether she needed anything, but whoever it was, she was not going to let anyone see her looking as if she had been rolling about on the deck.

ɡɪvɪŋ ʌp ðə jusləs ətɛmpt, ʃi weɪɾəd əntɪl beɪl hæd bʌɾənd hɪmsɛlf ʌp ən ədɑptəd ði æɾətud i θɔt pɹɑpɝ fəɹ ə sɔɪhɪn - laɪk ə kæptən ɑn ɪz kɔɹɾɝdɛk ɹɛɾi tə ʃaʊɾ ɔɹɾɝz, ʃi θɔt, saɪɪŋ tə hɝsɛlf - ðən bɑɹkt, "kʌm!" ðə wʊmən u oʊpən ðə dɔɹ wɑz ðə læst ʃi ɪkspɛktəd tə si.

Giving up the useless attempt, she waited until Bayle had buttoned himself up and adopted the attitude he thought proper for a so'jhin - Like a captain on his quarterdeck ready to shout orders, she thought, sighing to herself - then barked, "Come!" The woman who opened the door was the last she expected to see.

bɛθəmən aɪɾ əɹ hɛzɪɾəntli bɪfɔɹ dɑɹɾɪŋ ɪn ən kloʊzɪŋ ðə dɔɹ sɔfli bɪhaɪn hɝ. ðə sʌldəm tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ, ðən nɛlt, hoʊldɪŋ hɝsɛlf stɪfli əpɹaɪt. hɝ dɑɹk blu dʒɹɛs wɪð ɪts laɪtnɪŋ-wɝkt ɹɛd pænəlz lʊk fɹɛʃli klin ən aɪɝnd. ðə ʃɑɹp kɑntʃɹæs tə hɝ oʊn dɪʃəvəlmən ɪɹəteɪɾəd ɛdʒiənɪn. "maɪ leɪɾi," bɛθəmən bɪɡæn ənsɝteɪnli, ðən swɑloʊd. "maɪ leɪɾi, aɪ bɛɡ ə wɝd wɪð ju." ɡlænsɪŋ ət beɪl, ʃi lɪkt əɹ lɪps. "ɪn pɹaɪvət, ɪf ɪt plizɪz ju, maɪ leɪɾi?"

Bethamin eyed her hesitantly before darting in and closing the door softly behind her. The sul'dam took a deep breath, then knelt, holding herself stiffly upright. Her dark blue dress with its lightning-worked red panels looked freshly cleaned and ironed. The sharp contrast to her own dishevelment irritated Egeanin. "My Lady," Bethamin began uncertainly, then swallowed. "My Lady, I beg a word with you." Glancing at Bayle, she licked her lips. "In private, if it pleases you, my Lady?"
