ðə læs taɪm ɛdʒiənɪn hæd sin ðɪs wʊmən wɑz ɪn ə beɪsmən ɪn tæntʃəkoʊ, wən ʃi ɹimuvd ən æɾəm fɹəm bɛθəmən ən toʊld əɹ tə ɡoʊ. ðət wʊɾə bɪn ɪnʌf fəɹ blækmeɪl ɪf ʃi wɝ ə ðə haɪ blʌd! wɪθaʊt daʊt ðə tʃɑɹdʒ wəd bi ðə seɪm əz fəɹ fɹiɪŋ ə deɪmeɪn. tʃɹizən. ɪksɛp ðət bɛθəmən kəd nɑt ɹɪvil ɪt wɪθaʊt kəndɛmɪŋ hɝsɛlf, tu.

The last time Egeanin had seen this woman was in a basement in Tanchico, when she removed an a'dam from Bethamin and told her to go. That would have been enough for blackmail if she were of the High Blood! Without doubt the charge would be the same as for freeing a damane. Treason. Except that Bethamin could not reveal it without condemning herself, too.

"hi kən hɪɹ ɛniθɪŋ juv tə seɪ, bɛθəmən," ʃi sɛd kɑmli. ʃi wɑz ɪn ʃoʊl wɔɾɝz, ən ðət wɑz noʊ pleɪs fəɹ ɛniθɪŋ ɪksɛp kɑm. "wʌt dʒju wɑnt?"

"He can hear anything you have to say, Bethamin," she said calmly. She was in shoal waters, and that was no place for anything except calm. "What do you want?"

bɛθəmən ʃɪftəɾ ɑn əɹ niz ən weɪstəd mɔɹ taɪm wɪð lɪp lɪkɪŋ. ðɛn, sʌɾənli, wɝdz keɪm aʊɾ ɪn ə ɹʌʃ. "eɪ sikɝ keɪm tə mi ən ɔɹɾɝd mi tə ɹɪzum əɹ . . . əɹ əkweɪntəns ən ɹipɔɹɾ ɑn jə tə hɪm." əz ɪf tə stɑp hɝsɛlf bæbəlɪŋ, ʃi kɑɾ əɹ ʌndɝlɪp ɪn əɹ tiθ ən stɛɹɾ əɾ ɛdʒiənɪn. hɝ dɑɹk aɪz wɝ dɛspɹɪɾ ən pliɾɪŋ, dʒʌst əz ðeɪ hæd bɪn ɪn ðət tæntʃəkoʊ beɪsmənt.

Bethamin shifted on her knees and wasted more time with lip licking. Then, suddenly, words came out in a rush. "A Seeker came to me and ordered me to resume our . . . our acquaintance and report on you to him." As if to stop herself babbling, she caught her underlip in her teeth and stared at Egeanin. Her dark eyes were desperate and pleading, just as they had been in that Tanchico basement.

ɛdʒiənɪn mɛɾ əɹ ɡeɪz kuli. ʃoʊl wɔɾɝz, ən ən ʌnɪkspɛktɪd ɡeɪl. hɝ stʃɹeɪnʒ ɔɹɾɝz tə ɛbu dɑɹ sʌɾənli wɝ ɪkspleɪnd. ʃi dɪd nɑt niɾ ə dɪskɹɪpʃən tə noʊ ɪt mʌs bi ðə seɪm mæn. nɔɹ dɪd ʃi nid tə æsk waɪ bɛθəmən wɑz kəmɪɾɪŋ tʃɹizən baɪ bɪtʃɹeɪɪŋ ðə sikɝ. ɪf i dɪsaɪɾɪd ɪz səspɪʃənz wɝ stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf tə teɪk əɹ fəɹ kwɛstʃənɪŋ, ɪvɛntʃəwəli ɛdʒiənɪn wəd tɛl ɪm ɛvɹiθɪŋ ʃi nu, ɪnkluɾɪŋ əbaʊɾ ə sɝɾən beɪsmənt, ən bɛθəmən wəd sun faɪn hɝsɛlf wʌns mɔɹ wɛɹɪŋ ən æɾəm. ðə wʊmənz oʊnli hoʊp wɑz tə hɛlp ɛdʒiənɪn ɪveɪd hɪm.

Egeanin met her gaze coolly. Shoal waters, and an unexpected gale. Her strange orders to Ebou Dar suddenly were explained. She did not need a description to know it must be the same man. Nor did she need to ask why Bethamin was committing treason by betraying the Seeker. If he decided his suspicions were strong enough to take her for questioning, eventually Egeanin would tell him everything she knew, including about a certain basement, and Bethamin would soon find herself once more wearing an a'dam. The woman's only hope was to help Egeanin evade him.

"ɹaɪz," ʃi sɛd. "hæv ə sit." lʌkəli, ðəɹ wɝ tu tʃɛɹz, ðoʊ niðɝ əpɪɹd kʌmftəɹbəl. "beɪl, aɪ θɪŋk ðəɹ ɪz bɹændi ɪn ðət flæsk ɑn ðə dʒɹɔɝd tʃɛst."

"Rise," she said. "Have a seat." Luckily, there were two chairs, though neither appeared comfortable. "Bayle, I think there is brandy in that flask on the drawered chest."

bɛθəmən wɑz soʊ ʃeɪki ðəɾ ɛdʒiənɪn hæd tə hɛlp əɹ ʌp ən ɡaɪɾ əɹ tə ə tʃɛɹ. beɪl bɹɔt wɝk sɪlvɝ kʌps hoʊldɪŋ ə lɪɾəl bɹændi ən ɹɪmɛmbɝd tə baʊ ən pɹɛzən ɛdʒiənɪnz fɝst, bʌt wən i ɹɪtɝn tə ðə tʃɛst, ʃi sɔ hi hæd pɔɹd fəɹ hɪmsɛlf, əz wɛl. hi stʊd ðɛɹ, kʌp ɪn hænd, wɑtʃɪŋ əm əz ɪf ɪt wɝ ðə moʊs nætʃɹəl θɪŋ ɪn ðə wɝld. bɛθəmən stɛɹɾ əɾ ɪm pɑp-aɪd.

Bethamin was so shaky that Egeanin had to help her up and guide her to a chair. Bayle brought worked silver cups holding a little brandy and remembered to bow and present Egeanin's first, but when he returned to the chest, she saw he had poured for himself, as well. He stood there, cup in hand, watching them as if it were the most natural thing in the world. Bethamin stared at him pop-eyed.

"ju θɪŋk jə ɑɹ pɔɪzd oʊvɝ ði ɪmpəlɪŋ steɪk," ɛdʒiənɪn sɛd, ən ðə sʌldəm flɪntʃt, hɝ fɹaɪɾənd ɡeɪz dʒɝkɪŋ bæk tə ɛdʒiənɪnz feɪs. "ju ɑɹ ɹɔŋ, bɛθəmən. ði oʊnli ɹil kɹaɪm aɪ hæv kəmɪɾəd wɑz fɹiɪŋ ju." nɑt pɹɪsaɪsli tʃɹu, bʌɾ ɪn ði ɛnd, æftɝ ɔl, ʃi hæd pleɪs ðə meɪl æɾəm ɪn sjuɹɔθs hænz hɝsɛlf. ən tɔkɪŋ wɪð ɛɛs sədaɪ wɑz nɑɾ ə kɹaɪm. ðə sikɝ maɪt səspɛkt - hi hæd tʃɹaɪd tə lɪsən əɾ ə dɔɹ ɪn tæntʃəkoʊ - bʌt ʃi wɑz nɑɾ ə sʌldəm, tʃɑɹdʒd wɪð kætʃɪŋ mɛɹəθdəmeɪn. ət wɝs ðət mɛn ə ɹɛpɹəmænd. "soʊ lɔŋ əz i dʌzn lɝn əbaʊt ðæt, hiz noʊ ɹizən tə ɝɛs mi. ɪf i wɑns tə noʊ wʌɾ aɪ seɪ, əɹ ɛniθɪŋ ɛls əbaʊt mi, tɛl hɪm. dʒʌst ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðəɾ ɪf i dʌz dɪsaɪd tə ɝɛs mi, əl ɡɪv ɪm jəɹ neɪm." ə ɹimaɪndɝ kəɾ oʊnli ɡɑɹɾ əɡɛns bɛθəmən sʌɾənli θɪŋkɪŋ ʃi sɔ ə seɪf weɪ aʊt, livɪŋ əɹ bɪhaɪnd. "hi woʊn əv tə meɪk mi skɹim wʌns."

"You think you are poised over the impaling stake," Egeanin said, and the sul'dam flinched, her frightened gaze jerking back to Egeanin's face. "You are wrong, Bethamin. The only real crime I have committed was freeing you." Not precisely true, but in the end, after all, she had placed the male a'dam in Suroth's hands herself. And talking with Aes Sedai was not a crime. The Seeker might suspect - he had tried to listen at a door in Tanchico - but she was not a sul'dam, charged with catching marath'damane. At worst that meant a reprimand. "So long as he doesn't learn about that, he has no reason to arrest me. If he wants to know what I say, or anything else about me, tell him. Just remember that if he does decide to arrest me, I will give him your name." A reminder could only guard against Bethamin suddenly thinking she saw a safe way out, leaving her behind. "He won't have to make me scream once."

tə hɝ sɝpɹaɪz, ðə sʌldəm bɪɡæn tə læf hɪstɛɹɪkli. əntɪl ɛdʒiənɪn lin fɔɹwɝɾ ən slæp hɝ, ɛniweɪ.

To her surprise, the sul'dam began to laugh hysterically. Until Egeanin leaned forward and slapped her, anyway.

ɹʌbɪŋ əɹ tʃik sʌlənli, bɛθəmən sɛd, "hi noʊz nɪɹ ɪnʌf ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɪksɛp ðə beɪsmənt, maɪ leɪɾi." ən ʃi bɪɡæn tə dɪskɹaɪb ə fæntæstɪkəl wɛb ə tʃɹizən kənɛktɪŋ ɛdʒiənɪn ən beɪl ən sjuɹɔθ ən meɪbi ivən tuɑn hɝsɛlf wɪð ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən mɛɹəθdəmeɪn, ən deɪmeɪn u hæd bɪn ɛɛs sədaɪ.

Rubbing her cheek sullenly, Bethamin said, "He knows near enough everything except the basement, my Lady." And she began to describe a fantastical web of treason connecting Egeanin and Bayle and Suroth and maybe even Tuon herself with Aes Sedai, and marath'damane, and damane who had been Aes Sedai.

bɛθəmənz vɔɪs bɪɡæn tə ɡɹoʊ pænɪki əz ʃi dɑɹɾɪd fɹəm wʌn ɪnkɹɛɾəbəl tʃɑɹdʒ tə ənʌðɝ, ən bɪfɔɹ lɔŋ, ɛdʒiənɪn bɪɡæn sɪpɪŋ bɹændi. dʒʌst sɪps. ʃi wɑz kɑm. ʃi wɑz ɪn kəmæn ə hɝsɛlf. ʃi wɑz . . . ðɪs wɑz bɪɑnd ʃoʊl wɔɾɝz. ʃi wɑz ɹaɪɾɪŋ kloʊz ɑn ə li ʃɔɹ, ən soʊulblɪndɝ hɪmsɛlf ɹoʊd ðət ɡeɪl, kʌmɪŋ tə stil əɹ aɪz. æftɝ lɪsnɪŋ fəɹ ə taɪm wɪð ɪz oʊn aɪz ɡɹoʊɪŋ waɪɾɝ ən waɪɾɝ, beɪl dʒɹæŋk daʊn ə bɹɪmfəl kʌp ə ðə dɑɹk ɹɔ lɪkɝ ɪn wʌn ɡoʊ. ʃi wɑz ɹɪliv tə si hɪz ʃɑk, ən ɡɪlti ət filɪŋ ɹɪlivd. ʃi wəd nɑt bɪliv ɪm ə mɝɾɝɝ. bɪsaɪdz, hi wɑz vɛɹi ɡʊd juzɪŋ ɪz hænz bʌɾ oʊnli fɛɹ əɾ ə sɔɹd; wɪð wɛpənz əɹ bɛɹ-hændəd, ðə haɪ lɔɹd tʃɹɑk wʊɾə ɡʌɾɪd beɪl laɪk ə kɑɹp. hɝ oʊnli ɪkskjus fəɹ ivən kənsɪɾɝɪŋ ɪt wɑz ðəɾ i hæd bɪn wɪð tu ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn tæntʃəkoʊ. ðə hoʊl θɪŋ wɑz nɑnsɛns. ɪt hæd tə bi! ðoʊz tu ɛɛs sədaɪ hæd nɑt bɪn pɑɹɾ ʌv ɛni plɑt, dʒʌst ə tʃæns miɾɪŋ. laɪts tʃɹuθ, ðeɪ hæd bɪn lɪɾəl mɔɹ ðən ɡɝlz, ən nɪɹ ɪnəsəns ət ðæt, tu sɔfθɑɹɾɪd tə æksɛpt əɹ sədʒɛstʃən ðeɪ kʌt ðə sikɝz θɹoʊt wən ðeɪ hæd ðə tʃæns. ə pɪɾi, ðæt. ðeɪ hæd hændəɾ əɹ ðə meɪl æɾəm. aɪs kɹɛp daʊn əɹ spaɪn. ɪf ðə sikɝ ɛvɝ lɝnd ʃi hæɾ ɪntɛndəd dɪspoʊzɪŋ ə ði æɾəm ðə weɪ ðoʊz ɛɛs sədaɪ sədʒɛstəd, ɪf ɛniwʌn lɝnd, ʃi wəd bi dʒʌdʒd əz ɡɪlti ʌv tʃɹizən əz ɪf ʃi hæd səksiɾəd ɪn dʒɹɑpɪŋ ɪɾ ɪndə ði oʊʃənz dɛpθs. ɑɹ jə nɑt? ʃi dɪmændəɾ ə hɝsɛlf. ðə dɑɹk wʌn wɑz kʌmɪŋ tə stil əɹ aɪz.

Bethamin's voice began to grow panicky as she darted from one incredible charge to another, and before long, Egeanin began sipping brandy. Just sips. She was calm. She was in command of herself. She was . . . This was beyond shoal waters. She was riding close on a lee shore, and Soulblinder himself rode that gale, coming to steal her eyes. After listening for a time with his own eyes growing wider and wider, Bayle drank down a brimful cup of the dark raw liquor in one go. She was relieved to see his shock, and guilty at feeling relieved. She would not believe him a murderer. Besides, he was very good using his hands but only fair at a sword; with weapons or bare-handed, the High Lord Turak would have gutted Bayle like a carp. Her only excuse for even considering it was that he had been with two Aes Sedai in Tanchico. The whole thing was nonsense. It had to be! Those two Aes Sedai had not been part of any plot, just a chance meeting. Light's truth, they had been little more than girls, and near innocents at that, too softhearted to accept her suggestion they cut the Seeker's throat when they had the chance. A pity, that. They had handed her the male a'dam. Ice crept down her spine. If the Seeker ever learned she had intended disposing of the a'dam the way those Aes Sedai suggested, if anyone learned, she would be judged as guilty of treason as if she had succeeded in dropping it into the ocean's depths. Are you not? she demanded of herself. The Dark One was coming to steal her eyes.

tɪɹz stʃɹimɪŋ daʊn əɹ feɪs, bɛθəmən klʌtʃt əɹ kʌp tə hɝ bɹɛsts əz ðoʊ hʌɡɪŋ hɝsɛlf. ɪf ʃi wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kip fɹəm ʃeɪkɪŋ, ʃi feɪl mɪzɝəbli. tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ, ʃi stɛɹɾ əɾ ɛdʒiənɪn, əɹ pɝhæps ət sʌmθɪŋ bɪɑn hɝ. sʌmθɪŋ hɔɹəfaɪɪŋ. ðə faɪɝ hæd nɑt wɔɹm ðə ɹum vɛɹi fɑɹ jɛt, bʌt swɛt wɑz biɾɪd ɑn bɛθəmənz feɪs. ". . . ən ɪf i lɝnz əbaʊt ɹɛnə ən sɛɾə," ʃi bæbəld, "hi wɪl noʊ fəɹ ʃʊɹ! hɪl kʌm æftɝ mi, ən ði ʌðɝ sʌldəm! juv tə stɑp hɪm! ɪf i teɪks mi, əl ɡɪv ɪm jəɹ neɪm! aɪ wɪl!" əbɹʌpli ʃi tɪltəd lɪftəd ðə kʌp tə hɝ maʊθ ənstɛɾəli ən ɡʌlp ðə kɑntɛns, tʃoʊkɪŋ ən kɑfɪŋ, ðən θɹʌst ɪɾ aʊt təwɔɹd beɪl fəɹ mɔɹ. hi dɪd nɑt muv. hi lʊk pɑliækst.

Tears streaming down her face, Bethamin clutched her cup to her breasts as though hugging herself. If she was trying to keep from shaking, she failed miserably. Trembling, she stared at Egeanin, or perhaps at something beyond her. Something horrifying. The fire had not warmed the room very far yet, but sweat was beaded on Bethamin's face. ". . . and if he learns about Renna and Seta," she babbled, "he will know for sure! He'll come after me, and the other sul'dam! You have to stop him! If he takes me, I'll give him your name! I will!" Abruptly she tilted lifted the cup to her mouth unsteadily and gulped the contents, choking and coughing, then thrust it out toward Bayle for more. He did not move. He looked poleaxed.

"hu ɑɹ ɹɛnə ən sɛɾə?" ɛdʒiənɪn æskt. ʃi wɑz əz fɹaɪɾənd əz ðə sʌldəm, bʌɾ əz ɔlweɪz, ʃi kɛpt əɹ fɪɹ hɑɹd-ɹift. "wʌt kən ðə sikɝ lɝn əbaʊt ðɛm?" bɛθəmənz aɪz slɪɾ əweɪ, ɹəfjuzɪŋ tə mit hɝz, ən əbɹʌpli ʃi nu. "ðeɪ ɑɹ sʌldəm, ɑɹən ðeɪ, bɛθəmən? ən ðeɪ wɝ kɑlɝd, tu, dʒʌs laɪk ju."

"Who are Renna and Seta?" Egeanin asked. She was as frightened as the sul'dam, but as always, she kept her fear hard-reefed. "What can the Seeker learn about them?" Bethamin's eyes slid away, refusing to meet hers, and abruptly she knew. "They are sul'dam, aren't they, Bethamin? And they were collared, too, just like you."

"ðeɪ ɑɹ ɪn sjuɹɔθs sɝvəs," ðə wʊmən wɪmpɝd. "ðeɪ ɑɹ nɛvɝ əlaʊd tə bi kəmplit, ðoʊ. sjuɹɔθ noʊz."

"They are in Suroth's service," the woman whimpered. "They are never allowed to be complete, though. Suroth knows."

ɛdʒiənɪn ɹʌbd əɾ əɹ aɪz wɛɹəli. pɝhæps ðəɹ wɑz ə kənspɪɹəsi, æftɝ ɔl. əɹ sjuɹɔθ maɪt bi haɪɾɪŋ wʌt ðə pɛɹ wɝ tə pɹətɛk ði ɛmpaɪɝ. ði ɛmpaɪɝ dɪpɛndəɾ ɑn sʌldəm; ɪts stʃɹɛŋkθ wɑz bɪlt ɑn ðɛm. ðə nuz ðət sʌldəm wɝ wɪmən u kəd lɝn tə tʃænəl maɪt ʃæɾɝ ði ɛmpaɪɝ tə ɪts kɔɹ. ɪt hæd ʃʊɹli ʃeɪkən hɝ. meɪbi ʃæɾɝd hɝ. ʃi hɝsɛlf hæd nɑt fɹid bɛθəmən aʊɾ ə duɾi. soʊ mɛni θɪŋz hæd tʃeɪnʒd ɪn tæntʃəkoʊ. ʃi noʊ lɔŋɡɝ bɪliv ðəɾ ɛni wʊmən u kəd tʃænəl dɪzɝv tə bi kɑlɝd. kɹɪmənəlz, sɝɾənli, ən meɪbi ðoʊz u ɹəfjuzd oʊðz tə ðə kɹɪstəl θɹoʊn, ən . . . ʃi dɪd nɑt noʊ. wʌns, hɝ laɪf hæd bɪn meɪɾ ʌp ə ɹɑk-sɑləd sɝɾəntiz, laɪk ɡaɪɾɪŋ stɑɹz ðət nɛvɝ feɪld. ʃi wɑntəɾ əɹ oʊld laɪf bæk. ʃi wɑntəɾ ə fju sɝɾəntiz.

Egeanin rubbed at her eyes wearily. Perhaps there was a conspiracy, after all. Or Suroth might be hiding what the pair were to protect the Empire. The Empire depended on sul'dam; its strength was built on them. The news that sul'dam were women who could learn to channel might shatter the Empire to its core. It had surely shaken her. Maybe shattered her. She herself had not freed Bethamin out of duty. So many things had changed in Tanchico. She no longer believed that any woman who could channel deserved to be collared. Criminals, certainly, and maybe those who refused oaths to the Crystal Throne, and . . . She did not know. Once, her life had been made up of rock-solid certainties, like guiding stars that never failed. She wanted her old life back. She wanted a few certainties.

"aɪ θɔt," bɛθəmən bɪɡæn. ʃi wəɾ əv noʊ lɪps lɛft ɪf ʃi dɪd nɑt stɑp lɪkɪŋ ðɛm. "maɪ leɪɾi, ɪf ðə sikɝ . . . sʌfɝz ən æksəɾənt . . . pɝhæps ðə deɪnʒɝ wəd pæs wɪð hɪm." laɪt, ðə wʊmən bɪlivd ɪn ðɪs ɪntʃɹiɡ əɡɛns ðə kɹɪstəl θɹoʊn, ən ʃi wɑz ɹɛɾi tə lɛɾ ɪt pæs tə seɪv əɹ oʊn skɪn!

"I thought," Bethamin began. She would have no lips left if she did not stop licking them. "My Lady, if the Seeker . . . suffers an accident . . . perhaps the danger would pass with him." Light, the woman believed in this intrigue against the Crystal Throne, and she was ready to let it pass to save her own skin!

ɛdʒiənɪn ɹoʊz, ən ðə sʌldəm hæd noʊ tʃɔɪs bʌt tə fɑloʊ. "aɪ wɪl θɪŋk ɑn ɪt, bɛθəmən. jəl kʌm tə si mi ɛvɹi deɪ jə ɑɹ fɹi. ðə sikɝ wɪl ɪkspɛkt ɪt. əntɪl aɪ meɪk maɪ dɪsɪʒən, jəl də nʌθɪŋ. dʒju ʌndɝstæn mi? nʌθɪŋ ɪksɛp jəɹ duɾiz ən wʌɾ aɪ tɛl ju." bɛθəmən ʌndɝstʊd. ʃi wɑz soʊ ɹɪliv ðət sʌmwʌn ɛls wɑz dilɪŋ wɪð ðə deɪnʒɝ ðət ʃi nɛlt əɡɛn ən kɪst ɛdʒiənɪnz hænd.

Egeanin rose, and the sul'dam had no choice but to follow. "I will think on it, Bethamin. You will come to see me every day you are free. The Seeker will expect it. Until I make my decision, you will do nothing. Do you understand me? Nothing except your duties and what I tell you." Bethamin understood. She was so relieved that someone else was dealing with the danger that she knelt again and kissed Egeanin's hand.

ɔl bʌt bʌndəlɪŋ ðə wʊmən aʊɾ ə ðə ɹum, ɛdʒiənɪn kloʊz ðə dɔɹ, ðən hɝld əɹ kʌp ət ðə faɪɝpleɪs. ɪt hɪt ðə bɹɪks ən baʊnst ɔf, ɹoʊlɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə smɔl ɹʌɡ ɑn ðə flɔɹ. ɪt wɑz dɛntɪd. hɝ fɑðɝ hæd ɡɪvən əɹ ðət sɛɾ ə kʌps wən ʃi ɡeɪn əɹ fɝs kəmænd. ɔl ðə stʃɹɛŋkθ sim tə hæv litʃt aʊɾ ə hɝ. ðə sikɝ hæd nɪɾəd munbimz ən hæpənstæns ɪndə ə stʃɹæŋɡəlɪŋ kɔɹd fəɹ əɹ nɛk. ɪf ʃi wɑz nɑt neɪm pɹɑpɝɾi ɪnstɛd. ʃi ʃʌɾɝəd ət ðə pɑsəbɪləɾi. wʌtɛvɝ ʃi dɪd, ðə sikɝ hæɾ əɹ tʃɹæpt.

All but bundling the woman out of the room, Egeanin closed the door, then hurled her cup at the fireplace. It hit the bricks and bounced off, rolling across the small rug on the floor. It was dented. Her father had given her that set of cups when she gained her first command. All the strength seemed to have leached out of her. The Seeker had knitted moonbeams and happenstance into a strangling cord for her neck. If she was not named property instead. She shuddered at the possibility. Whatever she did, the Seeker had her trapped.

"aɪ kən kɪl hɪm." beɪl flɛkst ɪz hænz, bɹɔd laɪk ðə ɹɛst ə hɪm. "hi bi ə skɪni mæn, əz aɪ ɹikɔl. juz tə ɛvɹiwʌn oʊbeɪɪŋ ɪz wɝd. hɪl noʊ bi ɪkspɛktɪŋ ɛniwʌn tə snæp ɪz nɛk."

"I can kill him." Bayle flexed his hands, broad like the rest of him. "He be a skinny man, as I recall. Used to everyone obeying his word. He will no be expecting anyone to snap his neck."

"jul nɛvɝ faɪn ɪm tə kɪl, beɪl. hi woʊn miɾ əɹ ɪn ðə seɪm pleɪs twaɪs, ən ivən ɪf jə fɑloʊɾ əɹ deɪ ən naɪt, hi maɪt wɛl bi ɪn dɪsɡaɪz. jə kænɑt kɪl ɛvɹi mæn ʃi spiks tə."

"You'll never find him to kill, Bayle. He won't meet her in the same place twice, and even if you followed her day and night, he might well be in disguise. You cannot kill every man she speaks to."

stɪfənɪŋ əɹ spaɪn, ʃi mɑɹtʃt tə ðə teɪbəl wɛɹ əɹ ɹaɪɾɪŋ dɛsk sæɾ ən flɪpt oʊpən ðə lɪd. ðə weɪv-kɑɹvd ɹaɪɾɪŋ dɛsk, wɪð ɪts sɪlvɝ-maʊntəd ɡlæs ɪŋkpɑɾ ən sɪlvɝ sæn dʒɑɹ, hæd bɪn əɹ mʌðɝz ɡɪft ət ðət fɝs kəmænd. ðə nitli stækt ʃits ə faɪn peɪpɝ bɔɹ əɹ nuli ɡɹæntəd sɪdʒəl, ə sɔɹɾ ən ə faʊld æŋkɝ. "aɪ wɪl ɹaɪɾ aʊt jəɹ mænumɪʃən," ʃi sɛd, dɪpɪŋ ðə sɪlvɝ pɛn, "ænd ɡɪv jə ɪnʌf kɔɪn tə baɪ pæsədʒ." ðə pɛn ɡlaɪɾɪd əkɹɔs ðə peɪdʒ. ʃi hæɾ ɔlweɪz hæɾ ə ɡʊd hænd. lɔɡ ɛntʃɹiz hæd tə bi lɛɡəbəl. "nɑɾ ɪnʌf tə baɪ ə ʃɪp, aɪ fɪɹ, bʌɾ ɪt mʌs du. jəl dɪpɑɹɾ ɑn ðə fɝst əveɪləbəl ʃɪp. ʃeɪv ðə ɹɛst ə jəɹ hɛd, ən jə ʃəɾ əv noʊ tʃɹʌbəl. ɪts stɪl ə ʃɑk, siɪŋ bɔl mɛn nɑt wɛɹɪŋ wɪɡz, bʌt soʊ fɑɹ noʊ wʌn simz tə - " ʃi ɡæspt əz beɪl slɪd ðə peɪdʒ ɹaɪɾ aʊt fɹəm ʌndɝ əɹ pɛn.

Stiffening her spine, she marched to the table where her writing desk sat and flipped open the lid. The wave-carved writing desk, with its silver-mounted glass inkpot and silver sand jar, had been her mother's gift at that first command. The neatly stacked sheets of fine paper bore her newly granted sigil, a sword and a fouled anchor. "I will write out your manumission," she said, dipping the silver pen, "and give you enough coin to buy passage." The pen glided across the page. She had always had a good hand. Log entries had to be legible. "Not enough to buy a ship, I fear, but it must do. You will depart on the first available ship. Shave the rest of your head, and you should have no trouble. It's still a shock, seeing bald men not wearing wigs, but so far no one seems to - " She gasped as Bayle slid the page right out from under her pen.

"ɪf jə də fɹi mi, jə kən noʊ ɡɪmi ɔɹɾɝz," hi sɛd. "bɪsaɪdz, jə mʌst ɛnʃʊɹ aɪ kən səpɔɹt maɪsɛlf ɪf jə də fɹi mi." hi stʌk ðə peɪdʒ ɪndə ðə faɪɝ ən wɑtʃt waɪl ɪt blækən ən kɝld. "ə ʃɪp, jə dɪd seɪ, ən əl hoʊl jə tə ɪt."

"If you do free me, you can no give me orders," he said. "Besides, you must ensure I can support myself if you do free me." He stuck the page into the fire and watched while it blackened and curled. "A ship, you did say, and I will hold you to it."

"lɪsən wɛl ən hɪɹ," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn əɹ bɛs kɔɹɾɝdɛk vɔɪs, bʌɾ ɪt meɪd noʊ ɪmpɹɛʃən ɑn hɪm. ɪt hæd tə bi ðə kɝs dʒɹɛs.

"Listen well and hear," she said in her best quarterdeck voice, but it made no impression on him. It had to be the cursed dress.

"ju də niɾ ə kɹu," hi sɛd ɹaɪɾ oʊvɝ hɝ, "æn aɪ kən faɪn jə wʌn, ivən hɪɹ."

"You do need a crew," he said right over her, "and I can find you one, even here."

"wʌt ɡʊd wɪl ə kɹu də mi? aɪ doʊn əv ə ʃɪp. ɪf aɪ dɪd, wɛɹ kəɾ aɪ seɪl ðət ðə sikɝ kʊdn faɪn mi?"

"What good will a crew do me? I don't have a ship. If I did, where could I sail that the Seeker couldn't find me?"

beɪl ʃɹʌɡd əz ðoʊ ðət wɑz nɑɾ ɪmpɔɹɾənt. "ə kɹu, fɝst. aɪ dɪd ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðət jʌŋ fɛloʊ ɪn ðə kɪtʃənz, ðə wʌn wɪð ðə læs ɑn ɪz ni. stɑp ɡɹɪmæsɪŋ. ðəɹ bi noʊ hɑɹm tə ə lɪɾəl kɪsɪŋ."

Bayle shrugged as though that was not important. "A crew, first. I did recognize that young fellow in the kitchens, the one with the lass on his knee. Stop grimacing. There be no harm to a little kissing."

ʃi dʒɹu hɝsɛlf ʌp, pɹipɛɹd tə sɛɾ ɪm fɝmli tə ɹaɪts. ʃi wɑz fɹaʊnɪŋ, nɑt ɡɹɪmæsɪŋ, ðət pɛɹ hæd bɪn ɡɹoʊpɪŋ ət wʌn ənʌðɝ ɪn pʌblɪk laɪk ænəməlz, ən i wɑz əɹ pɹɑpɝɾi! hi kəd nɑt spik tə hɝ ðɪs weɪ!

She drew herself up, prepared to set him firmly to rights. She was frowning, not grimacing, that pair had been groping at one another in public like animals, and he was her property! He could not speak to her this way!

"hɪz neɪm bi mæt kɔθən," beɪl wɛn ɑn ivən əz ʃi oʊpən əɹ maʊθ. "baɪ hɪz kloʊðz, hiz kʌm ʌp ɪn ðə wɝld, ən fɑɹ. ðə fɝs taɪm aɪ dɪd si hɪm, hi dɪd bi ɪn ə fɑɹmɝz koʊt, ɪskeɪpɪŋ tʃɹɑləks ɪn ə pleɪs ivən tʃɹɑləks bi əfɹeɪɾ ʌv. ðə læs taɪm, hæf ðə taʊn ʌv waɪtbɹɪdʒ dɪd bi bɝnɪŋ, kloʊs ɪnʌf tə, ən ə mɹdʒɹɑl dɪd bi tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kɪl ɪm ən ɪz fɹɛnz. aɪ dɪd noʊ si fəɹ maɪsɛlf, bʌɾ ɛniθɪŋ ɛls bi mɔɹ ðən aɪ kən bɪliv. ɛni mæn u kən sɝvaɪv tʃɹɑləks ən mɹdʒɹɑl də bi jusfəl, aɪ θɪŋk. ɪspɛʃli naʊ."

"His name be Mat Cauthon," Bayle went on even as she opened her mouth. "By his clothes, he has come up in the world, and far. The first time I did see him, he did be in a farmer's coat, escaping Trollocs in a place even Trollocs be afraid of. The last time, half the town of Whitebridge did be burning, close enough to, and a Myrddraal did be trying to kill him and his friends. I did no see for myself, but anything else be more than I can believe. Any man who can survive Trollocs and Myrddraal do be useful, I think. Especially now."

"sʌmdeɪ," ʃi ɡɹaʊld, "aɪ æm gɑnə hæv tə si səm ə ðiz tʃɹɑləks ən mɹdʒɹɑl jə ɡoʊ ɑn əbaʊt." ðə θɪŋz kəd nɑt bi hæf əz fɪɹsəm əz i dɪskɹaɪbd.

"Someday," she growled, "I am going to have to see some of these Trollocs and Myrddraal you go on about." The things could not be half as fearsome as he described.

hi ɡɹɪn ən ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. hi nu wʌt ʃi θɔɾ əbaʊt ðiz soʊ-kɔld ʃæɾoʊzpɔn. "bɛɾɝ stɪl, jʌŋ mæstɝ kɔθən dɪɾ əv kəmpænjənz ɑn maɪ ʃɪp. ɡʊd mɛn fəɹ ðɪs sɪtʃueɪʃən, tu. wʌn, jə də noʊ. tɑm mɛɹɪlɪn."

He grinned and shook his head. He knew what she thought about these so-called Shadowspawn. "Better still, young Master Cauthon did have companions on my ship. Good men for this situation, too. One, you do know. Thom Merrilin."

ɛdʒiənɪnz bɹɛθ kɑt. mɛɹɪlɪn wɑz ə klɛvɝ oʊl mæn. ə deɪnʒɝəs oʊl mæn. ən i hæd bɪn wɪð ðoʊz tu ɛɛs sədaɪ wən ʃi mɛt beɪl. "beɪl, ɪz ðəɹ ə kənspɪɹəsi? tɛl mi. pliz?" noʊ wʌn sɛd pliz tə pɹɑpɝɾi, nɑɾ ivən tə sɔɪhɪn. nɑɾ ənlɛs ðeɪ wɑntəd sʌmθɪŋ bædli, ɛniweɪ.

Egeanin's breath caught. Merrilin was a clever old man. A dangerous old man. And he had been with those two Aes Sedai when she met Bayle. "Bayle, is there a conspiracy? Tell me. Please?" No one said please to property, not even to so'jhin. Not unless they wanted something badly, anyway.

ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛɾ əɡɛn, hi lin ə hæn ɑn ðə stoʊn mæntəlpis ən fɹaʊn ɪndə ðə fleɪmz. "ɛɛs sədaɪ də plɑt ðə weɪ fɪʃ swɪm. ðeɪ kəd skim wɪð sjuɹɔθ, bʌt ðə kwɛstʃən də bi, kəd ʃi skim wɪð ðɛm? aɪ dɪd si hɝ lʊk ət deɪmeɪn, laɪk ðeɪ dɪd bi meɪnʒi dɑɡz wɪð fliz ən kætʃɪŋ dɪzizəz. kəd ʃi ivən tɔk tə ən ɛɛs sədaɪ?" hi lʊkt ʌp, ən ɪz aɪz wɝ klɪɹ ən oʊpən, haɪɾɪŋ nʌθɪŋ. "aɪ də tɛl ðɪs fəɹ tʃɹu. ɑn maɪ ɡɹændmʌðɝz ɡɹeɪv, aɪ də noʊ ʌv noʊ plɑt. bʌt dɪɾ aɪ noʊ ʌv tɛn, aɪ stɪl wɪl noʊ lɛt ðət sikɝ əɹ ɛniwʌn ɛls hɑɹm ju, wʌtɛvɝ ɪt də teɪk." ɪt wɑz ðə sɔɹɾ ə θɪŋ ɛni lɔɪəl sɔɪhɪn maɪt seɪ. wɛl, noʊ sɔɪhɪn ʃi hæɾ ɛvɝ hɝɾ ʌv wʊɾə bɪn soʊ stʃɹeɪtfɔɹwɝd, bʌt ðə sɛntəməns wɝ ðə seɪm. oʊnli, ʃi nu hi dɪd nɑt min ɪt ðət weɪ, kəd nɛvɝ min ɪt ðət weɪ.

Shaking his head again, he leaned a hand on the stone mantelpiece and frowned into the flames. "Aes Sedai do plot the way fish swim. They could scheme with Suroth, but the question do be, could she scheme with them? I did see her look at damane, like they did be mangy dogs with fleas and catching diseases. Could she even talk to an Aes Sedai?" He looked up, and his eyes were clear and open, hiding nothing. "I do tell this for true. On my grandmother's grave, I do know of no plot. But did I know of ten, I still will no let that Seeker or anyone else harm you, whatever it do take." It was the sort of thing any loyal so'jhin might say. Well, no so'jhin she had ever heard of would have been so straightforward, but the sentiments were the same. Only, she knew he did not mean it that way, could never mean it that way.

"θæŋk ju, beɪl." ə stɛɾi vɔɪs wɑz ə nəsɛsəɾi fəɹ kəmænd, bʌt ʃi wɑz pɹaʊd ðət hɝz wɑz stɛɾi naʊ. "faɪn ðɪs mæstɝ kɔθən, ən tɑm mɛɹɪlɪn, ɪf jə kæn. pɝhæps sʌmθɪŋ kən bi dʌn."

"Thank you, Bayle." A steady voice was a necessity for command, but she was proud that hers was steady now. "Find this Master Cauthon, and Thom Merrilin, if you can. Perhaps something can be done."

hi feɪl tə baʊ bɪfɔɹ livɪŋ əɹ pɹɛzəns, bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑɾ ivən kənsɪɾɝ ʌpbɹeɪɾɪŋ hɪm. ʃi dɪd nɑɾ ɪntɛn tə lɛt ðə sikɝ teɪk hɝ, iðɝ. wʌtɛvɝ ɪt tʊk tə stɑp hɪm. ðət wɑz ə dɪsɪʒən ʃi hæd ɹitʃt bɪfɔɹ ʃi fɹid bɛθəmən. ʃi fɪl ðə dɛntɪd kʌp tə ðə bɹɪm wɪð bɹændi, minɪŋ tə ɡɛt soʊ dʒɹʌŋk ʃi kəd nɑt θɪŋk, bʌɾ ɪnstɛd ʃi sæt piɹɪŋ ɪndə ðə dɑɹk lɪkwəd wɪθaʊt tʌtʃɪŋ ə dʒɹɑp. wʌtɛvɝ ɪt tʊk. laɪt, ʃi wɑz noʊ bɛɾɝ ðən bɛθəmən! bʌt noʊɪŋ ɪt tʃeɪnʒd nʌθɪŋ. wʌtɛvɝ ɪt tʊk.

He failed to bow before leaving her presence, but she did not even consider upbraiding him. She did not intend to let the Seeker take her, either. Whatever it took to stop him. That was a decision she had reached before she freed Bethamin. She filled the dented cup to the brim with brandy, meaning to get so drunk she could not think, but instead she sat peering into the dark liquid without touching a drop. Whatever it took. Light, she was no better than Bethamin! But knowing it changed nothing. Whatever it took.


tʃæptɝ twɛntiɾu


CHAPTER 22

aʊɾ ə θɪn ɛɹ


Out of Thin Air

ði æmhɑɹə mɑɹkət wɑz wʌn ə θɹi ɪn fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ wɛɹ fɔɹənɝz wɝ əlaʊd tə tʃɹeɪd, bʌt dɪspaɪt ðə neɪm, ðə hjudʒ skwɛɹ hæd nʌθɪŋ ə ðə lʊk ʌv ə mɑɹkət, noʊ mɑɹkət stɔlz əɹ dɪspleɪz ə mɝtʃəndaɪz. ə fju maʊntəd ɹaɪɾɝz, ə hændfʊl ə kloʊz sɪdæn tʃɛɹz kæɹid baɪ bɹaɪtli lɪvɹid bɛɹɝz ən ði əkeɪʒənəl koʊtʃ wɪð ɪts wɪndoʊ kɝɾənz dʒɹɔn meɪd ðɛɹ weɪ ðoʊ ə spɑɹs jɛt bʌsəlɪŋ kɹaʊd ðət maɪɾ əv bɪn sin ɪn ɛni lɑɹdʒ sɪɾi. moʊst wɝ wɛl ɹæpt ɪn ðɛɹ kloʊks əɡɛns ðə mɔɹnɪŋ wɪnz bloʊɪŋ ɪn ɔf ðə leɪk ðət sɝaʊndəd ðə sɪɾi, ən ɪt wɑz ðə koʊl ðət meɪɾ əm hɝi mɔɹ ðən ɛni ɝdʒən bɪznəs. ɝaʊn ðə skwɛɹ, əz ət ðə sɪɾiz ʌðɝ tu stʃɹeɪnʒɝz' mɑɹkəts, ðə tɔl stoʊn haʊsəz ə bæŋkɝz ɹʌbd ʃoʊldɝz wɪð sleɪt-ɹuf stoʊn ɪnz wɛɹ ðə fɔɹən mɝtʃəns steɪɾ ən blɑki wɪndoʊləs stoʊn wɛɹhaʊzɪz wɛɹ ðɛɹ ɡʊdz wɝ stɔɹd, ɔl dʒʌmbəld ɪn əmʌŋ stoʊn steɪbəlz ən stoʊn-wɔld wæɡən jɑɹdz. fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ wɑz ə sɪɾi ʌv stoʊn wɔlz ən sleɪt ɹufs. ðɪs taɪm ə jɪɹ, ði ɪnz wɝ ə kɔɹɾɝ fʊl ət bɛst, ən ðə wɛɹhaʊzɪz ən wæɡən jɑɹdz ɛmptiɝ ðən ðæt. kʌm spɹɪŋ ən ðə fʊl ɹɪvaɪvəl ə tʃɹeɪd, ðoʊ, mɝtʃəns wəd peɪ tʃɹɪpəl fəɹ wʌtɛvɝ speɪs ðeɪ kəd faɪnd.

The Amhara Market was one of three in Far Madding where foreigners were allowed to trade, but despite the name, the huge square had nothing of the look of a market, no market stalls or displays of merchandise. A few mounted riders, a handful of closed sedan chairs carried by brightly liveried bearers and the occasional coach with its window curtains drawn made their way though a sparse yet bustling crowd that might have been seen in any large city. Most were well wrapped in their cloaks against the morning winds blowing in off the lake that surrounded the city, and it was the cold that made them hurry more than any urgent business. Around the square, as at the city's other two Strangers' Markets, the tall stone houses of bankers rubbed shoulders with slate-roofed stone inns where the foreign merchants stayed and blocky windowless stone warehouses where their goods were stored, all jumbled in among stone stables and stone-walled wagon yards. Far Madding was a city of stone walls and slate roofs. This time of year, the inns were a quarter full at best, and the warehouses and wagon yards emptier than that. Come spring and the full revival of trade, though, merchants would pay triple for whatever space they could find.

ə ɹaʊn mɑɹbəl pɛɾəstəl ɪn ðə sɛntɝ ə ðə skwɛɹ hɛld ə stætʃu ʌv seɪviən æmhɑɹə, tu spænz tɔl ən pɹaʊɾ ɪn fɝ-tʃɹɪmd ɹoʊbz ə mɑɹbəl, wɪð ɪlæbɹət mɑɹbəl tʃeɪnz ʌv ɔfəs ɝaʊn əɹ nɛk. hɝ mɑɹbəl feɪs wɑz stɝn bɪniθ ðə fɝs kaʊnsəlz dʒuəl mɑɹbəl daɪədɛm, ən əɹ ɹaɪt hæn fɝmli ɡɹɪp ðə hɪlt ʌv ə mɑɹbəl sɔɹd, ɪts pɔɪn ɹɛstɪŋ bɪtwin əɹ slɪpɝd fit, waɪl əɹ ɹeɪz lɛf hæn eɪmd ə wɔɹnɪŋ mɑɹbəl fɪŋɡɝ təwɔɹd ðə tiɹ ɡeɪt, səm θɹi-kɔɹɾɝz ʌv ə maɪl əweɪ. fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ dɪpɛndəɾ ɑn mɝtʃəns fɹəm tiɹ ən ɪljən ən keɪɛmlɪn, bʌt ðə haɪ kaʊnsəl wɑz ɛvɝ wɛɹi ʌv fɔɹənɝz ən ðɛɹ kɝʌptɪŋ aʊtlænd weɪz. wʌn ə ðə stil-kæp stʃɹit ɡɑɹdz, ɪn ə lɛðɝ koʊt soʊn wɪð oʊvɝlæpɪŋ skwɛɹ mɛɾəl pleɪts ən ə ɡoʊldən hæn ɑn ðə lɛft ʃoʊldɝ, stʊd bɪloʊ ðə stætʃu juzɪŋ ə lɔŋ lɪmbɝ poʊl tə fɹaɪɾən əweɪ blæk-wɪŋd ɡɹeɪ pɪdʒənz. seɪviən æmhɑɹə wɑz wʌn ə ðə θɹi moʊst ɹɪvɪɹd wɪmən ɪn fɑɹ mæɾɪŋz hɪstɝi, ðoʊ nʌn wɑz noʊn vɛɹi fɑɹ bɪɑn ðə leɪks ʃɔɹz. tu mɛn fɹəm ðə sɪɾi wɝ mɛnʃən ɪn ɛvɹi hɪstɝi ʌv ðə wɝld, ðoʊ ɪt hæd bɪn kɔld ɹɛn mədɔɹ wən wʌn wɑz bɔɹn ən fɛl mɔɹinə fəɹ ði ʌðɝ, bʌt fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ dɪɾ ɪts fɝvən bɛs tə fɝɡɛt ɹɑoʊlɪn dɑɹksbeɪn ən jʊɹiən stoʊnboʊ. ɪn ə ɹil weɪ, ðoʊz tu mɛn wɝ waɪ ɹænd wɑz ɪn fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ.

A round marble pedestal in the center of the square held a statue of Savion Amhara, two spans tall and proud in fur-trimmed robes of marble, with elaborate marble chains of office around her neck. Her marble face was stern beneath the First Counsel's jeweled marble diadem, and her right hand firmly gripped the hilt of a marble sword, its point resting between her slippered feet, while her raised left hand aimed a warning marble finger toward the Tear Gate, some three-quarters of a mile away. Far Madding depended on merchants from Tear and Illian and Caemlyn, but the High Council was ever wary of foreigners and their corrupting outland ways. One of the steel-capped Street Guards, in a leather coat sewn with overlapping square metal plates and a Golden Hand on the left shoulder, stood below the statue using a long limber pole to frighten away black-winged gray pigeons. Savion Amhara was one of the three most revered women in Far Madding's history, though none was known very far beyond the lake's shores. Two men from the city were mentioned in every history of the world, though it had been called Aren Mador when one was born and Fel Moreina for the other, but Far Madding did its fervent best to forget Raolin Darksbane and Yurian Stonebow. In a real way, those two men were why Rand was in Far Madding.

ə fju pipəl ɪn ði æmhɑɹə ɡlænst əɾ ɪm əz i pæst, jɛt noʊbɑdi ɡlæns twaɪs. ðəɾ i wɑz fɹəm ɔf wɑz pleɪn ɪnʌf, wɪð ɪz blu aɪz ən ɪz hɛɹ kʌɾ ət ðə ʃoʊldɝ. mɛn hɪɹ wɔɹ ɪt səmtaɪmz hæŋɪŋ ɔl ðə weɪ tə ðə weɪst, iðɝ taɪɾ ət ðə neɪp ə ðə nɛk əɹ hɛld wɪð ə klɪp. hɪz pleɪn bɹaʊn wʊlənz wɝ nɑndɪskɹɪpt, ðoʊ, noʊ bɛɾɝ ðən ə mɑɾɝətli səksɛsfəl mɝtʃən maɪt wɛɹ, ən i wɑz nɑt ði oʊnli wʌn kloʊɑkləs ɪn spaɪɾ ə ðə leɪk wɪnz. moʊst ə ði ʌðɝz wɝ fɔɹk-bɪɹɾəd kændɔɹi əɹ ɝæfɛlɪn wɪð bɛl bɹeɪdz, əɹ hɔk-noʊz sɑldəiənz, mɛn ən wɪmən u faʊn ðɪs wɛðɝ maɪl kəmpɛɹd tə bɔɹɾɝlənd wɪntɝ, bʌt nʌθɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪm sɛɾ i wɑz nɑɾ ə bɔɹɾɝləndɝ, tu. fəɹ ɪz pɑɹt, hi sɪmpli ɹəfjuz tə lɛt ðə koʊl tʌtʃ hɪm, ɪɡnɔɹɾ ɪɾ əz i maɪɾ əv ə flaɪ bʌzɪŋ. ə kloʊk maɪt ɡɛɾ ɪn ɪz weɪ, ɪf i faʊn ɪz tʃæns tə ækt.

A few people in the Amhara glanced at him as he passed, yet nobody glanced twice. That he was from off was plain enough, with his blue eyes and his hair cut at the shoulder. Men here wore it sometimes hanging all the way to the waist, either tied at the nape of the neck or held with a clip. His plain brown woolens were nondescript, though, no better than a moderately successful merchant might wear, and he was not the only one cloakless in spite of the lake winds. Most of the others were fork-bearded Kandori or Arafellin with belled braids, or hawk-nosed Saldaeans, men and women who found this weather mild compared to Borderland winter, but nothing about him said he was not a Borderlander, too. For his part, he simply refused to let the cold touch him, ignored it as he might have a fly buzzing. A cloak might get in his way, if he found his chance to act.

fəɹ wʌns, ivən ɪz haɪt dɪd nɑɾ ətʃɹæk noʊɾəs. ðəɹ wɝ ə ɡʊd mɛni vɛɹi tɔl mɛn ɪn fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ, fju ʌv əm neɪɾɪvz. mənəl ɹɑtʃeɪd hɪmsɛlf wɑz oʊnli ə hænd ʃɔɹɾɝ ðən ɹænd, ɪf ðæt. ɹænd steɪd wɛl bɪhaɪn ðə mæn, lɛɾɪŋ pipəl ən sɪdæn tʃɛɹz sɪf bɪtwin əm ən səmtaɪmz ivən haɪɾ ɪz kwɔɹi. wɪð ɪz hɛɹ daɪd blæk baɪ ɝbz nɪneɪiv hæd pɹəvaɪɾəd, hi daʊɾɪd ðət ðə ɹɛnəɡeɪɾ æʃəmən wəd noʊɾəs ɪm ivən ɪf ðə mæn tɝn ɝaʊnd. fəɹ ɪz pɑɹt, hi wɑz nɑt wɝiɾ əbaʊt luzɪŋ ɹɑtʃeɪd. moʊst ə ðə loʊkəl mɛn wɔɹ dʌl kʌlɝz, wɪð bɹaɪɾɝ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi əbaʊt ðə tʃɛst ən ʃoʊldɝz ən pɝhæps ə dʒuəl hɛɹ klɪp fəɹ ðə mɔɹ pɹɑspɝəs, waɪl ði aʊtlæn mɝtʃəns feɪvɝd soʊbɝ ʌnpɹitɛnʃəs kloʊðz, soʊ əz nɑt tə sim oʊvɝli wɛlθi, ən ðɛɹ ɡɑɹdz ən dʒɹaɪvɝz bʌndəl ðɛmsɛlvz ɪn ɹʌf wʊlənz. ɹɑtʃeɪdz bɹaɪt ɹɛd sɪlk koʊt stʊɾ aʊt. hi stʃɹoʊɾ əkɹɔs ðə skwɛɹ laɪk ə kɪŋ, wʌn hæn ɹɛstɪŋ laɪtli ɑn ðə hɪlt ə hɪz sɔɹd, ə fɝ-ɛdʒ kloʊk bɪloʊɪŋ bɪhaɪn ɪm ɪn ðə wɪnd. hi wɑz ə ful. ðət flæpɪŋ kloʊk ən ðə sɔɹɾ əlaɪk dʒɹu aɪz. hɪz wækst ən kɝl mʌstæʃɪz neɪmd ɪm ə mʊɹændiən, hu ʃəd bi ʃɪvɝɪŋ laɪk ɛni nɔɹməl hjumən biɪŋ, ən ðət sɔɹd . . . ə pjʊɹ bʊl ɡus ful.

For once, even his height did not attract notice. There were a good many very tall men in Far Madding, few of them natives. Manel Rochaid himself was only a hand shorter than Rand, if that. Rand stayed well behind the man, letting people and sedan chairs sift between them and sometimes even hide his quarry. With his hair dyed black by herbs Nynaeve had provided, he doubted that the renegade Asha'man would notice him even if the man turned around. For his part, he was not worried about losing Rochaid. Most of the local men wore dull colors, with brighter embroidery about the chest and shoulders and perhaps a jeweled hair clip for the more prosperous, while the outland merchants favored sober unpretentious clothes, so as not to seem overly wealthy, and their guards and drivers bundled themselves in rough woolens. Rochaid's bright red silk coat stood out. He strode across the square like a king, one hand resting lightly on the hilt of his sword, a fur-edged cloak billowing behind him in the wind. He was a fool. That flapping cloak and the sword alike drew eyes. His waxed and curled mustaches named him a Murandian, who should be shivering like any normal human being, and that sword . . . A pure bull goose fool.

jə ɑɹ ðə ful, kʌmɪŋ tə ðɪs pleɪs, luz θɝɪn pæntɪd waɪldli ɪnsaɪɾ ɪz hɛd. mædnəs! mædnəs! wɪv tə ɡɛɾ aʊt! wɪv tə!

You are the fool, coming to this place, Lews Therin panted wildly inside his head. Madness! Madness! We have to get out! We have to!

ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ðə vɔɪs, ɹænd pʊld ɪz snʌɡ ɡlʌvz taɪɾɝ ən kɛpt ə stɛɾi peɪs æftɝ ɹɑtʃeɪd. ə nʌmbɝ ə ðə stʃɹit ɡɑɹdz ɪn ðə skwɛɹ wɝ wɑtʃɪŋ ðə mæn. fɔɹənɝz wɝ kənsɪɾɝd tʃɹʌbəlmeɪkɝz ən hɑthɛdz, ən mʊɹændiənz hæɾ ə pɹɪkli ɹɛpjəteɪʃən. ə fɔɹənɝ kæɹiɪŋ ə sɔɹɾ ɔlweɪz ətʃɹæktəd ðə ɡɑɹdz' ətɛnʃən. ɹænd wɑz ɡlæɾ i hæd dɪsaɪɾɪd tə liv ɪz ət ði ɪn wɪð mɪn. ʃi nɛsəld ɪn ðə bæk ə hɪz hɛd mɔɹ stʃɹɔŋli ðən ɪleɪn əɹ eɪvinhə, əɹ ɑlɑnə. hi wɑz oʊnli veɪɡli əwɛɹ ə ði ʌðɝz. mɪn simd əlaɪv ɪnsaɪd hɪm.

Ignoring the voice, Rand pulled his snug gloves tighter and kept a steady pace after Rochaid. A number of the Street Guards in the square were watching the man. Foreigners were considered troublemakers and hotheads, and Murandians had a prickly reputation. A foreigner carrying a sword always attracted the Guards' attention. Rand was glad he had decided to leave his at the inn with Min. She nestled in the back of his head more strongly than Elayne or Aviendha, or Alanna. He was only vaguely aware of the others. Min seemed alive inside him.

əz ɹɑtʃeɪd lɛf ði æmhɑɹə, hɛɾɪŋ dipɝ ɪndə ðə sɪɾi, flaɪts ə pɪdʒənz spɹæŋ ʌp fɹəm ðə ɹuftɑps, bʌɾ ɪnstɛɾ ə meɪkɪŋ ði ʊnɛɹəŋ swups ðət nɔɹməli wʊɾə teɪkən əm ɪndə ðə skaɪ, bɝdz kɹæʃt ɪndə wʌn ənʌðɝ ən səm tʌmbəl flʌɾɝɪŋ tə ðə peɪvmənt. pipəl ɡeɪpt, ɪnkluɾɪŋ ðə stʃɹit ɡɑɹdz u hæd bɪn wɑtʃɪŋ ɹɑtʃeɪd soʊ ɪntɛnli ə moʊmən bɪfɔɹ. ðə mæn dɪd nɑt lʊk bæk, bʌɾ ɪt wəd nɑɾ əv mæɾɝd hæɾ i sin. hi nu ɹænd wɑz ɪn ðə sɪɾi wɪθaʊt siɪŋ ði ɪfɛks ʌv ə tɑvɝən, əɹ i wəd nɑɾ əv bɪn ðɛɹ.

As Rochaid left the Amhara, heading deeper into the city, flights of pigeons sprang up from the rooftops, but instead of making the unerring swoops that normally would have taken them into the sky, birds crashed into one another and some tumbled fluttering to the pavement. People gaped, including the Street Guards who had been watching Rochaid so intently a moment before. The man did not look back, but it would not have mattered had he seen. He knew Rand was in the city without seeing the effects of a ta'veren, or he would not have been there.

fɑloʊɪŋ ɹɑtʃeɪɾ ɑntu ðə stʃɹiɾ ə dʒɔɪ, ɹɪli tu bɹɔd stʃɹeɪt stʃɹits sɛpɝeɪɾəd baɪ ə mɛʒɝd ɹoʊ ʌv lifləs ɡɹeɪ-bɑɹk tʃɹiz, ɹænd smaɪld. ɹɑtʃeɪɾ ən ɪz fɹɛnz pɹɑbli θɔt ðɛmsɛlvz vɛɹi klɛvɝ. pɝhæps ðeɪ hæd faʊn ðə mæp ə ðə nɔɹðɝn pleɪnz ə mɑɹeɪɾoʊ ɹipleɪst ʌpsaɪd daʊn ɪn ðə ɹæks ɪn ðə stoʊn ə tiɹ, əɹ ðə bʊk ɑn sɪɾiz ə ðə saʊθ mɪʃhɪlvd ɪn ðə laɪbɹɛɹi ʌv ði ɛɛzdeɪʃɝ pæləs ɪn tʃeɪkɪn, əɹ wʌn ə ði ʌðɝ hɪns i hæd lɛf bɪhaɪnd. smɔl mɪsteɪks ə mæn ɪn ə hɝi maɪt meɪk, bʌɾ ɛni tu əɹ θɹi təɡɛðɝ peɪntəɾ ən æɹoʊ pɔɪntɪŋ tə fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ. ɹɑtʃeɪɾ ən ði ʌðɝz hæd bɪn kwɪk tə si ɪt, kwɪkɝ ðən i hæɾ ɪkspɛktəd, əɹ ɛls ðeɪ hæd hæd hɛlp tə pɔɪn ɪɾ aʊt. iðɝ weɪ, ɪt dɪd nɑt mæɾɝ.

Following Rochaid onto the Street of Joy, really two broad straight streets separated by a measured row of leafless gray-barked trees, Rand smiled. Rochaid and his friends probably thought themselves very clever. Perhaps they had found the map of the northern Plains of Maredo replaced upside down in the racks in the Stone of Tear, or the book on cities of the south misshelved in the library of the Aesdaishar Palace in Chachin, or one of the other hints he had left behind. Small mistakes a man in a hurry might make, but any two or three together painted an arrow pointing to Far Madding. Rochaid and the others had been quick to see it, quicker than he had expected, or else they had had help to point it out. Either way, it did not matter.

hi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ waɪ ðə mʊɹændiən hæd kʌm əhɛɾ ə ði ʌðɝz, bʌɾ i nu ðeɪ wəd kʌm, tɔɹvəl ən dæʃivə, dʒɛdwɪn ən kɪsmən, tə tʃɹaɪ fɪnɪʃɪŋ wʌt ðeɪ hæd bʌŋɡəld ɪn kɛɹhin. ə pɪɾi nʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən wəd bi ful ɪnʌf tə kʌm æftɝ ɪm hɪɹ. ðeɪ wəd dʒʌst sɛn ði ʌðɝz. hi wɑntəd tə kɪl ɹɑtʃeɪd bɪfɔɹ ðə ɹɛst ɝaɪvd, ɪf i kʊd. ivən hɪɹ, wɛɹ ðeɪ wɝ ɔl ɑn ən ikwəl fʊɾɪŋ, ɪt wəd bi bɛs tə kʌt daʊn ði ɑdz. tu deɪz ɹɑtʃeɪd hæd bɪn ɪn fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ, oʊpənli æskɪŋ kwɛstʃənz əbaʊɾ ə tɔl ɹɛd-hɛɹd mæn, swæɡɝɪŋ əbaʊɾ əz ɪf i hæd nɑɾ ə wɝi ɪn ðə wɝld. ðə mæn hæd sin ɛni nʌmbɝ u mɔɹ əɹ lɛs mɛɾ ɪz dɪskɹɪpʃən, bʌɾ i stɪl θɔɾ i wɑz ðə hʌntɝ, nɑt ðə hʌntəd.

He was not sure why the Murandian had come ahead of the others, but he knew they would come, Torval and Dashiva, Gedwyn and Kisman, to try finishing what they had bungled in Cairhien. A pity none of the Forsaken would be fool enough to come after him here. They would just send the others. He wanted to kill Rochaid before the rest arrived, if he could. Even here, where they were all on an equal footing, it would be best to cut down the odds. Two days Rochaid had been in Far Madding, openly asking questions about a tall red-haired man, swaggering about as if he had not a worry in the world. The man had seen any number who more or less met his description, but he still thought he was the hunter, not the hunted.

juv bɹɔɾ əs hɪɹ tə daɪ! luz θɝɪn moʊnd. biɪŋ hɪɹ ɪz əz bæɾ əz dɛθ!

You've brought us here to die! Lews Therin moaned. Being here is as bad as death!

ɹænd ʃɹʌɡd ənkʌmftəbli. hi əɡɹid wɪð ðə vɔɪs əbaʊt ðət læst. hi wəd bi əz ɡlæɾ əz luz θɝɪn tə liv. bʌt səmtaɪmz ði oʊnli tʃɔɪs wɑz bɪtwin bæɾ ən wɝs. ɹɑtʃeɪd wɑz əhɛɾ ə hɪm, ɔlmoʊst wɪðɪn ɹitʃ. ðət wɑz ɔl ðət mæɾɝd naʊ.

Rand shrugged uncomfortably. He agreed with the voice about that last. He would be as glad as Lews Therin to leave. But sometimes the only choice was between bad and worse. Rochaid was ahead of him, almost within reach. That was all that mattered now.

ðə ɡɹeɪ stoʊn ʃɑps ən ɪnz əlɔŋ ðə stʃɹiɾ ə dʒɔɪ tʃeɪnʒd ðə fɑɹðɝ ɹænd wɛn fɹəm ði æmhɑɹə mɑɹkət. sɪlvɝsmɪθs ɹipleɪs kʌtlɝz, ən ðən ɡoʊlsmɪθs ɹipleɪst sɪlvɝsmɪθs. simstʃɹəsəz ən teɪlɝz dɪspleɪɾ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd sɪlks ən bɹoʊkeɪdz ɪnstɛɾ ʌv wʊlənz. ðə koʊtʃɪz ðət ɹʌmbəld oʊvɝ ðə peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz naʊ hæd sɪɡəlz lækɝɾ ɑn ðə dɔɹz ən timz ə fɔɹ əɹ sɪks mætʃt fəɹ saɪz ən kʌlɝ, ən mɔɹ ɹaɪɾɝz wɝ maʊntəɾ ɑn pɹaɪm tɛɹən blʌdstɑk əɹ ænəməlz əz ɡʊd. sɪdæn tʃɛɹz bɔɹn baɪ tʃɹɑɾɪŋ bɛɹɝz bɪkeɪm ɔlmoʊst əz kɑmən əz pipəl əfʊt, ænd, əfʊt, ʃɑpkipɝz ɪn koʊts əɹ dʒɹɛsəz hɛvəli ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd ɝaʊn ðə tʃɛst ən ʃoʊldɝz wɝ aʊtnʌmbɝd baɪ foʊk ɪn lɪvɝi əz bɹaɪɾ əz ðəɾ ə ðə tʃɛɹ-bɛɹɝz. ɔfən əz nɑt, bɪts ə kʌlɝd ɡlæs naʊ dɛkɝeɪɾəd mɛnz hɛɹ klɪps, əɹ əkeɪʒənəli pɝlz əɹ ɹɪtʃɝ dʒɛmz, ðoʊ fju mɛn wɔk huz waɪvz kəɾ əfɔɹd dʒɛmz. oʊnli ðə koʊld wɪnd wɑz ðə seɪm, ðəɾ ən ðə stʃɹit ɡɑɹdz pətʃɹoʊlɪŋ ɪn θɹiz, aɪz əlɝt fəɹ tʃɹʌbəl. ðəɹ wɝ nɑt soʊ mɛni əz ɪn ðə stʃɹeɪnʒɝz' mɑɹkəts, jɛɾ əz sun əz wʌn pətʃɹoʊl stʃɹoʊɾ aʊɾ ə saɪɾ ənʌðɝ əpɪɹd, ən wɛɹɛvɝ ə stʃɹit waɪɾɝ ðən ən æliweɪ mɛt ðə stʃɹiɾ ə dʒɔɪ, ə stoʊn wɑtʃstæn stʊd wɪð tu ɡɑɹdzmɪn weɪɾɪŋ ət ðə fʊɾ ɪn keɪs ðə mæn ətɑp spɑɾəd tʃɹʌbəl. ðə pis wɑz kɛpt ɹɪɡɝəsli ɪn fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ.

The gray stone shops and inns along the Street of Joy changed the farther Rand went from the Amhara Market. Silversmiths replaced cutlers, and then goldsmiths replaced silversmiths. Seamstresses and tailors displayed embroidered silks and brocades instead of woolens. The coaches that rumbled over the paving stones now had sigils lacquered on the doors and teams of four or six matched for size and color, and more riders were mounted on prime Tairen bloodstock or animals as good. Sedan chairs borne by trotting bearers became almost as common as people afoot, and, afoot, shopkeepers in coats or dresses heavily embroidered around the chest and shoulders were outnumbered by folk in livery as bright as that of the chair-bearers. Often as not, bits of colored glass now decorated men's hair clips, or occasionally pearls or richer gems, though few men walked whose wives could afford gems. Only the cold wind was the same, that and the Street Guards patrolling in threes, eyes alert for trouble. There were not so many as in the Strangers' Markets, yet as soon as one patrol strode out of sight another appeared, and wherever a street wider than an alleyway met the Street of Joy, a stone watchstand stood with two Guardsmen waiting at the foot in case the man atop spotted trouble. The peace was kept rigorously in Far Madding.

ɹænd fɹaʊn əz ɹɑtʃeɪd kɛpt ɑn əlɔŋ ðə stʃɹit. kəɾ i bi hɛɾəd fəɹ ðə kaʊnsəlz' plɑzə, ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ði aɪlənd? ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ ðəɹ bʌt ðə hɔl ə ðə kaʊnsəlz, mɑnjəməns fɹəm mɔɹ ðən faɪv hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz ɝliɝ, wən fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ hæd bɪn ðə kæpəɾəl ə mɑɹeɪɾoʊ, ən ðə kaʊntɪŋhaʊsɪz ə ðə sɪɾiz wɛlθiəst wɪmən. ɪn fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ, ə wɛlθi mæn wɑz wʌn huz waɪf ɡeɪv ɪm ə dʒɛnɝəs əlaʊəns əɹ ə wɪɾoʊɝ u hæd bɪn pɹəvaɪɾəd fɔɹ. meɪbi ɹɑtʃeɪd wɑz miɾɪŋ dɑɹkfɹɛnz. bʌɾ ɪf soʊ, waɪ hæd ðə mæn weɪɾəd?

Rand frowned as Rochaid kept on along the street. Could he be headed for the Counsels' Plaza, in the middle of the island? There was nothing there but the Hall of the Counsels, monuments from more than five hundred years earlier, when Far Madding had been the capital of Maredo, and the countinghouses of the city's wealthiest women. In Far Madding, a wealthy man was one whose wife gave him a generous allowance or a widower who had been provided for. Maybe Rochaid was meeting Darkfriends. But if so, why had the man waited?

sʌɾənli ə weɪv ə dɪzinəs hɪt hɪm, ə mɝki feɪs fɪlɪŋ ɪz vɪʒən fəɹ ən ɪnstənt, ən i stæɡɝɾ əɡɛnst ə pæsɝbaɪ. tɔlɝ ðən ɹænd hɪmsɛlf, ɪn bɹaɪt ɡɹin lɪvɝi, ðə jɛloʊ-hɛɹd mæn ʃɪftəd ðə lɑɹdʒ bæskəɾ i wɑz kæɹiɪŋ ən fɛndɪd ɹænd ɔf dʒɛnli. ə lɔŋ, pʌkɝd skɑɹ ɹæn daʊn ðə saɪɾ ə hɪz sʌn-dɑɹk feɪs. boʊɪŋ ɪz hɛd, hi mɝmɝɾ ən əpɑlədʒi ən hɝiɾ ɑn.

Suddenly a wave of dizziness hit him, a murky face filling his vision for an instant, and he staggered against a passerby. Taller than Rand himself, in bright green livery, the yellow-haired man shifted the large basket he was carrying and fended Rand off gently. A long, puckered scar ran down the side of his sun-dark face. Bowing his head, he murmured an apology and hurried on.

ɹaɪɾɪŋ hɪmsɛlf, ɹænd ɡɹaʊld ə kɝs ʌndɝ ɪz bɹɛθ.

Righting himself, Rand growled a curse under his breath.

jə dɪstʃɹɔɪɾ əm ɔlɹɛɾi, luz θɝɪn wɪspɝɾ ɪn ɪz hɛd. naʊ juv sʌmwʌn ɛls tə dɪstʃɹɔɪ, ən nɑt bɪfɹtaɪm. haʊ mɛni wɪl wi θɹi kɪl bɪfɔɹ ði ɛnd, aɪ wʌndɝ.

You destroyed them already, Lews Therin whispered in his head. Now you have someone else to destroy, and not beforetime. How many will we three kill before the end, I wonder.

ʃʌɾ ʌp! ɹænd θɔt fɪɹsli, bʌt kækəlɪŋ, dɝɪsɪv læftɝ ænsɝd hɪm. ɪt wɑz nɑt ði ɪnkaʊntɝ wɪð ən ilmən ðəɾ ʌpsɛt hɪm. hi hæd sin mɛni sɪns kʌmɪŋ tə fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ. fəɹ səm ɹizən, hʌnʒɹədz ə ði il u flɛɾ æftɝ lɝnɪŋ ðə tʃɹuθ ə ðɛɹ hɪstɝi hæɾ ɛndəɾ ʌp ðɛɹ, ətɛmptɪŋ tə fɑloʊ ðə weɪ ʌv ðə lif wən ðeɪ hæd noʊ mɔɹ aɪdiə ʌv wʌt ðəɾ ɪnteɪld ɪksɛp ðət ðeɪ wɝ səpoʊz tə bi laɪflɔŋ ɡeɪʃeɪn. hi wɑz nɑɾ ivən wɝiɾ əbaʊt ðə dɪzinəs, əɹ huz feɪs ɪt wɑz ðəɾ i hæf sɔ wən ɪt stʃɹʌk. əhɛɾ ə hɪm, ə koʊtʃ dʒɹɔn baɪ sɪks ɡɹeɪz klæɾɝd θɹu ðə stʃɹim ə sɪdæn tʃɛɹz ən hɝiɪŋ foʊk ɪn lɪvɝi, ən mɛn ən wɪmən dɑɹɾɪŋ ɪn ən aʊɾ ə ðə ʃɑps, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ saɪn ʌv ə ɹɛd koʊt. hi smækt ə ɡlʌv fɪst ɪndə hɪz pɑm ɪn ɪɹɪteɪʃən.

Shut up! Rand thought fiercely, but cackling, derisive laughter answered him. It was not the encounter with an Aielman that upset him. He had seen many since coming to Far Madding. For some reason, hundreds of the Aiel who fled after learning the truth of their history had ended up there, attempting to follow the Way of the Leaf when they had no more idea of what that entailed except that they were supposed to be lifelong gai'shain. He was not even worried about the dizziness, or whose face it was that he half saw when it struck. Ahead of him, a coach drawn by six grays clattered through the stream of sedan chairs and hurrying folk in livery, and men and women darting in and out of the shops, but there was no sign of a red coat. He smacked a gloved fist into his palm in irritation.

ɡoʊɪŋ əhɛd blaɪnli wɑz ɪɾiɑtɪk. hi maɪt ɹʌn ɹaɪɾ ɪndə ðə mæn, əɹ ət lis bi sin. soʊ fɑɹ, ɹɑtʃeɪd θɔt ɹænd dɪd nɑt noʊ hi wɑz ɪn ðə sɪɾi, ən ædvæntɪdʒ tu ɪmpɔɹɾənt tə skwɑndɝ. hi nu wɛɹ ɹɑtʃeɪd hæɾ ɪz ɹumz, wʌn ə ði ɪnz ðət keɪɾɝd tə fɔɹən mɛn. hi kəd lɔɪɾɝ aʊtsaɪd təmɑɹoʊ ən weɪt fəɹ ənʌðɝ tʃæns. ði ʌðɝz maɪɾ ɝaɪv ɪn ðə naɪt, tu. hi θɔɾ i kəd kɪl ɛni tu təɡɛðɝ, əɹ meɪbi ivən ɔl faɪv, bʌɾ ɪt kəd nɑt bi dʌn kwaɪətli. hi wəd teɪk ɪnʒɝiz əɡɛns faɪv, ən ət bɛst, hi wəɾ əv tə əbændən ɪz sɔɹd, wɪtʃ i wɑz ɹɪlʌktən tə du. ɪt wɑz ə ɡɪft fɹəm eɪvinhə. ət wɝst . . .

Going ahead blindly was idiotic. He might run right into the man, or at least be seen. So far, Rochaid thought Rand did not know he was in the city, an advantage too important to squander. He knew where Rochaid had his rooms, one of the inns that catered to foreign men. He could loiter outside tomorrow and wait for another chance. The others might arrive in the night, too. He thought he could kill any two together, or maybe even all five, but it could not be done quietly. He would take injuries against five, and at best, he would have to abandon his sword, which he was reluctant to do. It was a gift from Aviendha. At worst . . .

ə flɪkɝ ə fɝ-tʃɹɪm kloʊk kɑɾ ɪz aɪ, flʌɾɝɪŋ ɪn ðə wɪn əz ɪt vænɪʃt ɝaʊn ə kɔɹnɝ əhɛd, ən i ɹæn təwɔɹɾ ɪt. ðə ɡɑɹdzmɪn ət ðə wɑtʃstæn ðəɹ stʃɹeɪɾənd, ðə mæn ət ðə tɑp teɪkɪŋ ɪz ɹæɾəl fɹəm ɪz bɛlt. wʌn ə ðoʊz ət ðə bɑɾəm ə ðə stæn hɛftəɾ ɪz lɔŋ kʌdʒəl, waɪl ði ʌðɝ lɪftəɾ ə kætʃpoʊl fɹəm wɛɹ ɪt hæd lin əɡɛns ðə wɑtʃstænz stɛps. ðə fɔɹkt ɛnd wɑz fæʃən tə kætʃ ən hoʊld ən ɑɹm əɹ ə lɛɡ əɹ ə nɛk, ən ðə poʊl ɪtsɛlf wɑz bɛltəd wɪð aɪɝn, pɹuf əɡɛnst ɛni sɔɹɾ əɹ æks. ðeɪ wɑtʃt ɪm kloʊsli, wɪð hɑɹɾ aɪz.

A flicker of fur-trimmed cloak caught his eye, fluttering in the wind as it vanished around a corner ahead, and he ran toward it. The Guardsmen at the watchstand there straightened, the man at the top taking his rattle from his belt. One of those at the bottom of the stand hefted his long cudgel, while the other lifted a catchpole from where it had leaned against the watchstand's steps. The forked end was fashioned to catch and hold an arm or a leg or a neck, and the pole itself was belted with iron, proof against any sword or axe. They watched him closely, with hard eyes.

hi nɑɾəd tə ðɛm ən smaɪld, ðən ɑstənteɪʃəsli pɪɹd daʊn ðə saɪd stʃɹit, sɝtʃɪŋ ðə kɹaʊd ðɛɹ. nɑɾ ə ɹʌnɪŋ θif, dʒʌst ə mæn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kætʃ ʌp tə sʌmwʌn. ðə kʌdʒəl wɛn bæk ɑntu ɪts bɛl hʊk, ðə kætʃpoʊl ɹɪtɝn tə ðə stɛps. hi dɪd nɑt lʊk ət ðə ɡɑɹdzmɪn əɡɛn. əhɛd, hi ɡɑɾ ə ɡlɪmps ə ðə kloʊk, ən meɪbi ə ɹɛd koʊt, əz ðə wɛɹɝ tɝn ɑntu ənʌðɝ stʃɹit.

He nodded to them and smiled, then ostentatiously peered down the side street, searching the crowd there. Not a running thief, just a man trying to catch up to someone. The cudgel went back onto its belt hook, the catchpole returned to the steps. He did not look at the Guardsmen again. Ahead, he got a glimpse of the cloak, and maybe a red coat, as the wearer turned onto another street.

ɹeɪzɪŋ ɪz hæn əz ɪf tə heɪl sʌmbɑɾi, ɹænd spɛɾ æftɝ ðə mæn, dɑdʒɪŋ bɪtwin pipəl ən stʃɹit pɛdlɝz' bæɹoʊz. hɔkɝz dɪspleɪɪŋ pɪnz əɹ niɾəlz əɹ koʊmz ɑn ðɛɹ tʃɹeɪz tʃɹaɪd tə kætʃ ɪz ətɛnʃən, əɹ ɛniwʌnz, wɪð ðɛɹ kɹaɪz. fju pipəl hɪɹ wɔɹ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi, ən ə sɪmpəl kɔɹd taɪɪŋ ə mænz hɛɹ wɑz mʌtʃ mɔɹ kɑmən ðən ivən ðə pleɪnəs klɪp. ðiz stʃɹits wɝ kɹæmpt ət bɛst, ən kɹʊkəd, ə hæphæzɝd meɪz wɛɹ tʃip ɪnz ən nɛɹoʊ stoʊn əpɑɹtmən bɪldɪŋz ə θɹi ən fɔɹ stɔɹiz taʊɝɾ oʊvɝ ðə ʃɑps ə bʊtʃɝz ən kændəlmeɪkɝz ən bɑɹbɝz, tɪnsmɪθs ən pɑɾɝz ən kupɝz. koʊtʃɪz wəd nɑɾ əv fɪɾ əlɔŋ ðiz stʃɹits, ən ðəɹ wɝ noʊ sɪdæn tʃɛɹz, iðɝ, noʊ ɹaɪɾɝz, ən oʊnli ə hændfʊl ə lɪvɹid sɝvəns, kæɹiɪŋ bæskəts ɑn ɛɹənz bʌt stʃɹoʊlɪŋ ən lʊkɪŋ daʊn ðɛɹ noʊzɪz əɾ ɛvɹiwʌn ɝaʊn əm ɪksɛp ðə stʃɹit ɡɑɹdz. ðɛɹ pətʃɹoʊlz ən wɑtʃstænz wɝ pɹɛzən ivən hɪɹ.

Raising his hand as if to hail somebody, Rand sped after the man, dodging between people and street peddlers' barrows. Hawkers displaying pins or needles or combs on their trays tried to catch his attention, or anyone's, with their cries. Few people here wore embroidery, and a simple cord tying a man's hair was much more common than even the plainest clip. These streets were cramped at best, and crooked, a haphazard maze where cheap inns and narrow stone apartment buildings of three and four stories towered over the shops of butchers and candlemakers and barbers, tinsmiths and potters and coopers. Coaches would not have fit along these streets, and there were no sedan chairs, either, no riders, and only a handful of liveried servants, carrying baskets on errands but strolling and looking down their noses at everyone around them except the Street Guards. Their patrols and watchstands were present even here.

ət læst i ɡɑt nɪɹ ɪnʌf fəɹ ət klɪɹ vju ʌv ðə mæn i wɑz fɑloʊɪŋ. ɹɑtʃeɪd hæd faɪnəli ʃoʊn ɪnʌf sɛns tə pʊl ɪz kloʊk əbaʊt hɪm, haɪɾɪŋ ɪz ɹɛd koʊɾ ən ɪz jusləs sɔɹd, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ daʊɾ ə hu hi wɑz. ɪn tʃɹuθ, hi sim tə bi tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə əvɔɪd noʊɾəs ɔltəɡɛðɝ naʊ, slɪŋkɪŋ əlɔŋ ðə saɪɾ ə ðə stʃɹit wɪð ɪz ʃoʊldɝ bɹʌʃɪŋ ðə ʃoʊpfɹʌns. əbɹʌpli hi lʊkt ɝaʊn fɝɾɪvli, ðən dɑɹɾɪd ɪndə ən æli bɪtwin ə taɪni bæskətwivɝz ʃɑp ən ən ɪn wɪð ə saɪn soʊ dɝɾi ðə neɪm wɑz kəmplitli əbskjʊɹd. ɹænd ɔlmoʊst ɡɹɪnd, ən weɪstəd noʊ taɪm hɝiɪŋ æftɝ hɪm. ðəɹ wɝ noʊ stʃɹit ɡɑɹdz əɹ wɑtʃstænz ɪn fɑɹ mæɾɪŋz æliweɪz.

At last he got near enough for at clear view of the man he was following. Rochaid had finally shown enough sense to pull his cloak about him, hiding his red coat and his useless sword, but there was no doubt of who he was. In truth, he seemed to be trying to avoid notice altogether now, slinking along the side of the street with his shoulder brushing the shopfronts. Abruptly he looked around furtively, then darted into an alley between a tiny basketweaver's shop and an inn with a sign so dirty the name was completely obscured. Rand almost grinned, and wasted no time hurrying after him. There were no Street Guards or watchstands in Far Madding's alleyways.

ðoʊz æliz wɝ ivən mɔɹ kɹʊkəd ðən ðə stʃɹits ɹænd hæd dʒʌs lɛft, meɪkɪŋ ə wɔɹən ə ðɛɹ oʊn θɹu ði ɪntɪɹiɝ ʌv ɛvɹi blɑk ə ðə sɪɾi, ən ɹɑtʃeɪd wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi aʊɾ ə saɪt, bʌt ɹænd kəd hɪɹ ɪz buts paʊndɪŋ ɑn ðə dæmp stoʊni dɝt. ðə saʊn baʊnst ən mʌltəplaɪd bɪtwin ðə wɪndoʊləs stoʊn wɔlz əntɪl i kəd hɑɹdli tɛl wɛɹ ɪt wɑz kʌmɪŋ fɹʌm, bʌɾ i fɑloʊd, ɹʌnɪŋ əlɔŋ pæsədʒəz bɛɹli waɪɾ ɪnʌf fəɹ tu mɛn əbɹɛst. ɪf ðeɪ wɝ fɹɛnli. waɪ hæd ɹɑtʃeɪd kʌm ɪndə ðɪs meɪz? wɛɹɛvɝ i wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ, hi wɑntəd tə bi ðəɹ kwɪkli. bʌɾ i kəd nɑt noʊ haʊ tə juz ði æliz tə ɡɛt fɹəm wʌn pleɪs tə ənʌðɝ.

Those alleys were even more crooked than the streets Rand had just left, making a warren of their own through the interior of every block of the city, and Rochaid was already out of sight, but Rand could hear his boots pounding on the damp stony dirt. The sound bounced and multiplied between the windowless stone walls until he could hardly tell where it was coming from, but he followed, running along passages barely wide enough for two men abreast. If they were friendly. Why had Rochaid come into this maze? Wherever he was going, he wanted to be there quickly. But he could not know how to use the alleys to get from one place to another.

əbɹʌpli ɹænd ɹilaɪz ði oʊnli buts i wɑz hɪɹɪŋ wɝ ɪz oʊn ən stɑp dɛd. saɪləns. fɹəm wɛɹ i stʊd, hi kəd si θɹi mɔɹ nɛɹoʊ æliz splɪɾɪŋ ɔf fɹəm ðə wʌn i stʊɾ ɪn. bɛɹli bɹiðɪŋ, hi stʃɹeɪn ɪz ɪɹz. saɪləns. ɔlmoʊst, hi dɪsaɪɾɪd tə tɝn bæk. ən ðən i hɝɾ ə dɪstən klæɾɝ fɹəm ðə nɪɹəst æli maʊθ, əz ðoʊ sʌmwʌn hæɾ æksədɛntəli kɪkt ə ɹɑk əɡɛnst ə stoʊn wɔl ɪn pæsɪŋ. bɛs tə kɪl ðə mæn ən bi dʌn.

Abruptly Rand realized the only boots he was hearing were his own and stopped dead. Silence. From where he stood, he could see three more narrow alleys splitting off from the one he stood in. Barely breathing, he strained his ears. Silence. Almost, he decided to turn back. And then he heard a distant clatter from the nearest alley mouth, as though someone had accidentally kicked a rock against a stone wall in passing. Best to kill the man and be done.

ɹænd tɝn ðə kɔɹnɝ ɪn tə ði æli, ən faʊn ɹɑtʃeɪd weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ hɪm.

Rand turned the corner in to the alley, and found Rochaid waiting for him.

ðə mʊɹændiən hæɾ ɪz kloʊk θɹoʊn bæk əɡɛn, ən boʊθ hænz ɑn ɪz sɔɹd hɪlt. ðə fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ pis-bɑnd woʊv hɪlt ən skæbɝɾ ɪnsaɪɾ ə nɛɾ ə faɪn waɪɝ. hi wɔɹ ə smɔl, noʊɪŋ smaɪl. "ju wɝ əz izi tə beɪɾ əz ə pɪdʒən," hi sɛd, bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə dʒɹɔ hɪz sɔɹd. ðə waɪɝz hæd bɪn kʌt, ðən fɪkst soʊ ðeɪ stɪl əpɪɹd sɑləd tə ə kæʒəwəl ɡlæns. "ɹʌn, ɪf jə wɑnt."

The Murandian had his cloak thrown back again, and both hands on his sword hilt. The Far Madding peace-bond wove hilt and scabbard inside a net of fine wire. He wore a small, knowing smile. "You were as easy to bait as a pigeon," he said, beginning to draw his sword. The wires had been cut, then fixed so they still appeared solid to a casual glance. "Run, if you want."

ɹænd dɪd nɑt ɹʌn. ɪnstɛd, hi stɛp fɔɹwɝd, slæmɪŋ ɪz lɛf hæn daʊn ɑn ði ɛn ə ɹɑtʃeɪdz sɔɹd hɪlt, tʃɹæpɪŋ ðə bleɪd stɪl hæf ɪn ɪts skæbɝd. sɝpɹaɪz waɪɾənd ðə mænz aɪz, jɛɾ i stɪl dɪd nɑt ɹilaɪz ðət pɔzɪŋ tə ɡloʊt hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi kɪl hɪm. hi muv bæk, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɡɛt ɹum tə kəmpliɾ ɪz dʒɹɔ, bʌt ɹænd fɑloʊd smuðli, kipɪŋ ðə sɔɹd tʃɹæpt, ən pɪvəɾəd fɹəm ðə hɪps, dʒɹaɪvɪŋ foʊldəd nʌkəlz hɑɹɾ ɪndə ɹɑtʃeɪdz θɹoʊt. kɑɹɾələdʒ kɹæk laʊdli, ən ðə ɹɛnəɡeɪd fɝɡɑɾ əbaʊt tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kɪl ɛniwʌn. stæɡɝɪŋ bækwɝdz, waɪd-aɪɾ ən stɛɹɪŋ, hi klæp boʊθ hænz tə hɪz θɹoʊɾ ən dɛspɝətli tʃɹaɪd tə pʊl ɛɹ θɹu hɪz ɹuənd wɪnpəp.

Rand did not run. Instead, he stepped forward, slamming his left hand down on the end of Rochaid's sword hilt, trapping the blade still half in its scabbard. Surprise widened the man's eyes, yet he still did not realize that pausing to gloat had already killed him. He moved back, trying to get room to complete his draw, but Rand followed smoothly, keeping the sword trapped, and pivoted from the hips, driving folded knuckles hard into Rochaid's throat. Cartilage cracked loudly, and the renegade forgot about trying to kill anyone. Staggering backwards, wide-eyed and staring, he clapped both hands to his throat and desperately tried to pull air through his ruined windpipe.

ɹænd wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi bɪɡɪnɪŋ ðə kɪlɪŋ stʃɹoʊk, bɪniθ ðə bɹɛstboʊn, wən ə wɪspɝ ə saʊn keɪm tə hɪm fɹəm bɪhaɪnd, ən sʌɾənli ɹɑtʃeɪdz tɔntɪŋ tʊk ɑn nu minɪŋ. bækhilɪŋ ɹɑtʃeɪd, ɹænd lɛt hɪmsɛlf fɔl tə ðə ɡɹaʊn ətɑp ðə mæn. hɑɹd-swʌŋ mɛɾəl klæŋd əɡɛnst ə stoʊn wɔl, ən ə mæn kɝst. ɡɹæbɪŋ ɹɑtʃeɪdz sɔɹd, ɹænd lɛt ðə moʊʃən ə fɔlɪŋ tɝn ɪndə ə ɹoʊl, pʊlɪŋ ðə bleɪd klɪɹ əz i tʌmbəld oʊvɝ ɪz oʊn ʃoʊldɝ. ɹɑtʃeɪd ɡeɪv ə ʃɹɪl, ɡɝɡəlɪŋ skɹim əz ɹænd keɪm ʌp ɪn ə kɹaʊtʃ feɪsɪŋ bæk ðə weɪ hi hæd kʌm.

Rand was already beginning the killing stroke, beneath the breastbone, when a whisper of sound came to him from behind, and suddenly Rochaid's taunting took on new meaning. Backheeling Rochaid, Rand let himself fall to the ground atop the man. Hard-swung metal clanged against a stone wall, and a man cursed. Grabbing Rochaid's sword, Rand let the motion of falling turn into a roll, pulling the blade clear as he tumbled over his own shoulder. Rochaid gave a shrill, gurgling scream as Rand came up in a crouch facing back the way he had come.

ɹeɪfɑɹ kɪsmən stʊd ɡeɪpɪŋ daʊn ət ɹɑtʃeɪd, ðə bleɪɾ i hæd mɛn tə stæb θɹu ɹænd ɪnstɛd dʒɹɪvən ɪndə ɹɑtʃeɪdz tʃɛst. blʌd bʌbəld ɑn ðə mʊɹændiənz lɪps, ən i dʌɡ hɪz hilz ɪndə ðə ɡɹaʊn ən blʌɾid ɪz hænz ɑn ðə ʃɑɹp stil əz ðoʊ hi kəd pʊʃ ɪɾ aʊɾ ə hɪm. ʌv oʊnli ævɝɪdʒ haɪt, ən peɪl fəɹ ə tɛɹən, kɪsmən wɔɹ kloʊðz əz pleɪn əz ɹændz ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə sɔɹd bɛlt. haɪɾɪŋ ðət bɪniθ ɪz kloʊk, hi cʊɾə ɡɔn ɛniwɛɹ ɪn fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ wɪθaʊt biɪŋ noʊɾəst.

Raefar Kisman stood gaping down at Rochaid, the blade he had meant to stab through Rand instead driven into Rochaid's chest. Blood bubbled on the Murandian's lips, and he dug his heels into the ground and bloodied his hands on the sharp steel as though he could push it out of him. Of only average height, and pale for a Tairen, Kisman wore clothes as plain as Rand's except for the sword belt. Hiding that beneath his cloak, he could have gone anywhere in Far Madding without being noticed.

hɪz dɪsmeɪ læstəɾ oʊnli ən ɪnstənt. əz ɹænd ɹoʊz, sɔɹd ɹɛɾi ɪn boʊθ hænz, kɪsmən dʒɝkt ɪz oʊn bleɪd fɹi ən dɪd nɑt lʊk əɾ ɪz θɹæʃɪŋ əkɑmpləs əɡɛn. hi wɑtʃt ɹænd, ən ɪz hænz ʃɪftəd nɝvəsli ɑn ðə lɔŋ hɪlt ə hɪz sɔɹd. noʊ daʊɾ i wɑz wʌn ə ðoʊz soʊ pɹaʊɾ ə biɪŋ eɪbəl tə juz ðə paʊɝ əz ə wɛpən ðəɾ i hæd dɪsdeɪn ɹɪli lɝnɪŋ ðə sɔɹd. ɹænd hæd nɑt dɪsdeɪnd. ɹɑtʃeɪd ɡeɪv ə læs twɪtʃ ən wɑz stɪl, stɛɹɪŋ ʌp ət ðə skaɪ.

His dismay lasted only an instant. As Rand rose, sword ready in both hands, Kisman jerked his own blade free and did not look at his thrashing accomplice again. He watched Rand, and his hands shifted nervously on the long hilt of his sword. No doubt he was one of those so proud of being able to use the Power as a weapon that he had disdained really learning the sword. Rand had not disdained. Rochaid gave a last twitch and was still, staring up at the sky.

"taɪm tə daɪ," ɹænd sɛd kwaɪətli, bʌɾ əz i stɑɹɾəd fɔɹwɝd, ə ɹæɾəl saʊndəd sʌmwɛɹ bɪhaɪn ðə tɛɹən, ən ɪnsɛsən tʃæɾɝɪŋ, ən ðən ənʌðɝ. ðə stʃɹit ɡɑɹdz.

"Time to die," Rand said quietly, but as he started forward, a rattle sounded somewhere behind the Tairen, an incessant chattering, and then another. The Street Guards.

"ðeɪl teɪk əs boʊθ," kɪsmən bɹiðd, saʊndɪŋ fɹæntɪk. "ɪf ðeɪ faɪn əs stændɪŋ oʊvɝ ə kɔɹps, ðəl hæŋ əs boʊθ! jə noʊ ðeɪ wɪl!"

"They'll take us both," Kisman breathed, sounding frantic. "If they find us standing over a corpse, they'll hang us both! You know they will!"

hi wɑz ɹaɪt, ət list ɪn pɑɹt. ɪf ðə ɡɑɹdz faʊn əm ðɛɹ, ðeɪ wəd boʊθ bi hɔld ɔf tə ðə sɛlz bɪniθ ðə hɔl ə ðə kaʊnsəlz. mɔɹ ɹæɾəlz tʃæɾɝd, kʌmɪŋ kloʊsɝ. ðə ɡɑɹdz mʌst əv noʊɾəst θɹi mɛn dʌkɪŋ wʌn baɪ wʌn ɪndə ðə seɪm æli. pɝhæps ðeɪ hæɾ ivən sin kɪsmənz sɔɹd. ɹɪlʌktənli, ɹænd nɑɾəd.

He was right, at least in part. If the Guards found them there, they would both be hauled off to the cells beneath the Hall of the Counsels. More rattles chattered, coming closer. The Guards must have noticed three men ducking one by one into the same alley. Perhaps they had even seen Kisman's sword. Reluctantly, Rand nodded.

ðə tɛɹən bækt əweɪ kɔʃəsli, ən wən i sɔ ɹænd meɪkɪŋ noʊ muv tə fɑloʊ, hi ʃiðd ɪz bleɪɾ ən ɹæn waɪldli, dɑɹk kloʊk flɛɹɪŋ bɪhaɪn hɪm.

The Tairen backed away cautiously, and when he saw Rand making no move to follow, he sheathed his blade and ran wildly, dark cloak flaring behind him.

ɹænd θɹu hɪz bɑɹoʊd sɔɹd daʊn ətɑp ɹɑtʃeɪdz bɑɾi ən ɹæn ði ʌðɝ weɪ. ðəɹ wɝ noʊ ɹæɾəlz ɪn ðət dɝɛkʃən jɛt. wɪð lʌk, hi kəd bi aʊɾ ɪndə ðə stʃɹits, blɛndɪŋ ɪndə ðə kɹaʊdz, bɪfɔɹ i wɑz sin. hi hæɾ ʌðɝ fɪɹz ðən ðə nus. stʃɹɪpɪŋ ɔf ɪz ɡlʌvz, ʃoʊɪŋ ðə dʒɹæɡənz ðət mɑɹkt ɪz ɑɹmz, wəd bi ɪnʌf tə pɹɪvɛn ɪz hæŋɪŋ, hi wɑz ʃʊɹ. bʌt ðə kaʊnsəlz hæd pɹoʊkleɪm ðɛɹ æksɛptəns ə ðəɾ ɑd dɪkɹi ɪleɪɾə hæɾ ɪʃud. wʌns i wɑz ɪn ə sɛl, hi wəd ɹɪmeɪn ðəɹ əntɪl ðə waɪt taʊɝ sɛn fəɹ hɪm. soʊ hi ɹæn əz hɑɹɾ əz i kʊd.

Rand threw his borrowed sword down atop Rochaid's body and ran the other way. There were no rattles in that direction yet. With luck, he could be out into the streets, blending into the crowds, before he was seen. He had other fears than the noose. Stripping off his gloves, showing the Dragons that marked his arms, would be enough to prevent his hanging, he was sure. But the Counsels had proclaimed their acceptance of that odd decree Elaida had issued. Once he was in a cell, he would remain there until the White Tower sent for him. So he ran as hard as he could.

mɛltɪŋ ɪndə ðə kɹaʊɾ ɪn ðə stʃɹit, kɪsmən hivd ə saɪ ʌv ɹɪlif əz θɹi stʃɹit ɡɑɹdz ɹæn ɪndə ði æli hi hæd dʒʌst ɪmɝdʒ fɹʌm. hoʊldɪŋ ɪz kloʊk kloʊs tə haɪɾ ɪz skæbɑɹɾɪd sɔɹd, hi muvd wɪð ðə floʊ ʌv tʃɹæfɪk, noʊ fæstɝ ðən ɛniwʌn ɛls ən sloʊɝ ðən sʌm. nʌθɪŋ tə dʒɹɔ ə ɡɑɹdzmænz aɪ. ə pɛɹ ə ðɛm pæst wɪð ə tʃɹʌs pɹɪznɝ stʌft ɪndə ə lɑɹdʒ sæk slʌŋ fɹəm ə kɔɹɾɝstæf kæɹiɾ ɑn ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz. oʊnli ðə mænz hɛd stʌk aʊt, hɪz aɪz waɪld ən dɑɹɾɪŋ. kɪsmən ʃʌɾɝəd. bɝn ɪz aɪz, ðət cʊɾə bɪn hɪm! hɪm!

Melting into the crowd in the street, Kisman heaved a sigh of relief as three Street Guards ran into the alley he had just emerged from. Holding his cloak close to hide his scabbarded sword, he moved with the flow of traffic, no faster than anyone else and slower than some. Nothing to draw a Guardsman's eye. A pair of them passed with a trussed prisoner stuffed into a large sack slung from a quarterstaff carried on their shoulders. Only the man's head stuck out, his eyes wild and darting. Kisman shuddered. Burn his eyes, that could have been him! Him!

hi hæd bɪn ə ful tə lɛt ɹɑtʃeɪd tɔk ɪm ɪndə ðɪs ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs. ðeɪ wɝ səpoʊz tə weɪɾ əntɪl ɛvɹiwʌn hæɾ ɝaɪvd, slɪpɪŋ ɪndə ðə sɪɾi wʌn baɪ wʌn tə əvɔɪd noʊɾəs. ɹɑtʃeɪd hæd wɑntəd ðə ɡlɔɹi ʌv biɪŋ ðə wʌn tə kɪl ælθɹ; ðə mʊɹændiən hæd bɝnd wɪð ðə dɪzaɪɝ tə pɹuv hɪmsɛlf ə bɛɾɝ mæn ðən ælθɹ. naʊ hi wɑz dɛɾ ʌv ɪt, ən vɛɹi nɪɹli ɹeɪfɑɹ kɪsmən wɪð hɪm, ən ðət meɪd kɪsmən fjʊɹiəs. hi wɑntəd paʊɝ mɔɹ ðən ɡlɔɹi, pɝhæps tə ɹul tiɹ fɹəm ðə stoʊn. pɝhæps mɔɹ. hi wɑntəd tə lɪv fɝɛvɝ. ðoʊz θɪŋz hæd bɪn pɹɑməst; ðeɪ wɝ ɪz du. pɑɹɾ ə hɪz æŋɡɝ wɑz kəz i wɑz ənʃʊɹ ðeɪ æktʃəli  wɝ səpoʊz tə kɪl ælθɹ. ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd nu hi wɑntəd tə - hi wəd nɑt slip saʊnli əntɪl ðə mæn wɑz dɛɾ ən bɛɹid! - ən jɛt . . .

He had been a fool to let Rochaid talk him into this in the first place. They were supposed to wait until everyone had arrived, slipping into the city one by one to avoid notice. Rochaid had wanted the glory of being the one to kill al'Thor; the Murandian had burned with the desire to prove himself a better man than al'Thor. Now he was dead of it, and very nearly Raefar Kisman with him, and that made Kisman furious. He wanted power more than glory, perhaps to rule Tear from the Stone. Perhaps more. He wanted to live forever. Those things had been promised; they were his due. Part of his anger was because he was unsure they actually were supposed to kill al'Thor. The Great Lord knew he wanted to - he would not sleep soundly until the man was dead and buried! - and yet . . .

"kɪl hɪm," ðə l hæɾ ɔɹɾɝd bɪfɔɹ sɛndɪŋ əm tə kɛɹhin, bʌɾ i hæd bɪn əz dɪspliz ðət ðeɪ wɝ faʊn aʊɾ əz ðət ðeɪ hæd feɪld. fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ wɑz tə bi ðɛɹ læs tʃæns; hi hæd meɪd ðəɾ əz pleɪn əz pɑlɪʃt bɹæs. dæʃivə hæd sɪmpli vænɪʃt. kɪsmən dɪd nɑt noʊ wɛðɝ i hæd ɹʌn əɹ ðə l hæd kɪl hɪm, ən i dɪd nɑt kɛɹ.

"Kill him," the M'Hael had ordered before sending them to Cairhien, but he had been as displeased that they were found out as that they had failed. Far Madding was to be their last chance; he had made that as plain as polished brass. Dashiva had simply vanished. Kisman did not know whether he had run or the M'Hael had killed him, and he did not care.

"kɪl hɪm," dɪmɑndɝd hæd kəmændəd leɪɾɝ, bʌɾ i hæɾ æɾəd ðəɾ ɪt wəd bi bɛɾɝ ðeɪ daɪd ðən lɛt ðɛmsɛlvz bi dɪskʌvɝɾ əɡɛn. baɪ ɛniwʌn, ivən ðə l, əz ɪf i dɪd nɑt noʊ ʌv teɪmz ɔɹɾɝ.

"Kill him," Demandred had commanded later, but he had added that it would be better they died than let themselves be discovered again. By anyone, even the M'Hael, as if he did not know of Taim's order.

ən leɪɾɝ stɪl, mɔɹaɪɾɪn hæd sɛd, "kɪl ɪm ɪf jə mʌst, bʌɾ əbʌv ɔl, bɹɪŋ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɪn ɪz pəzɛʃən tə mi. ðət wɪl ɹɪdim jəɹ pɹiviəs tʃɹænzɡɹɛʃənz." ðə mæn sɛɾ i wɑz wʌn ə ðə tʃoʊzən, ən noʊ wʌn wɑz mæɾ ɪnʌf tə meɪk ðət kleɪm ənlɛs ɪt wɑz tʃɹu, jɛɾ i sim tə θɪŋk ælθɹz bɪlɔŋɪŋz mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt ðən ɪz dɛθ, ðə kɪlɪŋ ɪnsɪdɛntəl ən nɑt ɹɪli nɛsəsɛɹi.

And later still, Moridin had said, "Kill him if you must, but above all, bring everything in his possession to me. That will redeem your previous transgressions." The man said he was one of the Chosen, and no one was mad enough to make that claim unless it was true, yet he seemed to think al'Thor's belongings more important than his death, the killing incidental and not really necessary.

ðoʊz tu wɝ ði oʊnli tʃoʊzən kɪsmən hæd mɛt, bʌt ðeɪ meɪɾ ɪz hɛd hɝt. ðeɪ wɝ wɝs ðən kɛɹhinɪn. hi səspɛktəd ðət wʌt ðeɪ lɛft ənsɛd kəd kɪl ə mæn kwɪkɝ ðən ə saɪn ɔɹɾɝ fɹəm ə haɪ lɔɹd. wɛl, wʌns tɔɹvəl ən dʒɛdwɪn ɝaɪvd, ðeɪ kəd wɝk aʊt -  əbɹʌpli sʌmθɪŋ stʌŋ ɪz ɹaɪɾ ɑɹm, ən i stɛɹd daʊn ɪn kɑnstɝneɪʃən ət ðə blʌdsteɪn spɹɛɾɪŋ ɑn ɪz kloʊk. ɪt dɪd nɑt fil laɪk ə dip kʌt, ən noʊ kʌtpɝs wʊɾə slæʃt ɪz fɔɹɑɹm.

Those two were the only Chosen Kisman had met, but they made his head hurt. They were worse than Cairhienin. He suspected that what they left unsaid could kill a man quicker than a signed order from a High Lord. Well, once Torval and Gedwyn arrived, they could work out -  Abruptly something stung his right arm, and he stared down in consternation at the bloodstain spreading on his cloak. It did not feel like a deep cut, and no cutpurse would have slashed his forearm.

"hi bɪlɔŋz tə mi," ə mæn wɪspɝd bɪhaɪn hɪm, bʌt wən i tɝnd, ðəɹ wɑz oʊnli ðə kɹaʊɾ ɪn ðə stʃɹit, ɔl ɡoʊɪŋ əbaʊt ðɛɹ bɪznəs. ðə fju hu noʊɾəst ðə dɑɹk steɪn ɑn ɪz kloʊk lʊkt əweɪ kwɪkli. ɪn ðɪs pleɪs, noʊ wʌn wɑntəd tə bi əsoʊsieɪɾəd wɪð ivən ðə smɔləs vaɪələns. ðeɪ wɝ ɡʊɾ əɾ ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ wʌt ðeɪ dɪd nɑt wɑnə si.

"He belongs to me," a man whispered behind him, but when he turned, there was only the crowd in the street, all going about their business. The few who noticed the dark stain on his cloak looked away quickly. In this place, no one wanted to be associated with even the smallest violence. They were good at ignoring what they did not want to see.

ðə waʊn θɹɑbd, bɝnɪŋ mɔɹ ðən ɪt hæɾ ət fɝst. ɹilisɪŋ ɪz kloʊk tə ðə wɪnd, kɪsmən pɹɛst ɪz lɛf hæn oʊvɝ ðə blʌɾi slæʃ ɪn ɪz sliv. hɪz ɑɹm fɛl swoʊlən tə hɪz tʌtʃ, ən hɑt. sʌɾənli hi stɛɹɾ ɪn hɔɹɝ əɾ ɪz ɹaɪt hænd, stɛɹɾ əz ɪt tɝn əz blæk ən bloʊɾɪd əz ə wik-oʊl kɔɹps.

The wound throbbed, burning more than it had at first. Releasing his cloak to the wind, Kisman pressed his left hand over the bloody slash in his sleeve. His arm felt swollen to his touch, and hot. Suddenly he stared in horror at his right hand, stared as it turned as black and bloated as a week-old corpse.

fɹæntəkəli hi bɪɡæn tə ɹʌn, pʊʃɪŋ pipəl aʊɾ ə hɪz weɪ, nɑkɪŋ əm daʊn. hi dɪd nɑt noʊ wʌt wɑz hæpənɪŋ tə hɪm, haʊ ɪt hæd bɪn dʌn, bʌɾ i wɑz ʃʊɹ ə ðə ɹɪzʌlt. ənlɛs i kəd ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ə ðə sɪɾi, bɪɑn ðə leɪk, ʌp ɪndə ðə hɪlz. hi hæɾ ə tʃæns, ðɛn. ə hɔɹs. hi niɾəd ə hɔɹs! hi hæd tə hæv ə tʃæns. hi hæd bɪn pɹɑməst i wəd lɪv fɝɛvɝ! ɔl i kəd si wɝ pipəl əfʊt, ən ðeɪ wɝ skæɾɝɪŋ bɪfɔɹ ɪz tʃɑɹdʒ. hi θɔɾ i hɝd ɡɑɹdzmɪnz ɹæɾəlz, bʌɾ ɪt maɪɾ əv bɪn ðə blʌd paʊndɪŋ ɪn ɪz ɪɹz. ɛvɹiθɪŋ wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ dɑɹk. hɪz feɪs hɪt sʌmθɪŋ hɑɹd, ən i nu hi hæd fɔlən. hɪz læs θɔt wɑz ðət wʌn ə ðə tʃoʊzən hæd dɪsaɪɾɪd tə pʌnɪʃ hɪm, bʌt fəɹ wʌt, hi kəd nɑɾ əv sɛd.

Frantically he began to run, pushing people out of his way, knocking them down. He did not know what was happening to him, how it had been done, but he was sure of the result. Unless he could get out of the city, beyond the lake, up into the hills. He had a chance, then. A horse. He needed a horse! He had to have a chance. He had been promised he would live forever! All he could see were people afoot, and they were scattering before his charge. He thought he heard Guardsmen's rattles, but it might have been the blood pounding in his ears. Everything was going dark. His face hit something hard, and he knew he had fallen. His last thought was that one of the Chosen had decided to punish him, but for what, he could not have said.

oʊnli ə fju mɛn wɝ sɪɾɪŋ ət ðə ɹaʊn teɪbəlz ɪn ðə kɑmən ɹum ə ðə kɹaʊn ə mɑɹeɪɾoʊ wən ɹænd wɔkt ɪn. dɪspaɪt ðə ɡɹænd neɪm, ɪt wɑz ə mɑɾəst ɪn, wɪð tu dʌzən ɹumz ɑn tu flɔɹz əbʌv. ðə plæstɝd wɔlz ə ðə kɑmən ɹum wɝ peɪntəd jɛloʊ, ən ðə mɛn sɝvɪŋ teɪbəl hɪɹ wɔɹ lɔŋ jɛloʊ eɪpɹənz. ə stoʊn faɪɝpleɪs əɾ iðɝ ɛn ə ðə ɹum ɡeɪv ɪɾ ə mɑɹkt wɔɹmθ æftɝ aʊtsaɪd. ðə ʃʌɾɝz wɝ boʊltəd, bʌt læmps hʌŋ ɑn ðə wɔlz tʊk ði ɛdʒ ɔf ðə dɪmnəs. ðə smɛlz dʒɹɪftɪŋ fɹəm ðə kɪtʃənz pɹɑməst ə teɪsti mɪddeɪ mil ə fɪʃ fɹəm ðə leɪk. ɹænd wəd bi sɑɹi tə mɪs ðæt. ðə kʊks ət ðə kɹaʊn ə mɑɹeɪɾoʊ wɝ vɛɹi ɡʊd.

Only a few men were sitting at the round tables in the common room of The Crown of Maredo when Rand walked in. Despite the grand name, it was a modest inn, with two dozen rooms on two floors above. The plastered walls of the common room were painted yellow, and the men serving table here wore long yellow aprons. A stone fireplace at either end of the room gave it a marked warmth after outside. The shutters were bolted, but lamps hung on the walls took the edge off the dimness. The smells drifting from the kitchens promised a tasty midday meal of fish from the lake. Rand would be sorry to miss that. The cooks at The Crown of Maredo were very good.

hi sɔ læn əɾ ə teɪbəl baɪ hɪmsɛlf əɡɛns ðə wɔl. ðə bɹeɪɾɪd lɛðɝ kɔɹd ðət hɛld lænz hɛɹ bæk dʒɹu saɪɾɛlɔŋ ɡlænsɪz fɹəm səm ə ði ʌðɝ mɛn, bʌɾ i ɹəfjuz tə ɡɪv ʌp wɛɹɪŋ ðə hædɔɹi ivən fəɹ ə lɪɾəl waɪl. hi mɛt ɹændz ɡeɪz, ən wən ɹænd nɑɾəd təwɔɹd ðə stɛɹz ət ðə bæk ə ðə ɹum, hi dɪd nɑt weɪs taɪm wɪð kwɛstʃənɪŋ lʊks; hi dʒʌst sɛt daʊn ɪz waɪnkʌp ən ɹoʊz, stɑɹɾɪŋ fəɹ ðə stɛɹz. ivən wɪð dʒʌst ə smɔl naɪf əɾ ɪz bɛlt, hi lʊk deɪnʒɝəs, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ tə bi dʌn əbaʊt ðæt, iðɝ. sɛvɹəl mɛn ət ðə teɪbəlz ɡlænst ɹændz weɪ, bʌt fəɹ səm ɹizən, ðeɪ lʊkt əweɪ hɝidli wən i mɛt ðɛɹ aɪz.

He saw Lan at a table by himself against the wall. The braided leather cord that held Lan's hair back drew sidelong glances from some of the other men, but he refused to give up wearing the hadori even for a little while. He met Rand's gaze, and when Rand nodded toward the stairs at the back of the room, he did not waste time with questioning looks; he just set down his winecup and rose, starting for the stairs. Even with just a small knife at his belt, he looked dangerous, but there was nothing to be done about that, either. Several men at the tables glanced Rand's way, but for some reason, they looked away hurriedly when he met their eyes.

nɪɹ ðə kɪtʃən, ət ðə dɔɹ tə ðə wɪmənz ɹum, ɹænd stɑpt. mɛn wɝ nɑɾ əlaʊɾ ɪn ðɛɹ. əsaɪd fɹəm ə fju flaʊɝz peɪntəɾ ɑn ðə jɛloʊ wɔlz, ðə wɪmənz ɹum wɑz nɑt mʌtʃ fænsiɝ ðən ðə kɑmən ɹum, ðoʊ ðə stænd-læmps wɝ peɪntəd jɛloʊ, tu, ən ðə feɪsɪŋz ə ðə faɪɝpleɪs. ðə jɛloʊ eɪpɹənz wɔɹn baɪ ðə wɪmən u sɝv teɪbəl hɪɹ wɝ noʊ dɪfɹən ðən ðoʊz wɔɹn baɪ ðə mɛn ɪn ðə kɑmən ɹum. mɪstʃɹəs nælhɛɹə, ðə slɪm, ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹɾ ɪnkipɝ, wɑz sɪɾɪŋ ət ðə seɪm teɪbəl əz mɪn, nɪneɪiv ən əliviə, ɔl ə ðɛm tʃæɾɪŋ ən læfɪŋ oʊvɝ ti.

Near the kitchen, at the door to the Women's Room, Rand stopped. Men were not allowed in there. Aside from a few flowers painted on the yellow walls, the Women's Room was not much fancier than the common room, though the stand-lamps were painted yellow, too, and the facings of the fireplace. The yellow aprons worn by the women who served table here were no different than those worn by the men in the common room. Mistress Nalhera, the slim, gray-haired innkeeper, was sitting at the same table as Min, Nynaeve and Alivia, all of them chatting and laughing over tea.

ɹændz dʒɔ taɪɾənd ət ðə saɪɾ ə ðə fɔɹmɝ deɪmeɪn. nɪneɪiv kleɪm ðə wʊmən hæɾ ɪnsɪstəɾ ɑn kʌmɪŋ əlɔŋ, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt bɪliv ɛniwʌn kəd "ɪnsɪst" ɑn ɛniθɪŋ wɪð nɪneɪiv. ʃi wɑntəɾ əliviə əlɔŋ fəɹ səm sikɹət ɹizən. ʃi hæd bɪn bɪheɪvɪŋ mɪstɪɹiəsli, əz ðoʊ wɝkɪŋ əz hɑɹɾ əz ʃi kəɾ ət biɪŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ, ɛvɝ sɪns i wɛn bæk fəɹ əɹ æftɝ livɪŋ ɪleɪn. ɔl θɹi wɪmən hæɾ ədɑptəd haɪ-nɛk fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ dʒɹɛsəz, hɛvəli ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd wɪð flaʊɝz ən bɝdz ɑn ðə bɑɾəs ən ʃoʊldɝz ən ɹaɪɾ ʌp tə ðɛɹ tʃɪnz, ðoʊ səmtaɪmz nɪneɪiv ɡɹʌmbəld oʊvɝ ðɛm. noʊ daʊt ʃi wʊɾə pɹəfɝd staʊt tu ɹɪvɝz wʊlənz tə ðə faɪnɝ mətɪɹiəl ʃi faʊn hɪɹ. ɑn ði ʌðɝ hænd, ɪf ðə ɹɛd dɑɾ ə ðə kɪsən ɑn əɹ fɔɹhɛd wɝ nɑɾ ɪnʌf tə dʒɹɔ ɛvɹi aɪ, ʃi hæd dɛk hɝsɛlf aʊɾ ɪn dʒuəlɹi əz ðoʊ ətɛndɪŋ ə ɹɔɪəl ɑɾiəns, ə slɪm ɡoʊldən bɛlt ən ə lɔŋ nɛkləs ən ɛni nʌmbɝ ə bɹeɪslɪts, ɔl bʌt wʌn sɛt wɪð bɹaɪt blu sæfaɪɝz ən pɑlɪʃt ɡɹin stoʊnz i dɪd nɑt noʊ, ən ɛvɹi fɪŋɡɝ ɑn əɹ ɹaɪt hæn hæɾ ə ɹɪŋ tə mætʃ. hɝ ɡɹeɪt sɝpən ɹɪŋ wɑz tʌkt əweɪ sʌmwɛɹ, soʊ əz nɑt tə ətʃɹækt ətɛnʃən, bʌt ðə ɹɛs dʒɹu tɛn taɪmz əz mʌtʃ. mɛni pipəl wəd nɑɾ əv noʊn ən ɛɛs sədaɪz ɹɪŋ ət saɪt, bʌɾ ɛniwʌn kəd si mʌni ɪn ðoʊz dʒɛmz.

Rand's jaw tightened at the sight of the former damane. Nynaeve claimed the woman had insisted on coming along, but he did not believe anyone could "insist" on anything with Nynaeve. She wanted Alivia along for some secret reason. She had been behaving mysteriously, as though working as hard as she could at being Aes Sedai, ever since he went back for her after leaving Elayne. All three women had adopted high-necked Far Madding dresses, heavily embroidered with flowers and birds on the bodice and shoulders and right up to their chins, though sometimes Nynaeve grumbled over them. No doubt she would have preferred stout Two Rivers woolens to the finer material she found here. On the other hand, if the red dot of the ki'sain on her forehead were not enough to draw every eye, she had decked herself out in jewelry as though attending a royal audience, a slim golden belt and a long necklace and any number of bracelets, all but one set with bright blue sapphires and polished green stones he did not know, and every finger on her right hand had a ring to match. Her Great Serpent ring was tucked away somewhere, so as not to attract attention, but the rest drew ten times as much. Many people would not have known an Aes Sedai's ring at sight, but anyone could see money in those gems.

ɹænd klɪɹɾ ɪz θɹoʊɾ ən bɛnt, hɪz hɛd. "waɪf, aɪ nid tə spik wɪð jə əpstɛɹz," hi sɛd, ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ ət ðə læs moʊmən tə æd, "ɪf ɪt plizɪz ju." hi kəd nɑt meɪk ɪt mɔɹ ɝdʒən ðən ðæt, nɑɾ ən meɪnteɪn ðə pɹəpɹaɪəɾiz, bʌɾ i hoʊp ðeɪ dɪd nɑt lɪŋɡɝ. ðeɪ maɪt, ɪf oʊnli tə dɛmənstʃɹeɪt fəɹ ði ɪnkipɝ ðət ðeɪ wɝ nɑɾ əɾ ɪz bɛk ən kɔl. fəɹ səm ɹizən, pipəl ɪn fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ æktʃəli  sim tə bɪliv ðət wɪmən fɹəm ɔf dʒʌmpt wən mɛn toʊld əm tə!

Rand cleared his throat and bent, his head. "Wife, I need to speak with you upstairs," he said, remembering at the last moment to add, "if it pleases you." He could not make it more urgent than that, not and maintain the proprieties, but he hoped they did not linger. They might, if only to demonstrate for the innkeeper that they were not at his beck and call. For some reason, people in Far Madding actually seemed to believe that women from off jumped when men told them to!

mɪn twɪstəɾ ɝaʊn ɪn əɹ tʃɛɹ tə ɡɹɪn ət hɪm, ðə weɪ ʃi dɪɾ ɛvɹi taɪm i kɔld əɹ waɪf. ðə fil ə hɝ ɪn ɪz hɛd wɑz wɔɹmθ ən dɪlaɪt, sʌɾənli spɑɹklɪŋ wɪð əmjuzmənt. ʃi faʊn ðɛɹ sɪtʃueɪʃən ɪn fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ vɛɹi əmjuzɪŋ. linɪŋ təwɔɹd mɪstʃɹəs nælhɛɹə wɪθaʊt teɪkɪŋ əɹ aɪz fɹəm hɪm, ʃi sɛd sʌmθɪŋ ɪn ə loʊ vɔɪs ðət meɪd ði oʊldɝ wʊmən kækəl wɪð læftɝ ən ɡeɪv nɪneɪiv ə peɪn ɪkspɹɛʃən.

Min twisted around in her chair to grin at him, the way she did every time he called her wife. The feel of her in his head was warmth and delight, suddenly sparkling with amusement. She found their situation in Far Madding very amusing. Leaning toward Mistress Nalhera without taking her eyes from him, she said something in a low voice that made the older woman cackle with laughter and gave Nynaeve a pained expression.

əliviə stʊɾ ʌp, lʊkɪŋ nʌθɪŋ laɪk ðə səbdud wʊmən i veɪɡli ɹɪmɛmbɝd hændɪŋ oʊvɝ tə teɪm. ɔl ðoʊz kæptʃɝd sʌldəm ən deɪmeɪn hæd bɪn ə bɝɾən i wɑz ɡlæd tə bi fɹi ʌv, noʊ mɔɹ. ðəɹ wɝ θɹɛdz ʌv waɪɾ ɪn əɹ ɡoʊldən hɛɹ ən faɪn laɪnz ət ðə kɔɹnɝz ə hɝ aɪz, bʌt ðoʊz aɪz wɝ fɪɹs naʊ. "wɛl?" ʃi dʒɹɔld, stɛɹɪŋ daʊn ət nɪneɪiv, bʌt sʌmhaʊ ʃi meɪd ðə wɝd boʊθ ə kɹɪɾɪsɪzəm ən ə kəmænd.

Alivia stood up, looking nothing like the subdued woman he vaguely remembered handing over to Taim. All those captured sul'dam and damane had been a burden he was glad to be free of, no more. There were threads of white in her golden hair and fine lines at the corners of her eyes, but those eyes were fierce now. "Well?" she drawled, staring down at Nynaeve, but somehow she made the word both a criticism and a command.

nɪneɪiv ɡlɛɹɾ ʌp ət ðə wʊmən ən tʊk əɹ swit taɪm ɪn stændɪŋ ən smuðɪŋ əɹ skɝts, bʌɾ ət list ʃi stʊd.

Nynaeve glared up at the woman and took her sweet time in standing and smoothing her skirts, but at least she stood.

ɹænd weɪɾəd noʊ lɔŋɡɝ bɪfɔɹ ɹʌʃɪŋ əpstɛɹz. læn wɑz weɪɾɪŋ ət ðə hɛɾ ə ðə stɛɹz, dʒʌst aʊɾ ə saɪɾ ə ðə kɑmən ɹum bɪloʊ. kwaɪətli, ɹænd ɡeɪv ə bɛɹ-boʊnz əkaʊn ʌv wʌt hæd hæpənd. lænz stoʊni feɪs nɛvɝ tʃeɪnʒd ɪkspɹɛʃən.

Rand waited no longer before rushing upstairs. Lan was waiting at the head of the stairs, just out of sight of the common room below. Quietly, Rand gave a bare-bones account of what had happened. Lan's stony face never changed expression.

"æt list wʌn ə ðɛm ɪz dʌn," hi sɛd, tɝnɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə ɹum i ʃɛɹd wɪð nɪneɪiv. "aɪl ɡɛɾ əɹ θɪŋz ɹɛɾi."

"At least one of them is done," he said, turning toward the room he shared with Nynaeve. "I'll get our things ready."

ɹænd wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi ɪn ðə ɹum i ən mɪn ʃɛɹd, hɝidli pʊlɪŋ ðɛɹ kloʊðz aʊɾ ə ðə tɔl wɔɹdʒɹoʊb ən stʌfɪŋ əm ɛni weɪ ðeɪ wəd ɡoʊ ɪndə wʌn ə ðə wɪkɝ pæk hæmpɝz, wən ʃi faɪnəli ɛntɝd ðə ɹum. fɑloʊd baɪ nɪneɪiv ən əliviə.

Rand was already in the room he and Min shared, hurriedly pulling their clothes out of the tall wardrobe and stuffing them any way they would go into one of the wicker pack hampers, when she finally entered the room. Followed by Nynaeve and Alivia.

"laɪt, jəl ɹuən əɹ θɪŋz ðət weɪ," mɪn ɪkskleɪmd, ʃoʊldɝɪŋ ɪm əweɪ fɹəm ðə hæmpɝ. ʃi bɪɡæn ɹimuvɪŋ ɡɑɹməns ən foʊldɪŋ əm nitli ɑn ðə bɛd bɪsaɪɾ ɪz pis-bɑndəd sɔɹd. "waɪ ɑɹ wi pækɪŋ?" ʃi æskt, bʌt ɡeɪv ɪm noʊ tʃæns tə ænsɝ. "mɪstʃɹəs nælhɛɹə sɛz jə wʊdn bi soʊ sʌlki ɪf aɪ swɪtʃt jə ɛvɹi mɔɹnɪŋ," ʃi læft, ʃeɪkɪŋ aʊt wʌn ə ðə koʊts ʃi dɪd nɑt wɛɹ hɪɹ. hi hæd toʊld əɹ i wəd baɪ hɝ nu, bʌt ʃi ɹəfjuz tə liv ði ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd koʊts ən bɹitʃɪz bɪhaɪnd. "aɪ toʊld əɹ aɪd kənsɪɾɝ ɪt. ʃi laɪks læn vɛɹi mʌtʃ." sʌɾənli ʃi pɪtʃt əɹ vɔɪs haɪ ɪn ɪməteɪʃən ə ði ɪnkipɝ. "ə nit, maɪld-mænɝd mæn ɪz mʌtʃ tə bi pɹəfɝɾ oʊvɝ ə pɹɪɾi feɪs, aɪ ɔlweɪz seɪ."

"Light, you'll ruin our things that way," Min exclaimed, shouldering him away from the hamper. She began removing garments and folding them neatly on the bed beside his peace-bonded sword. "Why are we packing?" she asked, but gave him no chance to answer. "Mistress Nalhera says you wouldn't be so sulky if I switched you every morning," she laughed, shaking out one of the coats she did not wear here. He had told her he would buy her new, but she refused to leave the embroidered coats and breeches behind. "I told her I'd consider it. She likes Lan very much." Suddenly she pitched her voice high in imitation of the innkeeper. "A neat, mild-mannered man is much to be preferred over a pretty face, I always say."

nɪneɪiv snɔɹɾɪd. "hu wɑns ə mæn ʃi kən meɪk dʒʌmp θɹu hups wɛnɛvɝ ʃi laɪks?" ɹænd stɛɹɾ ət hɝ, ən mɪnz maʊθ fɛl oʊpən. ðət wɑz ɪɡzækli wʌt nɪneɪiv dɪd tə læn, ən haʊ ðə mæn pʊɾ ʌp wɪð ɪt wɑz mɔɹ ðən ɹænd kəɾ ʌndɝstænd.
