Nynaeve snorted. "Who wants a man she can make jump through hoops whenever she likes?" Rand stared at her, and Min's mouth fell open. That was exactly what Nynaeve did to Lan, and how the man put up with it was more than Rand could understand.

"ju θɪŋk əbaʊt mɛn tu mʌtʃ, nɪneɪiv," əliviə dʒɹɔld. nɪneɪiv fɹaʊn bʌɾ ɪnstɛɾ ə seɪɪŋ ɛniθɪŋ, ʃi dʒʌst stʊd ðəɹ fɪŋɡɝɪŋ wʌn ə hɝ bɹeɪslɪts, ə pəkjuljɝ pis wɪð flæt ɡoʊldən tʃeɪnz stʃɹɛtʃɪŋ daʊn ðə bæk ə hɝ lɛf hæn tə ɹɪŋz ɑn ɔl fɔɹ fɪŋɡɝz. ði oʊldɝ wʊmən ʃʊk əɹ hɛɾ əz ðoʊ dɪsəpɔɪntɪɾ ət nɑt ɡɛɾɪŋ ə ɹaɪz.

"You think about men too much, Nynaeve," Alivia drawled. Nynaeve frowned but instead of saying anything, she just stood there fingering one of her bracelets, a peculiar piece with flat golden chains stretching down the back of her left hand to rings on all four fingers. The older woman shook her head as though disappointed at not getting a rise.

"aɪm pækɪŋ kəz wɪv tə ɡoʊ, ən bi kwɪk əbaʊɾ ɪt," ɹænd sɛd heɪstəli. nɪneɪiv maɪt bi kwaɪət fəɹ ðə moʊmənt, ɑɾ əz ðət wɑz, bʌɾ ɪf əɹ feɪs ɡɑɾ ɛni dɑɹkɝ ʃi wəd bi jæŋkɪŋ əɹ bɹeɪɾ ən ʃaʊɾɪŋ tɪl noʊ wʌn kəd ɡɛɾ ə wɝɾ ɪn ɛdʒwaɪz fəɹ aʊɝz.

"I'm packing because we have to go, and be quick about it," Rand said hastily. Nynaeve might be quiet for the moment, odd as that was, but if her face got any darker she would be yanking her braid and shouting till no one could get a word in edgewise for hours.

bɪfɔɹ i fɪnɪʃt ðə seɪm əkaʊn i hæd ɡɪvən læn, mɪn stɑp foʊldɪŋ θɪŋz ən stɑɹɾəd ɹɪpleɪsɪŋ əɹ bʊks ɪn ðə sɛkən hæmpɝ, hɝidli ɪnʌf ðət ʃi dɪd nɑt pæɾ əm wɪð kloʊks ðə weɪ ʃi juʒəwəli dɪd. ði ʌðɝ tu wɪmən stʊd stɛɹɪŋ əɾ ɪm əz ðoʊ ðeɪ hæd nɛvɝ sin ɪm bɪfɔɹ. ɪn keɪs ðeɪ wɝ nɑt biɪŋ əz kwɪk tə si əz mɪn, hi ɪmpeɪʃənli æɾəd, "ɹɑtʃeɪɾ ən kɪsmən æmbʊʃt mi. ðeɪ nu aɪ wɑz fɑloʊɪŋ. kɪsmən ɡɑɾ əweɪ. ɪf i noʊz ðɪs ɪn, hi ən dæʃivə ən dʒɛdwɪn ən tɔɹvəl maɪɾ ɔl tɝn ʌp hɪɹ, meɪbi ɪn tu əɹ θɹi deɪz, əɹ meɪbi ɪn ən aʊɝ əɹ soʊ."

Before he finished the same account he had given Lan, Min stopped folding things and started replacing her books in the second hamper, hurriedly enough that she did not pad them with cloaks the way she usually did. The other two women stood staring at him as though they had never seen him before. In case they were not being as quick to see as Min, he impatiently added, "Rochaid and Kisman ambushed me. They knew I was following. Kisman got away. If he knows this inn, he and Dashiva and Gedwyn and Torval might all turn up here, maybe in two or three days, or maybe in an hour or so."

"aɪ æm nɑt blaɪnd," nɪneɪiv sɛd, stɪl stɛɹɪŋ ət hɪm. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ hiɾ ɪn əɹ vɔɪs; wɑz ʃi pɹətɛstɪŋ dʒʌs fəɹ ðə fɔɹm ʌv ɪt? "ɪf jə wɑnə hɝi, hɛlp mɪn ɪnstɛɾ ə stændɪŋ ɝaʊn laɪk ə wʊlhɛd." ʃi stɛɹɾ əɾ ɪm ə moʊmən lɔŋɡɝ, ən ʃʊk əɹ hɛd bɪfɔɹ livɪŋ.

"I am not blind," Nynaeve said, still staring at him. There was no heat in her voice; was she protesting just for the form of it? "If you want to hurry, help Min instead of standing around like a woolhead." She stared at him a moment longer, and shook her head before leaving.

əliviə pɔzd ɪn ði ækt ə fɑloʊɪŋ, ən ɡlɛɹɾ ət ɹænd. noʊ, ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ səbduɾ əbaʊɾ əɹ ɛni lɔŋɡɝ. "ju kəd ɡɛt jɝsɛlf kɪld laɪk ðæt," ʃi sɛd dɪsəpɹuvɪŋli. "ju hæv tu mʌtʃ tə də tə ɡɛt kɪl jɛt. jə mʌs lɛɾ əs hɛlp."

Alivia paused in the act of following, and glared at Rand. No, there was nothing subdued about her any longer. "You could get yourself killed like that," she said disapprovingly. "You have too much to do to get killed yet. You must let us help."

hi fɹaʊn ət ðə dɔɹ kloʊzɪŋ bɪhaɪn hɝ. "hæv jə hæɾ ɛni vjuɪŋz əbaʊt hɝ, mɪn?"

He frowned at the door closing behind her. "Have you had any viewings about her, Min?"

"ɔl ðə taɪm, bʌt nɑt ðə kaɪn jə min, nʌθɪŋ aɪ ʌndɝstænd." ʃi ɹɪŋkəld əɹ noʊz ət wʌn ə ðə bʊks ən sɛɾ ɪɾ əsaɪd. smɔl tʃæns ʃi wəɾ əbændən ə sɪŋɡəl vɑljum ə hɝ nɑt-soʊ-smɔl laɪbɹɛɹi. əndaʊɾɪdli ʃi mɛn tə kæɹi ðət wʌn, ən ɹɛɾ ɪɾ ət ðə fɝst ɑpɝtunəɾi. ʃi spɛn aʊɝz wɪð əɹ noʊz ɪn ðoʊz bʊks. "ɹænd," ʃi sɛd sloʊli, "ju dɪɾ ɔl ðæt, kɪld wʌn mæn ən feɪst ənʌðɝ, ən . . . ɹænd, aɪ dɪdn fil ɛniθɪŋ. ɪn ðə bɑnd, aɪ min. noʊ fɪɹ, noʊ æŋɡɝ. nɑɾ ivən kənsɝn! nʌθɪŋ."

"All the time, but not the kind you mean, nothing I understand." She wrinkled her nose at one of the books and set it aside. Small chance she would abandon a single volume of her not-so-small library. Undoubtedly she meant to carry that one, and read it at the first opportunity. She spent hours with her nose in those books. "Rand," she said slowly, "you did all that, killed one man and faced another, and . . . Rand, I didn't feel anything. In the bond, I mean. No fear, no anger. Not even concern! Nothing."

"aɪ wɑzn æŋɡɹi wɪð hɪm." ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛd, hi bɪɡæn ʃʌvɪŋ kloʊðz ɪndə ðə hæmpɝ əɡɛn. "hi dʒʌs niɾəd kɪlɪŋ, ðæts ɔl. ən waɪ wəɾ aɪ bi əfɹeɪd?"

"I wasn't angry with him." Shaking his head, he began shoving clothes into the hamper again. "He just needed killing, that's all. And why would I be afraid?"

"oʊ," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn ə smɔl vɔɪs. "aɪ si." ʃi bɛn bæk tə ðə bʊks. ðə bɑn hæd ɡɔn vɛɹi stɪl, əz ɪf ʃi wɝ dip ɪn θɔt, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz ə tʃɹʌbəl θɹɛd wɝmɪŋ ðoʊ ðə stɪlnəs.

"Oh," she said in a small voice. "I see." She bent back to the books. The bond had gone very still, as if she were deep in thought, but there was a troubled thread worming though the stillness.

"mɪn, aɪ pɹɑməs aɪ woʊn lɛɾ ɛniθɪŋ hæpən tə ju." hi dɪd nɑt noʊ wɛðɝ i kəd kip ðət pɹɑməs, bʌɾ i ɪntɛndəd tə tʃɹaɪ.

"Min, I promise I won't let anything happen to you." He did not know whether he could keep that promise, but he intended to try.

ʃi smaɪld ət hɪm, ɔlmoʊs læfɪŋ. laɪt, ʃi wɑz bjuɾəfəl. "aɪ noʊ ðæt, ɹænd. ən aɪ woʊn lɛɾ ɛniθɪŋ hæpən tə ju." lʌv floʊɾ əlɔŋ ðə bɑn laɪk ðə bleɪz ʌv ə nundeɪ sʌn. "əliviəz ɹaɪt, ðoʊ. jə də hæv tə lɛɾ əs hɛlp sʌmhaʊ. ɪf jə dɪskɹaɪb ðiz fɛloʊz wɛl ɪnʌf, meɪbi wi kən æsk kwɛstʃənz. jə sɝɾənli kæn sɝtʃ ðə hoʊl sɪɾi əloʊn."

She smiled at him, almost laughing. Light, she was beautiful. "I know that, Rand. And I won't let anything happen to you." Love flowed along the bond like the blaze of a noonday sun. "Alivia's right, though. You do have to let us help somehow. If you describe these fellows well enough, maybe we can ask questions. You certainly can't search the whole city alone."

wəɹ dɛd mɛn, luz θɝɪn mɝmɝd. dɛd mɛn ʃəd bi kwaɪəɾ ɪn ðɛɹ ɡɹeɪvz, bʌt ðeɪ nɛvɝ ɑɹ.

We are dead men, Lews Therin murmured. Dead men should be quiet in their graves, but they never are.

ɹænd bɛɹli hɝd ðə vɔɪs ɪn ɪz hɛd. sʌɾənli hi nu hi dɪd nɑɾ əv tə dɪskɹaɪb kɪsmən ən ði ʌðɝz. hi kəd dʒɹɔ ðɛm soʊ wɛl ðəɾ ɛniwʌn wəd ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðə feɪsəz. ɪksɛpt, hi hæd nɛvɝ bɪn eɪbəl tə dʒɹɔ ɪn ɪz laɪf. luz θɝɪn kʊd, ðoʊ. ðət ʃʊɾə fɹaɪɾənd hɪm. ɪt ʃəd hæv.

Rand barely heard the voice in his head. Suddenly he knew he did not have to describe Kisman and the others. He could draw them so well that anyone would recognize the faces. Except, he had never been able to draw in his life. Lews Therin could, though. That should have frightened him. It should have.

ɪsəm peɪs ðə ɹum, stʌɾiɪŋ baɪ ði ɛvɝ-pɹɛzən laɪɾ ə tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd. ðə bɛd lɪnənz ʃɪftəd fɹəm ɹʌmpəl tə nitli meɪd bɪtwin wʌn ɡlæns ən ðə nɛkst. ðə kʌvɝlət tʃeɪnʒd fɹəm flaʊɝd tə pleɪn dɑɹk ɹɛd tə kwɪltɪd. ði ɪfɛmɝəl ɔlweɪz tʃeɪnʒd hɪɹ, ən i bɛɹli noʊɾəst ɛnimɔɹ. hi kəd nɑt juz tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd ðə weɪ ðə tʃoʊzən kʊd, bʌt hɪɹ wɑz wɛɹ i fɛl moʊs fɹi. hɪɹ, hi kəd bi hu hi wɑntəd tə bi. hi tʃʌkəld ət ðə θɔt.

Isam paced the room, studying by the ever-present light of Tel'aran'rhiod. The bed linens shifted from rumpled to neatly made between one glance and the next. The coverlet changed from flowered to plain dark red to quilted. The ephemeral always changed here, and he barely noticed anymore. He could not use Tel'aran'rhiod the way the Chosen could, but here was where he felt most free. Here, he could be who he wanted to be. He chuckled at the thought.

stɑpɪŋ bɪsaɪd ðə bɛd, hi kɛɹfəli ənʃiðd ðə tu pɔɪzən dæɡɝz ən stɛpt aʊɾ ə ði ənsin wɝld ɪndə ðə weɪkɪŋ. əz i dɪd, hi bɪkeɪm luk. ɪt simd əpɹoʊpɹiət.

Stopping beside the bed, he carefully unsheathed the two poisoned daggers and stepped out of the Unseen World into the waking. As he did, he became Luc. It seemed appropriate.

ðə ɹum wɑz dɑɹk ɪn ðə weɪkɪŋ wɝld, bʌt ðə sɪŋɡəl wɪndoʊ lɛɾ ɪn səfɪʃən munlaɪt fəɹ luk tə meɪk aʊt ðə maʊndɪd ʃeɪps ə tu pipəl laɪɪŋ əslip bɪniθ ðɛɹ blæŋkəts. wɪθaʊt hɛzəteɪʃən i dʒɹoʊv ə bleɪɾ ɪndə itʃ. ðeɪ woʊk wɪð smɔl kɹaɪz, bʌɾ i pʊl ðə bleɪdz fɹi ən dʒɹoʊv əm ɪn əɡɛn ən əɡɛn. wɪð ðə pɔɪzən, ɪt wɑz ənlaɪkli iðɝ wʊɾə hæd ðə stʃɹɛŋkθ tə ʃaʊt laʊdli ɪnʌf tə bi hɝɾ aʊtsaɪd ðə ɹum, bʌɾ i wɑntəd tə meɪk ðɪs kɪl ɪz oʊn ɪn ə weɪ ðət pɔɪzən kəd nɑt ɡɹænt. sun ðeɪ stɑp twɪtʃɪŋ wən i θɹʌst ə bleɪd bɪtwin ɹɪbz.

The room was dark in the waking world, but the single window let in sufficient moonlight for Luc to make out the mounded shapes of two people lying asleep beneath their blankets. Without hesitation he drove a blade into each. They woke with small cries, but he pulled the blades free and drove them in again and again. With the poison, it was unlikely either would have had the strength to shout loudly enough to be heard outside the room, but he wanted to make this kill his own in a way that poison could not grant. Soon they stopped twitching when he thrust a blade between ribs.

waɪpɪŋ ðə dæɡɝz klin ɑn ðə kʌvɝlət, hi ɹiʃiðd əm wɪð əz mʌtʃ kɛɹ əz i hæd dʒɹɔn ðɛm. hi hæd bɪn ɡɪvən mɛni ɡɪfs, bʌɾ ɪmjunəɾi tə pɔɪzən, əɹ ɛni ʌðɝ wɛpən, wɑz nɑɾ əmʌŋ ðɛm. ðən i tʊk ə ʃɔɹt kændəl fɹəm ɪz pɑkəɾ ən blu əweɪ ɪnʌf æʃ fɹəm ðə bæŋkt koʊlz ɪn ðə faɪɝpleɪs tə laɪt ðə wɪk. hi ɔlweɪz laɪk tə si ðə pipəl i kɪld, æftɝ ɪf i kəd nɑt dʊɹɪŋ. hi hæɾ ɪspɛʃli ɛndʒɔɪd ðoʊz tu ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn ðə stoʊn ə tɛɹ. ði ɪnkɹədulɪɾi ɑn ðɛɹ feɪsəz wən i əpɪɹɾ aʊɾ ə θɪn ɛɹ, ðə hɔɹɝ wən ðeɪ ɹilaɪzd i hæd nɑt kʌm tə seɪv ðɛm, wɝ tʃɹɛʒɝd mɛmɹiz. ðət hæd bɪn ɪsəm, nɑt hɪm, bʌt ðə mɛmɹiz wɝ nʌn ðə lɛs pɹaɪz fəɹ ðæt. niðɝ ə ðɛm ɡɑt tə kɪl ən ɛɛs sədaɪ vɛɹi ɔfən.

Wiping the daggers clean on the coverlet, he resheathed them with as much care as he had drawn them. He had been given many gifts, but immunity to poison, or any other weapon, was not among them. Then he took a short candle from his pocket and blew away enough ash from the banked coals in the fireplace to light the wick. He always liked to see the people he killed, after if he could not during. He had especially enjoyed those two Aes Sedai in the Stone of Tear. The incredulity on their faces when he appeared out of thin air, the horror when they realized he had not come to save them, were treasured memories. That had been Isam, not him, but the memories were none the less prized for that. Neither of them got to kill an Aes Sedai very often.

fəɹ ə moʊmən i stʌɾid ðə feɪsəz ə ðə mæn ən wʊmən ɑn ðə bɛd, ðən pɪntʃt aʊt ðə kændəlz fleɪm ən ɹɪtɝn ðə kændəl tə hɪz pɑkət bɪfɔɹ stɛpɪŋ bæk ɪndə tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd.

For a moment he studied the faces of the man and woman on the bed, then pinched out the candle's flame and returned the candle to his pocket before stepping back into Tel'aran'rhiod.

hɪz peɪtʃɹən ə ðə moʊmənt wɑz weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ hɪm. ə mæn, hi wɑz ʃʊɹ ə ðət mʌtʃ, bʌt luk kəd nɑt lʊk ət hɪm. ɪt wɑz nɑɾ əz ɪt wɑz wɪð ðoʊz slaɪmi ɡɹeɪ mɛn, hum jə dʒʌs dɪd nɑt noʊɾəs. hi hæd kɪld wʌn ə ðɛm, wʌns, ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ ɪtsɛlf. ðeɪ fɛl koʊld ən ɛmpti tə ðə tʌtʃ. ɪt hæd bɪn laɪk kɪlɪŋ ə kɔɹps. noʊ, ðɪs mæn hæd dʌn sʌmθɪŋ wɪð ðə paʊɝ soʊ luks aɪz slɪɾ əweɪ fɹəm ɪm laɪk wɔɾɝ slaɪɾɪŋ daʊn ɡlæs. ivən sin ət ðə kɔɹnɝ ə ði aɪ, hi wɑz ə blɝ.

His patron of the moment was waiting for him. A man, he was sure of that much, but Luc could not look at him. It was not as it was with those slimy Gray Men, whom you just did not notice. He had killed one of them, once, in the White Tower itself. They felt cold and empty to the touch. It had been like killing a corpse. No, this man had done something with the Power so Luc's eyes slid away from him like water sliding down glass. Even seen at the corner of the eye, he was a blur.

"ðə pɛɹ slipɪŋ ɪn ðɪs ɹum wɪl slip fɝɛvɝ," luk sɛd, "bʌt ðə mæn wɑz bɔld, ðə wʊmən ɡɹeɪ."

"The pair sleeping in this room will sleep forever," Luc said, "but the man was bald, the woman gray."

"ə pɪɾi," ðə mæn sɛd, ən ðə vɔɪs sim tə mɛlt ɪn luks ɪɹz. hi wəd nɑt bi eɪbəl tə ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ɪɾ ɪf i hɝɾ ɪt wɪθaʊt ðə dɪsɡaɪz. ðə mæn hæd tə bi wʌn ə ðə tʃoʊzən. fju seɪv ðə tʃoʊzən nu haʊ tə ɹitʃ hɪm, ən nʌn ə ðə mɛn əmʌŋ ðoʊz fju kəd tʃænəl, əɹ wʊɾə dɛɹd tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kəmæn hɪm. hɪz sɝvəsəz wɝ ɔlweɪz bɛɡd, ɪksɛp baɪ ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd hɪmsɛlf, ən mɔɹ ɹisənli baɪ ðə tʃoʊzən, bʌt nʌn ə ðə tʃoʊzən luk hæd mɛt hæɾ ɛvɝ teɪkən sətʃ pɹikɔʃənz əz ðɪs.

"A pity," the man said, and the voice seemed to melt in Luc's ears. He would not be able to recognize it if he heard it without the disguise. The man had to be one of the Chosen. Few save the Chosen knew how to reach him, and none of the men among those few could channel, or would have dared trying to command him. His services were always begged, except by the Great Lord himself, and more recently by the Chosen, but none of the Chosen Luc had met had ever taken such precautions as this.

"du jə wɑn mi tə tʃɹaɪ əɡɛn?" luk æskt.

"Do you want me to try again?" Luc asked.

"pɝhæps. wən aɪ tɛl ju. nɑt bɪfɔɹ. ɹɪmɛmbɝ, nɑɾ ə wɝɾ ə ðɪs tə ɛniwʌn."

"Perhaps. When I tell you. Not before. Remember, not a word of this to anyone."

"æz jə kəmænd," luk ɹɪplaɪd, boʊɪŋ, bʌt ðə mæn wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi meɪkɪŋ ə ɡeɪtweɪ, ə hoʊl ðəɾ oʊpən ɪndə ə snoʊi fɔɹəst ɡleɪd. hi wɑz ɡɔn bɪfɔɹ luk stʃɹeɪɾənd.

"As you command," Luc replied, bowing, but the man was already making a gateway, a hole that opened into a snowy forest glade. He was gone before Luc straightened.

ɪt ɹɪli wɑz ə pɪɾi. hi hæd ɹæðɝ lʊk fɔɹwɝd tə kɪlɪŋ ɪz nɛfju ən ðə wɛnk. bʌɾ ɪf ðəɹ wɑz taɪm tə pæs, hʌntɪŋ wɑz ɔlweɪz ə plɛʒɝ. hi bɪkeɪm ɪsəm. ɪsəm laɪkt kɪlɪŋ wʊlvz ivən mɔɹ ðən luk dɪd.

It really was a pity. He had rather looked forward to killing his nephew and the wench. But if there was time to pass, hunting was always a pleasure. He became Isam. Isam liked killing wolves even more than Luc did.


tʃæptɝ twɛntiθɹi


CHAPTER 23

tə luz ðə sʌn


To Lose the Sun

tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə hoʊl ði ʌnfəmɪljɝ wʊlən kloʊk taɪtli ɝaʊn əɹ wɪð wʌn hænd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ nɑt tə fɔl aʊɾ ə ði ivən mɔɹ ʌnfəmɪljɝ sæɾəl, ʃələn ɔkwɝdli hild əɹ hɔɹs fɔɹwɝɾ ən fɑloʊd hɑɹɪn ən əɹ sɔɹdmæstɝ moʊd θɹu ðə hoʊl ɪn ði ɛɹ ðət lɛd fɹəm ə steɪbliɑɹɾ ɪn ðə sʌn pæləs tə . . . ʃi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ wɛɹ, ɪksɛp ðəɾ ɪt wɑz ə lɔŋ oʊpən ɛɹiə - ə klɪɹɪŋ, wɑz ɪt kɔld? ʃi θɔt ðət wɑz ɹaɪt - ə klɪɹɪŋ lɑɹdʒɝ ðən ə ɹeɪkɝz dɛk, əmʌŋ stʌntɪd tʃɹiz speɪst aʊɾ ɑn hɪlz. ðə paɪnz, ði oʊnli tʃɹiz əmʌŋ əm ʃi ɹɛkəɡnaɪzd, wɝ tu smɔl ən twɪstəd fəɹ ɛni jus bʌt tɑɹ ən tɝpəntaɪn. moʊst ə ðə ɹɛst ʃoʊd bɛɹ ɡɹeɪ bɹæntʃəz ðət meɪɾ əɹ θɪŋk ə boʊnz. ðə mɔɹnɪŋ sʌn sæt dʒʌst əbʌv ðə tʃɹitɑps, ən ɪf ɛniθɪŋ, ðə koʊl simd mɔɹ bɪɾɝ hɪɹ ðən ɪt hæɾ ɪn ðə sɪɾi ʃi hæd lɛf bɪhaɪnd. ʃi hoʊp ðə hɔɹs dɪd nɑt mɪsstɛp ən tʌmbəl əɹ daʊn ɑntu ðə ɹɑks ðət stʌk ʌp wɛɹɛvɝ pætʃəz ə snoʊ dɪd nɑt kʌvɝ ðə ɹɑɾɪŋ livz ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd. ʃi dɪstʃɹʌstəd hɔɹsəz. ənlaɪk ʃɪps, ænəməlz hæd maɪnz ə ðɛɹ oʊn. ðeɪ wɝ tʃɹɛtʃɝəs θɪŋz tə klaɪm ɑn tɑp ʌv. ən hɔɹsəz hæd tiθ. wɛnɛvɝ əɹ maʊnt ʃoʊd hɪz, soʊ nɪɹ tə hɝ lɛɡz, ʃi flɪntʃt ən pæɾəd ɪz nɛk ən meɪd suðɪŋ saʊnz. ət list, ʃi hoʊp ðə bis faʊn əm suðɪŋ.

Trying to hold the unfamiliar woolen cloak tightly around her with one hand, trying not to fall out of the even more unfamiliar saddle, Shalon awkwardly heeled her horse forward and followed Harine and her Swordmaster Moad through the hole in the air that led from a stableyard in the Sun Palace to . . . She was not sure where, except that it was a long open area - a clearing, was it called? she thought that was right - a clearing larger than a raker's deck, among stunted trees spaced out on hills. The pines, the only trees among them she recognized, were too small and twisted for any use but tar and turpentine. Most of the rest showed bare gray branches that made her think of bones. The morning sun sat just above the treetops, and if anything, the cold seemed more bitter here than it had in the city she had left behind. She hoped the horse did not misstep and tumble her down onto the rocks that stuck up wherever patches of snow did not cover the rotting leaves on the ground. She distrusted horses. Unlike ships, animals had minds of their own. They were treacherous things to climb on top of. And horses had teeth. Whenever her mount showed his, so near to her legs, she flinched and patted his neck and made soothing sounds. At least, she hoped the beast found them soothing.

kædzueɪn hɝsɛlf, ɡɑɹbd ɪn ʌnɹiliv dɑɹk ɡɹin, sæɾ izəli ɑn ə tɔl hɔɹs wɪð ə blæk meɪn ən teɪl, meɪnteɪnɪŋ ðə wiv ðət meɪd ðə ɡeɪtweɪ. hɔɹsəz dɪd nɑt bɑðɝ hɝ. nʌθɪŋ bɑðɝd hɝ. ə sʌɾən bɹiz stɝd ðə dɑɹk ɡɹeɪ kloʊk spɹɛɾ oʊvɝ ðə bæk ɛn ə hɝ maʊnt, bʌt ʃi ɡeɪv noʊ saɪn ə filɪŋ ðə koʊld əɾ ɔl. ðə ɡoʊldən hɛɹ ɔɹnəməns dæŋɡəlɪŋ ɝaʊn əɹ dɑɹk ɡɹeɪ bʌn swʌŋ əz ʃi tɝn əɹ hɛd tə wɑtʃ ʃələn ən əɹ kəmpænjənz. ʃi wɑz ə hænsəm wʊmən, bʌt nɑt wʌn jə wəd noʊɾəs twaɪs ɪn ə kɹaʊɾ ɪksɛp ðəɾ əɹ smuð feɪs dɪd nɑt mætʃ əɹ hɛɹ. wʌns jə keɪm tə noʊ hɝ, ɪt wɑz tu leɪt.

Cadsuane herself, garbed in unrelieved dark green, sat easily on a tall horse with a black mane and tail, maintaining the weave that made the gateway. Horses did not bother her. Nothing bothered her. A sudden breeze stirred the dark gray cloak spread over the back end of her mount, but she gave no sign of feeling the cold at all. The golden hair ornaments dangling around her dark gray bun swung as she turned her head to watch Shalon and her companions. She was a handsome woman, but not one you would notice twice in a crowd except that her smooth face did not match her hair. Once you came to know her, it was too late.

ʃələn wʊɾə ɡɪvən mʌtʃ tə si haʊ ðət wiv wɑz dʌn, ivən ɪf ɪt hæd mɛn biɪŋ nɪɹ kædzueɪn, bʌt ʃi hæd nɑt bɪn əlaʊɾ ɪndə ðə steɪbliɑɹɾ əntɪl ðə ɡeɪtweɪ wɑz kəmplit, ən siɪŋ ə seɪl spɹɛɾ ɑn ðə jɑɹdɑɹm dɪd nɑt titʃ jə haʊ tə sɛɾ ə seɪl mʌtʃ lɛs meɪk wʌn. ɔl ʃi nu wɑz ðə neɪm. ɹaɪɾɪŋ pæst, ʃi əvɔɪɾəd miɾɪŋ ði ɛɛs sədaɪz ɡeɪz, bʌt ʃi fɛlt ɪt. ðə wʊmənz aɪz meɪɾ əɹ toʊz kɝl, sikɪŋ ə fʊɾɪŋ ðə stɝəps kəd nɑt ɡɪv. ʃi kəd si noʊ weɪ tə ɪskeɪp, jɛt ʃi hoʊp tə faɪnd wʌn θɹu stʌɾiɪŋ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. ðət ʃi nu vɛɹi lɪɾəl əbaʊɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ, ʃi wɑz ɹɛɾəli wɪlɪŋ tə ədmɪt - ʃi hæd nɛvɝ mɛt wʌn bɪfɔɹ seɪlɪŋ tə kɛɹhin, ən θɔɾ əbaʊɾ əm oʊnli tə pɹeɪz ðə laɪt ðət ʃi hæd nɑt bɪn tʃoʊzən tə bɪkʌm wʌn - bʌt ðəɹ wɝ kɝəns əmʌŋ kædzueɪnz kəmpænjənz, dip bɪniθ ðə sɝfəs. dip, stʃɹɔŋ kɝəns kəɾ ɔltɝ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ðət simd əpɛɹən ɑn ðə sɝfəs.

Shalon would have given much to see how that weave was done, even if it had meant being near Cadsuane, but she had not been allowed into the stableyard until the gateway was complete, and seeing a sail spread on the yardarm did not teach you how to set a sail much less make one. All she knew was the name. Riding past, she avoided meeting the Aes Sedai's gaze, but she felt it. The woman's eyes made her toes curl, seeking a footing the stirrups could not give. She could see no way to escape, yet she hoped to find one through studying the Aes Sedai. That she knew very little about Aes Sedai, she was readily willing to admit - she had never met one before sailing to Cairhien, and thought about them only to praise the Light that she had not been chosen to become one - but there were currents among Cadsuane's companions, deep beneath the surface. Deep, strong currents could alter everything that seemed apparent on the surface.

ðə fɔɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ hu hæd kʌm θɹu ɹaɪɾ æftɝ kædzueɪn wɝ weɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz ət wʌn saɪɾ ə ðə . . . klɪɹɪŋ . . . wɪð θɹi wɔɹɾɝz. ət list, ʃələn wɑz ʃʊɹ ðəɾ ɪvɑn wɑz ðə faɪɝi ɑlɑnəz wɔɹɾɝ, ən toʊmɑs wɑz staʊt lɪɾəl vɛɹɪnz, bʌt ʃi ɔlsoʊ wɑz ʃʊɹ ʃi hæd sin ðə vɛɹi jʌŋ mæn u steɪd soʊ kloʊs tə plʌmp deɪdʒiənz saɪd wɛɹɪŋ ən æʃəmənz blæk koʊt. ʃʊɹli hi kəd nɑt bi ə wɔɹɾɝ. kəd hi? ɛbən wɑz dʒʌst ə bɔɪ. jɛt wən ðə wʊmən ɡeɪzd ət hɪm, hɝ juʒəwəl pʌft-ʌp pɹaɪd sim tə swɛl fɝðɝ. kʌmaɪɹə, ə plɛzənt-lʊkɪŋ wʊmən wɪð blu aɪz ðət kəd tɝn ɪndə naɪvz wən sʌmθɪŋ ɪntʃɹəstəd hɝ, sæɾ əɹ sæɾəl ə lɪɾəl tə wʌn saɪd, stʌɾiɪŋ jʌŋ ɛbən soʊ ʃɑɹpli ɪt wɑz ə wʌndɝ i wɑz nɑt laɪɪŋ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊn flɛnst.

The four Aes Sedai who had come through right after Cadsuane were waiting on their horses at one side of the . . . clearing . . . with three Warders. At least, Shalon was sure that Ihvon was the fiery Alanna's Warder, and Tomas was stout little Verin's, but she also was sure she had seen the very young man who stayed so close to plump Daigian's side wearing an Asha'man's black coat. Surely he could not be a Warder. Could he? Eben was just a boy. Yet when the woman gazed at him, her usual puffed-up pride seemed to swell further. Kumira, a pleasant-looking woman with blue eyes that could turn into knives when something interested her, sat her saddle a little to one side, studying young Eben so sharply it was a wonder he was not lying on the ground flensed.

"aɪ wɪl nɑt pʊɾ ʌp wɪð ðɪs mʌtʃ lɔŋɡɝ," hɑɹɪn ɡɹʌmbəld, θʌmpɪŋ əɹ mɛɹ wɪð əɹ bɛɹ hilz tə kip ɪt muvɪŋ. hɝ bɹoʊkeɪɾɪd jɛloʊ sɪlks dɪd nɑt hɛlp əɹ kip ə ɡʊd siɾ ɪn ðə sæɾəl ɛni mɔɹ ðən dɪd ʃələnz blu. ʃi sweɪɾ ən slɪd wɪð ði ænəməlz muvməns, ɑn ðə pɔɪn ə tɑpəlɪŋ tə ðə ɡɹaʊn əɾ ɛvɹi stɛp. ðə bɹiz ɡʌstɪɾ əɡɛn, flɪpɪŋ ðə dæŋɡəlɪŋ ɛnz ə hɝ sæʃ əbaʊt, meɪkɪŋ əɹ kloʊk bɪloʊ, bʌt ʃi dɪsdeɪn tə kəntʃɹoʊl ðə ɡɑɹmənt. kloʊks wɝ nɑt mʌtʃ juzd ɪn ðə ʃɪps; ðeɪ ɡɑɾ ɪn ðə weɪ, ən kəd tæŋɡəl jəɹ ɑɹmz ən lɛɡz wən jə niɾəd əm fəɹ sɝvaɪvəl. moʊd hæd ɹəfjuzd wʌn, tʃɹʌstɪŋ tə ðə kwɪltɪd blu koʊɾ i wɔɹ ɪn ðə koʊldəst siz. nɛsun bihɑɹə, ɔl ɪn bɹɑnz wʊl, ɹoʊd θɹu ðə ɡeɪtweɪ lʊkɪŋ ɝaʊn əz ɪf tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə si ɛvɹiθɪŋ ət wʌns, ən ðən ɛlzə pɛnfəl, hu wɔɹ ə sʌlən ɪkspɹɛʃən fəɹ səm ɹizən ən klʌtʃt əɹ fɝ-laɪnd ɡɹin kloʊk taɪt. nʌn ə ði ʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ sim tə bɑðɝ mʌtʃ wɪð ʃɛltɝɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz fɹəm ðə koʊld.

"I will not put up with this much longer," Harine grumbled, thumping her mare with her bare heels to keep it moving. Her brocaded yellow silks did not help her keep a good seat in the saddle any more than did Shalon's blue. She swayed and slid with the animal's movements, on the point of toppling to the ground at every step. The breeze gusted again, flipping the dangling ends of her sash about, making her cloak billow, but she disdained to control the garment. Cloaks were not much used in the ships; they got in the way, and could tangle your arms and legs when you needed them for survival. Moad had refused one, trusting to the quilted blue coat he wore in the coldest seas. Nesune Bihara, all in bronze wool, rode through the gateway looking around as if trying to see everything at once, and then Elza Penfel, who wore a sullen expression for some reason and clutched her fur-lined green cloak tight. None of the other Aes Sedai seemed to bother much with sheltering themselves from the cold.

"aɪ meɪ bi eɪbəl tə si ðə kɔɹəmʊɹ, ʃi sɛz," hɑɹɪn mʌɾɝd, pʊlɪŋ əɾ əɹ ɹeɪnz əntɪl ðə mɛɹ tɝn təwɔɹd ðə saɪɾ ə ðə klɪɹɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm wɛɹ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ ɡæðɝɪŋ. "meɪ! ən ʃi ɔfɝz ðɪs tʃæns əz ðoʊ ɡɹæntɪŋ ə pɹɪvlədʒ." hɑɹɪn dɪd nɑt nid tə ɡɪv ə neɪm; wən hɑɹɪn sɛd "ʃi" ðət weɪ, laɪk ə dʒɛlifɪʃəz stɪŋ, ðəɹ kəɾ oʊnli bi wʌn wʊmən ʃi mɛnt. "aɪ hæv ðə ɹaɪt, bɑɹɡən fəɹ ən əɡɹid! ʃi dɪnaɪz mi ði əɡɹiɾ ɑntʊɹɑʒ! aɪ mʌs liv maɪ seɪlməstʃɹəs bɪhaɪnd, ən maɪ ətɛndəns!" ɛɹiən bɹoʊlɛoʊz əpɪɹd θɹu ði oʊpənɪŋ, əz ɪntɛn əz ɪf ʃi ɪkspɛktəd tə faɪn ə bæɾəl, fɑloʊd baɪ bɛldaɪn nɪɹæm, hu dɪd nɑɾ ivən lʊk laɪk ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. boʊθ wɔɹ ɡɹin, ɛɹiən kəmplitli, bɛldaɪn ɪn slæʃɪz ɪn əɹ slivz ən skɝts. dɪd ðət min sʌmθɪŋ? laɪkli nɑt. "æm aɪ tə əpɹoʊtʃ ðə kɔɹəmʊɹ laɪk ə dɛkɡɝl tʌtʃɪŋ maɪ hɑɹt tə ə seɪlməstʃɹəs?" wən sɛvɹəl ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ təɡɛðɝ, jə kəd si ðə smuð-feɪst eɪɡləsnəs klɪɹli, soʊ jə kəd nɑt seɪ wɛðɝ ɛni wʌn wɑz twɛnti əɹ twaɪs ðəɾ ivən ɪf əɹ hɛɹ wɑz waɪt, ən bɛldaɪn sɪmpli lʊkt ə ɡɝl ə twɛnti. ən ðət toʊl noʊ mɔɹ ðən dɪɾ əɹ skɝts. "æm aɪ tə ɛɹ maɪ oʊn bɛɾɪŋ ən wɑʃ maɪ oʊn lɪnənz? ʃi tɝnz pɹoʊɾəkɑl stʃɹeɪɾ ɪndə ðə wɪnd! əl nɑɾ əlaʊ ɪt! noʊ mɔɹ!" ðiz wɝ oʊl kəmpleɪns, vɔɪst ə dʌzən taɪmz sɪns læs naɪt, wən kædzueɪn leɪd daʊn əɹ kəndɪʃənz ɪf ðeɪ wɝ tə əkʌmpəni hɝ. ðoʊz kəndɪʃənz hæd bɪn stʃɹɪkt, bʌt hɑɹɪn hæd hæd noʊ tʃɔɪs seɪv tə æksid, wɪtʃ oʊnli æɾəd tə ðə bɪɾɝnəs.

"I may be able to see the Coramoor, she says," Harine muttered, pulling at her reins until the mare turned toward the side of the clearing away from where the Aes Sedai were gathering. "May! And she offers this chance as though granting a privilege." Harine did not need to give a name; when Harine said "she" that way, like a jellyfish's sting, there could only be one woman she meant. "I have the right, bargained for and agreed! She denies me the agreed entourage! I must leave my Sailmistress behind, and my attendants!" Erian Boroleos appeared through the opening, as intent as if she expected to find a battle, followed by Beldeine Nyram, who did not even look like an Aes Sedai. Both wore green, Erian completely, Beldeine in slashes in her sleeves and skirts. Did that mean something? Likely not. "Am I to approach the Coramoor like a deckgirl touching my heart to a Sailmistress?" When several Aes Sedai were together, you could see the smooth-faced agelessness clearly, so you could not say whether any one was twenty or twice that even if her hair was white, and Beldeine simply looked a girl of twenty. And that told no more than did her skirts. "Am I to air my own bedding and wash my own linens? She turns protocol straight into the wind! I will not allow it! No more!" These were old complaints, voiced a dozen times since last night, when Cadsuane laid down her conditions if they were to accompany her. Those conditions had been strict, but Harine had had no choice save to accede, which only added to the bitterness.

ʃələn lɪsənd wɪð hæf ən ɪɹ, nɑɾɪŋ ən mɝmɝɪŋ ði əpɹoʊpɹiət ɹɪspɑnsɪz. əɡɹimənt, ʌv kɔɹs. hɝ sɪstɝ ɪkspɛktəɾ əɡɹimənt. moʊst ə hɝ ətɛnʃən wɑz ɑn ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. sɝəptɪʃəsli. moʊd dɪd nɑt pɹitɛn tə lɪsən, bʌt ðɛn, hi wɑz hɑɹɪnz sɔɹdmæstɝ. hɑɹɪn maɪt bi taɪɾ əz ə wɛt nɑt wɪð ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls, jɛt ʃi ɡeɪv moʊd soʊ mʌtʃ liweɪ ɛniwʌn maɪɾ əv θɔt ðə hɑɹd-aɪd, ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd mæn wɑz əɹ lʌvɝ, ɪspɛʃli sɪns boʊθ wɝ wɪɾoʊd. ət list, ðeɪ maɪt θɪŋk ɪɾ ɪf ðeɪ dɪd nɑt noʊ hɑɹɪn. hɑɹɪn wəd nɛvɝ teɪk ə lʌvɝ u stʊd loʊɝ ðən ʃi, ən naʊ, ʌv kɔɹs, ðət mɛnt ʃi kəd teɪk nʌn. ɪn ɛni keɪs, wʌns ðeɪ stɑp ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz nɪɹ ðə tʃɹiz, moʊd lin ən ɛlboʊ ɑn ðə tɔl pɑməl ə hɪz sæɾəl, ɹɛstəɾ ə hæn ɑn ðə lɔŋ, kɑɹvd aɪvɝi hɪlt ə ðə sɔɹd θɹʌs bɪhaɪn ɪz ɡɹin sæʃ, ən oʊpənli stʌɾid ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ən ðə mɛn wɪð ðɛm. wɛɹ hæɾ i lɝn tə ɹaɪɾ ə hɔɹs? hi æktʃəli  lʊkt . . . kʌmftəɹbəl. ɛniwʌn kəd tɛl ɪz ɹæŋk əɾ ə ɡlæns, fɹəm ɪz eɪɾ ɪɹɪŋz ə ðə hɛviəst weɪɾ ən ðə nɑɾɪŋ ə hɪz sæʃ, ivən ɪf i wɑz nɑt wɛɹɪŋ ɪz sɔɹɾ ən mætʃɪŋ dæɡɝ. dɪɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ hæv noʊ weɪ tə də ðə seɪm? kəd ðeɪ tʃɹuli bi soʊ dɪsɔɹɡənaɪzd? səpoʊzədli ðə waɪt taʊɝ wɑz laɪk səm məkænɪkəl kəntʃɹaɪvəns ðət ɡɹaʊn ʌp θɹoʊnz ən ɹiʃeɪpt əm tə ɪts wɪl. ʌv kɔɹs, ðə məʃinɝi dɪd sim tə bi bɹoʊkən, naʊ.

Shalon listened with half an ear, nodding and murmuring the appropriate responses. Agreement, of course. Her sister expected agreement. Most of her attention was on the Aes Sedai. Surreptitiously. Moad did not pretend to listen, but then, he was Harine's Swordmaster. Harine might be tight as a wet knot with everyone else, yet she gave Moad so much leeway anyone might have thought the hard-eyed, gray-haired man was her lover, especially since both were widowed. At least, they might think it if they did not know Harine. Harine would never take a lover who stood lower than she, and now, of course, that meant she could take none. In any case, once they stopped their horses near the trees, Moad leaned an elbow on the tall pommel of his saddle, rested a hand on the long, carved ivory hilt of the sword thrust behind his green sash, and openly studied the Aes Sedai and the men with them. Where had he learned to ride a horse? He actually looked . . . comfortable. Anyone could tell his rank at a glance, from his eight earrings of the heaviest weight and the knotting of his sash, even if he was not wearing his sword and matching dagger. Did Aes Sedai have no way to do the same? Could they truly be so disorganized? Supposedly the White Tower was like some mechanical contrivance that ground up thrones and reshaped them to its will. Of course, the machinery did seem to be broken, now.

"aɪ sɛd, wɛɹ əz ʃi bɹɔɾ ʌs, ʃələn?"

"I said, where has she brought us, Shalon?"

hɑɹɪnz vɔɪs, laɪk ən aɪsi ɹeɪzɝ, dʒɹeɪn ðə blʌd fɹəm ʃələnz feɪs. sɝvɪŋ ʌndɝ ə jʌŋɡɝ sɪblɪŋ wɑz ɔlweɪz dɪfəkəlt, bʌt hɑɹɪn meɪɾ ɪt mɔɹ soʊ. ɪn pɹaɪvət ʃi wɑz bɪɑn kul, ən ɪn pʌblɪk ʃi wɑz keɪpəbəl ə hævɪŋ ə seɪlməstʃɹəs hʌŋ ʌp baɪ ði æŋkəlz, nɑt tə mɛnʃən ə wɪndfɪndɝ. ən sɪns ðət jʌŋ ʃɔɹbaʊnd wʊmən, mɪn, hæd toʊld əɹ ʃi wəd bi mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps wʌn deɪ, ʃi hæd ɡɹoʊn ɛvɝ ʃɑɹpɝ. stɛɹɪŋ hɑɹd-aɪɾ ət ʃələn, ʃi ɹeɪzd əɹ ɡoʊldən sɛnt-bɑks əz ɪf tə kʌvɝ ən ənplɛzən oʊɾɝ, ðoʊ ðə koʊl kɪld ɔl ðə pɝfjum.

Harine's voice, like an icy razor, drained the blood from Shalon's face. Serving under a younger sibling was always difficult, but Harine made it more so. In private she was beyond cool, and in public she was capable of having a Sailmistress hung up by the ankles, not to mention a Windfinder. And since that young shorebound woman, Min, had told her she would be Mistress of the Ships one day, she had grown ever sharper. Staring hard-eyed at Shalon, she raised her golden scent-box as if to cover an unpleasant odor, though the cold killed all the perfume.

hɝidli ʃələn lʊkt ɪndə ðə skaɪ, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə dʒʌdʒ ðə sʌn. ʃi wɪʃt əɹ sɛkstənt wɝ nɑt lɑkt əweɪ ɑn waɪt spɹeɪ - ðə ʃɔɹbaʊnd wɝ nɛvɝ əlaʊd tə si ə sɛkstənt, mʌtʃ lɛs si wʌn biɪŋ juzd - bʌt ʃi wɑz ənsɝɾən ɪt wʊɾə dʌn əɹ ɛni ɡʊd. ðiz tʃɹiz maɪt bi ʃɔɹt, bʌt ʃi stɪl kəd nɑt meɪk aʊɾ ə hɝaɪzən. kloʊs ɑn tə ðə nɔɹθ, ðə hɪlz ɹoʊz ɪndə maʊntənz ðət slæntəd nɔɹθis tə saʊθwɛst. ʃi kəd nɑt seɪ haʊ haɪ ʃi wɑz. ðəɹ wɑz fɑɹ tu mʌtʃ ʌp ən daʊn əbaʊt lændsaɪd tə sut hɝ. ivən soʊ, ɛni wɪndfɪndɝ nu haʊ tə meɪk ɹʌf əpɹɑksəmeɪʃənz. ən wən hɑɹɪn dɪmændəɾ ɪnfɝmeɪʃən, ʃi ɪkspɛktəd tə ɹəsiv ɪt.

Hurriedly Shalon looked into the sky, trying to judge the sun. She wished her sextant were not locked away on White Spray - the shorebound were never allowed to see a sextant, much less see one being used - but she was uncertain it would have done her any good. These trees might be short, but she still could not make out a horizon. Close on to the north, the hills rose into mountains that slanted northeast to southwest. She could not say how high she was. There was far too much up and down about landside to suit her. Even so, any Windfinder knew how to make rough approximations. And when Harine demanded information, she expected to receive it.

"aɪ kən oʊnli ɡɛs, weɪvməstʃɹəs," ʃi sɛd. hɑɹɪnz dʒɔ taɪɾənd, bʌt noʊ wɪndfɪndɝ wəd pɹizɛn ə ɡɛs əz ə fɝm pəzɪʃən. "aɪ bɪliv wəɹ θɹi əɹ fɔɹ hʌnʒɹəd liɡz saʊθ ə kɛɹhin. mɔɹ, aɪ kænɑt seɪ." ɛni fɝst-deɪ əpɹɛntəs juzɪŋ ə stʃɹɪŋ-stɪk u ɡeɪv ə fɪks ðət lus wʊɾə bɪn bɛn oʊvɝ fəɹ ðə dɛkmæstɝz stɑɹɾɝ, bʌt ðə wɝdz tʃɪld ʃələnz tʌŋ əz ʃi hɝd wʌt ʃi wɑz seɪɪŋ. ə hʌnʒɹəd liɡz oʊvɝ ðə fʊl tɝn ʌv ə deɪ wɑz ɡʊd seɪlɪŋ fəɹ ə ɹeɪkɝ. moʊd pɝst ɪz lɪps θɔtfəli.

"I can only guess, Wavemistress," she said. Harine's jaw tightened, but no Windfinder would present a guess as a firm position. "I believe we are three or four hundred leagues south of Cairhien. More, I cannot say." Any first-day apprentice using a string-stick who gave a fix that loose would have been bent over for the deckmaster's starter, but the words chilled Shalon's tongue as she heard what she was saying. A hundred leagues over the full turn of a day was good sailing for a raker. Moad pursed his lips thoughtfully.

hɑɹɪn nɑɾəd sloʊli, lʊkɪŋ ɹaɪt θɹu ʃələn əz ðoʊ ʃi kəd si ɹeɪkɝz ʌndɝ fʊl seɪl ɡlaɪɾɪŋ θɹu hoʊlz woʊvən ɪn ði ɛɹ wɪð ðə paʊɝ. ðə siz tʃɹuli wəd bi ðɛɹz, ðɛn. ɡɪvɪŋ hɝsɛlf ə ʃeɪk, ʃi lin təwɔɹd ʃələn, hɝ aɪz kætʃɪŋ ʃələnz laɪk hʊks. "ju mʌs lɝn ðɪs, wʌtɛvɝ ðə kɑst. tɛl əɹ jəl spaɪ ɑn mi ɪf ʃi titʃəz ju. ɪf jə kənvɪns hɝ, ʃi maɪt, ðə laɪt wɪlɪŋ. əɹ ət lis jə meɪ ɡɛt kloʊs ɪnʌf tə wʌn ə ði ʌðɝz tə lɝn ɪt."

Harine nodded slowly, looking right through Shalon as though she could see rakers under full sail gliding through holes woven in the air with the Power. The seas truly would be theirs, then. Giving herself a shake, she leaned toward Shalon, her eyes catching Shalon's like hooks. "You must learn this, whatever the cost. Tell her you will spy on me if she teaches you. If you convince her, she might, the Light willing. Or at least you may get close enough to one of the others to learn it."

ʃələn lɪkt əɹ lɪps. ʃi hoʊp hɑɹɪn hæd nɑt sin əɹ dʒɝk. "aɪ ɹəfjuzd əɹ bɪfɔɹ, weɪvməstʃɹəs." ʃi hæd niɾəd səm ɛkspləneɪʃən ʌv waɪ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ hæd hɛld əɹ fəɹ ə wik, ən ə vɝʒən ə ðə tʃɹuθ hæd sim seɪfəst. hɑɹɪn nu ɛvɹiθɪŋ. ɪksɛp ðə sikɹət vɛɹɪn hæd wɪŋkəld aʊt. ɪksɛp ðət ʃələn hæɾ əɡɹid tə kædzueɪnz dɪmænz ɪn ɔɹɾɝ tə haɪd ðət sikɹət. ðə ɡɹeɪs ə ðə laɪt bi əpɑn hɝ, ʃi ɹɪɡɹɛɾɪd eɪlɪl, bʌt ʃi hæd bɪn soʊ loʊnli ðət ʃi seɪl tu fɑɹ bɪfɔɹ ʃi nu ɪt. wɪð hɑɹɪn, ðəɹ wɝ noʊ ivnɪŋ tɔks oʊvɝ hʌnid waɪn tə sɑfən ðə lɔŋ mʌnθs pɑɹɾəd fɹəm əɹ hʌzbən mɪʃl. ət bɛst, mɛni mɔɹ mʌnθs wəd pæs bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəd laɪ ɪn ɪz ɑɹmz. "wɪð ɹɪspɛkt, waɪ ʃəd ʃi bɪliv mi naʊ?"

Shalon licked her lips. She hoped Harine had not seen her jerk. "I refused her before, Wavemistress." She had needed some explanation of why the Aes Sedai had held her for a week, and a version of the truth had seemed safest. Harine knew everything. Except the secret Verin had winkled out. Except that Shalon had agreed to Cadsuane's demands in order to hide that secret. The Grace of the Light be upon her, she regretted Ailil, but she had been so lonely that she sailed too far before she knew it. With Harine, there were no evening talks over honeyed wine to soften the long months parted from her husband Mishael. At best, many more months would pass before she could lie in his arms. "With respect, why should she believe me now?"

"bɪkɔz jə wɑn ðə lɝnɪŋ." hɑɹɪn tʃɑp ði ɛɹ wɪð wʌn hænd. "ðə ʃɔɹbaʊn ɔlweɪz bɪliv ɡɹid. jəl əv tə tɛl səm θɪŋz, ʌv kɔɹs, tə pɹuv jɝsɛlf. əl dɪsaɪd wʌɾ itʃ deɪ. pɝhæps aɪ kən stɪɹ əɹ wɛɹ aɪ wɪʃ."

"Because you want the learning." Harine chopped the air with one hand. "The shorebound always believe greed. You will have to tell some things, of course, to prove yourself. I will decide what each day. Perhaps I can steer her where I wish."

hɑɹd fɪŋɡɝz sim tə dɪɡ ɪndə ʃələnz skælp. ʃi hæɾ ɪntɛndəd tə tɛl kædzueɪn əz lɪɾəl əz ʃi kəd ɡɛt baɪ wɪð, ən əz sɛldəm, əntɪl ʃi faʊn ə weɪ fɹi ʌv hɝ. ɪf ʃi hæd tə tɔk wɪð ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɛvɹi deɪ, ən wɝs, laɪ tə hɝ aʊtʃɹaɪt, ðə wʊmən wəd pɹaɪ aʊt mɔɹ ðən ʃələn wɑntəd. mɔɹ ðən hɑɹɪn wɑntəd. mʌtʃ mɔɹ. ɪt wɑz əz sɝɾən əz sʌnɹaɪz. "fɝɡɪv mi, weɪvməstʃɹəs," ʃi sɛd wɪð ɛvɹi aʊns ə dɛfɝəns ʃi kəd faɪnd, "bʌɾ ɪf aɪ meɪ bi əlaʊd tə seɪ soʊ - "

Hard fingers seemed to dig into Shalon's scalp. She had intended to tell Cadsuane as little as she could get by with, and as seldom, until she found a way free of her. If she had to talk with the Aes Sedai every day, and worse, lie to her outright, the woman would pry out more than Shalon wanted. More than Harine wanted. Much more. It was as certain as sunrise. "Forgive me, Wavemistress," she said with every ounce of deference she could find, "but if I may be allowed to say so - "

ʃi kʌɾ ɔf əz sɝin nɛmdɑl ɹoʊɾ ʌp ən ɹeɪn tə ə hɔl bɪfɔɹ ðɛm. ðə læst ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ən wɔɹɾɝz hæd kʌm θɹu, ən kædzueɪn hæd lɛt ðə ɡeɪtweɪ vænɪʃ. kɔɹəl, ə θɪn wʊmən ɪf pɹɪɾi, wɑz læfɪŋ ən tɔsɪŋ əɹ meɪn ə blæk hɛɹ əz ʃi spoʊk tə kʌmaɪɹə. mɛɹaɪs, ə tɔl wʊmən wɪð aɪz blɝ ðən kʌmaɪɹəz ən ə mɔɹ ðən hænsəm feɪs ðət wɑz stɝn ɪnʌf tə ɡɪv ivən hɑɹɪn pɔz, wɑz juzɪŋ ʃɑɹp dʒɛstʃɝz tə dɝɛk ðə fɔɹ mɛn liɾɪŋ pækhɔɹsɪz. ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls wɑz ɡæðɝɪŋ ɹeɪnz. ɪt sim ðeɪ wɝ ɔl ɡɛɾɪŋ ɹɛɾi tə liv ðə klɪɹɪŋ.

She cut off as Sarene Nemdahl rode up and reined to a halt before them. The last of the Aes Sedai and Warders had come through, and Cadsuane had let the gateway vanish. Corele, a thin woman if pretty, was laughing and tossing her mane of black hair as she spoke to Kumira. Merise, a tall woman with eyes bluer than Kumira's and a more than handsome face that was stern enough to give even Harine pause, was using sharp gestures to direct the four men leading packhorses. Everyone else was gathering reins. It seemed they were all getting ready to leave the clearing.

sɝin wɑz lʌvli, ðoʊ ði æbsəns ə dʒuəlɹi lɛsən əɹ lʊks, ʌv kɔɹs, əz dɪd ðə pleɪn waɪt dʒɹɛs ʃi wɔɹ. ðə ʃɔɹbaʊn sim tə hæv noʊ dʒɔɪ ʌv kʌlɝ əɾ ɔl. ivən əɹ dɑɹk kloʊk wɑz laɪnd wɪð waɪt fɝ. "kædzueɪn, ʃiz æskt . . . ɪnstʃɹʌktəd . . . mi tə bi jəɹ ətɛndənt, weɪvməstʃɹəs," ʃi sɛd, ɪnklaɪnɪŋ əɹ hɛd ɹɪspɛkfəli. "aɪ wɪl ænsɝ jəɹ kwɛstʃənz, tə ði ɪkstɛn ðəɾ aɪ kæn, ən hɛlp jə wɪð ðə kʌstəmz, əz wɛl əz aɪ noʊ ðɛm. aɪ ɹilaɪz jə maɪt fil dɪskʌmfɝɾ ət biɪŋ wɪð mi, bʌt wən kædzueɪn kəmænz, wi mʌst oʊbeɪ."

Sarene was lovely, though the absence of jewelry lessened her looks, of course, as did the plain white dress she wore. The shorebound seemed to have no joy of color at all. Even her dark cloak was lined with white fur. "Cadsuane, she has asked . . . instructed . . . me to be your attendant, Wavemistress," she said, inclining her head respectfully. "I will answer your questions, to the extent that I can, and help you with the customs, as well as I know them. I realize you might feel discomfort at being with me, but when Cadsuane commands, we must obey."

ʃələn smaɪld. ʃi daʊɾɪd ði ɛɛs sədaɪ nu ðəɾ ɪn ðə ʃɪps, ən ətɛndənt wɑz wʌt ðə ʃɔɹbaʊnd wəd kɔl ə sɝvənt. hɑɹɪn wəd pɹɑbli læf ən dɪmæn tə noʊ wɛðɝ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ kəd klin lɪnənz pɹɑpɝli. ɪt wəd bi ɡʊd tə hæv əɹ ɪn ə ɡʊd mud.

Shalon smiled. She doubted the Aes Sedai knew that in the ships, an attendant was what the shorebound would call a servant. Harine would probably laugh and demand to know whether the Aes Sedai could clean linens properly. It would be good to have her in a good mood.

ɹæðɝ ðən læfɪŋ, ðoʊ, hɑɹɪn stɪfən ɪn əɹ sæɾəl əz ðoʊ hɝ bækboʊn hæd bɪkʌm ə meɪnməst, ən əɹ aɪz pɑpt. "aɪ fil noʊ dɪskʌmfɝt!" ʃi snæpt. "aɪ sɪmpli pɹəfɝ tə . . . tə pʊɾ ɛni kwɛstʃənz tə sʌmwʌn ɛls . . . tə kædzueɪn. jɛs. tə kædzueɪn. ən aɪ sɝɾənli də nɑɾ əv tə oʊbeɪ hɝ əɹ ɛniwʌn! nɑɾ ɛniwʌn! ɪksɛp ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps!" ʃələn fɹaʊnd; ɪt wɑz ənlaɪk əɹ sɪstɝ tə saʊn skæɾɝ-wɪtɪd. dʒɹɔɪŋ ə dip bɹɛθ, hɑɹɪn kəntɪnjuɾ ɪn ə fɝmɝ toʊn, ðoʊ ɪn ə weɪ, dʒʌst əz ɑdli əz bɪfɔɹ. "aɪ spik fəɹ ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps tə ði æθɑn maɪɹ, ən aɪ dɪmæn du ɹɪspɛkt! aɪ dɪmæn ɪt, dʒju hɪɹ mi? də ju?"

Rather than laughing, though, Harine stiffened in her saddle as though her backbone had become a mainmast, and her eyes popped. "I feel no discomfort!" she snapped. "I simply prefer to . . . to put any questions to someone else . . . to Cadsuane. Yes. To Cadsuane. And I certainly do not have to obey her or anyone! Not anyone! Except the Mistress of the Ships!" Shalon frowned; it was unlike her sister to sound scatter-witted. Drawing a deep breath, Harine continued in a firmer tone, though in a way, just as oddly as before. "I speak for the Mistress of the Ships to the Atha'an Miere, and I demand due respect! I demand it, do you hear me? Do you?"

"aɪ kən æsk əɹ tə neɪm sʌmwʌn ɛls," sɝin sɛd daʊtfəli, əz ɪf ʃi dɪd nɑɾ ɪkspɛkt əɹ æskɪŋ wəd tʃeɪnʒ ɛniθɪŋ. "ju mʌst ʌndɝstæn ðət ʃi ɡeɪv mi kwaɪt spəsɪfɪk ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz ðət deɪ. bʌɾ aɪ ʃəd nɑɾ əv lɔs maɪ tɛmpɝ. ðəɾ ɪz ə feɪlɪŋ ə maɪn. tɛmpɝ dɪstʃɹɔɪz lɑdʒɪk."

"I can ask her to name someone else," Sarene said doubtfully, as if she did not expect her asking would change anything. "You must understand that she gave me quite specific instructions that day. But I should not have lost my temper. That is a failing of mine. Temper destroys logic."

"aɪ ʌndɝstæn oʊbeɪɪŋ ɔɹɾɝz," hɑɹɪn ɡɹaʊld, kɹaʊtʃɪŋ ɪn ðə sæɾəl. ʃi lʊkt ɹɛɾi tə lɔntʃ hɝsɛlf ət sɝinz θɹoʊt. "aɪ əpɹuv ʌv oʊbeɪɪŋ ɔɹɾɝz!" ʃi vɛɹi nɪɹli snɑɹəld. "haʊɛvɝ, ɔɹɾɝz ðəɾ əv bɪn kæɹiɾ aʊt kən bi fɝɡɑɾən. ðeɪ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ nid bi spoʊkən ʌv. dʒju ʌndɝstæn mi?" ʃələn stɛɹd saɪdweɪz ət hɝ. wʌt wɑz ʃi tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt? wʌɾ ɔɹɾɝz hæd sɝin kæɹiɾ aʊt, ən waɪ dɪd hɑɹɪn wɑn əm fɝɡɑɾən? moʊd meɪd noʊ pɹiɾəns ə haɪɾɪŋ ɪz ɹeɪzd aɪbɹaʊz. hɑɹɪn wɑz əwɛɹ ə hɪz skɹuɾəni, ət list, ən əɹ feɪs bɪkeɪm ə θʌndɝhɛd.

"I understand obeying orders," Harine growled, crouching in the saddle. She looked ready to launch herself at Sarene's throat. "I approve of obeying orders!" she very nearly snarled. "However, orders that have been carried out can be forgotten. They no longer need be spoken of. Do you understand me?" Shalon stared sideways at her. What was she talking about? What orders had Sarene carried out, and why did Harine want them forgotten? Moad made no pretence of hiding his raised eyebrows. Harine was aware of his scrutiny, at least, and her face became a thunderhead.

sɝin sim nɑt tə noʊɾəs. "aɪ də nɑt si haʊ wʌn kən dɪlɪbɝətli fɝɡɛt," ʃi sɛd sloʊli, ə smɔl fɹaʊn kɹisɪŋ əɹ fɔɹhɛd, "bʌɾ aɪ səpoʊz jə min ðət wi ʃəd pɹitɛn tə. ɪz ðəɾ ɪt?" ðə biɾɪd bɹeɪdz dæŋɡəlɪŋ fɹəm əɹ kaʊl klɪk təɡɛðɝ əz ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛɾ ət ðɪs fulɪʃnəs. "vɛɹi wɛl. əl ænsɝ jəɹ kwɛstʃənz əz wɛl əz aɪ kæn. wʌt dʒju wɪʃ tə noʊ?" hɑɹɪn saɪd laʊdli. ʃələn maɪɾ əv teɪkən ɪt fəɹ ɪmpeɪʃəns, bʌt ʃi θɔɾ ɪt wɑz ɹɪlif. ɹɪlif!

Sarene seemed not to notice. "I do not see how one can deliberately forget," she said slowly, a small frown creasing her forehead, "but I suppose you mean that we should pretend to. Is that it?" The beaded braids dangling from her cowl clicked together as she shook her head at this foolishness. "Very well. I will answer your questions as well as I can. What do you wish to know?" Harine sighed loudly. Shalon might have taken it for impatience, but she thought it was relief. Relief!

ɹɪlivd əɹ nɑt, hɑɹɪn bɪkeɪm əɹ nɔɹməl sɛlf əɡɛn, sɛlf-pəzɛst ən kəmændɪŋ, miɾɪŋ ði ɛɛs sədaɪz ɡeɪz əz ðoʊ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə meɪk əɹ dʒɹɑp əɹ aɪz. "ju kən tɛl mi wɛɹ wəɹ ən wɛɹ wəɹ ɡoʊɪŋ," ʃi dɪmændəd.

Relieved or not, Harine became her normal self again, self-possessed and commanding, meeting the Aes Sedai's gaze as though trying to make her drop her eyes. "You can tell me where we are and where we are going," she demanded.

"wi ɑɹ ɪn ðə hɪlz ə kintɑɹə," kædzueɪn sɛd, əpɪɹɪŋ bɪfɔɹ əm sʌɾənli, hɝ maʊn ɹɪɹɪŋ ən pɔɪŋ ði ɛɹ, flɪŋɪŋ snoʊ, "ænd wəɹ ɡoʊɪŋ tə fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ." nɑɾ oʊnli dɪd ʃi steɪ ɪn ðə sæɾəl, ʃi dɪd nɑɾ ivən sim tə noʊɾəs ði ænəməlz hivɪŋ!

"We are in the Hills of Kintara," Cadsuane said, appearing before them suddenly, her mount rearing and pawing the air, flinging snow, "and we are going to Far Madding." Not only did she stay in the saddle, she did not even seem to notice the animal's heaving!

"ɪz ðə kɔɹəmʊɹ ɪn ðɪs fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ?"

"Is the Coramoor in this Far Madding?"

"peɪʃəns ɪz ə vɝtʃu, aɪm toʊld, weɪvməstʃɹəs." dɪspaɪt kædzueɪnz jus ə hɑɹɪnz pɹɑpɝ taɪɾəl, ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɹɪspɛkt ɪn əɹ mænɝ. fɑɹ fɹəm ɪt. "ju wɪl ɹaɪd wɪð mi. kip ʌp ən tʃɹaɪ nɑt tə fɔl ɔf. ɪt wəd bi ənplɛzənt, ɪf aɪ hæd tə hæv jə kæɹid laɪk sæks ʌv ɡɹeɪn. wʌns wi ɹitʃ ðə sɪɾi, kip saɪlən ənlɛs aɪ tɛl jə tə spik. aɪ woʊn əv jə kɹieɪɾɪŋ pɹɑbləmz θɹu ɪɡnɝəns. jəl lɛt sɝin ɡaɪd ju. ʃiz əɹ ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz."

"Patience is a virtue, I am told, Wavemistress." Despite Cadsuane's use of Harine's proper title, there was no respect in her manner. Far from it. "You will ride with me. Keep up and try not to fall off. It would be unpleasant, if I had to have you carried like sacks of grain. Once we reach the city, keep silent unless I tell you to speak. I won't have you creating problems through ignorance. You will let Sarene guide you. She has her instructions."

ʃələn ɪkspɛktəɾ ən aʊtbɝst ə ɹeɪdʒ, bʌt hɑɹɪn hɛld əɹ tʌŋ, ðoʊ wɪð ɑbviəs ɛfɝt. wʌns kædzueɪn tɝn əweɪ, hɑɹɪn dɪd mʌɾɝ æŋɡɹəli ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛθ, bʌt ʃi klæmpt əɹ tiθ taɪt wən sɝinz hɔɹs muvd. pleɪnli, hɝ mʌɾɝz wɝ nɑt tə bi oʊvɝhɝd baɪ ɛɛs sədaɪ.

Shalon expected an outburst of rage, but Harine held her tongue, though with obvious effort. Once Cadsuane turned away, Harine did mutter angrily under her breath, but she clamped her teeth tight when Sarene's horse moved. Plainly, her mutters were not to be overheard by Aes Sedai.

ɹaɪɾɪŋ wɪð kædzueɪn, ɪt tɝn aʊt, mɛn ɹaɪɾɪŋ bɪhaɪn hɝ, saʊθwɝd θɹu ðə tʃɹiz. ɑlɑnə ən vɛɹɪn æktʃəli  ɹoʊd bɪsaɪd ðə wʊmən, bʌt wʌn lʊk fɹəm əɹ wən hɑɹɪn ətɛmptəd tə dʒɔɪn əm meɪd klɪɹ ðət noʊ wʌn ɛls wɑz wɛlkəm. wʌns əɡɛn ði ɪkspɛktəɾ ɪksploʊʒən dɪd nɑt kʌm. ɪnstɛd, hɑɹɪn fɹaʊn ət sɝin fəɹ səm ɹizən, ðən dʒɝkt əɹ maʊn ɝaʊn tə teɪk pəzɪʃən bɪtwin ʃələn ən moʊd. ʃi dɪd nɑt bɑðɝ æskɪŋ ɛni fɝðɝ kwɛstʃənz ə sɝin, ɑn ʃələnz ʌðɝ saɪd, oʊnli ɡlaʊɝɾ ət ðə bæks ə ðə wɪmən əhɛd. ɪf ʃələn hæd nɑt noʊn hɑɹɪn bɛɾɝ, wʊɾə əv sɛd ðəɹ wɑz mɔɹ sʌlk ðən æŋɡɝ ɪn ðət ɡlɛɹ.

Riding with Cadsuane, it turned out, meant riding behind her, southward through the trees. Alanna and Verin actually rode beside the woman, but one look from her when Harine attempted to join them made clear that no one else was welcome. Once again the expected explosion did not come. Instead, Harine frowned at Sarene for some reason, then jerked her mount around to take position between Shalon and Moad. She did not bother asking any further questions of Sarene, on Shalon's other side, only glowered at the backs of the women ahead. If Shalon had not known Harine better, she would have said there was more sulk than anger in that glare.

fəɹ əɹ pɑɹt, ʃələn wɑz ɡlæd tə ɹaɪɾ ɪn saɪləns. ɹaɪɾɪŋ ə hɔɹs wɑz dɪfəkəlt ɪnʌf wɪθaʊt hævɪŋ tə tɔk ət ðə seɪm taɪm. bɪsaɪdz, ʃi sʌɾənli nu waɪ hɑɹɪn wɑz bɪheɪvɪŋ ɪn sətʃ ə pəkjuljɝ fæʃən. hɑɹɪn mʌs bi tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə smuð ðə wɔɾɝz wɪð ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. ɪt hæd tə bi ðæt. hɑɹɪn nɛvɝ kəntʃɹoʊld əɹ tɛmpɝ wɪθaʊt ɡɹeɪt nid. ðə stʃɹeɪn ə kəntʃɹoʊlɪŋ ɪt naʊ mʌst əv əɹ bɔɪlɪŋ ɪnsaɪd. ən ɪf əɹ ɛfɝts dɪd nɑɾ ɛn əz ʃi wɑntəd, ʃi wəd bɔɪl ʃələn. θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt ðət meɪd ʃələnz hɛɾ eɪk. ðə laɪt hɛlp ən ɡaɪd hɝ, ðəɹ hæd tə bi ə weɪ tə əvɔɪd spaɪɪŋ ɑn əɹ sɪstɝ wɪθaʊt faɪndɪŋ əɹ tʃik-tʃeɪn stʃɹɪpt ʌv ɑnɝz ən hɝsɛlf əsaɪn tə ə skaʊ ʌndɝ ə seɪlməstʃɹəs bɹuɾɪŋ oʊvɝ waɪ ʃi hæd nɛvɝ ɹɪzən haɪɝ ən ɹɛɾi tə teɪk aʊɾ əɹ ɡɹivənsəz ɑn ɛvɹiwʌn ɝaʊn hɝ. ikwəli əz bæd, mɪʃl maɪt dɪklɛɹ ðɛɹ mɛɹɪdʒ vaʊz bɹoʊkən. ðəɹ dʒʌs hæd tə bi ə weɪ.

For her part, Shalon was glad to ride in silence. Riding a horse was difficult enough without having to talk at the same time. Besides, she suddenly knew why Harine was behaving in such a peculiar fashion. Harine must be trying to smooth the waters with the Aes Sedai. It had to be that. Harine never controlled her temper without great need. The strain of controlling it now must have her boiling inside. And if her efforts did not end as she wanted, she would boil Shalon. Thinking about that made Shalon's head ache. The Light help and guide her, there had to be a way to avoid spying on her sister without finding her cheek-chain stripped of honors and herself assigned to a scow under a Sailmistress brooding over why she had never risen higher and ready to take out her grievances on everyone around her. Equally as bad, Mishael might declare their marriage vows broken. There just had to be a way.

səmtaɪmz ʃi twɪstəɾ ɝaʊn ɪn əɹ sæɾəl tə lʊk ət ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɹaɪɾɪŋ bɪhaɪn hɝ. ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ tə lɝn fɹəm ðə wɪmən ɪn fɹʌnt, sɝɾənli. ɛvɹi soʊ ɔfən kædzueɪn ən vɛɹɪn ɪkstʃeɪnʒd wɝdz, bʌt linɪŋ kloʊs tə wʌn ənʌðɝ ən spikɪŋ tu sɔfli tə bi oʊvɝhɝd. ɑlɑnə əpɪɹɾ ɪntɛn ɑn wʌtɛvɝ leɪ əhɛd, hɝ aɪz ɔlweɪz lʊkɪŋ saʊθ. tu əɹ θɹi taɪmz ʃi kwɪkən əɹ hɔɹsəz peɪs fəɹ ə fju stɛps bɪfɔɹ kædzueɪn bɹɔɾ əɹ bæk wɪð ə kwaɪət wɝd ðəɾ ɑlɑnə oʊbeɪd ɹɪlʌktənli, wɪð hɑt-aɪd stɛɹ əɹ sʌlən ɡɹɪmɑs. kædzueɪn ən vɛɹɪn əpɪɹd səlɪsəɾəs ə ðə wʊmən, kædzueɪn pæɾɪŋ əɹ ɑɹm ɪn ɔlmoʊs ðə weɪ ʃələn pæɾəd əɹ maʊns nɛk ən vɛɹɪn bimɪŋ ət hɝ, əz ðoʊ ɑlɑnə wɝ ɹəkʌvɝɪŋ fɹəm ən ɪlnəs. wɪtʃ toʊld ʃələn nʌθɪŋ. soʊ ʃi θɔɾ əbaʊt ði ʌðɝz.

Sometimes she twisted around in her saddle to look at the Aes Sedai riding behind her. There was nothing to learn from the women in front, certainly. Every so often Cadsuane and Verin exchanged words, but leaning close to one another and speaking too softly to be overheard. Alanna appeared intent on whatever lay ahead, her eyes always looking south. Two or three times she quickened her horse's pace for a few steps before Cadsuane brought her back with a quiet word that Alanna obeyed reluctantly, with hot-eyed stare or sullen grimace. Cadsuane and Verin appeared solicitous of the woman, Cadsuane patting her arm in almost the way Shalon patted her mount's neck and Verin beaming at her, as though Alanna were recovering from an illness. Which told Shalon nothing. So she thought about the others.

jə dɪd nɑt ɹaɪz ɪn ðə ʃɪps dʒʌs θɹu jəɹ əbɪləɾi tə wiv ðə wɪnz əɹ pɹɪdɪk ðə wɛðɝ əɹ fɪks ə pəzɪʃən. jə niɾəd tə ɹid ði ɪntɛn ðət leɪ bɪtwin ðə wɝdz ə jəɹ ɔɹɾɝz, tə ɪntɝpɹət smɔl dʒɛstʃɝz ən feɪʃəl ɪkspɹɛʃənz; jə hæd tə noʊɾəs u dɪfɝd tə hum, ivən sʌɾəli, fəɹ kɝədʒ ən əbɪləɾi əloʊn tʊk jə oʊnli soʊ haɪ.

You did not rise in the ships just through your ability to Weave the Winds or predict the weather or fix a position. You needed to read the intent that lay between the words of your orders, to interpret small gestures and facial expressions; you had to notice who deferred to whom, even subtly, for courage and ability alone took you only so high.

fɔɹ ə ðɛm, nɛsun ən ɛɹiən, bɛldaɪn ən ɛlzə, ɹoʊɾ ɪn ə klʌstɝ nɑt fɑɹ bɪhaɪn hɝ, ðoʊ ðeɪ wɝ nɑt ɹɪli təɡɛðɝ, oʊnli ɑkjəpaɪɪŋ ðə seɪm speɪs. ðeɪ dɪd nɑt tɔk əmʌŋ ðɛmsɛlvz, əɹ lʊk ət wʌn ənʌðɝ. ðeɪ dɪd nɑt sim tə laɪk wʌn ənʌðɝ vɛɹi mʌtʃ. ɪn əɹ maɪnd, ʃələn hæɾ əm ɪn ðə seɪm boʊt wɪð sɝin. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ pɹitɛndəd ðət ðeɪ wɝ ɔl wʌn ʌndɝ kædzueɪn, jɛt ðət wɑz pleɪnli əntʃɹu. mɛɹaɪs, kɔɹəl, kʌmaɪɹə ən deɪdʒiən kɹuɾ ənʌðɝ boʊt, kəmændəd baɪ kædzueɪn. səmtaɪmz ɑlɑnə simd ɪn wʌn boʊt, səmtaɪmz ði ʌðɝ, waɪl vɛɹɪn əpɪɹd tə bi ɪn səm weɪ ʌv kædzueɪnz boʊt bʌt nɑɾ ɪn ɪt. swɪmɪŋ əlɔŋsaɪd, pɝhæps, wɪð kædzueɪn hoʊldɪŋ əɹ hænd. ɪf ðət wɑz nɑt stʃɹeɪnʒ ɪnʌf, ðəɹ wɑz ðə mæɾɝ ə dɛfɝəns.

Four of them, Nesune and Erian, Beldeine and Elza, rode in a cluster not far behind her, though they were not really together, only occupying the same space. They did not talk among themselves, or look at one another. They did not seem to like one another very much. In her mind, Shalon had them in the same boat with Sarene. The Aes Sedai pretended that they were all one under Cadsuane, yet that was plainly untrue. Merise, Corele, Kumira and Daigian crewed another boat, commanded by Cadsuane. Sometimes Alanna seemed in one boat, sometimes the other, while Verin appeared to be in some way of Cadsuane's boat but not in it. Swimming alongside, perhaps, with Cadsuane holding her hand. If that was not strange enough, there was the matter of deference.

ɑdli, ɪt sim ðəɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ væljud stʃɹɛŋkθ ɪn ðə paʊɝ əbʌv ɪkspɪɹiəns əɹ skɪl. ðeɪ ɹæŋk ðɛmsɛlvz baɪ stʃɹɛŋkθ, laɪk dɛkmən skwɑbəlɪŋ ɪn ʃɔɹɪzaɪd tævɝnz. ɔl dɪfɝd tə kædzueɪn, ʌv kɔɹs, jɛt ðəɹ wɝ ɑɾətiz əmʌŋ ðə ɹɛst. baɪ ðɛɹ oʊn haɪɝɑɹki, səm ɪn nɛsunz boʊt wɝ ɪn ə pəzɪʃən tə ɪkspɛk dɛfɝəns fɹəm səm ɪn kædzueɪnz, bʌɾ ɔlðoʊ ðoʊz ɪn kædzueɪnz boʊɾ u ʃəd dɪfɝ dɪd soʊ, ðeɪ dɪd soʊ əz ðoʊ tə ə supɪɹiɝ u hæd kəmɪɾəd ə ɡɹivəs kɹaɪm noʊn tə ɔl. baɪ ðət haɪɝɑɹki, nɛsun stʊd haɪɝ ðən ɛni seɪv kædzueɪn ən mɛɹaɪs, jɛt ʃi feɪs deɪdʒiən, hu stʊɾ ət ðə vɛɹi bɑɾəm, əz ɪf wɪlfəli dɪfaɪən oʊvɝ kəmɪɾɪŋ ðət kɹaɪm, ən soʊ dɪd ði ʌðɝz ɪn əɹ boʊt. ɪt wɑz ɔl vɛɹi dɪskɹit, ə slaɪtli lɪftəd tʃɪn, ə smɔl ɑɹtʃ ə ði aɪbɹaʊ, ə twɪst ə ðə lɪps, bʌɾ ɑbviəs tə ən aɪ tʃɹeɪn klaɪmɪŋ ɪn ðə ʃɪps. pɝhæps ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ ɪn ɪt ðət wəd hɛlp hɝ, bʌɾ ɪf ʃi hæd tə pɪk oʊkəm, ði oʊnli weɪ wɑz tə faɪn ə θɹɛɾ ən pʊl.

Oddly, it seemed that Aes Sedai valued strength in the Power above experience or skill. They ranked themselves by strength, like deckmen squabbling in shoreside taverns. All deferred to Cadsuane, of course, yet there were oddities among the rest. By their own hierarchy, some in Nesune's boat were in a position to expect deference from some in Cadsuane's, but although those in Cadsuane's boat who should defer did so, they did so as though to a superior who had committed a grievous crime known to all. By that hierarchy, Nesune stood higher than any save Cadsuane and Merise, yet she faced Daigian, who stood at the very bottom, as if willfully defiant over committing that crime, and so did the others in her boat. It was all very discreet, a slightly lifted chin, a small arch of the eyebrow, a twist of the lips, but obvious to an eye trained climbing in the ships. Perhaps there was nothing in it that would help her, but if she had to pick oakum, the only way was to find a thread and pull.

ðə wɪn bɪɡæn tə pɪk ʌp; ɡʌsts flæɾənd əɹ kloʊk əɡɛnst əɹ bæk ən meɪɾ ɪt flæp ɑn iðɝ saɪɾ əhɛɾ ə hɝ. ʃi wɑz hɑɹdli əwɛɹ ʌv ɪt.

The wind began to pick up; gusts flattened her cloak against her back and made it flap on either side ahead of her. She was hardly aware of it.

ðə wɔɹɾɝz maɪt bi ənʌðɝ θɹɛd. ðeɪ wɝ ɔl ət ðə vɛɹi ɹɪɹ, hɪɾən baɪ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɹaɪɾɪŋ bɪhaɪnd nɛsun ən ði ʌðɝ θɹi. ɪn tʃɹuθ, ʃələn hæɾ ɪkspɛktəd ðəɾ əmʌŋ twɛlv ɛɛs sədaɪ, ðəɹ wəd bi mɔɹ ðən sɛvən wɔɹɾɝz. ɛvɹi ɛɛs sədaɪ wɑz səpoʊz tə hæv wʌn, ɪf nɑt mɔɹ. ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛɾ ɪɹɪɾəbli. ɪksɛp ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ, ʌv kɔɹs. ʃi wɑz nɑɾ ɪntaɪɝli ɪɡnɝən ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ.

The Warders might be another thread. They were all at the very rear, hidden by the Aes Sedai riding behind Nesune and the other three. In truth, Shalon had expected that among twelve Aes Sedai, there would be more than seven Warders. Every Aes Sedai was supposed to have one, if not more. She shook her head irritably. Except the Red Ajah, of course. She was not entirely ignorant of Aes Sedai.

ɛniweɪ, ðə kwɛstʃən wɑz nɑt haʊ mɛni wɔɹɾɝz, bʌt wɛðɝ ðeɪ ɔl wɝ wɔɹɾɝz. ʃi wɑz sɝɾən ʃi hæd sin ɡɹɪzəld oʊl deɪmɝ ən ðə soʊ-pɹɪɾi dʒɑhɹ ɪn blæk koʊts, tu, bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ sʌɾənli tʊk ʌp wɪð ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. ət ðə taɪm, ʃi hæd bɪn ənwɪlɪŋ tə lʊk tu kloʊsli ət ðə blækoʊts, ən ɪn tʃɹuθ, ʃi hæd bɪn hæf-blaɪnd wɪð ðə deɪnti eɪlɪl əz wɛl, bʌt ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ. ən wʌtɛvɝ ðə keɪs wɪð ɛbən, ʃi wɑz ɔlmoʊst sɝɾən ði ʌðɝ tu wɝ wɔɹɾɝz, naʊ. ɔlmoʊst. dʒɑhɹ dʒʌmpt əz fæst əz nɛθən əɹ bæsɑn wən mɛɹaɪs pɔɪntəd, ən fɹəm ðə weɪ kɔɹəl smaɪld ət deɪmɝ, hi wɑz iðɝ əɹ wɔɹɾɝ əɹ əɹ bɛdwɹmɝ, ən ʃələn kəd nɑɾ ɪmædʒən ə wʊmən laɪk kɔɹəl teɪkɪŋ ə nɪɹli bɔld oʊl mæn wɪð ə lɪmp ɪndə hɝ bɛd. ʃi maɪt noʊ lɪɾəl əbaʊɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ, bʌt ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ bɑndɪŋ mɛn u kəd tʃænəl wɑz nɑɾ ən æksɛptɪd pɹæktəs. ɪf ʃi kəd pɹuv ðeɪ hæd dʌn soʊ, pɝhæps ðət wɑz ə naɪf ʃɑɹp ɪnʌf tə kʌt hɝsɛlf fɹi fɹəm kædzueɪn.

Anyway, the question was not how many Warders, but whether they all were Warders. She was certain she had seen grizzled old Damer and the so-pretty Jahar in black coats, too, before they suddenly took up with the Aes Sedai. At the time, she had been unwilling to look too closely at the blackcoats, and in truth, she had been half-blind with the dainty Ailil as well, but she was sure. And whatever the case with Eben, she was almost certain the other two were Warders, now. Almost. Jahar jumped as fast as Nethan or Bassane when Merise pointed, and from the way Corele smiled at Damer, he was either her Warder or her bedwarmer, and Shalon could not imagine a woman like Corele taking a nearly bald old man with a limp into her bed. She might know little about Aes Sedai, but she was sure bonding men who could channel was not an accepted practice. If she could prove they had done so, perhaps that was a knife sharp enough to cut herself free from Cadsuane.

"ðə mɛn, ðeɪ kən noʊ lɔŋɡɝ tʃænəl naʊ," sɝin mɝmɝd.

"The men, they can no longer channel now," Sarene murmured.

ʃələn stʃɹeɪɾənd hɝsɛlf ɝaʊn ɪn ðə sæɾəl soʊ kwɪkli ðət ʃi hæd tə ɡɹæb əɹ hɔɹsəz meɪn wɪð boʊθ hænz tə kip fɹəm fɔlɪŋ ɔf. ðə wɪn blu hɝ kloʊk oʊvɝ əɹ hɛd, ən ʃi hæd tə faɪt ðət daʊn bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəd sɪɾ ʌp. ðeɪ wɝ kʌmɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə tʃɹiz əbʌv ə waɪd ɹoʊd ðət kɝv saʊθwɝɾ aʊɾ ə ðə hɪlz tə ə leɪk pɝhæps ə maɪl ɔf, ɑn ði ɛdʒ ə flæt læn kʌvɝd wɪð bɹaʊn ɡɹæs, ə si ʌv bɹaʊn stʃɹɛtʃɪŋ tə ðə hɝaɪzən. ðə leɪk, bɔɹɾɝd əlɔŋ ðə wɛst wɪð ə nɛɹoʊ wɑʃ ə ɹidz, wɑz ə pɪɾəfəl ɪkskjus fəɹ ə bɑɾi ʌv wɔɾɝ, noʊ mɔɹ ðən tɛn maɪlz lɔŋ ət moʊst ən lɛs ðən ðət waɪd. ə fɛɹ-saɪzd aɪlən kɹaʊtʃt ɪn ðə mɪɾəl, sɝaʊndəd baɪ haɪ, taʊɝ-stʌɾɪd wɔlz əz fɑɹ əz ʃi kəd si, ən kʌvɝd baɪ ə sɪɾi. ʃi tʊk ɔl ðəɾ ɪn əɾ ə ɡlæns, hɝ aɪz fæsənɪŋ ɑn sɝin. ɪt wɑz ɔlmoʊst əz ɪf ðə wʊmən hæd bɪn ɹiɾɪŋ əɹ maɪnd. "waɪ kən ðeɪ nɑt tʃænəl?" ʃi æskt. "dɪd jə . . . ? hæv jə . . . dʒɛntəld . . . ðɛm?" ʃi θɔt ðət wɑz ðə ɹaɪt wɝd, bʌt ðət wɑz səpoʊz tə kɪl ðə mæn. ʃi hæɾ ɔlweɪz səpoʊzd ɪt wɑz dʒʌst ən ɑd weɪ tə sɑfən ɛksəkjuʃən fəɹ səm ənnoʊn ɹizən.

Shalon straightened herself around in the saddle so quickly that she had to grab her horse's mane with both hands to keep from falling off. The wind blew her cloak over her head, and she had to fight that down before she could sit up. They were coming out of the trees above a wide road that curved southward out of the hills to a lake perhaps a mile off, on the edge of flat land covered with brown grass, a sea of brown stretching to the horizon. The lake, bordered along the west with a narrow wash of reeds, was a pitiful excuse for a body of water, no more than ten miles long at most and less than that wide. A fair-sized island crouched in the middle, surrounded by high, tower-studded walls as far as she could see, and covered by a city. She took all that in at a glance, her eyes fastening on Sarene. It was almost as if the woman had been reading her mind. "Why can they not channel?" she asked. "Did you . . . ? Have you . . . gentled . . . them?" She thought that was the right word, but that was supposed to kill the man. She had always supposed it was just an odd way to soften execution for some unknown reason.

sɝin blɪŋkt, ən ʃələn ɹilaɪz ði ɛɛs sədaɪ hæd bɪn spikɪŋ tə hɝsɛlf. fəɹ ə moʊmənt ʃi stʌɾid ʃələn əz ðeɪ fɑloʊd kædzueɪn daʊn ðə sloʊp, ðən tɝn əɹ ɡeɪz bæk tə ðə sɪɾi ɑn ði aɪlənd. "ju noʊɾəs θɪŋz, ʃələn. ɪt wəd bi bɛst ɪf jə kip wʌt juv noʊɾəst əbaʊt ðə mɛn tə jɝsɛlf."

Sarene blinked, and Shalon realized the Aes Sedai had been speaking to herself. For a moment she studied Shalon as they followed Cadsuane down the slope, then turned her gaze back to the city on the island. "You notice things, Shalon. It would be best if you keep what you have noticed about the men to yourself."

"sʌtʃ əz əm biɪŋ wɔɹɾɝz?" ʃələn sɛd kwaɪətli. "ɪz ðət waɪ jə kəd bɑn ðɛm? kəz jə dʒɛntəl ðɛm?" ʃi hoʊp tə dʒɑɹ səm ædmɪʃən lus, bʌt ði ɛɛs sədaɪ mɪɹli ɡlænst ət hɝ. ʃi dɪd nɑt spik əɡɛn əntɪl ðeɪ hæd ɹitʃt ðə bɑɾəm ə ðə hɪl ən tɝn ɑntu ðə ɹoʊd bɪhaɪn kædzueɪn. ðə ɹoʊd wɑz waɪd, ðə dɝt pæk hɑɹd baɪ mʌtʃ tʃɹæfɪk, bʌt ðeɪ hæɾ ɪt tə ðɛmsɛlvz.

"Such as them being Warders?" Shalon said quietly. "Is that why you could bond them? Because you gentled them?" She hoped to jar some admission loose, but the Aes Sedai merely glanced at her. She did not speak again until they had reached the bottom of the hill and turned onto the road behind Cadsuane. The road was wide, the dirt packed hard by much traffic, but they had it to themselves.

"ɪɾ ɪz nɑɾ ɪɡzækli ə sikɹət," sɝin sɛɾ ət læst, ən nɑt vɛɹi wɪlɪŋli fəɹ sʌmθɪŋ ðət wɑz nɑɾ ə sikɹət, "bʌt niðɝ ɪz ɪt wɛl noʊn. wi də nɑt spik ə fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ ɔfən, ɪksɛp fəɹ sɪstɝz bɔɹn ðɛɹ, ən ivən ðeɪ sɛldəm vɪzət. stɪl, jə ʃəd noʊ bɪfɔɹ jə ɛntɝ. ðə sɪɾi pəzɛsəz ə tɛɹæŋɡɹil. əɹ pɝhæps ɪts θɹi tɛɹæŋɡɹil. noʊ wʌn noʊz. ðeɪ - əɹ ɪt - kænɑt bi stʌɾid ɛni mɔɹ ðən ðeɪ kən bi ɹimuvd. ðeɪ mʌst əv bɪn meɪd dʊɹɪŋ ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ, wən fɪɹ ə mædmən tʃænəlɪŋ ðə paʊɝ wɑz ðə mæɾɝ ʌv ɛvɹi deɪ. bʌt tə peɪ sətʃ ə pɹaɪs fəɹ ðə seɪfti." ðə biɾɪd bɹeɪdz dæŋɡəlɪŋ ɑntu hɝ tʃɛst ɹæɾəld təɡɛðɝ əz ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛɾ ɪn dɪsbɪlif. "ðiz tɛɹæŋɡɹil, ðeɪ dupləkeɪɾ ə stɛɾɪŋ. ɪn ði ɪmpɔɹɾənt weɪz ət list, aɪ fɪɹ, ðoʊ aɪ səpoʊz ən oʊɡiɝ wəd nɑt θɪŋk soʊ." ʃi ɡeɪv ə doʊlfəl saɪ.

"It is not exactly a secret," Sarene said at last, and not very willingly for something that was not a secret, "but neither is it well known. We do not speak of Far Madding often, except for sisters born there, and even they seldom visit. Still, you should know before you enter. The city possesses a ter'angreal. Or perhaps it is three ter'angreal. No one knows. They - or it - cannot be studied any more than they can be removed. They must have been made during the Breaking, when fear of madmen channeling the Power was the matter of every day. But to pay such a price for the safety." The beaded braids dangling onto her chest rattled together as she shook her head in disbelief. "These ter'angreal, they duplicate a stedding. In the important ways at least, I fear, though I suppose an Ogier would not think so." She gave a doleful sigh.

ʃələn ɡeɪpt ət hɝ, ən ɪkstʃeɪnʒd kənfjuz lʊks wɪð hɑɹɪn ən moʊd. waɪ wəd feɪbəlz fɹaɪɾən ən ɛɛs sədaɪ? hɑɹɪn oʊpən əɹ maʊθ, ðən moʊʃən fəɹ ʃələn tə æsk ði ɑbviəs kwɛstʃən. pɝhæps ʃi wɑz tə meɪk fɹɛnz wɪð sɝin tə hɛlp smuð əɹ kɔɹs, tu? ʃələnz hɛd ɹɪli dɪɾ eɪk. bʌt ʃi wɑz kjʊɹiəs, tu.

Shalon gaped at her, and exchanged confused looks with Harine and Moad. Why would fables frighten an Aes Sedai? Harine opened her mouth, then motioned for Shalon to ask the obvious question. Perhaps she was to make friends with Sarene to help smooth her course, too? Shalon's head really did ache. But she was curious, too.

"wʌt weɪz ɑɹ ðoʊz?" ʃi æskt kɛɹfəli. dɪd ðə wʊmən ɹɪli bɪliv ɪn pipəl faɪv spænz tɔl u sæŋ tə tʃɹiz? ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊɾ æksiz, tu. hɪɹ kʌm ði æɛlfɪn tə stil ɔl jəɹ bɹɛd; hɪɹ kʌm ði oʊɡiɝ tə tʃɑp ɔf jəɹ hɛd. laɪt, ʃi hæd nɑt hɝd ðət sɪns hɑɹɪn wɑz stɪl ɪn liɾɪŋ stʃɹɪŋz. wɪð ðɛɹ mʌðɝ ɹaɪzɪŋ ɪn ðə ʃɪps, ʃi hæd bɪn tʃɑɹdʒd wɪð ɹeɪzɪŋ hɑɹɪn əlɔŋ wɪð əɹ oʊn fɝs tʃaɪld.

"What ways are those?" she asked carefully. Did the woman really believe in people five spans tall who sang to trees? There was something about axes, too. Here come the Aelfinn to steal all your bread; here come the Ogier to chop off your head. Light, she had not heard that since Harine was still in leading strings. With their mother rising in the ships, she had been charged with raising Harine along with her own first child.

sɝinz aɪz waɪɾənd ɪn sɝpɹaɪz. "ju tʃɹuli də nɑt noʊ?" hɝ ɡeɪz wɛn bæk tə ði aɪlən sɪɾi əhɛd. baɪ hɝ ɪkspɹɛʃən, ʃi wɑz əbaʊt tə ɛntɝ ðə bɪlʒz. "ɪnsaɪd ðə stɛɾɪŋ, jə kænɑt tʃænəl. jə kænɑɾ ivən fil ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs. noʊ wiv meɪɾ aʊtsaɪd kən əfɛkt wʌɾ ɪz ɪnsaɪd, nɑt ðət ðət mæɾɝz. ɪn tʃɹuθ, hɪɹ ðəɹ ɑɹ tu stɛɾɪŋ, wʌn wɪðɪn ði ʌðɝ. ðə lɑɹdʒɝ əfɛks mɛn, bʌt wɪl ɛntɝ ðə smɔlɝ bɪfɔɹ wi ɹitʃ ðə bɹɪdʒ."

Sarene's eyes widened in surprise. "You truly do not know?" Her gaze went back to the island city ahead. By her expression, she was about to enter the bilges. "Inside the stedding, you cannot channel. You cannot even feel the True Source. No weave made outside can affect what is inside, not that that matters. In truth, here there are two stedding, one within the other. The larger affects men, but we will enter the smaller before we reach the bridge."

"ju wɪl nɑt bi eɪbəl tə tʃænəl ɪn ðɛɹ?" hɑɹɪn sɛd. wən ði ɛɛs sədaɪ nɑɾəd wɪθaʊt lʊkɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm ðə sɪɾi, ə θɪn fɹɔsti smaɪl tʌtʃt hɑɹɪnz lɪps. "pɝhæps æftɝ wi faɪn kɔɹɾɝz, jə ən aɪ kən dɪskʌs ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz."

"You will not be able to channel in there?" Harine said. When the Aes Sedai nodded without looking away from the city, a thin frosty smile touched Harine's lips. "Perhaps after we find quarters, you and I can discuss instructions."

"ju ɹɛd ðə fəlɑsəfi?" sɝin lʊk stɑɹɾəld. "ðə θɪɹi ʌv ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz, ɪts nɑt wɛl θɔɾ ə ðiz deɪz, jɛɾ aɪ hæv ɔlweɪz bɪliv ðəɹ wɑz mʌtʃ tə lɝn ðɛɹ. ə dɪskʌʃən wɪl bi plɛzənt, tə teɪk maɪ maɪn fɹəm ʌðɝ mæɾɝz. ɪf kædzueɪn əlaʊz əs taɪm."

"You read the philosophy?" Sarene looked startled. "The Theory of Instructions, it is not well thought of these days, yet I have always believed there was much to learn there. A discussion will be pleasant, to take my mind from other matters. If Cadsuane allows us time."

hɑɹɪnz maʊθ fɛl oʊpən. ɡeɪpɪŋ ət ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, ʃi fɝɡɑt tə klɪŋ tə hɝ sæɾəl, ən oʊnli moʊd sizɪŋ əɹ ɑɹm seɪvd əɹ fɹəm ə fɔl.

Harine's mouth fell open. Gaping at the Aes Sedai, she forgot to cling to her saddle, and only Moad seizing her arm saved her from a fall.

ʃələn hæd nɛvɝ hɝd hɑɹɪn mɛnʃən fəlɑsəfi, bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt kɛɹ wʌɾ əɹ sɪstɝ wɑz tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt. stɛɹɪŋ təwɔɹd fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ, ʃi swɑloʊd hɑɹd. ʃi hæd lɝn tə ʃið sʌmwʌn əɡɛns juzɪŋ ðə paʊɝ, ʌv kɔɹs, ən bɪn ʃið hɝsɛlf əz pɑɹɾ ə hɝ tʃɹeɪnɪŋ, jɛt wən jə wɝ ʃiðd, jə kəd stɪl fil ðə sɔɹs. wʌt wəɾ ɪt bi laɪk nɑt tə fil ɪt, laɪk ðə sʌn dʒʌst aʊɾ ə saɪt bɪɑn ðə kɔɹnɝ ə jəɹ aɪ? wʌt wəɾ ɪt bi laɪk tə luz ðə sʌn?

Shalon had never heard Harine mention philosophy, but she did not care what her sister was talking about. Staring toward Far Madding, she swallowed hard. She had learned to sheathe someone against using the Power, of course, and been sheathed herself as part of her training, yet when you were sheathed, you could still feel the Source. What would it be like not to feel it, like the sun just out of sight beyond the corner of your eye? What would it be like to lose the sun?

əz ðeɪ ɹoʊd nɪɹɝ ðə leɪk, ʃi fɛl mɔɹ əwɛɹ ə ðə sɔɹs ðən ʃi hæd sɪns əɹ fɝs dʒɔɪ ət tʌtʃɪŋ ɪt. ɪt wɑz ɔl ʃi kəd də nɑt tə dʒɹɪŋk ʌv ɪt, bʌt ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wəd si ðə laɪɾ ən noʊ, ən laɪkli noʊ waɪ. ʃi wəd nɑt ʃeɪm hɝsɛlf əɹ hɑɹɪn ɪn ðət mænɝ. smɔl, bimi kɹæf dɑɾəd ðə wɔɾɝ, nʌn mɔɹ ðən sɪks əɹ sɛvən spænz ɪn lɛŋθ, səm hɔlɪŋ ɪn nɛts, ʌðɝz kɹipɪŋ əlɔŋ ɑn lɔŋ swips. dʒʌdʒɪŋ baɪ ðə wɪnswɛp swɛlz ðət ɹoʊld əkɹɔs ðə sɝfəs, səmtaɪmz kɹæʃɪŋ ɪndə wʌn ənʌðɝ ɪn faʊntənz ə foʊm laɪk sɝf, seɪlz maɪɾ əv bɪn əz mʌtʃ hɪnʒɹəns əz hɛlp. stɪl, ðə boʊts simd ɔlmoʊst ə fəmɪljɝ θɪŋ, ðoʊ nʌθɪŋ laɪk ðə slik fɔɹz əɹ eɪts əɹ twɛlvz kæɹiɾ ɑn ðə ʃɪps. ə taɪni kʌmfɝɾ əmɪd stʃɹeɪnʒnəs.

As they rode nearer the lake, she felt more aware of the Source than she had since her first joy at touching it. It was all she could do not to drink of it, but the Aes Sedai would see the light and know, and likely know why. She would not shame herself or Harine in that manner. Small, beamy craft dotted the water, none more than six or seven spans in length, some hauling in nets, others creeping along on long sweeps. Judging by the windswept swells that rolled across the surface, sometimes crashing into one another in fountains of foam like surf, sails might have been as much hindrance as help. Still, the boats seemed almost a familiar thing, though nothing like the sleek fours or eights or twelves carried on the ships. A tiny comfort amid strangeness.

ðə ɹoʊd tɝn ɑntu ə spɪɾ ə læn dʒʌɾɪŋ hæf ə maɪl əɹ mɔɹ ɪndə ðə leɪk, ən əbɹʌpli ðə sɔɹs vænɪʃt. sɝin saɪd, bʌt ɡeɪv noʊ ʌðɝ saɪn ʃi hæd noʊɾəst. ʃələn wɛɾ əɹ lɪps. ɪt wɑz nɑt soʊ bæɾ əz ʃi hæd fɪɹd. ɪt meɪɾ əɹ fil . . . ɛmpti . . . bʌt ʃi kəd bɛɹ ðæt. əz lɔŋ əz ʃi dɪd nɑɾ əv tə bɛɹ ɪt tu lɔŋ. ðə wɪnd, ɡʌstɪŋ ən kɝlɪŋ ən tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə stil kloʊks, sʌɾənli fɛl mʌtʃ koʊldɝ.

The road turned onto a spit of land jutting half a mile or more into the lake, and abruptly the Source vanished. Sarene sighed, but gave no other sign she had noticed. Shalon wet her lips. It was not so bad as she had feared. It made her feel . . . empty . . . but she could bear that. As long as she did not have to bear it too long. The wind, gusting and curling and trying to steal cloaks, suddenly felt much colder.

ət ði ɛn ə ðə spɪt, ə vɪlədʒ ʌv ɡɹeɪ stoʊn haʊsəz wɪð dɑɹkɝ sleɪt ɹufs stʊd bɪtwin ɹoʊɾ ən wɔɾɝ ɑn wʌn saɪd. vɪlədʒ wɪmən hɝiɪŋ əlɔŋ wɪð lɑɹdʒ bæskəts stɑpt ət ðə saɪɾ ə ðə maʊntəd pɑɹɾi. mɔɹ ðən wʌn fɛlt əɾ əɹ oʊn noʊz əz ʃi stɛɹd. ʃələn hæd ɡɹoʊn ɔlmoʊst əkʌstəm tə ðoʊz stɛɹz, ɪn kɛɹhin. ɪn ɛni keɪs, ðə fɔɹɾəfəkeɪʃən ɑpəzət ðə vɪlədʒ dʒɹu hɝ aɪz, ə maʊn ə taɪt-fɪɾəd stoʊn faɪv spænz haɪ wɪð soʊlʒɝz wɑtʃɪŋ θɹu ðə bɑɹd feɪsɡɑɹdz ə ðɛɹ hɛlməts fɹəm ətɑp taʊɝz ət ðə kɔɹnɝz. səm hɛl dʒɹɔn kɹɔsboʊz wɛɹ ʃi kəd si ðɛm. fɹəm ə lɑɹdʒ aɪɝn-pleɪɾəd dɔɹ ət ði ɛnd nɪɹəs ðə bɹɪdʒ, mɔɹ hɛlməɾɪd soʊlʒɝz spɪld aʊɾ ɪndə ðə ɹoʊd, mɛn ɪn skwɛɹ-skeɪld ɑɹmɝ wɪð ə ɡoʊldən sɔɹd wɝkt ɑn ðə lɛft ʃoʊldɝ. səm wɔɹ sɔɹdz ət ðɛɹ weɪsts ən ʌðɝz kæɹid lɔŋ spɪɹz əɹ kɹɔsboʊz. ʃələn wʌndɝd wɛðɝ ðeɪ ɪkspɛktəd ði ɛɛs sədaɪ tə tʃɹaɪ faɪɾɪŋ pæst. ən ɔfəsɝ wɪð ə jɛloʊ plum ɑn ɪz hɛlmət moʊʃən kædzueɪn tə ə hɔlt, ðən əpɹoʊtʃt əɹ ən ɹimuvd ɪz hɛlmət, fɹiɪŋ ɡɹeɪ-stʃɹik hɛɹ ðət spɪl daʊn ɪz bæk tə hɪz weɪst. hi hæɾ ə hɑɹd, dɪsɡɹʌntəl feɪs.

At the end of the spit, a village of gray stone houses with darker slate roofs stood between road and water on one side. Village women hurrying along with large baskets stopped at the sight of the mounted party. More than one felt at her own nose as she stared. Shalon had grown almost accustomed to those stares, in Cairhien. In any case, the fortification opposite the village drew her eyes, a mound of tight-fitted stone five spans high with soldiers watching through the barred faceguards of their helmets from atop towers at the corners. Some held drawn crossbows where she could see them. From a large iron-plated door at the end nearest the bridge, more helmeted soldiers spilled out into the road, men in square-scaled armor with a golden sword worked on the left shoulder. Some wore swords at their waists and others carried long spears or crossbows. Shalon wondered whether they expected the Aes Sedai to try fighting past. An officer with a yellow plume on his helmet motioned Cadsuane to a halt, then approached her and removed his helmet, freeing gray-streaked hair that spilled down his back to his waist. He had a hard, disgruntled face.

kædzueɪn lin loʊ ɪn əɹ sæɾəl tə ɪkstʃeɪnʒ ə fju kwaɪət wɝdz wɪð ðə mæn, ðən pɹədust ə fæt pɝs fɹəm bɪniθ əɹ sæɾəlbæɡz. hi tʊk ɪɾ ən stɛp bæk, moʊʃənɪŋ wʌn ə ðə soʊlʒɝz fɔɹwɝd, ə tɔl boʊni mæn u wɑz nɑt wɛɹɪŋ ə hɛlmət. hi kæɹiɾ ə ɹaɪɾɪŋ bɔɹd, ən ɪz hɛɹ, ɡæðɝɾ ət ðə bæk ə hɪz hɛd laɪk ði ɔfəsɝz, ɔlsoʊ hʌŋ tə hɪz weɪst. hi bɛn ɪz nɛk ɹɪspɛkfəli bɪfɔɹ ɪnkwaɪɝɪŋ ɑlɑnəz neɪm, ən ɹoʊɾ ɪt vɛɹi kɛɹfəli, wɪð ɪz tʌŋ kɑt bɪtwin ɪz tiθ, dɪpɪŋ ɪz pɛn ɔfən. hɛlməɾ ɑn ɪz hɪp, ðə dɪskəntɛntɪɾ ɔfəsɝ stʊd stʌɾiɪŋ ði ʌðɝz bɪhaɪn kædzueɪn wɪð noʊ ɪkspɹɛʃən. ðə pɝs hʌŋ fɹəm ɪz hæn əz ðoʊ fɝɡɑɾən. hi simd ʌnəwɛɹ i hæd bɪn spikɪŋ wɪð ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. əɹ meɪbi, hi dɪd nɑt kɛɹ. hɪɹ, ən ɛɛs sədaɪ wɑz noʊ dɪfɹən fɹəm ɛni ʌðɝ wʊmən. ʃələn ʃʌɾɝəd. hɪɹ, ʃi wɑz noʊ dɪfɹən fɹəm ɛni ʌðɝ wʊmən, bɝɛft ə hɝ ɡɪfs fəɹ ðə dʊɹeɪʃən ə hɝ steɪ. bɝɛft.

Cadsuane leaned low in her saddle to exchange a few quiet words with the man, then produced a fat purse from beneath her saddlebags. He took it and stepped back, motioning one of the soldiers forward, a tall bony man who was not wearing a helmet. He carried a writing board, and his hair, gathered at the back of his head like the officer's, also hung to his waist. He bent his neck respectfully before inquiring Alanna's name, and wrote it very carefully, with his tongue caught between his teeth, dipping his pen often. Helmet on his hip, the discontented officer stood studying the others behind Cadsuane with no expression. The purse hung from his hand as though forgotten. He seemed unaware he had been speaking with an Aes Sedai. Or maybe, he did not care. Here, an Aes Sedai was no different from any other woman. Shalon shuddered. Here, she was no different from any other woman, bereft of her gifts for the duration of her stay. Bereft.

"ðeɪ teɪk ðə neɪmz ʌv ɔl fɔɹənɝz," sɝin sɛd. "ðə kaʊnsəlz, ðeɪ laɪk tə noʊ hu ɪz ɪn ðə sɪɾi."

"They take the names of all foreigners," Sarene said. "The Counsels, they like to know who is in the city."

"pɝhæps ðeɪ wəɾ ədmɪɾ ə weɪvməstʃɹəs wɪθaʊt bɹaɪbz," hɑɹɪn sɛd dʒɹɪli. ðə boʊni soʊlʒɝ, tɝnɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm ɑlɑnə, ɡeɪv ðə juʒəwəl ʃɔɹbaʊn stɑɹɾ ət ʃələn ən hɑɹɪnz dʒuəlɹi bɪfɔɹ kʌmɪŋ təwɔɹd ðɛm.

"Perhaps they would admit a Wavemistress without bribes," Harine said drily. The bony soldier, turning away from Alanna, gave the usual shorebound start at Shalon and Harine's jewelry before coming toward them.

"jɔɹ neɪm, mɪstʃɹəs, ɪf ɪt plizɪz ju?" hi sɛd pəlaɪtli tə sɝin, dʌkɪŋ ɪz hɛɾ əɡɛn. ʃi ɡeɪv ɪt wɪθaʊt mɛnʃənɪŋ ðət ʃi wɑz ɛɛs sədaɪ. ʃələn ɡeɪv hɝz əz sɪmpli, bʌt hɑɹɪn ɔfɝd ðə taɪɾəlz əz wɛl, hɑɹɪn dɪn toʊɡɑɹə tu wɪnz, weɪvməstʃɹəs ə klæn ʃoʊdaɪn, æmbæsəɾɝ ɪkstʃɹɔɹɾənɛɹi ʌv ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps tə ði æθɑn maɪɹ. ðə fɛloʊ blɪŋkt, ðən bɪɾ ɪz tʌŋ ən bɛn ɪz nɛk oʊvɝ ðə ɹaɪɾɪŋ bɔɹd. hɑɹɪn skaʊld. wən ʃi wɑntəd tə ɪmpɹɛs sʌmwʌn, ʃi ɪkspɛktəɾ əm tə bi ɪmpɹɛst.

"Your name, Mistress, if it pleases you?" he said politely to Sarene, ducking his head again. She gave it without mentioning that she was Aes Sedai. Shalon gave hers as simply, but Harine offered the titles as well, Harine din Togara Two Winds, Wavemistress of Clan Shodein, Ambassador Extraordinary of the Mistress of the Ships to the Atha'an Miere. The fellow blinked, then bit his tongue and bent his neck over the writing board. Harine scowled. When she wanted to impress someone, she expected them to be impressed.

əz ðə boʊni mæn wɑz ɹaɪɾɪŋ, ə stɑki, hɛlməɾɪd soʊlʒɝ wɪð ə lɛðɝ skɹɪp hæŋɪŋ fɹəm ɪz ʃoʊldɝ pʊʃt bɪtwin hɑɹɪnz hɔɹs ən moʊdz. bɪhaɪn ðə bɑɹz ə hɪz feɪsɡɑɹd, ə pʌkɝd skɑɹ daʊn ɪz feɪs pʊld ʌp wʌn saɪɾ ə hɪz maʊθ ɪn ə snɪɹ, bʌɾ i baʊɾ ɪz hɛd tə hɑɹɪn ɹɪspɛkfəli ɪnʌf. ən ðən i tʃɹaɪd tə teɪk moʊdz sɔɹd.

As the bony man was writing, a stocky, helmeted soldier with a leather scrip hanging from his shoulder pushed between Harine's horse and Moad's. Behind the bars of his faceguard, a puckered scar down his face pulled up one side of his mouth in a sneer, but he bowed his head to Harine respectfully enough. And then he tried to take Moad's sword.

"ju mʌst əlaʊ ɪɾ əɹ liv jəɹ bleɪdz hɪɹ əntɪl jə dɪpɑɹt," sɝin sɛd kwɪkli wən ðə sɔɹdmæstɝ twɪtʃt ðə skæbɝɾ aʊɾ ə ðə stɑki mænz hænz. "ðɪs sɝvəs, ɪts wʌt kædzueɪn wɑz peɪɪŋ fɔɹ, weɪvməstʃɹəs. ɪn fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ, noʊ mæn ɪz əlaʊd tə kæɹi mɔɹ ðən ðə bɛl naɪf ənlɛs ɪts pis-bɑndəd soʊ ɪt kænɑt bi dʒɹɔn. ivən ðə wɔl ɡɑɹdz laɪk ðiz mɛn kænɑt teɪk ə sɔɹɾ əweɪ fɹəm ðɛɹ pleɪs ə duɾi. ɪz ðət nɑt soʊ?" ʃi æsk ðə skɪni soʊlʒɝ, ən i ɹɪplaɪd ðəɾ ɪt wɑz, ən ə ɡʊd θɪŋ, tu.

"You must allow it or leave your blades here until you depart," Sarene said quickly when the Swordmaster twitched the scabbard out of the stocky man's hands. "This service, it is what Cadsuane was paying for, Wavemistress. In Far Madding, no man is allowed to carry more than the belt knife unless it is peace-bonded so it cannot be drawn. Even the Wall Guards like these men cannot take a sword away from their place of duty. Is that not so?" she asked the skinny soldier, and he replied that it was, and a good thing, too.

wɪð ə ʃɹʌɡ, moʊd lɪftəd ðə sɔɹd fɹəm ɪz sæʃ, ən wən ðə fɛloʊ wɪð ðə pɝpɛtʃuəl snɪɹ dɪmændəɾ ɪz aɪvɝi-hɪltɪd dæɡɝ əz wɛl, hi hændəd ðəɾ oʊvɝ. tʌkɪŋ ðə lɔŋ dæɡɝ bɪhaɪn ɪz bɛlt, ðə mæn pɹədust ə spul ə faɪn waɪɝ fɹəm ɪz skɹɪp ən dɛfli bɪɡæn ɹæpɪŋ ðə sɔɹɾ ɪn ə faɪn nɛt. ɛvɹi soʊ ɔfən i pɔz tə plʌk ə sil-pɹɛs fɹəm ɪz bɛlt ən foʊld ə smɔl lɛd dɪsk ɝaʊn ðə waɪɝz, bʌɾ i hæd kwɪk, pɹæktəs hænz.

With a shrug, Moad lifted the sword from his sash, and when the fellow with the perpetual sneer demanded his ivory-hilted dagger as well, he handed that over. Tucking the long dagger behind his belt, the man produced a spool of fine wire from his scrip and deftly began wrapping the sword in a fine net. Every so often he paused to pluck a seal-press from his belt and fold a small lead disc around the wires, but he had quick, practiced hands.

"ðə lɪst ə neɪmz, ɪɾəl bi dɪstʃɹɪbjəɾəd tə ði ʌðɝ tu bɹɪdʒəz," sɝin wɛn ɑn, "æn ðə mɛn wɪl əv tə ʃoʊ ðə waɪɝz ənbɹoʊkən əɹ ðəl bi hɛld əntɪl ə mædʒəstʃɹeɪt dətɝmənz ðət noʊ ʌðɝ kɹaɪm əz bɪn kəmɪɾəd. ivən ɪf nʌn hæz, ðə pɛnəlti ɪz boʊθ ə vɛɹi hɛvi faɪn ən flɑɡɪŋ. moʊs fɔɹənɝz, ðeɪ dəpɑzɪt ðɛɹ wɛpənz bɪfɔɹ ɛntɝɪŋ tə seɪv ðə kɔɪn, bʌt ðət wəd min wi mʌs liv baɪ ðɪs bɹɪdʒ. ðə laɪɾ əloʊn noʊz wɪtʃ dɝɛkʃən wɪl wɑnə ɡoʊ wən wi liv hɪɹ." lʊkɪŋ təwɔɹd kædzueɪn, hu əpɪɹd tə bi ɹistʃɹeɪnɪŋ ɑlɑnə fɹəm ɹaɪɾɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə lɔŋ bɹɪdʒ əloʊn, sɝin æɾəd ɔlmoʊst ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛθ, "æt list, aɪ hoʊp ðəɾ ɪz əɹ ɹizənɪŋ."

"The list of names, it will be distributed to the other two bridges," Sarene went on, "and the men will have to show the wires unbroken or they will be held until a magistrate determines that no other crime has been committed. Even if none has, the penalty is both a very heavy fine and flogging. Most foreigners, they deposit their weapons before entering to save the coin, but that would mean we must leave by this bridge. The Light alone knows which direction we will want to go when we leave here." Looking toward Cadsuane, who appeared to be restraining Alanna from riding across the long bridge alone, Sarene added almost under her breath, "At least, I hope that is her reasoning."

hɑɹɪn snɔɹɾɪd. "ðɪs ɪz ɹɪdɪkjələs. haʊ ɪz i tə dɪfɛn hɪmsɛlf?"

Harine snorted. "This is ridiculous. How is he to defend himself?"

"noʊ nid fəɹ ɛni mæn tə dɪfɛn hɪmsɛlf ɪn fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ, mɪstʃɹəs." ðə stɑki mænz vɔɪs wɑz kɔɹs, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt saʊn mɑkɪŋ. hi wɑz steɪɾɪŋ ði ɑbviəs. "ðə stʃɹit ɡɑɹdz teɪk kɛɹ ə ðæt. lɛɾ ɛni mæn əz wɑns stɑɹt kæɹiɪŋ ə sɔɹd, ən sun wid bi əz bæɾ əz ɛvɹaɪpleɪs ɛls. aɪ hɝd wʌt ðəɹ laɪk, mɪstʃɹəs, ən wi doʊnt wɑn ðət hɪɹ." boʊɪŋ tə hɑɹɪn, hi stʃɹoʊɾ ɑn daʊn ðə kɑləm fɑloʊd baɪ ðə mæn wɪð ðə ɹaɪɾɪŋ bɔɹd.

"No need for any man to defend himself in Far Madding, Mistress." The stocky man's voice was coarse, but he did not sound mocking. He was stating the obvious. "The Street Guards take care of that. Let any man as wants start carrying a sword, and soon we'd be as bad as everyplace else. I heard what they're like, Mistress, and we don't want that here." Bowing to Harine, he strode on down the column followed by the man with the writing board.

moʊd bɹifli ɪɡzæmən ɪz sɔɹɾ ən dæɡɝ, boʊθ nitli ɹæp hɪlt ən skæbɝd, ðən izd əm bæk ɪn pleɪs, teɪkɪŋ kɛɹ nɑt tə snæɡ hɪz sæʃ ɑn ðə silz. "sɔɹdz oʊnli bɪkʌm jusfəl wən wɪts feɪl," hi sɛd. hɑɹɪn snɔɹɾɪd əɡɛn. ʃələn wʌndɝd haʊ ðət fɛloʊ hæd ɡeɪn ɪz skɑɹ ɪf fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ wɑz soʊ seɪf.

Moad briefly examined his sword and dagger, both neatly wrapped hilt and scabbard, then eased them back in place, taking care not to snag his sash on the seals. "Swords only become useful when wits fail," he said. Harine snorted again. Shalon wondered how that fellow had gained his scar if Far Madding was so safe.

saʊnz ə pɹoʊɾɛst ɹoʊz fɹəm ðə ɹɪɹ, wɛɹ ði ʌðɝ mɛn wɝ, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ kwɪkli saɪlənst. baɪ mɛɹaɪs, ʃələn wəɾ əv weɪdʒɝd. ət taɪmz, ðə wʊmən meɪd kædzueɪn sim læks. hɝ wɔɹɾɝz wɝ laɪk ðə tʃɹeɪnd ɡɑɹd dɑɡz ði æmɑjɹ juzd, ɹɛɾi tə lip əɾ ə wɪsəl, ən ʃi wɑz nɑɾ əɾ ɔl hɛzɪɾənt əbaʊt kɔlɪŋ daʊn ði ʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪz wɔɹɾɝz. sun ɪnʌf ɔl ə ðə sɔɹdz hæd bɪn pis-bɑndəd, ən ðə pækhɔɹsɪz sɝtʃt fəɹ hɪɾən wɛpənz, ən ðeɪ ɹoʊɾ aʊɾ ɑntu ðə bɹɪdʒ, hʊvz ɹɪŋɪŋ ɑn stoʊn. ʃələn tʃɹaɪd tə teɪk ɪn ɛvɹiθɪŋ, nɑt soʊ mʌtʃ fɹəm ɪntʃɹəst əz tə teɪk əɹ maɪn ɔf wʌt wɑz mɪsɪŋ.

Sounds of protest rose from the rear, where the other men were, but they were quickly silenced. By Merise, Shalon would have wagered. At times, the woman made Cadsuane seem lax. Her Warders were like the trained guard dogs the Amayar used, ready to leap at a whistle, and she was not at all hesitant about calling down the other Aes Sedai's Warders. Soon enough all of the swords had been peace-bonded, and the packhorses searched for hidden weapons, and they rode out onto the bridge, hooves ringing on stone. Shalon tried to take in everything, not so much from interest as to take her mind off what was missing.

ðə bɹɪdʒ wɑz flæɾ ən əz waɪɾ əz ðə ɹoʊd bɪhaɪnd, wɪð loʊ stoʊn koʊpɪŋz ɑn ðə saɪd ðət wəd stɑp ə wæɡən fɹəm plʌnʒɪŋ oʊvɝ bʌt ɡɪv noʊ ʃɛltɝ tə ətækɝz, ən ɪt wɑz lɔŋ, tu, pɝhæp əz mʌtʃ əz θɹi-kɔɹɾɝz ʌv ə maɪl, ən stʃɹeɪɾ əz ən æɹoʊ. naʊ ən ðən wʌn ə ðə boʊts pæs bɪniθ, wɪtʃ ðeɪ kəd nɑɾ əv dʌn hæd ðeɪ hæd mæsts. tɔl taʊɝz flæŋk ðə sɪɾiz aɪɝn-stʃɹæpt ɡeɪts - ðə keɪɛmlɪn ɡeɪt wɑz ðə neɪm sɝin ɡeɪv - wɛɹ ɡɑɹdz wɪð ðə ɡoʊldən sɔɹɾ ɑn ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz baʊd ðɛɹ hɛdz tə ðə wɪmən ən kæst səspɪʃəs aɪz ɑn ðə mɛn. ðə stʃɹit bɪɑnd. . . .

The bridge was flat and as wide as the road behind, with low stone copings on the side that would stop a wagon from plunging over but give no shelter to attackers, and it was long, too, perhap as much as three-quarters of a mile, and straight as an arrow. Now and then one of the boats passed beneath, which they could not have done had they had masts.
