Tall towers flanked the city's iron-strapped gates - the Caemlyn Gate was the name Sarene gave - where guards with the golden sword on their shoulders bowed their heads to the women and cast suspicious eyes on the men. The street beyond. . . .

tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə bi əbzɝvənt wɑz noʊ jus. ðə stʃɹit wɑz waɪɾ ən stʃɹeɪt, fʊl ə pipəl ən kɑɹts, laɪnd wɪð stoʊn bɪldɪŋz tu əɹ θɹi stɔɹiz haɪ, ən ɪɾ ɔl simd ə blɝ. ðə sɔɹs wɑz ɡɔn! ʃi nu ɪt wəd kʌm bæk wən ʃi lɛf ðɪs pleɪs, ən laɪt, ʃi wɑntəd tə liv naʊ. bʌt haʊ lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ ʃi kʊd? ðə kɔɹəmʊɹ maɪt bi ɪn ðɪs sɪɾi, ən hɑɹɪn mɛn tə meɪk hɝsɛlf fæs tə ðə kɔɹəmʊɹ, pɝhæps kəz ə hu hi wɑz, pɝhæps kəz ʃi θɔɾ i wəd hɛlp əɹ ɹaɪz tə mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps. əntɪl hɑɹɪn lɛft, əntɪl kædzueɪn fɹiɾ əm fɹəm ði əɡɹimənt, ʃələn wɑz æŋkɝd hɪɹ. hɪɹ, wɛɹ ðəɹ wɑz noʊ tʃɹu sɔɹs.

Trying to be observant was no use. The street was wide and straight, full of people and carts, lined with stone buildings two or three stories high, and it all seemed a blur. The Source was gone! She knew it would come back when she left this place, and Light, she wanted to leave now. But how long before she could? The Coramoor might be in this city, and Harine meant to make herself fast to the Coramoor, perhaps because of who he was, perhaps because she thought he would help her rise to Mistress of the Ships. Until Harine left, until Cadsuane freed them from the agreement, Shalon was anchored here. Here, where there was no True Source.

sɝin tɔkt ɪnsɛsənli, jɛt ʃələn bɛɹli hɝd hɝ. ðeɪ kɹɔst ə lɑɹdʒ skwɛɹ wɪð ə hjudʒ stætʃu ʌv ə wʊmən ɪn ðə sɛntɝ, bʌt ʃələn kɑɾ oʊnli hɝ neɪm, aɪnjən əvhɑɝɪn, ðoʊ ʃi nu sɝin wɑz tɛlɪŋ əɹ waɪ ðə wʊmən wɑz feɪməs ɪn fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ ən waɪ hɝ stætʃu wɑz pɔɪntɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə keɪɛmlɪn ɡeɪt. ə ɹoʊ ʌv lifləs tʃɹiz dɪvaɪɾəd ðə stʃɹit bɪɑn ðə skwɛɹ. sɪdæn tʃɛɹz ən koʊtʃɪz ən mɛn ɪn skwɛɹ-skeɪld ɑɹmɝ θɹɛɾəd ðoʊ ðə kɹaʊdz, bʌt ðeɪ ɹɛdʒəstɝɾ oʊnli ɑn əɹ aɪz. tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ, ʃi hʌɾəld ɪn ɑn hɝsɛlf. ðə sɪɾi vænɪʃt. taɪm vænɪʃt. ɛvɹiθɪŋ vænɪʃt ɪksɛpt əɹ fɪɹ ðət ʃi wəd nɛvɝ fil ðə sɔɹs əɡɛn. ʃi hæd nɛvɝ bɪfɔɹ ɹilaɪzd wʌt kʌmfɝt ʃi hæd teɪkən ɪn ɪts ənsin pɹɛzəns. ɪt hæɾ ɔlweɪz bɪn ðɛɹ, pɹɑməsɪŋ dʒɔɪ bɪɑnd noʊɪŋ, laɪf soʊ ɹɪtʃ ðət kʌlɝz peɪld wən ðə paʊɝ wɑz ɡɔn fɹəm hɝ. ən naʊ ðə sɔɹs ɪtsɛlf wɑz ɡɔn. ɡɔn. ðət wɑz ɔl ʃi wɑz əwɛɹ ʌv, ɔl ʃi kəd bi əwɛɹ ʌv. ɪt wɑz ɡɔn.

Sarene talked incessantly, yet Shalon barely heard her. They crossed a large square with a huge statue of a woman in the center, but Shalon caught only her name, Einion Avharin, though she knew Sarene was telling her why the woman was famous in Far Madding and why her statue was pointing toward the Caemlyn Gate. A row of leafless trees divided the street beyond the square. Sedan chairs and coaches and men in square-scaled armor threaded though the crowds, but they registered only on her eyes. Trembling, she huddled in on herself. The city vanished. Time vanished. Everything vanished except her fear that she would never feel the Source again. She had never before realized what comfort she had taken in its unseen presence. It had always been there, promising joy beyond knowing, life so rich that colors paled when the Power was gone from her. And now the Source itself was gone. Gone. That was all she was aware of, all she could be aware of. It was gone.


tʃæptɝ twɛntifɔɹ


CHAPTER 24

əmʌŋ ðə kaʊnsəlz


Among the Counsels

sʌmwʌn ʃʊk ʃələnz ɑɹm. ɪt wɑz sɝin, ən ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɑz tɔkɪŋ tə hɝ. "ɪɾ ɪz ɪn ðɛɹ," sɝin sɛd, "ɪn ðə hɔl ə ðə kaʊnsəlz. bɪniθ ðə doʊm." wɪθdʒɹɔɪŋ əɹ hænd, ʃi tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ ən ɡæðɝɾ əɹ ɹeɪnz. "ɪɾ ɪz ɹɪdɪkjələs tə θɪŋk ðət ði ɪfɛkt ɪz ɛni wɝs dʒʌs kəz wəɹ kloʊs," ʃi mʌɾɝd, "bʌɾ ɪt dʌz fil soʊ."

Someone shook Shalon's arm. It was Sarene, and the Aes Sedai was talking to her. "It is in there," Sarene said, "in the Hall of the Counsels. Beneath the dome." Withdrawing her hand, she took a deep breath and gathered her reins. "It is ridiculous to think that the effect is any worse just because we are close," she muttered, "but it does feel so."

ʃələn ɹaʊz hɝsɛlf wɪð ən ɛfɝt. ði ɛmptinəs wəd nɑt ɡoʊ əweɪ, bʌt ʃi fɔɹs hɝsɛlf tə ɪɡnɔɹ ɪt. jɛɾ ɪn tʃɹuθ ʃi fɛl kɔɹd laɪk ə pis ə fɹut.

Shalon roused herself with an effort. The emptiness would not go away, but she forced herself to ignore it. Yet in truth she felt cored like a piece of fruit.

ðeɪ wɝ ɪn ə hjudʒ - ʃi səpoʊzd ɪt wɑz stɪl kɔld ə skwɛɹ, ðoʊ ðɪs wʌn wɑz ɹaʊnd - ə hjudʒ skwɛɹ peɪvd wɪð waɪt stoʊn. ət ðə sɛntɝ stʊɾ ə ɡɹeɪt pæləs, ə ɹaʊn stʃɹʌktʃɝ ɔl ʌv waɪɾ ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə tɔl blu doʊm ɑn tɑp, laɪk hæf ʌv ə bɔl. mæsɪv fluɾəd kɑləmz sɝaʊndəd ði ʌpɝ tu lɛvəlz bɪloʊ ðə doʊm, ən ə stɛɾi stʃɹim ə pipəl floʊɾ ʌp ən daʊn ðə bɹɔd waɪt stoʊn stɛɹz liɾɪŋ ʌp tə ðə sɛkən lɛvəl ɑn iðɝ saɪd. ɪksɛp fəɹ ə pɛɹ ə tɔl ɑɹtʃt bɹɑnz ɡeɪts stændɪŋ oʊpən dɝɛkli əhɛɾ ə ðɛm, ðə loʊəs lɛvəl wɑz ɔl waɪt stoʊn kɑɹvd wɪð daɪəɾɪmd wɪmən mɔɹ ðən twaɪs laɪf-saɪz, ən bɪtwin ðɛm, waɪt stoʊn ʃivz ʌv ɡɹeɪn ən boʊls ə klɔθ ðət sim tə hæv ðɛɹ fɹi ɛnz ɹɪpəlɪŋ ɪn ə wɪnd, ən stæks ʌv ɪŋɡəts ðət maɪɾ əv bɪn mɛn fəɹ ɡoʊld əɹ sɪlvɝ əɹ aɪɝn əɹ pɝhæps ɔl θɹi, ən sæks spɪlɪŋ aʊt wʌt lʊkt kɔɪnz ən dʒɛmstoʊnz. bɪniθ ðə wɪmənz fit, mʌtʃ smɔlɝ waɪt stoʊn fɪɡjɝz dʒɹoʊv wæɡənz ən wɝk fɔɹdʒɪz ən lumz ɪn ə kəntɪnjuəs bænd. ðiz pipəl hæd meɪɾ ə mɑnjəmən pɹoʊkleɪmɪŋ ðɛɹ səksɛs ət tʃɹeɪd. ðət wɑz fulɪʃ. wən pipəl dɪsaɪɾɪd jə wɝ bɛɾɝ ət tʃɹeɪd ðən ðeɪ, ðeɪ nɑɾ oʊnli ɡɹu dʒɛləs, ðeɪ bɪkeɪm stʌbɝn ən tʃɹaɪd tə dɪmæn ɹɪdɪkjələs bɑɹɡənz. ən səmtaɪmz jə hæd noʊ ɔltɝnəɾɪv seɪv tə æksɛpt.

They were in a huge - she supposed it was still called a square, though this one was round - a huge square paved with white stone. At the center stood a great palace, a round structure all of white except for the tall blue dome on top, like half of a ball. Massive fluted columns surrounded the upper two levels below the dome, and a steady stream of people flowed up and down the broad white stone stairs leading up to the second level on either side. Except for a pair of tall arched bronze gates standing open directly ahead of them, the lowest level was all white stone carved with diademed women more than twice life-size, and between them, white stone sheaves of grain and bolts of cloth that seemed to have their free ends rippling in a wind, and stacks of ingots that might have been meant for gold or silver or iron or perhaps all three, and sacks spilling out what looked coins and gemstones. Beneath the women's feet, much smaller white stone figures drove wagons and worked forges and looms in a continuous band. These people had made a monument proclaiming their success at trade. That was foolish. When people decided you were better at trade than they, they not only grew jealous, they became stubborn and tried to demand ridiculous bargains. And sometimes you had no alternative save to accept.

ʃi ɹilaɪz ðət hɑɹɪn wɑz fɹaʊnɪŋ ət hɝ, ən stʃɹeɪɾənd hɝsɛlf ɪn ðə sæɾəl. "fɝɡɪv mi, weɪvməstʃɹəs," ʃi sɛd. ðə sɔɹs wɑz ɡɔn, bʌɾ ɪt wəd ɹɪtɝn - ʌv kɔɹs ɪt wʊd! - ən ʃi hæɾ əɹ duɾi. ʃi wɑz əʃeɪm ðət ʃi hæd lɛt hɝsɛlf ɡɪv ɪn tə fɪɹ, jɛt ði ɛmptinəs ɹɪmeɪnd. oʊ, laɪt, ði ɛmptinəs! "aɪ æm bɛɾɝ, naʊ. əl də bɛɾɝ fɹəm hɪɹ ɑn." hɑɹɪn mɪɹli nɑɾəd, stɪl fɹaʊnɪŋ, ən ʃələnz skælp pɹɪkəld. wən hɑɹɪn feɪl tə dɪlɪvɝ ən ɪkspɛktəd tʌŋ-læʃɪŋ, ɪt wɑz kəz ʃi ɪntɛndəd tə dɪlɪvɝ wɝs.

She realized that Harine was frowning at her, and straightened herself in the saddle. "Forgive me, Wavemistress," she said. The Source was gone, but it would return - of course it would! - and she had her duty. She was ashamed that she had let herself give in to fear, yet the emptiness remained. Oh, Light, the emptiness! "I am better, now. I will do better from here on." Harine merely nodded, still frowning, and Shalon's scalp prickled. When Harine failed to deliver an expected tongue-lashing, it was because she intended to deliver worse.

kædzueɪn ɹoʊd stʃɹeɪɾ əkɹɔs ðə skwɛɹ ən θɹu ðə hɔl ə ðə kaʊnsəlz' oʊpən ɡeɪts ɪndə ə lɑɹdʒ, haɪ-silɪŋɡd ɹum ðəɾ əpɪɹd tə bi ən ɪndɔɹ steɪbliɑɹd. ə dʌzən mɛn ɪn blu koʊts, skwɑɾɪŋ bɪsaɪd sɪdæn tʃɛɹz wɪð boʊθ ə ɡoʊldən sɔɹɾ ən ə ɡoʊldən hæn peɪntəɾ ɑn ðə dɔɹz, lʊkt ʌp ɪn sɝpɹaɪz wən ðeɪ ɹoʊɾ ɪn. soʊ dɪd ðə mɛn ɪn blu vɛsts u wɝ ənhɑɹnəsɪŋ ðə tim fɹəm ə koʊtʃ wɪð ðə sɔɹd-ænd-hæn sɪdʒəl, ən ðoʊz swipɪŋ ðə stoʊn flɔɹ wɪð lɑɹdʒ pʊʃbɹumz. tu mɔɹ ɡɹumz wɝ liɾɪŋ hɔɹsəz daʊn ə waɪd kɔɹəɾɝ ðət ɡeɪv ɔf ðə smɛl ə heɪ ən dʌŋ.

Cadsuane rode straight across the square and through the Hall of the Counsels' open gates into a large, high-ceilinged room that appeared to be an indoor stableyard. A dozen men in blue coats, squatting beside sedan chairs with both a golden sword and a golden hand painted on the doors, looked up in surprise when they rode in. So did the men in blue vests who were unharnessing the team from a coach with the sword-and-hand sigil, and those sweeping the stone floor with large pushbrooms. Two more grooms were leading horses down a wide corridor that gave off the smell of hay and dung.

ə plʌmp, smuð-tʃik mæn ɪn ɪz mɪɾəl jɪɹz keɪm skɝiɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz, bɑbɪŋ ɪz hɛɾ ɪn smɔl baʊz ən dʒɹaɪ-wɑʃɪŋ ɪz hænz. wɛɹ ði ʌðɝ mɛn hæd ðɛɹ lɔŋ hɛɹ taɪɾ ət ðə neɪp ə ðə nɛk, hɪz wɑz kɑt wɪð ə smɔl sɪlvɝ klɪp, ən ɪz blu koʊɾ əpɪɹɾ ʌv ɡʊd kwɑləɾi wʊl, wɪð ðə ɡoʊldən sɔɹd-ænd-hæn ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd lɑɹdʒ ɑn ɪz lɛf bɹɛst. "fɝɡɪv mi," hi sɛd wɪð ən ʌŋtʃwəs smaɪl, "aɪ min noʊ əfɛns, bʌɾ aɪ fɪɹ jə mʌst əv mɪsteɪkən jəɹ dɝɛkʃən. ðɪs ɪz ðə hɔl ə ðə kaʊnsəlz, ən - "

A plump, smooth-cheeked man in his middle years came scurrying across the paving stones, bobbing his head in small bows and dry-washing his hands. Where the other men had their long hair tied at the nape of the neck, his was caught with a small silver clip, and his blue coat appeared of good quality wool, with the golden Sword-and-Hand embroidered large on his left breast. "Forgive me," he said with an unctuous smile, "I mean no offense, but I fear you must have mistaken your direction. This is the Hall of the Counsels, and - "

"tɛl fɝs kaʊnsəl bɑɹsælə ðət kædzueɪn məleɪdʒɹɪn ɪz hɪɹ tə si hɝ," kædzueɪn bɹoʊk ɪn ɑn ɪm əz ʃi dɪsmaʊntɪd.

"Tell First Counsel Barsalla that Cadsuane Melaidhrin is here to see her," Cadsuane broke in on him as she dismounted.

ðə mænz smaɪl slɪɾ ɔf tə wʌn saɪd, ən ɪz aɪz waɪɾənd. "kædzueɪn məleɪdʒɹɪn? aɪ θɔt jə wɝ - !" hi kʌt hɪmsɛlf ʃɔɹɾ əɾ əɹ sʌɾənli hɑɹd stɛɹ, ðən kɔft ɪndə hɪz hæn ən ɹiəsumd ɪz fʊlsəm smaɪl. "fɝɡɪv mi, kædzueɪn sədaɪ. wɪl jə əlaʊ mi tə ʃoʊ jə ən jəɹ kəmpænjənz tə ə weɪɾɪŋ ɹum wɛɹ jə kən ɹəsiv wɛlkəm waɪl aɪ sɛnd wɝd tə ðə fɝs kaʊnsəl?" hɪz aɪz waɪɾənd slaɪtli əz i tʊk ɪn ðoʊz kəmpænjənz. pleɪnli hi, tu, kəd ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ɛɛs sədaɪ, ət list ɪn ə ɡɹup. ʃələn ən hɑɹɪn meɪɾ ɪm blɪŋk, bʌɾ i hæd sɛlf-kəntʃɹoʊl, fəɹ wʌn ə ðə ʃɔɹbaʊnd. hi dɪd nɑt ɡeɪp.

The man's smile slid off to one side, and his eyes widened. "Cadsuane Melaidhrin? I thought you were - !" He cut himself short at her suddenly hard stare, then coughed into his hand and reassumed his fulsome smile. "Forgive me, Cadsuane Sedai. Will you allow me to show you and your companions to a waiting room where you can receive welcome while I send word to the First Counsel?" His eyes widened slightly as he took in those companions. Plainly he, too, could recognize Aes Sedai, at least in a group. Shalon and Harine made him blink, but he had self-control, for one of the shorebound. He did not gape.

"aɪl əlaʊ jə tə ɹʌn tɛl əlaɪz aɪm hɪɹ əz fæst əz jəɹ lɛɡz kən kæɹi ju, bɔɪ," kædzueɪn ɹɪplaɪd, ənfæsənɪŋ əɹ kloʊk ən tɔsɪŋ ɪɾ əkɹɔs əɹ sæɾəl. "tɛl əɹ əl bi ɪn ðə doʊm, ən tɛl əɹ aɪ doʊn əv ɔl deɪ. wɛl? hɑp!" ðɪs taɪm ðə mænz smaɪl dɪd nɑt slaɪd, ɪt tɝn sɪkli, bʌɾ i oʊnli hɛzɪteɪɾɪd ə moʊmən bɪfɔɹ sɛɾɪŋ ɔf əɾ ə dɛd ɹʌn waɪl ʃaʊɾɪŋ fəɹ ɡɹumz tə kʌm teɪk ðə hɔɹsəz.

"I'll allow you to run tell Aleis I'm here as fast as your legs can carry you, boy," Cadsuane replied, unfastening her cloak and tossing it across her saddle. "Tell her I'll be in the dome, and tell her I don't have all day. Well? Hop!" This time the man's smile did not slide, it turned sickly, but he only hesitated a moment before setting off at a dead run while shouting for grooms to come take the horses.

kædzueɪn hæd dɪsmɪst ɪm fɹəm əɹ ətɛnʃən əz sun əz ʃi fɪnɪʃt ɡɪvɪŋ ɪm ɪz ɔɹɾɝz, haʊɛvɝ. "vɛɹɪn, kʌmaɪɹə, jə tu wɪl kʌm wɪð mi," ʃi ənaʊns bɹɪskli. "mɛɹaɪs, kip ɛvɹiwʌn təɡɛðɝ ən ɹɛɾi əntɪl aɪ - ɑlɑnə, kʌm bæk ən dɪsmaʊnt. ɑlɑnə!" ɹɪlʌktənli ɑlɑnə tɝn əɹ maʊn əweɪ fɹəm ðə ɡeɪts ən klaɪm daʊn wɪð ə sʌlki ɡlaʊɝ. hɝ slɪm wɔɹɾɝ, ɪvɑn, wɑtʃt əɹ æŋkʃəsli. kædzueɪn saɪɾ əz ðoʊ hɝ peɪʃəns wɑz ɔlmoʊst əɾ ən ɛnd. "sɪɾ ɑn əɹ ɪf jə mʌs tə kip əɹ hɪɹ, mɛɹaɪs," ʃi sɛd, hændɪŋ əɹ ɹeɪnz tə ə smɔl, wɪɹi ɡɹum. "aɪ wɑn ɛvɹiwʌn ɹɛɾi tə liv wən aɪm dʌn wɪð əlaɪz." mɛɹaɪs nɑɾəd, ən kædzueɪn tɝn tə ðə ɡɹum. "ə lɪɾəl wɔɾɝ ɪz ɔl i nidz," ʃi sɛd, ɡɪvɪŋ əɹ hɔɹs ən əfɛkʃənət pæt. "aɪ hævən ɛksɝsaɪzd ɪm mʌtʃ tədeɪ."

Cadsuane had dismissed him from her attention as soon as she finished giving him his orders, however. "Verin, Kumira, you two will come with me," she announced briskly. "Merise, keep everyone together and ready until I - Alanna, come back and dismount. Alanna!" Reluctantly Alanna turned her mount away from the gates and climbed down with a sulky glower. Her slim Warder, Ihvon, watched her anxiously. Cadsuane sighed as though her patience was almost at an end. "Sit on her if you must to keep her here, Merise," she said, handing her reins to a small, wiry groom. "I want everyone ready to leave when I'm done with Aleis." Merise nodded, and Cadsuane turned to the groom. "A little water is all he needs," she said, giving her horse an affectionate pat. "I haven't exercised him much today."

ʃələn wɑz mɔɹ ðən hæpi tə tɝn əɹ oʊn hɔɹs oʊvɝ tə ə ɡɹum wɪθaʊɾ ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz. ʃi wəd nɑt maɪn ɪf i kɪl ðə kɹitʃɝ. ʃi dɪd nɑt noʊ haʊ fɑɹ ʃi hæd ɹɪɾən ɪn ə deɪz, bʌt ʃi fɛlt əz ðoʊ ʃi hæd bɪn ɪn ðət sæɾəl ɛvɹi maɪl ə ðə haʊɛvɝ mɛni hʌnʒɹəd liɡz tə kɛɹhin. ʃi fɛlt ɹʌmpəld ɪn əɹ flɛʃ əz wɛl əz əɹ kloʊðz. əbɹʌpli, ʃi ɹilaɪz ðət dʒɑhɹz pɹɪɾi feɪs wɑz nɑt wɪð ði ʌðɝ mɛn. vɛɹɪnz toʊmɑs, ə stɑki ɡɹeɪ-hɛɾ əz hɑɹɾ əz ɛni ʌv ði ʌðɝz, wɑz liɾɪŋ ðə spɑɾəd ɡɹeɪ pæk ænəməl ðət hæd bɪn dʒɑhɹz. wɛɹ hæd ðə jʌŋ mæn ɡɑɾən tə? mɛɹaɪs sɝɾənli dɪd nɑɾ əpɪɹ kənsɝn baɪ hɪz æbsəns.

Shalon was more than happy to turn her own horse over to a groom without instructions. She would not mind if he killed the creature. She did not know how far she had ridden in a daze, but she felt as though she had been in that saddle every mile of the however many hundred leagues to Cairhien. She felt rumpled in her flesh as well as her clothes. Abruptly, she realized that Jahar's pretty face was not with the other men. Verin's Tomas, a stocky gray-head as hard as any of the others, was leading the spotted gray pack animal that had been Jahar's. Where had the young man gotten to? Merise certainly did not appear concerned by his absence.

"ðɪs fɝs kaʊnsəl," hɑɹɪn ɡɹaʊld, lɛɾɪŋ moʊd hɛlp əɹ daʊn. ʃi muvd əz stɪfli əz ʃələn. hi hæd sɪmpli lɛp fɹəm ɪz hɔɹs. "ʃi ɪz ən ɪmpɔɹɾənt wʊmən hɪɹ, sɝin?"

"This First Counsel," Harine growled, letting Moad help her down. She moved as stiffly as Shalon. He had simply leapt from his horse. "She is an important woman here, Sarene?"

"ju maɪt seɪ ʃiz ðə ɹulɝ ə fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ, ðoʊ ði ʌðɝ kaʊnsəlz, ðeɪ kɔl əɹ fɝst əmʌŋ ikwəlz, wʌtɛvɝ ðəɾ ɪz səpoʊz tə min." hændɪŋ oʊvɝ əɹ oʊn maʊn tə ə ɡɹum, sɝin lʊkt kwaɪɾ ʌnɹəmpəld. pɝhæps ʃi hæd bɪn əpsɛt bɪfɔɹ oʊvɝ ðɪs tɛɹæŋɡɹil ðət stoʊl ðə sɔɹs, bʌt naʊ ʃi wɑz ɔl kul dɪtætʃmənt, laɪk kɑɹvd aɪs. ðə ɡɹum stʌmbəld oʊvɝ ɪz oʊn fit lʊkɪŋ əɾ əɹ feɪs. "wʌns, ðə fɝs kaʊnsəl, ʃi ædvaɪz ðə kwinz ə mɑɹeɪɾoʊ, bʌt sɪns mɑɹeɪɾoʊz . . . dɪsəluʃən . . . moʊs fɝs kaʊnsəlz əv kənsɪɾɝd ðɛmsɛlvz ðə nætʃɹəl ɛɹz ə mɑɹeɪɾoʊz ɹulɝz."

"You might say she is the ruler of Far Madding, though the other Counsels, they call her first among equals, whatever that is supposed to mean." Handing over her own mount to a groom, Sarene looked quite unrumpled. Perhaps she had been upset before over this ter'angreal that stole the Source, but now she was all cool detachment, like carved ice. The groom stumbled over his own feet looking at her face. "Once, the First Counsel, she advised the queens of Maredo, but since Maredo's . . . dissolution . . . most First Counsels have considered themselves the natural heirs of Maredo's rulers."

ʃələn nu ðəɾ əɹ nɑlədʒ ə ðə ʃɔɹbaʊnz hɪstɝi wɑz əz ənsɝɾən əz əɹ nɑlədʒ ə dʒiɑɡɹəfi əweɪ fɹəm ðə ʃɔɹ, bʌt ʃi hæd nɛvɝ hɝɾ ʌv ɛni neɪʃən kɔl mɑɹeɪɾoʊ. ɪt wɑz ɪnʌf fəɹ hɑɹɪn, ðoʊ. ɪf ðɪs fɝs kaʊnsəl ɹul hɪɹ, ðə weɪvməstʃɹəs ə klæn ʃoʊdaɪn mʌs mit hɝ. hɑɹɪnz dɪɡnəɾi dɪmændəd noʊ lɛs. ʃi hɑbəl dətɝmənədli əkɹɔs ðə steɪbliɑɹd tə kædzueɪn.

Shalon knew that her knowledge of the shorebound's history was as uncertain as her knowledge of geography away from the shore, but she had never heard of any nation called Maredo. It was enough for Harine, though. If this First Counsel ruled here, the Wavemistress of Clan Shodein must meet her. Harine's dignity demanded no less. She hobbled determinedly across the stableyard to Cadsuane.

"oʊ, jɛs," ði ɪnsʌfɝəbəl ɛɛs sədaɪ sɛd bɪfɔɹ hɑɹɪn kəd mɔɹ ðən oʊpən əɹ maʊθ. "ju wɪl kʌm wɪð mi, əz wɛl. ən jəɹ sɪstɝ. aɪ θɪŋk nɑt jəɹ sɔɹdmæstɝ, ðoʊ. ə mæn ɪn ðə doʊm wəd bi bæɾ ɪnʌf; bʌɾ ə mæn wɪð ə sɔɹd maɪt meɪk ðə kaʊnsəlz fɔl oʊvɝ ɪn fɪts. juv ə kwɛstʃən, weɪvməstʃɹəs?" hɑɹɪn snæpt əɹ maʊθ ʃʌt wɪð ən ɑɾəbəl klɪk ə tiθ. "ɡʊd," kædzueɪn mɝmɝd. ʃələn ɡɹoʊnd. ðɪs wɑz nɑɾ ɪmpɹuvɪŋ əɹ sɪstɝz tɛmpɝ baɪ ə fɛðɝ.

"Oh, yes," the insufferable Aes Sedai said before Harine could more than open her mouth. "You will come with me, as well. And your sister. I think not your Swordmaster, though. A man in the dome would be bad enough; but a man with a sword might make the Counsels fall over in fits. You have a question, Wavemistress?" Harine snapped her mouth shut with an audible click of teeth. "Good," Cadsuane murmured. Shalon groaned. This was not improving her sister's temper by a feather.

kædzueɪn lɛɾ əm əlɔŋ bɹɔd, blu-taɪl kɔɹɪɾɝz hʌŋ wɪð bɹaɪt tæpəstʃɹiz ən lɪt baɪ ɡɪldɪd stæn læmps wɪð ɡlɪɾɝɪŋ mɪɹɝz, wɛɹ sɝvəns ɪn blu fɝst stɛɹɾ əɾ əm ɪn sɝpɹaɪz, ðən meɪd heɪsti ʃɔɹbaʊn kɝɾəsiz əz ðeɪ pæst. ʃi lɛɾ əm ʌp lɔŋ, swupɪŋ flaɪts ʌv waɪt stoʊn stɛɹz ðət hʌŋ ənsəpɔɹɾɪd ɪksɛpt wɛɹ ðeɪ tʌtʃt ə peɪl wɔl, wɪtʃ ðeɪ dɪd nɑɾ ɔlweɪz. kædzueɪn ɡlaɪɾɪd laɪk ə swɑn, bʌɾ əɾ ə spid ðət meɪd ði eɪk ɪn ʃələnz lɛɡz bɪɡɪn tə bɝn. hɑɹɪnz feɪs sɛɾ ɪn ə wʊɾən mæsk, haɪɾɪŋ ði ɛfɝɾ ə tʃɹɑɾɪŋ ʌp stɛɹz. ivən kʌmaɪɹə simd ə tʃɹaɪfəl sɝpɹaɪzd, ðoʊ kædzueɪnz peɪs kɑzd əɹ noʊ əpɛɹən ɪɡzɝʃən. ɹaʊn lɪɾəl vɛɹɪn tʃɝn əweɪ ət kædzueɪnz saɪd, naʊ ən ðən smaɪlɪŋ oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ ət hɑɹɪn ən ʃələn. səmtaɪmz ʃələn θɔt ʃi heɪɾəd vɛɹɪn, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ spaɪɾ əɹ əmjuzmən ɪn ðoʊz smaɪlz, oʊnli ɛnkɝɪdʒmənt.

Cadsuane led them along broad, blue-tiled corridors hung with bright tapestries and lit by gilded stand lamps with glittering mirrors, where servants in blue first stared at them in surprise, then made hasty shorebound courtesies as they passed. She led them up long, swooping flights of white stone stairs that hung unsupported except where they touched a pale wall, which they did not always. Cadsuane glided like a swan, but at a speed that made the ache in Shalon's legs begin to burn. Harine's face set in a wooden mask, hiding the effort of trotting up stairs. Even Kumira seemed a trifle surprised, though Cadsuane's pace caused her no apparent exertion. Round little Verin churned away at Cadsuane's side, now and then smiling over her shoulder at Harine and Shalon. Sometimes Shalon thought she hated Verin, but there was no spite or amusement in those smiles, only encouragement.

kædzueɪn tʊk əm ʌp ə faɪnəl kɝlɪŋ flaɪɾ ə stɛɹz, ɛnkloʊz baɪ wɔlz, ən sʌɾənli ðeɪ wɝ ɑn ə bælkəni wɪð ən ɪntʃɹəkət, ɡɪldɪd mɛɾəl ɹeɪlɪŋ ðət ɹæn ɔl ðə weɪ ɝaʊnd. . . . fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ʃələn' ɡeɪpt. əbʌv əɹ ɹoʊz ən oʊvɝɑɹtʃɪŋ blu doʊm ə hʌnʒɹəd fiɾ əɹ mɔɹ haɪ əɾ ɪts pik. nʌθɪŋ hɛld ɪɾ ʌp bʌɾ ɪtsɛlf. hɝ ɪɡnɝəns ə ðə ʃɔɹbaʊn ɪkstɛndəd tə ɑɹkətɛktʃɝ əz wɛl əz dʒiɑɡɹəfi ən hɪstɝi - ən ɛɛs sədaɪ - ɪn fækt, hɝ ɪɡnɝəns ə ðə ʃɔɹbaʊnd wɑz ɔlmoʊs kəmplit, ɛksɛptɪŋ oʊnli kɛɹhin. ʃi nu haʊ tə dʒɹɔ ðə plænz fəɹ ə ɹeɪkɝ ən si ɪt bɪlt, bʌt ʃi kəd nɑt bɪɡɪn tə ɪmædʒən haʊ tə kənstʃɹʌk ðɪs.

Cadsuane took them up a final curling flight of stairs, enclosed by walls, and suddenly they were on a balcony with an intricate, gilded metal railing that ran all the way around. . . . For a moment, Shalon' gaped. Above her rose an overarching blue dome a hundred feet or more high at its peak. Nothing held it up but itself. Her ignorance of the shorebound extended to architecture as well as geography and history - and Aes Sedai - in fact, her ignorance of the shorebound was almost complete, excepting only Cairhien. She knew how to draw the plans for a raker and see it built, but she could not begin to imagine how to construct this.

ɑɹtʃt dɔɹweɪz ɛdʒd wɪð waɪt stoʊn, laɪk ðə wʌn ðeɪ hæd kʌm θɹu, mɑɹk stɛɹz ət θɹi ʌðɝ pleɪsəz ɝaʊn ðə lɔŋ bælkəni, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ əloʊn, ən ðət sim tə pliz kædzueɪn, ðoʊ ɔl ʃi dɪd wɑz nɑd tə hɝsɛlf. "kʌmaɪɹə, ʃoʊ ðə weɪvməstʃɹəs ən əɹ sɪstɝ fɑɹ mæɾɪŋz ɡɑɹɾiən." hɝ vɔɪs ɛkoʊd feɪnli ɪnsaɪd ðə væs doʊm. ʃi dʒɹu vɛɹɪn ə lɪɾəl dɪstəns əweɪ, ən ðə pɛɹ ə ðɛm pʊt ðɛɹ hɛdz təɡɛðɝ. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɛkoʊ ʌv wʌt ðeɪ wɪspɝd.

Arched doorways edged with white stone, like the one they had come through, marked stairs at three other places around the long balcony, but they were alone, and that seemed to please Cadsuane, though all she did was nod to herself. "Kumira, show the Wavemistress and her sister Far Madding's guardian." Her voice echoed faintly inside the vast dome. She drew Verin a little distance away, and the pair of them put their heads together. There was no echo of what they whispered.

"ju mʌs fɝɡɪv ðɛm," kʌmaɪɹə toʊl hɑɹɪn ən ʃələn kwaɪətli. ivən ðət pɹədust ə slaɪt saʊnd, ɪf nɑt kwaɪɾ ən ɛkoʊ. "pis, bʌt ðɪs mʌs bi ɑkwɝd, ivən fəɹ kædzueɪn." ʃi ɹæn əɹ fɪŋɡɝz θɹu hɝ ʃɔɹt bɹaʊn hɛɹ ən ʃʊk əɹ hɛd tə sɛɾəl ɪt bæk ɪn pleɪs. "ðə kaʊnsəlz ɑɹ sɛldəm hæpi tə si ɛɛs sədaɪ, ɪspɛʃli sɪstɝz bɔɹn hɪɹ. aɪ θɪŋk ðeɪ wəd laɪk tə pɹitɛn ðə paʊɝ dʌzn ɪɡzɪst. wɛl, ðɛɹ hɪstɝi ɡɪvz əm ɹizən, ən fəɹ ðə læs tu θaʊzən jɪɹz ðeɪv hæd ðə minz tə səpɔɹt ðə pɹitɛns. ɪn ɛni ɪvɛnt, kædzueɪn ɪz kædzueɪn. ʃi sɛldəm siz ə swɛl hɛd wɪθaʊt dəsaɪɾɪŋ tə dɪfleɪɾ ɪt, ivən wən ɪt hæpənz tə bi wɛɹɪŋ ə kɹaʊn. əɹ ə kaʊnsəlz daɪədɛm. hɝ læs vɪzət wɑz oʊvɝ twɛnti jɪɹz əɡoʊ, dʊɹɪŋ ði il wɔɹ, bʌɾ aɪ səspɛk səm u ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɪɾəl wɑnə haɪɾ ʌndɝ ðɛɹ bɛdz wən ðeɪ lɝn ʃiz bæk." kʌmaɪɹə ɡeɪv ə smɔl, əmjuz læf. ʃələn sɔ nʌθɪŋ tə læf æt. hɑɹɪn twɪstəɾ əɹ lɪps, bʌɾ ɪt meɪɾ əɹ lʊk əz ðoʊ ʃi sʌfɝd fɹəm ə bæd bɛli.

"You must forgive them," Kumira told Harine and Shalon quietly. Even that produced a slight sound, if not quite an echo. "Peace, but this must be awkward, even for Cadsuane." She ran her fingers through her short brown hair and shook her head to settle it back in place. "The Counsels are seldom happy to see Aes Sedai, especially sisters born here. I think they would like to pretend the Power doesn't exist. Well, their history gives them reason, and for the last two thousand years they have had the means to support the pretense. In any event, Cadsuane is Cadsuane. She seldom sees a swelled head without deciding to deflate it, even when it happens to be wearing a crown. Or a Counsel's diadem. Her last visit was over twenty years ago, during the Aiel War, but I suspect some who remember it will want to hide under their beds when they learn she is back." Kumira gave a small, amused laugh. Shalon saw nothing to laugh at. Harine twisted her lips, but it made her look as though she suffered from a bad belly.

"ju wɪʃ tə si ðə . . . ɡɑɹɾiən?" kʌmaɪɹə wɛn ɑn. "æz ɡʊɾ ə neɪm əz ɛni, aɪ səpoʊz. ðəɹ ɪzən mʌtʃ tə si." ʃi stɛp kɔʃəsli kloʊsɝ tə ðə ɡɪldɪd ɹeɪlɪŋ ən pɪɹɾ oʊvɝ əz ɪf fɪɹɪŋ ʃi maɪt fɔl, bʌt ðoʊz blu aɪz hæd ʃɑɹpən əɡɛn. "aɪ wəd ɡɪv ɛniθɪŋ tə stʌɾi ɪt, bʌt ðəɾ ɪz ɪmpɑsəbəl, ʌv kɔɹs. hu noʊz wʌɾ ɛls ɪt maɪt bi eɪbəl tə də bɪsaɪd wʌt wi ɔlɹɛɾi noʊ?" hɝ toʊn hɛld əz mʌtʃ ɑ əz ɹəɡɹɛt.

"You wish to see the . . . guardian?" Kumira went on. "As good a name as any, I suppose. There isn't much to see." She stepped cautiously closer to the gilded railing and peered over as if fearing she might fall, but those blue eyes had sharpened again. "I would give anything to study it, but that is impossible, of course. Who knows what else it might be able to do beside what we already know?" Her tone held as much awe as regret.

ʃələn hæd noʊ fɪɹ ə haɪts, ən ʃi pɹɛs hɝsɛlf əɡɛns ði ɪlæbɹətli wɝk mɛɾəl bɪsaɪd ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, wɑntɪŋ tə si ðɪs θɪŋ ðət hæd teɪkən ðə sɔɹs əweɪ. æftɝ ə moʊmənt, hɑɹɪn dʒɔɪn ðɛm. tə ʃələnz sɝpɹaɪz, ðə dʒɹɑp ðət meɪd kʌmaɪɹə ənizi wɑz lɛs ðən twɛnti fit, bɪloʊ, ə smuð flɔɹ taɪld ɪn blu ən waɪt tə meɪk ə kɑnvəluɾəd meɪz sɛntɝɾ ɑn ə dʌbəl-pɔɪntəd ɹɛɾ oʊvəl ɹɪmd wɪð jɛloʊ. bɪniθ ðə bælkəni, θɹi wɪmən ɪn waɪt sæɾ ɑn stulz speɪst ikwəli ɝaʊn ði ɛdʒ ə ðə flɔɹ, ɹaɪɾ əɡɛns ðə doʊmz wɔl, ən bɪsaɪɾ itʃ wʊmən, ə dɪsk ə fʊl spæn əkɹɔs ðət lʊk laɪk klaʊɾəd kɹɪstəl hæd bɪn sɛɾ ɪndə ðə flɔɹ ən ɪnleɪd wɪð ə lɔŋ θɪn wɛdʒ ə klɪɹ kɹɪstəl ðət pɔɪntəd təwɔɹd ðə tʃeɪmbɝz sɛntɝ. mɛɾəl kɑlɝz sɝaʊndəd ðə mɝki dɪsks, mɑɹkt ɔf laɪk ə kʌmpəs bʌt wɪð ɛvɝ-smɔlɝ mɑɹkɪŋz bɪtwin ðə lɑɹdʒɝ. ʃələn kəd nɑt bi ʃʊɹ, bʌt ðə kɑlɝ nɪɹəst əɹ əpɪɹd tə bi ɪnskɹaɪbd wɪð numɝəlz. ðət wɑz ɔl. noʊ mɑnstʃɹəs ʃeɪps. ʃi hæɾ ɪmædʒən sʌmθɪŋ hjudʒ ən blæk ðət sʌkt ɪn ðə laɪt. hɝ hænz taɪɾənd ɑn ðə ɹeɪl tə kip fɹəm tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ, ən ʃi lɑkt əɹ niz tə hoʊl hɝsɛlf stɪl. wʌtɛvɝ wɑz daʊn ðɛɹ, ɪt hæd stoʊlən ðə laɪt.

Shalon had no fear of heights, and she pressed herself against the elaborately worked metal beside the Aes Sedai, wanting to see this thing that had taken the Source away. After a moment, Harine joined them. To Shalon's surprise, the drop that made Kumira uneasy was less than twenty feet, below, a smooth floor tiled in blue and white to make a convoluted maze centered on a double-pointed red oval rimmed with yellow. Beneath the balcony, three women in white sat on stools spaced equally around the edge of the floor, right against the dome's wall, and beside each woman, a disc a full span across that looked like clouded crystal had been set into the floor and inlaid with a long thin wedge of clear crystal that pointed toward the chamber's center. Metal collars surrounded the murky discs, marked off like a compass but with ever-smaller markings between the larger. Shalon could not be sure, but the collar nearest her appeared to be inscribed with numerals. That was all. No monstrous shapes. She had imagined something huge and black that sucked in the light. Her hands tightened on the rail to keep from trembling, and she locked her knees to hold herself still. Whatever was down there, it had stolen the Light.

ə wɪspɝ ə slɪpɝz ənaʊns nu ɝaɪvəlz ɑn ðə bælkəni baɪ ðə seɪm dɔɹweɪ ðeɪ hæd juzd, əbaʊɾ ə dʌzən smaɪlɪŋ wɪmən wɪð ðɛɹ hɛɹ ɑn tɑp ə ðɛɹ hɛdz, ɪn floʊɪŋ blu sɪlk ɹoʊbz wɔɹn oʊvɝ ðɛɹ dʒɹɛsəz laɪk slivələs koʊts, ɹɪtʃli ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd ɪn ɡoʊld ən tʃɹeɪlɪŋ bɪhaɪn əm ɑn ðə flɔɹ. ðiz pipəl nu haʊ tə mɑɹk aʊt ɹæŋk. itʃ wʊmən wɔɹ ə lɑɹdʒ pɛndən ɪn ðə ʃeɪp ə ðət ɡoʊld-ɹɪmd ɹɛɾ oʊvəl səspɛndəd fɹəm ə nɛkləs ə hɛvi ɡoʊldən lɪŋks, ən ðə seɪm ʃeɪp wɑz ɹɪpiɾɪd ət ðə fɹʌn ʌv itʃ nɛɹoʊ ɡoʊldən daɪədɛm. ɑn wʌn wʊmən, ðə ɹɛɾ oʊvəlz wɝ meɪɾ ə ɹubiz, nɑɾ ɪnæməl, ən sæfaɪɝz ən munstoʊnz ɔlmoʊs hɪd ðə ɡoʊldən sɝkləɾ ɑn əɹ bɹaʊz, ən ʃi wɔɹ ə hɛvi ɡoʊldən sɪɡnɪt ɹɪŋ ɑn əɹ ɹaɪt fɔɹfɪŋɡɝ. ʃi wɑz tɔl ən steɪtli, hɝ blæk hɛɹ dʒɹɔn ʌp ɪn ə lɑɹdʒ bɔl, hɛvəli wɪŋd wɪð waɪt, ðoʊ hɝ feɪs wɑz ənlaɪnd. ði ʌðɝz wɝ tɔl, ʃɔɹt, staʊt, θɪn, pɹɪɾi ən pleɪn, nʌn jʌŋ, ən ɛvɹi wʌn ə ðɛm hæɾ ən ɛɹ ʌv əθɔɹəɾi əbaʊt hɝ, bʌt ʃi stʊɾ aʊt fəɹ mɔɹ ðən əɹ dʒɛmz. kəmpæʃən ən wɪzdəm fɪld əɹ lɑɹdʒ dɑɹk aɪz, ən ɪt wɑz kəmæn ðət ʃi ɹeɪɾieɪtəd, nɑt sɪmpəl əθɔɹəɾi. ʃələn dɪd nɑt nid tə bi toʊl ðət ðɪs wɑz ðə fɝs kaʊnsəl, bʌt ðə wʊmən ənaʊnst ɪɾ ɛniweɪ.

A whisper of slippers announced new arrivals on the balcony by the same doorway they had used, about a dozen smiling women with their hair on top of their heads, in flowing blue silk robes worn over their dresses like sleeveless coats, richly embroidered in gold and trailing behind them on the floor. These people knew how to mark out rank. Each woman wore a large pendant in the shape of that gold-rimmed red oval suspended from a necklace of heavy golden links, and the same shape was repeated at the front of each narrow golden diadem. On one woman, the red ovals were made of rubies, not enamel, and sapphires and moonstones almost hid the golden circlet on her brows, and she wore a heavy golden signet ring on her right forefinger. She was tall and stately, her black hair drawn up in a large ball, heavily winged with white, though her face was unlined. The others were tall, short, stout, thin, pretty and plain, none young, and every one of them had an air of authority about her, but she stood out for more than her gems. Compassion and wisdom filled her large dark eyes, and it was command that she radiated, not simple authority. Shalon did not need to be told that this was the First Counsel, but the woman announced it anyway.

"aɪ æm əlaɪz bɑɹsælə, fɝs kaʊnsəl ə fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ." hɝ mɛləfls vɔɪs, dip fəɹ ə wʊmən, sim tə bi meɪkɪŋ ə pɹɑkləmeɪʃən, ən ɪkspɛktɪŋ tʃɪɹz. ðə saʊn ə hɝ vɔɪs baʊnsɪŋ ɪnsaɪd ðə doʊm ɡeɪv sʌmθɪŋ laɪk ækləmeɪʃən. "fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ ɡɪvz wɛlkəm tə hɑɹɪn dɪn toʊɡɑɹə tu wɪnz, weɪvməstʃɹəs ə klæn ʃoʊdaɪn ən æmbæsəɾɝ ɪkstʃɹɔɹɾənɛɹi fəɹ ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps tə ði æθɑn maɪɹ. meɪ ðə laɪɾ ɪlumin jə ən si jə pɹɑspɝ. jəɹ kʌmɪŋ ɡlæɾənz ɛvɹi hɑɹɾ ɪn fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ. aɪ ɛmbɹeɪs ðə tʃæns tə lɝn mɔɹ ə ði æθɑn maɪɹ, bʌt jə mʌs bi wɪɹi fɹəm ðə ɹɪɡɝz ə jəɹ dʒɝni. aɪ hæv ɝeɪnʒd plɛzən kɔɹɾɝz fəɹ jə ɪn maɪ pæləs. wən juv ɹɛstəɾ ən iɾən, wi kən tɔk; tə əɹ mjutʃəwəl ædvæntɪdʒ, ɪf ɪt plizɪz ðə laɪt." ði ʌðɝz spɹɛd ðə skɝts ə ðɛɹ ɹoʊbz ən meɪd hæf baʊz.

"I am Aleis Barsalla, First Counsel of Far Madding." Her mellifluous voice, deep for a woman, seemed to be making a proclamation, and expecting cheers. The sound of her voice bouncing inside the dome gave something like acclamation. "Far Madding gives welcome to Harine din Togara Two Winds, Wavemistress of Clan Shodein and Ambassador Extraordinary for the Mistress of the Ships to the Atha'an Miere. May the Light illumine you and see you prosper. Your coming gladdens every heart in Far Madding. I embrace the chance to learn more of the Atha'an Miere, but you must be weary from the rigors of your journey. I have arranged pleasant quarters for you in my palace. When you have rested and eaten, we can talk; to our mutual advantage, if it pleases the Light." The others spread the skirts of their robes and made half bows.

hɑɹɪn ɪnklaɪn əɹ hɛd slaɪtli, ə hɪn ə sæɾəsfækʃən ɪn əɹ smaɪl. hɪɹ, ət læst, wɝ ðoʊz u ʃoʊɾ əɹ pɹɑpɝ ɹɪspɛkt. ən vɛɹi laɪkli ɪt hɛlp ðət ðeɪ dɪd nɑt ɡeɪp əɾ əɹ ən ʃələnz dʒuəlɹi.

Harine inclined her head slightly, a hint of satisfaction in her smile. Here, at last, were those who showed her proper respect. And very likely it helped that they did not gape at her and Shalon's jewelry.

"ðə mɛsənʒɝz fɹəm ðə ɡeɪts ɑɹ əz kwɪk əz ɛvɝ, ɪt simz, əlaɪz," kædzueɪn sɛd. "ɪz ðəɹ noʊ wɛlkəm fəɹ mi?" əlaɪz' smaɪl θɪn fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ən səm ə ði ʌðɝ smaɪlz feɪɾəd ɔltəɡɛðɝ əz kædzueɪn muv tə stæn bɪsaɪd hɑɹɪn. ðoʊz ðət ɹɪmeɪnd wɝ fɔɹst. ə pɹɪɾi wʊmən wɪð ə sɪɹiəs kæs tə hɝ feɪs wɛn soʊ fɑɹ əz tə skaʊl.

"The messengers from the gates are as quick as ever, it seems, Aleis," Cadsuane said. "Is there no welcome for me?" Aleis' smile thinned for a moment, and some of the other smiles faded altogether as Cadsuane moved to stand beside Harine. Those that remained were forced. A pretty woman with a serious cast to her face went so far as to scowl.

"wi ɑɹ ɡɹeɪtfəl tə jə fəɹ bɹɪŋɪŋ ðə weɪvməstʃɹəs hɪɹ, kædzueɪn sədaɪ." ðə fɝs kaʊnsəl dɪd nɑt saʊn pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli ɡɹeɪtfəl. ʃi dʒɹu hɝsɛlf ʌp tə hɝ fʊl haɪɾ ən lʊk stʃɹeɪɾ əhɛd, oʊvɝ kædzueɪnz hɛd ɹæðɝ ðən ət hɝ. "aɪ æm ʃʊɹ wi kən faɪn səm weɪ tə meɪk ðə dɛpθ ʌv əɹ ɡɹæɾətud noʊn bɪfɔɹ jə liv."

"We are grateful to you for bringing the Wavemistress here, Cadsuane Sedai." The First Counsel did not sound particularly grateful. She drew herself up to her full height and looked straight ahead, over Cadsuane's head rather than at her. "I am sure we can find some way to make the depth of our gratitude known before you leave."

ʃi kəd nɑɾ əv meɪɾ əɹ dɪsmɪsəl pleɪnɝ ʃɔɹɾ ʌv ə kəmænd, bʌt ði ɛɛs sədaɪ smaɪld ʌp ət ðə tɔlɝ wʊmən. ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ən ənplɛzən smaɪl, ɪɡzækli, bʌt niðɝ wɑz ɪɾ ɪn ðə list əmjuzd. "aɪ meɪ nɑt bi livɪŋ fəɹ ə waɪl, əlaɪz. aɪ θæŋk jə fəɹ ði ɔfɝ ʌv əkɑmədeɪʃənz, ən æksɛpt. ə pæləs ɑn ðə haɪts ɪz ɔlweɪz pɹɛfɝəbəl tə ivən ðə bɛst ɪn." ðə fɝs kaʊnsəlz aɪz waɪɾənd wɪð stɑɹɾəlmənt, ðən nɛɹoʊɾ ɪn dɪtɝməneɪʃən.

She could not have made her dismissal plainer short of a command, but the Aes Sedai smiled up at the taller woman. It was not an unpleasant smile, exactly, but neither was it in the least amused. "I may not be leaving for a while, Aleis. I thank you for the offer of accommodations, and accept. A palace on the Heights is always preferable to even the best inn." The First Counsel's eyes widened with startlement, then narrowed in determination.

"kædzueɪn mʌst steɪ wɪð mi," hɑɹɪn sɛd, mænɪdʒɪŋ tə saʊnd noʊ mɔɹ ðən hæf stʃɹæŋɡəld, bɪfɔɹ əlaɪz kəd spik. "wɛɹ ʃiz ənwɛlkəm, soʊ æm aɪ." ðɪs hæd bɪn pɑɹɾ ə ðə bɑɹɡən fɔɹst ɑn hɝ, ɪf ðeɪ wɝ tə əkʌmpəni kædzueɪn. əmʌŋ ʌðɝ θɪŋz ðeɪ mʌst ɡoʊ wən ən wɛɹ ʃi sɛɾ əntɪl ðeɪ dʒɔɪn ðə kɔɹəmʊɹ, ən ɪnkluɾ əɹ ɪn ɛni ɪnvɪteɪʃənz ðeɪ ɹəsivd. ðət læs hæd sim vɛɹi smɔl ət ðə taɪm, ɪspɛʃli weɪɾ əɡɛns ðə ɹɛst, bʌt pleɪnli ðə wʊmən hæd noʊn ɪɡzækli ðə ɹɪsɛpʃən ʃi wəd ɹəsiv.

"Cadsuane must stay with me," Harine said, managing to sound no more than half strangled, before Aleis could speak. "Where she is unwelcome, so am I." This had been part of the bargain forced on her, if they were to accompany Cadsuane. Among other things they must go when and where she said until they joined the Coramoor, and include her in any invitations they received. That last had seemed very small at the time, especially weighed against the rest, but plainly the woman had known exactly the reception she would receive.

"noʊ nid tə bi dɪshɑɹɾənd, əlaɪz." kædzueɪn lin təwɔɹd ðə fɝs kaʊnsəl kɑnfaɪɾɪŋli, bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt loʊɝ əɹ vɔɪs. ðə ɹɪvɝbɝeɪʃənz ɪn ðə doʊm mæɡnəfaɪɾ əɹ wɝdz. "aɪm ʃʊɹ jə noʊ lɔŋɡɝ əv ɛni bæd hæbəts fəɹ mi tə kɝɛkt."

"No need to be disheartened, Aleis." Cadsuane leaned toward the First Counsel confidingly, but she did not lower her voice. The reverberations in the dome magnified her words. "I'm sure you no longer have any bad habits for me to correct."

ðə fɝs kaʊnsəlz feɪs flʌɾəd wɪð kɹɪmzən, ən bɪhaɪn əɹ bæk, spɛkjələɾɪv fɹaʊnz pæs bɪtwin ði ʌðɝ kaʊnsəlz. səm kɑntəmpleɪɾɪd əɹ əz ɪf wɪð fɹɛʃ aɪz. haʊ dɪd ðeɪ əteɪn ɹæŋk, ən haʊ luz ɪt? bɪsaɪdz əlaɪz, ðeɪ wɝ twɛlv, ʃʊɹli ə koʊɪnsɪɾəns, bʌt ðə fɝs twɛlv əmʌŋ ə klænz seɪlməstʃɹɛsəz tʃoʊz ðə weɪvməstʃɹəs, juʒəwəli wʌn ə ðɛɹ oʊn nʌmbɝ, dʒʌst əz ðə fɝs twɛlv əmʌŋ ðə weɪvməstʃɹɛsəz tʃoʊz ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps. ðət wɑz waɪ hɑɹɪn hæɾ æksɛptɪd ðət stʃɹeɪnʒ ɡɝlz wɝdz, kəz ʃi wɑz ə ðə fɝs twɛlv. ðæt, ən ðə fæk ðət tu ɛɛs sədaɪ sɛd ðə ɡɝl sɔ tʃɹu vɪʒənz. eɪ weɪvməstʃɹəs əɹ ivən ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps kəd bi dɪpoʊzd, ðoʊ oʊnli fəɹ spɛsəfaɪd kɑzəz, sətʃ əz ɡɹoʊs ɪnkɑmpəɾəns əɹ luzɪŋ əɹ wɪts, ən ðə fɝs twɛlv hæd tə spik wɪð ə junænəməs vɔɪs. θɪŋz sim tə bi dʌn dɪfɹənli əmʌŋ ðə ʃɔɹbaʊnd, ən ɔfən slɑpəli. əlaɪz' aɪz, fɪks naʊ ɑn kædzueɪn, wɝ boʊθ heɪt-fɪld ən hʌntəd. pɝhæps ʃi kəd fil twɛlv sɛts ʌv aɪz ɑn əɹ bæk. ði ʌðɝ kaʊnsəlz hæɾ əɹ ɑn ðə skeɪlz. bʌɾ ɪf kædzueɪn hæd tʃoʊzən tə mɛɾəl ɪn ðə pɑlətɪks ə ðɪs pleɪs, waɪ? ən waɪ soʊ blʌnli?

The First Counsel's face flooded with crimson, and behind her back, speculative frowns passed between the other Counsels. Some contemplated her as if with fresh eyes. How did they attain rank, and how lose it? Besides Aleis, they were twelve, surely a coincidence, but the First Twelve among a clan's Sailmistresses chose the Wavemistress, usually one of their own number, just as the First Twelve among the Wavemistresses chose the Mistress of the Ships. That was why Harine had accepted that strange girl's words, because she was of the First Twelve. That, and the fact that two Aes Sedai said the girl saw true visions. A Wavemistress or even the Mistress of the Ships could be deposed, though only for specified causes, such as gross incompetence or losing her wits, and the First Twelve had to speak with a unanimous voice. Things seemed to be done differently among the shorebound, and often sloppily. Aleis' eyes, fixed now on Cadsuane, were both hate-filled and hunted. Perhaps she could feel twelve sets of eyes on her back. The other Counsels had her on the scales. But if Cadsuane had chosen to meddle in the politics of this place, why? And why so bluntly?

"ə mæn dʒʌs tʃænəld," vɛɹɪn sɛd sʌɾənli. ʃi hæd nɑt dʒɔɪn ðə ɹɛst ən wɑz piɹɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə ɹeɪl, tɛn peɪsɪz əweɪ. ðə doʊm meɪɾ əɹ vɔɪs kæɹi. "du juv mɛni mɛn tʃænəlɪŋ leɪtli, fɝs kaʊnsəl?"

"A man just channeled," Verin said suddenly. She had not joined the rest and was peering over the rail, ten paces away. The dome made her voice carry. "Do you have many men channeling lately, First Counsel?"

ʃələn lʊk daʊn, ən blɪŋkt. ðə fɔɹmɝli klɪɹ wɛdʒəz wɝ naʊ blæk, ən ɹæðɝ ðən pɔɪntɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə tʃeɪmbɝz hɑɹt, sʌmhaʊ ðeɪ hæd tɝn ɪn ɹʌfli ðə seɪm dɝɛkʃən. wʌn ə ðə wɪmən bɪloʊ wɑz ɑn əɹ fit, bɛndɪŋ oʊvɝ tə stʌɾi wɛɹ əlɔŋ ðə mɑɹkt kɑlɝ ðə θɪn blæk wɛdʒ wɑz pɔɪntɪŋ, ən ði ʌðɝ tu wɪmən wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi ɹeɪsɪŋ təwɔɹɾ ə ɹaʊnd-tɑp dɔɹweɪ. sʌɾənli, ʃələn nu. tʃɹaɪæŋɡjəleɪʃən wɑz ə sɪmpəl mæɾɝ tə ɛni wɪndfɪndɝ. sʌmwɛɹ bɪɑn ðət dɔɹweɪ wɑz ə tʃɑɹt, ən sun ðə pəzɪʃən wɛɹ ðə mæn hæd tʃænəld wəd bi mɑɹkt ɑn ɪt.

Shalon looked down, and blinked. The formerly clear wedges were now black, and rather than pointing toward the chamber's heart, somehow they had turned in roughly the same direction. One of the women below was on her feet, bending over to study where along the marked collar the thin black wedge was pointing, and the other two women were already racing toward a round-topped doorway. Suddenly, Shalon knew. Triangulation was a simple matter to any Windfinder. Somewhere beyond that doorway was a chart, and soon the position where the man had channeled would be marked on it.

"ɪt wəd bi ɹɛd fəɹ ə wʊmən, nɑt blæk," kʌmaɪɹə sɛɾ ɪn ɔlmoʊst ə wɪspɝ. ʃi stɪl stʊɾ ə lɪɾəl bæk fɹəm ðə ɹeɪl, bʌt ʃi wɑz ɡɹɪpɪŋ ɪt wɪð boʊθ hænz ən linɪŋ fɔɹwɝd tə pɪɹ ət ðə sin bɪloʊ. "ɪt wɔɹnz ən loʊkeɪts ən dɪfɛnz. ən wʌɾ ɛls? ðə wɪmən u meɪɾ ɪt wʊɾə wɑntəd mɔɹ, pɝhæps niɾəd mɔɹ. nɑt noʊɪŋ wʌɾ ɛls kəd bi ɪnkɹɛɾəbli deɪnʒɝəs." ʃi dɪd nɑt saʊn fɹaɪɾənd, ðoʊ. ʃi saʊndəɾ ɪksaɪɾəd.

"It would be red for a woman, not black," Kumira said in almost a whisper. She still stood a little back from the rail, but she was gripping it with both hands and leaning forward to peer at the scene below. "It warns and locates and defends. And what else? The women who made it would have wanted more, perhaps needed more. Not knowing what else could be incredibly dangerous." She did not sound frightened, though. She sounded excited.

"æn æʃəmən, aɪ ɪkspɛkt," əlaɪz sɛd kɑmli, pʊlɪŋ əɹ ɡeɪz fɹəm kædzueɪn. "ðeɪ kænɑt tʃɹʌbəl ʌs. ðeɪ ɑɹ fɹi tə ɛntɝ ðə sɪɾi, soʊ lɔŋ əz ðeɪ oʊbeɪ ðə lɔ." haʊɛvɝ kɑm ʃi wɑz, səm ə ðə wɪmən bɪhaɪn əɹ tɪɾɝd laɪk nu dɛkɡɝlz ðɛɹ fɝs taɪm əmʌŋ ðə ʃɔɹbaʊnd. "fɝɡɪv mi, ɛɛs sədaɪ. fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ ɡɪvz jə wɛlkəm. aɪm əfɹeɪɾ aɪ doʊnt noʊ jəɹ neɪm, ðoʊ."

"An Asha'man, I expect," Aleis said calmly, pulling her gaze from Cadsuane. "They cannot trouble us. They are free to enter the city, so long as they obey the law." However calm she was, some of the women behind her tittered like new deckgirls their first time among the shorebound. "Forgive me, Aes Sedai. Far Madding gives you welcome. I am afraid I don't know your name, though."

vɛɹɪn wɑz stɪl ɡeɪzɪŋ daʊn ət ðə doʊmz flɔɹ. ʃələn ɡlænst oʊvɝ ðə ɹeɪl əɡɛn, ən blɪŋkt əz ðə θɪn blæk wɛdʒəz . . . tʃeɪnʒd. wʌn moʊmən ðeɪ wɝ blæk ən pɔɪntɪŋ nɔɹθ, ðə nɛks klɪɹ ən wʌns əɡɛn pɔɪntɪŋ tə ðə sɛntɝ ə ðə meɪz. ðeɪ dɪd nɑt tɝn; ðeɪ dʒʌst wɝ wʌn θɪŋ, ðən ði ʌðɝ.

Verin was still gazing down at the dome's floor. Shalon glanced over the rail again, and blinked as the thin black wedges . . . changed. One moment they were black and pointing north, the next clear and once again pointing to the center of the maze. They did not turn; they just were one thing, then the other.

"ɔl ə jə meɪ kɔl mi idwinə," vɛɹɪn sɛd. ʃələn bɛɹli səpɹɛst ə stɑɹt. kʌmaɪɹə dɪd nɑt soʊ mʌtʃ əz blɪŋk. "du jə kənsɪɾɝ hɪstɝi, fɝs kaʊnsəl?" vɛɹɪn kəntɪnjud wɪθaʊt lʊkɪŋ ʌp. "ɡɛɹ əmɑlɑsənz sidʒ ə fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ læstəd dʒʌs θɹi wiks. ə sævədʒ bɪznəs, ət ði ɛnd."

"All of you may call me Eadwina," Verin said. Shalon barely suppressed a start. Kumira did not so much as blink. "Do you consider history, First Counsel?" Verin continued without looking up. "Guaire Amalasan's siege of Far Madding lasted just three weeks. A savage business, at the end."

"aɪ daʊt ðeɪ wɑnə hɪɹ əbaʊt hɪm," kædzueɪn sɛd ʃɑɹpli, ən ɪndid, fəɹ səm ɹizən mɔɹ ðən wʌn ə ðə kaʊnsəlz lʊkt ənkʌmftəɹbəl. hu ɪn ðə laɪt wɑz ðɪs ɡɛɹ əmɑlɑsən? ðə neɪm saʊndəd veɪɡli fəmɪljɝ, bʌt ʃələn kəd nɑt pleɪs ɪt. səm ʃɔɹbaʊn kɑŋkɝɝ, ɑbviəsli.

"I doubt they want to hear about him," Cadsuane said sharply, and indeed, for some reason more than one of the Counsels looked uncomfortable. Who in the Light was this Guaire Amalasan? The name sounded vaguely familiar, but Shalon could not place it. Some shorebound conqueror, obviously.

əlaɪz ɡlænst ət kædzueɪn, ən əɹ maʊθ taɪɾənd. "hɪstɝi ɹɛkɝdz ɡɛɹ əmɑlɑsən əz ə ɹɪmɑɹkəbəl dʒɛnɝəl, idwinə sədaɪ, pɝhæps sɛkən oʊnli tə ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ hɪmsɛlf. wʌt bɹɪŋz ɪm tə maɪnd?"

Aleis glanced at Cadsuane, and her mouth tightened. "History records Guaire Amalasan as a remarkable general, Eadwina Sedai, perhaps second only to Artur Hawkwing himself. What brings him to mind?"

ʃələn hæd nɛvɝ sin wʌn ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ tʃɹævlɪŋ wɪð kædzueɪn feɪl tə hiɾ əɹ moʊs kæʒəwəl wɔɹnɪŋ əz kwɪkli əz ðeɪ oʊbeɪɾ əɹ kəmænz, bʌt vɛɹɪn peɪd noʊ hid ðɪs taɪm. ʃi dɪd nɑt lʊk ʌp. "aɪ wɑz dʒʌs θɪŋkɪŋ ðəɾ i kʊdn juz ðə paʊɝ, jɛɾ i kɹʌʃt fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ laɪk ən oʊvɝɹaɪp plʌm." ðə staʊt lɪɾəl ɛɛs sədaɪ pɔzd əz ðoʊ sʌmθɪŋ hæd dʒʌst əkɝd tə hɝ. "ju noʊ, ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn əz ɑɹmiz ɪn ɪljən ən tiɹ, ɪn ændɝ ən kɛɹhin. nɑt tə mɛnʃən mɛni tɛnz ə θaʊzənz ʌv il. vɛɹi fɪɹs, ði il. aɪ wʌndɝ jə kən bi soʊ kəmpleɪsən əbaʊɾ ɪz æʃəmən skaʊɾɪŋ ju."

Shalon had never seen one of the Aes Sedai traveling with Cadsuane fail to heed her most casual warning as quickly as they obeyed her commands, but Verin paid no heed this time. She did not look up. "I was just thinking that he couldn't use the Power, yet he crushed Far Madding like an overripe plum." The stout little Aes Sedai paused as though something had just occurred to her. "You know, the Dragon Reborn has armies in Illian and Tear, in Andor and Cairhien. Not to mention many tens of thousands of Aiel. Very fierce, the Aiel. I wonder you can be so complacent about his Asha'man scouting you."

"aɪ θɪŋk juv fɹaɪɾənd əm kwaɪɾ ɪnʌf," kædzueɪn sɛd fɝmli.

"I think you have frightened them quite enough," Cadsuane said firmly.

vɛɹɪn faɪnəli tɝn fɹəm ðə ɡɪldɪd ɹeɪl, hɝ aɪz oʊpən vɛɹi waɪd, ə ɹaʊnd, stɑɹɾəld ʃɔɹbɝd. hɝ plʌmp hænz ivən flʌɾɝd laɪk wɪŋz. "oʊ. aɪ dɪdn min . . . oʊ, noʊ. aɪ wəd θɪŋk ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn wʊɾə muvd əɡɛns jə ɔlɹɛɾi ɪf i ɪntɛndəd tə. noʊ, aɪ səspɛk ðə sintʃæn . . . juv hɝɾ ə ðɛm? wʌt wi hɪɹ fɹəm ɔltɑɹə ən fɑɹðɝ wɛst ɪz ɹɪli kwaɪt hɔɹəbəl. ðeɪ sim tə swip ɛvɹiθɪŋ bɪfɔɹ ðɛm. noʊ, aɪ səspɛk ðəɹ sʌmwʌt mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt tə hɪz plænz ðən kæptʃɝɪŋ fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ. ənlɛs jə də sʌmθɪŋ tə æŋɡɝ hɪm, ʌv kɔɹs, əɹ əpsɛɾ ɪz fɑloʊɝz. bʌɾ aɪm ʃʊɹ jə ɑɹ tu ɪntɛlədʒən tə də ðæt." ʃi lʊk vɛɹi ɪnəsənt. ðəɹ wɑz ə stɝ əmʌŋ ðə kaʊnsəlz, ðə ɹɪpəl ðət smɔl fɪʃ meɪɾ ɑn ðə sɝfəs wən ə laɪənfɪʃ swæm bɪloʊ.

Verin finally turned from the gilded rail, her eyes open very wide, a round, startled shorebird. Her plump hands even fluttered like wings. "Oh. I didn't mean . . . Oh, no. I would think the Dragon Reborn would have moved against you already if he intended to. No, I suspect the Seanchan . . . You've heard of them? What we hear from Altara and farther west is really quite horrible. They seem to sweep everything before them. No, I suspect they're somewhat more important to his plans than capturing Far Madding. Unless you do something to anger him, of course, or upset his followers. But I am sure you are too intelligent to do that." She looked very innocent. There was a stir among the Counsels, the ripple that small fish made on the surface when a lionfish swam below.

kædzueɪn saɪd, hɝ peɪʃəns klɪɹli əɾ ən ɛnd. "ɪf jə wɑnə dɪskʌs ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, idwinə, jə mʌs də soʊ wɪθaʊt mi. aɪ wɑnə wɑʃ maɪ feɪs ən əv səm hɑt ti."

Cadsuane sighed, her patience clearly at an end. "If you want to discuss the Dragon Reborn, Eadwina, you must do so without me. I want to wash my face and have some hot tea."

ðə fɝs kaʊnsəl dʒɝkt əz ðoʊ ʃi hæd fɝɡɑɾən kædzueɪnz ɛɡzɪstəns, ɪnkɹɛɾəbəl əz ðət simd. "jɛs. jɛs, ʌv kɔɹs. kmɪɹ, nɑɹveɪ, wəd jə pliz ɛskɔɹt ðə weɪvməstʃɹəs ən kædzueɪn sədaɪ tə . . . tə maɪ pæləs ən meɪk əm wɛlkəm?" ðət slaɪt hɪtʃ wɑz ði oʊnli saɪn ʃi ɡeɪv ə dɪskʌmfɝɾ ət hævɪŋ kædzueɪn ɪn əɹ dwɛlɪŋ. "aɪ wɪʃ tə hæv səm fɝðɝ tɔk wɪð idwinə sədaɪ, ɪf ɪt plizɪz hɝ." fɑloʊd baɪ moʊst ə ðə kaʊnsəlz, əlaɪz ɡlaɪɾɪd əweɪ əlɔŋ ðə bælkəni. vɛɹɪn lʊk sʌɾənli əlɑɹmd ən ənsɝɾən əz ðeɪ ɡæðɝɾ əɹ ʌp ən swɛpt əɹ əlɔŋ. ʃələn dɪd nɑt bɪliv ðə sɝpɹaɪz əɹ əniz ɛni mɔɹ ðən ʃi hæd ði ɝliɝ ɪnəsəns. ʃi θɔt ʃi nu naʊ wɛɹ dʒɑhɹ wɑz. ʃi dʒʌs dɪd nɑt noʊ waɪ.

The First Counsel jerked as though she had forgotten Cadsuane's existence, incredible as that seemed. "Yes. Yes, of course. Cumere, Narvais, would you please escort the Wavemistress and Cadsuane Sedai to . . . to my palace and make them welcome?" That slight hitch was the only sign she gave of discomfort at having Cadsuane in her dwelling. "I wish to have some further talk with Eadwina Sedai, if it pleases her." Followed by most of the Counsels, Aleis glided away along the balcony. Verin looked suddenly alarmed and uncertain as they gathered her up and swept her along. Shalon did not believe the surprise or unease any more than she had the earlier innocence. She thought she knew now where Jahar was. She just did not know why.

ðə wɪmən əlaɪz hæd neɪmd, ðə pɹɪɾi wʌn u hæd skaʊld ət kædzueɪn, ən ə slɪm ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd wʊmən, tʊk ðə fɝs kaʊnsəlz ɹɪkwɛst əz ə kəmænd, wɪtʃ pɝhæps ɪt wɑz. ðeɪ spɹɛd ðɛɹ ɹoʊbz ən meɪd ðoʊz hæf baʊz, æskɪŋ hɑɹɪn wɛðɝ ʃi wəd bi pliz tə əkʌmpəni ðɛm ən ənaʊnsɪŋ ɪn flaʊɝi tɝmz ðɛɹ plɛʒɝ əɾ ɛskɔɹɾɪŋ hɝ. hɑɹɪn lɪsənd wɪð ə saʊɝ feɪs. ðeɪ kəd stʃɹu bæskəts ə ɹoʊz pɛɾəlz ɪn əɹ pæθ ɪf ðeɪ wɪʃt, bʌt ðə fɝs kaʊnsəl hæd lɛft əɹ tə ʌndɝlɪŋz. ʃələn wʌndɝd wɛðɝ ðəɹ wɑz ɛni weɪ tə əvɔɪɾ əɹ sɪstɝ əntɪl əɹ tɛmpɝ kuld.

The women Aleis had named, the pretty one who had scowled at Cadsuane, and a slim gray-haired woman, took the First Counsel's request as a command, which perhaps it was. They spread their robes and made those half bows, asking Harine whether she would be pleased to accompany them and announcing in flowery terms their pleasure at escorting her. Harine listened with a sour face. They could strew baskets of rose petals in her path if they wished, but the First Counsel had left her to underlings. Shalon wondered whether there was any way to avoid her sister until her temper cooled.

kædzueɪn dɪd nɑt wɑtʃ vɛɹɪn liv wɪð əlaɪz, nɑɾ oʊpənli, bʌɾ əɹ maʊθ kɝvd ɪn ə feɪn smaɪl wən ðeɪ vænɪʃt θɹu ðə nɛkst ɑɹtʃt dɔɹweɪ əlɔŋ ðə bælkəni. "kmɪɹ ən nɑɹveɪ," ʃi sɛɾ əbɹʌpli. "ðæt wəd bi kmɪɹ paʊiz ən nɑɹveɪ mæzlɪn? aɪ hæv hɝd θɪŋz əbaʊt ju." ðət dʒɝk ðɛɹ ətɛnʃən əweɪ fɹəm hɑɹɪn. "ðɛɹ ɑɹ stændɝdz ɛni kaʊnsəl ʃəd mit," kædzueɪn wɛn ɑn ɪn ə fɝm toʊn, teɪkɪŋ əm itʃ baɪ ə sliv ən tɝnɪŋ əm təwɔɹd ðə stɛɹz ɑn iðɝ saɪɾ ə hɝ. ɪkstʃeɪnʒɪŋ wɝid ɡlænsɪz, ðeɪ lɛt hɝ, hɑɹɪn əpɛɹənli kwaɪt fɝɡɑɾən. ət ðə dɔɹweɪ, kædzueɪn pɔz tə lʊk bæk, bʌt nɑɾ ət hɑɹɪn əɹ ʃələn. "kʌmaɪɹə? kʌmaɪɹə!"

Cadsuane did not watch Verin leave with Aleis, not openly, but her mouth curved in a faint smile when they vanished through the next arched doorway along the balcony. "Cumere and Narvais," she said abruptly. "That would be Cumere Powys and Narvais Maslin? I have heard things about you." That jerked their attention away from Harine. "There are standards any Counsel should meet," Cadsuane went on in a firm tone, taking them each by a sleeve and turning them toward the stairs on either side of her. Exchanging worried glances, they let her, Harine apparently quite forgotten. At the doorway, Cadsuane paused to look back, but not at Harine or Shalon. "Kumira? Kumira!"

ði ʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt, ən wɪð ə læs lɪŋɡɝɪŋ lʊk oʊvɝ ðə ɹeɪlɪŋ, pʊl hɝsɛlf əweɪ tə fɑloʊ kædzueɪn. wɪtʃ lɛf hɑɹɪn ən ʃələn noʊ ɑpʃən ɪksɛp tə fɑloʊ, tu, əɹ bi lɛf tə tʃɹaɪ faɪndɪŋ ðɛɹ oʊn weɪ aʊt. ʃələn dɑɹɾɪd æftɝ ði ʌðɝz, ən hɑɹɪn wɑz noʊ lɛs kwɪk. stɪl ɡɹɪpɪŋ ðə kaʊnsəlz tə hɝ saɪdz, kædzueɪn lɛd ðə weɪ daʊn ðə kɝlɪŋ stɛɹz, tɔkɪŋ ɪn ə loʊ vɔɪs. wɪð kʌmaɪɹə bɪtwin əɹ ən ðə θɹi, ʃələn kəd hɪɹ nʌθɪŋ. kmɪɹ ən nɑɹveɪ tʃɹaɪd tə spik, bʌt kædzueɪn əlaʊd niðɝ mɔɹ ðən ə fju wɝdz bɪfɔɹ ʃi bɪɡæn əɡɛn. ʃi sim kɑm, mæɾɝ-ʌv-fækt. ðə pɛɹ wɪð əɹ bɪɡæn tə lʊk æŋkʃəs. wʌɾ ɪn ðə laɪt wɑz kædzueɪn ʌp tə?

The other Aes Sedai gave a start, and with a last lingering look over the railing, pulled herself away to follow Cadsuane. Which left Harine and Shalon no option except to follow, too, or be left to try finding their own way out. Shalon darted after the others, and Harine was no less quick. Still gripping the Counsels to her sides, Cadsuane led the way down the curling stairs, talking in a low voice. With Kumira between her and the three, Shalon could hear nothing. Cumere and Narvais tried to speak, but Cadsuane allowed neither more than a few words before she began again. She seemed calm, matter-of-fact. The pair with her began to look anxious. What in the Light was Cadsuane up to?

"ðɪs pleɪs tʃɹʌbəlz ju?" hɑɹɪn sɛd sʌɾənli.

"This place troubles you?" Harine said suddenly.

"ɪɾ ɪz əz ɪf aɪ hæv lɔs maɪ aɪz." ʃələn ʃɪvɝɾ ət ðə tʃɹuθ ə ðæt. "aɪ æm əfɹeɪd, weɪvməstʃɹəs, bʌt ðə laɪt wɪlɪŋ, aɪ kən kəntʃɹoʊl maɪ fɪɹ." laɪt, ʃi hoʊpt ʃi kʊd. ʃi dɛspɝətli niɾəd tə.

"It is as if I have lost my eyes." Shalon shivered at the truth of that. "I am afraid, Wavemistress, but the Light willing, I can control my fear." Light, she hoped she could. She desperately needed to.

hɑɹɪn nɑɾəd, fɹaʊnɪŋ ət ðə wɪmən əhɛɾ ə ðɛm daʊn ðə stɛɹz. "aɪ də nɑt noʊ wɛðɝ əlaɪz' pæləs əz ə tʌb bɪɡ ɪnʌf fəɹ əs tə beɪð təɡɛðɝ, ən aɪ daʊt ðeɪ noʊ hʌnid waɪn, bʌt wɪl faɪn sʌmθɪŋ." ɡlænsɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm kædzueɪn ən ði ʌðɝz, ʃi tʌtʃt ʃələnz ɑɹm ɔkwɝdli. "aɪ wɑz əfɹeɪɾ ə ðə dɑɹk wən aɪ wɑz ə tʃaɪld, ən jə nɛvɝ lɛf mi əloʊn tɪl ðə fɪɹ pæst. əl nɑt liv jə əloʊn, iðɝ, ʃələn."

Harine nodded, frowning at the women ahead of them down the stairs. "I do not know whether Aleis' palace has a tub big enough for us to bathe together, and I doubt they know honeyed wine, but we will find something." Glancing away from Cadsuane and the others, she touched Shalon's arm awkwardly. "I was afraid of the dark when I was a child, and you never left me alone till the fear passed. I will not leave you alone, either, Shalon."

ʃələn mɪst ə stɛp ən bɛɹli kɑt hɝsɛlf ʃɔɹɾ ə tʌmbəlɪŋ daʊn hɛɾ oʊvɝ hilz. hɑɹɪn hæd nɑt juzd əɹ neɪm ɪksɛpt ɪn pɹaɪvət sɪns ʃi wɑz fɝs meɪd seɪlməstʃɹəs. ʃi hæd nɑt bɪn ðɪs fɹɛnli ɪn pɹaɪvət sɪns bɪfɔɹ ðæt. "θæŋk ju," ʃi sɛd, ən wɪð ən ɛfɝt, æɾəd, "hɑɹɪn." hɝ sɪstɝ pæɾəd əɹ ɑɹm əɡɛn, ən smaɪld. hɑɹɪn wɑz ʌnpɹæktəst ət smaɪlɪŋ, bʌt ði ɑkwɝɾ ɛfɝt hɛld wɔɹmθ.

Shalon missed a step and barely caught herself short of tumbling down head over heels. Harine had not used her name except in private since she was first made Sailmistress. She had not been this friendly in private since before that. "Thank you," she said, and with an effort, added, "Harine." Her sister patted her arm again, and smiled. Harine was unpracticed at smiling, but the awkward effort held warmth.

ðəɹ wɑz noʊ wɔɹmθ ɪn ðə lʊk ʃi dɝɛktəd təwɔɹd ðə wɪmən əhɛd, ðoʊ. "pɝhæps aɪ tʃɹuli kən meɪk ə bɑɹɡən hɪɹ. kædzueɪn əz ɔlɹɛɾi ʃɪftəd ðɛɹ bæləst soʊ ðeɪ ɹaɪd wɪð ə lɪst. jə mʌs tʃɹaɪ tə faɪn aʊt waɪ, ʃələn, wən jə ɡɛt kloʊs tə hɝ. aɪ wəd laɪk tə pʊɾ əlaɪz' aɪtiθ ɑn ə stʃɹɪŋ - wɔkɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm mi wɪθaʊt soʊ mʌtʃ əz ə wɝd! - bʌt nɑɾ ət ði ɪkspɛns ə lɛɾɪŋ kædzueɪn mɛʃ ðə kɔɹəmʊɹ ɪn səm tʃɹʌbəl hɪɹ. jə mʌs faɪn aʊt, ʃələn."

There was no warmth in the look she directed toward the women ahead, though. "Perhaps I truly can make a bargain here. Cadsuane has already shifted their ballast so they ride with a list. You must try to find out why, Shalon, when you get close to her. I would like to put Aleis' eyeteeth on a string - walking away from me without so much as a word! - but not at the expense of letting Cadsuane mesh the Coramoor in some trouble here. You must find out, Shalon."

"aɪ θɪŋk pɝhæps kædzueɪn mɛɾəlz ðə weɪ ɛniwʌn ɛls bɹiðz," ʃələn ɹɪplaɪd wɪð ə saɪ, "bʌɾ əl tʃɹaɪ, hɑɹɪn. əl də maɪ bɛst."

"I think perhaps Cadsuane meddles the way anyone else breathes," Shalon replied with a sigh, "but I will try, Harine. I will do my best."

"ju ɔlweɪz hæv, sɪstɝ. jə ɔlweɪz wɪl. aɪ noʊ ðæt."

"You always have, sister. You always will. I know that."

ʃələn saɪɾ əɡɛn. ɪt wɑz mʌtʃ tu sun tə tɛs ðə dɛpθ ə hɝ sɪstɝz nufaʊnd wɔɹmθ. kənfɛʃən maɪt bɹɪŋ æbsəluʃən əɹ nɑt, ən ʃi kəd nɑt lɪv wɪð ðə lɔs ə hɝ mɛɹɪdʒ ən əɹ ɹæŋk ət wʌn bloʊ. bʌt fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm sɪns vɛɹɪn hæd blʌnli leɪɾ aʊt kædzueɪnz tɝmz fəɹ kipɪŋ əɹ sikɹət, ʃələn bɪɡæn tə kənsɪɾɝ kənfɛʃən.

Shalon sighed again. It was much too soon to test the depth of her sister's newfound warmth. Confession might bring absolution or not, and she could not live with the loss of her marriage and her rank at one blow. But for the first time since Verin had bluntly laid out Cadsuane's terms for keeping her secret, Shalon began to consider confession.


tʃæptɝ twɛntifaɪv


CHAPTER 25

bɑnz


Bonds

ɪn ɪz ɹum ət ðə kaʊnsəlz hɛd, ɹænd sæɾ ɑn ðə bɛd wɪð ɪz lɛɡz foʊldəɾ ən ɪz bæk əɡɛns ðə wɔl, pleɪɪŋ ðə sɪlvɝ-maʊntəd flut tɑm mɛɹɪlɪn hæd ɡɪvən ɪm soʊ lɔŋ əɡoʊ. ən eɪdʒ əɡoʊ. ðɪs ɹum, wɪð kɑɹvd wɔl pænəlz ən wɪndoʊz oʊvɝlʊkɪŋ ðə nɛθvɪn mɑɹkət, wɑz bɛɾɝ ðən ðət ðeɪ hæɾ əbændən ət ðə kɹaʊn ə mɑɹeɪɾoʊ. ðə pɪloʊz stæk bɪsaɪɾ ɪm wɝ ɡus daʊn, ðə bɛd hæɾ ən ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd kænəpi ən kɝɾənz, ən ðə mɪɹɝ əbʌv ðə wɑʃstæn hæd nɑɾ ə sɪŋɡəl bʌbəl. ðə lɪntəl əbʌv ðə stoʊn faɪɝpleɪs ivən hæɾ ə bɪɾ ə sɪmpəl kɑɹvɪŋ. ɪt wɑz ə ɹum fəɹ ə wɛl-tə-du fɔɹən mɝtʃənt. hi wɑz ɡlæɾ i hæd θɔt tə bɹɪŋ ɪnʌf ɡoʊld wən i lɛf kɛɹhin. hi hæd lɔs ðə hæbəɾ ə kæɹiɪŋ mʌtʃ. ɛvɹiθɪŋ hæd bɪn pɹəvaɪɾəd fəɹ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. stɪl, hi cʊɾə ɝn ə bɛɾ ə səm sɔɹt wɪð ðə flut. ðə tun wɑz kɔld "ləmɛn fəɹ ðə lɔŋ naɪt," ən i hæd nɛvɝ hɝɾ ɪt bɪfɔɹ ɪn ɪz laɪf. luz θɝɪn hæd, ðoʊ. ɪt wɑz laɪk ðə skɪl ət dʒɹɔɪŋ. ɹænd θɔt ðət ʃəd fɹaɪɾən hɪm, əɹ meɪk ɪm æŋɡɹi, bʌɾ i sɪmpli sæɾ ən pleɪd waɪl luz θɝɪn wɛpt.

In his room at The Counsel's Head, Rand sat on the bed with his legs folded and his back against the wall, playing the silver-mounted flute Thom Merrilin had given him so long ago. An Age ago. This room, with carved wall panels and windows overlooking the Nethvin Market, was better than that they had abandoned at The Crown of Maredo. The pillows stacked beside him were goose down, the bed had an embroidered canopy and curtains, and the mirror above the washstand had not a single bubble. The lintel above the stone fireplace even had a bit of simple carving. It was a room for a well-to-do foreign merchant. He was glad he had thought to bring enough gold when he left Cairhien. He had lost the habit of carrying much. Everything had been provided for the Dragon Reborn. Still, he could have earned a bed of some sort with the flute. The tune was called "Lament for the Long Night," and he had never heard it before in his life. Lews Therin had, though. It was like the skill at drawing. Rand thought that should frighten him, or make him angry, but he simply sat and played while Lews Therin wept.

"laɪt, ɹænd," mɪn mʌɾɝd, "ɑɹ jə dʒʌs gɑnə sɪt ðəɹ pʌfɪŋ ɑn ðət θɪŋ?" hɝ skɝts swɝld əz ʃi peɪst ʌp ən daʊn ðə flaʊɝd kɑɹpət. ðə bɑnd wɪð əɹ ən ɪleɪn ən eɪvinhə fɛlt əz ðoʊ hi hæd nɛvɝ noʊn ɛniθɪŋ ɛls əɹ wɑntəd tə. hi bɹiðd, ən i wɑz bɑndəd tə ðɛm; wʌn wɑz əz nætʃɹəl əz ði ʌðɝ. "ɪf ʃi sɛz wʌn ɹɔŋ wɝd wɛɹ ɪt kən bi oʊvɝhɝd, ɪf ʃiz ɔlɹɛɾi sɛɾ ɪt . . . aɪm nɑt lɛɾɪŋ ɛniwʌn, hɔl jə ɔf tə ə sɛl fəɹ ɪleɪɾə!" ɑlɑnəz bɑn hæd nɛvɝ fɛl ðət weɪ. ɪt hæd nɑt tʃeɪnʒd, nɑɾ ɪn ɪtsɛlf, jɛɾ ɪnkɹisɪŋli sɪns ðət deɪ ɪn keɪɛmlɪn, ɑlɑnəz bɑn simd ən ɪntʃɹuʒən, ə stʃɹeɪnʒɝ lʊkɪŋ oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ, ə sændspɝ ɪn ɪz but. "du juv tə pleɪ ðæt? ɪt meɪks mi wɑnə kɹaɪ, ən ɪt meɪks maɪ skɪn kɹɔl ət ðə seɪm taɪm. ɪf ʃi pʊts jə ɪn deɪnʒɝ . . . !" snætʃɪŋ wʌn ə hɝ naɪvz fɹəm ɪts haɪɾɪŋ pleɪs ʌp ə lus-fɪɾɪŋ sliv, ʃi flɝɪʃt ɪɾ ɪn əɹ fɪst.

"Light, Rand," Min muttered, "are you just going to sit there puffing on that thing?" Her skirts swirled as she paced up and down the flowered carpet. The bond with her and Elayne and Aviendha felt as though he had never known anything else or wanted to. He breathed, and he was bonded to them; one was as natural as the other. "If she says one wrong word where it can be overheard, if she's already said it . . . I am not letting anyone, haul you off to a cell for Elaida!" Alanna's bond had never felt that way. It had not changed, not in itself, yet increasingly since that day in Caemlyn, Alanna's bond seemed an intrusion, a stranger looking over his shoulder, a sandspur in his boot. "Do you have to play that? It makes me want to cry, and it makes my skin crawl at the same time. If she puts you in danger . . . !" Snatching one of her knives from its hiding place up a loose-fitting sleeve, she flourished it in her fist.

hi tʊk ðə fluɾ əweɪ fɹəm ɪz maʊθ ən saɪlənli lʊkt əɾ əɹ oʊvɝ ɪt. hɝ feɪs ɹɛɾənd, ən wɪð ə sʌɾən snɑɹl, ʃi hɝl ðə bleɪd tə stɪk kwɪvɝɪŋ ɪn ðə dɔɹ.

He took the flute away from his mouth and silently looked at her over it. Her face reddened, and with a sudden snarl, she hurled the blade to stick quivering in the door.

"ʃiz ðɛɹ," hi sɛd, juzɪŋ ðə flut tə pɔɪnt. ʌnkɑnʃəsli, hi ʃɪftəd ði ɪnstʃɹəmənt, fɑloʊɪŋ ɑlɑnə ɪɡzækli. "ʃil bi hɪɹ sun." ʃi hæd bɪn ɪn fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ sɪns ðə deɪ bɪfɔɹ, ən i dɪd nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd waɪ ʃi hæd weɪɾəd tɪl naʊ. ɑlɑnə wɑz ə tæŋɡəl ʌv ɪmoʊʃənz ɪnsaɪɾ ɪz skʌl, nɝvəs ən wɛɹi, wɝiɾ ən dɪtɝmən ən əbʌv ɔl, æŋɡɹi. ɪn ə bɛɹli ɹistʃɹeɪn fjʊɹi. "ɪf jud ɹæðɝ nɑt bi hɪɹ, jə kən weɪt. . . ." mɪn ʃʊk əɹ hɛd fɪɹsli. ɹaɪt bɪsaɪɾ ɑlɑnə ɪn ɪz hɛd leɪ ðə bʌndəl ðət wɑz hɝ. ʃi bʌbəld wɪð wɝi ən æŋɡɝ, tu, bʌt lʌv ʃoʊn θɹu laɪk ə bikən wɛnɛvɝ ʃi lʊkt əɾ ɪm ən ɔfən wən ʃi dɪd nɑt. fɪɹ ʃoʊn θɹu, əz wɛl, ðoʊ ʃi wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə haɪd ðæt.

"She's there," he said, using the flute to point. Unconsciously, he shifted the instrument, following Alanna exactly. "She'll be here soon." She had been in Far Madding since the day before, and he did not understand why she had waited till now. Alanna was a tangle of emotions inside his skull, nervous and wary, worried and determined and above all, angry. In a barely restrained fury. "If you'd rather not be here, you can wait. . . ." Min shook her head fiercely. Right beside Alanna in his head lay the bundle that was her. She bubbled with worry and anger, too, but love shone through like a beacon whenever she looked at him and often when she did not. Fear shone through, as well, though she was trying to hide that.

hi pʊt ðə flut bæk tə hɪz lɪps ən bɪɡæn "ðə dʒɹʌŋkən pɛdlɝ." ðət wɑz dʒɑli ɪnʌf tə tʃɪɹ ðə dɛd. luz θɝɪn snɑɹəld ət hɪm.

He put the flute back to his lips and began "The Drunken Peddler." That was jolly enough to cheer the dead. Lews Therin snarled at him.

mɪn stʊd stʌɾiɪŋ hɪm, hɝ ɑɹmz foʊldəd, ðən əbɹʌpli ɡeɪv əɹ dʒɹɛs ə twɪtʃ, sɛɾəlɪŋ ɪɾ ɑn əɹ hɪps. wɪð ə saɪ, hi loʊɝd ðə fluɾ ən weɪɾəd. wən ə wʊmən ədʒʌstəɾ əɹ kloʊðz fəɹ noʊ ɹizən, ɪt wɑz laɪk ə mæn taɪɾənɪŋ ðə stʃɹæps ə hɪz ɑɹmɝ ən tʃɛkɪŋ ɪz sæɾəl ɡɝθ; ʃi mɛn tə dʒɹaɪv hoʊm ə tʃɑɹdʒ, ən jə wəd bi kʌt daʊn laɪk ə dɔɡ ɪf jə ɹæn. dɪtɝməneɪʃən wɑz əz stʃɹɔŋ ɪn mɪn naʊ əz ɪt wɑz ɪn ɑlɑnə, twɪn sʌnz flɛɹɪŋ ɪn ðə bæk ə hɪz bɹeɪn.

Min stood studying him, her arms folded, then abruptly gave her dress a twitch, settling it on her hips. With a sigh, he lowered the flute and waited. When a woman adjusted her clothes for no reason, it was like a man tightening the straps of his armor and checking his saddle girth; she meant to drive home a charge, and you would be cut down like a dog if you ran. Determination was as strong in Min now as it was in Alanna, twin suns flaring in the back of his brain.

"wi wɪl nɑt tɔk əbaʊɾ ɑlɑnə ɛni mɔɹ əntɪl ʃi ɡɛts hɪɹ," ʃi sɛd fɝmli, əz ðoʊ hi hæd bɪn ðə wʌn ɪnsɪstɪŋ. dɪtɝməneɪʃən, ən stɪl ðə fɪɹ, stʃɹɔŋɝ naʊ ðən bɪfɔɹ, kəntɪnjuəli tʃɹæmpəl daʊn ən kəntɪnjuəli spɹɪŋɪŋ bæk ʌp.

"We will not talk about Alanna any more until she gets here," she said firmly, as though he had been the one insisting. Determination, and still the fear, stronger now than before, continually trampled down and continually springing back up.

"waɪ, ʌv kɔɹs, waɪf, ɪf ɪt plizɪz ju," hi ɹɪplaɪd, bɛndɪŋ ɪz nɛk ɪn ði əpɹuv fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ fæʃən. ʃi snɪf laʊdli.

"Why, of course, wife, if it pleases you," he replied, bending his neck in the approved Far Madding fashion. She sniffed loudly.

"ɹænd, aɪ laɪk əliviə. aɪ du, ivən ɪf ʃi dʌz meɪk nɪneɪiv əv kɪɾənz lɛft ən ɹaɪt." wʌn fɪs plæntəɾ ɑn əɹ hɪp, mɪn lin fɔɹwɝɾ ən pɔɪntəɾ ə fɪŋɡɝ əɾ ɪz noʊz. "bʌt ʃiz gɑnə kɪl ju." ʃi bɪɾ ɔf ɛvɹi wɝd.

"Rand, I like Alivia. I do, even if she does make Nynaeve have kittens left and right." One fist planted on her hip, Min leaned forward and pointed a finger at his nose. "But she is going to kill you." She bit off every word.

"ju sɛd ʃi wɑz gɑnə hɛlp mi daɪ," hi sɛd kwaɪətli. "ðoʊz wɝ jəɹ wɝdz." haʊ wəɾ i fil ət daɪɪŋ? sædnəs ət livɪŋ hɝ, ət livɪŋ ɪleɪn ən eɪvinhə. sædnəs fəɹ ðə peɪn i hæd bɹɔt ðɛm. hi wəd laɪk tə si hɪz fɑðɝ əɡɛn bɪfɔɹ ði ɛnd. əsaɪd fɹəm ðoʊz θɪŋz, hi ɔlmoʊs θɔt dɛθ wəd bi ə ɹɪlif.

"You said she was going to help me die," he said quietly. "Those were your words." How would he feel at dying? Sadness at leaving her, at leaving Elayne and Aviendha. Sadness for the pain he had brought them. He would like to see his father again before the end. Aside from those things, he almost thought death would be a relief.

dɛθ ɪz ə ɹɪlif, luz θɝɪn sɛd fɝvənli. aɪ wɑn dɛθ. wi dɪzɝv dɛθ!

Death is a relief, Lews Therin said fervently. I want death. We deserve death!

"hɛlpɪŋ mi daɪ ɪzən ðə seɪm əz kɪlɪŋ mi," ɹænd wɛn ɑn. hi wɑz vɛɹi ɡʊɾ əɾ ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ðə vɔɪs, naʊ. "ənlɛs juv tʃeɪnʒd jəɹ maɪn əbaʊt wʌt jə sɔ."

"Helping me die isn't the same as killing me," Rand went on. He was very good at ignoring the voice, now. "Unless you've changed your mind about what you saw."

mɪn flʌŋ ʌp əɹ hænz ɪn ɛksæspɝeɪʃən. "aɪ sɔ wʌɾ aɪ sɔ ən ɪts wʌɾ aɪ toʊl ju, bʌt ðə pɪɾ ə dum swɑloʊ mi ɪf aɪ kən si ɛni dɪfɝəns. ən aɪ kæn si waɪ jə θɪŋk ðəɹ ɪz!"

Min flung up her hands in exasperation. "I saw what I saw and it's what I told you, but the Pit of Doom swallow me if I can see any difference. And I can't see why you think there is!"

"sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ, aɪ hæv tə daɪ, mɪn," hi sɛd peɪʃənli. hi hæd bɪn toʊl baɪ ðoʊz i hæd tə bɪliv. tə lɪv, jə mʌs daɪ. ðət stɪl meɪd noʊ sɛns tə hɪm, bʌɾ ɪt lɛft wʌn koʊl hɑɹd fækt. dʒʌst əz ðə pɹɑfəsiz ə ðə dʒɹæɡən sim tə seɪ, hi hæd tə daɪ. "nɑt sun, aɪ hoʊp. aɪ plæn nɑt sun. aɪm sɑɹi, mɪn. aɪ nɛvɝ ʃəɾ əv lɛt jə bɑn mi." bʌɾ i hæd nɑt bɪn stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf tə ɹəfjuz, ɛni mɔɹ ðən i hæd bɪn stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf tə pʊʃ əɹ əweɪ. hi wɑz tu wik fəɹ wʌt hæd tə bi dʌn. hi niɾəd tə dʒɹɪŋk ɪn wɪntɝ, tɪl i meɪd wɪntɝz hɑɹt sim sʌndeɪ nun.

"Sooner or later, I have to die, Min," he said patiently. He had been told by those he had to believe. To live, you must die. That still made no sense to him, but it left one cold hard fact. Just as the Prophecies of the Dragon seemed to say, he had to die. "Not soon, I hope. I plan not soon. I'm sorry, Min. I never should have let you bond me." But he had not been strong enough to refuse, any more than he had been strong enough to push her away. He was too weak for what had to be done. He needed to drink in winter, till he made winter's heart seem Sunday noon.

"ɪf jə hædnt, wiɾ əv taɪd jə ʌp ən dʌn ɪɾ ɛniweɪ." bɛs nɑt tə æsk haʊ ðət wʊɾə dɪfɝd fɹəm wʌɾ ɑlɑnə hæd dʌn, hi dɪsaɪɾɪd. sɝɾənli, ʃi sɔ ə dɪfɝəns. klaɪmɪŋ ɑntu ðə bɛɾ ɑn əɹ niz, ʃi kʌpt ɪz feɪs ɪn əɹ hænz, "ju lɪsən tə mi, ɹænd ælθɹ. aɪ woʊn lɛt jə daɪ. ən ɪf jə mænədʒ ɪt dʒʌs tə spaɪt mi, əl fɑloʊ jə ən bɹɪŋ jə bæk." sʌɾənli ə θɪk veɪn ʌv əmjuzmən ɹɪpəl θɹu ðə sɪɹiəsnəs i fɛlt ɪn ɪz hɛd. hɝ vɔɪs tʊk ɑn ə mɑk stɝnnəs: "æn ðən əl bɹɪŋ jə bæk hɪɹ tə lɪv. əl meɪk jə ɡɹoʊ jəɹ hɛɹ bɪloʊ jəɹ weɪst ən wɛɹ hɛɹ klɪps wɪð munstoʊnz."

"If you hadn't, we'd have tied you up and done it anyway." Best not to ask how that would have differed from what Alanna had done, he decided. Certainly, she saw a difference. Climbing onto the bed on her knees, she cupped his face in her hands, "You listen to me, Rand al'Thor. I won't let you die. And if you manage it just to spite me, I'll follow you and bring you back." Suddenly a thick vein of amusement rippled through the seriousness he felt in his head. Her voice took on a mock sternness: "And then I'll bring you back here to live. I'll make you grow your hair below your waist and wear hair clips with moonstones."

hi smaɪld ət hɝ. ʃi kəd stɪl meɪk ɪm smaɪl. "aɪ nɛvɝ hɝɾ ʌv ə feɪt wɝs ðən dɛθ, bʌɾ aɪ θɪŋk ðət fɪts."

He smiled at her. She could still make him smile. "I never heard of a fate worse than death, but I think that fits."

sʌmwʌn nɑkt ət ðə dɔɹ, ən mɪn fɹoʊz. ɪn ə saɪlən kwɛstʃən, ʃi maʊðd ɑlɑnəz neɪm. ɹænd nɑɾəd, ən tə hɪz əmeɪzmənt, mɪn pʊʃt ɪm oʊvɝ ɑntu ðə pɪloʊz ən flʌŋ hɝsɛlf ɑn ɪz tʃɛst. skwɝmɪŋ ɝaʊnd, ʃi ɹeɪzd əɹ hɛd, ən i ɹilaɪzd ʃi wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə si hɝsɛlf ɪn ðə wɑʃstæn mɪɹɝ. faɪnəli ʃi faʊn ə pəzɪʃən ʃi laɪkt, laɪɪŋ hæf ɑn tɑp ə hɪm wɪð wʌn hæn bɪhaɪn ɪz nɛk ən ði ʌðɝ bɪsaɪɾ əɹ feɪs ɑn ɪz tʃɛst. "kʌm ɪn," ʃi kɔld.

Someone knocked at the door, and Min froze. In a silent question, she mouthed Alanna's name. Rand nodded, and to his amazement, Min pushed him over onto the pillows and flung herself on his chest. Squirming around, she raised her head, and he realized she was trying to see herself in the washstand mirror. Finally she found a position she liked, lying half on top of him with one hand behind his neck and the other beside her face on his chest. "Come in," she called.

kædzueɪn stɛpt ɪndə ðə ɹum ən stɑpt, fɹaʊnɪŋ ət ðə naɪf stʌk ɪn ðə dɔɹ. ɪn ə dʒɹɛs ə faɪn dɑɹk ɡɹin wʊl ən ə fɝ-laɪn kloʊk hɛl baɪ ə sɪlvɝ bɹutʃ ət ðə nɛk, ʃi maɪɾ əv pæs fəɹ ə səksɛsfəl mɝtʃən əɹ ə bæŋkɝ, ðoʊ ðə ɡoʊldən bɝdz ən fɪʃ, stɑɹz ən munz dæŋɡəlɪŋ fɹəm ði aɪɝn-ɡɹeɪ bʌn ətɑp əɹ hɛd wʊɾə bɪn ɑstənteɪʃəs fəɹ iðɝ. ʃi wɑz nɑt wɛɹɪŋ əɹ ɡɹeɪt sɝpən ɹɪŋ, soʊ ɪt simd ʃi wɑz meɪkɪŋ səm ɛfɝt tə əvɔɪd tu mʌtʃ noʊɾəs. "hæv jə tʃɪlʒɹən bɪn ɑɹɡjuɪŋ?" ʃi æsk maɪldli.

Cadsuane stepped into the room and stopped, frowning at the knife stuck in the door. In a dress of fine dark green wool and a fur-lined cloak held by a silver brooch at the neck, she might have passed for a successful merchant or a banker, though the golden birds and fish, stars and moons dangling from the iron-gray bun atop her head would have been ostentatious for either. She was not wearing her Great Serpent ring, so it seemed she was making some effort to avoid too much notice. "Have you children been arguing?" she asked mildly.

ɹænd kəɾ ɔlmoʊs fil luz θɝɪn ɡoʊ stɪl, laɪk ə ɹɪdʒ kæt kɹaʊtʃɪŋ ɪn ðə ʃædoʊz. luz θɝɪn wɑz ɔlmoʊst əz wɛɹi ʌv ðɪs wʊmən əz i wɑz hɪmsɛlf.

Rand could almost feel Lews Therin go still, like a ridge cat crouching in the shadows. Lews Therin was almost as wary of this woman as he was himself.

ɹɛd-feɪst, mɪn skɹæmbəl tə hɝ fit smuðɪŋ fjʊɹiəsli əɾ əɹ dʒɹɛs. "ju sɛɾ ɪt wɑz hɝ!" ʃi sɛɾ əkjuzɪŋli, dʒʌst əz ɑlɑnə ɛntɝd. kædzueɪn kloʊz ðə dɔɹ.

Red-faced, Min scrambled to her feet smoothing furiously at her dress. "You said it was her!" she said accusingly, just as Alanna entered. Cadsuane closed the door.

ɑlɑnə ɡlænst wʌns ət mɪn ən dɪsmɪs hɝ, foʊkəsɪŋ ɑn ɹænd. wɪθaʊt teɪkɪŋ əɹ dɑɹk aɪz fɹəm hɪm, ʃi swɛpt əɹ kloʊk ɔf ən flʌŋ ɪɾ oʊvɝ wʌn ə ðə ɹumz tu tʃɛɹz. hɝ hænz sɛɾəld ɑn əɹ dɑɹk ɡɹeɪ skɝts, ɡɹɪpɪŋ əm hɑɹd. ʃi wɑz nɑt wɛɹɪŋ əɹ ɡoʊldən ɛɛs sədaɪ ɹɪŋ, iðɝ. fɹəm ðə moʊmən əɹ aɪz fɛl ɑn hɪm, dʒɔɪ blumd əlɔŋ ðə bɑnd. ɔl ðə ɹɛst wɑz stɪl ðɛɹ, ðə nɝvəsnəs, ðə fjʊɹi, bʌɾ i hæd nɛvɝ ɪkspɛktəɾ əɹ tə fil dʒɔɪ!

Alanna glanced once at Min and dismissed her, focusing on Rand. Without taking her dark eyes from him, she swept her cloak off and flung it over one of the room's two chairs. Her hands settled on her dark gray skirts, gripping them hard. She was not wearing her golden Aes Sedai ring, either. From the moment her eyes fell on him, joy bloomed along the bond. All the rest was still there, the nervousness, the fury, but he had never expected her to feel joy!

nɑt tʃeɪnʒɪŋ haʊ hi leɪ, hi pɪkt ʌp ðə fluɾ ən tɔɪd wɪð ɪt. "ʃʊɾ aɪ bi sɝpɹaɪz tə si ju, kædzueɪn? jə pɑp ʌp wən aɪ doʊnt wɑnə si jə tu ɔfən tə sut. hu tɔt jə tə tʃɹævəl?" ɪt hæd tə hæv bɪn ðæt. wʌn moʊmən ɑlɑnə hæd bɪn ə veɪɡ əwɛɹnəs ɑn ði ɛdʒ ə θɔt, ən ðə nɛkst ʃi spɹæŋ tə laɪf fʊl stʃɹɛŋkθ ɪn ɪz hɛd. ət fɝst, hi hæd θɔt ʃi hɝsɛlf hæd lɝn tʃɹævlɪŋ sʌmhaʊ, bʌt siɪŋ kædzueɪn, hi nu bɛɾɝ.

Not changing how he lay, he picked up the flute and toyed with it. "Should I be surprised to see you, Cadsuane? You pop up when I don't want to see you too often to suit. Who taught you to Travel?" It had to have been that. One moment Alanna had been a vague awareness on the edge of thought, and the next she sprang to life full strength in his head. At first, he had thought she herself had learned Traveling somehow, but seeing Cadsuane, he knew better.

ɑlɑnəz maʊθ taɪɾənd, ən ivən mɪn lʊk dɪsəpɹuvɪŋ. ði ɪmoʊʃənz floʊɪŋ əlɔŋ ðə wɔɹɾɝ bɑn fɹəm wʌn dʒʌmpt ən skɪɾɝd; fɹəm ði ʌðɝ, ðəɹ wɑz dʒʌst æŋɡɝ mɪŋɡəld wɪð dɪlaɪt, naʊ. waɪ dɪɾ ɑlɑnə fil dʒɔɪ?

Alanna's mouth tightened, and even Min looked disapproving. The emotions flowing along the Warder bond from one jumped and skittered; from the other, there was just anger mingled with delight, now. Why did Alanna feel joy?

"stɪl noʊ mɔɹ mænɝz ðən ə ɡoʊt, aɪ si," kædzueɪn sɛd dʒɹaɪli. "bɔɪ, aɪ hɑɹdli θɪŋk aɪ nid jəɹ pɝmɪʃən tə vɪzət maɪ bɝθpleɪs. əz fəɹ tʃɹævlɪŋ, ɪts nʌn ə jəɹ bɪznəs wɛɹ əɹ wən aɪ lɝn ɛniθɪŋ." ənpɪnɪŋ əɹ kloʊk, ʃi stʌk ðə bɹutʃ ɑn əɹ bɛlt, ɹɛɾi tə hænd, ən foʊldəd ðə kloʊk oʊvɝ wʌn ɑɹm əz ðoʊ meɪkɪŋ ɪt nit wɝ mʌtʃ mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt ðən i wɑz. hɝ vɔɪs tʊk ɑn ən ɛdʒ ʌv ɪɹɪteɪʃən. "juv lʌmbɝd mi wɪð ə lɑɾ ə tʃɹævlɪŋ kəmpænjənz, wʌn weɪ ən ənʌðɝ. ɑlɑnə wɑz soʊ fɹæntɪk tə si jə əɡɛn, oʊnli ə hɑɹɾ ə stoʊn cʊɾə ɹəfjuz tə bɹɪŋ hɝ, ən sɔɹɪliə sɛd səm ə ði ʌðɝz u plɛdʒ ðɛmsɛlvz tə jə wəd bi ɡʊd fəɹ nʌθɪŋ əntɪl ðeɪ wɝ əlaʊd tə ɡoʊ wɪð ɑlɑnə, soʊ aɪv ɛndəɾ ʌp bɹɪŋɪŋ nɛsun, sɝin, ɛɹiən, bɛldaɪn ən ɛlzə, tu. nɑt tə mɛnʃən hɑɹɪn, plʌs əɹ sɪstɝ ən ðət sɔɹdmæstɝ ə hɝz. ʃi dɪdnt noʊ wɛðɝ tə feɪnt, skɹim əɹ baɪt sʌmwʌn wən ʃi faʊn aʊɾ ɑlɑnə wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ ɔf tə faɪn ju. ən ðən ðəɹ ɑɹ ðoʊz θɹi blæk-koʊɾəd fɹɛnz ə jʊɹz. aɪ doʊnt noʊ haʊ iɡɝ ðeɪ ɑɹ tə si ju, bʌt ðəɹ hɪɹ, əz wɛl. wɛl, naʊ ðət wiv loʊkeɪɾəd ju, aɪ kən sɛn ðə si foʊk ən ðə sɪstɝz tə jə ən lɛt jə dil wɪð ðɛm."

"Still no more manners than a goat, I see," Cadsuane said dryly. "Boy, I hardly think I need your permission to visit my birthplace. As for Traveling, it is none of your business where or when I learned anything." Unpinning her cloak, she stuck the brooch on her belt, ready to hand, and folded the cloak over one arm as though making it neat were much more important than he was. Her voice took on an edge of irritation. "You've lumbered me with a lot of traveling companions, one way and another. Alanna was so frantic to see you again, only a heart of stone could have refused to bring her, and Sorilea said some of the others who pledged themselves to you would be good for nothing until they were allowed to go with Alanna, so I've ended up bringing Nesune, Sarene, Erian, Beldeine and Elza, too. Not to mention Harine, plus her sister and that Swordmaster of hers. She didn't know whether to faint, scream or bite someone when she found out Alanna was going off to find you. And then there are those three black-coated friends of yours. I don't know how eager they are to see you, but they're here, as well. Well, now that we've located you, I can send the Sea Folk and the sisters to you and let you deal with them."

ɹænd spɹæŋ tə hɪz fit wɪð ə mʌɾɝd oʊθ. "noʊ! kip əm əweɪ fɹəm mi!"

Rand sprang to his feet with a muttered oath. "No! Keep them away from me!"

kædzueɪnz dɑɹk aɪz nɛɹoʊd. "aɪv wɔɹn jə bɪfɔɹ əbaʊt jəɹ læŋɡwədʒ; əl nɑt wɔɹn jə əɡɛn." ʃi fɹaʊn əɾ ɪm ə moʊmən lɔŋɡɝ, ðən nɑɾəd əz ðoʊ ʃi θɔɾ i hæd teɪkən ðə lɛsən tə hɑɹt. "naʊ, wʌt meɪks jə θɪŋk jə kən tɛl mi wʌt tə du, bɔɪ?"

Cadsuane's dark eyes narrowed. "I've warned you before about your language; I will not warn you again." She frowned at him a moment longer, then nodded as though she thought he had taken the lesson to heart. "Now, what makes you think you can tell me what to do, boy?"

ɹænd stʃɹʌɡəld wɪð hɪmsɛlf. hi kəd nɑɾ ɪʃu ɔɹɾɝz hɪɹ. hi hæd nɛvɝ bɪn eɪbəl tə ɔɹɾɝ kædzueɪn ɛniwɛɹ. mɪn sɛɾ i niɾəd ðə wʊmən, ðət ʃi wəd titʃ ɪm sʌmθɪŋ i niɾəd tə lɝn, bʌɾ ɪf ɛniθɪŋ, ðəɾ oʊnli meɪɾ ɪm mɔɹ ənizi əbaʊt hɝ. "aɪ wɑnə fɪnɪʃ maɪ bɪznəs hɪɹ ən liv kwaɪətli," hi sɛɾ ət læst. "ɪf jə tɛl ðɛm, ət lis meɪk ʃʊɹ ðeɪ si aɪ kæn əfɔɹd tə hæv əm kʌm ɛniwɛɹ nɪɹ mi, nɑɾ əntɪl aɪm ɹɛɾi tə liv." ðə wʊmən ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ ət hɪm, weɪɾɪŋ, ən i tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ. waɪ dɪd ʃi ɔlweɪz nid tə meɪk ɛvɹiθɪŋ dɪfəkəlt? "aɪ wəɾ əpɹiʃieɪɾ ɪt vɛɹi mʌtʃ ɪf jə dɪdn tɛl ɛni ʌv əm wɛɹ aɪ æm." ɹɪlʌktənli, vɛɹi ɹɪlʌktənli, hi æɾəd, "pliz." mɪn ɛksheɪld əz ðoʊ ʃi hæd bɪn hoʊldɪŋ əɹ bɹɛθ.

Rand struggled with himself. He could not issue orders here. He had never been able to order Cadsuane anywhere. Min said he needed the woman, that she would teach him something he needed to learn, but if anything, that only made him more uneasy about her. "I want to finish my business here and leave quietly," he said at last. "If you tell them, at least make sure they see I can't afford to have them come anywhere near me, not until I'm ready to leave." The woman raised an eyebrow at him, waiting, and he took a deep breath. Why did she always need to make everything difficult? "I would appreciate it very much if you didn't tell any of them where I am." Reluctantly, very reluctantly, he added, "Please." Min exhaled as though she had been holding her breath.

"ɡʊd," kædzueɪn sɛɾ æftɝ ə moʊmənt. "ju kən ʃoʊ mænɝz wən jə tʃɹaɪ, ivən ɪf ɪt dʌz meɪk jə lʊk əz ðoʊ jəɹ tiθ ætʃt. aɪ səpoʊz aɪ kən kip jəɹ sikɹət fəɹ ju, fəɹ ðə taɪm biɪŋ. nɑɾ ɔl ə ðɛm ivən noʊ jə ɑɹ ɪn ðə sɪɾi. oʊ, jɛs. aɪ ʃəd tɛl ju, mɛɹaɪs əz bɑndəd nɛɹɪʃmə, kɔɹəl əz deɪmɝ, ən jʌŋ hɑpwəl ɪz deɪdʒiənz." ʃi sɛd ðəɾ əz ðoʊ ɪt wɝ dʒʌst ə kæʒəwəl bɪɾ ʌv ɪnfɝmeɪʃən ðət maɪɾ izəli hæv slɪpt əɹ maɪnd.

"Good," Cadsuane said after a moment. "You can show manners when you try, even if it does make you look as though your teeth ached. I suppose I can keep your secret for you, for the time being. Not all of them even know you are in the city. Oh, yes. I should tell you, Merise has bonded Narishma, Corele has Damer, and young Hopwil is Daigian's." She said that as though it were just a casual bit of information that might easily have slipped her mind.

hi dɪd nɑt bɑðɝ tə mʌɾɝ ɪz oʊθ ðɪs taɪm, ən kædzueɪnz fʊl-ɑɹm slæp ɔlmoʊst ənhɪnʒd ɪz dʒɔ. blæk spɑts ʃɪmɝɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪz aɪz. wʌn ə ði ʌðɝ wɪmən ɡæspt.

He did not bother to mutter his oath this time, and Cadsuane's full-armed slap almost unhinged his jaw. Black spots shimmered in front of his eyes. One of the other women gasped.

"aɪ dɪd tɛl ju," kædzueɪn sɛd plɑtʃədli. "noʊ mɔɹ wɔɹnɪŋz."

"I did tell you," Cadsuane said placidly. "No more warnings."

mɪn tʊk ə stɛp təwɔɹd hɪm, ən i ʃʊk ɪz hɛd slaɪtli. ɪt hɛlp tə klɪɹ ðə spɑts. hi wɑntəd tə ɹʌb ɪz dʒɔ, bʌɾ i kɛpt ɪz hænz əɾ ɪz saɪdz. hi hæd tə meɪk hɪmsɛlf lusən ɪz ɡɹɪp ɑn ðə flut. fəɹ kædzueɪnz pɑɹt, ðə slæp maɪt nɛvɝ hæɾ əkɝd.

Min took a step toward him, and he shook his head slightly. It helped to clear the spots. He wanted to rub his jaw, but he kept his hands at his sides. He had to make himself loosen his grip on the flute. For Cadsuane's part, the slap might never had occurred.

"waɪ wəd flɪn ən ði ʌðɝz æksɛp biɪŋ bɑndəd?" hi dɪmændəd.

"Why would Flinn and the others accept being bonded?" he demanded.

"æsk əm wən jə si ðɛm," ʃi ɹɪplaɪd. "mɪn, aɪ səspɛkt ɑlɑnə wɑns tə bi əloʊn wɪð ɪm əwaɪl." tɝnɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə dɔɹ wɪθaʊt weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ mɪnz ɹɪplaɪ, ʃi æɾəd, "ɑlɑnə, əl bi weɪɾɪŋ bɪloʊ, ɪn ðə wɪmənz ɹum. doʊn bi tu lɔŋ. aɪ wɑnə ɡɛt bæk tə ðə haɪts. mɪn?"

"Ask them when you see them," she replied. "Min, I suspect Alanna wants to be alone with him awhile." Turning toward the door without waiting for Min's reply, she added, "Alanna, I will be waiting below, in the Women's Room. Don't be too long. I want to get back to the Heights. Min?"

mɪn ɡlɛɹɾ əɾ ɑlɑnə. ʃi ɡlɛɹɾ ət ɹænd. ðən ʃi flʌŋ ʌp əɹ hænz ən stɔkt aʊɾ æftɝ kædzueɪn, mʌɾɝɪŋ ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛθ. ʃi slæm ðə dɔɹ bɪhaɪn hɝ.

Min glared at Alanna. She glared at Rand. Then she flung up her hands and stalked out after Cadsuane, muttering under her breath. She slammed the door behind her.

"aɪ laɪk jə bɛɾɝ wɪð jəɹ oʊn hɛɹ." ɑlɑnə foʊldəɾ əɹ ɑɹmz bɪniθ əɹ bɹɛsts ən stʌɾid hɪm. æŋɡɝ ən dʒɔɪ wɔɹd wɪð wʌn ənʌðɝ ɪn ðə bɑnd. "aɪ hæd hoʊp ðət biɪŋ kloʊs tə jə wəd bi bɛɾɝ, bʌt jə ɑɹ stɪl laɪk ə stoʊn ɪn maɪ hɛd. ivən stændɪŋ hɪɹ, aɪ kən hɑɹdli tɛl wɛðɝ jəɹ əpsɛɾ əɹ nɑt. ivən soʊ, biɪŋ hɪɹ ɪz bɛɾɝ. aɪ dɪslaɪk biɪŋ pɑɹɾəd fɹəm ə wɔɹɾɝ soʊ lɔŋ."

"I liked you better with your own hair." Alanna folded her arms beneath her breasts and studied him. Anger and joy warred with one another in the bond. "I had hoped that being close to you would be better, but you are still like a stone in my head. Even standing here, I can hardly tell whether you're upset or not. Even so, being here is better. I dislike being parted from a Warder so long."

ɹænd ɪɡnɔɹɾ əɹ ən ðə ɹɪpəlɪŋ dʒɔɪ ðət floʊɾ əlɔŋ ðə bɑnd. "ʃi dɪdn æsk waɪ aɪ keɪm tə fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ," ɹænd sɛd kwaɪətli, stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə dɔɹ əz ɪf i kəd si kædzueɪn θɹu ðə wʊd. ʃʊɹli, ʃi hæd tə wʌndɝ. "ju toʊld əɹ aɪ wɑz hɪɹ, ɑlɑnə. ɪt hæd tə bi ju. wʌt hæpən tə jəɹ oʊθ?"

Rand ignored her and the rippling joy that flowed along the bond. "She didn't ask why I came to Far Madding," Rand said quietly, staring at the door as if he could see Cadsuane through the wood. Surely, she had to wonder. "You told her I was here, Alanna. It had to be you. What happened to your oath?"

ɑlɑnə dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ, ən ə moʊmən pæs bɪfɔɹ ʃi ɹɪplaɪd. "aɪ æm nɑt ʃʊɹ kædzueɪn kɛɹz tu pɪnz əbaʊt ju," ʃi snæpt. "aɪ kip ðəɾ oʊθ əz wɛl əz aɪ kæn, bʌt jə də meɪk kipɪŋ ɪt hɑɹd." hɝ vɔɪs bɪɡæn tə hɑɹɾən, ən æŋɡɝ wɛl mɔɹ stʃɹɔŋli θɹu ðə bɑnd. "aɪ oʊ fiəlti tə ə mæn u wɔks ɔf ən livz mi bɪhaɪnd. dʒʌs haʊ æm aɪ səpoʊz tə sɝv ju? mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾəntli, wʌd jə du?" kɹɔsɪŋ ðə kɑɹpət, ʃi stʊd stɛɹɪŋ ʌp ət hɪm, fjʊɹi bɝnɪŋ ɪn əɹ aɪz. hi tɑpt əɹ baɪ mɔɹ ðən ə fʊt, ən ʃi sim nɑt tə noʊɾəs. "ju dɪd sʌmθɪŋ, aɪ noʊ. aɪ wɑz ʌnkɑnʃəs fəɹ θɹi deɪz! wʌd jə du?"

Alanna drew a deep breath, and a moment passed before she replied. "I am not sure Cadsuane cares two pins about you," she snapped. "I keep that oath as well as I can, but you do make keeping it hard." Her voice began to harden, and anger welled more strongly through the bond. "I owe fealty to a man who walks off and leaves me behind. Just how am I supposed to serve you? More importantly, what did you do?" Crossing the carpet, she stood staring up at him, fury burning in her eyes. He topped her by more than a foot, and she seemed not to notice. "You did something, I know. I was unconscious for three days! What did you do?"

"aɪ dɪsaɪɾɪd ɪf aɪ wɑz gɑnə bi bɑndəd, ɪt maɪɾ əz wɛl bi baɪ sʌmwʌn aɪ sɛd kʊd." hi bɛɹli kɑɾ əɹ hæn bɪfɔɹ ɪt lændəɾ ɑn ɪz feɪs. "aɪv bɪn slæpt ɪnʌf fəɹ wʌn deɪ."
