"I decided if I was going to be bonded, it might as well be by someone I said could." He barely caught her hand before it landed on his face. "I've been slapped enough for one day."

ʃi ɡlɛɹɾ ʌp ət hɪm, tiθ bɛɹɾ əz ɪf ɹɛɾi tə baɪɾ aʊɾ ɪz θɹoʊt. ðə bɑn kæɹiɾ oʊnli fjʊɹi ən aʊtʃɹeɪdʒ, naʊ, dɪstɪl tə dæɡɝz. "ju lɛt sʌmwʌn ɛls bɑn ju?" ʃi snɑɹəld. "haʊ dɛɹ ju! huɛvɝ ʃi ɪz, əl si hɝ bɪfɔɹ ə kɔɹt! əl si hɝ bɝtʃt! jə ɑɹ maɪn!"

She glared up at him, teeth bared as if ready to bite out his throat. The bond carried only fury and outrage, now, distilled to daggers. "You let someone else bond you?" she snarled. "How dare you! Whoever she is, I'll see her before a court! I'll see her birched! You are mine!"

"bɪkɔz jə tʊk mi, ɑlɑnə," hi sɛd koʊldli. "ɪf mɔɹ sɪstɝz nu, jə wəd bi ðə wʌn bɝtʃt." mɪn hæd toʊld ɪm wʌns ðəɾ i kəd tʃɹʌst ɑlɑnə, ðət ʃi hæd sin ðə ɡɹin ən fɔɹ ʌðɝ sɪstɝz "ɪn ɪz hænd." hi dɪd tʃɹʌs hɝ, ɪn ən ɑd fæʃən, jɛɾ i wɑz ɪn ɑlɑnəz hænd, tu, ən i dɪd nɑt wɑnə bi. "ɹilis mi, ən əl dɪnaɪ ɪɾ ɛvɝ hæpənd." hi hæd nɑɾ ivən noʊn ðət wɑz pɑsəbəl əntɪl læn toʊld ɪm əbaʊt hɪmsɛlf ən maɪɹɛl. "ɹilis mi, ən əl sɛt jə fɹi ʌv jəɹ oʊθ."

"Because you took me, Alanna," he said coldly. "If more sisters knew, you would be the one birched." Min had told him once that he could trust Alanna, that she had seen the Green and four other sisters "in his hand." He did trust her, in an odd fashion, yet he was in Alanna's hand, too, and he did not want to be. "Release me, and I'll deny it ever happened." He had not even known that was possible until Lan told him about himself and Myrelle. "Release me, and I'll set you free of your oath."

ðə ɹɔɪlɪŋ æŋɡɝ floʊɪŋ θɹu ðə bɑn lɛsənd wɪθaʊt dɪsəpɪɹɪŋ, bʌɾ əɹ feɪs ɡɹu kɑm, ən əɹ vɔɪs wɑz kəmpoʊzd. "ju ɑɹ hɝɾɪŋ maɪ ɹɪst."

The roiling anger flowing through the bond lessened without disappearing, but her face grew calm, and her voice was composed. "You are hurting my wrist."

hi nu hi wɑz. hi kəd fil ðə peɪn θɹu ðə bɑnd. hi lɛt ɡoʊ, ən ʃi məsɑʒd əɹ ɹɪs fɑɹ mɔɹ ɑstənteɪʃəsli ðən ɹikwaɪɝd baɪ ðə hɝɾ i fɛlt. stɪl ɹʌbɪŋ əɹ ɹɪst, ʃi sæɾ ɑn ðə sɛkən tʃɛɹ ən kɹɔst əɹ lɛɡz. ʃi sim tə bi θɪŋkɪŋ.

He knew he was. He could feel the pain through the bond. He let go, and she massaged her wrist far more ostentatiously than required by the hurt he felt. Still rubbing her wrist, she sat on the second chair and crossed her legs. She seemed to be thinking.

"aɪv θɔɾ ə biɪŋ fɹi ʌv ju," ʃi sɛd faɪnəli. "aɪ hæv dʒɹimd ʌv ɪt." ʃi ɡeɪv ə smɔl, ɹufəl læf. "aɪ ivən æskt kædzueɪn tə lemi pæs ðə bɑn tə hɝ. ə saɪn ə haʊ dɛspɹɪɾ aɪ wɑz, tə æsk sətʃ ə θɪŋ. bʌɾ ɪf ɛniwʌn kən hændəl ju, kædzueɪn kæn. oʊnli, ʃi ɹəfjuzd. ʃi wɑz fjʊɹiəs ðəɾ aɪ sədʒɛstəɾ ɪt wɪθaʊɾ æskɪŋ ju, aʊtʃɹeɪdʒd, bʌɾ ivən ɪf jə əɡɹid, ʃi woʊnt." ʃi spɹɛɾ əɹ hænz. "soʊ jə ɑɹ maɪn." hɝ feɪs dɪd nɑt tʃeɪnʒ, bʌɾ əz ʃi sɛd ðæt, ðə dʒɔɪ flɛɹɾ ənu. "haʊɛvɝ aɪ əkwaɪɝd ju, jə ɑɹ maɪ wɔɹɾɝ, ən aɪ hæv ə ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾi. ðəɾ ɪz əz stʃɹɔŋ ɪn mi əz ði oʊθ aɪ swɔɹ tə oʊbeɪ ju. ɛvɹi bɪɾ əz stʃɹɔŋ. soʊ əl nɑt ɹilis jə tə ɛniwʌn ənlɛs aɪ noʊ ʃi kən hændəl jə pɹɑpɝli. hu bɑndəd ju? ɪf ʃiz keɪpəbəl, əl lɛɾ əɹ əv ju."

"I've thought of being free of you," she said finally. "I have dreamed of it." She gave a small, rueful laugh. "I even asked Cadsuane to let me pass the bond to her. A sign of how desperate I was, to ask such a thing. But if anyone can handle you, Cadsuane can. Only, she refused. She was furious that I suggested it without asking you, outraged, but even if you agreed, she won't." She spread her hands. "So you are mine." Her face did not change, but as she said that, the joy flared anew. "However I acquired you, you are my Warder, and I have a responsibility. That is as strong in me as the oath I swore to obey you. Every bit as strong. So I will not release you to anyone unless I know she can handle you properly. Who bonded you? If she is capable, I will let her have you."

dʒʌs ðə pɑsəbɪləɾi ðət kædzueɪn maɪɾ əv ɹəsivd ɪz bɑn sɛn aɪsɪkəlz daʊn ɹændz spaɪn. ɑlɑnə hæd nɛvɝ bɪn eɪbəl tə kəntʃɹoʊl ɪm wɪð ðə bɑnd, ən i dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ɛni sɪstɝ kʊd, bʌɾ i wəd nɛvɝ ɹɪsk ɪt wɪð ðət wʌn. laɪt!

Just the possibility that Cadsuane might have received his bond sent icicles down Rand's spine. Alanna had never been able to control him with the bond, and he did not think any sister could, but he would never risk it with that one. Light!

"wʌt meɪks jə θɪŋk ʃi dʌzn kɛɹ əbaʊt mi?" hi dɪmændəɾ ɪnstɛɾ ʌv ænsɝɪŋ ɑlɑnəz kwɛstʃən. tʃɹʌst əɹ noʊ tʃɹʌst, noʊ wʌn wəd lɝn ðəɾ ænsɝ ɪf i kəd hɛlp ɪt. wʌɾ ɪleɪn ən mɪn ən eɪvinhə hæd dʌn maɪt bi əlaʊd baɪ taʊɝ lɔ, jɛt ðeɪ hæd wɝs tə fɪɹ ðən pʌnɪʃmən fɹəm ʌðɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪf ɪt keɪm aʊt ðeɪ wɝ lɪŋk tə hɪm ɪn ðɪs weɪ. sɪɾɪŋ daʊn ɑn ði ɛdʒ ə ðə bɛd, hi tɝn ðə fluɾ oʊvɝ ɪn ɪz hænz. "dʒʌs kəz ʃi ɹəfjuz maɪ bɑnd? meɪbi ʃi ɪzən əz nɑnʃəlɑn əbaʊt ðə kɑnsəkwɛnsəz əz ju. ʃi keɪm tə mi ɪn kɛɹhin, ən steɪd lɔŋ æftɝ ðəɹ kəd bi ɛni ɹizən bʌt mi. æm aɪ ɹɪli səpoʊz tə bɪliv ʃi dʒʌs dɪsaɪɾɪd tə vɪzət fɹɛnz waɪl aɪ hæpən tə bi hɪɹ? ʃi bɹɔt jə tə fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ soʊ ʃi kəd faɪn mi."

"What makes you think she doesn't care about me?" he demanded instead of answering Alanna's question. Trust or no trust, no one would learn that answer if he could help it. What Elayne and Min and Aviendha had done might be allowed by Tower law, yet they had worse to fear than punishment from other Aes Sedai if it came out they were linked to him in this way. Sitting down on the edge of the bed, he turned the flute over in his hands. "Just because she refused my bond? Maybe she isn't as nonchalant about the consequences as you. She came to me in Cairhien, and stayed long after there could be any reason but me. Am I really supposed to believe she just decided to visit friends while I happen to be here? She brought you to Far Madding so she could find me."

"ɹænd, ʃi wɑntəd tə noʊ wɛɹ jə wɝ ɛvɹi deɪ," ɑlɑnə sɛd dɪsmɪsɪvli, "bʌɾ aɪ daʊt ðɛɹz ə ʃɛpɝɾ ɪn seɪlaɪzɪn u dʌznt wʌndɝ wɛɹ jə ɑɹ. ðə hoʊl wɝld wɑns tə noʊ ðæt. aɪ nu jə wɝ fɑɹ tə ðə saʊθ, ðət jə hædn muv fəɹ deɪz. noʊ mɔɹ. wən aɪ faʊn aʊt ʃi ən vɛɹɪn wɝ kʌmɪŋ hɪɹ, aɪ hæd tə bɛɡ hɝ - bɛɡ ɑn maɪ niz! - bɪfɔɹ ʃi wəd lemi kʌm əlɔŋ. bʌɾ aɪ dɪdnt noʊ maɪsɛlf ðət jə wɝ hɪɹ əntɪl aɪ keɪm aʊɾ ə ðə ɡeɪtweɪ ɪn ðə hɪlz əbʌv ðə sɪɾi. bɪfɔɹ ðæt, aɪ θɔɾ aɪ maɪɾ əv tə tʃɹævəl hæfweɪ tə tɛɹ tə faɪn ju. kædzueɪn tɔt mi ðæt, wən wi keɪm hɪɹ, soʊ doʊn θɪŋk jə kən ɪveɪd mi soʊ izəli ɪn ðə fjutʃɝ."

"Rand, she wanted to know where you were every day," Alanna said dismissively, "but I doubt there's a shepherd in Seleisin who doesn't wonder where you are. The whole world wants to know that. I knew you were far to the south, that you hadn't moved for days. No more. When I found out she and Verin were coming here, I had to beg her - beg on my knees! - before she would let me come along. But I didn't know myself that you were here until I came out of the gateway in the hills above the city. Before that, I thought I might have to Travel halfway to Tear to find you. Cadsuane taught me that, when we came here, so don't think you can evade me so easily in the future."

kædzueɪn hæd tɔɾ ɑlɑnə tə tʃɹævəl? ðət stɪl dɪd nɑt seɪ hu hæd tɔt kædzueɪn, ðoʊ. nɑt ðəɾ ɪt mæɾɝd, hi səpoʊzd. "æn deɪmɝ ən ði ʌðɝ tu əlaʊd ðɛmsɛlvz tə bi bɑndəd? əɹ dɪd ðoʊz sɪstɝz dʒʌs teɪk əm ðə weɪ jə tʊk mi?"

Cadsuane had taught Alanna to Travel? That still did not say who had taught Cadsuane, though. Not that it mattered, he supposed. "And Damer and the other two allowed themselves to be bonded? Or did those sisters just take them the way you took me?"

ə feɪn flʌʃ steɪn əɹ tʃiks, bʌɾ əɹ vɔɪs wɑz stɛɾi. "aɪ hɝd mɛɹaɪs æsk dʒɑhɹ. ɪt tʊk ɪm tu deɪz tə æksɛpt, ən ʃi nɛvɝ pɹɛʃɝɾ ɪm ðəɾ aɪ sɔ. aɪ kænɑt spik fəɹ ði ʌðɝz, bʌɾ əz kædzueɪn sɛd, jə kən ɔlweɪz æsk ðɛm. ɹænd, jə mʌst ʌndɝstænd, ðoʊz mɛn wɝ əfɹeɪd tə ɡoʊ bæk tə ðɪs 'blæk taʊɝ' ʌv jʊɹz." hɝ maʊθ twɪstəd saʊɝli ɝaʊn ðə neɪm. "ðeɪ wɝ əfɹeɪd ðeɪ wəd bi bleɪmd ɪn ði ətæk ɑn ju. ɪf ðeɪ sɪmpli ɹæn, ðeɪ wəd bi hʌntəd daʊn əz dɛzɝɾɝz. aɪ ʌndɝstæn ðəɾ ɪz jəɹ stændɪŋ ɔɹɾɝ? wɛɹ ɛls kəd ðeɪ ɡoʊ, ɪksɛp tə ɛɛs sədaɪ? ən ə ɡʊd θɪŋ ðeɪ dɪd, tu." ʃi smaɪld əz ðoʊ ʃi hæd dʒʌst sin sʌmθɪŋ wʌndɝfəl, ən əɹ vɔɪs bɪkeɪm ɪksaɪɾəd. "ɹænd, deɪmɝ əz dɪskʌvɝɾ ə weɪ tə hil biɪŋ stɪld! laɪt, aɪ kən seɪ ðət wɝd wɪθaʊt fɹizɪŋ maɪ tʌŋ. hi hild ɝɡən ən ɹɑneɪl ən sæʃəl. ðeɪv swɔɹn fiəlti tə ju, tu, dʒʌs laɪk ɔl ði ʌðɝz."

A faint flush stained her cheeks, but her voice was steady. "I heard Merise ask Jahar. It took him two days to accept, and she never pressured him that I saw. I cannot speak for the others, but as Cadsuane said, you can always ask them. Rand, you must understand, those men were afraid to go back to this 'Black Tower' of yours." Her mouth twisted sourly around the name. "They were afraid they would be blamed in the attack on you. If they simply ran, they would be hunted down as deserters. I understand that is your standing order? Where else could they go, except to Aes Sedai? And a good thing they did, too." She smiled as though she had just seen something wonderful, and her voice became excited. "Rand, Damer has discovered a way to Heal being stilled! Light, I can say that word without freezing my tongue. He Healed Irgain and Ronaille and Sashalle. They've sworn fealty to you, too, just like all the others."

"wʌt dʒju min, ɔl ði ʌðɝz?"

"What do you mean, all the others?"

"aɪ min ɔl ðə sɪstɝz ði il wɝ hoʊldɪŋ. ivən ðə ɹɛdz." ʃi saʊndəd hæf dɪsbɪlivɪŋ əbaʊt ðæt, əz wɛl ʃi ʃʊd, bʌt dɪsbɪlif mɛltəɾ ɪndə ɪntɛnsəɾi əz ʃi pʊt boʊθ fiɾ ɑn ðə flɔɹ ən lin təwɔɹd hɪm, hɝ aɪz fɪkst ɑn hɪz. "ɛvɹi wʌn ə ðɛm əz swɔɹn ən æksɛptɪd ðə pɛnəns jə pʊɾ ɑn nɛsun ən ði ʌðɝz, ðə fɝs faɪv ə ðɛm u swɔɹ. kædzueɪn dʌzn tʃɹʌs ðɛm. ʃi wʊdn lɛɾ əm bɹɪŋ ɛni ʌv ðɛɹ wɔɹɾɝz. aɪ ədmɪɾ aɪ wɑz ənsɝɾən ət fɝst, bʌɾ aɪ bɪliv jə kən tʃɹʌs ðɛm. ðeɪ swɔɹ oʊθ tə ju. jə noʊ wʌt ðət minz fəɹ ə sɪstɝ. wi kæn bɹeɪk ən oʊθ, ɹænd. ɪɾ ɪzən pɑsəbəl."

"I mean all the sisters the Aiel were holding. Even the Reds." She sounded half disbelieving about that, as well she should, but disbelief melted into intensity as she put both feet on the floor and leaned toward him, her eyes fixed on his. "Every one of them has sworn and accepted the penance you put on Nesune and the others, the first five of them who swore. Cadsuane doesn't trust them. She wouldn't let them bring any of their Warders. I admit I was uncertain at first, but I believe you can trust them. They swore oath to you. You know what that means for a sister. We can't break an oath, Rand. It isn't possible."

ivən ðə ɹɛdz. hi hæd bɪn sɝpɹaɪzd wən ðoʊz fɝs faɪv kæptɪvz ɔfɝd fiəlti. ɪleɪɾə hæd sɛn əm tə kɪdnæp hɪm, ən ðeɪ hæd. hi hæd bɪn ʃʊɹ ɪt wɑz ɪm biɪŋ tɑvɝən ðət hæd dʌn ɪt, bʌt ðəɾ oʊnli ɔltɝd tʃæns, meɪd wʌt maɪt hæpən wʌn taɪm ɪn ə mɪljən bɪkʌm ə sɝɾənti. ɪt wɑz hɑɹd tə bɪliv ðəɾ ə ɹɛd wəd swɛɹ ʌndɝ ɛni sɝkəmstænsəz tə ə mæn u kəd tʃænəl.

Even the Reds. He had been surprised when those first five captives offered fealty. Elaida had sent them to kidnap him, and they had. He had been sure it was him being ta'veren that had done it, but that only altered chance, made what might happen one time in a million become a certainty. It was hard to believe that a Red would swear under any circumstances to a man who could channel.

"ju niɾ ʌs, ɹænd." ɹaɪzɪŋ, ʃi ʃɪftəɾ əz ɪf ʃi wɑntəd tə peɪs, bʌɾ ɪnstɛd ʃi stʊd wɑtʃɪŋ hɪm, ənblɪŋkɪŋ. hɝ hænz smuðd əɹ skɝts əz ɪf ʃi wɑz ʌnəwɛɹ ʌv wʌt ðeɪ wɝ duɪŋ. "ju nid ðə səpɔɹɾ ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ. wɪθaʊɾ ɪt, jəl əv tə kɑŋkɝ ɛvɹi neɪʃən, ən jə hævən dʌn vɛɹi wɛl ət ðət ðʌs fɑɹ. ðə ɹɪbɛljən ɪn kɛɹhin maɪt sim fɪnɪʃt tə ju, bʌt nɑɾ ɛvɹiwʌn laɪks dɑbɹeɪn biɪŋ neɪm jəɹ stuɝd. ə ɡʊd mɛni maɪt ɡoʊ tə tɔɹæm ɹieɪɾən, ɪf i ɹiəpɪɹz. ðə haɪ lɔɹd dɑɹlɪn ɪz snʌɡ ɪn ðə stoʊn, soʊ wi hɪɹ, ənaʊnst əz jəɹ stuɝɾ ɪn tiɹ, bʌt ðə ɹɛbəlz ðəɹ hævən kʌm stʃɹimɪŋ aʊɾ ə hæɾən mɝk tə səpɔɹt hɪm. əz fəɹ ændɝ, ɪleɪn tʃɹəkən maɪt seɪ ʃɪl səpɔɹt jə wʌns ʃiz ðə θɹoʊn, bʌt ʃiz mənuvɝd jəɹ soʊlʒɝz aʊɾ ə keɪɛmlɪn, ən əl wɛɹ bɛlz ɪn ðə blaɪɾ ɪf ʃi lɛts əm ɹɪmeɪn ɪn ændɝ wən ʃi dʌz səksid. sɪstɝz kən hɛlp ju. ɪleɪn wɪl lɪsən tə ʌs. ðə ɹɛbəlz ɪn kɛɹhin ən tiɹ wɪl lɪsən. ðə waɪt taʊɝ əz stɑpt wɔɹz ən ɛndəd ɹɪbɛljənz fəɹ θɹi θaʊzən jɪɹz. jə meɪ nɑt laɪk ðə tʃɹiɾi ɹæfɛlə ən mɛɹænə nəɡoʊʃieɪɾəd wɪð hɑɹɪn, bʌt ðeɪ ɡɑɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ jə æsk fɔɹ. laɪt, mæn, lɛɾ əs hɛlp ju!"

"You need us, Rand." Rising, she shifted as if she wanted to pace, but instead she stood watching him, unblinking. Her hands smoothed her skirts as if she was unaware of what they were doing. "You need the support of Aes Sedai. Without it, you will have to conquer every nation, and you haven't done very well at that thus far. The rebellion in Cairhien might seem finished to you, but not everyone likes Dobraine being named your Steward. A good many might go to Toram Riatin, if he reappears. The High Lord Darlin is snug in the Stone, so we hear, announced as your Steward in Tear, but the rebels there haven't come streaming out of Haddon Mirk to support him. As for Andor, Elayne Trakand might say she will support you once she has the throne, but she has maneuvered your soldiers out of Caemlyn, and I'll wear bells in the Blight if she lets them remain in Andor when she does succeed. Sisters can help you. Elayne will listen to us. The rebels in Cairhien and Tear will listen. The White Tower has stopped wars and ended rebellions for three thousand years. You may not like the treaty Rafela and Merana negotiated with Harine, but they got everything you asked for. Light, man, let us help you!"

ɹænd nɑɾəd sloʊli. ɪt hæd sim dʒʌst ə weɪ tə ɪmpɹɛs pipəl wɪð ɪz paʊɝ, ðəɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ ɡeɪv ɪm fiəlti. fɪɹ ðət ðeɪ maɪt mənɪpjəleɪɾ ɪm tə ðɛɹ oʊn ɛnz hæd blaɪndɪɾ ɪm tə ɛniθɪŋ ɛls. hi dɪd nɑt laɪk ædmɪɾɪŋ ðæt. hi hæd bɪn ə ful.

Rand nodded slowly. It had seemed just a way to impress people with his power, that Aes Sedai gave him fealty. Fear that they might manipulate him to their own ends had blinded him to anything else. He did not like admitting that. He had been a fool.

ə mæn u tʃɹʌsts ɛvɹiwʌn ɪz ə ful, luz θɝɪn sɛd, ən ə mæn u tʃɹʌsts noʊ wʌn ɪz ə ful. wəɹ ɔl fulz, ɪf wi laɪv lɔŋ ɪnʌf. hi ɔlmoʊst saʊndəd seɪn.

A man who trusts everyone is a fool, Lews Therin said, and a man who trusts no one is a fool. We are all fools, if we live long enough. He almost sounded sane.

"ɡoʊ bæk tə kɛɹhin," hi sɛd. "tɛl ɹæfɛlə ən mɛɹænə aɪ wɑn əm tə əpɹoʊtʃ ðə ɹɛbəlz ɪn hæɾən mɝk. tɛl əm tə teɪk bɛɹə ən feɪlʒɹɪn, tu." ðoʊz wɝ ðə fɔɹ bɪsaɪdz ɑlɑnə hum mɪn sɛɾ i kəd tʃɹʌst. wʌt hæd ʃi sɛɾ əbaʊt ðə faɪv ʌðɝz kædzueɪn hæd bɹɔt wɪð hɝ? ðəɾ itʃ wəd sɝv ɪm ɪn əɹ fæʃən. ðət wɑz nɑt stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf, nɑt jɛt. "aɪ wɑn dɑɹlɪn sɪsnɛɹə əz maɪ stuɝɾ ən ðə lɔz aɪ meɪd lɛft ɪn pleɪs. ðeɪ kən nəɡoʊʃieɪɾ əweɪ ɛniθɪŋ ɛls əz lɔŋ əz ðeɪ ɛn ðə ɹɪbɛljən. æftɝ ðət . . . wʌts ðə mæɾɝ?"

"Go back to Cairhien," he said. "Tell Rafela and Merana I want them to approach the rebels in Haddon Mirk. Tell them to take Bera and Faeldrin, too." Those were the four besides Alanna whom Min said he could trust. What had she said about the five others Cadsuane had brought with her? That each would serve him in her fashion. That was not strong enough, not yet. "I want Darlin Sisnera as my Steward and the laws I made left in place. They can negotiate away anything else as long as they end the rebellion. After that . . . What's the matter?"

ɑlɑnəz feɪs hæd fɔlən, ən ʃi hæd sæɡd bæk ɪn əɹ tʃɛɹ. "ɪts dʒʌs ðəɾ aɪv kʌm ɔl ðɪs weɪ, ən jə ɑɹ sɛndɪŋ mi ɹaɪɾ ɔf əɡɛn. aɪ səpoʊz ɪts fəɹ ðə bɛst, wɪð ðət ɡɝl hɪɹ," ʃi saɪd. "ju hæv noʊ aɪdiə wʌɾ aɪ wɛn θɹu ɪn kɛɹhin, mæskɪŋ ðə bɑn dʒʌst ɪnʌf tə kip wʌt ðə tu ʌv jə wɝ duɪŋ fɹəm kipɪŋ mi əweɪk ɔl naɪt. ðəɾ ɪz mʌtʃ hɑɹɾɝ ðən sɪmpli mæskɪŋ ɪt kəmplitli, bʌɾ aɪ dɪslaɪk luzɪŋ tʌtʃ wɪð maɪ wɔɹɾɝz kəmplitli. oʊnli, ɡoʊɪŋ bæk tə kɛɹhin wɪl bi ɔlmoʊst əz bæd."

Alanna's face had fallen, and she had sagged back in her chair. "It's just that I've come all this way, and you are sending me right off again. I suppose it is for the best, with that girl here," she sighed. "You have no idea what I went through in Cairhien, masking the bond just enough to keep what the two of you were doing from keeping me awake all night. That is much harder than simply masking it completely, but I dislike losing touch with my Warders completely. Only, going back to Cairhien will be almost as bad."

ɹænd klɪɹɾ ɪz θɹoʊt. "ðæts wʌɾ aɪ wɑn jə tə du." wɪmən, hi hæd lɝnd, tɔkt əbaʊt səm θɪŋz mʌtʃ mɔɹ oʊpənli ðən mɛn, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz stɪl ə ʃɑk wən ðeɪ dɪd. hi hoʊpt ɪleɪn ən eɪvinhə mæsk ðə bɑnd wən i wɑz meɪkɪŋ lʌv wɪð mɪn. wən ðə tu ʌv əm wɝ təɡɛðɝ ɪn bɛd, noʊ wʌn ɛls ɪɡzɪstəɾ ɪksɛp hɝ, ðə seɪm əz ɪt hæd bɪn wɪð ɪleɪn. hi sɝɾənli dɪd nɑt wɑnə tɔk əbaʊɾ ɪt wɪð ɑlɑnə. "aɪ meɪ bi dʌn hɪɹ baɪ ðə taɪm jə fɪnɪʃ ɪn kɛɹhin. ɪf aɪ hævənt . . . ɪf aɪ hævənt, jə kən ɹɪtɝn hɪɹ. bʌt jəl əv tə steɪ əweɪ fɹəm mi əntɪl aɪ seɪ ʌðɝwaɪz." ivən wɪð ðət ɹistʃɹɪkʃən, ðə dʒɔɪ bɪloʊɾ ʌp ɪn əɹ əfɹɛʃ.

Rand cleared his throat. "That's what I want you to do." Women, he had learned, talked about some things much more openly than men, but it was still a shock when they did. He hoped Elayne and Aviendha masked the bond when he was making love with Min. When the two of them were together in bed, no one else existed except her, the same as it had been with Elayne. He certainly did not want to talk about it with Alanna. "I may be done here by the time you finish in Cairhien. If I haven't . . . If I haven't, you can return here. But you'll have to stay away from me until I say otherwise." Even with that restriction, the joy billowed up in her afresh.

"ju ɑɹən gɑnə tɛl mi hu bɑndəd ju, ɑɹ ju?" hi ʃʊk ɪz hɛd, ən ʃi saɪd. "aɪ hæd bɛɾɝ ɡoʊ." ɹaɪzɪŋ, ʃi tʊk ʌp əɹ kloʊk ən dʒɹeɪpt ɪɾ oʊvɝ əɹ ɑɹm. "kædzueɪn ɪz ɪmpeɪʃən ət bɛst. sɔɹɪliə ədmɑnɪʃt əɹ tə lʊk æftɝ əs laɪk ə mʌðɝ hɛn, ən ʃi dʌz. æftɝ əɹ fæʃən." ət ðə dɔɹ, ʃi pɔz fəɹ wʌn læs kwɛstʃən. "waɪ ɑɹ jə hɪɹ, ɹænd? kædzueɪn meɪ nɑt kɛɹ, bʌɾ aɪ du. əl kip ɪt sikɹət, ɪf jə wɪʃ. aɪ hæv nɛvɝ bɪn eɪbəl tə steɪ mɔɹ ðən ə fju deɪz ɪn ə stɛɾɪŋ. waɪ wəd jə bi wɪlɪŋ tə steɪ hɪɹ, wɛɹ jə kæn ivən fil ðə sɔɹs?"

"You aren't going to tell me who bonded you, are you?" He shook his head, and she sighed. "I had better go." Rising, she took up her cloak and draped it over her arm. "Cadsuane is impatient at best. Sorilea admonished her to look after us like a mother hen, and she does. After her fashion." At the door, she paused for one last question. "Why are you here, Rand? Cadsuane may not care, but I do. I'll keep it secret, if you wish. I have never been able to stay more than a few days in a stedding. Why would you be willing to stay here, where you can't even feel the Source?"

"meɪbi ɪɾ ɪzən ðət bæd fəɹ mi," hi laɪd. hi kəd tɛl hɝ, hi ɹilaɪzd. hi dɪd tʃɹʌst əɹ tə kip ɪt sikɹət. bʌt ʃi dɪd si hɪm əz əɹ wɔɹɾɝ, ən ʃi wɑz ə ɡɹin. noʊ ɛkspləneɪʃən kəd meɪk əɹ lɛɾ ɪm feɪs ɪɾ əloʊn, bʌɾ ɪn fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ, ʃi wɑz noʊ bɛɾɝ eɪbəl tə dɪfɛn hɝsɛlf ðən mɪn, meɪbi lɛs. "ɡoʊ ɑn, ɑlɑnə. aɪv weɪstəɾ ɪnʌf taɪm."

"Maybe it isn't that bad for me," he lied. He could tell her, he realized. He did trust her to keep it secret. But she did see him as her Warder, and she was a Green. No explanation could make her let him face it alone, but in Far Madding, she was no better able to defend herself than Min, maybe less. "Go on, Alanna. I've wasted enough time."

wʌns ʃi wɑz ɡɔn, hi ʃɪftəd hɪmsɛlf tə pʊɾ ɪz bæk əɡɛns ðə wɔl əɡɛn ən sæt fɪŋɡɝɪŋ ðə flut. hi θɔɾ ɪnstɛɾ ə pleɪɪŋ, ðoʊ. mɪn sɛɾ i niɾəd kædzueɪn, bʌt kædzueɪn wɑz nɑɾ ɪntʃɹəstəɾ ɪn ɪm ɪksɛpt əz ə kjʊɹiɑsəɾi. ə bæd-mænɝd kjʊɹiɑsəɾi. sʌmhaʊ, hi hæd tə meɪk əɹ ɪntʃɹəstəd. haʊ ɪn ðə laɪt wɑz i gɑnə də ðæt?

Once she was gone, he shifted himself to put his back against the wall again and sat fingering the flute. He thought instead of playing, though. Min said he needed Cadsuane, but Cadsuane was not interested in him except as a curiosity. A bad-mannered curiosity. Somehow, he had to make her interested. How in the Light was he going to do that?

wɪð səm dɪfəkəlti vɛɹɪn skwiz hɝsɛlf aʊɾ ə ðə sɪdæn tʃɛɹ ɪn ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹɾ ʌv əlaɪz' pæləs. ʃi wɑz sɪmpli nɑt kənstʃɹʌktəd tə fɪt ðə θɪŋz, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ ðə fæstəst weɪ tə ɡɛɾ əbaʊɾ ɪn fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ. koʊtʃɪz ɔlweɪz bɑɡd daʊn ɪn ðə kɹaʊdz sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ, ən ðeɪ kəd nɑt ɡoʊ səm pleɪsəz ʃi wɑntəd tə. ðə dæmp wɪnz ɔf ðə leɪk wɝ tɝnɪŋ koʊldɝ əz ivnɪŋ dipən ɪndə twaɪlaɪt, bʌt ʃi lɛt ðə wɪnd wɪp əɹ kloʊk əbaʊt waɪl ʃi dʌɡ tu sɪlvɝ pɛniz fɹəm əɹ pɝs ən ɡeɪv əm tə ðə bɛɹɝz. ʃi wɑz nɑt səpoʊz tə, ʌv kɔɹs, sɪns ðeɪ wɝ əlaɪz' bɔɪz, bʌɾ idwinə wəd nɑt noʊ ðæt. ðeɪ ʃəd nɑɾ əv æksɛptɪd, bʌt ðə sɪlvɝ vænɪʃt ɪndə ðɛɹ koʊts ɪn ə twɪŋkəlɪŋ, ən ðə jʌŋɡɝ ə ðə pɛɹ, ə hænsəm fɛloʊ ɪn ɪz mɪɾəl jɪɹz, ivən meɪɾ əɹ ə flɝɪʃɪŋ baʊ bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ pɪkt ʌp ðə tʃɛɹ ən tʃɹɑɾəd ɔf təwɔɹd ðə steɪbəl, ə loʊ stʃɹʌktʃɝ sɛɾ ɪn ə kɔɹnɝ əɡɛns ðə fɹʌnt wɔl. vɛɹɪn saɪd. ə bɔɪ ɪn ɪz mɪɾəl jɪɹz. ɪt hæd nɑt teɪkən əɹ lɔŋ bæk ɪn fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ tə bɪɡɪn θɪŋkɪŋ əz ɪf ʃi hæd nɛvɝ lɛft. ʃi hæd tə bi kɛɹfəl əbaʊt ðæt. ɪt kəd bi deɪnʒɝəs, nɑt list ɪf əlaɪz əɹ ði ʌðɝz dɪskʌvɝɾ əɹ dɪsɛpʃən. ʃi səspɛktəd ðə wɔɹəns fəɹ vɛɹɪn mæθwɪnz ɛɡzaɪl hæd nɛvɝ bɪn səspɛndəd. fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ kɛp kwaɪət wən ən ɛɛs sədaɪ fɛl əfaʊl ə ðə lɔ, bʌt ðə kaʊnsəlz hæd noʊ ɹizən tə fɪɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən fəɹ ɪts oʊn ɹizənz, ðə taʊɝ ɪn tɝn kɛp kwaɪəɾ ɑn ðoʊz ɹɛɹ əkeɪʒənz wən ə sɪstɝ faʊn hɝsɛlf stʃɹʌŋ ʌp fəɹ ə dʒudɪʃəl flɑɡɪŋ. ʃi hæd noʊ ɪntɛntʃən ə biɪŋ ðə leɪɾəst ɹizən fəɹ ðə taʊɝ tə kip saɪləns.

With some difficulty Verin squeezed herself out of the sedan chair in the courtyard of Aleis' palace. She was simply not constructed to fit the things, but they were the fastest way to get about in Far Madding. Coaches always bogged down in the crowds sooner or later, and they could not go some places she wanted to. The damp winds off the lake were turning colder as evening deepened into twilight, but she let the wind whip her cloak about while she dug two silver pennies from her purse and gave them to the bearers. She was not supposed to, of course, since they were Aleis' boys, but Eadwina would not know that. They should not have accepted, but the silver vanished into their coats in a twinkling, and the younger of the pair, a handsome fellow in his middle years, even made her a flourishing bow before they picked up the chair and trotted off toward the stable, a low structure set in a corner against the front wall. Verin sighed. A boy in his middle years. It had not taken her long back in Far Madding to begin thinking as if she had never left. She had to be careful about that. It could be dangerous, not least if Aleis or the others discovered her deception. She suspected the warrants for Verin Mathwin's exile had never been suspended. Far Madding kept quiet when an Aes Sedai fell afoul of the law, but the Counsels had no reason to fear Aes Sedai, and for its own reasons, the Tower in turn kept quiet on those rare occasions when a sister found herself strung up for a judicial flogging. She had no intention of being the latest reason for the Tower to keep silence.

əlaɪz' pæləs wɑz nɑɾ ə pætʃ ɑn ðə sʌn pæləs, ʌv kɔɹs, əɹ ðə ɹɔɪəl pæləs ɪn ændɝ, əɹ ɛni ʌv ðə pæləsəz kɪŋz ən kwinz ɹul fɹʌm. ɪt wɑz əɹ oʊn pɹɑpɝɾi, nɑɾ ətætʃt tə hɝ pəzɪʃən əz fɝs kaʊnsəl. ʌðɝz, lɑɹdʒɝ ən smɔlɝ, mɑɹtʃt əweɪ ɑn iðɝ saɪd, itʃ sɝaʊndəd baɪ ə haɪ wɔl ɪksɛpt ɑn ði ɛnd wɛɹ ðə haɪts, ði oʊnli pɔɪn əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ ə hɪl ɑn ði ɪntaɪɝ aɪlənd, fɛl əweɪ tə ðə wɔɾɝ ɪn ə ʃɪɹ blʌf. stɪl, ɪt wɑz nɑt smɔl, iðɝ. ðə bɑɹsælə wɪmən hæd bɪn dilɪŋ ɪn tʃɹeɪɾ ən pɑlətɪks sɪns ðə sɪɾi wɑz stɪl kɔl fɛl mɔɹinə. tɔl-kɑləmd wɔks sɝaʊndəd ðə bɑɹsælə pæləs ɑn boʊθ lɛvəlz, ən ðə waɪt mɑɹbəl kjub kʌvɝd moʊst ə ðə wɔld ɡɹaʊnz.

Aleis' palace was not a patch on the Sun Palace, of course, or the Royal Palace in Andor, or any of the palaces kings and queens ruled from. It was her own property, not attached to her position as First Counsel. Others, larger and smaller, marched away on either side, each surrounded by a high wall except on the end where the Heights, the only point approaching a hill on the entire island, fell away to the water in a sheer bluff. Still, it was not small, either. The Barsalla women had been dealing in trade and politics since the city was still called Fel Moreina. Tall-columned walks surrounded the Barsalla palace on both levels, and the white marble cube covered most of the walled grounds.

ʃi faʊn kædzueɪn ɪn ə sɪɾɪŋ ɹum ðət wʊɾə ɔfɝɾ ə ɡʊd vju ʌv ðə leɪk ɪf ðə kɝɾənz hæd nɑt bɪn dʒɹɔn tə kip ɪn ðə wɔɹmθ ə ðə bleɪz ɪn ðə waɪd mɑɹbəl faɪɝpleɪs. kædzueɪn sæt, wɪð əɹ soʊɪŋ bæskəɾ ɑn ə smɔl ɪnleɪd teɪbəl bɪsaɪɾ əɹ tʃɛɹ, kɑmli wɝkɪŋ wɪð niɾəl ən ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi hup. ʃi wɑz nɑɾ əloʊn. vɛɹɪn foʊldəɾ əɹ kloʊk oʊvɝ ðə bæk ʌv ə pæɾəd tʃɛɹ ən tʊk ənʌðɝ tə weɪt.

She found Cadsuane in a sitting room that would have offered a good view of the lake if the curtains had not been drawn to keep in the warmth of the blaze in the wide marble fireplace. Cadsuane sat, with her sewing basket on a small inlaid table beside her chair, calmly working with needle and embroidery hoop. She was not alone. Verin folded her cloak over the back of a padded chair and took another to wait.

ɛlzə bɛɹli ɡlænst ət hɝ. ðə juʒəwəli plɛzənt-feɪst ɡɹin stʊɾ ɑn ðə kɑɹpəɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə kædzueɪn lʊkɪŋ kwaɪt fɪɹs, hɝ feɪs ɹɛɾ ən əɹ aɪz ɡlɛɹɪŋ. ɛlzə wɑz ɔlweɪz vɛɹi kɑnʃəs ʌv wɛɹ ʃi stʊd wɪð ɹɪspɛk tə ʌðɝ sɪstɝz, pɝhæps tu mʌtʃ soʊ. fəɹ əɹ tə ɪɡnɔɹ vɛɹɪn, mʌtʃ lɛs kənfɹʌn kædzueɪn, ʃi mʌst əv bɪn ɪn ə faɪn swɪvət. "haʊ kəd jə lɛɾ əɹ ɡoʊ?" ʃi dɪmændəɾ ə kædzueɪn. "haʊ ɑɹ wi tə faɪn ɪm wɪθaʊt hɝ?" ɑ, soʊ ðət wɑz ɪt.

Elza barely glanced at her. The usually pleasant-faced Green stood on the carpet in front of Cadsuane looking quite fierce, her face red and her eyes glaring. Elza was always very conscious of where she stood with respect to other sisters, perhaps too much so. For her to ignore Verin, much less confront Cadsuane, she must have been in a fine swivet. "How could you let her go?" she demanded of Cadsuane. "How are we to find him without her?" Ah, so that was it.

kædzueɪnz hɛd ɹɪmeɪn bɛn oʊvɝ əɹ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi hup, ən əɹ niɾəl kəntɪnjud tə meɪk taɪni stɪtʃɪz. "ju kən weɪɾ əntɪl ʃi ɹɪtɝnz," ʃi sɛd kɑmli.

Cadsuane's head remained bent over her embroidery hoop, and her needle continued to make tiny stitches. "You can wait until she returns," she said calmly.

ɛlzəz hænz dʌbəld ɪndə fɪsts əɾ əɹ saɪd. "haʊ kən jə bi soʊ dɪtætʃt?" ʃi dɪmændəd. "hi ɪz ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn! ðɪs pleɪs kəd bi ə dɛθ tʃɹæp fəɹ hɪm! juv tə - !" hɝ tiθ snæpt ʃʌɾ əz kædzueɪn hɛld ʌp ə fɪŋɡɝ. ðət wɑz ɔl kædzueɪn dɪd, bʌt fɹəm əɹ ɪt wɑz ɪnʌf.

Elza's hands doubled into fists at her side. "How can you be so detached?" she demanded. "He is the Dragon Reborn! This place could be a death trap for him! You have to - !" Her teeth snapped shut as Cadsuane held up a finger. That was all Cadsuane did, but from her it was enough.

"aɪv pʊɾ ʌp wɪð jəɹ taɪɹeɪd lɔŋ ɪnʌf, ɛlzə. jə meɪ ɡoʊ. naʊ!"

"I've put up with your tirade long enough, Elza. You may go. Now!"

ɛlzə hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, bʌt ʃi ɹɪli hæd noʊ tʃɔɪs. hɝ feɪs wɑz stɪl ɹɛɾ əz ʃi bɑbd ə kɝtsi wɪð əɹ dɑɹk ɡɹin skɝts klʌtʃt ɪn əɹ fɪsts, bʌɾ ɪf ʃi stɔk fɹəm ðə sɪɾɪŋ ɹum, ʃi stɪl lɛft wɪθaʊt fɝðɝ dɪleɪ.

Elza hesitated, but she really had no choice. Her face was still red as she bobbed a curtsy with her dark green skirts clutched in her fists, but if she stalked from the sitting room, she still left without further delay.

kædzueɪn sɛt ði ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi hup ɑn əɹ læp ən lin bæk. "wɪl jə meɪk mi səm ti, vɛɹɪn?"

Cadsuane set the embroidery hoop on her lap and leaned back. "Will you make me some tea, Verin?"

ɪn spaɪɾ ə hɝsɛlf, vɛɹɪn ɡeɪv ə smɔl stɑɹt. ði ʌðɝ sɪstɝ hæd nɑt lʊkt ɪn əɹ dɝɛkʃən wʌns. "ʌv kɔɹs, kædzueɪn." ə hɛvəli wɝk sɪlvɝ tipɑt sæɾ ɑn ə fɔɹ-lɛɡəd stæn ɑn wʌn ə ðə saɪd teɪbəlz, ən wɑz stɪl hɑt, lʌkəli. "wɑz ɪt waɪz tə lɛɾ ɑlɑnə ɡoʊ?" ʃi æskt.

In spite of herself, Verin gave a small start. The other sister had not looked in her direction once. "Of course, Cadsuane." A heavily worked silver teapot sat on a four-legged stand on one of the side tables, and was still hot, luckily. "Was it wise to let Alanna go?" she asked.

"aɪ kəd hɑɹdli stɑp əɹ wɪθaʊt lɛɾɪŋ ðə bɔɪ noʊ mɔɹ ðən i ʃʊd, naʊ kəɾ aɪ?" kædzueɪn ɹɪplaɪd dʒɹaɪli.

"I could hardly stop her without letting the boy know more than he should, now could I?" Cadsuane replied dryly.

teɪkɪŋ əɹ taɪm, vɛɹɪn tɪp ðə tipɑt tə pɔɹ ɪndə ə θɪn blu pɔɹsələn kʌp. nɑt si foʊk pɔɹsələn, bʌt vɛɹi faɪn. "du juv ɛni aɪdiə waɪ hi keɪm tə fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ, ʌv ɔl pleɪsəz? aɪ nɪɹli swɑloʊd maɪ tʌŋ wən ɪt keɪm tə mi ðət ðə ɹizən i hæd stɑp lipɪŋ əbaʊt maɪt bi kəz i wɑz hɪɹ. ɪf ɪts sʌmθɪŋ deɪnʒɝəs, pɝhæps wi ʃəd tʃɹaɪ tə stɑp hɪm."

Taking her time, Verin tipped the teapot to pour into a thin blue porcelain cup. Not Sea Folk porcelain, but very fine. "Do you have any idea why he came to Far Madding, of all places? I nearly swallowed my tongue when it came to me that the reason he had stopped leaping about might be because he was here. If it's something dangerous, perhaps we should try to stop him."

"vɛɹɪn, hi kən də wʌtɛvɝ ɪz hɑɹt dɪzaɪɝz, ɛniθɪŋ əɾ ɔl, əz lɔŋ əz i laɪvz tə ɹitʃ tɑɹmən ɡdən. ən əz lɔŋ əz aɪ kən bi əɾ ɪz saɪd lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə meɪk ɪm lɝn haʊ tə læf əɡɛn, ən kɹaɪ." kloʊzɪŋ əɹ aɪz, ʃi ɹʌbd əɹ tɛmpəlz wɪð əɹ fɪŋɡɝtɪps ən saɪd. "hi ɪz tɝnɪŋ ɪndə ə stoʊn, vɛɹɪn, ən ɪf i dʌzn ɹilɝn ðət hiz hjumən, wɪnɪŋ ðə læs bæɾəl meɪ nɑt bi mʌtʃ bɛɾɝ ðən luzɪŋ. jʌŋ mɪn toʊld ɪm i nidz mi; aɪ ɡɑt ðət mʌtʃ aʊɾ ə hɝ wɪθaʊt ɹaʊzɪŋ əɹ səspɪʃənz. bʌɾ aɪ mʌst weɪt fəɹ ɪm tə kʌm tə mi. jə si ðə weɪ hi ɹʌnz ɹʌfʃɑɾ oʊvɝ ɑlɑnə ən ði ʌðɝz. ɪɾəl bi hɑɹɾ ɪnʌf titʃɪŋ hɪm, ɪf i dʌz æsk. hi faɪts ɡaɪɾəns, hi θɪŋks i mʌs də ɛvɹiθɪŋ, lɝn ɛvɹiθɪŋ, ɑn ɪz oʊn, ən ɪf aɪ də nɑt meɪk ɪm wɝk fəɹ ɪt, hi woʊn lɝn əɾ ɔl." hɝ hænz dʒɹɑpt ɑntu ði ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi hup ɑn əɹ læp. "aɪ sim tə bi ɪn ə kənfaɪɾɪŋ mud tənaɪt. ənjuʒəwəl, fəɹ mi. ɪf jə ɛvɝ fɪnɪʃ pɔɹɪŋ ðət ti, aɪ meɪ kənfaɪd səm mɔɹ."

"Verin, he can do whatever his heart desires, anything at all, as long as he lives to reach Tarmon Gai'don. And as long as I can be at his side long enough to make him learn how to laugh again, and cry." Closing her eyes, she rubbed her temples with her fingertips and sighed. "He is turning into a stone, Verin, and if he doesn't relearn that he's human, winning the Last Battle may not be much better than losing. Young Min told him he needs me; I got that much out of her without rousing her suspicions. But I must wait for him to come to me. You see the way he runs roughshod over Alanna and the others. It will be hard enough teaching him, if he does ask. He fights guidance, he thinks he must do everything, learn everything, on his own, and if I do not make him work for it, he won't learn at all." Her hands dropped onto the embroidery hoop on her lap. "I seem to be in a confiding mood tonight. Unusual, for me. If you ever finish pouring that tea, I may confide some more."

"oʊ, jɛs; ʌv kɔɹs." heɪstəli fɪlɪŋ ə sɛkən kʌp, vɛɹɪn slɪp ðə smɔl vaɪəl bæk ɪndə hɝ paʊtʃ ənoʊpənd. ɪt wɑz ɡʊd tə bi ʃʊɹ ə kædzueɪn ət læst. "du jə teɪk hʌni?" ʃi æskt ɪn əɹ moʊs mʌɾəld vɔɪs. "aɪ nɛvɝ kən ɹɪmɛmbɝ."

"Oh, yes; of course." Hastily filling a second cup, Verin slipped the small vial back into her pouch unopened. It was good to be sure of Cadsuane at last. "Do you take honey?" she asked in her most muddled voice. "I never can remember."


tʃæptɝ twɛntisɪks


CHAPTER 26

ɛkspɛkteɪʃən


Expectation

wɔkɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə bɹaʊn-ɡɹæs vɪlədʒ ɡɹin ʌv ɛmənz fild wɪð ɛɡwin, ɪleɪn fɛl sæɾənd baɪ ðə tʃeɪnʒəz. ɛɡwin sim stʌn baɪ ðɛm. wən ʃi fɝst əpɪɹɾ ɪn tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd, ə lɔŋ bɹeɪd hæd dæŋɡəl daʊn ɛɡwinz bæk ən ʃi wɑz ɪn ə pleɪn wʊlən dʒɹɛs, ʌv ɔl θɪŋz, wɪð staʊt ʃuz pikɪŋ aʊt bɪniθ əɹ skɝts əz ʃi wɔkt. ɪleɪn səpoʊzd ɪt wɑz ðə sɔɹɾ ə kloʊðɪŋ ʃi hæd wɔɹn wən ʃi lɪvd ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. naʊ hɝ dɑɹk hɛɹ hʌŋ əbaʊɾ əɹ ʃoʊldɝz, sɪkjʊɹd baɪ ə smɔl kæp ə faɪn leɪs, ən əɹ ɡɑɹməns wɝ əz faɪn əz ɪleɪnz, ə ɹɪtʃ blu ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd wɪð sɪlvɝ ɑn ðə bɑɾəs ən haɪ nɛk əz wɛl əz əlɔŋ ðə hɛm ə hɝ skɝɾ ən əɹ kʌfs. sɪlvɝ-wɝk vɛlvət slɪpɝz ɹipleɪs ðə θɪk lɛðɝ ʃuz. ɪleɪn niɾəd tə meɪnteɪn əɹ foʊkəs tə kip əɹ oʊn ɡɹin sɪlk ɹaɪɾɪŋ dʒɹɛs fɹəm ɔltɝɪŋ, pɝhæps ɪn ɪmbɛɹəsɪŋ fæʃən, bʌt fəɹ əɹ fɹɛnd, wɪθaʊɾ ɛni daʊt, ðə tʃeɪnʒəz wɝ dɪlɪbɝɪt.

Walking across the brown-grassed village green of Emond's Field with Egwene, Elayne felt saddened by the changes. Egwene seemed stunned by them. When she first appeared in Tel'aran'rhiod, a long braid had dangled down Egwene's back and she was in a plain woolen dress, of all things, with stout shoes peeking out beneath her skirts as she walked. Elayne supposed it was the sort of clothing she had worn when she lived in the Two Rivers. Now her dark hair hung about her shoulders, secured by a small cap of fine lace, and her garments were as fine as Elayne's, a rich blue embroidered with silver on the bodice and high neck as well as along the hem of her skirt and her cuffs. Silver-worked velvet slippers replaced the thick leather shoes. Elayne needed to maintain her focus to keep her own green silk riding dress from altering, perhaps in embarrassing fashion, but for her friend, without any doubt, the changes were deliberate.

ʃi hoʊpt ɹænd kəd stɪl lʌv ɛmənz fild, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ðə vɪlədʒ wɛɹ i ən ɛɡwin hæd ɡɹoʊn ʌp. ðəɹ wɝ noʊ pipəl, hɪɹ ɪn ðə wɝld ə dʒɹimz, jɛt klɪɹli ɛmənz fild wɑz ə kənsɪɾɝəbəl taʊn naʊ, ə pɹɑspɝəs taʊn, wɪð nɪɹli wʌn haʊs ɪn θɹi meɪɾ ʌv wɛl-dʒɹɛst stoʊn, səm ə θɹi stɔɹiz, ən mɔɹ ɹuft wɪð taɪlz ɪn ɛvɹi hju ʌv ðə ɹeɪnboʊ ðən wɪð θætʃ. səm stʃɹits wɝ peɪvd wɪð smuð wɛl-fɪɾəd stoʊn, nu ən ənwɹn əz jɛt, ən ðəɹ wɑz ivən ə θɪk stoʊn wɔl ɡoʊɪŋ ʌp ɝaʊn ðə taʊn, wɪð taʊɝz ən aɪɝn-pleɪɾəd ɡeɪts ðət wʊɾə suɾəd ə bɔɹɾɝlənd taʊn. aʊtsaɪd ðə wɔlz ðəɹ wɝ ɡɹɪstmɪlz ən sɔmɪlz, ən aɪɝn faʊnʒɹi ən lɑɹdʒ wɝkʃɑps fəɹ wivɝz ə boʊθ wʊlənz ən kɑɹpəts, ən wɪðɪn wɝ ʃɑps ɹʌn baɪ fɝnɪtʃɝ meɪkɝz, pɑɾɝz, simstʃɹəsəz, kʌtlɝz, ən ɡoʊld-æn sɪlvɝsmɪθs, mɛni əz faɪn əz kəd bi sin ɪn keɪɛmlɪn, ðoʊ səm ə ðə staɪlz sim tə bi fɹəm ɑɹæd dumən əɹ tæɹɑbən.

She hoped Rand could still love Emond's Field, but it was no longer the village where he and Egwene had grown up. There were no people, here in the World of Dreams, yet clearly Emond's Field was a considerable town now, a prosperous town, with nearly one house in three made of well-dressed stone, some of three stories, and more roofed with tiles in every hue of the rainbow than with thatch. Some streets were paved with smooth well-fitted stone, new and unworn as yet, and there was even a thick stone wall going up around the town, with towers and iron-plated gates that would have suited a Borderland town. Outside the walls there were gristmills and sawmills, an iron foundry and large workshops for weavers of both woolens and carpets, and within were shops run by furniture makers, potters, seamstresses, cutlers, and gold-and silversmiths, many as fine as could be seen in Caemlyn, though some of the styles seemed to be from Arad Doman or Tarabon.

ði ɛɹ wɑz kul bʌt nɑt koʊld, ən ðəɹ wɑz nɑɾ ə saɪn ə snoʊ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, ət lis fəɹ ðə moʊmənt. ðə sʌn stʊd stʃɹeɪɾ oʊvɝhɛd hɪɹ, ðoʊ ɪleɪn hoʊpt ɪt wɑz stɪl naɪɾ ɪn ðə weɪkɪŋ wɝld. ʃi wɑntəd səm ɹil slip bɪfɔɹ ʃi hæd tə feɪs ðə mɔɹnɪŋ. ʃi wɑz ɔlweɪz taɪɝd, ðə læs fju deɪz; ðəɹ wɑz dʒʌst soʊ mʌtʃ tə bi dʌn, ən soʊ fju aʊɝz. ðeɪ hæd kʌm hɪɹ kəz ɪt simd ənlaɪkli ɛni spaɪ kəd faɪn əm hɪɹ, bʌɾ ɛɡwin hæd lɪŋɡɝd tə stɛɹ ət ðə tʃeɪnʒəz ɪn ðə pleɪs ʃi wɑz bɔɹn. ən ɪleɪn hæɾ əɹ oʊn ɹizənz, bɪɑn ɹænd, fəɹ wɑntɪŋ tə lʊk oʊvɝ ɛmənz fild. ðə pɹɑbləm, wʌn ə ðə pɹɑbləmz, wɑz ðət wʌn aʊɝ maɪt pæs ɪn ðə weɪkɪŋ wɝld waɪl jə spɛn faɪv əɹ tɛn ɪn ðə wɝld ə dʒɹimz, bʌɾ ɪt kəd dʒʌst əz izəli bi ði ʌðɝ weɪ ɝaʊnd. ɪt maɪt bi mɔɹnɪŋ ɔlɹɛɾi ɪn keɪɛmlɪn.

The air was cool but not cold, and there was not a sign of snow on the ground, at least for the moment. The sun stood straight overhead here, though Elayne hoped it was still night in the waking world. She wanted some real sleep before she had to face the morning. She was always tired, the last few days; there was just so much to be done, and so few hours. They had come here because it seemed unlikely any spy could find them here, but Egwene had lingered to stare at the changes in the place she was born. And Elayne had her own reasons, beyond Rand, for wanting to look over Emond's Field. The problem, one of the problems, was that one hour might pass in the waking world while you spent five or ten in the World of Dreams, but it could just as easily be the other way around. It might be morning already in Caemlyn.

stɑpɪŋ ət ði ɛdʒ ə ðə ɡɹin, ɛɡwin ɡeɪz bæk ət ðə waɪd stoʊn bɹɪdʒ ðəɾ ɑɹtʃt oʊvɝ ðə ɹæpədli waɪɾənɪŋ stʃɹim ɹʌnɪŋ fɹəm ə spɹɪŋ ðət ɡʌʃt aʊɾ ʌv ə stoʊn aʊtkɹɑp stʃɹɔŋli ɪnʌf tə nɑk ə mæn daʊn. ə mæsɪv mɑɹbəl ʃæf kɑɹvd ɔl oʊvɝ wɪð neɪmz stʊɾ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə ɡɹin, ən tu tɔl flæɡpoʊlz ɑn stoʊn beɪsəz. "ə bæɾəl mɑnjəmənt," ʃi mɝmɝd. "hu kəɾ ɪmædʒən sətʃ ə θɪŋ ɪn ɛmənz fild? ðoʊ mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd ðət wʌns ə ɡɹeɪt bæɾəl wɑz fɔɾ ɑn ðɪs spɑt, ɪn ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz, wən meɪnɛðɝən daɪd."

Stopping at the edge of the green, Egwene gazed back at the wide stone bridge that arched over the rapidly widening stream running from a spring that gushed out of a stone outcrop strongly enough to knock a man down. A massive marble shaft carved all over with names stood in the middle of the green, and two tall flagpoles on stone bases. "A battle monument," she murmured. "Who could imagine such a thing in Emond's Field? Though Moiraine said that once a great battle was fought on this spot, in the Trolloc Wars, when Manetheren died."

"ɪt wɑz ɪn ðə hɪstɝi aɪ stʌɾid," ɪleɪn sɛd kwaɪətli, ɡlænsɪŋ ət ðə bɛɹ flæɡpoʊlz. bɛɹ fəɹ ðə moʊmənt. ʃi kəd nɑt fil ɹænd, hɪɹ. oʊ, hi wɑz stɪl ɪn əɹ hɛɾ əz mʌtʃ əz bɝdʒɪt, ə ɹɑklaɪk nɑɾ ʌv ɪmoʊʃənz ən fɪzɪkəl sɛnseɪʃənz ðət wɑz ivən mɔɹ dɪfəkəl tə ɪntɝpɹət naʊ ðəɾ i wɑz fɑɹ əweɪ, jɛt hɪɹ ɪn tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd, ʃi kəd nɑt noʊ wɪtʃ dɝɛkʃən i wɑz. ʃi mɪs ðət nɑlədʒ, smɔl əz ɪt wɑz. ʃi mɪs hɪm.

"It was in the history I studied," Elayne said quietly, glancing at the bare flagpoles. Bare for the moment. She could not feel Rand, here. Oh, he was still in her head as much as Birgitte, a rocklike knot of emotions and physical sensations that was even more difficult to interpret now that he was far away, yet here in Tel'aran'rhiod, she could not know which direction he was. She missed that knowledge, small as it was. She missed him.

bænɝz əpɪɹɾ ətɑp ðə flæɡpoʊlz, ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ dʒʌs lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə ɹɪpəl wʌns læzəli. lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə meɪk aʊɾ ɑn wʌn ə ɹɛɾ iɡəl flaɪɪŋ əkɹɔs ə fild ə blu. nɑɾ ə ɹɛɾ iɡəl; ðə ɹɛɾ iɡəl. wʌns, vɪzəɾɪŋ ðɪs pleɪs wɪð nɪneɪiv ɪn tɛlɝɑnɹhiəd, ʃi hæd θɔt ʃi ɡlɪmpst ɪt, hæd dɪsaɪɾɪd ʃi mʌs bi mɪsteɪkən. mæstɝ nɔɹi hæd bɪɡʌn sɛɾɪŋ əɹ stʃɹeɪt. ʃi lʌvd ɹænd, bʌɾ ɪf sʌmwʌn ɪn ðə pleɪs i ɡɹu ʌp wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɹeɪz meɪnɛðɝən fɹəm ɪts eɪntʃənt ɡɹeɪv, ʃi wəɾ əv tə teɪk kɑɡnəzəns, haʊɛvɝ mʌtʃ ɪt peɪn hɪm. ðət bænɝ ən ðət neɪm stɪl kæɹiɾ ɪnʌf paʊɝ tə θɹɛɾən ændɝ.

Banners appeared atop the flagpoles, remaining just long enough to ripple once lazily. Long enough to make out on one a red eagle flying across a field of blue. Not a red eagle; the Red Eagle. Once, visiting this place with Nynaeve in Tel'aran'rhiod, she had thought she glimpsed it, had decided she must be mistaken. Master Norry had begun setting her straight. She loved Rand, but if someone in the place he grew up was trying to raise Manetheren from its ancient grave, she would have to take cognizance, however much it pained him. That banner and that name still carried enough power to threaten Andor.

"aɪ hɝɾ əbaʊt tʃeɪnʒəz fɹəm boʊd kɔθən ən ði ʌðɝ nɑvəsɪz fɹəm hoʊm," ɛɡwin wɛn ɑn, fɹaʊnɪŋ ət ðə haʊsəz ɝaʊn ðə ɡɹin, "bʌt nʌθɪŋ laɪk ðɪs." moʊst ə ðoʊz haʊsəz wɝ stoʊn. ə taɪni ɪn stɪl stʊd bɪsaɪd ðə spɹɔlɪŋ stoʊn faʊndeɪʃən ə səm mʌtʃ lɑɹdʒɝ bɪldɪŋ, wɪð ə hjudʒ oʊk ɡɹoʊɪŋ ʌp θɹu ðə mɪɾəl ʌv ɪt, bʌt wʌt lʊk tə bi ən ɪn mɛni taɪmz bɪɡɝ wɑz ɔlmoʊs fɪnɪʃt ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə faʊndeɪʃən, wɪð ə lɑɹdʒ saɪn ɹiɾɪŋ ði ɑɹtʃɝz ɔlɹɛɾi hʌŋ əbʌv ðə dɔɹ. "aɪ wʌndɝ wɛðɝ maɪ fɑðɝ ɪz stɪl meɪɝ. ɪz maɪ mʌðɝ wɛl? maɪ sɪstɝz?"

"I heard about changes from Bode Cauthon and the other novices from home," Egwene went on, frowning at the houses around the green, "but nothing like this." Most of those houses were stone. A tiny inn still stood beside the sprawling stone foundation of some much larger building, with a huge oak growing up through the middle of it, but what looked to be an inn many times bigger was almost finished on the other side of the foundation, with a large sign reading The Archers already hung above the door. "I wonder whether my father is still Mayor. Is my mother well? My sisters?"

"aɪ noʊ jə ɑɹ muvɪŋ ði ɑɹmi təmɑɹoʊ," ɪleɪn sɛd, "ɪf ɪɾ ɪzən təmɑɹoʊ ɔlɹɛɾi, bʌt ʃʊɹli jə kəd faɪn ə fju aʊɝz tə vɪzət hɪɹ wʌns jə ɹitʃ tɑɹ vəlɑn." tʃɹævlɪŋ meɪd sətʃ θɪŋz izi. pɝhæps ʃi hɝsɛlf ʃəd sɛn sʌmwʌn tə ɛmənz fild. ɪf ʃi nu hum tə tʃɹʌs fəɹ ðə mɪʃən. ɪf ʃi kəd spɛɹ ɛniwʌn ʃi dɪd tʃɹʌst.

"I know you are moving the army tomorrow," Elayne said, "if it isn't tomorrow already, but surely you could find a few hours to visit here once you reach Tar Valon." Traveling made such things easy. Perhaps she herself should send someone to Emond's Field. If she knew whom to trust for the mission. If she could spare anyone she did trust.

ɛɡwin ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "ɪleɪn, aɪv hæd tə ɔɹɾɝ wɪmən aɪ ɡɹu ʌp wɪð swɪtʃt kəz ðeɪ doʊn bɪliv aɪm ði æmɪɝlɪn sit, əɹ ɪf ðeɪ du, ðət ðeɪ kən bɹeɪk ðə ɹulz kəz ðeɪ nu mi." sʌɾənli ðə sɛvən-stʃɹaɪp stoʊl hʌŋ fɹəm əɹ ʃoʊldɝz. əntɪl ʃi noʊɾəst ɪt wɪð ə ɡɹɪmɑs, ən ɪt vænɪʃt əɡɛn. "aɪ doʊn θɪŋk aɪ kən feɪs kənfɹʌntɪŋ ɛmənz fild əz æmɪɝlɪn," ʃi sɛd sædli. "nɑt jɛt." ʃi ɡeɪv hɝsɛlf ə ʃeɪk, ən əɹ vɔɪs fɝmd. "ðə wil tɝnz, ɪleɪn, ən ɛvɹiθɪŋ tʃeɪnʒəz. aɪ mʌst ɡɛt juz tə ɪt. əl ɡɛt juz tə ɪt." ʃi saʊndəɾ ə ɡɹeɪt dil laɪk sɪuən sɑntʃ, əz sɪuən hæd saʊndəɾ ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn bɪfɔɹ ɛvɹiθɪŋ hæd tʃeɪnʒd. stoʊl əɹ noʊ stoʊl, ɛɡwin saʊndəd laɪk ði æmɪɝlɪn sit. "ɑɹ jə sɝɾən aɪ kæn sɛn jə səm ʌv ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪnz soʊlʒɝz? ɪnʌf tə hɛlp sɪkjʊɹ keɪɛmlɪn, ət list."

Egwene shook her head. "Elayne, I've had to order women I grew up with switched because they don't believe I am the Amyrlin Seat, or if they do, that they can break the rules because they knew me." Suddenly the seven-striped stole hung from her shoulders. Until she noticed it with a grimace, and it vanished again. "I don't think I can face confronting Emond's Field as Amyrlin," she said sadly. "Not yet." She gave herself a shake, and her voice firmed. "The Wheel turns, Elayne, and everything changes. I must get used to it. I will get used to it." She sounded a great deal like Siuan Sanche, as Siuan had sounded in Tar Valon before everything had changed. Stole or no stole, Egwene sounded like the Amyrlin Seat. "Are you certain I can't send you some of Gareth Bryne's soldiers? Enough to help secure Caemlyn, at least."

əbɹʌpli, ðeɪ wɝ sɝaʊndəd baɪ ɡlɪsnɪŋ snoʊ, stændɪŋ ni-dip ɪn ɪt. snoʊ meɪd ɡlimɪŋ waɪt maʊnz ɑn ðə ɹuftɑps əz ɪf fɹəm ə hɛvi fɔl. ðɪs wɑz nɑt ðə fɝs taɪm sətʃ ə θɪŋ hæd hæpənd, ən ðeɪ sɪmpli ɹəfjuz tə lɛt ðə sʌɾən koʊl tʌtʃ ðɛm, ɹæðɝ ðən ɪmædʒənɪŋ kloʊks ən wɔɹmɝ kloʊðz.

Abruptly, they were surrounded by glistening snow, standing knee-deep in it. Snow made gleaming white mounds on the rooftops as if from a heavy fall. This was not the first time such a thing had happened, and they simply refused to let the sudden cold touch them, rather than imagining cloaks and warmer clothes.

"noʊ wʌn ɪz gɑnə muv əɡɛns mi bɪfɔɹ spɹɪŋ," ɪleɪn sɛd. ɑɹmiz dɪd nɑt muv ɪn wɪntɝ, ət list, nɑɾ ənlɛs ðeɪ hæd ðə bɛnəfɪɾ ə tʃɹævlɪŋ, laɪk ɛɡwinz ɑɹmi. snoʊ bɑɡd ɛvɹiθɪŋ daʊn, ən mʌd wɛnɛvɝ ðə snoʊ mɛltəd. ðoʊz bɔɹɾɝləndɝz pɹɑbli hæd bɪɡʌn ðɛɹ mɑɹtʃ saʊθ θɪŋkɪŋ wɪntɝ wɑz nɛvɝ kʌmɪŋ ðɪs jɪɹ. "bɪsaɪdz, jəl niɾ ɛvɹi mæn wən jə ɹitʃ tɑɹ vəlɑn."

"No one is going to move against me before spring," Elayne said. Armies did not move in winter, at least, not unless they had the benefit of Traveling, like Egwene's army. Snow bogged everything down, and mud whenever the snow melted. Those Borderlanders probably had begun their march south thinking winter was never coming this year. "Besides, you will need every man when you reach Tar Valon."

ʌnsɝpɹaɪzɪŋli, ɛɡwin nɑɾəd æksɛptəns wɪθaʊt meɪkɪŋ ði ɔfɝ əɡɛn. ivən wɪð ðɪs pæs mʌnθ ə hɑɹd ɹəkɹuɾɪŋ bɪhaɪn hɝ, ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn stɪl hæd noʊ mɔɹ ðən hæf ðə soʊlʒɝz i hæd toʊld əɹ wəd bi niɾəd tə teɪk tɑɹ vəlɑn. əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə ɛɡwin, hi wɑz ɹɛɾi tə bɪɡɪn wɪð wʌɾ i hæd, bʌt klɪɹli ɪt tʃɹʌbəl hɝ. "aɪ hæv hɑɹd dɪsɪʒənz tə meɪk, ɪleɪn. ðə wil wivz əz ðə wil wɪlz, bʌɾ ɪts stɪl mi hu hæz tə dɪsaɪd."

Unsurprisingly, Egwene nodded acceptance without making the offer again. Even with this past month of hard recruiting behind her, Gareth Bryne still had no more than half the soldiers he had told her would be needed to take Tar Valon. According to Egwene, he was ready to begin with what he had, but clearly it troubled her. "I have hard decisions to make, Elayne. The Wheel weaves as the Wheel wills, but it is still me who has to decide."

ɪmpʌlsɪvli, ɪleɪn weɪɾɪd θɹu ðə snoʊ ən θɹu hɝ ɑɹmz ɝaʊn ɛɡwin tə hʌɡ hɝ. ət list, ʃi stɑɹɾəd aʊt weɪɾɪŋ. əz ʃi klæsp ði ʌðɝ wʊmən tə hɝ, ðə snoʊ vænɪʃt, livɪŋ nɑt soʊ mʌtʃ əz ə dæmp spɑɾ ɑn ðɛɹ dʒɹɛsəz. ðə tu ʌv əm stæɡɝɾ əz ɪf dænsɪŋ wɪð wʌn ənʌðɝ ən ɔlmoʊs fɛl.

Impulsively, Elayne waded through the snow and threw her arms around Egwene to hug her. At least, she started out wading. As she clasped the other woman to her, the snow vanished, leaving not so much as a damp spot on their dresses. The two of them staggered as if dancing with one another and almost fell.

"aɪ noʊ jəl meɪk ðə ɹaɪt dɪsɪʒən," ɪleɪn sɛd, læfɪŋ ɪn spaɪɾ ə hɝsɛlf. ɛɡwin dɪd nɑt dʒɔɪn əɹ læftɝ.

"I know you will make the right decision," Elayne said, laughing in spite of herself. Egwene did not join her laughter.

"aɪ hoʊp soʊ," ʃi sɛd ɡɹeɪvli, "bɪkɔz wʌtɛvɝ aɪ dɪsaɪd, pipəl ɑɹ gɑnə daɪ fəɹ ɪt." ʃi pæɾəd ɪleɪnz ɑɹm. "wɛl, jə ʌndɝstæn ðət sɔɹɾ ə dɪsɪʒən, doʊn ju. wi boʊθ nid tə bi bæk ɪn əɹ bɛdz." ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd bɪfɔɹ ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn. "ɪleɪn, ɪf ɹænd kʌmz tə jə əɡɛn, jə mʌs lemi noʊ wʌɾ i sɛz, wɛðɝ i ɡɪvz jə ɛni klu wʌɾ i minz tə də əɹ wɛɹ i minz tə ɡoʊ."

"I hope so," she said gravely, "because whatever I decide, people are going to die for it." She patted Elayne's arm. "Well, you understand that sort of decision, don't you. We both need to be back in our beds." She hesitated before going on. "Elayne, if Rand comes to you again, you must let me know what he says, whether he gives you any clue what he means to do or where he means to go."

"aɪ wɪl tɛl jə wʌtɛvɝ aɪ kæn, ɛɡwin." ɪleɪn fɛlt ə stæb ʌv ɡɪlt. ʃi hæd toʊld ɛɡwin ɛvɹiθɪŋ - ɔlmoʊst ɛvɹiθɪŋ - bʌt nɑt ðət ʃi hæd bɑndəd ɹænd wɪð mɪn ən eɪvinhə. taʊɝ lɔ dɪd nɑt pɹoʊhɪbət wʌt ðeɪ hæd dʌn. vɛɹi kɛɹfəl kwɛstʃənɪŋ ə vændin hæd meɪd ðət mʌtʃ klɪɹ. bʌt wɛðɝ ɪt wəd bi pɝmɪɾəd wɑz nɑt klɪɹ əɾ ɔl. stɪl, əz ʃi hæd hɝɾ ən ɝæfɛlɪn mɝsənɛɹi ɹɪkɹuɾɪd baɪ bɝdʒɪt seɪ, "wʌt wɑz nɑt fɔɹbɪɾən wɑz əlaʊd." ðət saʊndəɾ ɔlmoʊs laɪk wʌn ə liniz oʊl seɪɪŋz, ðoʊ ʃi daʊɾɪd əɹ nɝs wəɾ ɛvɝ əv bɪn soʊ pɝmɪsɪv. "jɔɹ tʃɹʌbəl baɪ hɪm, ɛɡwin. mɔɹ ðən juʒəwəl, aɪ min. aɪ kən tɛl. waɪ?"

"I will tell you whatever I can, Egwene." Elayne felt a stab of guilt. She had told Egwene everything - almost everything - but not that she had bonded Rand with Min and Aviendha. Tower law did not prohibit what they had done. Very careful questioning of Vandene had made that much clear. But whether it would be permitted was not clear at all. Still, as she had heard an Arafellin mercenary recruited by Birgitte say, "what was not forbidden was allowed." That sounded almost like one of Lini's old sayings, though she doubted her nurse would ever have been so permissive. "You're troubled by him, Egwene. More than usual, I mean. I can tell. Why?"

"aɪ hæv ɹizən tə bi, ɪleɪn. ði aɪz-ænd-ɪɹz ɹipɔɹt vɛɹi tʃɹʌbəlɪŋ ɹumɝz. oʊnli ɹumɝz, aɪ hoʊp, bʌɾ ɪf ðeɪ ɑɹənt . . ." ʃi wɑz vɛɹi mʌtʃ ði æmɪɝlɪn sit naʊ, ə ʃɔɹt slɛndɝ jʌŋ wʊmən u sim stʃɹɔŋ əz stil ən tɔl əz ə maʊntən. dɪtɝməneɪʃən fɪld əɹ dɑɹk aɪz ən sɛɾ əɹ dʒɔ. "aɪ noʊ jə lʌv hɪm. aɪ lʌv hɪm, tu. bʌɾ aɪm nɑt tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə hil ðə waɪt taʊɝ dʒʌst soʊ hi kən tʃeɪn ɛɛs sədaɪ laɪk deɪmeɪn. slip wɛl ən əv plɛzən dʒɹimz, ɪleɪn. plɛzən dʒɹimz ɑɹ mɔɹ væljəbəl ðən pipəl ɹilaɪz." ən wɪð ðæt, ʃi wɑz ɡɔn, bæk tə ðə weɪkɪŋ wɝld.

"I have reason to be, Elayne. The eyes-and-ears report very troubling rumors. Only rumors, I hope, but if they aren't . . ." She was very much the Amyrlin Seat now, a short slender young woman who seemed strong as steel and tall as a mountain. Determination filled her dark eyes and set her jaw. "I know you love him. I love him, too. But I am not trying to Heal the White Tower just so he can chain Aes Sedai like damane. Sleep well and have pleasant dreams, Elayne. Pleasant dreams are more valuable than people realize." And with that, she was gone, back to the waking world.

fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ɪleɪn stʊd stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə spɑt wɛɹ ɛɡwin hæd bɪn. wʌt hæd ʃi bɪn tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt? ɹænd wəd nɛvɝ də ðæt! ɪf oʊnli fəɹ lʌv ə hɝ, hi wəd nɑt! ʃi pɹɑɾɪd ðət ɹɑk-hɑɹd nɑɾ ɪn ðə bæk ə hɝ hɛd. wɪð ɪm soʊ fɑɹ əweɪ, ðə veɪnz ʌv ɡoʊld ʃoʊn oʊnli ɪn mɛmɹi. ʃʊɹli hi wəd nɑt. tʃɹʌbəld ɪn hɝsɛlf, ʃi stɛpt aʊɾ ə ðə dʒɹim, bæk tə hɝ slipɪŋ bɑɾi.

For a moment, Elayne stood staring at the spot where Egwene had been. What had she been talking about? Rand would never do that! If only for love of her, he would not! She prodded that rock-hard knot in the back of her head. With him so far away, the veins of gold shone only in memory. Surely he would not. Troubled in herself, she stepped out of the dream, back to her sleeping body.

ʃi niɾəd slip, bʌt noʊ sunɝ wɑz ʃi bæk ɪn əɹ oʊn bɑɾi ðən sʌnlaɪt fɛl ɑn əɹ aɪlɪdz. wʌɾ aʊɝ wɑz ɪt? ʃi hæɾ əpɔɪnmənts tə kip, duɾiz tə kæɹi aʊt. ʃi wɑntəd tə slip fəɹ mʌnθs. ʃi ɹɛsəld wɪð duɾi, bʌt duɾi wʌn. ʃi hæɾ ə bɪzi deɪ əhɛd. ɛvɹi deɪ wɑz ə bɪzi deɪ. hɝ aɪz pɑpt oʊpən, filɪŋ ɡɹeɪni, əz ɪf ʃi hæd nɑt slɛpt əɾ ɔl. baɪ ðə slæn ə laɪt θɹu ðə wɪndoʊz, ɪt wɑz wɛl bɪɑn sʌnɹaɪz. ʃi kəd sɪmpli laɪ ðɛɹ. duɾi. eɪvinhə ʃɪftəɾ ɪn əɹ slip, ən ɪleɪn poʊkt əɹ ʃɑɹpli ɪn ðə ɹɪbz. ɪf ʃi hæd tə bi əweɪk, ðən eɪvinhə wɑz nɑt gɑnə lɑl əbaʊt.

She needed sleep, but no sooner was she back in her own body than sunlight fell on her eyelids. What hour was it? She had appointments to keep, duties to carry out. She wanted to sleep for months. She wrestled with duty, but duty won. She had a busy day ahead. Every day was a busy day. Her eyes popped open, feeling grainy, as if she had not slept at all. By the slant of light through the windows, it was well beyond sunrise. She could simply lie there. Duty. Aviendha shifted in her sleep, and Elayne poked her sharply in the ribs. If she had to be awake, then Aviendha was not going to loll about.

eɪvinhə woʊk wɪð ə stɑɹt, stʃɹɛtʃɪŋ fəɹ əɹ naɪf laɪɪŋ ətɑp ðə smɔl teɪbəl ɑn əɹ saɪɾ ə ðə bɛd. bɪfɔɹ əɹ hæn tʌtʃt ðə dɑɹk hɔɹn hɪlt, ʃi lɛɾ ɪt fɔl. "sʌmθɪŋ woʊk mi," ʃi mʌɾɝd. "aɪ θɔɾ ə ʃeɪɾoʊ wɑz - lʊk ət ðə sʌn! waɪ dɪd jə lemi slip soʊ leɪt?" ʃi dɪmændəd, skɹæmbəlɪŋ fɹəm ðə bɛd. "dʒʌs kəz aɪm əlaʊd tə steɪ wɪð jə - " ðə wɝdz wɝ mʌfəl fəɹ ən ɪnstən əz ʃi dʒɝkt əɹ slip-ɹɪŋkəld ʃɪft ɔf oʊvɝ əɹ hɛd " - dʌz nɑt min mɑneɪəl woʊn swɪtʃ mi ɪf ʃi θɪŋks aɪm biɪŋ leɪzi. dʒju min tə laɪ ðəɹ ɔl deɪ?"

Aviendha woke with a start, stretching for her knife lying atop the small table on her side of the bed. Before her hand touched the dark horn hilt, she let it fall. "Something woke me," she muttered. "I thought a Shaido was - Look at the sun! Why did you let me sleep so late?" she demanded, scrambling from the bed. "Just because I'm allowed to stay with you - " the words were muffled for an instant as she jerked her sleep-wrinkled shift off over her head " - does not mean Monaelle won't switch me if she thinks I am being lazy. Do you mean to lie there all day?"

wɪð ə ɡɹoʊn, ɪleɪn klaɪmd aʊɾ ə ðə bɛd. ɛsænd wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi weɪɾɪŋ ət ðə dɔɹ tə ðə dʒɹɛsɪŋ ɹum; ʃi nɛvɝ weɪkt ɪleɪn ənlɛs ɪleɪn ɹɪmɛmbɝd tə ɔɹɾɝ ɪt. ɪleɪn sɝɛndɝd hɝsɛlf tə ðə waɪt-hɛɹd wʊmənz ɔlmoʊst saɪlən mɪnəstʃɹeɪʃənz waɪl eɪvinhə dʒɹɛs hɝsɛlf, bʌɾ əɹ sɪstɝ meɪɾ ʌp fəɹ ɛsænz kwaɪət wɪð ə læfɪŋ stʃɹɪŋ ə kɑmɛns əlɔŋ ðə laɪn ə haʊ hævɪŋ sʌmwʌn ɛls pʊt jəɹ kloʊðz ɑn jə mʌs fil laɪk biɪŋ ə beɪbi əɡɛn ən haʊ ɪleɪn maɪt fɝɡɛt haʊ tə pʊɾ ɑn əɹ oʊn kloʊðz ən nid sʌmbɑɾi tə dʒɹɛs hɝ. ʃi hæd dʌn vɛɹi mʌtʃ ðə seɪm ɛvɹi mɔɹnɪŋ sɪns ðeɪ hæd bɪɡʌn tə ʃɛɹ ðə seɪm bɛd. eɪvinhə faʊn ɪt vɛɹi fʌni. ɪleɪn dɪd nɑt seɪ ə wɝd, ɪksɛp tə ænsɝ əɹ taɪɝ-wʊmənz sədʒɛstʃənz ɑn wʌt ʃi ʃəd wɛɹ, əntɪl ðə læs mʌðɝ-ʌv-pɝl bʌɾən wɑz dʌn ʌp ən ʃi stʊɾ ɪɡzæmɪnɪŋ hɝsɛlf ɪn ðə stænd-mɪɹɝ.

With a groan, Elayne climbed out of the bed. Essande was already waiting at the door to the dressing room; she never waked Elayne unless Elayne remembered to order it. Elayne surrendered herself to the white-haired woman's almost silent ministrations while Aviendha dressed herself, but her sister made up for Essande's quiet with a laughing string of comments along the line of how having someone else put your clothes on you must feel like being a baby again and how Elayne might forget how to put on her own clothes and need somebody to dress her. She had done very much the same every morning since they had begun to share the same bed. Aviendha found it very funny. Elayne did not say a word, except to answer her tire-woman's suggestions on what she should wear, until the last mother-of-pearl button was done up and she stood examining herself in the stand-mirror.

"ɛsænd," ʃi sɛd ðɛn, kæʒəwəli, "ɑɹ eɪvinhəz kloʊðz ɹɛɾi?" ðə faɪn blu wʊl wɪð ə lɪɾəl sɪlvɝ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi wəd də wɛl ɪnʌf fəɹ wʌt ʃi feɪs tədeɪ.

"Essande," she said then, casually, "are Aviendha's clothes ready?" The fine blue wool with a little silver embroidery would do well enough for what she faced today.

ɛsæn bɹaɪɾənd. "ɔl leɪɾi eɪvinhəz pɹɪɾi sɪlks ən leɪsəz, maɪ leɪɾi? oʊ, jɛs. ɔl bɹʌʃt ən klin ən aɪɝn ən pʊɾ əweɪ." ʃi dʒɛstʃɝd tə ðə wɔɹdʒɹoʊbz laɪnɪŋ wʌn wɔl.

Essande brightened. "All Lady Aviendha's pretty silks and laces, my Lady? Oh, yes. All brushed and cleaned and ironed and put away." She gestured to the wardrobes lining one wall.

ɪleɪn smaɪld oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ əɾ əɹ sɪstɝ. eɪvinhə stɛɹɾ ət ðə wɔɹdʒɹoʊbz əz ðoʊ ðeɪ kənteɪn vaɪpɝz, ðən ɡʌlpt ən heɪstəli fɪnɪʃt waɪndɪŋ ðə dɑɹk foʊldəd kɝtʃəf ɝaʊn əɹ hɛd.

Elayne smiled over her shoulder at her sister. Aviendha stared at the wardrobes as though they contained vipers, then gulped and hastily finished winding the dark folded kerchief around her head.

wən ɪleɪn hæd dɪsmɪst ɛsænd, ʃi sɛd, "dʒʌst ɪn keɪs jə nid ðɛm."

When Elayne had dismissed Essande, she said, "Just in case you need them."

"vɛɹi wɛl," eɪvinhə mʌɾɝd, pʊɾɪŋ ɑn əɹ sɪlvɝ nɛkləs. "noʊ mɔɹ dʒoʊks əbaʊt ðə wʊmən dʒɹɛsɪŋ ju."

"Very well," Aviendha muttered, putting on her silver necklace. "No more jokes about the woman dressing you."

"ɡʊd. əɹ əl tɛl əɹ tə stɑɹt dʒɹɛsɪŋ ju. naʊ, ðət wəd bi əmjuzɪŋ."

"Good. Or I'll tell her to start dressing you. Now, that would be amusing."

ɡɹʌmbəlɪŋ ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛθ əbaʊt pipəl u kəd nɑt teɪk ə dʒoʊk, eɪvinhə pleɪnli dɪd nɑɾ əɡɹi. ɪleɪn hæf ɪkspɛktəɾ əɹ tə dɪmæn ðəɾ ɔl ðə kloʊðz ʃi hæɾ əkwaɪɝd bi dɪskɑɹɾɪd. ʃi wɑz ə lɪɾəl sɝpɹaɪzd eɪvinhə hæd nɑt sin tə ɪɾ ɔlɹɛɾi.

Grumbling under her breath about people who could not take a joke, Aviendha plainly did not agree. Elayne half expected her to demand that all the clothes she had acquired be discarded. She was a little surprised Aviendha had not seen to it already.

fəɹ eɪvinhə, ðə bɹɛkfəs leɪɾ aʊɾ ɪn ðə sɪɾɪŋ ɹum kənsɪstəɾ ə kjʊɹd hæm wɪð ɹeɪzənz, ɛɡz kʊkt wɪð dʒɹaɪd plʌmz, dʒɹaɪd fɪʃ pɹipɛɹd wɪð paɪn nʌts, fɹɛʃ bɹɛd slæðɝd wɪð bʌɾɝ, ən ti meɪd sɪɹəpi wɪð hʌni. wɛl, nɑɾ æktʃəli  sɪɹəpi, bʌɾ ɪt sim soʊ. ɪleɪn ɡɑt noʊ bʌɾɝ ɑn əɹ bɹɛd, vɛɹi lɪɾəl hʌni ɪn əɹ ti, ən ɪnstɛɾ ə ðə ɹɛst, ə hɑt pɔɹədʒ ʌv ɡɹeɪnz ən ɝbz ðət wɑz səpoʊz tə bi ɪspɛʃli hɛlθi. ʃi dɪd nɑt fil wɪð tʃaɪld, noʊ mæɾɝ wʌt mɪn hæd toʊld eɪvinhə, bʌt mɪn hæd toʊl bɝdʒɪt, tu, wʌns ðə θɹi ʌv əm bɪɡæn ɡɛɾɪŋ dʒɹʌŋk. bɪtwin əɹ wɔɹɾɝ, daɪɛlɪn, ən ɹɪn hɑɹfɝ, ʃi naʊ faʊn hɝsɛlf lɪməɾəd tə ə daɪət "suɾəbəl fəɹ ə wʊmən ɪn əɹ kəndɪʃən." ɪf ʃi sɛn tə ðə kɪtʃənz fəɹ ə tʃɹit, sʌmhaʊ ɪt nɛvɝ ɝaɪvd, ən ɪf ʃi slɪp daʊn ðəɹ hɝsɛlf, ðə kʊks ɡeɪv əɹ sətʃ ɡlʌm dɪsəpɹuvɪŋ stɛɹz ðət ʃi slɪp bæk aʊɾ əɡɛn wɪð nʌθɪŋ.

For Aviendha, the breakfast laid out in the sitting room consisted of cured ham with raisins, eggs cooked with dried plums, dried fish prepared with pine nuts, fresh bread slathered with butter, and tea made syrupy with honey. Well, not actually syrupy, but it seemed so. Elayne got no butter on her bread, very little honey in her tea, and instead of the rest, a hot porridge of grains and herbs that was supposed to be especially healthy. She did not feel with child, no matter what Min had told Aviendha, but Min had told Birgitte, too, once the three of them began getting drunk. Between her Warder, Dyelin, and Reene Harfor, she now found herself limited to a diet "suitable for a woman in her condition." If she sent to the kitchens for a treat, somehow it never arrived, and if she slipped down there herself, the cooks gave her such glum disapproving stares that she slipped back out again with nothing.

ʃi dɪd nɑt ɹɪli mɔɹn ðə spaɪst waɪn ən swits ən ði ʌðɝ θɪŋz ʃi wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ əlaʊd - nɑt ðət mʌtʃ, ɛniweɪ, ɪksɛpt wən eɪvinhə wɑz ɡɑbəlɪŋ tɑɹts əɹ pʊɾɪŋz - bʌɾ ɛvɹiwʌn ɪn ðə pæləs nu ʃi wɑz pɹɛɡnənt. ən ə kɔɹs, ðət mɛn ðeɪ nu haʊ ʃi hæd ɡɑɾən ðət weɪ, ɪf nɑt wɪð hum. ðə mɛn wɝ nɑt tu bæd, bɪɑn ðə fæk ðət ðeɪ nu, ən ʃi nu ðeɪ nu, bʌt ðə wɪmən dɪd nɑt bɑðɝ tə haɪd noʊɪŋ. wɛðɝ ðeɪ æksɛptɪɾ əɹ dɪpɹəkeɪɾɪd ðə sɪtʃueɪʃən, hæf lʊkt əɾ əɹ əz ðoʊ ʃi wɝ ə hɔɪɾən ən ði ʌðɝ hæf wɪð spɛkjəleɪʃən. fɔɹsɪŋ hɝsɛlf tə swɑloʊ ðə pɔɹədʒ - ɪt wɑz nɑt ðət bæd, ɹɪli, bʌt ʃi dɪɹli wʊɾə lʌv səm ə ðə hæm eɪvinhə wɑz slaɪsɪŋ, əɹ ə lɪɾəl ə ði ɛɡ wɪð plʌmz - spunɪŋ lʌmpi pɔɹədʒ ɪndə hɝ maʊθ, ʃi ɔlmoʊs lʊk fɔɹwɝd tə ðə stɑɹɾ ə bɝθɪŋ sɪknəs, soʊ ʃi kəd ʃɛɹ ðə kwizi bɛli wɪð bɝdʒɪt.

She did not really mourn the spiced wine and sweets and the other things she was no longer allowed - not that much, anyway, except when Aviendha was gobbling tarts or puddings - but everyone in the Palace knew she was pregnant. And of course, that meant they knew how she had gotten that way, if not with whom. The men were not too bad, beyond the fact that they knew, and she knew they knew, but the women did not bother to hide knowing. Whether they accepted or deprecated the situation, half looked at her as though she were a hoyden and the other half with speculation. Forcing herself to swallow the porridge - it was not that bad, really, but she dearly would have loved some of the ham Aviendha was slicing, or a little of the egg with plums - spooning lumpy porridge into her mouth, she almost looked forward to the start of birthing sickness, so she could share the queasy belly with Birgitte.

ðə fɝs vɪzəɾɝ tə ɛntɝ əɹ əpɑɹtməns ðət mɔɹnɪŋ bɪsaɪɾ ɛsænd wɑz ðə liɾɪŋ kændəɾeɪt əmʌŋ ðə pæləs wɪmən fəɹ ðə fɑðɝ ə hɝ bɛɹli kwɪkən tʃaɪld.

The first visitor to enter her apartments that morning beside Essande was the leading candidate among the Palace women for the father of her barely quickened child.

"maɪ kwin," kæptən mɛlɝ sɛd, swipɪŋ ɔf ɪz plum hæɾ ɪn ə flɝɪʃɪŋ baʊ. "ðə tʃif klɝk əweɪts jəɹ mædʒəstiz plɛʒɝ." ðə kæptənz dɑɹk, ənblɪŋkɪŋ aɪz sɛɾ i wəd nɛvɝ əv dʒɹimz ə ðə mɛn i kɪld, ən ðə leɪs-ɛdʒ sæʃ əkɹɔs ɪz tʃɛst ən ðə leɪs əɾ ɪz nɛk ən ɹɪsts oʊnli meɪɾ ɪm lʊk hɑɹɾɝ. waɪpɪŋ ɡɹis fɹəm əɹ tʃɪn wɪð ə lɪnən næpkɪn, eɪvinhə wɑtʃt ɪm wɪð noʊ ɪkspɹɛʃən ɑn əɹ feɪs. ðə tu ɡɑɹdzwɪmən stændɪŋ wʌn ɑn iðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə dɔɹz ɡɹɪməs feɪnli. mɛlɝ ɔlɹɛɾi hæɾ ə ɹɛpjəteɪʃən fəɹ pɪntʃɪŋ ɡɑɹdzwɪmənz bɑɾəmz, ðə pɹɪɾiɝ wʌnz' ət list, nɑt tə mɛnʃən dɪspɛɹɪdʒɪŋ ðɛɹ əbɪləɾiz ɪn ðə sɪɾiz tævɝnz. ðə sɛkənd wɑz fɑɹ wɝs, ɪn ðə ɡɑɹdzwɪmənz aɪz.

"My Queen," Captain Mellar said, sweeping off his plumed hat in a flourishing bow. "The Chief Clerk awaits Your Majesty's pleasure." The captain's dark, unblinking eyes said he would never have dreams of the men he killed, and the lace-edged sash across his chest and the lace at his neck and wrists only made him look harder. Wiping grease from her chin with a linen napkin, Aviendha watched him with no expression on her face. The two Guardswomen standing one on either side of the doors grimaced faintly. Mellar already had a reputation for pinching Guardswomen's bottoms, the prettier ones' at least, not to mention disparaging their abilities in the city's taverns. The second was far worse, in the Guardswomen's eyes.

"aɪ æm nɑɾ ə kwin, jɛt, kæptən," ɪleɪn sɛd bɹɪskli. ʃi ɔlweɪz tʃɹaɪd tə kip əz mʌtʃ tə ðə pɔɪn əz pɑsəbəl wɪð ðə mæn. "haʊ ɪz ɹəkɹuɾɪŋ fəɹ maɪ bɑɾiɡɑɹd kʌmɪŋ əlɔŋ?"

"I am not a queen, yet, Captain," Elayne said briskly. She always tried to keep as much to the point as possible with the man. "How is recruiting for my bodyguard coming along?"

"oʊnli θɝɾi-tu, soʊ fɑɹ, maɪ leɪɾi." stɪl hoʊldɪŋ ɪz hæt, ðə hætʃət-feɪs mæn ɹɛstəd boʊθ hænz ɑn ɪz sɔɹd hɪlt, hɪz laʊnʒɪŋ pɑstʃɝ hɑɹdli suɾəbəl fəɹ ðə pɹɛzəns ʌv wʌn i hæd kɔld ɪz kwin. nɔɹ wɑz ɪz ɡɹɪn. "leɪɾi bɝdʒɪɾ əz ɪɡzæktɪŋ stændɝdz. nɑt mɛni wɪmən kən mætʃ ðɛm. ɡɪmi tɛn deɪz, ən aɪ kən faɪn ə hʌnʒɹəd mɛn hul bɛɾɝ əm ən hoʊl jə əz dɪɹ ɪn ðɛɹ hɑɹts əz aɪ du."

"Only thirty-two, so far, my Lady." Still holding his hat, the hatchet-faced man rested both hands on his sword hilt, his lounging posture hardly suitable for the presence of one he had called his queen. Nor was his grin. "Lady Birgitte has exacting standards. Not many women can match them. Give me ten days, and I can find a hundred men who'll better them and hold you as dear in their hearts as I do."

"aɪ θɪŋk nɑt, kæptən mɛlɝ." ɪt wɑz ən ɛfɝt tə kip ə tʃɪl aʊɾ ə hɝ vɔɪs. hi hæd tə hæv hɝd ðə ɹumɝz kənsɝnɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ən hɝ. kəɾ i θɪŋk ðət dʒʌs kəz ʃi hæd nɑt dɪnaɪd ðɛm, ʃi maɪɾ æktʃəli  faɪn ɪm . . . ətʃɹæktɪv? pʊʃɪŋ əweɪ ðə hæf-ɛmpti pɔɹədʒ boʊl, ʃi səpɹɛst ə ʃʌɾɝ. θɝɾi-tu, soʊ fɑɹ? ðə nʌmbɝz wɝ ɡɹoʊɪŋ kwɪkli. səm ə ðə hʌntɝz fəɹ ðə hɔɹn u hæd bɪn dɪmændɪŋ ɹæŋk hæd dɪsaɪɾɪd ðət sɝvɪŋ ɪn ɪleɪnz bɑɾiɡɑɹd kæɹiɾ ə sɝɾən flɛɹ. ʃi kənsiɾɪd ðət ðə wɪmən kəd nɑɾ ɔl bi ɑn duɾi deɪ ən naɪt, bʌt noʊ mæɾɝ wʌt bɝdʒɪt sɛd, ðə ɡoʊl ʌv ə hʌnʒɹəd simd ɪksɛsɪv. ðə wʊmən dʌɡ ɪn əɹ hilz naʊ əɾ ɛni sədʒɛstʃən ə fjuɝ, ðoʊ. "pliz tɛl ðə tʃif klɝk i kən kʌm ɪn," ʃi toʊl hɪm. hi swɛpt əɹ ənʌðɝ ɪlæbɹət baʊ.

"I think not, Captain Mellar." It was an effort to keep a chill out of her voice. He had to have heard the rumors concerning himself and her. Could he think that just because she had not denied them, she might actually find him . . . attractive? Pushing away the half-empty porridge bowl, she suppressed a shudder. Thirty-two, so far? The numbers were growing quickly. Some of the Hunters for the Horn who had been demanding rank had decided that serving in Elayne's bodyguard carried a certain flair. She conceded that the women could not all be on duty day and night, but no matter what Birgitte said, the goal of a hundred seemed excessive. The woman dug in her heels now at any suggestion of fewer, though. "Please tell the Chief Clerk he can come in," she told him. He swept her another elaborate bow.

ʃi ɹoʊz tə fɑloʊ hɪm, ən əz i pʊld wʌn ə ðə laɪən-kɑɹv dɔɹz oʊpən, ʃi leɪɾ ə hæn ɑn ɪz ɑɹm ən smaɪld. "θæŋk jə əɡɛn fəɹ seɪvɪŋ maɪ laɪf, kæptən," ʃi sɛd, ðɪs taɪm wɔɹm ɪnʌf fəɹ ə kɝɛs.

She rose to follow him, and as he pulled one of the lion-carved doors open, she laid a hand on his arm and smiled. "Thank you again for saving my life, Captain," she said, this time warm enough for a caress.

ðə fɛloʊ smɝkt ət hɝ! ðə ɡɑɹdzwɪmən stɛɹd stʃɹeɪɾ əhɛd, fɹoʊzən, ðoʊz ʃi kəd si aʊɾ ɪn ðə hɔl bɪfɔɹ ðə dɔɹz kloʊz bɪhaɪn ɪm əz wɛl əz ðoʊz ɪnsaɪd, ən wən ɪleɪn tɝn ɝaʊnd, eɪvinhə wɑz stɛɹɪŋ əɾ əɹ wɪð lɪɾəl mɔɹ ɪkspɹɛʃən ðən ʃi hæd ʃoʊn mɛlɝ. ðət lɪɾəl wɑz pjʊɹ əmeɪzmənt, ðoʊ. ɪleɪn saɪd.

The fellow smirked at her! The Guardswomen stared straight ahead, frozen, those she could see out in the hall before the doors closed behind him as well as those inside, and when Elayne turned around, Aviendha was staring at her with little more expression than she had shown Mellar. That little was pure amazement, though. Elayne sighed.

kɹɔsɪŋ ðə kɑɹpəts, ʃi bɛn tə pʊɾ ən ɑɹm ɝaʊn əɹ sɪstɝ ən spoʊk sɔfli, fəɹ əɹ ɪɹ əloʊn. ʃi tʃɹʌstɪd ðə wɪmən ə hɝ bɑɾiɡɑɹd wɪð θɪŋz ʃi toʊl vɛɹi fju ʌðɝz, bʌt ðəɹ wɝ səm mæɾɝz ʃi dɛɹd nɑt tʃɹʌs tə ðɛm. "aɪ sɔ ə meɪd pæsɪŋ, eɪvinhə. meɪdz ɡɑsəp wɝs ðən mɛn. ðə mɔɹ u θɪŋk ðɪs tʃaɪld ɪz dɔɪlɪn mɛlɝz, ðə seɪfɝ ɪɾəl bi. ɪf nɛsəsɛɹi, əl lɛt ðə mæn pɪntʃ maɪ bɑɾəm."

Crossing the carpets, she bent to put an arm around her sister and spoke softly, for her ear alone. She trusted the women of her bodyguard with things she told very few others, but there were some matters she dared not trust to them. "I saw a maid passing, Aviendha. Maids gossip worse than men. The more who think this child is Doilin Mellar's, the safer it will be. If necessary, I'll let the man pinch my bottom."

"aɪ si," eɪvinhə sɛd sloʊli, ən fɹaʊn ɪndə hɝ pleɪɾ əz ðoʊ siɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ ʌðɝ ðən ði ɛɡz ən plʌmz ʃi bɪɡæn pʊʃɪŋ ɝaʊnd wɪð əɹ spun.

"I see," Aviendha said slowly, and frowned into her plate as though seeing something other than the eggs and plums she began pushing around with her spoon.

mæstɝ nɔɹi pɹizɛntəɾ ɪz juʒəwəl blɛn ə məndeɪn meɪntənəns ə ðə pæləs ən ðə sɪɾi, tɪdbɪts fɹəm ɪz kɔɹəspɑndəns ɪn fɔɹən kæpəɾəlz, ən ɪnfɝmeɪʃən ɡlin fɹəm mɝtʃəns ən bæŋkɝz ən ʌðɝz u hæd dilɪŋz bɪɑn ðə bɔɹɾɝz, bʌɾ ɪz fɝs pis ə nuz wɑz baɪ fɑɹ ðə moʊst ɪmpɔɹɾənt tə hɝ, ɪf nɑt ðə moʊst ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ.

Master Norry presented his usual blend of mundane maintenance of the Palace and the city, tidbits from his correspondents in foreign capitals, and information gleaned from merchants and bankers and others who had dealings beyond the borders, but his first piece of news was by far the most important to her, if not the most interesting.

"ðə tu moʊs pɹɑmənən bæŋkɝz ɪn ðə sɪɾi ɑɹ . . . əmɛnəbəl, maɪ leɪɾi," hi sɛɾ ɪn ðət dʒɹaɪ-æz-dʌs vɔɪs ə hɪz. klʌtʃɪŋ ɪz lɛðɝ foʊldɝ tə hɪz nɛɹoʊ tʃɛst, hi aɪɾ eɪvinhə saɪdweɪz. hi wɑz stɪl nɑɾ əkʌstəm tə hɝ pɹɛzəns waɪl i meɪɾ ɪz ɹɪpɔɹts. əɹ ðə ɡɑɹdzwɪmən. eɪvinhə bɛɹɾ əɹ tiθ ət hɪm, ən i blɪŋkt, ðən kɔft ɪndə ə boʊni hænd. "mæstɝ hɔfli ən mɪstʃɹəs ændskeɪl wɝ sʌmwʌt . . . hɛzɪɾənt . . . ət fɝst, bʌt ðeɪ noʊ ðə mɑɹkət fəɹ æləm əz wɛl əz aɪ. ɪt wəd nɑt bi seɪf tə seɪ ðət ðɛɹ kɑfɝz ɑɹ naʊ jʊɹz, bʌɾ aɪ hæv ɝeɪnʒd fəɹ twɛnti θaʊzənd ɡoʊl kɹaʊnz tə bi muv tə ðə pæləs stʃɹɔŋɡɹum, ən mɔɹ wɪl kʌm əz niɾəd."

"The two most prominent bankers in the city are . . . amenable, my Lady," he said in that dry-as-dust voice of his. Clutching his leather folder to his narrow chest, he eyed Aviendha sideways. He was still not accustomed to her presence while he made his reports. Or the Guardswomen. Aviendha bared her teeth at him, and he blinked, then coughed into a bony hand. "Master Hoffley and Mistress Andscale were somewhat . . . hesitant . . . at first, but they know the market for alum as well as I. It would not be safe to say that their coffers are now yours, but I have arranged for twenty thousand gold crowns to be moved to the Palace strongroom, and more will come as needed."

"ɪnfɔɹm ðə leɪɾi bɝdʒɪt," ɪleɪn toʊl hɪm, haɪɾɪŋ əɹ ɹɪlif. bɝdʒɪt hæd nɑt jɛt saɪn ɪnʌf nu ɡɑɹdz tə hoʊld ə sɪɾi əz lɑɹdʒ əz keɪɛmlɪn, mʌtʃ lɛs də ɛniθɪŋ ɛls, bʌɾ ɪleɪn kəd nɑɾ ɪkspɛk tə si ɹɛvənu fɹəm əɹ ɪsteɪts bɪfɔɹ spɹɪŋ, ən ðə mɝsənɛɹiz wɝ ɪkspɛnsɪv. naʊ ʃi wəd nɑt luz əm fəɹ læk ʌv ɡoʊl bɪfɔɹ bɝdʒɪt ɹɪkɹuɾɪd mɛn tə ɹipleɪs ðɛm. "nɛkst, mæstɝ nɔɹi?"

"Inform the Lady Birgitte," Elayne told him, hiding her relief. Birgitte had not yet signed enough new Guards to hold a city as large as Caemlyn, much less do anything else, but Elayne could not expect to see revenue from her estates before spring, and the mercenaries were expensive. Now she would not lose them for lack of gold before Birgitte recruited men to replace them. "Next, Master Norry?"

"aɪ fɪɹ ðə suɝz mʌs bi ɡɪvən ə haɪ pɹaɪɔɹəɾi, maɪ leɪɾi. ðə ɹæts ɑɹ bɹiɾɪŋ ɪn əm əz ɪf ɪt wɝ spɹɪŋ, ən . . ."

"I fear the sewers must be given a high priority, my Lady. The rats are breeding in them as if it were spring, and . . ."

hi mɪŋɡəld ɪɾ ɔl təɡɛðɝ, əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə wʌɾ i fɛlt wɑz moʊs pɹɛsɪŋ. nɔɹi sim tə teɪk ɪɾ əz ə pɝsənəl feɪljɝ ðəɾ i hæd nɑt jɛt lɝn u hæd fɹiɾ ɛləniə ən nɑiən, ðoʊ lɛs ðən ə wik hæd pæst sɪns ðɛɹ ɹɛskju. ðə pɹaɪs ʌv ɡɹeɪn wɑz klaɪmɪŋ ɛksɹbɪɾəntli, əlɔŋ wɪð ðəɾ ʌv ɛvɹi ʌðɝ sɔɹɾ ə fudstʌf, ən ɪt wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi əpɛɹən ðət ɹɪpɛɹz tə ðə pæləs ɹuf wəd teɪk lɔŋɡɝ ən kɑs mɔɹ ðən ðə meɪsənz hæd fɝst ɛstəmeɪɾəd, bʌt fuɾ ɔlweɪz ɡɹu mɔɹ ɪkspɛnsɪv əz wɪntɝ wɛn ɑn ən meɪsənz ɔlweɪz kɑs mɔɹ ðən ðeɪ fɝs hæd sɛd ðeɪ wʊd. nɔɹi ədmɪɾəd ðəɾ ɪz læs kɔɹəspɑndəns fɹəm nu bɹəm wɑz sɛvɹəl deɪz oʊld, bʌt ðə bɔɹɾɝləndɝz əpɪɹd kɑntɛn tə ɹɪmeɪn wɛɹ ðeɪ wɝ, wɪtʃ i kəd nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd. ɛni ɑɹmi, mʌtʃ lɛs wʌn əz lɑɹdʒ əz ðɪs wɑz sɛd tə bi, ɔt tə bi stʃɹɪpɪŋ ðə kʌntʃɹisaɪɾ ɝaʊn ɪt bɛɹ baɪ naʊ. ɪleɪn dɪd nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd waɪ iðɝ, bʌt ʃi wɑz kəntɛn ðəɾ ɪt wɑz soʊ. fəɹ ðə taɪm biɪŋ. ɹumɝz ɪn kɛɹhin ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ swɛɹɪŋ fiəlti tə ɹænd ət list ɡeɪv ə ɹizən fəɹ ɛɡwinz kənsɝn, ðoʊ ɪt hɑɹdli sim laɪkli ɛni sɪstɝ wəɾ æktʃəli  də sətʃ ə θɪŋ. ðət wɑz ðə list ɪmpɔɹɾənt pis ə nuz, ɪn nɔɹiz ɛstəmeɪʃən, bʌt nɑɾ ɪn hɝz. ɹænd kəd nɑɾ əfɔɹd tə eɪljəneɪt ðə sɪstɝz wɪð ɛɡwin. hi kəd nɑɾ əfɔɹd tə eɪljəneɪɾ ɛni ɛɛs sədaɪ. bʌɾ i dɪd sim tə faɪnd weɪz tə də soʊ.

He mingled it all together, according to what he felt was most pressing. Norry seemed to take it as a personal failure that he had not yet learned who had freed Elenia and Naean, though less than a week had passed since their rescue. The price of grain was climbing exorbitantly, along with that of every other sort of foodstuff, and it was already apparent that repairs to the Palace roof would take longer and cost more than the masons had first estimated, but food always grew more expensive as winter went on and masons always cost more than they first had said they would. Norry admitted that his last correspondence from New Braem was several days old, but the Borderlanders appeared content to remain where they were, which he could not understand. Any army, much less one as large as this was said to be, ought to be stripping the countryside around it bare by now. Elayne did not understand why either, but she was content that it was so. For the time being. Rumors in Cairhien of Aes Sedai swearing fealty to Rand at least gave a reason for Egwene's concern, though it hardly seemed likely any sister would actually do such a thing. That was the least important piece of news, in Norry's estimation, but not in hers. Rand could not afford to alienate the sisters with Egwene. He could not afford to alienate any Aes Sedai. But he did seem to find ways to do so.

ɹɪn hɑɹfɝ sun ɹipleɪs hælwɪn nɔɹi, nɑɾɪŋ tə ðə bɑɾiɡɑɹdz ət ðə dɔɹ ɪn pæsɪŋ ən ɡɪvɪŋ eɪvinhə ən oʊpən smaɪl. ɪf ðə plʌmp ɡɹeɪɪŋ wʊmən hæɾ ɛvɝ bɪn ənsɝɾən əbaʊɾ ɪleɪn kɔlɪŋ eɪvinhə sɪstɝ, ʃi hæd nɛvɝ ʃoʊn ɪt, ən naʊ ʃi dʒɛnjəwənli əpɪɹd tə əpɹuv. smaɪlz əɹ noʊ smaɪlz, ðoʊ, hɝ ɹipɔɹt wɑz mʌtʃ mɔɹ ɡɹɪm ðən ɛniθɪŋ ɪn ðə tʃif klɝks.

Reene Harfor soon replaced Halwin Norry, nodding to the bodyguards at the door in passing and giving Aviendha an open smile. If the plump graying woman had ever been uncertain about Elayne calling Aviendha sister, she had never shown it, and now she genuinely appeared to approve. Smiles or no smiles, though, her report was much more grim than anything in the Chief Clerk's.

"dʒɑn skɛlɪɾ ɪz ɪn ðə peɪ ʌv haʊs ɑɝɔn, maɪ leɪɾi," ɹɪn sɛd, hɝ ɹaʊn feɪs stɝn ɪnʌf tə fɪɾ ə hæŋmən. "twaɪs naʊ hiz bɪn sin æksɛptɪŋ ə pɝs fɹəm mɛn noʊn tə feɪvɝ ɑɝɔn. ən ðəɹ ɪz noʊ daʊt ðəɾ ɛstɝ nɔɹhəm ɪz ɪn sʌmwʌnz peɪ. ʃi ɪzən stilɪŋ, bʌt ʃiz oʊvɝ fɪfti kɹaʊnz ʌv ɡoʊl hɪɾən ʌndɝ ə lus flɔɹbɔɹd, ən ʃi æɾəd tɛn kɹaʊnz læs naɪt."

"Jon Skellit is in the pay of House Arawn, my Lady," Reene said, her round face stern enough to fit a hangman. "Twice now he has been seen accepting a purse from men known to favor Arawn. And there is no doubt that Ester Norham is in someone's pay. She isn't stealing, but she has over fifty crowns of gold hidden under a loose floorboard, and she added ten crowns last night."

"du əz wɪð ði ʌðɝz," ɪleɪn sɛd sædli. ðə fɝs meɪd hæɾ ənkʌvɝd naɪn spaɪz ʃi wɑz sɝɾən ʌv, soʊ fɑɹ, fɔɹ ə ðɛm ɛmplɔɪd baɪ pipəl ɹɪn hæd nɑt jɛt bɪn eɪbəl tə ənkʌvɝ. ðət ɹɪn hæd faʊn ɛni əɾ ɔl wɑz ɪnʌf tə æŋɡɝ ɪleɪn, bʌt ðə bɑɹbɝ ən ðə hɛɹdʒɹɛsɝ wɝ sʌmθɪŋ mɔɹ. boʊθ hæd bɪn ɪn əɹ mʌðɝz sɝvəs. ə pɪɾi ðeɪ hæd nɑt sin fɪt tə tʃɹænsfɝ ðɛɹ lɔɪəlti tə mɔɹɡeɪsəz dɔɾɝ.

"Do as with the others," Elayne said sadly. The First Maid had uncovered nine spies she was certain of, so far, four of them employed by people Reene had not yet been able to uncover. That Reene had found any at all was enough to anger Elayne, but the barber and the hairdresser were something more. Both had been in her mother's service. A pity they had not seen fit to transfer their loyalty to Morgase's daughter.

eɪvinhə ɡɹɪməst əz mɪstʃɹəs hɑɹfɝ mɝmɝd ðət ʃi wʊd, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ pɔɪn ɪn dɪstʃɑɹdʒɪŋ ðə spaɪz, əɹ kɪlɪŋ əm əz eɪvinhə hæd sədʒɛstəd. ðeɪ wəd dʒʌs bi ɹipleɪs baɪ spaɪz ʃi dɪd nɑt noʊ. ə spaɪ ɪz jəɹ ɛnəmiz tul əntɪl jə noʊ hɝ, hɝ mʌðɝ hæd sɛd, bʌt ðən ʃiz jəɹ tul. wən jə faɪn ə spaɪ, tɑm hæd toʊl hɝ, ɹæp ɪm ɪn swɑɾəlɪŋ ən fiɾ ɪm wɪð ə spun. ðə mɛn ən wɪmən u hæd bɪtʃɹeɪd ðɛɹ sɝvəs wəd bi "əlaʊd" tə dɪskʌvɝ wʌɾ ɪleɪn wɑntəɾ əm tə noʊ, nɑɾ ɔl tʃɹu, sətʃ əz ðə nʌmbɝz bɝdʒɪt hæd ɹɪkɹuɾɪd.

Aviendha grimaced as Mistress Harfor murmured that she would, but there was no point in discharging the spies, or killing them as Aviendha had suggested. They would just be replaced by spies she did not know. A spy is your enemy's tool until you know her, her mother had said, but then she is your tool. When you find a spy, Thom had told her, wrap him in swaddling and feed him with a spoon. The men and women who had betrayed their service would be "allowed" to discover what Elayne wanted them to know, not all true, such as the numbers Birgitte had recruited.

"æn ði ʌðɝ mæɾɝ, mɪstʃɹəs hɑɹfɝ?"

"And the other matter, Mistress Harfor?"

"nʌθɪŋ jɛt, maɪ leɪɾi, bʌɾ aɪ hæv hoʊps," ɹɪn sɛɾ ivən mɔɹ ɡɹɪmli ðən bɪfɔɹ. "aɪ hæv hoʊps."

"Nothing yet, my Lady, but I have hopes," Reene said even more grimly than before. "I have hopes."

fɑloʊɪŋ ðə fɝs meɪdz dɪpɑɹtʃɝ keɪm tu dɛləɡeɪʃənz ə mɝtʃəns, fɝst ə lɑɹdʒ ɡɹup ə kændɔɹi wɪð dʒɛm-stʌɾɪd ɪɹɪŋz ən sɪlvɝ ɡɪld-tʃeɪnz dʒɹeɪpt əkɹɔs ðɛɹ tʃɛsts ən ðɛn, ɹaɪt bɪhaɪn ðɛm, hæf ə dʌzən ɪliɑnɝz wɪð oʊnli ə tʌtʃ ʌv ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi ɑn ʌðɝwaɪz sɑmbɝ koʊts ən dʒɹɛsəz. ʃi juzd wʌn ə ðə smɔlɝ ɹɪsɛpʃən ɹumz. ðə tæpəstʃɹiz flæŋkɪŋ ðə mɑɹbəl faɪɝpleɪs wɝ ə hʌntɪŋ sinz, nɑt ðə waɪt laɪən, ən ðə pɑlɪʃt wʊɾən wɔl pænəlz wɝ ənkɑɹvd. ðeɪ wɝ mɝtʃəns, nɑt dɪpləmæts, ðoʊ səm sim tə fil slaɪɾɪd ðət ʃi ɔfɝɾ oʊnli waɪn ən dɪd nɑt dʒɹɪŋk wɪð ðɛm. kændɔɹi əɹ ɪliɑnɝz, ðeɪ ɔlsoʊ lʊkt əskæns ət ðə tu ɡɑɹdzwɪmən u fɑloʊɾ əɹ ɪndə ðə ɹum ən poʊstɪd ðɛmsɛlvz bɪsaɪd ðə dɔɹ, ðoʊ ɪf baɪ ðɪs taɪm ðeɪ hæd nɑt hɝd ðə teɪlz ʌv ən ətɛmp tə kɪl hɝ, ðeɪ mʌs bi dɛf. sɪks mɔɹ ə hɝ bɑɾiɡɑɹd weɪɾəd aʊtsaɪd ðə dɔɹ.

Following the First Maid's departure came two delegations of merchants, first a large group of Kandori with gem-studded earrings and silver guild-chains draped across their chests and then, right behind them, half a dozen Illianers with only a touch of embroidery on otherwise somber coats and dresses. She used one of the smaller reception rooms. The tapestries flanking the marble fireplace were of hunting scenes, not the White Lion, and the polished wooden wall panels were uncarved. They were merchants, not diplomats, though some seemed to feel slighted that she offered only wine and did not drink with them. Kandori or Illianers, they also looked askance at the two Guardswomen who followed her into the room and posted themselves beside the door, though if by this time they had not heard the tales of an attempt to kill her, they must be deaf. Six more of her bodyguard waited outside the door.

ðə kændɔɹi stʌɾid eɪvinhə sɝəptɪʃəsli wən nɑt lɪsnɪŋ ətɛntɪvli tə ɪleɪn, ən ði ɪliɑnɝz əvɔɪɾəd lʊkɪŋ əɾ əɹ əɾ ɔl æftɝ ðə fɝst waɪɾənɪŋ ʌv aɪz ɪn sɝpɹaɪz. daʊtləs ðeɪ ɹɛd səɡnɪfɪkəns ɪndə ðə pɹɛzəns ʌv ən il, ivən ɪf ʃi oʊnli sæɾ ɑn ðə flɔɹ ɪn ə kɔɹnɝ ən sɛd nʌθɪŋ, bʌt wɛðɝ kændɔɹi əɹ ɪliɑnɝz, ðə mɝtʃəns wɑntəd ðə seɪm θɪŋ, ɹiəʃʊɹəns ðəɾ ɪleɪn wəd nɑt soʊ æŋɡɝ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn ðəɾ i wəɾ ɪntɝfɪɹ wɪð tʃɹeɪd baɪ sɛndɪŋ ɪz ɑɹmiz ən ɪz il tə ɹævədʒ ændɝ, ðoʊ ðeɪ dɪd nɑt kʌm aʊɾ ən seɪ soʊ. nɔɹ dɪd ðeɪ mɛnʃən ðəɾ il ən ðə lidʒən ə ðə dʒɹæɡən boʊθ hæd lɑɹdʒ ɛnkæmpməns nɑt mɛni maɪlz fɹəm keɪɛmlɪn. ðɛɹ pəlaɪt kwɛstʃənz əbaʊɾ əɹ plænz naʊ ðət ʃi hæd ɹimuv ðə dʒɹæɡən bænɝz ən ðə bænɝz ə laɪt fɹəm keɪɛmlɪn wɝ səfɪʃənt. ʃi toʊld əm wʌt ʃi toʊld ɛvɹiwʌn, ðəɾ ændɝ wəɾ əlaɪ ɪtsɛlf tə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn bʌt wɑz nɑɾ ɪz kɑŋkwɛst. ɪn ɹɪtɝn, ðeɪ ɔfɝd veɪɡ wɪʃɪz fəɹ əɹ wɛl-biɪŋ, sədʒɛstɪŋ ðət ðeɪ səpɔɹɾəd əɹ kleɪm tə ðə laɪən θɹoʊn hoʊlhɑɹɾɪdli wɪθaʊɾ æktʃəli  seɪɪŋ ɛni sətʃ θɪŋ. æftɝ ɔl, ɪf ʃi feɪld, ðeɪ wɑnə tə bi wɛlkəm ɪn ændɝ ʌndɝ huɛvɝ dɪd ɡeɪn ðə kɹaʊn.

The Kandori studied Aviendha surreptitiously when not listening attentively to Elayne, and the Illianers avoided looking at her at all after the first widening of eyes in surprise. Doubtless they read significance into the presence of an Aiel, even if she only sat on the floor in a corner and said nothing, but whether Kandori or Illianers, the merchants wanted the same thing, reassurance that Elayne would not so anger the Dragon Reborn that he would interfere with trade by sending his armies and his Aiel to ravage Andor, though they did not come out and say so. Nor did they mention that Aiel and the Legion of the Dragon both had large encampments not many miles from Caemlyn. Their polite questions about her plans now that she had removed the Dragon banners and the Banners of Light from Caemlyn were sufficient. She told them what she told everyone, that Andor would ally itself to the Dragon Reborn but was not his conquest. In return, they offered vague wishes for her well-being, suggesting that they supported her claim to the Lion Throne wholeheartedly without actually saying any such thing. After all, if she failed, they would want to be welcome in Andor under whoever did gain the crown.

wən ði ɪliɑnɝz hæd meɪd ðɛɹ baʊz ən kɝtsiz ən dɪpɑɹɾəd, ʃi kloʊzd əɹ aɪz fəɹ ə moʊmən ən ɹʌbd əɹ tɛmpəlz. ʃi stɪl hæɾ ə miɾɪŋ wɪð ə dɛləɡeɪʃən ʌv ɡlæsmeɪkɝz bɪfɔɹ ðə mɪddeɪ mil, ən faɪv mɔɹ wɪð mɝtʃəns əɹ kɹæftsfoʊk leɪɾɝ; ə vɛɹi bɪzi deɪ, fʊl ə mili-maʊð plæɾɪtudz ən æmbɪɡjuəɾi. ən wɪð nɪneɪiv ən mɛɝɪlɪl ɡɔn, ɪt wɑz əɹ tɝn tə titʃ ðə wɪndfɪndɝz əɡɛn tənaɪt, ət bɛst ə lɛs plɛzən ɪkspɪɹiəns ðən ðə wɝs miɾɪŋ wɪð mɝtʃəns. wɪtʃ maɪt liv əɹ ə lɪɾəl taɪm tə stʌɾi ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil ðeɪ hæd bɹɔɾ aʊɾ ʌv ɛbu dɑɹ bɪfɔɹ ʃi wɑz soʊ wɪɹi ðət ʃi kəd noʊ lɔŋɡɝ kip əɹ aɪz oʊpən. ɪt wɑz ɪmbɛɹəsɪŋ wən eɪvinhə hæd tə hæf kæɹi hɝ tə bɛd, bʌt ʃi kəd nɑt stɑp. ðəɹ wɑz tu mʌtʃ tə bi dʌn ən nɑɾ ɪnʌf taɪm ɪn ə deɪ.

When the Illianers had made their bows and curtsies and departed, she closed her eyes for a moment and rubbed her temples. She still had a meeting with a delegation of glassmakers before the midday meal, and five more with merchants or craftsfolk later; a very busy day, full of mealy-mouthed platitudes and ambiguity. And with Nynaeve and Merilille gone, it was her turn to teach the Windfinders again tonight, at best a less pleasant experience than the worst meeting with merchants. Which might leave her a little time to study the ter'angreal they had brought out of Ebou Dar before she was so weary that she could no longer keep her eyes open. It was embarrassing when Aviendha had to half carry her to bed, but she could not stop. There was too much to be done and not enough time in a day.

ðəɹ wɑz ɔlmoʊst ən aʊɝ bɪfɔɹ ðə ɡlæsmeɪkɝz, bʌɾ eɪvinhə ɹuθləsli ɹoʊɾ oʊvɝ əɹ sədʒɛstʃən ðət ʃi maɪt teɪk ə pik ət ðə θɪŋz fɹəm ɛbu dɑɹ.

There was almost an hour before the glassmakers, but Aviendha ruthlessly rode over her suggestion that she might take a peek at the things from Ebou Dar.
