"hæz bɝdʒɪt bɪn tɔkɪŋ tə ju?" ɪleɪn dɪmændəɾ əz əɹ sɪstɝ ɔl bʌt dʒɹæɡd əɹ ʌp ə nɛɹoʊ flaɪɾ ə stoʊn stɛɹz. fɔɹ ɡɑɹdzwɪmən wɛn əhɛd, ən ði ʌðɝz tʃɹeɪl bɪhaɪnd, stuɾiəsli ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ wʌt pæs bɪtwin əɹ ən eɪvinhə. ðoʊ ʃi θɔt ðət ɹæsɔɹiə dəmæntʃ, ə stɑki hʌntɝ fəɹ ðə hɔɹn wɪð ðə blu aɪz ən jɛloʊ hɛɹ əkeɪʒənəli faʊn əmʌŋ tɛɹənz, wɔɹ ə taɪni smaɪl.

"Has Birgitte been talking to you?" Elayne demanded as her sister all but dragged her up a narrow flight of stone stairs. Four Guardswomen went ahead, and the others trailed behind, studiously ignoring what passed between her and Aviendha. Though she thought that Rasoria Domanche, a stocky Hunter for the Horn with the blue eyes and yellow hair occasionally found among Tairens, wore a tiny smile.

"du aɪ niɾ əɹ tə tɛl mi jə spɛn tu mɛni aʊɝz ɪnsaɪɾ ən slip tu lɪɾəl?" eɪvinhə ɹɪplaɪd kəntɛmptʃwəsli. "ju nid fɹɛʃ ɛɹ."

"Do I need her to tell me you spend too many hours inside and sleep too little?" Aviendha replied contemptuously. "You need fresh air."

ði ɛɹ ɪn ðə haɪ kɑləneɪd wɑz sɝɾənli fɹɛʃ. ən kɹɪsp, ðoʊ ðə sʌn stʊd haɪ ɪn ə ɡɹeɪ skaɪ. ə koʊl bɹiz blu ɝaʊn ðə smuð kɑləmz, soʊ ðə ɡɑɹdzwɪmən stændɪŋ ɹɛɾi tə pɹətɛkt əɹ fɹəm pɪdʒənz hæd tə hæŋ ɑn tə ðɛɹ plum hæts. pɝvɝsli, ɪleɪn ɹəfjuz tə ɪɡnɔɹ ðə tʃɪl.

The air in the high colonnade was certainly fresh. And crisp, though the sun stood high in a gray sky. A cold breeze blew around the smooth columns, so the Guardswomen standing ready to protect her from pigeons had to hang on to their plumed hats. Perversely, Elayne refused to ignore the chill.

"daɪɛlɪn tɔk tə ju," ʃi ɡɹʌmbəld, ʃɪvɝɪŋ. daɪɛlɪn kleɪmd ə wʊmən wɪð tʃaɪl niɾəd lɔŋ wɔks ɛvɹi deɪ. ʃi hæd bɪn kwɪk tə ɹimaɪn ɪleɪn ðæt, dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ əɹ nɑt, ʃi wɑz ɹɪli oʊnli ðə haɪ siɾ ə haʊs tʃɹəkən fəɹ ðə moʊmənt, ən ɪf ðə haɪ siɾ ə tʃɹəkənd wɑntəd tə tɔk wɪð ðə haɪ siɾ ə tæɹɑvɪn, ʃi kəd də ɪt tʃɹæmpɪŋ ʌp ən daʊn ðə pæləs kɔɹɪɾɝz əɹ nɑɾ əɾ ɔl.

"Dyelin talked to you," she grumbled, shivering. Dyelin claimed a woman with child needed long walks every day. She had been quick to remind Elayne that, Daughter-Heir or not, she was really only the High Seat of House Trakand for the moment, and if the High Seat of Trakand wanted to talk with the High Seat of Taravin, she could do it tramping up and down the Palace corridors or not at all.

"mɑneɪəl əz bɔɹn sɛvən tʃɪlʒɹən," eɪvinhə ɹɪplaɪd. "ʃi sɛz aɪ mʌst si jə ɡɛt fɹɛʃ ɛɹ." dɪspaɪt noʊ mɔɹ ðən əɹ ʃɔl pʊld oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝz, ʃi ɡeɪv noʊ saɪn ə filɪŋ ðə wɪnd. bʌt ðɛn, il wɝ əz ɡʊɾ əz ðə sɪstɝz əɾ ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ði ɛləməns. ɹæpɪŋ əɹ ɑɹmz ɝaʊn hɝsɛlf, ɪleɪn skaʊld.

"Monaelle has borne seven children," Aviendha replied. "She says I must see you get fresh air." Despite no more than her shawl pulled over her shoulders, she gave no sign of feeling the wind. But then, Aiel were as good as the sisters at ignoring the elements. Wrapping her arms around herself, Elayne scowled.

"stɑp sʌlkɪŋ, sɪstɝ," eɪvinhə sɛd. ʃi pɔɪntəd daʊn tə wʌn ə ðə steɪbliɑɹdz, dʒʌs vɪzəbəl oʊvɝ ðə waɪt-taɪld ɹufs. "lʊk, ɹin kɔɹli ɪz ɔlɹɛɾi tʃɛkɪŋ tə si ɪf mɛɝɪlɪl ʃiændɪvɪn ɪz ɹɪtɝnɪŋ." ðə fəmɪljɝ vɝɾɪkəl slæʃ ə laɪɾ əpɪɹɾ ɪn ðə steɪbliɑɹɾ ən ɹoʊteɪɾɪd ɪndə ə hoʊl ɪn ði ɛɹ tɛn fit tɔl ən əz waɪd.

"Stop sulking, sister," Aviendha said. She pointed down to one of the stableyards, just visible over the white-tiled roofs. "Look, Reanne Corly is already checking to see if Merilille Ceandevin is returning." The familiar vertical slash of light appeared in the stableyard and rotated into a hole in the air ten feet tall and as wide.

ɪleɪn skaʊl daʊn ət ɹinz hɛd. ʃi wɑz nɑt sʌlkɪŋ. pɝhæps ʃi ʃəd nɑɾ əv tɔt ɹin tə tʃɹævəl, sɪns ðə kɪnswʊmən wɑz nɑt jɛɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ, bʌt nʌn ə ði ʌðɝ sɪstɝz wɝ stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf tə meɪk ðə wiv wɝk, ən ɪf ðə wɪndfɪndɝz wɝ əlaʊd tə lɝn, ðən ðə fju kɪnswɪmən u kəd ʃəd bi əlaʊd, tu, ɪn əɹ bʊk. bɪsaɪdz, ʃi kəd nɑt də ɛvɹiθɪŋ hɝsɛlf. laɪt, hæd wɪntɝ bɪn ðɪs aɪsi bɪfɔɹ ʃi lɝn tə stɑp hiɾ ən koʊl fɹəm tʌtʃɪŋ hɝ?

Elayne scowled down at Reanne's head. She was not sulking. Perhaps she should not have taught Reanne to Travel, since the Kinswoman was not yet Aes Sedai, but none of the other sisters were strong enough to make the weave work, and if the Windfinders were allowed to learn, then the few Kinswomen who could should be allowed, too, in her book. Besides, she could not do everything herself. Light, had winter been this icy before she learned to stop heat and cold from touching her?

tə hɝ sɝpɹaɪz, mɛɝɪlɪl ɹoʊd θɹu ðə ɡeɪtweɪ ʃeɪkɪŋ snoʊ fɹəm əɹ dɑɹk fɝ-laɪn kloʊk, fɑloʊd baɪ ðə hɛlməɾɪd ɡɑɹdzmɪn u hæd bɪn sɛn ɔf wɪð əɹ sɛvən deɪz ɝliɝ. zeɪɾə ən ðə wɪndfɪndɝz hæd bɪn moʊst ənplɛzən oʊvɝ əɹ dɪsəpɪɹəns, tə pʊɾ ɪt maɪldli, bʌt ðə ɡɹeɪ hæd lɛpt əɾ ə tʃæns tə ɪskeɪp əm fəɹ haʊɛvɝ lɔŋ. ɪt hæd bɪn nɛsəsɛɹi tə tʃɛk fəɹ əɹ ɛvɹi deɪ, oʊpənɪŋ ə ɡeɪtweɪ tə ðə seɪm spɑt, jɛɾ ɪleɪn hæd nɑɾ ɪkspɛktəɾ əɹ fəɹ ə wik jɛɾ ət ðə vɛɹi bɛst. əz ðə læst ə ðə tɛn ɹɛd-kloʊkt ɡɑɹdz ɛntɝd ðə steɪbliɑɹd, ðə slɪm lɪɾəl ɡɹeɪ sɪstɝ klaɪm daʊn fɹəm əɹ sæɾəl, hændəɾ əɹ ɹeɪnz tə ə ɡɹum, ən hɝiɾ ɪndə ðə pæləs bɪfɔɹ ðə wʊmən fɹəm ðə steɪbəlz kəd mɔɹ ðən ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ə hɝ weɪ.

To her surprise, Merilille rode through the gateway shaking snow from her dark fur-lined cloak, followed by the helmeted Guardsmen who had been sent off with her seven days earlier. Zaida and the Windfinders had been most unpleasant over her disappearance, to put it mildly, but the Gray had leaped at a chance to escape them for however long. It had been necessary to check for her every day, opening a gateway to the same spot, yet Elayne had not expected her for a week yet at the very best. As the last of the ten red-cloaked Guards entered the stableyard, the slim little Gray sister climbed down from her saddle, handed her reins to a groom, and hurried into the Palace before the woman from the stables could more than get out of her way.

"aɪ æm ɛndʒɔɪɪŋ ðə fɹɛʃ ɛɹ," ɪleɪn sɛd, dʒʌs kipɪŋ əɹ tiθ fɹəm tʃæɾɝɪŋ, "bʌɾ ɪf mɛɝɪlɪl ɪz bæk, aɪ mʌst ɡoʊ daʊn." eɪvinhə kwɝkt ən aɪbɹaʊ əz ɪf ʃi səspɛktəd ði ɪveɪʒən, bʌt ʃi wɑz ðə fɝs tə stɑɹt fəɹ ðə stɛɹz. mɛɝɪlɪlz ɹɪtɝn wɑz ɪmpɔɹɾənt, ən baɪ hɝ heɪst, ʃi bɹɔɾ iðɝ vɛɹi ɡʊd nuz əɹ vɛɹi bæd.

"I am enjoying the fresh air," Elayne said, just keeping her teeth from chattering, "but if Merilille is back, I must go down." Aviendha quirked an eyebrow as if she suspected the evasion, but she was the first to start for the stairs. Merilille's return was important, and by her haste, she brought either very good news or very bad.

baɪ ðə taɪm ɪleɪn ən əɹ sɪstɝ wɔkt ɪndə hɝ sɪɾɪŋ ɹum - fɑloʊd baɪ tu ʌv ðə ɡɑɹdzwɪmən, ʌv kɔɹs, hu plæntəd ðɛmsɛlvz bɪsaɪd ðə dɔɹz - mɛɝɪlɪl wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi ðɛɹ. hɝ dæmp-spɑɾəd kloʊk leɪ oʊvɝ ðə bæk ʌv ə tʃɛɹ, hɝ peɪl ɡɹeɪ ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɡlʌvz wɝ tʌk bɪhaɪn əɹ bɛlt, ən əɹ blæk hɛɹ cʊɾə juzd ə bɹʌʃ. wɪð pɝpəl kɹɛsəns ʌndɝ əɹ dɑɹk aɪz, mɛɝɪlɪlz peɪl feɪs lʊkt əz wɪɹi əz ɪleɪn fɛlt.

By the time Elayne and her sister walked into her sitting room - followed by two of the Guardswomen, of course, who planted themselves beside the doors - Merilille was already there. Her damp-spotted cloak lay over the back of a chair, her pale gray riding gloves were tucked behind her belt, and her black hair could have used a brush. With purple crescents under her dark eyes, Merilille's pale face looked as weary as Elayne felt.

əz kwɪkli əz ʃi hæd kʌm ʌp fɹəm ðə steɪbliɑɹd, ʃi wɑz nɑɾ əloʊn. bɝdʒɪt, fɹaʊnɪŋ pɛnsɪvli, stʊd wɪð wʌn hæn ɑn ðə kɑɹv mæntəl oʊvɝ ðə faɪɝpleɪs. ði ʌðɝ ɡɹɪpt əɹ lɔŋ ɡoʊldən bɹeɪd, ɔlmoʊs laɪk nɪneɪiv. tədeɪ, ʃi wɔɹ vəlumənəs dɑɹk ɡɹin tʃɹaʊzɝz wɪð əɹ ʃɔɹt ɹɛd koʊt, ə kɑmbəneɪʃən tə meɪk ði aɪ flɪntʃ. ən kæptən mɛlɝ meɪɾ ɪleɪn ən ɪlæbɹət baʊ, weɪvɪŋ ɪz waɪt-plum hæɾ əbaʊt. hi hæd noʊ pleɪs hɪɹ, bʌt ʃi lɛɾ ɪm steɪ, ən ivən ɡeɪv ɪm ə vɛɹi wɔɹm smaɪl. vɛɹi wɔɹm.

As quickly as she had come up from the stableyard, she was not alone. Birgitte, frowning pensively, stood with one hand on the carved mantel over the fireplace. The other gripped her long golden braid, almost like Nynaeve. Today, she wore voluminous dark green trousers with her short red coat, a combination to make the eye flinch. And Captain Mellar made Elayne an elaborate bow, waving his white-plumed hat about. He had no place here, but she let him stay, and even gave him a very warm smile. Very warm.

ðə plʌmp jʌŋ meɪɾ u hæd dʒʌs pleɪst ə lɑɹdʒ sɪlvɝ tʃɹeɪ ɑn wʌn ə ðə saɪdbɔɹdz blɪŋkt ən lʊkt waɪd-aɪɾ ət mɛlɝ bɪfɔɹ ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ tə meɪk əɹ kɝtsi ɑn ɡoʊɪŋ. ɪleɪn hɛld əɹ smaɪl əntɪl ðə dɔɹ kloʊzd. wʌtɛvɝ pɹətɛktəɾ əɹ beɪbi, ʃi wɑz wɪlɪŋ tə du. ðəɹ wɑz hɑt spaɪst waɪn ɑn ðə ɹoʊp wɝk tʃɹeɪ fəɹ ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls, ən wik ti fəɹ hɝ. wɛl, ət list ɪt wɑz hɑt.

The plump young maid who had just placed a large silver tray on one of the sideboards blinked and looked wide-eyed at Mellar before remembering to make her curtsy on going. Elayne held her smile until the door closed. Whatever protected her baby, she was willing to do. There was hot spiced wine on the rope work tray for everyone else, and weak tea for her. Well, at least it was hot.

"aɪ wɑz kwaɪt lʌki," mɛɝɪlɪl saɪd wʌns ʃi wɑz siɾəd, ɡɪvɪŋ mɛlɝ ən ənsɝɾən ɡlæns oʊvɝ əɹ waɪnkʌp. ʃi nu ðə teɪl ə hɪm seɪvɪŋ ɪleɪnz laɪf, bʌt ʃi hæd lɛf bɪfɔɹ ðə ɹumɝz bɪɡæn. "ɪt tɝn aʊt ðət ɹin hæɾ oʊpən əɹ ɡeɪtweɪ nɑt faɪv maɪlz fɹəm ðə bɔɹɾɝləndɝz. ðeɪv nɑt muv sɪns ɝaɪvɪŋ." hɝ noʊz ɹɪŋkəld. "ɪf nɑt fəɹ ðə wɛðɝ, ðə stɛntʃ ə lætʃɹinz ən hɔɹs dʌŋ wəd bi oʊvɝpaʊɹɪŋ. jə wɝ ɹaɪt, ɪleɪn. ɔl fɔɹ ɹulɝz ɑɹ ðɛɹ, ɪn fɔɹ kæmps ə fju maɪlz əpɑɹt. itʃ hoʊlz ən ɑɹmi. aɪ faʊn ðə ʃaɪnɝənz ðə fɝs deɪ, ən moʊst ə maɪ taɪm sɪns əz bɪn spɛn tɔkɪŋ wɪð isɑɹ ə ʃaɪnɝ ən ði ʌðɝ θɹi. wi mɛɾ ɪn ə dɪfɹən kæmp itʃ deɪ."

"I was quite lucky," Merilille sighed once she was seated, giving Mellar an uncertain glance over her winecup. She knew the tale of him saving Elayne's life, but she had left before the rumors began. "It turned out that Reanne had opened her gateway not five miles from the Borderlanders. They have not moved since arriving." Her nose wrinkled. "If not for the weather, the stench of latrines and horse dung would be overpowering. You were right, Elayne. All four rulers are there, in four camps a few miles apart. Each holds an army. I found the Shienarans the first day, and most of my time since has been spent talking with Easar of Shienar and the other three. We met in a different camp each day."

"ju spɛn ə lɪɾəl taɪm lʊkɪŋ tu, aɪ hoʊp," bɝdʒɪt sɛd ɹɪspɛkfəli fɹəm ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə faɪɝpleɪs. ʃi wɑz ɹɪspɛkfəl wɪð ɛvɹi ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪksɛp ðə wʌn ʃi wɑz bɑndəd tə. "haʊ mɛni ɑɹ ðeɪ?"

"You spent a little time looking too, I hope," Birgitte said respectfully from in front of the fireplace. She was respectful with every Aes Sedai except the one she was bonded to. "How many are they?"

"aɪ doʊn səpoʊz jə ɡɑɾ ən ækjɝət kaʊnt," mɛlɝ pʊɾ ɪn, saʊndɪŋ əz ðoʊ hi ɪkspɛktəɾ ɛniθɪŋ bʌt. fəɹ wʌns, hɪz nɛɹoʊ feɪs wɑz ənsmaɪlɪŋ. piɹɪŋ ɪndə hɪz waɪn, hi ʃɹʌɡd. "wʌtɛvɝ jə sɔ maɪɾ əv səm vælju, ðoʊ. ɪf ðəɹ ɑɹ ɪnʌf ə ðɛm, ðeɪ meɪ stɑɹv ðɛmsɛlvz bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ kən θɹɛɾən keɪɛmlɪn. ðə lɑɹdʒəst ɑɹmi ɪn ðə wɝld ɪz dʒʌst soʊ mɛni wɔkɪŋ kɔɹpsəz wɪθaʊt fuɾ ən fɑɾɝ." hi læft. bɝdʒɪt stɛɹɾ əɾ ɪz bæk dɑɹkli, bʌɾ ɪleɪn lɪftəɾ ə hæn slaɪtli əɾ əɹ saɪd, moʊʃənɪŋ ði ʌðɝ wʊmən tə kip saɪlənt.

"I don't suppose you got an accurate count," Mellar put in, sounding as though he expected anything but. For once, his narrow face was unsmiling. Peering into his wine, he shrugged. "Whatever you saw might have some value, though. If there are enough of them, they may starve themselves before they can threaten Caemlyn. The largest army in the world is just so many walking corpses without food and fodder." He laughed. Birgitte stared at his back darkly, but Elayne lifted a hand slightly at her side, motioning the other woman to keep silent.

"ðeɪ ɑɹ nɑɾ ɪn ə ɡʊd weɪ fəɹ fud, kæptən," mɛɝɪlɪl sɛd kuli, sɪɾɪŋ ʌp stʃɹeɪɾɝ ɪn spaɪɾ ə hɝ ɑbviəs fətiɡ, "bʌt niðɝ ɑɹ ðeɪ stɑɹvɪŋ kwaɪt jɛt. aɪ ʃəd nɑt kaʊn ɑn stɑɹveɪʃən tə dɪfit ðɛm, ɪf ɪt kʌmz tə ðæt." æftɝ ə lɪɾəl taɪm əweɪ fɹəm ðə si foʊk, hɝ bɪɡ aɪz wɝ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ pɝpɛtʃuəli stɑɹɾəld, ən dɪspaɪɾ əɹ smuð ɛɛs sədaɪ kəmpoʊʒɝ, ɪt wɑz pleɪn ʃi hæd dɪsaɪɾɪd tə dɪslaɪk dɔɪlɪn mɛlɝ noʊ mæɾɝ huz laɪf i hæd seɪvd. "æz fəɹ nʌmbɝz, sʌmθɪŋ oʊvɝ tu hʌnʒɹəd θaʊzənd, aɪ ʃəd seɪ, ən aɪ vɛɹi mʌtʃ daʊɾ ɛniwʌn bʌt ðɛɹ oʊn ɔfəsɝz kəd bi mɔɹ ækjɝət ðən ðæt. ivən hʌŋɡɹi, ðəɾ ɪz ə ɡɹeɪt mɛni sɔɹdz," mɛlɝ ʃɹʌɡd əɡɛn, ʌndɪstɝbd baɪ ɛɛs sədaɪ stɛɹz.

"They are not in a good way for food, Captain," Merilille said coolly, sitting up straighter in spite of her obvious fatigue, "but neither are they starving quite yet. I should not count on starvation to defeat them, if it comes to that." After a little time away from the Sea Folk, her big eyes were no longer perpetually startled, and despite her smooth Aes Sedai composure, it was plain she had decided to dislike Doilin Mellar no matter whose life he had saved. "As for numbers, something over two hundred thousand, I should say, and I very much doubt anyone but their own officers could be more accurate than that. Even hungry, that is a great many swords," Mellar shrugged again, undisturbed by Aes Sedai stares.

ðə slɪm ɡɹeɪ sɪstɝ niðɝ lʊkt əɾ ɪm əɡɛn nɔɹ ɪɡnɔɹɾ ɪm ɪn ɛni ɑbviəs weɪ; hi dʒʌst sim tə bɪkʌm ə pis ə ðə fɝnɪtʃɝ fəɹ əɹ əz ʃi wɛn ɑn. "ðɛɹ ɑɹ ət lis tɛn sɪstɝz wɪð ðɛm, ɪleɪn, ðoʊ ðeɪ meɪɾ ə ɡɹeɪɾ ɛfɝt tə haɪd ðə fækt. nɑɾ ædhɪɹəns tə ɛɡwin, aɪ ʃəd θɪŋk, ðoʊ ðeɪ nid nɑt bi ɪleɪɾəz iðɝ. ə ɡʊd mɛni sɪstɝz əpɪɹ tə bi sɪɾɪŋ tə wʌn saɪɾ əntɪl ðə taʊɝz tʃɹʌbəlz ɑɹ oʊvɝ, aɪ fɪɹ." ʃi saɪɾ əɡɛn, pɝhæps nɑt fɹəm taɪɹədnəs ðɪs taɪm.

The slim Gray sister neither looked at him again nor ignored him in any obvious way; he just seemed to become a piece of the furniture for her as she went on. "There are at least ten sisters with them, Elayne, though they made a great effort to hide the fact. Not adherents to Egwene, I should think, though they need not be Elaida's either. A good many sisters appear to be sitting to one side until the Tower's troubles are over, I fear." She sighed again, perhaps not from tiredness this time.

wɪð ə ɡɹɪmɑs, ɪleɪn sɛɾ əɹ tikʌp əsaɪd. ðə kɪtʃənz hæd nɑt sɛn ʌp ɛni hʌni, ən ʃi ɹɪli dɪd nɑt laɪk ɪt bɪɾɝ. "wʌt də ðeɪ wɑnt, mɛɝɪlɪl? ðə ɹulɝz, nɑt ðə sɪstɝz." tɛn sɪstɝz meɪd ðəɾ ɑɹmi tɛn taɪmz əz deɪnʒɝəs, ɪspɛʃli tə ɹænd. noʊ, tə ɛniwʌn. "ðeɪ hævən bɪn sɪɾɪŋ ðəɹ ɪn ðə snoʊ ɔl ðɪs taɪm fəɹ ðə dʒɔɪ ʌv ɪt."

With a grimace, Elayne set her teacup aside. The kitchens had not sent up any honey, and she really did not like it bitter. "What do they want, Merilille? The rulers, not the sisters." Ten sisters made that army ten times as dangerous, especially to Rand. No, to anyone. "They haven't been sitting there in the snow all this time for the joy of it."

ðə ɡɹeɪ spɹɛɾ əɹ slɪm hænz slaɪtli. "oʊvɝ ðə lɔŋ ɹʌn, aɪ kən oʊnli meɪk səpəzɪʃənz. oʊvɝ ðə ʃɔɹt, ðeɪ wɑnə mit ju, ən əz sun əz pɑsəbəl. ðeɪ sɛn ɹaɪɾɝz təwɔɹd keɪɛmlɪn wən ðeɪ ɝaɪvd ət nu bɹəm, bʌt ðɪs taɪm ə jɪɹ, ɪt maɪt teɪk ənʌðɝ wik əɹ mɔɹ bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ ɝaɪv hɪɹ. tɛnoʊbiə ʌv sɑldɑiə lɛt slɪp, əɹ pɹitɛndəd tə lɛt slɪp, ðət ðeɪ noʊ juv səm kənɛkʃən tə, əɹ list ə kloʊs əkweɪntəns wɪð, ə sɝɾən pɝsən ɪn hum ðeɪ ɔlsoʊ əpɛɹənli hæv ən ɪntʃɹəst. sʌmhaʊ, ðeɪ noʊ ʌv jəɹ pɹɛzəns ɪn fɑlm wən sɝɾən ɪvɛns tʊk pleɪs." mɛlɝ fɹaʊn ɪn kənfjuʒən, bʌt noʊ wʌn ɛnlaɪɾənd hɪm. "aɪ dɪd nɑt dɪskloʊz tʃɹævlɪŋ, kəz ə ðoʊz sɪstɝz, bʌɾ aɪ dɪd seɪ aɪ kəd ɹɪtɝn wɪð ə ɹɪplaɪ vɛɹi sun."

The Gray spread her slim hands slightly. "Over the long run, I can only make suppositions. Over the short, they want to meet you, and as soon as possible. They sent riders toward Caemlyn when they arrived at New Braem, but this time of year, it might take another week or more before they arrive here. Tenobia of Saldaea let slip, or pretended to let slip, that they know you have some connection to, or least a close acquaintance with, a certain person in whom they also apparently have an interest. Somehow, they know of your presence in Falme when certain events took place." Mellar frowned in confusion, but no one enlightened him. "I did not disclose Traveling, because of those sisters, but I did say I could return with a reply very soon."

ɪleɪn ɪkstʃeɪnʒd ə lʊk wɪð bɝdʒɪt, hu ɔlsoʊ ʃɹʌɡd, ðoʊ ɪn əɹ keɪs niðɝ fɹəm dɪtætʃmənt nɔɹ fɹəm dɪsdeɪn. ðə lɑɹdʒəs hoʊl ɪn ɪleɪnz hoʊps tə juz ðə bɔɹɾɝləndɝz tə ɪnfluəns əɹ əpoʊnəns fəɹ ðə θɹoʊn hæd bɪn haʊ tə əpɹoʊtʃ sɪɾɪŋ ɹulɝz waɪl ʃi wɑz mɪɹli ðə haɪ siɾ ə tʃɹəkən ən dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ ʌv ə dɪsis kwin. bɝdʒɪts ʃɹʌɡ sɛd bi θæŋkfəl fəɹ ðə hoʊl kloʊzɪŋ, bʌɾ ɪleɪn wʌndɝd haʊ ðiz pipəl fɹəm ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz hæd lɝnd wʌt vɛɹi fju ʌðɝz nu. ən ɪf ðeɪ nu, haʊ mɛni mɔɹ dɪd, tu? ʃi wəd pɹətɛkt əɹ ʌnbɔɹn tʃaɪld.

Elayne exchanged a look with Birgitte, who also shrugged, though in her case neither from detachment nor from disdain. The largest hole in Elayne's hopes to use the Borderlanders to influence her opponents for the throne had been how to approach sitting rulers while she was merely the High Seat of Trakand and Daughter-Heir of a deceased queen. Birgitte's shrug said be thankful for the hole closing, but Elayne wondered how these people from the Borderlands had learned what very few others knew. And if they knew, how many more did, too? She would protect her unborn child.

"wʊd jə bi wɪlɪŋ tə ɡoʊ bæk ɹaɪɾ əweɪ, mɛɝɪlɪl?" ʃi æskt. ði ʌðɝ sɪstɝ æksɛptɪd wɪð əlækɹəɾi, ən wɪð ə slaɪt waɪɾənɪŋ ə hɝ aɪz ðət sədʒɛstəd ʃi wəd pʊɾ ʌp wɪð ɛni əmaʊn ə stɛntʃ tə əvɔɪd ɹɪtɝnɪŋ tə ðə wɪndfɪndɝz ə lɪɾəl lɔŋɡɝ. "ðɛn wɪl ɡoʊ təɡɛðɝ. ɪf ðeɪ wɑnə mit mi sun, nʌθɪŋ kən bi sunɝ ðən tədeɪ." ðeɪ nu tu mʌtʃ fəɹ dɪleɪ. nʌθɪŋ kəd bi əlaʊd tə θɹɛɾən əɹ tʃaɪld. nʌθɪŋ!

"Would you be willing to go back right away, Merilille?" she asked. The other sister accepted with alacrity, and with a slight widening of her eyes that suggested she would put up with any amount of stench to avoid returning to the Windfinders a little longer. "Then we will go together. If they want to meet me soon, nothing can be sooner than today." They knew too much for delay. Nothing could be allowed to threaten her child. Nothing!


tʃæptɝ twɛntisɛvən


CHAPTER 27

tə sɝpɹaɪz kwinz ən kɪŋz


To Surprise Queens and Kings

ɪt wɑz nɑt kwaɪt soʊ sɪmpəl əz dʒʌst seɪɪŋ ʃi wəd ɡoʊ, ʌv kɔɹs.

It was not quite so simple as just saying she would go, of course.

"ðɪs ɪz ənwaɪz, sɪstɝ," eɪvinhə sɛd dɑɹkli əz mɛɝɪlɪl skɝiɾ ɔf tə fɹɛʃən hɝsɛlf. skɝiɾ ɪn tʃɹuθ; ðə ɡɹeɪ sim tə bi kipɪŋ ə ʃɑɹp aɪ aʊt fəɹ si foʊk bɪfɔɹ ʃi ɹitʃt ðə sɪɾɪŋ ɹum dɔɹz. wən ə sɪstɝ ʌv ɪleɪnz stændɪŋ sɛd ɡoʊ, mɛɝɪlɪl wɛnt. ɑɹmz foʊldəɾ ən ʃɔl ɹæpt ɝaʊn əɹ soʊ ʃi lʊk vɛɹi mʌtʃ ðə waɪz wʌn, eɪvinhə stʊɾ oʊvɝ ɪleɪn əɾ əɹ ɹaɪɾɪŋ teɪbəl, "ðɪs ɪz vɛɹi ənwaɪz."

"This is unwise, sister," Aviendha said darkly as Merilille scurried off to freshen herself. Scurried in truth; the Gray seemed to be keeping a sharp eye out for Sea Folk before she reached the sitting room doors. When a sister of Elayne's standing said go, Merilille went. Arms folded and shawl wrapped around her so she looked very much the Wise One, Aviendha stood over Elayne at her writing table, "This is very unwise."

"waɪz?" bɝdʒɪt ɡɹaʊld, fiɾ əpɑɹɾ ən fɪsts plæntəɾ ɑn əɹ hɪps. "waɪz? ðə ɡɝl wʊdnt noʊ 'waɪz' ɪf ɪt bɪɾ əɹ ɑn ðə noʊz! waɪ ðɪs ɹʌʃ? lɛt mɛɝɪlɪl də wʌt ɡɹeɪz du, ɝeɪnʒ ə pɑɹli ɪn ə fju deɪz, əɹ ə wik. kwinz heɪt biɪŋ sɝpɹaɪzd, ən kɪŋz dɪspaɪz ɪt. bɪliv mi, aɪ noʊ ɪt tə maɪ kɑst. ðeɪ faɪnd weɪz tə meɪk jə ɹəɡɹɛɾ ɪt." ðə wɔɹɾɝ bɑn mɪɹɝɾ əɹ æŋɡɝ ən fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən.

"Wise?" Birgitte growled, feet apart and fists planted on her hips. "Wise? The girl wouldn't know 'wise' if it bit her on the nose! Why this rush? Let Merilille do what Grays do, arrange a parley in a few days, or a week. Queens hate being surprised, and kings despise it. Believe me, I know it to my cost. They find ways to make you regret it." The Warder bond mirrored her anger and frustration.

"aɪ wɑnə kætʃ əm baɪ sɝpɹaɪz, bɝdʒɪt. ɪt maɪt hɛlp mi tə faɪn aʊt dʒʌs haʊ mʌtʃ ðeɪ noʊ əbaʊt mi." ɡɹɪmæsɪŋ, ɪleɪn pʊʃt əweɪ ðə blɑɾɪd peɪdʒ ən tʊk ənʌðɝ ʃit fɹəm ði ɪnleɪd ɹoʊzwʊd peɪpɝ-bɑks. hɝ wɪɹinəs hæd vænɪʃt wɪð mɛɝɪlɪlz nuz, bʌt ɹaɪɾɪŋ ə stɛɾi, klin hæn dɪd sim dɪfəkəlt. ðə wɝɾɪŋ niɾəd tə bi dʒʌst ɹaɪt, tu. ðɪs wɑz nɑt tə bi ə lɛɾɝ fɹəm ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ ʌv ændɝ, bʌt fɹəm ɪleɪn tʃɹəkənd, ɛɛs sədaɪ ʌv ðə ɡɹin ədʒɑ. ðeɪ hæd tə si wʌt ʃi wɑntəɾ əm tə si.

"I want to catch them by surprise, Birgitte. It might help me to find out just how much they know about me." Grimacing, Elayne pushed away the blotted page and took another sheet from the inlaid rosewood paper-box. Her weariness had vanished with Merilille's news, but writing a steady, clean hand did seem difficult. The wording needed to be just right, too. This was not to be a letter from the Daughter-Heir of Andor, but from Elayne Trakand, Aes Sedai of the Green Ajah. They had to see what she wanted them to see.

"tʃɹaɪ tə tɔk səm blʌɾi sɛns ɪndə hɝ, eɪvinhə," bɝdʒɪt mʌɾɝd. "ɪn keɪs jə kænt, aɪ hæd bɛst si ɪf aɪ kən skɹeɪp təɡɛðɝ ə suɾəbəl fleɪmɪŋ ɛskɔɹt."

"Try to talk some bloody sense into her, Aviendha," Birgitte muttered. "In case you can't, I had best see if I can scrape together a suitable flaming escort."

"noʊ ɛskɔɹt, bɝdʒɪt. ɪksɛp fəɹ ju. ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ən əɹ wɔɹɾɝ. ən eɪvinhə, ʌv kɔɹs." ɪleɪn pɔzd ɪn ɹaɪɾɪŋ tə smaɪl əɾ əɹ sɪstɝ, hu dɪd nɑt smaɪl bæk.

"No escort, Birgitte. Except for you. An Aes Sedai and her Warder. And Aviendha, of course." Elayne paused in writing to smile at her sister, who did not smile back.

"aɪ noʊ jəɹ kɝədʒ, ɪleɪn," eɪvinhə sɛd. "aɪ ædmaɪɹ jəɹ kɝədʒ. bʌɾ ivən ʃəməd kɑnd noʊ wən tə bi kɔʃəs!" ʃi spoʊk ə kɑʃən? eɪvinhə wəd nɑt noʊ kɑʃən ɪf . . . wɛl . . . ɪf ɪt bɪɾ əɹ ɑn ðə noʊz!

"I know your courage, Elayne," Aviendha said. "I admire your courage. But even Sha'mad Conde know when to be cautious!" She spoke of caution? Aviendha would not know caution if . . . well . . . if it bit her on the nose!

"æn ɛɛs sədaɪ ən əɹ wɔɹɾɝ?" bɝdʒɪɾ ɪkskleɪmd. "aɪ toʊl ju, jə kænt ɡoʊ ɹʌnɪŋ ɔf tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə hæv ædvɛntʃɝz ɛni mɔɹ!"

"An Aes Sedai and her Warder?" Birgitte exclaimed. "I told you, you can't go running off trying to have adventures any more!"

"noʊ ɛskɔɹt," ɪleɪn sɛd fɝmli, dɪpɪŋ əɹ pɛn fəɹ ənʌðɝ tʃɹaɪ. "ðɪs ɪzən ən ædvɛntʃɝ. ɪts dʒʌs ðə weɪ ɪt mʌs bi dʌn." θɹoʊɪŋ ʌp əɹ hænz, bɝdʒɪt ɡɹaʊl sɛvɹəl oʊðz, bʌt nʌθɪŋ ɪleɪn hæd nɑt hɝd bɪfɔɹ.

"No escort," Elayne said firmly, dipping her pen for another try. "This isn't an adventure. It is just the way it must be done." Throwing up her hands, Birgitte growled several oaths, but nothing Elayne had not heard before.

tə hɝ sɝpɹaɪz, mɛlɝ meɪd noʊ əbdʒɛkʃən tə steɪɪŋ bɪhaɪnd. ə miɾɪŋ wɪð fɔɹ ɹulɝz wəd hɑɹdli bi əz bɔɹɪŋ əz miɾɪŋ mɝtʃəns, bʌɾ i bɛɡd liv tə bi əbaʊɾ ɪz duɾiz sɪns ʃi dɪd nɑt nid hɪm. ðət kəntɛntəd hɝ. eɪ kæptən ə ðə ɹɔɪəl ɡɑɹdz wəd meɪk ðə bɔɹɾɝləndɝz θɪŋk ə hɝ əz dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ sunɝ ðən ʃi wɑntəd. nɑt tə mɛnʃən ðət mɛlɝ maɪt dɪsaɪd tə lɪɹ ət hɝ.

To her surprise, Mellar made no objection to staying behind. A meeting with four rulers would hardly be as boring as meeting merchants, but he begged leave to be about his duties since she did not need him. That contented her. A Captain of the Royal Guards would make the Borderlanders think of her as Daughter-Heir sooner than she wanted. Not to mention that Mellar might decide to leer at her.

kæptən mɛlɝz ʌnkənsɝn wɑz nɑt ʃɛɹd baɪ ðə ɹɛst ə hɝ bɑɾiɡɑɹd, ðoʊ. wʌn ə ðə ɡɑɹdzwɪmən əpɛɹənli wɛn ɹʌnɪŋ fəɹ keɪsil, kəz ðə tɔl ɝæfɛlɪn wʊmən keɪm stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ ɪndə ðə sɪɾɪŋ ɹum waɪl ɪleɪn wɑz stɪl ɹaɪɾɪŋ, dɪmændɪŋ tə əkʌmpəni ɪleɪn wɪð ði ɪntaɪɝ bɑɾiɡɑɹd. bɝdʒɪt faɪnəli hæd tə ɔɹɾɝ əɹ aʊt tə stɑp əɹ pɹoʊɾɛsts.

Captain Mellar's unconcern was not shared by the rest of her bodyguard, though. One of the Guardswomen apparently went running for Caseille, because the tall Arafellin woman came striding into the sitting room while Elayne was still writing, demanding to accompany Elayne with the entire bodyguard. Birgitte finally had to order her out to stop her protests.

fəɹ wʌns, bɝdʒɪɾ əpɪɹd tə ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðə fæk ðəɾ ɪleɪn wɑz nɑt gɑnə bi bʌdʒd, livɪŋ wɪð keɪsil tə tʃeɪnʒ əɹ kloʊðz. wɛl, ʃi stɔkt ɔf ɡɹʌmbəlɪŋ oʊðz, slæmɪŋ ðə dɔɹ bɪhaɪn əɹ wɪð ə kɹæʃ, bʌɾ ət list ʃi dɪd ɡoʊ. jə maɪɾ əv θɔt ʃi wəd bi hæpi fəɹ ə tʃæns tə teɪk ɔf ðət kæptən-dʒɛnɝəlz koʊt, bʌt ðə bɑn maɪɾ əz wɛl əv bɪn ən ɛkoʊ ʌv əɹ kɝsɪz. eɪvinhə dɪd nɑt kɝs, bʌt ʃi kɛpt ʌp əɹ ædmənɪʃənz. ɛvɹiθɪŋ hæd tə bi dʌn ɪn sətʃ ə wɝlwɪnd, ðoʊ, ðəɾ ɪleɪn hæɾ ən ɪkskjus tə ɪɡnɔɹ ðɛm.

For once, Birgitte appeared to recognize the fact that Elayne was not going to be budged, leaving with Caseille to change her clothes. Well, she stalked off grumbling oaths, slamming the door behind her with a crash, but at least she did go. You might have thought she would be happy for a chance to take off that Captain-General's coat, but the bond might as well have been an echo of her curses. Aviendha did not curse, but she kept up her admonitions. Everything had to be done in such a whirlwind, though, that Elayne had an excuse to ignore them.

ɛsænd wɑz sʌmən ən bɪɡæn leɪɪŋ aʊt suɾəbəl ɡɑɹməns, waɪl ɪleɪn heɪstəli eɪɾ əɹ mɪddeɪ mil ɝli. ʃi hæd nɑt sɛn fəɹ ɪt; eɪvinhə hæd. əpɛɹənli, mɑneɪəl sɛd mɪsɪŋ milz wɑz əz bæɾ əz iɾɪŋ tu mʌtʃ. mɪstʃɹəs hɑɹfɝ, ɪnfɔɹm ðət ʃi wəɾ əv tə hændəl ðə ɡlæsmeɪkɝz, ən ði ʌðɝ dɛləɡeɪʃənz əz wɛl, ɡɹɪməs feɪnli ivən əz ʃi ɪnklaɪn əɹ hɛɾ ɪn æksɛptəns. bɪfɔɹ livɪŋ, ʃi ənaʊns ðət ʃi hæɾ əkwaɪɝd ɡoʊts fəɹ ðə pæləs. ɪleɪn niɾəd tə dʒɹɪŋk ɡoʊts mɪlk, ən lɑts ʌv ɪt. kɛɝin ɡɹoʊn ət hɪɹɪŋ ðət ʃi wɑz tə titʃ ðə wɪndfɪndɝz ðət naɪt, bʌɾ ət lis ðə wʊmən meɪd noʊ kɑmɛn ɑn əɹ daɪət. ɪn tʃɹuθ, ʃi hoʊp tə bi bæk ɪn ðə pæləs baɪ naɪtfɔl, bʌt ʃi ɔlsoʊ ɪkspɛktəd tə bi əz taɪɝɾ əz ɪf ʃi hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi tɔt ðət lɛsən. vændin dɪd nɑɾ ɔfɝ ædvaɪs, iðɝ, nɑɾ ə ðət sɔɹt. ɪleɪn hæd stʌɾid ðə neɪʃənz ə ðə blaɪtbɔɹɾɝ əlɔŋ wɪð ɛvɹi ʌðɝ læn əz pɑɹɾ ə hɝ ɛdʒəkeɪʃən, ən hæd dɪskʌst əɹ ɪntɛntʃənz wɪð ðə waɪt-hɛɹd ɡɹin, hu nu ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz wɛl, jɛt ʃi wəɾ əv dɪɹli lʌv tə teɪk vændin əlɔŋ. sʌmwʌn u hæɾ æktʃəli  lɪvd ɪn ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz maɪt si nuɑnsɪz ðəɾ ɪskeɪp hɝ. bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt dɛɹ də mɔɹ ðən æsk ə fju læs hɝid kwɛstʃənz waɪl ɛsænd wɑz dʒɹɛsɪŋ hɝ, dʒʌs tə ɹiəʃʊɹ hɝsɛlf ɑn θɪŋz vændin hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi toʊl hɝ. nɑt ðət ʃi niɾəd ɹiəʃʊɹəns, ʃi ɹilaɪzd. ʃi fɛlt əz foʊkəst əz bɝdʒɪt dʒɹɔɪŋ ə baʊ.

Essande was summoned and began laying out suitable garments, while Elayne hastily ate her midday meal early. She had not sent for it; Aviendha had. Apparently, Monaelle said missing meals was as bad as eating too much. Mistress Harfor, informed that she would have to handle the glassmakers, and the other delegations as well, grimaced faintly even as she inclined her head in acceptance. Before leaving, she announced that she had acquired goats for the Palace. Elayne needed to drink goat's milk, and lots of it. Careane groaned at hearing that she was to teach the Windfinders that night, but at least the woman made no comment on her diet. In truth, she hoped to be back in the Palace by nightfall, but she also expected to be as tired as if she had already taught that lesson. Vandene did not offer advice, either, not of that sort. Elayne had studied the nations of the Blightborder along with every other land as part of her education, and had discussed her intentions with the white-haired Green, who knew the Borderlands well, yet she would have dearly loved to take Vandene along. Someone who had actually lived in the Borderlands might see nuances that escaped her. But she did not dare do more than ask a few last hurried questions while Essande was dressing her, just to reassure herself on things Vandene had already told her. Not that she needed reassurance, she realized. She felt as focused as Birgitte drawing a bow.

faɪnəli, ɹin hæd tə bi bɹɔt fɹəm wɛɹ ʃi wɑz jɛɾ əɡɛn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kənvɪns ə fɔɹmɝ sʌldəm ðət ʃi, tu, kəd tʃænəl. ɹin hæd bɪn meɪkɪŋ ðət wiv ɪn ðə steɪbliɑɹɾ ɛvɹi deɪ sɪns ʃi fɝst woʊv ɪt tə sɛn mɛɝɪlɪl ɔf; ʃi kəɾ oʊpən ɪɾ ɑn ðə seɪm spɑɾ ɪn bɹəm wʊd wɪð noʊ dɪfəkəlti. ðəɹ wɝ noʊ mæps ə ðəɾ ɛɹiə ɪn ðə pæləs ðət wɝ ɡʊɾ ɪnʌf fəɹ mɛɝɪlɪl tə mɑɹk ðə kæmps pəzɪʃənz vɛɹi wɛl, ən ɪf ɪleɪn əɹ eɪvinhə woʊv ðə ɡeɪtweɪ, ɪt maɪɾ oʊpən tɛn maɪlz əɹ mɔɹ fɑɹðɝ fɹəm ðə kæmps ðən ðə smɔl klɪɹɪŋ ɹin nu. ðə snoʊ hæd stɑp fɔlɪŋ ɪn bɹəm wʊd bɪfɔɹ ðə ɡɹeɪ ɹɪtɝnd, jɛɾ ivən soʊ, tɛn maɪlz ɪn fɹɛʃ snoʊ kəd min ənʌðɝ tu aʊɝz ət bɛst. ɪleɪn wɑntəd ðɪs dʌn kwɪkli. spid. ɛvɹiwʌn hæd tə muv wɪð spid.

Finally, Reanne had to be brought from where she was yet again trying to convince a former sul'dam that she, too, could channel. Reanne had been making that weave in the stableyard every day since she first wove it to send Merilille off; she could open it on the same spot in Braem Wood with no difficulty. There were no maps of that area in the Palace that were good enough for Merilille to mark the camp's positions very well, and if Elayne or Aviendha wove the gateway, it might open ten miles or more farther from the camps than the small clearing Reanne knew. The snow had stopped falling in Braem Wood before the Gray returned, yet even so, ten miles in fresh snow could mean another two hours at best. Elayne wanted this done quickly. Speed. Everyone had to move with speed.

ðə si foʊk mʌst əv bɪn əwɛɹ ə ðə bʌsəl ðəɾ ɛnvɛləp ðə pæləs, ɡɑɹdzwɪmən ɹʌnɪŋ θɹu ðə hɔlweɪz kæɹiɪŋ mɛsədʒəz ən fɛtʃɪŋ ðɪs pɝsən əɹ ðæt, bʌɾ ɪleɪn meɪd ʃʊɹ ðeɪ wɝ toʊl nʌθɪŋ. səpoʊz zeɪɾə dɪsaɪɾɪd tə kʌm əlɔŋ, ʃi wɑz keɪpəbəl ə hævɪŋ wʌn ə ðə wɪndfɪndɝz meɪk əɹ oʊn ɡeɪtweɪ ɪf ɪleɪn ɹəfjuz hɝ, ən ðə weɪvməstʃɹəs wɑz ə kɑmpləkeɪʃən tə bi əvɔɪɾəd. ðə wʊmən ɔlɹɛɾi bɪheɪvd əz ðoʊ ʃi hæɾ əz mʌtʃ ɹaɪɾ ɪn ðə pæləs əz ɪleɪn hɝsɛlf. zeɪɾə tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə dɑmənɪɹ kəd ɹuən ɛvɹiθɪŋ əz ʃʊɹli əz mɛlɝ lɪɹɪŋ ət hɝ.

The Sea Folk must have been aware of the bustle that enveloped the Palace, Guardswomen running through the hallways carrying messages and fetching this person or that, but Elayne made sure they were told nothing. Suppose Zaida decided to come along, she was capable of having one of the Windfinders make her own gateway if Elayne refused her, and the Wavemistress was a complication to be avoided. The woman already behaved as though she had as much right in the Palace as Elayne herself. Zaida trying to domineer could ruin everything as surely as Mellar leering at her.

meɪkɪŋ heɪst sim bɪɑn ɛsænz əbɪləɾi, jɛɾ ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls flu, ən baɪ ðə taɪm ðə sʌn stʊd stʃɹeɪɾ oʊvɝhɛd, ɪleɪn faʊn hɝsɛlf ɹaɪɾɪŋ faɪɹhɑɹt sloʊli θɹu ðə snoʊz ə bɹəm wʊd, nɪɹ ɪnʌf fɪfti liɡz nɔɹθ ə keɪɛmlɪn əz ðə waɪld ɡus flu bʌɾ oʊnli ə stɛp θɹu ðə ɡeɪtweɪ ɪndə θɪk fɔɹəst ə tɔl paɪn ən lɛðɝlif ən oʊk mɪkst wɪð ɡɹeɪ-bɹæntʃt tʃɹiz ðət hæd lɔs ðɛɹ livz. əkeɪʒənəli ə bɹɔd mɛdoʊ oʊpən ʌp, kʌvɝd wɪð snoʊ laɪk waɪt kɑɹpəts, ənblɛmɪʃt seɪv fəɹ ðə hʊfpɹɪns ə mɛɝɪlɪlz ɹʌnɪŋ hɔɹs. mɛɝɪlɪl hæd bɪn sɛn əhɛd wɪð ðə lɛɾɝ, ən ɪleɪn, eɪvinhə ən bɝdʒɪt hæd fɑloʊɾ æftɝ ən aʊɝ, tə ɡɪv əɹ taɪm tə ɹitʃ ðə bɔɹɾɝləndɝz əhɛɾ ə ðɛm. ðə ɹoʊd fɹəm keɪɛmlɪn tə nu bɹəm leɪ səm maɪlz tə ðə wɛst. hɪɹ, ðeɪ cʊɾə bɪn ə θaʊzən liɡz fɹəm hjumən hæbəteɪʃən.

Making haste seemed beyond Essande's ability, yet everyone else flew, and by the time the sun stood straight overhead, Elayne found herself riding Fireheart slowly through the snows of Braem Wood, near enough fifty leagues north of Caemlyn as the wild goose flew but only a step through the gateway into thick forest of tall pine and leatherleaf and oak mixed with gray-branched trees that had lost their leaves. Occasionally a broad meadow opened up, covered with snow like white carpets, unblemished save for the hoofprints of Merilille's running horse. Merilille had been sent ahead with the letter, and Elayne, Aviendha and Birgitte had followed after an hour, to give her time to reach the Borderlanders ahead of them. The road from Caemlyn to New Braem lay some miles to the west. Here, they could have been a thousand leagues from human habitation.

fəɹ ɪleɪn, dʒɹɛsɪŋ hæd bɪn əz sɪɹiəs əz tʃuzɪŋ ɑɹmɝ. hɝ kloʊk wɑz laɪnd wɪð mɑɹɾən fəɹ æɾəd wɔɹmθ, bʌt ðə mətɪɹiəl wɑz dɑɹk ɡɹin wʊl, sɑf jɛt θɪk, ən əɹ ɹaɪɾɪŋ dʒɹɛs wɑz ɡɹin sɪlk, ən ʌnədɔɹnd. ivən əɹ snʌɡ ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɡlʌvz wɝ pleɪn dɑɹk ɡɹin lɛðɝ. ənlɛs ðə sɔɹdz hæd bɪn dʒɹɔn, ðət wɑz ði ɑɹmɝ ɪn wɪtʃ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ feɪst ɹulɝz. hɝ oʊnli vɪzəbəl dʒuəlɹi wɑz ə smɔl æmbɝ bɹutʃ ɪn ðə ʃeɪp ʌv ə tɝɾəl, ən ɪf ɛniwʌn θɔt ðəɾ ɑd, lɛt ðɛm. ən ɑɹmi ʌv bɔɹɾɝləndɝz wɑz bɪɑn ɛni tʃɹæp wʌn ə hɝ ɹaɪvəlz kəd leɪ, əɹ ivən ɪleɪɾə, bʌt ðoʊz tɛn sɪstɝz - tɛn əɹ mɔɹ - maɪt bi ɪleɪɾəz. ʃi wɑz nɑɾ əbaʊt tə lɛt hɝsɛlf bi bʌndəld ɔf bæk tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ.

For Elayne, dressing had been as serious as choosing armor. Her cloak was lined with marten for added warmth, but the material was dark green wool, soft yet thick, and her riding dress was green silk, and unadorned. Even her snug riding gloves were plain dark green leather. Unless the swords had been drawn, that was the armor in which an Aes Sedai faced rulers. Her only visible jewelry was a small amber brooch in the shape of a turtle, and if anyone thought that odd, let them. An army of Borderlanders was beyond any trap one of her rivals could lay, or even Elaida, but those ten sisters - ten or more - might be Elaida's. She was not about to let herself be bundled off back to the White Tower.

"wi kən tɝn bæk fɹəm ðɪs wɪθaʊɾ ɪnkɝɪŋ toʊ, ɪleɪn." eɪvinhə, skaʊlɪŋ, stɪl wɔɹ əɹ il ɡɑɹməns, wɪð əɹ sɪŋɡəl sɪlvɝ nɛkləs ən hɛvi aɪvɝi bɹeɪslət. hɝ stɑki beɪ wɑz ə hænd ʃɔɹɾɝ ðən faɪɹhɑɹɾ əɹ bɝdʒɪts lin ɡɹeɪ, æɹoʊ, ən mʌtʃ dʒɛnlɝ tə hændəl, ðoʊ ʃi ɹoʊd mɔɹ izəli ðən wʌns ʃi hæd. dɑɹk-stɑkɪnɡd lɛɡz bɛɹɾ əbʌv ðə ni baɪ stʃɹædlɪŋ ə sæɾəl, ʃi æktʃəli  lʊkt wɔɹm, ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə ʃɔl ɹæpt ɝaʊn əɹ hɛd. ənlaɪk bɝdʒɪt, ʃi hæd nɑt sist əɹ ətɛmps tə dɪsweɪɾ ɪleɪn. "sɝpɹaɪz ɪz ɔl vɛɹi wɛl, ðəl wɪl ɹɪspɛk jə mɔɹ ɪf ðeɪ mʌs mit jə hæfweɪ."

"We can turn back from this without incurring toh, Elayne." Aviendha, scowling, still wore her Aiel garments, with her single silver necklace and heavy ivory bracelet. Her stocky bay was a hand shorter than Fireheart or Birgitte's lean gray, Arrow, and much gentler to handle, though she rode more easily than once she had. Dark-stockinged legs bared above the knee by straddling a saddle, she actually looked warm, except for the shawl wrapped around her head. Unlike Birgitte, she had not ceased her attempts to dissuade Elayne. "Surprise is all very well, but they will respect you more if they must meet you halfway."

"aɪ kən hɑɹdli əbændən mɛɝɪlɪl," ɪleɪn sɛd mɔɹ peɪʃənli ðən ʃi fɛlt. pɝhæps ʃi wɑz nɑt wɪɹi ɛni lɔŋɡɝ, bʌt niðɝ dɪd ʃi fil pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli fɹɛʃ, nɑɾ əɾ ɔl ɹɛɾi tə pʊɾ ʌp wɪð bædʒɝɪŋ. bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt wɑnə snæp əɾ eɪvinhə. "ʃi maɪt fil sʌmθɪŋ ʌv ə ful, stændɪŋ ðəɹ wɪð ə lɛɾɝ ənaʊnsɪŋ ðəɾ aɪm kʌmɪŋ ən aɪ doʊn kʌm. wɝs, aɪ wəd fil ə ful."

"I can hardly abandon Merilille," Elayne said more patiently than she felt. Perhaps she was not weary any longer, but neither did she feel particularly fresh, not at all ready to put up with badgering. But she did not want to snap at Aviendha. "She might feel something of a fool, standing there with a letter announcing that I'm coming and I don't come. Worse, I would feel a fool."

"bɛɾɝ tə fil ə ful ðən bi wʌn," bɝdʒɪt mʌɾɝd, hæf ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛθ. hɝ dɑɹk kloʊk spɹɛd bɪhaɪn əɹ sæɾəl, ən əɹ ɪntʃɹəkət bɹeɪd hʌŋ fɹəm ði oʊpənɪŋ ə hɝ hʊɾ ɔlmoʊs tə hɝ weɪst. pʊlɪŋ ðət hʊɾ ʌp dʒʌst ɪnʌf tə fɹeɪm əɹ feɪs wɑz ðə wʌn kənsɛʃən ʃi hæd meɪd tə ðə koʊld ən ðə ɡʌstɪŋ wɪn ðət səmtaɪmz lɪftəd fɹɛʃ-fɔlən snoʊ laɪk fɛðɝz. ʃi dɪd nɑt wɑn əɹ vɪʒən əbskjʊɹd. ðə kʌvɝ ɑn əɹ baʊz sæɾəl-keɪs, mɛn tə kip ðə bɑstʃɹɪŋ dʒɹaɪ, hʌŋ daʊn soʊ ʃi kəd ɹitʃ ðə baʊ kwɪkli. ðə sədʒɛstʃən ðət ʃi wɛɹ ə sɔɹd hæd bɪn kwɔʃt wɪð əz mʌtʃ ɪndɪɡneɪʃən əz ɪf ɪleɪn hæɾ æskt eɪvinhə tə wɛɹ wʌn. bɝdʒɪt nu ðə baʊ, bʌt ʃi kleɪmd ʃi maɪt stæb hɝsɛlf tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə dʒɹɔ ə sɔɹd. stɪl, hɝ ʃɔɹt ɡɹin koʊt wʊɾə blɛndəɾ ɪndə wʊdlænz əɾ ənʌðɝ taɪm ə ðə jɪɹ, ən fəɹ ə wʌndɝ, hɝ waɪd-lɛɡəd tʃɹaʊzɝz wɝ ðə seɪm kʌlɝ. ʃi wɑz ə wɔɹɾɝ naʊ, nɑt ðə kæptən-dʒɛnɝəl ə ðə kwinz ɡɑɹd, jɛt ʃi wɑz nɑt soʊ pliz baɪ ðə taɪɾəl əz maɪɾ əv bɪn ɪkspɛktəd. ðə bɑn kæɹiɾ əz mʌtʃ fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən əz əlɝtnəs.

"Better to feel a fool than be one," Birgitte muttered, half under her breath. Her dark cloak spread behind her saddle, and her intricate braid hung from the opening of her hood almost to her waist. Pulling that hood up just enough to frame her face was the one concession she had made to the cold and the gusting wind that sometimes lifted fresh-fallen snow like feathers. She did not want her vision obscured. The cover on her bow's saddle-case, meant to keep the bowstring dry, hung down so she could reach the bow quickly. The suggestion that she wear a sword had been quashed with as much indignation as if Elayne had asked Aviendha to wear one. Birgitte knew the bow, but she claimed she might stab herself trying to draw a sword. Still, her short green coat would have blended into woodlands at another time of the year, and for a wonder, her wide-legged trousers were the same color. She was a Warder now, not the Captain-General of the Queen's Guard, yet she was not so pleased by the title as might have been expected. The bond carried as much frustration as alertness.

ɪleɪn saɪd, hɝ bɹɛθ mɪstɪŋ. "ju tu noʊ wʌɾ aɪ hoʊp tə ətʃiv hɪɹ. juv noʊn sɪns aɪ dɪsaɪɾɪd. waɪ ɑɹ jə sʌɾənli tʃɹiɾɪŋ mi əz ɪf aɪm meɪɾ ə bloʊn ɡlæs?"

Elayne sighed, her breath misting. "You two know what I hope to achieve here. You've known since I decided. Why are you suddenly treating me as if I'm made of blown glass?"

ðə pɛɹ ɪkstʃeɪnʒd lʊks pæs hɝ, itʃ weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ði ʌðɝ tə spik fɝst, ðən saɪlənli tɝn tə stɛɹ stʃɹeɪɾ əhɛd, ən sʌɾənli ʃi nu.

The pair exchanged looks past her, each waiting for the other to speak first, then silently turned to stare straight ahead, and suddenly she knew.

"wɛn maɪ tʃaɪld ɪz bɔɹn," ʃi sɛd dʒɹaɪli, "ju kən boʊθ əplaɪ tə bi hɝ wɛt nɝs." ɪf əɹ tʃaɪld wɑz "hɝ." ɪf mɪn hæd sɛd, ɪt wɑz lɔst ɪn eɪvinhə ən bɝdʒɪts waɪn-heɪz mɛmɹiz ə ðət naɪt. ɪt maɪt bi bɛɾɝ tə hæv ə sʌn fɝst, soʊ hi kəd bɪɡɪn ɪz tʃɹeɪnɪŋ bɪfɔɹ ɪz sɪstɝ keɪm. jɛɾ ə dɔɾɝ sɪkjʊɹd ðə səksɛʃən, waɪl ə loʊn sʌn wəd bi pʊʃt əsaɪd, ən əz mʌtʃ əz ʃi wɑntəd mɔɹ ðən wʌn, nʌθɪŋ sɛd ʃi wəɾ əv ənʌðɝ tʃaɪld. ðə laɪt sɛn əɹ mɔɹ ə ɹændz tʃɪlʒɹən, bʌt ʃi hæd tə bi pɹæktəkəl. "aɪ maɪsɛlf də nɑt niɾ ə wɛt nɝs."

"When my child is born," she said dryly, "you can both apply to be her wet nurse." If her child was "her." If Min had said, it was lost in Aviendha and Birgitte's wine-hazed memories of that night. It might be better to have a son first, so he could begin his training before his sister came. Yet a daughter secured the succession, while a lone son would be pushed aside, and as much as she wanted more than one, nothing said she would have another child. The Light send her more of Rand's children, but she had to be practical. "I myself do not need a wet nurse."

eɪvinhəz sʌn-dɑɹkən tʃiks tɝn dɑɹkɝ wɪð ɪmbɛɹəsmənt. bɝdʒɪts ɪkspɹɛʃən dɪd nɑt tʃeɪnʒ, jɛt ðə seɪm ɪmoʊʃən uzd əlɔŋ ðə wɔɹɾɝ bɑnd.

Aviendha's sun-darkened cheeks turned darker with embarrassment. Birgitte's expression did not change, yet the same emotion oozed along the Warder bond.

ðeɪ ɹoʊd sloʊli, fɑloʊɪŋ mɛɝɪlɪlz tʃɹæks fəɹ kloʊs ɑn tu aʊɝz, ən ɪleɪn wɑz θɪŋkɪŋ ðət ðə nɪɹəs kæmp mʌs bi vɛɹi kloʊz wən bɝdʒɪt sʌɾənli pɔɪntəɾ əhɛɾ ən sɛd, "ʃaɪnɝənz," ðən izd əɹ baʊ ɪn ɪts keɪs. əlɝtnəs swɑloʊd fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən ən ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɛls ɪn ðə bɑnd. eɪvinhə tʌtʃt ðə hɪlt ə hɝ bɛl naɪf əz ɪf meɪkɪŋ ʃʊɹ ɪt wɑz ðɛɹ.

They rode slowly, following Merilille's tracks for close on two hours, and Elayne was thinking that the nearest camp must be very close when Birgitte suddenly pointed ahead and said, "Shienarans," then eased her bow in its case. Alertness swallowed frustration and everything else in the bond. Aviendha touched the hilt of her belt knife as if making sure it was there.

weɪɾɪŋ bɪniθ ðə tʃɹiz, ɔf tə wʌn saɪd fɹəm mɛɝɪlɪlz tʃɹeɪsəz, mɛn ən hɔɹsəz əlaɪk wɝ soʊ stɪl ðəɾ ɪleɪn ɔlmoʊs tʊk əm fəɹ nætʃɹəl aʊtkɹɑps ə səm sɔɹɾ əntɪl ʃi meɪɾ aʊt ðə stʃɹeɪnʒ swupɪŋ kɹɛsts ɑn ðɛɹ hɛlməts. ðɛɹ maʊns wɝ nɑɾ ɑɹmɝd, əz ʃaɪnɝən hɛviz' ænəməlz ɔfən wɝ, bʌt ðə mɛn ðɛmsɛlvz wɔɹ pleɪt-ænd-meɪl, wɪð lɔŋ-hɪltɪd sɔɹdz ɑn ðɛɹ bæks, ən sɔɹdz ən meɪsəz hʌŋ ət ðɛɹ bɛls ən fɹəm ðɛɹ sæɾəlz. ðɛɹ dɑɹk aɪz nɛvɝ blɪŋkt. wʌn ə ðə hɔɹsəz swɪʃt ɪts teɪl, ən ðə muvmən sim stɑɹtlɪŋ.

Waiting beneath the trees, off to one side from Merilille's traces, men and horses alike were so still that Elayne almost took them for natural outcrops of some sort until she made out the strange swooping crests on their helmets. Their mounts were not armored, as Shienaran heavies' animals often were, but the men themselves wore plate-and-mail, with long-hilted swords on their backs, and swords and maces hung at their belts and from their saddles. Their dark eyes never blinked. One of the horses swished its tail, and the movement seemed startling.

ə ʃɑɹp-feɪs mæn wɪð ə hɑɹʃ vɔɪs spoʊk əz ɪleɪn ən ði ʌðɝ tu wɪmən dʒɹu ɹeɪn ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm. ðə kɹɛst ətɑp ɪz hɛlmət lʊk laɪk nɛɹoʊ wɪŋz. "kɪŋ isɑɹ sɛnz ɪz əʃʊɹəns ə jəɹ seɪfti, ɪleɪn sədaɪ, ən aɪ æd maɪ oʊn. aɪm kən jəkɑɾə, lɔɹɾ ə fæl aɪsən, ən meɪ pis əbændən mi ən ðə blaɪt kənsum maɪ soʊl ɪf hɑɹm bɪfɔlz jə əɹ ɛniwʌn wɪð jə ɪn əɹ kæmp."

A sharp-faced man with a harsh voice spoke as Elayne and the other two women drew rein in front of him. The crest atop his helmet looked like narrow wings. "King Easar sends his assurance of your safety, Elayne Sedai, and I add my own. I am Kayen Yokata, Lord of Fal Eisen, and may Peace abandon me and the Blight consume my soul if harm befalls you or anyone with you in our camp."

ðət wɑz nɑt soʊ kʌmfɝɾɪŋ əz ɪleɪn maɪɾ əv wɪʃt. ɔl ðiz ɡɛɹəntiz ə hɝ seɪfti oʊnli meɪd klɪɹ ðət ðəɹ hæd bɪn səm kwɛstʃən ʌv ɪt, ən maɪt stɪl bi. "dʌz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ niɾ əʃʊɹənsɪz fɹəm ʃaɪnɝənz?" ʃi sɛd. ʃi stɑɹɾəd tə ɹʌn θɹu ə nɑvəs ɛksɝsaɪz fəɹ kɑmnəs, ən ɹilaɪzd ʃi dɪd nɑt niɾ ɪt. vɛɹi stʃɹeɪnʒ. "ju meɪ lɛd, lɔɹd kən." hi mɪɹli nɑɾəd ən tɝn ɪz hɔɹs.

That was not so comforting as Elayne might have wished. All these guarantees of her safety only made clear that there had been some question of it, and might still be. "Does an Aes Sedai need assurances from Shienarans?" she said. She started to run through a novice exercise for calmness, and realized she did not need it. Very strange. "You may lead, Lord Kayen." He merely nodded and turned his horse.

səm ə ðə ʃaɪnɝənz ɡlænst əɾ eɪvinhə wɪθaʊɾ ɪkspɹɛʃən, ɹɛkəɡnaɪzɪŋ ən il, bʌt fəɹ ðə moʊs pɑɹt ðeɪ sɪmpli fɛl ɪn bɪhaɪnd. oʊnli ðə hʊvz kɹʌntʃɪŋ ðə hɑɹɾɝ snoʊ bɪniθ ðə fɹɛʃ fɔl bɹoʊk ðə saɪləns ə ðɛɹ ʃɔɹt ɹaɪd. ʃi hæd bɪn ɹaɪt. ðə ʃaɪnɝən kæmp wɑz vɛɹi kloʊs. ʃi bɪɡæn tə si sɛntʃɹiz, maʊntəɾ ən ɑɹmɝd, dʒʌs mɪnəts leɪɾɝ, ən sun æftɝ ðət ðeɪ ɹoʊɾ ɪndə ðə ʃaɪnɝən kæmp.

Some of the Shienarans glanced at Aviendha without expression, recognizing an Aiel, but for the most part they simply fell in behind. Only the hooves crunching the harder snow beneath the fresh fall broke the silence of their short ride. She had been right. The Shienaran camp was very close. She began to see sentries, mounted and armored, just minutes later, and soon after that they rode into the Shienaran camp.

spɹɔld əmʌŋ ðə tʃɹiz, ði ɛnkæmpmən sim lɑɹdʒɝ ðən ʃi hæɾ ɪmædʒənd. wɛðɝ ʃi lʊk lɛft, ɹaɪɾ əɹ əhɛd, tɛns ən kʊkfaɪɝz, laɪnz ə tɛðɝd hɔɹsəz ən ɹoʊz ʌv wæɡənz stʃɹɛtʃt aʊɾ ə hɝ saɪt. əz ʃi ən əɹ ɛskɔɹt pæst, soʊlʒɝz lʊkt ʌp ɪn kjʊɹiɑsəɾi, hɑɹd-feɪs mɛn wɪð ðɛɹ hɛdz ʃeɪvd ɪksɛp fəɹ ə tʌft ɑn tɑp ðət wɑz səmtaɪmz lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə ɹitʃ ðə ʃoʊldɝz. fju wɔɹ ɛni pɑɹɾ ə ðɛɹ ɑɹmɝ, bʌɾ ɑɹmɝ ən wɛpənz ɔlweɪz leɪ kloʊs tə hænd. ðə smɛl wɑz nɑt soʊ bæɾ əz mɛɝɪlɪl hæd dɪskɹaɪbd, ðoʊ ʃi kəd meɪk aʊt ðə feɪn oʊɾɝ ə lætʃɹinz ən hɔɹs dʌŋ bɪniθ ði ɝoʊmə ʌv wʌtɛvɝ wɑz bɔɪlɪŋ ɪn ɔl ðiz kʊkpɑts. noʊ wʌn əpɪɹd hʌŋɡɹi, ðoʊ mɛni wɝ lin. nɑt ðə linnəs ə stɑɹveɪʃən, ðoʊ, dʒʌs ðəɾ ə mɛn u hæd nɛvɝ kæɹid mʌtʃ fæɾ ɑn ðɛm. ʃi dɪd noʊɾəs ðət ðəɹ wɝ noʊ spɪts oʊvɝ ɛni faɪɝ ʃi kəd si. mit wəd bi hɑɹɾɝ tə kʌm baɪ ðən ɡɹeɪn, ðoʊ ɡɹeɪn ɪtsɛlf wɑz ɪn ʃɔɹɾ ɪnʌf səplaɪ ðɪs leɪɾ ɪn wɪntɝ. bɑɹli sup dɪd nɑt stʃɹɛŋθən ə mæn ðə weɪ mit dɪd. ðeɪ niɾəd tə muv sun; noʊwɛɹ kəd səpɔɹt fɔɹ ɑɹmiz ðɪs saɪz fəɹ lɔŋ. ʃi dʒʌs hæd tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ðeɪ muvd ɪn ðə ɹaɪt dɝɛkʃən.

Sprawled among the trees, the encampment seemed larger than she had imagined. Whether she looked left, right or ahead, tents and cookfires, lines of tethered horses and rows of wagons stretched out of her sight. As she and her escort passed, soldiers looked up in curiosity, hard-faced men with their heads shaved except for a tuft on top that was sometimes long enough to reach the shoulders. Few wore any part of their armor, but armor and weapons always lay close to hand. The smell was not so bad as Merilille had described, though she could make out the faint odor of latrines and horse dung beneath the aroma of whatever was boiling in all these cookpots. No one appeared hungry, though many were lean. Not the leanness of starvation, though, just that of men who had never carried much fat on them. She did notice that there were no spits over any fire she could see. Meat would be harder to come by than grain, though grain itself was in short enough supply this late in winter. Barley soup did not strengthen a man the way meat did. They needed to move soon; nowhere could support four armies this size for long. She just had to make sure they moved in the right direction.

nɑɾ ɛvɹiwʌn ʃi sɔ wɑz ə soʊlʒɝ wɪð ə ʃeɪvən hɛd, ʌv kɔɹs, ðoʊ ðə mɛn əmʌŋ əm lʊkt ɔlmoʊst əz hɑɹd. ðəɹ wɝ flɛtʃɝz meɪkɪŋ æɹoʊz, wilɹaɪts wɝkɪŋ ɑn wæɡənz, fɛɹiɝz ʃuɪŋ hɔɹsəz, lɔnʒɹəsəz stɝɪŋ bɔɪlɪŋ kɛɾəlz, wɪmən wɝkɪŋ wɪð niɾəlz u maɪɾ əv bɪn simstʃɹəsəz əɹ waɪvz. ɡɹeɪt nʌmbɝz ə pipəl ɔlweɪz fɑloʊɾ ən ɑɹmi, səmtaɪmz əz mɛni əz ðə soʊlʒɝz ðɛmsɛlvz. ʃi dɪd nɑt si ɛniwʌn u cʊɾə bɪn ɛɛs sədaɪ, ðoʊ; sɪstɝz wɝ ənlaɪkli tə pʊʃ ʌp ðɛɹ slivz ən wɝk wʊɾən pæɾəlz ɪn ðə lɔnʒɹi kɛɾəlz, əɹ dɑn pætʃt wʊlənz ən sɪt dɑɹnɪŋ bɹitʃɪz. waɪ dɪd ðeɪ wɑnə ɹɪmeɪn hɪɾən? ʃi ɹɪzɪstɪd ðə dɪzaɪɝ tə ɛmbɹeɪs ðə sɔɹs, tə dʒɹɔ seɪaɪdɑɹ θɹu ðə tɝɾəl æŋɡɹil pɪn tə hɝ bɹɛst. wʌn bæɾəl əɾ ə taɪm, ən fɝst ʃi mʌs faɪt fəɹ ændɝ.

Not everyone she saw was a soldier with a shaven head, of course, though the men among them looked almost as hard. There were fletchers making arrows, wheelwrights working on wagons, farriers shoeing horses, laundresses stirring boiling kettles, women working with needles who might have been seamstresses or wives. Great numbers of people always followed an army, sometimes as many as the soldiers themselves. She did not see anyone who could have been Aes Sedai, though; sisters were unlikely to push up their sleeves and work wooden paddles in the laundry kettles, or don patched woolens and sit darning breeches. Why did they want to remain hidden? She resisted the desire to embrace the Source, to draw saidar through the turtle angreal pinned to her breast. One battle at a time, and first she must fight for Andor.

bɪfɔɹ ə mʌtʃ lɑɹdʒɝ tɛn ðən ɛni ʌv ði ʌðɝz ʃi kəd si, peɪl kænvəs wɪð ə sɪŋɡəl lɔŋ pik, kən dɪsmaʊntɪɾ ən hændəɾ əɹ daʊn. hi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd oʊvɝ wɛðɝ tə də ðə seɪm fəɹ bɝdʒɪɾ ən eɪvinhə, bʌt bɝdʒɪt sɑlvd ɪz dɪlɛmə baɪ stɛpɪŋ daʊn smuðli ən hændɪŋ əɹ ɹeɪnz tə ə weɪɾɪŋ soʊlʒɝ, eɪvinhə baɪ hæf-fɔlɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə sæɾəl. ʃi hæɾ ɪmpɹuvd əɹ ɹaɪɾɪŋ, bʌt maʊntɪŋ ən dɪsmaʊntɪŋ stɪl ɡeɪv əɹ dɪfəkəlti. ɡlɛɹɪŋ ɝaʊn əɹ tə si wɛðɝ ɛniwʌn wɑz læfɪŋ, ʃi smuð daʊn əɹ bʌlki skɝts, ðən ənɹæp ðə ʃɔl fɹəm ɝaʊn əɹ hɛɾ ən sɛɾəld ɪɾ ɑn əɹ ʃoʊldɝz. bɝdʒɪt wɑtʃt əɹ hɔɹs biɪŋ teɪkən əweɪ əz ðoʊ ʃi wɪʃt ʃi hæd teɪkən əɹ baʊ ən kwɪvɝ fɹəm ðə sæɾəl. kən pʊld oʊpən wʌn ə ði ɛntʃɹi flæps ən baʊd.

Before a much larger tent than any of the others she could see, pale canvas with a single long peak, Kayen dismounted and handed her down. He hesitated over whether to do the same for Birgitte and Aviendha, but Birgitte solved his dilemma by stepping down smoothly and handing her reins to a waiting soldier, Aviendha by half-falling out of the saddle. She had improved her riding, but mounting and dismounting still gave her difficulty. Glaring around her to see whether anyone was laughing, she smoothed down her bulky skirts, then unwrapped the shawl from around her head and settled it on her shoulders. Birgitte watched her horse being taken away as though she wished she had taken her bow and quiver from the saddle. Kayen pulled open one of the entry flaps and bowed.

dʒɹɔɪŋ ə læs dip kɑmɪŋ bɹɛθ, ɪleɪn lɛd ði ʌðɝ tu wɪmən ɪn. ʃi kəd nɑɾ əlaʊ ðɛm tə si hɝ əz ə sʌpləkənt. ʃi wɑz nɑt hɪɹ tə bɛɡ, əɹ tə dɪfɛnd. səmtaɪmz, ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn hæd toʊld əɹ wən ʃi wɑz ə tʃaɪld, jə faɪn jɝsɛlf aʊtnʌmbɝd, wɪð noʊ pæθ tə slɪp əweɪ. ɔlweɪz də wʌt jəɹ ɛnəmi list ɪkspɛks, ɪleɪn. ɪn ðət keɪs, jə mʌst ətæk. fɹəm ðə stɑɹt, ʃi mʌst ətæk.

Drawing a last deep calming breath, Elayne led the other two women in. She could not allow them to see her as a supplicant. She was not here to beg, or to defend. Sometimes, Gareth Bryne had told her when she was a child, you find yourself outnumbered, with no path to slip away. Always do what your enemy least expects, Elayne. In that case, you must attack. From the start, she must attack.

ɪnsaɪd, mɛɝɪlɪl ɡlaɪɾɪd tə hɝ əkɹɔs ðə leɪɝd kɑɹpəts leɪd daʊn fəɹ ə flɔɹ. ðə dɪmɪnjəɾɪv ɡɹeɪz smaɪl wɑz nɑt pɹɪsaɪsli ɹɪlivd, bʌt klɪɹli ʃi wɑz ɡlæd tə si ɪleɪn. əsaɪd fɹəm hɝ, ðəɹ wɝ oʊnli faɪv ʌðɝz pɹɛzənt, tu wɪmən ən θɹi mɛn, ən wʌn ə ðə læɾɝ wɑz ə sɝvənt, ən oʊl kævəlɹimən baɪ hɪz baʊd lɛɡz ən skɑɹd feɪs, hu keɪm tə teɪk kloʊks ən ɡlʌvz - ən blɪŋk əɾ eɪvinhə - bɪfɔɹ ɹitʃɹiɾɪŋ tə ə pleɪn wʊɾən teɪbəl ðət hɛld ə sɪlvɝ tʃɹeɪ wɪð ə tɔl-nɛk pɪtʃɝ ən ən ɝeɪ ʌv kʌps. ði ʌðɝ fɔɹ ɹul ðə neɪʃənz ə ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz. ə skæɾɝɪŋ ə bækləs kæmp tʃɛɹz ən fɔɹ lɑɹdʒ bɹeɪʒɝz hoʊldɪŋ ɡloʊɪŋ koʊlz kəmpliɾəd ðə tɛns fɝnɪʃɪŋz. ðɪs wɑz nɑt ðə sɔɹɾ ə ɹɪsɛpʃən ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ ʌv ændɝ maɪɾ əv ɪkspɛktəd, wɪð kɔɹɾiɝz ən mɛni sɝvəns, ən aɪɾəl kɑnvɝseɪʃən tə bi meɪd bɪfɔɹ sɪɹiəs dɪskʌʃənz kəd bɪɡɪn, ən mɛn ən wɪmən ət ðoʊz ɹulɝz' ʃoʊldɝz tə ædvaɪz ðɛm. wʌt ʃi faʊnd wɑz wʌt ʃi hæd hoʊp fɔɹ.

Inside, Merilille glided to her across the layered carpets laid down for a floor. The diminutive Gray's smile was not precisely relieved, but clearly she was glad to see Elayne. Aside from her, there were only five others present, two women and three men, and one of the latter was a servant, an old cavalryman by his bowed legs and scarred face, who came to take cloaks and gloves - and blink at Aviendha - before retreating to a plain wooden table that held a silver tray with a tall-necked pitcher and an array of cups. The other four ruled the nations of the Borderlands. A scattering of backless camp chairs and four large braziers holding glowing coals completed the tent's furnishings. This was not the sort of reception the Daughter-Heir of Andor might have expected, with courtiers and many servants, and idle conversation to be made before serious discussions could begin, and men and women at those rulers' shoulders to advise them. What she found was what she had hoped for.

hilɪŋ hæd ɹɪd mɛɝɪlɪlz aɪz ə ðɛɹ dɑɹk sɝkəlz bɪfɔɹ ʃi lɛf ðə pæləs, ən ʃi meɪɾ ɪleɪnz ɪntʃɹədʌkʃən wɪð sɪmpəl dɪɡnəɾi. "ðɪs ɪz ɪleɪn tʃɹəkənd, ʌv ðə ɡɹin ədʒɑ, əz aɪ toʊl ju." ðæt, ən nʌθɪŋ mɔɹ. ɪleɪn nu ɪnʌf fɹəm vændin tə pɪk aʊt wʌn fɹəm ənʌðɝ ə ðə fɔɹ ɹulɝz u feɪs hɝ.

Healing had rid Merilille's eyes of their dark circles before she left the Palace, and she made Elayne's introduction with simple dignity. "This is Elayne Trakand, of the Green Ajah, as I told you." That, and nothing more. Elayne knew enough from Vandene to pick out one from another of the four rulers who faced her.

"aɪ ɡɪv jə wɛlkəm, ɪleɪn sədaɪ," isɑɹ ə ʃaɪnɝ sɛd. "pis ən ðə laɪt feɪvɝ ju." hi wɑz ə ʃɔɹt mæn, noʊ tɔlɝ ðən hɝsɛlf, slɪm ɪn ə bɹɑnz-kʌlɝd koʊt, hɪz feɪs ənɹɪŋkəl dɪspaɪɾ ə lɔŋ waɪt tɑpnɑt ðət hʌŋ oʊvɝ ðə saɪɾ ə hɪz hɛd. lʊkɪŋ əɾ ɪz sæɾ aɪz, ʃi ɹimaɪndəd hɝsɛlf ðəɾ i wɑz əkaʊntəɾ ə waɪz ɹulɝ ən ə skɪl dɪpləmæɾ əz wɛl əz ə faɪn soʊlʒɝ. ɪn əpɪɹəns, hi wɑz nʌn ə ðoʊz θɪŋz. "meɪ aɪ ɔfɝ jə waɪn? ðə spaɪsəz ɑɹ nɑt fɹɛʃ, bʌt ðeɪv ɡeɪn ɛkstʃɹə ʃɑɹpnəs wɪð eɪdʒ."

"I give you welcome, Elayne Sedai," Easar of Shienar said. "Peace and the Light favor you." He was a short man, no taller than herself, slim in a bronze-colored coat, his face unwrinkled despite a long white topknot that hung over the side of his head. Looking at his sad eyes, she reminded herself that he was accounted a wise ruler and a skilled diplomat as well as a fine soldier. In appearance, he was none of those things. "May I offer you wine? The spices are not fresh, but they have gained extra sharpness with age."

"wɛn mɛɝɪlɪl toʊld əs jə wəd kʌm ɔl ðə weɪ fɹəm keɪɛmlɪn tədeɪ, aɪ kənfɛs aɪ wʊɾə daʊɾɪd hɝ, wɝ ʃi nɑɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ." ɛθɛniɛl ə kændɝ, pɝhæps hæf ə hæn tɔlɝ ðən mɛɝɪlɪl, wɑz plʌmp, hɝ blæk hɛɹ laɪtli dʌstɪd wɪð ɡɹeɪ, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ mʌðɝli əbaʊɾ əɹ dɪspaɪɾ əɹ smaɪl. ɹiɡəl dɪɡnəɾi kloʊðd əɹ əz mʌtʃ əz dɪɾ əɹ faɪn blu wʊl. hɝ aɪz wɝ blu, tu, klɪɹ ən lɛvəl.

"When Merilille told us you would come all the way from Caemlyn today, I confess I would have doubted her, were she not Aes Sedai." Ethenielle of Kandor, perhaps half a hand taller than Merilille, was plump, her black hair lightly dusted with gray, but there was nothing motherly about her despite her smile. Regal dignity clothed her as much as did her fine blue wool. Her eyes were blue, too, clear and level.

"wi ɑɹ pliz ðət jə dɪd kʌm," peɪɾɝ ə ɝæfəl sɛɾ ɪn ə sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli dip, ɹɪtʃ vɔɪs ðət meɪɾ ɪleɪn fil wɔɹmd, sʌmhaʊ. "wi hæv mʌtʃ tə dɪskʌs wɪð ju." vændin hæd sɛɾ i wɑz ðə moʊs bjuɾəfəl mæn ɪn ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz, ən pɝhæps i hæd bɪn lɔŋ əɡoʊ, bʌɾ eɪdʒ hæd leɪd dip laɪnz ɪn ɪz feɪs, ən oʊnli ə fɹɪnʒ ə ʃɔɹt ɡɹeɪ hɛɹ ɹɪmeɪn ɑn ɪz hɛd. hi wɑz tɔl ən bɹɔd-ʃoʊldɝd, ðoʊ, ɪn pleɪn ɡɹin, ən i dɪd lʊk stʃɹɔŋ. ən nɑɾ ə ful.

"We are pleased that you did come," Paitar of Arafel said in a surprisingly deep, rich voice that made Elayne feel warmed, somehow. "We have much to discuss with you." Vandene had said he was the most beautiful man in the Borderlands, and perhaps he had been long ago, but age had laid deep lines in his face, and only a fringe of short gray hair remained on his head. He was tall and broad-shouldered, though, in plain green, and he did look strong. And not a fool.

wɛɹ ði ʌðɝz kæɹid ðɛɹ jɪɹz wɪð ɡɹeɪs, tɛnoʊbiə ʌv sɑldɑiə flɔntɪd juθ ɪf nɑt bjuɾi, wɪð əɹ iɡəlz bik ʌv ə noʊz ən waɪd maʊð. hɝ tɪltəd, ɔlmoʊs pɝpəl aɪz, lɛvəl wɪð ɪleɪnz, wɝ əɹ bɛs fitʃɝ. pɝhæps əɹ oʊnli wʌn. wɛɹ ði ʌðɝz dʒɹɛst sɪmpli, ivən ɪf ðeɪ dɪd ɹul neɪʃənz, hɝ peɪl blu dʒɹɛs wɑz wɝkt wɪð pɝlz ən sæfaɪɝz ən ʃi wɔɹ mɔɹ sæfaɪɝz ɪn əɹ hɛɹ. suɾəbəl fəɹ ðə kɔɹt, bʌt hɑɹdli fəɹ ə kæmp. ən wɛɹ ðeɪ wɝ kɝɾiəs . . . "ʌndɝ ðə laɪt, mɛɝɪlɪl sədaɪ," tɛnoʊbiə sɛɾ ɪn ə haɪ vɔɪs, fɹaʊnɪŋ, "aɪ noʊ jə spik tʃɹuθ, bʌt ʃi lʊks mɔɹ ə tʃaɪl ðən ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. jə dɪd nɑt mɛnʃən ʃi wəd bi bɹɪŋɪŋ ə blæk-aɪɾ il."

Where the others carried their years with grace, Tenobia of Saldaea flaunted youth if not beauty, with her eagle's beak of a nose and wide mouth. Her tilted, almost purple eyes, level with Elayne's, were her best feature. Perhaps her only one. Where the others dressed simply, even if they did rule nations, her pale blue dress was worked with pearls and sapphires and she wore more sapphires in her hair. Suitable for the court, but hardly for a camp. And where they were courteous . . . "Under the Light, Merilille Sedai," Tenobia said in a high voice, frowning, "I know you speak truth, but she looks more a child than an Aes Sedai. You did not mention she would be bringing a black-eyed Aiel."

isɑɹz feɪs nɛvɝ tʃeɪnʒd, bʌt peɪɾɝz maʊθ taɪɾənd, ən ɛθɛniɛl wɛn soʊ fɑɹ əz tə kʌɾ əɹ aɪz bɹifli təwɔɹd tɛnoʊbiə ɪn ə ɡlæns ðət wʊɾə suɾəd ə mʌðɝ. ə vɛɹi ɪɹəteɪɾəd ən dɪspliz mʌðɝ.

Easar's face never changed, but Paitar's mouth tightened, and Ethenielle went so far as to cut her eyes briefly toward Tenobia in a glance that would have suited a mother. A very irritated and displeased mother.

"blæk?" eɪvinhə mʌɾɝd ɪn kənfjuʒən. "maɪ aɪz ɑɹ nɑt blæk. aɪ nɛvɝ sɔ blæk aɪz ɪksɛpt ɑn ə pɛdlɝ əntɪl aɪ kɹɔs ðə dʒɹæɡoʊnwɔl."

"Black?" Aviendha muttered in confusion. "My eyes are not black. I never saw black eyes except on a peddler until I crossed the Dragonwall."

"ju noʊ aɪ kən spik oʊnli ðə tʃɹuθ, tɛnoʊbiə, ən aɪ əʃʊɹ ju," mɛɝɪlɪl bɪɡæn.

"You know I can speak only the truth, Tenobia, and I assure you," Merilille began.

ɪleɪn saɪlənst əɹ wɪð ə tʌtʃ ɑn ði ɑɹm. "ɪɾ ɪz ɪnʌf ðət jə noʊ aɪm ɛɛs sədaɪ, tɛnoʊbiə. ðɪs ɪz maɪ sɪstɝ, eɪvinhə, ʌv ðə naɪn væliz sɛpt ə ðə tɑɹdæɾ il." eɪvinhə smaɪld ət ðɛm, əɹ ət lis bɛɹɾ əɹ tiθ. "ðɪs ɪz maɪ wɔɹɾɝ, leɪɾi bɝdʒɪt tʃɹɑilaɪən." bɝdʒɪt meɪɾ ə ʃɔɹt baʊ, hɝ ɡoʊldən bɹeɪd sweɪɪŋ.

Elayne silenced her with a touch on the arm. "It is enough that you know I am Aes Sedai, Tenobia. This is my sister, Aviendha, of the Nine Valleys Sept of the Taardad Aiel." Aviendha smiled at them, or at least bared her teeth. "This is my Warder, Lady Birgitte Trahelion." Birgitte made a short bow, her golden braid swaying.

wʌn ənaʊnsmən kɑzd əz mɛni stɑɹɾəld lʊks əz ði ʌðɝ - ən il wʊmən wɑz əɹ sɪstɝ? hɝ wɔɹɾɝ wɑz ə wʊmən? - bʌt tɛnoʊbiə ən ði ʌðɝz ɹuld lænz ɑn ði ɛdʒ ə ðə blaɪt, wɛɹ naɪtmɛɹz tʃɹuli maɪt wɔk əbɹɔɾ ɪn deɪlaɪɾ ən ɛniwʌn u lɛt ðɛmsɛlvz bi stɑɹɾəld tu ɡɹeɪtli wɑz əz ɡʊɾ əz dɛd. ɪleɪn ɡeɪv əm noʊ tʃæns tə ɹɪkʌvɝ fʊli, ðoʊ. ətæk bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ noʊ wʌt jə ɑɹ duɪŋ, ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn hæd sɛd, ən kip ətækɪŋ əntɪl jə ɹaʊɾ əm əɹ bɹeɪk θɹu.

One announcement caused as many startled looks as the other - an Aiel woman was her sister? her Warder was a woman? - but Tenobia and the others ruled lands on the edge of the Blight, where nightmares truly might walk abroad in daylight and anyone who let themselves be startled too greatly was as good as dead. Elayne gave them no chance to recover fully, though. Attack before they know what you are doing, Gareth Bryne had said, and keep attacking until you rout them or break through.

"ʃæl wi kənsɪɾɝ ðə naɪsɪɾiz kəmpliɾəd?" ʃi sɛd, teɪkɪŋ ə kʌp ðət ɡeɪv ɔf ði ɝoʊmə ʌv spaɪst waɪn fɹəm ðə tʃɹeɪ pɹɑfɝd baɪ ði oʊl soʊlʒɝ. ə sɝdʒ ə kɑʃən floʊɾ əlɔŋ ðə wɔɹɾɝ bɑnd, ən ʃi sɔ eɪvinhə ɡlæns saɪdweɪz ət ðə kʌp, bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt min tə dʒɹɪŋk. ʃi wɑz dʒʌst ɡlæd niðɝ æktʃəli  spoʊk. "oʊnli ə ful wəd juv hæv kʌm ɔl ðɪs weɪ tə ɪnveɪɾ ændɝ," ʃi sɛd, wɔkɪŋ tə ðə tʃɛɹz ən sɪɾɪŋ. ɹulɝz əɹ nɑt, ðeɪ hæd noʊ tʃɔɪs bʌt tə fɑloʊ əɹ stɛɹ əɾ əɹ bæk. ət bɝdʒɪts bæk, sɪns ʃi stʊd bɪhaɪn hɝ. əz juʒəwəl, eɪvinhə foʊldəd hɝsɛlf tə ðə flɔɹ ən ɝeɪnʒd əɹ skɝts ɪn ə nit fæn. ðeɪ fɑloʊd. "ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn bɹɪŋz ju," ɪleɪn wɛn ɑn. "ju ɹɪkwɛstɪd ðɪs ɑɾiəns wɪð mi kəz aɪ wɑz ət fɑlm. ðə kwɛstʃən ɪz, waɪ ɪz ðəɾ ɪmpɔɹɾənt tə dʒju jə θɪŋk aɪ kən tɛl jə mɔɹ ʌv wʌt hæpən ðəɹ ðən jə ɔlɹɛɾi noʊ? ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ wɑz saʊndəd, dɛd hɪɹoʊz aʊɾ ə lɛdʒən ɹoʊɾ əɡɛnst sintʃæn ɪnveɪɾɝz, ən ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn fɔt ðə ʃædoʊ ɪn ðə skaɪ fəɹ ɔl tə si. ɪf jə noʊ ðət mʌtʃ, jə noʊ əz mʌtʃ əz aɪ."

"Shall we consider the niceties completed?" she said, taking a cup that gave off the aroma of spiced wine from the tray proffered by the old soldier. A surge of caution flowed along the Warder bond, and she saw Aviendha glance sideways at the cup, but she did not mean to drink. She was just glad neither actually spoke. "Only a fool would think you have come all this way to invade Andor," she said, walking to the chairs and sitting. Rulers or not, they had no choice but to follow or stare at her back. At Birgitte's back, since she stood behind her. As usual, Aviendha folded herself to the floor and arranged her skirts in a neat fan. They followed. "The Dragon Reborn brings you," Elayne went on. "You requested this audience with me because I was at Falme. The question is, why is that important to you? Do you think I can tell you more of what happened there than you already know? The Horn of Valere was sounded, dead heroes out of legend rode against Seanchan invaders, and the Dragon Reborn fought the Shadow in the sky for all to see. If you know that much, you know as much as I."

"ɑɾiəns?" tɛnoʊbiə sɛɾ ɪnkɹɛdʒjələsli, pɔzɪŋ hæf-siɾəd. ðə kæmp tʃɛɹ kɹikt əz ʃi lɛt hɝsɛlf dʒɹɑp ðə ɹɛst ə ðə weɪ. "noʊ wʌn ɹɪkwɛstɪɾ ən ɑɾiəns! ivən ɪf jə ɔlɹɛɾi hɛl ðə θɹoʊn ʌv ændɝ - !"

"Audience?" Tenobia said incredulously, pausing half-seated. The camp chair creaked as she let herself drop the rest of the way. "No one requested an audience! Even if you already held the throne of Andor - !"

"lɛɾ əs steɪ tə ðə pɔɪnt, tɛnoʊbiə," peɪɾɝ bɹoʊk ɪn maɪldli. ɹæðɝ ðən sɪɾɪŋ, hi stʊd, əkeɪʒənəli sɪpɪŋ əɾ ɪz waɪn. ɪleɪn wɑz ɡlæd ʃi kəd si ðə ɹɪŋkəlz ɑn ɪz feɪs. ðət vɔɪs kəd kənfjuz ə wʊmənz θɔts, ʌðɝwaɪz.

"Let us stay to the point, Tenobia," Paitar broke in mildly. Rather than sitting, he stood, occasionally sipping at his wine. Elayne was glad she could see the wrinkles on his face. That voice could confuse a woman's thoughts, otherwise.

ɛθɛniɛl spɛɹd tɛnoʊbiə ənʌðɝ kwɪk ɡlæns waɪl siɾɪŋ hɝsɛlf, ən mɝmɝd sʌmθɪŋ ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛθ. ɪleɪn θɔt ʃi hɝd ðə wɝd "mɛɹɪdʒ," wɪð ə ɹufəl saʊnd, bʌt ðət meɪd noʊ sɛns. ɪn ɛni keɪs, ʃi tɝn əɹ ətɛnʃən tə ɪleɪn əz sun əz ʃi wɑz sɛɾəld ɪn əɹ tʃɛɹ. "aɪ maɪt laɪk jəɹ fɝɑsəɾi ənʌðɝ taɪm, ɪleɪn sədaɪ, bʌt ðɛɹz lɪɾəl tə ɛndʒɔɪ fɔlɪŋ ɪndə ən æmbʊʃ ðət wʌn ə jəɹ oʊn ælaɪz əz hɛlp leɪ." tɛnoʊbiə skaʊld, ðoʊ ɛθɛniɛl dɪd nɑɾ ivən dɑɹt ðoʊz ʃɑɹp aɪz ɪn əɹ dɝɛkʃən. "wʌt hæpən ət fɑlm," ðə kwin ə kændɝ toʊld ɪleɪn, "ɪz nɑt soʊ ɪmpɔɹɾənt əz wʌt keɪm ʌv ɪt. noʊ, peɪɾɝ; wi mʌs tɛl əɹ wʌt wi mʌs tɛl hɝ. ʃi ɔlɹɛɾi noʊz tu mʌtʃ fəɹ ɛniθɪŋ ɛls. wi noʊ ðət jə wɝ ə kəmpænjən tə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn ət fɑlm, ɪleɪn. ə fɹɛnd, pɝhæps. jə ɑɹ ɹaɪt; wɪv nɑt kʌm tə ɪnveɪd. wɪv kʌm tə faɪn ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. ən wɪv mɑɹtʃt ɔl ðɪs weɪ oʊnli tə faɪn ðət noʊ wʌn noʊz wɛɹ hiz tə bi faʊnd. dʒju noʊ wɛɹ i ɪz?"

Ethenielle spared Tenobia another quick glance while seating herself, and murmured something under her breath. Elayne thought she heard the word "marriage," with a rueful sound, but that made no sense. In any case, she turned her attention to Elayne as soon as she was settled in her chair. "I might like your ferocity another time, Elayne Sedai, but there's little to enjoy falling into an ambush that one of your own allies has helped lay." Tenobia scowled, though Ethenielle did not even dart those sharp eyes in her direction. "What happened at Falme," the Queen of Kandor told Elayne, "is not so important as what came of it. No, Paitar; we must tell her what we must tell her. She already knows too much for anything else. We know that you were a companion to the Dragon Reborn at Falme, Elayne. A friend, perhaps. You are right; we have not come to invade. We have come to find the Dragon Reborn. And we have marched all this way only to find that no one knows where he is to be found. Do you know where he is?"

ɪleɪn hɪɾ əɹ ɹɪlif ət ðə blʌn kwɛstʃən. ɪt wəd nɛvɝ əv bɪn æskt ɪf ðeɪ θɔt ʃi wɑz mɔɹ ðən ə kəmpænjən əɹ fɹɛnd. ʃi kəd bi dʒʌst əz blʌnt. ətæk ən kip ətækɪŋ. "waɪ dʒju wɑnə faɪn hɪm? ɛməsɛɹiz əɹ mɛsənʒɝz kəd teɪk ɛni wɝd jə wɑntəd tə sɛn hɪm." wɪtʃ wɑz əz ɡʊɾ əz æskɪŋ waɪ ðeɪ bɹɔt væst ɑɹmiz.

Elayne hid her relief at the blunt question. It would never have been asked if they thought she was more than a companion or friend. She could be just as blunt. Attack and keep attacking. "Why do you want to find him? Emissaries or messengers could take any word you wanted to send him." Which was as good as asking why they brought vast armies.

isɑɹ hæd teɪkən noʊ waɪn, ən i stʊd wɪð ɪz fɪsts ɑn ɪz hɪps. "ðə wɔɹ əɡɛns ðə ʃædoʊ ɪz fɔɾ əlɔŋ ðə blaɪt," hi sɛd ɡɹɪmli. "ðə læs bæɾəl wɪl bi fɔɾ ɪn ðə blaɪt, ɪf nɑɾ ət ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl ɪtsɛlf. ən i ɪɡnɔɹz ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz ən kənsɝnz hɪmsɛlf wɪð lænz ðəɾ əv nɑt sin ə mɹdʒɹɑl sɪns ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz."

Easar had taken no wine, and he stood with his fists on his hips. "The war against the Shadow is fought along the Blight," he said grimly. "The Last Battle will be fought in the Blight, if not at Shayol Ghul itself. And he ignores the Borderlands and concerns himself with lands that have not seen a Myrddraal since the Trolloc Wars."

"ðə kɑɹəkɑɹn dɪsaɪdz wɛɹ tə dæns ðə spɪɹz, wɛtləndɝ," eɪvinhə snɪɹd. "ɪf jə fɑloʊ hɪm, ðən jə faɪt wɛɹ i sɛz." noʊ wʌn lʊkt ət hɝ. ðeɪ wɝ ɔl lʊkɪŋ əɾ ɪleɪn. noʊ wʌn tʊk ði oʊpənɪŋ eɪvinhə hæɾ ɔfɝd.

"The Car'a'carn decides where to dance the spears, wetlander," Aviendha sneered. "If you follow him, then you fight where he says." No one looked at her. They were all looking at Elayne. No one took the opening Aviendha had offered.

ɪleɪn meɪd hɝsɛlf bɹið ivənli ən mit ðɛɹ ɡeɪzəz wɪθaʊt blɪŋkɪŋ. eɪ bɔɹɾɝlənd ɑɹmi wɑz tu ɡɹeɪɾ ə tʃɹæp fəɹ ɪleɪɾə tə leɪ ɪn ɔɹɾɝ tə kætʃ ɪleɪn tʃɹəkənd, bʌt ɹænd ælθɹ, ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, maɪt bi ənʌðɝ mæɾɝ. mɛɝɪlɪl ʃɪftəɾ ɑn əɹ tʃɛɹ, bʌt ʃi hæɾ əɹ ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz. noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ mɛni tʃɹiɾiz ðə ɡɹeɪ sɪstɝ hæd nəɡoʊʃieɪɾəd, wʌns ɪleɪn bɪɡæn, ʃi wɑz tə kip saɪlənt. kɑnfəɾəns floʊɾ əlɔŋ ðə bɑnd wɪð bɝdʒɪt. ɹænd wɑz ə stoʊn, ənɹiɾəbəl, ən dɪstənt. "ju noʊ ʌv ðə waɪt taʊɝz pɹɑkləmeɪʃən ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ hɪm?" ʃi æskt kwaɪətli. ðeɪ mʌst, baɪ naʊ.

Elayne made herself breathe evenly and meet their gazes without blinking. A Borderland army was too great a trap for Elaida to lay in order to catch Elayne Trakand, but Rand al'Thor, the Dragon Reborn, might be another matter. Merilille shifted on her chair, but she had her instructions. No matter how many treaties the Gray sister had negotiated, once Elayne began, she was to keep silent. Confidence flowed along the bond with Birgitte. Rand was a stone, unreadable, and distant. "You know of the White Tower's proclamation regarding him?" she asked quietly. They must, by now.

"ðə taʊɝ kɔlz ənæθəmə ɑn ɛniwʌn u əpɹoʊtʃɪz ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn seɪv θɹu ði ɔfəsəz ə ðə taʊɝ," peɪɾɝ sɛd dʒʌst əz kwaɪətli. teɪkɪŋ ə siɾ ət læst, hi ɹəɡɑɹɾəd əɹ wɪð sɪɹiəs aɪz. "ju ɑɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ. ʃʊɹli ðət kaʊns əz ðə seɪm θɪŋ."

"The Tower calls anathema on anyone who approaches the Dragon Reborn save through the offices of the Tower," Paitar said just as quietly. Taking a seat at last, he regarded her with serious eyes. "You are Aes Sedai. Surely that counts as the same thing."

"ðə taʊɝ mɛɾəlz ɛvɹiwɛɹ," tɛnoʊbiə mʌɾɝd. "noʊ, ɛθɛniɛl; əl seɪ ðɪs! ðə hoʊl wɝl noʊz ðə taʊɝ ɪz dɪvaɪɾəd. dʒju fɑloʊ ɪleɪɾə əɹ ðə ɹɛbəlz, ɪleɪn?"

"The Tower meddles everywhere," Tenobia muttered. "No, Ethenielle; I will say this! The whole world knows the Tower is divided. Do you follow Elaida or the rebels, Elayne?"

"ðə wɝl sɛldəm noʊz wʌɾ ɪt θɪŋks ɪt noʊz," mɛɝɪlɪl sɛɾ ɪn ə vɔɪs ðət sim tə loʊɝ ðə tɛmpɹətʃɝ ɪn ðə tɛnt. ðə taɪni wʊmən u ɹæn wən ɪleɪn ɔɹɾɝd əɹ ən skwikt wən wɪndfɪndɝz lʊkt əɾ əɹ sæɾ ʌp stʃɹeɪɾ ən feɪs tɛnoʊbiə əz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ, hɝ smuð feɪs əz fɹɔsti əz əɹ toʊn. "ði əfɛɹz ə ðə taʊɝ ɑɹ fəɹ ɪnɪʃiəts tə noʊ, tɛnoʊbiə. ɪf jə wɑnə lɝn, æsk tə hæv jəɹ neɪm ɹɪɾən ɪn ðə nɑvəs bʊk, ən ɪn twɛnti jɪɹz jə maɪt lɝn ə lɪɾəl."

"The world seldom knows what it thinks it knows," Merilille said in a voice that seemed to lower the temperature in the tent. The tiny woman who ran when Elayne ordered her and squeaked when Windfinders looked at her sat up straight and faced Tenobia as an Aes Sedai, her smooth face as frosty as her tone. "The affairs of the Tower are for initiates to know, Tenobia. If you want to learn, ask to have your name written in the novice book, and in twenty years you might learn a little."

hɝ ɪlumən mædʒəsti, tɛnoʊbiə si bæʃɪɹ kæzɑɾi, ʃild ə ðə nɔɹθ ən sɔɹɾ ə ðə blaɪtbɔɹɾɝ, haɪ siɾ ə haʊs kæzɑɾi, leɪɾi ʌv ʃheɪni, æsnɛl, kʌnwɔɹ ən ɡɑnɑi, ɡlɛɹɾ ət mɛɝɪlɪl wɪð ɔl ðə fjʊɹi ʌv ə blɪzɝd. ən sɛd nʌθɪŋ. ɪleɪnz ɹɪspɛk fəɹ əɹ ɪnkɹist slaɪtli.

Her Illumined Majesty, Tenobia si Bashere Kazadi, Shield of the North and Sword of the Blightborder, High Seat of House Kazadi, Lady of Shahayni, Asnelle, Kunwar and Ganai, glared at Merilille with all the fury of a blizzard. And said nothing. Elayne's respect for her increased slightly.

mɛɝɪlɪlz dɪsəbiɾiəns dɪd nɑt dɪspliz hɝ. ɪt seɪvd əɹ fɹəm tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pɹɛvɝəkeɪt waɪl simɪŋ tə spik oʊnli ðə tʃɹuθ. ɛɡwin sɛd ðeɪ mʌs tʃɹaɪ tə lɪv əz ɪf ðeɪ hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi swɔɹn ðə θɹi oʊðz, ən hɪɹ ən naʊ, ɪleɪn fɛl ðə weɪɾ ʌv ɪt. hɪɹ, ʃi wɑz nɑt ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ ʌv ændɝ stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ tə kleɪm əɹ mʌðɝz θɹoʊn, əɹ nɑɾ oʊnli ðæt. ʃi wɑz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ʌv ðə ɡɹin ədʒɑ, wɪð mɔɹ ɹizən fəɹ teɪkɪŋ kɛɹ wɪð əɹ wɝdz ðən sɪmpli haɪɾɪŋ wʌt ʃi wɑntəd tə ɹɪmeɪn hɪɾən.

Merilille's disobedience did not displease her. It saved her from trying to prevaricate while seeming to speak only the truth. Egwene said they must try to live as if they had already sworn the Three Oaths, and here and now, Elayne felt the weight of it. Here, she was not the Daughter-Heir of Andor struggling to claim her mother's throne, or not only that. She was an Aes Sedai of the Green Ajah, with more reason for taking care with her words than simply hiding what she wanted to remain hidden.

"aɪ kænɑt tɛl jə ɪɡzækli wɛɹ i ɪz." tʃɹuθ, kəz ʃi kəɾ oʊnli hæv ɡɪvən əm ə veɪɡ dɝɛkʃən, ɹʌfli təwɔɹd tiɹ, ən noʊ tɛlɪŋ haʊ fɑɹ; tʃɹuθ, kəz ʃi dɪd nɑt tʃɹʌst əm səfɪʃənli fəɹ ivən ðæt. ʃi dʒʌs hæd tə bi kɛɹfəl wʌt ʃi sɛd, ən haʊ. "aɪ də noʊ ðəɾ əpɛɹənli hi ɪntɛnz tə ɹɪmeɪn wɛɹ hiz əwaɪl." hi hæd nɑt muv fəɹ deɪz, ðə fɝs taɪm sɪns livɪŋ əɹ ðəɾ i hæd ɹɪmeɪn ɪn ɛni wʌn pleɪs lɔŋɡɝ ðən hæf ə deɪ. "aɪ wɪl tɛl jə wʌɾ aɪ kæn, bʌɾ oʊnli ɪf jə əɡɹi ðət jəl mɑɹtʃ saʊθ wɪðɪn ðə wik. jəl ɹʌn aʊɾ ə bɑɹli əz wɛl əz miɾ ɪf jə ɹɪmeɪn hɪɹ mʌtʃ lɔŋɡɝ, ɛniweɪ. aɪ pɹɑməs, jəl bi mɑɹtʃɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn." tə bɪɡɪn wɪð ðeɪ wəd bi, əɾ ɛni ɹeɪt.

"I cannot tell you exactly where he is." Truth, because she could only have given them a vague direction, roughly toward Tear, and no telling how far; truth, because she did not trust them sufficiently for even that. She just had to be careful what she said, and how. "I do know that apparently he intends to remain where he is awhile." He had not moved for days, the first time since leaving her that he had remained in any one place longer than half a day. "I will tell you what I can, but only if you agree that you will march south within the week. You will run out of barley as well as meat if you remain here much longer, anyway. I promise, you will be marching toward the Dragon Reborn." To begin with they would be, at any rate.

peɪɾɝ ʃʊk ɪz bɔl hɛd. "ju wɑn əs tə ɛntɝ ændɝ? ɪleɪn sədaɪ - əɹ ʃəɾ aɪ kɔl jə leɪɾi ɪleɪn, naʊ? - aɪ wɪʃ jə ðə laɪts blɛsɪŋ ɪn jəɹ kwɛs fəɹ ændɝz kɹaʊn, bʌt nɑɾ ɪnʌf tə ɔfɝ maɪ mɛn tə faɪt fəɹ ɪt."

Paitar shook his bald head. "You want us to enter Andor? Elayne Sedai - or should I call you Lady Elayne, now? - I wish you the Light's blessing in your quest for Andor's crown, but not enough to offer my men to fight for it."

"ɪleɪn sədaɪ ən leɪɾi ɪleɪn ɑɹ wʌn ən ðə seɪm," ʃi toʊl ðɛm. "aɪ də nɑɾ æsk jə tə faɪt fəɹ mi. ɪn tʃɹuθ, aɪ hoʊp wɪð ɔl maɪ hɑɹt ðət jə kɹɔs ændɝ wɪθaʊt soʊ mʌtʃ əz ə skɝmɪʃ." ɹeɪzɪŋ əɹ sɪlvɝ waɪnkʌp, ʃi wɛɾ əɹ lɪps wɪθaʊt dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ. ə flæʃ ə kɑʃən sɝdʒ θɹu ðə wɔɹɾɝ bɑnd, ən ɪn spaɪɾ ə hɝsɛlf, ɪleɪn læft. eɪvinhə wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ əɹ fɹəm ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɝ aɪ ən fɹaʊnɪŋ. ivən naʊ, ðeɪ wɝ gɑnə lʊk æftɝ ðə mʌðɝ tə bi.

"Elayne Sedai and Lady Elayne are one and the same," she told them. "I do not ask you to fight for me. In truth, I hope with all my heart that you cross Andor without so much as a skirmish." Raising her silver winecup, she wet her lips without drinking. A flash of caution surged through the Warder bond, and in spite of herself, Elayne laughed. Aviendha was watching her from the corner of her eye and frowning. Even now, they were going to look after the mother to be.

"aɪ æm ɡlæd sʌmwʌn faɪnz ðɪs əmjuzɪŋ," ɛθɛniɛl sɛd ɹaɪli. "tʃɹaɪ tə θɪŋk laɪk ə saʊθlændɝ, peɪɾɝ. ðeɪ pleɪ ðə ɡeɪm ə haʊsəz hɪɹ, ən aɪ θɪŋk ʃiz biɪŋ vɛɹi klɛvɝ əɾ ɪt. ʃi ʃəd bi, aɪ səpoʊz; aɪv ɔlweɪz hɝd ðəɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ kɹieɪɾəd deɪz deɪmɑɹ."

"I am glad someone finds this amusing," Ethenielle said wryly. "Try to think like a Southlander, Paitar. They play the Game of Houses here, and I think she is being very clever at it. She should be, I suppose; I've always heard that Aes Sedai created Daes Dae'mar."

"θɪŋk tæktɪks, peɪɾɝ." isɑɹ wɑz stʌɾiɪŋ ɪleɪn, wɛɹɪŋ ə smɔl smaɪl. "wi muv təwɔɹd keɪɛmlɪn əz ɪnveɪɾɝz, soʊ ɛni ændɔɝən wɪl si ɪt. wɪntɝ meɪ bi maɪl hɪɹ, bʌt wɪl stɪl nid wiks tə ɹaɪd ðət fɑɹ. baɪ ðə taɪm wi du, ʃɪl əv ɹæliɾ ɪnʌf ə ði ændɔɝən haʊsəz əɡɛnst ʌs, ən tə hɝ, ðət ʃɪl əv ðə laɪən θɹoʊn, əɹ nɪɹ ɪnʌf. ət ðə list, ɪnʌf stʃɹɛŋkθ wɪl əv bɪn plɛdʒ tə hɝ ðət noʊ wʌn ɛls wɪl bi eɪbəl tə stæn lɔŋ əɡɛns hɝ." tɛnoʊbiə ʃɪftəɾ ɑn əɹ tʃɛɹ, fɹaʊnɪŋ ən ədʒʌstɪŋ əɹ skɝts, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz ə ɹɪspɛkt ɪn əɹ aɪz wən ʃi lʊkt əɾ ɪleɪn ðət hæd nɑt bɪn ðəɹ bɪfɔɹ.

"Think tactics, Paitar." Easar was studying Elayne, wearing a small smile. "We move toward Caemlyn as invaders, so any Andoran will see it. Winter may be mild here, but we'll still need weeks to ride that far. By the time we do, she will have rallied enough of the Andoran Houses against us, and to her, that she will have the Lion Throne, or near enough. At the least, enough strength will have been pledged to her that no one else will be able to stand long against her." Tenobia shifted on her chair, frowning and adjusting her skirts, but there was a respect in her eyes when she looked at Elayne that had not been there before.

"ænd wən wi ɹitʃ keɪɛmlɪn, ɪleɪn sədaɪ," ɛθɛniɛl sɛd, "ju wɪl . . . nəɡoʊʃieɪt . . . əs ɪndə livɪŋ ændɝ wɪθaʊɾ ə bæɾəl biɪŋ fɔt." ðət keɪm aʊɾ əz nɑt kwaɪɾ ə kwɛstʃən, bʌɾ ɔlmoʊst. "vɛɹi klɛvɝ ɪndid."

"And when we reach Caemlyn, Elayne Sedai," Ethenielle said, "you will . . . negotiate . . . us into leaving Andor without a battle being fought." That came out as not quite a question, but almost. "Very clever indeed."

"ɪf ɔl wɝks əz ʃi plænz," isɑɹ sɛd, hɪz smaɪl feɪɾɪŋ. hi pʊɾ aʊɾ ə hænd wɪθaʊt lʊkɪŋ, ən ði oʊl soʊlʒɝ pleɪst ə waɪnkʌp ɪn ɪt. "bæɾəlz sɛldəm du; ivən ðɪs blʌdləs sɔɹt, aɪ θɪŋk."

"If all works as she plans," Easar said, his smile fading. He put out a hand without looking, and the old soldier placed a winecup in it. "Battles seldom do; even this bloodless sort, I think."

"aɪ vɛɹi mʌtʃ wɑn ɪɾ ɔl tə bi blʌdləs," ɪleɪn sɛd. laɪt, ɪt hæd tə bi, əɹ ɪnstɛɾ ə seɪvɪŋ əɹ kʌntʃɹi fɹəm sɪvəl wɔɹ, ʃi hæd plʌnʒd ɪɾ ɪndə wɝs. "aɪ wɪl wɝk hɑɹd tə si ðəɾ ɪɾ ɪz. aɪ ɪkspɛk jə tə də ðə seɪm."

"I very much want it all to be bloodless," Elayne said. Light, it had to be, or instead of saving her country from civil war, she had plunged it into worse. "I will work hard to see that it is. I expect you to do the same."

"du jə ɔlsoʊ hæpən tə noʊ wɛɹ maɪ ʌŋkəl dævɹæm ɪz, ɪleɪn sədaɪ?" tɛnoʊbiə sɛd sʌɾənli. "dævɹæm bæʃɪɹ? aɪ wəd laɪk tə spik wɪð ɪm əz mʌtʃ əz wɪð ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn."

"Do you also happen to know where my Uncle Davram is, Elayne Sedai?" Tenobia said suddenly. "Davram Bashere? I would like to speak with him as much as with the Dragon Reborn."

"lɔɹd dævɹæm ɪz nɑt fɑɹ fɹəm keɪɛmlɪn, tɛnoʊbiə. aɪ kænɑt pɹɑməs hɪl stɪl bi ðəɹ wən jə ɝaɪv, ðoʊ. ðəɾ ɪz, ɪf jə əɡɹi?" ɪleɪn meɪd hɝsɛlf bɹið, tə haɪɾ əɹ æŋzaɪəɾi. ʃi wɑz bɪɑnd wɛɹ ʃi kəd tɝn bæk, naʊ. ðeɪ wəd muv saʊθ naʊ, ʃi wɑz sɝɾən, bʌt wɪθaʊt ðɛɹ əɡɹimənt, ðəɹ wəd bi blʌdʃɛd.

"Lord Davram is not far from Caemlyn, Tenobia. I cannot promise he will still be there when you arrive, though. That is, if you agree?" Elayne made herself breathe, to hide her anxiety. She was beyond where she could turn back, now. They would move south now, she was certain, but without their agreement, there would be bloodshed.

fəɹ ə lɔŋ moʊmən ðəɹ wɑz saɪləns ɪn ðə tɛn ɪksɛp fəɹ ə koʊl kɹækɪŋ ɪn wʌn ə ðə bɹeɪʒɝz. ɛθɛniɛl ɪkstʃeɪnʒd ɡlænsɪz wɪð ðə tu mɛn.

For a long moment there was silence in the tent except for a coal cracking in one of the braziers. Ethenielle exchanged glances with the two men.

"soʊ lɔŋ əz aɪ ɡɛt tə si maɪ ʌŋkəl," tɛnoʊbiə sɛd hiɾɪdli, "aɪ æm əɡɹid."

"So long as I get to see my uncle," Tenobia said heatedly, "I am agreed."

"ɑn maɪ ɑnɝ, aɪm əɡɹid," isɑɹ sɛd dɪsaɪsɪvli, ən ɔlmoʊst ətɑp hɪm, ɪf ɪn ə maɪldɝ toʊn, peɪɾɝ sɛd, "ʌndɝ ðə laɪt, aɪm əɡɹid."

"On my honor, I am agreed," Easar said decisively, and almost atop him, if in a milder tone, Paitar said, "Under the Light, I am agreed."

"ðɛn soʊ ɑɹ wi ɔl," ɛθɛniɛl bɹiðd. "ænd naʊ jəɹ pɑɹt, ɪleɪn sədaɪ. wɛɹ də wi faɪn ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn?"

"Then so are we all," Ethenielle breathed. "And now your part, Elayne Sedai. Where do we find the Dragon Reborn?"

ə θɹɪl ʃɑt θɹu ɪleɪn, ən ʃi kəd nɑt seɪ wɛðɝ ɪt wɑz ɪɡzɪlɝeɪʃən, əɹ fɪɹ. ʃi hæd dʌn wʌt ʃi hæd kʌm fɔɹ, ɹɪsk ðə deɪnʒɝz fəɹ hɝsɛlf ən fəɹ ændɝ, ən oʊnli taɪm wəd tɛl wɛðɝ ʃi hæd meɪd ðə ɹaɪt dɪsɪʒən. ʃi ænsɝd wɪθaʊt hɛzəteɪʃən, "æz aɪ toʊl ju, aɪ kænɑt seɪ ɪɡzækli wɛɹ. ə sɝtʃ ɪn mʊɹændi wɪl bi pɹɑfəɾəbəl, ðoʊ." tʃɹuθ, ðoʊ ðə pɹɑfət wəd bi hɝz, nɑt ðɛɹz, ɪf ɛni keɪm. ɛɡwin hæd muv fɹəm mʊɹændi tədeɪ, teɪkɪŋ əweɪ ði ɑɹmi ðət hæd hɛld ɑɝəθɛl ɹɛnʃɝ ən ði ʌðɝ noʊbəlz ɪn ðə saʊθ. pɝhæps ðə bɔɹɾɝləndɝz muvɪŋ saʊθ wəd fɔɹs ɑɝəθɛl ən lwɑn ən pɛlɪvɑɹ tə dɪsaɪɾ əz daɪɛlɪn bɪliv ðeɪ wʊd, tə səpɔɹt hɝ. ðə laɪt sɛn ɪt soʊ.

A thrill shot through Elayne, and she could not say whether it was exhilaration, or fear. She had done what she had come for, risked the dangers for herself and for Andor, and only time would tell whether she had made the right decision. She answered without hesitation, "As I told you, I cannot say exactly where. A search in Murandy will be profitable, though." Truth, though the profit would be hers, not theirs, if any came. Egwene had moved from Murandy today, taking away the army that had held Arathelle Renshar and the other nobles in the south. Perhaps the Borderlanders moving south would force Arathelle and Luan and Pelivar to decide as Dyelin believed they would, to support her. The Light send it so.

ɪksɛp fəɹ tɛnoʊbiə, ðə bɔɹɾɝləndɝz dɪd nɑt sim əɾ ɔl ɪɡzʌltən oʊvɝ lɝnɪŋ wɛɹ tə faɪn ɹænd. ɛθɛniɛl lɛɾ aʊɾ ə lɔŋ bɹɛθ, ɔlmoʊst ə saɪ, ən isɑɹ sɪmpli nɑɾəd ən pɝst ɪz lɪps ɪn θɔt. peɪɾɝ dʒɹæŋk daʊn hæf ɪz waɪn, ðə fɝst ɹil dʒɹɪŋk i hæd teɪkən. ɪt vɛɹi mʌtʃ sim ðət haʊɛvɝ mʌtʃ ðeɪ wɑntəd tə faɪn ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, ðeɪ wɝ nɑt lʊkɪŋ fɔɹwɝd tə miɾɪŋ hɪm. tɛnoʊbiə, ɑn ði ʌðɝ hænd, kɔl fəɹ ði oʊl soʊlʒɝ tə bɹɪŋ əɹ waɪn ən wɛn ɑn əbaʊt haʊ mʌtʃ ʃi wɑntəd tə si hɝ ʌŋkəl. ɪleɪn wəd nɑɾ əv θɔt ðə wʊmən hæd soʊ mʌtʃ fæmli filɪŋ.

Except for Tenobia, the Borderlanders did not seem at all exultant over learning where to find Rand. Ethenielle let out a long breath, almost a sigh, and Easar simply nodded and pursed his lips in thought. Paitar drank down half his wine, the first real drink he had taken. It very much seemed that however much they wanted to find the Dragon Reborn, they were not looking forward to meeting him. Tenobia, on the other hand, called for the old soldier to bring her wine and went on about how much she wanted to see her uncle. Elayne would not have thought the woman had so much family feeling.

naɪt keɪm ɝli ðət taɪm ə jɪɹ, ən oʊnli ə fju aʊɝz ə deɪlaɪt ɹɪmeɪnd, əz isɑɹ pɔɪntəɾ aʊt, ɔfɝɪŋ bɛdz fəɹ ðə naɪt. ɛθɛniɛl sədʒɛstəd ðəɾ əɹ oʊn tɛnt wəd bi mɔɹ kʌmftəɹbəl, jɛt ðeɪ ɡeɪv noʊ saɪn ə dɪsəpɔɪnmənt wən ɪleɪn sɛd ʃi mʌs liv ɪmiɾiətli.

Night came early that time of year, and only a few hours of daylight remained, as Easar pointed out, offering beds for the night. Ethenielle suggested that her own tent would be more comfortable, yet they gave no sign of disappointment when Elayne said she must leave immediately.

"ɹɪmɑɹkəbəl ðət jə kən kʌvɝ sətʃ dɪstəns soʊ kwɪkli," ɛθɛniɛl mɝmɝd. "aɪ hæv hɝɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ spik ʌv ə θɪŋ kɔl tʃɹævlɪŋ. ə lɔs tælənt?"

"Remarkable that you can cover such distance so quickly," Ethenielle murmured. "I have heard Aes Sedai speak of a thing called Traveling. A lost Talent?"

"hæv jə ɪnkaʊntɝd mɛni sɪstɝz ɑn jəɹ dʒɝni?" ɪleɪn æskt.

"Have you encountered many sisters on your journey?" Elayne asked.

"sʌm," ɛθɛniɛl ɹɪplaɪd. "ðɛɹ ɑɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ ɛvɹiwɛɹ, ɪt simz." ivən tɛnoʊbiə wɑz sʌɾənli ɪkspɹɛʃənləs.

"Some," Ethenielle replied. "There are Aes Sedai everywhere, it seems." Even Tenobia was suddenly expressionless.

əlaʊɪŋ bɝdʒɪt tə leɪ ðə mɑɹɾən-laɪnd kloʊk ɑn əɹ ʃoʊldɝz, ɪleɪn nɑɾəd. "soʊ ðəɹ ɑɹ. wəd juv əɹ hɔɹsəz bɹɔt?"

Allowing Birgitte to lay the marten-lined cloak on her shoulders, Elayne nodded. "So there are. Would you have our horses brought?"

nʌn ə ðɛm spoʊk əɡɛn əntɪl ðeɪ wɝ aʊɾ ə ðə kæmp, ɹaɪɾɪŋ θɹu ðə tʃɹiz. ðə hɔɹs-smɛl ən lætʃɹin-stɪŋk hæd simd maɪld ɪn ðə kæmp, bʌt ðɛɹ æbsəns hɪɹ meɪd ði ɛɹ sim vɛɹi fɹɛʃ, ən ðə snoʊ waɪɾɝ, sʌmhaʊ.
