None of them spoke again until they were out of the camp, riding through the trees. The horse-smell and latrine-stink had seemed mild in the camp, but their absence here made the air seem very fresh, and the snow whiter, somehow.

"ju wɝ vɛɹi kwaɪət, bɝdʒɪt tʃɹɑilaɪən," eɪvinhə sɛd, θʌmpɪŋ əɹ beɪz ɹɪbz wɪð əɹ hilz. ʃi ɔlweɪz bɪliv ði ænəməl wəd stɑp wɪθaʊt ɹimaɪndɝz tə kip ɡoʊɪŋ.

"You were very quiet, Birgitte Trahelion," Aviendha said, thumping her bay's ribs with her heels. She always believed the animal would stop without reminders to keep going.

"eɪ wɔɹɾɝ dʌzn spik fəɹ əɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ; ʃi blʌɾi lɪsənz ən wɑtʃəz əɹ bæk," bɝdʒɪt ɹɪplaɪd dʒɹaɪli. ɪt wɑz ənlaɪkli ðə fɔɹəs kənteɪn ɛniwʌn u maɪt θɹɛɾən ðɛm, ðɪs nɪɹ ðə ʃaɪnɝən kæmp, bʌɾ əɹ baʊ ɹɪmeɪn ənkʌvɝd, ən əɹ aɪz skæn ðə tʃɹiz.

"A Warder doesn't speak for her Aes Sedai; she bloody listens and watches her back," Birgitte replied dryly. It was unlikely the forest contained anyone who might threaten them, this near the Shienaran camp, but her bow remained uncovered, and her eyes scanned the trees.

"ə mʌtʃ heɪstiɝ fɔɹm ə nɪɡoʊʃieɪʃən ðən aɪm juz tə, ɪleɪn," mɛɝɪlɪl sɛd. "nɔɹməli, ðiz mæɾɝz ɹikwaɪɝ deɪz əɹ wiks ə tɔkɪŋ, ɪf nɑt mʌnθs, bɪfɔɹ ɛniθɪŋ ɪz əɡɹid. jə wɝ lʌki ðeɪ ɑɹ nɑt dəmɑni. əɹ kɛɹhinɪn," ʃi ədmɪɾəd dʒudɪʃɪsli. "bɔɹɾɝləndɝz ɑɹ ɹifɹɛʃɪŋli oʊpən ən stʃɹeɪtfɔɹwɝd. izi tə dil wɪð."

"A much hastier form of negotiation than I am used to, Elayne," Merilille said. "Normally, these matters require days or weeks of talking, if not months, before anything is agreed. You were lucky they are not Domani. Or Cairhienin," she admitted judiciously. "Borderlanders are refreshingly open and straightforward. Easy to deal with."

oʊpən ən stʃɹeɪtfɔɹwɝd? ɪleɪn ʃʊk əɹ hɛd slaɪtli. ðeɪ wɑntəd tə faɪn ɹænd, bʌt kənsild waɪ. ðeɪ kənsil ðə pɹɛzəns ə sɪstɝz, tu. ət lis ðeɪ wəd bi muvɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm hɪm, wʌns ʃi hæɾ əm ɑn ðɛɹ weɪ tə mʊɹændi. ðət wəɾ əv tə du, fəɹ naʊ, bʌt ʃi hæd tə wɔɹn hɪm, wʌns ʃi kəd fɪɡjɝ aʊt haʊ tə də soʊ wɪθaʊɾ ɛndeɪnʒɝɪŋ hɪm. teɪk kɛɹ ə hɪm, mɪn, ʃi θɔt. teɪk kɛɹ ə hɪm fəɹ ʌs.

Open and straightforward? Elayne shook her head slightly. They wanted to find Rand, but concealed why. They concealed the presence of sisters, too. At least they would be moving away from him, once she had them on their way to Murandy. That would have to do, for now, but she had to warn him, once she could figure out how to do so without endangering him. Take care of him, Min, she thought. Take care of him for us.

ə fju maɪlz fɹəm ðə kæmp, ʃi ɹeɪn ɪn tə stʌɾi ðə fɔɹəst əz əsɪdwəsli əz bɝdʒɪt. ɪspɛʃli bɪhaɪn ðɛm. ðə sʌn sæt loʊ ɑn ðə tʃɹitɑps. ə tʃɹɑɾɪŋ waɪt fɑks əpɪɹd fəɹ ən ɪnstən ən wɑz ɡɔn. sʌmθɪŋ flɪkɝɾ ɑn ə bɛɹ ɡɹeɪ bɹæntʃ, ə bɝd pɝhæps, əɹ ə skwɝəl. ə dɑɹk hɔk sʌɾənli plʌməɾɪd aʊɾ ə ðə skaɪ, ən ə θɪn skwil bɹoʊk ði ɛɹ ən ɛndəd sʌɾənli. ðeɪ wɝ nɑt biɪŋ fɑloʊd. ɪt wɑz nɑt ðə ʃaɪnɝənz ʃi wɝiɾ əbaʊt, bʌt ðoʊz hɪɾən sɪstɝz. ðə wɪɹinəs ðət hæd vænɪʃt ɝliɝ, wɪð mɛɝɪlɪlz nuz, hæd ɹɪtɝnd wɪð ɪntʃɹəs naʊ ðəɾ əɹ miɾɪŋ wɪð ðə bɔɹɾɝləndɝz wɑz dʌn. ʃi wɑntəd nʌθɪŋ soʊ mʌtʃ əz tə klaɪm ɪndə hɝ bɛɾ əz sun əz pɑsəbəl, bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt wɑn ɪɾ ɪnʌf tə ɡɪv ðə wiv fəɹ tʃɹævlɪŋ tə sɪstɝz ʃi dɪd nɑt noʊ.

A few miles from the camp, she reined in to study the forest as assiduously as Birgitte. Especially behind them. The sun sat low on the treetops. A trotting white fox appeared for an instant and was gone. Something flickered on a bare gray branch, a bird perhaps, or a squirrel. A dark hawk suddenly plummeted out of the sky, and a thin squeal broke the air and ended suddenly. They were not being followed. It was not the Shienarans she worried about, but those hidden sisters. The weariness that had vanished earlier, with Merilille's news, had returned with interest now that her meeting with the Borderlanders was done. She wanted nothing so much as to climb into her bed as soon as possible, but she did not want it enough to give the weave for Traveling to sisters she did not know.

ʃi cʊɾə woʊvən ə ɡeɪtweɪ tə ðə pæləs steɪbliɑɹd, bʌɾ oʊnli ət ðə ɹɪsk ə kɪlɪŋ sʌmwʌn u hæpən tə bi kɹɔsɪŋ wɛɹ ɪɾ oʊpənd, soʊ ɪnstɛd ʃi woʊv wʌn fəɹ ənʌðɝ pleɪs ʃi nu dʒʌst əz wɛl. ʃi wɑz soʊ taɪɝd ðəɾ ɪt ɹikwaɪɝɾ ɛfɝt tə wiv, soʊ taɪɝd ðət ʃi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ə ði æŋɡɹil pɪn tə hɝ dʒɹɛs əntɪl ðə sɪlvɝi slæʃ hæɾ əpɪɹɾ ɪn ði ɛɹ ən oʊpən ɑntu ə fil kʌvɝd wɪð bɹaʊn ɡɹæs biɾən flæt baɪ ɝliɝ snoʊfɔlz, ə fil dʒʌst saʊθ ə keɪɛmlɪn wɛɹ ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn hæɾ ɔfən teɪkən əɹ tə wɑtʃ ðə kwinz ɡɑɹdz ɹaɪd tə kəmænd, bɹeɪkɪŋ fɹəm kɑləmz tə fɔɹm ə laɪn fɔɹ əbɹɛst əɾ ə ʃaʊɾəd ɔɹɾɝ.

She could have woven a gateway to the Palace stableyard, but only at the risk of killing someone who happened to be crossing where it opened, so instead she wove one for another place she knew just as well. She was so tired that it required effort to weave, so tired that she did not think of the angreal pinned to her dress until the silvery slash had appeared in the air and opened onto a field covered with brown grass beaten flat by earlier snowfalls, a field just south of Caemlyn where Gareth Bryne had often taken her to watch the Queen's Guards ride to command, breaking from columns to form a line four abreast at a shouted order.

"ɑɹ jə dʒʌs gɑnə lʊk əɾ ɪt?" bɝdʒɪt dɪmændəd.

"Are you just going to look at it?" Birgitte demanded.

ɪleɪn blɪŋkt. eɪvinhə ən mɛɝɪlɪl wɝ stʌɾiɪŋ əɹ wɪð kənsɝn. bɝdʒɪts feɪs ɡeɪv nʌθɪŋ əweɪ, bʌt ðə bɑn kæɹid wɝi, tu.

Elayne blinked. Aviendha and Merilille were studying her with concern. Birgitte's face gave nothing away, but the bond carried worry, too.

"aɪ wɑz dʒʌs θɪŋkɪŋ," ɪleɪn sɛd, ən hil faɪɹhɑɹt θɹu ðə ɡeɪtweɪ. bɛd wəd bi wʌndɝfəl.

"I was just thinking," Elayne said, and heeled Fireheart through the gateway. Bed would be wonderful.

fɹəm ði oʊl pɹæktəs fil tə ðə tɔl ɑɹtʃt ɡeɪts sɛɾ ɪn ðə peɪl, fɪfti-fʊt-haɪ sɪɾi wɔlz wɑz ə ʃɔɹt ɹaɪd. ðə lɔŋ mɑɹkət bɪldɪŋz laɪnɪŋ ði əpɹoʊtʃ tə ðə ɡeɪts wɝ ɛmpti ət ðɪs aʊɝ, bʌt ʃɑɹp-aɪd ɡɑɹdzmɪn stɪl kɛpt ə wɑtʃ. ðeɪ wɑtʃt əɹ ən ði ʌðɝz ɹaɪɾ ɪn əpɛɹənli wɪθaʊt ɹɛkəɡnaɪzɪŋ hɝ. mɝsənɛɹiz, vɛɹi laɪkli. ðeɪ wəd nɑt noʊ hɝ ənlɛs ðeɪ sɔ hɝ ɑn ðə laɪən θɹoʊn. wɪð ðə hɛlp ə ðə laɪt, ən lʌk, ðeɪ wəd si hɝ ðɛɹ.

From the old practice field to the tall arched gates set in the pale, fifty-foot-high city walls was a short ride. The long market buildings lining the approach to the gates were empty at this hour, but sharp-eyed Guardsmen still kept a watch. They watched her and the others ride in apparently without recognizing her. Mercenaries, very likely. They would not know her unless they saw her on the Lion Throne. With the help of the Light, and luck, they would see her there.

twaɪlaɪt wɑz fæst əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ, ðə skaɪ tɝnɪŋ ə dip ɡɹeɪ ən ðə ʃædoʊz slæntɪŋ lɔŋ əkɹɔs ðə stʃɹits. vɛɹi fju pipəl wɝ stɪl aʊɾ ən əbaʊt, ə skæɾɝɪŋ ə foʊk hɝiɪŋ tə fɪnɪʃ ðɛɹ deɪz wɝk bɪfɔɹ ɡoʊɪŋ hoʊm tə dɪnɝ ən ə wɔɹm faɪɝ. ə pɛɹ ə bɛɹɝz kæɹiɪŋ ə mɝtʃəns dɑɹk lækɝd sɪdæn-tʃɛɹ wɛn tʃɹɑɾɪŋ pæst əlɔŋ ə stʃɹiɾ əhɛd, ən ə fju moʊməns leɪɾɝ wʌn ə ðə bɪɡ pʌmp-wæɡənz ɹʌmbəld ɪn ði ʌðɝ dɝɛkʃən bɪhaɪn eɪt ɹʌnɪŋ hɔɹsəz, ɪts aɪɝn-ʃɑd wilz laʊɾ ɑn ðə peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz. ənʌðɝ faɪɝ, sʌmwɛɹ. ðeɪ hæpən moʊst ɔfən ət naɪt. ə pətʃɹoʊl ə fɔɹ ɡɑɹdzmæn wɔk ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz təwɔɹɾ əɹ ən ɑn, wɪθaʊt lʊkɪŋ əɾ əɹ twaɪs. ðeɪ dɪd nɑt ɹɛkəɡnaɪz əɹ ɛnimɔɹ ðən ðə mɛn ət ðə ɡeɪts.

Twilight was fast approaching, the sky turning a deep gray and the shadows slanting long across the streets. Very few people were still out and about, a scattering of folk hurrying to finish their day's work before going home to dinner and a warm fire. A pair of bearers carrying a merchant's dark lacquered sedan-chair went trotting past along a street ahead, and a few moments later one of the big pump-wagons rumbled in the other direction behind eight running horses, its iron-shod wheels loud on the paving stones. Another fire, somewhere. They happened most often at night. A patrol of four Guardsman walked their horses toward her and on, without looking at her twice. They did not recognize her anymore than the men at the gates.

sweɪɪŋ ɪn əɹ sæɾəl, ʃi ɹoʊd wɪʃɪŋ fəɹ əɹ bɛd.

Swaying in her saddle, she rode wishing for her bed.

ɪt wɑz ə ʃɑk tə ɹilaɪz ðət ʃi wɑz biɪŋ lɪftəd daʊn fɹəm əɹ sæɾəl. ʃi oʊpən aɪz ʃi dɪd nɑt ɹɪmɛmbɝ kloʊzɪŋ ən faʊn hɝsɛlf biɪŋ kæɹiɾ ɪndə ðə pæləs ɪn bɝdʒɪts ɑɹmz.

It was a shock to realize that she was being lifted down from her saddle. She opened eyes she did not remember closing and found herself being carried into the Palace in Birgitte's arms.

"pʊt mi daʊn," ʃi sɛd taɪɹədli. "aɪ kən stɪl wɔk."

"Put me down," she said tiredly. "I can still walk."

"ju kən hɑɹdli stæn ʌp," bɝdʒɪt ɡɹaʊld. "bi stɪl."

"You can hardly stand up," Birgitte growled. "Be still."

"ju kænɑt tɔk wɪð hɝ!" eɪvinhə sɛd laʊdli.

"You cannot talk with her!" Aviendha said loudly.

"ʃi ɹɪli dʌz nid slip, mæstɝ nɔɹi," mɛɝɪlɪl sɛɾ ɪn fɝm toʊnz. "təmɑɹoʊ wɪl əv tə du."

"She really does need sleep, Master Norry," Merilille said in firm tones. "Tomorrow will have to do."

"fɝɡɪv mi, bʌt təmɑɹoʊ wɪl nɑt du," nɔɹi ɹɪplaɪd, fəɹ ə wʌndɝ saʊndɪŋ vɛɹi fɝm hɪmsɛlf. "ɪɾ ɪz ɝdʒən aɪ spik wɪð əɹ naʊ!"

"Forgive me, but tomorrow will not do," Norry replied, for a wonder sounding very firm himself. "It is urgent I speak with her now!"

ɪleɪnz hɛd wɑntəd tə wɑbəl əz ʃi lɪftəɾ ɪt. hælwɪn nɔɹi wɑz klʌtʃɪŋ ðət lɛðɝ foʊldɝ tə hɪz skɪni tʃɛst, əz ɔlweɪz, bʌt ðə dʒɹaɪ mæn u tɔkt ə kɹaʊn hɛdz wɪð ðə seɪm dʌsti toʊn i juz fəɹ spikɪŋ ə ðə ɹuf ɹɪpɛɹz wɑz ɔlmoʊs dænsɪŋ ɑn ɪz toʊz ɪn ən ɛfɝt tə ɡɛt baɪ eɪvinhə ən mɛɝɪlɪl, hu itʃ hæɾ ɪm baɪ ən ɑɹm, hoʊldɪŋ ɪm bæk.

Elayne's head wanted to wobble as she lifted it. Halwin Norry was clutching that leather folder to his skinny chest, as always, but the dry man who talked of crowned heads with the same dusty tone he used for speaking of the roof repairs was almost dancing on his toes in an effort to get by Aviendha and Merilille, who each had him by an arm, holding him back.

"pʊt mi daʊn, bɝdʒɪt," ʃi sɛɾ əɡɛn, ən fəɹ ðə sɛkənd wʌndɝ ɪn əz mɛni moʊməns, bɝdʒɪɾ oʊbeɪd. ʃi kɛpt ə səpɔɹɾɪŋ ɑɹm ɝaʊn ɪleɪn, ðoʊ, fəɹ wɪtʃ ɪleɪn wɑz ɡɹeɪtfəl. ʃi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ əɹ lɛɡz wʊɾə səpɔɹɾəd əɹ fəɹ vɛɹi lɔŋ. "wʌɾ ɪz ɪt, mæstɝ nɔɹi? lɛt ðə mæn ɡoʊ, eɪvinhə. mɛɝɪlɪl?"

"Put me down, Birgitte," she said again, and for the second wonder in as many moments, Birgitte obeyed. She kept a supporting arm around Elayne, though, for which Elayne was grateful. She was not sure her legs would have supported her for very long. "What is it, Master Norry? Let the man go, Aviendha. Merilille?"

ðə fɝs klɝk dɑɹɾɪd fɔɹwɝɾ əz sun ðeɪ lɛt ɡoʊ ʌv hɪm. "wɝd bɪɡæn ɝaɪvɪŋ sun æftɝ jə lɛft, maɪ leɪɾi," hi sɛd, nɑt saʊndɪŋ dʌsti əɾ ɔl. wɝi pɪntʃt ɪz bɹaʊz. "ðɛɹ ɑɹ fɔɹ ɑɹmiz. . . . smɔl, aɪ ʃəd seɪ naʊ, aɪ səpoʊz. laɪt, aɪ ɹikɔl wən faɪv θaʊzən mɛn wɑz ən ɑɹmi." hi ɹʌbd ə hæn oʊvɝ ɪz bɔl hɛd, livɪŋ ðə waɪt tʌfs ɹaɪzɪŋ bɪhaɪn ɪz ɪɹz ɪn ɹʌfəl dɪsɝeɪ. "ðɛɹ ɑɹ fɔɹ smɔl ɑɹmiz əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ keɪɛmlɪn, fɹəm ði ist," hi wɛn ɑn ɪn ə mɔɹ juʒəwəl toʊn fəɹ hɪm. ɔlmoʊst. "ðeɪ wɪl bi hɪɹ ɪnsaɪd ðə wik, aɪ fɪɹ. twɛnti θaʊzən mɛn. pɝhæps θɝɾi. aɪ kænɑt bi ʃʊɹ." hi hæf ɪkstɛndəd ðə foʊldɝ tə hɝ əz ɪf ɔfɝɪŋ tə ʃoʊ hɝ ðə peɪpɝz ɪnsaɪd. hi wɑz ædʒəteɪɾəd.

The First Clerk darted forward as soon they let go of him. "Word began arriving soon after you left, my Lady," he said, not sounding dusty at all. Worry pinched his brows. "There are four armies. . . . Small, I should say now, I suppose. Light, I recall when five thousand men was an army." He rubbed a hand over his bald head, leaving the white tufts rising behind his ears in ruffled disarray. "There are four small armies approaching Caemlyn, from the east," he went on in a more usual tone for him. Almost. "They will be here inside the week, I fear. Twenty thousand men. Perhaps thirty. I cannot be sure." He half extended the folder to her as if offering to show her the papers inside. He was agitated.

"hu?" ʃi sɛd. ɛləniə hæɾ ɪsteɪts, ən fɔɹsɪz, ɪn ði ist, bʌt soʊ dɪd nɑiən. bʌt niðɝ kəd ɹeɪz twɛnti θaʊzən mɛn. ən ðə snoʊ ən mʌd ʃʊɾə hɛld əm əntɪl spɹɪŋ. "ʃʊd" ən "wʊd" bɪl noʊ bɹɪdʒəz, ʃi sim tə hɪɹ liniz θɪn vɔɪs seɪ.

"Who?" she said. Elenia had estates, and forces, in the east, but so did Naean. But neither could raise twenty thousand men. And the snow and mud should have held them until spring. "Should" and "would" build no bridges, she seemed to hear Lini's thin voice say.

"aɪ də nɑt noʊ, maɪ leɪɾi," nɔɹi ɹɪplaɪd, "nɑt jɛt."

"I do not know, my Lady," Norry replied, "not yet."

ɪt dɪd nɑt mæɾɝ, ɪleɪn səpoʊzd. huɛvɝ ɪt wɑz, ðeɪ wɝ kʌmɪŋ, ən naʊ. "æt fɝs laɪt, mæstɝ nɔɹi, aɪ wɑn jə tə bɪɡɪn baɪɪŋ ɔl ðə fudstʌfs jə kən faɪn aʊtsaɪd ðə wɔlz ən ɡɛɾ ɪt bɹɔɾ ɪn. bɝdʒɪt, hæv ðə bænɝmən ənaʊnsɪŋ ðə saɪnɪŋ baʊnti æd ðət mɝsənɛɹiz əv fɔɹ deɪz tə saɪn wɪð ðə ɡɑɹdz əɹ ðeɪ mʌs liv ðə sɪɾi. ən əv ənaʊnsməns meɪd tə ðə pipəl, tu, mæstɝ nɔɹi. huɛvɝ wɑns tə liv bɪfɔɹ ðə sidʒ bɪɡɪnz ʃəd ɡoʊ naʊ. ɪɾəl kʌt daʊn ðə nʌmbɝ ə maʊðz wɪv tə fid, ən ɪt maɪt lɛɾ ə fju mɔɹ mɛn tə ɛnlɪst ɪn ðə ɡɑɹdz." pʊʃɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm bɝdʒɪts səpɔɹt, ʃi stʃɹoʊɾ əlɔŋ ðə hɔlweɪ, hɛɾɪŋ fəɹ əɹ əpɑɹtməns. ði ʌðɝz wɝ fɔɹs tə fɑloʊ. "mɛɝɪlɪl, lɛt ðə kɪnswɪmən noʊ, ən ði æθɑn maɪɹ. ðeɪ meɪ wɑnə liv bɪfɔɹ ɪt bɪɡɪnz, tu, mæps, bɝdʒɪt. hæv ðə ɡʊd mæps bɹɔt tə maɪ əpɑɹtməns. ən ənʌðɝ θɪŋ, mæstɝ nɔɹi . . ."

It did not matter, Elayne supposed. Whoever it was, they were coming, and now. "At first light, Master Norry, I want you to begin buying all the foodstuffs you can find outside the walls and get it brought in. Birgitte, have the bannerman announcing the signing bounty add that mercenaries have four days to sign with the Guards or they must leave the city. And have announcements made to the people, too, Master Norry. Whoever wants to leave before the siege begins should go now. It will cut down the number of mouths we have to feed, and it might lead a few more men to enlist in the Guards." Pushing away from Birgitte's support, she strode along the hallway, heading for her apartments. The others were forced to follow. "Merilille, let the Kinswomen know, and the Atha'an Miere. They may want to leave before it begins, too, Maps, Birgitte. Have the good maps brought to my apartments. And another thing, Master Norry . . ."

ðəɹ wɑz noʊ taɪm fəɹ slip, noʊ taɪm fəɹ wɪɹinəs. ʃi hæɾ ə sɪɾi tə dɪfɛnd.

There was no time for sleep, no time for weariness. She had a city to defend.


tʃæptɝ twɛntieɪt


CHAPTER 28

nuz ɪn ə klɔθ sæk


News in a Cloth Sack

ðə mɔɹnɪŋ æftɝ mæt pɹɑməs tə hɛlp tɛslɪn, ɪf i kəd - ən dʒoʊlin, ən ðɪs idɛzinə hi hæd jɛt tə leɪ aɪz ɑn! - taɪlɪn ənaʊns ðət ʃi wɑz dɪpɑɹɾɪŋ ðə sɪɾi.

The morning after Mat promised to help Teslyn, if he could - and Joline, and this Edesina he had yet to lay eyes on! - Tylin announced that she was departing the city.

"sjuɹɔθ ɪz gɑnə ʃoʊ mi haʊ mʌtʃ ʌv ɔltɑɹə aɪ kəntʃɹoʊl naʊ, pɪdʒən," ʃi sɛd. hɝ bɛl naɪf wɑz stʌk ɪn ðə kɑɹv bɪdpoʊst, ən ðeɪ wɝ stɪl laɪɪŋ ɑn ðə ɹʌmpəld lɪnən ʃits əmɪɾ ə tæŋɡəl ə bɛɾɪŋ, hɪm ɪn oʊnli ðə sɪlk skɑɹf ðət hɪd ðə hæŋɪŋ skɑɹ ɝaʊn ɪz nɛk, ən əɹ ɪn əɹ skɪn. ə vɛɹi faɪn skɪn ɪt wɑz, tu, əz smuð əz i hæɾ ɛvɝ tʌtʃt. aɪdli ʃi tʃɹeɪst ɪz ʌðɝ skɑɹz wɪð ə lɔŋ, ɡɹin-lækɝd fɪŋɡɝneɪl. wʌn weɪ ən ənʌðɝ, hi hæɾ əkwaɪɝd kwaɪɾ ə fju, ðoʊ nɑt fəɹ wɑn ə tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə əvɔɪd ðɛm. hɪz haɪd wəd nɑt bɹɪŋ mʌtʃ əɾ ɑkʃən, ðət wɑz fəɹ ʃʊɹ, bʌt ðə skɑɹz fæsəneɪɾəd hɝ. "ɪt wɑzn əɹ aɪdiə, æktʃəli . tuɑn ɪɾəl wɪl . . . hɛlp mi . . . ɪf aɪ si wɪð maɪ oʊn aɪz ɪnstɛɾ ə dʒʌst ɑn ə mæp, ən wʌt ðət ɡɝl sədʒɛsts, sjuɹɔθ dʌz. ʃi wəd laɪk tə si ɪt dʌn jɛstɝdeɪ, ðoʊ. wɪl bi ɡoʊɪŋ baɪ tɔɹeɪkən, soʊ tə kʌvɝ ðə ɡɹaʊn kwɪkli. əz mʌtʃ əz tu hʌnʒɹəd maɪlz ɪn ə deɪ, ɪt simz. oʊ, doʊn lʊk sɪk, paɪɡlɛt. aɪ woʊn meɪk jə klaɪm ɑn wʌn ə ðoʊz θɪŋz."

"Suroth is going to show me how much of Altara I control now, pigeon," she said. Her belt knife was stuck in the carved bedpost, and they were still lying on the rumpled linen sheets amid a tangle of bedding, him in only the silk scarf that hid the hanging scar around his neck, and her in her skin. A very fine skin it was, too, as smooth as he had ever touched. Idly she traced his other scars with a long, green-lacquered fingernail. One way and another, he had acquired quite a few, though not for want of trying to avoid them. His hide would not bring much at auction, that was for sure, but the scars fascinated her. "It wasn't her idea, actually. Tuon thinks it will . . . help me . . . if I see with my own eyes instead of just on a map, and what that girl suggests, Suroth does. She would like to see it done yesterday, though. We'll be going by to'raken, so to cover the ground quickly. As much as two hundred miles in a day, it seems. Oh, don't look sick, piglet. I won't make you climb on one of those things."

mæt hivd ə saɪ ʌv ɹɪlif. ɪt hæd nɑt bɪn ðə pɹɑspɛkt ə flaɪɪŋ ðəɾ ʌpsɛt hɪm. hi θɔɾ i maɪɾ æktʃəli  laɪk ðæt. bʌɾ ɪf i wɑz aʊɾ ʌv ɛbu dɑɹ fəɹ ɛni lɛŋθ ə taɪm, ðə laɪɾ əloʊn nu wɛðɝ tɛslɪn əɹ dʒoʊlin əɹ ivən ðɪs idɛzinə maɪt ɡɹoʊ ɪmpeɪʃən ɪnʌf tə də sʌmθɪŋ stupəd, əɹ wʌɾ ɪɾiəsi bɛslən maɪt ɡɛɾ ʌp tə. bɛslən wɝiɾ ɪm ɔlmoʊst əz mʌtʃ əz ðə wɪmən. taɪlɪn, ɪksaɪɾəd baɪ hɝ kʌmɪŋ flaɪɾ ɑn wʌn ə ðə sintʃæn bists, lʊk mɔɹ ən iɡəl ðən ɛvɝ.

Mat heaved a sigh of relief. It had not been the prospect of flying that upset him. He thought he might actually like that. But if he was out of Ebou Dar for any length of time, the Light alone knew whether Teslyn or Joline or even this Edesina might grow impatient enough to do something stupid, or what idiocy Beslan might get up to. Beslan worried him almost as much as the women. Tylin, excited by her coming flight on one of the Seanchan beasts, looked more an eagle than ever.

"aɪl bi ɡɔn lɪɾəl mɔɹ ðən ə wik, swiɾəlɪŋ. m." ðət ɡɹin fɪŋɡɝneɪl tʃɹeɪs ðə fʊt-lɔŋ pʌkɝɪŋ ðət slæntəɾ əkɹɔs ɪz ɹɪbz. "ʃæl aɪ taɪ jə tə ðə bɛd soʊ əl noʊ jəl bi seɪf tɪl aɪ ɹɪtɝn?"

"I'll be gone little more than a week, sweetling. Hmmm." That green fingernail traced the foot-long puckering that slanted across his ribs. "Shall I tie you to the bed so I'll know you will be safe till I return?"

ɹɪtɝnɪŋ əɹ wɪkəd smaɪl wɪð ɪz moʊst wɪnɪŋ ɡɹɪn tʊk ə bɪɾ ʌv ɛfɝt. hi wɑz fɛɹli ʃʊɹ ʃi wɑz dʒoʊkɪŋ, bʌɾ oʊnli fɛɹli. ðə kloʊðz ʃi tʃoʊz tədeɪ pʊɾ ɪm ɔl ɪn ɹɛd bɹɪljən ɪnʌf tə hɝt ði aɪ; ɔl ɹɛɾ ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə flaʊɝz wɝkt ɑn ðə koʊɾ ən ðə kloʊk, ɛniweɪ, ən ɪz blæk hæɾ ən skɑɹf. ðə waɪt leɪs əɾ ɪz nɛk ən ɹɪsts oʊnli meɪd ðə ɹɛs lʊk ɹɛɾɝ. stɪl, hi skɹæmbəld ɪndə ðɛm, iɡɝ tə ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ə hɝ əpɑɹtməns. wɪð taɪlɪn, ə mæn wɑz waɪz nɑt tə bi tu ʃʊɹ ʌv ɛniθɪŋ. ʃi maɪt nɑt bi dʒoʊkɪŋ, tu.

Returning her wicked smile with his most winning grin took a bit of effort. He was fairly sure she was joking, but only fairly. The clothes she chose today put him all in red brilliant enough to hurt the eye; all red except for the flowers worked on the coat and the cloak, anyway, and his black hat and scarf. The white lace at his neck and wrists only made the rest look redder. Still, he scrambled into them, eager to get out of her apartments. With Tylin, a man was wise not to be too sure of anything. She might not be joking, too.

taɪlɪn hæd nɑɾ ɪɡzædʒɝeɪɾəd sjuɹɔθs ɪmpeɪʃəns, ɪɾ əpɪɹd. ɪn lɪɾəl mɔɹ ðən tu aʊɝz baɪ ðə dʒuəl sɪləndɝ-klɑk ɪn taɪlɪnz sɪɾɪŋ ɹum, ə ɡɪft fɹəm sjuɹɔθ, hi wɑz əkʌmpəniɪŋ ðə kwin tə ðə dɑks. wɛl, sjuɹɔθ ən taɪlɪn ɹoʊɾ ət ðə hɛɾ ə ðə twɛnti əɹ soʊ ʌðɝ blʌd ðət wɝ tə əkʌmpəni ðɛm, ən ðɛɹ əsɔɹɾɪd sɔɪhɪn, mɛn ən wɪmən u baʊd ðɛɹ hæf-ʃeɪv hɛdz tə ðə blʌɾ ən stɛɹd daʊn ðɛɹ noʊzɪz əɾ ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls, waɪl i ɹoʊd bɪhaɪn ɑn pɪps. ən ɔltɑɹən kwinz "pɹɪɾi" kəd nɑt ɹaɪd wɪð ðə blʌd, wɪtʃ ɪnkluɾəd taɪlɪn hɝsɛlf naʊ, ʌv kɔɹs. ɪt wɑz nɑɾ əz ɪf i wɑz ə hɝɛɾətɛɹi sɝvən əɹ ɛniθɪŋ ə ðət lɛvəl.

Tylin had not exaggerated Suroth's impatience, it appeared. In little more than two hours by the jeweled cylinder-clock in Tylin's sitting room, a gift from Suroth, he was accompanying the Queen to the docks. Well, Suroth and Tylin rode at the head of the twenty or so other Blood that were to accompany them, and their assorted so'jhin, men and women who bowed their half-shaved heads to the Blood and stared down their noses at everyone else, while he rode behind on Pips. An Altaran Queen's "pretty" could not ride with the Blood, which included Tylin herself now, of course. It was not as if he was a hereditary servant or anything of that level.

ðə blʌɾ ən moʊst ə ðə sɔɪhɪn wɝ maʊntəɾ ɑn faɪn ænəməlz, slik mɛɹz wɪð ɑɹtʃt nɛks ən ə dɛləkət stɛp, dip-tʃɛstəd ɡɛldɪŋz wɪð fɪɹs aɪz ən stʃɹɔŋ wɪðɝz. hɪz lʌk sim tə hæv noʊ ɪfɛkt ɑn hɔɹs ɹeɪsɪŋ, bʌɾ i wʊɾə weɪdʒɝɾ ɑn pɪps əɡɛnst ɛni ʌv ðɛm. ðə blʌnt-noʊz beɪ ɡɛldɪŋ wɑz nɑt ʃoʊi, bʌt mæt wɑz ʃʊɹ i kəɾ aʊtʃɹʌn nɪɹli ɔl ə ðoʊz pɹɪɾi ænəməlz ɪn ə spɹɪn ən ɔl ə ðɛm oʊvɝ ə lɔŋ hɔl. æftɝ soʊ lɔŋ ɪn ðə steɪbəlz, pɪps wɑntəd tə fɹɪsk ɪf i kəd nɑt ɹʌn, ən ɪt tʊk ɔl mæts skɪl - wɛl, ɔl ðə skɪl ðət hæd sʌmhaʊ kʌm wɪð ðoʊz ʌðɝ mɛnz mɛmɹiz - tə kip ði ænəməl ɪn hænd. bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ wɝ hæfweɪ tə ðə dɑks, ðoʊ, hɪz lɛɡ wɑz eɪkɪŋ tə ðə hɪp. ɪf i wɑz tə liv ɛbu dɑɹ ɛni taɪm sun, ɪt wəɾ əv tə bi baɪ si, əɹ wɪð lukəz ʃoʊ. hi hæɾ ə ɡʊd noʊʃən haʊ tə meɪk ðə mæn liv bɪfɔɹ spɹɪŋ, ɪf ɪt keɪm tə ðæt. ə deɪnʒɝəs noʊʃən, meɪbi, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt si mʌtʃ tʃɔɪs. ði ɔltɝnəɾɪv wɑz ɹɪskiɝ stɪl.

The Blood and most of the so'jhin were mounted on fine animals, sleek mares with arched necks and a delicate step, deep-chested geldings with fierce eyes and strong withers. His luck seemed to have no effect on horse racing, but he would have wagered on Pips against any of them. The blunt-nosed bay gelding was not showy, but Mat was sure he could outrun nearly all of those pretty animals in a sprint and all of them over a long haul. After so long in the stables, Pips wanted to frisk if he could not run, and it took all Mat's skill - well, all the skill that had somehow come with those other men's memories - to keep the animal in hand. Before they were halfway to the docks, though, his leg was aching to the hip. If he was to leave Ebou Dar any time soon, it would have to be by sea, or with Luca's show. He had a good notion how to make the man leave before spring, if it came to that. A dangerous notion, maybe, but he did not see much choice. The alternative was riskier still.

hi wɑz nɑɾ əloʊn ət ðə ɹɪɹ. mɔɹ ðən fɪfti mɛn ən wɪmən, blɛsədli wɛɹɪŋ θɪk waɪt wʊlən ɹoʊbz oʊvɝ ðə ʃɪɹ ɡɑɹməns ðeɪ juʒəwəli wɛn ɝaʊn ɪn, mɑɹtʃt bɪhaɪn ɪm ɪn tu ɹoʊz, səm liɾɪŋ pækhɔɹsɪz wɪð lɑɹdʒ wɪkɝ hæmpɝz fʊl ə dɛlɪkəsiz. ðə blʌd kəd nɑt də wɪθaʊt ðɛɹ sɝvəns; ɪn fækt, ðeɪ sim tə θɪŋk ðeɪ wəd bi slipɪŋ ɹʌf, wɪð soʊ fju. ðə dækoʊvæl sɛldəm ɹeɪz ðɛɹ aɪz fɹəm ðə peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz, ən ðɛɹ feɪsəz wɝ mik əz mɪlk. hi hæd sin ə dækoʊvæl sɛn fəɹ ə stʃɹæpɪŋ wʌns, ə jɛloʊ-hɛɹd mæn əbaʊɾ ɪz eɪdʒ, ən ðə fɛloʊ hæd ɹeɪs tə bɹɪŋ ði ɪnstʃɹəmən ə hɪz oʊn pʌnɪʃmənt. hi hæd nɑɾ ivən tʃɹaɪd tə dɪleɪ əɹ haɪd, mʌtʃ lɛs ɪskeɪp ðə stʃɹæpɪŋ. mæt kəd nɑɾ ʌndɝstæn pipəl laɪk ðæt.

He was not alone at the rear. More than fifty men and women, blessedly wearing thick white woolen robes over the sheer garments they usually went around in, marched behind him in two rows, some leading packhorses with large wicker hampers full of delicacies. The Blood could not do without their servants; in fact, they seemed to think they would be sleeping rough, with so few. The da'covale seldom raised their eyes from the paving stones, and their faces were meek as milk. He had seen a da'covale sent for a strapping once, a yellow-haired man about his age, and the fellow had raced to bring the instrument of his own punishment. He had not even tried to delay or hide, much less escape the strapping. Mat could not understand people like that.

əhɛɾ ə hɪm ɹoʊd sɪks sʌldəm, ðɛɹ ʃɔɹt dɪvaɪɾəd skɝts ʃoʊɪŋ ðɛɹ æŋkəlz. vɛɹi naɪs æŋkəlz ɑn wʌn əɹ tu, bʌt ðə wɪmən sæt ðɛɹ sæɾəlz əz ɪf ðeɪ wɝ ə ðə blʌd, tu. ðə kaʊlz ə ðɛɹ laɪtnɪŋ-pænəl kloʊks hʌŋ daʊn ðɛɹ bæks, ən ðeɪ lɛt ðə koʊld ɡʌsts lɪf ðə kloʊks əz ðoʊ ðə tʃɪl dɪd nɑt tʌtʃ ðɛm, əɹ wəd nɑt dɛɹ. tu hæd liʃt deɪmeɪn wɔkɪŋ bɪsaɪd ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz.

Ahead of him rode six sul'dam, their short divided skirts showing their ankles. Very nice ankles on one or two, but the women sat their saddles as if they were of the Blood, too. The cowls of their lightning-paneled cloaks hung down their backs, and they let the cold gusts lift the cloaks as though the chill did not touch them, or would not dare. Two had leashed damane walking beside their horses.

mæt stʌɾid ðə wɪmən sɝəptɪʃəsli. wʌn ə ðə deɪmeɪn, ə ʃɔɹt wʊmən wɪð peɪl blu aɪz, wɑz lɪŋk baɪ ə sɪlvɝi æɾəm tə ðə plʌmp ɑləv-skɪn sʌldəm i hæd sin wɔkɪŋ tɛslɪn. ðə dɑɹk-hɛɹd deɪmeɪn ænsɝd tə ðə neɪm pʊɹə. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ eɪɡləsnəs wɑz klɪɹ ɑn əɹ smuð feɪs. hi hæd nɑt ɹɪli bɪliv tɛslɪn wən ʃi sɛd ðə wʊmən hæd bɪkʌm ə tʃɹu deɪmeɪn, bʌt ðə ɡɹeɪɪŋ sʌldəm lin loʊ ɪn əɹ sæɾəl tə seɪ sʌmθɪŋ tə ðə wʊmən u hæd bɪn ɹaɪmə ɡælfɹi, ən wʌtɛvɝ ɪt wɑz ðə sʌldəm mɝmɝd, pʊɹə læft ən klæpt əɹ hænz ɪn dɪlaɪt.

Mat studied the women surreptitiously. One of the damane, a short woman with pale blue eyes, was linked by a silvery a'dam to the plump olive-skinned sul'dam he had seen walking Teslyn. The dark-haired damane answered to the name Pura. The Aes Sedai agelessness was clear on her smooth face. He had not really believed Teslyn when she said the woman had become a true damane, but the graying sul'dam leaned low in her saddle to say something to the woman who had been Ryma Galfrey, and whatever it was the sul'dam murmured, Pura laughed and clapped her hands in delight.

mæt ʃɪvɝd. ʃi wəd blʌɾi wɛl ʃaʊt fəɹ hɛlp ɪf i tʃɹaɪd tə teɪk ði æɾəm fɹəm əɹ nɛk. laɪt, wʌt wɑz i θɪŋkɪŋ ʌv! bæɾ ɪnʌf ðəɾ i wɑz stʌk wɪð pʊlɪŋ θɹi ɛɛs sədaɪz beɪkən ɔf ðə faɪɝ fəɹ əm - bɝn hɪm, bʌɾ i dɪd sim tə ɡɛt lʌmbɝd wɪð duɪŋ ðəɾ ɛvɹi taɪm i blʌɾi tɝn ɝaʊnd! - bæɾ ɪnʌf ðæt, wɪθaʊt θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɡɛɾ ɛni mɔɹ aʊɾ ʌv ɛbu dɑɹ.

Mat shivered. She would bloody well shout for help if he tried to take the a'dam from her neck. Light, what was he thinking of! Bad enough that he was stuck with pulling three Aes Sedai's bacon off the fire for them - Burn him, but he did seem to get lumbered with doing that every time he bloody turned around! - bad enough that, without thinking about trying to get any more out of Ebou Dar.

ɛbu dɑɹ wɑz ə ɡɹeɪt sipɔɹt, wɪð pɝhæps ðə lɑɹdʒəs hɑɹbɝ ɪn ðə noʊn wɝld, ən ðə dɑks wɝ lɔŋ ɡɹeɪ fɪŋɡɝz ə stoʊn θɹʌstɪŋ aʊt fɹəm ðə ki ðət ɹæn ðə hoʊl lɛŋθ ə ðə sɪɾi. ɔlmoʊst ɔl ðə mʊɹɪŋ spɑts wɝ teɪkən baɪ sintʃæn vɛsəlz ʌv ɛvɹi saɪz, ðə kɹuz ɪn ðə ɹɪɡɪŋ ən tʃɪɹɪŋ vɪɡɝəsli əz sjuɹɔθ pæs baɪ, ə θʌndɝ ə vɔɪsəz kɔlɪŋ əɹ neɪm. ðə mɛn ɑn ʌðɝ ʃɪps weɪv ðɛɹ ɑɹmz ən ʃaʊɾəd əz wɛl, ðoʊ mɛni əpɪɹd kənfjuzd əz tə hu əɹ wʌt ðeɪ wɝ tʃɪɹɪŋ. noʊ daʊt ðeɪ θɔɾ ɪɾ ɪkspɛktəɾ ə ðɛm. ɑn ðoʊz vɛsəlz, ðə wɪn bloʊɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə hɑɹbɝ stɝd ðə ɡoʊldən biz ʌv ɪljən, ən ðə kɹɛsən munz ə tiɹ, ən ðə ɡoʊldən hɔk ə min. əpɛɹənli ɹænd hæd nɑɾ ɔɹɾɝd ðə mɝtʃəns ðəɹ tə stɑp tʃɹeɪɾɪŋ wɪð sintʃæn-hɛl pɔɹts, əɹ ɛls ðə mɝtʃəns wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ bɪhaɪn ɪz bæk. kʌlɝz flæʃt θɹu mæts skʌl, ən i ʃʊk ɪz hɛd tə klɪɹ ɪt. moʊs mɝtʃəns wəd tʃɹeɪd wɪð ðɛɹ mʌðɝz mɝɾɝɝ ɪf ɪt bɹɔt pɹɑfət.

Ebou Dar was a great seaport, with perhaps the largest harbor in the known world, and the docks were long gray fingers of stone thrusting out from the quay that ran the whole length of the city. Almost all the mooring spots were taken by Seanchan vessels of every size, the crews in the rigging and cheering vigorously as Suroth passed by, a thunder of voices calling her name. The men on other ships waved their arms and shouted as well, though many appeared confused as to who or what they were cheering. No doubt they thought it expected of them. On those vessels, the wind blowing across the harbor stirred the Golden Bees of Illian, and the Crescent Moons of Tear, and the Golden Hawk of Mayene. Apparently Rand had not ordered the merchants there to stop trading with Seanchan-held ports, or else the merchants were going behind his back. Colors flashed through Mat's skull, and he shook his head to clear it. Most merchants would trade with their mother's murderer if it brought profit.

ðə sʌðɝnmoʊs dɑk hæd bɪn klɪɹɾ ə ʃɪps, ən sintʃæn ɔfəsɝz wɪð θɪn plumz ɑn ðɛɹ lækɝd hɛlməts stʊd weɪɾɪŋ tə hæn sjuɹɔθ ən taɪlɪn daʊn ɪndə wʌn ə ðə lɑɹdʒ ɹoʊboʊts ðət stʊd weɪɾɪŋ, eɪt mɛn ɑn ðə lɔŋ ɔɹz ʌv itʃ. æftɝ taɪlɪn ɡeɪv mæt ə læs kɪs, ɛniweɪ, ɔlmoʊs jæŋkɪŋ ɪz hɛɹ aʊt tə pʊl ɪz hɛd daʊn, ən æftɝ ʃi pɪntʃt ɪz bɑɾəm əz ðoʊ noʊ wʌn wɑz blʌɾi wɑtʃɪŋ! sjuɹɔθ fɹaʊn ɪmpeɪʃənli əntɪl taɪlɪn wɑz sɛɾəld ɪn ðə lɔŋ boʊt, ən ɪn tʃɹuθ, ðə sintʃæn wʊmən dɪd nɑt stɑp tʃeɪfɪŋ ivən ðɛn, twɪtʃɪŋ əɹ fɪŋɡɝz əɾ ælwɪn, hɝ sɔɪhɪn, soʊ ðə ʃɑɹp-feɪst wʊmən wɑz kəntɪnjuəli skɹæmbəlɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə bɛntʃɪz tə fɛtʃ əɹ wʌn θɪŋ əɹ ənʌðɝ.

The southernmost dock had been cleared of ships, and Seanchan officers with thin plumes on their lacquered helmets stood waiting to hand Suroth and Tylin down into one of the large rowboats that stood waiting, eight men on the long oars of each. After Tylin gave Mat a last kiss, anyway, almost yanking his hair out to pull his head down, and after she pinched his bottom as though no one was bloody watching! Suroth frowned impatiently until Tylin was settled in the long boat, and in truth, the Seanchan woman did not stop chafing even then, twitching her fingers at Alwhin, her so'jhin, so the sharp-faced woman was continually scrambling across the benches to fetch her one thing or another.

ðə ɹɛst ə ðə blʌd ɹəsiv dip baʊz fɹəm ði ɔfəsɝz, bʌt hæd tə klaɪm daʊn ðə læɾɝz wɪð ðɛɹ sɔɪhɪnz eɪd. ðə sʌldəm hɛlp ðə deɪmeɪn ɪndə ðə boʊts, ən noʊ wʌn əɾ ɔl hɛlp ðə waɪt-ɹoʊb foʊk loʊd ðə pæk hæmpɝz ən ðɛmsɛlvz. sun ɪnʌf, ðə boʊts wɝ kɹɔsɪŋ ðə hɑɹbɝ təwɔɹd wɛɹ ðə ɹeɪkən ən tɔɹeɪkən wɝ kɛp saʊθ ə ðə ɹæhəd, spaɪɾɝɪŋ θɹu ðə spɹɔlɪŋ æŋkɝd fliɾ ə sintʃæn ʃɪps ən ðə skɔɹz ə kæptʃɝd si foʊk vɛsəlz ðət dɑɾəd ðə hɑɹbɝ. ðə ɡɹeɪɾɝ nʌmbɝ ə ðoʊz əpɪɹd tə hæv bɪn ɹɹɪɡd wɪð ɹɪb sintʃæn seɪlz ən dɪfɹən laɪnz. ðɛɹ kɹuz wɝ sintʃæn, tu. ɛksɛptɪŋ ðə wɪndfɪndɝz i tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə θɪŋk əbaʊt, ən meɪbi səm u hæd bɪn soʊld, ðə sɝvaɪvɪŋ æθɑn maɪɹ wɝ ɔl ɪn ðə ɹæhəd wɪð ði ʌðɝ dækoʊvæl klɪɹɪŋ ðə sɪltɪd-ʌp kənælz. ən ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ i kəd də əbaʊɾ ɪt. hi dɪd nɑɾ oʊ ðɛm ɛniθɪŋ, hi hæd mɔɹ ɑn ɪz pleɪt ðən i kəd hændəl ɔlɹɛɾi, ən ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ i kəd du. ðət wɑz ɔl ðəɹ wɑz tə ɪt!

The rest of the Blood received deep bows from the officers, but had to climb down the ladders with their so'jhin's aid. The sul'dam helped the damane into the boats, and no one at all helped the white-robed folk load the pack hampers and themselves. Soon enough, the boats were crossing the harbor toward where the raken and to'raken were kept south of the Rahad, spidering through the sprawling anchored fleet of Seanchan ships and the scores of captured Sea Folk vessels that dotted the harbor. The greater number of those appeared to have been rerigged with ribbed Seanchan sails and different lines. Their crews were Seanchan, too. Excepting the Windfinders he tried not to think about, and maybe some who had been sold, the surviving Atha'an Miere were all in the Rahad with the other da'covale clearing the silted-up canals. And there was nothing he could do about it. He did not owe them anything, he had more on his plate than he could handle already, and there was nothing he could do. That was all there was to it!

hi wɑntəd tə ɹaɪɾ əweɪ ɪmiɾiətli, tə liv ðə si foʊk ʃɪps bɪhaɪn hɪm. noʊ wʌn ɑn ðə dɑks peɪɾ ɪm ðə slaɪɾəst hid. ði ɔfəsɝz hæd ɡɔn əweɪ əz sun əz ðə boʊts kæst ɔf. sʌmwʌn, hi dɪd nɑt noʊ hu, hæd teɪkən ðə pækhɔɹsɪz əweɪ. ðə simən klaɪmd aʊɾ ə ðə ɹɪɡɪŋ ən wɛn bæk tə ðɛɹ wɝk, ən ðə mɛmbɝz ə ðə kɑɹɡoʊ-loʊɾɝz ɡɪl bɪɡæn pʊʃɪŋ ðɛɹ loʊ, hɛvi bæɹoʊz stækt wɪð beɪlz ən kɹeɪts ən bæɹəlz. bʌɾ ɪf i lɛf tu sun, taɪlɪn maɪt dɪsaɪɾ i wɑz plænɪŋ tə kip ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɹaɪɾ aʊɾ ə ðə sɪɾi ən sɛn fəɹ hɪm, soʊ hi sæt pɪps ɑn ði ɛn ə ðə dɑk ən weɪv laɪk ə bʊl ɡus ful tɪl ʃi wɑz fɑɹ ɪnʌf əweɪ ðət ʃi kəd nɑt si hɪm wɪθaʊɾ ə lʊkɪŋ ɡlæs.

He wanted to ride away immediately, to leave the Sea Folk ships behind him. No one on the docks paid him the slightest heed. The officers had gone away as soon as the boats cast off. Someone, he did not know who, had taken the packhorses away. The seamen climbed out of the rigging and went back to their work, and the members of the cargo-loaders guild began pushing their low, heavy barrows stacked with bales and crates and barrels. But if he left too soon, Tylin might decide he was planning to keep riding right out of the city and send for him, so he sat Pips on the end of the dock and waved like a bull goose fool till she was far enough away that she could not see him without a looking glass.

dɪspaɪt ðə θɹɑbɪŋ lɛɡ, hi ɹoʊd sloʊli bæk ʌp ɔlmoʊs ðə hoʊl lɛŋθ ə ðə ki. hi əvɔɪɾəd lʊkɪŋ ət ðə hɑɹbɝ əɡɛn. soʊbɝli dʒɹɛs mɝtʃəns stʊd wɑtʃɪŋ ðɛɹ kɑɹɡoʊ biɪŋ loʊɾəd əɹ ənloʊɾəd, səmtaɪmz slɪpɪŋ ə pɝs tə ə mæn əɹ wʊmən ɪn ə ɡɹin lɛðɝ vɛs tə əbteɪn dʒɛnlɝ hænlɪŋ fəɹ ðɛɹ ɡʊdz əɹ mɔɹ spid, nɑt ðəɾ ɪt sim pɑsəbəl ðə ɡɪldfoʊk kəd muv ɛni fæstɝ. sʌðɝnɝz ɔlweɪz sim tə muv əɾ ə hæf tʃɹɑɾ ənlɛs ðə sʌn wɑz ɹaɪɾ oʊvɝhɛd, wən ðə hit hɪɹ kəd ɹoʊst ə dʌk, ən wɪð ə ɡɹeɪ skaɪ ən ə kʌɾɪŋ wɪn ɔf ðə si, ɪt wʊɾə bɪn koʊl noʊ mæɾɝ wɛɹ ðə sʌn stʊd.

Despite the throbbing leg, he rode slowly back up almost the whole length of the quay. He avoided looking at the harbor again. Soberly dressed merchants stood watching their cargo being loaded or unloaded, sometimes slipping a purse to a man or woman in a green leather vest to obtain gentler handling for their goods or more speed, not that it seemed possible the guildfolk could move any faster. Southerners always seemed to move at a half trot unless the sun was right overhead, when the heat here could roast a duck, and with a gray sky and a cutting wind off the sea, it would have been cold no matter where the sun stood.

baɪ ðə taɪm i wɑz əbɹɛst ə ðə mɔl hɛɹə, hi hæd kaʊntəd mɔɹ ðən twɛnti sʌldəm pətʃɹoʊlɪŋ ðə dɑks wɪð deɪmeɪn, poʊkɪŋ ðɛɹ noʊzɪz ɪndə boʊts livɪŋ æŋkɝd ʃɪps ðət wɝ nɑt sintʃæn, bɔɹɾɪŋ ɛni vɛsəl nuli ɝaɪvd ət ðə dɑks ɔɹ, fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, ɹɛɾi tə kæst ɔf laɪnz. hi hæd bɪn kwaɪt ʃʊɹ ðeɪ wəd bi ðɛɹ. ɪt wɑz gɑnə hæv tə bi vɑlən lukə. ði oʊnli ɔltɝnəɾɪv wɑz dʒʌs tu hæzɝɾəs, ɪksɛpt ɪn ən ɪmɝdʒənsi. lukə wɑz tʃænsi, tu, bʌt ði oʊnli ɹil tʃɔɪs lɛft.

By the time he was abreast of the Mol Hara, he had counted more than twenty sul'dam patrolling the docks with damane, poking their noses into boats leaving anchored ships that were not Seanchan, boarding any vessel newly arrived at the docks or, for that matter, ready to cast off lines. He had been quite sure they would be there. It was going to have to be Valan Luca. The only alternative was just too hazardous, except in an emergency. Luca was chancy, too, but the only real choice left.

bæk ət ðə tɑɹɑsɪn pæləs, hi klaɪm daʊn ɔf pɪps wɪð ə wɪns ən pʊld ɪz wɔkɪŋ stæf aʊt fɹəm bɪhaɪn ðə sæɾəl ɡɝθ. lɛɾɪŋ ə ɡɹum teɪk ðə beɪ, hi lɪmpt ɪnsaɪd, hɪz lɛf lɛɡ bɛɹli eɪbəl tə səpɔɹɾ ɪz weɪt. meɪbi ə soʊk ɪn ə hɑt bæθ wəd teɪk səm ə ðə peɪn. meɪbi ðən i kəd θɪŋk. lukə hæd tə bi kɑt baɪ sɝpɹaɪz, bʌt bɪfɔɹ ɪt keɪm tə lukə, ðəɹ wɝ ə fju ʌðɝ lɪɾəl pɹɑbləmz tə oʊvɝkʌm.

Back at the Tarasin Palace, he climbed down off Pips with a wince and pulled his walking staff out from behind the saddle girth. Letting a groom take the bay, he limped inside, his left leg barely able to support his weight. Maybe a soak in a hot bath would take some of the pain. Maybe then he could think. Luca had to be caught by surprise, but before it came to Luca, there were a few other little problems to overcome.

"ɑ, ðəɹ jə ɑɹ," noʊl sɛd, pɑpɪŋ ʌp ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm. mæt hæd kɑɾ oʊnli ɡlɪmpsɪz ə ði oʊl mæn sɪns ɡɛɾɪŋ ɪm ə bɛd, bʌɾ i lʊkt wɛl-ɹɛstəɾ ɪn ɪz fɹɛʃli bɹʌʃt ɡɹeɪ koʊt, kənsɪɾɝɪŋ ðəɾ i vænɪʃt ɪndə ðə sɪɾi ɛvɹi deɪ ən oʊnli ɹɪtɝn tə ðə pæləs ət naɪt. ədʒʌstɪŋ ðə bɪts ə leɪs əɾ ɪz kʌfs, hi smaɪl kɑnfaɪɾɪŋli, ɹɪvilɪŋ ðə ɡæps ɪn ɪz tiθ. "ju ɑɹ plænɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ, lɔɹd mæt, ən aɪ wəd laɪk tə ɔfɝ maɪ sɝvəsəz."

"Ah, there you are," Noal said, popping up in front of him. Mat had caught only glimpses of the old man since getting him a bed, but he looked well-rested in his freshly brushed gray coat, considering that he vanished into the city every day and only returned to the Palace at night. Adjusting the bits of lace at his cuffs, he smiled confidingly, revealing the gaps in his teeth. "You are planning something, Lord Mat, and I would like to offer my services."

"aɪm plænɪŋ tə teɪk ðə weɪɾ ɔf maɪ lɛɡ," mæt sɛɾ əz kæʒəwəli əz i kʊd. noʊl sim hɑɹmləs ɪnʌf. əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə hɑɹnən, hi toʊl stɔɹiz bɪfɔɹ ɡoʊɪŋ tə slip, stɔɹiz ðət hɑɹnən ən ði ʌðɝ ɹɛdʒɹmz sim tə swɑloʊ hoʊl, ivən ðə wʌn əbaʊt səm pleɪs kɔld ʃɪbujə, səpoʊzədli bɪɑn ði il weɪst, wɛɹ wɪmən u kəd tʃænəl hæd tætud feɪsəz, oʊvɝ θɹi hʌnʒɹəd kɹaɪmz kæɹiɾ ə pɛnəlti ʌv dɛθ, ən dʒaɪəns lɪvd ʌndɝ ðə maʊntənz, mɛn tɔlɝ ðən oʊɡiɝ, wɪð ðɛɹ feɪsəz ɑn ðɛɹ bɛliz. hi kleɪm tə hæv bɪn ðɛɹ. noʊ wʌn u meɪd kleɪmz laɪk ðət kəd bi ɛniθɪŋ bʌt hɑɹmləs. ɑn ði ʌðɝ hænd, ðə wʌn taɪm mæt hæd sin ɪm hændəl ðoʊz lɔŋ dæɡɝz i kæɹiɾ ʌndɝ ɪz koʊt, hi hæd lʊk fɑɹ fɹəm hɑɹmləs. ðəɹ wɑz ə weɪ ə mæn hæɾ ə tʌtʃɪŋ ə wɛpən ðət sɛɾ i wɑz əkʌstəm tə juzɪŋ ɪt. "ɪf aɪ dɪsaɪd tə plæn ɛniθɪŋ ɛls, əl kip jə ɪn maɪnd."

"I'm planning to take the weight off my leg," Mat said as casually as he could. Noal seemed harmless enough. According to Harnan, he told stories before going to sleep, stories that Harnan and the other Redarms seemed to swallow whole, even the one about some place called Shibouya, supposedly beyond the Aiel Waste, where women who could channel had tattooed faces, over three hundred crimes carried a penalty of death, and giants lived under the mountains, men taller than Ogier, with their faces on their bellies. He claimed to have been there. No one who made claims like that could be anything but harmless. On the other hand, the one time Mat had seen him handle those long daggers he carried under his coat, he had looked far from harmless. There was a way a man had of touching a weapon that said he was accustomed to using it. "If I decide to plan anything else, I'll keep you in mind."

stɪl smaɪlɪŋ, noʊl tæpt wʌn ə ðoʊz kɹʊkəd fɪŋɡɝz əɡɛns ðə saɪɾ ə hɪz bik ʌv ə noʊz. "ju doʊn tʃɹʌs mi, jɛt. ðəɾ ɪz ʌndɝstændəbəl. ɔlðoʊ, ɪf aɪ mɛn jə ɛni hɑɹm, ɔl aɪ hæd tə də wɑz stæn bæk ðət naɪɾ ɪn ði æli. juv ðə lʊk ɪn jəɹ aɪ. aɪv sin ɡɹeɪt mɛn leɪɪŋ plænz, ən vɪlənz dɑɹk əz ðə pɪɾ ə dum, tu. ðəɹ ɪz ə lʊk ə mæn ɡɛts, leɪɪŋ deɪnʒɝəs plænz i dʌznt wɑnt noʊn."

Still smiling, Noal tapped one of those crooked fingers against the side of his beak of a nose. "You don't trust me, yet. That is understandable. Although, if I meant you any harm, all I had to do was stand back that night in the alley. You have the look in your eye. I've seen great men laying plans, and villains dark as the Pit of Doom, too. There is a look a man gets, laying dangerous plans he doesn't want known."

"maɪ aɪz ɑɹ dʒʌs taɪɝd," mæt læft, linɪŋ ɑn ɪz stæf. ɡɹeɪt mɛn leɪɪŋ plænz? ði oʊl fɛloʊ hæd pɹɑbli sin əm ɪn ʃɪbujə, wɪð ðə dʒaɪəns. "aɪ də θæŋk jə fəɹ ðəɾ æli, jə noʊ. ɪf ðɛɹz ɛvɝ ɛniθɪŋ mɔɹ aɪ kən də fəɹ ju, æsk. bʌt ɹaɪt naʊ, aɪm gɑnə faɪn ə hɑt bæθ."

"My eyes are just tired," Mat laughed, leaning on his staff. Great men laying plans? The old fellow had probably seen them in Shibouya, with the giants. "I do thank you for that alley, you know. If there's ever anything more I can do for you, ask. But right now, I am going to find a hot bath."

"dʌz ðɪs ɡoʊləm dʒɹɪŋk blʌd?" noʊl æskt kætʃɪŋ mæts ɑɹm əz i stɑɹɾəd tə hɑbəl baɪ.

"Does this gholam drink blood?" Noal asked catching Mat's arm as he started to hobble by.

laɪt, hi wɪʃt i hæd nɑt mɛnʃən ðət neɪm wɛɹ ði oʊl mæn kəd hɪɹ. hi wɪʃt bɝdʒɪt hæd nɛvɝ toʊld ɪm əbaʊt ðə θɪŋ. "waɪ dʒju æsk?" ɡoʊləm lɪvd ɑn blʌd. ðeɪ eɪt nʌθɪŋ ɛls.

Light, he wished he had not mentioned that name where the old man could hear. He wished Birgitte had never told him about the thing. "Why do you ask?" Gholam lived on blood. They ate nothing else.

"ðɛɹ wɑz ənʌðɝ mæn faʊnd wɪð ɪz θɹoʊt tɔɹn aʊt, læs naɪt, oʊnli ðəɹ wɑz ɔlmoʊs noʊ blʌɾ ɑn ɪm əɹ ɪz bɛɾɪŋ. dɪɾ aɪ mɛnʃən? hi wɑz əɾ ən ɪn daʊn nɪɹ ðə moʊldin ɡeɪt. ɪf ðət θɪŋ dɪd liv ðə sɪɾi, ɪts bæk." ɡlænsɪŋ bɪɑn mæt, hi meɪɾ ə loʊ, ɪlæbɹət baʊ tə sʌmwʌn. "ɪf jə tʃeɪnʒ jəɹ maɪnd, aɪm ɔlweɪz ɹɛɾi," hi sɛɾ ɪn ə loʊɝ vɔɪs wən i stʃɹeɪɾənd.

"There was another man found with his throat torn out, last night, only there was almost no blood on him or his bedding. Did I mention? He was at an inn down near the Moldine Gate. If that thing did leave the city, it's back." Glancing beyond Mat, he made a low, elaborate bow to someone. "If you change your mind, I am always ready," he said in a lower voice when he straightened.

mæt lʊkt oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ əz ði oʊl mæn hɝiɾ ɔf. tuɑn wɑz stændɪŋ bɪniθ wʌn ə ðə ɡɪldɪd stæn læmps, wɑtʃɪŋ ɪm θɹu hɝ veɪl. lʊkɪŋ ət hɪm, ət list. ɡlænsɪŋ? əz ɔlweɪz, ðə moʊmən i sɔ hɝ, ʃi tɝn əweɪ ən ɡlaɪɾɪd ɔf daʊn ðə hɔl, hɝ pliɾɪd waɪt skɝts ɹʌslɪŋ feɪnli. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ wʌn wɪð hɝ, tədeɪ.

Mat looked over his shoulder as the old man hurried off. Tuon was standing beneath one of the gilded stand lamps, watching him through her veil. Looking at him, at least. Glancing? As always, the moment he saw her, she turned away and glided off down the hall, her pleated white skirts rustling faintly. There was no one with her, today.

fəɹ ðə sɛkən taɪm ðət deɪ, mæt ʃɪvɝd. ə pɪɾi ðə ɡɝl hæd nɑt ɡɔn wɪð sjuɹɔθ ən taɪlɪn. ə mæn ɡɪvən ə loʊf ʃəd nɑt kəmpleɪn ðəɾ ə fju kɹʌmz wɝ mɪsɪŋ, bʌɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ ən sintʃæn, ɡoʊləm stɔkɪŋ ɪm ən oʊl mɛn poʊkɪŋ ðɛɹ noʊzɪz ɪn ən skɪni ɡɝlz stɛɹɪŋ əɾ ɪm wɑz ɪnʌf tə ɡɪv ɛni mæn ðə ɡɑlɪwɑɡz. meɪbi hi ʃəd fɝɡɛɾ əbaʊt weɪstɪŋ taɪm soʊkɪŋ ɪz lɛɡ.

For the second time that day, Mat shivered. A pity the girl had not gone with Suroth and Tylin. A man given a loaf should not complain that a few crumbs were missing, but Aes Sedai and Seanchan, gholam stalking him and old men poking their noses in and skinny girls staring at him was enough to give any man the golliwogs. Maybe he should forget about wasting time soaking his leg.

hi fɛl bɛɾɝ wʌns i hæd sɛn ləpɪn tə fɛtʃ ðə ɹɛst ə hɪz oʊn kloʊðz fɹəm bɛslənz tɔɪ kʌbɝd. ən nɹɪm tə faɪn dʒulɪn. hɪz lɛɡ stɪl hɝt laɪk faɪɝ ən wɑbəld wən i wɑntəd tə wɔk, bʌɾ ɪf i wɑz nɑt gɑnə weɪs taɪm, ðən i maɪɾ əz wɛl ɡɛɾ ə muv ɑn əbaʊɾ ɪt. hi wɑntəd tə bi ɡɔn fɹəm ɛbu dɑɹ bɪfɔɹ taɪlɪn keɪm bæk, ən ðət ɡeɪv ɪm tɛn deɪz. lɛs, tə bi ɑn ðə seɪf saɪd.

He felt better once he had sent Lopin to fetch the rest of his own clothes from Beslan's toy cupboard. And Nerim to find Juilin. His leg still hurt like fire and wobbled when he wanted to walk, but if he was not going to waste time, then he might as well get a move on about it. He wanted to be gone from Ebou Dar before Tylin came back, and that gave him ten days. Less, to be on the safe side.

wən ðə θif-kætʃɝ stʌk ɪz hɛɾ ɪn ət ðə bɛdʒɹum dɔɹ, mæt wɑz stʌɾiɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ɪn taɪlɪnz tɔl stænd-mɪɹɝ. ðə ɹɛd . . . ɡɑɹməns . . . wɝ tʌkt əweɪ ɪn ðə wɔɹdʒɹoʊb wɪð ðə ɹɛst ə ðə ɡɔdz ʃi hæd ɡɪvən hɪm. meɪbi taɪlɪnz nɛks pɹɪɾi kəd ɡɛt səm jus ə ðɛm. ðə koʊɾ i hæd pʊɾ ɑn wɑz ðə pleɪnəst i oʊnd, ə faɪn-woʊvən blu wʊl wɪθaʊɾ ə θɹɛɾ ʌv ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi. ðə sɔɹɾ ə koʊɾ ə mæn kəd bi pɹaʊd tə wɛɹ, wɪθaʊt hævɪŋ ɛvɹibɑɾi stɛɹ ət hɪm. ə disən koʊt.

When the thief-catcher stuck his head in at the bedroom door, Mat was studying himself in Tylin's tall stand-mirror. The red . . . garments . . . were tucked away in the wardrobe with the rest of the gauds she had given him. Maybe Tylin's next pretty could get some use of them. The coat he had put on was the plainest he owned, a fine-woven blue wool without a thread of embroidery. The sort of coat a man could be proud to wear, without having everybody stare at him. A decent coat.

"meɪbi ə lɪɾəl leɪs," hi mʌɾɝd, fɪŋɡɝɪŋ ðə nɛk ə hɪz ʃɝt. "dʒʌst ə lɪɾəl." ɪt ɹɪli wɑz ə vɛɹi pleɪn koʊt, kʌm tə θɪŋk. ɔlmoʊst soʊbɝ.

"Maybe a little lace," he muttered, fingering the neck of his shirt. "Just a little." It really was a very plain coat, come to think. Almost sober.

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ ɛniθɪŋ əbaʊt leɪs," dʒulɪn sɛd. "ɪz ðət waɪ jə wɑntəd mi?"

"I don't know anything about lace," Juilin said. "Is that why you wanted me?"

"noʊ, ʌv kɔɹs nɑt. wʌɾ ɑɹ jə ɡɹɪnɪŋ æt?" ðə fɛloʊ wɑz nɑt dʒʌst ɡɹɪnɪŋ; hɪz smaɪl nɪɹli splɪɾ ɪz dɑɹk feɪs ɪn tu.

"No, of course not. What are you grinning at?" The fellow was not just grinning; his smile nearly split his dark face in two.

"aɪ æm hæpi, ðæts ɔl. sjuɹɔθ ɪz ɡɔn, ən aɪm hæpi. ɪf jə doʊnt wɑnə æsk mi əbaʊt leɪs, wʌt dʒju wɑnt?"

"I am happy, that's all. Suroth is gone, and I am happy. If you don't want to ask me about lace, what do you want?"

blʌɾ ən blʌɾi æʃəz! ðə wʊmən i wɑz ɪntʃɹəstəɾ ɪn mʌs bi wʌn ə sjuɹɔθs dækoʊvæl! wʌn ʃi hæd lɛf bɪhaɪnd. hi sɝɾənli hæd noʊ ʌðɝ ɹizən tə kɛɹ wɛðɝ ʃi wɑz ɡɔn, mʌtʃ lɛs bi hæpi oʊvɝ ɪt. ən ðə mæn wɑntəd tə teɪk wʌn ə hɝ pɹɑpɝɾi! wɛl, meɪbi ðət wɑz nɑt soʊ mʌtʃ, kəmpɛɹd tə teɪkɪŋ ə kʌpəl ə deɪmeɪn.

Blood and bloody ashes! The woman he was interested in must be one of Suroth's da'covale! One she had left behind. He certainly had no other reason to care whether she was gone, much less be happy over it. And the man wanted to take one of her property! Well, maybe that was not so much, compared to taking a couple of damane.

lɪmpɪŋ oʊvɝ tə pʊɾ ən ɑɹm ɝaʊn dʒulɪnz ʃoʊldɝz, mæt wɔkt ɪm aʊɾ ɪndə ðə sɪɾɪŋ ɹum. "aɪ niɾ ə deɪmeɪn dʒɹɛs tə fɪɾ ə wʊmən əbaʊt soʊ haɪ," hi hɛld ʌp ə hæn dʒʌst əbaʊɾ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ, "æn slɛndɝ." hi ɡeɪv ðə fɛloʊ hɪz moʊst sənsɪɹ smaɪl, bʌt dʒulɪnz oʊn smaɪl feɪɾəd mɑɹkədli. "aɪ nid θɹi sʌldəm dʒɹɛsəz, tu, ən ən æɾəm. ən ɪt keɪm tə mi ðət ðə mæn u noʊz bɛs haʊ tə stil sʌmθɪŋ wɪθaʊt ɡɛɾɪŋ kɑt wəd bi ə θif-kætʃɝ."

Limping over to put an arm around Juilin's shoulders, Mat walked him out into the sitting room. "I need a damane dress to fit a woman about so high," he held up a hand just about his shoulder, "and slender." He gave the fellow his most sincere smile, but Juilin's own smile faded markedly. "I need three sul'dam dresses, too, and an a'dam. And it came to me that the man who knows best how to steal something without getting caught would be a thief-catcher."

"aɪ æm ə θif-kætʃɝ," ðə mæn ɡɹaʊld, ʃeɪkɪŋ ɔf mæts ɑɹm, "nɑɾ ə θif!"

"I am a thief-catcher," the man growled, shaking off Mat's arm, "not a thief!"

mæt lɛɾ ɪz oʊn ɡɹɪn vænɪʃ. "dʒulɪn, jə noʊ ði oʊnli weɪ tə teɪk ðoʊz sɪstɝz aʊɾ ə ðə sɪɾi ɪz ɪf ðə ɡɑɹdz θɪŋk ðəɹ stɪl deɪmeɪn. tɛslɪn ən idɛzinə ɑɹ wɛɹɪŋ wʌt ðeɪ nid, bʌt wɪv tə dɪsɡaɪz dʒoʊlin. sjuɹɔθ wɪl bi bæk ɪn tɛn deɪz, dʒulɪn. ɪf wi ɑɹənt ɡɔn baɪ ðɛn, ɪn ɔl laɪklihʊd jəɹ pɹɪɾi wɪl stɪl bi hɝ pɹɑpɝɾi wən wi ɡoʊ." hi kəd nɑt hɛlp filɪŋ ðəɾ ɪf ðeɪ wɝ nɑt ɡɔn baɪ ðɛn, nʌn ə ðɛm wəd bi ɡoʊɪŋ. laɪt, ə mæn kəd ʃɪvɝ hɪmsɛlf tə dɛθ ɪndɔɹz ɪn ðɪs sɪɾi.

Mat let his own grin vanish. "Juilin, you know the only way to take those sisters out of the city is if the guards think they're still damane. Teslyn and Edesina are wearing what they need, but we have to disguise Joline. Suroth will be back in ten days, Juilin. If we aren't gone by then, in all likelihood your pretty will still be her property when we go." He could not help feeling that if they were not gone by then, none of them would be going. Light, a man could shiver himself to death indoors in this city.

stʌfɪŋ ɪz fɪsts ɪndə ðə pɑkəts ə hɪz dɑɹk tɛɹən koʊt, dʒulɪn ɡlɛɹɾ ət hɪm. ɡlɛɹd θɹu hɪm, ɹɪli, ət sʌmθɪŋ ðə θif-kætʃɝ dɪd nɑt laɪk. faɪnəli hi ɡɹɪməst, ən mʌɾɝd, "ɪt woʊn bi izi."

Stuffing his fists into the pockets of his dark Tairen coat, Juilin glared at him. Glared through him, really, at something the thief-catcher did not like. Finally he grimaced, and muttered, "It won't be easy."

ðə deɪz ðət fɑloʊd wɝ ɛniθɪŋ bʌɾ izi. ðə sɝvɪŋ wɪmən klʌkt ən læft oʊvɝ ɪz nu kloʊðz. hɪz oʊl kloʊðz, ðət wɑz. ðeɪ ɡɹɪn ən meɪd weɪdʒɝz wɛɹ i kəd hɪɹ oʊvɝ haʊ fæst i kəd tʃeɪnʒ bæk wən taɪlɪn ɹɪtɝnd - moʊst sim tə θɪŋk i wəd ɹeɪs θɹu ðə hɔlz ɹɪpɪŋ ɔf wʌtɛvɝ i wɑz wɛɹɪŋ əz sun i hɝd ʃi wɑz ɑn əɹ weɪ - bʌɾ i peɪɾ əm noʊ maɪnd. ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə pɑɹɾ əbaʊt taɪlɪn ɹɪtɝnɪŋ. ðə fɝs taɪm ə sɝvɪŋ wʊmən mɛnʃən ɪt, hi nɪɹli dʒʌmpt aʊɾ ə hɪz skɪn θɪŋkɪŋ ʃi æktʃəli  hæd fəɹ səm ɹizən.

The days that followed were anything but easy. The serving women clucked and laughed over his new clothes. His old clothes, that was. They grinned and made wagers where he could hear over how fast he could change back when Tylin returned - most seemed to think he would race through the halls ripping off whatever he was wearing as soon he heard she was on her way - but he paid them no mind. Except for the part about Tylin returning. The first time a serving woman mentioned it, he nearly jumped out of his skin thinking she actually had for some reason.

ə nʌmbɝ ə ðə wɪmən ən nɪɹli ɔl ðə mɛn tʊk ɪz tʃeɪnʒ ə kloʊðɪŋ tə min i wɑz livɪŋ. ɹʌnɪŋ əweɪ, ðeɪ kɔld ɪt dɪsəpɹuvɪŋli, ən dɪd wʌt ðeɪ kəd tə hæmpɝ hɪm. ɪn ðɛɹ aɪz, hi wɑz ði ɔɪnmənt tə suð taɪlɪnz eɪkɪŋ, tuθ, ən ðeɪ dɪd nɑt wɑn əɹ tə kʌm bæk ən baɪɾ əm fəɹ luzɪŋ ɪt. ɪf i hæd nɑt meɪd ʃʊɹ ləpɪn əɹ nɹɪm wɑz ɔlweɪz ɪn taɪlɪnz əpɑɹtməns ɡɑɹɾɪŋ ɪz bɪlɔŋɪŋz, ðə kloʊðz wʊɾə vænɪʃt əɡɛn, ən oʊnli veɪnɪn ən ðə ɹɛdʒɹmz kɛpt pɪps fɹəm dɪsəpɪɹɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə steɪbəlz.

A number of the women and nearly all the men took his change of clothing to mean he was leaving. Running away, they called it disapprovingly, and did what they could to hamper him. In their eyes, he was the ointment to soothe Tylin's aching, tooth, and they did not want her to come back and bite them for losing it. If he had not made sure Lopin or Nerim was always in Tylin's apartments guarding his belongings, the clothes would have vanished again, and only Vanin and the Redarms kept Pips from disappearing out of the stables.

mæt tʃɹaɪd tə ɛnkɝɪdʒ ðə bɪlif. wən i wɛn ən tu deɪmeɪn vænɪʃt ət ðə seɪm taɪm, ði ɪvɛns wɝ ʃʊɹ tə bi lɪŋkt, bʌt wɪð taɪlɪn ɡɔn ən ɪz ɪntɛntʃən tə ɹʌn əweɪ pleɪn bɪfɔɹ ʃi ɹɪtɝnd, ʃi wəd bi seɪf fɹəm bleɪm. ɛvɹi deɪ, ivən wən ɪt ɹeɪnd, hi ɹoʊd pɪps ɪn sɝkəlz ɪn ðə steɪbəl, fəɹ ə lɔŋɡɝ taɪm ɛvɹi deɪ, əz ɪf tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə bɪld ʌp ɪz stæmənə. wɪtʃ i æktʃəli  wɑz, hi ɹilaɪzd æftɝ ə waɪl. hɪz lɛɡ ən hɪp stɪl ætʃt laɪk fjʊɹi, bʌɾ i bɪɡæn tə θɪŋk i kəd mænədʒ əz mʌtʃ əz tɛn maɪlz bɪfɔɹ niɾɪŋ tə klaɪm daʊn. eɪt maɪlz, ɛniweɪ.

Mat tried to encourage the belief. When he went and two damane vanished at the same time, the events were sure to be linked, but with Tylin gone and his intention to run away plain before she returned, she would be safe from blame. Every day, even when it rained, he rode Pips in circles in the stable, for a longer time every day, as if trying to build up his stamina. Which he actually was, he realized after a while. His leg and hip still ached like fury, but he began to think he could manage as much as ten miles before needing to climb down. Eight miles, anyway.

ɔfən, ɪf ðə skaɪ wɑz klɪɹ, sʌldəm wɝ wɔkɪŋ deɪmeɪn wən i ɛksɝsaɪzd. ðə sintʃæn wɪmən wɝ əwɛɹ i wɑz nɑt taɪlɪnz pɹɑpɝɾi, bʌɾ ɑn ði ʌðɝ hænd, hi hɝd səm kɔl ɪm əɹ tɔɪ! taɪlɪnz tɔɪ, ðeɪ sɛd, əz ɪf ðət wɑz ɪz neɪm! hi wɑz nɑɾ ɪmpɔɹɾənt ɪnʌf fəɹ əm tə lɝn ɪf i hæɾ ənʌðɝ. tə ðɛm, sʌmwʌn wɑz iðɝ dækoʊvæl əɹ nɑt, ən ðɪs hæfweɪ bɪznəs əmjuzd əm noʊ ɛnd. hi ɹoʊd tə ðə saʊn ə sʌldəm læfɪŋ, ən tʃɹaɪd tə tɛl hɪmsɛlf ɪt wɑz ɔl tə ðə ɡʊd. ðə mɔɹ pipəl u kəd tɛl ðəɾ i wɝk tə fli bɪfɔɹ taɪlɪn ɹɪtɝnd, ðə bɛɾɝ fəɹ hɝ. ɪt dʒʌst wɑz nɑt vɛɹi plɛzən fəɹ hɪm.

Often, if the sky was clear, sul'dam were walking damane when he exercised. The Seanchan women were aware he was not Tylin's property, but on the other hand, he heard some call him her toy! Tylin's Toy, they said, as if that was his name! He was not important enough for them to learn if he had another. To them, someone was either da'covale or not, and this halfway business amused them no end. He rode to the sound of sul'dam laughing, and tried to tell himself it was all to the good. The more people who could tell that he worked to flee before Tylin returned, the better for her. It just was not very pleasant for him.

naʊ ən ðən i sɔ ɛɛs sədaɪ feɪsəz əmʌŋ ðə deɪmeɪn biɪŋ wɔkt, θɹi bɪsaɪdz tɛslɪn, bʌɾ i hæd nɑɾ ə klu wʌɾ idɛzinə lʊk laɪk. ʃi cʊɾə bɪn ðə ʃɔɹt peɪl wʊmən u ɹimaɪndəɾ ɪm ə mɔɪɹeɪn, əɹ ðə tɔl wʌn wɪð sɪlvɝi-ɡoʊldən hɛɹ, əɹ ðə slɛndɝ blæk-hɛɹd wʊmən. ɡɪldɪŋ əlɔŋ bɪsaɪɾ ə sʌldəm, ɛni ʌv əm maɪɾ əv bɪn teɪkɪŋ ə wɔk ɑn əɹ oʊn, ɪf nɑt fəɹ ðə ɡlimɪŋ kɑlɝ ɝaʊn əɹ nɛk ən ðə liʃ taɪɪŋ əɹ tə ðə sʌldəmz ɹɪst. tɛslɪn hɝsɛlf lʊkt ɪnkɹisɪŋli ɡɹɪm ɛvɹi taɪm i sɔ hɝ, stɛɹɪŋ fɪksədli stʃɹeɪɾ əhɛd. ɛvɹi taɪm, ðəɹ sim tə bi mɔɹ dɪtɝməneɪʃən ɑn əɹ feɪs. ən sʌmθɪŋ ðət maɪɾ əv bɪn pænɪk, tu. hi bɪɡæn tə wɝi əbaʊt hɝ, ən əɹ ɪmpeɪʃəns.

Now and then he saw Aes Sedai faces among the damane being walked, three besides Teslyn, but he had not a clue what Edesina looked like. She could have been the short pale woman who reminded him of Moiraine, or the tall one with silvery-golden hair, or the slender black-haired woman. Gilding along beside a sul'dam, any of them might have been taking a walk on her own, if not for the gleaming collar around her neck and the leash tying her to the sul'dam's wrist. Teslyn herself looked increasingly grim every time he saw her, staring fixedly straight ahead. Every time, there seemed to be more determination on her face. And something that might have been panic, too. He began to worry about her, and her impatience.

hi wɑntəd tə ɹiəʃʊɹ tɛslɪn - hi dɪd nɑt nid ðoʊz oʊl mɛmɹiz tə tɛl ɪm ðət dɪtɝməneɪʃən kəmbaɪnd wɪð pænɪk kəd ɡɛt pipəl kɪld, bʌt ðeɪ kənfɝmd ɪt - hi wɑntəd tə ɹiəʃʊɹ hɝ, oʊnli hi dɛɹd nɑt ɡoʊ nɪɹ ðə kɛnəlz ɪn ði æɾɪk əɡɛn. tuɑn kəntɪnjud tə bi ðəɹ wən i tɝn ɝaʊnd, lʊkɪŋ əɾ ɪm əɹ ɡlænsɪŋ əɹ wʌtɛvɝ ʃi wɑz duɪŋ, dʒʌs tu ɔfən fəɹ kʌmfɝt. nɑɾ ɪnʌf tə meɪk ɪm θɪŋk ʃi wɑz fɑloʊɪŋ hɪm. waɪ wəd ʃi də ðæt? dʒʌs tu ɔfən. əkeɪʒənəli hɝ sɔɪhɪn sɪlutʃə wɑz wɪð hɝ, ən naʊ ən ðən ænæθ, ðoʊ ðə stʃɹeɪnʒ tɔl wʊmən sim tə vænɪʃ fɹəm ðə pæləs æftɝ ə taɪm, ət lis fɹəm ðə hɔlweɪz. ʃi wɑz "ɑn ɹitʃɹit," hi hɝd, wʌtɛvɝ ðət wɑz səpoʊz tə min, ən i oʊnli wɪʃt ʃi hæd teɪkən tuɑn wɪð hɝ. hi daʊɾɪd ðə ɡɝl wəd bɪliv i wɑz teɪkɪŋ swits tə ə wɪndfɪndɝ ə sɛkən taɪm. meɪbi ʃi stɪl wɑntəd tə baɪ hɪm? ɪf ðət wɑz ðə keɪs, hi stɪl kəd nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd waɪ. hi hæd nɛvɝ bɪn eɪbəl tə ʌndɝstænd wʌɾ ətʃɹæktəd wɪmən tə ə mæn - ðeɪ sim tə ɡoʊ pɑp-aɪɾ oʊvɝ ðə moʊst ɔɹɾənɛɹi lʊkɪŋ fɛloʊz - bʌɾ i nu hi wɑz noʊ bjuɾi, noʊ mæɾɝ wʌt taɪlɪn sɛd. wɪmən laɪd tə ɡɛɾ ə mæn ɪndə bɛd, ən ðeɪ laɪd wɝs wʌns ðeɪ hæɾ ɪm ðɛɹ.

He wanted to reassure Teslyn - he did not need those old memories to tell him that determination combined with panic could get people killed, but they confirmed it - he wanted to reassure her, only he dared not go near the kennels in the attic again. Tuon continued to be there when he turned around, looking at him or glancing or whatever she was doing, just too often for comfort. Not enough to make him think she was following him. Why would she do that? Just too often. Occasionally her so'jhin Selucia was with her, and now and then Anath, though the strange tall woman seemed to vanish from the Palace after a time, at least from the hallways. She was "on retreat," he heard, whatever that was supposed to mean, and he only wished she had taken Tuon with her. He doubted the girl would believe he was taking sweets to a Windfinder a second time. Maybe she still wanted to buy him? If that was the case, he still could not understand why. He had never been able to understand what attracted women to a man - they seemed to go pop-eyed over the most ordinary looking fellows - but he knew he was no beauty, no matter what Tylin said. Women lied to get a man into bed, and they lied worse once they had him there.

ɪn ɛni keɪs, tuɑn wɑz ə maɪnɝ ɪɹəɾənt. ə flaɪ ɑn ɪz ɪɹ. noʊ mɔɹ ðən ðæt. ɪt tʊk mɔɹ ðən tʃæɾɝɪŋ wɪmən əɹ stɛɹɪŋ ɡɝlz tə meɪk ɪm swɛt. æbsən əz ʃi wɑz, haʊɛvɝ, taɪlɪn dɪd. ɪf ʃi keɪm bæk ən kɑɾ ɪm pɹipɛɹɪŋ tə liv, ʃi maɪt tʃeɪnʒ əɹ maɪn əbaʊt sɛlɪŋ. ʃi wɑz ə haɪ leɪɾi hɝsɛlf naʊ, æftɝ ɔl, ən i wɑz ʃʊɹ ʃi wəd ʃeɪv əɹ hɛɹ tə ə kɹɛs bɪfɔɹ mʌtʃ lɔŋɡɝ. ə pɹɑpɝ sintʃæn haɪ blʌd, ən u nu wʌt ʃi wəd də ðɛn? taɪlɪn kɑzd ə lɪɾəl swɛt, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz mɔɹ ðən ɪnʌf ɛls tə dʒɹɛntʃ ə mæn ɪn ɪt.

In any case, Tuon was a minor irritant. A fly on his ear. No more than that. It took more than chattering women or staring girls to make him sweat. Absent as she was, however, Tylin did. If she came back and caught him preparing to leave, she might change her mind about selling. She was a High Lady herself now, after all, and he was sure she would shave her hair to a crest before much longer. A proper Seanchan High Blood, and who knew what she would do then? Tylin caused a little sweat, but there was more than enough else to drench a man in it.

hi kəntɪnjud tə hɪɹ fɹəm noʊl əbaʊt ðə ɡoʊləmz mɝɾɝz, ən səmtaɪmz fɹəm tɑm. ðəɹ wɑz ə fɹɛʃ wʌn ɛvɹi naɪt, ðoʊ noʊ wʌn bʌt ðoʊz tu ən ɪm sim tə kənɛk ðə kɪlɪŋz. mæt kɛp tə oʊpən pleɪsəz əz mʌtʃ əz i kʊd, wɪð pipəl ɝaʊn əz ɔfən əz pɑsəbəl. hi stɑp slipɪŋ ɪn taɪlɪnz bɛd, ən nɛvɝ spɛn tu naɪts ɹʌnɪŋ ɪn ðə seɪm pleɪs. ɪf ðət mɛn ə naɪɾ ɪn ə steɪbəl lɔft, wɛl, hi hæd slɛpt ɪn heɪlɑfs bɪfɔɹ, ɔlðoʊ hi dɪd nɑt ɹikɔl heɪ stɪkɪŋ θɹu hɪz kloʊðz kwaɪt ðət ʃɑɹpli. stɪl, bɛɾɝ stʌk baɪ heɪ ðən hævɪŋ ɪz θɹoʊt tɔɹn aʊt.

He continued to hear from Noal about the gholam's murders, and sometimes from Thom. There was a fresh one every night, though no one but those two and him seemed to connect the killings. Mat kept to open places as much as he could, with people around as often as possible. He stopped sleeping in Tylin's bed, and never spent two nights running in the same place. If that meant a night in a stable loft, well, he had slept in haylofts before, although he did not recall hay sticking through his clothes quite that sharply. Still, better stuck by hay than having his throat torn out.

hi hæd sɔɾ aʊt tɑm stʃɹeɪɾ əweɪ æftɝ i dɪsaɪɾɪd tə tʃɹaɪ fɹiɪŋ tɛslɪn, ən hæd faʊn ɪm ɪn ðə kɪtʃənz tʃæɾɪŋ wɪð ðə kʊks oʊvɝ ə hʌni-ɡleɪz tʃɪkən. tɑm ɡɑɾ ɑn əz wɛl wɪð kʊks əz i dɪd wɪð fɑɹmɝz ən mɝtʃəns ən noʊbəlz. hi hæɾ ə weɪ ʌv ɡɛɾɪŋ ɑn wɪð ɛvɹiwʌn, dɪd tɑm mɛɹɪlɪn, ə weɪ ʌv hɪɹɪŋ ɛvɹiwʌnz ɡɑsəp ən fɪɾɪŋ ɪt təɡɛðɝ tə meɪk ə pɪktʃɝ. hi kəd lʊk ət θɪŋz fɹəm ə slæn ən si wʌɾ ʌðɝz mɪst. əz sun əz i fɪnɪʃt ðə tʃɪkən, tɑm hæd kʌm ʌp wɪð ði oʊnli weɪ tə ɡɛt ði ɛɛs sədaɪ pæs ðə ɡɑɹdz. ðə hoʊl θɪŋ hæɾ ɔlmoʊst simd izi, ðɛn. fəɹ ə vɛɹi ʃɔɹt waɪl. bʌɾ ʌðɝ ɑbstəkəlz ɝoʊz.

He had sought out Thom straight away after he decided to try freeing Teslyn, and had found him in the kitchens chatting with the cooks over a honey-glazed chicken. Thom got on as well with cooks as he did with farmers and merchants and nobles. He had a way of getting on with everyone, did Thom Merrilin, a way of hearing everyone's gossip and fitting it together to make a picture. He could look at things from a slant and see what others missed. As soon as he finished the chicken, Thom had come up with the only way to get the Aes Sedai past the guards. The whole thing had almost seemed easy, then. For a very short while. But other obstacles arose.

dʒulɪn pəzɛs ðə seɪm sɔɹɾ ə twɪsti weɪ ʌv lʊkɪŋ ət θɪŋz, pɝhæps fɹəm ɪz jɪɹz əz θif-kætʃɝ, ən səm naɪts mæt mɛt wɪð ɪm ən tɑm ɪn ðə taɪni ɹum ðə tu mɛn ʃɛɹɾ ɪn ðə sɝvəns' kɔɹɾɝz tə tʃɹaɪ plænɪŋ haʊ tə oʊvɝkʌm ðoʊz ɑbstəkəlz. ðoʊz wɝ wʌt ɹɪli meɪd mæt swɛt.

Juilin possessed the same sort of twisty way of looking at things, perhaps from his years as thief-catcher, and some nights Mat met with him and Thom in the tiny room the two men shared in the servants' quarters to try planning how to overcome those obstacles. Those were what really made Mat sweat.

ət ðə fɝst ə ðoʊz miɾɪŋz, ðə naɪt taɪlɪn lɛft, bɛslən bɑɹdʒd ɪn lʊkɪŋ fəɹ tɑm, soʊ hi sɛd. ənfɔɹtʃənətli, hi hæd lɪsən ət ðə dɔɹ fɝst, hɪɹɪŋ ɪnʌf ðəɾ i kəd nɑt bi fɔɪstɪɾ ɔf wɪð ə stɔɹi. vɛɹi ənfɔɹtʃənətli, hi wɑntəd tə teɪk pɑɹt. hi ivən toʊld əm dʒʌs haʊ tə də ɪt.

At the first of those meetings, the night Tylin left, Beslan barged in looking for Thom, so he said. Unfortunately, he had listened at the door first, hearing enough that he could not be foisted off with a story. Very unfortunately, he wanted to take part. He even told them just how to do it.

"æn əpɹaɪzɪŋ," hi sɛd, skwɑɾɪŋ ɑn ðə θɹi-lɛɡəd stul bɪtwin ðə tu nɛɹoʊ bɛdz. ə wɑʃstænd wɪð ə tʃɪpt waɪt pɪtʃɝ ən boʊl ən noʊ mɪɹɝ fɪnɪʃt kɹaʊɾɪŋ ðə ɹum. dʒulɪn sæɾ ɑn ði ɛdʒ ʌv wʌn bɛɾ ɪn ɪz ʃɝtslivz, hɪz feɪs ənɹiɾəbəl, ən tɑm wɑz stʃɹɛtʃt aʊɾ ɑn ði ʌðɝ ɪɡzæmɪnɪŋ ɪz nʌkəlz wɪð ə fɹaʊn. ðət lɛf mæt tə lin əɡɛns ðə dɔɹ tə kip ɛniwʌn ɛls fɹəm bɑɹdʒɪŋ ɪn. hi dɪd nɑt noʊ wɛðɝ tə læf əɹ kɹaɪ. pleɪnli tɑm hæd noʊn əbaʊt ðɪs mædnəs ɔl əlɔŋ; ðɪs wɑz wʌɾ i hæd bɪn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kul daʊn. "ðə pipəl wɪl ɹaɪz wən aɪ ɡɪv ðə wɝd," bɛslən wɛn ɑn. "maɪ fɹɛnz ən aɪ hæv tɔk tə mɛn ɔl oʊvɝ ðə sɪɾi. ðeɪ ɑɹ ɹɛɾi tə faɪt!"

"An uprising," he said, squatting on the three-legged stool between the two narrow beds. A washstand with a chipped white pitcher and bowl and no mirror finished crowding the room. Juilin sat on the edge of one bed in his shirtsleeves, his face unreadable, and Thom was stretched out on the other examining his knuckles with a frown. That left Mat to lean against the door to keep anyone else from barging in. He did not know whether to laugh or cry. Plainly Thom had known about this madness all along; this was what he had been trying to cool down. "The people will rise when I give the word," Beslan went on. "My friends and I have talked to men all over the city. They are ready to fight!"

saɪɪŋ, mæt izd ɪz weɪt mɔɹ ɑntu hɪz ɡʊd lɛɡ. hi səspɛktəd ðət wən bɛslən ɡeɪv ðə wɝd, hi ən ɪz fɹɛnz wəd ɹaɪz əloʊn. moʊs pipəl wɝ mɔɹ wɪlɪŋ tə tɔk əbaʊt faɪɾɪŋ ðən tə də ɪt, ɪspɛʃli əɡɛnst soʊlʒɝz. "bɛslən, ɪn ɡlimənz teɪlz, ɡɹumz wɪð pɪtʃfɔɹks ən beɪkɝz wɪð kɑbəlstoʊnz dɪfiɾ ɑɹmiz kəz ðeɪ wɑnə bi fɹi." tɑm snɔɹɾɪd soʊ hɑɹd, hɪz lɔŋ waɪt mʌstæʃ stɝd. mæt ɪɡnɔɹd hɪm. "ɪn ɹil laɪf, ðə ɡɹumz ən ðə beɪkɝz ɡɛt kɪld. aɪ noʊ ɡʊd soʊlʒɝz wən aɪ si ðɛm, ən ðə sintʃæn ɑɹ vɛɹi ɡʊd."

Sighing, Mat eased his weight more onto his good leg. He suspected that when Beslan gave the word, he and his friends would rise alone. Most people were more willing to talk about fighting than to do it, especially against soldiers. "Beslan, in gleeman's tales, grooms with pitchforks and bakers with cobblestones defeat armies because they want to be free." Thom snorted so hard, his long white mustache stirred. Mat ignored him. "In real life, the grooms and the bakers get killed. I know good soldiers when I see them, and the Seanchan are very good."

"ɪf wi fɹi ðə deɪmeɪn əlɔŋ wɪð ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, ðəl faɪt bɪsaɪɾ ʌs!" bɛslən ɪnsɪstəd.

"If we free the damane along with the Aes Sedai, they will fight beside us!" Beslan insisted.

"ðɛɹ mʌs bi tu hʌnʒɹəd əɹ mɔɹ deɪmeɪn ʌp ɪn ði æɾɪk, bɛslən, moʊst ə ðɛm sintʃæn. fɹi ðɛm, ən laɪk əz nɑt, ɛvɹi læst wʌn wɪl ɹʌn tə faɪn ə sʌldəm. laɪt, wi kʊdn ivən tʃɹʌst ɔl ðə wɪmən u ɑɹən sintʃæn!" mæt hɛld ʌp ə hæn tə fɔɹstɔl bɛslənz pɹoʊɾɛst. "wi hæv noʊ weɪ tə faɪn aʊt wɪtʃ wi kən tʃɹʌst, ən noʊ taɪm tə. ən ɪf wi dɪd, wiɾ əv tə kɪl ðə ɹɛst. aɪm nɑɾ ʌp tə kɪlɪŋ ə wʊmən huz oʊnli kɹaɪm ɪz ðət ʃiz ɑn ə liʃ. ɑɹ ju?" bɛslən lʊkt əweɪ, bʌɾ ɪz dʒɔ wɑz sɛt. hi wɑz nɑt ɡɪvɪŋ ʌp.

"There must be two hundred or more damane up in the attic, Beslan, most of them Seanchan. Free them, and like as not, every last one will run to find a sul'dam. Light, we couldn't even trust all the women who aren't Seanchan!" Mat held up a hand to forestall Beslan's protest. "We have no way to find out which we can trust, and no time to. And if we did, we'd have to kill the rest. I'm not up to killing a woman whose only crime is that she's on a leash. Are you?" Beslan looked away, but his jaw was set. He was not giving up.

"wɛðɝ wi fɹi ɛni deɪmeɪn əɹ nɑt," mæt wɛn ɑn, "ɪf ðə pipəl ɹaɪz ʌp, ðə sintʃæn wɪl tɝn ɛbu dɑɹ ɪndə ə slɔɾɝ jɑɹd. ðeɪ pʊt daʊn ɹɪbɛljənz hɑɹd, bɛslən. vɛɹi hɑɹd! wi kəd kɪl ɛvɹi deɪmeɪn ɪn ði æɾɪk, ən ðeɪ wəd bɹɪŋ ɪn mɔɹ fɹəm ðə kæmps. jəɹ mʌðɝ wɪl kʌm bæk tə faɪn ɹʌbəl ɪnsaɪd ðə wɔlz ən jəɹ hɛd stʌk ʌp aʊtsaɪd ðɛm. wɛɹ hɝz wɪl sun dʒɔɪn ɪt. jə doʊn θɪŋk ðəl bɪliv ʃi dɪd nɑt noʊ wʌɾ əɹ oʊn sʌn wɑz plænɪŋ, də ju?" laɪt, dɪd ʃi? ðə wʊmən wɑz bɹeɪv ɪnʌf tə tʃɹaɪ ɪt. hi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ʃi wɑz stupəɾ ɪnʌf, bʌt . . .

"Whether we free any damane or not," Mat went on, "if the people rise up, the Seanchan will turn Ebou Dar into a slaughter yard. They put down rebellions hard, Beslan. Very hard! We could kill every damane in the attic, and they would bring in more from the camps. Your mother will come back to find rubble inside the walls and your head stuck up outside them. Where hers will soon join it. You don't think they'll believe she did not know what her own son was planning, do you?" Light, did she? The woman was brave enough to try it. He did not think she was stupid enough, but . . .

"ʃi sɛz wəɹ maɪs," bɛslən sɛd bɪɾɝli. " 'wɛn wʊlfhnz pæs baɪ, maɪs laɪ kwaɪəɾ əɹ ɡɛɾ iɾən,' " hi kwoʊɾəd. "aɪ doʊn laɪk biɪŋ ə maʊs, mæt."

"She says we are mice," Beslan said bitterly. " 'When wolfhounds pass by, mice lie quiet or get eaten,' " he quoted. "I don't like being a mouse, Mat."

mæt bɹiðd ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ izəli. "bɛɾɝ ə laɪv maʊs ðən ə dɛd wʌn, bɛslən." wɪtʃ maɪt nɑɾ əv bɪn ðə moʊs dɪpləmæɾɪk weɪ tə pʊɾ ɪt - bɛslən ɡɹɪməst əɾ ɪm - bʌɾ ɪt wɑz tʃɹu.

Mat breathed a little more easily. "Better a live mouse than a dead one, Beslan." Which might not have been the most diplomatic way to put it - Beslan grimaced at him - but it was true.

hi ɛnkɝɪdʒ bɛslən tə dʒɔɪn ðə miɾɪŋz, ɪf dʒʌs tə kip ə ɹeɪn ɑn hɪm, bʌt bɛslən sɛldəm keɪm, ən ɪt fɛl tə tɑm tə tʃɹaɪ tə kul ðə mænz ɑɹɾɝ wən ən əz i kʊd. ðə moʊst i kəd pɝsweɪd bɛslən tə pɹɑməs wɑz ðəɾ i kəd nɑt kɔl fəɹ ðə ɹaɪzɪŋ əntɪl ðə ɹɛst ə ðɛm hæd bɪn ɡɔn ə mʌnθ, tə lɛɾ əm ɡɛt klɪɹ. ðət wɑz sʌmθɪŋ sɛɾəld, ɪf nɑt sæɾɪsfæktʃɹəli. ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɛls sim tə bi teɪk tu stɛps ən hɪɾ ə stoʊn wɔl. əɹ ə tʃɹɪp waɪɝ.

He encouraged Beslan to join the meetings, if just to keep a rein on him, but Beslan seldom came, and it fell to Thom to try to cool the man's ardor when and as he could. The most he could persuade Beslan to promise was that he could not call for the rising until the rest of them had been gone a month, to let them get clear. That was something settled, if not satisfactorily. Everything else seemed to be take two steps and hit a stone wall. Or a trip wire.

dʒulɪnz leɪɾi lʌv hæd kwaɪɾ ə hoʊld ɑn hɪm. fəɹ hɝ, hi sim tə nɑt tə maɪn dɔfɪŋ ɪz tɛɹən kloʊðz fəɹ ə sɝvəns ɡɹin-ænd-waɪt lɪvɝi, əɹ mɪsɪŋ slip tə spɛn tu naɪts swipɪŋ ðə flɔɹ nɑt fɑɹ fɹəm ðə stɛɹz ðət lɛɾ ʌp tə ðə kɛnəlz. noʊ wʌn lʊk twaɪs əɾ ə sɝvən pʊʃɪŋ ə bɹum, nɑɾ ivən ði ʌðɝ sɝvəns. ðə tɑɹɑsɪn pæləs hæɾ ɪnʌf ə ðoʊz ðət ðeɪ dɪd nɑɾ ɔl noʊ wʌn ənʌðɝ, ən ɪf ðeɪ sɔ ə mæn ɪn lɪvɝi wɪð ə bɹum, ðeɪ əsumd i wɑz səpoʊz tə bi juzɪŋ ɪt. dʒulɪn spɛn tu hoʊl deɪz swipɪŋ, tu, ən faɪnəli ɹipɔɹɾəd ðət sʌldəm ɪnspɛktɪd ðə kɛnəlz fɝs θɪŋ ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ ən dʒʌst æftɝ dɑɹk, ən maɪt bi ɪn əɹ aʊɾ əɾ ɛni taɪm ə ðə deɪ bɪtwin, bʌɾ ət naɪt ðə deɪmeɪn wɝ lɛf tə ðɛmsɛlvz.

Juilin's lady love had quite a hold on him. For her, he seemed to not to mind doffing his Tairen clothes for a servant's green-and-white livery, or missing sleep to spend two nights sweeping the floor not far from the stairs that led up to the kennels. No one looked twice at a servant pushing a broom, not even the other servants. The Tarasin Palace had enough of those that they did not all know one another, and if they saw a man in livery with a broom, they assumed he was supposed to be using it. Juilin spent two whole days sweeping, too, and finally reported that sul'dam inspected the kennels first thing in the morning and just after dark, and might be in or out at any time of the day between, but at night the damane were left to themselves.

"aɪ oʊvɝhɝɾ ə sʌldəm seɪ ʃi wɑz ɡlæd ʃi wɑzn aʊɾ ɪn ðə kæmps wɛɹ . . ." laɪɪŋ stʃɹɛtʃt aʊɾ ɑn ɪz θɪn mætʃɹəs, dʒulɪn pɔz tə jɔn koʊpiəsli bɪhaɪn ɪz hænd. tɑm wɑz sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ði ɛdʒ ə hɪz bɛd, wɪtʃ lɛf ðə stul fəɹ mæt. ɪt wɑz bɛɾɝ ðən stændɪŋ, ɪf nɑt baɪ mʌtʃ. moʊs pipəl wəd bi əslip ət ðəɾ aʊɝ. "wɛɹ ʃiɾ əv tə stænd ɡɑɹd səm naɪts," ðə θif-kætʃɝ kəntɪnjud wən i kəd spik əɡɛn. "sɛd ʃi laɪk biɪŋ eɪbəl tə lɛt ðə deɪmeɪn slip ɔl naɪt, tu, soʊ ðeɪ wɝ ɔl fɹɛʃ kʌm sʌnɹaɪz."

"I overheard a sul'dam say she was glad she wasn't out in the camps where . . ." Lying stretched out on his thin mattress, Juilin paused to yawn copiously behind his hand. Thom was sitting on the edge of his bed, which left the stool for Mat. It was better than standing, if not by much. Most people would be asleep at that hour. "Where she'd have to stand guard some nights," the thief-catcher continued when he could speak again. "Said she liked being able to let the damane sleep all night, too, so they were all fresh come sunrise."

"soʊ wi mʌs muv ət naɪt," tɑm mɝmɝd, fɪŋɡɝɪŋ ɪz lɔŋ waɪt mʌstæʃ. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ nid tə æd ðəɾ ɛniθɪŋ muvɪŋ ət naɪt dʒɹu aɪz. sintʃæn pətʃɹoʊl ðə stʃɹits ət naɪt, wɪtʃ ðə sɪvəl ɡɑɹd nɛvɝ hæd. ðə ɡɑɹd hæd bɪn əmɛnəbəl tə bɹaɪbz, tu, əntɪl ðə sintʃæn dɪsbændɪd ðɛm. naʊ, ət naɪt, ɪt wɑz əz laɪkli tə bi ðə dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹdz ɪn ðə stʃɹit, ən ɛniwʌn u tʃɹaɪd tə bɹaɪb əm maɪt nɑt lɪv tə feɪs tʃɹaɪəl.

"So we must move at night," Thom murmured, fingering his long white mustache. There was no need to add that anything moving at night drew eyes. Seanchan patrolled the streets at night, which the Civil Guard never had. The Guard had been amenable to bribes, too, until the Seanchan disbanded them. Now, at night, it was as likely to be the Deathwatch Guards in the street, and anyone who tried to bribe them might not live to face trial.

"hæv jə faʊn ən æɾəm jɛt, dʒulɪn?" mæt æskt. "ɔɹ ðə dʒɹɛsəz? dʒɹɛsəz kæn bi əz dɪfəkəlt əz ən æɾəm."

"Have you found an a'dam yet, Juilin?" Mat asked. "Or the dresses? Dresses can't be as difficult as an a'dam."

dʒulɪn jɔn ɪndə hɪz hæn əɡɛn. "aɪl ɡɛɾ əm wən aɪ ɡɛt ðɛm. ðeɪ doʊn dʒʌs liv iðɝ laɪɪŋ əbaʊt, jə noʊ."

Juilin yawned into his hand again. "I'll get them when I get them. They don't just leave either lying about, you know."

tɑm dɪskʌvɝd ðət sɪmpli wɔkɪŋ deɪmeɪn θɹu ðə ɡeɪts wɑz nɑt pɑsəbəl. əɹ ɹæðɝ, əz i fɹili ədmɪɾəd, ɹaɪzɛl hæd dɪskʌvɝɾ ɪt. ɪt sim ðət wʌn ə ðə haɪ-ɹæŋkɪŋ ɔfəsɝz steɪɪŋ ət ðə wɑndɝɪŋ wʊmən hæɾ ə sɪŋɪŋ vɔɪs ʃi faʊn moʊst ɛntɝteɪnɪŋ.

Thom discovered that simply walking damane through the gates was not possible. Or rather, as he freely admitted, Riselle had discovered it. It seemed that one of the high-ranking officers staying at The Wandering Woman had a singing voice she found most entertaining.

"wʌn ə ðə blʌd kən teɪk deɪmeɪn aʊt wɪð noʊ kwɛstʃənz æskt," tɑm sɛɾ ət ðɛɹ nɛks miɾɪŋ. ðɪs taɪm, hi ən dʒulɪn boʊθ wɝ sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðɛɹ bɛdz. mæt wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə heɪt ðət stul. "ɔɹ fju ɪnʌf, ɛniweɪ. sʌldəm, ðoʊ, niɾ ən ɔɹɾɝ saɪn ən sil baɪ wʌn ə ðə blʌd, ən ɔfəsɝ huz kæptən əɹ əbʌv, əɹ ə dɝsʌldəm. ðə ɡɑɹdz ət ðə ɡeɪts ən ɑn ðə dɑks əv lɪsts ʌv ɛvɹi sil ɪn ðə sɪɾi ðət kwɑləfaɪz, soʊ aɪ kæn dʒʌs meɪk ɛni sɔɹɾ ə sil ən θɪŋk ɪɾəl bi æksɛptɪd. aɪ niɾ ə kɑpi ʌv ðə ɹaɪt sɔɹɾ ʌv ɔɹɾɝ wɪð ðə ɹaɪt sɔɹɾ ə sil. ðət livz ðə kwɛstʃən ə hu wɪl bi əɹ θɹi sʌldəm."

"One of the Blood can take damane out with no questions asked," Thom said at their next meeting. This time, he and Juilin both were sitting on their beds. Mat was beginning to hate that stool. "Or few enough, anyway. Sul'dam, though, need an order signed and sealed by one of the Blood, an officer who's captain or above, or a der'sul'dam. The guards at the gates and on the docks have lists of every seal in the city that qualifies, so I can't just make any sort of seal and think it will be accepted. I need a copy of the right sort of order with the right sort of seal. That leaves the question of who will be our three sul'dam."

"meɪbi ɹaɪzɛl wɪl bi wʌn," mæt sədʒɛstəd. ʃi dɪd nɑt noʊ wʌt ðeɪ wɝ duɪŋ, ən tɛlɪŋ əɹ wəd bi ə ɹɪsk. tɑm hæɾ æskt əɹ ɔl sɔɹts ə kwɛstʃənz, əz ɪf i wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə lɝn əbaʊt laɪf ʌndɝ ðə sintʃæn, ən ʃi hæd bɪn hæpi ɪnʌf tə æsk əɹ sintʃæn fɹɛnd, bʌt ʃi maɪt nɑt bi hæpi ɪnʌf tə tʃæns əɹ pɹɪɾi hɛd ɡoʊɪŋ ʌp ɑn ə spaɪk. ʃi kəd də wɝs ðən seɪ noʊ. "ænd wʌɾ əbaʊt jəɹ leɪɾi lʌv, dʒulɪn?" hi hæɾ ə θɔɾ ɑn ðə θɝd. hi hæɾ æsk dʒulɪn tə faɪn ə sʌldəm dʒɹɛs ðət wəd fɪt sɛɾəl ɑnən, ðoʊ ðəɹ hæd bɪn noʊ tʃæns tə æktʃəli  pʊɾ ɪt tə hɝ, jɛt. hi hæɾ oʊnli bɪn bæk tə ðə wɑndɝɪŋ wʊmən wʌns sɪns dʒoʊlin hæd wɔkt ɪndə ðə kɪtʃən, tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ʃi ʌndɝstʊɾ i wɑz duɪŋ ɔl i kʊd. ʃi dɪd nɑt, bʌt mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən hæɾ æktʃəli  mænədʒ tə smʌðɝ ði ɛɛs sədaɪz æŋɡɝ bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəd bɪɡɪn ʃaʊɾɪŋ. ʃi wəd meɪk ðə pɝfək sʌldəm fəɹ dʒoʊlin.

"Maybe Riselle will be one," Mat suggested. She did not know what they were doing, and telling her would be a risk. Thom had asked her all sorts of questions, as if he was trying to learn about life under the Seanchan, and she had been happy enough to ask her Seanchan friend, but she might not be happy enough to chance her pretty head going up on a spike. She could do worse than say no. "And what about your lady love, Juilin?" He had a thought on the third. He had asked Juilin to find a sul'dam dress that would fit Setalle Anan, though there had been no chance to actually put it to her, yet. He had only been back to The Wandering Woman once since Joline had walked into the kitchen, to make sure she understood he was doing all he could. She did not, but Mistress Anan had actually managed to smother the Aes Sedai's anger before she could begin shouting. She would make the perfect sul'dam for Joline.

dʒulɪn ʃɹʌɡd ənkʌmftəbli. "aɪ hæɾ ə hɑɹɾ ɪnʌf taɪm kənvɪnsɪŋ θɛɹə tə ɹʌn əweɪ wɪð mi. ʃiz . . . tɪmɪd, naʊ. aɪ kən hɛlp əɹ oʊvɝkʌm ðæt, ɪn taɪm - aɪ noʊ aɪ kən - bʌɾ aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ʃiz ʌp tə ɛniθɪŋ laɪk pɹitɛndɪŋ tə bi ə sʌldəm."

Juilin shrugged uncomfortably. "I had a hard enough time convincing Thera to run away with me. She is . . . timid, now. I can help her overcome that, in time - I know I can - but I don't think she is up to anything like pretending to be a sul'dam."

tɑm tʌɡd əɾ ɪz mʌstæʃɪz. "ɪts ənlaɪkli ɹaɪzɛl wəd liv ʌndɝ ɛni sɝkəmstænsəz. ɪt simz ʃi laɪks bænɝ-dʒɛnɝəl lɔɹd jəmɑɾəz sɪŋɪŋ wɛl ɪnʌf ðət ʃiz dɪsaɪɾɪd tə mɛɹi hɪm." hi saɪd ɹɪɡɹɛtfəli. "ðɛɹ wɪl bi noʊ mɔɹ ɪnfɝmeɪʃən fɹəm ðət wɛl, aɪ fɪɹ." ən noʊ mɔɹ pɪloʊɪŋ ɪz hɛɾ ɑn əɹ bʊzəm, hɪz ɪkspɹɛʃən sɛd. "wɛl, boʊθ ə jə θɪŋk ɑn u wi kən æsk. ən si ɪf jə kən leɪ hænz ɑn ə kɑpi ʌv ðoʊz ɔɹɾɝz."

Thom tugged at his mustaches. "It's unlikely Riselle would leave under any circumstances. It seems she likes Banner-General Lord Yamada's singing well enough that she has decided to marry him." He sighed regretfully. "There will be no more information from that well, I fear." And no more pillowing his head on her bosom, his expression said. "Well, both of you think on who we can ask. And see if you can lay hands on a copy of those orders."

tɑm mænədʒ tə faɪn ðə pɹɑpɝ ɪŋks ən peɪpɝ, ən wɑz ɹɛɾi tə ɪməteɪɾ ɛniwʌnz hæn ən sil. hi wɑz kəntɛmptʃuəs ə silz; ɛniwʌn wɪð ə tɝnəp ən ə naɪf kəd kɑpi ðoʊz, hi sɛd. ɹaɪɾɪŋ ənʌðɝ mænz hæn soʊ ðə mæn hɪmsɛlf wəd θɪŋk i hæd ɹɪɾən ɪt wɑz ən ɑɹt. bʌt nʌn ə ðɛm wɝ eɪbəl tə faɪn ə kɑpi ʌv ɔɹɾɝz wɪð ðə nɛsəsɛɹi sil tə kɑpi. laɪk æɾəm, ðə sintʃæn dɪd nɑt liv ɔɹɾɝz laɪɪŋ əbaʊt. dʒulɪn sim tə meɪkɪŋ noʊ pɹɑɡɹɛs wɪð ði æɾəm, iðɝ. tu stɛps fɔɹwɝd, ən ə stoʊn wɔl. ən sɪks deɪz wɝ ɡɔn, dʒʌs laɪk ðæt. fɔɹ lɛft. tə mæt, ɪt fɛlt əz ɪf sɪks jɪɹz hæd pæst sɪns taɪlɪnz dɪpɑɹtʃɝ, ən fɔɹ aʊɝz ɹɪmeɪn tɪl ʃi keɪm bæk.

Thom managed to find the proper inks and paper, and was ready to imitate anyone's hand and seal. He was contemptuous of seals; anyone with a turnip and a knife could copy those, he said. Writing another man's hand so the man himself would think he had written it was an art. But none of them were able to find a copy of orders with the necessary seal to copy. Like a'dam, the Seanchan did not leave orders lying about. Juilin seemed to making no progress with the a'dam, either. Two steps forward, and a stone wall. And six days were gone, just like that. Four left. To Mat, it felt as if six years had passed since Tylin's departure, and four hours remained till she came back.

ɑn ðə sɛvənθ deɪ, tɑm stɑp mæt ɪn ðə hɔlweɪ əz sun əz i keɪm ɪn fɹəm ɪz ɹaɪd. smaɪlɪŋ əz ðoʊ meɪkɪŋ aɪɾəl kɑnvɝseɪʃən, ðə wʌn-taɪm ɡlimən pɪtʃt ɪz vɔɪs loʊ. ðə sɝvəns hɝiɪŋ pæs kəd nɑɾ əv hɝd mɔɹ ðən ə mɝmɝ. "əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə noʊl, ðə ɡoʊləm kɪld əɡɛn læs naɪt. ðə sikɝz əv bɪn ɔɹɾɝd tə faɪn ðə kɪlɝ ɪf ðeɪv tə stɑp iɾɪŋ əɹ slipɪŋ tə də ɪt, ðoʊ aɪ kæn faɪn aʊɾ u ɡeɪv ði ɔɹɾɝ. ivən ðə fæk ðət ðeɪv bɪn ɔɹɾɝd tə də ɛniθɪŋ simz tə bi ə sikɹət. ðeɪ ɑɹ pɹæktəkli ɹɛɾiɪŋ ðə ɹæk ən hiɾɪŋ ðɛɹ aɪɝnz ɔlɹɛɾi, ðoʊ."

On the seventh day, Thom stopped Mat in the hallway as soon as he came in from his ride. Smiling as though making idle conversation, the one-time gleeman pitched his voice low. The servants hurrying past could not have heard more than a murmur. "According to Noal, the gholam killed again last night. The Seekers have been ordered to find the killer if they have to stop eating or sleeping to do it, though I can't find out who gave the order. Even the fact that they have been ordered to do anything seems to be a secret. They are practically readying the rack and heating their irons already, though."

noʊ mæɾɝ ðət tɑmz vɔɪs wɑz loʊ, mæt lʊkt ɝaʊn tə si wɛðɝ ɛniwʌn wɑz lɪsnɪŋ. ði oʊnli pɝsən ɪn saɪt wɑz ə staʊt ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd mæn neɪm nɑɹvɪn, ɪn lɪvɝi bʌt niðɝ hɝiɪŋ nɔɹ kæɹiɪŋ ɛniθɪŋ. sɝvəns əz haɪ əz nɑɹvɪn dɪd nɑt kæɹi əɹ hɝi. hi blɪŋkt ət ðə saɪɾ ə mæt tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə lʊk ɛvɹi dɝɛkʃən ət wʌns, ən fɹaʊnd. mæt wɑntəd tə snɑɹl, bʌɾ ɪnstɛɾ i ɡɹɪn əz dɪsɑɹmɪŋli əz i nu haʊ, ən nɑɹvɪn wɛn ɔf skaʊlɪŋ. mæt wɑz ʃʊɹ ðə fɛloʊ hæd bɪn ɹispɑnsəbəl fəɹ ðə fɝst ətɛmp tə ɹimuv pɪps fɹəm ðə steɪbəl.

No matter that Thom's voice was low, Mat looked around to see whether anyone was listening. The only person in sight was a stout gray-haired man named Narvin, in livery but neither hurrying nor carrying anything. Servants as high as Narvin did not carry or hurry. He blinked at the sight of Mat trying to look every direction at once, and frowned. Mat wanted to snarl, but instead he grinned as disarmingly as he knew how, and Narvin went off scowling. Mat was sure the fellow had been responsible for the first attempt to remove Pips from the stable.

"noʊl toʊl jə əbaʊt ðə sikɝz?" hi wɪspɝɾ ɪnkɹɛdʒjələsli əz sun əz nɑɹvɪn wɑz fɑɹ ɪnʌf əweɪ.

"Noal told you about the Seekers?" he whispered incredulously as soon as Narvin was far enough away.

θɔɹn weɪvd ə lin hæn dɪsmɪsɪvli. "ʌv kɔɹs nɑt. dʒʌst əbaʊt ðə kɪlɪŋ. ðoʊ hi dʌz sim tə hɪɹ wɪspɝz, ən noʊ wʌt ðeɪ min. ə ɹɛɹ tælənt, ðæt. aɪ wʌndɝ wɛðɝ i ɹɪli hæz bɪn tə ʃɑɹə," hi mjuzd. "hi sɛɾ i . . ." tɑm klɪɹɾ ɪz θɹoʊɾ ʌndɝ mæts ɡlɛɹ. "wɛl, leɪɾɝ fəɹ ðæt. aɪ də hæv ʌðɝ ɹisɔɹsɪz ðən ðə mʌtʃ-ləmɛntɪd ɹaɪzɛl. sɛvɹəl ə ðɛm ɑɹ lɪsənɝz. lɪsənɝz ɹɪli də sim tə hɪɹ ɛvɹiθɪŋ."

Thorn waved a lean hand dismissively. "Of course not. Just about the killing. Though he does seem to hear whispers, and know what they mean. A rare talent, that. I wonder whether he really has been to Shara," he mused. "He said he . . ." Thom cleared his throat under Mat's glare. "Well, later for that. I do have other resources than the much-lamented Riselle. Several of them are Listeners. Listeners really do seem to hear everything."

"juv bɪn tɔkɪŋ tə lɪsənɝz?" mæts vɔɪs skwik laɪk ə ɹʌsti hɪnʒ. hi θɔɾ ɪz θɹoʊt maɪɾ əv ɹʌstəd sɑləd!

"You've been talking to Listeners?" Mat's voice squeaked like a rusty hinge. He thought his throat might have rusted solid!

"ðɛɹz nʌθɪŋ tə ɪt, əz lɔŋ əz ðeɪ doʊnt noʊ jə noʊ," tɑm tʃʌkəld. "mæt, wɪð sintʃæn juv tə əsum ðeɪ ɑɹ ɔl lɪsənɝz. ðət weɪ, jə lɝn wʌt jə wɑnə noʊ wɪθaʊt seɪɪŋ ðə ɹɔŋ θɪŋ ɪn ðə ɹɔŋ ɪɹ." hi kɔft ən nʌkəld ɪz mʌstæʃ, nɑt kwaɪt haɪɾɪŋ ə smaɪl soʊ sɛlf-dɛpɹəkeɪɾɪŋ ɪɾ ɔl bʌɾ ɪnvaɪɾəd pɹeɪz. "aɪ dʒʌs hæpən tə noʊ tu əɹ θɹi hu ɹɪli ɑɹ. ɪn ɛni keɪs, mɔɹ ɪnfɝmeɪʃən nɛvɝ hɝts. jə də wɑnə bi ɡɔn bɪfɔɹ taɪlɪn ɹɪtɝnz, doʊn ju? jə sim tə lʊkɪŋ ə lɪɾəl . . . fɝlɔɹn . . . wɪð əɹ ɡɔn."

"There's nothing to it, as long as they don't know you know," Thom chuckled. "Mat, with Seanchan you have to assume they are all Listeners. That way, you learn what you want to know without saying the wrong thing in the wrong ear." He coughed and knuckled his mustache, not quite hiding a smile so self-deprecating it all but invited praise. "I just happen to know two or three who really are. In any case, more information never hurts. You do want to be gone before Tylin returns, don't you? You seem to looking a little . . . forlorn . . . with her gone."

mæt kəɾ oʊnli ɡɹoʊn.
