Mat could only groan.

ðət naɪt, ðə ɡoʊləm stʃɹʌk əɡɛn. ləpɪn ən nɹɪm wɝ bʌbəlɪŋ oʊvɝ wɪð ðə nuz bɪfɔɹ mæt hæd fɪnɪʃt ɪz bɹɛkfəs fɪʃ. ðə hoʊl sɪɾi wɑz ɪn ən ʌpɹɔɹ, ðeɪ kleɪmd. ðə leɪɾəst vɪktəm, ə wʊmən, hæd bɪn dɪskʌvɝɾ ət ðə maʊθ ʌv ən æli, ən sʌɾənli pipəl wɝ tɔkɪŋ, pʊɾɪŋ təɡɛðɝ wʌn kɪlɪŋ wɪð ənʌðɝ. ðəɹ wɑz ə mædmæn ɑn ðə lus, ən ðə pipəl wɝ dɪmændɪŋ mɔɹ sintʃæn pətʃɹoʊlz ɑn ðə stʃɹits ət naɪt. mæt pʊʃt ɪz pleɪɾ əweɪ, ɔl hʌŋɡɝ ɡɔn. mɔɹ pətʃɹoʊlz. ən ɪf ðət wɝ nɑt bæɾ ɪnʌf, sjuɹɔθ maɪt kʌm bæk ɝli ɪf ʃi lɝn ə ðɪs, bɹɪŋɪŋ taɪlɪn wɪð hɝ. ət bɛst, hi kəɾ oʊnli kaʊn ɑn tu mɔɹ deɪz. hi θɔɾ i maɪt luz wʌt hiɾ ɔlɹɛɾi iɾən.

That night, the gholam struck again. Lopin and Nerim were bubbling over with the news before Mat had finished his breakfast fish. The whole city was in an uproar, they claimed. The latest victim, a woman, had been discovered at the mouth of an alley, and suddenly people were talking, putting together one killing with another. There was a madman on the loose, and the people were demanding more Seanchan patrols on the streets at night. Mat pushed his plate away, all hunger gone. More patrols. And if that were not bad enough, Suroth might come back early if she learned of this, bringing Tylin with her. At best, he could only count on two more days. He thought he might lose what he'd already eaten.

hi spɛn ðə ɹɛst ə ðə mɔɹnɪŋ peɪsɪŋ - wɛl, lɪmpɪŋ - ʌp ən daʊn ðə kɑɹpəɾ ɪn taɪlɪnz bɛdtʃeɪmbɝ, ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ðə peɪn ɪn ɪz lɛɡ waɪl i tʃɹaɪd tə θɪŋk ə sʌmθɪŋ, ɛniθɪŋ, ðət wəd lɛɾ ɪm kæɹi aʊt ði ɪmpɑsəbəl ɪn tu deɪz. ðə peɪn ɹɪli wɑz lɛs. hi hæd ɡɪvən ʌp ðə wɔkɪŋ stɪk, pʊʃɪŋ hɪmsɛlf tə ɹɪɡeɪn stʃɹɛŋkθ. hi θɔɾ i maɪt mænədʒ tu əɹ θɹi maɪlz ɑn fʊt wɪθaʊt niɾɪŋ tə ɹɛs ðə lɛɡ. wɪθaʊt ɹɛstɪŋ ɪt vɛɹi mʌtʃ, ɛniweɪ.

He spent the rest of the morning pacing - well, limping - up and down the carpet in Tylin's bedchamber, ignoring the pain in his leg while he tried to think of something, anything, that would let him carry out the impossible in two days. The pain really was less. He had given up the walking stick, pushing himself to regain strength. He thought he might manage two or three miles on foot without needing to rest the leg. Without resting it very much, anyway.

ət mɪddeɪ, dʒulɪn bɹɔɾ ɪm ði oʊnli ɹɪli ɡʊd nuz i hæd hɝɾ ɪn ən eɪdʒ. ɪt wɑz nɑt nuz, ɪɡzækli. ɪt wɑz ə klɔθ sæk kənteɪnɪŋ tu dʒɹɛsəz ɹæpt ɝaʊn ðə sɪlvɝ lɛŋθ ʌv ən æɾəm.

At midday, Juilin brought him the only really good news he had heard in an Age. It was not news, exactly. It was a cloth sack containing two dresses wrapped around the silver length of an a'dam.


tʃæptɝ twɛntinaɪn


CHAPTER 29

ənʌðɝ plæn


Another Plan

ðə bim-silɪŋɡd beɪsmən ə ðə wɑndɝɪŋ wʊmən wɑz lɑɹdʒ, jɛɾ ɪt simd əz kɹæmpt əz ðə ɹum tɑm ən dʒulɪn ʃɛɹd, ðoʊ ɪt hɛld oʊnli faɪv pipəl. ði ɔɪl læmp sɛɾ ɑn ən ʌpɛndəd bæɹəl kæs flɪkɝɪŋ ʃædoʊz. fɑɹðɝ əweɪ, ðə beɪsmənt wɑz ɔl ʃædoʊ. ði aɪl bɪtwin ðə ʃɛlvz ən ðə ɹʌf stoʊn wɔlz wɑz bɛɹli waɪɾɝ ðən ə bæɹəl wɑz tɔl, bʌt ðət wɑz nɑt wʌt meɪɾ ɪt sim kɹaʊɾəd.

The beam-ceilinged basement of The Wandering Woman was large, yet it seemed as cramped as the room Thom and Juilin shared, though it held only five people. The oil lamp set on an upended barrel cast flickering shadows. Farther away, the basement was all shadow. The aisle between the shelves and the rough stone walls was barely wider than a barrel was tall, but that was not what made it seem crowded.

"aɪ æsk fəɹ jəɹ hɛlp, nɑɾ ə nus ɝaʊn maɪ nɛk," dʒoʊlin sɛd koʊldli. æftɝ nɪɹ ə wik ɪn mɪstʃɹəs ɑnənz kɛɹ, iɾɪŋ inɪdz kʊkɪŋ, ði ɛɛs sədaɪ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ lʊk hæɡɝd. ðə fɹeɪd dʒɹɛs mæt hæd fɝst sin ɑn əɹ wɑz ɡɔn, ɹipleɪs baɪ haɪ-nɛk faɪn blu wʊl wɪð ə tʌtʃ ə leɪs əɾ əɹ ɹɪsts ən ʌndɝ əɹ tʃɪn. ɪn ðə weɪvɝɪŋ laɪt, hɝ feɪs hæf ʃæɾoʊd, ʃi lʊk fjʊɹiəs, hɝ aɪz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə bɔɹ hoʊlz θɹu mæts feɪs. "ɪf ɛniθɪŋ wɛn ɝaɪ - ɛniθɪŋ! - aɪd bi hɛlpləs!"

"I asked for your help, not a noose around my neck," Joline said coldly. After near a week in Mistress Anan's care, eating Enid's cooking, the Aes Sedai no longer looked haggard. The frayed dress Mat had first seen on her was gone, replaced by high-necked fine blue wool with a touch of lace at her wrists and under her chin. In the wavering light, her face half shadowed, she looked furious, her eyes trying to bore holes through Mat's face. "If anything went awry - anything! - I'd be helpless!"

hi wɑz hævɪŋ nʌn ʌv ɪt. ɔfɝ tə hɛlp aʊɾ ə ðə ɡʊdnəs ə jəɹ hɑɹt - wɛl, sɔɹɾ ʌv - ən si wʌɾ ɪt ɡɑt ju. hi pɹæktəkli ʃʊk ði æɾəm ʌndɝ əɹ noʊz. ɪt wɪɡɡəld ɪn ɪz hæn laɪk ə lɔŋ sɪlvɝ sneɪk, ɡlɪntɪŋ ɪn ðə dɪm læmplaɪt, ðə kɑlɝ ən bɹeɪslət boʊθ skɹeɪpɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə stoʊn flɔɹ, ən dʒoʊlin ɡæðɝɾ əɹ dɑɹk skɝts ən stɛp bæk tə əvɔɪd biɪŋ tʌtʃt. ɪt maɪɾ əv bɪn ə vaɪpɝ fɹəm ðə weɪ hɝ maʊθ twɪstəd. hi wʌndɝd wɛðɝ ɪt wəd fɪt hɝ; ðə kɑlɝ sim lɑɹdʒɝ ðən əɹ slɪm nɛk. "mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən wɪl teɪk ɪɾ ɔf əz sun əz wi ɡɛt jə aʊtsaɪd ðə wɔlz," hi ɡɹaʊld. "ju tʃɹʌs hɝ, doʊn ju? ʃi ɹɪskt əɹ hɛd tə haɪd jə daʊn hɪɹ. aɪm tɛlɪŋ ju, ɪts ði oʊnli weɪ!" dʒoʊlin ɹeɪzd əɹ tʃɪn stʌbɝnli. mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən mʌɾɝd æŋɡɹəli ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛθ.

He was having none of it. Offer to help out of the goodness of your heart - well, sort of - and see what it got you. He practically shook the a'dam under her nose. It wiggled in his hand like a long silver snake, glinting in the dim lamplight, the collar and bracelet both scraping across the stone floor, and Joline gathered her dark skirts and stepped back to avoid being touched. It might have been a viper from the way her mouth twisted. He wondered whether it would fit her; the collar seemed larger than her slim neck. "Mistress Anan will take it off as soon as we get you outside the walls," he growled. "You trust her, don't you? She risked her head to hide you down here. I'm telling you, it is the only way!" Joline raised her chin stubbornly. Mistress Anan muttered angrily under her breath.

"ʃi dʌz nɑt wɑnə wɛɹ ðə θɪŋ," fɛn sɛɾ ɪn ə flæt vɔɪs bɪhaɪn mæt.

"She does not want to wear the thing," Fen said in a flat voice behind Mat.

"ɪf ʃi dʌznt wɑnə wɛɹ ɪt, ðən ʃi dʌznt wɛɹ ɪt," blɹɪk sɛɾ ɪn ən ivən flæɾɝ, ət fɛnz saɪd.

"If she doesn't want to wear it, then she doesn't wear it," Blaeric said in an even flatter, at Fen's side.

dʒoʊlinz dɑɹk-hɛɹd wɔɹɾɝz wɝ laɪk piz ɪn ə pɑd fəɹ mɛn soʊ dɪfɹənt. fɛn, wɪð ɪz dɑɹk tɪltəɾ aɪz ən ə tʃɪn ðət kəd tʃɪp stoʊn, wɑz ə tʌtʃ ʃɔɹɾɝ ðən blɹɪk, ən meɪbi ə lɪɾəl hɛviɝ ɪn ðə tʃɛst ən ʃoʊldɝz, jɛt ðeɪ cʊɾə wɔɹn itʃ ʌðɝz kloʊðz wɪθaʊt mʌtʃ dɪfəkəlti. wɛɹ fɛnz stʃɹeɪt blæk hɛɹ hʌŋ ɔlmoʊs tə hɪz ʃoʊldɝz, blu-aɪd blɹɪks vɛɹi ʃɔɹt hɛɹ wɑz slaɪtli laɪɾɝ ɪn kʌlɝ. blɹɪk wɑz ʃaɪnɝən, ən i hæd ʃeɪvd ɪz tɑpnɑɾ ən wɑz lɛɾɪŋ ɪz hɛɹ ɡɹoʊ ɪn tə əvɔɪd noʊɾəs, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt laɪk ɪt. fɛn, ə sɑldəiən, sim nɑt tə laɪk mʌtʃ ɪksɛp fəɹ dʒoʊlin. ðeɪ boʊθ laɪk dʒoʊlin ə lɑt. ðə pɛɹ ə ðɛm tɔkt əlaɪk, θɔɾ əlaɪk, muvd əlaɪk. ðeɪ wɔɹ dɪnʒi ʃɝts ən wɝkmɪnz pleɪn wʊlən vɛsts ðət hʌŋ daʊn bɪloʊ ðɛɹ hɪps, jɛɾ ɛniwʌn u tʊk əm fəɹ leɪbɝɝz, ivən ɪn ðɪs pʊɹ laɪt, wɑz blaɪnd. baɪ deɪ, ɪn ðə steɪbəlz wɛɹ mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən hæɾ əm wɝkɪŋ . . . laɪt! ðeɪ wɝ lʊkɪŋ ət mæt əz laɪənz maɪt lʊk əɾ ə ɡoʊt ðət hæd bɛɹɾ ɪts tiθ ət ðɛm. hi muv soʊ hi dɪd nɑɾ əv tə si ðə wɔɹɾɝz ivən fɹəm ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɪz aɪ. ðə naɪvz hɪɾən əbaʊɾ ɪm ɪn vɛɹiəs pleɪsəz wɝ smɔl kʌmfɝt, wɪð əm əɾ ɪz bæk.

Joline's dark-haired Warders were like peas in a pod for men so different. Fen, with his dark tilted eyes and a chin that could chip stone, was a touch shorter than Blaeric, and maybe a little heavier in the chest and shoulders, yet they could have worn each other's clothes without much difficulty. Where Fen's straight black hair hung almost to his shoulders, blue-eyed Blaeric's very short hair was slightly lighter in color. Blaeric was Shienaran, and he had shaved his topknot and was letting his hair grow in to avoid notice, but he did not like it. Fen, a Saldaean, seemed not to like much except for Joline. They both liked Joline a lot. The pair of them talked alike, thought alike, moved alike. They wore dingy shirts and workmen's plain woolen vests that hung down below their hips, yet anyone who took them for laborers, even in this poor light, was blind. By day, in the stables where Mistress Anan had them working . . . Light! They were looking at Mat as lions might look at a goat that had bared its teeth at them. He moved so he did not have to see the Warders even from the corner of his eye. The knives hidden about him in various places were small comfort, with them at his back.

"ɪf jəl nɑt lɪsən tə hɪm, dʒoʊlin mɑzə, jəl lɪsən tə mi." plæntɪŋ əɹ hænz ɑn əɹ hɪps, sɛɾəl ɹaʊndəɾ ɑn ðə slɛndɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ, hɝ heɪzəl aɪz ɡlɛɹɪŋ. "aɪ min tə si jə bæk ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ ɪf aɪ hæv tə wɔk ɛvɹi stɛp ə ðə weɪ pʊʃɪŋ ju! pɝhæps əlɔŋ ðə weɪ jəl ʃoʊ mi ðət jə noʊ wʌɾ ɪt minz tə bi ɛɛs sədaɪ. aɪd sɛɾəl fəɹ ə ɡlɪmps ʌv ə ɡɹoʊn wʊmən. soʊ fɑɹ, ɔl aɪ hæv sin ɪz ə nɑvəs snaɪvəlɪŋ ɪn əɹ bɛɾ ən θɹoʊɪŋ tæntʃɹəmz!"

"If you will not listen to him, Joline Maza, you will listen to me." Planting her hands on her hips, Setalle rounded on the slender Aes Sedai, her hazel eyes glaring. "I mean to see you back in the White Tower if I have to walk every step of the way pushing you! Perhaps along the way you will show me that you know what it means to be Aes Sedai. I'd settle for a glimpse of a grown woman. So far, all I have seen is a novice sniveling in her bed and throwing tantrums!"

dʒoʊlin stɛɹɾ ət hɝ, ðoʊz bɪɡ bɹaʊn aɪz əz waɪɾ əz ðeɪ wəd ɡoʊ, əz ɪf ʃi kəd nɑt bɪliv əɹ ɪɹz. mæt wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ i bɪliv hɪz, iðɝ. ɪnkipɝz dɪd nɑt lip daʊn ɛɛs sədaɪz θɹoʊts. fɛn ɡɹʌntɪd, ən blɹɪk mʌɾɝd sʌmθɪŋ ðət saʊndəɾ ʌnkəmpləmɛntɝi.

Joline stared at her, those big brown eyes as wide as they would go, as if she could not believe her ears. Mat was not sure he believed his, either. Innkeepers did not leap down Aes Sedai's throats. Fen grunted, and Blaeric muttered something that sounded uncomplimentary.

"ðɛɹz noʊ nid fəɹ jə tə ɡoʊ fɑɹðɝ ðən bɪɑn saɪɾ ə ðə ɡɑɹdz ət ðə ɡeɪts," mæt toʊl sɛɾəl heɪstəli, hoʊpɪŋ tə daɪvɝɾ ɛni ɪksploʊʒən dʒoʊlin maɪt bi kənsɪɾɝɪŋ. "kip ðə hʊɾ ə jəɹ kloʊk pʊld ʌp . . ." laɪt, hi hæd tə ɡɛɾ əɹ wʌn ə ðoʊz fænsi kloʊks! wɛl, ɪf dʒulɪn kəd stil ən æɾəm, hi kəd stil ə blʌɾi kloʊk, tu. ". . . ən ðə ɡɑɹdz wɪl dʒʌst si ənʌðɝ sʌldəm. jə kən bi bæk hɪɹ bɪfɔɹ deɪbɹeɪk, ən noʊ wʌn ðə waɪzɝ. ənlɛs jə ɪnsɪst ɑn wɛɹɪŋ jəɹ mɛɹɪdʒ naɪf." hi læft əɾ ɪz oʊn dʒoʊk, bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt.

"There's no need for you to go farther than beyond sight of the guards at the gates," Mat told Setalle hastily, hoping to divert any explosion Joline might be considering. "Keep the hood of your cloak pulled up . . ." Light, he had to get her one of those fancy cloaks! Well, if Juilin could steal an a'dam, he could steal a bloody cloak, too. ". . . and the guards will just see another sul'dam. You can be back here before daybreak, and no one the wiser. Unless you insist on wearing your marriage knife." He laughed at his own joke, but she did not.

"du jə θɪŋk aɪ kəd ɹɪmeɪn ɛniwɛɹ wɪmən ɑɹ tɝn ɪndə ænəməlz kəz ðeɪ kən tʃænəl?" ʃi dɪmændəd, stɔkɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə flɔɹ tɪl ʃi stʊd toʊ-tə-toʊ wɪð hɪm. "du jə θɪŋk aɪd lɛt maɪ fæmli steɪ?" ɪf əɹ aɪz hæd ɡlɛɹɾ ət dʒoʊlin, ðeɪ bleɪzd ʌp ət hɪm. fɹæŋkli, hi hæd nɛvɝ kənsɪɾɝd ðə kwɛstʃən. sɝɾənli hi wəd laɪk tə si ðə deɪmeɪn fɹid, bʌt waɪ ʃəɾ ɪt mæɾɝ ðɪs mʌtʃ tə hɝ? pleɪnli, ɪt dɪd, ðoʊ; hɝ hæn slɪɾ əlɔŋ ðə hɪlt ə ðə lɔŋ kɝv dæɡɝ stʌk bɪhaɪn əɹ bɛlt, kɝɛsɪŋ ɪt. ɛbu dɑɹi dɪd nɑt teɪk kaɪnli tə ɪnsəls, ən ʃi wɑz pjʊɹ ɛbu dɑɹi tə ðəɾ ɪkstɛnt. "aɪ bɪɡæn nɪɡoʊʃieɪɾɪŋ ðə seɪl ə ðə wɑndɝɪŋ wʊmən tu deɪz æftɝ ðə sintʃæn ɝaɪvd, wən aɪ kəd si wʌt ðeɪ ɑɹ. aɪ ʃʊɾə hændəɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ oʊvɝ tə laɪɾəl ɪlɑnɪd deɪz əɡoʊ, bʌɾ aɪv bɪn hoʊldɪŋ ɔf kəz laɪɾəl wəd nɑɾ ɪkspɛk tə faɪn ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn ðə beɪsmənt. wən jə ɑɹ ɹɛɾi tə ɡoʊ, aɪ kən hæn oʊvɝ ðə kiz ən ɡoʊ wɪð ju. laɪɾəl ɪz ɡɹoʊɪŋ ɪmpeɪʃənt," ʃi æɾəd sɪɡnɪfɪkənli oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ tə dʒoʊlin.

"Do you think I could remain anywhere women are turned into animals because they can channel?" she demanded, stalking across the floor till she stood toe-to-toe with him. "Do you think I'd let my family stay?" If her eyes had glared at Joline, they blazed up at him. Frankly, he had never considered the question. Certainly he would like to see the damane freed, but why should it matter this much to her? Plainly, it did, though; her hand slid along the hilt of the long curved dagger stuck behind her belt, caressing it. Ebou Dari did not take kindly to insults, and she was pure Ebou Dari to that extent. "I began negotiating the sale of The Wandering Woman two days after the Seanchan arrived, when I could see what they are. I should have handed everything over to Lydel Elonid days ago, but I've been holding off because Lydel would not expect to find an Aes Sedai in the basement. When you are ready to go, I can hand over the keys and go with you. Lydel is growing impatient," she added significantly over her shoulder to Joline.

ən wʌɾ əbaʊɾ ɪz ɡoʊld? hi wɑntəd tə æsk ɪndɪɡnənli. wəd laɪɾəl əv lɛɾ ɪm teɪk ðəɾ əweɪ, ə wɪndfɔl ʌndɝ əɹ kɪtʃən flɔɹ? stɪl, ɪt wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ɛls ðət meɪɾ ɪm tʃoʊk. sʌɾənli hi kəd si hɪmsɛlf sæɾəld wɪð mɪstʃɹəs ɑnənz hoʊl fæmli, ɪnkluɾɪŋ ðə mɛɹid sʌnz ən dɔɾɝz wɪð ðɛɹ tʃɪlʒɹən, ən meɪbi ə fju æns ən ʌŋkəlz ən kʌzənz, əz wɛl. dʌzənz ə ðɛm. skɔɹz, meɪbi. ʃi maɪt bi fɹəm ɔf, bʌɾ əɹ hʌzbən hæd ɹileɪʃənz ɔl oʊvɝ ðə sɪɾi. blɹɪk slæpt ɪm ɑn ðə bæk soʊ hɑɹd ðəɾ i stæɡɝd.

And what about his gold? he wanted to ask indignantly. Would Lydel have let him take that away, a windfall under her kitchen floor? Still, it was something else that made him choke. Suddenly he could see himself saddled with Mistress Anan's whole family, including the married sons and daughters with their children, and maybe a few aunts and uncles and cousins, as well. Dozens of them. Scores, maybe. She might be from off, but her husband had relations all over the city. Blaeric slapped him on the back so hard that he staggered.

hi ʃoʊd ðə fɛloʊ hɪz tiθ ən hoʊp ðə ʃaɪnɝən wəd teɪk ɪt fəɹ ə smaɪl ə θæŋks. blɹɪks ɪkspɹɛʃən nɛvɝ ɔltɝd. blʌɾi wɔɹɾɝz! blʌɾi ɛɛs sədaɪ! blʌɾi, blʌɾi ɪnkipɝz!

He showed the fellow his teeth and hoped the Shienaran would take it for a smile of thanks. Blaeric's expression never altered. Bloody Warders! Bloody Aes Sedai! Bloody, bloody innkeepers!

"mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən," hi sɛd kɛɹfəli, "ðə weɪ aɪ min tə ɡɛɾ əweɪ fɹəm ɛbu dɑɹ, ðɛɹz oʊnli ɹum fəɹ soʊ mɛni." hi hæd nɑt toʊld əɹ əbaʊt lukəz ʃoʊ, jɛt. ðəɹ wɑz ə tʃæns i kəd nɑt kənvɪns ðə mæn, æftɝ ɔl. ən ðə mɔɹ pipəl i hæd tə kənvɪns lukə tə teɪk, ðə hɑɹɾɝ ɪt wəd bi. "kʌm bæk hɪɹ wʌns wɝ aʊtsaɪd ðə sɪɾi. ɪf juv tə liv, ɡoʊ ɑn wʌn jəɹ hʌzbənz fɪʃɪŋ boʊts. aɪ sədʒɛs jə weɪɾ ə fju deɪz, ðoʊ. meɪbi ə wik əɹ soʊ. wʌns ðə sintʃæn dɪskʌvɝ tu deɪmeɪn mɪsɪŋ, ðəl bi ɔl oʊvɝ ɛniθɪŋ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə liv."

"Mistress Anan," he said carefully, "the way I mean to get away from Ebou Dar, there's only room for so many." He had not told her about Luca's show, yet. There was a chance he could not convince the man, after all. And the more people he had to convince Luca to take, the harder it would be. "Come back here once we're outside the city. If you have to leave, go on one your husband's fishing boats. I suggest you wait a few days, though. Maybe a week or so. Once the Seanchan discover two damane missing, they'll be all over anything trying to leave."

"tu?" dʒoʊlin pʊɾ ɪn ʃɑɹpli. "tɛslɪn ən hu?"

"Two?" Joline put in sharply. "Teslyn and who?"

mæt wɪnst. hi hæd nɑt mɛn tə lɛt ðət slɪp. hi hæd dʒoʊlin pɛɡd, ən pɛtʃələnt, wɪlfəl ən spɔɪld wɝ ðə wɝdz ðət keɪm moʊst ɹɛɾəli tə maɪnd. ɛniθɪŋ əɾ ɔl ðət meɪɾ əɹ θɪŋk ðɪs mɔɹ dɪfəkəlt, mɔɹ laɪkli tə feɪl, maɪt dʒʌs bi ɪnʌf tə meɪk əɹ dɪsaɪd tə tʃɹaɪ səm kɹækbɹeɪn skim ə hɝ oʊn. sʌmθɪŋ ðət wəd noʊ daʊt ɹuən ɪz oʊn plænz. ʃi wəd bi kæptʃɝd fəɹ ʃʊɹ ɪf ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə ɹʌn ɑn əɹ oʊn, ən ʃi wəd faɪt. ən wʌns ðə sintʃæn lɝn ðəɹ hæd bɪn ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn ðə sɪɾi, ɹaɪɾ ʌndɝ ðɛɹ noʊzɪz, ðeɪ wəɾ ɪntɛnsəfaɪ ðə sɝtʃɪz fəɹ mɛɹəθdəmeɪn əɡɛn, ɪnkɹis ðə stʃɹit pətʃɹoʊlz mɔɹ ðən ðeɪ ɔlɹɛɾi hæd fəɹ ðə "mæd kɪlɝ," ən wɝst ʌv ɔl, ðeɪ maɪt wɛl meɪk ɪɾ ivən hɑɹɾɝ tə pæs ðə ɡeɪts.

Mat winced. He had not meant to let that slip. He had Joline pegged, and petulant, willful and spoiled were the words that came most readily to mind. Anything at all that made her think this more difficult, more likely to fail, might just be enough to make her decide to try some crackbrained scheme of her own. Something that would no doubt ruin his own plans. She would be captured for sure if she tried to run on her own, and she would fight. And once the Seanchan learned there had been an Aes Sedai in the city, right under their noses, they would intensify the searches for marath'damane again, increase the street patrols more than they already had for the "mad killer," and worst of all, they might well make it even harder to pass the gates.

"idɛzinə æziɾɪn," hi sɛd ɹɪlʌktənli. "aɪ doʊnt noʊ ɛniθɪŋ mɔɹ əbaʊt hɝ."

"Edesina Azzedin," he said reluctantly. "I don't know anything more about her."

"idɛzinə," dʒoʊlin sɛd sloʊli. ə taɪni fɹaʊn kɹist əɹ smuð fɔɹhɛd. "aɪ hɝd ðət ʃi hæd - " wʌtɛvɝ ʃi hæd hɝd, ʃi snæpt əɹ tiθ ʃʌɾ ɑn ɪɾ ən fɪkst ɪm ə fɪɹs stɛɹ. "ɑɹ ðeɪ hoʊldɪŋ ɛni ʌðɝ sɪstɝz? ɪf tɛslɪn ɪz ɡɛɾɪŋ fɹi, aɪ woʊn liv ɛni ʌðɝ sɪstɝ tə ðɛm!"

"Edesina," Joline said slowly. A tiny frown creased her smooth forehead. "I heard that she had - " Whatever she had heard, she snapped her teeth shut on it and fixed him a fierce stare. "Are they holding any other sisters? If Teslyn is getting free, I won't leave any other sister to them!"

ɪt tʊk ən ɛfɝɾ ɑn mæts pɑɹt nɑt tə ɡeɪp. pɛtʃələn ən spɔɪld? hi wɑz lʊkɪŋ əɾ ə laɪoʊnəs tə mætʃ blɹɪk ən fɛn. "bɪliv mi, aɪ woʊn liv ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn ðə kɛnəlz ənlɛs ʃi wɑns tə steɪ," hi sɛd, meɪkɪŋ ɪz vɔɪs əz ɹaɪ əz i kʊd. ðə wʊmən wɑz stɪl wɪlfəl. ʃi maɪɾ ɪnsɪst ɑn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɹɛskju ði ʌðɝ tu laɪk pʊɹə. laɪt, hi ʃəd nɛvɝ əv lɛt hɪmsɛlf ɡɛt tæŋɡəld wɪð ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən i dɪd nɑt niɾ ɛni eɪntʃən mɛmɹiz tə wɔɹn hɪm! hɪz oʊn wəd də vɛɹi wɛl, θæŋk ju.

It took an effort on Mat's part not to gape. Petulant and spoiled? He was looking at a lioness to match Blaeric and Fen. "Believe me, I won't leave an Aes Sedai in the kennels unless she wants to stay," he said, making his voice as wry as he could. The woman was still willful. She might insist on trying to rescue the other two like Pura. Light, he should never have let himself get tangled with Aes Sedai, and he did not need any ancient memories to warn him! His own would do very well, thank you.

fɛn poʊkt ɪm ɑn ðə bæk ə hɪz lɛft ʃoʊldɝ wɪð ə hɑɹd fɪŋɡɝ. "doʊn bi soʊ laɪt-tʌŋd," ðə wɔɹɾɝ sɛd wɔɹnɪŋli.

Fen poked him on the back of his left shoulder with a hard finger. "Don't be so light-tongued," the Warder said warningly.

blɹɪk poʊkt ɪm ɑn ðə bæk ə ði ʌðɝ ʃoʊldɝ. "ɹɪmɛmbɝ u jə ɑɹ tɔkɪŋ tə!"

Blaeric poked him on the back of the other shoulder. "Remember who you are talking to!"

dʒoʊlin snɪft əɾ ɪz toʊn, bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt pɹoʊb fɝðɝ.

Joline sniffed at his tone, but she did not probe further.

mæt fɛlt ə nɑt lusən ɪn ðə bæk ə hɪz nɛk, əbaʊt wɛɹ ə hɛdzmənz æks wəd stʃɹaɪk. ɛɛs sədaɪ twɪstəd wɝdz wɪð ʌðɝ pipəl; ðeɪ dɪd nɑɾ ɪkspɛkt ʌðɝz tə juz ðɛɹ oʊn tʃɹɪks ɑn ðɛm.

Mat felt a knot loosen in the back of his neck, about where a headsman's axe would strike. Aes Sedai twisted words with other people; they did not expect others to use their own tricks on them.

hi tɝn tə sɛɾəl. "mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən, jə kən si jəɹ hʌzbənz boʊts ɑɹ mʌtʃ bɛɾɝ - "

He turned to Setalle. "Mistress Anan, you can see your husband's boats are much better - "

"ɪt maɪt bi soʊ," ʃi bɹoʊk ɪn, "ɪksɛp ðət dʒæsfɝ seɪld wɪð ɔl tɛn ə hɪz boʊts ən ɔl ʌv əɹ kɪn θɹi deɪz əɡoʊ. aɪ ɪkspɛk ðə ɡɪlz wɪl wɑnə tɔk tə hɪm ɪf i ɛvɝ ɹɪtɝnz. hi ɪzən səpoʊz tə kæɹi pæsənʒɝz. ðeɪ ɑɹ koʊstɪŋ tə ɪljən, wɛɹ ðəl weɪt fəɹ mi. aɪ doʊn ɹɪli ɪntɛn tə ɡoʊ əz fɑɹ əz tɑɹ vəlɑn, jə si."

"It might be so," she broke in, "except that Jasfer sailed with all ten of his boats and all of our kin three days ago. I expect the guilds will want to talk to him if he ever returns. He isn't supposed to carry passengers. They are coasting to Illian, where they will wait for me. I don't really intend to go as far as Tar Valon, you see."

ðɪs taɪm, mæt kəd nɑt stɑp ə wɪns. hi hæɾ ɪntɛndəd fɔlɪŋ bæk ɑn dʒæsfɝ ɑnənz fɪʃɪŋ boʊts ɪf i feɪl tə pɝsweɪd lukə. ə deɪnʒɝəs ɑpʃən, tʃɹu, mɔɹ ðən deɪnʒɝəs. mæd, meɪbi. ðə sʌldəm ɑn ðə dɑks laɪkli wʊɾə wɑntəd tə tʃɛk ɛni ɔɹɾɝ ðət sɛn deɪmeɪn aʊɾ ɑn fɪʃɪŋ boʊts, ɪspɛʃli ɪn ðə naɪt. bʌt ðə boʊts hæɾ ɔlweɪz bɪn ɪn ðə bæk ə hɪz maɪnd. wɛl, hi wɑz dʒʌs gɑnə hæv twɪs lukəz ɑɹm hɑɹd, dʒʌst əz hɑɹɾ əz nɛsəsɛɹi.

This time, Mat could not stop a wince. He had intended falling back on Jasfer Anan's fishing boats if he failed to persuade Luca. A dangerous option, true, more than dangerous. Mad, maybe. The sul'dam on the docks likely would have wanted to check any order that sent damane out on fishing boats, especially in the night. But the boats had always been in the back of his mind. Well, he was just going to have twist Luca's arm hard, just as hard as necessary.

"ju lɛt jəɹ kɪn ɡoʊ aʊɾ ɪn ðɪs sizən?" dɪsbɪlif ən skɔɹn mɪŋɡəld ɪn dʒoʊlinz vɔɪs. "wɛn ðə wɝst stɔɹmz ɑɹ bɹuɪŋ?"

"You let your kin go out in this season?" Disbelief and scorn mingled in Joline's voice. "When the worst storms are brewing?"

hɝ bæk tə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən ɹeɪzd əɹ hɛd pɹaʊdli, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz nɑt pɹaɪɾ ɪn hɝsɛlf. "aɪ tʃɹʌs dʒæsfɝ tə seɪl ɪndə ðə tiθ ʌv ə sɛmɑɹoʊz, ɪf nid bi. aɪ tʃɹʌst ɪm əz mʌtʃ əz jə də jəɹ wɔɹɾɝz, ɡɹin. mɔɹ."

Her back to the Aes Sedai, Mistress Anan raised her head proudly, but it was not pride in herself. "I trust Jasfer to sail into the teeth of a cemaros, if need be. I trust him as much as you do your Warders, Green. More."

fɹaʊnɪŋ sʌɾənli, dʒoʊlin pɪkt ʌp ðə læmp baɪ ði aɪɝn beɪs ən muvd ɪt tə kæs laɪɾ ɑn ði ɪnkipɝz feɪs. "hæv wi mɛt sʌmwɛɹ bɪfɔɹ? səmtaɪmz, wən aɪ kænɑt si jəɹ feɪs, jəɹ vɔɪs saʊnz fəmɪljɝ."

Frowning suddenly, Joline picked up the lamp by the iron base and moved it to cast light on the innkeeper's face. "Have we met somewhere before? Sometimes, when I cannot see your face, your voice sounds familiar."

ɪnstɛɾ ʌv ænsɝɪŋ, sɛɾəl tʊk ði æɾəm fɹəm mæt ən fʌmbəld ət ðə flæt sɛɡmɛntɪd bɹeɪsləɾ ɑn wʌn ɛn ə ðə ɹaʊn sɪlvɝ liʃ. ðə hoʊl θɪŋ wɑz meɪɾ ɪn sɛɡməns, fɪɾəd təɡɛðɝ soʊ kʌnɪŋli jə kəd nɑt si haʊ ɪt hæd bɪn dʌn. "wi maɪɾ əz wɛl ɡɛt ðə tɛstɪŋ oʊvɝ wɪð."

Instead of answering, Setalle took the a'dam from Mat and fumbled at the flat segmented bracelet on one end of the round silver leash. The whole thing was made in segments, fitted together so cunningly you could not see how it had been done. "We might as well get the testing over with."

"tɛstɪŋ?" hi sɛd, ən ðoʊz heɪzəl aɪz ɡeɪv ɪm ə wɪðɝɪŋ lʊk.

"Testing?" he said, and those hazel eyes gave him a withering look.

"nɑɾ ɛvɹi wʊmən kən bi ə sʌldəm. jə ʃəd noʊ ðət baɪ naʊ. aɪ hæv hoʊps ðəɾ aɪ kæn, bʌt bɛɾɝ wi faɪn aʊt bɪfɔɹ ðə læst aʊɝ." skaʊlɪŋ ət ðə stʌbɝnli kloʊz bɹeɪslət, ʃi tɝn ɪɾ ɪn əɹ hænz. "du jə noʊ haʊ tə oʊpən ðɪs θɪŋ? aɪ kænɑɾ ivən faɪnd wɛɹ ɪɾ oʊpənz."

"Not every woman can be a sul'dam. You should know that by now. I have hopes that I can, but better we find out before the last hour." Scowling at the stubbornly closed bracelet, she turned it in her hands. "Do you know how to open this thing? I cannot even find where it opens."

"jɛs," hi sɛd feɪnli. ði oʊnli taɪmz i hæd tɔkt wɪð sintʃæn əbaʊt sʌldəm ən deɪmeɪn, ɪt hæd bɪn kɔʃəs kwɛstʃənz əbaʊt haʊ ðeɪ wɝ juzd ɪn bæɾəl. hi hæd nɛvɝ ivən θɔɾ əbaʊt haʊ sʌldəm wɝ tʃoʊzən. hi maɪɾ əv tə faɪɾ əm - ðoʊz eɪntʃən mɛmɹiz hɑɹdli lɛɾ ɪm stɑp θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt haʊ tə faɪt bæɾəlz - bʌɾ i hæd sɝɾənli nɛvɝ mɛn tə ɹəkɹuɾ ɛni. "bɛɾɝ tə tɛst ɪt naʊ." ɪnstɛɾ ʌv . . . laɪt!

"Yes," he said faintly. The only times he had talked with Seanchan about sul'dam and damane, it had been cautious questions about how they were used in battle. He had never even thought about how sul'dam were chosen. He might have to fight them - those ancient memories hardly let him stop thinking about how to fight battles - but he had certainly never meant to recruit any. "Better to test it now." Instead of . . . Light!

ðə kætʃəz wɝ ə sɪmpəl mæɾɝ fəɹ hɪm, ðə bɹeɪsləɾ iziəst. ðət wɑz dʒʌst ə mæɾɝ ə skwizɪŋ ðə ɹaɪt spɑts, tɑp ən bɑɾəm, nɑt kwaɪɾ ɑpəzət ðə liʃ. ɪt kəd bi dʌn wɪð wʌn hænd, ən ðə bɹeɪslət pɑpt oʊpən ɑn wʌn wɪð ə mətælɪk klɪk. ðə kɑlɝ wɑz ə lɪɾəl tʃɹɪkiɝ, ən ɹikwaɪɝd boʊθ hænz. pʊɾɪŋ ɪz fɪŋɡɝz ɑn ðə pɹɑpɝ spɑts ɑn iðɝ saɪɾ ʌv wɛɹ ðə liʃ ətætʃt, hi pɹɛst, ðən twɪstəɾ ən pʊld waɪl hoʊldɪŋ ðə pɹɛʃɝ. nʌθɪŋ hæpənd, ðəɾ i kəd si, əntɪl i twɪstəd ðə tu saɪdz ði ʌðɝ weɪ. ðən ðeɪ keɪm əpɑɹt ɹaɪt bɪsaɪd ðə liʃ, wɪð ə ʃɑɹpɝ klɪk ðən ðə bɹeɪslət. sɪmpəl. ʌv kɔɹs, fɪɡjɝɪŋ ɪɾ aʊt hæd teɪkən ɪm nɪɹli ən aʊɝ, bæk ɪn ðə pæləs, ivən wɪð wʌt dʒulɪn hæd sin tə hɛlp. noʊbɑdi hɪɹ pɹeɪz hɪm, ðoʊ. noʊbɑdi ivən lʊkt əz ðoʊ hi hæd dʌn ɛniθɪŋ ðeɪ kəd nɑt!

The catches were a simple matter for him, the bracelet easiest. That was just a matter of squeezing the right spots, top and bottom, not quite opposite the leash. It could be done with one hand, and the bracelet popped open on one with a metallic click. The collar was a little trickier, and required both hands. Putting his fingers on the proper spots on either side of where the leash attached, he pressed, then twisted and pulled while holding the pressure. Nothing happened, that he could see, until he twisted the two sides the other way. Then they came apart right beside the leash, with a sharper click than the bracelet. Simple. Of course, figuring it out had taken him nearly an hour, back in the Palace, even with what Juilin had seen to help. Nobody here praised him, though. Nobody even looked as though he had done anything they could not!

snæpɪŋ ðə bɹeɪsləɾ ɝaʊn əɹ ɹɪst, sɛɾəl lup ðə liʃ ɪn kɔɪlz ɑn əɹ fɔɹɑɹm, ðən hɛld ʌp ði oʊpən kɑlɝ. dʒoʊlin stɛɹɾ ɪt wɪð loʊθɪŋ, hɝ hænz taɪɾənɪŋ ɪndə fɪsts ɡɹɪpɪŋ əɹ skɝts.

Snapping the bracelet around her wrist, Setalle looped the leash in coils on her forearm, then held up the open collar. Joline stared it with loathing, her hands tightening into fists gripping her skirts.

"du jə wɑnə ɪskeɪp?" ði ɪnkipɝ æskt kwaɪətli.

"Do you want to escape?" the innkeeper asked quietly.

æftɝ ə moʊmənt, dʒoʊlin stʃɹeɪɾənd ən lɪftəɾ əɹ tʃɪn. sɛɾəl kloʊz ðə kɑlɝ ɝaʊn ði ɛɛs sədaɪz nɛk wɪð ðə seɪm kɹɪsp snæp ɪt hæd meɪɾ oʊpənɪŋ. hi mʌst əv bɪn ɹɔŋ əbaʊt ðə saɪz; ɪt fɪɾ əɹ kwaɪt snʌɡli ətɑp ðə haɪ nɛk ə hɝ dʒɹɛs. dʒoʊlinz maʊθ twɪtʃt, ðət wɑz ɔl, bʌt mæt kəɾ ɔlmoʊs fil blɹɪk ən fɛn tɛnsɪŋ bɪhaɪn hɪm. hi hɛld ɪz bɹɛθ.

After a moment, Joline straightened and lifted her chin. Setalle closed the collar around the Aes Sedai's neck with the same crisp snap it had made opening. He must have been wrong about the size; it fit her quite snugly atop the high neck of her dress. Joline's mouth twitched, that was all, but Mat could almost feel Blaeric and Fen tensing behind him. He held his breath.

saɪd baɪ saɪd, ðə tu wɪmən tʊk ə smɔl stɛp, bɹʌʃɪŋ baɪ mæt, ən i bɪɡæn tə bɹið. dʒoʊlin fɹaʊn ənsɝteɪnli. ðən ðeɪ tʊk ə sɛkən stɛp.

Side by side, the two women took a small step, brushing by Mat, and he began to breathe. Joline frowned uncertainly. Then they took a second step.

wɪð ə kɹaɪ, ði ɛɛs sədaɪ fɛl tə ðə flɔɹ, ɹaɪðɪŋ ɪn æɡəni. ʃi kəd nɑt fɔɹm wɝdz, oʊnli ɪnkɹisɪŋli laʊɾɝ moʊnz. ʃi hʌɾəld ɪn ɑn hɝsɛlf, hɝ ɑɹmz ən lɛɡz ən ivən əɹ fɪŋɡɝz twɪtʃɪŋ ən kɹʊkɪŋ əɾ ɑɾ æŋɡəlz.

With a cry, the Aes Sedai fell to the floor, writhing in agony. She could not form words, only increasingly louder moans. She huddled in on herself, her arms and legs and even her fingers twitching and crooking at odd angles.

sɛɾəl dʒɹɑp tə hɝ niz əz sun əz dʒoʊlin hɪt ðə flɔɹ, hɝ hænz ɡoʊɪŋ tə ðə kɑlɝ, bʌt ʃi wɑz noʊ kwɪkɝ ðən blɹɪk ən fɛn, ðoʊ ðɛɹ ækʃənz dɪd sim ɑd. nilɪŋ, blɹɪk ɹeɪzd ə weɪlɪŋ dʒoʊlin ən səpɔɹɾəd əɹ əɡɛnst ɪz tʃɛst waɪl i bɪɡæn tə məsɑʒ əɹ nɛk, ʌv ɔl θɪŋz. fɛn wɝkt ɪz fɪŋɡɝz əlɔŋ əɹ ɑɹmz. ðə kɑlɝ keɪm lus, ən sɛɾəl fɛl bæk ɑn əɹ hilz, bʌt dʒoʊlin kəntɪnjud tə dʒɝk ən wɪmpɝ, ən əɹ wɔɹɾɝz kəntɪnjud tə wɝk oʊvɝ əɹ əz ðoʊ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɹʌb əweɪ kɹæmps. ðeɪ ʃɑt koʊl stɛɹz ət mæt əz ðoʊ ɪt wɝ ɔl ɪz fɔlt.

Setalle dropped to her knees as soon as Joline hit the floor, her hands going to the collar, but she was no quicker than Blaeric and Fen, though their actions did seem odd. Kneeling, Blaeric raised a wailing Joline and supported her against his chest while he began to massage her neck, of all things. Fen worked his fingers along her arms. The collar came loose, and Setalle fell back on her heels, but Joline continued to jerk and whimper, and her Warders continued to work over her as though trying to rub away cramps. They shot cold stares at Mat as though it were all his fault.

lʊkɪŋ daʊn ɑn ɔl ɪz faɪn plænz laɪɪŋ ɪn ɹuənz, mæt bɛɹli sɔ ðə mɛn. hi dɪd nɑt noʊ wʌt tə də nɛkst, wɛɹ tə bɪɡɪn. taɪlɪn maɪt bi bæk ɪn tu mɔɹ deɪz, ən i wɑz ʃʊɹ i hæd tə bi ɡɔn bɪfɔɹ ʃi ɹɪtɝnd.

Looking down on all his fine plans lying in ruins, Mat barely saw the men. He did not know what to do next, where to begin. Tylin might be back in two more days, and he was sure he had to be gone before she returned.

skwizɪŋ pæst sɛɾəl, hi pæɾəd əɹ ɑn ðə ʃoʊldɝ. "tɛl əɹ wɪl tʃɹaɪ sʌmθɪŋ ɛls," hi mʌɾɝd. bʌt wʌt? ɑbviəsli ɪt hæd tə bi ə wʊmən wɪð ə sʌldəmz əbɪləɾiz tə hændəl ði æɾəm.

Squeezing past Setalle, he patted her on the shoulder. "Tell her we'll try something else," he muttered. But what? Obviously it had to be a woman with a sul'dam's abilities to handle the a'dam.

ði ɪnkipɝ kɑɾ ɪm ɪn ðə dɑɹk ət ðə fʊɾ ə ðə stɛɹz liɾɪŋ ʌp tə ðə kɪtʃən waɪl i wɑz ɡæðɝɪŋ ɪz hæɾ ən kloʊk. ə staʊt, pleɪn wʊl kloʊk wɪð noʊ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi. ə mæn kəd də wɪθaʊɾ ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝi. hi sɝɾənli dɪd nɑt mɪs ɪt. ən ɔl ðət leɪs! sɝɾənli nɑt!

The innkeeper caught him in the dark at the foot of the stairs leading up to the kitchen while he was gathering his hat and cloak. A stout, plain wool cloak with no embroidery. A man could do without embroidery. He certainly did not miss it. And all that lace! Certainly not!

"du juv ənʌðɝ plæn ɹɛɾi?" ʃi æskt. hi kəd nɑt meɪk aʊɾ əɹ feɪs ɪn ðə dɑɹk, bʌt ðə sɪlvɝ lɛŋθ ə ði æɾəm ɡlimd ivən soʊ. ʃi wɑz ɡɹoʊpɪŋ ət ðə bɹeɪsləɾ ɑn əɹ ɹɪst.

"Do you have another plan ready?" she asked. He could not make out her face in the dark, but the silver length of the a'dam gleamed even so. She was groping at the bracelet on her wrist.

"aɪ ɔlweɪz əv ənʌðɝ plæn," hi laɪd, ənduɪŋ ðə bɹeɪslət fəɹ hɝ. "æt lis jə kən fɝɡɛɾ əbaʊt ɹɪskɪŋ jəɹ nɛk. əz sun əz aɪ teɪk dʒoʊlin ɔf jəɹ hænz, jə kən ɡoʊ dʒɔɪn jəɹ hʌzbənd."

"I always have another plan," he lied, undoing the bracelet for her. "At least you can forget about risking your neck. As soon as I take Joline off your hands, you can go join your husband."

ʃi dʒʌst ɡɹʌntɪd. hi səspɛktəd ʃi nu hi hæd noʊ plæn.

She just grunted. He suspected she knew he had no plan.

hi wɑntəd tə əvɔɪd ðə kɑmən ɹum fʊl ə sintʃæn, soʊ hi wɛn aʊt θɹu ðə kɪtʃən ɪndə ðə steɪbliɑɹɾ ən aʊt θɹu ðə ɡeɪɾ ɪndə ðə mɔl hɛɹə. hi wɑz nɑɾ əfɹeɪd ðəɾ ɛni ʌv əm wəd mɑɹk ɪm aʊɾ əɹ wʌndɝ waɪ hi wɑz ðɛɹ. ɪn ɪz dʒɹæb kloʊðz, ðeɪ sim tə teɪk ɪm fəɹ sʌmwʌn ɹʌnɪŋ ən ɛɹən fəɹ ði ɪnkipɝ wən i keɪm ɪn. bʌt ðəɹ hæd bɪn θɹi sʌldəm əmʌŋ ðə sintʃæn, tu wɪð deɪmeɪn. hi wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə bi əfɹeɪɾ i wəɾ əv tə liv tɛslɪn ən idɛzinə kɑlɝd, ən i dʒʌs dɪd nɑt wɑnə lʊk ət deɪmeɪn ɹaɪt ðɛn. blʌɾ ən blʌɾi æʃəz, hi hæɾ oʊnli pɹɑməs tə tʃɹaɪ!

He wanted to avoid the common room full of Seanchan, so he went out through the kitchen into the stableyard and out through the gate into the Mol Hara. He was not afraid that any of them would mark him out or wonder why he was there. In his drab clothes, they seemed to take him for someone running an errand for the innkeeper when he came in. But there had been three sul'dam among the Seanchan, two with damane. He was beginning to be afraid he would have to leave Teslyn and Edesina collared, and he just did not want to look at damane right then. Blood and bloody ashes, he had only promised to try!

ðə wik sʌn stɪl stʊd haɪ ɪn ðə skaɪ, bʌt ðə si wɪnd wɑz pɪkɪŋ ʌp, fʊl ə sɔlt ən ə koʊl pɹɑməs ə ɹeɪn. ɪksɛp fəɹ ə skwɑɾ ə dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹdz mɑɹtʃɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə skwɛɹ, hjumənz ɹæðɝ ðən oʊɡiɝ, ɛvɹiwʌn ɪn ðə mɔl hɛɹə wɑz hɝiɪŋ tə bi dʌn wɪð wʌtɛvɝ ðeɪ wɝ əbaʊt bɪfɔɹ ðə ɹeɪn keɪm. əz i ɹitʃt ðə beɪs ə kwin nɑɹaɪnz tɔl bɛɹ-bɹɛstəd stætʃu, ə hæn fɛl ɑn ɪz ʃoʊldɝ.

The weak sun still stood high in the sky, but the sea wind was picking up, full of salt and a cold promise of rain. Except for a squad of Deathwatch Guards marching across the square, humans rather than Ogier, everyone in the Mol Hara was hurrying to be done with whatever they were about before the rain came. As he reached the base of Queen Nariene's tall bare-breasted statue, a hand fell on his shoulder.

"aɪ dɪd noʊ ɹɛkəɡnaɪz jə ət fɝst, wɪθaʊt jəɹ fænsi kloʊðz, mæt kɔθən."

"I did no recognize you at first, without your fancy clothes, Mat Cauthon."

mæt tɝn tə faɪn hɪmsɛlf feɪsɪŋ ðə hɛvisɛɾ ɪliɑnɝ sɔɪhɪn i hæd sin ðə deɪ dʒoʊlin ɹiəpɪɹɾ ɪn ɪz laɪf. ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ə plɛzən əsoʊsieɪʃən. ðə ɹaʊnd-feɪs fɛloʊ dɪd lʊk ɑd, bɪtwin ðət bɪɹɾ ən hæf ðə hɛɹ ɑn ɪz hɛd mɪsɪŋ, ən i wɑz ʃɪvɝɪŋ ɪn ɪz ʃɝtslivz, ʌv ɔl θɪŋz.

Mat turned to find himself facing the heavyset Illianer so'jhin he had seen the day Joline reappeared in his life. It was not a pleasant association. The round-faced fellow did look odd, between that beard and half the hair on his head missing, and he was shivering in his shirtsleeves, of all things.

"ju noʊ mi?" mæt sɛd kɔʃəsli.

"You know me?" Mat said cautiously.

ðə hɛvisɛt mæn bimd ə waɪd smaɪl ət hɪm. "fɔɹtʃən pɹɪk mi, aɪ du. jə dɪd teɪk ə mɛmɝəbəl vɔɪədʒ ɑn maɪ ʃɪp, wʌns, wɪð tʃɹɑləks ən ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ ət wʌn ɛn ən ə mɹdʒɹɑl ən waɪtbɹɪdʒ ɪn fleɪmz ət ði ʌðɝ. beɪl doʊmən, mæstɝ kɔθən. dʒju ɹɪmɛmbɝ mi naʊ?"

The heavyset man beamed a wide smile at him. "Fortune prick me, I do. You did take a memorable voyage on my ship, once, with Trollocs and Shadar Logoth at one end and a Myrddraal and Whitebridge in flames at the other. Bayle Domon, Master Cauthon. Do you remember me now?"

"aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ." hi dɪd, æftɝ ə fæʃən. moʊst ə ðət vɔɪədʒ wɑz veɪɡ ɪn ɪz hɛd, tæɾɝd baɪ ðə hoʊlz ðoʊz ʌðɝ mɛnz mɛmɹiz hæd fɪld. "wil əv tə sɪt daʊn oʊvɝ hɑt spaɪst waɪn səm taɪm ən tɔk oʊvɝ oʊl taɪmz." wɪtʃ wəd nɛvɝ hæpən ɪf i sɔ doʊmən fɝst. wʌt ɹɪmeɪn ɪn ɪz mɛmɹi ʌv ðət vɔɪədʒ wɑz stʃɹeɪnʒli ənplɛzənt, laɪk ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ ə dɛθli ɪlnəs. ʌv kɔɹs, hi hæd bɪn ɪl, ɪn ə weɪ. ənʌðɝ ənplɛzən mɛmɹi.

"I remember." He did, after a fashion. Most of that voyage was vague in his head, tattered by the holes those other men's memories had filled. "We'll have to sit down over hot spiced wine some time and talk over old times." Which would never happen if he saw Domon first. What remained in his memory of that voyage was strangely unpleasant, like remembering a deathly illness. Of course, he had been ill, in a way. Another unpleasant memory.

"ðɛɹ bi noʊ taɪm laɪk naʊ," doʊmən læft, swɪŋɪŋ ə θɪk ɑɹm ɝaʊn mæts ʃoʊldɝz ən tɝnɪŋ ɪm bæk təwɔɹd ðə wɑndɝɪŋ wʊmən.

"There be no time like now," Domon laughed, swinging a thick arm around Mat's shoulders and turning him back toward The Wandering Woman.

ʃɔɹɾ ə faɪɾɪŋ, ðəɹ sim tə bi noʊ weɪ tə ɪskeɪp ðə mæn, soʊ mæt wɛnt. ə nɑk-daʊn faɪt wɑz noʊ weɪ tə əvɔɪd biɪŋ noʊɾəst. ɛniweɪ, hi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ i wəd wɪn. doʊmən lʊk fæt, bʌt ðə fæt wɑz leɪɝɾ oʊvɝ hɑɹd mʌsəl. ə dʒɹɪŋk wəd nɑt ɡoʊ əmɪs ɪn ɛni keɪs. bɪsaɪdz wɪtʃ, hædn doʊmən bɪn sʌmθɪŋ ʌv ə smʌɡəlɝ? hi maɪt noʊ pæðz ɪn ən aʊɾ ʌv ɛbu dɑɹ ðəɾ ʌðɝz dɪd nɑt, ən i maɪt ɹɪvil əm tə ə lɪɾəl dʒudɪʃəs kwɛstʃənɪŋ. ɪspɛʃli oʊvɝ waɪn. ə fæt pɝs ʌv ɡoʊld leɪ ɪn mæts koʊt pɑkət, ən i dɪd nɑt maɪn spɛndɪŋ ɪɾ ɔl tə ɡɛt ðə mæn dʒɹʌŋk əz ə fɪɾəlɝ ət sʌndeɪ. dʒɹʌŋk mɛn tɔkt.

Short of fighting, there seemed to be no way to escape the man, so Mat went. A knock-down fight was no way to avoid being noticed. Anyway, he was not sure he would win. Domon looked fat, but the fat was layered over hard muscle. A drink would not go amiss in any case. Besides which, hadn't Domon been something of a smuggler? He might know paths in and out of Ebou Dar that others did not, and he might reveal them to a little judicious questioning. Especially over wine. A fat purse of gold lay in Mat's coat pocket, and he did not mind spending it all to get the man drunk as a fiddler at Sunday. Drunk men talked.

doʊmən hʌsəld ɪm θɹu ðə kɑmən ɹum, boʊɪŋ lɛft ən ɹaɪt tə blʌɾ ən ɔfəsɝz u bɛɹli sɔ hɪm ɪf ðæt, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑɾ ɛntɝ ðə kɪtʃənz, wɛɹ inɪd maɪɾ əv ɡɪvən əm ə bɛntʃ ɪn ðə kɔɹnɝ. ɪnstɛd, hi tʊk mæt ʌp ðə ɹeɪləs stɛɹz. əntɪl i ʌʃɝd mæt ɪndə ə ɹum ət ðə bæk ə ði ɪn, mæt əsum doʊmən wɑz gɑnə fɛtʃ ɪz koʊɾ ən kloʊk. ə ɡʊd faɪɝ bleɪzɪŋ ɑn ðə hɑɹθ wɔɹm ðə ɹum, bʌt mæt sʌɾənli fɛl koʊldɝ ðən i hæɾ aʊtsaɪd.

Domon hustled him through the common room, bowing left and right to Blood and officers who barely saw him if that, but he did not enter the kitchens, where Enid might have given them a bench in the corner. Instead, he took Mat up the railless stairs. Until he ushered Mat into a room at the back of the inn, Mat assumed Domon was going to fetch his coat and cloak. A good fire blazing on the hearth warmed the room, but Mat suddenly felt colder than he had outside.

kloʊzɪŋ ðə dɔɹ bɪhaɪn ðɛm, doʊmən plæntəd hɪmsɛlf ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ɪt wɪð ɪz ɑɹmz foʊldəɾ əkɹɔs ɪz tʃɛst. "ju də bi ɪn ðə pɹɛzəns ə kæptən ə ðə ɡɹin leɪɾi ɛdʒiənɪn tæmɝəθ," hi ɪntoʊnd, ðən æɾəd ɪn ə mɔɹ nɔɹməl toʊn, "ðɪs bi mæt kɔθən."

Closing the door behind them, Domon planted himself in front of it with his arms folded across his chest. "You do be in the presence of Captain of the Green Lady Egeanin Tamarath," he intoned, then added in a more normal tone, "This be Mat Cauthon."

mæt lʊk fɹəm doʊmən tə ðə tɔl wʊmən siɾəd stɪfli ɑn ə læɾɝ-bækt tʃɛɹ. hɝ pliɾɪd dʒɹɛs wɑz peɪl jɛloʊ tədeɪ, ən ʃi wɔɹ ə flaʊɝ-ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd ɹoʊb oʊvɝ ɪt, bʌɾ i ɹɪmɛmbɝd hɝ. hɝ peɪl feɪs wɑz hɑɹd, ən əɹ blu aɪz wɝ ɛvɹi bɪɾ əz pɹɛɾətɔɹi əz taɪlɪnz. oʊnli, hi səspɛktəɾ ɛdʒiənɪn wɑz nɑɾ æftɝ kɪsəz. hɝ hænz wɝ slɛndɝ, bʌt ðeɪ hæd sɔɝdzmənz kælʌsɪz. hi hæd noʊ tʃæns tə æsk wʌt ðɪs wɑz əbaʊt, ən noʊ nid.

Mat looked from Domon to the tall woman seated stiffly on a ladder-backed chair. Her pleated dress was pale yellow today, and she wore a flower-embroidered robe over it, but he remembered her. Her pale face was hard, and her blue eyes were every bit as predatory as Tylin's. Only, he suspected Egeanin was not after kisses. Her hands were slender, but they had swordsman's calluses. He had no chance to ask what this was about, and no need.

"maɪ sɔɪhɪn ɪnfɔɹmz mi jə ɑɹ nɑɾ ʌnfəmɪljɝ wɪð deɪnʒɝ, mæstɝ kɔθən," ʃi sɛɾ əz sun əz doʊmən fɪnɪʃt spikɪŋ. hɝ sloʊ sintʃæn dʒɹɔl stɪl saʊndəd pɝɛmptɝi ən kəmændɪŋ, bʌt ðɛn, ʃi wɑz ə ðə blʌd. "aɪ nid sətʃ mɛn tə kɹu ə ʃɪp, ən əl peɪ wɛl, ɪn ɡoʊl nɑt sɪlvɝ. ɪf jə noʊ ʌðɝz laɪk jɝsɛlf, əl haɪɝ ðɛm. ðeɪ mʌs bi eɪbəl tə hoʊl ðɛɹ tʌŋz, ðoʊ. maɪ bɪznəs ɪz maɪ oʊn. beɪl mɛnʃən tu ʌðɝ neɪmz. tɑm mɛɹɪlɪn ən dʒulɪn sændɑɹ. ɪf iðɝ ɪz hɪɹ ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ, aɪ kən juz ðɛɹ skɪlz, əz wɛl. ðeɪ noʊ mi, ən noʊ ðeɪ kən tʃɹʌs mi wɪð ðɛɹ lɪvz. soʊ kən ju, mæstɝ kɔθən."

"My so'jhin informs me you are not unfamiliar with danger, Master Cauthon," she said as soon as Domon finished speaking. Her slow Seanchan drawl still sounded peremptory and commanding, but then, she was of the Blood. "I need such men to crew a ship, and I will pay well, in gold not silver. If you know others like yourself, I will hire them. They must be able to hold their tongues, though. My business is my own. Bayle mentioned two other names. Thom Merrilin and Juilin Sandar. If either is here in Ebou Dar, I can use their skills, as well. They know me, and know they can trust me with their lives. So can you, Master Cauthon."

mæt sæt daʊn ɑn ðə ɹumz sɛkən tʃɛɹ ən θɹu bæk ɪz kloʊk. hi wɑz nɑt səpoʊz tə sɪɾ ivən wɪð wʌn ə ðə lɛsɝ blʌd - əz əɹ dɑɹk boʊl-kʌt hɛɹ ən ɡɹin-lækɝd lɪɾəl fɪŋɡɝneɪlz pɹoʊkleɪmd əɹ tə bi - bʌɾ i niɾəd tə θɪŋk. "ju hæv ə ʃɪp?" hi æskt, ɪn ðə meɪn tə ɡeɪn taɪm. ʃi oʊpən əɹ maʊθ æŋɡɹəli. æskɪŋ kwɛstʃənz ə ðə blʌd wɑz səpoʊz tə bi dʌn dɛləkətli.

Mat sat down on the room's second chair and threw back his cloak. He was not supposed to sit even with one of the lesser Blood - as her dark bowl-cut hair and green-lacquered little fingernails proclaimed her to be - but he needed to think. "You have a ship?" he asked, in the main to gain time. She opened her mouth angrily. Asking questions of the Blood was supposed to be done delicately.

doʊmən ɡɹʌntɪɾ ən ʃʊk ɪz hɛd, ən fəɹ ə moʊmənt ʃi lʊkt ivən æŋɡɹiɝ, bʌt ðən əɹ stɝn feɪs smuðd. ɑn ði ʌðɝ hænd, hɝ aɪz bɔɹɾ ɪndə mæt laɪk ɔɡɝz, ən ʃi ɹoʊz tə stænd wɪð əɹ fiɾ əpɑɹɾ ən əɹ hænz ɑn əɹ hɪps, kənfɹʌntɪŋ hɪm. "aɪ wɪl əv ə vɛsəl baɪ ði ɛn ə spɹɪŋ ət leɪɾəst, əz sun əz maɪ ɡoʊl kən bi bɹɔt fɹəm kæntʃɹɪn," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn ən aɪsi vɔɪs.

Domon grunted and shook his head, and for a moment she looked even angrier, but then her stern face smoothed. On the other hand, her eyes bored into Mat like augers, and she rose to stand with her feet apart and her hands on her hips, confronting him. "I will have a vessel by the end of spring at latest, as soon as my gold can be brought from Cantorin," she said in an icy voice.

mæt saɪd. wɛl, ðəɹ ɹɪli hæd bɪn noʊ tʃæns i kəd teɪk ɛɛs sədaɪ aʊɾ ɑn ə ʃɪp oʊn baɪ ə sintʃæn, nɑt ɹɪli. "haʊ dʒju noʊ tɑm ən dʒulɪn?" doʊmən cʊɾə toʊld əɹ əbaʊt tɑm, sɝɾənli, bʌt, laɪt, haʊ kəd ʃi noʊ dʒulɪn?

Mat sighed. Well, there really had been no chance he could take Aes Sedai out on a ship owned by a Seanchan, not really. "How do you know Thom and Juilin?" Domon could have told her about Thom, certainly, but, Light, how could she know Juilin?

"ju æsk tu mɛni kwɛstʃənz," ʃi sɛd fɝmli, tɝnɪŋ əweɪ. "aɪ fɪɹ aɪ kænɑt juz jə æftɝ ɔl. beɪl, pʊɾ ɪm aʊt." ðə læst wɑz ə pɝɛmptɝi kəmænd.

"You ask too many questions," she said firmly, turning away. "I fear I cannot use you after all. Bayle, put him out." The last was a peremptory command.

doʊmən dɪd nɑt muv fɹəm ðə dɔɹ. "tɛl hɪm," hi ɝdʒ hɝ. "sun əɹ leɪt, hi mʌs noʊ ɛvɹiθɪŋ əɹ hɪl pʊt jə ɪn ɡɹeɪɾɝ deɪnʒɝ ðən jə feɪs naʊ. tɛl hɪm." ivən fəɹ ə sɔɪhɪn, hi sim tə ɡɛɾ əweɪ wɪð ə ɡɹeɪt dil. ðə sintʃæn wɝ ɡɹeɪt wʌnz fəɹ pɹɑpɝɾi kipɪŋ ɪts pleɪs. fəɹ ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls kipɪŋ ðɛɹz, fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ. ɛdʒiənɪn mʌs nɑt bi ə kɔɹɾɝ əz tʌf əz ʃi lʊkt.

Domon did not move from the door. "Tell him," he urged her. "Soon or late, he must know everything or he will put you in greater danger than you face now. Tell him." Even for a so'jhin, he seemed to get away with a great deal. The Seanchan were great ones for property keeping its place. For everyone else keeping theirs, for that matter. Egeanin must not be a quarter as tough as she looked.

ʃi lʊk vɛɹi tʌf ət ðə moʊmənt, kɪkɪŋ əɹ skɝts ən stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ bæk ən fɔɹθ, skaʊlɪŋ ət doʊmən, ət mæt. faɪnəli, ʃi stɑpt. "aɪ ɡeɪv əm səm smɔl eɪɾ ɪn tæntʃəkoʊ," ʃi sɛd. æftɝ ə moʊmənt ʃi æɾəd, "æn tu wɪmən u wɝ wɪð ðɛm, ɪleɪn tʃɹəkən ən nɪneɪiv ɑlmɹə." hɝ aɪz foʊkəst ɑn ɪm ɪntɛnli, wɑtʃɪŋ tə si wɛðɝ i nu ðə neɪmz.

She looked very tough at the moment, kicking her skirts and striding back and forth, scowling at Domon, at Mat. Finally, she stopped. "I gave them some small aid in Tanchico," she said. After a moment she added, "And two women who were with them, Elayne Trakand and Nynaeve al'Meara." Her eyes focused on him intently, watching to see whether he knew the names.

mæts tʃɛs fɛl taɪt. ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ə peɪn, bʌt mɔɹ laɪk wɑtʃɪŋ ə hɔɹs i hæd bɛɾ ɑn stʃɹik təwɔɹd ðə fɪnɪʃ laɪn wɪð ʌðɝz kloʊs bɪhaɪn ən ðə kwɛstʃən stɪl ɪn daʊt. wʌɾ ɪn ðə laɪt hæd nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn bɪn ʌp tə ɪn tæntʃəkoʊ ðət ðeɪ hæd niɾəd ə sintʃænz hɛlp, ən hæd ɡɑɾən ɪt? tɑm ən dʒulɪn hæd bɪn kloʊsəməðd əbaʊt ðə dɪteɪlz. ðət wɑz bɪsaɪd ðə pɔɪnt, ɛniweɪ. ɛdʒiənɪn wɑntəd mɛn u kəd kip əɹ sikɹəts ən dɪd nɑt maɪn deɪnʒɝ. ʃi hɝsɛlf wɑz ɪn deɪnʒɝ. vɛɹi lɪɾəl wɑz deɪnʒɝəs tə wʌn ə ðə blʌd, ɪksɛp fəɹ ʌðɝ blʌɾ ən . . . "ðə sikɝz ɑɹ æftɝ ju," hi sɛd.

Mat's chest felt tight. It was not a pain, but more like watching a horse he had bet on streak toward the finish line with others close behind and the question still in doubt. What in the Light had Nynaeve and Elayne been up to in Tanchico that they had needed a Seanchan's help, and had gotten it? Thom and Juilin had been closemouthed about the details. That was beside the point, anyway. Egeanin wanted men who could keep her secrets and did not mind danger. She herself was in danger. Very little was dangerous to one of the Blood, except for other Blood and . . . "The Seekers are after you," he said.

ðə weɪ hɝ hɛd keɪm ʌp wɑz kɑnfɝmeɪʃən ɪnʌf, ən əɹ hænd wɛn tə hɝ saɪɾ əz ðoʊ ɹitʃɪŋ fəɹ ə sɔɹd. doʊmən ʃɪftəɾ ɪz fiɾ ən flɛkst ɪz bɪɡ hænz, hɪz aɪz ɑn mæt. aɪz sʌɾənli hɑɹɾɝ ðən ɛdʒiənɪnz. ðə θɪk mæn noʊ lɔŋɡɝ lʊk fʌni; hi lʊk deɪnʒɝəs. əbɹʌpli ɪt keɪm tə mæt ðəɾ i maɪt nɑt liv ðə ɹum əlaɪv.

The way her head came up was confirmation enough, and her hand went to her side as though reaching for a sword. Domon shifted his feet and flexed his big hands, his eyes on Mat. Eyes suddenly harder than Egeanin's. The thick man no longer looked funny; he looked dangerous. Abruptly it came to Mat that he might not leave the room alive.

"ɪf jə nid tə ɡɛɾ əweɪ fɹəm ðə sikɝz, aɪ kən hɛlp ju," hi sɛd kwɪkli. "jul əv tə ɡoʊ wɛɹ ðə sintʃæn ɑɹən ɪn kəntʃɹoʊl. ɛniwɛɹ ðeɪ ɑɹ, ðə sikɝz kən faɪn ju. ən ɪts bɛs tə ɡoʊ əz sun əz pɑsəbəl. jə kən ɔlweɪz ɡɛt mɔɹ ɡoʊld. ɪf ðə sikɝz doʊn teɪk jə fɝst. tɑm tɛlz mi ðəɹ ɡɛɾɪŋ vɛɹi æktɪv əbaʊt sʌmθɪŋ. hiɾɪŋ ði aɪɝnz ən ɡɛɾɪŋ ðə ɹæk ɹɛɾi."

"If you need to get away from the Seekers, I can help you," he said quickly. "You'll have to go where the Seanchan aren't in control. Anywhere they are, the Seekers can find you. And it's best to go as soon as possible. You can always get more gold. If the Seekers don't take you first. Thom tells me they're getting very active about something. Heating the irons and getting the rack ready."

fəɹ ə taɪm ɛdʒiənɪn stʊd moʊʃənləs, stɛɹɪŋ ət hɪm. ət læst, ʃi ɪkstʃeɪnʒd ə lɔŋ lʊk wɪð doʊmən. "pɝhæps ɪt wəd bi wɛl tə liv əz sun əz pɑsəbəl," ʃi bɹiðd. hɝ toʊn fɝmd ɪmiɾiətli, ðoʊ. ɪf ðəɹ hæd bɪn wɝi ɑn əɹ feɪs fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ɪt vænɪʃt. "ðə sikɝz wɪl nɑt stɑp mi livɪŋ ðə sɪɾi, aɪ θɪŋk, bʌt ðeɪ θɪŋk ðeɪ kən fɑloʊ mi tə sʌmθɪŋ ðeɪ wɑn mɔɹ ðən ðeɪ wɑn mi. ðəl fɑloʊ mi, ən əntɪl aɪ liv ðə lænz ɔlɹɛɾi hɛl baɪ ðə ɹaɪædʒɛl, ðeɪ kən kɔl ɑn soʊlʒɝz tə ɝɛs mi, wɪtʃ ðəl əz sun əz ðeɪ dɪsaɪɾ aɪm ɡoʊɪŋ tə lænz nɑt jɛt ɡæðɝd. ðəɾ ɪz wən əl nid ðə skɪlz ə jəɹ fɹɛn tɑm mɛɹɪlɪn, mæstɝ kɔθən. bɪtwin hɪɹ ən ðɛɹ, aɪ mʌs vænɪʃ fɹəm ðə sikɝz' saɪt. aɪ meɪ nɑɾ əv ðə ɡoʊl fɹəm kæntʃɹɪn, bʌɾ aɪ hæv ɪnʌf tə ɹɪwɔɹd jəɹ hɛlp hænsəmli. jə kən ɹɛst əʃʊɹɾ ə ðæt."

For a time Egeanin stood motionless, staring at him. At last, she exchanged a long look with Domon. "Perhaps it would be well to leave as soon as possible," she breathed. Her tone firmed immediately, though. If there had been worry on her face for a moment, it vanished. "The Seekers will not stop me leaving the city, I think, but they think they can follow me to something they want more than they want me. They will follow me, and until I leave the lands already held by the Rhyagelle, they can call on soldiers to arrest me, which they will as soon as they decide I am going to lands not yet gathered. That is when I will need the skills of your friend Thom Merrilin, Master Cauthon. Between here and there, I must vanish from the Seekers' sight. I may not have the gold from Cantorin, but I have enough to reward your help handsomely. You can rest assured of that."

"kɔl mi mæt," hi sɛd, ɡɪvɪŋ əɹ ɪz vɛɹi bɛst smaɪl. ivən hɑɹd-feɪst wɪmən sɔfən fəɹ ɪz bɛst smaɪl. wɛl, ʃi dɪd nɑt sɑfən vɪzəbli - ɪf ɛniθɪŋ, ʃi fɹaʊn slaɪtli - bʌt wʌn θɪŋ i dɪd noʊ əbaʊt wɪmən wɑz ði ɪfɛkt ɪz smaɪlz hæd. "aɪ noʊ haʊ tə meɪk jə vænɪʃ naʊ. noʊ jus weɪɾɪŋ, jə noʊ. ðə sikɝz maɪt dɪsaɪd tə ɝɛs jə təmɑɹoʊ." ðət hɪt hoʊm. ʃi dɪd nɑt flɪntʃ - hi səspɛktəd vɛɹi lɪɾəl meɪɾ əɹ flɪntʃ - bʌt ʃi ɔlmoʊs nɑɾəd. "ðɛɹ ɪz dʒʌst wʌn θɪŋ, ɛdʒiənɪn." ðɪs stɪl kəd bloʊ ʌp ɪn ɪz feɪs laɪk wʌn ʌv ɑlʌdʒɹəz faɪɹwɝks, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt hɛzəteɪt. səmtaɪmz, jə dʒʌs hæd tə tɔs ðə daɪs. "aɪ doʊnt niɾ ɛni ɡoʊld, bʌɾ aɪ də hæv niɾ ə θɹi sʌldəm u wɪl kip ðɛɹ maʊðz ʃʌt. dʒju θɪŋk jə səplaɪ kəd ðoʊz?"

"Call me Mat," he said, giving her his very best smile. Even hard-faced women softened for his best smile. Well, she did not soften visibly - if anything, she frowned slightly - but one thing he did know about women was the effect his smiles had. "I know how to make you vanish now. No use waiting, you know. The Seekers might decide to arrest you tomorrow." That hit home. She did not flinch - he suspected very little made her flinch - but she almost nodded. "There is just one thing, Egeanin." This still could blow up in his face like one of Aludra's fireworks, but he did not hesitate. Sometimes, you just had to toss the dice. "I don't need any gold, but I do have need of three sul'dam who will keep their mouths shut. Do you think you supply could those?"

æftɝ ə moʊmən ðət sim tə stʃɹɛtʃ aʊɝz, ʃi nɑɾəd, ən i smaɪl tə hɪmsɛlf. hɪz hɔɹs hæd kɹɔs fɝst.

After a moment that seemed to stretch hours, she nodded, and he smiled to himself. His horse had crossed first.

"doʊmən," tɑm sɛɾ ɪn ə flæt vɔɪs ɝaʊn ðə paɪpɛstəm klɛntʃt bɪtwin ɪz tiθ. hi wɑz laɪɪŋ wɪð ə θɪn pɪloʊ dʌbəld ʌp bɪniθ ɪz hɛd, ən i sim tə bi stʌɾiɪŋ ðə feɪn blu heɪz ðət hʌŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ ə ðə wɪndoʊləs ɹum. ðə sɪŋɡəl læmp ɡeɪv ə fɪtfəl laɪt. "æn ɛdʒiənɪn."

"Domon," Thom said in a flat voice around the pipestem clenched between his teeth. He was lying with a thin pillow doubled up beneath his head, and he seemed to be studying the faint blue haze that hung in the air of the windowless room. The single lamp gave a fitful light. "And Egeanin."

"ænd ʃiz ə ðə blʌd, naʊ." sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ði ɛdʒ ə hɪz bɛd, dʒulɪn pɪɹɾ ɪndə ðə tʃɑɹd boʊl ə hɪz paɪp. "aɪ də nɑt noʊ əz aɪ laɪk ðæt."

"And she is of the Blood, now." Sitting on the edge of his bed, Juilin peered into the charred bowl of his pipe. "I do not know as I like that."

"ɑɹ jə seɪɪŋ wi kæn tʃɹʌs ðɛm?" mæt dɪmændəd, tæmpɪŋ daʊn ɪz təbæk wɪð ə kɛɹləs θʌm. hi snætʃt ɪz θʌm aʊt wɪð ə maɪld oʊθ ən stʌk ɪɾ ɪn ɪz maʊθ tə sʌk ðə bɝn əweɪ. jɛɾ əɡɛn i hæd ðə tʃɔɪs ə ðə stul əɹ stændɪŋ, bʌt fəɹ wʌns i dɪd nɑt maɪn ðə stul. dilɪŋ wɪð ɛdʒiənɪn hæd teɪkən lɪɾəl ɪnʌf ə ði æftɝnun, bʌt tɑm hæd bɪn aʊɾ ə ðə pæləs əntɪl æftɝ dɑɹk, waɪl dʒulɪn hæd teɪkən ivən lɔŋɡɝ tə əpɪɹ. niðɝ əpɪɹd nɪɹli əz plizd wɪð mæts nuz əz i ɪkspɛktəd. tɑm hæd dʒʌst saɪd ðəɾ i hæd faɪnəli ɡɑɾən ə ɡʊd lʊk ət wʌn ə ði æksɛptɪd silz, bʌt dʒulɪn ɡlaʊɝd wɛnɛvɝ i lʊkt ət ðə bʌndəl laɪɪŋ ɪn ðə kɔɹnɝ ə ðə ɹum wɛɹ i hæd hɝld ɪt. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ blʌɾi nid fəɹ ðə mæn tə kæɹi ɑn soʊ dʒʌs kəz ðeɪ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ niɾəd ðə sʌldəm dʒɹɛsəz. "aɪ tɛl ju, ðəɹ boʊθ skɛɹd spɪtləs oʊvɝ ðə sikɝz," mæt wɛn ɑn wən ɪz θʌm wɑz kuld. meɪbi nɑɾ ɪɡzækli spɪtləs, bʌt fɹaɪɾənd nʌnðəlɛs. "ɛdʒiənɪn meɪ bi blʌd, bʌt ʃi nɛvɝ twɪtʃt ən aɪləd wən aɪ toʊld əɹ wʌɾ aɪ wɑntəd sʌldəm fɔɹ. ʃi dʒʌst sɛd ʃi nu θɹi hu wəd də wʌt wi nid, ən ʃi kəɾ əv əm ɹɛɾi təmɑɹoʊ."

"Are you saying we can't trust them?" Mat demanded, tamping down his tabac with a careless thumb. He snatched his thumb out with a mild oath and stuck it in his mouth to suck the burn away. Yet again he had the choice of the stool or standing, but for once he did not mind the stool. Dealing with Egeanin had taken little enough of the afternoon, but Thom had been out of the Palace until after dark, while Juilin had taken even longer to appear. Neither appeared nearly as pleased with Mat's news as he expected. Thom had just sighed that he had finally gotten a good look at one of the accepted seals, but Juilin glowered whenever he looked at the bundle lying in the corner of the room where he had hurled it. There was no bloody need for the man to carry on so just because they no longer needed the sul'dam dresses. "I tell you, they're both scared spitless over the Seekers," Mat went on when his thumb was cooled. Maybe not exactly spitless, but frightened nonetheless. "Egeanin may be Blood, but she never twitched an eyelid when I told her what I wanted sul'dam for. She just said she knew three who would do what we need, and she could have them ready tomorrow."

"æn ɑnɝəbəl wʊmən, ɛdʒiənɪn," tɑm mjuzd. ɛvɹi soʊ ɔfən i pɔz tə bloʊ ə smoʊk ɹɪŋ. "ɑd, tʃɹu, bʌt ðɛn, ʃiz sintʃæn. aɪ θɪŋk ivən nɪneɪiv keɪm tə laɪk hɝ, ən aɪ noʊ ɪleɪn dɪd. ən ʃi laɪk ðɛm. ivən ɪf ðeɪ wɝ ɛɛs sədaɪ, əz ʃi bɪlivd. ʃi wɑz vɛɹi jusfəl ɪn tæntʃəkoʊ. vɛɹi jusfəl. mɔɹ ðən mɪɹli kɑmpəɾənt. aɪ tʃɹuli wəd laɪk tə noʊ haʊ ʃi keɪm bi ɹeɪz tə ðə blʌd, bʌt jɛs, aɪ bɪliv wi kən tʃɹʌst ɛdʒiənɪn. ən doʊmən. ən ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ mæn, doʊmən."

"An honorable woman, Egeanin," Thom mused. Every so often he paused to blow a smoke ring. "Odd, true, but then, she is Seanchan. I think even Nynaeve came to like her, and I know Elayne did. And she liked them. Even if they were Aes Sedai, as she believed. She was very useful in Tanchico. Very useful. More than merely competent. I truly would like to know how she came be raised to the Blood, but yes, I believe we can trust Egeanin. And Domon. An interesting man, Domon."

"ə smʌɡəlɝ," dʒulɪn mʌɾɝd dɪspɛɹɪdʒɪŋli. "ænd naʊ hi bɪlɔŋz tə hɝ. sɔɪhɪn ɑɹ mɔɹ ðən dʒʌs pɹɑpɝɾi, jə noʊ. ðəɹ ɑɹ sɔɪhɪn u tɛl blʌd wʌt tə du." tɑm ɹeɪzd ə ʃæɡi aɪbɹaʊ ət hɪm. dʒʌs ðæt, bʌɾ æftɝ ə moʊmənt, ðə θif-kætʃɝ ʃɹʌɡd. "aɪ səpoʊz doʊmən ɪz tʃɹʌstwɝði," hi sɛd ɹɪlʌktənli. "fɔɹ ə smʌɡəlɝ."

"A smuggler," Juilin muttered disparagingly. "And now he belongs to her. So'jhin are more than just property, you know. There are so'jhin who tell Blood what to do." Thom raised a shaggy eyebrow at him. Just that, but after a moment, the thief-catcher shrugged. "I suppose Domon is trustworthy," he said reluctantly. "For a smuggler."

mæt snɔɹɾɪd. meɪbi ðeɪ wɝ dʒɛləs. wɛl, hi wɑz tɑvɝən, ən ðeɪ hæd tə lɪv wɪð ɪt. "ðɛn təmɑɹoʊ naɪt, wi liv. ði oʊnli tʃeɪnʒ ɪn ðə plæn ɪz ðət wɪv θɹi ɹil sʌldəm ən wʌn ə ðə blʌd tə ɡɛɾ əs θɹu ðə ɡeɪts."

Mat snorted. Maybe they were jealous. Well, he was ta'veren, and they had to live with it. "Then tomorrow night, we leave. The only change in the plan is that we have three real sul'dam and one of the Blood to get us through the gates."

"æn ðiz sʌldəm ɑɹ gɑnə teɪk θɹi ɛɛs sədaɪ aʊɾ ə ðə sɪɾi, lɛɾ əm ɡoʊ, ən nɛvɝ θɪŋk ə ɹeɪzɪŋ ən əlɑɹm," dʒulɪn mʌɾɝd. "wʌns, waɪl ɹænd ælθɹ wɑz ɪn tɛɹ, aɪ sɔ ə tɔs kɔɪn læn ɑn ɪts ɛdʒ faɪv taɪmz ɪn ə ɹoʊ. wi faɪnəli wɔkt əweɪ ən lɛft ɪt stændɪŋ ðəɹ ɑn ðə teɪbəl. aɪ səpoʊz ɛniθɪŋ kən hæpən."

"And these sul'dam are going to take three Aes Sedai out of the city, let them go, and never think of raising an alarm," Juilin muttered. "Once, while Rand al'Thor was in Tear, I saw a tossed coin land on its edge five times in a row. We finally walked away and left it standing there on the table. I suppose anything can happen."

"iðɝ jə tʃɹʌst əm əɹ jə doʊnt, dʒulɪn," mæt ɡɹaʊld. ðə θif-kætʃɝ ɡlɛɹɾ ət ðə bʌndəl dʒɹɛsəz ɪn ðə kɔɹnɝ, ən mæt ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "wʌt dɪd ðeɪ də tə hɛlp jə ɪn tæntʃəkoʊ, tɑm? blʌɾ ən æʃəz, doʊn ðə tu ʌv jə ɡoʊ ɔl flæt-aɪɾ ɑn mi əɡɛn! jə noʊ, ən ðeɪ noʊ, ən aɪ maɪɾ əz wɛl."

"Either you trust them or you don't, Juilin," Mat growled. The thief-catcher glared at the bundled dresses in the corner, and Mat shook his head. "What did they do to help you in Tanchico, Thom? Blood and ashes, don't the two of you go all flat-eyed on me again! You know, and they know, and I might as well."

"nɪneɪiv sɛd nɑt tə tɛl ɛniwʌn," dʒulɪn sɛɾ əz ɪf ðət ɹɪli mæɾɝd. "ɪleɪn sɛd nɑt tə. wi pɹɑməst. jə maɪt seɪ wi swɔɹ ən oʊθ."

"Nynaeve said not to tell anyone," Juilin said as if that really mattered. "Elayne said not to. We promised. You might say we swore an oath."

tɑm ʃʊk ɪz hɛɾ ɑn ðə pɪloʊ. "sɝkəmstænsəz ɔltɝ keɪsəz, dʒulɪn. ən ɪn ɛni keɪs, ɪt wɑzn ən oʊθ." hi blu θɹi pɝfək smoʊk ɹɪŋz, wʌn ɪnsaɪd ði ʌðɝ. "ðeɪ hɛlpt əs əkwaɪɝ ən dɪspoʊz ʌv ə sɔɹɾ ə meɪl æɾəm, mæt. ðə blæk ədʒɑ əpɛɹənli wɑntəd tə juz ɪɾ ɑn ɹænd. jə kən si waɪ nɪneɪiv ən ɪleɪn wɑntəɾ ɪt kɛp kwaɪət. ɪf wɝd spɹɛd ðət sətʃ ə θɪŋ ɛvɝ ɪɡzɪstəd, ðə laɪt noʊz wʌt kaɪndə teɪlz wəd spɹɪŋ ʌp."

Thom shook his head on the pillow. "Circumstances alter cases, Juilin. And in any case, it wasn't an oath." He blew three perfect smoke rings, one inside the other. "They helped us acquire and dispose of a sort of male a'dam, Mat. The Black Ajah apparently wanted to use it on Rand. You can see why Nynaeve and Elayne wanted it kept quiet. If word spread that such a thing ever existed, the Light knows what kind of tales would spring up."

"hu kɛɹz wʌt stɔɹiz pipəl tɛl?" ə meɪl æɾəm? laɪt, ɪf ðə blæk ədʒɑ hæd ɡɑɾən ðəɾ ɑntu ɹændz nɛk, əɹ ðə sintʃæn hæd . . . ðoʊz kʌlɝz wɝl θɹu hɪz hɛɾ əɡɛn, ən i meɪd hɪmsɛlf stɑp θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt ɹænd. "ɡɑsəp ɪzən gɑnə hɝt . . . ɛnibəɾi." noʊ kʌlɝz ðət taɪm. hi kəɾ əvɔɪɾ ɪɾ əz lɔŋ əz i dɪd nɑt θɪŋk əbaʊt . . . ðə kʌlɝz swɝld əɡɛn, ən i ɡɹaʊn ɪz tiθ ɑn ɪz paɪpɛstəm.

"Who cares what stories people tell?" A male a'dam? Light, if the Black Ajah had gotten that onto Rand's neck, or the Seanchan had . . . Those colors whirled through his head again, and he made himself stop thinking about Rand. "Gossip isn't going to hurt . . . anybody." No colors that time. He could avoid it as long as he did not think about . . . The colors swirled again, and he ground his teeth on his pipestem.

"nɑt tʃɹu, mæt. stɔɹiz əv paʊɝ. ɡlimənz teɪlz, ən bɑɹdz' ɛpɪks, ən ɹumɝz ɪn ðə stʃɹiɾ əlaɪk. ðeɪ stɝ pæʃənz, ən tʃeɪnʒ ðə weɪ mɛn si ðə wɝld. tədeɪ, aɪ hɝɾ ə mæn seɪ ðət ɹænd hæd swɔɹn fiəlti tə ɪleɪɾə, ðəɾ i wɑz ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ. ðə fɛloʊ bɪlivd ɪt, mæt. wʌɾ ɪf, seɪ, ɪnʌf tɛɹənz bɪɡɪn tə bɪliv? tɛɹənz dɪslaɪk ɛɛs sədaɪ. kɝɛkt, dʒulɪn?"

"Not true, Mat. Stories have power. Gleemen's tales, and bards' epics, and rumors in the street alike. They stir passions, and change the way men see the world. Today, I heard a man say that Rand had sworn fealty to Elaida, that he was in the White Tower. The fellow believed it, Mat. What if, say, enough Tairens begin to believe? Tairens dislike Aes Sedai. Correct, Juilin?"

"sʌm du," dʒulɪn əlaʊd, ðən æɾəd əz ðoʊ tɑm hæd dʒɹæɡd ɪt fɹəm hɪm, "moʊs du. bʌt ɹaɪət mɛni ʌv əs əv mɛɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ, nɑt tə noʊ ɪt. ðeɪ weɪ ðə lɔ wɑz, fɝbɪɾɪŋ tʃænəlɪŋ, fju ɛɛs sədaɪ keɪm tə tɛɹ, ən ðeɪ vɛɹi sɛldəm ædvɝtaɪzd u ðeɪ wɝ."

"Some do," Juilin allowed, then added as though Thom had dragged it from him, "Most do. But riot many of us have met Aes Sedai, not to know it. They way the law was, forbidding channeling, few Aes Sedai came to Tear, and they very seldom advertised who they were."

"ðæts bɪsaɪd ðə pɔɪnt, maɪ faɪn ɛɛs sədaɪ-lʌvɪŋ tɛɹən fɹɛnd. ən ɪt ɡɪvz weɪt tə maɪ ɑɹɡjəmən ɪn ɛni ɪvɛnt. tɛɹ hoʊlz tə ɹænd, ðə noʊbəlz də ət list, kəz ðəɹ əfɹeɪɾ ɪf ðeɪ də nɑt, hɪl kʌm bæk, bʌɾ ɪf ðeɪ bɪliv ðə taʊɝ hoʊlz hɪm, ðən meɪbi hi kæn kʌm bæk. ɪf ðeɪ bɪliv hiz ə tul ə ðə taʊɝ, ɪts dʒʌst wʌn mɔɹ ɹizən fəɹ əm tə tɝn ɑn hɪm. lɛɾ ɪnʌf tɛɹənz bɪliv ðoʊz tu θɪŋz, ən i maɪɾ əz wɛl əv lɛf tiɹ əz sun əz i dʒɹu kælændɝ. ðəɾ ɪz dʒʌs ðə wʌn ɹumɝ, ən dʒʌs tiɹ, bʌɾ ɪt kəd də əz mʌtʃ hɑɹm ɪn kɛɹhin, əɹ ɪljən, əɹ ɛniwɛɹ. aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌt sɔɹɾ ə teɪlz maɪt spɹɪŋ fɹəm ə meɪl æɾəm, ɪn ə wɝld wɪð ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, ən æʃəmən, bʌɾ aɪm tu oʊl tə wɑnə faɪn aʊt."

"That's beside the point, my fine Aes Sedai-loving Tairen friend. And it gives weight to my argument in any event. Tear holds to Rand, the nobles do at least, because they're afraid if they do not, he'll come back, but if they believe the Tower holds him, then maybe he can't come back. If they believe he's a tool of the Tower, it is just one more reason for them to turn on him. Let enough Tairens believe those two things, and he might as well have left Tear as soon as he drew Callandor. That is just the one rumor, and just Tear, but it could do as much harm in Cairhien, or Illian, or anywhere. I don't know what sort of tales might spring from a male a'dam, in a world with the Dragon Reborn, and Asha'man, but I'm too old to want to find out."

mæt ʌndɝstʊd, ɪn ə mænɝ ə spikɪŋ. ə mæn ɔlweɪz tʃɹaɪd tə meɪk huɛvɝ wɑz kəmændɪŋ ðə tʃɹups əɡɛnst ɪm bɪliv ðəɾ i wɑz duɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ ʌðɝ ðən wʌɾ i wɑz, ðəɾ i wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ wɛɹ i hæd noʊ ɪntɛntʃən ʌv ɡoʊɪŋ, ən ði ɛnəmi tʃɹaɪd tə də ðə seɪm tə hɪm, ɪf ði ɛnəmi wɑz ɛni ɡʊɾ ət ðə kɹæft. səmtaɪmz boʊθ saɪdz kəd ɡɛt soʊ kənfjuz ðət vɛɹi stʃɹeɪnʒ θɪŋz hæpənd. tʃɹædʒəɾiz, səmtaɪmz. sɪɾiz bɝn ðət noʊ wʌn hæɾ ɛni ɪntʃɹəst ɪn bɝnɪŋ, ɪksɛp ðət ðə bɝnɝz bɪlivd wʌt wɑz əntʃɹu, ən θaʊzənz daɪd. kɹɑps dɪstʃɹɔɪd fəɹ ðə seɪm ɹizən, ən tɛnz ə θaʊzənz daɪɾ ɪn ðə fæmən ðət fɑloʊd.

Mat understood, in a manner of speaking. A man always tried to make whoever was commanding the troops against him believe that he was doing something other than what he was, that he was going where he had no intention of going, and the enemy tried to do the same to him, if the enemy was any good at the craft. Sometimes both sides could get so confused that very strange things happened. Tragedies, sometimes. Cities burned that no one had any interest in burning, except that the burners believed what was untrue, and thousands died. Crops destroyed for the same reason, and tens of thousands died in the famine that followed.

"soʊ aɪ woʊn kɹæk maɪ tiθ əbaʊt ðɪs æɾəm fəɹ mɛn," hi sɛd. "aɪ səpoʊz sʌmbɑɾi hæz θɔt tə tɛl . . . hɪm?" kʌlɝz flæʃt. meɪbi hi kəd dʒʌst ɪɡnɔɹ ðɛm, əɹ ɡɹoʊ juz tə ðɛm. ðeɪ wɝ ɡɔn əz fæst əz ðeɪ keɪm, ən ðeɪ dɪd nɑt hɝt. hi dʒʌs dɪd nɑt laɪk θɪŋz i kəd nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd. ɪspɛʃli wən ðeɪ maɪɾ əv tə də wɪð ðə paʊɝ ɪn səm weɪ. ðə sɪlvɝ fɑkshɛɾ ʌndɝ ɪz ʃɝt maɪt pɹətɛkt ɪm əɡɛns ðə paʊɝ, bʌt ðət pɹətɛkʃən hæɾ əz mɛni hoʊlz əz ɪz oʊn mɛmɹiz.

"So I won't crack my teeth about this a'dam for men," he said. "I suppose somebody has thought to tell . . . him?" Colors flashed. Maybe he could just ignore them, or grow used to them. They were gone as fast as they came, and they did not hurt. He just did not like things he could not understand. Especially when they might have to do with the Power in some way. The silver foxhead under his shirt might protect him against the Power, but that protection had as many holes as his own memories.

"wi hæv nɑɾ ɪɡzækli bɪn ɪn ɹɛɡjəlɝ kəmjunəkeɪʃən," tɑm sɛd dʒɹaɪli, wæɡəlɪŋ ɪz aɪbɹaʊz. "aɪ səpoʊz ɪleɪn ən nɪneɪiv əv faʊn səm weɪ tə lɛɾ ɪm noʊ, ɪf ðeɪ θɪŋk ɪɾ ɪmpɔɹɾənt."

"We have not exactly been in regular communication," Thom said dryly, waggling his eyebrows. "I suppose Elayne and Nynaeve have found some way to let him know, if they think it important."

"waɪ ʃəd ðeɪ?" dʒulɪn sɛd, bɛndɪŋ tə tʌɡ ɔf ə but wɪð ə ɡɹʌnt. "ðə θɪŋ ɪz ət ðə bɑɾəm ə ðə si." skaʊlɪŋ, hi hɝl ðə buɾ ət ðə bʌndəl dʒɹɛsəz ɪn ðə kɔɹnɝ. "ɑɹ jə gɑnə lɛɾ əs ɡɛɾ ɛni slip tənaɪt, mæt? aɪ doʊn θɪŋk wɪl əv ɛni təmɑɹoʊ naɪt, ən aɪ laɪk tə slip ət list ɛvɹi ʌðɝ naɪt."

"Why should they?" Juilin said, bending to tug off a boot with a grunt. "The thing is at the bottom of the sea." Scowling, he hurled the boot at the bundled dresses in the corner. "Are you going to let us get any sleep tonight, Mat? I don't think we'll have any tomorrow night, and I like to sleep at least every other night."

ðət naɪt, mæt tʃoʊz tə slip ɪn taɪlɪnz bɛd. nɑt fəɹ oʊl taɪmz' seɪk. ðət θɔt meɪɾ ɪm læf, ðoʊ hɪz læftɝ hæd tu mʌtʃ ə ðə saʊn ʌv ə wɪmpɝ tə bi vɛɹi fʌni. ɪt wɑz dʒʌs ðəɾ ə ɡʊd fɛðɝ mætʃɹəs ən ɡus-daʊn pɪloʊz wɝ pɹɛfɝəbəl tə ə heɪlɔft wən ə mæn dɪd nɑt noʊ wən ɪz nɛks disənt naɪts slip wəd kʌm.

That night, Mat chose to sleep in Tylin's bed. Not for old times' sake. That thought made him laugh, though his laughter had too much of the sound of a whimper to be very funny. It was just that a good feather mattress and goose-down pillows were preferable to a hayloft when a man did not know when his next decent night's sleep would come.

ðə tʃɹʌbəl wɑz ðəɾ i kəd nɑt slip. hi leɪ ðəɹ ɪn ðə dɑɹk wɪð ən ɑɹm bɪhaɪn ɪz hɛɾ ən ðə mədæljənz lɛðɝ kɔɹd lup θɹu ɪtsɛlf ɑn ɪz ɹɪst, ɹɛɾi tə hæn ɪn keɪs ðə ɡoʊləm slɪd θɹu ðə kɹæk ʌndɝ ðə dɔɹ, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz nɑt ðə ɡoʊləm ðət kɛpt ɪm əweɪk. hi kəd nɑt stɑp ɡoʊɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə plæn ɪn ɪz hɛd. ɪt wɑz ə ɡʊd plæn, ən sɪmpəl; əz sɪmpəl əz ɪt kəd bi, ɪn ðə sɝkəmstænsəz. oʊnli, noʊ bæɾəl ɛvɝ wɛn əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə plæn, ivən ðə bɛst. ɡɹeɪt kæptənz ɝn ðɛɹ ɹɛpjəteɪʃən nɑt dʒʌs fəɹ leɪɪŋ bɹɪljən plænz, bʌt fəɹ stɪl biɪŋ eɪbəl tə faɪn vɪktɝi æftɝ ðoʊz plænz bɪɡæn tə fɔl əpɑɹt. soʊ wən fɝs laɪɾ ɪlumən ðə wɪndoʊz, hi wɑz stɪl laɪɪŋ ðɛɹ, ɹoʊlɪŋ ðə mədæljən əkɹɔs ðə bæk ə hɪz fɪŋɡɝz ən tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə θɪŋk ʌv wʌt wɑz gɑnə ɡoʊ ɹɔŋ.

The trouble was that he could not sleep. He lay there in the dark with an arm behind his head and the medallion's leather cord looped through itself on his wrist, ready to hand in case the gholam slid through the crack under the door, but it was not the gholam that kept him awake. He could not stop going over the plan in his head. It was a good plan, and simple; as simple as it could be, in the circumstances. Only, no battle ever went according to plan, even the best. Great captains earned their reputation not just for laying brilliant plans, but for still being able to find victory after those plans began to fall apart. So when first light illumined the windows, he was still lying there, rolling the medallion across the back of his fingers and trying to think of what was going to go wrong.


tʃæptɝ θɝɾi


CHAPTER 30

koʊld, fæt ɹeɪndʒɹɑps


Cold, Fat Raindrops

ðə deɪ dɔn koʊld, wɪð ɡɹeɪ klaʊdz ðəɾ əbskjʊɹd ðə ɹaɪzɪŋ sʌn ən wɪnz ɔf ðə si ʌv stɔɹmz ðət ɹæɾəld lus peɪnz ʌv ɡlæs ɪn ðə wɪndoʊ keɪsməns. ɪn stɔɹiz, nɑt ðə sɔɹɾ ə deɪ fəɹ ɡɹæn ɹɛskjuz ən ɪskeɪps. ɪt wɑz ə deɪ fəɹ mɝɾɝz. nɑɾ ə plɛzən θɔt wən jə wɝ hoʊpɪŋ tə lɪv pæst ənʌðɝ dɔn. bʌt ðə plæn wɑz sɪmpəl. naʊ ðəɾ i hæɾ ə sintʃæn blʌd tə juz, nʌθɪŋ kəd pɑsəbli ɡoʊ ɹɔŋ. mæt tʃɹaɪd vɛɹi hɑɹd tə kənvɪns hɪmsɛlf ə ðæt.

The day dawned cold, with gray clouds that obscured the rising sun and winds off the Sea of Storms that rattled loose panes of glass in the window casements. In stories, not the sort of day for grand rescues and escapes. It was a day for murders. Not a pleasant thought when you were hoping to live past another dawn. But the plan was simple. Now that he had a Seanchan Blood to use, nothing could possibly go wrong. Mat tried very hard to convince himself of that.

ləpɪn bɹɔɾ ɪm bɹɛkfəst, bɹɛɾ ən hæm ən səm hɑɹd jɛloʊ tʃiz, waɪl i dʒɹɛst. nɹɪm wɑz foʊldɪŋ ə fju læs pisəz ə kloʊðɪŋ ðət wɝ tə ɡoʊ tə ði ɪn, ɪnkluɾɪŋ səm ə ðə ʃɝts taɪlɪn hæd hæd meɪd. ðeɪ wɝ ɡʊd ʃɝts, æftɝ ɔl, ən nɹɪm kleɪmd i kəd də sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt ðə leɪs, ðoʊ əz juʒəwəl i meɪɾ ɪt saʊn əz ɪf i wɑz ɔfɝɪŋ tə soʊ ə ʃɹaʊd. ðə luɡjubɹiəs, ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd lɪɾəl fɛloʊ wɑz hændi wɪð ə niɾəl, əz mæt nu wɛl. hi hæd soʊn ʌp ɪnʌf ə mæts wunz.

Lopin brought him breakfast, bread and ham and some hard yellow cheese, while he dressed. Nerim was folding a few last pieces of clothing that were to go to the inn, including some of the shirts Tylin had had made. They were good shirts, after all, and Nerim claimed he could do something about the lace, though as usual he made it sound as if he was offering to sew a shroud. The lugubrious, gray-haired little fellow was handy with a needle, as Mat knew well. He had sewn up enough of Mat's wounds.

"nɹɪm ən əl teɪk oʊlvɝ aʊt baɪ ðə ɹɛfjus ɡeɪɾ ət ðə ɹɪɹ ə ðə pæləs," ləpɪn ɹəsaɪɾəd wɪð ɪɡzædʒɝeɪɾəd peɪʃəns, hɪz hænz klæspt əɾ ɪz weɪst. sɝvəns ɪn ə pæləs sɛldəm mɪs milz, ən ɪz dɑɹk tɛɹən koʊt fɪt mɔɹ taɪtli ðən ɛvɝ oʊvɝ ɪz ɹaʊn bɛli. fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, ðə bɑɾəm ə ðə koʊt dɪd nɑɾ əpɪɹ tə flɛɹ əz mʌtʃ əz ɪt wʌns hæd. "ðɛɹ ɪz nɛvɝ ɛniwʌn ðəɹ ɪksɛp ðə ɡɑɹdz əntɪl ðə ɹɛfjus kɑɹt livz ɪn ði æftɝnun, ən ðeɪ ɑɹ əkʌstəm tə əs teɪkɪŋ maɪ lɔɹdz θɪŋz aʊt ðət weɪ, soʊ ðeɪ woʊn ɹɪmɑɹk ʌs. ət ðə wɑndɝɪŋ wʊmən, wɪl sɪkjʊɹ maɪ lɔɹdz ɡoʊld ən ðə ɹɛst ə maɪ lɔɹdz ɡɑɹməns, ən mɛtwɪn, fɝdʒɪn ən ɡɔɹɾɝən wɪl miɾ əs wɪð ðə hɔɹsəz. wi ən ðə ɹɛdʒɹmz wɪl ðən teɪk jʌŋ oʊlvɝ θɹu ðə dæl ɹə ɡeɪɾ ət mɪdæftɝnun. aɪ hæv ðə lɑɾɝi toʊkənz fəɹ ðə hɔɹsəz, ɪnkluɾɪŋ boʊθ pæk ænəməlz, ɪn maɪ pɑkət, maɪ lɔɹd. ðəɹ ɪz ən əbændən steɪbəl ɑn ðə ɡɹeɪt nɔɹθ ɹoʊd, əbaʊɾ ə maɪl nɔɹθ ə ðə sɝkəɾ ə hɛvən, wɛɹ wɪl weɪɾ əntɪl wi si maɪ lɔɹd. aɪ tʃɹʌst aɪ hæv maɪ lɔɹdz ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz kɝɛkli?"

"Nerim and I will take Olver out by the refuse gate at the rear of the Palace," Lopin recited with exaggerated patience, his hands clasped at his waist. Servants in a palace seldom missed meals, and his dark Tairen coat fit more tightly than ever over his round belly. For that matter, the bottom of the coat did not appear to flare as much as it once had. "There is never anyone there except the guards until the refuse cart leaves in the afternoon, and they are accustomed to us taking my Lord's things out that way, so they won't remark us. At The Wandering Woman, we will secure my Lord's gold and the rest of my Lord's garments, and Metwyn, Fergin and Gorderan will meet us with the horses. We and the Redarms will then take young Olver through the Dal Eira Gate at midafternoon. I have the lottery tokens for the horses, including both pack animals, in my pocket, my Lord. There is an abandoned stable on the Great North Road, about a mile north of the Circuit of Heaven, where we will wait until we see my Lord. I trust I have my Lord's instructions correctly?"

mæt swɑloʊd ðə læst ə ðə tʃiz ən dʌstɪɾ ɪz hænz. "ju θɪŋk aɪm meɪkɪŋ jə ɡoʊ oʊvɝ ɪt tu ɔfən?" hi sɛd, ʃɹʌɡɪŋ ɪndə hɪz koʊt. ə pleɪn dɑɹk ɡɹin koʊt. ə mæn wɑntəd tə bi pleɪn waɪl əbaʊt bɪznəs laɪk tədeɪz. "aɪ wɑnə meɪk ʃʊɹ juv ɪt baɪ hɑɹt. ɹɪmɛmbɝ, ɪf jə doʊn si mi bɪfɔɹ sʌnɹaɪz təmɑɹoʊ, jə kip muvɪŋ əntɪl jə faɪn tælmɑnz ən ðə bænd." ði əlɑɹm wəd ɡoʊ ʌp wɪð ðə mɔɹnɪŋ ɪnspɛkʃən ə ðə kɛnəlz, ən ɪf i wɑz nɑɾ aʊɾ ə ðə sɪɾi bɪfɔɹ ðæt, hi ɪkspɛktəd tə lɝn wɛðɝ ɪz lʌk ɹæn tə stɑpɪŋ ə hɛdzmənz æks. hi hæd bɪn toʊl ðəɾ i wɑz feɪɾɪd tə daɪ ən lɪv əɡɛn - ə pɹɑfəsi, əɹ nɪɹ ɪnʌf wʌn - bʌɾ i wɑz pɹɪɾi ʃʊɹ ðət hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi hæpənd.

Mat swallowed the last of the cheese and dusted his hands. "You think I'm making you go over it too often?" he said, shrugging into his coat. A plain dark green coat. A man wanted to be plain while about business like today's. "I want to make sure you have it by heart. Remember, if you don't see me before sunrise tomorrow, you keep moving until you find Talmanes and the Band." The alarm would go up with the morning inspection of the kennels, and if he was not out of the city before that, he expected to learn whether his luck ran to stopping a headsman's axe. He had been told that he was fated to die and live again - a prophecy, or near enough one - but he was pretty sure that had already happened.

"ʌv kɔɹs, maɪ lɔɹd," ləpɪn sɛd blænli. "ɪt wɪl bi əz maɪ lɔɹd kəmænz."

"Of course, my Lord," Lopin said blandly. "It will be as my Lord commands."

"sɝɾənli, maɪ lɔɹd," nɹɪm mɝmɝd, fjunɝiəl əz ɛvɝ. "maɪ lɔɹd kəmænz, ən wi oʊbeɪ."

"Certainly, my Lord," Nerim murmured, funereal as ever. "My Lord commands, and we obey."

mæt səspɛktəd ðeɪ wɝ laɪɪŋ, bʌt tu əɹ θɹi deɪz weɪɾɪŋ wəd nɑt hɝt ðɛm, ən baɪ ðət taɪm, ðeɪ wəɾ əv tə si hi wɑz nɑt kʌmɪŋ. mɛtwɪn ən ði ʌðɝ tu soʊlʒɝz wəd kənvɪns ðɛm, ɪf nid bi. ðoʊz θɹi maɪt fɑloʊ mæt kɔθən, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ nɑt ful ɪnʌf tə stʃɹɛtʃ ðɛɹ nɛks ɑn ðə tʃɑpɪŋ blɑk ɪf ɪz hɛd hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi fɔlən. fəɹ səm ɹizən, hi wɑz nɑɾ əz ʃʊɹ ə ləpɪn ən nɹɪm.

Mat suspected they were lying, but two or three days waiting would not hurt them, and by that time, they would have to see he was not coming. Metwyn and the other two soldiers would convince them, if need be. Those three might follow Mat Cauthon, but they were not fool enough to stretch their necks on the chopping block if his head had already fallen. For some reason, he was not as sure of Lopin and Nerim.

oʊlvɝ wɑz nɑɾ əz əpsɛɾ oʊvɝ livɪŋ ɹaɪzɛl əz mæt hæd fɪɹɾ i wəd bi. hi bɹɔt ðə səbdʒɛkt ʌp waɪl i wɑz hɛlpɪŋ ðə bɔɪ bʌndəl ɪz bɪlɔŋɪŋz tə bi kæɹiɾ oʊvɝ tə ði ɪn. ɔl ʌv oʊlvɝz θɪŋz wɝ leɪɾ aʊt nitli ɑn ðə nɛɹoʊ bɛɾ ɪn wʌt hæd bɪn ðə sʌlkɪŋ ɹum, ə smɔl sɪɾɪŋ ɹum, wən ði əpɑɹtməns hæd bɪn mæts.

Olver was not as upset over leaving Riselle as Mat had feared he would be. He brought the subject up while he was helping the boy bundle his belongings to be carried over to the inn. All of Olver's things were laid out neatly on the narrow bed in what had been the sulking room, a small sitting room, when the apartments had been Mat's.

"ʃi ɪz ɡɛɾɪŋ mɛɹid, mæt," oʊlvɝ sɛd peɪʃənli, əz ðoʊ ɪkspleɪnɪŋ tə sʌmwʌn u dɪdn si ði ɑbviəs. pɑpɪŋ oʊpən ə nɛɹoʊ lɪɾəl kɑɹv bɑks ɹaɪzɛl hæd ɡɪvən hɪm, dʒʌs lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ɪz ɹɛdhɔks fɛðɝ wɑz seɪf, hi snæpt ɪt ʃʌɾ ən tʌkt ɪɾ ɪndə ðə lɛðɝ skɹɪp i wəd bi kæɹiɪŋ ɑn ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. hi wɑz əz kɛɹfəl ə ðə fɛðɝ əz i hæd bɪn ə ðə pɝs hoʊldɪŋ twɛnti ɡoʊl kɹaʊnz ən ə fɪsfəl ə sɪlvɝ. "aɪ doʊn θɪŋk əɹ hʌzbənd wəd laɪk əɹ tə kip titʃɪŋ mi tə ɹid. aɪ wəd nɑt, ɪf aɪ wɝ əɹ hʌzbənd."

"She is getting married, Mat," Olver said patiently, as though explaining to someone who didn't see the obvious. Popping open a narrow little carved box Riselle had given him, just long enough to make sure his redhawk's feather was safe, he snapped it shut and tucked it into the leather scrip he would be carrying on his shoulder. He was as careful of the feather as he had been of the purse holding twenty gold crowns and a fistful of silver. "I don't think her husband would like her to keep teaching me to read. I would not, if I were her husband."

"oʊ," mæt sɛd. ɹaɪzɛl hæd wɝkt kwɪkli wʌns ʃi meɪɾ əɹ maɪn ʌp. hɝ mɛɹɪdʒ tə bænɝ-dʒɛnɝəl jəmɑɾə hæd bɪn ənaʊns pʌblɪkli jɛstɝdeɪ ən wɑz tə teɪk pleɪs təmɑɹoʊ, ðoʊ baɪ kʌstəm ðəɹ wɑz juʒəwəli ə weɪɾ ə mʌnθs bɪtwin. jəmɑɾə maɪt bi ə ɡʊd dʒɛnɝəl - mæt dɪd nɑt noʊ - bʌɾ i hæd nɛvɝ stʊɾ ə tʃæns əɡɛnst ɹaɪzɛl ən ðət mɑɹvələs bʊzəm. tədeɪ ðeɪ wɝ lʊkɪŋ əɾ ə vɪnjɝɾ ɪn ðə ɹænən hɪlz ðət ðə ɡɹum wɑz baɪɪŋ fəɹ əɹ wɛɾɪŋ ɡɪft. "aɪ dʒʌs θɔt jə maɪt wɑnə - aɪ doʊnt noʊ - teɪk əɹ wɪð ʌs, əɹ sʌmθɪŋ."

"Oh," Mat said. Riselle had worked quickly once she made her mind up. Her marriage to Banner-General Yamada had been announced publicly yesterday and was to take place tomorrow, though by custom there was usually a wait of months between. Yamada might be a good general - Mat did not know - but he had never stood a chance against Riselle and that marvelous bosom. Today they were looking at a vineyard in the Rhannon Hills that the groom was buying for her wedding gift. "I just thought you might want to - I don't know - take her with us, or something."

"aɪm nɑɾ ə tʃaɪld, mæt," oʊlvɝ sɛd dʒɹaɪli. foʊldɪŋ ðə lɪnən klɔθ bæk ɝaʊn ɪz stʃɹaɪp tɝɾəl ʃɛl, hi æɾəd ðət tə ðə skɹɪp. "ju wɪl pleɪ sneɪks ən fɑksəz wɪð mi, woʊn ju? ɹaɪzɛl ɛndʒɔɪz pleɪɪŋ, ən jə nɛvɝ əv taɪm ɛni mɔɹ." dɪspaɪt ðə kloʊðz mæt wɑz bʌndəlɪŋ ʌp ɪn ə kloʊk ðət wəd ɡoʊ ɪndə ə pæk hæmpɝ, ðə bɔɪ hæɾ ə spɛɹ pɛɹ ə bɹitʃɪz ən səm klin ʃɝts ən stɑkɪŋz ɪn ðə skɹɪp, tu. ən ðə ɡeɪm ə sneɪks ən fɑksəz ɪz dɛd fɑðɝ hæd meɪd fəɹ hɪm. jə wɝ lɛs laɪkli tə luz wʌt jə kɛpt ɑn jəɹ pɝsən, ən oʊlvɝ hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi lɔs mɔɹ ɪn ɪz tɛn jɪɹz ðən moʊs pipəl dɪɾ ɪn ə laɪftaɪm. bʌɾ i stɪl bɪliv jə kəd wɪn ət sneɪks ən fɑksəz wɪθaʊt bɹeɪkɪŋ ðə ɹulz, tu.

"I'm not a child, Mat," Olver said dryly. Folding the linen cloth back around his striped turtle shell, he added that to the scrip. "You will play Snakes and Foxes with me, won't you? Riselle enjoys playing, and you never have time any more." Despite the clothes Mat was bundling up in a cloak that would go into a pack hamper, the boy had a spare pair of breeches and some clean shirts and stockings in the scrip, too. And the game of Snakes and Foxes his dead father had made for him. You were less likely to lose what you kept on your person, and Olver had already lost more in his ten years than most people did in a lifetime. But he still believed you could win at Snakes and Foxes without breaking the rules, too.

"aɪ wɪl," mæt pɹɑməst. hi wəɾ ɪf i mænədʒ tə meɪk ɪɾ aʊɾ ə ðə sɪɾi. hi wɑz sɝɾənli bɹeɪkɪŋ ɪnʌf ɹulz tə dɪzɝv tə wɪn. "ju dʒʌs teɪk kɛɹ ʌv wɪn tɪl aɪ ɡɛt ðɛɹ." oʊlvɝ dʒɪnd waɪdli, ən fəɹ hɪm, ðət wɑz vɛɹi waɪɾ ɪndid. ðə bɔɪ lʌv ðət lɛɡi ɡɹeɪ ɡɛldɪŋ ɔlmoʊst əz mʌtʃ əz i dɪd sneɪks ən fɑksəz.

"I will," Mat promised. He would if he managed to make it out of the city. He was certainly breaking enough rules to deserve to win. "You just take care of Wind till I get there." Olver ginned widely, and for him, that was very wide indeed. The boy loved that leggy gray gelding almost as much as he did Snakes and Foxes.

ənfɔɹtʃənətli, bɛslən wɑz ənʌðɝ u sim tə θɪŋk jə kəd wɪn ət sneɪks ən fɑksəz.

Unfortunately, Beslan was another who seemed to think you could win at Snakes and Foxes.

"tənaɪt," hi ɡɹaʊld, stɔkɪŋ ʌp ən daʊn ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə faɪɝpleɪs ɪn taɪlɪnz sɪɾɪŋ ɹum. ðə slɛndɝ mænz aɪz wɝ koʊld ɪnʌf tə teɪk əweɪ ðə wɔɹmθ ə ðə bleɪz, ən ɪz hænz wɝ klæsp bɪhaɪn ɪz bæk əz ɪf tə kip əm fɹəm ðə hɪlt ə hɪz nɛɹoʊ-bleɪɾɪd sɔɹd. ðə dʒuəl sɪləndɝ-klɑk ɑn ðə weɪv-kɑɹv mɑɹbəl mæntəl tʃaɪm fɔɹ taɪmz fəɹ ðə sɛkən aʊɝ ə ðə mɔɹnɪŋ. "wɪð ə fju deɪz' wɔɹnɪŋ, aɪ cʊɾə leɪɾ ɑn sʌmθɪŋ mæɡnɪfəsənt!"

"Tonight," he growled, stalking up and down in front of the fireplace in Tylin's sitting room. The slender man's eyes were cold enough to take away the warmth of the blaze, and his hands were clasped behind his back as if to keep them from the hilt of his narrow-bladed sword. The jeweled cylinder-clock on the wave-carved marble mantel chimed four times for the second hour of the morning. "With a few days' warning, I could have laid on something magnificent!"

"aɪ doʊnt wɑn ɛniθɪŋ mæɡnɪfəsənt," mæt toʊl hɪm. hi dɪd nɑt wɑn ɛniθɪŋ fɹəm ðə mæn, bʌt baɪ tʃæns bɛslən hæd sin tɑm slɪpɪŋ ɪndə ðə steɪbliɑɹɾ ə ðə wɑndɝɪŋ wʊmən ə lɪɾəl ɝliɝ. tɑm hæd ɡɔn tə kip dʒoʊlin əmjuzd əntɪl ɛdʒiənɪn bɹɔɾ əɹ sʌldəm ðəɾ ivnɪŋ, tə sɛɾəl əɹ nɝvz ən dʒɑli hɝ əlɔŋ wɪð kɔɹtli mænɝz, bʌt ðəɹ cʊɾə bɪn ɛni nʌmbɝ ə ɹizənz fəɹ ɪm tə vɪzət ði ɪn. wɛl, meɪbi nɑt ðət mɛni, wɪð ɪt fʊl ə sintʃæn, bʌt sɛvɹəl, ʃʊɹli. oʊnli, bɛslən hæd lɛp tə ðə ɹizən laɪk ə dʌk lipɪŋ ɑn ə biɾəl, ən i ɹəfjuz tə bi lɛft aʊt. "ɪt wɪl bi ɪnʌf ɪf ə fju ʌv jəɹ fɹɛnz faɪɝ səm ə ðə stɔɹz ðə sintʃæn əv stɑkpaɪld ɑn ðə beɪ ɹoʊd. æftɝ mɪdnaɪt, maɪnd, əz nɪɹ əz ðeɪ kən ɹɛkən ɪt; bɛɾɝ ən aʊɝ leɪɾɝ ðən ɛni taɪm bɪfɔɹ." wɪð ɛni lʌk, hi wəd bi aʊɾ ə ðə sɪɾi bɪfɔɹ mɪdnaɪt. "ðæt wɪl dʒɹɔ ðɛɹ ətɛnʃən əweɪ saʊθ, ən jə noʊ luzɪŋ stɔɹz wɪl hɝt ðɛm."

"I don't want anything magnificent," Mat told him. He did not want anything from the man, but by chance Beslan had seen Thom slipping into the stableyard of The Wandering Woman a little earlier. Thom had gone to keep Joline amused until Egeanin brought her sul'dam that evening, to settle her nerves and jolly her along with courtly manners, but there could have been any number of reasons for him to visit the inn. Well, maybe not that many, with it full of Seanchan, but several, surely. Only, Beslan had leaped to the reason like a duck leaping on a beetle, and he refused to be left out. "It will be enough if a few of your friends fire some of the stores the Seanchan have stockpiled on the Bay Road. After midnight, mind, as near as they can reckon it; better an hour later than any time before." With any luck, he would be out of the city before midnight. "That will draw their attention away south, and you know losing stores will hurt them."

"aɪ sɛɾ aɪ wəd də ɪt," bɛslən sɛd saʊɝli, "bʌt jə kæn seɪ sɛɾɪŋ faɪɝz ɪz ɪɡzækli ə ɡɹæn dʒɛstʃɝ."

"I said I would do it," Beslan said sourly, "but you can't say setting fires is exactly a grand gesture."

sɪɾɪŋ bæk, mæt ɹɛstəɾ ɪz hænz ɑn ðə bæmbu-kɑɹvd ɑɹmz ə ðə tʃɛɹ ən fɹaʊnd. hi wɑntəd tə ɹɛst ɪz hænz, ɛniweɪ, bʌɾ ɪz sɪɡnɪt ɹɪŋ meɪɾ ə mətælɪk klɪkɪŋ ɑn ðə ɡɪldɪd wʊɾ əz i tæpt ɪz fɪŋɡɝz. "bɛslən, jəl bi sin əɾ ən ɪn wən ðoʊz faɪɝz ɑɹ sɛt, woʊn ju?" ði ʌðɝ mæn ɡɹɪməst. "bɛslən?"

Sitting back, Mat rested his hands on the bamboo-carved arms of the chair and frowned. He wanted to rest his hands, anyway, but his signet ring made a metallic clicking on the gilded wood as he tapped his fingers. "Beslan, you will be seen at an inn when those fires are set, won't you?" The other man grimaced. "Beslan?"

bɛslən flʌŋ ʌp ɪz hænz. "aɪ noʊ; aɪ noʊ. aɪ mʌsnt ɛndeɪnʒɝ mʌðɝ. əl bi sin. baɪ mɪdnaɪt, əl bi əz dʒɹʌŋk əz ən ɪnkipɝz hʌzbənd! jə kən weɪdʒɝ əl bi sin! ɪt dʒʌst ɪzən vɛɹi hɪɹoʊɪk, mæt. aɪm ət wɔɹ wɪð ðə sintʃæn wɛðɝ əɹ nɑt mʌðɝ ɪz."
