Beslan flung up his hands. "I know; I know. I mustn't endanger Mother. I'll be seen. By midnight, I will be as drunk as an innkeeper's husband! You can wager I'll be seen! It just isn't very heroic, Mat. I'm at war with the Seanchan whether or not Mother is."

mæt tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə saɪ. hi ɔlmoʊst səksiɾəd.

Mat tried not to sigh. He almost succeeded.

ðəɹ wɑz noʊ weɪ tə haɪd ðə θɹi ɹɛdʒɹmz muvɪŋ hɔɹsəz aʊɾ ə ðə steɪbəlz, ʌv kɔɹs. twaɪs ðət mɔɹnɪŋ i noʊɾəst sɝvɪŋ wɪmən hændɪŋ kɔɪnz tə ʌðɝz, ən boʊθ taɪmz ðə wʊmən duɪŋ ðə hændɪŋ oʊvɝ ɡlɛɹd wən ʃi sɔ hɪm. ivən wɪð veɪnɪn ən hɑɹnən əpɛɹənli stɪl sɑlədli ɪnskɑnst ɪn ðə lɔŋ bæɹəks ɹum nɪɹ ðə steɪbəlz, ðə pæləs nu ðət mæt kɔθən wɑz livɪŋ sun, ən weɪdʒɝz wɝ biɪŋ peɪɾ ɔlɹɛɾi. hi dʒʌs hæd tə meɪk ʃʊɹ noʊ wʌn faʊn aʊt haʊ sun bɪfɔɹ ɪt wɑz tu leɪt.

There was no way to hide the three Redarms moving horses out of the stables, of course. Twice that morning he noticed serving women handing coins to others, and both times the woman doing the handing over glared when she saw him. Even with Vanin and Harnan apparently still solidly ensconced in the long barracks room near the stables, the Palace knew that Mat Cauthon was leaving soon, and wagers were being paid already. He just had to make sure no one found out how soon before it was too late.

ðə wɪn pɪkt ʌp stʃɹɛŋkθ əz ðə mɔɹnɪŋ wɔɹ ɑn, bʌɾ i hæd pɪps sæɾəld ən ɹoʊɾ ɪz ɛnləs sɝkəlz ɪn ðə pæləs steɪbliɑɹd, hʌɾəlɪŋ ə lɪɾəl ɪn ɪz sæɾəl ən klʌtʃɪŋ ɪz kloʊk kloʊs. hi ɹoʊd mɔɹ sloʊli ðən juʒəwəl, soʊ pɪps' stil ʃuz meɪɾ ə leɪzi, plɑɾɪŋ saʊn ɑn ðə peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz. naʊ ən ðən i ɡɹɪməst ət ðə dɑɹkənɪŋ klaʊdz ɪn ðə skaɪ ən ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. noʊ, mæt kɔθən dɪd nɑt laɪk biɪŋ aʊɾ ɪn ðɪs wɛðɝ. mæt kɔθən wəd bi steɪɪŋ sʌmwɛɹ wɔɹm ən dʒɹaɪ əntɪl ðə skaɪz klɪɹd, jɛs, hi wʊd.

The wind picked up strength as the morning wore on, but he had Pips saddled and rode his endless circles in the Palace stableyard, huddling a little in his saddle and clutching his cloak close. He rode more slowly than usual, so Pips' steel shoes made a lazy, plodding sound on the paving stones. Now and then he grimaced at the darkening clouds in the sky and shook his head. No, Mat Cauthon did not like being out in this weather. Mat Cauthon would be staying somewhere warm and dry until the skies cleared, yes, he would.

ðə sʌldəm wɔkɪŋ deɪmeɪn ɪn ðɛɹ oʊn sɝkəl ɪn ðə steɪbliɑɹd nu hi wɑz livɪŋ sun, tu. meɪbi ðə sɝvɪŋ wɪmən dɪd nɑt tɔk dɝɛkli tə ðə sintʃæn wɪmən, bʌt wʌt wʌn wʊmən nu wɑz ɔlweɪz noʊn tə ɛvɹi wʊmən ɪnsaɪɾ ə maɪl sun ɪnʌf. waɪldfaɪɝ dɪd nɑt ɹʌn θɹu dʒɹaɪ wʊdz əz fæst əz ɡɑsəp ɹæn θɹu wɪmən. ə tɔl jɛloʊ-hɛɹd sʌldəm ɡlænst ɪn ɪz dɝɛkʃən ən ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. ə ʃɔɹt staʊt sʌldəm læft aʊt laʊd, splɪɾɪŋ ə feɪs əz dɑɹk əz ɛni ʌv ðə si foʊk. hi wɑz dʒʌs taɪlɪnz tɔɪ.

The sul'dam walking damane in their own circle in the stableyard knew he was leaving soon, too. Maybe the serving women did not talk directly to the Seanchan women, but what one woman knew was always known to every woman inside a mile soon enough. Wildfire did not run through dry woods as fast as gossip ran through women. A tall yellow-haired sul'dam glanced in his direction and shook her head. A short stout sul'dam laughed out loud, splitting a face as dark as any of the Sea Folk. He was just Tylin's Toy.

ðə sʌldəm dɪd nɑt kənsɝn hɪm, bʌt tɛslɪn dɪd. fəɹ sɛvɹəl deɪz, əntɪl ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ, hi hæd nɑt sin əɹ əmʌŋ ðə deɪmeɪn biɪŋ ɛksɝsaɪzd. tədeɪ ðə sʌldəm lɛt ðɛɹ kloʊks flaɪ wɪð ðə wɪnd, bʌt ðə deɪmeɪn ɔl hɛl ðɛɹz taɪtli ɝaʊn ðɛm, ɪksɛp tɛslɪnz ɡɹeɪ kloʊk flæp ðɪs weɪ ən ðæt, fɝɡɑɾən, ən ʃi stʌmbəld ə lɪɾəl wɛɹ ðə peɪvmənt wɑz ənivən. hɝ aɪz wɝ waɪɾ ən wɝiɾ ɪn ðəɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ feɪs. əkeɪʒənəli ʃi dɑɹɾɪd ə ɡlæns ət ðə bʌksəm blæk-hɛɹd sʌldəm wɛɹɪŋ ði ʌðɝ ɛn ə hɝ sɪlvɝ liʃ, ən wən ʃi dɪd, ʃi lɪkt əɹ lɪps ənsɝteɪnli.

The sul'dam did not concern him, but Teslyn did. For several days, until this morning, he had not seen her among the damane being exercised. Today the sul'dam let their cloaks fly with the wind, but the damane all held theirs tightly around them, except Teslyn's gray cloak flapped this way and that, forgotten, and she stumbled a little where the pavement was uneven. Her eyes were wide and worried in that Aes Sedai face. Occasionally she darted a glance at the buxom black-haired sul'dam wearing the other end of her silver leash, and when she did, she licked her lips uncertainly.

ə taɪtnəs sɛɾəld ɪn mæts bɛli. wɛɹ hæd ðə dɪtɝməneɪʃən ɡɔn? ɪf ʃi wɑz ɹɛɾi tə nʌkəl ʌndɝ. . . .

A tightness settled in Mat's belly. Where had the determination gone? If she was ready to knuckle under. . . .

"ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɔl ɹaɪt?" veɪnɪn sɛd wən mæt dɪsmaʊntɪɾ ən ɡeɪv ɪm pɪps' ɹeɪnz. ɹeɪn hæd bɪɡʌn tə fɔl, koʊl fæt dʒɹɑps, ən ðə sʌldəm wɝ hɝiɪŋ ðɛɹ tʃɑɹdʒəz ɪnsaɪd, læfɪŋ ən ɹʌnɪŋ tə əvɔɪd ɡɛɾɪŋ wɛt. səm ə ðə deɪmeɪn wɝ læfɪŋ, tu, ə saʊn tə tʃɪl mæts blʌd. veɪnɪn tʊk noʊ tʃænsəz ɛniwʌn maɪt wʌndɝ waɪ ðeɪ wɝ stændɪŋ ɪn ðə ɹeɪn tə tɔk. ðə fæt mæn bɛn tə lɪf pɪps' lɛft fɔɹɛlɪɡ ən stʌɾi ðə huf. "ju lʊk ə maɪt mɔɹ pik ðən juʒəwəl."

"Everything all right?" Vanin said when Mat dismounted and gave him Pips' reins. Rain had begun to fall, cold fat drops, and the sul'dam were hurrying their charges inside, laughing and running to avoid getting wet. Some of the damane were laughing, too, a sound to chill Mat's blood. Vanin took no chances anyone might wonder why they were standing in the rain to talk. The fat man bent to lift Pips' left foreleg and study the hoof. "You look a mite more peaked than usual."

"ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɪz dʒʌs faɪn," mæt toʊl hɪm. ði eɪk ɪn ɪz lɛɡ ən hɪp nɔd laɪk ə tuθ, bʌɾ i wɑz bɛɹli əwɛɹ ʌv ɪɾ əɹ ə ðə kwɪkənɪŋ ɹeɪn. laɪt, ɪf tɛslɪn wɑz kɹækɪŋ naʊ. . . . "dʒʌst ɹɪmɛmbɝ. ɪf jə hɪɹ ʃaʊɾɪŋ ɪnsaɪd ðə pæləs tənaɪt, əɹ ɛniθɪŋ ðət saʊnz laɪk tʃɹʌbəl, jə ən hɑɹnən doʊnt weɪt. jə ɹaɪɾ aʊt ɹaɪt ðən ən ɡoʊ faɪn oʊlvɝ. hɪl bi - "

"Everything is just fine," Mat told him. The ache in his leg and hip gnawed like a tooth, but he was barely aware of it or of the quickening rain. Light, if Teslyn was cracking now. . . . "Just remember. If you hear shouting inside the Palace tonight, or anything that sounds like trouble, you and Harnan don't wait. You ride out right then and go find Olver. He'll be - "

"aɪ noʊ wɛɹ ðə lɪɾəl taɪkəl bi." lɛɾɪŋ ɡoʊ ʌv pɪps' lɛɡ ən stʃɹeɪɾənɪŋ, veɪnɪn spæt θɹu wʌn ə ðə ɡæps ɪn ɪz tiθ. ɹeɪndʒɹɑps ɹæn daʊn ɪz feɪs. "hɑɹnən eɪn tu stupəd tə pʊɾ ɪz buts ɑn əloʊn, ən aɪ noʊ wʌt tə du. jə dʒʌs teɪk kɛɹ ə jəɹ pis ʌv ɪɾ ən meɪk ʃʊɹ jəɹ lʌk ɪz wɝkɪŋ. kʌm ɑn ðɛɹ, bɔɪ," hi æɾəd mʌtʃ mɔɹ wɔɹmli tə pɪps. "aɪ ɡɑt səm ɡʊɾ oʊts fəɹ ju. ən ə faɪn hɑt fɪʃ stu fəɹ mi."

"I know where the little tyke'll be." Letting go of Pips' leg and straightening, Vanin spat through one of the gaps in his teeth. Raindrops ran down his face. "Harnan ain't too stupid to put his boots on alone, and I know what to do. You just take care of your piece of it and make sure your luck is working. Come on there, boy," he added much more warmly to Pips. "I got some good oats for you. And a fine hot fish stew for me."

mæt nu hi ʃəɾ it, tu, bʌɾ i fɛlt əz ðoʊ hi hæd swɑloʊɾ ə stoʊn, ən ɪt dɪd nɑt liv ɹum fəɹ fud. hɑbəlɪŋ bæk ʌp tə taɪlɪnz əpɑɹtməns, hi θɹu hɪz dæmp kloʊk oʊvɝ ə tʃɛɹ, ən fəɹ ə taɪm, stʊd stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə kɔɹnɝ wɛɹ ɪz blæk-hæftɪd spɪɹ stʊd pɹɑp nɛks tə hɪz ənstʃɹʌŋ baʊ. hi plæn tə kʌm bæk fəɹ ði æʃhændʒɹeɪ ət ðə læs moʊmənt. ðə blʌd ʃəɾ ɔl bi əbɛd baɪ ðə taɪm i muvd, ən ðə sɝvəns, əz wɛl, wɪð oʊnli ðə ɡɑɹdz aʊtsaɪd ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ əweɪk, bʌɾ i wəd nɑt ɹɪsk biɪŋ sin wɪð ɪt bɪfɔɹ i hæd tə. ivən ðə sintʃæn u kɔld ɪm tɔɪ wəd teɪk noʊɾəs ə hɪm kæɹiɪŋ ə wɛpən θɹu ðə hɔlz ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə naɪt. hi hæd mɛn tə kæɹi ðə baʊ, tu. ɡʊd blæk ju wɑz ɔlmoʊst ɪmpɑsəbəl tə faɪn aʊtsaɪd ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, ən ðeɪ kʌɾ ɪt tu ʃɔɹt bɪsaɪdz. ənstʃɹʌŋ, ə baʊ ʃəd bi tu hænz tɔlɝ ðən ðə mæn u wəd dʒɹɔ ɪt. meɪbi hi ʃəɾ əbændən ɪɾ æftɝ ɔl, ðoʊ. hi wəd nid boʊθ hænz tə juz ði æʃhændʒɹeɪ, ɪf ɪt keɪm tə ðæt, ən ðə moʊmənt niɾəd tə dʒɹɑp ðə baʊ maɪt bi ðə moʊmən ðət kɪl hɪm.

Mat knew he should eat, too, but he felt as though he had swallowed a stone, and it did not leave room for food. Hobbling back up to Tylin's apartments, he threw his damp cloak over a chair, and for a time, stood staring at the corner where his black-hafted spear stood propped next to his unstrung bow. He planned to come back for the ashandarei at the last moment. The Blood should all be abed by the time he moved, and the servants, as well, with only the guards outside remaining awake, but he would not risk being seen with it before he had to. Even the Seanchan who called him Toy would take notice of him carrying a weapon through the halls in the middle of the night. He had meant to carry the bow, too. Good black yew was almost impossible to find outside the Two Rivers, and they cut it too short besides. Unstrung, a bow should be two hands taller than the man who would draw it. Maybe he should abandon it after all, though. He would need both hands to use the ashandarei, if it came to that, and the moment needed to drop the bow might be the moment that killed him.

"ɛvɹiθɪŋ wɪl ɡoʊ əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə plæn," hi sɛɾ əlaʊd. blʌɾ ən æʃəz, hi saʊndəɾ əz wʊl-hɛɾəd əz bɛslən! "aɪ æm nɑt gɑnə hæv faɪt maɪ weɪ aʊɾ ə ðə blʌɾi pæləs!" ən ɔlmoʊst əz ful-wɪɾɪd. lʌk wɑz ə vɛɹi faɪn θɪŋ wɪð ðə daɪs. dɪpɛndɪŋ ɑn lʌk ʌðɝ pleɪsəz kəd ɡɛɾ ə mæn dɛd.

"Everything will go according to plan," he said aloud. Blood and ashes, he sounded as wool-headed as Beslan! "I am not going to have fight my way out of the bloody Palace!" And almost as fool-witted. Luck was a very fine thing with the dice. Depending on luck other places could get a man dead.

laɪɪŋ daʊn ɑn ðə bɛd, hi pɹɑpt wʌn buɾɪd fʊɾ ətɑp ði ʌðɝ ən leɪ stʌɾiɪŋ ðə baʊ ən ðə spɪɹ. wɪð ðə dɔɹ tə ðə sɪɾɪŋ ɹum oʊpən, hi kəd hɪɹ ðə sɪləndɝ-klɑk sɔfli tʃaɪm itʃ aʊɝ əweɪ. laɪt, hi niɾəd ɪz lʌk tənaɪt.

Lying down on the bed, he propped one booted foot atop the other and lay studying the bow and the spear. With the door to the sitting room open, he could hear the cylinder-clock softly chime each hour away. Light, he needed his luck tonight.

ðə wɪndoʊ laɪt feɪɾəd soʊ sloʊli hi ɔlmoʊst ɡɑɾ ʌp tə si wɛðɝ ðə sʌn hæd stɑpt, bʌɾ ɪvɛntʃəwəli ɡɹeɪ laɪt feɪɾəd tə pɝpəl twaɪlaɪt, ðən tə fʊl dɑɹk. ðə klɑk tʃaɪm twaɪs, ən ðən ði oʊnli saʊnz wɝ ðə dʒɹʌmɪŋ ə ðə ɹeɪn ən ðə ɹʌʃ ə ðə wɪnd. wɝkmɪn u hæd bɪn bɹeɪvɪŋ ðə wɛðɝ wəd bi daʊnɪŋ tulz tə tʃɹʌdʒ hoʊm. noʊ wʌn keɪm tə laɪt ðə læmps əɹ tɛn ðə faɪɝz. noʊ wʌn ɪkspɛktəɾ ɪm tə bi ðɛɹ, sɪns i hæd slɛpt ɪn ðə bɛd ðə naɪt bɪfɔɹ. ðə fleɪmz ɪn ðə bɛdʒɹum faɪɝpleɪs dwɪndəld ən daɪd. ɛvɹiθɪŋ wɑz ɪn moʊʃən, naʊ. oʊlvɝ wɑz snʌɡ ɪn ðəɾ oʊl steɪbəl; ɪt stɪl hæd moʊst ʌv ɪts ɹuf. ðə klɑk saʊndəd ðə fɝs fʊl aʊɝ ə ðə naɪt, ən æftɝ noʊ mɔɹ ðən ə wik, fɔɹ tʃaɪmz fəɹ ðə sɛkənd.

The window light faded so slowly he almost got up to see whether the sun had stopped, but eventually gray light faded to purple twilight, then to full dark. The clock chimed twice, and then the only sounds were the drumming of the rain and the rush of the wind. Workmen who had been braving the weather would be downing tools to trudge home. No one came to light the lamps or tend the fires. No one expected him to be there, since he had slept in the bed the night before. The flames in the bedroom fireplace dwindled and died. Everything was in motion, now. Olver was snug in that old stable; it still had most of its roof. The clock sounded the first full hour of the night, and after no more than a week, four chimes for the second.

ɹaɪzɪŋ fɹəm ðə bɛd, hi fɛlt ɪz weɪ ɪndə ðə pɪtʃ-dɑɹk sɪɾɪŋ ɹum ən pʊld oʊpən ðə hɪnʒd keɪsmən ʌv wʌn ə ðə tɔl wɪndoʊz. ðə stʃɹɔŋ wɪn dʒɹoʊv ɹeɪndʒɹɑps θɹu ði ɪntʃɹəkət waɪt ɹɔt-aɪɝn skɹin, kwɪkli soʊkɪŋ ɪz koʊt. ðə mun wɑz hɪɾən bɪhaɪn klaʊdz, ən ðə sɪɾi wɑz ə mæs ə ɹeɪn-ʃɹaʊɾɪd dɑɹknəs wɪθaʊɾ ivən laɪtnɪŋ tə bɹeɪk ɪt. ɔl ðə stʃɹitlɑmps hæɾ əpɛɹənli bɪn ɪkstɪŋɡwɪʃt baɪ ðə ɹeɪn ən waɪnd; ðə naɪt wəd haɪɾ əm wən ðeɪ lɛf ðə pæləs. ən ɛni pətʃɹoʊl ðət sɔ ðɛm aʊɾ ɪn ðɪs wɛðɝ wəd lʊk twaɪs. ʃɪvɝɪŋ əz ðə wɪn kʌt θɹu hɪz dæmp koʊt, hi ʃʌt ðə keɪsmənt.

Rising from the bed, he felt his way into the pitch-dark sitting room and pulled open the hinged casement of one of the tall windows. The strong wind drove raindrops through the intricate white wrought-iron screen, quickly soaking his coat. The moon was hidden behind clouds, and the city was a mass of rain-shrouded darkness without even lightning to break it. All the streetlamps had apparently been extinguished by the rain and wind; the night would hide them when they left the Palace. And any patrol that saw them out in this weather would look twice. Shivering as the wind cut through his damp coat, he shut the casement.

teɪkɪŋ ə siɾ ɑn ði ɛdʒ ʌv wʌn ə ðə bæmbu-kɑɹv tʃɛɹz, hi pɹɑpt ɪz ɛlboʊz ɑn ɪz niz ən wɑtʃt ðə klɑk əbʌv ðə dɛd faɪɝpleɪs. hi kəd nɑt si ɪɾ ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs, bʌt hɪɹ, hi kəd hɪɹ ðə stɛɾi tɪk. hi ɹɪmeɪn moʊʃənləs, ðoʊ ðə sɪŋɡəl tʃaɪm ʌv ənʌðɝ aʊɝ meɪɾ ɪm twɪtʃ. ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ naʊ bʌt tə weɪt. ɪn ə lɪɾəl waɪl, ɛdʒiənɪn wəd bi ɪntʃɹədusɪŋ dʒoʊlin tə hɝ sʌldəm. ɪf ʃi ɹɪli hæd bɪn eɪbəl tə faɪn θɹi hu wəd də əz ʃi kleɪmd. ɪf dʒoʊlin dɪd nɑt pænɪk wən ðeɪ fɝs pʊt ði æɾəm ɑn hɝ. tɑm, dʒoʊlin ən ði ʌðɝz fɹəm ði ɪn wəd miɾ ɪm dʒʌs bɪfɔɹ i ɹitʃt ðə dæl ɹə. ən ɪf i dɪd nɑt ɹitʃ ɪt, tɑm hæd ɡɔn əhɛd wɪð kɑɹvɪŋ ɪz tɝnəp; hi wɑz ʃʊɹ i kəd ɡɛɾ əm pæs ðə ɡeɪts wɪð ɪz fɔɹdʒd ɔɹɾɝ. ət lis ðeɪ hæɾ ə tʃæns, ɪf ɪɾ ɔl fɛl əpɑɹt. ɪf. tu mɛni ɪfs tə θɪŋk əbaʊt, naʊ. ɪt wɑz tu leɪt fəɹ ðæt.

Taking a seat on the edge of one of the bamboo-carved chairs, he propped his elbows on his knees and watched the clock above the dead fireplace. He could not see it in the darkness, but here, he could hear the steady tick. He remained motionless, though the single chime of another hour made him twitch. There was nothing now but to wait. In a little while, Egeanin would be introducing Joline to her sul'dam. If she really had been able to find three who would do as she claimed. If Joline did not panic when they first put the a'dam on her. Thom, Joline and the others from the inn would meet him just before he reached the Dal Eira. And if he did not reach it, Thom had gone ahead with carving his turnip; he was sure he could get them past the gates with his forged order. At least they had a chance, if it all fell apart. If. Too many ifs to think about, now. It was too late for that.

dɪŋ, fɹəm ðə klɑk, laɪk ə pis ə kɹɪstəl tæpt wɪð ə spun. dɪŋ. əbaʊt naʊ, dʒulɪn wəd bi meɪkɪŋ ɪz weɪ tə hɪz pɹɛʃəs θɛɹə, ən wɪð ɛni lʌk bɛslən wɑz stɑɹɾɪŋ tə dʒɹɪŋk hɑɹɾ əɾ ən ɪn sʌmwɛɹ. dʒɹɔɪŋ ə dip bɹɛθ, hi stʊɾ ɪn ðə blæknəs ən tʃɛkt ɪz naɪvz baɪ fil, ʌp ɪz slivz, bɪniθ ɪz koʊt, tʌkt ɪndə ðə tɝnd-daʊn tɑps ə hɪz buts, wʌn hæŋɪŋ daʊn ɪnsaɪd ðə bæk ə hɪz kɑlɝ. ðət dʌn, hi lɛf ði əpɑɹtməns. tu leɪt fəɹ ɛniθɪŋ bʌt bɪɡɪnɪŋ.

Ding, from the clock, like a piece of crystal tapped with a spoon. Ding. About now, Juilin would be making his way to his precious Thera, and with any luck Beslan was starting to drink hard at an inn somewhere. Drawing a deep breath, he stood in the blackness and checked his knives by feel, up his sleeves, beneath his coat, tucked into the turned-down tops of his boots, one hanging down inside the back of his collar. That done, he left the apartments. Too late for anything but beginning.

ði ɛmpti hɔlweɪz i wɔkt əlɔŋ wɝ oʊnli dɪmli lɪt. wʌn stæn læmp ɪn θɹi əɹ fɔɹ kæɹid fleɪmz ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə mɪɹɝz, lɪɾəl pulz ə laɪt wɪð peɪl ʃædoʊz bɪtwin ðət nɛvɝ kwaɪt ɹitʃt dɑɹknəs. hɪz buts wɝ laʊɾ ɑn ðə flɔɹ taɪlz. ðeɪ ɹæŋ ɑn ðə mɑɹbəl stɛɹz. ɪt wɑz ənlaɪkli ɛniwʌn əɾ ɔl wəd bi əweɪk ðɪs leɪt, bʌɾ ɪf sʌmwʌn dɪd si hɪm, hi mʌs nɑt lʊk əz ɪf i wɝ skʌlkɪŋ. tʌkɪŋ ɪz θʌmz bɪhaɪn ɪz bɛlt, hi meɪd hɪmsɛlf sɔntɝ. ɪt wɑz noʊ wɝs ðən stilɪŋ ə paɪ fɹəm ə kɪtʃən wɪndoʊ sɪl. ðoʊ, kʌm tə θɪŋk ʌv ɪt, ðə spɑɾi mɛmɹiz ðət ɹɪmeɪn ə hɪz bɔɪhʊd sim tə kənteɪn ɡɛɾɪŋ hæf-skɪn fəɹ ðəɾ ə taɪm əɹ tu.

The empty hallways he walked along were only dimly lit. One stand lamp in three or four carried flames in front of the mirrors, little pools of light with pale shadows between that never quite reached darkness. His boots were loud on the floor tiles. They rang on the marble stairs. It was unlikely anyone at all would be awake this late, but if someone did see him, he must not look as if he were skulking. Tucking his thumbs behind his belt, he made himself saunter. It was no worse than stealing a pie from a kitchen window sill. Though, come to think of it, the spotty memories that remained of his boyhood seemed to contain getting half-skinned for that a time or two.

stɛpɪŋ ɑntu ðə kɑləmd wɔk ðət bɔɹɾɝd ðə steɪbliɑɹd, hi tɝn ʌp ɪz kɑlɝ əɡɛns ðə wɪnd-dʒɹɪvən ɹeɪn flaɪɪŋ bɪtwin ðə fluɾəd waɪt kɑləmz. blʌɾi ɹeɪn! ə mæn kəd dʒɹaʊn ɪn ɪt, ivən wən i hæd nɑt ɹɪli bɪn aʊtsaɪd jɛt. ðə wɔl-maʊntəd læmps hæd bloʊn aʊt, ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə pɛɹ flæŋkɪŋ ði oʊpən ɡeɪts, ði oʊnli ɡloʊɪŋ spɑts ɪn ðə pɔɹɪŋ ɹeɪn. hi kəd nɑt meɪk aʊt ðə ɡɑɹdz aʊtsaɪd ðə ɡeɪts. ðə sintʃæn skwɑd wəd bi əz moʊʃənləs əz ɪf ɪt wɝ ə plɛzən æftɝnun. vɛɹi laɪkli ði ɛbu dɑɹi, tu; ðeɪ dɪd nɑt laɪk biɪŋ ʃoʊn ʌp ɪn ɛni weɪ. æftɝ ə moʊmən i ɹitʃɹiɾəd tə ði æntəɹum dɔɹ, tə əvɔɪd ɡɛɾɪŋ kəmplitli dʒɹɛntʃt. nʌθɪŋ muvd ɪn ðə steɪbliɑɹd. wɛɹ wɝ ðeɪ? blʌɾ ən blʌɾi æʃəz, wɛɹ . . . ?

Stepping onto the columned walk that bordered the stableyard, he turned up his collar against the wind-driven rain flying between the fluted white columns. Bloody rain! A man could drown in it, even when he had not really been outside yet. The wall-mounted lamps had blown out, except for the pair flanking the open gates, the only glowing spots in the pouring rain. He could not make out the guards outside the gates. The Seanchan squad would be as motionless as if it were a pleasant afternoon. Very likely the Ebou Dari, too; they did not like being shown up in any way. After a moment he retreated to the anteroom door, to avoid getting completely drenched. Nothing moved in the stableyard. Where were they? Blood and bloody ashes, where . . . ?

ɹaɪɾɝz əpɪɹɾ ɪn ðə ɡeɪts, lɛd baɪ tu mɛn əfʊt kæɹiɪŋ poʊl-læntɝnz. hi kəd nɑt kaʊn əm ɪn ðə ɹeɪn, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ tu mɛni. wəd sintʃæn mɛsənʒɝz əv læntɝn-bɛɹɝz? meɪbi, ɪn ðɪs wɛðɝ. ɡɹɪmæsɪŋ, hi tʊk ənʌðɝ stɛp bæk, ɪndə ði æntəɹum. ðə θɪn laɪɾ ʌv ə sɪŋɡəl stænd-læmp bɪhaɪn ɪm wɑz ɪnʌf tə tɝn ðə naɪɾ aʊtsaɪd tə ə blæŋkəɾ ə blæk, bʌɾ i pɪɹɾ ɪndə ɪt. ɪn ə fju mɪnəts, fɔɹ hɛvəli kloʊk fɪɡjɝz əpɪɹd, hɝiɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə dɔɹ. ɪf ðeɪ wɝ mɛsənʒɝz, ðeɪ wəd pæs ɪm baɪ wɪθaʊɾ ə sɛkənd ɡlæns.

Riders appeared in the gates, led by two men afoot carrying pole-lanterns. He could not count them in the rain, but they were too many. Would Seanchan messengers have lantern-bearers? Maybe, in this weather. Grimacing, he took another step back, into the anteroom. The thin light of a single stand-lamp behind him was enough to turn the night outside to a blanket of black, but he peered into it. In a few minutes, four heavily cloaked figures appeared, hurrying toward the door. If they were messengers, they would pass him by without a second glance.

"jɔɹ mæn veɪnɪn ɪz ɹud," ɛdʒiənɪn ənaʊnst, θɹoʊɪŋ bæk əɹ hʊɾ əz sun ʃi wɑz bɪɑn ðə fluɾəd kɑləmz. ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs, hɝ feɪs wɑz dʒʌst ə ʃædoʊ, bʌt ðə koʊlnəs ə hɝ vɔɪs wɑz səfɪʃən tə tɛl ɪm wʌɾ i wəd si bɪfɔɹ ʃi stɛpt ɪndə ði æntəɹum, fɔɹsɪŋ ɪm tə muv bæk. hɝ bɹaʊz wɝ dʒɹɔn daʊn ʃɑɹpli, ən əɹ blu aɪz wɝ aɪsi ɔɡɝz. ə ɡɹɪm-feɪs doʊmən fɑloʊd hɝ, ʃeɪkɪŋ ɹeɪn fɹəm ɪz kloʊk, ən ðən ə pɛɹ ə sʌldəm, wʌn peɪl ən jɛloʊ-hɛɹd, ði ʌðɝ wɪð lɔŋ bɹaʊn hɛɹ. hi kəd nɑt si mʌtʃ mɔɹ sɪns ðeɪ stʊd wɪð ðɛɹ hɛdz daʊn, stʌɾiɪŋ ðə flɔɹ taɪlz ɪn fɹʌn ə ðɛɹ fit. "ju dɪdn tɛl mi ʃi hæd tu mɛn wɪð hɝ," ɛdʒiənɪn wɛn ɑn, pilɪŋ əɹ ɡlʌvz ɔf. ɑd, haʊ ʃi kəd meɪk ðət dʒɹɔl saʊn bɹɪsk. ʃi dɪd nɑt ɡɪv ə mæn ɹum tə skwiz ɪn ə wɝd. "ɔɹ ðət mɪstʃɹəs ɑnən wɑz kʌmɪŋ. lʌkəli, aɪ noʊ haʊ tə ədæpt. plænz ɔlweɪz niɾ ədæptɪŋ, wʌns ði æŋkɝ ɪz dʒɹaɪ. spikɪŋ ə dʒɹaɪ, hæv jə bɪn ɹʌnɪŋ ɝaʊn aʊtsaɪɾ ɔlɹɛɾi? aɪ tʃɹʌs jə hævənt ɡɑɾən jɝsɛlf noʊɾəst."

"Your man Vanin is rude," Egeanin announced, throwing back her hood as soon she was beyond the fluted columns. In the darkness, her face was just a shadow, but the coldness of her voice was sufficient to tell him what he would see before she stepped into the anteroom, forcing him to move back. Her brows were drawn down sharply, and her blue eyes were icy augers. A grim-faced Domon followed her, shaking rain from his cloak, and then a pair of sul'dam, one pale and yellow-haired, the other with long brown hair. He could not see much more since they stood with their heads down, studying the floor tiles in front of their feet. "You didn't tell me she had two men with her," Egeanin went on, peeling her gloves off. Odd, how she could make that drawl sound brisk. She did not give a man room to squeeze in a word. "Or that Mistress Anan was coming. Luckily, I know how to adapt. Plans always need adapting, once the anchor is dry. Speaking of dry, have you been running around outside already? I trust you haven't gotten yourself noticed."

"wʌt dʒju min, jə ədæptəd, ðə plæn?" mæt dɪmændəd, ɹeɪkɪŋ ɪz hænz θɹu hɪz hɛɹ. laɪt, ɪt wɑz wɛt! "aɪ hæɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ leɪɾ aʊt!" waɪ wɝ ðoʊz tu sʌldəm stændɪŋ soʊ stɪl? ɪf i hæɾ ɛvɝ sin stætʃuz ə ɹɪlʌktəns, ɪt wɑz ðət pɛɹ. "hu ɑɹ ðoʊz ʌðɝz aʊt ðɛɹ?"

"What do you mean, you adapted, the plan?" Mat demanded, raking his hands through his hair. Light, it was wet! "I had everything laid out!" Why were those two sul'dam standing so still? If he had ever seen statues of reluctance, it was that pair. "Who are those others out there?"

"ðə pipəl fɹəm ði ɪn," ɛdʒiənɪn sɛɾ ɪmpeɪʃənli. "fɔɹ wʌn θɪŋ, aɪ niɾ ə pɹɑpɝ ɑntʊɹɑʒ tə lʊk ɹaɪt fəɹ ɛni stʃɹit pətʃɹoʊlz. ðoʊz tu - wɔɹɾɝz? - ɑɹ mʌskjəlɝ fɛloʊz; ðeɪ meɪk ɛksələn læntɝn-bɛɹɝz. fəɹ ənʌðɝ, aɪ dɪdnt wɑnə ɹɪsk mɪsɪŋ əm ɪn ðɪs bloʊ. bɛɾɝ ðət wəɹ ɔl təɡɛðɝ fɹəm ðə stɑɹt." hɝ hɛd tɝnd, fɑloʊɪŋ ɪz ɡlænsɪz ət ðə sʌldəm. "ðiz ɑɹ sɛɾə zɑɹbi ən ɹɛnə əmeɪn. aɪ səspɛk ðeɪ hoʊp jəl fɝɡɛt ðoʊz neɪmz æftɝ tənaɪt."

"The people from the inn," Egeanin said impatiently. "For one thing, I need a proper entourage to look right for any street patrols. Those two - Warders? - are muscular fellows; they make excellent lantern-bearers. For another, I didn't want to risk missing them in this blow. Better that we are all together from the start." Her head turned, following his glances at the sul'dam. "These are Seta Zarbey and Renna Emain. I suspect they hope you'll forget those names after tonight."

ðə peɪl wʊmən flɪntʃt ət ðə neɪm sɛɾə, wɪtʃ meɪd ði ʌðɝ ɹɛnə. niðɝ ɹeɪzd əɹ hɛd. wʌt hoʊl dɪɾ ɛdʒiənɪn əv ɑn ðɛm, ɛniweɪ? nɑt ðəɾ ɪt mæɾɝd. ɔl ðət mæɾɝd wɑz ðət ðeɪ wɝ hɪɹ ən ɹɛɾi tə də wʌt wɑz nɛsəsɛɹi.

The pale woman flinched at the name Seta, which made the other Renna. Neither raised her head. What hold did Egeanin have on them, anyway? Not that it mattered. All that mattered was that they were here and ready to do what was necessary.

"noʊ pɔɪn stændɪŋ hɪɹ," mæt sɛd. "lɛts ɡɛɾ ɑn wɪð ɪt." hi lɛɾ əɹ tʃeɪnʒəz ɪn ðə plæn ɡoʊ wɪθaʊt fɝðɝ kɑmɛnt. æftɝ ɔl, laɪɪŋ ɑn ðət bɛɾ ɪn taɪlɪnz əpɑɹtməns, hi hæd dɪsaɪɾɪd tə ɹɪsk ə tʃeɪnʒ əɹ tu hɪmsɛlf.

"No point standing here," Mat said. "Let's get on with it." He let her changes in the plan go without further comment. After all, lying on that bed in Tylin's apartments, he had decided to risk a change or two himself.


tʃæptɝ θɝɾiwʌn


CHAPTER 31

wʌt ði æɛlfɪn sɛd


What the Aelfinn Said

ðə sintʃæn noʊbəlwʊmən ɪkspɹɛst sɝpɹaɪz, ən noʊ lɪɾəl ɪɹɪteɪʃən, wən mæt əkʌmpəniɾ əɹ təwɔɹd ðə kɛnəlz. sɛɾə ən ɹɛnə nu ðə weɪ, ʌv kɔɹs, ən i wɑz səpoʊz tə bi ɡɛɾɪŋ ɪz kloʊk ən wʌtɛvɝ ɛls i mɛn tə kæɹi. ðə tu sʌldəm fɑloʊɾ əm θɹu ðə pʊɹli lɪt hɔlz, kloʊks hæŋɪŋ daʊn ðɛɹ bæks ən aɪz ɑn ðə flɔɹ. doʊmən bɹɔɾ ʌp ðə ɹɪɹ əz ðoʊ ʃɛpɝɾɪŋ ðə pɛɹ. ðə bɹeɪd hæŋɪŋ daʊn ðə saɪɾ ə hɪz hɛd sweɪɾ əz ɪz aɪz dɑɹɾɪd daʊn ɛvɹi kɹɔsɪŋ kɔɹəɾɝ, ən səmtaɪmz i fɛlt əɾ ɪz weɪst əz ðoʊ ɪkspɛktɪŋ tə faɪn ə sɔɹɾ əɹ ə kʌdʒəl. ɪksɛp fəɹ ðɛm, ðə tæpəstʃɹi-laɪn hɔlweɪz wɝ saɪlən ən stɪl.

The Seanchan noblewoman expressed surprise, and no little irritation, when Mat accompanied her toward the kennels. Seta and Renna knew the way, of course, and he was supposed to be getting his cloak and whatever else he meant to carry. The two sul'dam followed them through the poorly lit halls, cloaks hanging down their backs and eyes on the floor. Domon brought up the rear as though shepherding the pair. The braid hanging down the side of his head swayed as his eyes darted down every crossing corridor, and sometimes he felt at his waist as though expecting to find a sword or a cudgel. Except for them, the tapestry-lined hallways were silent and still.

"aɪ hæv ə smɔl ɛɹən ʌp ðɛɹ," mæt toʊld ɛdʒiənɪn, əz kæʒəwəli əz i nu haʊ, ən smaɪl fəɹ hɝ. "noʊ nid tə bɑðɝ jɝsɛlf. woʊn teɪk ə mɪnut." hɪz vɛɹi bɛst smaɪl sim tə meɪk noʊ mɔɹ ɪmpɹɛʃən ðən ɪt hæd jɛstɝdeɪ ɪn əɹ ɹum ət ði ɪn.

"I have a small errand up there," Mat told Egeanin, as casually as he knew how, and smiled for her. "No need to bother yourself. Won't take a minute." His very best smile seemed to make no more impression than it had yesterday in her room at the inn.

"ɪf jə ɹɛk mi naʊ - " ʃi ɡɹaʊld ɪn ə θɹɛɾənɪŋ toʊn.

"If you wreck me now - " she growled in a threatening tone.

"dʒʌst ɹɪmɛmbɝ u plæn ðɪs," hi mʌɾɝd, ən ʃi ɡɹʌntɪd. laɪt, wɪmən ɔlweɪz sim tə θɪŋk ðeɪ kəd dʒʌst stɛp ɪn ən teɪk oʊvɝ, ən də ə bɛɾɝ dʒɑb ðən ðə mæn huz dʒɑb ɪt wɑz!

"Just remember who planned this," he muttered, and she grunted. Light, women always seemed to think they could just step in and take over, and do a better job than the man whose job it was!

ət list ʃi meɪd noʊ fɝðɝ kəmpleɪnt. ðeɪ klaɪm kwɪkli tə ðə tɑp flɔɹ ə ðə pæləs, ðən ʌp ðə dɑɹk nɛɹoʊ stɛɹz tə ðə spɹɔlɪŋ æɾɪk. oʊnli ə fju ʌv ðə læmps wɝ lɪt, nɑɾ ivən əz mɛni əz ɪn ðə hɔlweɪz bɪloʊ, ən ðə meɪz ə nɛɹoʊ kɔɹɪɾɝz bɪtwin ðə taɪni wʊɾən ɹumz wɑz ə mæs ə peɪl ʃædoʊz. nʌθɪŋ muvd, ən mæt bɹiðd ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ izəli. hi wʊɾə bɹiðd iziɝ stɪl ɪf ɹɛnə hæd nɑt saɪd wɪð ɑbviəs ɹɪlif.

At least she made no further complaint. They climbed quickly to the top floor of the Palace, then up the dark narrow stairs to the sprawling attic. Only a few of the lamps were lit, not even as many as in the hallways below, and the maze of narrow corridors between the tiny wooden rooms was a mass of pale shadows. Nothing moved, and Mat breathed a little more easily. He would have breathed easier still if Renna had not sighed with obvious relief.

ʃi ən sɛɾə nu wɛɹ ðə vɛɹiəs deɪmeɪn wɝ kɛnɪld, ən ɪf ðeɪ dɪd nɑɾ ɪɡzækli hɝi, ðeɪ meɪd noʊ dɪleɪ ɪn hɛɾɪŋ dipɝ ɪn ði æɾɪk, pɝhæps kəz doʊmən stɪl wɔkt ət ðɛɹ hilz. ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ən ɪmədʒ tə ɪnspaɪɹ kɑnfəɾəns. wɛl, ɪf wɪʃɪz wɝ hɔɹsəz, bɛɡɝz wəd ɹaɪd. ə mæn meɪd də wɪð wʌɾ i hæd. ɪspɛʃli wən i hæd noʊ tʃɔɪs.

She and Seta knew where the various damane were kenneled, and if they did not exactly hurry, they made no delay in heading deeper in the attic, perhaps because Domon still walked at their heels. It was not an image to inspire confidence. Well, if wishes were horses, beggars would ride. A man made do with what he had. Especially when he had no choice.

ɛdʒiənɪn ɡeɪv ɪm ə læs hɑɹd lʊk ən ɡɹaʊld əɡɛn, wɝdləsli ðɪs taɪm, ðən stʃɹoʊɾ ɔf æftɝ ði ʌðɝz, hɝ kloʊk flɛɹɪŋ bɪhaɪn hɝ. hi ɡɹɪməst əɾ əɹ bæk. ðə weɪ ðə wʊmən wɔkt, jə kəd teɪk əɹ fəɹ ə mæn ɪf ʃi wɑz nɑt wɛɹɪŋ ə dʒɹɛs.

Egeanin gave him a last hard look and growled again, wordlessly this time, then strode off after the others, her cloak flaring behind her. He grimaced at her back. The way the woman walked, you could take her for a man if she was not wearing a dress.

hi dɪɾ əv ən ɛɹənd, ən meɪbi nɑt soʊ smɔl. ɪt wɑz nɑt sʌmθɪŋ i wɑntəd tə du. laɪt, hi hæd tʃɹaɪd tə tɔk hɪmsɛlf aʊɾ ʌv ɪt! ɪt wɑz sʌmθɪŋ i blʌɾi wɛl hæd tə du, ðoʊ. əz sun əz ɛdʒiənɪn vænɪʃt ɝaʊn ə kɔɹnɝ æftɝ doʊmən ən ði ʌðɝz, hi dɑɹɾɪd fəɹ ðə nɪɹəst ɹum ðəɾ i ɹɪmɛmbɝd kənteɪnɪŋ wʌn ə ðə si foʊk.

He did have an errand, and maybe not so small. It was not something he wanted to do. Light, he had tried to talk himself out of it! It was something he bloody well had to do, though. As soon as Egeanin vanished around a corner after Domon and the others, he darted for the nearest room that he remembered containing one of the Sea Folk.

izɪŋ oʊpən ðə pleɪn wʊɾən dɔɹ saʊnləsli, hi slɪpt ɪndə ðə pɪtʃ-blæk ɪntɪɹiɝ. ðə slipɪŋ wʊmən ɪnsaɪd snɔɹd wɪð ə ɹæspɪŋ saʊnd. sloʊli hi fɛlt ɪz weɪ fɔɹwɝɾ əntɪl ɪz ni bʌmpt ɪndə ðə bɛd, ðən fɛlt əlɔŋ ðə maʊn bɪniθ ðə blæŋkəts mɔɹ kwɪkli, faɪndɪŋ əɹ hɛd dʒʌst ɪn taɪm tə klæmp ɪz hæn oʊvɝ əɹ maʊθ əz ʃi dʒɝkt əweɪk.

Easing open the plain wooden door soundlessly, he slipped into the pitch-black interior. The sleeping woman inside snored with a rasping sound. Slowly he felt his way forward until his knee bumped into the bed, then felt along the mound beneath the blankets more quickly, finding her head just in time to clamp his hand over her mouth as she jerked awake.

"aɪ wɑn jə tə ænsɝ ə kwɛstʃən," hi wɪspɝd. blʌɾ ən æʃəz, wʌɾ ɪf i hæd mɪsteɪkən ðə ɹum? wʌɾ ɪf ðɪs wɑz nɑɾ ə wɪndfɪndɝ əɾ ɔl, bʌt wʌn ə ðə blʌɾi sintʃæn wɪmən? "wʌt wəd jə də ɪf aɪ tʊk ðət kɑlɝ ɔf jəɹ nɛk?" lɪftɪŋ ɪz hænd, hi hɛld ɪz bɹɛθ.

"I want you to answer a question," he whispered. Blood and ashes, what if he had mistaken the room? What if this was not a Windfinder at all, but one of the bloody Seanchan women? "What would you do if I took that collar off your neck?" Lifting his hand, he held his breath.

"aɪ wəd fɹi maɪ sɪstɝz, ɪf ɪt plizɪz ðə laɪt ðət ʃəd hæpən." ðə si foʊk æksɛns ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs meɪɾ ɪm bɹið əɡɛn. "ðə laɪt bi wɪlɪŋ, wi wəd kɹɔs ðə hɑɹbɝ, sʌmhaʊ, tə wɛɹ əɹ pipəl ɑɹ hɛld, ən fɹi əz mɛni əz wi wɝ eɪbəl." ði ənsin wʊmənz vɔɪs ɹɪmeɪn loʊ, bʌt ɡɹu fɪɹsɝ baɪ ðə wɝd. "ðə laɪt bi wɪlɪŋ, wi wəd teɪk bæk əɹ ʃɪps, ən faɪɾ əɹ weɪ tə si. naʊ! ɪf ðɪs ɪz ə tʃɹɪk, pʌnɪʃ mi fəɹ ɪɾ ən bi dʌn, əɹ kɪl mi fəɹ ɪt. aɪ wɑz ɑn ðə bɹɪŋk ə jildɪŋ, ʌv ɡɪvɪŋ ʌp maɪsɛlf, ən ðə ʃeɪm ə ðət wɪl bɝn mi fɝɛvɝ, bʌt juv ɹimaɪndəd mi hu aɪ æm, ən naʊ əl nɛvɝ jild. dʒju hɪɹ mi? nɛvɝ!"

"I would free my sisters, if it pleases the Light that should happen." The Sea Folk accents in the darkness made him breathe again. "The Light be willing, we would cross the harbor, somehow, to where our people are held, and free as many as we were able." The unseen woman's voice remained low, but grew fiercer by the word. "The Light be willing, we would take back our ships, and fight our way to sea. Now! If this is a trick, punish me for it and be done, or kill me for it. I was on the brink of yielding, of giving up myself, and the shame of that will burn me forever, but you have reminded me who I am, and now I will never yield. Do you hear me? Never!"

"æn ɪf aɪ æsk jə tə weɪt fəɹ θɹi aʊɝz?" hi æskt, stɪl kɹaʊtʃɪŋ oʊvɝ hɝ. "aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ ði æθɑn maɪɹ dʒʌdʒɪŋ ðə pæsədʒ ʌv ən aʊɝ wɪðɪn mɪnəts." ðət fɛloʊ hæd nɑt bɪn hɪm, bʌt ðə mɛmɹi wɑz ɪz naʊ, pæsədʒ ɑn ən æθɑn maɪɹ vɛsəl fɹəm ælɔɹələn tə bɑɹɑʃtə, ən ə bɹaɪt-aɪd si foʊk wʊmən u wɛpt wən ʃi ɹəfjuz tə fɑloʊ hɪm əʃɔɹ.

"And if I asked you to wait for three hours?" he asked, still crouching over her. "I remember the Atha'an Miere judging the passage of an hour within minutes." That fellow had not been him, but the memory was his now, passage on an Atha'an Miere vessel from Allorallen to Barashta, and a bright-eyed Sea Folk woman who wept when she refused to follow him ashore.

"hu ɑɹ ju?" ʃi wɪspɝd.

"Who are you?" she whispered.

"aɪm kɔl mæt kɔθən, ɪf ɪt meɪks ə dɪfɝəns."

"I'm called Mat Cauthon, if it makes a difference."

"aɪ æm nɛstɛl dɪn sækʊɹə saʊθ stɑɹ, mæt kɔθən." hi hɝɾ əɹ spɪt, ən nu wʌt ʃi wɑz duɪŋ. hi spæɾ ɑn ɪz oʊn pɑm, ən ðɛɹ tu hænz faʊn itʃ ʌðɝ ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs. hɝz wɑz əz kælʌzd əz hɪz, hɝ ɡɹɪp stʃɹɔŋ. "aɪ wɪl weɪt," ʃi sɛd. "æn əl ɹɪmɛmbɝ ju. jə ɑɹ ə ɡɹeɪɾ ən ɡʊd mæn."

"I am Nestelle din Sakura South Star, Mat Cauthon." He heard her spit, and knew what she was doing. He spat on his own palm, and their two hands found each other in the darkness. Hers was as callused as his, her grip strong. "I will wait," she said. "And I will remember you. You are a great and good man."

"aɪm dʒʌst ə ɡæmblɝ," hi toʊl hɝ. hɝ hænd ɡaɪɾəd ɪz tə ðə sɛɡmɛntɪd kɑlɝ ɝaʊn əɹ nɛk, ən ɪt keɪm oʊpən fəɹ ɪm wɪð ə mətælɪk snɪk. ʃi dʒɹu ə vɛɹi lɔŋ bɹɛθ.

"I'm just a gambler," he told her. Her hand guided his to the segmented collar around her neck, and it came open for him with a metallic snick. She drew a very long breath.

hi oʊnli hæd tə pʊɾ əɹ fɪŋɡɝz ɪn ðə pɹɑpɝ pleɪsəz ən ʃoʊ hɝ ðə tʃɹɪk wʌns bɪfɔɹ ʃi ɡɑɾ ɪt, bʌɾ i meɪɾ əɹ kloʊs ən oʊpən ðə kɑlɝ θɹi taɪmz bɪfɔɹ i wɑz sæɾəsfaɪd. ɪf i wɑz gɑnə də ðɪs, hi maɪɾ əz wɛl meɪk ʃʊɹ ɪt wɑz dʌn ɹaɪt. "θɹi aʊɝz, əz nɪɹ əz jə kæn," hi ɹimaɪndəd hɝ.

He only had to put her fingers in the proper places and show her the trick once before she got it, but he made her close and open the collar three times before he was satisfied. If he was going to do this, he might as well make sure it was done right. "Three hours, as near as you can," he reminded her.

"æz nɪɹ əz aɪ kæn," ʃi wɪspɝd.

"As near as I can," she whispered.

ʃi kəd ɹuən ɛvɹiθɪŋ, bʌɾ ɪf i kəd nɑt teɪk ə tʃæns, ðən u kʊd? hi wɑz ðə mæn wɪð ðə lʌk, æftɝ ɔl. meɪbi ɪt hæd nɑt bɪn ɔl ðət mʌtʃ ɪn ɛvəɾəns leɪtli, bʌɾ i hæd faʊn ɛdʒiənɪn dʒʌst wən i niɾəd hɝ. mæt kɔθən stɪl hæd ðə lʌk.

She could ruin everything, but if he could not take a chance, then who could? He was the man with the luck, after all. Maybe it had not been all that much in evidence lately, but he had found Egeanin just when he needed her. Mat Cauthon still had the luck.

slɪpɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə ɹum əz kwaɪətli əz i hæɾ ɛntɝd, hi kloʊz ðə dɔɹ. ən ɔlmoʊs tʃoʊkt ɑn ɪz tʌŋ. hi wɑz stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə bæk ʌv ə waɪd, ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd wʊmən ɪn ə ɹɛd-pænəl dʒɹɛs. bɪɑn əɹ stʊɾ ɛdʒiənɪn dʒɹɔn ʌp tə hɝ fʊl haɪt, ən tɛslɪn, kənɛktəd tə ɹɛnə baɪ ðə sɪlvɝ lɛŋθ ʌv ən æɾəm. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ saɪn ə doʊmən əɹ sɛɾə əɹ ðɪs idɛzinə hi stɪl hæd nɑt sin tə noʊ hɝ. ɛdʒiənɪn lʊk fɪɹs əz ə laɪoʊnəs oʊvɝ əɹ kɪl, bʌt tɛslɪn wɑz waɪd-aɪɾ ən tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ, tɛɹəfaɪd hæf aʊɾ ə hɝ wɪts, ən ɹɛnəz maʊθ hæɾ ə twɪs ðət sɛd ʃi maɪt sɪk ʌp ɛni moʊmənt naʊ.

Slipping out of the room as quietly as he had entered, he closed the door. And almost choked on his tongue. He was staring at the back of a wide, gray-haired woman in a red-paneled dress. Beyond her stood Egeanin drawn up to her full height, and Teslyn, connected to Renna by the silver length of an a'dam. There was no sign of Domon or Seta or this Edesina he still had not seen to know her. Egeanin looked fierce as a lioness over her kill, but Teslyn was wide-eyed and trembling, terrified half out of her wits, and Renna's mouth had a twist that said she might sick up any moment now.

nɑt dɛɹɪŋ tə bɹið, hi tʊk ə kɔʃəs stɛp təwɔɹd ðə ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd wʊmən, stʃɹɛtʃɪŋ aʊɾ ɪz hænz. ɪf i oʊvɝpaʊɝɾ əɹ bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəd kɹaɪ aʊt, ðeɪ kəd haɪd hɝ. . . . wɛɹ? sɛɾə ən ɹɛnə wəd wɑnə kɪl hɝ. noʊ mæɾɝ wʌt hoʊld ɛdʒiənɪn hæɾ ɑn ðɛm, ðə wʊmən kəd neɪm ðɛm.

Not daring to breathe, he took a cautious step toward the gray-haired woman, stretching out his hands. If he overpowered her before she could cry out, they could hide her. . . . Where? Seta and Renna would want to kill her. No matter what hold Egeanin had on them, the woman could name them.

ɛdʒiənɪnz stɝn blu aɪz kɑɾ ɪz oʊvɝ ðə ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd sʌldəmz ʃoʊldɝ fəɹ ə bɹif ɪnstən bɪfɔɹ foʊkəsɪŋ ɑn ði ʌðɝ wʊmənz feɪs əɡɛn. "noʊ!" ʃi sɛd ʃɑɹpli. "ðɛɹ ɪz noʊ taɪm tə weɪst wɪð tʃeɪnʒəz tə maɪ plænz, naʊ. ðə haɪ leɪɾi sjuɹɔθ sɛɾ aɪ kəd juz ɛni deɪmeɪn aɪ wɪʃ, dɝsʌldəm."

Egeanin's stern blue eyes caught his over the gray-haired sul'dam's shoulder for a brief instant before focusing on the other woman's face again. "No!" she said sharply. "There is no time to waste with changes to my plans, now. The High Lady Suroth said I could use any damane I wish, Der'sul'dam."

"ʌv kɔɹs, maɪ leɪɾi," ðə ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd wʊmən ɹɪplaɪd, saʊndɪŋ kənfjuzd. "aɪ mɪɹli pɔɪntəɾ aʊt ðət tɛsi ɪz nɑt ɹɪli tʃɹeɪnd. aɪ æktʃəli  keɪm ʌp tə lʊk ɪn ɑn ʃiz ɪz kʌmɪŋ əlɔŋ vɛɹi naɪsli, naʊ, maɪ leɪɾi, bʌt . . ."

"Of course, my Lady," the gray-haired woman replied, sounding confused. "I merely pointed out that Tessi is not really trained. I actually came up to look in on her. She is coming along very nicely, now, my Lady, but . . ."

stɪl nɑt bɹiðɪŋ, mæt bækt əweɪ ɑn tɪptoʊ. hi iz daʊn ðə dɑɹk nɛɹoʊ stɛɹz juzɪŋ ɪz hænz əɡɛns ðə wɔlz tə səpɔɹɾ əz mʌtʃ ə hɪz weɪɾ əz pɑsəbəl. hi dɪd nɑt ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɛni kɹiki stɛps kʌmɪŋ ʌp, bʌt ðəɹ wɝ tʃænsəz, ən ðən ðəɹ wɝ tʃænsəz. ə mæn tʊk ðoʊz i hæd tə, ən dɪd nɑt pɹɛs ɪz lʌk ʌðɝwaɪz. ðət wɑz ðə weɪ tə ə lɔŋ laɪf, sʌmθɪŋ i wɪʃt fəɹ vɛɹi mʌtʃ.

Still not breathing, Mat backed away on tiptoe. He eased down the dark narrow stairs using his hands against the walls to support as much of his weight as possible. He did not remember any creaky steps coming up, but there were chances, and then there were chances. A man took those he had to, and did not press his luck otherwise. That was the way to a long life, something he wished for very much.

ət ðə fʊɾ ə ðə stɛps, hi pɔz tə sʌk ɪn ɛɹ əntɪl ɪz hɑɹt stɑpt paʊndɪŋ. əntɪl ɪt sloʊɾ ə lɪɾəl, ɛniweɪ. ɪt maɪt nɑt stɑp paʊndɪŋ tɪl təmɑɹoʊ. hi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ i hæd dʒɹɔn bɹɛθ sɪns siɪŋ ðə ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd wʊmən. laɪt! ɪf ɛdʒiənɪn θɔt ʃi hæd ðə mæɾɝ ɪn hænd, wɛl ən blʌɾi ɡʊd, bʌt dʒʌs ðə seɪm, laɪt! ʃi mʌst əv nusəz ɝaʊn ðə tu sʌldəmz nɛks! hɝ plæn? wɛl, ʃi hæd bɪn ɹaɪɾ əbaʊt noʊ taɪm tə weɪst. hi ɹæn.

At the foot of the steps, he paused to suck in air until his heart stopped pounding. Until it slowed a little, anyway. It might not stop pounding till tomorrow. He was not sure he had drawn breath since seeing the gray-haired woman. Light! If Egeanin thought she had the matter in hand, well and bloody good, but just the same, Light! She must have nooses around the two sul'dam's necks! Her plan? Well, she had been right about no time to waste. He ran.

hi ɹæn əntɪl ɪz hɪp ɡeɪv ə ʃɑɹp twɪnʒ, ən i stʌmbəld ɪndə ə tɝkwɔɪz-ɪnleɪd teɪbəl. hi kɑɾ ə sʌmɝ tæpəstʃɹi tə kip fɹəm fɔlɪŋ, ən ðə bɹaɪt-flaʊɝd lɛŋθ ə sɪlk tɔɹ fɹi fɹəm ðə jɛloʊ mɑɹbəl kɔɹnəs fəɹ hæf ɪts lɛŋθ. ðə tɔl waɪt pɔɹsələn veɪs sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðə teɪbəl tɑpəld, ʃæɾɝɪŋ ɑn ðə blu-ænd-ɹɛd flɔɹ taɪlz wɪð ə kɹæʃ ðəɾ ɛkoʊɾ əlɔŋ ðə hɔlweɪ. æftɝ ðæt, hi hɑbəld. bʌɾ i hɑbəld əz fæst əz ɛni mæn ɛvɝ hæd. ɪf ɛniwʌn keɪm tə ɪnvɛstəɡeɪt ðə nɔɪz, ðeɪ wɝ nɑt gɑnə faɪn mæt kɔθən stændɪŋ oʊvɝ ðət mɛs, əɹ wɪðɪn tu kɔɹɪɾɝz ʌv ɪt.

He ran until his hip gave a sharp twinge, and he stumbled into a turquoise-inlaid table. He caught a summer tapestry to keep from falling, and the bright-flowered length of silk tore free from the yellow marble cornice for half its length. The tall white porcelain vase sitting on the table toppled, shattering on the blue-and-red floor tiles with a crash that echoed along the hallway. After that, he hobbled. But he hobbled as fast as any man ever had. If anyone came to investigate the noise, they were not going to find Mat Cauthon standing over that mess, or within two corridors of it.

lɪmpɪŋ ðə ɹɛst ə ðə weɪ tə taɪlɪnz əpɑɹtməns, hi wɑz əkɹɔs ðə sɪɾɪŋ ɹum ən ɪndə ðə bɛdtʃeɪmbɝ bɪfɔɹ i ɹilaɪz ðət ðə læmps wɝ ɔl lɪt. ðə bleɪz ɪn ðə bɛdʒɹum faɪɝpleɪs hæd bɪn ɹɪnud wɪð splɪt bɪləts fɹəm ðə ɡɪldɪd wʊd-bæskət. taɪlɪn, hɝ ɑɹmz dʌbəl bɪhaɪn əɹ tə wɝk əɾ əɹ bʌɾənz, lʊkt ʌp əɾ ɪz ɛntʃɹəns ən fɹaʊnd. hɝ dɑɹk ɡɹin ɹaɪɾɪŋ dʒɹɛs wɑz ɹɪŋkəld. ðə faɪɝ kɹækəld ən spæɾ ə ʃaʊɝ ə spɑɹks ʌp ðə tʃɪmni.

Limping the rest of the way to Tylin's apartments, he was across the sitting room and into the bedchamber before he realized that the lamps were all lit. The blaze in the bedroom fireplace had been renewed with split billets from the gilded wood-basket. Tylin, her arms doubled behind her to work at her buttons, looked up at his entrance and frowned. Her dark green riding dress was wrinkled. The fire crackled and spat a shower of sparks up the chimney.

"aɪ dɪdn ɪkspɛk jə bæk jɛt," hi sɛd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə θɪŋk. ʌv ɛvɹiθɪŋ i hæd kənsɪɾɝd ɡoʊɪŋ əmɪs tənaɪt, taɪlɪn ɹɪtɝnɪŋ ɝli hæd nɛvɝ bɪn ɪn ɪt. hɪz bɹeɪn sim fɹoʊzən.

"I didn't expect you back yet," he said, trying to think. Of everything he had considered going amiss tonight, Tylin returning early had never been in it. His brain seemed frozen.

"sjuɹɔθ lɝn ðəɾ ən ɑɹmi hæd vænɪʃt ɪn mʊɹændi," taɪlɪn ɹɪplaɪd sloʊli, stʃɹeɪɾənɪŋ. ʃi spoʊk æbsənli, ɡɪvɪŋ wʌt ʃi sɛɾ ə fɹækʃən ə ði ətɛnʃən ʃi pʊɾ ɪndə stʌɾiɪŋ mæt kɔθən. "wʌɾ ɑɹmi, əɹ haʊ ɛni ɑɹmi kən vænɪʃ, aɪ doʊnt noʊ, bʌt ʃi dɪsaɪɾɪd əɹ ɹɪtɝn wɑz ɝdʒənt. wi lɛft ɛvɹiwʌn bɪhaɪnd, keɪm əz fæst əz wʌn ə ðə bists kəd kæɹi dʒʌs ðə tu ʌv əs ən ðə wʊmən u hændəld ɪt, ən kɑməndɪɹd tu hɔɹsəz tə ɹaɪɾ ʌp fɹəm ðə dɑks əloʊn. ʃi ivən wɛn tə ðəɾ ɪn əkɹɔs ðə skwɛɹ wɛɹ ɔl ðɛɹ ɔfəsɝz ɑɹ ɪnstɛɾ ə kʌmɪŋ hɪɹ. aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ʃi ɪntɛnz tə slip tənaɪt, əɹ lɛɾ ɛni ʌv ðɛm. . . ."

"Suroth learned that an army had vanished in Murandy," Tylin replied slowly, straightening. She spoke absently, giving what she said a fraction of the attention she put into studying Mat Cauthon. "What army, or how any army can vanish, I don't know, but she decided her return was urgent. We left everyone behind, came as fast as one of the beasts could carry just the two of us and the woman who handled it, and commandeered two horses to ride up from the docks alone. She even went to that inn across the square where all their officers are instead of coming here. I don't think she intends to sleep tonight, or let any of them. . . ."

lɛɾɪŋ əɹ wɝdz tʃɹeɪl ɔf, taɪlɪn ɡlaɪɾɪd tə hɪm əkɹɔs ðə kɑɹpəts ən fɪŋɡɝɾ ɪz pleɪn ɡɹin koʊt. "ðə tʃɹʌbəl wɪð hævɪŋ ə pɛt fɑks," ʃi mɝmɝd, "ɪz ðət sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ ɪt ɹɪmɛmbɝz ɪts ə fɑks." ðoʊz bɪɡ dɑɹk aɪz pɪɹɾ ʌp ət hɪm. sʌɾənli ʃi siz tu hænfəlz ə hɪz hɛɹ ən pʊld ɪz hɛd daʊn fəɹ ə kɪs ðət kɝld ɪz toʊz ɪn ɪz buts. "ðæt," ʃi sɛd bɹɛθləsli wən ʃi faɪnəli lɛɾ ɪm ɡoʊ, "ɪz tə ʃoʊ jə haʊ mʌtʃ əl mɪs ju." wɪθaʊt ðə slaɪɾəst tʃeɪnʒ ʌv ɪkspɹɛʃən, ʃi slæpt ɪm soʊ hɑɹd ðət sɪlvɝ flɛks floʊɾəd ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪz aɪz. "æn ðəɾ ɪz fəɹ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə snik əweɪ waɪl aɪ wɑz ɡɔn." tɝnɪŋ əɹ bæk, ʃi pʊld əɹ meɪn ə ɹeɪvən hɛɹ oʊvɝ wʌn ʃoʊldɝ. "əndu maɪ bʌɾənz fəɹ mi, maɪ pɹɪɾi lɪɾəl fɑks. wi ɝaɪv soʊ leɪɾ aɪ dɪsaɪɾɪd nɑt tə weɪk maɪ meɪdz, bʌt ðiz fɪŋɡɝneɪlz meɪk bʌɾənz ɔl bʌɾ ɪmpɑsəbəl. wʌn læs naɪt təɡɛðɝ, ən təmɑɹoʊ əl sɛn jə ɑn jəɹ weɪ."

Letting her words trail off, Tylin glided to him across the carpets and fingered his plain green coat. "The trouble with having a pet fox," she murmured, "is that sooner or later it remembers it is a fox." Those big dark eyes peered up at him. Suddenly she seized two handfuls of his hair and pulled his head down for a kiss that curled his toes in his boots. "That," she said breathlessly when she finally let him go, "is to show you how much I will miss you." Without the slightest change of expression, she slapped him so hard that silver flecks floated in front of his eyes. "And that is for trying to sneak away while I was gone." Turning her back, she pulled her mane of raven hair over one shoulder. "Undo my buttons for me, my pretty little fox. We arrived so late I decided not to wake my maids, but these fingernails make buttons all but impossible. One last night together, and tomorrow I will send you on your way."

mæt ɹʌbd ɪz tʃik. ðə wʊmən cʊɾə bɹoʊkən ə tuθ fəɹ hɪm! ət list ʃi hæd dʒɑɹɾ ɪz θɔts lus. ɪf sjuɹɔθ wɑz ət ðə wɑndɝɪŋ wʊmən, ʃi wɑz nɑɾ ɪn ðə tɑɹɑsɪn pæləs tə si wʌt ʃi ʃəd nɑt. hɪz lʌk wɑz stɪl ɡʊd. hi oʊnli hæd tə wɝi əbaʊt ðə wʊmən ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm. ði oʊnli weɪ wɑz fɔɹwɝd.

Mat rubbed his cheek. The woman could have broken a tooth for him! At least she had jarred his thoughts loose. If Suroth was at The Wandering Woman, she was not in the Tarasin Palace to see what she should not. His luck was still good. He only had to worry about the woman in front of him. The only way was forward.

"aɪm ɡoʊɪŋ tənaɪt," hi sɛd, pʊɾɪŋ ɪz hænz ɑn taɪlɪnz ʃoʊldɝz. "ænd wən aɪ du, aɪm teɪkɪŋ ə kʌpəl ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ fɹəm ði æɾɪk. kʌm wɪð mi. əl sɛn tɑm ən dʒulɪn tə faɪn bɛslən, ən - "

"I'm going tonight," he said, putting his hands on Tylin's shoulders. "And when I do, I'm taking a couple of Aes Sedai from the attic. Come with me. I'll send Thom and Juilin to find Beslan, and - "

"ɡoʊ wɪð ju?" ʃi sɛɾ ɪnkɹɛdʒjələsli, muvɪŋ əweɪ ən tɝnɪŋ tə feɪs hɪm. hɝ pɹaʊd feɪs wɑz skɔɹnfəl. "pɪdʒən, aɪ doʊn fænsi bɪkʌmɪŋ jəɹ pɹɪɾi, ən aɪ hæv noʊ ɪntɛntʃən ə bɪkʌmɪŋ ə ɹɛfjʊdʒi. əɹ ə livɪŋ ɔltɑɹə tə huɛvɝ ðə sintʃæn tʃuz tə ɹipleɪs mi. aɪm ðə kwin ʌv ɔltɑɹə, ðə laɪt hɛlp mi, ən əl nɑɾ əbændən maɪ kʌntʃɹi naʊ. jə ɹɪli min tə tʃɹaɪ fɹiɪŋ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ? aɪ wɪʃ jə wɛl ɪn ɪt, ɪf jə mʌst - aɪ wɪʃ ðə sɪstɝz wɛl - bʌɾ ɪt simz ə ɡʊd weɪ tə hæv jəɹ hɛd stʌk ʌp ɑn ə spaɪk, swiɾəlɪŋ. ɪts tu pɹɪɾi ə hɛd tə bi kʌɾ ɔf ən kʌvɝd wɪð tɑɹ."

"Go with you?" she said incredulously, moving away and turning to face him. Her proud face was scornful. "Pigeon, I don't fancy becoming your pretty, and I have no intention of becoming a refugee. Or of leaving Altara to whoever the Seanchan choose to replace me. I am the Queen of Altara, the Light help me, and I will not abandon my country now. You really mean to try freeing the Aes Sedai? I wish you well in it, if you must - I wish the sisters well - but it seems a good way to have your head stuck up on a spike, sweetling. It's too pretty a head to be cut off and covered with tar."

hi tʃɹaɪd tə teɪk əɹ baɪ ðə ʃoʊldɝz əɡɛn, bʌt ʃi stɛp bæk wɪð ə pɪɹsɪŋ lʊk ðət meɪɾ ɪz hænz fɔl. hi pʊɾ ɛvɹi skɹæp ə ɝdʒənsi hi kəd faɪn ɪndə hɪz vɔɪs. "taɪlɪn, aɪ meɪd ʃʊɹ ɛvɹibɑɾi nu aɪ wɑz livɪŋ, ən æŋkʃəs tə bi ɡɔn bɪfɔɹ jə ɹɪtɝnd, soʊ ðə sintʃæn wəd noʊ jə dɪdn əv ɛniθɪŋ tə də wɪð ɪt, bʌt naʊ - "

He tried to take her by the shoulders again, but she stepped back with a piercing look that made his hands fall. He put every scrap of urgency he could find into his voice. "Tylin, I made sure everybody knew I was leaving, and anxious to be gone before you returned, so the Seanchan would know you didn't have anything to do with it, but now - "

"aɪ ɹɪtɝn ən sɝpɹaɪz ju," ʃi bɹoʊk ɪn fɪɹsli, "æn jə taɪd mi ʌp ən lɛf mi ʌndɝ ðə bɛd. wən aɪm dɪskʌvɝɾ ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ, əl bi fjʊɹiəs wɪð ju. aʊtʃɹeɪdʒd!" ʃi smaɪld, bʌɾ əɹ aɪz ɡlɪɾɝd, nɑt ðət fɑɹ fɹəm aʊtʃɹeɪdʒ naʊ, wʌtɛvɝ ʃi sɛɾ əbaʊt fɑksəz ən sɛndɪŋ ɪm ɑn ɪz weɪ. "aɪ wɪl ɔfɝ ə baʊnti fəɹ ju, ən tɛl tuɑn ʃi kən baɪ jə wən jəɹ kɑt, ɪf ʃi stɪl wɑns ju. əl bi ðə pɝfək haɪ blʌɾ ɪn maɪ æŋɡɝ. ðəl bɪliv mi, dʌklɪŋ. aɪv ɔlɹɛɾi toʊl sjuɹɔθ aɪ ɪntɛn tə ʃeɪv maɪ hɛɹ."

"I returned and surprised you," she broke in fiercely, "and you tied me up and left me under the bed. When I am discovered in the morning, I will be furious with you. Outraged!" She smiled, but her eyes glittered, not that far from outrage now, whatever she said about foxes and sending him on his way. "I will offer a bounty for you, and tell Tuon she can buy you when you're caught, if she still wants you. I will be the perfect High Blood in my anger. They'll believe me, duckling. I've already told Suroth I intend to shave my hair."

mæt ɡɹɪnd wikli. hi sɝɾənli bɪliv hɝ. ʃi ɹɪli wəd sɛl ɪm ɪf i wɑz kɑt. "wɪmən ɑɹ ə meɪz θɹu bɹaɪɹz ɪn ðə naɪt," ði oʊl seɪɪŋ wɛnt, ən ivən ðeɪ də nɑt noʊ ðə weɪ.

Mat grinned weakly. He certainly believed her. She really would sell him if he was caught. "Women are a maze through briars in the night," the old saying went, and even they do not know the way.

taɪlɪn ɪnsɪstəɾ ɑn supɝvaɪzɪŋ əɹ oʊn baɪndɪŋ. ʃi sim tə teɪk pɹaɪɾ ɪn ɪt. ʃi hæd tə bi baʊnd wɪð stʃɹɪps kʌt fɹəm əɹ skɝts, əz ɪf ʃi hæd kʌm ɑn ɪm baɪ sɝpɹaɪz ən bɪn oʊvɝpaʊɝd. ðə nɑts hæd tə bi taɪt, soʊ ʃi kəd nɑɾ ɪskeɪp haʊɛvɝ ʃi stʃɹʌɡəld, ən ʃi dɪd stʃɹʌɡəl əɡɛnst əm wʌns ðeɪ wɝ taɪd, θɹæʃɪŋ əbaʊt hɑɹɾ ɪnʌf ðəɾ ɪt simd ʃi ɹɪli wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɡɛt fɹi. meɪbi ʃi wɑz; hɝ maʊθ twɪstəɾ ɪn ə snɑɹl wən ʃi feɪld. hɝ æŋkəlz ən ɹɪsts hæd tə bi taɪd təɡɛðɝ ɪn ðə smɔl ə hɝ bæk, ən ə liʃ ɹʌn fɹəm əɹ nɛk tə wʌn lɛɡ ʌv ðə bɛd, soʊ ʃi kəd nɑt ɹɪɡəl əɹ weɪ əkɹɔs ðə flɔɹ ən aʊɾ ɪndə ðə hɔl. ən ə kɔɹs, ʃi kəd nɑt bi eɪbəl tə ʃaʊt fəɹ hɛlp, iðɝ. wən i dʒɛnli pʊʃt wʌn ə hɝ sɪlk kɝtʃəfs ɪndə hɝ maʊθ ən taɪɾ ənʌðɝ tə hoʊld ɪɾ ɪn pleɪs, ʃi smaɪld, bʌɾ əɹ aɪz wɝ fɪɹs. ə meɪz θɹu bɹaɪɹz ɪn ðə naɪt.

Tylin insisted on supervising her own binding. She seemed to take pride in it. She had to be bound with strips cut from her skirts, as if she had come on him by surprise and been overpowered. The knots had to be tight, so she could not escape however she struggled, and she did struggle against them once they were tied, thrashing about hard enough that it seemed she really was trying to get free. Maybe she was; her mouth twisted in a snarl when she failed. Her ankles and wrists had to be tied together in the small of her back, and a leash run from her neck to one leg of the bed, so she could not wriggle her way across the floor and out into the hall. And of course, she could not be able to shout for help, either. When he gently pushed one of her silk kerchiefs into her mouth and tied another to hold it in place, she smiled, but her eyes were fierce. A maze through briars in the night.

"aɪ æm gɑnə mɪs ju," hi sɛd kwaɪətli əz i pʊʃt əɹ bɪniθ ði ɛdʒ ə ðə bɛd. tə hɪz sɝpɹaɪz, hi ɹilaɪz ðəɾ i ɹɪli wʊd. laɪt! hɝidli hi ɡæðɝɾ ɪz kloʊk ən ɡlʌvz ən spɪɹ, ən snʌf ðə læmps ɑn ɪz weɪ aʊt. wɪmən kəd tæŋɡəl ə mæn ɪn ðət meɪz bɪfɔɹ i nu ɪt.

"I am going to miss you," he said quietly as he pushed her beneath the edge of the bed. To his surprise, he realized that he really would. Light! Hurriedly he gathered his cloak and gloves and spear, and snuffed the lamps on his way out. Women could tangle a man in that maze before he knew it.

ðə hɔlweɪz ɹɪmeɪn ɛmpti, ən saɪlən seɪv fəɹ ðə saʊn ə hɪz oʊn lɪmpɪŋ butstɛps, bʌɾ ɛni ɹɪlif i fɛl vænɪʃt wən i ɹitʃt ði æntəɹum ɔf ðə steɪbliɑɹd.

The hallways remained empty, and silent save for the sound of his own limping bootsteps, but any relief he felt vanished when he reached the anteroom off the stableyard.

ðə sɪŋɡəl lɪt stænd-læmp stɪl kæst ə weɪvɝɪŋ laɪɾ ɑn ðoʊz ɪnɛvəɾəbəl flaʊɝd tæpəstʃɹiz, bʌt dʒulɪn ən ɪz wʊmən wɝ nɑt ðɛɹ, ən niðɝ wɝ ɛdʒiənɪn ən ði ʌðɝz. wɪð ðə taɪm i hæd teɪkən ʌp wɪð taɪlɪn, ðeɪ ɔl ʃʊɾə bɪn weɪɾɪŋ ɑn ɪm baɪ naʊ. bɪɑn ðə kɑləmd wɔk ðə ɹeɪn wɑz ʃiɾɪŋ daʊn ɪn ə sɑləd blæk kɝɾən ðət hɪɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ. kəd ðeɪv ɡɔn ɑn tə ðə steɪbəlz? ðəɾ ɛdʒiənɪn sim tə tʃeɪnʒ ɪz plæn wɛnɛvɝ ɪt suɾəd hɝ.

The single lit stand-lamp still cast a wavering light on those inevitable flowered tapestries, but Juilin and his woman were not there, and neither were Egeanin and the others. With the time he had taken up with Tylin, they all should have been waiting on him by now. Beyond the columned walk the rain was sheeting down in a solid black curtain that hid everything. Could they have gone on to the stables? That Egeanin seemed to change his plan whenever it suited her.

ɡɹʌmbəlɪŋ ʌndɝ ɪz bɹɛθ, hi hɪtʃt ɪz kloʊk ɝaʊn ɪm ən pɹipɛɹd tə meɪk ɪz weɪ tə ðə steɪbəlz θɹu ðə daʊnpɔɹ. hi hæd hæd dʒʌst əbaʊɾ ɔl i kəd teɪk ʌv wɪmən tənaɪt.

Grumbling under his breath, he hitched his cloak around him and prepared to make his way to the stables through the downpour. He had had just about all he could take of women tonight.

"soʊ jə ɑɹ ɪntɛndɪŋ tə liv. aɪ kænɑɾ əlaʊ ðæt, tɔɪ."

"So you are intending to leave. I cannot allow that, Toy."

wɪð ən oʊθ, hi spʌn ɑn ɪz hil ən faʊn hɪmsɛlf feɪsɪŋ tuɑn, hɝ dɑɹk feɪs stɝn bɪhaɪn əɹ lɔŋ tʃɹænspɛɹən veɪl. ðə nɛɹoʊ sɝklət hoʊldɪŋ ðə veɪl ɑn əɹ ʃeɪvən hɛd wɑz ə mæs ə faɪɝdʒɹɑps ən pɝlz, jɛɾ ənʌðɝ fɔɹtʃən teɪkən təɡɛðɝ wɪð ðə waɪd dʒuəl bɛl ðət sɪntʃt əɹ weɪst ən ðə lɔŋ nɛkləs ɝaʊn əɹ nɛk. ə faɪn taɪm ɪt wɑz tə bi noʊɾɪsɪŋ dʒuəlz, haʊɛvɝ ɹɪtʃ. wʌɾ ɪn ðə laɪt wɑz ʃi duɪŋ əweɪk? blʌɾ ən æʃəz, ɪf ʃi wɛn ɹʌnɪŋ ɔf, ʃaʊɾɪŋ fəɹ ɡɑɹdz tə stɑp ɪm . . . !

With an oath, he spun on his heel and found himself facing Tuon, her dark face stern behind her long transparent veil. The narrow circlet holding the veil on her shaven head was a mass of firedrops and pearls, yet another fortune taken together with the wide jeweled belt that cinched her waist and the long necklace around her neck. A fine time it was to be noticing jewels, however rich. What in the Light was she doing awake? Blood and ashes, if she went running off, shouting for guards to stop him . . . !

dɛspɝətli hi ɹitʃt fəɹ ðə skɪni ɡɝl, bʌt ʃi ɹɪθd əweɪ fɹəm ɪz ɡɹɪp ən sɛn ði æʃhændʒɹeɪ flaɪɪŋ wɪð ə ʃɑɹp bloʊ ðət hæf nʌmd ɪz ɹɪst. hi ɪkspɛktəɾ əɹ tə fli, bʌɾ ɪnstɛd ʃi ɹeɪn bloʊz ət hɪm, pʌntʃɪŋ wɪð foʊldəd nʌkəlz, tʃɑpɪŋ əɹ hænz laɪk æks bleɪdz. hi hæd kwɪk hænz, ðə kwɪkɪs θɔɹn hæɾ ɛvɝ sin əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə ði oʊld ɡlimən, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ɔl i kəd də tə wɔɹɾ əɹ ɔf, fɝɡɛɾ əbaʊt ɡɹæbɪŋ hɝ. ɪf i hæd nɑt bɪn tʃɹaɪɪŋ soʊ hɑɹd tə kip əɹ fɹəm bɹeɪkɪŋ ɪz noʊz - əɹ sʌmθɪŋ ɛls, meɪbi; ʃi hɪt vɛɹi hɑɹd fəɹ sətʃ ə taɪni θɪŋ - ɪksɛp fəɹ ðæt, hi maɪɾ əv faʊn ðə hoʊl θɪŋ læfəbəl. hi taʊɝɾ oʊvɝ hɝ, ðoʊ hi wɑz nɑt mʌtʃ əbʌv ævɝɪdʒ haɪt, jɛt ʃi keɪm əɾ ɪm ɪn ə kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾəd fjʊɹi, əz ðoʊ ʃi wɝ ðə tɔlɝ ən stʃɹɔŋɝ ən ɪkspɛktəd tə oʊvɝwɛlm hɪm. fəɹ səm ɹizən, æftɝ ə fju moʊməns əɹ fʊl lɪps kɝvd ɪn ə smaɪl, ən ɪf i hæd nɑt noʊn bɛɾɝ, hi wʊɾə sɛd ðoʊz bɪɡ lɪkwəɾ aɪz tʊk ɑn ə ɡloʊ ʌv dɪlaɪt. bɝn hɪm, θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt haʊ pɹɪɾi ə wʊmən wɑz əɾ ə taɪm laɪk ðɪs wɑz əz bæɾ əz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pɹaɪs əɹ dʒɛmz!

Desperately he reached for the skinny girl, but she writhed away from his grip and sent the ashandarei flying with a sharp blow that half numbed his wrist. He expected her to flee, but instead she rained blows at him, punching with folded knuckles, chopping her hands like axe blades. He had quick hands, the quickest Thorn had ever seen according to the old gleeman, but it was all he could do to ward her off, forget about grabbing her. If he had not been trying so hard to keep her from breaking his nose - or something else, maybe; she hit very hard for such a tiny thing - except for that, he might have found the whole thing laughable. He towered over her, though he was not much above average height, yet she came at him in a concentrated fury, as though she were the taller and stronger and expected to overwhelm him. For some reason, after a few moments her full lips curved in a smile, and if he had not known better, he would have said those big liquid eyes took on a glow of delight. Burn him, thinking about how pretty a woman was at a time like this was as bad as trying to price her gems!

əbɹʌpli, ʃi floʊd bæk fɹəm hɪm, juzɪŋ boʊθ hænz tə ɹiədʒʌs ðə sɝkəl ə dʒɛmz ðət sɪkjʊɹɾ əɹ veɪl. ðəɹ wɑz sɝɾənli nʌθɪŋ laɪk dɪlaɪɾ ɑn əɹ feɪs naʊ. hɝ ɪkspɹɛʃən wɑz ɔl kɑnsəntʃɹeɪʃən. pleɪsɪŋ əɹ fit kɛɹfəli, nɛvɝ teɪkɪŋ əɹ aɪz fɹəm ɪz feɪs, ʃi bɪɡæn sloʊli ɡæðɝɪŋ əɹ waɪt pliɾɪd skɝts ɪn əɹ hænz, ɪntʃɪŋ əm ʌp əbʌv əɹ niz ɪn foʊlz.

Abruptly, she flowed back from him, using both hands to readjust the circle of gems that secured her veil. There was certainly nothing like delight on her face now. Her expression was all concentration. Placing her feet carefully, never taking her eyes from his face, she began slowly gathering her white pleated skirts in her hands, inching them up above her knees in folds.

hi kəd nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd waɪ ʃi wɑz nɑɾ ɔlɹɛɾi ʃaʊɾɪŋ fəɹ hɛlp, bʌɾ i nu ʃi wɑz əbaʊt tə kɪk ət hɪm. wɛl, nɑɾ ɪf i hæɾ ɛniθɪŋ tə seɪ əbaʊɾ ɪt! hi lɛp fəɹ hɝ, ən ɛvɹiθɪŋ hæpən ət wʌns. ə stæb ə peɪn ɪn ɪz hɪp sɛn ɪm tə wʌn ni. tuɑn snætʃt əɹ skɝts ɔlmoʊs tə hɝ oʊn hɪps, ən əɹ slɪm, waɪt-stɑkɪnɡd lɛɡ flæʃt aʊɾ əɾ ɪm ɪn ə kɪk ðət pæst oʊvɝ ɪz hɛɾ əz ʃi wɑz sʌɾənli hɔɪstəɾ ɪndə ði ɛɹ.

He could not understand why she was not already shouting for help, but he knew she was about to kick at him. Well, not if he had anything to say about it! He leaped for her, and everything happened at once. A stab of pain in his hip sent him to one knee. Tuon snatched her skirts almost to her own hips, and her slim, white-stockinged leg flashed out at him in a kick that passed over his head as she was suddenly hoisted into the air.

hi θɔɾ i mʌs bi əz sɝpɹaɪz tə si noʊl wɪð ɪz ɑɹmz ɹæpt ɝaʊn ðə ɡɝl əz ʃi wɑz tə hæv ðoʊz ɑɹmz ðɛɹ, bʌɾ i ɹiæktəd fæstɝ ðən ʃi. əz ʃi oʊpən əɹ maʊθ tə ʃaʊɾ ət læst, mæt skɹæmbəl tə hɪz fiɾ ən bɪɡæn stʌfɪŋ əɹ veɪl bɪtwin əɹ tiθ, tɪpɪŋ ðə dʒuəl sɝklət tə ðə flɔɹ wɪð ə flɪp ə hɪz hænd. ʃi dɪd nɑt koʊɑpɝeɪt ðə weɪ taɪlɪn hæd, ʌv kɔɹs. ə fɝm ɡɹɪp ɑn əɹ dʒɔ wɑz ɔl ðət kɛpt əɹ fɹəm sɪŋkɪŋ əɹ tiθ ɪndə hɪz fɪŋɡɝz. æŋɡɹi saʊnz keɪm fɹəm əɹ θɹoʊt, ən əɹ aɪz ʃoʊɾ ə fjʊɹi ðeɪ nɛvɝ hæɾ ət ðə wɝst ə hɝ ətæk. ʃi twɪstəɾ ɪn noʊlz ɡɹɪp ən fleɪld əɹ lɛɡz, bʌt ðə wɔɹn oʊl mæn mænədʒ tə ʃɪft ɪz bɝɾən ən hɪmsɛlf tə əvɔɪɾ ɛvɹi kɪk ə hɝ hilz. wɔɹn əɹ nɑt, hi sim tə hæv noʊ dɪfəkəlti hæŋɪŋ ɑn tə hɝ.

He thought he must be as surprised to see Noal with his arms wrapped around the girl as she was to have those arms there, but he reacted faster than she. As she opened her mouth to shout at last, Mat scrambled to his feet and began stuffing her veil between her teeth, tipping the jeweled circlet to the floor with a flip of his hand. She did not cooperate the way Tylin had, of course. A firm grip on her jaw was all that kept her from sinking her teeth into his fingers. Angry sounds came from her throat, and her eyes showed a fury they never had at the worst of her attack. She twisted in Noal's grip and flailed her legs, but the worn old man managed to shift his burden and himself to avoid every kick of her heels. Worn or not, he seemed to have no difficulty hanging on to her.

"du jə ɔfən əv ðɪs sɔɹɾ ə tʃɹʌbəl wɪð wɪmən?" hi æsk maɪldli ɝaʊn ə ɡæp-tuθ smaɪl. hi wɑz wɛɹɪŋ ɪz kloʊk, ən ɪz bʌndəl bɪlɔŋɪŋz wɝ taɪɾ oʊvɝ ɪɾ əkɹɔs ɪz bæk.

"Do you often have this sort of trouble with women?" he asked mildly around a gap-toothed smile. He was wearing his cloak, and his bundled belongings were tied over it across his back.

"ɔlweɪz," mæt ɹɪplaɪd saʊɝli, ən ɡɹʌntɪd wən ə ni kɑɾ ɪz eɪkɪŋ hɪp. mænɪdʒɪŋ tə əntaɪ hɪz nɛk-skɑɹf wʌn-hændəd, hi juzd ɪt tə sɪkjʊɹ ðə wɑɾəd veɪl ɪn tuɑnz maʊθ ət ðə kɑst ʌv ə nɪp θʌm. laɪt, wʌt wɑz i gɑnə də wɪð hɝ?

"Always," Mat replied sourly, and grunted when a knee caught his aching hip. Managing to untie his neck-scarf one-handed, he used it to secure the wadded veil in Tuon's mouth at the cost of a nipped thumb. Light, what was he going to do with her?

"aɪ dɪdnt noʊ ðɪs wɑz wʌt jə wɝ plænɪŋ," noʊl sɛd, nɑt bɹiðɪŋ hɑɹɾ ɪn spaɪɾ ə ðə weɪ ðə taɪni wʊmən θɹæʃt hɝsɛlf əbaʊɾ ɪn ɪz ɡɹɪp, "bʌɾ əz jə kən si, ɪm livɪŋ tənaɪt, tu. aɪ θɔt ðəɾ ɪn ə deɪ əɹ tu, ðɪs maɪt bi ən ənplɛzən pleɪs fəɹ sʌmwʌn jə ɡeɪv ə bɛd tə."

"I didn't know this was what you were planning," Noal said, not breathing hard in spite of the way the tiny woman thrashed herself about in his grip, "but as you can see, I'm leaving tonight, too. I thought that in a day or two, this might be an unpleasant place for someone you gave a bed to."

"ə waɪz dɪsɪʒən," mæt mʌɾɝd. laɪt, hi ʃʊɾə θɔɾ ʌv wɔɹnɪŋ noʊl.

"A wise decision," Mat muttered. Light, he should have thought of warning Noal.

loʊɝɪŋ hɪmsɛlf tə hɪz niz, hi əvɔɪɾəd tuɑnz kɪks - moʊst ə ðɛm, ɛniweɪ - lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə kætʃ əɹ lɛɡz. ə naɪf plʌk fɹəm ɪz sliv stɑɹɾəd ə kʌɾ ɪn ðə hɛm ə hɝ dʒɹɛs, ən i tɔɹ əweɪ ə lɔŋ stʃɹɪp tə taɪ hɝ æŋkəlz. ɪt wɑz ə ɡʊd θɪŋ i hæd ɡɑɾən ɔl ðət pɹæktəs wɪð taɪlɪn ɝliɝ. hi wɑz nɑɾ əkʌstəm tə taɪɪŋ wɪmən ʌp. tɛɹɪŋ ɔf ə sɛkən stʃɹɪp ə klɔθ fɹəm ðə bɑɾəm ə hɝ skɝt, hi pɪkt ʌp ðə sɝkəl ə dʒɛmz fɹəm ðə flɔɹ, ən stʊd wɪð wʌn ɡɹʌn fəɹ ði ɛfɝɾ ən ə dipɝ wʌn fəɹ ə læst, tu-lɛɡəd kɪk ðət sɛt faɪɝ tə hɪz hɪp. wən i sɛt ðə sɝklət bæk ɑn əɹ hɛd, tuɑn stɛɹɾ ɪm stʃɹeɪɾ ɪn ði aɪ. ʃi hæd stɑp θɹæʃɪŋ əbaʊt jusləsli, bʌt ʃi wɑz nɑɾ əfɹeɪd. laɪt, ɪn əɹ pleɪs, hi wʊɾə bɪn sɔɪlɪŋ hɪmsɛlf.

Lowering himself to his knees, he avoided Tuon's kicks - most of them, anyway - long enough to catch her legs. A knife plucked from his sleeve started a cut in the hem of her dress, and he tore away a long strip to tie her ankles. It was a good thing he had gotten all that practice with Tylin earlier. He was not accustomed to tying women up. Tearing off a second strip of cloth from the bottom of her skirt, he picked up the circle of gems from the floor, and stood with one grunt for the effort and a deeper one for a last, two-legged kick that set fire to his hip. When he set the circlet back on her head, Tuon stared him straight in the eye. She had stopped thrashing about uselessly, but she was not afraid. Light, in her place, he would have been soiling himself.

dʒulɪn faɪnəli ɝaɪvd, ðɛn, kloʊkt ən fʊli əkuɾɝd, wɪð ɪz ʃɔɹt sɔɹɾ ən nɑtʃt sɔɹd-bɹeɪkɝ əɾ ɪz bɛlt ən ɪz θɪn bæmbu stæf ɪn wʌn hænd. ə slɛndɝ, dɑɹk-hɛɹd wʊmən ɪn ðə θɪk waɪt ɹoʊbz wɔɹn baɪ dækoʊvæl aʊtsaɪd klʌŋ tə hɪz ɹaɪɾ ɑɹm. ʃi wɑz pɹɪɾi, ɪn ə paʊɾi weɪ, wɪð ə ɹoʊzbʌd maʊθ, bʌt faɪv əɹ sɪks jɪɹz oʊldɝ ðən mæt hæɾ ɪkspɛktəd, ən əɹ lɑɹdʒ dɑɹk aɪz dɑɹɾɪd tɪmədli. ət ðə saɪɾ ə tuɑn, ʃi skwikt ən lɛt ɡoʊ ʌv dʒulɪn əz ðoʊ hi wɝ ə hɑt stoʊv, foʊldɪŋ hɝsɛlf tə ðə flɔɹ bɪsaɪd ðə dɔɹ wɪð əɹ hɛɾ ɑn əɹ niz.

Juilin finally arrived, then, cloaked and fully accoutered, with his short sword and notched sword-breaker at his belt and his thin bamboo staff in one hand. A slender, dark-haired woman in the thick white robes worn by da'covale outside clung to his right arm. She was pretty, in a pouty way, with a rosebud mouth, but five or six years older than Mat had expected, and her large dark eyes darted timidly. At the sight of Tuon, she squeaked and let go of Juilin as though he were a hot stove, folding herself to the floor beside the door with her head on her knees.

"aɪ hæd tə tɔk θɛɹə ɪndə ɹʌnɪŋ əweɪ ɔl oʊvɝ əɡɛn," ðə θif-kætʃɝ saɪd, ɡɪvɪŋ əɹ ə kənsɝn lʊk. ðət wɑz ɔl ði ɛkspləneɪʃən i meɪd fəɹ ɪz leɪtnəs, bɪfɔɹ tɝnɪŋ ɪz ətɛnʃən tə noʊlz bɝɾən. pʊʃɪŋ bæk ðə ɹɪdɪkjələs kɑnɪkəl ɹɛd kæp i wɔɹ, hi skɹætʃt ɪz hɛd. "ænd wʌt də wi də wɪð hɝ?" hi æsk sɪmpli.

"I had to talk Thera into running away all over again," the thief-catcher sighed, giving her a concerned look. That was all the explanation he made for his lateness, before turning his attention to Noal's burden. Pushing back the ridiculous conical red cap he wore, he scratched his head. "And what do we do with her?" he asked simply.

"liv əɹ ɪn ðə steɪbəlz," mæt ɹɪplaɪd. ðeɪ wəɾ ɪf veɪnɪn hæd kənvɪns ðə ɡɹumz tə lɛɾ ɪm ən hɑɹnən tɛn tə ɛni mɛsənʒɝz' hɔɹsəz ðət keɪm ɪn. əntɪl naʊ, ðət hæd sim laɪk oʊnli ən æɾəd pɹikɔʃən, nɑt ɹɪli nɛsəsɛɹi. əntɪl naʊ. "ɪn ðə heɪlɔft. ʃi ʃʊdn bi faʊn bɪfɔɹ mɔɹnɪŋ, wən ðeɪ fɔɹk daʊn fɹɛʃ heɪ fəɹ ðə stɔlz."

"Leave her in the stables," Mat replied. They would if Vanin had convinced the grooms to let him and Harnan tend to any messengers' horses that came in. Until now, that had seemed like only an added precaution, not really necessary. Until now. "In the hayloft. She shouldn't be found before morning, when they fork down fresh hay for the stalls."

"æn aɪ θɔt jə wɝ kɪdnæpɪŋ hɝ," noʊl saɪd, sɛɾɪŋ tuɑnz baʊn fit bæk ɑn ðə flɔɹ ən ʃɪftɪŋ ɪz hoʊld ɑn əɹ tə ɡɹɪpɪŋ əɹ ʌpɝ ɑɹmz. hɛd haɪ, ðə lɪɾəl wʊmən dɪsdeɪn tə stʃɹʌɡəl. ivən wɪð ə ɡæɡ ɪn əɹ maʊθ, skɔɹn wɑz klɪɹ ɑn əɹ feɪs. ʃi ɹəfjuz tə faɪt, nɑt kəz ɪt wɑz hoʊpləs, bʌt kəz ʃi dɪd nɑt tʃuz tə faɪt.

"And I thought you were kidnaping her," Noal sighed, setting Tuon's bound feet back on the floor and shifting his hold on her to gripping her upper arms. Head high, the little woman disdained to struggle. Even with a gag in her mouth, scorn was clear on her face. She refused to fight, not because it was hopeless, but because she did not choose to fight.

butstɛps ɛkoʊɾ ɪn ðə kɔɹəɾɝ liɾɪŋ tə ði æntəɹum, ɡɹoʊɪŋ laʊɾɝ. ɪt kəd bi ɛdʒiənɪn ət læst. əɹ ðə weɪ ðə naɪt sim tə bi tɝnɪŋ, ɪt maɪt bi dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹdz. ði oʊɡiɝ sɔɹt.

Bootsteps echoed in the corridor leading to the anteroom, growing louder. It could be Egeanin at last. Or the way the night seemed to be turning, it might be Deathwatch Guards. The Ogier sort.

heɪstəli, mæt moʊʃən ði ʌðɝ təwɔɹd kɔɹnɝz aʊɾ ə saɪɾ ʌv ɛniwʌn kʌmɪŋ θɹu ðə dɔɹ, ðən hɑbəld oʊvɝ tə pɪk ʌp ɪz blæk spɪɹ. dʒulɪn pʊl θɛɹə tə hɝ fiɾ ən dʒɹu hɝ tə hɪz lɛft, wɛɹ ʃi kɹaʊtʃt ɪn ðə kɔɹnɝ waɪl i stʊɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ wɪð ɪz stæf hɛld ɪn boʊθ hænz. ɪɾ əpɪɹɾ ə fɹeɪl wɛpən, bʌt ðə θif-kætʃɝ kəd juz ɪt tə ɡɹeɪɾ ɪfɛkt. noʊl dʒɹæɡd tuɑn tə ði ɑpəzət kɔɹnɝ ə ðə ɹum ən ɹilist wʌn ə hɝ ɑɹmz tə pʊɾ ə hæn ɪnsaɪɾ ɪz koʊt, wɛɹ i kɛpt ɪz lɔŋ naɪvz. mæt plæntəd hɪmsɛlf ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə ɹum wɪð ɪz bæk tə ðə ɹeɪn-soʊk naɪt, ði æʃhændʒɹeɪ əpɹaɪɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm. noʊ mæɾɝ u keɪm ɪndə ðə ɹum, hi wɑz nɑt gɑnə bi eɪbəl tə dæns əbaʊt, wɪð ɪz hɪp nɑɾɪd ɪn ə fɪs fɹəm tuɑnz kɪks, bʌɾ ɪf wɝs keɪm tə wɝst, hi kəɾ ət lis liv mɑɹks ɑn ə fju pipəl.

Hastily, Mat motioned the other toward corners out of sight of anyone coming through the door, then hobbled over to pick up his black spear. Juilin pulled Thera to her feet and drew her to his left, where she crouched in the corner while he stood in front of her with his staff held in both hands. It appeared a frail weapon, but the thief-catcher could use it to great effect. Noal dragged Tuon to the opposite corner of the room and released one of her arms to put a hand inside his coat, where he kept his long knives. Mat planted himself in the middle of the room with his back to the rain-soaked night, the ashandarei upright in front of him. No matter who came into the room, he was not going to be able to dance about, with his hip knotted in a fist from Tuon's kicks, but if worse came to worst, he could at least leave marks on a few people.

wən ɛdʒiənɪn stʃɹoʊd θɹu ðət dɔɹweɪ, hi sæɡd ɑn ðə spɪɹ ɪn ɹɪlif. tu sʌldəm ɛntɝɾ æftɝ hɝ, ən doʊmən fɑloʊd. mæt ɡɑɾ ɪz fɝs lʊk əɾ idɛzinə tə noʊ hu hi wɑz siɪŋ, ðoʊ hi dɪd ɹikɔl əɹ fɹəm wʌn deɪ wən ðə deɪmeɪn wɝ biɪŋ ɛksɝsaɪzd, ə slɛndɝ hænsəm wʊmən ɪn wʌn ə ðoʊz pleɪn ɡɹeɪ dʒɹɛsəz, wɪð blæk hɛɹ spɪlɪŋ tə hɝ weɪst. dɪspaɪt ði æɾəm liʃɪŋ əɹ tə sɛɾəz ɹɪst, idɛzinə lʊkt əbaʊɾ əɹ kɑmli. ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ɑn ə liʃ, pɝhæps, bʌɾ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ kɑnfəɾənt ðət liʃ wɑz kʌmɪŋ ɔf sun. tɛslɪn, ɑn ði ʌðɝ hænd, wɑz ə kwɪvɝɪŋ mæs ʌv iɡɝnəs, lɪkɪŋ əɹ lɪps ən stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə dɔɹ tə ðə steɪbliɑɹd. ɹɛnə ən sɛɾə hɝid ðə tu ɛɛs sədaɪ əlɔŋ bɪhaɪn ɛdʒiənɪn wɪθaʊt teɪkɪŋ ðɛɹ aɪz fɹəm ðə steɪbliɑɹd dɔɹ.

When Egeanin strode through that doorway, he sagged on the spear in relief. Two sul'dam entered after her, and Domon followed. Mat got his first look at Edesina to know who he was seeing, though he did recall her from one day when the damane were being exercised, a slender handsome woman in one of those plain gray dresses, with black hair spilling to her waist. Despite the a'dam leashing her to Seta's wrist, Edesina looked about her calmly. An Aes Sedai on a leash, perhaps, but an Aes Sedai confident that leash was coming off soon. Teslyn, on the other hand, was a quivering mass of eagerness, licking her lips and staring at the door to the stableyard. Renna and Seta hurried the two Aes Sedai along behind Egeanin without taking their eyes from the stableyard door.

"aɪ hæd tə suð ðə dɝsʌldəm," ɛdʒiənɪn sɛd, əz sun əz ʃi wɑz ɪndə ðə ɹum. "ðeɪ ɑɹ vɛɹi pɹətɛktɪv ə ðɛɹ tʃɑɹdʒəz." noʊɾɪsɪŋ dʒulɪn ən θɛɹə, ʃi skaʊld; ðəɹ hæd nɑt simd ɛni ɹizən tə tɛl əɹ əbaʊt θɛɹə, nɑt wən ʃi wɑz wɪlɪŋ tə hɛlp deɪmeɪn, bʌt klɪɹli ʃi dɪd nɑt laɪk ðə sɝpɹaɪz ʌv wʊlən ɹoʊbz. "hɝ siɪŋ sɛɾə ən ɹɛnə tʃeɪnʒəz ə fju θɪŋz, ʌv kɔɹs," ʃi wɛn ɑn, "bʌt - " hɝ wɝdz kʌɾ ɔf əz ðoʊ slaɪst wɪð ə naɪf əz əɹ aɪz fɛl ɑn tuɑn. ɛdʒiənɪn wɑz ə peɪl wʊmən, bʌt ʃi wɛn pəlɝ. tuɑn ɡlɛɹd bæk əbʌv əɹ ɡæɡ wɪð ðə stɝn fɝɑsəɾi ʌv ə hɛdzmən. "oʊ, laɪt!" ɛdʒiənɪn sɛd hɔɹsli, sɪŋkɪŋ tə hɝ niz. "ju mædmæn! ɪts dɛθ baɪ sloʊ tɔɹtʃɝ tə leɪ hænz ɑn ðə dɔɾɝ ə ðə naɪn munz!" ðə tu sʌldəm ɡæspt, ən nɛlt wɪθaʊt hɛzəteɪʃən, nɑɾ oʊnli pʊlɪŋ ðə tu ɛɛs sədaɪ daʊn wɪð əm bʌt ɡɹɪpɪŋ ði æɾəm ɹaɪɾ ət ðə kɑlɝ tə fɔɹs ðɛɹ feɪsəz tə ðə flɔɹ.

"I had to soothe the der'sul'dam," Egeanin said, as soon as she was into the room. "They are very protective of their charges." Noticing Juilin and Thera, she scowled; there had not seemed any reason to tell her about Thera, not when she was willing to help damane, but clearly she did not like the surprise of woolen robes. "Her seeing Seta and Renna changes a few things, of course," she went on, "but - " Her words cut off as though sliced with a knife as her eyes fell on Tuon. Egeanin was a pale woman, but she went paler. Tuon glared back above her gag with the stern ferocity of a headsman. "Oh, Light!" Egeanin said hoarsely, sinking to her knees. "You madman! It's death by slow torture to lay hands on the Daughter of the Nine Moons!" The two sul'dam gasped, and knelt without hesitation, not only pulling the two Aes Sedai down with them but gripping the a'dam right at the collar to force their faces to the floor.

mæt ɡɹʌntɪɾ əz ðoʊ tuɑn hæd dʒʌs kɪkt ɪm skwɛɹ ɪn ðə bɛli. hi fɛlt əz ɪf ʃi hæd. ðə dɔɾɝ ə ðə naɪn munz. ði æɛlfɪn hæd toʊld ɪm tʃɹuθ, mʌtʃ əz i heɪɾəd noʊɪŋ. hi wəd daɪ ən lɪv əɡɛn, ɪf i hæd nɑɾ ɔlɹɛɾi. hi wəd ɡɪv ʌp hæf ðə laɪɾ ə ðə wɝl tə seɪv ðə wɝld, ən i dɪd nɑɾ ivən wɑnə θɪŋk əbaʊt wʌt ðət mɛnt. hi wəd mɛɹi. . . . "ʃi ɪz maɪ waɪf," hi sɛd sɔfli. sʌmbɑɾi meɪɾ ə tʃoʊkɪŋ saʊnd; hi θɔɾ ɪt wɑz doʊmən.

Mat grunted as though Tuon had just kicked him square in the belly. He felt as if she had. The Daughter of the Nine Moons. The Aelfinn had told him truth, much as he hated knowing. He would die and live again, if he had not already. He would give up half the light of the world to save the world, and he did not even want to think about what that meant. He would marry. . . . "She is my wife," he said softly. Somebody made a choking sound; he thought it was Domon.

"wʌt?" ɛdʒiənɪn skwikt, hɝ hɛd wɪpɪŋ təwɔɹɾ ɪm soʊ fæs ðəɾ əɹ teɪl ə hɛɹ swʌŋ ɝaʊn tə slæp əɹ feɪs. hi wəd nɑɾ əv θɔt ʃi kəd skwik. "ju kænɑt seɪ ðæt! jə mʌs nɑt seɪ ðæt!"

"What?" Egeanin squeaked, her head whipping toward him so fast that her tail of hair swung around to slap her face. He would not have thought she could squeak. "You cannot say that! You must not say that!"

"waɪ nɑt?" hi dɪmændəd. ði æɛlfɪn ɔlweɪz ɡeɪv tʃɹu ænsɝz. ɔlweɪz. "ʃi ɪz maɪ waɪf. jəɹ blʌɾi dɔɾɝ ə ðə naɪn munz ɪz maɪ waɪf!"

"Why not?" he demanded. The Aelfinn always gave true answers. Always. "She is my wife. Your bloody Daughter of the Nine Moons is my wife!"

ðeɪ stɛɹɾ ət hɪm, ɪksɛp fəɹ dʒulɪn, hu tʊk ɔf ɪz kæp ən stɛɹɾ ɪndə ðæt. doʊmən ʃʊk ɪz hɛd, ən noʊl læf sɔfli. ɛdʒiənɪnz maʊθ hʌŋ oʊpən. ðə tu sʌldəm ɡeɪpt əz ðoʊ əɾ ə mædmæn, stɑɹk ɹeɪvɪŋ ən lus. tuɑn stɛɹd, bʌɾ əɹ ɪkspɹɛʃən wɑz æbsəlutli ənɹiɾəbəl, haɪɾɪŋ ɛvɹi θɔt bɪhaɪn ðoʊz dɑɹk aɪz. oʊ, laɪt, wʌt wɑz i tə du? fəɹ wʌn θɪŋ, ɡɛɾ ə muv ɑn bɪfɔɹ . . .

They stared at him, except for Juilin, who took off his cap and stared into that. Domon shook his head, and Noal laughed softly. Egeanin's mouth hung open. The two sul'dam gaped as though at a madman, stark raving and loose. Tuon stared, but her expression was absolutely unreadable, hiding every thought behind those dark eyes. Oh, Light, what was he to do? For one thing, get a move on before . . .

sɪlutʃə skɝiɾ ɪndə ðə ɹum, ən mæt ɡɹoʊnd. wɑz ɛvɹibɑɾi ɪn ðə hoʊl blʌɾi pæləs gɑnə wɔk ɪn? doʊmən tʃɹaɪd tə ɡɹæb hɝ, bʌt ʃi ɪluɾɪd hɪm, dɑɹɾɪŋ əbaʊt. ðə bʌksəm ɡoʊldən-hɛɹd sɔɪhɪn wɑz nɑt soʊ steɪtli əz juʒəwəl, ɹɪŋɪŋ əɹ hænz ən lʊkɪŋ ɝaʊn ɪn ə hʌntəd fæʃən. "fɝɡɪv mi fəɹ spikɪŋ," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn ə fɪɹ-fɪl vɔɪs, "bʌt wʌt jə də ɪz fulɪʃ bɪɑn mædnəs." wɪð ə ɡɹoʊn, ʃi dɑɹɾɪd tə hæf kɹaʊtʃ bɪtwin ðə nilɪŋ sʌldəm wɪð wʌn hæn ɑn ðə ʃoʊldɝ ʌv itʃ, əz ðoʊ sikɪŋ ðɛɹ pɹətɛkʃən. hɝ blu aɪz nɛvɝ sis flɪɾɪŋ əbaʊt ðə ɹum. "wʌtɛvɝ ði oʊmənz, ðɪs kən stɪl bi ɹɛktəfaɪɾ ɪf jəl oʊnli kənsɛn tə dʒɹɔ bæk."

Selucia scurried into the room, and Mat groaned. Was everybody in the whole bloody Palace going to walk in? Domon tried to grab her, but she eluded him, darting about. The buxom golden-haired so'jhin was not so stately as usual, wringing her hands and looking around in a hunted fashion. "Forgive me for speaking," she said in a fear-filled voice, "but what you do is foolish beyond madness." With a groan, she darted to half crouch between the kneeling sul'dam with one hand on the shoulder of each, as though seeking their protection. Her blue eyes never ceased flitting about the room. "Whatever the omens, this can still be rectified if you will only consent to draw back."

"bi izi, sɪlutʃə," mæt sɛɾ ɪn ə suðɪŋ. ʃi wɑz nɑt lʊkɪŋ ət hɪm, bʌɾ i meɪd kɑmɪŋ dʒɛstʃɝz ɛniweɪ. ɪn nʌn ə hɪz mɛmɹiz kəɾ i faɪn ə weɪ tə dil wɪð ə hɪstɛɹɪkəl wʊmən. ɪksɛp tə haɪd. "noʊ wʌn ɪz gɑnə bi hɝt. noʊ wʌn! aɪ pɹɑməs ju. jə kən bi izi, naʊ."

"Be easy, Selucia," Mat said in a soothing. She was not looking at him, but he made calming gestures anyway. In none of his memories could he find a way to deal with a hysterical woman. Except to hide. "No one is going to be hurt. No one! I promise you. You can be easy, now."

fəɹ səm ɹizən, kɑnstɝneɪʃən flæʃt əkɹɔs əɹ feɪs, bʌt ʃi sɛɾəld tə hɝ niz ən foʊldəɾ əɹ hænz ɪn əɹ læp. sʌɾənli, ɔl əɹ fɪɹ vænɪʃt, ən ʃi wɑz əz ɹiɡəl əz ɛvɝ ʃi hæd bɪn. "aɪ wɪl oʊbeɪ ju, soʊ lɔŋ əz jə də nɑt hɑɹm maɪ mɪstʃɹəs. ɪf jə du, əl kɪl ju."

For some reason, consternation flashed across her face, but she settled to her knees and folded her hands in her lap. Suddenly, all her fear vanished, and she was as regal as ever she had been. "I will obey you, so long as you do not harm my mistress. If you do, I will kill you."

fɹəm ɛdʒiənɪn, ðət wʊɾə ɡɪvən ɪm pɔz. kʌmɪŋ fɹəm ðɪs plʌmp kɹim-tʃikt wʊmən, ʃɔɹɾ ivən ɪf ʃi wɑz tɔlɝ ðən əɹ mɪstʃɹəs, hi pʊɾ ɪɾ aʊɾ ə hɪz maɪnd. ðə laɪt nu wɪmən wɝ deɪnʒɝəs, bʌɾ i θɔɾ i kəd hændəl ə leɪɾiz meɪd. ət list ʃi wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ hɪstɛɹɪkəl. ɑd, haʊ ðət keɪm ən wɛn ɪn wɪmən.

From Egeanin, that would have given him pause. Coming from this plump cream-cheeked woman, short even if she was taller than her mistress, he put it out of his mind. The Light knew women were dangerous, but he thought he could handle a lady's maid. At least she was no longer hysterical. Odd, how that came and went in women.

"aɪ səpoʊz jə min tə liv əm boʊθ ɪn ðə heɪlɔft?" noʊl sɛd.

"I suppose you mean to leave them both in the hayloft?" Noal said.

"noʊ," mæt ɹɪplaɪd, lʊkɪŋ ət tuɑn. ʃi stɛɹd ɹaɪt bæk, stɪl wɪð noʊ ɪkspɹɛʃən i kəd ɹid. ə bɔɪ-slɪm lɪɾəl wʊmən, wən i laɪkt wɪmən wɪð flɛʃ ɑn ðɛɹ boʊnz. ɛɹ tə ðə sintʃæn θɹoʊn, wən noʊbəlwɪmən ɡeɪv ɪm ɡus bʌmps. ə wʊmən u hæd wɑntəd tə baɪ hɪm, ən naʊ laɪkli wɑntəd tə pʊɾ ə naɪf ɪn ɪz ɹɪbz. ən ʃi wəd bi hɪz waɪf. ði æɛlfɪn ɔlweɪz ɡeɪv tʃɹu ænsɝz. "wi ɑɹ teɪkɪŋ əm wɪð ʌs," hi sɛd.

"No," Mat replied, looking at Tuon. She stared right back, still with no expression he could read. A boy-slim little woman, when he liked women with flesh on their bones. Heir to the Seanchan throne, when noblewomen gave him goose bumps. A woman who had wanted to buy him, and now likely wanted to put a knife in his ribs. And she would be his wife. The Aelfinn always gave true answers. "We are taking them with us," he said.

ət læst, tuɑn ʃoʊɾ ɪkspɹɛʃən. ʃi smaɪld, əz ɪf ʃi sʌɾənli nu ə sikɹət. ʃi smaɪld, ən i ʃɪvɝd. oʊ, laɪt, haʊ hi ʃɪvɝd.

At last, Tuon showed expression. She smiled, as if she suddenly knew a secret. She smiled, and he shivered. Oh, Light, how he shivered.


tʃæptɝ θɝɾitu


CHAPTER 32

eɪ pɔɹʃən ʌv wɪzdəm


A Portion of Wisdom

ðə ɡoʊldən wil wɑz ə lɑɹdʒ ɪn, dʒʌst ɔf ði əvhɑɝɪn mɑɹkət, wɪð ə lɔŋ, bim-silɪŋɡd kɑmən ɹum kɹaʊɾəd wɪð smɔl skwɛɹ teɪbəlz. ivən ət mɪddeɪ noʊ mɔɹ ðən wʌn teɪbəl ɪn faɪv hæɾ ɛniwʌn sɪɾɪŋ əɾ ɪt, ðoʊ, juʒəwəli ən aʊtlæn mɝtʃən feɪsɪŋ ə wʊmən ɪn soʊbɝ kʌlɝz wɪð əɹ hɛɹ wɔɹn ɑn tɑp ə hɝ hɛɾ əɹ ɡæðɝɾ ʌp ət ðə neɪp ə hɝ nɛk. ðə wɪmən wɝ mɝtʃəns, tu, əɹ bæŋkɝz; ɪn fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ, bæŋkɪŋ ən tʃɹeɪd wɝ fɔɹbɪɾən tə mɛn. ɔl ðə fɔɹənɝz ɪn ðə kɑmən ɹum wɝ meɪl, sɪns ðə wɪmən əmʌŋ əm kəd bi teɪkən ɪndə ðə wɪmənz ɹum. ðə smɛlz ə fɪʃ ən mʌɾən kʊkɪŋ ɪn ðə kɪtʃənz fɪl ði ɛɹ, ən əkeɪʒənəli ə ʃaʊt fɹəm wʌn ə ðə teɪbəlz sʌmənd wʌn ə ðə sɝvɪŋ mɛn u weɪɾəd ɪn ə laɪn ət ðə bæk ə ðə ɹum. ʌðɝwaɪz, ðə mɝtʃəns ən bæŋkɝz kɛp ðɛɹ vɔɪsəz loʊ. ðə saʊn ə ðə ɹeɪn aʊtsaɪd wɑz laʊɾɝ.

The Golden Wheel was a large inn, just off the Avharin Market, with a long, beam-ceilinged common room crowded with small square tables. Even at midday no more than one table in five had anyone sitting at it, though, usually an outland merchant facing a woman in sober colors with her hair worn on top of her head or gathered up at the nape of her neck. The women were merchants, too, or bankers; in Far Madding, banking and trade were forbidden to men. All the foreigners in the common room were male, since the women among them could be taken into the Women's Room. The smells of fish and mutton cooking in the kitchens filled the air, and occasionally a shout from one of the tables summoned one of the serving men who waited in a line at the back of the room. Otherwise, the merchants and bankers kept their voices low. The sound of the rain outside was louder.

"ɑɹ jə sɝɾən?" ɹænd æskt, teɪkɪŋ ðə kɹis dʒɹɔɪŋz bæk fɹəm ə læntɝn-dʒɔd sɝvɪŋ mæn i hæd dʒɹɔn ɔf tə wʌn saɪɾ ə ðə ɹum.

"Are you certain?" Rand asked, taking the creased drawings back from a lantern-jawed serving man he had drawn off to one side of the room.

"aɪ θɪŋk ɪts hɪm," ðə fɛloʊ sɛɾ ənsɝteɪnli, waɪpɪŋ ɪz hænz ɑn ə lɔŋ eɪpɹən ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd wɪð ə jɛloʊ wæɡən wil. "ɪt lʊks laɪk hɪm. hi ʃəd bi bæk sun." hɪz aɪz dɑɹɾɪd bɪɑn ɹænd, ən i saɪd. "ju bɛɾɝ baɪ ə dʒɹɪŋk əɹ ɡoʊ. mɪstʃɹəs ɡɔlɡɝ dʌzn laɪk əs tɔkɪŋ wən wi ʃəd bi wɝkɪŋ. ən ʃi wʊdn laɪk mi tɔkɪŋ əbaʊɾ əɹ peɪtʃɹənz ɛni taɪm."

"I think it's him," the fellow said uncertainly, wiping his hands on a long apron embroidered with a yellow wagon wheel. "It looks like him. He should be back soon." His eyes darted beyond Rand, and he sighed. "You better buy a drink or go. Mistress Gallger doesn't like us talking when we should be working. And she wouldn't like me talking about her patrons any time."

ɹænd ɡlænst oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. ə lin wʊmən wɪð ə tɔl aɪvɝi koʊm stʌk ɪn ðə dɑɹk bʌn ɑn ðə bæk ə hɝ hɛd wɑz stændɪŋ ɪn ðə jɛloʊ-peɪntəɾ ɑɹtʃ ðət lɛd tə ðə wɪmənz ɹum. ðə weɪ ʃi lʊkt oʊvɝ ðə kɑmən ɹum - hæf kwin sɝveɪɪŋ əɹ doʊmeɪn, hæf fɑɹmɝ sɝveɪɪŋ əɹ filz, ən iðɝ weɪ dɪsplizd wɪð ðə spɑɹsɪɾi ʌv tʃɹeɪd ʃi sɔ - neɪmd əɹ ði ɪnkipɝ. wən əɹ ɡeɪz fɛl ɑn ɹænd ən ðə læntɝn-dʒɔd fɛloʊ, ʃi fɹaʊnd.

Rand glanced over his shoulder. A lean woman with a tall ivory comb stuck in the dark bun on the back of her head was standing in the yellow-painted arch that led to the Women's Room. The way she looked over the common room - half queen surveying her domain, half farmer surveying her fields, and either way displeased with the sparsity of trade she saw - named her the innkeeper. When her gaze fell on Rand and the lantern-jawed fellow, she frowned.

"mʌld waɪn," ɹænd sɛd, hændɪŋ ðə mæn səm kɔɪnz, kɑpɝz fəɹ ðə waɪn ən ə sɪlvɝ mɑɹk fəɹ ɪz ɪnfɝmeɪʃən, ənsɝɾən əz ɪt wɑz. mɔɹ ðən ə wik hæd pæst sɪns i hæd kɪld ɹɑtʃeɪɾ ən kɪsmən hæd ɡɑɾən əweɪ, ən ɪn ɔl ðoʊz deɪz ðɪs wɑz ðə fɝs taɪm i hæd ɡɑɾən mɔɹ ðən ə ʃɹʌɡ əɹ ə ʃeɪk ə ðə hɛd wən i ʃoʊd ðə dʒɹɔɪŋz.

"Mulled wine," Rand said, handing the man some coins, coppers for the wine and a silver mark for his information, uncertain as it was. More than a week had passed since he had killed Rochaid and Kisman had gotten away, and in all those days this was the first time he had gotten more than a shrug or a shake of the head when he showed the drawings.

ðəɹ wɝ ə dʌzən ɛmpti teɪbəlz ɹaɪɾ ət hænd, bʌɾ i wɑntəd tə bi ɪn ə kɔɹnɝ ət ðə fɹʌn ə ðə ɹum, wɛɹ i kəd si hu keɪm ɪn wɪθaʊt biɪŋ sin hɪmsɛlf, ən əz i ɛdʒd ɪz weɪ bɪtwin ðə teɪbəlz, snætʃɪz ə kɑnvɝseɪʃən kɑɾ ɪz ɪɹ.

There were a dozen empty tables right at hand, but he wanted to be in a corner at the front of the room, where he could see who came in without being seen himself, and as he edged his way between the tables, snatches of conversation caught his ear.

ə tɔl peɪl wʊmən ɪn dɑɹk ɡɹin sɪlk ʃʊk əɹ hɛɾ əɾ ə stɑki mæn ɪn ə taɪt-fɪɾɪŋ blæk tɛɹən koʊt. ən aɪɝn-ɡɹeɪ bʌn meɪɾ əɹ lʊk ə lɪɾəl laɪk kædzueɪn fɹəm ðə saɪd. hi əpɪɹd tə bi meɪɾ ə stoʊn blɑks, bʌɾ ɪz dɑɹk skwɛɹ feɪs wɑz wɝid. "ju kən pʊt jəɹ maɪn əɾ iz əbaʊɾ ændɝ, mæstɝ ædmaɪɹə," ʃi sɛd suðɪŋli. "bɪliv mi, ði ændɔɹənz wɪl ʃaʊɾ ən ʃeɪk sɔɹdz ət wʌn ənʌðɝ, bʌt ðəl nɛvɝ lɛɾ ɪt kʌm tə æktʃəwəl faɪɾɪŋ. ɪts ɪn jəɹ bɛst ɪntʃɹəsts tə steɪ wɪð ðə pɹɛzən ɹut fəɹ jəɹ ɡʊdz. kɛɹhin wəd tæks jə ə fɪfθ mɔɹ ðən fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ. θɪŋk ə ði æɾəd ɪkspɛns." ðə tɛɹən ɡɹɪməst əz ɪf i wɝ θɪŋkɪŋ ʌv ɪt. əɹ wʌndɝɪŋ wɛðɝ ɪz bɛst ɪntʃɹəsts ɹɪli koʊənsaɪɾəd wɪð hɝz.

A tall pale woman in dark green silk shook her head at a stocky man in a tight-fitting black Tairen coat. An iron-gray bun made her look a little like Cadsuane from the side.
