He appeared to be made of stone blocks, but his dark square face was worried. "You can put your mind at ease about Andor, Master Admira," she said soothingly. "Believe me, the Andorans will shout and shake swords at one another, but they'll never let it come to actual fighting. It is in your best interests to stay with the present route for your goods. Cairhien would tax you a fifth more than Far Madding. Think of the added expense." The Tairen grimaced as if he were thinking of it. Or wondering whether his best interests really coincided with hers.

"aɪ hɪɹ ðə bɑɾi dɪd bi ɔl blæk ən swoʊlən," ə lin, waɪt-bɪɹɾəd ɪliɑnɝ ɪn ə dɑɹk blu koʊt sɛɾ əɾ ənʌðɝ teɪbəl. "aɪ hɪɹ ðə kaʊnsəlz dɪɾ ɔɹɾɝ ɪt bɝnd." hi ɹeɪzd ɪz aɪbɹaʊz sɪɡnɪfɪkənli ən tæp ðə saɪɾ ʌv ə pɔɪntəd noʊz ðət ɡeɪv ɪm ði əpɪɹəns ʌv ə wizəl.

"I hear the body did be all black and swollen," a lean, white-bearded Illianer in a dark blue coat said at another table. "I hear the Counsels did order it burned." He raised his eyebrows significantly and tapped the side of a pointed nose that gave him the appearance of a weasel.

"ɪf ðəɹ wɑz pleɪɡ ɪn ðə sɪɾi, mæstɝ ɑzɛɹioʊz, ðə kaʊnsəlz wʊɾə ənaʊnst ɪt," ðə slɪm wʊmən sɪɾɪŋ əkɹɔs fɹəm ɪm sɛd kɑmli. wɪð tu ɪlæbɹəɾ aɪvɝi koʊmz ɪn əɹ ɹoʊl hɛɹ, ʃi wɑz pɹɪɾi, ɪn ə fɑks-feɪst weɪ, ən kul əz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ, ðoʊ wɪð feɪn laɪnz ət ðə kɔɹnɝz ə hɝ bɹaʊn aɪz. "aɪ ɹɪli də sədʒɛst əɡɛns muvɪŋ ɛni ʌv jəɹ tʃɹeɪd tə luɡɹd. mʊɹændi ɪz moʊst ənsɛɾəld. ðə noʊbəlz wɪl nɛvɝ stæn fəɹ ɹɔdʒɹən bɪldɪŋ ən ɑɹmi. ən ðəɹ ɑɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪnvɑlvd, əz aɪm ʃʊɹ juv hɝd. ðə laɪɾ əloʊn noʊz wʌt ðəl du." ði ɪliɑnɝ ʃɹʌɡd ənkʌmftəbli. ðiz deɪz, noʊ wʌn wɑz vɛɹi sɝɾən wʌɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ wəd du, ɪf ðeɪ ɛvɝ hæd bɪn.

"If there was plague in the city, Master Azereos, the Counsels would have announced it," the slim woman sitting across from him said calmly. With two elaborate ivory combs in her rolled hair, she was pretty, in a fox-faced way, and cool as an Aes Sedai, though with faint lines at the corners of her brown eyes. "I really do suggest against moving any of your trade to Lugard. Murandy is most unsettled. The nobles will never stand for Roedran building an army. And there are Aes Sedai involved, as I'm sure you have heard. The Light alone knows what they will do." The Illianer shrugged uncomfortably. These days, no one was very certain what Aes Sedai would do, if they ever had been.

eɪ kændɔɹi wɪð ɡɹeɪ stʃɹiks ɪn ɪz fɔɹk bɪɹɾ ən ə lɑɹdʒ pɝl ɪn ɪz lɛft ɪɹ wɑz linɪŋ təwɔɹɾ ə staʊt wʊmən ɪn dɑɹk ɡɹeɪ sɪlk u wɔɹ əɹ blæk hɛɹ ɪn ə taɪt ɹoʊl əlɔŋ ðə tɑp ə hɝ hɛd. "aɪ hɪɹ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn əz bɪn kɹaʊn kɪŋ ʌv ɪljən, mɪstʃɹəs ʃɪməl." ə fɹaʊn pʊt mɔɹ ɹɪŋkəlz ɪn ɪz fɔɹhɛd. "ɡɪvən ðə waɪt taʊɝz pɹɑkləmeɪʃən, aɪm kənsɪɾɝɪŋ sɛndɪŋ maɪ spɹɪŋ wæɡənz tə tʃɹævəl əlɔŋ ði ɛɹɪnɪn tə tɛɹ. ðə ɹɪvɝ ɹoʊd meɪ bi ə hɑɹɾɝ ɹut, bʌɾ ɪljən ɪz nɑt sətʃ ə mɑɹkət fəɹ fɝz ðəɾ aɪ wɑnə teɪk tu mɛni ɹɪsks."

A Kandori with gray streaks in his forked beard and a large pearl in his left ear was leaning toward a stout woman in dark gray silk who wore her black hair in a tight roll along the top of her head. "I hear the Dragon Reborn has been crowned King of Illian, Mistress Shimel." A frown put more wrinkles in his forehead. "Given the White Tower's proclamation, I am considering sending my spring wagons to travel along the Erinin to Tear. The River Road may be a harder route, but Illian is not such a market for furs that I want to take too many risks."

ðə staʊt wʊmən smaɪld, ə vɛɹi θɪn smaɪl fəɹ sətʃ ə ɹaʊn feɪs. "aɪm toʊl ðə mæn əz hɑɹdli bɪn sin ɪn ɪljən sɪns i tʊk ðə kɹaʊn, mæstɝ pɑzəvinə. ɪn ɛni keɪs, ðə taʊɝ wɪl dil wɪð hɪm, ɪf ɪt hæzən ɔlɹɛɾi, ən ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ, aɪ ɹəsivd wɝd ðət ðə stoʊn ə tiɹ ɪz ʌndɝ sidʒ. ðəɾ ɪz hɑɹdli ə sɪtʃueɪʃən wɛɹ jəl faɪn mʌtʃ mɑɹkət fəɹ fɝz, naʊ ɪt? noʊ, tiɹ ɪz nɑɾ ə pleɪs tə əvɔɪd ɹɪsks." ðə ɹɪŋkəlz ɪn mæstɝ pɑzəvinəz fɔɹhɛd dipənd.

The stout woman smiled, a very thin smile for such a round face. "I'm told the man has hardly been seen in Illian since he took the crown, Master Posavina. In any case, the Tower will deal with him, if it hasn't already, and this morning, I received word that the Stone of Tear is under siege. That is hardly a situation where you will find much market for furs, now it? No, Tear is not a place to avoid risks." The wrinkles in Master Posavina's forehead deepened.

ɹitʃɪŋ ə smɔl teɪbəl ɪn ðə kɔɹnɝ, ɹænd tɔst ɪz kloʊk oʊvɝ ðə bæk ə ðə tʃɛɹ ən sæt wɪð ɪz bæk tə ðə wɔl, tɝnɪŋ ʌp ɪz kɑlɝ. ðə læntɝn-dʒɔd fɛloʊ bɹɔɾ ə stimɪŋ pjuɾɝ kʌp ə spaɪst waɪn, mɝmɝɾ ə hɝid θæŋks fəɹ ðə sɪlvɝ, ən skɝiɾ ɔf əɾ ə ʃaʊt fɹəm ənʌðɝ teɪbəl. tu lɑɹdʒ faɪɝpleɪsəz ɑn iðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə ɹum tʊk ðə tʃɪl ɔf ði ɛɹ, bʌɾ ɪf ɛniwʌn noʊɾəst ðət ɹænd kɛpt ɪz ɡlʌvz ɑn, noʊ wʌn ɡlænst əɾ ɪm twaɪs. hi pɹitɛndəd tə stɛɹ ɪndə ðə waɪnkʌp bɪtwin ɪz hænz ɑn ðə teɪbəl waɪl kipɪŋ ən aɪ ɑn ðə dɔɹ tə ðə stʃɹit.

Reaching a small table in the corner, Rand tossed his cloak over the back of the chair and sat with his back to the wall, turning up his collar. The lantern-jawed fellow brought a steaming pewter cup of spiced wine, murmured a hurried thanks for the silver, and scurried off at a shout from another table. Two large fireplaces on either side of the room took the chill off the air, but if anyone noticed that Rand kept his gloves on, no one glanced at him twice. He pretended to stare into the winecup between his hands on the table while keeping an eye on the door to the street.

moʊst ʌv wʌɾ i hæɾ oʊvɝhɝd dɪd nɑɾ ɪntʃɹəst ɪm ɡɹeɪtli. hi hæd hɝɾ əz mʌtʃ bɪfɔɹ, ən səmtaɪmz nu mɔɹ ðən ðə pipəl i ivzdʒɹɑpt ɑn. ɪleɪn əɡɹid wɪð ðə peɪl wʊmən, fəɹ ɪɡzæmpəl, ən ʃi hæd tə noʊ ændɝ bɛɾɝ ðən ɛni fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ mɝtʃənt. ðə stoʊn ʌndɝ sidʒ wɑz nu, ðoʊ. stɪl, hi nid nɑt tʃɹʌbəl hɪmsɛlf wɪð ɪt jɛt. ðə stoʊn hæd nɛvɝ fɔlən, ɪksɛp tə hɪm, ən i nu ɑlɑnə wɑz sʌmwɛɹ ɪn tɛɹ. hi hæd fɛlt əɹ lip fɹəm dʒʌs nɔɹθ ə fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ tə sʌmwɛɹ mʌtʃ fɑɹðɝ nɔɹθ, ðɛn, ə deɪ leɪɾɝ, tə sʌmwɛɹ fɑɹ tə ðə saʊθ ən ist. ʃi wɑz dɪstən ɪnʌf ðəɾ i kəd nɑt seɪ wɛðɝ ʃi wɑz ɪn hæɾən mɝk əɹ ðə sɪɾi ʌv tɛɹ ɪtsɛlf, jɛɾ i wɑz kɑnfəɾənt ʃi wɑz wʌn pleɪs əɹ ði ʌðɝ, wɪð fɔɹ ʌðɝ sɪstɝz i kəd tʃɹʌst. ɪf mɛɹænə ən ɹæfɛlə kəd ɡɛt wʌɾ i wɑntəd fɹəm ðə si foʊk, ðeɪ kəd fɹəm ðə tɛɹənz, tu. ɹæfɛlə wɑz tɛɹən, ən ðət ʃəd hɛlp. noʊ, ðə wɝl kəd ɡɛɾ əlɔŋ wɪθaʊɾ ɪm ə lɪɾəl lɔŋɡɝ. ɪt hæd tə.

Most of what he had overheard did not interest him greatly. He had heard as much before, and sometimes knew more than the people he eavesdropped on. Elayne agreed with the pale woman, for example, and she had to know Andor better than any Far Madding merchant. The Stone under siege was new, though. Still, he need not trouble himself with it yet. The Stone had never fallen, except to him, and he knew Alanna was somewhere in Tear. He had felt her leap from just north of Far Madding to somewhere much farther north, then, a day later, to somewhere far to the south and east. She was distant enough that he could not say whether she was in Haddon Mirk or the city of Tear itself, yet he was confident she was one place or the other, with four other sisters he could trust. If Merana and Rafela could get what he wanted from the Sea Folk, they could from the Tairens, too. Rafela was Tairen, and that should help. No, the world could get along without him a little longer. It had to.

ə tɔl mæn swɑðd ɪn ə lɔŋ, dæmp kloʊk wɪð ðə hʊd haɪɾɪŋ ɪz feɪs keɪm ɪn fɹəm ðə stʃɹit, ən ɹændz aɪz fɑloʊɾ ɪm tə ðə stɛɹz ət ðə bæk ə ðə ɹum. stɑɹɾɪŋ ʌp, ðə fɛloʊ θɹu bæk ɪz kaʊl, ɹɪvilɪŋ ə fɹɪnʒ ʌv ɡɹeɪ hɛɹ ən ə peɪl pɪntʃt feɪs. hi kəd nɑt bi ðə wʌn ðə sɝvɪŋ mæn mɛnt. noʊ wʌn wɪð aɪz wəd kənfjuz ɪm wɪð pɝəl tɔɹvəl.

A tall man swathed in a long, damp cloak with the hood hiding his face came in from the street, and Rand's eyes followed him to the stairs at the back of the room. Starting up, the fellow threw back his cowl, revealing a fringe of gray hair and a pale pinched face. He could not be the one the serving man meant. No one with eyes would confuse him with Peral Torval.

ɹænd wɛn bæk tə stʌɾiɪŋ ðə sɝfəs ə hɪz waɪn, hɪz θɔts tɝnɪŋ saʊɝ. mɪn ən nɪneɪiv hæd ɹəfjuz tə spɛnd wʌn mɔɹ aʊɝ tʃɹæmpɪŋ ðə stʃɹits, əz mɪn hæd pʊɾ ɪt, ən i səspɛktəɾ əliviə wɑz oʊnli ɡoʊɪŋ θɹu ðə moʊʃənz ə ʃoʊɪŋ ðə dʒɹɔɪŋz. wən ʃi dɪɾ ivən ðæt. ðeɪ wɝ ɔl θɹi aʊɾ ə ðə sɪɾi fəɹ ðə deɪ, ɪn ðə hɪlz, hi dʒʌdʒ fɹəm wʌt ðə bɑn toʊld ɪm ə mɪn. ʃi fɛl vɛɹi ɪksaɪɾəd əbaʊt sʌmθɪŋ. ðə θɹi ʌv əm bɪliv kɪsmən hæd flɛɾ æftɝ feɪlɪŋ tə kɪl ɹænd, ən ði ʌðɝ ɹɛnəɡeɪdz hæɾ iðɝ ɡɔn wɪð ɪm əɹ nɛvɝ kʌm əɾ ɔl. ðeɪ hæɾ ɔl bɪn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə tɔk ɪm ɪndə livɪŋ fəɹ deɪz, naʊ. ət lis læn hæd nɑt ɡɪvən ʌp.

Rand went back to studying the surface of his wine, his thoughts turning sour. Min and Nynaeve had refused to spend one more hour tramping the streets, as Min had put it, and he suspected Alivia was only going through the motions of showing the drawings. When she did even that. They were all three out of the city for the day, in the hills, he judged from what the bond told him of Min. She felt very excited about something. The three of them believed Kisman had fled after failing to kill Rand, and the other renegades had either gone with him or never come at all. They had all been trying to talk him into leaving for days, now. At least Lan had not given up.

waɪ kæn ðə wɪmən bi ɹaɪt? luz θɝɪn wɪspɝd fɪɹsli ɪn ɪz hɛd. ðɪs sɪɾi ɪz wɝs ðən ɛni pɹɪzən. ðəɹ ɪz noʊ sɔɹs hɪɹ! waɪ wəd ðeɪ steɪ? waɪ wəɾ ɛni seɪn mæn steɪ? wi kəd ɹaɪɾ aʊt, bɪɑn ðə bæɹiɝ, dʒʌs fəɹ ə deɪ, ə fju aʊɝz. laɪt, dʒʌs fəɹ ə fju aʊɝz! ðə vɔɪs læft ʌnkəntʃɹoʊləbli, waɪldli. oʊ, laɪt, waɪ də aɪ hæv ə mædmæn ɪn maɪ hɛd? waɪ? waɪ?

Why can't the women be right? Lews Therin whispered fiercely in his head. This city is worse than any prison. There is no Source here! Why would they stay? Why would any sane man stay? We could ride out, beyond the barrier, just for a day, a few hours. Light, just for a few hours! The voice laughed uncontrollably, wildly. Oh, Light, why do I have a madman in my head? Why? Why?

æŋɡɹəli, ɹænd fɔɹs luz θɝɪn tə ə mjuɾɪd hʌm, laɪk ə baɪtim bʌzɪŋ nɪɹbaɪ. hi hæd θɔɾ əbaʊɾ əkʌmpəniɪŋ ðə wɪmən ɑn ðɛɹ ɹaɪd, dʒʌs tə fil ðə sɔɹs əɡɛn, ðoʊ oʊnli mɪn hæd ʃoʊn mʌtʃ ɪnθuziæzəm. nɪneɪiv ən əliviə wəd nɑɾ ədmɪt waɪ ðeɪ wɑntəd tə ɹaɪɾ aʊt wən ðə mɔɹnɪŋ skaɪ hæd pɹɑməs ðə ɹeɪn ðət wɑz pɔɹɪŋ daʊn aʊtsaɪd naʊ. ðɪs wɑz nɑt ðə fɝs taɪm ðeɪ hæd ɡɔn. tə fil ðə sɔɹs, hi səspɛktəd. tə dʒɹɪŋk ɪn ðə wʌn paʊɝ əɡɛn, ɪf oʊnli fəɹ ə ʃɔɹt taɪm. wɛl, hi kəɾ ɛndʒjʊɹ nɑt biɪŋ eɪbəl tə tʃænəl. hi kəɾ ɛndʒjʊɹ ði æbsəns ə ðə sɔɹs. hi kʊd! hi hæd tə, soʊ hi kəd kɪl ðə mɛn u hæd tʃɹaɪd tə kɪl hɪm.

Angrily, Rand forced Lews Therin to a muted hum, like a biteme buzzing nearby. He had thought about accompanying the women on their ride, just to feel the Source again, though only Min had shown much enthusiasm. Nynaeve and Alivia would not admit why they wanted to ride out when the morning sky had promised the rain that was pouring down outside now. This was not the first time they had gone. To feel the Source, he suspected. To drink in the One Power again, if only for a short time. Well, he could endure not being able to channel. He could endure the absence of the Source. He could! He had to, so he could kill the men who had tried to kill him.

ðəɾ ɪz nɑt ðə ɹizən! luz θɝɪn ʃaʊɾəd, fɔɹsɪŋ pæst ɹændz ɛfɝts tə ʃʌɾ ɪm ʌp. jə ɑɹ əfɹeɪd! ɪf ðə sɪknəs teɪks jə waɪl jə ɑɹ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə juz ði æksɛs tɛɹæŋɡɹil, ɪt kəd kɪl ju, əɹ wɝs! ɪt kəd kɪl əs ɔl! hi moʊnd.

That is not the reason! Lews Therin shouted, forcing past Rand's efforts to shut him up. You are afraid! If the sickness takes you while you are trying to use the access ter'angreal, it could kill you, or worse! It could kill us all! he moaned.

waɪn slɑpt oʊvɝ ɹændz ɹɪst, soʊkɪŋ ɪz koʊts-liv, ən i lusən ɪz ɡɹɪp ɑn ðə waɪnkʌp. ðə θɪŋ hæd nɑt bɪn ɪn tʃɹu ɹaʊn tə bɪɡɪn wɪð, ən i dɪd nɑt θɪŋk i hæd bɛn ɪɾ ɪnʌf tə bi noʊɾəst. hi wɑz nɑɾ əfɹeɪd! hi ɹəfjuz tə lɛt fɪɹ tʌtʃ hɪm. laɪt, hi hæd tə daɪ, ɪvɛntʃəwəli. hi hæɾ æksɛptɪd ðæt.

Wine slopped over Rand's wrist, soaking his coats-leeve, and he loosened his grip on the winecup. The thing had not been in true round to begin with, and he did not think he had bent it enough to be noticed. He was not afraid! He refused to let fear touch him. Light, he had to die, eventually. He had accepted that.

ðeɪ tʃɹaɪd tə kɪl mi, ən aɪ wɑn əm dɛd fəɹ ɪt, hi θɔt. ɪf ɪt teɪks ə lɪɾəl taɪm, wɛl, meɪbi ðə sɪknəs wɪl pæs baɪ ðɛn. bɝn ju, aɪ hæv tə lɪv əntɪl ðə læs bæɾəl. ɪn ɪz hɛd, luz θɝɪn læf mɔɹ waɪldli ðən bɪfɔɹ.

They tried to kill me, and I want them dead for it, he thought. If it takes a little time, well, maybe the sickness will pass by then. Burn you, I have to live until the Last Battle. In his head, Lews Therin laughed more wildly than before.

ənʌðɝ tɔl mæn swæɡɝɾ ɪn, θɹu ðə dɔɹ tə ðə steɪbliɑɹd, ɔlmoʊst ət ðə fʊɾ ə ðə stɛɹz ɪn ðə bæk ə ðə ɹum. ʃeɪkɪŋ ɹeɪn fɹəm ɪz kloʊk, hi tɔs bæk ɪz hʊɾ ən stʃɹoʊd tə ðə dɔɹweɪ ʌv ðə wɪmənz ɹum. wɪð ɪz snɪɹɪŋ maʊθ ən ʃɑɹp noʊz, ən ə ɡeɪz ðət swɛp kəntɛmptʃwəsli oʊvɝ ðə pipəl ət ðə teɪbəlz, hi dɪd lʊk sʌmθɪŋ laɪk tɔɹvəl, bʌt wɪð twɛnti jɪɹz' mɔɹ wɛɹ ɑn ɪz feɪs ən θɝɾi paʊnz ə fæɾ ɑn ɪz fɹeɪm. piɹɪŋ θɹu ðə jɛloʊ ɑɹtʃ, hi kɔld aʊɾ ɪn ə haɪ, pɹɪsi vɔɪs ðət wɑz θɪk wɪð ði æksɛns ʌv ɪljən. "mɪstʃɹəs ɡɔlɡɝ, aɪ də bi livɪŋ ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ. ɝli, soʊ aɪ də ɪkspɛk noʊ tʃɑɹdʒəz fəɹ təmɑɹoʊ, maɪnd!" tɔɹvəl wɑz ə tæɹɑbənɝ.

Another tall man swaggered in, through the door to the stableyard, almost at the foot of the stairs in the back of the room. Shaking rain from his cloak, he tossed back his hood and strode to the doorway of the Women's Room. With his sneering mouth and sharp nose, and a gaze that swept contemptuously over the people at the tables, he did look something like Torval, but with twenty years' more wear on his face and thirty pounds of fat on his frame. Peering through the yellow arch, he called out in a high, prissy voice that was thick with the accents of Illian. "Mistress Gallger, I do be leaving in the morning. Early, so I do expect no charges for tomorrow, mind!" Torval was a Taraboner.

ɡæðɝɪŋ ɪz kloʊk, ɹænd lɛft ɪz waɪnkʌp ɑn ðə teɪbəl ən dɪd nɑt lʊk bæk.

Gathering his cloak, Rand left his winecup on the table and did not look back.

ðə nun skaɪ wɑz ɡɹeɪ ən koʊld, ən ɪf ðə ɹeɪn hæd slækənd, ɪt wɑz nɑt baɪ mʌtʃ, ən dʒɹɪvən baɪ blʌstɝi leɪk wɪnz, ɪt wɑz ɪnʌf tə hæv dʒɹɪvən ɔlmoʊst ɛvɹiwʌn fɹəm ðə stʃɹits. hi hɛl ðə kloʊk ɝaʊn ɪm wʌn-hændəd, əz mʌtʃ tə ʃɛltɝ, ðə dʒɹɔɪŋz ɪn ɪz koʊt pɑkəɾ əz tə kip ðə ɹɛst ə hɪm dʒɹaɪ, ən juz ði ʌðɝ tə hoʊld ɪz hʊɾ əɡɛns ðə ɡʌsts. ðə wɪnbloʊn ɹeɪndʒɹɑps hɪɾ ɪz feɪs laɪk flɛks ʌv aɪs. ə loʊn sɪdæn tʃɛɹ pæs hɪm, ðə bɛɹɝz' hɛɹ hæŋɪŋ sɑɾən daʊn ðɛɹ bæks ən ðɛɹ buts splæʃɪŋ ɪn pʌɾəlz ɑn ðə peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz. ə fju pipəl tʃɹʌdʒd əlɔŋ ðə stʃɹits ɹæpt ʌp ɪn ðɛɹ kloʊks. ðəɹ wɝ aʊɝz ə deɪlaɪt lɛft, sətʃ əz ɪt wɑz, bʌɾ i wɔk baɪ ən ɪn kɔl ðə hɑɹɾ ə ðə pleɪn wɪθaʊt ɡoʊɪŋ ɪn, ən ðən baɪ ðə θɹi leɪɾiz ə mɑɹeɪɾoʊ. hi toʊl hɪmsɛlf ɪt wɑz ðə ɹeɪn. ðɪs wɑz noʊ wɛðɝ tə bi meɪkɪŋ ɪz weɪ fɹəm ɪn tə ɪn. hi nu hi wɑz laɪɪŋ, ðoʊ.

The noon sky was gray and cold, and if the rain had slackened, it was not by much, and driven by blustery lake winds, it was enough to have driven almost everyone from the streets. He held the cloak around him one-handed, as much to shelter, the drawings in his coat pocket as to keep the rest of him dry, and used the other to hold his hood against the gusts. The windblown raindrops hit his face like flecks of ice. A lone sedan chair passed him, the bearers' hair hanging sodden down their backs and their boots splashing in puddles on the paving stones. A few people trudged along the streets wrapped up in their cloaks. There were hours of daylight left, such as it was, but he walked by an inn called The Heart of the Plain without going in, and then by The Three Ladies of Maredo. He told himself it was the rain. This was no weather to be making his way from inn to inn. He knew he was lying, though.

ə ʃɔɹt staʊt wʊmən kʌmɪŋ daʊn ðə stʃɹit bʌndəld ɪn ə dɑɹk kloʊk sʌɾənli vɪɹd təwɔɹd hɪm. wən ʃi stɑpt ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm ən ɹeɪzd əɹ hɛd, hi sɔ ɪt wɑz vɛɹɪn.

A short stout woman coming down the street bundled in a dark cloak suddenly veered toward him. When she stopped in front of him and raised her head, he saw it was Verin.

"soʊ jə ɑɹ hɪɹ æftɝ ɔl," ʃi sɛd. ɹeɪndʒɹɑps fɛl ɑn əɹ ʌptɝn feɪs, bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt sim tə noʊɾəs. "jɔɹ ɪnkipɝ θɔt jə ɪntɛndəd tə wɔk ʌp tə ði əvhɑɝɪn, bʌt ʃi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ. aɪm əfɹeɪd mɪstʃɹəs kin dʌzn peɪ mʌtʃ ətɛnʃən tə ðə kʌmɪŋz ən ɡoʊɪŋz ə mɛn. ən hɪɹ aɪm wɪð maɪ ʃuz soʊk θɹu, ən maɪ stɑkɪŋz. aɪ juz tə laɪk wɔkɪŋ ɪn ðə ɹeɪn wən aɪ wɑz ə ɡɝl, bʌɾ ɪt simz tə hæv lɔst ɪts tʃɑɹm sʌmwɛɹ əlɔŋ ðə weɪ."

"So you are here after all," she said. Raindrops fell on her upturned face, but she did not seem to notice. "Your innkeeper thought you intended to walk up to the Avharin, but she was not sure. I'm afraid Mistress Keene doesn't pay much attention to the comings and goings of men. And here I am with my shoes soaked through, and my stockings. I used to like walking in the rain when I was a girl, but it seems to have lost its charm somewhere along the way."

"dɪd kædzueɪn sɛn ju?" hi æskt, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kip ɪz vɔɪs fɹəm saʊndɪŋ hoʊpfəl. hi hæd kɛpt ɪz ɹum ət ðə kaʊnsəlz hɛɾ æftɝ ɑlɑnə lɛf soʊ ðət kædzueɪn kəd faɪn hɪm. hi kəd hɑɹdli meɪk əɹ ɪntʃɹəstəɾ ɪf ʃi hæd tə hʌn fəɹ ɪm ɪn baɪ ɪn. ɪspɛʃli sɪns ʃi hæd ʃoʊn noʊ ɛvəɾəns ðət ʃi wəd hʌnt.

"Did Cadsuane send you?" he asked, trying to keep his voice from sounding hopeful. He had kept his room at The Counsel's Head after Alanna left so that Cadsuane could find him. He could hardly make her interested if she had to hunt for him inn by inn. Especially since she had shown no evidence that she would hunt.

"oʊ, noʊ; ʃi wəd nɛvɝ də ðæt." vɛɹɪn saʊndəd sɝpɹaɪzd ət ðə θɔt. "aɪ dʒʌs θɔt jə maɪt wɑnə hɪɹ ðə nuz. kædzueɪn ɪz aʊt ɹaɪɾɪŋ wɪð ðə ɡɝlz." ʃi fɹaʊn θɔtfəli, tɪltɪŋ əɹ hɛd. "ðoʊ aɪ səpoʊz aɪ ʃʊdn kɔl əliviə ə ɡɝl. ən ɪntʃɹiɡɪŋ wʊmən. mʌtʃ tu oʊl tə bɪkʌm ə nɑvəs, ənfɔɹtʃənətli; oʊ, jɛs, vɛɹi ənfɔɹtʃənət. ʃi dʒɹɪŋks ɪn wʌtɛvɝ ʃiz tɔt. aɪ bɪliv ʃi meɪ noʊ ɔlmoʊst ɛvɹi weɪ ðəɹ ɪz tə dɪstʃɹɔɪ sʌmθɪŋ wɪð ðə paʊɝ, bʌt ʃi noʊz ɔlmoʊs nʌθɪŋ ɛls."

"Oh, no; she would never do that." Verin sounded surprised at the thought. "I just thought you might want to hear the news. Cadsuane is out riding with the girls." She frowned thoughtfully, tilting her head. "Though I suppose I shouldn't call Alivia a girl. An intriguing woman. Much too old to become a novice, unfortunately; oh, yes, very unfortunate. She drinks in whatever she's taught. I believe she may know almost every way there is to destroy something with the Power, but she knows almost nothing else."

hi dʒɹu hɝ tə ðə saɪɾ ə ðə stʃɹit, wɛɹ ðə dip oʊvɝhæŋɪŋ ivz ʌv ə sɪŋɡəl-stɔɹi stoʊn haʊs ɡeɪv ə lɪɾəl ʃɛltɝ fɹəm ðə ɹeɪn, ɪf nɑt fɹəm ðə wɪn tə ɛni ɡɹeɪɾ ɪkstɛnt. kædzueɪn wɑz wɪð mɪn ən ði ʌðɝz? ɪt maɪt min nʌθɪŋ. hi hæd sin ɛɛs sədaɪ fæsəneɪɾəd wɪð nɪneɪiv bɪfɔɹ, ən əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə mɪn, əliviə wɑz ivən stʃɹɔŋɝ. "wʌt nuz, vɛɹɪn?" hi sɛd kwaɪətli.

He drew her to the side of the street, where the deep overhanging eaves of a single-story stone house gave a little shelter from the rain, if not from the wind to any great extent. Cadsuane was with Min and the others? It might mean nothing. He had seen Aes Sedai fascinated with Nynaeve before, and according to Min, Alivia was even stronger. "What news, Verin?" he said quietly.

ðə ɹaʊn lɪɾəl ɛɛs sədaɪ blɪŋkt əz ðoʊ ʃi fɝɡɑɾən ðəɹ wɑz ɛni nuz, ðən smaɪl sʌɾənli. "oʊ, jɛs. ðə sintʃæn. ðeɪ ɑɹ ɪn ɪljən. nɑt ðə sɪɾi, nɑt jɛt; noʊ nid tə ɡoʊ peɪl. bʌt ðeɪv kɹɔs ðə bɔɹɾɝ. ðeɪ ɑɹ bɪldɪŋ fɔɹɾəfaɪd kæmps əlɔŋ ðə koʊst ən ɪnlænd. aɪ noʊ lɪɾəl ə mɪlətɛɹi mæɾɝz. aɪ ɔlweɪz skɪp oʊvɝ ðə bæɾəlz wən aɪ ɹɛɾ ə hɪstɝi. bʌɾ ɪt dʌz sim tə mi ðət wɛðɝ ðeɪ ɑɹ ɪn ðə sɪɾi jɛɾ əɹ nɑt, ðəɾ ɪz wɛɹ ðeɪ ɑɹ eɪmɪŋ. jəɹ bæɾəlz doʊn sim tə hæv dʌn mʌtʃ tə sloʊ ðɛm. ðæts waɪ aɪ doʊn ɹɛɾ əbaʊt ðə bæɾəlz. ðeɪ sɛldəm sim tə ɔltɝ ɛniθɪŋ ɪn ðə lɔŋ ɹʌn, oʊnli ɪn ðə ʃɔɹt. ɑɹ jə wɛl?"

The round little Aes Sedai blinked as though she forgotten there was any news, then smiled suddenly. "Oh, yes. The Seanchan. They are in Illian. Not the city, not yet; no need to go pale. But they have crossed the border. They are building fortified camps along the coast and inland. I know little of military matters. I always skip over the battles when I read a history. But it does seem to me that whether they are in the city yet or not, that is where they are aiming. Your battles don't seem to have done much to slow them. That's why I don't read about the battles. They seldom seem to alter anything in the long run, only in the short. Are you well?"

hi fɔɹst ɪz aɪz oʊpən. vɛɹɪn pɪɹɾ ʌp əɾ ɪm laɪk ə tʃʌbi spɛɹoʊ. ɔl ðət faɪɾɪŋ, ɔl ðoʊz mɛn dɛd, mɛn i hæd kɪld, ən ɪt hæd tʃeɪnʒd nʌθɪŋ. nʌθɪŋ!

He forced his eyes open. Verin peered up at him like a chubby sparrow. All that fighting, all those men dead, men he had killed, and it had changed nothing. Nothing!

ʃiz ɹɔŋ, luz θɝɪn mɝmɝɾ ɪn ɪz hɛd. bæɾəlz kən ɔltɝ hɪstɝi. hi dɪd nɑt saʊn plizd wɪð ɪt. ðə tʃɹʌbəl ɪz, səmtaɪmz jə kænɑt seɪ haʊ hɪstɝi wɪl bi tʃeɪnʒd əntɪl ɪts tu leɪt.

She is wrong, Lews Therin murmured in his head. Battles can alter history. He did not sound pleased with it. The trouble is, sometimes you cannot say how history will be changed until it is too late.

"vɛɹɪn, ɪf aɪ wɛn tə kædzueɪn, wəd ʃi tɔk wɪð mi? əbaʊt sʌmθɪŋ ʌðɝ ðən haʊ maɪ mænɝz doʊn sut hɝ? ðæts ɔl ʃi ɛvɝ simz tə kɛɹ əbaʊt."

"Verin, if I went to Cadsuane, would she talk with me? About something other than how my manners don't suit her? That's all she ever seems to care about."

"oʊ, dɪɹ. aɪm əfɹeɪd kædzueɪn ɪz vɛɹi mʌtʃ ə tʃɹədɪʃənəlɪst ɪn səm weɪz, ɹænd. aɪv nɛvɝ æktʃəli  hɝɾ əɹ kɔl ə mæn ʌpəɾi, bʌt . . ." ʃi leɪd fɪŋɡɝtɪps əɡɛnst əɹ maʊθ ɪn θɔt fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ðən nɑɾəd, ɹeɪndʒɹɑps slaɪɾɪŋ daʊn əɹ feɪs. "aɪ ʃɪl wɪl lɪsən tə juv hæv tə seɪ, ɪf jə kən mænədʒ tə ɪɹeɪs ðə bæɾ ɪmpɹɛʃən jə meɪɾ ɑn hɝ. əɹ ət list smʌdʒ ɪt, əz mʌtʃ əz jə kæn. fju sɪstɝz ɑɹ ɪmpɹɛs baɪ taɪɾəlz əɹ kɹaʊnz, ɹænd, ən kædzueɪn lɛs ðən ɛni ʌðɝ aɪ noʊ. ʃi kɛɹz mʌtʃ mɔɹ əbaʊt wɛðɝ əɹ nɑt pipəl ɑɹ fulz. ɪf jə kən ʃoʊ hɝ jə ɑɹən ə ʃɪl wɪl lɪsən."

"Oh, dear. I'm afraid Cadsuane is very much a traditionalist in some ways, Rand. I've never actually heard her call a man uppity, but . . ." She laid fingertips against her mouth in thought for a moment, then nodded, raindrops sliding down her face. "I believe she will listen to what you have to say, if you can manage to erase the bad impression you made on her. Or at least smudge it, as much as you can. Few sisters are impressed by titles or crowns, Rand, and Cadsuane less than any other I know. She cares much more about whether or not people are fools. If you can show her you aren't a fool, she will listen."

"ðɛn tɛl əɹ . . ." hi dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ. laɪt, hi wɑntəd tə stʃɹæŋɡəl kɪsmən ən dæʃivə ən ɔl ə ðɛm wɪð ɪz bɛɹ hænz! "tɛl əɹ əl bi livɪŋ fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ təmɑɹoʊ, ən aɪ hoʊp ʃɪl kʌm wɪð mi, əz maɪ ædvaɪzɝ." luz θɝɪn saɪd wɪð ɹɪlif ət ðə fɝs pɑɹɾ ə ðæt; ɪf i hæd bɪn mɔɹ ðən ə vɔɪs, ɹænd wʊɾə sɛɾ i stɪfən ət ðə sɛkən pɑɹt. "tɛl əɹ aɪ æksɛpt əɹ tɝmz; aɪ əpɑlədʒaɪz fəɹ maɪ bɪheɪvjɝ ɪn kɛɹhin, ən əl də maɪ bɛs tə wɑtʃ maɪ mænɝz ɪn ðə fjutʃɝ." seɪɪŋ ðət hɑɹdli ɡɹeɪɾɪd əɾ ɔl. wɛl, ə lɪɾəl, bʌɾ ənlɛs mɪn wɑz ɹɔŋ, hi niɾəd kædzueɪn, ən mɪn wɑz nɛvɝ ɹɔŋ wɪð əɹ vjuɪŋz.

"Then tell her . . ." He drew a deep breath. Light, he wanted to strangle Kisman and Dashiva and all of them with his bare hands! "Tell her I'll be leaving Far Madding tomorrow, and I hope she will come with me, as my advisor." Lews Therin sighed with relief at the first part of that; if he had been more than a voice, Rand would have said he stiffened at the second part. "Tell her I accept her terms; I apologize for my behavior in Cairhien, and I will do my best to watch my manners in the future." Saying that hardly grated at all. Well, a little, but unless Min was wrong, he needed Cadsuane, and Min was never wrong with her viewings.

"soʊ jə faʊnd wʌt jə ɑɹ æftɝ hɪɹ?" hi fɹaʊn ət hɝ, ən ʃi smaɪl bæk ən pæɾəd ɪz ɑɹm. "ɪf jə hæd kʌm tə fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ θɪŋkɪŋ jə kəd kɑŋkɝ ðə sɪɾi baɪ ənaʊnsɪŋ u jə ɑɹ, jə wʊɾə lɛft əz sun əz jə ɹilaɪz jə kænɑt tʃænəl hɪɹ. ðət livz wɑntɪŋ tə faɪn sʌmθɪŋ, əɹ sʌmwʌn."

"So you found what you are after here?" He frowned at her, and she smiled back and patted his arm. "If you had come to Far Madding thinking you could conquer the city by announcing who you are, you would have left as soon as you realized you cannot channel here. That leaves wanting to find something, or someone."

"meɪbi aɪ faʊnd wʌɾ aɪ nid," hi sɛd kɝtli. dʒʌs nɑt wʌɾ i wɑntəd.

"Maybe I found what I need," he said curtly. Just not what he wanted.

"ðɛn kʌm tə ðə bɑɹsælə pæləs, ɑn ðə haɪts, ðɪs ivnɪŋ, ɹænd. ɛniwʌn kən tɛl jə haʊ tə faɪn ɪt. aɪ ɹɪli æm ʃʊɹ ʃɪl bi wɪlɪŋ tə lɪsən tə ju." ʃɪftɪŋ əɹ kloʊk, ʃi sim tə noʊɾəs ðə dæmpnəs ə ðə wʊl fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm. "oʊ, maɪ. aɪ mʌst ɡoʊ dʒɹaɪ ɔf. aɪ sədʒɛs jə də ðə seɪm." hæf tɝn tə liv, ʃi pɔzd ən lʊk bæk oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ ət hɪm. hɝ dɑɹk aɪz wɝ ənblɪŋkɪŋ. sʌɾənli ʃi dɪd nɑt saʊn mʌɾəld əɾ ɔl. "ju kəd də fɑɹ wɝs ðən kædzueɪn fəɹ ən ædvaɪzɝ, ɹænd, bʌɾ aɪ daʊt jə kəd də bɛɾɝ. ɪf ʃi æksɛps, ən jə tʃɹuli ɑɹ nɑɾ ə ful, jəl lɪsən tə hɝ ædvaɪs." ʃi ɡlaɪɾɪd əweɪ θɹu ðə ɹeɪn lʊkɪŋ nʌθɪŋ soʊ mʌtʃ əz ə vɛɹi staʊt swɑn.

"Then come to the Barsalla palace, on the Heights, this evening, Rand. Anyone can tell you how to find it. I really am sure she will be willing to listen to you." Shifting her cloak, she seemed to notice the dampness of the wool for the first time. "Oh, my. I must go dry off. I suggest you do the same." Half turned to leave, she paused and looked back over her shoulder at him. Her dark eyes were unblinking. Suddenly she did not sound muddled at all. "You could do far worse than Cadsuane for an advisor, Rand, but I doubt you could do better. If she accepts, and you truly are not a fool, you will listen to her advice." She glided away through the rain looking nothing so much as a very stout swan.

səmtaɪmz ðət wʊmən fɹaɪɾənz mi, luz θɝɪn mɝmɝd, ən ɹænd nɑɾəd. kædzueɪn dɪd nɑt fɹaɪɾən hɪm, bʌt ʃi meɪɾ ɪm wɛɹi. ɛni ɛɛs sədaɪ hu hæd nɑt swɔɹn tə hɪm meɪɾ ɪm wɛɹi, ɪksɛp fəɹ nɪneɪiv. ən i wɑz nɑɾ ɔlweɪz sɝɾən ə hɝ, iðɝ.

Sometimes that woman frightens me, Lews Therin murmured, and Rand nodded. Cadsuane did not frighten him, but she made him wary. Any Aes Sedai who had not sworn to him made him wary, except for Nynaeve. And he was not always certain of her, either.

ðə ɹeɪn daɪɾ əweɪ waɪl i wɑz wɔkɪŋ ðə tu maɪlz bæk tə ðə kaʊnsəlz hɛd, bʌt ðə wɪn pɪkt ʌp, ən ðə saɪn oʊvɝ ðə dɔɹ, peɪntəd wɪð ðə stɝn vɪzədʒ ʌv ə wʊmən wɛɹɪŋ ðə dʒuəl kɔɹənɛɾ ʌv ə fɝs kaʊnsəl, swʌŋ ɑn kɹikɪŋ hɪnʒɪz. ðə kɑmən ɹum wɑz smɔlɝ ðən ðəɾ ə ðə ɡoʊldən wil, bʌt ðə wɔl pænəlz wɝ kɑɹvd ən pɑlɪʃt, ðə teɪbəlz bɪniθ ðə ɹɛd silɪŋ bimz nɑt soʊ kɹaʊɾəd təɡɛðɝ. ðə dɔɹweɪ tə ðə wɪmənz ɹum wɑz ɹɛd, tu, ən kɑɹv laɪk ɪntʃɹəkət leɪs, əz wɝ ðə lɪntəlz ə ðə peɪl mɑɹbəl faɪɝpleɪsəz. ət ðə kaʊnsəlz hɛd, ðə sɝvɪŋ mɛn sɪkjʊɹd ðɛɹ lɔŋ hɛɹ wɪð pɑlɪʃt sɪlvɝ klɪps. oʊnli tu ʌv əm wɝ tə bi sin, stændɪŋ nɪɹ ðə kɪtʃən dɔɹ, bʌt ðəɹ wɝ dʒʌs θɹi mɛn ət ðə teɪbəlz, fɔɹən mɝtʃəns sɪɾɪŋ fɑɹ əpɑɹt, itʃ ɪnɡɹoʊst ɪn ɪz oʊn waɪn. kəmpɛɾətɝz, pɝhæps, sɪns naʊ ən ðən wʌn əɹ ənʌðɝ wəd ʃɪft ɑn ɪz tʃɛɹ ən fɹaʊn ət ði ʌðɝ tu. wʌn, ə ɡɹeɪɪŋ mæn, wɔɹ ə dɑɹk ɡɹeɪ sɪlk koʊt, ən ə lin fɛloʊ wɪð ə hɑɹd feɪs hæɾ ə ɹɛd stoʊn ðə saɪz ʌv ə pɪdʒənz ɛɡ ɪn ɪz ɪɹ. ðə kaʊnsəlz hɛd keɪɾɝd tə ðə wɛlθiɝ aʊtlæn mɝtʃəns, ən ðəɹ wɝ nɑt mɛni ʌv ðoʊz ɪn fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ ət pɹɛzənt.

The rain died away while he was walking the two miles back to The Counsel's Head, but the wind picked up, and the sign over the door, painted with the stern visage of a woman wearing the jeweled coronet of a First Counsel, swung on creaking hinges. The common room was smaller than that of The Golden Wheel, but the wall panels were carved and polished, the tables beneath the red ceiling beams not so crowded together. The doorway to the Women's Room was red, too, and carved like intricate lace, as were the lintels of the pale marble fireplaces. At The Counsel's Head, the serving men secured their long hair with polished silver clips. Only two of them were to be seen, standing near the kitchen door, but there were just three men at the tables, foreign merchants sitting far apart, each engrossed in his own wine. Competitors, perhaps, since now and then one or another would shift on his chair and frown at the other two. One, a graying man, wore a dark gray silk coat, and a lean fellow with a hard face had a red stone the size of a pigeon's egg in his ear. The Counsel's Head catered to the wealthier outland merchants, and there were not many of those in Far Madding at present.

ðə klɑk ɑn ə mæntəl ɪn ðə wɪmənz ɹum - ə klɑk wɪð ə sɪlvɝ keɪs, soʊ mɪn sɛd - ɹæŋ ði aʊɝ wɪð smɔl bɛlz əz i keɪm ɪndə ðə kɑmən ɹum, ən bɪfɔɹ i hæd fɪnɪʃt ʃeɪkɪŋ aʊɾ ɪz kloʊk, læn ɛntɝd. əz sun əz ðə wɔɹɾɝ mɛt ɹændz aɪ, hi ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. wɛl, ɹænd hæd nɑt ɹɪli ɪkspɛktəd tə faɪn əm ət ðɪs pɔɪnt. ivən fəɹ ə tɑvɝən, ðət maɪt bi pʊʃɪŋ ði ɪmpɑsəbəl.

The clock on a mantel in the Women's Room - a clock with a silver case, so Min said - rang the hour with small bells as he came into the common room, and before he had finished shaking out his cloak, Lan entered. As soon as the Warder met Rand's eye, he shook his head. Well, Rand had not really expected to find them at this point. Even for a ta'veren, that might be pushing the impossible.

wʌns ðeɪ boʊθ hæd stimɪŋ kʌps ʌv waɪn ən wɝ sɛɾəld ɑn ə lɔŋ ɹɛd bɛntʃ ɪn fɹʌn ʌv wʌn ə ðə faɪɝpleɪsəz, hi toʊld læn wʌɾ i hæd dɪsaɪɾɪd, ən waɪ. pɑɹɾ ʌv waɪ. ði ɪmpɔɹɾənt pɑɹt. "ɪf aɪ hæd maɪ hænz ɑn əm ɹaɪt ðɪs mɪnət, aɪd kɪl əm ən teɪk maɪ tʃænsəz ɪskeɪpɪŋ, bʌt kɪlɪŋ əm tʃeɪnʒəz nʌθɪŋ. ɪt dʌzn tʃeɪnʒ ɪnʌf, ɛniweɪ," hi kɝɛktəd, fɹaʊnɪŋ ɪndə ðə fleɪmz. "aɪ kən weɪt wʌn mɔɹ deɪ, hoʊpɪŋ tə faɪn əm təmɑɹoʊ, fəɹ wiks. mʌnθs. oʊnli, ðə wɝld woʊnt weɪt fəɹ mi. aɪ θɔɾ aɪd bi dʌn wɪð əm baɪ naʊ, bʌɾ ɪvɛns ɑɹ ɔlɹɛɾi mɑɹtʃɪŋ əhɛɾ ʌv wʌɾ aɪ ɪkspɛktəd. dʒʌs ði ɪvɛns aɪ noʊ əbaʊt. laɪt, wʌts hæpənɪŋ ðəɾ aɪ doʊnt noʊ əbaʊt kəz aɪ hævən hɝd səm mɝtʃənt næɾɝɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪɾ oʊvɝ ɪz waɪn?"

Once they both had steaming cups of wine and were settled on a long red bench in front of one of the fireplaces, he told Lan what he had decided, and why. Part of why. The important part. "If I had my hands on them right this minute, I'd kill them and take my chances escaping, but killing them changes nothing. It doesn't change enough, anyway," he corrected, frowning into the flames. "I can wait one more day, hoping to find them tomorrow, for weeks. Months. Only, the world won't wait for me. I thought I'd be done with them by now, but events are already marching ahead of what I expected. Just the events I know about. Light, what's happening that I don't know about because I haven't heard some merchant nattering about it over his wine?"

"ju kən nɛvɝ noʊ ɛvɹiθɪŋ," læn sɛd kwaɪətli, "æn pɑɹɾ ʌv wʌt jə noʊ ɪz ɔlweɪz ɹɔŋ. pɝhæps ivən ðə moʊst ɪmpɔɹɾənt pɑɹt. ə pɔɹʃən ʌv wɪzdəm laɪz ɪn noʊɪŋ ðæt. ə pɔɹʃən ə kɝədʒ laɪz ɪn ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn ɛniweɪ."

"You can never know everything," Lan said quietly, "and part of what you know is always wrong. Perhaps even the most important part. A portion of wisdom lies in knowing that. A portion of courage lies in going on anyway."

ɹænd stʃɹɛtʃt ɪz buts təwɔɹd ðə faɪɝ. "dɪd nɪneɪiv tɛl jə ʃi ən ði ʌðɝz əv bɪn kipɪŋ kʌmpəni wɪð kædzueɪn? ðəɹ ɑn ə ɹaɪd wɪð əɹ ɹaɪt naʊ." ɑn ðə weɪ bæk fɹəm ɪt, ɹæðɝ. hi kəd fil mɪn dʒɹɔɪŋ kloʊsɝ. ʃi wəd nɑt bi mʌtʃ lɔŋɡɝ. ʃi wɑz stɪl ɪksaɪɾəd əbaʊt sʌmθɪŋ, ə filɪŋ ðət sɝdʒd ən fɛl əz ɪf ʃi wɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə hoʊld ɪt daʊn.

Rand stretched his boots toward the fire. "Did Nynaeve tell you she and the others have been keeping company with Cadsuane? They're on a ride with her right now." On the way back from it, rather. He could feel Min drawing closer. She would not be much longer. She was still excited about something, a feeling that surged and fell as if she were trying to hold it down.

læn smaɪld, ə ɹɛɹ ɪvɛnt wɪθaʊt nɪneɪiv pɹɛzənt. ɪt dɪd nɑt ɹitʃ ɪz aɪsi aɪz, ðoʊ. "ʃi fɝbeɪd mi tə ɹɪvil ɪt tə ju, bʌt sɪns jə ɔlɹɛɾi noʊ . . . ʃi ən mɪn kənvɪnst əliviə ðəɾ ɪf ðeɪ kəd kætʃ kædzueɪnz ɪntʃɹəs ðɛmsɛlvz, ðeɪ maɪt bi eɪbəl tə bɹɪŋ əɹ kloʊsɝ tə ju. ðeɪ faʊn aʊt wɛɹ ʃiz steɪɪŋ ən æskt əɹ tə titʃ ðɛm." ðə smaɪl feɪɾəd, livɪŋ ə feɪs kɑɹv fɹəm stoʊn. "maɪ waɪf əz meɪɾ ə sækɹəfaɪs fəɹ ju, ʃifɝɾɝ," hi sɛd kwaɪətli. "aɪ hoʊp jə ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðæt. ʃɪl nɑt seɪ mʌtʃ, bʌɾ aɪ bɪliv kædzueɪn tʃɹits əɹ əz ɪf ʃi wɝ stɪl wʌn ə ði æksɛptɪd, əɹ meɪbi ə nɑvəs. jə noʊ haʊ hɑɹd ðət wəd bi fəɹ nɪneɪiv tə bɛɹ."

Lan smiled, a rare event without Nynaeve present. It did not reach his icy eyes, though. "She forbade me to reveal it to you, but since you already know . . . She and Min convinced Alivia that if they could catch Cadsuane's interest themselves, they might be able to bring her closer to you. They found out where she is staying and asked her to teach them." The smile faded, leaving a face carved from stone. "My wife has made a sacrifice for you, sheepherder," he said quietly. "I hope you remember that. She will not say much, but I believe Cadsuane treats her as if she were still one of the Accepted, or maybe a novice. You know how hard that would be for Nynaeve to bear."

"kædzueɪn tʃɹits ɛvɹiwʌn əz ɪf ðeɪ wɝ nɑvəsɪz," ɹænd mʌɾɝd. ʌpəɾi? laɪt, haʊ wɑz i tə dil wɪð ðə wʊmən? ən jɛɾ i hæd tə faɪn ə weɪ. ðeɪ sæɾ ɪn saɪləns, stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə faɪɝ əntɪl stim bɪɡæn tə ɹaɪz fɹəm ðɛɹ aʊt-θɹʌs butsoʊlz.

"Cadsuane treats everyone as if they were novices," Rand muttered. Uppity? Light, how was he to deal with the woman? And yet he had to find a way. They sat in silence, staring at the fire until steam began to rise from their out-thrust bootsoles.

ðə bɑnd ɡeɪv ɪm wɔɹnɪŋ, ən i lʊkt ɝaʊn dʒʌst əz nɪneɪiv əpɪɹd θɹu ðə dɔɹ tə ðə steɪbliɑɹd, ən ðən mɪn ən əliviə, ʃeɪkɪŋ ðə ɹeɪn ɔf ðɛɹ kloʊks ən ədʒʌstɪŋ ðɛɹ dɪvaɪɾəd skɝts ən ɡɹɪmæsɪŋ ət dæmp spɑts əz ɪf ðeɪ hæɾ ɪkspɛktəd tə ɡoʊ ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðɪs wɛðɝ wɪθaʊt ɡɛɾɪŋ dæmp. əz juʒəwəl, nɪneɪiv wɑz wɛɹɪŋ əɹ dʒuəl tɛɹæŋɡɹil, bɛlt ən nɛkləs, bɹeɪslɪts ən ɹɪŋz, ən ði ɑd bɹeɪslət-ænd-ɹɪŋz æŋɡɹil.

The bond gave him warning, and he looked around just as Nynaeve appeared through the door to the stableyard, and then Min and Alivia, shaking the rain off their cloaks and adjusting their divided skirts and grimacing at damp spots as if they had expected to go riding in this weather without getting damp. As usual, Nynaeve was wearing her jeweled ter'angreal, belt and necklace, bracelets and rings, and the odd bracelet-and-rings angreal.

stɪl niɾənɪŋ hɝsɛlf, mɪn lʊkt ət ɹænd ən smaɪld, nɑɾ əɾ ɔl sɝpɹaɪz tə si hɪm ðɛɹ, ʌv kɔɹs. wɔɹmθ floʊd fɹəm əɹ əlɔŋ ðə bɑn laɪk ə kɝɛs, ðoʊ ʃi wɑz stɪl tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə səpɹɛs əɹ ɪksaɪtmənt. ði ʌðɝ tu wɪmən tʊk lɔŋɡɝ tə noʊɾəs læn ən hɪm, bʌt wən ðeɪ dɪd, ðeɪ hændəd ðɛɹ kloʊks tə wʌn ə ðə sɝvɪŋ mɛn tə bi teɪkən ʌp tə ðɛɹ ɹumz ən dʒɔɪn ðə tu mɛn ət ðə faɪɝpleɪs, hoʊldɪŋ aʊt ðɛɹ hænz tə ðə wɔɹmθ.

Still neatening herself, Min looked at Rand and smiled, not at all surprised to see him there, of course. Warmth flowed from her along the bond like a caress, though she was still trying to suppress her excitement. The other two women took longer to notice Lan and him, but when they did, they handed their cloaks to one of the serving men to be taken up to their rooms and joined the two men at the fireplace, holding out their hands to the warmth.

"dɪd jə ɛndʒɔɪ jəɹ ɹaɪɾ ɪn ðə ɹeɪn wɪð kædzueɪn?" ɹænd æskt, ɹeɪzɪŋ ɪz kʌp tə teɪk ə maʊθfʊl ə ðə swit waɪn. mɪnz hɛd dʒɝk təwɔɹd hɪm, ən ə flæʃ ʌv ɡɪl stæbd əlɔŋ ðə bɑnd, bʌt ði ɪkspɹɛʃən ɑn əɹ feɪs wɑz pjʊɹəst ɪndɪɡneɪʃən. hi ɔlmoʊs tʃoʊkt ɪn swɑloʊɪŋ. haʊ wɑz əɹ miɾɪŋ kædzueɪn bɪhaɪn ɪz bæk ɪz fɔlt? "stɑp ɡlɛɹɪŋ ət læn, nɪneɪiv," hi sɛd wən i kəd tɔk. "vɛɹɪn toʊl mi." nɪneɪiv ʃɪftəɾ əɹ dɑɹk ɡlaʊɝ tə hɪm, ən i ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. hi hæd hɝd wɪmən seɪ ðəɾ ɪt, wʌtɛvɝ "ɪt" wɑz, wɑz ɔlweɪz ə mænz fɔlt, bʌt səmtaɪmz wɪmən ɹɪli sim tə bɪliv ɪt! "aɪ əpɑlədʒaɪz fəɹ wʌtɛvɝ juv ɡɔn θɹu wɪð əɹ ɑn maɪ bɪhæf," hi kəntɪnjud, "bʌt jə woʊnt nid tə ɛni lɔŋɡɝ. aɪ æskt əɹ tə bi maɪ ædvaɪzɝ. əɹ ɹæðɝ, aɪ æsk vɛɹɪn tə tɛl əɹ aɪ wɑnə æsk. tənaɪt. wɪð ɛni lʌk, ʃɪl liv wɪð əs təmɑɹoʊ." hi ɪkspɛktəɾ ɛkskləmeɪʃənz ə sɝpɹaɪzd ɹɪlif, bʌt ðət wɑz nɑt wʌɾ i ɡɑt.

"Did you enjoy your ride in the rain with Cadsuane?" Rand asked, raising his cup to take a mouthful of the sweet wine. Min's head jerked toward him, and a flash of guilt stabbed along the bond, but the expression on her face was purest indignation. He almost choked in swallowing. How was her meeting Cadsuane behind his back his fault? "Stop glaring at Lan, Nynaeve," he said when he could talk. "Verin told me." Nynaeve shifted her dark glower to him, and he shook his head. He had heard women say that it, whatever "it" was, was always a man's fault, but sometimes women really seemed to believe it! "I apologize for whatever you've gone through with her on my behalf," he continued, "but you won't need to any longer. I asked her to be my advisor. Or rather, I asked Verin to tell her I want to ask. Tonight. With any luck, she will leave with us tomorrow." He expected exclamations of surprised relief, but that was not what he got.

"ə ɹɪmɑɹkəbəl wʊmən, kædzueɪn," əliviə sɛd, pæɾɪŋ əɹ waɪt-θɹɛɾəd ɡoʊldən hɛɹ ɪndə pleɪs. hɝ hʌski dʒɹɔl saʊndəɾ ɪmpɹɛst. "ə stʃɹɪk tæskməstʃɹəs, ʃi kən titʃ."

"A remarkable woman, Cadsuane," Alivia said, patting her white-threaded golden hair into place. Her husky drawl sounded impressed. "A strict taskmistress, she can teach."

"səmtaɪmz jə kən si ðə fɔɹəst, wʊlhɛd, ɪf jəɹ lɛd tə ɪt baɪ ðə noʊz," mɪn sɛd, foʊldɪŋ əɹ ɑɹmz ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛsts. ðə bɑn kæɹiɾ əpɹuvəl, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ɪt wɑz fəɹ dəsaɪɾɪŋ tə ɡɪv ʌp ɑn faɪndɪŋ ðə ɹɛnəɡeɪdz. "ɹɪmɛmbɝ ʃi wɑns ən əpɑlədʒi fəɹ kɛɹhin. θɪŋk ə hɝ əz jəɹ ænt, ðə wʌn u woʊn pʊɾ ʌp wɪð ɛni nɑnsɛns, ən jəl də ɔl ɹaɪt wɪð hɝ."

"Sometimes you can see the forest, woolhead, if you're led to it by the nose," Min said, folding her arms under her breasts. The bond carried approval, but he did not think it was for deciding to give up on finding the renegades. "Remember she wants an apology for Cairhien. Think of her as your aunt, the one who won't put up with any nonsense, and you will do all right with her."

"kædzueɪn ɪz nɑɾ əz bæɾ əz ʃi simz." nɪneɪiv fɹaʊn ət ði ʌðɝ tu wɪmən, ən əɹ hæn twɪtʃt təwɔɹd ðə bɹeɪd dʒɹɔn oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ, ðoʊ ɔl ðeɪ hæd dʌn wɑz lʊk ət hɝ. "wɛl, ʃi ɪzənt! wɪl wɝk aʊɾ əɹ . . . dɪfɝənsɪz . . . ɪn taɪm. ðæts ɔl ɪɾəl teɪk. ə lɪɾəl taɪm."

"Cadsuane is not as bad as she seems." Nynaeve frowned at the other two women, and her hand twitched toward the braid drawn over her shoulder, though all they had done was look at her. "Well, she isn't! We will work out our . . . differences . . . in time. That's all it will take. A little time."

ɹænd ɪkstʃeɪnʒd ɡlænsɪz wɪð læn, hu ʃɹʌɡd slaɪtli ən tʊk ənʌðɝ dʒɹɪŋk. ɹænd ɛksheɪl sloʊli. nɪneɪiv hæd dɪfɝənsɪz wɪð kædzueɪn ʃi kəd wɝk aʊt wɪð taɪm, mɪn sɔ ə stʃɹɪkt æn ɪn ðə wʊmən, ən əliviə ə stʃɹɪk titʃɝ. ðə fɝst wəd kɑz spɑɹks tə flaɪ əntɪl ɪt wɑz wɝkt aʊt, ɪf i nu nɪneɪiv, ən ðə læs tu hi dɪd nɑt wɑnt. bʌɾ i wɑz stʌk wɪð ðɛm. hi tʊk ənʌðɝ swɑloʊ ʌv waɪn hɪmsɛlf.

Rand exchanged glances with Lan, who shrugged slightly and took another drink. Rand exhaled slowly. Nynaeve had differences with Cadsuane she could work out with time, Min saw a strict aunt in the woman, and Alivia a strict teacher. The first would cause sparks to fly until it was worked out, if he knew Nynaeve, and the last two he did not want. But he was stuck with them. He took another swallow of wine himself.

ðə mɛn ət ðə teɪbəlz wɝ nɑt nɪɹ ɪnʌf tə oʊvɝhɪɹ ənlɛs ʃi spoʊk laʊdli, bʌt nɪneɪiv loʊɝɾ əɹ vɔɪs ən lin təwɔɹd ɹænd. "kædzueɪn ʃoʊd mi wʌt tu ʌv maɪ tɛɹæŋɡɹil du," ʃi wɪspɝd, ə ɡloʊ ʌv ɪksaɪtmən ɪn əɹ aɪz. "aɪl weɪdʒɝ ðoʊz ɔɹnəməns ʃi wɛɹz ɑɹ tɛɹæŋɡɹil, tu. ʃi ɹɛkəɡnaɪz maɪn əz sun əz ʃi tʌtʃt ðɛm." smaɪlɪŋ, nɪneɪiv θʌmd wʌn ə ðə θɹi ɹɪŋz ɑn əɹ ɹaɪt hænd, ðə wʌn wɪð ə peɪl ɡɹin stoʊn. "aɪ nu ðɪs wəd dɪtɛk sʌmwʌn tʃænəlɪŋ seɪaɪdɑɹ əz mʌtʃ əz θɹi maɪlz əweɪ, ɪf aɪ sɛɾ ɪt, bʌt ʃi sɛz ɪɾəl dɪtɛk seɪɾɪn, tu. ʃi sim tə θɪŋk ɪt ʃəd tɛl mi wʌt dɝɛkʃən ðeɪ wɝ, əz wɛl, bʌt wi kəd nɑt si haʊ."

The men at the tables were not near enough to overhear unless she spoke loudly, but Nynaeve lowered her voice and leaned toward Rand. "Cadsuane showed me what two of my ter'angreal do," she whispered, a glow of excitement in her eyes. "I'll wager those ornaments she wears are ter'angreal, too. She recognized mine as soon as she touched them." Smiling, Nynaeve thumbed one of the three rings on her right hand, the one with a pale green stone. "I knew this would detect someone channeling saidar as much as three miles away, if I set it, but she says it will detect saidin, too. She seemed to think it should tell me what direction they were, as well, but we could not see how."

tɝnɪŋ fɹəm ðə faɪɝpleɪs, əliviə snɪf laʊdli, bʌt ʃi ɔlsoʊ loʊɝɾ əɹ vɔɪs tə seɪ, "æn jə wɝ sæɾəsfaɪd wən ʃi kəd nɑt. aɪ sɔ ɪɾ ɑn jəɹ feɪs. haʊ kən jə bi sæɾəsfaɪd wɪð nɑt noʊɪŋ, wɪð ɪɡnɝəns?"

Turning from the fireplace, Alivia sniffed loudly, but she also lowered her voice to say, "And you were satisfied when she could not. I saw it on your face. How can you be satisfied with not knowing, with ignorance?"

"dʒʌst wɪð əɹ nɑt noʊɪŋ ɛvɹiθɪŋ," nɪneɪiv mʌɾɝd, ɡlaʊɝɪŋ oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ ət ðə tɔlɝ wʊmən, bʌɾ ən ɪnstən leɪɾɝ əɹ smaɪl ɹɪtɝnd. "ðə moʊst ɪmpɔɹɾənt θɪŋ, ɹænd, ɪz ðɪs." hɝ hænz sɛɾəld ɑn ðə slɪm dʒuəl bɛlt ɝaʊn əɹ weɪst. "ʃi kɔld ɪɾ ə 'wɛl.' " hi ɡeɪv ə stɑɹɾ əz sʌmθɪŋ bɹʌʃt ɪz feɪs, ən ʃi ɡɪɡəld. nɪneɪiv æktʃəli  ɡɪɡəld! "ɪɾ ɪz ə wɛl," ʃi læf bɪhaɪn fɪŋɡɝz pɹɛst oʊvɝ əɹ maʊθ, "ɔɹ ə bæɹəl, ɛniweɪ. ən fʊl ə seɪaɪdɑɹ. nɑt vɛɹi mʌtʃ, bʌɾ ɔl aɪ hæv tə də tə ɪts ɪz ɛmbɹeɪs seɪaɪdɑɹ θɹu ɪɾ əz ɪf ɪt wɑz ən æŋɡɹil. ɪzən ðət wʌndɝfəl?"

"Just with her not knowing everything," Nynaeve muttered, glowering over her shoulder at the taller woman, but an instant later her smile returned. "The most important thing, Rand, is this." Her hands settled on the slim jeweled belt around her waist. "She called it a 'Well.' " He gave a start as something brushed his face, and she giggled. Nynaeve actually giggled! "It is a well," she laughed behind fingers pressed over her mouth, "or a barrel, anyway. And full of saidar. Not very much, but all I have to do to refill it is embrace saidar through it as if it was an angreal. Isn't that wonderful?"

"wʌndɝfəl," hi sɛd wɪθaʊt mʌtʃ ɪnθuziæzəm. soʊ kædzueɪn wɑz wɔkɪŋ ɝaʊnd wɪð tɛɹæŋɡɹil ɪn əɹ hɛɹ, wɑz ʃi, ən vɛɹi laɪkli wʌn ə ðiz "wɛlz" əmʌŋ ðɛm, əɹ ʃi wəd nɑɾ əv ɹɛkəɡnaɪzd ɪt. laɪt, hi θɔt noʊ wʌn hæɾ ɛvɝ faʊn tu tɛɹæŋɡɹil ðət dɪd ðə seɪm θɪŋ. miɾɪŋ əɹ tənaɪt wʊɾə bɪn bæɾ ɪnʌf wɪθaʊt noʊɪŋ ʃi wəd bi eɪbəl tə tʃænəl, ivən hɪɹ.

"Wonderful," he said without much enthusiasm. So Cadsuane was walking around with ter'angreal in her hair, was she, and very likely one of these "wells" among them, or she would not have recognized it. Light, he thought no one had ever found two ter'angreal that did the same thing. Meeting her tonight would have been bad enough without knowing she would be able to channel, even here.

hi wɑz əbaʊt tə æsk mɪn tə kʌm wɪð hɪm, wən mɪstʃɹəs kin bʌsəld ʌp, ðə waɪt bʌn ɑn tɑp ə hɝ hɛd dʒɹɔn soʊ taɪɾ ɪt simd ʃi wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pʊl ðə skɪn ɔf ə hɝ feɪs. ʃi kæst ə səspɪʃəs, dɪsəpɹuvɪŋ lʊk oʊvɝ ɹænd ən læn ən pɝst əɹ lɪps əz ɪf kənsɪɾɝɪŋ wʌt ðeɪ hæd dʌn ɹɔŋ. hi hæd sin əɹ ɡɪv ðə seɪm lʊk tə ðə mɝtʃəns u steɪɾ ət ði ɪn. ðə mɛn, ɛniweɪ. ɪf ði əkɑmədeɪʃənz hæd nɑt bɪn soʊ kʌmftəɹbəl ən ðə fud soʊ ɡʊd, ʃi maɪt nɑɾ əv hæɾ ɛni kʌstəm.

He was about to ask Min to come with him, when Mistress Keene bustled up, the white bun on top of her head drawn so tight it seemed she was trying to pull the skin off of her face. She cast a suspicious, disapproving look over Rand and Lan and pursed her lips as if considering what they had done wrong. He had seen her give the same look to the merchants who stayed at the inn. The men, anyway. If the accommodations had not been so comfortable and the food so good, she might not have had any custom.

"ðɪs wɑz dɪlɪvɝd fəɹ jəɹ hʌzbən ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ, mɪstʃɹəs fɑɹʃɔ," ʃi sɛd, hændɪŋ mɪn ə lɛɾɝ sild wɪð ən əntaɪɾi blɑb ə ɹɛd wæks. ði ɪnkipɝz pɔɪntəd tʃɪn ɹoʊz. "æn ə wʊmən wɑz ɪnkwaɪɝɪŋ æftɝ hɪm."

"This was delivered for your husband this morning, Mistress Farshaw," she said, handing Min a letter sealed with an untidy blob of red wax. The innkeeper's pointed chin rose. "And a woman was inquiring after him."

"vɛɹɪn," ɹænd sɛd kwɪkli, tə fɔɹstɔl kwɛstʃənz ən ɡɛt ɹɪɾ ə ðə wʊmən. hu nu tə sɛn ɪm ə lɛɾɝ hɪɹ? kædzueɪn? wʌn ə ði æʃəmən wɪð hɝ? meɪbi wʌn ə ði ʌðɝ sɪstɝz? hi fɹaʊn ət ðə foʊldəd skwɛɹ ə peɪpɝ ɪn mɪnz hænd, ɪmpeɪʃən fəɹ ði ɪnkipɝ tə liv.

"Verin," Rand said quickly, to forestall questions and get rid of the woman. Who knew to send him a letter here? Cadsuane? One of the Asha'man with her? Maybe one of the other sisters? He frowned at the folded square of paper in Min's hand, impatient for the innkeeper to leave.

mɪnz lɪps twɪtʃt, ən ʃi əvɔɪɾəd lʊkɪŋ əɾ ɪm soʊ hɑɹd ðəɾ i nu hi kɑz ðə smaɪl. hɝ əmjuzmən tʃɹɪkəl θɹu ðə bɑnd. "θæŋk ju, mɪstʃɹəs kin. vɛɹɪn ɪz ə fɹɛnd."

Min's lips twitched, and she avoided looking at him so hard that he knew he caused the smile. Her amusement trickled through the bond. "Thank you, Mistress Keene. Verin is a friend."

ðət ʃɑɹp tʃɪn ɹoʊz haɪɝ. "ɪf jə æsk mi, mɪstʃɹəs fɑɹʃɔ, wən juv ə pɹɪɾi hʌzbənd, jə nid tə wɑtʃ jəɹ fɹɛnz, tu."

That sharp chin rose higher. "If you ask me, Mistress Farshaw, when you have a pretty husband, you need to watch your friends, too."

wɑtʃɪŋ ðə wʊmən mɑɹtʃ bæk tə ðə ɹɛɾ ɑɹtʃ, mɪnz aɪz spɑɹkəld wɪð ðə mɝθ ðət floʊɾ əlɔŋ ðə bɑnd, ən əɹ maʊθ stʃɹʌɡəld əɡɛns læfɪŋ. ɪnstɛɾ ə hændɪŋ ðə mɛsədʒ tə ɹænd, ʃi bɹoʊk ðə sil wɪð əɹ θʌm ən ənfoʊldəd ðə lɛɾɝ hɝsɛlf, fəɹ ɔl ðə wɝld əz ɪf ʃi wɝ ə neɪɾɪv ə ðɪs mæd sɪɾi.

Watching the woman march back to the red arch, Min's eyes sparkled with the mirth that flowed along the bond, and her mouth struggled against laughing. Instead of handing the message to Rand, she broke the seal with her thumb and unfolded the letter herself, for all the world as if she were a native of this mad city.

ʃi fɹaʊn slaɪtli əz ʃi ɹɛd, bʌɾ ə bɹif flɛɹ ɪn ðə bɑnd wɑz ði oʊnli wɔɹnɪŋ i hæd. kɹʌmplɪŋ ðə lɛɾɝ, ʃi tɝn təwɔɹd ðə faɪɝpleɪs; hi baʊndəd fɹəm ðə bɛntʃ tə snætʃ ɪt fɹəm əɹ hæn dʒʌs bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəd tɔs ɪɾ ɪndə ðə fleɪmz.

She frowned slightly as she read, but a brief flare in the bond was the only warning he had. Crumpling the letter, she turned toward the fireplace; he bounded from the bench to snatch it from her hand just before she could toss it into the flames.

"doʊn bi ə ful," ʃi sɛd, kætʃɪŋ ɪz ɹɪst. ʃi stɛɹɾ ʌp ət hɪm, hɝ lɑɹdʒ dɑɹk aɪz dɛdli sɪɹiəs. ɔl ðət keɪm tə hɪm θɹu ðə bɑnd wɑz ə ɡɹɪm ɪntɛnsəɾi. "pliz doʊn bi ə ful."

"Don't be a fool," she said, catching his wrist. She stared up at him, her large dark eyes deadly serious. All that came to him through the bond was a grim intensity. "Please don't be a fool."

"aɪ pɹɑməs vɛɹɪn aɪd tʃɹaɪ nɑt," hi sɛd, bʌt mɪn dɪd nɑt smaɪl.

"I promised Verin I'd try not," he said, but Min did not smile.

hi smuðd aʊt ðə peɪdʒ ɑn ɪz tʃɛst. ðə ɹaɪɾɪŋ wɑz ɪn ə spaɪɾɝi hæn i dɪd nɑt ɹɛkəɡnaɪz, ən ðəɹ wɑz noʊ sɪɡnətʃɝ.

He smoothed out the page on his chest. The writing was in a spidery hand he did not recognize, and there was no signature.

aɪ noʊ hu jə ɑɹ, ən aɪ wɪʃ jə wɛl, bʌɾ aɪ ɔlsoʊ wɪʃ jə ɡɔn fɹəm fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ. ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn livz dɛθ ən dɪstʃɹʌkʃən wɛɹ i stɛps. aɪ naʊ noʊ waɪ jə ɑɹ hɪɹ, tu. jə kɪld ɹɑtʃeɪd, ən kɪsmən ɔlsoʊ ɪz dɛd. tɔɹvəl ən dʒɛdwɪn əv teɪkən ðə tɑp flɔɹ əbʌv ə butmeɪkɝ neɪm zɹæm ɑn blu kɑɹp stʃɹit, dʒʌst əbʌv ði ɪljən ɡeɪt. kɪl əm ən ɡoʊ, ən liv fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ ɪn pis.

I know who you are, and I wish you well, but I also wish you gone from Far Madding. The Dragon Reborn leaves death and destruction where he steps. I now know why you are here, too. You killed Rochaid, and Kisman also is dead. Torval and Gedwyn have taken the top floor above a bootmaker named Zeram on Blue Carp Street, just above the Illian Gate. Kill them and go, and leave Far Madding in peace.

ðə klɑk ɪn ðə wɪmənz ɹum ɹæŋ ði aʊɝ. aʊɝz ə deɪlaɪt ɹɪmeɪn bɪfɔɹ i hæd tə mit kædzueɪn.

The clock in the Women's Room rang the hour. Hours of daylight remained before he had to meet Cadsuane.


tʃæptɝ θɝɾiθɹi


CHAPTER 33

blu kɑɹp stʃɹit


Blue Carp Street

mɪn sæt kɹɔs-lɛɡəɾ ɑn ðə bɛd, nɑɾ əz kʌmftəɹbəl ə pəzɪʃən ɪn ə ɹaɪɾɪŋ dʒɹɛs əz ɪt wɑz ɪn bɹitʃɪz, ən ɹoʊld wʌn ə hɝ naɪvz əkɹɔs ðə bæks ə hɝ fɪŋɡɝz. ɪt wɑz ən æbsəlutli jusləs skɪl, tɑm hæd toʊl hɝ, bʌt səmtaɪmz ɪt kɑt pipəlz' aɪz ən meɪɾ əm peɪ ətɛnʃən wɪθaʊt nid tə də mɔɹ. ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðɛɹ ɹum ɹænd wɑz hoʊldɪŋ ɪz skæbɑɹɾɪd sɔɹɾ ʌp tə stʌɾi ðə kʌts i hæd meɪɾ ɪn ðə pis-bɑnd, ən peɪɾ əɹ noʊ ətɛnʃən əɾ ɔl. ðə dʒɹæɡənz hɛdz ɑn ðə bæks ə hɪz hænz ɡlɪɾɝd, mətælɪk ɹɛɾ ən ɡoʊld.

Min sat cross-legged on the bed, not as comfortable a position in a riding dress as it was in breeches, and rolled one of her knives across the backs of her fingers. It was an absolutely useless skill, Thom had told her, but sometimes it caught peoples' eyes and made them pay attention without need to do more. In the middle of their room Rand was holding his scabbarded sword up to study the cuts he had made in the peace-bond, and paid her no attention at all. The Dragon's heads on the backs of his hands glittered, metallic red and gold.

"ju ədmɪt ðɪs əz tə bi ə tʃɹæp," ʃi ɡɹaʊld ət hɪm. "læn ədmɪts ɪt. ə hæf-blaɪnd ɡoʊɾ ɪn seɪlaɪzɪn əz mɔɹ bɹeɪnz ðən tə wɔk ɪndə ə tʃɹæp! 'oʊnli fulz kɪs hɔɹnəts əɹ baɪt faɪɝ!' " ʃi kwoʊɾəd.

"You admit this has to be a trap," she growled at him. "Lan admits it. A half-blind goat in Seleisin has more brains than to walk into a trap! 'Only fools kiss hornets or bite fire!' " she quoted.

"ə tʃɹæp ɪzən ɹɪli ə tʃɹæp ɪf jə noʊ ɪts ðɛɹ," hi sɛɾ æbsənli, bɛndɪŋ ði ɛn ʌv wʌn ə ðə sɛvɝd waɪɝz ə lɪɾəl tə laɪn ʌp bɛɾɝ wɪð ɪts meɪt. "ɪf jə noʊ ɪts ðɛɹ, meɪbi jə kən si ə weɪ tə wɔk ɪn soʊ ɪɾ ɪzən ə tʃɹæp əɾ ɔl."

"A trap isn't really a trap if you know it's there," he said absently, bending the end of one of the severed wires a little to line up better with its mate. "If you know it's there, maybe you can see a way to walk in so it isn't a trap at all."

ʃi θɹu ðə naɪf əz hɑɹɾ əz ʃi kʊd. ɪt flu ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪz feɪs tə stɪk kwɪvɝɪŋ ɪn ðə dɔɹ, ən ʃi ɡeɪv ə lɪɾəl dʒʌmp ɹɪkɔlɪŋ ðə læs taɪm ʃi hæd dʌn ðæt. wɛl, ʃi wɑz nɑt laɪɪŋ ɑn tɑp ə hɪm, naʊ, ən kædzueɪn wɑz nɑt gɑnə wɔk ɪn, wɝs lʌk. bɝn ðə mæn, ðət fɹoʊzən nɑɾ ʌv ɪmoʊʃənz ɪn əɹ hɛd hæd nɑɾ ivən kwɪvɝd wən ðə naɪf stʃɹik baɪ, nɑt baɪ soʊ mʌtʃ əz ə flɪkɝ ə sɝpɹaɪz! "ivən ɪf jə dʒʌst si dʒɛdwɪn ən tɔɹvəl, jə noʊ ði ʌðɝz wɪl bi ðɛɹ, haɪɾɪŋ. laɪt, ðeɪ cʊɾə fɪfti sɛl-sɔɹdz weɪɾɪŋ!"

She threw the knife as hard as she could. It flew in front of his face to stick quivering in the door, and she gave a little jump recalling the last time she had done that. Well, she was not lying on top of him, now, and Cadsuane was not going to walk in, worse luck. Burn the man, that frozen knot of emotions in her head had not even quivered when the knife streaked by, not by so much as a flicker of surprise! "Even if you just see Gedwyn and Torval, you know the others will be there, hiding. Light, they could have fifty sell-swords waiting!"

"ɪn fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ?" hi stɑp lʊkɪŋ ət ðə naɪf stɪkɪŋ ɪn ðə dɔɹ, bʌɾ oʊnli tə ʃeɪk ɪz hɛɾ ən ɡoʊ bæk tə ɪɡzæmɪnɪŋ ðə pis-bɑnd. "aɪ daʊt ðəɹ ɑɹ tu mɝsənɛɹiz ɪn ðə hoʊl sɪɾi, mɪn. bɪliv mi, aɪ doʊn ɪntɛn tə ɡɛt maɪsɛlf kɪl hɪɹ. ənlɛs aɪ kən si haʊ tə spɹɪŋ ðə tʃɹæp wɪθaʊt ɡɛɾɪŋ kɑt, aɪ woʊnt ɡoʊ nɪɹ ɪt." ðəɹ wɑz noʊ mɔɹ fɪɹ ɪn ɪm ðən ɪn ə stoʊn! ən əbaʊɾ əz mʌtʃ sɛns! hi dɪd nɑɾ ɪntɛn tə ɡɛt kɪld, əz ɪf ɛniwʌn ɛvɝ ɪntɛndəd tə!

"In Far Madding?" He stopped looking at the knife sticking in the door, but only to shake his head and go back to examining the peace-bond. "I doubt there are two mercenaries in the whole city, Min. Believe me, I don't intend to get myself killed here. Unless I can see how to spring the trap without getting caught, I won't go near it." There was no more fear in him than in a stone! And about as much sense! He did not intend to get killed, as if anyone ever intended to!

skɹæmbəlɪŋ ɔf ðə bɛd, ʃi oʊpən ðə fɹʌn ə ðə bɛdsaɪd teɪbəl lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə teɪk aʊt ðə stʃɹæp ðət mɪstʃɹəs kin meɪd ʃʊɹ wɑz ɪn ɛvɹi ɹum, ivən ɪf ʃi dɪd ɹɛn tə aʊtləndɝz. ðə θɪŋ wɑz əz lɔŋ əz əɹ ɑɹm ən əz waɪɾ əz əɹ hænd, wɪð ə wʊɾən hændəl ət wʌn ɛn ən ði ʌðɝ ɛn splɪɾ ɪndə θɹi teɪlz. "meɪbi ɪf aɪ tʊk ðɪs tə ju, ɪt wəd klɪɹ jəɹ noʊz ɪnʌf tə smɛl wʌts ɪn fɹʌn ə ju!" ʃi kɹaɪd.

Scrambling off the bed, she opened the front of the bedside table long enough to take out the strap that Mistress Keene made sure was in every room, even if she did rent to outlanders. The thing was as long as her arm and as wide as her hand, with a wooden handle at one end and the other end split into three tails. "Maybe if I took this to you, it would clear your nose enough to smell what's in front of you!" she cried.

ðət wɑz wən nɪneɪiv ən læn ən əliviə wɔkt ɪn. nɪneɪiv ən læn wɝ kloʊkt, ən læn hæɾ ɪz sɔɹɾ əɾ ɪz hɪp. nɪneɪiv hæd ɹimuvd ɔl ə ðə dʒuəlɹi ɪksɛp fəɹ wʌn ɡɛm bɹeɪsləɾ ən ðə dʒuəl bɛlt, ðə wɛl. læn kloʊz ðə dɔɹ kwaɪətli. nɪneɪiv ən əliviə stʊd stɛɹɪŋ ət mɪn wɪð ðə stʃɹæp ɹeɪzd oʊvɝ əɹ hɛd.

That was when Nynaeve and Lan and Alivia walked in. Nynaeve and Lan were cloaked, and Lan had his sword at his hip. Nynaeve had removed all of the jewelry except for one gemmed bracelet and the jeweled belt, the Well. Lan closed the door quietly. Nynaeve and Alivia stood staring at Min with the strap raised over her head.

heɪstəli ʃi dʒɹɑp ðə θɪŋ tə ðə flaʊɝd kɑɹpəɾ ən kɪkt ɪɾ ʌndɝniθ ðə bɛd wɪð ðə saɪɾ ə hɝ fʊt. "aɪ doʊn ʌndɝstænd waɪ jəɹ lɛɾɪŋ læn də ðɪs, nɪneɪiv," ʃi sɛɾ əz fɝmli əz ʃi kʊd. ət ðə moʊmənt, ðət wɑz nɑt pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli fɝm. waɪ dɪd pipəl ɔlweɪz wɔk ɪn ət ðə wɝs taɪm?

Hastily she dropped the thing to the flowered carpet and kicked it underneath the bed with the side of her foot. "I don't understand why you're letting Lan do this, Nynaeve," she said as firmly as she could. At the moment, that was not particularly firm. Why did people always walk in at the worst time?

"ə sɪstɝ əz tə tʃɹʌst əɹ wɔɹɾɝz dʒʌdʒmən səmtaɪmz," nɪneɪiv sɛd kuli, dʒɹɔɪŋ ɑn əɹ ɡlʌvz. hɝ feɪs bɪlɔŋd ɑn ə pɔɹsələn dɑl fəɹ ɔl ði ɪmoʊʃən ɪt dɪspleɪd. oʊ, ʃi wɑz biɪŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ tə hɝ toʊneɪlz.

"A sister has to trust her Warder's judgment sometimes," Nynaeve said coolly, drawing on her gloves. Her face belonged on a porcelain doll for all the emotion it displayed. Oh, she was being Aes Sedai to her toenails.

hi ɪzən jəɹ wɔɹɾɝ, hiz jəɹ hʌzbənd, mɪn wɑntəd tə seɪ, ən ət lis jə kən ɡoʊ əlɔŋ tə lʊk æftɝ hɪm. aɪ doʊnt noʊ ɪf maɪ wɔɹɾɝ wɪl ɛvɝ mɛɹi mi, ən i θɹɛɾənd tə taɪ mi ʌp ɪf aɪ tʃɹaɪd tə ɡoʊ wɪð hɪm! nɑt ðət ʃi hæɾ ɑɹɡjud vɛɹi hɑɹɾ ɑn ðət pɔɪnt. ɪf i wɑz gɑnə bi ə bʊl-ɡus ful, ðəɹ wɝ bɛɾɝ weɪz tə seɪv ɪm ðən tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə stɪk ə naɪf ɪn sʌmbɑɾi.

He isn't your Warder, he's your husband, Min wanted to say, and at least you can go along to look after him. I don't know if my Warder will ever marry me, and he threatened to tie me up if I tried to go with him! Not that she had argued very hard on that point. If he was going to be a bull-goose fool, there were better ways to save him than trying to stick a knife in somebody.

"ɪf wəɹ gɑnə də ðɪs, ʃifɝɾɝ," læn sɛd ɡɹɪmli, "bɛst wi bi əbaʊɾ ɪt waɪl ðɛɹz stɪl laɪt tə si." hɪz blu aɪz sim koʊldɝ ðən ɛvɝ, ən hɑɹɾ əz pɑlɪʃt stoʊnz. nɪneɪiv ɡeɪv ɪm ə wɝid lʊk ðəɾ ɔlmoʊs meɪd mɪn fil sɑɹi fəɹ hɝ. ɔlmoʊst.

"If we are going to do this, sheepherder," Lan said grimly, "best we be about it while there's still light to see." His blue eyes seemed colder than ever, and hard as polished stones. Nynaeve gave him a worried look that almost made Min feel sorry for her. Almost.

ɹænd bɛltəɾ ɪz sɔɹɾ oʊvɝ ɪz koʊt, ðən sɛɾəld ɪz kloʊk wɪð ðə hʊd hæŋɪŋ daʊn ɪz bæk ən tɝn təwɔɹd hɝ. hɪz feɪs wɑz əz hɑɹɾ əz lænz, hɪz blu-ɡɹeɪ aɪz ɔlmoʊst əz koʊld, bʌɾ ɪn əɹ hɛd ðət fɹoʊzən stoʊn bleɪzd wɪð veɪnz ə faɪɝi ɡoʊld. ʃi wɑntəd tə tæŋɡəl əɹ hænz ɪn ðə blæk-daɪd hɛɹ ðəɾ ɔlmoʊs bɹʌʃt ɪz ʃoʊldɝz ən kɪs ɪm noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ mɛni pipəl wɝ wɑtʃɪŋ. ɪnstɛd, ʃi foʊldəɾ əɹ ɑɹmz əkɹɔs əɹ tʃɛst ən lɪftəɾ əɹ tʃɪn, meɪkɪŋ əɹ dɪsəpɹuvəl klɪɹ. ʃi dɪd nɑɾ ɪntɛn fəɹ ɪm tə daɪ hɪɹ, iðɝ, ən ʃi wɑz nɑɾ əbaʊt tə lɛɾ ɪm stɑɹt θɪŋkɪŋ ʃi wəd ɡɪv ɪn dʒʌs kəz i wɑz stʌbɝn.

Rand belted his sword over his coat, then settled his cloak with the hood hanging down his back and turned toward her. His face was as hard as Lan's, his blue-gray eyes almost as cold, but in her head that frozen stone blazed with veins of fiery gold. She wanted to tangle her hands in the black-dyed hair that almost brushed his shoulders and kiss him no matter how many people were watching. Instead, she folded her arms across her chest and lifted her chin, making her disapproval clear. She did not intend for him to die here, either, and she was not about to let him start thinking she would give in just because he was stubborn.

hi dɪd nɑt tʃɹaɪ tə teɪk əɹ ɪn ɪz ɑɹmz. nɑɾɪŋ əz ɪf i æktʃəli  ʌndɝstʊd, hi pɪkt ʌp ɪz ɡlʌvz fɹəm ðə smɔl teɪbəl baɪ ðə dɔɹ. "aɪl bi bæk əz sun əz aɪ kæn, mɪn. ðən wɪl ɡoʊ tə kædzueɪn." ðoʊz ɡoʊldən veɪnz kəntɪnjud tə ɡloʊ ivən æftɝ i lɛf ðə ɹum, fɑloʊd baɪ læn.

He did not try to take her in his arms. Nodding as if he actually understood, he picked up his gloves from the small table by the door. "I'll be back as soon as I can, Min. Then we'll go to Cadsuane." Those golden veins continued to glow even after he left the room, followed by Lan.

nɪneɪiv pɔzd, hoʊldɪŋ ðə dɔɹ. "aɪ wɪl lʊk æftɝ əm boʊθ, mɪn. əliviə, pliz steɪ wɪð əɹ ən si ʃi dʌzn də ɛniθɪŋ fulɪʃ." ʃi wɑz ɔl kul, dɪɡnəfaɪɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ kəmpoʊʒɝ. əntɪl ʃi ɡlænst ɪndə ðə hɔlweɪ. "bɝn ðɛm!" ʃi jɛlpt. "ðeɪɹ livɪŋ!" ən ʃi ɹæn, livɪŋ ðə dɔɹ stændɪŋ hæf oʊpən.

Nynaeve paused, holding the door. "I will look after them both, Min. Alivia, please stay with her and see she doesn't do anything foolish." She was all cool, dignified Aes Sedai composure. Until she glanced into the hallway. "Burn them!" she yelped. "They're leaving!" And she ran, leaving the door standing half open.

əliviə kloʊzd ɪt. "ʃæl wi pleɪ ɡeɪmz tə pæs ðə taɪm, mɪn?" kɹɔsɪŋ ðə kɑɹpət, ʃi sæt daʊn ɑn ðə stul ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə faɪɝpleɪs ən tʊk ə pis ə stʃɹɪŋ fɹəm əɹ bɛltpaʊtʃ. "kæts kɹeɪɾəl?"

Alivia closed it. "Shall we play games to pass the time, Min?" Crossing the carpet, she sat down on the stool in front of the fireplace and took a piece of string from her beltpouch. "Cat's cradle?"

"noʊ, θæŋk ju, əliviə," mɪn sɛd, ɔlmoʊst ʃeɪkɪŋ əɹ hɛɾ ət ði iɡɝnəs ɪn ðə wʊmənz vɔɪs. ɹænd maɪt bi kəmpleɪsən əbaʊt wʌɾ əliviə wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ tə du, bʌt mɪn hæd sɛt hɝsɛlf tə ɡɛt tə noʊ hɝ, ən wʌt ʃi hæd faʊnd wɑz stɑɹtlɪŋ. ɑn ðə sɝfəs, ðə fɔɹmɝ deɪmeɪn wɑz ə mətʃʊɹ wʊmən u əpɪɹd wɛl ɪndə hɝ mɪɾəl jɪɹz, stɝn ən fɪɹs ən ivən ɪntɪmɪdeɪɾɪŋ. ʃi sɝɾənli mænədʒ tə ɪntɪmɪdeɪt nɪneɪiv. nɪneɪiv sɛldəm sɛd pliz tə ɛniwʌn ɪksɛpt əliviə. bʌt ʃi hæd bɪn meɪd deɪmeɪn ət fɔɹtin, ən əɹ lʌv ə pleɪɪŋ tʃɪlʒɹənz ɡeɪmz wɑz nɑt ði oʊnli ɑɾəti əbaʊt hɝ.

"No, thank you, Alivia," Min said, almost shaking her head at the eagerness in the woman's voice. Rand might be complacent about what Alivia was going to do, but Min had set herself to get to know her, and what she had found was startling. On the surface, the former damane was a mature woman who appeared well into her middle years, stern and fierce and even intimidating. She certainly managed to intimidate Nynaeve. Nynaeve seldom said please to anyone except Alivia. But she had been made damane at fourteen, and her love of playing children's games was not the only oddity about her.

mɪn wɪʃt ðəɹ wɑz ə klɑk ɪn ðə ɹum, ðoʊ ði oʊnli ɪn ʃi kəɾ ɪmædʒən wɪð ə klɑk ɪn ɛvɹi ɹum wəd bi ən ɪn fəɹ kwinz ən kɪŋz. peɪsɪŋ bæk ən fɔɹθ ʌndɝ əliviəz wɑtʃfəl ɡeɪz, ʃi kaʊntəd sɛkənz ɪn əɹ hɛd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə dʒʌdʒ haʊ lɔŋ ɪt wəd teɪk ɹænd ən ði ʌðɝz tə ɡoʊ bɪɑn saɪɾ ə ði ɪn. wən ʃi dɪsaɪɾɪd ɪnʌf taɪm hæd pæst, ʃi tʊk əɹ kloʊk fɹəm ðə wɔɹdʒɹoʊb.

Min wished there was a clock in the room, though the only inn she could imagine with a clock in every room would be an inn for queens and kings. Pacing back and forth under Alivia's watchful gaze, she counted seconds in her head, trying to judge how long it would take Rand and the others to go beyond sight of the inn. When she decided enough time had passed, she took her cloak from the wardrobe.

əliviə dɑɹɾɪd tə blɑk ðə dɔɹ, hænz ɑn əɹ hɪps, ən ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ tʃaɪldlaɪk ɪn əɹ ɪkspɹɛʃən. "ju ɑɹənt ɡoʊɪŋ æftɝ ðɛm," ʃi dʒɹɔld ɪn ə fɝm vɔɪs. "ɪt wəɾ oʊnli kɑz tʃɹʌbəl, naʊ, ən aɪ kæn əlaʊ ðæt." wɪð ðoʊz blu aɪz ən ðət ɡoʊldən hɛɹ, hɝ kʌlɝɪŋ wɑz ɔl ɹɔŋ, bʌt ʃi ɹimaɪndəd mɪn ə hɝ æn ɹænə, hu ɔlweɪz sim tə noʊ wən jə hæd dʌn sʌmθɪŋ ɹɔŋ ən ɔlweɪz sɔ tə ɪt ðət jə dɪd nɑt wɑnə də ɪɾ əɡɛn.

Alivia darted to block the door, hands on her hips, and there was nothing childlike in her expression. "You aren't going after them," she drawled in a firm voice. "It would only cause trouble, now, and I can't allow that." With those blue eyes and that golden hair, her coloring was all wrong, but she reminded Min of her Aunt Rana, who always seemed to know when you had done something wrong and always saw to it that you did not want to do it again.

"du jə ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðoʊz tɔks wi hæɾ əbaʊt mɛn, əliviə?" ði ʌðɝ wʊmən tɝn bɹaɪt ɹɛd, ən mɪn hɝidli æɾəd, "aɪ min ðə wʌn əbaʊt haʊ ðeɪ doʊn ɔlweɪz θɪŋk wɪð ðɛɹ bɹeɪnz." ʃi hæɾ ɔfən hɝd wɪmən snɪɹ ðət səm ʌðɝ wʊmən nu nʌθɪŋ əbaʊt mɛn, bʌt ʃi hæd nɛvɝ æktʃəli  mɛt wʌn ə ðoʊz əntɪl ʃi ɪnkaʊntɝɾ əliviə. ʃi ɹɪli dɪd noʊ nʌθɪŋ! "ɹænd wɪl ɡɛt hɪmsɛlf ɪn mɔɹ ðən ɪnʌf tʃɹʌbəl wɪθaʊɾ aɪm gɑnə tə faɪn kædzueɪn, ən ɪf jə tʃɹaɪ tə stɑp mi . . ." ʃi hɛld ʌp ə klɛntʃt fɪst.

"Do you remember those talks we had about men, Alivia?" The other woman turned bright red, and Min hurriedly added, "I mean the one about how they don't always think with their brains." She had often heard women sneer that some other woman knew nothing about men, but she had never actually met one of those until she encountered Alivia. She really did know nothing! "Rand will get himself in more than enough trouble without me. I am going to find Cadsuane, and if you try to stop me . . ." She held up a clenched fist.

fəɹ ə lɔŋ moʊmənt, əliviə fɹaʊn ət hɝ. faɪnəli ʃi sɛd, "lɛt mi ɡɛt maɪ kloʊk, ən əl ɡoʊ wɪð ju."

For a long moment, Alivia frowned at her. Finally she said, "Let me get my cloak, and I'll go with you."

ðəɹ wɝ noʊ sɪdæn tʃɛɹz əɹ lɪvɹid sɝvəns tə bi sin ɑn blu kɑɹp stʃɹit, ən kæɹɪdʒɪz wəd nɛvɝ əv fɪɾ əlɔŋ ðə nɛɹoʊ, twɪstɪŋ pæsədʒ. sleɪt-ɹuf stoʊn ʃɑps ən haʊsəz laɪn ðə stʃɹit, moʊst ə tu stɔɹiz, səmtaɪmz dʒæmd wʌn hɑɹɾ əɡɛns ðə nɛkst ən səmtaɪmz wɪð ə lɪɾəl æliweɪ bɪtwin. ðə peɪvmənt wɑz stɪl slɪk fɹəm ðə ɹeɪn, ən ðə koʊld wɪn tʃɹaɪd tə kæɹi ɹændz kloʊk əweɪ, bʌt pipəl wɝ bæk aʊɾ ən bʌsəlɪŋ əbaʊt. θɹi stʃɹit ɡɑɹdz, wʌn wɪð ə kætʃpoʊl ɑn ɪz ʃoʊldɝ, pɔz tə ɡlæns ət ɹændz sɔɹd, ðən wɛn ɑn ðɛɹ weɪ. nɑt fɑɹ əlɔŋ ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə stʃɹit, ðə bɪldɪŋ haʊzɪŋ ðə ʃɑp ə ðə butmeɪkɝ zɹæm ɹoʊz ə fʊl θɹi stɔɹiz, nɑt kaʊntɪŋ ði æɾɪk ʌndɝ ðə pikt ɹuf.

There were no sedan chairs or liveried servants to be seen on Blue Carp Street, and carriages would never have fit along the narrow, twisting passage. Slate-roofed stone shops and houses lined the street, most of two stories, sometimes jammed one hard against the next and sometimes with a little alleyway between. The pavement was still slick from the rain, and the cold wind tried to carry Rand's cloak away, but people were back out and bustling about. Three Street Guards, one with a catchpole on his shoulder, paused to glance at Rand's sword, then went on their way. Not far along on the other side of the street, the building housing the shop of the bootmaker Zeram rose a full three stories, not counting the attic under the peaked roof.

ə skɪni mæn wɪð vɛɹi lɪɾəl tʃɪn dʒɹɑpt ɹændz kɔɪn ɪndə hɪz pɝs ən juzd ə θɪn stʃɹɪp ʌv wʊd tə lɪft ə bɹaʊn-kɹʌstɪd mitpi fɹəm ðə tʃɑɹkoʊl ɡɹɪl ɑn ɪz bæɹoʊ. hɪz feɪs wɑz laɪnd, hɪz dɑɹk koʊt ʃæbi, ən ɪz lɔŋ ɡɹeɪɪŋ hɛɹ wɑz taɪd wɪð ə lɛðɝ kɔɹd. hɪz aɪz flɪkɝd tə ɹændz sɔɹd, ən lʊkt əweɪ kwɪkli. "waɪ dʒju æsk əbaʊt ðə butmeɪkɝ? ðæts ðə bɛs mʌɾən, ðɛɹ." ə tuθi ɡɹɪn meɪɾ ɪz tʃɪn ɔlmoʊs vænɪʃ, ən ɪz aɪz sʌɾənli lʊk vɛɹi ʃɪfti. "fɝs kaʊnsəl hɝsɛlf doʊn it bɛɾɝ."

A skinny man with very little chin dropped Rand's coin into his purse and used a thin strip of wood to lift a brown-crusted meatpie from the charcoal grill on his barrow. His face was lined, his dark coat shabby, and his long graying hair was tied with a leather cord. His eyes flickered to Rand's sword, and looked away quickly. "Why do you ask about the bootmaker? That's the best mutton, there." A toothy grin made his chin almost vanish, and his eyes suddenly looked very shifty. "First Counsel herself don't eat better."

ðəɹ wɝ mit paɪz kɔl pæstiz wən aɪ wɑz ə bɔɪ, luz θɝɪn mɝmɝd. wi wəd baɪ ðɛm ɪn ðə kʌntʃɹi ən . . .

There were meat pies called pasties when I was a boy, Lews Therin murmured. We would buy them in the country and . . .

dʒʌɡəlɪŋ ðə paɪ fɹəm hæn tə hænd, ðə hit soʊkɪŋ θɹu hɪz ɡlʌvz, ɹænd səpɹɛs ðə vɔɪs. "aɪ laɪk tə noʊ wʌt kaɪndə mæn meɪks maɪ buts. ɪz i səspɪʃəs ə stʃɹeɪnʒɝz, fəɹ ɪnstəns? ə mæn dʌzn də hɪz bɛst wɝk ɪf hiz səspɪʃəs ə ju."

Juggling the pie from hand to hand, the heat soaking through his gloves, Rand suppressed the voice. "I like to know what kind of man makes my boots. Is he suspicious of strangers, for instance? A man doesn't do his best work if he's suspicious of you."

"jɛs, mɪstʃɹəs," ðə tʃɪnləs fɛloʊ sɛd, dʌkɪŋ ɪz hɛd tə ə staʊt ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd wʊmən wɪð ə skwɪnt. ɹæpɪŋ fɔɹ mit paɪz ɪn kɔɹs peɪpɝ, hi hændəɾ əɹ ðə pækədʒ bɪfɔɹ teɪkɪŋ əɹ kɔɪnz. "ə plɛʒɝ, mɪstʃɹəs. ðə laɪt ʃaɪn ɑn ju." ʃi tɑɾɝd əweɪ wɪθaʊɾ ə wɝd, klʌtʃɪŋ ðə ɹæpt paɪz ʌndɝ əɹ kloʊk, ən i ɡɹɪməst saʊɝli əɾ əɹ bæk bɪfɔɹ ɹɪtɝnɪŋ ɪz ətɛnʃən tə ɹænd. "zɹæm nɛvɝ hæɾ ə səspɪʃəs boʊn, ən ɪf i dɪd, mɪlsə wʊdn lɛɾ ɪm kip ɪt. ðæts ɪz waɪf. sɪns ðə læst ə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən mɛɹid, mɪlsəz bɪn ɹɛntɪŋ aʊt ðə tɑp flɔɹ. wɛnɛvɝ ʃi faɪnz sʌmbɑɾi doʊn maɪn biɪŋ lɑkt ɪn ət naɪt, ɛniweɪ," hi læft. "mɪlsə hæd stɛɹz pʊɾ ɪn ɹaɪɾ ʌp tə ðə θɝd flɔɹ, soʊ ɪts pɹaɪvət, bʌt ʃi wʊdn peɪ fəɹ hævɪŋ ə nu dɔɹ kʌɾ əz wɛl, soʊ ðə stɛɹz kʌm aʊɾ ɪn ðə ʃɑp, ən ʃiz nɑt tʃɹʌstɪŋ ɪnʌf tə liv ðəɾ ənlɑkt ət naɪt. jə gɑnə it ðət paɪ, əɹ dʒʌs lʊk əɾ ɪt?"

"Yes, Mistress," the chinless fellow said, ducking his head to a stout gray-haired woman with a squint. Wrapping four meat pies in coarse paper, he handed her the package before taking her coins. "A pleasure, Mistress. The Light shine on you." She tottered away without a word, clutching the wrapped pies under her cloak, and he grimaced sourly at her back before returning his attention to Rand. "Zeram never had a suspicious bone, and if he did, Milsa wouldn't let him keep it. That's his wife. Since the last of the children married, Milsa's been renting out the top floor. Whenever she finds somebody don't mind being locked in at night, anyway," he laughed. "Milsa had stairs put in right up to the third floor, so it's private, but she wouldn't pay for having a new door cut as well, so the stairs come out in the shop, and she's not trusting enough to leave that unlocked at night. You going to eat that pie, or just look at it?"

teɪkɪŋ ə kwɪk baɪt, ɹænd waɪp hɑt dʒus fɹəm ɪz tʃɪn ən wɔkt oʊvɝ tə ʃɛltɝ bɪniθ ði ivz ʌv ə smɔl kʌtlɝz ʃɑp. əlɔŋ ðə stʃɹiɾ ʌðɝz wɝ snætʃɪŋ ə kwɪk mil fɹəm ðə fud-pɛdlɝz, mit paɪz əɹ fɹaɪd fɪʃ əɹ twɪstəd peɪpɝ koʊnz hipt wɪð ɹoʊstəd piz. θɹi əɹ fɔɹ mɛn əz tɔl əz hi, ən tu əɹ θɹi wɪmən əz tɔl əz moʊst ə ði ʌðɝ mɛn ɪn ðə stʃɹit, maɪɾ əv bɪn il. meɪbi ðə tʃɪnləs fɛloʊ wɑz nɑɾ əz ʃɪfti əz i simd, əɹ meɪbi ɪt wɑz dʒʌs ðət ɹænd hæɾ iɾən nʌθɪŋ sɪns bɹɛkfəst, bʌt ɹænd faʊn hɪmsɛlf wɑntɪŋ tə ɡɑbəl ðə paɪ daʊn ən baɪ ənʌðɝ. ɪnstɛd, hi meɪd hɪmsɛlf it sloʊli. zɹæm sim tə bi duɪŋ ə ɡʊd bɪznəs. ə stɛɾi ɪf nɑt kɑnstən floʊ ʌv mɛn wɛn ɪndə hɪz ʃɑp, moʊs kæɹiɪŋ ə pɛɹ ə buts tə bi mɛndɪd. ivən ɪf i lɛt vɪzəɾɝz ɡoʊ ʌp wɪθaʊt sɛndɪŋ wɝɾ əhɛd, hi wəd bi eɪbəl tə aɪdɛntəfaɪ ðɛm leɪɾɝ, ən meɪbi soʊ wəd tu əɹ θɹi ʌðɝz.

Taking a quick bite, Rand wiped hot juice from his chin and walked over to shelter beneath the eaves of a small cutler's shop. Along the street others were snatching a quick meal from the food-peddlers, meat pies or fried fish or twisted paper cones heaped with roasted peas. Three or four men as tall as he, and two or three women as tall as most of the other men in the street, might have been Aiel. Maybe the chinless fellow was not as shifty as he seemed, or maybe it was just that Rand had eaten nothing since breakfast, but Rand found himself wanting to gobble the pie down and buy another. Instead, he made himself eat slowly. Zeram seemed to be doing a good business. A steady if not constant flow of men went into his shop, most carrying a pair of boots to be mended. Even if he let visitors go up without sending word ahead, he would be able to identify them later, and maybe so would two or three others.

ɪf ðə ɹɛnəɡeɪdz wɝ ɹɛntɪŋ ðə tɑp flɔɹ fɹəm ðə butmeɪkɝz waɪf, biɪŋ lɑkt ɪn ət naɪt wəd nɑɾ ɪnkənvinjəns əm mʌtʃ. tə ðə saʊθ, ən æliweɪ sɛpɝeɪɾəd ðə butmeɪkɝz fɹəm ə sɪŋɡəl-stɔɹi haʊs, ə deɪnʒɝəs dʒɹɑp, bʌɾ ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪd, ə tu-stɔɹi bɪldɪŋ wɪð ə simstʃɹɪs ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊn flɔɹ stʊd wɔl-tə-wɔl wɪð ðə butmeɪkɝ. zɹæmz bɪldɪŋ hæd noʊ wɪndoʊz ɪksɛpt ət ðə fɹʌnt - ɪn bæk wɑz ənʌðɝ æli, fəɹ teɪkɪŋ əweɪ ɹʌbɪʃ; ɹænd hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi tʃɛkt - bʌt ðəɹ hæd tə bi ə weɪ ɑntu ðə ɹuf soʊ ðə sleɪts kəd bi ɹɪpɛɹd wən nɛsəsɛɹi. fɹəm ðəɹ ɪt wəd bi ə ʃɔɹt dʒɹɑp tə ðə simstʃɹɪsəz ɹuf, wɪð oʊnli θɹi mɔɹ tə kɹɔs bɪfɔɹ ənʌðɝ loʊ bɪldɪŋ, ə kændəlmeɪkɝz ʃɑp, ən ən izi dʒʌmp tə ðə stʃɹit, əɹ ɪndə ði æli bɪhaɪn ðə bɪldɪŋz. ðəɹ wəd nɑt bi ə ɡɹeɪt dil ə ɹɪsk ɪn ɪɾ ət naɪt, əɹ ivən ɪn deɪlaɪt, ɪf jə steɪd bæk fɹəm ðə stʃɹiɾ ən wɝ kɛɹfəl əbaʊt ðə ɡɑɹdz pətʃɹoʊlz wən jə keɪm daʊn. ðə weɪ blu kɑɹp stʃɹit bɛnt, ðə nɪɹəst wɑtʃstænz wɝ aʊɾ ə saɪt.

If the renegades were renting the top floor from the bootmaker's wife, being locked in at night would not inconvenience them much. To the south, an alleyway separated the bootmaker's from a single-story house, a dangerous drop, but on the other side, a two-story building with a seamstress on the ground floor stood wall-to-wall with the bootmaker. Zeram's building had no windows except at the front - in back was another alley, for taking away rubbish; Rand had already checked - but there had to be a way onto the roof so the slates could be repaired when necessary. From there it would be a short drop to the seamstress's roof, with only three more to cross before another low building, a candlemaker's shop, and an easy jump to the street, or into the alley behind the buildings. There would not be a great deal of risk in it at night, or even in daylight, if you stayed back from the street and were careful about the Guard's patrols when you came down. The way Blue Carp Street bent, the nearest watchstands were out of sight.

tu mɛn əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ ðə butmeɪkɝz meɪɾ ɪm tɝn əweɪ ən pɹitɛn tə pɪɹ θɹu ðə bʌbəl peɪnz ə ðə kʌtlɝz smɔl ʃɑpwəndoʊ əɾ ə dɪspleɪ ʌv sɪzɝz ən naɪvz fæsən tə ə bɔɹd. wʌn ə ðə mɛn wɑz tɔl, ðoʊ nɑɾ əz tɔl əz ðə pɑsəbəl ilmɛn. ðɛɹ dip kaʊlz hɪd ðɛɹ feɪsəz, bʌt niðɝ kæɹiɾ ə pɛɹ ə buts, ən ɔlðoʊ ðeɪ hɛl ðɛɹ kloʊks wɪð boʊθ hænz, ðə wɪn flɪp ðə teɪlz ə ðɛm ɪnʌf tə ʃoʊ ðə bɑɾəmz ə skæbɑɹɾɪd sɔɹdz. ə ɡʌs pʊl ðə ʃɔɹɾɝ mænz hʊd fɹəm ɪz hɛd, ən i snætʃt ɪt bæk əɡɛn, bʌt nɑt bɪfɔɹ ðə dæmədʒ wɑz dʌn. tʃɑɹl dʒɛdwɪn hæd teɪkən tə wɛɹɪŋ ɪz hɛɹ kɑɾ ət ðə neɪp ə hɪz nɛk ɪn ə sɪlvɝ klɪp sɛt wɪð ə lɑɹdʒ ɹɛd stoʊn, bʌɾ i wɑz stɪl ə hɑɹd-feɪs mæn wɪð ə tʃælənʒɪŋ lʊk əbaʊt hɪm. ən dʒɛdwɪnz pɹɛzəns meɪd ði ʌðɝ tɔɹvəl. ɹænd wɑz wɪlɪŋ tə weɪdʒɝ ɑn ɪt. nʌn ə ði ʌðɝz wɑz əz tɔl.

Two men approaching the bootmaker's made him turn away and pretend to peer through the bubbled panes of the cutler's small shopwindow at a display of scissors and knives fastened to a board. One of the men was tall, though not as tall as the possible Aielmen. Their deep cowls hid their faces, but neither carried a pair of boots, and although they held their cloaks with both hands, the wind flipped the tails of them enough to show the bottoms of scabbarded swords. A gust pulled the shorter man's hood from his head, and he snatched it back again, but not before the damage was done. Charl Gedwyn had taken to wearing his hair caught at the nape of his neck in a silver clip set with a large red stone, but he was still a hard-faced man with a challenging look about him. And Gedwyn's presence made the other Torval. Rand was willing to wager on it. None of the others was as tall.

weɪɾɪŋ əntɪl ðə pɛɹ hæd ɡɔn ɪndə zɹæmz ʃɑp, ɹænd lɪkt ə fju ɡɹisi kɹʌmz fɹəm ɪz ɡlʌvz ən wɛn ɪn sɝtʃ ə nɪneɪiv ən læn. hi faʊn əm bɪfɔɹ i wɑz fɑɹ ɪnʌf əlɔŋ ðə kɝv ə ðə stʃɹit tə luz saɪɾ ə ðə butmeɪkɝz. ðə kændəlmeɪkɝz i hæd mɑɹkt əz ə weɪ daʊn fɹəm ðə ɹuftɑps stʊɾ ə lɪɾəl bɪhaɪn hɪm, wɪð ən æli ət wʌn saɪd. əhɛd, ðə nɛɹoʊ stʃɹit twɪstəd bæk ði ʌðɝ weɪ. noʊ mɔɹ ðən fɪfti peɪsɪz fɑɹðɝ ɑn wɑz ə wɑtʃstænd wɪð ə stʃɹit ɡɑɹɾ ət ðə tɑp, bʌɾ ənʌðɝ bɪldɪŋ ə θɹi stɔɹiz, ə kæbəntmeɪkɝz ðət ʃɛɹd ði æliweɪ wɪð ðə kændəlmeɪkɝ, blɑk ðə ɹuftɑps bɪɑn fɹəm ɪz vju.

Waiting until the pair had gone into Zeram's shop, Rand licked a few greasy crumbs from his gloves and went in search of Nynaeve and Lan. He found them before he was far enough along the curve of the street to lose sight of the bootmaker's. The candlemaker's he had marked as a way down from the rooftops stood a little behind him, with an alley at one side. Ahead, the narrow street twisted back the other way. No more than fifty paces farther on was a watchstand with a Street Guard at the top, but another building of three stories, a cabinetmaker's that shared the alleyway with the candlemaker, blocked the rooftops beyond from his view.

"hæf ə dʌzən pipəl ɹɛkəɡnaɪz tɔɹvəl ən dʒɛdwɪn," læn sɛd, "bʌt nʌn ə ði ʌðɝz." hi kɛpt ɪz vɔɪs loʊ, ðoʊ noʊ wʌn pæsɪŋ mɔɹ ðən ɡlænst ət ðə θɹi ʌv ðɛm. ə ɡlɪmps ə tu mɛn wɛɹɪŋ sɔɹdz bɪniθ ðɛɹ kloʊks wɑz ɪnʌf tə meɪk ɛvɹiwʌn u noʊɾəst stɛp ə lɪɾəl fæstɝ.

"Half a dozen people recognized Torval and Gedwyn," Lan said, "but none of the others." He kept his voice low, though no one passing more than glanced at the three of them. A glimpse of two men wearing swords beneath their cloaks was enough to make everyone who noticed step a little faster.

"ə bʊtʃɝ daʊn ðə stʃɹit sɛz ðoʊz tu baɪ fɹəm hɪm," nɪneɪiv sɛd, "bʌt nɛvɝ mɔɹ ðən ɪnʌf fəɹ tu." ʃi lʊk saɪdweɪz ət læn əz ðoʊ hɝz wɑz ðə ɹil pɹuf.

"A butcher down the street says those two buy from him," Nynaeve said, "but never more than enough for two." She looked sideways at Lan as though hers was the real proof.

"aɪ sɔ ðɛm," ɹænd sɛd. "ðeɪɹ ɪnsaɪd naʊ. nɪneɪiv, kən jə lɪf læn ən mi tə ðət ɹuftɑp fɹəm ði æli bɪhaɪn ðə bɪldɪŋ?"

"I saw them," Rand said. "They're inside now. Nynaeve, can you lift Lan and me to that rooftop from the alley behind the building?"

nɪneɪiv fɹaʊn ət zɹæmz bɪldɪŋ, ɹʌbɪŋ ðə bɛlt ɝaʊn əɹ weɪst wɪð wʌn hænd. "wʌn əɾ ə taɪm, aɪ kʊd," ʃi sɛd faɪnəli. "bʌɾ ɪt wəd juz mɔɹ ðən hæf wʌt ðə wɛl hoʊlz. aɪ wʊdn bi eɪbəl tə lɪf jə daʊn əɡɛn."

Nynaeve frowned at Zeram's building, rubbing the belt around her waist with one hand. "One at a time, I could," she said finally. "But it would use more than half what the Well holds. I wouldn't be able to lift you down again."

"ʌp ɪz ɪnʌf," ɹænd toʊl hɝ. "wi wɪl liv oʊvɝ ðə ɹuftɑps, ən klaɪm daʊn ɹaɪɾ oʊvɝ bɪsaɪd ðə kændəlmeɪkɝ."

"Up is enough," Rand told her. "We will leave over the rooftops, and climb down right over beside the candlemaker."

ʃi pɹətɛstəd, ʌv kɔɹs, əz ðeɪ wɔk bæk daʊn ðə stʃɹit təwɔɹd ðə butmeɪkɝz ʃɑp. nɪneɪiv ɔlweɪz fɔɾ ɛniθɪŋ ʃi hæd nɑt θɔɾ ə hɝsɛlf. "aɪ æm dʒʌst səpoʊz tə pʊt jə ɑn ðə ɹuf ən weɪt?" ʃi mʌɾɝd, skaʊlɪŋ lɛft ən ɹaɪt soʊ hɑɹd ðəɾ əz mɛni pipəl ʃaɪɾ əweɪ fɹəm əɹ əz fɹəm ðə mɛn flæŋkɪŋ hɝ, sɔɹdz əɹ noʊ sɔɹdz. ʃi θɹʌst əɹ hæn aʊt fɹəm ʌndɝ əɹ kloʊk tə ʃoʊ ðə bɹeɪslət wɪð ɪts peɪl ɹɛd stoʊnz. "ðɪs kən kʌvɝ mi wɪð ɑɹmɝ bɛɾɝ ðən ɛni stil. aɪd hɑɹdli ivən fil ə sɔɹd hɪɾɪŋ mi. aɪ θɔɾ aɪ wəd bi ɡoʊɪŋ ɪnsaɪd wɪð ju."

She protested, of course, as they walked back down the street toward the bootmaker's shop. Nynaeve always fought anything she had not thought of herself. "I am just supposed to put you on the roof and wait?" she muttered, scowling left and right so hard that as many people shied away from her as from the men flanking her, swords or no swords. She thrust her hand out from under her cloak to show the bracelet with its pale red stones. "This can cover me with armor better than any steel. I'd hardly even feel a sword hitting me. I thought I would be going inside with you."

"æn də wʌt?" ɹænd æsk sɔfli. "hoʊld əm wɪð ðə paʊɝ fəɹ əs tə kɪl? kɪl əm jɝsɛlf?" ʃi fɹaʊn ət ðə peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ fit.

"And do what?" Rand asked softly. "Hold them with the Power for us to kill? Kill them yourself?" She frowned at the paving stones in front of her feet.

wɔkɪŋ bɪɑn zɹæmz ʃɑp, ɹænd pɔzd ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə loʊ haʊs ən lʊkt ɝaʊn əz kæʒəwəli əz i kʊd. ðəɹ wɝ noʊ stʃɹit ɡɑɹdz ɪn saɪt, bʌt wən i pɹɑɾɪd nɪneɪiv ɪndə ðə nɛɹoʊ æli, hi muv kwɪkli. hi hæd nɑt sin ɛni ɡɑɹdz bɪfɔɹ fɑloʊɪŋ ɹɑtʃeɪd, iðɝ.

Walking beyond Zeram's shop, Rand paused in front of the low house and looked around as casually as he could. There were no Street Guards in sight, but when he prodded Nynaeve into the narrow alley, he moved quickly. He had not seen any Guards before following Rochaid, either.

"ju ɑɹ vɛɹi kwaɪət," læn sɛd, fɑloʊɪŋ kloʊs bɪhaɪnd.

"You are very quiet," Lan said, following close behind.

ʃi tʊk θɹi mɔɹ kwɪk stɛps bɪfɔɹ ɹɪplaɪɪŋ, wɪθaʊt sloʊɪŋ əɹ lʊkɪŋ bæk. "aɪ dɪdn θɪŋk, bɪfɔɹ," ʃi sɛd kwaɪətli. "aɪ wɑz θɪŋkɪŋ ʌv ɪɾ əz ən ædvɛntʃɝ, kənfɹʌntɪŋ dɑɹkfɹɛnz, ɹɛnəɡeɪɾ æʃəmən, bʌt jə ɑɹ ɡoʊɪŋ ʌp ðəɹ tə ɛksəkjut ðɛm. jəl kɪl əm bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ noʊ jəɹ ðəɹ ɪf jə kæn, woʊn ju?"

She took three more quick steps before replying, without slowing or looking back. "I didn't think, before," she said quietly. "I was thinking of it as an adventure, confronting Darkfriends, renegade Asha'man, but you are going up there to execute them. You'll kill them before they know you're there if you can, won't you?"

ɹænd ɡlænst oʊvɝ, hɪz ʃoʊldɝ ət læn, bʌt ði oʊldɝ mæn oʊnli ʃʊk ɪz hɛd, əz kənfjuzd əz i wɑz. ʌv kɔɹs ðeɪ wəd kɪl əm wɪθaʊt wɔɹnɪŋ ɪf ðeɪ kʊd. ðɪs wɑz nɑɾ ə duəl; ɪt wɑz ði ɛksəkjuʃən ʃi hæd neɪmd ɪt. ət list, ɹænd hoʊp vɛɹi mʌtʃ ɪt wəd bi.

Rand glanced over, his shoulder at Lan, but the older man only shook his head, as confused as he was. Of course they would kill them without warning if they could. This was not a duel; it was the execution she had named it. At least, Rand hoped very much it would be.

ði æli ðət ɹæn bɪhaɪn ðə bɪldɪŋz wɑz ə lɪɾəl waɪɾɝ ðən ðə wʌn tə ðə stʃɹit, ðə ɹɑki sɔɪl ɹʌɾɪd wɪð ðə tʃɹæks ə ðə ɹʌbɪʃ bæɹoʊz ðət wɝ pʊʃt əlɔŋ ɪt mɔɹnɪŋz. blæŋk stoʊn wɔlz ɹoʊz ɝaʊn ðɛm. noʊ wʌn wɑntəɾ ə wɪndoʊ tə wɑtʃ ðə ɹʌbɪʃ kɑɹts.

The alley that ran behind the buildings was a little wider than the one to the street, the rocky soil rutted with the tracks of the rubbish barrows that were pushed along it mornings. Blank stone walls rose around them. No one wanted a window to watch the rubbish carts.

nɪneɪiv stʊd piɹɪŋ ʌp ət ðə bæk ə zɹæmz bɪldɪŋ, ðən sʌɾənli saɪd. "kɪl əm ɪn ðɛɹ slip, ɪf jə kæn," ʃi sɛd, vɛɹi kwaɪətli fəɹ sətʃ fɪɹs wɝdz.

Nynaeve stood peering up at the back of Zeram's building, then suddenly sighed. "Kill them in their sleep, if you can," she said, very quietly for such fierce words.

sʌmθɪŋ ənsin ɹæp snʌɡli ɝaʊn ɹændz tʃɛs bɪniθ ɪz ɑɹmz, ən sloʊli hi ɹoʊz ɪndə ði ɛɹ, floʊɾɪŋ haɪɝ əntɪl i dʒɹɪftəɾ oʊvɝ ði ɛdʒ ə ði oʊvɝhæŋɪŋ iv. ði ɪnvɪzəbəl hɑɹnəs vænɪʃt, ən ɪz buts dʒɹɑp tə ðə sloʊpɪŋ ɹuf, slaɪɾɪŋ ə lɪɾəl ɑn ðə dæmp ɡɹeɪ sleɪts. kɹaʊtʃɪŋ, hi muv bæk ɑn ɔl fɔɹz. ə fju moʊməns leɪɾɝ, læn floʊɾəd ʌp tə læn ɑn ðə ɹuf, tu. ðə wɔɹɾɝ kɹaʊtʃt əz wɛl, ən pɪɹɾ ɪndə ði æli bɪloʊ.

Something unseen wrapped snugly around Rand's chest beneath his arms, and slowly he rose into the air, floating higher until he drifted over the edge of the overhanging eave.
