The invisible harness vanished, and his boots dropped to the sloping roof, sliding a little on the damp gray slates. Crouching, he moved back on all fours. A few moments later, Lan floated up to land on the roof, too. The Warder crouched as well, and peered into the alley below.

"ʃi ɪz ɡɔn," læn sɛd faɪnəli. twɪstɪŋ ɝaʊn tə feɪs ɹænd, hi pɔɪntəd. "ðɛɹ ɪz əɹ weɪ ɪn."

"She is gone," Lan said finally. Twisting around to face Rand, he pointed. "There is our way in."

ɪt wɑz ə tʃɹæpdɔɹ sɛɾ əmʌŋ ðə sleɪts haɪ təwɔɹd ðə pik, wɪð mɛɾəl flæʃɪŋ tə kip wɔɾɝ aʊɾ ə ði æɾɪk ðət lɪftɪŋ ɪt ɹɪvild. ɹænd loʊɝd hɪmsɛlf ɪndə ə dʌsti speɪs, dɪmli lɪt baɪ ðə laɪt θɹu ðə tʃɹæpdɔɹ. fəɹ ə moʊmənt, hi hʌŋ baɪ hɪz hænz, ðən lɛt ɡoʊ, dʒɹɑpɪŋ ðə læs fju fit. ɪksɛp fəɹ ə tʃɛɹ wɪð θɹi lɛɡz ən ə tʃɛst wɪð ðə lɪd θɹoʊn oʊpən, ðə lɔŋ ɹum wɑz əz ɛmpti əz ðə tʃɛst. əpɛɹənli zɹæm hæd stɑp juzɪŋ ði æɾɪk fəɹ stɔɹədʒ wən ɪz waɪf bɪɡæn teɪkɪŋ ɹɛntɝz.

It was a trapdoor set among the slates high toward the peak, with metal flashing to keep water out of the attic that lifting it revealed. Rand lowered himself into a dusty space, dimly lit by the light through the trapdoor. For a moment, he hung by his hands, then let go, dropping the last few feet. Except for a chair with three legs and a chest with the lid thrown open, the long room was as empty as the chest. Apparently Zeram had stopped using the attic for storage when his wife began taking renters.

stɛpɪŋ laɪtli, ðə tu mɛn sɝtʃt ðə flɔɹbɔɹdz əntɪl ðeɪ faʊn ənʌðɝ, lɑɹdʒɝ tʃɹæpdɔɹ laɪɪŋ flæɾ əɡɛns ðə flɔɹ. læn fɛl ðə bɹæs hɪnʒɪz ən wɪspɝd ðət ðeɪ wɝ dʒɹaɪ bʌɾ ʌnɹəstɪd. ɹænd dʒɹu hɪz sɔɹɾ ən nɑɾəd, ən læn snætʃt ðə tʃɹæpdɔɹ oʊpən.

Stepping lightly, the two men searched the floorboards until they found another, larger trapdoor lying flat against the floor. Lan felt the brass hinges and whispered that they were dry but unrusted. Rand drew his sword and nodded, and Lan snatched the trapdoor open.

ɹænd wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ wʌɾ i wəd faɪnd wən i spɹæŋ daʊn θɹu ði oʊpənɪŋ, juzɪŋ ə hæn ɑn ðə koʊpɪŋ tə kəntʃɹoʊl ɪz fɔl. hi lændəd laɪtli ɑn ðə bɔlz ə hɪz fit, ɪn ə ɹum ðət sim tə hæv teɪkən ði æɾɪks pleɪs fɹəm ðə wɔɹdʒɹoʊbz ən kæbənəts ʃʌvd əɡɛns ðə wɔlz, ðə wʊɾən tʃɛsts paɪld ɑn wʌn ənʌðɝ ən teɪbəlz wɪð tʃɛɹz stændɪŋ ətɑp ðɛm. ðə læs θɪŋ i ɪkspɛktəd, ðoʊ, wɑz tu dɛd mɛn spɹɔld ɑn ðə flɔɹ əz ɪf ðeɪ hæd bɪn dʒɹæɡd ɪndə ðə stɔɹədʒ ɹum ən flʌŋ daʊn. ðə blæk swoʊlən feɪsəz wɝ ənɹɛkəɡnaɪzəbəl, bʌt ðə ʃɔɹɾɝ ə ðə pɛɹ wɔɹ ə sɪlvɝ hɛɹklɪp sɛt wɪð ə lɑɹdʒ ɹɛd stoʊn.

Rand was not sure what he would find when he sprang down through the opening, using a hand on the coping to control his fall. He landed lightly on the balls of his feet, in a room that seemed to have taken the attic's place from the wardrobes and cabinets shoved against the walls, the wooden chests piled on one another and tables with chairs standing atop them. The last thing he expected, though, was two dead men sprawled on the floor as if they had been dragged into the storage room and flung down. The black swollen faces were unrecognizable, but the shorter of the pair wore a silver hairclip set with a large red stone.

dʒɹɑpɪŋ saʊnləsli fɹəm ði æɾɪk, læn lʊkt ət ðə kɔɹpsəz ən ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ. ðət wɑz ɔl. nʌθɪŋ ɛvɝ sɝpɹaɪz hɪm.

Dropping soundlessly from the attic, Lan looked at the corpses and raised an eyebrow. That was all. Nothing ever surprised him.

"feɪn ɪz hɪɹ," ɹænd wɪspɝd. əz ɪf seɪɪŋ ðə neɪm wɝ ə tʃɹɪɡɝ, ðə twɪn wunz ɪn ɪz saɪd bɪɡæn θɹɑbɪŋ, ði oʊldɝ laɪk ə dɪsk ʌv aɪs, ðə nuɝ ə bɑɹ ə faɪɝ əkɹɔs ɪt. "ɪt wɑz ɪm sɛn ðə lɛɾɝ."

"Fain is here," Rand whispered. As if saying the name were a trigger, the twin wounds in his side began throbbing, the older like a disc of ice, the newer a bar of fire across it. "It was him sent the letter."

læn dʒɛstʃɝd təwɔɹd ðə tʃɹæpdɔɹ wɪð ɪz sɔɹd, bʌt ɹænd ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. hi hæd wɑntəd tə kɪl ðə ɹɛnəɡeɪdz wɪð ɪz oʊn hænz, jɛt naʊ ðət tɔɹvəl ən dʒɛdwɪn wɝ dɛd - ən ɔlmoʊst sɝɾənli kɪsmən, tu; ðəɹ wɑz ðət swoʊlən kɔɹps mɛnʃən baɪ ðə mɝtʃən ət ðə ɡoʊldən wil - naʊ, hi ɹilaɪzd i dɪd nɑt kɛɹ u kɪld əm soʊ lɔŋ əz ðeɪ wɝ dɛd. ɪf ə stʃɹeɪnʒɝ fɪnɪʃt dæʃivə, ɪt wəd nɑt mæɾɝ. feɪn wɑz ənʌðɝ mæɾɝ. feɪn hæd hɛɹɹoʊd ðə tu ɹɪvɝz wɪð tʃɹɑləks, ən ɡɪvən ɪm ə sɛkənd waʊn ðət wəd nɑt hil. ɪf feɪn wɑz wɪðɪn ɹitʃ, ɹænd wəd nɑɾ əlaʊ hɪm tə ɪskeɪp. hi moʊʃən fəɹ læn tə də əz ðeɪ hæɾ ɪn ði æɾɪk, ən sɛt hɪmsɛlf ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə dɔɹ wɪð ɪz sɔɹɾ ɪn boʊθ hænz. wən ði ʌðɝ mæn pʊl ðə dɔɹ oʊpən, hi dɑɹɾɪd ɪndə ə lɑɹdʒ læmplɪt ɹum wɪð ə poʊstɪd bɛɾ əɡɛns ðə fɑɹ wɔl ən ə faɪɝ kɹæklɪŋ ɪn ə smɔl faɪɝpleɪs.

Lan gestured toward the trapdoor with his sword, but Rand shook his head. He had wanted to kill the renegades with his own hands, yet now that Torval and Gedwyn were dead - and almost certainly Kisman, too; there was that swollen corpse mentioned by the merchant at The Golden Wheel - now, he realized he did not care who killed them so long as they were dead. If a stranger finished Dashiva, it would not matter. Fain was another matter. Fain had harrowed the Two Rivers with Trollocs, and given him a second wound that would not heal. If Fain was within reach, Rand would not allow him to escape. He motioned for Lan to do as they had in the attic, and set himself in front of the door with his sword in both hands. When the other man pulled the door open, he darted into a large lamplit room with a posted bed against the far wall and a fire crackling in a small fireplace.

oʊnli ðə spiɾ ə hɪz muvmən seɪv hɪm. ə flɪkɝ ə muvmən kɑt ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɪz aɪ, sʌmθɪŋ tʌɡd ət ðə kloʊk bɪloʊɪŋ bɪhaɪn hɪm, ən i spʌn ɔkwɝdli tə fɛn ɔf slæʃɪz ʌv ə kɝv dæɡɝ. ɛvɹi muvmənt wɑz ən ɛfɝɾ ʌv wɪl. ðə wunz ɪn ɪz saɪd noʊ lɔŋɡɝ θɹɑbd; ðeɪ klɔɾ ət hɪm, moʊltən aɪɝn ən ðə vɛɹi soʊl ʌv aɪs wɔɹɪŋ tə ɹɪp ɪm oʊpən. luz θɝɪn haʊld. ɪt wɑz ɔl ɹænd kəd də tə θɪŋk, wɪð ði æɡəni.

Only the speed of his movement saved him. A flicker of movement caught the corner of his eye, something tugged at the cloak billowing behind him, and he spun awkwardly to fend off slashes of a curved dagger. Every movement was an effort of will. The wounds in his side no longer throbbed; they clawed at him, molten iron and the very soul of ice warring to rip him open. Lews Therin howled. It was all Rand could do to think, with the agony.

"aɪ toʊl jə hiz maɪn!" ðə boʊni mæn skɹimd, dænsɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm ɹændz kʌt. wɪð ɪz feɪs kəntɔɹɾəd ɪn fjʊɹi, hɪz bɪɡ noʊz ən ɪɹz ðət stʌk aʊt meɪɾ ɪm sim sʌmθɪŋ kəntʃɹaɪv tə fɹaɪɾən tʃɪlʒɹən, bʌɾ ɪz aɪz hɛl mɝɾɝ. tiθ bɛɹɾ ɪn ə snɑɹl, hi lʊk laɪk ə wizəl waɪld wɪð kɪlɪŋ fjʊɹi. ə ɹæbɪd wizəl, ɹɛɾi tə sævədʒ ivən ə lɛpɝd. wɪð ðət dæɡɝ, hi kəd kɪl ɛni nʌmbɝ ə lɛpɝdz. "maɪn!" pdən feɪn ʃɹikt, lipɪŋ bæk əɡɛn əz læn ɹʌʃt ɪndə ðə ɹum. "kɪl ði ʌɡli wʌn!"

"I told you he's mine!" the bony man screamed, dancing away from Rand's cut. With his face contorted in fury, his big nose and ears that stuck out made him seem something contrived to frighten children, but his eyes held murder. Teeth bared in a snarl, he looked like a weasel wild with killing fury. A rabid weasel, ready to savage even a leopard. With that dagger, he could kill any number of leopards. "Mine!" Padan Fain shrieked, leaping back again as Lan rushed into the room. "Kill the ugly one!"

oʊnli wən læn tɝn əweɪ fɹəm feɪn dɪd ɹænd ɹilaɪz sʌmwʌn ɛls wɑz ɪn ðə ɹum, ə tɔl peɪl mæn u keɪm ɔlmoʊst iɡɝli tə mit ðə wɔɹɾɝ bleɪd tə bleɪd. tɔɹæm ɹieɪɾənz feɪs wɑz hæɡɝd, bʌɾ i floʊɾ ɪndə ðə dæns ə sɔɹdz wɪð ðə ɡɹeɪs ə ðə bleɪdmæstɝ i wɑz. læn mɛɾ ɪm wɪð ən ikwəl ɡɹeɪs, ə dæns ə stil ən dɛθ.

Only when Lan turned away from Fain did Rand realize someone else was in the room, a tall pale man who came almost eagerly to meet the Warder blade to blade. Toram Riatin's face was haggard, but he flowed into the dance of swords with the grace of the blademaster he was. Lan met him with an equal grace, a dance of steel and death.

stɑɹɾəld əz ɹænd wɑz tə si ðə mæn u hæd tʃɹaɪd tə kleɪm ðə θɹoʊn ə kɛɹhin ɪn ə wɔɹn koʊɾ ɪn fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ, hi kɛpt ɪz aɪz ɑn feɪn ən ɪz sɔɹd təwɔɹd ðə wʌn taɪm pɛdlɝ. dɑɹkfɹɛn ən wɝs, mɔɪɹeɪn hæd kɔld ɪm lɔŋ əɡoʊ. ðə blaɪndɪŋ peɪn ɪn ɹændz saɪd meɪɾ ɪm stʌmbəl əz i ədvænst ɑn feɪn, ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ðə stæmp ə buts ən ðə ɹɪŋ ə stil ɑn stil bɪhaɪn ɪm əz i ɪɡnɔɹd luz θɝɪnz ɡɹoʊnz ɪn ɪz hɛd. feɪn dænst ən dɑɹɾɪd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɡɛt kloʊs ɪnʌf tə juz ðə dæɡɝ ðət hæd meɪd ðə nɛvɝ-hilɪŋ slæʃ ɪn ɹændz saɪd, ɡɹoʊlɪŋ kɝsɪz ɪn ə loʊ vɔɪs əz ɹændz bleɪd fɔɹst ɪm bæk. əbɹʌpli hi tɝn ən ɹæn, təwɔɹd ðə bæk ə ðə bɪldɪŋ.

Startled as Rand was to see the man who had tried to claim the throne of Cairhien in a worn coat in Far Madding, he kept his eyes on Fain and his sword toward the one time peddler. Darkfriend and worse, Moiraine had called him long ago. The blinding pain in Rand's side made him stumble as he advanced on Fain, ignoring the stamp of boots and the ring of steel on steel behind him as he ignored Lews Therin's groans in his head. Fain danced and darted, trying to get close enough to use the dagger that had made the never-healing slash in Rand's side, growling curses in a low voice as Rand's blade forced him back. Abruptly he turned and ran, toward the back of the building.

ðə tɔɹmɛn tɛɹɪŋ ət ɹænd feɪɾəd tə mɪɹ θɹɑbɪŋ əz feɪn vænɪʃt fɹəm ðə ɹum, bʌɾ i fɑloʊd kɔʃəsli ivən soʊ. ət ðə dɔɹweɪ, ðoʊ, hi sɔ ðət feɪn wɑz nɑt tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə haɪd. ðə mæn stʊd weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ɪm ət ðə hɛɾ ə stɛɹz liɾɪŋ daʊn, ðə kɝv dæɡɝ ɪn wʌn hænd. ðə lɑɹdʒ ɹubi kæpɪŋ ðə hɪlt ɡlɪɾɝd, kætʃɪŋ ðə laɪɾ ə ðə læmps sɛɾ ɑn teɪbəlz əbaʊt ðə wɪndoʊləs ɹum. əz sun əz ɹænd stɛpt ɪndə ðə ɹum, faɪɝ ən aɪs ɹeɪdʒd ɪn ɪz saɪd tɪl i kəd fil ɪz hɑɹt ʃʌɾɝɪŋ. steɪɪŋ əpɹaɪt wɑz ən ɛfɝɾ ʌv aɪɝn wɪl. teɪkɪŋ ə stɛp fɔɹwɝd meɪd ðəɾ ɛfɝt sim peɪl, bʌɾ i tʊk ðət stɛp, ən ðə nɛkst.

The torment tearing at Rand faded to mere throbbing as Fain vanished from the room, but he followed cautiously even so. At the doorway, though, he saw that Fain was not trying to hide. The man stood waiting for him at the head of stairs leading down, the curved dagger in one hand. The large ruby capping the hilt glittered, catching the light of the lamps set on tables about the windowless room. As soon as Rand stepped into the room, fire and ice raged in his side till he could feel his heart shuddering. Staying upright was an effort of iron will. Taking a step forward made that effort seem pale, but he took that step, and the next.

"aɪ wɑn ɪm tə noʊ hu ɪz kɪlɪŋ hɪm," feɪn waɪn pətʃələnli. hi wɑz ɡlɛɹɪŋ stʃɹeɪɾ ət ɹænd, bʌɾ i sim tə tɔkɪŋ tə hɪmsɛlf. "aɪ wɑn ɪm tə noʊ! bʌɾ ɪf hiz dɛd, ðən hɪl stɑp hɔntɪŋ maɪ dʒɹimz. jɛs. hɪl stɑp, ðɛn." wɪð ə smaɪl, hi ɹeɪzd ɪz fɹi hænd.

"I want him to know who is killing him," Fain whined petulantly. He was glaring straight at Rand, but he seemed to talking to himself. "I want him to know! But if he's dead, then he will stop haunting my dreams. Yes. He will stop, then." With a smile, he raised his free hand.

tɔɹvəl ən dʒɛdwɪn keɪm ʌp ðə stɛɹz wɪð ðɛɹ kloʊks oʊvɝ ðɛɹ ɑɹmz.

Torval and Gedwyn came up the stairs with their cloaks over their arms.

"aɪ seɪ wi ɑɹənt ɡoʊɪŋ nɪɹ ɪm əntɪl aɪ noʊ wɛɹ ði ʌðɝz ɑɹ," dʒɛdwɪn ɡɹaʊld. "ðə l wɪl kɪl əs ɪf . . ."

"I say we aren't going near him until I know where the others are," Gedwyn growled. "The M'Hael will kill us if . . ."

wɪθaʊt θɔt, ɹænd twɪstəɾ ɪz ɹɪsts ɪn kʌɾɪŋ ðə wɪn ən ɪmiɾiətli fɑloʊd wɪð ənfoʊldɪŋ ðə fæn.

Without thought, Rand twisted his wrists in Cutting the Wind and immediately followed with Unfolding the Fan.

ði ɪluʒən ə dɛd mɛn kʌm bæk tə laɪf vænɪʃt, ən feɪn lɛp bæk wɪð ə ʃɹik, blʌd stʃɹimɪŋ daʊn ðə saɪɾ ə hɪz feɪs. sʌɾənli hi tɪltəɾ ɪz hɛɾ əz ðoʊ lɪsnɪŋ, ən ə moʊmən leɪɾɝ, eɪmɪŋ ə skɹim ʌv wɝdləs fjʊɹi ət ɹænd, hi flɛd daʊn ðə stɛɹz.

The illusion of dead men come back to life vanished, and Fain leaped back with a shriek, blood streaming down the side of his face. Suddenly he tilted his head as though listening, and a moment later, aiming a scream of wordless fury at Rand, he fled down the stairs.

wʌndɝɪŋ, ɹænd muv tə fɑloʊ ðə dɪsɛndɪŋ θʌmps ə feɪnz buts, bʌt læn kɑɾ ɪz ɑɹm.

Wondering, Rand moved to follow the descending thumps of Fain's boots, but Lan caught his arm.

"ðə stʃɹiɾ aʊt fɹʌn ɪz fɪlɪŋ ʌp wɪð ɡɑɹdz, ʃifɝɾɝ." ə dɑɹk wɛtnəs steɪn ðə lɛf saɪɾ ə lænz koʊt, bʌɾ ɪz sɔɹd wɑz ʃiðd, pɹuf ə hu hæd dæns ðət dæns ðə bɛɾɝ. "taɪm wi wɝ ɑn ðə ɹuf, ɪf wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ."

"The street out front is filling up with Guards, sheepherder." A dark wetness stained the left side of Lan's coat, but his sword was sheathed, proof of who had danced that dance the better. "Time we were on the roof, if we're going."

"ə mæn kæn ivən wɔk daʊn ən æli wɪð ə sɔɹɾ ɪn ðɪs sɪɾi," ɹænd mʌɾɝd, ʃiðɪŋ ɪz oʊn bleɪd. læn dɪd nɑt læf, bʌt ðɛn, hi sɛldəm dɪɾ ɪksɛp fəɹ nɪneɪiv. ʃaʊts ən skɹimz ɹoʊz ʌp ðə stɛɹwɛl fɹəm bɪloʊ. meɪbi ðə stʃɹit ɡɑɹdz wəd kæptʃɝ feɪn. meɪbi hi wəd hæŋ fəɹ ðə kɔɹpsəz ʌp hɪɹ. ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ɪnʌf, bʌɾ ɪt wəɾ əv tə du. ɹænd wɑz taɪɝɾ ʌv wʌt wəɾ əv tə du.

"A man can't even walk down an alley with a sword in this city," Rand muttered, sheathing his own blade. Lan did not laugh, but then, he seldom did except for Nynaeve. Shouts and screams rose up the stairwell from below. Maybe the Street Guards would capture Fain. Maybe he would hang for the corpses up here. It was not enough, but it would have to do. Rand was tired of what would have to do.

ɪn ði æɾɪk, læn lɛp tə kætʃ ðə koʊpɪŋ ə ðə tʃɹæpdɔɹ ɪn ðə ɹuf ən pʊl hɪmsɛlf ʌp ən aʊt. ɹænd wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ i kəd meɪk ðət lip. ði æɡəni wɑz ɡɔn wɪð feɪn, bʌɾ ɪz saɪd fɛlt əz ɪf ɪt hæd bɪn biɾən wɪð æksəhændəlz. əz i wɑz ɡæðɝɪŋ hɪmsɛlf tə tʃɹaɪ, læn pʊɾ ɪz hɛd bæk θɹu ðə tʃɹæpdɔɹ ən ɪkstɛndəɾ ə hænd.

In the attic, Lan leapt to catch the coping of the trapdoor in the roof and pull himself up and out. Rand was not sure he could make that leap. The agony was gone with Fain, but his side felt as if it had been beaten with axehandles. As he was gathering himself to try, Lan put his head back through the trapdoor and extended a hand.

"ðeɪ meɪ nɑt kʌm ʌp ɹaɪɾ əweɪ, ʃifɝɾɝ, bʌɾ ɪz ðəɹ ɛni pɔɪn ɪn weɪɾɪŋ tə si?"

"They may not come up right away, sheepherder, but is there any point in waiting to see?"

ɹænd kɑt lænz hæn ən lɛt hɪmsɛlf bi dʒɹɔn ʌp tə wɛɹ i kəd kætʃ ðə koʊpɪŋ ən pʊl hɪmsɛlf aʊɾ ɑntu ðə ɹuf. kɹaʊtʃɪŋ loʊ, ðeɪ muvd əlɔŋ ðə dæmp sleɪts tə ðə bæk ə ðə bɪldɪŋ, ðən bɪɡæn ðə ʃɔɹt klaɪm tə ðə pik. ðəɹ maɪt bi ɡɑɹdz ɪn ðə stʃɹit, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz stɪl ə tʃæns tə ɡɛɾ əweɪ ənsin, ɪspɛʃli ɪf ðeɪ kəd sɪɡnəl nɪneɪiv tə meɪk ə dɪstʃɹækʃən.

Rand caught Lan's hand and let himself be drawn up to where he could catch the coping and pull himself out onto the roof. Crouching low, they moved along the damp slates to the back of the building, then began the short climb to the peak. There might be Guards in the street, but there was still a chance to get away unseen, especially if they could signal Nynaeve to make a distraction.

ɹænd ɹitʃt fəɹ ðə ɹuf pik, ən bɪhaɪn hɪm, lænz but slɪpt ɑn ðə sleɪts wɪð ə skɹitʃ. twɪstɪŋ ɝaʊnd, ɹænd siz ði ʌðɝ mænz ɹɪst, bʌt lænz weɪt pʊld ɪm daʊn ðə slɪk ɡɹeɪ sloʊp. veɪnli ðeɪ skɹæbəld wɪð ðɛɹ fɹi hænz fəɹ ɛni hoʊld, ði ɛdʒ ʌv ə sleɪt, ɛniθɪŋ. niðɝ ʌɾɝd ə wɝd. lænz lɛɡz wɛn oʊvɝ ði ɛdʒ, ən ðən ðə ɹɛst ə hɪm. ɹændz ɡlʌv fɪŋɡɝz kɑɾ ɑn sʌmθɪŋ; hi dɪd nɑt noʊ wʌt, ən i dɪd nɑt kɛɹ. hɪz hɛɾ ən wʌn ʃoʊldɝ stʌk oʊvɝ ði ɛdʒ ə ðə ɹuf, ən læn wɑz dæŋɡəlɪŋ fɹəm ɪz ɡɹɪp əbʌv ðə tɛn-peɪs dʒɹɑp tə ði æli nɛks tə ðə loʊ haʊs.

Rand reached for the roof peak, and behind him, Lan's boot slipped on the slates with a screech. Twisting around, Rand seized the other man's wrist, but Lan's weight pulled him down the slick gray slope. Vainly they scrabbled with their free hands for any hold, the edge of a slate, anything. Neither uttered a word. Lan's legs went over the edge, and then the rest of him. Rand's gloved fingers caught on something; he did not know what, and he did not care. His head and one shoulder stuck over the edge of the roof, and Lan was dangling from his grip above the ten-pace drop to the alley next to the low house.

"lɛt ɡoʊ," læn sɛd kwaɪətli. hi lʊkt ʌp ət ɹænd, hɪz aɪz koʊld ən hɑɹd, noʊ ɪkspɹɛʃən ɑn ɪz feɪs. "lɛt ɡoʊ."

"Let go," Lan said quietly. He looked up at Rand, his eyes cold and hard, no expression on his face. "Let go."

"wɛn ðə sʌn tɝnz ɡɹin," ɹænd toʊl hɪm. ɪf i kəd dʒʌs pʊl ði ʌðɝ mæn ʌp ə lɪɾəl, ɪnʌf tə kætʃ ði iv . . .

"When the sun turns green," Rand told him. If he could just pull the other man up a little, enough to catch the eave . . .

wʌtɛvɝ ɪz fɪŋɡɝz hæd kɑt bɹoʊk wɪð ə ʃɑɹp snæp, ən ði æli ɹʌʃt ʌp tə mit ðɛm.

Whatever his fingers had caught broke with a sharp snap, and the alley rushed up to meet them.


tʃæptɝ θɝɾifɔɹ


CHAPTER 34

ðə hʌmɪŋbɝdz sikɹət


The Hummingbird's Secret

tʃɹaɪɪŋ nɑt tə bi tu ɑbviəs əbaʊt wɑtʃɪŋ ði æli bɪsaɪd ðə kændəlmeɪkɝz, nɪneɪiv sɛt ðə foʊldəd lɛŋθ ə flæt ɡɹin bɹeɪd bæk ɑn ðə hɔkɝz tʃɹeɪ ən slɪpt əɹ hæn ɪnsaɪɾ əɹ kloʊk tə hɛlp hoʊld ɪt ʃʌɾ əɡɛns ðə wɪnd. ɪt wɑz ə faɪnɝ kloʊk ðən ɛni ɑn ðə pipəl wɔkɪŋ baɪ, bʌt pleɪn ɪnʌf ðət noʊ wʌn mɔɹ ðən ɡlænst əɾ əɹ ɪn pæsɪŋ. ðeɪ wəɾ ɪf ðeɪ sɔ hɝ bɛlt, ðoʊ. wɪmən u wɔɹ dʒuəlz dɪd nɑt fɹikwən blu kɑɹp stʃɹit, əɹ baɪ fɹəm stʃɹit pɛdlɝz. æftɝ stændɪŋ ðəɹ fəɹ əɹ tə fɪŋɡɝ ɛvɹi læs bɪɾ ə bɹeɪɾ ɑn ðə tʃɹeɪ, ðə lin wʊmən ɡɹɪməst, bʌt nɪneɪiv hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi bɑt θɹi pisəz ə bɹeɪd, tu lɛŋθs ə ɹɪbən ən ə pækəɾ ə pɪnz fɹəm hɔkɝz, dʒʌs fəɹ ə ɹizən tə lɔɪɾɝ. pɪnz wɝ ɔlweɪz jusfəl, bʌt ʃi dɪd hɑt noʊ wʌt ʃi wɑz gɑnə də wɪð ðə ɹɛst.

Trying not to be too obvious about watching the alley beside the candlemaker's, Nynaeve set the folded length of flat green braid back on the hawker's tray and slipped her hand inside her cloak to help hold it shut against the wind. It was a finer cloak than any on the people walking by, but plain enough that no one more than glanced at her in passing. They would if they saw her belt, though. Women who wore jewels did not frequent Blue Carp Street, or buy from street peddlers. After standing there for her to finger every last bit of braid on the tray, the lean woman grimaced, but Nynaeve had already bought three pieces of braid, two lengths of ribbon and a packet of pins from hawkers, just for a reason to loiter. Pins were always useful, but she did hot know what she was going to do with the rest.

sʌɾənli ʃi hɝɾ ə kəmoʊʃən daʊn ðə stʃɹit, ɪn ðə dɝɛkʃən ə ðə wɑtʃstænd, ðə ɹækɪɾ ə stʃɹit ɡɑɹdz' ɹæɾəlz laʊɾ ən ɡɹoʊɪŋ laʊɾɝ. ðə ɡɑɹdzmæn skɹæmbəl daʊn fɹəm ɪz pɝtʃ. pæsɝzbi nɪɹ ðə wɑtʃstæn stɛɹd daʊn ðə kɹɔsɪŋ stʃɹiɾ ən fɝðɝ ʌp blu kɑɹp stʃɹit, ðən hɝidli pɹɛs ðɛmsɛlvz əɡɛns ðə saɪdz ə ðə stʃɹiɾ əz ɹʌnɪŋ ɡɑɹdzmɪn əpɪɹd, swɪŋɪŋ ðɛɹ wʊɾən ɹæɾəlz oʊvɝhɛd. nɑɾ ə pətʃɹoʊl ə tu əɹ θɹi, bʌɾ ə flʌɾ ʌv ɑɹmɝd mɛn paʊndɪŋ daʊn blu kɑɹp stʃɹit, ən mɔɹ dʒɔɪnɪŋ ðə taɪd fɹəm ði ʌðɝ stʃɹit. pipəl sloʊ tə ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ə ðɛɹ weɪ wɝ ʃʌvd əsaɪd, ən wʌn mæn wɛn daʊn ʌndɝ ðɛɹ buts. ðeɪ dɪd nɑt sloʊ ə stɛp əz ðeɪ tʃɹæmpəl hɪm.

Suddenly she heard a commotion down the street, in the direction of the watchstand, the racket of Street Guards' rattles loud and growing louder. The Guardsman scrambled down from his perch. Passersby near the watchstand stared down the crossing street and further up Blue Carp Street, then hurriedly pressed themselves against the sides of the street as running Guardsmen appeared, swinging their wooden rattles overhead. Not a patrol of two or three, but a flood of armored men pounding down Blue Carp Street, and more joining the tide from the other street. People slow to get out of their way were shoved aside, and one man went down under their boots. They did not slow a step as they trampled him.

ðə bɹeɪd-sɛlɝ spɪl hæf əɹ tʃɹeɪ skɹæmbəlɪŋ tə ðə saɪɾ ə ðə stʃɹit, ən nɪneɪiv wɑz dʒʌst əz kwɪk tə skwiz hɝsɛlf əɡɛns ðə stoʊn haʊsfɹʌn əlɔŋsaɪd ðə ɡeɪpɪŋ wʊmən. fɪlɪŋ ðə stʃɹit, kætʃpoʊlz ən kɔɹɾɝstɑfs dʒʌɾɪŋ ʌp laɪk paɪks, ðə mæs ʌv ɡɑɹdzmɪn bʌmpt əɹ wɪð ʃoʊldɝz, skɹeɪpɪŋ əɹ əlɔŋ ðə wɔl. ðə bɹeɪd-sɛlɝ jɛld əz əɹ tʃɹeɪ wɑz ɹɪpt əweɪ ən vænɪʃt, bʌt ðə ɡɑɹdz wɝ ɔl stɛɹɪŋ əhɛd.

The braid-seller spilled half her tray scrambling to the side of the street, and Nynaeve was just as quick to squeeze herself against the stone housefront alongside the gaping woman. Filling the street, catchpoles and quarterstaffs jutting up like pikes, the mass of Guardsmen bumped her with shoulders, scraping her along the wall. The braid-seller yelled as her tray was ripped away and vanished, but the Guards were all staring ahead.

wən ðə læs mæn ɹæn pæst, nɪneɪiv wɑz ə ɡʊd tɛn peɪsɪz fɑɹðɝ daʊn ðə stʃɹit ðən ʃi hæd bɪn. ðə bɹeɪd-sɛlɝ ʃaʊɾəd æŋɡɹəli ən ʃʊk əɹ fɪsts ət ðə mɛnz bæks. ɪndɪɡnənli pʊlɪŋ əɹ twɪstəd kloʊk ɪndə səm pɹɑpɝ ɔɹɾɝ, nɪneɪiv wɑz ʌv ə maɪn tə də mɔɹ ðən ʃaʊt. ʃi wɑz hæf ʌv ə maɪn tə . . .

When the last man ran past, Nynaeve was a good ten paces farther down the street than she had been. The braid-seller shouted angrily and shook her fists at the men's backs. Indignantly pulling her twisted cloak into some proper order, Nynaeve was of a mind to do more than shout. She was half of a mind to . . .

əbɹʌpli hɝ bɹɛθ fɹoʊz ɪn əɹ θɹoʊt. ðə stʃɹit ɡɑɹdz hæd stɑpt ɪn ə mæs, pɝhæps ə hʌnʒɹəd mɛn ʃaʊɾɪŋ tə wʌn ənʌðɝ əz ɪf ðeɪ sʌɾənli wɝ ənsɝɾən wʌt tə də nɛkst. ðeɪ wɝ stɑpt ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə butmeɪkɝz ʃɑp. oʊ, laɪt, læn. ən ɹænd, tu, ɔlweɪz ɹænd, bʌt fɝst ən fɔɹmoʊst ɔlweɪz ðə hɑɹɾ ə hɝ hɑɹt, læn.

Abruptly her breath froze in her throat. The Street Guards had stopped in a mass, perhaps a hundred men shouting to one another as if they suddenly were uncertain what to do next. They were stopped in front of the bootmaker's shop. Oh, Light, Lan. And Rand, too, always Rand, but first and foremost always the heart of her heart, Lan.

ʃi meɪd hɝsɛlf bɹið. ə hʌnʒɹəd mɛn. ʃi tʌtʃt ðə dʒuəl bɛlt, ðə wɛl, ɝaʊn əɹ weɪst. lɛs ðən hæf ðə seɪaɪdɑɹ ʃi hæd stɔɹɾ ɪn ɪt ɹɪmeɪnd, bʌɾ ɪt maɪt bi ɪnʌf. ɪt wəɾ əv tə bi ɪnʌf, ðoʊ ʃi dɪd nɑt noʊ fəɹ wʌɾ ɪɡzækli, jɛt. tʌɡɪŋ ðə kaʊl ə hɝ kloʊk ʌp, ʃi stɑɹɾəd təwɔɹd ðə mɛn ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə butmeɪkɝz. nʌn wɑz lʊkɪŋ əɹ weɪ. ʃi kəd . . .

She made herself breathe. A hundred men. She touched the jeweled belt, the Well, around her waist. Less than half the saidar she had stored in it remained, but it might be enough. It would have to be enough, though she did not know for what exactly, yet. Tugging the cowl of her cloak up, she started toward the men in front of the bootmaker's. None was looking her way. She could . . .

hænz siz hɝ, dʒɹæɡɪŋ əɹ bækwɝɾ ən spɪnɪŋ əɹ ɝaʊn tə feɪs ði ʌðɝ dɝɛkʃən.

Hands seized her, dragging her backward and spinning her around to face the other direction.

kædzueɪn hæd wʌn ə hɝ ɑɹmz, ʃi ɹilaɪzd, ən əliviə ði ʌðɝ, ðə pɛɹ ə ðɛm hɝiɪŋ əɹ əlɔŋ ðə stʃɹit. əweɪ fɹəm ðə butmeɪkɝz. wɔkɪŋ bɪsaɪɾ əliviə, mɪn kɛp kæstɪŋ wɝid lʊks oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ. əbɹʌpli ʃi flɪntʃt. "hi . . . aɪ θɪŋk i fɛl," ʃi wɪspɝd. "aɪ θɪŋk hiz ʌnkɑnʃəs, bʌt hiz hɝt, aɪ doʊnt noʊ haʊ bædli."

Cadsuane had one of her arms, she realized, and Alivia the other, the pair of them hurrying her along the street. Away from the bootmaker's. Walking beside Alivia, Min kept casting worried looks over her shoulder. Abruptly she flinched. "He . . . I think he fell," she whispered. "I think he's unconscious, but he's hurt, I don't know how badly."

"wi wɪl də hɪm noʊ ɡʊd hɪɹ, əɹ aʊɝsɛlvz," kædzueɪn sɛd kɑmli. ðə ɡoʊldən ɔɹnəməns dæŋɡəlɪŋ fɹəm ðə fɹʌn ə hɝ bʌn swʌŋ ɪnsaɪd ðə hʊɾ ə hɝ kloʊk əz ʃi swɪvɛld əɹ hɛd, hɝ aɪz sɝtʃɪŋ θɹu ðə pipəl əhɛɾ ə ðɛm. ʃi hɛl ðə dip kaʊl əɡɛns ðə wɪnd wɪð əɹ fɹi hænd, lɛɾɪŋ əɹ kloʊk flæp bɪhaɪn hɝ. "aɪ wɑnə bi əweɪ fɹəm hɪɹ bɪfɔɹ wʌn ə ðoʊz bɔɪz θɪŋks ʌv æskɪŋ wɪmən tə ʃoʊ ðɛɹ feɪsəz. ɛni ɛɛs sədaɪ faʊnd nɪɹ blu kɑɹp stʃɹit ðɪs æftɝnun wɪl əv kwɛstʃənz tə ænsɝ kəz ə ðɪs tʃaɪld."

"We will do him no good here, or ourselves," Cadsuane said calmly. The golden ornaments dangling from the front of her bun swung inside the hood of her cloak as she swivelled her head, her eyes searching through the people ahead of them. She held the deep cowl against the wind with her free hand, letting her cloak flap behind her. "I want to be away from here before one of those boys thinks of asking women to show their faces. Any Aes Sedai found near Blue Carp Street this afternoon will have questions to answer because of this child."

"lɛt mi ɡoʊ!" nɪneɪiv snæpt, pʊlɪŋ əɡɛns ðɛm. læn. ɪf ɹænd hæd bɪn nɑkt ʌnkɑnʃəs, wʌɾ ə læn? "aɪ hæv tə ɡoʊ bæk ən hɛlp ðɛm!" ðə tu wɪmən dʒɹæɡd əɹ əlɔŋ wɪð hænz laɪk aɪɝn. ɛvɹiwʌn ðeɪ pæst wɑz piɹɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə butmeɪkɝz ʃɑp.

"Let me go!" Nynaeve snapped, pulling against them. Lan. If Rand had been knocked unconscious, what of Lan? "I have to go back and help them!" The two women dragged her along with hands like iron. Everyone they passed was peering toward the bootmaker's shop.

"ju hæv dʌn kwaɪɾ ɪnʌf ɔlɹɛɾi, jə ful ɡɝl." kædzueɪnz vɔɪs wɑz koʊld aɪɝn. "aɪ toʊl jə əbaʊt fɑɹ mæɾɪŋz wɑtʃdɔɡz. fɔ! juv pʊɾ ə pænɪk ɪn ðə kaʊnsəlz wɪð jəɹ tʃænəlɪŋ wɛɹ noʊ wʌn kən tʃænəl. ɪf ðə ɡɑɹdz əv ðɛm, ɪts kəz ə ju."

"You have done quite enough already, you fool girl." Cadsuane's voice was cold iron. "I told you about Far Madding's watchdogs. Phaw! You've put a panic in the Counsels with your channeling where no one can channel. If the Guards have them, it is because of you."

"aɪ θɔt seɪaɪdɑɹ wʊdn mæɾɝ," nɪneɪiv sɛd wikli. "ɪt wɑz oʊnli ə lɪɾəl, ən nɑt fəɹ lɔŋ. aɪ . . . aɪ θɔt meɪbi ðeɪ wʊdn ivən noʊɾəs."

"I thought saidar wouldn't matter," Nynaeve said weakly. "It was only a little, and not for long. I . . . I thought maybe they wouldn't even notice."

kædzueɪn ɡeɪv əɹ ə dɪsɡʌstəd ɡlæns. "ðɪs weɪ, əliviə," ʃi sɛd, pʊlɪŋ nɪneɪiv ɝaʊn ðə kɔɹnɝ baɪ ði əbændənd wɑtʃstænd. smɔl nɑts ʌv ɪksaɪɾəd pipəl dɑɾəd ðə stʃɹit, dʒæbɝɪŋ. ə mæn dʒɛstʃɝd vɪɡɝəsli əz ɪf wildɪŋ ə kætʃpoʊl. ə wʊmən pɔɪntəd tə ði ɛmpti wɑtʃstænd, ʃeɪkɪŋ əɹ hɛɾ ɪn wʌndɝ.

Cadsuane gave her a disgusted glance. "This way, Alivia," she said, pulling Nynaeve around the corner by the abandoned watchstand. Small knots of excited people dotted the street, jabbering. A man gestured vigorously as if wielding a catchpole. A woman pointed to the empty watchstand, shaking her head in wonder.

"seɪ sʌmθɪŋ, mɪn," nɪneɪiv pliɾəd. "wi kæn dʒʌs liv ðɛm." ʃi dɪd nɑɾ ivən θɪŋk ʌv ədʒɹɛsɪŋ əliviə, hu wɔɹ ə feɪs tə meɪk kædzueɪn əpɪɹ sɑft.

"Say something, Min," Nynaeve pleaded. "We can't just leave them." She did not even think of addressing Alivia, who wore a face to make Cadsuane appear soft.

"doʊn ɪkspɛk sɪmpəθi fɹəm mi." mɪnz loʊ vɔɪs wɑz ɔlmoʊst əz tʃɪl əz kædzueɪnz. wən ʃi lʊkt ət nɪneɪiv, ɪt wɑz ə saɪɾɛlɔŋ ɡlɛɹ bɪfɔɹ snæpɪŋ əɹ aɪz bæk tə ðə stʃɹiɾ əhɛd. "aɪ bɛɡd jə tə hɛlp mi stɑp ðɛm, bʌt jə hæd tə bi əz wʊl-hɛɾəd əz ðeɪ wɝ. naʊ wɪv tə dɪpɛn ɑn kædzueɪn."

"Don't expect sympathy from me." Min's low voice was almost as chill as Cadsuane's. When she looked at Nynaeve, it was a sidelong glare before snapping her eyes back to the street ahead. "I begged you to help me stop them, but you had to be as wool-headed as they were. Now we have to depend on Cadsuane."

nɪneɪiv snɪft. "wʌt kən ʃi du? də aɪ nid tə ɹimaɪn jə ðət læn ən ɹænd ɑɹ bɪhaɪn ʌs, ən ɡɛɾɪŋ fɑɹðɝ bɪhaɪn baɪ ðə mɪnət?"

Nynaeve sniffed. "What can she do? Do I need to remind you that Lan and Rand are behind us, and getting farther behind by the minute?"

"ðə bɔɪ ɪzən ði oʊnli wʌn u nidz lɛsənz ɪn mænɝz," kædzueɪn mʌɾɝd. "hi hæzən əpɑlədʒaɪz tə mi, jɛt, bʌɾ i toʊl vɛɹɪn i wʊd, ən aɪ səpoʊz aɪ kən æksɛp ðət fəɹ ðə moʊmənt. fɔ! ðət bɔɪ pʊts mi tə mɔɹ tʃɹʌbəl ðən ɛni tɛn aɪ ɛvɝ mɛt bɪfɔɹ. əl də wʌɾ aɪ kæn, ɡɝl, wɪtʃ ɪz ə saɪt mɔɹ ðən jə kəd də tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə bæɾɝ jəɹ weɪ θɹu ðə stʃɹit ɡɑɹdz. fɹəm hɪɹ ɑn, jəl ɪɡzækli əz aɪ seɪ, əɹ əl əv əliviə sɪɾ ɑn ju!" əliviə nɑɾəd. soʊ dɪd mɪn!

"The boy isn't the only one who needs lessons in manners," Cadsuane muttered. "He hasn't apologized to me, yet, but he told Verin he would, and I suppose I can accept that for the moment. Phaw! That boy puts me to more trouble than any ten I ever met before. I will do what I can, girl, which is a sight more than you could do trying to batter your way through the Street Guards. From here on, you will exactly as I say, or I will have Alivia sit on you!" Alivia nodded. So did Min!

nɪneɪiv ɡɹɪməst. ðə wʊmən wɑz səpoʊz tə dɪfɝ tə hɝ! stɪl, ə ɡɛst ə ðə fɝs kaʊnsəl kəd də mɔɹ ðən pleɪn nɪneɪiv ɑlmɹə, ivən ɪf ʃi dɑn əɹ ɡɹeɪt sɝpən ɹɪŋ. fəɹ læn, ʃi kəd pʊɾ ʌp wɪð kædzueɪn.

Nynaeve grimaced. The woman was supposed to defer to her! Still, a guest of the First Counsel could do more than plain Nynaeve al'Meara, even if she donned her Great Serpent ring. For Lan, she could put up with Cadsuane.

bʌt wən ʃi æskt wʌt kædzueɪn plæn tə də tə fɹi ðə mɛn, ði oʊnli ænsɝ ðə wʊmən wəd ɡɪv wɑz "mʌtʃ mɔɹ ðən aɪ wɑn tə, ɡɝl, ɪf aɪ kən də ɛniθɪŋ əɾ ɔl. bʌɾ aɪ meɪd ðə bɔɪ pɹɑməsəz, ən aɪ kip maɪ pɹɑməsəz. aɪ hoʊp i ɹɪmɛmbɝz ðæt." dɪlɪvɝɾ ɪn ə vɔɪs laɪk aɪs, ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ə ɹɪplaɪ tə ɪnspaɪɹ kɑnfəɾəns.

But when she asked what Cadsuane planned to do to free the men, the only answer the woman would give was "Much more than I want to, girl, if I can do anything at all. But I made the boy promises, and I keep my promises. I hope he remembers that." Delivered in a voice like ice, it was not a reply to inspire confidence.

ɹænd woʊk ɪn dɑɹknəs ən peɪn, laɪɪŋ ɑn ɪz bæk. hɪz ɡlʌvz wɝ ɡɔn, ən i kəd fil ə ɹʌf pælət bɪniθ hɪm. ðeɪ hæd teɪkən ɪz buts, tu. hɪz ɡlʌvz wɝ ɡɔn. ðeɪ nu hu hi wɑz. kɛɹfəli, hi sæɾ ʌp. hɪz feɪs fɛl bɹuzd ən ɛvɹi mʌsəl ɪn ɪz bɑɾi hɝɾ əz ɪf i hæd bɪn biɾən, bʌt nʌθɪŋ sim tə bi bɹoʊkən.

Rand woke in darkness and pain, lying on his back. His gloves were gone, and he could feel a rough pallet beneath him. They had taken his boots, too. His gloves were gone. They knew who he was. Carefully, he sat up. His face felt bruised and every muscle in his body hurt as if he had been beaten, but nothing seemed to be broken.

stændɪŋ sloʊli, hi fɛlt ɪz weɪ əlɔŋ ðə stoʊn wɔl bɪsaɪd ðə pælət, ɹitʃɪŋ ə kɔɹnɝ ɔlmoʊst ɪmiɾiətli, ən ðən ə dɔɹ kʌvɝd wɪð ɹʌf aɪɝn stʃɹæps. ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs ɪz fɪŋɡɝz tʃɹeɪst ə smɔl flæp, bʌɾ i kəd nɑt pʊʃ ɪɾ oʊpən. noʊ hɪn ə laɪt sipt ɪn ɝaʊn ɪts ɛdʒəz. ɪnsaɪɾ ɪz hɛd, luz θɝɪn bɪɡæn tə pænt. ɹænd muvd ɑn, filɪŋ ɪz weɪ, ðə flɔɹstoʊnz koʊl bɪniθ ɪz bɛɹ fit. ðə nɛks kɔɹnɝ keɪm ɔlmoʊst ɪmiɾiətli, ən ðən ə θɝd, wɛɹ ɪz toʊz stʃɹʌk sʌmθɪŋ ðət ɹæɾəld ɑn ðə stoʊn flɔɹ. kipɪŋ wʌn hæn ɑn ðə wɔl, hi bɛn ən faʊn ə wʊɾən bʌkət. hi lɛft ɪt ðəɹ ən meɪd hɪmsɛlf kəmplit ðə sɝkət, ɔl ðə weɪ bæk tə ði aɪɝn dɔɹ. ɔl ðə weɪ. hi wɑz ɪnsaɪɾ ə blæk bɑks θɹi peɪsɪz lɔŋ ən dʒʌst oʊvɝ tu peɪsɪz waɪd. ɹeɪzɪŋ wʌn hænd, hi faʊn ðə stoʊn silɪŋ lɛs ðən ə fʊɾ əbʌv ɪz hɛd.

Standing slowly, he felt his way along the stone wall beside the pallet, reaching a corner almost immediately, and then a door covered with rough iron straps. In the darkness his fingers traced a small flap, but he could not push it open. No hint of light seeped in around its edges. Inside his head, Lews Therin began to pant. Rand moved on, feeling his way, the floorstones cold beneath his bare feet. The next corner came almost immediately, and then a third, where his toes struck something that rattled on the stone floor. Keeping one hand on the wall, he bent and found a wooden bucket. He left it there and made himself complete the circuit, all the way back to the iron door. All the way. He was inside a black box three paces long and just over two paces wide. Raising one hand, he found the stone ceiling less than a foot above his head.

kloʊzd ɪn, luz θɝɪn pæntɪd hɔɹsli. ɪts ðə bɑks əɡɛn. wən ðoʊz wɪmən pʊɾ əs ɪn ðə bɑks. wɪv tə ɡɛɾ aʊt! hi haʊld. wɪv tə ɡɛɾ aʊt!

Closed in, Lews Therin panted hoarsely. It's the box again. When those women put us in the box. We have to get out! he howled. We have to get out!

ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ðə skɹimɪŋ vɔɪs ɪn ɪz hɛd, ɹænd bækt əweɪ fɹəm ðə dɔɹ əntɪl i θɔɾ i wɑz ɪn ðə sɛntɝ ə ðə sɛl, ðən loʊɝd hɪmsɛlf tə sɪt kɹɔs-lɛɡəɾ ɑn ðə flɔɹ. hi wɑz əz fɑɹ fɹəm ðə wɔlz əz i kəd pʊt hɪmsɛlf, ən ɪn ðə dɑɹk i tʃɹaɪd tə ɪmædʒən əm fɑɹðɝ əweɪ, bʌɾ ɪt sim ðəɾ ɪf i ɹitʃt aʊt, hi wəd nɑɾ əv tə stʃɹeɪɾən ɪz ɑɹm fʊli tə tʌtʃ stoʊn. hi kəd fil hɪmsɛlf tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ, əz ɪf ɪt wɝ sʌmwʌn ɛlsəz bɑɾi ʃeɪkɪŋ ʌnkəntʃɹoʊləbli. ðə wɔlz sim dʒʌs bɪsaɪd hɪm, ðə silɪŋ ɹaɪɾ oʊvɝ ɪz hɛd. hi hæd tə faɪt ðɪs, əɹ i wəd bi əz mæɾ əz luz θɝɪn baɪ ðə taɪm ɛniwʌn keɪm tə lɛɾ ɪm aʊt. ðeɪ wəɾ əv tə lɛɾ ɪm aʊɾ ɪvɛntʃəwəli, ɪf oʊnli tə hæn ɪm oʊvɝ tə huɛvɝ ɪleɪɾə sɛnt. haʊ mɛni mʌnθs fəɹ ə mɛsədʒ tə ɹitʃ tɑɹ vəlɑn ən ɪleɪɾəz ɛməsɛɹiz tə ɹɪtɝn? ɪf ðəɹ wɝ sɪstɝz lɔɪəl tə ɪleɪɾə kloʊsɝ ðən tɑɹ vəlɑn, ɪt maɪt hæpən sunɝ. hɔɹɝ æɾəd tə hɪz ʃʌɾɝz əz i ɹilaɪz ðəɾ i wɑz hoʊpɪŋ ðoʊz sɪstɝz wɝ kloʊsɝ, wɝ ɪn ðə sɪɾi ɔlɹɛɾi, soʊ ðeɪ kəd teɪk ɪm aʊɾ ə ðɪs bɑks.

Ignoring the screaming voice in his head, Rand backed away from the door until he thought he was in the center of the cell, then lowered himself to sit cross-legged on the floor. He was as far from the walls as he could put himself, and in the dark he tried to imagine them farther away, but it seemed that if he reached out, he would not have to straighten his arm fully to touch stone. He could feel himself trembling, as if it were someone else's body shaking uncontrollably. The walls seemed just beside him, the ceiling right over his head. He had to fight this, or he would be as mad as Lews Therin by the time anyone came to let him out. They would have to let him out eventually, if only to hand him over to whoever Elaida sent. How many months for a message to reach Tar Valon and Elaida's emissaries to return? If there were sisters loyal to Elaida closer than Tar Valon, it might happen sooner. Horror added to his shudders as he realized that he was hoping those sisters were closer, were in the city already, so they could take him out of this box.

"aɪ wɪl nɑt sɝɛndɝ!" hi ʃaʊɾəd. "aɪ wɪl bi əz hɑɹɾ əz aɪ nid tə bi!" ɪn ðət kənfaɪn speɪs, hɪz vɔɪs bum laɪk θʌndɝ.

"I will not surrender!" he shouted. "I will be as hard as I need to be!" In that confined space, his voice boomed like thunder.

mɔɪɹeɪn hæd daɪd kəz i wɑz nɑt hɑɹɾ ɪnʌf tə də wʌt hæd tə bi dʌn. hɝ neɪm ɔlweɪz hɛɾəd ðə lɪst ɪnɡɹeɪvd ɑn ɪz bɹeɪn, ðə wɪmən u hæd daɪd kəz ə hɪm. mɔɪɹeɪn dəmədʒɹd. ɛvɹi neɪm ɑn ðət lɪs bɹɔɾ æŋɡwɪʃ ðət meɪɾ ɪm fɝɡɛt ðə peɪnz ə hɪz bɑɾi, fɝɡɛt ðə stoʊn wɔlz dʒʌs bɪɑn ɪz fɪŋɡɝtɪps. koʊləveɪɪɹ seɪɡən, hu daɪd kəz i hæd stʃɹɪpt əɹ ʌv ɛvɹiθɪŋ ʃi væljud. laɪæ, meɪɾən ə ðə spɪɹ, ʌv ðə koʊseɪɾə tʃɑɝin, hu daɪɾ əɾ ɪz oʊn hænz kəz ʃi fɑloʊɾ ɪm tə ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ. dʒɛnhaɪlɪn, ə meɪɾən ə ðə koʊl pik maɪæɡoʊmə hu daɪd kəz ʃi wɑntəd ði ɑnɝ ʌv ɡɑɹɾɪŋ ɪz dɔɹ. hi hæd tə bi hɑɹd! wʌn baɪ wʌn i sʌmən ʌp ðə neɪmz ɑn ðət lɔŋ lɪst, peɪʃənli fɔɹdʒɪŋ ɪz soʊl ɪn ðə faɪɝz ə peɪn.

Moiraine had died because he was not hard enough to do what had to be done. Her name always headed the list engraved on his brain, the women who had died because of him. Moiraine Damodred. Every name on that list brought anguish that made him forget the pains of his body, forget the stone walls just beyond his fingertips. Colavaere Saighan, who died because he had stripped her of everything she valued. Liah, Maiden of the Spear, of the Cosaida Chareen, who died at his own hands because she followed him to Shadar Logoth. Jendhilin, a Maiden of the Cold Peak Miagoma who died because she wanted the honor of guarding his door. He had to be hard! One by one he summoned up the names on that long list, patiently forging his soul in the fires of pain.

pɹɛpɝeɪʃən tʊk lɔŋɡɝ ðən kædzueɪn hæd hoʊpt, lɑɹdʒli kəz ʃi hæd tə ɪmpɹɛs ɑn vɛɹiəs pipəl ðəɾ ə ɡɹæn ɹɛskju ɪn ðə bɛs tʃɹədɪʃənz ʌv ɡlimənz teɪlz wɑz aʊɾ ə ðə kwɛstʃən, soʊ ɪt wɑz naɪt bɪfɔɹ ʃi faʊn hɝsɛlf wɔkɪŋ əlɔŋ ðə læmplɪt kɔɹɪɾɝz ə ðə hɔl ə ðə kaʊnsəlz. wɔkɪŋ səɾətli, nɑt hɝiɪŋ. hɝi, ən pipəl əsum ðət jə wɝ æŋkʃəs, ðət ðeɪ hæd ði ʌpɝ hænd. ɪf ɛvɝ ɪn əɹ laɪf ʃi hæd niɾəd tə kip ði ʌpɝ hæn fɹəm ðə stɑɹt, ɪt wɑz tənaɪt.

Preparation took longer than Cadsuane had hoped, largely because she had to impress on various people that a grand rescue in the best traditions of gleemen's tales was out of the question, so it was night before she found herself walking along the lamplit corridors of the Hall of the Counsels. Walking sedately, not hurrying. Hurry, and people assumed that you were anxious, that they had the upper hand. If ever in her life she had needed to keep the upper hand from the start, it was tonight.

ðə kɔɹɪɾɝz ʃʊɾə bɪn ɛmpti ət ðɪs aʊɝ, bʌt tədeɪz ɪvɛns hæd tʃeɪnʒd ðə nɔɹməl kɔɹs ə θɪŋz. blu-koʊɾəd klɝks wɝ skɝiɪŋ ɛvɹiwɛɹ, səmtaɪmz pɔzɪŋ tə ɡeɪp əɾ əɹ kəmpænjənz. kwaɪt pɑsəbli, ðeɪ hæd nɛvɝ sin fɔɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ ət wʌns - ʃi wɑz nɑt wɪlɪŋ tə əlaʊ nɪneɪiv ðət taɪɾəl əntɪl ʃi tʊk ðə θɹi oʊðz - ən tədeɪz kəmoʊʃən wʊɾə æɾəd tə ðɛɹ kənfjuʒən ət ðə saɪt. ðə θɹi mɛn bɹɪŋɪŋ ʌp ðə ɹɪɹ ɝn ɔlmoʊst əz mɛni stɛɹz, ðoʊ. ðə klɝks maɪt nɑt noʊ ðə minɪŋ ə ðɛɹ blæk koʊts əɹ ðə pɪnz ɑn ðɛɹ haɪ kɑlɝz, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz vɛɹi ənlaɪkli ɛni ʌv ðoʊz klɝks hæɾ ɛvɝ sin θɹi mɛn wɛɹɪŋ sɔɹdz ɪn ðiz hɔlweɪz. ɪn ɛni keɪs, wɪð ə lɪɾəl lʌk, noʊ wʌn wəd ɡoʊ ɹʌnɪŋ tə ɪnfɔɹm əlaɪz u wɑz kʌmɪŋ tə bɹeɪk ɪn ɑn ðə kaʊnsəlz sɪɾɪŋ ɪn kloʊz sɛʃən. ɪt wɑz ə pɪɾi ʃi kəd nɑɾ əv bɹɔt ðə mɛn baɪ ðɛmsɛlvz, bʌɾ ivən deɪdʒiən hæd dɪspleɪd bækboʊn ət ðə sədʒɛstʃən. ə ɡɹeɪt pɪɾi ðəɾ ɔl ə hɝ kəmpænjənz wɝ nɑt dɪspleɪɪŋ ðə kəmpoʊʒɝ ʃoʊd baɪ mɛɹaɪs ən ði ʌðɝ tu sɪstɝz.

The corridors should have been empty at this hour, but today's events had changed the normal course of things. Blue-coated clerks were scurrying everywhere, sometimes pausing to gape at her companions. Quite possibly, they had never seen four Aes Sedai at once - she was not willing to allow Nynaeve that title until she took the Three Oaths - and today's commotion would have added to their confusion at the sight. The three men bringing up the rear earned almost as many stares, though. The clerks might not know the meaning of their black coats or the pins on their high collars, but it was very unlikely any of those clerks had ever seen three men wearing swords in these hallways. In any case, with a little luck, no one would go running to inform Aleis who was coming to break in on the Counsels sitting in closed session. It was a pity she could not have brought the men by themselves, but even Daigian had displayed backbone at the suggestion. A great pity that all of her companions were not displaying the composure showed by Merise and the other two sisters.

"ðɪs wɪl nɛvɝ wɝk," nɪneɪiv ɡɹʌmbəld, fəɹ pɝhæps ðə tɛnθ taɪm sɪns livɪŋ ðə haɪts. "wi ʃəd stʃɹaɪk hɑɹd fɹəm ðə stɑɹt!"

"This will never work," Nynaeve grumbled, for perhaps the tenth time since leaving the Heights. "We should strike hard from the start!"

"wi ʃʊɾə muv fæstɝ," mɪn mʌɾɝd dɑɹkli. "aɪ kən fil ɪm tʃeɪnʒɪŋ. ɪf i wɑz ə stoʊn bɪfɔɹ, hiz aɪɝn, naʊ! laɪt, wʌɾ ɑɹ ðeɪ duɪŋ tə hɪm?" əlɔŋ oʊnli kəz ʃi wɑz ə lɪŋk tə ðə bɔɪ, ʃi hæd bɪn ənsisɪŋ wɪð əɹ ɹɪpɔɹts, itʃ blikɝ ðən ðə læst. kædzueɪn hæd nɑt toʊld əɹ wʌt ðə sɛlz wɝ laɪk, nɑt wən ðə ɡɝl hæd bɹoʊkən daʊn dʒʌs tɛlɪŋ əɹ wʌt ðə sɪstɝz u kɪdnæp ðə bɔɪ hæd dʌn tə hɪm.

"We should have moved faster," Min muttered darkly. "I can feel him changing. If he was a stone before, he's iron, now! Light, what are they doing to him?" Along only because she was a link to the boy, she had been unceasing with her reports, each bleaker than the last. Cadsuane had not told her what the cells were like, not when the girl had broken down just telling her what the sisters who kidnapped the boy had done to him.

kædzueɪn saɪd. ə ɹæɡtæɡ ɑɹmi ʃi hæɾ əsɛmbəld, bʌɾ ivən ə meɪkʃɪft ɑɹmi niɾəd dɪsəplən. ɪspɛʃli wɪð ðə bæɾəl dʒʌst əhɛd. ɪt wʊɾə bɪn wɝs hæd ʃi nɑt fɔɹs ðə si foʊk wɪmən tə ɹɪmeɪn bɪhaɪnd. "aɪ kən də ðɪs wɪθaʊɾ iðɝ ə ju, ɪf nid bi," ʃi sɛd fɝmli. "noʊ; doʊn seɪ ɛniθɪŋ, nɪneɪiv. mɛɹaɪs əɹ kɔɹəl kən wɛɹ ðət bɛlt əz wɛl əz ju. soʊ ɪf jə tʃɪlʒɹən də nɑt stɑp waɪnɪŋ, əl əv əliviə teɪk jə bæk tə ðə haɪts ən ɡɪv jə sʌmθɪŋ tə waɪn əbaʊt." ðət wɑz ði oʊnli ɹizən ʃi hæd bɹɔt ðə stʃɹeɪnʒ waɪldɝ. əliviə hæɾ ə tɛndənsi tə bɪkʌm vɛɹi maɪld-mænɝɾ ɝaʊn ðoʊz ʃi kəd nɑt stɛɹ daʊn, bʌt ʃi stɛɹd vɛɹi fɪɹsli ət ðoʊz tu tʃæɾɝɪŋ mæɡpaɪz.

Cadsuane sighed. A ragtag army she had assembled, but even a makeshift army needed discipline. Especially with the battle just ahead. It would have been worse had she not forced the Sea Folk women to remain behind. "I can do this without either of you, if need be," she said firmly. "No; don't say anything, Nynaeve. Merise or Corele can wear that belt as well as you. So if you children do not stop whining, I will have Alivia take you back to the Heights and give you something to whine about." That was the only reason she had brought the strange wilder. Alivia had a tendency to become very mild-mannered around those she could not stare down, but she stared very fiercely at those two chattering magpies.

ðɛɹ hɛdz swɪvəl təwɔɹd ðə ɡoʊldən-hɛɹd wʊmən əz wʌn, ən ðə mæɡpaɪz fɛl blɛsədli saɪlənt. saɪlənt, jɛt hɑɹdli æksɛptɪŋ. mɪn kəd ɡɹaɪn əɹ tiθ ɔl ʃi wɑntəd, bʌt nɪneɪivz sʌlən ɡlaʊɝ ɪɹəteɪɾəd kædzueɪn. ðə ɡɝl hæd ɡʊd mətɪɹiəl ɪn hɝ, bʌɾ əɹ tʃɹeɪnɪŋ hæd bɪn kʌt fɑɹ tu ʃɔɹt. hɝ əbɪləɾi wɪð hilɪŋ wɑz lɪɾəl ʃɔɹɾ ə mɝækjələs, hɝ əbɪləɾi wɪð ɔlmoʊst ɛniθɪŋ ɛls dɪzməl. ən ʃi hæd nɑt bɪn pʊt θɹu ðə lɛsənz ðət wʌt mʌs bi ɛndʒjʊɹd, kəd bi ɛndʒjʊɹd. ɪn tʃɹuθ, kædzueɪn sɪmpəθaɪzd wɪð hɝ. sʌmwʌt. ɪt wɑz ə lɛsən nɑɾ ɛvɹiwʌn kəd lɝn ɪn ðə taʊɝ. ʃi hɝsɛlf, fʊl ə pɹaɪɾ ɪn əɹ nu ʃɔl ən əɹ oʊn stʃɹɛŋkθ, hæd bɪn tɔt baɪ ə nɪɹ tuθləs waɪldɝ əɾ ə fɑɹm ɪn ðə hɑɹɾ ə ðə blæk hɪlz. oʊ, ɪt wɑz ə vɛɹi ɹæɡtæɡ lɪɾəl ɑɹmi ʃi hæd ɡæðɝd tə tʃɹaɪ stændɪŋ fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ ɑn ɪts hɛd.

Their heads swiveled toward the golden-haired woman as one, and the magpies fell blessedly silent. Silent, yet hardly accepting. Min could grind her teeth all she wanted, but Nynaeve's sullen glower irritated Cadsuane. The girl had good material in her, but her training had been cut far too short. Her ability with Healing was little short of miraculous, her ability with almost anything else dismal. And she had not been put through the lessons that what must be endured, could be endured. In truth, Cadsuane sympathized with her. Somewhat. It was a lesson not everyone could learn in the Tower. She herself, full of pride in her new shawl and her own strength, had been taught by a near toothless wilder at a farm in the heart of the Black Hills. Oh, it was a very ragtag little army she had gathered to try standing Far Madding on its head.

klɝks ən mɛsənʒɝz hæf-fɪl ðə kɑləmd æntəɹum tə ðə kaʊnsəlz' tʃeɪmbɝ, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ, æftɝ ɔl, oʊnli klɝks ən mɛsənʒɝz. ðə klɝks hɛzɪteɪɾɪd ɪn ɔfɪʃəs pʌzəlmənt, itʃ weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ənʌðɝ tə spik fɝst, bʌt ðə ɹɛd-koʊɾəd mɛsənʒɝz, hu nu ɪt wɑz nɑt ðɛɹ pleɪs tə seɪ ɛniθɪŋ, bækt əkɹɔs ðə blu flɔɹtaɪlz tə ðə saɪdz ə ðə ɹum, ən ðə klɝks pɑɹɾəd ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ, nʌn kwaɪt dɛɹɪŋ tə bi ðə fɝs tə oʊpən ɪz maʊθ. ivən soʊ, ʃi hɝɾ ə kəlɛktɪv ɡæsp wən ʃi oʊpənd wʌn ə ðə tɔl dɔɹz kɑɹvd wɪð ðə hæn ən sɔɹd.

Clerks and messengers half-filled the columned anteroom to the Counsels' Chamber, but they were, after all, only clerks and messengers. The clerks hesitated in officious puzzlement, each waiting for another to speak first, but the red-coated messengers, who knew it was not their place to say anything, backed across the blue floortiles to the sides of the room, and the clerks parted in front of her, none quite daring to be the first to open his mouth. Even so, she heard a collective gasp when she opened one of the tall doors carved with the Hand and Sword.

ðə kaʊnsəlz' tʃeɪmbɝ wɑz nɑt lɑɹdʒ. fɔɹ mɪɹɝd stænd-læmps səfaɪs tə laɪɾ ɪt, ən ə lɑɹdʒ tɛɹən kɑɹpəɾ ɪn ɹɛɾ ən blu ən ɡoʊld ɔlmoʊs kʌvɝd ðə flɔɹ taɪlz. ə waɪd mɑɹbəl faɪɝpleɪs ɑn wʌn saɪɾ ə ðə ɹum meɪɾ ə fɛɹ dʒɑb ʌv wɔɹmɪŋ ði ɛɹ, ðoʊ ðə ɡlæs dɔɹz liɾɪŋ tə ðə kɑləneɪɾ aʊtsaɪd ɹæɾəld ɪn ðə naɪt wɪnd, laʊɾ ɪnʌf tə dʒɹaʊn ðə tɪkɪŋ ə ðə tɔl, ɡɪldɪɾ ɪliɑnɝ klɑk ɑn ðə mæntəl. θɝtin kɑɹvd ən ɡɪldɪd tʃɛɹz, vɛɹi nɪɹli θɹoʊnz, meɪɾ ən ɑɹk feɪsɪŋ ðə dɔɹ, ɔl ɑkjəpaɪd baɪ wɝid-lʊkɪŋ wɪmən.

The Counsels' Chamber was not large. Four mirrored stand-lamps sufficed to light it, and a large Tairen carpet in red and blue and gold almost covered the floor tiles. A wide marble fireplace on one side of the room made a fair job of warming the air, though the glassed doors leading to the colonnade outside rattled in the night wind, loud enough to drown the ticking of the tall, gilded Illianer clock on the mantel. Thirteen carved and gilded chairs, very nearly thrones, made an arc facing the door, all occupied by worried-looking women.

əlaɪz, ət ðə hɛɾ ə ði ɑɹk, fɹaʊnd wən ʃi sɔ kædzueɪn lɛɾ əɹ lɪɾəl pɝeɪɾ ɪndə ðə tʃeɪmbɝ. "ðɪs sɛʃən ɪz kloʊzd, ɛɛs sədaɪ," ʃi sɛd, ət wʌns fɔɹməl ən koʊld. "wi meɪ æsk jə tə spik tə əs leɪɾɝ, bʌt - "

Aleis, at the head of the arc, frowned when she saw Cadsuane lead her little parade into the chamber. "This session is closed, Aes Sedai," she said, at once formal and cold. "We may ask you to speak to us later, but - "

"ju noʊ hu juv ɪn ðə sɛlz," kædzueɪn kʌɾ ɪn.

"You know who you have in the cells," Cadsuane cut in.

ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ə kwɛstʃən, bʌɾ əlaɪz tʃɹaɪd tə blʌf əɹ weɪ pæst. "ə nʌmbɝ ə mɛn, aɪ bɪliv. pʌblɪk dʒɹʌŋkɝdz, vɛɹiəs fɔɹənɝz ɝɛstəd fəɹ faɪɾɪŋ əɹ stilɪŋ, ə mæn fɹəm ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz teɪkən dʒʌs tədeɪ hu meɪ hæv mɝɾɝd θɹi mɛn. aɪ də nɑt kip ə pɝsənəl ɹɛkɝɾ ə ɝɛsts, kædzueɪn sədaɪ." nɪneɪiv dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ ət mɛnʃən ʌv ə mæn teɪkən fəɹ mɝɾɝ, ən əɹ aɪz ɡlɪɾɝd deɪnʒɝəsli, bʌɾ ət ðə lis ðə tʃaɪl hæd sɛns ɪnʌf tə kip əɹ maʊθ ʃʌt.

It was not a question, but Aleis tried to bluff her way past. "A number of men, I believe. Public drunkards, various foreigners arrested for fighting or stealing, a man from the Borderlands taken just today who may have murdered three men. I do not keep a personal record of arrests, Cadsuane Sedai." Nynaeve drew a deep breath at mention of a man taken for murder, and her eyes glittered dangerously, but at the least the child had sense enough to keep her mouth shut.

"soʊ jəl tʃɹaɪ tə kənsil ðət jə hoʊl ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn," kædzueɪn sɛd kwaɪətli. ʃi hæd hoʊpt - hoʊp fɝvənli! - ðət vɛɹɪnz speɪdwɝk wəd meɪk əm bæk əweɪ fɹəm ðɪs. pɝhæps ɪt kəd stɪl bi dʌn sɪmpli, ðoʊ. "aɪ kən teɪk ɪm ɔf jəɹ hænz. aɪ hæv feɪs mɔɹ ðən twɛnti mɛn u kəd tʃænəl, oʊvɝ ðə jɪɹz. hi hoʊlz noʊ fɪɹz fəɹ mi."

"So you will try to conceal that you hold the Dragon Reborn," Cadsuane said quietly. She had hoped - hoped fervently! - that Verin's spadework would make them back away from this. Perhaps it could still be done simply, though. "I can take him off your hands. I have faced more than twenty men who could channel, over the years. He holds no fears for me."

"wi də θæŋk jə fəɹ ði ɔfɝ," əlaɪz ɹɪplaɪd smuðli, "bʌt wi pɹəfɝ tə kəmjunəkeɪt wɪð tɑɹ vəlɑn, fɝst." tə nəɡoʊʃieɪɾ ɪz pɹaɪs, ʃi mɛnt. wɛl, wʌt hæd tə bi, hæd tə bi. "du jə maɪn tɛlɪŋ əs haʊ jə lɝnd - "

"We do thank you for the offer," Aleis replied smoothly, "but we prefer to communicate with Tar Valon, first." To negotiate his price, she meant. Well, what had to be, had to be. "Do you mind telling us how you learned - "

kædzueɪn bɹoʊk ɪn əɡɛn. "pɝhæps aɪ ʃʊɾə mɛnʃən ɝliɝ, ðiz mɛn bɪhaɪn mi ɑɹ æʃəmən."

Cadsuane broke in again. "Perhaps I should have mentioned earlier, these men behind me are Asha'man."

ðə θɹi stɛp fɔɹwɝd ðɛn, əz ðeɪ hæd bɪn ɪnstʃɹʌktəd, ən ʃi hæd tə ədmɪt ðeɪ ɡeɪv ə deɪnʒɝəs əpɪɹəns. ɡɹɪzəl deɪmɝ lʊkt ə ɡɹeɪɪŋ bɛɹ wɪð sɔɹ tiθ, pɹɪɾi dʒɑhɹ simd ə dɑɹk, slik lɛpɝd, ən ɛbənz ənblɪŋkɪŋ ɡeɪz wɑz pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli ɑmənəs kʌmɪŋ fɹəm ðət juθfəl feɪs. ðeɪ sɝɾənli hæd ðɛɹ ɪfɛkt ɑn ðə kaʊnsəlz. səm sɪmpli ʃɪftəɾ ɪn ðɛɹ tʃɛɹz əz ɪf tə dʒɹɔ bæk, bʌt sɪpɹin lɛɾ əɹ maʊθ fɔl oʊpən, ənfɔɹtʃənət wɪð əɹ pɹoʊtʃɹuɾɪŋ tiθ. sɪbeɪn, hɝ hɛɹ əz ɡɹeɪ əz kædzueɪnz, sæɡd bæk ɪn əɹ tʃɛɹ ən bɪɡæn fænɪŋ hɝsɛlf wɪð ə slɛndɝ hænd, waɪl kmɪɹz maʊθ twɪstəɾ əz ɪf ʃi maɪt vɑmət.

The three stepped forward then, as they had been instructed, and she had to admit they gave a dangerous appearance. Grizzled Damer looked a graying bear with sore teeth, pretty Jahar seemed a dark, sleek leopard, and Eben's unblinking gaze was particularly ominous coming from that youthful face. They certainly had their effect on the Counsels. Some simply shifted in their chairs as if to draw back, but Cyprien let her mouth fall open, unfortunate with her protruding teeth. Sybaine, her hair as gray as Cadsuane's, sagged back in her chair and began fanning herself with a slender hand, while Cumere's mouth twisted as if she might vomit.

əlaɪz wɑz meɪɾ ə stɝnɝ stʌf, ðoʊ ʃi pɹɛs boʊθ hænz taɪɾ əɡɛnst əɹ mɪdʒɹəf. "aɪ toʊl jə wʌns ðəɾ æʃəmən wɝ fɹi tə vɪzət soʊ lɔŋ əz ðeɪ oʊbeɪd ðə lɔ. wɪv noʊ fɪɹ ʌv æʃəmən, kædzueɪn, ðoʊ aɪ mʌst seɪ aɪm sɝpɹaɪz tə si jə ɪn ðɛɹ kʌmpəni. pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli ɪn vju ʌv ði ɔfɝ juv dʒʌs meɪd."

Aleis was made of sterner stuff, though she pressed both hands tight against her midriff. "I told you once that Asha'man were free to visit so long as they obeyed the law. We have no fear of Asha'man, Cadsuane, though I must say I am surprised to see you in their company. Particularly in view of the offer you have just made."

soʊ, ʃi wɑz pleɪn kædzueɪn naʊ, wɑz ʃi? stɪl, ʃi ɹɪɡɹɛɾɪd ðə nəsɛsəɾi tə bɹeɪk əlaɪz. ʃi lɛd fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ wɛl, bʌt ʃi maɪt nɛvɝ ɹɪkʌvɝ fɹəm tənaɪt. "ɑɹ jə fɝɡɛɾɪŋ wʌɾ ɛls hæpən tədeɪ, əlaɪz? sʌmwʌn tʃænəld ɪnsaɪd ðə sɪɾi." əɡɛn kaʊnsəlz ʃɪftəd, ən wɝid fɹaʊnz kɹis mɔɹ ðən wʌn fɔɹhɛd.

So, she was plain Cadsuane now, was she? Still, she regretted the necessity to break Aleis. She led Far Madding well, but she might never recover from tonight. "Are you forgetting what else happened today, Aleis? Someone channeled inside the city." Again Counsels shifted, and worried frowns creased more than one forehead.

"æn æbɝeɪʃən." ðə kulnəs wɑz ɡɔn fɹəm əlaɪz' vɔɪs, ɹipleɪs baɪ æŋɡɝ, ən meɪbi ə tʌtʃ ə fɪɹ. hɝ aɪz ʃoʊn dɑɹkli. "pɝhæps ðə ɡɑɹɾiənz wɝ ɪn ɛɹɝ. noʊ wʌn u wɑz kwɛstʃən sɔ ɛniθɪŋ tə sədʒɛst - "

"An aberration." The coolness was gone from Aleis' voice, replaced by anger, and maybe a touch of fear. Her eyes shone darkly. "Perhaps the guardians were in error. No one who was questioned saw anything to suggest - "

"ivən wʌt wi θɪŋk ɪz pɝfəkt kən əv flɔz, əlaɪz." kædzueɪn dʒɹu ɑn əɹ oʊn wɛl, teɪkɪŋ ɪn seɪaɪdɑɹ ɪn ə mɛʒɝɾ əmaʊnt. ʃi hæd pɹæktəs; ðə lɪɾəl ɡoʊldən hʌmɪŋbɝd kəd nɑt hoʊl nɪɹ soʊ mʌtʃ əz nɪneɪivz bɛlt. "flɔz kən pæs ənnoʊɾɪst fəɹ sɛntʃɝiz bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ ɑɹ faʊnd." ðə floʊ ʌv ɛɹ ʃi woʊv wɑz dʒʌst ɪnʌf tə lɪf ðə dʒɛm-ɛnkɹʌstɪd kɔɹənɛt fɹəm əlaɪz' hɛɾ ən sɛɾ ɪɾ ɑn ðə kɑɹpəɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə wʊmənz fit. "wʌns ðeɪ ɑɹ faʊnd, haʊɛvɝ, ɪt simz ðəɾ ɛniwʌn u lʊks kən faɪn ðɛm."

"Even what we think is perfect can have flaws, Aleis." Cadsuane drew on her own Well, taking in saidar in a measured amount. She had practice; the little golden hummingbird could not hold near so much as Nynaeve's belt. "Flaws can pass unnoticed for centuries before they are found." The flow of Air she wove was just enough to lift the gem-encrusted coronet from Aleis' head and set it on the carpet in front of the woman's feet. "Once they are found, however, it seems that anyone who looks can find them."

θɝtin sɛts ə ʃɑkt aɪz stɛɹɾ ət ðə kɔɹənɛt. wʌn ən ɔl, ðə kaʊnsəlz sim fɹoʊzən, bɛɹli bɹiðɪŋ.

Thirteen sets of shocked eyes stared at the coronet. One and all, the Counsels seemed frozen, barely breathing.

"nɑt soʊ mʌtʃ ə flɔ əz ə bɑɹn dɔɹ, simz tə mi," deɪmɝ ənaʊnst. "aɪ θɪŋk ɪts pɹɪɾiɝ ɑn jəɹ hɛd."

"Not so much a flaw as a barn door, seems to me," Damer announced. "I think it's prettier on your head."

ðə ɡloʊ ʌv ðə paʊɝ sʌɾənli ʃoʊn ɝaʊnd nɪneɪiv, ən ðə kɔɹənɛt flu təwɔɹɾ əlaɪz, sloʊɪŋ ət ðə læst ɪnstən soʊ ðəɾ ɪt sɛɾəld əbʌv əɹ blʌdləs feɪs ɹæðɝ ðən kɹækɪŋ əɹ hɛd. ðə laɪɾ ə seɪaɪdɑɹ dɪd nɑt vænɪʃ fɹəm ðə ɡɝl, ðoʊ. wɛl, lɛɾ əɹ dʒɹeɪn əɹ wɛl.

The glow of the Power suddenly shone around Nynaeve, and the coronet flew toward Aleis, slowing at the last instant so that it settled above her bloodless face rather than cracking her head. The light of saidar did not vanish from the girl, though. Well, let her drain her Well.

"wɪl . . . ?" əlaɪz swɑloʊd, bʌt wən ʃi wɛn ɑn, hɝ vɔɪs stɪl kɹækt. "wɪl ɪt bi səfɪʃən ɪf wi ɹilis ɪm tə ju?" wɛðɝ ʃi mɛn kædzueɪn əɹ ði æʃəmən wɑz ənklɪɹ, pɝhæps ivən tə hɝ.

"Will . . . ?" Aleis swallowed, but when she went on, her voice still cracked. "Will it be sufficient if we release him to you?" Whether she meant Cadsuane or the Asha'man was unclear, perhaps even to her.

"aɪ θɪŋk ðəɾ ɪt wɪl," kædzueɪn sɛd kɑmli, ən əlaɪz sæɡd laɪk ə stʃɹɪŋləs pʌpət. ʃɑkt əz ðeɪ wɝ baɪ ðə dɪspleɪ ʌv tʃænəlɪŋ, kwɛstʃənɪŋ lʊks pæs bɪtwin ði ʌðɝ kaʊnsəlz. aɪz dɑɹɾɪd təwɔɹɾ əlaɪz, feɪsəz fɝmd, nɑdz wɝ ɪkstʃeɪnʒd. kædzueɪn dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ. ʃi hæd pɹɑməs ðə bɔɪ ðət wʌtɛvɝ ʃi dɪd wəd bi fəɹ ɪz ɡʊd, nɑt ðə ɡʊɾ ə ðə taʊɝ əɹ ɛniwʌn ɛlsəz, ən naʊ ʃi hæd bɹoʊkən ə ɡʊd wʊmən fəɹ ɪz ɡʊd. "aɪ æm vɛɹi sɑɹi, əlaɪz," ʃi sɛd. jə ɑɹ bɪldɪŋ ʌp ə lɑɹdʒ əkaʊn ɔlɹɛɾi, bɔɪ, ʃi θɔt.

"I think that it will," Cadsuane said calmly, and Aleis sagged like a stringless puppet. Shocked as they were by the display of channeling, questioning looks passed between the other Counsels. Eyes darted toward Aleis, faces firmed, nods were exchanged. Cadsuane drew a deep breath. She had promised the boy that whatever she did would be for his good, not the good of the Tower or anyone else's, and now she had broken a good woman for his good. "I am very sorry, Aleis," she said. You are building up a large account already, boy, she thought.


tʃæptɝ θɝɾifaɪv


CHAPTER 35

wɪð ðə tʃoʊɾən kæl


With the Choedan Kal

ɹænd ɹoʊɾ əkɹɔs ðə waɪd stoʊn bɹɪdʒ liɾɪŋ nɔɹθ fɹəm ðə keɪɛmlɪn ɡeɪt wɪθaʊt lʊkɪŋ bæk. ðə sʌn wɑz ə peɪl ɡoʊldən bɔl dʒʌst ɹɪzən əbʌv ðə hɝaɪzən ɪn ə klaʊdləs skaɪ, bʌt ði ɛɹ wɑz koʊld ɪnʌf tə mɪst ɪz bɹɛθ, ən ðə leɪk wɪnz meɪɾ ɪz kloʊk flaɪ əbaʊt. hi dɪd nɑt fil ðə tʃɪl, ðoʊ, ɪksɛpt əz sʌmθɪŋ dɪstən ən nɑt ɹɪli kənɛktəd tə hɪm. hi wɑz koʊldɝ ðən ɛni wɪntɝ kəd bi. ðə ɡɑɹdz u hæd kʌm tə teɪk ɪm aʊɾ ə ðə sɛl ðə naɪt bɪfɔɹ hæd bɪn sɝpɹaɪz tə faɪn ɪm wɛɹɪŋ ə smɔl smaɪl. hi wɔɹ ɪt stɪl, ə slaɪt kɝv ə hɪz maʊθ. nɪneɪiv hæd hild ɪz bɹuzəz juzɪŋ ðə læst ə ðə seɪaɪdɑɹ ɪn əɹ bɛlt, jɛt ðə hɛlməɾɪd ɔfəsɝ u keɪm ɪndə ðə ɹoʊɾ ət ðə fʊɾ ə ðə bɹɪdʒ, ə stɑki mæn wɪð blʌn fitʃɝz, ɡeɪv ə stɑɹɾ ət ðə saɪɾ ə hɪm, əz ðoʊ hɪz feɪs wɑz stɪl swoʊlən ən pɝpəl.

Rand rode across the wide stone bridge leading north from the Caemlyn Gate without looking back. The sun was a pale golden ball just risen above the horizon in a cloudless sky, but the air was cold enough to mist his breath, and the lake winds made his cloak fly about. He did not feel the chill, though, except as something distant and not really connected to him. He was colder than any winter could be. The guards who had come to take him out of the cell the night before had been surprised to find him wearing a small smile. He wore it still, a slight curve of his mouth. Nynaeve had Healed his bruises using the last of the saidar in her belt, yet the helmeted officer who came into the road at the foot of the bridge, a stocky man with blunt features, gave a start at the sight of him, as though his face was still swollen and purple.

kædzueɪn lin fɹəm əɹ sæɾəl tə spik ə fju kwaɪət wɝdz ən hæn ði ɔfəsɝ ə foʊldəd peɪpɝ. hi fɹaʊn əɾ əɹ ən bɪɡæn tə ɹid, ðən dʒɝkt ɪz hɛɾ ʌp tə stɛɹ ɪn əmeɪzmən ət ðə mɛn ən wɪmən weɪɾɪŋ peɪʃənli ɑn ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz bɪhaɪn hɝ. stɑɹɾɪŋ əɡɛn ət ðə tɑp ə ðə peɪdʒ, hi ɹɛd muvɪŋ ɪz lɪps saɪlənli, əz ɪf i wɑntəd tə bi ʃʊɹ ʌv ɛvɹi wɝd, ən smɔl wʌndɝ. saɪn ən sil baɪ ɔl θɝtin kaʊnsəlz, ði ɔɹɾɝ sɛd ðət ðəɹ wɑz tə bi noʊ tʃɛkɪŋ ə pis-bɑnz, noʊ sɝtʃ ə ðə pækhɔɹsɪz. ðɪs pɑɹɾiz neɪmz wɝ tə bi blɑɾɪd aʊt kəmplitli ɪn ðə ɹɛkɝd bʊks, ən ði ɔɹɾɝ ɪtsɛlf bɝnd. ðeɪ hæd nɛvɝ kʌm tə fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ. noʊ ɛɛs sədaɪ, noʊ æθɑn maɪɹ, nʌn ə ðɛm.

Cadsuane leaned from her saddle to speak a few quiet words and hand the officer a folded paper. He frowned at her and began to read, then jerked his head up to stare in amazement at the men and women waiting patiently on their horses behind her. Starting again at the top of the page, he read moving his lips silently, as if he wanted to be sure of every word, and small wonder. Signed and sealed by all thirteen Counsels, the order said that there was to be no checking of peace-bonds, no search of the packhorses. This party's names were to be blotted out completely in the record books, and the order itself burned. They had never come to Far Madding. No Aes Sedai, no Atha'an Miere, none of them.

"ɪts oʊvɝ, ɹænd," mɪn sɛd dʒɛnli, muvɪŋ əɹ stɝɾi bɹaʊn mɛɹ nɪɹɝ tə hɪz ɡɹeɪ ɡɛldɪŋ, ðoʊ ʃi ɔlɹɛɾi steɪɾ əz kloʊs tə hɪm əz nɪneɪiv dɪd tə læn. lænz bɹuzəz, ən ə bɹoʊkən ɑɹm, hæd bɪn hil bɪfɔɹ ʃi hæɾ ətɛndəd tə ɹænd. mɪnz feɪs ɹəflɛktəd ðə wɝi floʊɪŋ θɹu ðə bɑnd. lɛɾɪŋ əɹ kloʊk ɡoʊ ɑn ðə wɪnd, ʃi pæɾəd ɪz ɑɹm. "ju doʊn əv tə θɪŋk əbaʊɾ ɪɾ ɛnimɔɹ."

"It's over, Rand," Min said gently, moving her sturdy brown mare nearer to his gray gelding, though she already stayed as close to him as Nynaeve did to Lan. Lan's bruises, and a broken arm, had been Healed before she had attended to Rand. Min's face reflected the worry flowing through the bond. Letting her cloak go on the wind, she patted his arm. "You don't have to think about it anymore."

"aɪm ɡɹeɪtfəl tə fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ, mɪn." hɪz vɔɪs wɑz ɪmoʊʃənləs, dɪstənt, əz ɪt hæd bɪn wən i siz seɪɾɪn ɪn ði ɝli deɪz. hi wʊɾə wɔɹmd ɪt fəɹ hɝ, bʌt ðət sim bɪɑn hɪm. "aɪ ɹɪli dɪd faɪnd wʌɾ aɪ niɾəd hɪɹ." ɪf ə sɔɹd hæd mɛmɹi, ɪt maɪt bi ɡɹeɪtfəl tə ðə fɔɹdʒ faɪɝ, bʌt nɛvɝ fɑn ʌv ɪt. wən ðeɪ wɝ weɪv θɹu, hi kæntɝd ðə ɡɹeɪ ʌp ðə hɑɹd-pæk dɝt ɹoʊɾ ən ɪndə ðə hɪlz, ən i dɪd nɑt soʊ mʌtʃ əz ɡlæns bæk əntɪl tʃɹiz hɪɾ ɛni saɪɾ ə ðə sɪɾi.

"I'm grateful to Far Madding, Min." His voice was emotionless, distant, as it had been when he seized saidin in the early days. He would have warmed it for her, but that seemed beyond him. "I really did find what I needed here." If a sword had memory, it might be grateful to the forge fire, but never fond of it. When they were waved through, he cantered the gray up the hard-packed dirt road and into the hills, and he did not so much as glance back until trees hid any sight of the city.

ðə ɹoʊd klaɪmd ən waʊn θɹu fɔɹəstəd wɪntɝ hɪlz, wɛɹ oʊnli paɪn ən lɛðɝlif ʃoʊd ɡɹin ən moʊs bɹæntʃəz wɝ stɑɹk ən ɡɹeɪ, ən sʌɾənli ðə sɔɹs wɑz ðəɹ əɡɛn, simɪŋli dʒʌs bɪɑn ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɪz aɪ. ɪt pʌlsd ən bɛkən ən fɪld ɪm wɪð hʌŋɡɝ laɪk stɑɹveɪʃən. wɪθaʊt θɔɾ i ɹitʃt aʊɾ ən fɪl ði ɛmptinəs ɪn hɪmsɛlf wɪð seɪɾɪn, ən ævəlæntʃ ə faɪɝ, ə stɔɹm ʌv aɪs, ɔl lɑɹɾɪd wɪð ðə fɪlθi teɪn ðət meɪd ðə lɑɹdʒɝ waʊn ɪn ɪz saɪd pʌls. hi sweɪɾ ɪn ðə sæɾəl əz ɪz hɛd spʌn ən ɪz stʌmək klɛntʃt ivən əz i fɔt tə ɹaɪd ði ævəlæntʃ ðət tʃɹaɪd tə sɪɹ ɪz maɪnd, tə sɔɹ ɑn ðə stɔɹm ðət tʃɹaɪd tə skaʊɝ ɪz soʊl. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ fɝɡɪvnəs əɹ pɪɾi ɪn ðə meɪl hæf ə ðə paʊɝ. ə mæn fɔɾ ɪt, əɹ daɪd. hi kəd fil ðə θɹi æʃəmən bɪhaɪn ɪm fɪlɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz tu, dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ ət seɪɾɪn laɪk mɛn dʒʌst aʊɾ ə ðə weɪst u hæd faʊnd wɔɾɝ. ɪn ɪz hɛd, luz θɝɪn saɪd wɪð ɹɪlif.

The road climbed and wound through forested winter hills, where only pine and leatherleaf showed green and most branches were stark and gray, and suddenly the Source was there again, seemingly just beyond the corner of his eye. It pulsed and beckoned and filled him with hunger like starvation. Without thought he reached out and filled the emptiness in himself with saidin, an avalanche of fire, a storm of ice, all larded with the filthy taint that made the larger wound in his side pulse. He swayed in the saddle as his head spun and his stomach clenched even as he fought to ride the avalanche that tried to sear his mind, to soar on the storm that tried to scour his soul. There was no forgiveness or pity in the male half of the Power. A man fought it, or died. He could feel the three Asha'man behind him filling themselves too, drinking at saidin like men just out of the Waste who had found water. In his head, Lews Therin sighed with relief.

mɪn ɹeɪn əɹ maʊn soʊ kloʊs tə hɪm ðət ðɛɹ lɛɡz tʌtʃt. "ɑɹ jə ɔl ɹaɪt?" ʃi sɛd wɝidli. "ju lʊk ɪl."

Min reined her mount so close to him that their legs touched. "Are you all right?" she said worriedly. "You look ill."

"aɪm əz wɛl əz ɹeɪnwɔɾɝ," hi toʊl hɝ, ən ðə laɪ wɑz nɑt dʒʌst əbaʊɾ ɪz bɛli. hi wɑz stil, ən tə hɪz sɝpɹaɪz, stɪl nɑt hɑɹɾ ɪnʌf. hi hæɾ ɪntɛndəd sɛndɪŋ əɹ tə keɪɛmlɪn, wɪð əliviə tə pɹətɛk hɝ. ɪf ðə ɡoʊldən-hɛɹd wʊmən wɑz gɑnə hɛlp ɪm daɪ, hi hæd tə bi eɪbəl tə tʃɹʌs hɝ. hi hæd plæn ɪz wɝdz, bʌt lʊkɪŋ ɪndə mɪnz dɑɹk aɪz, hi wɑz nɑt hɑɹɾ ɪnʌf tə meɪk ɪz tʌŋ fɔɹm ðɛm. tɝnɪŋ ðə ɡɹeɪ ɪn əmʌŋ ðə bɛɹ-bɹæntʃt tʃɹiz, hi spoʊk tə kædzueɪn oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. "ðɪs ɪz ðə pleɪs."

"I'm as well as rainwater," he told her, and the lie was not just about his belly. He was steel, and to his surprise, still not hard enough. He had intended sending her to Caemlyn, with Alivia to protect her. If the golden-haired woman was going to help him die, he had to be able to trust her. He had planned his words, but looking into Min's dark eyes, he was not hard enough to make his tongue form them. Turning the gray in among the bare-branched trees, he spoke to Cadsuane over his shoulder. "This is the place."

ʃi fɑloʊd hɪm, ʌv kɔɹs. ðeɪ ɔl dɪd. hɑɹɪn hæd bɛɹli lɛɾ ɪm aʊɾ ə hɝ saɪt lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə slip ə fju aʊɝz læs naɪt. hi wʊɾə lɛft əɹ bɪhaɪnd, bʌɾ ɑn ðət sʌbʒɪkt, kædzueɪn hæd ɡɪvən ɪm əɹ fɝst ædvaɪs. jə meɪɾ ə bɑɹɡən wɪð ðɛm, bɔɪ, ðə seɪm əz saɪnɪŋ ə tʃɹiɾi. əɹ ɡɪvɪŋ jəɹ wɝd. kip ɪt, əɹ tɛl əm ɪts bɹoʊkən. ʌðɝwaɪz, jə ɑɹ dʒʌst ə θif. blʌnt, tə ðə pɔɪnt, ən ɪn toʊnz ðət lɛf noʊ daʊɾ əz tə hɝ əpɪnjən ə θivz. hi hæd nɛvɝ pɹɑməs tə fɑloʊ hɝ kaʊnsəl, bʌt ʃi wɑz tu ɹɪlʌktən əbaʊt biɪŋ ɪz ædvaɪzɝ əɾ ɔl fəɹ ɪm tə ɹɪsk dʒɹaɪvɪŋ əɹ əweɪ ðɪs sun, soʊ ðə weɪvməstʃɹəs ən ði ʌðɝ tu si foʊk ɹoʊd wɪð əliviə, əhɛɾ ə vɛɹɪn ən ði ʌðɝ faɪv ɛɛs sədaɪ hu hæd swɔɹn tə hɪm, ən ðə fɔɹ u wɝ kædzueɪnz kəmpænjənz. ʃi wəɾ əz sun liv ɪm əz ðɛm, hi wɑz sɝɾən, meɪbi sunɝ.

She followed him, of course. They all did. Harine had barely let him out of her sight long enough to sleep a few hours last night. He would have left her behind, but on that subject, Cadsuane had given him her first advice. You made a bargain with them, boy, the same as signing a treaty. Or giving your word. Keep it, or tell them it's broken. Otherwise, you are just a thief. Blunt, to the point, and in tones that left no doubt as to her opinion of thieves. He had never promised to follow her counsel, but she was too reluctant about being his advisor at all for him to risk driving her away this soon, so the Wavemistress and the other two Sea Folk rode with Alivia, ahead of Verin and the other five Aes Sedai who had sworn to him, and the four who were Cadsuane's companions. She would as soon leave him as them, he was certain, maybe sooner.

tə ʌðɝ aɪz ðən hɪz, nʌθɪŋ dɪstɪŋɡwɪʃt ðə pleɪs wɛɹ i hæd dʌɡ bɪfɔɹ ɡoʊɪŋ ɪndə fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ. tə hɪz aɪz, ə θɪn ʃæf ðət ʃoʊn laɪk ə læntɝn ɹoʊz θɹu ðə dæmp mʌltʃ ɑn ðə fɔɹəs flɔɹ. ivən ənʌðɝ mæn u kəd tʃænəl cʊɾə wɔk θɹu ðət ʃæft wɪθaʊt noʊɪŋ ɪt wɑz ðɛɹ. hi dɪd nɑt bɑðɝ tə dɪsmaʊnt. juzɪŋ floʊz ʌv ɛɹ, hi ɹɪpt əsaɪd ðə θɪk leɪɝ ə ɹɑɾɪŋ livz ən twɪɡz ən ʃʌvəld əweɪ dæmp ɝθ əntɪl i ənkʌvɝɾ ə lɔŋ, nɛɹoʊ bʌndəl taɪd wɪð lɛðɝ kɔɹdz. klɑdz ə dɝt klʌŋ tə ðə ɹæpɪŋ-klɔθ əz i floʊɾəd kælændɝ tə hɪz hænd. hi hæd nɑt dɛɹd kæɹi ðət tə fɑɹ mæɾɪŋ. wɪθaʊɾ ə skæbɝd, hi wʊɾə hæd tə liv ɪɾ ət ðə bɹɪdʒ fɔɹtʃɹəs, ə deɪnʒɝəs flæɡ weɪɾɪŋ tə ənaʊns ɪz pɹɛzəns. ɪt wɑz ənlaɪkli ðəɹ wɑz ənʌðɝ sɔɹd meɪɾ ə kɹɪstəl tə bi faʊn ɪn ðə wɝld, ən tu mɛni pipəl nu ðət ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn hæd wʌn. ən livɪŋ ɪt hɪɹ, hi hæd stɪl ɛndəɾ ʌp ɪn ə dɑɹk, kɹæmp stoʊn bɑks ʌndɝ ðə . . . noʊ. ðət wɑz dʌn ən oʊvɝ. oʊvɝ. luz θɝɪn pæntɪɾ ɪn ðə ʃædoʊz ə hɪz maɪnd.

To other eyes than his, nothing distinguished the place where he had dug before going into Far Madding. To his eyes, a thin shaft that shone like a lantern rose through the damp mulch on the forest floor. Even another man who could channel could have walked through that shaft without knowing it was there. He did not bother to dismount. Using flows of Air, he ripped aside the thick layer of rotting leaves and twigs and shoveled away damp earth until he uncovered a long, narrow bundle tied with leather cords. Clods of dirt clung to the wrapping-cloth as he floated Callandor to his hand. He had not dared carry that to Far Madding. Without a scabbard, he would have had to leave it at the bridge fortress, a dangerous flag waiting to announce his presence. It was unlikely there was another sword made of crystal to be found in the world, and too many people knew that the Dragon Reborn had one. And leaving it here, he had still ended up in a dark, cramped stone box under the . . . No. That was done and over. Over. Lews Therin panted in the shadows of his mind.

θɹʌstɪŋ kælændɝ ʌndɝ ɪz sæɾəl-ɡɝθ, hi ɹeɪn ðə ɡɹeɪ ɝaʊn tə feɪs ði ʌðɝz. ðə hɔɹsəz hɛl ðɛɹ teɪlz taɪɾ əɡɛns ðə wɪnd, bʌt naʊ ən ðən wʌn stæmpt ə huf əɹ tɔst ɪts hɛd, ɪmpeɪʃən tə bi muvɪŋ əɡɛn æftɝ soʊ lɔŋ ɪn ðə steɪbəl. ðə lɛðɝ skɹɪp ðət hʌŋ fɹəm nɪneɪivz ʃoʊldɝ lʊkt ɪŋkɔŋɹuəs wɪð ɔl ðə bi-ɡɛm tɛɹæŋɡɹil ʃi wɔɹ. naʊ ðət ðə taɪm wɑz nɪɹ, ʃi wɑz stʃɹoʊkɪŋ ðə bʌlʒɪŋ skɹɪp, əpɛɹənli wɪθaʊt ɹilaɪzɪŋ wʌt ʃi wɑz duɪŋ. ʃi wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə haɪɾ əɹ fɪɹ, bʌɾ əɹ tʃɪn tʃɹɛmbəld. kædzueɪn wɑz lʊkɪŋ əɾ ɪm ɪmpæsɪvli. hɝ kaʊl hæd fɔlən daʊn əɹ bæk, ən səmtaɪmz ə ɡʌst stʃɹɔŋɝ ðən moʊst sweɪd ðə ɡoʊldən fɪʃ ən bɝdz, stɑɹz ən munz, dæŋɡəlɪŋ fɹəm əɹ bʌn.

Thrusting Callandor under his saddle-girth, he reined the gray around to face the others. The horses held their tails tight against the wind, but now and then one stamped a hoof or tossed its head, impatient to be moving again after so long in the stable. The leather scrip that hung from Nynaeve's shoulder looked incongruous with all the be-gemmed ter'angreal she wore. Now that the time was near, she was stroking the bulging scrip, apparently without realizing what she was doing. She was trying to hide her fear, but her chin trembled. Cadsuane was looking at him impassively. Her cowl had fallen down her back, and sometimes a gust stronger than most swayed the golden fish and birds, stars and moons, dangling from her bun.

"aɪ æm gɑnə ɹimuv ðə teɪn fɹəm ðə meɪl hæf ə ðə sɔɹs," hi ənaʊnst.

"I am going to remove the taint from the male half of the Source," he announced.

ðə θɹi æʃəmən, naʊ ɪn pleɪn dɑɹk koʊts ən kloʊks laɪk ði ʌðɝ wɔɹɾɝz, ɪkstʃeɪnʒd ɪksaɪɾəd ɡlænsɪz, bʌɾ ə ɹɪpəl pæs θɹu ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. nɛsun lɛɾ aʊɾ ə ɡæsp ðət sim tu lɑɹdʒ fəɹ ðə slɛndɝ, bɝd-laɪk sɪstɝ.

The three Asha'man, now in plain dark coats and cloaks like the other Warders, exchanged excited glances, but a ripple passed through the Aes Sedai. Nesune let out a gasp that seemed too large for the slender, bird-like sister.

kædzueɪnz ɪkspɹɛʃən nɛvɝ ɔltɝd. "wɪð ðæt?" ʃi sɛd, ɹeɪzɪŋ ə skɛptəkəl aɪbɹaʊ ət ðə bʌndəl bɪniθ ɪz lɛɡ.

Cadsuane's expression never altered. "With that?" she said, raising a skeptical eyebrow at the bundle beneath his leg.

"wɪð ðə tʃoʊɾən kæl," hi ɹɪplaɪd. ðət neɪm wɑz ənʌðɝ ɡɪft fɹəm luz θɝɪn, ɹɛstɪŋ ɪn ɹændz hɛɾ əz ɪf ɪt hæɾ ɔlweɪz bɪn ðɛɹ. "ju noʊ ðɛm əz ɪmɛns stætʃuz, sɑŋɡɹil, wʌn bɛɹiɾ ɪn kɛɹhin, ði ʌðɝ ɑn tʃɹɛmælkɪŋ." hɑɹɪnz hɛd dʒɝkt, meɪkɪŋ ðə ɡoʊldən mədæljənz ɑn əɹ noʊz tʃeɪn klɪk təɡɛðɝ, ət mɛnʃən ə ðə si foʊk aɪlənd. "ðeɪɹ tu bɪɡ tə bi muvd wɪð ɛni iz, bʌɾ aɪ hæv ə pɛɹ ə tɛɹæŋɡɹil kɔld æksɛs kiz. juzɪŋ ðoʊz, ðə tʃoʊɾən kæl kən bi tæp fɹəm ɛniwɛɹ ɪn ðə wɝld."

"With the Choedan Kal," he replied. That name was another gift from Lews Therin, resting in Rand's head as if it had always been there. "You know them as immense statues, sa'angreal, one buried in Cairhien, the other on Tremalking." Harine's head jerked, making the golden medallions on her nose chain click together, at mention of the Sea Folk island. "They're too big to be moved with any ease, but I have a pair of ter'angreal called access keys. Using those, the Choedan Kal can be tapped from anywhere in the world."

deɪnʒɝəs, luz θɝɪn moʊnd. mædnəs. ɹænd ɪɡnɔɹd hɪm. fəɹ ðə moʊmənt, oʊnli kædzueɪn mæɾɝd.

Dangerous, Lews Therin moaned. Madness. Rand ignored him. For the moment, only Cadsuane mattered.

hɝ beɪ flɪkt wʌn blæk ɪɹ, ən ət ðəɾ i simd mɔɹ ɪksaɪɾəbəl ðən ɪz ɹaɪɾɝ. "wʌn ə ðoʊz sɑŋɡɹil ɪz meɪd fəɹ ə wʊmən," ʃi sɛd kuli. "hu dʒju pɹəpoʊz tə juz ðæt? əɹ də ðiz kiz əlaʊ jə tə dʒɹɔ ɑn boʊθ jɝsɛlf?"

Her bay flicked one black ear, and at that he seemed more excitable than his rider. "One of those sa'angreal is made for a woman," she said coolly. "Who do you propose to use that? Or do these keys allow you to draw on both yourself?"

"nɪneɪiv wɪl lɪŋk wɪð mi." hi tʃɹʌstɪd nɪneɪiv, tə lɪŋk wɪð, bʌt noʊ wʌn ɛls. ʃi wɑz ɛɛs sədaɪ, bʌt ʃi hæd bɪn ðə wɪzdəm ʌv ɛmənz fild; hi hæd tə tʃɹʌs hɝ. ʃi smaɪld əɾ ɪm ən nɑɾəd fɝmli, hɝ tʃɪn noʊ lɔŋɡɝ tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ. "doʊn tʃɹaɪ tə stɑp mi, kædzueɪn." ʃi sɛd nʌθɪŋ, oʊnli stʌɾid hɪm, dɑɹk aɪz weɪɪŋ ən mɛʒɝɪŋ.

"Nynaeve will link with me." He trusted Nynaeve, to link with, but no one else. She was Aes Sedai, but she had been the Wisdom of Emond's Field; he had to trust her. She smiled at him and nodded firmly, her chin no longer trembling. "Don't try to stop me, Cadsuane." She said nothing, only studied him, dark eyes weighing and measuring.

"fɝɡɪv mi, kædzueɪn," kʌmaɪɹə bɹoʊk ɪndə ðə saɪləns, hilɪŋ əɹ dæpəl fɔɹwɝd. "jʌŋ mæn, hæv jə kənsɪɾɝd ðə pɑsəbɪləɾi ʌv feɪljɝ? hæv jə kənsɪɾɝd ðə kɑnsəkwɛnsəz ə feɪljɝ?"

"Forgive me, Cadsuane," Kumira broke into the silence, heeling her dapple forward. "Young man, have you considered the possibility of failure? Have you considered the consequences of failure?"

"aɪ mʌst æsk ðə seɪm kwɛstʃən," nɛsun sɛd ʃɑɹpli. ʃi sæt vɛɹi stʃɹeɪɾ ɪn əɹ sæɾəl, ən əɹ dɑɹk aɪz mɛt ɹændz ɡeɪz lɛvəli. "baɪ ɛvɹiθɪŋ aɪ hæv ɹɛd, ði ətɛmp tə juz ðoʊz sɑŋɡɹil meɪ ɹɪzʌlt ɪn dɪzæstɝ. təɡɛðɝ, ðeɪ maɪt bi stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf tə kɹæk ðə wɝld laɪk ən ɛɡ."

"I must ask the same question," Nesune said sharply. She sat very straight in her saddle, and her dark eyes met Rand's gaze levelly. "By everything I have read, the attempt to use those sa'angreal may result in disaster. Together, they might be strong enough to crack the world like an egg."

laɪk ən ɛɡ! luz θɝɪn əɡɹid. ðeɪ wɝ nɛvɝ tɛstəd, nɛvɝ tʃɹaɪd. ðɪs ɪz ɪnseɪn! hi ʃɹikt. jə ɑɹ mæd! mæd!

Like an egg! Lews Therin agreed. They were never tested, never tried. This is insane! he shrieked. You are mad! Mad!

"ðə læst aɪ hɝd," ɹænd toʊl ðə sɪstɝz, "wʌn æʃəmən ɪn fɪfti hæd ɡɔn mæɾ ən hæd tə bi pʊt daʊn laɪk ə ɹæbɪd dɔɡ. mɔɹ wɪl hæv, baɪ naʊ. ðəɹ ɪz ə ɹɪsk tə duɪŋ ðɪs, bʌɾ ɪts ɔl meɪbi ən maɪt. ɪf aɪ doʊn tʃɹaɪ, ðə sɝɾənti ɪz ðət mɔɹ ən mɔɹ mɛn wɪl ɡoʊ mæd, meɪbi skɔɹz, meɪbi ɔl ʌv ʌs, ən sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ ɪɾəl bi tu mɛni tə bi kɪld izəli. wɪl jə ɛndʒɔɪ weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ðə læs bæɾəl wɪð ə hʌnʒɹəd ɹæbɪɾ æʃəmən wɑndɝɪŋ əbaʊt, əɹ tu hʌnʒɹəd, əɹ faɪv? ən meɪbi mi wʌn ə ðɛm? haʊ lɔŋ wɪl ðə wɝl sɝvaɪv ðæt?" hi spoʊk tə ðə tu bɹaʊnz, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz kædzueɪn u hi wɑtʃt. hɝ ɔlmoʊs blæk aɪz nɛvɝ lɛf hɪm. hi niɾəd tə kip əɹ wɪð hɪm, bʌɾ ɪf ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə tɔk ɪm aʊɾ ʌv ɪt, hi wəd ɹɪdʒɛkt əɹ ædvaɪs noʊ mæɾɝ ðə kɑnsəkwɛnsəz. ɪf ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə stɑp ɪm . . . ? seɪɾɪn ɹeɪdʒd ɪnsaɪd hɪm.

"The last I heard," Rand told the sisters, "one Asha'man in fifty had gone mad and had to be put down like a rabid dog. More will have, by now. There is a risk to doing this, but it's all maybe and might. If I don't try, the certainty is that more and more men will go mad, maybe scores, maybe all of us, and sooner or later it will be too many to be killed easily. Will you enjoy waiting for the Last Battle with a hundred rabid Asha'man wandering about, or two hundred, or five? And maybe me one of them? How long will the world survive that?" He spoke to the two Browns, but it was Cadsuane who he watched. Her almost black eyes never left him. He needed to keep her with him, but if she tried to talk him out of it, he would reject her advice no matter the consequences. If she tried to stop him . . . ? Saidin raged inside him.

"wɪl jə də ðə did hɪɹ?" ʃi æskt.

"Will you do the deed here?" she asked.

"ɪn ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ," hi toʊl hɝ, ən ʃi nɑɾəd.

"In Shadar Logoth," he told her, and she nodded.

"ə fɪɾɪŋ pleɪs," ʃi sɛd, "ɪf wəɹ tə ɹɪsk dɪstʃɹɔɪɪŋ ðə wɝld."

"A fitting place," she said, "if we are to risk destroying the world."

luz θɝɪn skɹimd, ə dwɪndəlɪŋ haʊl ðəɾ ɛkoʊɾ ɪnsaɪd ɹændz skʌl əz ðə vɔɪs flɛɾ ɪndə ðə dɑɹk dɛpθs. ðəɹ wɑz noʊwɛɹ tə haɪd, ðoʊ. noʊ seɪf pleɪs.

Lews Therin screamed, a dwindling howl that echoed inside Rand's skull as the voice fled into the dark depths. There was nowhere to hide, though. No safe place.

ðə ɡeɪtweɪ hi woʊv dɪd nɑɾ oʊpən ɪndə ðə ɹuən sɪɾi ʌv ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ ɪtsɛlf, bʌt tə ə θɪnli wʊɾɪd, ənivən hɪltɑp ə fju maɪlz tə ðə nɔɹθ, wɛɹ ðə hɔɹs hʊvz ɹæŋ ɑn spɑɹs, stoʊni sɔɪl ðət hæd stʌntɪd ðə lifləs tʃɹiz, ən ɹæɡəd pætʃəz ə snoʊ kʌvɝd ðə ɡɹaʊnd. əz ɹænd dɪsmaʊntɪd, hɪz aɪ wɑz kɑt baɪ dɪstənt ɡlɪmpsɪz ə ðə pleɪs wʌns kɔld ɑɹɪdhɔl ʃoʊɪŋ əbʌv ðə tʃɹiz, taʊɝz ðəɾ ɛndəɾ əbɹʌpli ɪn dʒæɡd stoʊn, ən waɪɾ ʌnjən-ʃeɪp doʊmz ðət cʊɾə ʃɛltɝɾ ə vɪlədʒ hæd ðeɪ bɪn hoʊl. hi dɪd nɑt lʊk fəɹ lɔŋ. dɪspaɪt ðə klɪɹ mɔɹnɪŋ skaɪ, ðoʊz peɪl doʊmz feɪl tə ɡlim əz ðeɪ ʃʊd, əz ɪf sʌmθɪŋ kæst ə ʃædoʊ oʊvɝ ðə spɹɔlɪŋ ɹuən. ivən ət ðɪs dɪstəns fɹəm ðə sɪɾi, ðə sɛkənd nɛvɝ-hilɪŋ waʊn ɪn ɪz saɪd hæd bɪɡʌn tə θɹəb feɪnli. ðə slæʃ ɡɪvən baɪ pdən feɪnz dæɡɝ, ðə dæɡɝ ðət hæd kʌm fɹəm ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ, dɪd nɑt bit təɡɛðɝ wɪð ðə pʌlsɪŋ ə ðə lɑɹdʒɝ waʊn ɪt kʌɾ əkɹɔs, bʌt ɹæðɝ əɡɛnst ɪt, ɔltɝneɪɾɪŋ.

The gateway he wove did not open into the ruined city of Shadar Logoth itself, but to a thinly wooded, uneven hilltop a few miles to the north, where the horse hooves rang on sparse, stony soil that had stunted the leafless trees, and ragged patches of snow covered the ground. As Rand dismounted, his eye was caught by distant glimpses of the place once called Aridhol showing above the trees, towers that ended abruptly in jagged stone, and white onion-shaped domes that could have sheltered a village had they been whole. He did not look for long. Despite the clear morning sky, those pale domes failed to gleam as they should, as if something cast a shadow over the sprawling ruin. Even at this distance from the city, the second never-healing wound in his side had begun to throb faintly. The slash given by Padan Fain's dagger, the dagger that had come from Shadar Logoth, did not beat together with the pulsing of the larger wound it cut across, but rather against it, alternating.

kædzueɪn tʊk tʃɑɹdʒ, ɪʃuɪŋ bɹɪsk kəmænz, əz maɪɾ əv bɪn ɪkspɛktəd. wʌn weɪ əɹ ənʌðɝ, ɛɛs sədaɪ ɔlweɪz dɪd, ɡɪvən hæf ə tʃæns, ən ɹænd dɪd nɑt tʃɹaɪ tə stɑp hɝ. læn ən nɛθən ən bæsɑn ɹoʊd daʊn ɪndə ðə fɔɹəs tə skaʊt, ən ði ʌðɝ wɔɹɾɝz hɝid tə fæsən ðə hɔɹsəz tə loʊ bɹæntʃəz aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ. mɪn stʊɾ ʌp ɪn əɹ stɝəps ən pʊld ɹændz hɛd tə wɛɹ ʃi kəd kɪs ɪz aɪz. wɪθaʊt spikɪŋ ə wɝd, ʃi wɛn tə dʒɔɪn ðə mɛn wɪð ðə hɔɹsəz. ðə bɑn sɝdʒd wɪð əɹ lʌv fəɹ hɪm, wɪð kɑnfəɾəns ən ə tʃɹʌst soʊ kəmplit ðəɾ i stɛɹɾ æftɝ əɹ ɪn əmeɪzmənt.

Cadsuane took charge, issuing brisk commands, as might have been expected. One way or another, Aes Sedai always did, given half a chance, and Rand did not try to stop her. Lan and Nethan and Bassane rode down into the forest to scout, and the other Warders hurried to fasten the horses to low branches out of the way. Min stood up in her stirrups and pulled Rand's head to where she could kiss his eyes. Without speaking a word, she went to join the men with the horses. The bond surged with her love for him, with confidence and a trust so complete that he stared after her in amazement.

ɛbən keɪm tə teɪk ɹændz maʊnt, ɡɹɪnɪŋ fɹəm ɪɹ tə ɪɹ. təɡɛðɝ wɪð ɪz noʊz, ðoʊz ɪɹz stɪl sim tə meɪk ʌp hæf ɪz feɪs, bʌɾ i wɑz ə slɛndɝ juθ ɹæðɝ ðən ɡɔki, naʊ. "ɪt wɪl bi wʌndɝfəl, tʃænəlɪŋ wɪθaʊt ðə teɪnt, maɪ lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən," hi sɛɾ ɪksaɪɾədli. ɹænd θɔɾ ɛbən maɪt bi əz mʌtʃ əz sɛvəntin, bʌɾ i saʊndəd jʌŋɡɝ. "ðæɾ ɔlweɪz meɪks mi wɑnə ɛmpti maɪ bɛli, ɪf aɪ θɪŋk ɑn ɪt." hi tʃɹɑɾəd əweɪ wɪð ðə ɡɹeɪ, stɪl ɡɹɪnɪŋ.

Eben came to take Rand's mount, grinning from ear to ear. Together with his nose, those ears still seemed to make up half his face, but he was a slender youth rather than gawky, now. "It will be wonderful, channeling without the taint, my Lord Dragon," he said excitedly. Rand thought Eben might be as much as seventeen, but he sounded younger. "That always makes me want to empty my belly, if I think on it." He trotted away with the gray, still grinning.

ðə paʊɝ ɹɔɹɾ ɪn ɹænd, ən ðə fɪlθ tɑɹnɪʃɪŋ ðə pjʊɹ laɪf ə seɪɾɪn sipt ɪndə hɪm, ɹæŋk ɹʌnəlz ðət wəd bɹɪŋ mædnəs ən dɛθ.

The Power roared in Rand, and the filth tarnishing the pure life of saidin seeped into him, rank runnels that would bring madness and death.

kædzueɪn ɡæðɝd ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɝaʊn hɝ, ən əliviə ən ðə si foʊk wɪndfɪndɝ, tu. hɑɹɪn ɡɹʌmbəld laʊdli əbaʊt biɪŋ ɪkskluɾəd, əntɪl ə fɪŋɡɝ pɔɪntəd baɪ kædzueɪn sɛn əɹ stɔkɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə hɪltɑp. moʊd, ɪn ɪz ɑd blu kwɪltɪd koʊt, sæt hɑɹɪn daʊn ɑn ən aʊtkɹɑp, ən tɔk suðɪŋli, ðoʊ səmtaɪmz ɪz aɪz wɛn tə ðə sɝaʊndɪŋ tʃɹiz, ən ðən i slɪɾ ə hæn əlɔŋ ðə lɔŋ aɪvɝi hɪlt ə hɪz sɔɹd. dʒɑhɹ əpɪɹd fɹəm ðə dɝɛkʃən ə ðə hɔɹsəz, stʃɹɪpɪŋ ðə klɔθ ɹæpɪŋz fɹəm kælændɝ. ðə kɹɪstəl sɔɹd, wɪð ɪts lɔŋ klɪɹ hɪlt ən slaɪtli kɝvɪŋ bleɪd, spɑɹkəld ɪn ðə peɪl sʌnlaɪt. əɾ ən ɪmpɪɹiəs dʒɛstʃɝ fɹəm mɛɹaɪs, hi kwɪkən ɪz stɛp tə dʒɔɪn hɝ. deɪmɝ wɑz ɪn ðət ɡɹup, tu, ən ɛbən. kædzueɪn hæd nɑɾ æsk tə juz kælændɝ. ðət kəd pæs. fəɹ naʊ, ɪt kʊd.

Cadsuane gathered the Aes Sedai around her, and Alivia and the Sea Folk Windfinder, too. Harine grumbled loudly about being excluded, until a finger pointed by Cadsuane sent her stalking across the hilltop. Moad, in his odd blue quilted coat, sat Harine down on an outcrop, and talked soothingly, though sometimes his eyes went to the surrounding trees, and then he slid a hand along the long ivory hilt of his sword. Jahar appeared from the direction of the horses, stripping the Cloth wrappings from Callandor. The crystal sword, with its long clear hilt and slightly curving blade, sparkled in the pale sunlight. At an imperious gesture from Merise, he quickened his step to join her. Damer was in that group, too, and Eben. Cadsuane had not asked to use Callandor. That could pass. For now, it could.

"ðæt wʊmən kəd tʃɹaɪ ə stoʊnz peɪʃəns!" nɪneɪiv mʌɾɝd, stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ ʌp tə ɹænd. wɪð wʌn hænd, ʃi hɛl ðə skɹɪps stʃɹæp fɝmli ɑn əɹ ʃoʊldɝ, waɪl ði ʌðɝ wɑz dʒʌst əz fɝmli ɝaʊn ðə θɪk bɹeɪd hæŋɪŋ fɹəm əɹ kaʊl. "tə ðə pɪɾ ə dum wɪð hɝ, ðæts wʌɾ aɪ seɪ! ɑɹ jə ʃʊɹ mɪn kʊdn bi ɹɔŋ dʒʌs ðɪs wʌns? wɛl, aɪ səpoʊz nɑt. bʌt stɪl . . . ! wɪl jə stɑp smaɪlɪŋ laɪk ðæt? jud meɪk ə kæt nɝvəs!"

"That woman could try a stone's patience!" Nynaeve muttered, striding up to Rand. With one hand, she held the scrip's strap firmly on her shoulder, while the other was just as firmly around the thick braid hanging from her cowl. "To the Pit of Doom with her, that's what I say! Are you sure Min couldn't be wrong just this once? Well, I suppose not. But still . . . ! Will you stop smiling like that? You'd make a cat nervous!"

"wi maɪɾ əz wɛl bɪɡɪn," hi toʊl hɝ, ən ʃi blɪŋkt.

"We might as well begin," he told her, and she blinked.

"ʃʊdnt wi weɪɾ ɑn kædzueɪn?" noʊ wʌn wəd səspɛkt ʃi hæd bɪn kəmpleɪnɪŋ əbaʊt ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ə moʊmən ɝliɝ. ɪf ɛniθɪŋ, ʃi saʊndəɾ æŋkʃəs nɑt tə əpsɛt hɝ.

"Shouldn't we wait on Cadsuane?" No one would suspect she had been complaining about the Aes Sedai a moment earlier. If anything, she sounded anxious not to upset her.

"ʃi wɪl də wʌt ʃɪl du, nɪneɪiv. wɪð jəɹ hɛlp, əl də wʌɾ aɪ mʌst."

"She will do what she will do, Nynaeve. With your help, I will do what I must."

stɪl ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, klʌtʃɪŋ ðə skɹɪp tə hɝ tʃɛst ən kæstɪŋ wɝid ɡlænsɪz ɪn ðə dɝɛkʃən ə ðə wɪmən ɡæðɝɾ ɝaʊn kædzueɪn. əliviə lɛf ðət ɡɹup ən hɝid təwɔɹɾ əm əkɹɔs ði ənivən ɡɹaʊn hoʊldɪŋ əɹ kloʊk kloʊzd wɪð boʊθ hænz.

Still she hesitated, clutching the scrip to her chest and casting worried glances in the direction of the women gathered around Cadsuane. Alivia left that group and hurried toward them across the uneven ground holding her cloak closed with both hands.

"kædzueɪn sɛz aɪ mʌst əv ðə tɛɹæŋɡɹil, nɪneɪiv," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn ðət sɑf sintʃæn dʒɹɔl. "naʊ doʊn ɑɹɡju; ðəɹ ɪzən taɪm. bɪsaɪdz, ðeɪ ɑɹ noʊ ɡʊd tə jə ɪf jəɹ gɑnə bi lɪŋk tə hɪm."

"Cadsuane says I must have the ter'angreal, Nynaeve," she said in that soft Seanchan drawl. "Now don't argue; there isn't time. Besides, they are no good to you if you're going to be linked to him."
