Verin and the Sea Folk woman were sitting beside the cloak-covered form of Kumira, their lips moving silently in prayers for her soul, and Nesune was trying awkwardly to comfort a weeping Daigian, who cradled young Eben's corpse in her arms and rocked him like a baby. Greens were used to that sort of thing, but Cadsuane did not like losing two of her people in return for no more than a few singed Forsaken and one dead renegade.

"ɪts klin," dʒɑhɹ sɛd sɔfli jɛɾ əɡɛn. ðɪs taɪm, mɛɹaɪs wɑz ðə wʌn sɪɾɪŋ, wɪð ɪz hɛd ɹɛstɪŋ ɪn əɹ læp. hɝ blu aɪz wɝ əz stɝn əz ɛvɝ, bʌt ʃi stʃɹoʊkt ɪz blæk hɛɹ dʒɛnli. "ɪts klin."

"It's clean," Jahar said softly yet again. This time, Merise was the one sitting, with his head resting in her lap. Her blue eyes were as stern as ever, but she stroked his black hair gently. "It's clean."

kædzueɪn ɪkstʃeɪnʒd lʊks wɪð mɛɹaɪs oʊvɝ ðə bɔɪz hɛd. deɪmɝ ən dʒɑhɹ boʊθ sɛd ðə seɪm θɪŋ, ðə teɪnt wɑz ɡɔn, bʌt haʊ kəd ðeɪ bi ʃʊɹ səm skɹæp dɪd nɑt ɹɪmeɪn? mɛɹaɪs hæɾ əlaʊɾ əɹ tə lɪŋk wɪð ðə bɔɪ, ən ʃi kəd nɑt fil ɛniθɪŋ laɪk wʌt ði ʌðɝ ɡɹin hæd dɪskɹaɪbd, jɛt haʊ kəd ðeɪ bi sɝɾən? seɪɾɪn wɑz soʊ eɪliən ðəɾ ɛniθɪŋ kəd bi hɪɾən ɪn ðət mæd keɪɑs.

Cadsuane exchanged looks with Merise over the boy's head. Damer and Jahar both said the same thing, the taint was gone, but how could they be sure some scrap did not remain? Merise had allowed her to link with the boy, and she could not feel anything like what the other Green had described, yet how could they be certain? Saidin was so alien that anything could be hidden in that mad chaos.

"aɪ wɑnə liv əz sun əz ðə ɹɛst ə ðə wɔɹɾɝz ɹɪtɝn," ʃi ənaʊnst. ðəɹ wɝ tu mɛni kwɛstʃənz fəɹ wɪtʃ ʃi hæd noʊ ænsɝz tə sut hɝ, bʌt ʃi hæd jʌŋ ælθɹ naʊ, ən ʃi dɪd nɑɾ ɪntɛn tə luz hɪm.

"I want to leave as soon as the rest of the Warders return," she announced. There were too many questions for which she had no answers to suit her, but she had young al'Thor now, and she did not intend to lose him.

naɪt fɛl. ɑn ðə hɪltɑp, ðə wɪn blu dʌst əkɹɔs ðə fɹæɡməns ʌv wʌt hæd wʌns bɪn ə tɛɹæŋɡɹil. bɪloʊ leɪ ðə tum ə ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ, oʊpən tə ɡɪv ðə wɝl hoʊp. ən ɑn dɪstən tʃɹɛmælkɪŋ, ðə wɝd bɪɡæn tə spɹɛd ðət ðə taɪm ʌv ɪluʒənz wɑz əɾ ən ɛnd.

Night fell. On the hilltop, the wind blew dust across the fragments of what had once been a ter'angreal. Below lay the tomb of Shadar Logoth, open to give the world hope. And on distant Tremalking, the word began to spread that the Time of Illusions was at an end.

ði ɛn ə ðə naɪnθ bʊk ə ðə wil ə taɪm ɡlɔsɝi eɪ noʊɾ ɑn deɪts ɪn ðɪs ɡlɔsɝi. ðə toʊmən kæləndɝ (dɪvaɪz baɪ toʊmə dɝ ɑməd) wɑz ədɑptəɾ əpɹɑksəmətli tu sɛntʃɝiz æftɝ ðə dɛθ ə ðə læs meɪl ɛɛs sədaɪ, ɹəkɔɹɾɪŋ jɪɹz æftɝ ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld (æb). soʊ mɛni ɹɛkɝdz wɝ dɪstʃɹɔɪɾ ɪn ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz ðəɾ ət ðɛɹ ɛn ðəɹ wɑz ɑɹɡjəmən əbaʊt ði ɪɡzæk jɪɹ ʌndɝ ði oʊl sɪstəm. ə nu kæləndɝ, pɹəpoʊz baɪ tiəm ʌv ɡɑzɹ, sɛləbɹeɪɾəd fɹiɾəm fɹəm ðə tʃɹɑlɑk θɹɛɾ ən ɹəkɔɹɾəd itʃ jɪɹ əz ə fɹi jɪɹ (fi). ðə ɡɑzɝən kæləndɝ ɡeɪnd waɪɾ æksɛptəns wɪðɪn twɛnti jɪɹz æftɝ ðə wɔɹz' ɛnd. ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ ətɛmptəd tə ɪstæblɪʃ ə nu kæləndɝ beɪst ɑn ðə faʊndɪŋ ə hɪz ɛmpaɪɝ (, fɹəm ðə faʊndɪŋ), bʌɾ oʊnli hɪstɔɹiənz naʊ ɹəfɝ tə ɪt. æftɝ ðə dɛθ ən dɪstʃɹʌkʃən ə ðə wɔɹ ə ðə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz, ə θɝd kæləndɝ wɑz dɪvaɪz baɪ ɝɛn dɪn dʒubaɪ sɔɹɪŋ ɡʌl, ə skɑlɝ ə ðə si foʊk, ən pɹɑməlɡeɪɾəd baɪ ðə pɑnɑɹtʃ fɛɹiɾ ə tæɹɑbən. ðə fɛɹid kæləndɝ, deɪɾɪŋ fɹəm ði ɑɹbɪtʃɹɛɹəli dɪsaɪɾɪd ɛn ə ðə wɔɹ ə ðə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz ən ɹəkɔɹɾɪŋ jɪɹz ə ðə nu ɛɹə (nəbɹæskə), ɪz kɝənli ɪn jus.

The End of the Ninth Book of The Wheel of Time GLOSSARY A Note on Dates in This Glossary. The Toman Calendar (devised by Toma dur Ahmid) was adopted approximately two centuries after the death of the last male Aes Sedai, recording years After the Breaking of the World (AB). So many records were destroyed in the Trolloc Wars that at their end there was argument about the exact year under the old system. A new calendar, proposed by Tiam of Gazar, celebrated freedom from the Trolloc threat and recorded each year as a Free Year (FY). The Gazaran Calendar gained wide acceptance within twenty years after the Wars' end. Artur Hawkwing attempted to establish a new calendar based on the founding of his empire (FF, From the Founding), but only historians now refer to it. After the death and destruction of the War of the Hundred Years, a third calendar was devised by Uren din Jubai Soaring Gull, a scholar of the Sea Folk, and promulgated by the Panarch Farede of Tarabon. The Farede Calendar, dating from the arbitrarily decided end of the War of the Hundred Years and recording years of the New Era (NE), is currently in use.

ɑɹmmɪn: soʊlʒɝz u oʊ əlidʒəns əɹ fiəlti tə ə pɝtɪkjəlɝ lɔɹɾ əɹ leɪɾi.

armsmen: Soldiers who owe allegiance or fealty to a particular lord or lady.

æʃəmən: (wʌn) ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "ɡɑɹɾiən" əɹ "ɡɑɹɾiənz," bʌɾ ɔlweɪz ə ɡɑɹɾiən ə dʒʌstəs ən tʃɹuθ. (tu) ðə neɪm ɡɪvən, boʊθ kəlɛktɪvli ən əz ə ɹæŋk, tə ðə mɛn u hæv kʌm tə ðə blæk taʊɝ, nɪɹ keɪɛmlɪn ɪn ændɝ, ɪn ɔɹɾɝ tə lɝn tə tʃænəl. ðɛɹ tʃɹeɪnɪŋ kɑnsəntʃɹeɪts ɑn ðə weɪz ɪn wɪtʃ ðə wʌn paʊɝ kən bi juzd əz ə wɛpən, ən ɪn ənʌðɝ dɪpɑɹtʃɝ fɹəm ðə jusədʒəz ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ, wʌns ðeɪ lɝn tə siz seɪɾɪn, ðə meɪl hæf ə ðə paʊɝ, ðeɪ ɑɹ ɹikwaɪɝd tə pɝfɔɹm ɔl tʃɔɹz ən leɪbɝz wɪð ðə paʊɝ. wən nuli ɛnɹoʊld, ə mæn ɪz tɝmd ə soʊlʒɝ; hi wɛɹz ə pleɪn blæk koʊt wɪð ə haɪ kɑlɝ, ɪn ði ændɔɝən fæʃən. biɪŋ ɹeɪz tə dɛɾəkeɪtəd bɹɪŋz ðə ɹaɪt tə wɛɹ ə sɪlvɝ pɪn, kɔl ðə sɔɹd, ɑn ðə kɑlɝ ə hɪz koʊt. pɹəmoʊʃən tə æʃəmən bɹɪŋz ðə ɹaɪt tə wɛɹ ə dʒɹæɡən pɪn, ɪn ɡoʊld ən ɹɛɾ ɪnæməl, ɑn ðə kɑlɝ ɑpəzət ðə sɔɹd. ɔlðoʊ mɛni wɪmən, ɪnkluɾɪŋ waɪvz, fli wən ðeɪ lɝn ðət ðɛɹ mɛn æktʃəli  kən tʃænəl, ə fɛɹ nʌmbɝ ə mɛn ət ðə blæk taʊɝ ɑɹ mɛɹid, ən ðeɪ juz ə vɝʒən ə ðə wɔɹɾɝ bɑn tə kɹieɪɾ ə lɪŋk wɪð ðɛɹ waɪvz. ðɪs seɪm bɑnd, ɔltɝd tə kəmpɛl oʊbiɾiəns, hæz ɹisənli bɪn juz tə bɑn kæptʃɝɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ əz wɛl.

Asha'man: (1) In the Old Tongue, "Guardian" or "Guardians," but always a guardian of justice and truth. (2) The name given, both collectively and as a rank, to the men who have come to the Black Tower, near Caemlyn in Andor, in order to learn to channel. Their training concentrates on the ways in which the One Power can be used as a weapon, and in another departure from the usages of the White Tower, once they learn to seize saidin, the male half of the Power, they are required to perform all chores and labors with the Power. When newly enrolled, a man is termed a Soldier; he wears a plain black coat with a high collar, in the Andoran fashion. Being raised to Dedicated brings the right to wear a silver pin, called the Sword, on the collar of his coat. Promotion to Asha'man brings the right to wear a Dragon pin, in gold and red enamel, on the collar opposite the Sword. Although many women, including wives, flee when they learn that their men actually can channel, a fair number of men at the Black Tower are married, and they use a version of the Warder bond to create a link with their wives. This same bond, altered to compel obedience, has recently been used to bond captured Aes Sedai as well.

beɪlwɝ, sɛbæn: fɔɹmɝli peɪdʒɹən naɪlz sɛkɹətɛɹi, ɪn pʌblɪk, ən sikɹɪtli naɪlz spaɪmæstɝ. hi eɪɾəd mɔɹɡeɪsəz ɪskeɪp fɹəm ðə sintʃæn ɪn æmədɔɹ fəɹ ɪz oʊn ɹizənz, ən naʊ ɪz ɛmplɔɪɾ əz sɛkɹətɛɹi tə pɛɹɪn tæʃɪɹ eɪbɑɹə ən feɪl ni bæʃɪɹ teɪbɑɹə.

Balwer, Sebban: Formerly Pedron Niall's secretary, in public, and secretly Niall's spymaster. He aided Morgase's escape from the Seanchan in Amador for his own reasons, and now is employed as secretary to Perrin t'Bashere Aybara and Faile ni Bashere t'Aybara.

blʌd, ðə: tɝm juz baɪ ðə sintʃæn tə dɛzəɡneɪt ðə noʊbɪləɾi. wʌn kən bi ɹeɪz tə ðə blʌɾ əz wɛl əz bɔɹn tə ɪt.

Blood, the: Term used by the Seanchan to designate the nobility. One can be raised to the Blood as well as born to it.

tʃɑ feɪl: (wʌn) ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "ðə fælkənz tælən." (tu) neɪm teɪkən baɪ ðə jʌŋ kɛɹhinɪn ən tɛɹənz, ətɛmptəd fɑloʊɝz ə dʒiɾoʊ, hu hæv swɔɹn fiəlti tə feɪl ni bæʃɪɹ teɪbɑɹə. ɪn sikɹət, ðeɪ ækt əz əɹ pɝsənəl skaʊts ən spaɪz.

Cha Faile: (1) In the Old Tongue, "the Falcon's Talon." (2) Name taken by the young Cairhienin and Tairens, attempted followers of ji'e'toh, who have sworn fealty to Faile ni Bashere t'Aybara. In secret, they act as her personal scouts and spies.

kəmpænjənz, ðə: ði ɪlit mɪlətɛɹi fɔɹmeɪʃən ʌv ɪɪliən, kɝənli kəmændəd baɪ fɝs kæptən dɛmiɾɝ mɑɹkəlɪn. ðə kəmpænjənz pɹəvaɪɾ ə bɑɾiɡɑɹd fəɹ ðə kɪŋ ʌv ɪljən ən ɡɑɹd ki pɔɪns ɝaʊn ðə neɪʃən. ədɪʃənəli, ðə kəmpænjənz əv tʃɹədɪʃənəli bɪn juzd ɪn bæɾəl tə əsɔl ði ɛnəmiz stʃɹɔŋɡəs pəzɪʃənz, tə ɪksplɔɪt wiknəsəz, ænd, ɪf nɛsəsɛɹi, tə kʌvɝ ðə ɹitʃɹiɾ ə ðə kɪŋ. ənlaɪk moʊst ʌðɝ sətʃ ɪlit fɔɹmeɪʃənz, fɔɹənɝz (ɛksɛptɪŋ tɛɹənz, ɔltɑɹənz ən mʊɹændiənz) ɑɹ nɑɾ oʊnli wɛlkəm, ðeɪ kən ɹaɪz ivən tə ðə haɪəst ɹæŋk, əz kən kɑmənɝz, wɪtʃ ɔlsoʊ ɪz ənjuʒəwəl. ðə junəfɔɹm ə ðə kəmpænjənz kənsɪsts ʌv ə ɡɹin koʊt, ə bɹɛstpleɪt wɝkt wɪð ðə naɪn biz ʌv ɪljən, ən ə kɑnɪkəl hɛlmət wɪð ə feɪsɡɑɹɾ ə stil bɑɹz. ðə fɝs kæptən wɛɹz fɔɹ ɹɪŋz ʌv ɡoʊldən bɹeɪɾ ɑn ðə kʌfs ə hɪz koʊt, ən θɹi θɪn ɡoʊldən plumz ɑn ɪz hɛlmət. ðə sɛkən kæptən wɛɹz θɹi ɹɪŋz ʌv ɡoʊldən bɹeɪɾ ɑn itʃ kʌf, ən θɹi ɡoʊldən plumz tɪpt wɪð ɡɹin. lutɛnəns wɛɹ tu jɛloʊ ɹɪŋz ɑn ðɛɹ kʌfs, ən tu θɪn ɡɹin plumz, ʌndɝ-lutɛnəns wʌn jɛloʊ ɹɪŋ ən ə sɪŋɡəl ɡɹin plum. bænɝmɪn ɑɹ dɛzɪɡneɪɾɪd baɪ tu bɹoʊkən ɹɪŋz ə jɛloʊ ɑn ðə kʌfs ən ə sɪŋɡəl jɛloʊ plum, skwədmən baɪ ə sɪŋɡəl bɹoʊkən ɹɪŋ ə jɛloʊ.

Companions, the: The elite military formation of IIlian, currently commanded by First Captain Demetre Marcolin. The Companions provide a bodyguard for the King of Illian and guard key points around the nation. Additionally, the Companions have traditionally been used in battle to assault the enemy's strongest positions, to exploit weaknesses, and, if necessary, to cover the retreat of the King. Unlike most other such elite formations, foreigners (excepting Tairens, Altarans and Murandians) are not only welcome, they can rise even to the highest rank, as can commoners, which also is unusual. The uniform of the Companions consists of a green coat, a breastplate worked with the Nine Bees of Illian, and a conical helmet with a faceguard of steel bars. The First Captain wears four rings of golden braid on the cuffs of his coat, and three thin golden plumes on his helmet. The Second Captain wears three rings of golden braid on each cuff, and three golden plumes tipped with green. Lieutenants wear two yellow rings on their cuffs, and two thin green plumes, under-lieutenants one yellow ring and a single green plume. Bannermen are designated by two broken rings of yellow on the cuffs and a single yellow plume, squadmen by a single broken ring of yellow.

kənsɑlədeɪʃən, ðə: wən ði ɑɹmiz sɛn baɪ ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ ʌndɝ ɪz sʌn luthɛɹ lændəɾ ɪn sintʃæn, ðeɪ dɪskʌvɝɾ ə ʃɪftɪŋ kwɪlt ə neɪʃənz ɔfən ət wɔɹ wɪð wʌn ənʌðɝ, wɛɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ ɔfən ɹeɪnd. wɪθaʊɾ ɛni ɪkwɪvələn ə ðə waɪt taʊɝ, ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝk fəɹ ðɛɹ oʊn ɪndəvɪdʒəwəl paʊɝ, juzɪŋ ðə paʊɝ. fɔɹmɪŋ smɔl ɡɹups, ðeɪ skimd əɡɛnst wʌn ənʌðɝ kɑnstənli. ɪn lɑɹdʒ pɑɹɾ ɪt wɑz ðɪs kɑnstən skimɪŋ fəɹ pɝsənəl ædvæntɪdʒ ən ðə ɹɪzʌltɪŋ wɔɹz əmʌŋ ðə mɪɹiəd neɪʃənz ðəɾ əlaʊd ði ɑɹmiz fɹəm ist ə ði ɛɹɪθ oʊʃən tə bɪɡɪn ðə kɑŋkwɛst ʌv ən ɪntaɪɝ kɑntənənt, ən fəɹ ðɛɹ dɪsɛndəns tə kəmpliɾ ɪt. ðɪs kɑŋkwɛst, dʊɹɪŋ wɪtʃ ðə dɪsɛndəns ə ði ɝɪdʒənəl ɑɹmiz bɪkeɪm sintʃæn əz mʌtʃ əz ðeɪ kɑŋkɝd sintʃæn, tʊk mɔɹ ðən naɪn hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz ən ɪz kɔl ðə kənsɑlədeɪʃən.

Consolidation, the: When the armies sent by Artur Hawkwing under his son Luthair landed in Seanchan, they discovered a shifting quilt of nations often at war with one another, where Aes Sedai often reigned. Without any equivalent of the White Tower, Aes Sedai worked for their own individual power, using the Power. Forming small groups, they schemed against one another constantly. In large part it was this constant scheming for personal advantage and the resulting wars among the myriad nations that allowed the armies from east of the Aryth Ocean to begin the conquest of an entire continent, and for their descendants to complete it. This conquest, during which the descendants of the original armies became Seanchan as much as they conquered Seanchan, took more than nine hundred years and is called the Consolidation.

kɔɝɪn: ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "ðə ɹɪtɝn:" ðə neɪm ɡɪvən baɪ ðə sintʃæn boʊθ tə ðə fliɾ ə θaʊzənz ə ʃɪps ən tə ðə hʌnʒɹədz ə θaʊzənz ə soʊlʒɝz, kɹæfsmən ən ʌðɝz kæɹid baɪ ðoʊz ʃɪps, hu wɪl kʌm bɪhaɪn ðə fɔɹʌnɝz tə ɹikleɪm ðə lænz stoʊlən fɹəm ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋz dɪsɛndəns. si ɔlsoʊ fɔɹʌnɝz.

Corenne: In the Old Tongue, "the Return:" The name given by the Seanchan both to the fleet of thousands of ships and to the hundreds of thousands of soldiers, craftsmen and others carried by those ships, who will come behind the Forerunners to reclaim the lands stolen from Artur Hawkwing's descendants. See also Forerunners.

dɔɾɝz ə saɪləns, ðə: dʊɹɪŋ ðə hɪstɝi ʌv ðə waɪt taʊɝ (oʊvɝ θɹi θaʊzən jɪɹz), vɛɹiəs wɪmən u hæv bɪn pʊɾ aʊɾ əv bɪn ənwɪlɪŋ tə æksɛp ðɛɹ feɪts ən əv tʃɹaɪd tə bæn təɡɛðɝ. sətʃ ɡɹups - moʊst ə ðɛm baɪ fɑɹ, ət list - hæv bɪn dɪspɝs baɪ ðə waɪt taʊɝ əz sun əz faʊn ən pʌnɪʃt səvɪɹli ən pʌblɪkli tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ðət ðə lɛsən ɪz kæɹid tə ɛvɹiwʌn. ðə læst ɡɹup tə bi dɪspɝs kɔl ðɛmsɛlvz ðə dɔɾɝz ə saɪləns (sɛvənnaɪnfɔɹ-sɛvənhʌnʒɹədnaɪntieɪt ni). ðə dɔɾɝz kənsɪstəɾ ə tu æksɛptɪɾ u hæd bɪn pʊɾ aʊɾ ə ðə taʊɝ ən twɛnti-θɹi wɪmən ðeɪ hæd ɡæðɝɾ ən tʃɹeɪnd. ɔl wɝ kæɹid bæk tə tɑɹ vəlɑn ən pʌnɪʃt, ən ðə twɛnti-θɹi wɝ ɛnɹoʊld ɪn ðə nɑvəs bʊk. oʊnli wʌn ə ðoʊz mænədʒ tə ɹitʃ ðə ʃɔl. si ɔlsoʊ kɪn, ðə.

Daughters of Silence, the: During the history of the White Tower (over three thousand years), various women who have been put out have been unwilling to accept their fates and have tried to band together. Such groups - most of them by far, at least - have been dispersed by the White Tower as soon as found and punished severely and publicly to make sure that the lesson is carried to everyone. The last group to be dispersed called themselves the Daughters of Silence (794-798 NE). The Daughters consisted of two Accepted who had been put out of the Tower and twenty-three women they had gathered and trained. All were carried back to Tar Valon and punished, and the twenty-three were enrolled in the novice book. Only one of those managed to reach the shawl. See also Kin, the.

dækoʊvæl: (wʌn) ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "wʌn u ɪz oʊnd," əɹ "pɝsən u ɪz pɹɑpɝɾi." (tu) əmʌŋ ðə sintʃæn, ðə tɝm ɔfən juzd, əlɔŋ wɪð pɹɑpɝɾi, fəɹ sleɪvz. sleɪvɝi hæz ə lɔŋ ən ənjuʒəwəl hɪstɝi əmʌŋ ðə sintʃæn, wɪð sleɪvz hævɪŋ ði əbɪləɾi tə ɹaɪz tə pəzɪʃənz ʌv ɡɹeɪt paʊɝ ən oʊpən əθɔɹəɾi, ɪnkluɾɪŋ oʊvɝ ðoʊz u ɑɹ fɹi. si ɔlsoʊ sɔɪhɪn.

da'covale: (1) In the Old Tongue, "one who is owned," or "person who is property." (2) Among the Seanchan, the term often used, along with property, for slaves. Slavery has a long and unusual history among the Seanchan, with slaves having the ability to rise to positions of great power and open authority, including over those who are free. See also so'jhin.

dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹdz, ðə: ði ɪlit mɪlətɛɹi fɔɹmeɪʃən ə ðə sintʃæn ɛmpaɪɝ, ɪnkluɾɪŋ boʊθ hjumənz ən oʊɡiɝ. ðə hjumən mɛmbɝz ə ðə dɛθwɑtʃ ɡɑɹɾ ɑɹ ɔl dækoʊvæl, bɔɹn əz pɹɑpɝɾi ən tʃoʊzən waɪl jʌŋ tə sɝv ði ɛmpɹɛs, huz pɝsənəl pɹɑpɝɾi ðeɪ ɑɹ. fənæɾɪkəli lɔɪəl ən fɪɹsli pɹaʊd, ðeɪ ɔfən dɪspleɪ ðə ɹeɪvənz tætuɾ ɑn ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz, ðə mɑɹk ʌv ə dækoʊvæl ə ði ɛmpɹɛs. ðə hɛlməts ən ɑɹmɝ ɑɹ lækɝɾ ɪn dɑɹk ɡɹin ən blʌd-ɹɛd, ðɛɹ ʃilz ɑɹ lækɝd blæk, ən ðɛɹ spɪɹz ən sɔɹdz kæɹi blæk tæsəlz. si ɔlsoʊ dækoʊvæl.

Deathwatch Guards, the: The elite military formation of the Seanchan Empire, including both humans and Ogier. The human members of the Deathwatch Guard are all da'covale, born as property and chosen while young to serve the Empress, whose personal property they are. Fanatically loyal and fiercely proud, they often display the ravens tattooed on their shoulders, the mark of a da'covale of the Empress. The helmets and armor are lacquered in dark green and blood-red, their shields are lacquered black, and their spears and swords carry black tassels. See also da'covale.

dɪfɛndɝz ə ðə stoʊn, ðə: ði ɪlit mɪlətɛɹi fɔɹmeɪʃən ə tɛɹ. ðə kɝən kæptən ə ðə stoʊn (kəmændɝ ə ðə dɪfɛndɝz) ɪz ɹɑdʒɹəvɑɹ taɪhɛɹə. oʊnli tɛɹənz ɑɹ æksɛptɪɾ ɪndə ðə dɪfɛndɝz, ən ɔfəsɝz ɑɹ juʒəwəli ʌv noʊbəl bɝθ, ðoʊ ɔfən fɹəm maɪnɝ haʊsəz əɹ maɪnɝ bɹæntʃəz ə stʃɹɔŋ haʊzɪz. ðə dɪfɛndɝz ɑɹ tæsk tə hoʊl ðə ɡɹeɪt fɔɹtʃɹəs kɔl ðə stoʊn ə tiɹ, ɪn ðə sɪɾi ʌv tiɹ, tə dɪfɛn ðə sɪɾi, ən tə pɹəvaɪd pəlis sɝvəsəz ɪn pleɪs ʌv ɛni sɪɾi wɑtʃ əɹ ðə laɪk. ɪksɛpt ɪn taɪmz ʌv wɔɹ, ðɛɹ duɾiz sɛldəm teɪk əm fɑɹ fɹəm ðə sɪɾi. ðɛn, əz wɪð ʌðɝ ɪlit fɔɹmeɪʃənz, ðeɪ ɑɹ ðə kɔɹ ɝaʊnd wɪtʃ ði ɑɹmi ɪz fɔɹmd. ðə junəfɔɹm ə ðə dɪfɛndɝz kənsɪsts ʌv ə blæk koʊt wɪð pæɾəd slivz stʃɹaɪp blæk-ænd-ɡoʊld wɪð blæk kʌfs, ə bɝnɪʃt bɹɛstpleɪt, ən ə ɹɪm hɛlmət wɪð ə feɪsɡɑɹɾ ə stil bɑɹz. ðə kæptən ə ðə stoʊn wɛɹz θɹi ʃɔɹt waɪt plumz ɑn ɪz hɛlmət, ən ɑn ðə kʌfs ə hɪz koʊt θɹi ɪntɝtwaɪnd ɡoʊldən bɹeɪdz ɑn ə waɪt bænd. kæptənz wɛɹ tu waɪt plumz ən ə sɪŋɡəl laɪn ʌv ɡoʊldən bɹeɪɾ ɑn waɪt kʌfs, lutɛnəns wʌn waɪt plum ən ə sɪŋɡəl laɪn ə blæk bɹeɪɾ ɑn waɪt kʌfs ən ʌndɝ-lutɛnəns wʌn ʃɔɹt blæk plum ən pleɪn waɪt kʌfs. bænɝmɪn əv ɡoʊld-kʌlɝd kʌfs ɑn ðɛɹ koʊts, ən skwədmən əv kʌfs stʃɹaɪp blæk-ænd-ɡoʊld.

Defenders of the Stone, the: The elite military formation of Tear. The current Captain of the Stone (commander of the Defenders) is Rodrivar Tihera. Only Tairens are accepted into the Defenders, and officers are usually of noble birth, though often from minor Houses or minor branches of strong Houses. The Defenders are tasked to hold the great fortress called the Stone of Tear, in the city of Tear, to defend the city, and to provide police services in place of any City Watch or the like. Except in times of war, their duties seldom take them far from the city. Then, as with other elite formations, they are the core around which the army is formed. The uniform of the Defenders consists of a black coat with padded sleeves striped black-and-gold with black cuffs, a burnished breastplate, and a rimmed helmet with a faceguard of steel bars. The Captain of the Stone wears three short white plumes on his helmet, and on the cuffs of his coat three intertwined golden braids on a white band. Captains wear two white plumes and a single line of golden braid on white cuffs, lieutenants one white plume and a single line of black braid on white cuffs and under-lieutenants one short black plume and plain white cuffs. Bannermen have gold-colored cuffs on their coats, and squadmen have cuffs striped black-and-gold.

dɛlvɪŋ: (wʌn) ði əbɪləɾi tə juz ðə wʌn paʊɝ tə daɪəɡnoʊs fɪzɪkəl kəndɪʃən ən ɪlnəs. (tu) ði əbɪləɾi tə faɪn dəpɑzɪts ə mɛɾəl ɔɹz wɪð ðə wʌn paʊɝ. ðət ðɪs əz lɔŋ bɪn ə lɔst əbɪləɾi əmʌŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ meɪ əkaʊn fəɹ ðə neɪm bɪkʌmɪŋ ətætʃt tə ənʌðɝ əbɪləɾi.

Delving: (1) The ability to use the One Power to diagnose physical condition and illness. (2) The ability to find deposits of metal ores with the One Power. That this has long been a lost ability among Aes Sedai may account for the name becoming attached to another ability.

dɝmɝæt-: (wʌn) ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "mæstɝ hænlɝ." (tu) əmʌŋ ðə sintʃæn, ðə sʌfɪks əplaɪd tə ɪndəkeɪɾ ə sinjɝ ən haɪli skɪl hænlɝ ʌv wʌn ə ði ɛɡzɑɾɪks, wʌn u tʃɹeɪnz ʌðɝz, əz ɪn dɝmɝətʃɹeɪkən. dɝmɝæt kən əv ə fɛɹli haɪ soʊʃəl stæɾəs, ðə haɪəst ʌv ɔl hɛl baɪ dɝsʌldəm, ðə tʃɹeɪnɝz ə sʌldəm, hu ɹæŋk wɪð fɛɹli haɪ mɪlətɛɹi ɔfəsɝz. si ɔlsoʊ mɔɝæt.

der'morat-: (1) In the Old Tongue, "master handler." (2) Among the Seanchan, the suffix applied to indicate a senior and highly skilled handler of one of the exotics, one who trains others, as in der'morat'raken. Der'morat can have a fairly high social status, the highest of all held by der'sul'dam, the trainers of sul'dam, who rank with fairly high military officers. See also morat.

feɪn, pdən: fɔɹmɝ dɑɹkfɹɛnd, naʊ mɔɹ ən wɝs ðən ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd, ən ən ɛnəmi ʌv ðə fɔɹseɪkən əz mʌtʃ əz hiz ə ɹænd ælθɹ, hum i heɪts wɪð ə pæʃən. læst sin juzɪŋ ðə neɪm dʒɛɹɑl mɔɹɾɪθ, ædvaɪzɪŋ lɔɹd tɔɹæm ɹieɪɾən ɪn ɪz ɹɪbɛljən əɡɛns ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn ɪn kɛɹhin.

Fain, Padan: Former Darkfriend, now more and worse than a Darkfriend, and an enemy of the Forsaken as much as he is of Rand al'Thor, whom he hates with a passion. Last seen using the name Jeraal Mordeth, advising Lord Toram Riatin in his rebellion against the Dragon Reborn in Cairhien.

fɪsts ə hɛvən, ðə: laɪtli ɑɹmd ən laɪtli ɑɹmɝd sintʃæn ɪnfəntʃɹi kæɹiɾ ɪndə bæɾəl ɑn ðə bæks ə ðə flaɪɪŋ kɹitʃɝz kɔl tɔɹeɪkən. ɔl ɑɹ smɔl mɛn, əɹ wɪmən, lɑɹdʒli kəz ə lɪməts əz tə haʊ mʌtʃ weɪɾ ə tɔɹeɪkən kən kæɹi fəɹ ɛni dɪstəns. kənsɪɾɝd tə bi əmʌŋ ðə tʌfəst soʊlʒɝz, ðeɪ ɑɹ juz pɹaɪmɛɹəli fəɹ ɹeɪdz, sɝpɹaɪz əsɔls ɑn pəzɪʃənz əɾ ən ɛnəmiz ɹɪɹ, ən wɛɹ spiɾ ɪn ɡɛɾɪŋ soʊlʒɝz ɪndə pleɪs ɪz ə ði ɛsəns.

Fists of Heaven, the: Lightly armed and lightly armored Seanchan infantry carried into battle on the backs of the flying creatures called to'raken. All are small men, or women, largely because of limits as to how much weight a to'raken can carry for any distance. Considered to be among the toughest soldiers, they are used primarily for raids, surprise assaults on positions at an enemy's rear, and where speed in getting soldiers into place is of the essence.

fɔɹʌnɝz, ðə: si heɪlin.

Forerunners, the: See Hailene.

fɔɹseɪkən, ðə: ðə neɪm ɡɪvən tə θɝtin paʊɝfəl ɛɛs sədaɪ, mɛn ən wɪmən boʊθ, hu wɛn oʊvɝ tə ðə ʃædoʊ dʊɹɪŋ ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz ən wɝ tʃɹæpt ɪn ðə silɪŋ ə ðə bɔɹ ɪndə ðə dɑɹk wʌnz pɹɪzən. waɪl ɪts lɔŋ bɪn bɪliv ðət ðeɪ əloʊn əbændən ðə laɪt dʊɹɪŋ ðə wɔɹ ə ðə ʃædoʊ, ɪn fækt ʌðɝz dɪɾ əz wɛl; ðiz θɝtin wɝ oʊnli ðə haɪəst ɹæŋkɪŋ əmʌŋ ðɛm. ðə fɔɹseɪkən (hu kɔl ðɛmsɛlvz ðə tʃoʊzən) ɑɹ sʌmwʌt ɹədust ɪn nʌmbɝ sɪns ðɛɹ əweɪkənɪŋ ɪn ðə pɹɛzən deɪ. ðə noʊn sɝvaɪvɝz ɑɹ dɪmɑndɝd, sɛmɝhɪdʒ, ɡɹeɪndəl, mɛsænə, mɑɡiɾin, ən tu hu wɝ ɹiɪnkɑɹneɪɾɪd ɪn nu bɑɾiz ən ɡɪvən nu neɪmz, oʊsɑnɡɝ ən ɝæŋɡɝ. ɹisənli, ə mæn kɔlɪŋ hɪmsɛlf mɔɹaɪɾɪn əz əpɪɹd, ən meɪ bi jɛɾ ənʌðɝ ə ðə dɛd fɔɹseɪkən bɹɔt bæk fɹəm ðə ɡɹeɪv baɪ ðə dɑɹk wʌn. ðə seɪm pɑsəbɪləɾi meɪ ɪɡzɪst ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ ðə wʊmən kɔlɪŋ hɝsɛlf sɪndeɪn, bʌt sɪns ɝæŋɡɝ wɑz ə mæn bɹɔt bæk əz ə wʊmən, spɛkjəleɪʃən əz tə ði aɪdɛntɪɾiz ə mɔɹaɪɾɪn ən sɪndeɪn meɪ pɹuv fjuɾəl əntɪl mɔɹ ɪz lɝnd.

Forsaken, the: The name given to thirteen powerful Aes Sedai, men and women both, who went over to the Shadow during the Age of Legends and were trapped in the sealing of the Bore into the Dark One's prison. While it has long been believed that they alone abandoned the Light during the War of the Shadow, in fact others did as well; these thirteen were only the highest ranking among them. The Forsaken (who call themselves the Chosen) are somewhat reduced in number since their awakening in the present day. The known survivors are Demandred, Semirhage, Graendal, Mesaana, Moghedien, and two who were reincarnated in new bodies and given new names, Osan'gar and Aran'gar. Recently, a man calling himself Moridin has appeared, and may be yet another of the dead Forsaken brought back from the grave by the Dark One. The same possibility may exist regarding the woman calling herself Cyndane, but since Aran'gar was a man brought back as a woman, speculation as to the identities of Moridin and Cyndane may prove futile until more is learned.

heɪlin: ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "fɔɹʌnɝz," əɹ "ðoʊz u kʌm bɪfɔɹ." ðə tɝm əplaɪd baɪ ðə sintʃæn tə ðə mæsɪv ɛkspədɪʃənɛɹi fɔɹs sɛn əkɹɔs ði ɛɹɪθ oʊʃən tə skaʊɾ aʊt ðə lænz wɛɹ ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ wʌns ɹuld. naʊ ʌndɝ ðə kəmæn ə ðə haɪ leɪɾi sjuɹɔθ, ɪts nʌmbɝz swoʊlən baɪ ɹəkɹuts fɹəm kɑŋkɝd lænz, ðə heɪlin əz ɡɔn fɑɹ bɪɑn ɪts ɝɪdʒənəl ɡoʊlz.

Hailene: In the Old Tongue, "Forerunners," or "Those Who Come Before." The term applied by the Seanchan to the massive expeditionary force sent across the Aryth Ocean to scout out the lands where Artur Hawkwing once ruled. Now under the command of the High Lady Suroth, its numbers swollen by recruits from conquered lands, the Hailene has gone far beyond its original goals.

hænlən, dɑvd: eɪ dɑɹkfɹɛnd, fɔɹmɝli kəmændɝ ə ðə waɪt laɪənz ɪn sɝvəs tə ðə fɔɹseɪkən ɹɑvɪn waɪl i hɛl keɪɛmlɪn juzɪŋ ðə neɪm lɔɹd ɡeɪbɹəl. fɹəm ðɛɹ, hænlən tʊk ðə waɪt laɪənz tə kɛɹhin ʌndɝ ɔɹɾɝz tə fɝðɝ ðə ɹɪbɛljən əɡɛns ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn. ðə waɪt laɪənz wɝ dɪstʃɹɔɪd baɪ ə "bʌbəl ʌv ivəl," ən hænlən əz bɪn ɔɹɾɝd bæk tə keɪɛmlɪn fəɹ pɝpəsəz əz jɛɾ ənnoʊn.

Hanlon, Daved: A Darkfriend, formerly commander of the White Lions in service to the Forsaken Rahvin while he held Caemlyn using the name Lord Gaebril. From there, Hanlon took the White Lions to Cairhien under orders to further the rebellion against the Dragon Reborn. The White Lions were destroyed by a "bubble of evil," and Hanlon has been ordered back to Caemlyn for purposes as yet unknown.

ɪʃɑɹə: ðə fɝs kwin ʌv ændɝ (sɝkə fi naɪnnaɪnfɔɹwʌnzɪɹoʊɾuzɪɹoʊ). ət ðə dɛθ ʌv ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ, ɪʃɑɹə kənvɪnst əɹ hʌzbənd, wʌn ə hɔkwɪŋz fɔɹmoʊs dʒɛnɝəlz, tə ɹeɪz ðə sidʒ ə tɑɹ vəlɑn ən əkʌmpəni hɝ tə keɪɛmlɪn wɪð əz mɛni soʊlʒɝz əz i kəd bɹeɪk əweɪ fɹəm ði ɑɹmi. wɛɹ ʌðɝz tʃɹaɪd tə siz ðə hoʊl ə hɔkwɪŋz ɛmpaɪɝ ən feɪld, ɪʃɑɹə tʊk ə fɝm hoʊld ɑn ə smɔl pɑɹɾ ən səksiɾəd. tədeɪ, nɪɹli ɛvɹi noʊbəl haʊs ɪn ændɝ kənteɪnz səm ʌv ɪʃɑɹəz blʌd, ən ðə ɹaɪt tə kleɪm ðə laɪən θɹoʊn dɪpɛnz boʊθ ɑn dɝɛk dɪsɛn fɹəm əɹ ən ɑn ðə nʌmbɝ ə laɪnz ə kənɛkʃən tə hɝ ðət kən bi ɪstæblɪʃt.

Ishara: The first Queen of Andor (circa FY 9941020). At the death of Artur Hawkwing, Ishara convinced her husband, one of Hawkwing's foremost generals, to raise the siege of Tar Valon and accompany her to Caemlyn with as many soldiers as he could break away from the army. Where others tried to seize the whole of Hawkwing's empire and failed, Ishara took a firm hold on a small part and succeeded. Today, nearly every noble House in Andor contains some of Ishara's blood, and the right to claim the Lion Throne depends both on direct descent from her and on the number of lines of connection to her that can be established.

kɪn, ðə: ivən dʊɹɪŋ ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz, mɔɹ ðən tu θaʊzən jɪɹz əɡoʊ (sɝkə wʌnzɪɹoʊzɪɹoʊzɪɹoʊwʌnθɹifaɪvzɪɹoʊ æb), ðə waɪt taʊɝ kəntɪnjud tə meɪnteɪn ɪts stændɝdz, pʊɾɪŋ aʊt wɪmən u feɪl tə mɛʒɝ ʌp. wʌn ɡɹup ə ðiz wɪmən, fɪɹɪŋ tə ɹɪtɝn hoʊm ɪn ðə mɪdst ə ðə wɔɹz, flɛd tə bɑɹɑʃtə (nɪɹ ðə pɹɛzənt-deɪ saɪɾ ʌv ɛbu dɑɹ), əz fɑɹ fɹəm ðə faɪɾɪŋ əz wɑz pɑsəbəl tə ɡoʊ ət ðət taɪm. kɔlɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz ðə kɪn, ən kɪnswɪmən, ðeɪ kɛpt ɪn haɪɾɪŋ ən ɔfɝɾ ə seɪf heɪvən fəɹ ʌðɝz u hæd bɪn pʊɾ aʊt. ɪn taɪm, ðɛɹ əpɹoʊtʃɪz tə wɪmən toʊl tə liv ðə taʊɝ lɛd tə kɑntæks wɪð ɹʌnəweɪz, ən waɪl ði ɪɡzækt ɹizənz meɪ nɛvɝ bi noʊn, ðə kɪn bɪɡæn tə æksɛpt ɹʌnəweɪz, əz wɛl. ðeɪ meɪd ɡɹeɪɾ ɛfɝts tə kip ðiz ɡɝlz fɹəm lɝnɪŋ ɛniθɪŋ əbaʊt ðə kɪn əntɪl ðeɪ wɝ ʃʊɹ ðəɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ wəd nɑt swup daʊn ən ɹiteɪk ðɛm. æftɝ ɔl, ɛvɹiwʌn nu ðət ɹʌnəweɪz wɝ ɔlweɪz kɑt sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ, ən ðə kɪn nu ðəɾ ənlɛs ðeɪ hɛl ðɛmsɛlvz sikɹət, ðeɪ ðɛmsɛlvz wəd bi pʌnɪʃt səvɪɹli.

Kin, the: Even during the Trolloc Wars, more than two thousand years ago (circa 10001350 AB), the White Tower continued to maintain its standards, putting out women who failed to measure up. One group of these women, fearing to return home in the midst of the wars, fled to Barashta (near the present-day site of Ebou Dar), as far from the fighting as was possible to go at that time. Calling themselves the Kin, and Kinswomen, they kept in hiding and offered a safe haven for others who had been put out. In time, their approaches to women told to leave the Tower led to contacts with runaways, and while the exact reasons may never be known, the Kin began to accept runaways, as well. They made great efforts to keep these girls from learning anything about the Kin until they were sure that Aes Sedai would not swoop down and retake them. After all, everyone knew that runaways were always caught sooner or later, and the Kin knew that unless they held themselves secret, they themselves would be punished severely.

ənnoʊn tə ðə kɪn, ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn ðə taʊɝ wɝ əwɛɹ ə ðɛɹ ɛɡzɪstəns ɔlmoʊs fɹəm ðə vɛɹi fɝst, bʌt pɹɑsəkjuʃən ə ðə wɔɹz lɛf noʊ taɪm fəɹ dilɪŋ wɪð ðɛm. baɪ ði ɛn ə ðə wɔɹz, ðə taʊɝ ɹilaɪz ðəɾ ɪt maɪt nɑt bi ɪn ðɛɹ bɛst ɪntʃɹəsts tə snʌf pʊt ðə kɪn. pɹaɪɝ tə ðət taɪm, ə mədʒɔɹəɾi ʌv ɹʌnəweɪz æktʃəli  hæd mænədʒ tə ɪskeɪp, wʌtɛvɝ ðə taʊɝz pɹɑpəɡændə, bʌt wʌns ðə kɪn bɪɡæn hɛlpɪŋ ðɛm, ðə taʊɝ nu ɪɡzækli wɛɹ ɛni ɹʌnəweɪ wɑz hɛɾɪŋ, ən ðeɪ bɪɡæn ɹəteɪkɪŋ naɪn aʊɾ ə tɛn. sɪns kɪnswɪmən muvd ɪn ən aʊɾ ə bɑɹɑʃtə (æn leɪɾɝ ɛbu dɑɹ) ɪn ən ɛfɝt tə haɪd ðɛɹ ɛɡzɪstəns ən ðɛɹ nʌmbɝz, nɛvɝ steɪɪŋ mɔɹ ðən tɛn jɪɹz lɛst sʌmwʌn noʊɾəs ðət ðeɪ dɪd nɑɾ eɪdʒ əɾ ə nɔɹməl spid, ðə taʊɝ bɪliv ðeɪ wɝ fju, ən ðeɪ sɝɾənli wɝ kipɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz loʊ. ɪn ɔɹɾɝ tə juz ðə kɪn əz ə tʃɹæp fəɹ ɹʌnəweɪz, ðə taʊɝ dɪsaɪɾɪd tə liv əm əloʊn, ənlaɪk ɛni ʌðɝ sɪməlɝ ɡɹup ɪn hɪstɝi, ən tə kip ðə vɛɹi ɛɡzɪstəns ə ðə kɪn ə sikɹət noʊn oʊnli tə fʊl ɛɛs sədaɪ.

Unknown to the Kin, Aes Sedai in the Tower were aware of their existence almost from the very first, but prosecution of the wars left no time for dealing with them. By the end of the wars, the Tower realized that it might not be in their best interests to snuff put the Kin. Prior to that time, a majority of runaways actually had managed to escape, whatever the Tower's propaganda, but once the Kin began helping them, the Tower knew exactly where any runaway was heading, and they began retaking nine out of ten. Since Kinswomen moved in and out of Barashta (and later Ebou Dar) in an effort to hide their existence and their numbers, never staying more than ten years lest someone notice that they did not age at a normal speed, the Tower believed they were few, and they certainly were keeping themselves low. In order to use the Kin as a trap for runaways, the Tower decided to leave them alone, unlike any other similar group in history, and to keep the very existence of the Kin a secret known only to full Aes Sedai.

ðə kɪn də nɑɾ əv lɔz, bʌt ɹæðɝ ɹulz beɪst ɪn pɑɹɾ ɑn ðə ɹulz fəɹ nɑvəsɪz ən æksɛptɪɾ ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ, ən ɪn pɑɹɾ ɑn ðə nəsɛsəɾi ʌv meɪnteɪnɪŋ sikɹəsi. əz maɪt bi ɪkspɛktəd ɡɪvən ði ɔɹədʒɪnz ə ðə kɪn, ðeɪ meɪnteɪn ðɛɹ ɹulz vɛɹi fɝmli ɑn ɔl ə ðɛɹ mɛmbɝz.

The Kin do not have laws, but rather rules based in part on the rules for novices and Accepted in the White Tower, and in part on the necessity of maintaining secrecy. As might be expected given the origins of the Kin, they maintain their rules very firmly on all of their members.

ɹisən oʊpən kɑntæks bɪtwin ɛɛs sədaɪ ən kɪnswɪmən, waɪl noʊn oʊnli tə ə hændfʊl ə sɪstɝz, hæv pɹədust ə nʌmbɝ ə ʃɑks, ɪnkluɾɪŋ ðə fæks ðət ðəɹ ɑɹ twaɪs əz mɛni kɪnswɪmən əz ɛɛs sədaɪ ən ðət səm ɑɹ mɔɹ ðən ə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz oʊldɝ ðən ɛni ɛɛs sədaɪ hæz lɪv sɪns bɪfɔɹ ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz. ði ɪfɛkt ə ðiz ɹɛvəleɪʃənz, boʊθ ɑn ɛɛs sədaɪ ən ɑn kɪnswɪmən, ɪz əz jɛɾ ə mæɾɝ fəɹ spɛkjəleɪʃən. si ɔlsoʊ dɔɾɝz ə saɪləns, ðə; nɪɾɪŋ sɝkəl, ðə.

Recent open contacts between Aes Sedai and Kinswomen, while known only to a handful of sisters, have produced a number of shocks, including the facts that there are twice as many Kinswomen as Aes Sedai and that some are more than a hundred years older than any Aes Sedai has lived since before the Trolloc Wars. The effect of these revelations, both on Aes Sedai and on Kinswomen, is as yet a matter for speculation. See also Daughters of Silence, the; Knitting Circle, the.

nɪɾɪŋ sɝkəl, ðə: ðə liɾɝz ə ðə kɪn. sɪns noʊ mɛmbɝ ə ðə kɪn əz ɛvɝ noʊn haʊ ɛɛs sədaɪ ɝeɪnʒ ðɛɹ oʊn haɪɝɑɹki - nɑlədʒ pæst ɑn oʊnli wən ən æksɛptɪɾ əz pæst əɹ tɛs fəɹ ðə ʃɔl - ðeɪ pʊt noʊ stɔɹ ɪn stʃɹɛŋkθ ɪn ðə paʊɝ bʌt ɡɪv ɡɹeɪt weɪt tə eɪdʒ, wɪð ði oʊldɝ wʊmən ɔlweɪz stændɪŋ əbʌv ðə jʌŋɡɝ. ðə nɪɾɪŋ sɝkəl (ə taɪɾəl tʃoʊzən, laɪk ðə kɪn, kəz ɪts ɪnɑkjuəs) ðʌs kənsɪsts ə ðə θɝtin oʊldəs kɪnswɪmən ɹɛzəɾənt ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ, wɪð ði oʊldəst ɡɪvən ðə taɪɾəl ʌv ɛldəst. baɪ ðə ɹulz, ɔl wɪl əv tə stɛp daʊn wən ɪts taɪm fəɹ əm tə muv ɑn, bʌt soʊ lɔŋ əz ðeɪ ɑɹ ɹɛzəɾənt ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ, ðeɪv səpɹim əθɔɹəɾi oʊvɝ ðə kɪn, tə ə dɪɡɹi ðəɾ ɛni æmɪɝlɪn sit wəɾ ɛnvi. si ɔlsoʊ kɪn, ðə.

Knitting Circle, the: The leaders of the Kin. Since no member of the Kin has ever known how Aes Sedai arrange their own hierarchy - knowledge passed on only when an Accepted has passed her test for the shawl - they put no store in strength in the Power but give great weight to age, with the older woman always standing above the younger. The Knitting Circle (a title chosen, like the Kin, because it is innocuous) thus consists of the thirteen oldest Kinswomen resident in Ebou Dar, with the oldest given the title of Eldest. By the rules, all will have to step down when it is time for them to move on, but so long as they are resident in Ebou Dar, they have supreme authority over the Kin, to a degree that any Amyrlin Seat would envy. See also Kin, the.

læns-kæptən: ɪn moʊs lænz, noʊbəlwɪmən də nɑt pɝsənəli lɛd ðɛɹ ɑɹmmɪn ɪndə bæɾəl ʌndɝ nɔɹməl sɝkəmstænsəz. ɪnstɛd, ðeɪ haɪɝ ə pɹəfɛʃənəl soʊlʒɝ, ɔlmoʊst ɔlweɪz ə kɑmənɝ, hu ɪz ɹispɑnsəbəl boʊθ fəɹ tʃɹeɪnɪŋ ən liɾɪŋ ðɛɹ ɑɹmmɪn. dɪpɛndɪŋ ɑn ðə lænd, ðɪs mæn kən bi kɔld ə læns-kæptən, sɔɹd-kæptən, mæstɝ ə ðə hɔɹs, əɹ mæstɝ ə ðə lænsɪz. ɹumɝz ə kloʊsɝ ɹileɪʃənʃɪps ðən leɪɾi ən sɝvən ɔfən spɹɪŋ ʌp, pɝhæps ɪnɛvəɾəbli. səmtaɪmz ðeɪ ɑɹ tʃɹu.

Lance-Captain: In most lands, noblewomen do not personally lead their armsmen into battle under normal circumstances. Instead, they hire a professional soldier, almost always a commoner, who is responsible both for training and leading their armsmen. Depending on the land, this man can be called a Lance-Captain, Sword-Captain, Master of the Horse, or Master of the Lances. Rumors of closer relationships than Lady and servant often spring up, perhaps inevitably. Sometimes they are true.

lidʒən ə ðə dʒɹæɡən, ðə: ə lɑɹdʒ mɪlətɛɹi fɔɹmeɪʃən, ɔl ɪnfəntʃɹi, ɡɪvɪŋ əlidʒəns tə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, tʃɹeɪn baɪ dævɹæm bæʃɪɹ əlɔŋ laɪnz wɝkt aʊt baɪ hɪmsɛlf ən mæt kɔθən, laɪnz wɪtʃ dɪpɑɹt ʃɑɹpli fɹəm ðə juʒəwəl ɛmplɔɪmən ə fʊt. waɪl mɛni mɛn sɪmpli wɔk ɪn tə vɑləntɪɹ, lɑɹdʒ nʌmbɝz ə ðə lidʒən ɑɹ skupt ʌp baɪ ɹəkɹuɾɪŋ pɑɹɾiz fɹəm ðə blæk taʊɝ, hu fɝst ɡæðɝ ɔl ə ðə mɛn ɪn ən ɛɹiə hu wɝ wɪlɪŋ tə fɑloʊ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, ən oʊnli æftɝ teɪkɪŋ əm θɹu ɡeɪtweɪz tə nɪɹ keɪɛmlɪn wɪnoʊ aʊt ðoʊz u kən bi tɔt tə tʃænəl. ðə ɹɪmeɪndɝ, baɪ fɑɹ ðə ɡɹeɪɾɝ nʌmbɝ, ɑɹ sɛn tə bæʃɪɹz tʃɹeɪnɪŋ kæmps.

Legion of the Dragon, the: A large military formation, all infantry, giving allegiance to the Dragon Reborn, trained by Davram Bashere along lines worked out by himself and Mat Cauthon, lines which depart sharply from the usual employment of foot. While many men simply walk in to volunteer, large numbers of the Legion are scooped up by recruiting parties from the Black Tower, who first gather all of the men in an area who were willing to follow the Dragon Reborn, and only after taking them through gateways to near Caemlyn winnow out those who can be taught to channel. The remainder, by far the greater number, are sent to Bashere's training camps.

mɛɹəθdəmeɪn: ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "ðoʊz u mʌs bi liʃt," ən ɔlsoʊ "wʌn u mʌs bi liʃt." ðə tɝm əplaɪd baɪ ðə sintʃæn tə ɛni wʊmən keɪpəbəl ə tʃænəlɪŋ u hæz nɑt bɪn kɑlɝɾ əz ə deɪmeɪn.

marath'damane: In the Old Tongue, "those who must be leashed," and also "one who must be leashed." The term applied by the Seanchan to any woman capable of channeling who has not been collared as a damane.

mæstɝ ə ðə lænsɪz: si læns-kæptən.

Master of the Lances: See Lance-Captain.

mæstɝ ə ðə hɔɹs: si læns-kæptən.

Master of the Horse: See Lance-Captain.

mɛɝeɪɾɪn: ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "ðə bɹʌðɝləs." ðə neɪm ədɑptəd, əz ə səsaɪəɾi, baɪ ðoʊz il u əbændən klæn ən sɛpt ən wɛn tə ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ kəz ðeɪ kəd nɑɾ æksɛpt ɹænd ælθɹ, ə wɛtləndɝ, əz ðə kɑɹəkɑɹn, əɹ kəz ðeɪ ɹəfjuz tə æksɛpt ɪz ɹɛvəleɪʃənz kənsɝnɪŋ ðə hɪstɝi ən ɔɹədʒɪnz ə ði il. dɛzɝɾɪŋ klæn ən sɛp fəɹ ɛni ɹizən ɪz ənæθəmə əmʌŋ ði il, ðɛɹfɔɹ ðɛɹ oʊn wɔɹiɝ səsaɪəɾiz əmʌŋ ðə ʃeɪɾoʊ wɝ ənwɪlɪŋ tə teɪk əm ɪn, ən ðeɪ fɔɹm ðɪs səsaɪəɾi, ðə bɹʌðɝləs.

Mera'din: In the Old Tongue, "the Brotherless." The name adopted, as a society, by those Aiel who abandoned clan and sept and went to the Shaido because they could not accept Rand al'Thor, a wetlander, as the Car'a'carn, or because they refused to accept his revelations concerning the history and origins of the Aiel. Deserting clan and sept for any reason is anathema among the Aiel, therefore their own warrior societies among the Shaido were unwilling to take them in, and they formed this society, the Brotherless.

mɔɝæt-: ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "hænlɝ." əmʌŋ ðə sintʃæn, ɪts juz fəɹ ðoʊz u hændəl ɛɡzɑɾɪks, sətʃ əz mɔɹətʃɹeɪkən, ə ɹeɪkən hænlɝ əɹ ɹaɪɾɝ, ɔlsoʊ ɪnfɔɹməli kɔld ə flaɪɝ. si ɔlsoʊ dɝmɝæt-.

morat-: In the Old Tongue, "handler." Among the Seanchan, it is used for those who handle exotics, such as morat'raken, a raken handler or rider, also informally called a flier. See also der'morat-.

pɹɑfət, ðə: mɔɹ fɔɹməli, ðə pɹɑfəɾ ə ðə lɔɹd dʒɹæɡən. wʌns noʊn əz mæsimə dɑɡɝ, ə ʃaɪnɝən soʊlʒɝ, hi ʌndɝwɛn ə ɹɛvəleɪʃən ən dɪsaɪɾɪd ðəɾ i hæd bɪn kɔl tə spɹɛd ðə wɝɾ ə ðə dʒɹæɡənz ɹibɝθ. hi bɪlivz ðət nʌθɪŋ - nʌθɪŋ! - ɪz mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt ðən æknɑlɪdʒɪŋ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn əz ðə laɪt meɪd flɛʃ ən biɪŋ ɹɛɾi wən ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn kɔlz, ən i ən ɪz fɑloʊɝz wɪl juz ɛni minz tə fɔɹs ʌðɝz tə sɪŋ ðə ɡlɔɹiz ə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, fɔɹseɪkɪŋ ɛni neɪm bʌt "ðə pɹɑfət," hiz bɹɔt keɪɑs tə mʌtʃ ʌv ɡildən ən ɑmɑdɪʃiə, lɑɹdʒ pɑɹts ʌv wɪtʃ i kəntʃɹoʊlz.

Prophet, the: More formally, the Prophet of the Lord Dragon. Once known as Masema Dagar, a Shienaran soldier, he underwent a revelation and decided that he had been called to spread the word of the Dragon's Rebirth. He believes that nothing - nothing! - is more important than acknowledging the Dragon Reborn as the Light made flesh and being ready when the Dragon Reborn calls, and he and his followers will use any means to force others to sing the glories of the Dragon Reborn, Forsaking any name but "the Prophet," he has brought chaos to much of Ghealdan and Amadicia, large parts of which he controls.

ɹɪtɝn, ðə: si kɔɝɪn.

Return, the: See Corenne.

si foʊk haɪɝɑɹki: ði æθɑn maɪɹ, ðə si foʊk, ɑɹ ɹul baɪ ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps tə ði æθɑn maɪɹ. ʃiz əsɪstəd baɪ ðə wɪndfɪndɝ tə ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps, ən baɪ ðə mæstɝ ə ðə bleɪdz. bɪloʊ ðɪs kʌm ðə klæn weɪvməstʃɹɛsəz, itʃ əsɪstəd baɪ hɝ wɪndfɪndɝ ən əɹ sɔɹdmæstɝ. bɪloʊ hɝ ɑɹ ðə seɪlməstʃɹɛsəz (ʃɪp kæptənz) ʌv əɹ klæn, itʃ əsɪstəd baɪ hɝ wɪndfɪndɝ ən əɹ kɑɹɡəmæstɝ. ðə wɪndfɪndɝ tə ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps əz əθɔɹəɾi oʊvɝ ɔl wɪndfɪndɝz tə klæn weɪvməstʃɹɛsəz, hu ɪn tɝn əv əθɔɹəɾi oʊvɝ ɔl ðə wɪndfɪndɝz ə hɝ klæn. laɪkwaɪz, ðə mæstɝ ə ðə bleɪdz əz əθɔɹəɾi oʊvɝ ɔl sɔɹdmæstɝz, ən ðeɪ ɪn tɝn oʊvɝ ðə kɑɹɡəmæstɝz ə ðɛɹ klænz. ɹæŋk ɪz nɑt hɝɛɾətɛɹi əmʌŋ ðə si foʊk. ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps ɪz tʃoʊzən, fəɹ laɪf, baɪ ðə fɝs twɛlv ə ði æθɑn maɪɹ, ðə twɛlv moʊst sinjɝ klæn weɪvməstʃɹɛsəz. ə klæn weɪvməstʃɹəs ɪz ɪlɛktəd baɪ ðə twɛlv sinjɝmoʊst seɪlməstʃɹɛsəz ə hɝ klæn, kɔl sɪmpli ðə fɝs twɛlv, ə tɝm wɪtʃ ɪz ɔlsoʊ juz tə dɛzəɡneɪt ðə sinjɝ seɪlməstʃɹɛsəz pɹɛzən ɛniwɛɹ. ʃi kən ɔlsoʊ bi ɹimuv baɪ ə voʊɾ ə ðoʊz seɪm fɝs twɛlv. ɪn fækt, ɛniwʌn ʌðɝ ðən ðə mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪps kən bi dɪmoʊɾɪd, ivən ɔl ðə weɪ daʊn tə dɛkhænd, fəɹ mælfizəns, kaʊɝɾəs əɹ ʌðɝ kɹaɪmz. ɔlsoʊ, ðə wɪndfɪndɝ tə ə weɪvməstʃɹəs əɹ mɪstʃɹəs ə ðə ʃɪp u daɪz wɪl, ʌv nəsɛsəɾi, hæv tə sɝv ə loʊɝ ɹæŋkɪŋ wʊmən, ən əɹ oʊn ɹæŋk ðʌs dikɹisəz.

Sea Folk hierarchy: The Atha'an Miere, the Sea Folk, are ruled by the Mistress of the Ships to the Atha'an Miere. She is assisted by the Windfinder to the Mistress of the Ships, and by the Master of the Blades. Below this come the clan Wavemistresses, each assisted by her Windfinder and her Swordmaster. Below her are the Sailmistresses (ship captains) of her clan, each assisted by her Windfinder and her Cargomaster. The Windfinder to the Mistress of the Ships has authority over all Windfinders to clan Wavemistresses, who in turn have authority over all the Windfinders of her clan. Likewise, the Master of the Blades has authority over all Swordmasters, and they in turn over the Cargomasters of their clans. Rank is not hereditary among the Sea Folk. The Mistress of the Ships is chosen, for life, by the First Twelve of the Atha'an Miere, the twelve most senior clan Wavemistresses. A clan Wavemistress is elected by the twelve seniormost Sailmistresses of her clan, called simply the First Twelve, a term which is also used to designate the senior Sailmistresses present anywhere. She can also be removed by a vote of those same First Twelve. In fact, anyone other than the Mistress of the Ships can be demoted, even all the way down to deckhand, for malfeasance, cowardice or other crimes. Also, the Windfinder to a Wavemistress or Mistress of the Ship who dies will, of necessity, have to serve a lower ranking woman, and her own rank thus decreases.

siməsiv: ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "loʊɝɾ aɪz," əɹ "daʊnkæst aɪz." əmʌŋ ðə sintʃæn, tə seɪ ðət wʌn əz "bɪkʌm siməsiv" minz ðət wʌn əz "lɔs feɪs." si ɔlsoʊ seɪaɪtɑɹ.

sei'mosiev: In the Old Tongue, "lowered eyes," or "downcast eyes." Among the Seanchan, to say that one has "become sei'mosiev" means that one has "lost face." See also sei'taer.

seɪaɪtɑɹ: ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "stʃɹeɪɾ aɪz," əɹ "lɛvəl aɪz." əmʌŋ ðə sintʃæn, ɪt ɹəfɝz tə ɑnɝ əɹ feɪs, tə ði əbɪləɾi tə mit sʌmwʌnz aɪz. ɪts pɑsəbəl tə "bi" əɹ "hæv" seɪaɪtɑɹ, minɪŋ ðət wʌn əz ɑnɝ ən feɪs, ən ɔlsoʊ tə "ɡeɪn" əɹ "luz" seɪaɪtɑɹ. si ɔlsoʊ siməsiv.

sei'taer: In the Old Tongue, "straight eyes," or "level eyes." Among the Seanchan, it refers to honor or face, to the ability to meet someone's eyes. It is possible to "be" or "have" sei'taer, meaning that one has honor and face, and also to "gain" or "lose" sei'taer. See also sei'mosiev.

ʃɛn ən kɑlhɑɹ: ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "ðə bæn ə ðə ɹɛd hænd." (wʌn) ə lɛdʒəndɛɹi ɡɹup ə hɪɹoʊz u hæd mɛni ɛksplɔɪts, faɪnəli daɪɪŋ ɪn ðə dɪfɛns ə meɪnɛðɝən wən ðət lænd wɑz dɪstʃɹɔɪd dʊɹɪŋ ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz. (tu) ə mɪlətɛɹi fɔɹmeɪʃən pʊt təɡɛðɝ ɔlmoʊs baɪ æksəɾənt baɪ mæt kɔθən ən ɔɹɡənaɪzd əlɔŋ ðə laɪnz ə mɪlətɛɹi fɔɹsɪz dʊɹɪŋ wʌɾ ɪz kənsɪɾɝd ðə haɪɾ ə ðə mɪlətɛɹi ɑɹts, ðə deɪz ʌv ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ ən ðə sɛntʃɝiz ɪmiɾiətli pɹisiɾɪŋ.

Shen an Calhar: In the Old Tongue, "the Band of the Red Hand." (1) A legendary group of heroes who had many exploits, finally dying in the defense of Manetheren when that land was destroyed during the Trolloc Wars. (2) A military formation put together almost by accident by Mat Cauthon and organized along the lines of military forces during what is considered the height of the military arts, the days of Artur Hawkwing and the centuries immediately preceding.

sɔɪhɪn: ðə kloʊsəs tʃɹænzleɪʃən fɹəm ði oʊl tʌŋ wəd bi "ə haɪɾ əmʌŋ loʊnəs," ðoʊ səm tʃɹænzleɪɾ ɪɾ əz minɪŋ "boʊθ skaɪ ən væli" əmʌŋ sɛvɹəl ʌðɝ pɑsəbɪləɾiz. sɔɪhɪn ɪz ðə tɝm əplaɪd baɪ ðə sintʃæn tə hɝɛɾətɛɹi ʌpɝ sɝvəns. ðeɪ ɑɹ dækoʊvæl, pɹɑpɝɾi, jɛɾ ɑkjəpaɪ pəzɪʃənz ə kənsɪɾɝəbəl əθɔɹəɾi ən ɔfən paʊɝ. ivən ðə blʌd stɛp kɛɹfəli ɝaʊn sɔɪhɪn ə ði ɪmpɪɹiəl fæmli, ən spik tə sɔɪhɪn ə ði ɛmpɹɛs hɝsɛlf əz tə ikwəlz. si ɔlsoʊ blʌd, ðə; dækoʊvæl.

so'jhin: The closest translation from the Old Tongue would be "a height among lowness," though some translate it as meaning "both sky and valley" among several other possibilities. So'jhin is the term applied by the Seanchan to hereditary upper servants. They are da'covale, property, yet occupy positions of considerable authority and often power. Even the Blood step carefully around so'jhin of the Imperial family, and speak to so'jhin of the Empress herself as to equals. See also Blood, the; da'covale.

sɔɹd-kæptən: si læns-kæptən.

Sword-Captain: See Lance-Captain.

waɪz wʊmən: ɑnɝɪfɪk juzd ɪn ɛbu dɑɹ fəɹ wɪmən feɪm fəɹ ðɛɹ ɪnkɹɛɾəbəl əbɪləɾiz ət hilɪŋ ɔlmoʊst ɛni ɪnʒɝi. eɪ waɪz wʊmən ɪz tʃɹədɪʃənəli mɑɹk baɪ ə ɹɛd bɛlt. waɪl səm əv noʊɾəd ðət mɛni, ɪndid moʊst, ɛbu dɑɹi waɪz wɪmən wɝ nɑɾ ivən fɹəm ɔltɑɹə, mʌtʃ lɛs ɛbu dɑɹ, wʌt wɑz nɑt noʊn əntɪl ɹisənli, ən stɪl ɪz noʊn oʊnli tə ə fju, ɪz ðəɾ ɔl waɪz wɪmən ɑɹ ɪn fækt kɪnswɪmən ən juz vɛɹiəs vɝʒənz ə hilɪŋ, ɡɪvɪŋ aʊɾ ɝbz ən poʊltəsəz oʊnli əz ə kʌvɝ. wɪð ðə flaɪɾ ə ðə kɪn fɹəm ɛbu dɑɹ æftɝ ðə sintʃæn tʊk ðə sɪɾi, noʊ waɪz wɪmən ɹɪmeɪn ðɛɹ. si ɔlsoʊ kɪn, ðə.

Wise Woman: Honorific used in Ebou Dar for women famed for their incredible abilities at healing almost any injury. A Wise Woman is traditionally marked by a red belt. While some have noted that many, indeed most, Ebou Dari Wise Women were not even from Altara, much less Ebou Dar, what was not known until recently, and still is known only to a few, is that all Wise Women are in fact Kinswomen and use various versions of Healing, giving out herbs and poultices only as a cover. With the flight of the Kin from Ebou Dar after the Seanchan took the city, no Wise Women remain there. See also Kin, the.

əbaʊt ði ɔθɝ ɹɑbɝt dʒɔɹɾən wɑz bɔɹn ɪn naɪntinfɔɹɾieɪt ɪn tʃɑɹlstən, saʊθ kɛɹəlaɪnə. hi tɔt hɪmsɛlf tə ɹid wən i wɑz fɔɹ wɪð ði ɪnsɪdɛntəl eɪɾ ʌv ə twɛlv-jɪɹz-oʊldɝ bɹʌðɝ, ən wɑz tæklɪŋ mɑɹk tweɪn ən dʒulz vɝn baɪ faɪv. hi wɑz ə ɡɹædʒəwəɾ ə ðə sɪɾədɛl, ðə mɪlətɛɹi kɑlɪdʒ ə saʊθ kɛɹəlaɪnə, wɪð ə dɪɡɹi ɪn fɪzɪks. hi sɝv tu tʊɹz ɪn viɛtnɑm wɪð ðə juɛs. ɑɹmi; əmʌŋ ɪz dɛkɝeɪʃənz ɑɹ ðə dɪstɪŋɡwɪʃt flaɪɪŋ kɹɔs wɪð bɹɑnz oʊk lif klʌstɝ, ðə bɹɑnz stɑɹ wɪð "vi" ən bɹɑnz oʊk lif klʌstɝ, ən tu viɛtnɑmis ɡæləntʃɹi kɹɔsɪz wɪð pɑm. ə hɪstɝi bʌf, hi ɔlsoʊ ɹoʊt dæns ən θiəɾɝ kɹɪɾɪsɪzəm. hi ɛndʒɔɪd ði aʊtdɔɹ spɔɹts ə hʌntɪŋ, fɪʃɪŋ, ən seɪlɪŋ, ən ði ɪndɔɹ spɔɹts ə poʊkɝ, tʃɛs, pul, ən paɪp kəlɛktɪŋ. hi bɪɡæn ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɪn naɪntinsɛvəntisɛvən ən kəntɪnjuɾ əntɪl ɪz dɛθ ɑn sɛptɛmbɝ sɪkstinθ, tuθaʊzənsɛvən.

About the Author Robert Jordan was born in 1948 in Charleston, South Carolina. He taught himself to read when he was four with the incidental aid of a twelve-years-older brother, and was tackling Mark Twain and Jules Verne by five. He was a graduate of The Citadel, The Military College of South Carolina, with a degree in physics. He served two tours in Vietnam with the U.S. Army; among his decorations are the Distinguished Flying Cross with bronze oak leaf cluster, the Bronze Star with "V" and bronze oak leaf cluster, and two Vietnamese Gallantry Crosses with Palm. A history buff, he also wrote dance and theater criticism. He enjoyed the outdoor sports of hunting, fishing, and sailing, and the indoor sports of poker, chess, pool, and pipe collecting. He began writing in 1977 and continued until his death on September 16, 2007.

teɪbəl ə kɑntɛns taɪɾəl kɑpiɹaɪt dɛɾəkeɪʃən kɑntɛns mæps pɹoʊlɑɡ: snoʊ wʌn livɪŋ ðə pɹɑfət tu teɪkən θɹi kʌstəmz fɔɹ ɔfɝz faɪv flæɡz sɪks ðə sɛn ə mædnəs sɛvən ðə stʃɹits ə keɪɛmlɪn eɪt si foʊk ən kɪn naɪn eɪ kʌp ə ti tɛn eɪ plæn səksidz ɪlɛvən aɪdiəz ʌv ɪmpɔɹɾəns twɛlv eɪ lɪli ɪn wɪntɝ θɝtin wʌndɝfəl nuz fɔɹtin wʌɾ ə veɪl haɪdz fɪftin ɪn niɾ ʌv ə bɛlfndɝ sɪkstin ən ʌnɪkspɛktɪɾ ɪnkaʊntɝ sɛvəntin pɪŋk ɹɪbənz eɪtin ən ɔfɝ naɪntin θɹi wɪmən twɛnti kwɛstʃənz ə tʃɹizən twɛntiwʌn eɪ mæɾɝ ə pɹɑpɝɾi twɛntiɾu aʊɾ ə θɪn ɛɹ twɛntiθɹi tə luz ðə sʌn twɛntifɔɹ əmʌŋ ðə kaʊnsəlz twɛntifaɪv bɑnz twɛntisɪks ɛkspɛkteɪʃən twɛntisɛvən tə sɝpɹaɪz kwinz ən kɪŋz twɛntieɪt nuz ɪn ə klɔθ sæk twɛntinaɪn ənʌðɝ plæn θɝɾi koʊld, fæt ɹeɪndʒɹɑps θɝɾiwʌn wʌt ði æɛlfɪn sɛd θɝɾitu eɪ pɔɹʃən ʌv wɪzdəm θɝɾiθɹi blu kɑɹp stʃɹit θɝɾifɔɹ ðə hʌmɪŋbɝdz sikɹət θɝɾifaɪv wɪð ðə tʃoʊɾən kæl ɡlɔsɝi əbaʊt ði ɔθɝ
